title: Acting Up
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Iljaz Sinanoski, Bitola, Macedonia, May 6, 2001
description: he night of April 30, while everybody was asleep, some 50 stores were burned down in Bitola, and some houses, too. It was the Macedonian youth who did it. This did not come out of the blue: two days before, eight security men -- four Macedonian policemen from Bitola and four soldiers -- were killed by Albanian rebels. But these were not only Albanian shops. They were also Muslim Macedonian and Turkish. We are Macedonians too, of Islamic faith. All in all, our family lost three out of seven shops. The people who did this came back the next day, around lunchtime, and then thoroughly looted one of them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Job Hunters Increase
description: In the latest sign that the buoyant French economy might be succumbing to slowing global growth, the number of people registered as seeking jobs rose in April by 5,000, to 2.3 million. The increase, the first in nine months, was evidence of spreading job cuts as French exports stall. Numerous companies in France, including the food giant Danone, the appliance maker Moulinex, and the British retailer Marks & Spencer, have announced layoffs in recent months. The announcements have so unsettled the government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, a Socialist, that it is planning legislation to make it more expensive for companies to lay off workers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: He Was Walking A Perilous Line
description: To get acquainted with a filmmaker as intellectually mercurial as the Iranian Moshen Makhmalbaf, one needs a good block of his work. A half-dozen Makhmalbaf films released on videotape this week by Facets International only begin to provide a grasp.

title: Indonesian Fires 4 Ministers in Frantic Bid to Stay in Office
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 1  Maneuvering desperately to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid dismissed four cabinet ministers today, including the security minister and the national police chief, who had opposed Mr. Wahid's threats to declare a state of emergency.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Leak At Nuclear Reactor
description: Radioactive water leaked from a nuclear reactor yesterday during tests at a power plant in the city of Temelin, a plant spokesman said. The accident, attributed to human error, was quickly contained and posed no danger to the staff or the public, the spokesman said. But the mishap seems bound to raise tensions again over the Soviet-designed plant, which stands just 35 miles from the Austrian border and has been the target of fierce protests from Austrians. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Nuclear Power: Worth the Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown's Tape of Heroics Provides the Inspiration
description: With Eric Snow running on a fractured right ankle, Allen Iverson hobbled by a bruised tailbone and George Lynch sidelined with a broken left foot, the Philadelphia 76ers have drawn inspiration from Willis Reed.

title: The Bright Colors of Joy, Painted in Buoyant Motion
description: Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering'' creates a haunted world of sunlight and approaching clouds populated by a small group of men and women with profound though unstated ties to one another. The ballet requires sensitivity to dramatic nuance much more than any technical skill, suffering more than most from disengaged dancing.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE<BR

title: El Paso's Share of California Gas Market Is Questioned
description: The El Paso Corporation's share of the Southern California natural gas market may be smaller than an energy agency study showed because the survey did not include in-state production, storage or competing pipelines, the study's author said today during a hearing at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: New Twist In BP Dispute In Russia
description: BP's long-running dispute with the Tyumen Oil Company has taken an unexpected turn, throwing into doubt an agreement between Tyumen and another Russian oil company, Sidanko.

title: Canadian Driller Fights Hostile Kazakh Bid
description: Doing business here is not for the fainthearted, as Hurricane Hydrocarbons, a Canadian company with all its operations here, has been learning. On top of the usual developing-country headaches, Hurricane has suffered from being too strong a magnet for unwanted attention.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Saudi Prince Cancels Visit
description: Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia has canceled a visit to Canada after reports that a Canadian held in a Saudi jail has been tortured. The man, William Sampson, was arrested in connection with bombings in Saudi Arabia last November that killed one person and wounded four others. A Saudi newspaper quoted a government spokesman who complained about Canada's ''meddling'' in the case. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: A Mountain Road, Silent Monks and Noisy Old Racecars
description: IT has been 48 years since the Carthusian Order of Catholic monks first allowed vintage racecars to make the 5.2-mile run up Mount Equinox. Now the Mount Equinox Vintage Hill Climb is a yearly event; the faithful will gather again on June 9-10 for a weekend of racing pre-1959 sports cars up the mountain and against the clock.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rockaways Ferry Delayed
description: A proposed ferry service between the Rockaways and downtown Manhattan that was scheduled to begin today will be delayed several weeks, its backers announced yesterday. Fox Navigation, the operator of the planned ferry, cannot find a boat big enough to accommodate the expected ridership and seaworthy enough to withstand the rough waters, said Serena Torrey, a spokeswoman for Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who helped with the project. Ms. Torrey said a suitable vessel would be bought ''in a matter of weeks.'' The 30-minute ferry ride is expected to cost $10 and travel between the Riis Park Coast Guard Station in the Rockaways and Pier 11 in Manhattan. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, WILBERT
description: STEIN-Wilbert. Died on May 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Gussie for 30 years who predeceased Wilbert 5 years ago. Devoted father to stepson Lester Lehon and deceased son Jacob, loving grandfather to six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Wilbert lived life to its fullest. Services 11am Friday from Sinai Chapels, Flushing-Fresh Meadows, NY. Interment to follow at Mt Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Jeffrey Vallance -- 'The Virgin, the Poet and the President'
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today : Redistricting Hearing
description: The New York State Legislature plans a public hearing on Congressional and state legislative redistricting. Room 213, Queens Borough Hall, 120-55 Queens Blvd, Kew Gardens, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Information: (212) 618-1100.

title: Controversial Ruling on Library Filters
description: In early 1997, the Minneapolis Public Library began giving its patrons unfettered and unlimited access to the Internet. The librarys First Amendment-inspired policy was intended to provide a needed service to the community. But Wendy Adamson, a reference desk librarian at the library's central branch, said it effectively made her working life a nightmare, and federal officials appear poised to agree with her.

description: To the Editor:

title: Vija Celmins
description: McKee

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Growth Picks Up
description: Canadian economic growth accelerated to a faster-than-expected 2.5 percent annualized pace in the first quarter of 2001, as heavier consumer spending outweighed declines in business investment and exports. Gross domestic product rose 0.6 percent to 1.03 trillion Canadian dollars ($665 billion) in the January-March period, from 1.02 trillion dollars in the fourth quarter, Statistics Canada said.

title: Unexpected Consequences Of a Promise Hastily Made
description: The feelings stirred up by ''A Love Divided,'' the true story of a sleepy Irish village nearly torn apart by religious strife in the late 1950's, are so volatile that it is difficult to watch the film without taking sides. The movie pits a stubbornly independent Protestant mother against a rabidly militant Catholic priest who is only too willing to incite mob violence to get his way.

title: Stocks Close Higher After Late-Day Rally
description: After a cautious reading of reports on employment and manufacturing that gave conflicting messages about the strength of the American economy, investors embraced battered technology stocks today and touched off a modest rally.

title: Salmon Gravlax
description: Gravlax is raw salmon, usually cured in a mixture of salt, sugar and alcohol (we use vodka here but other approaches call for more powerful liquids like cognac or even bourbon). It is basically a Scandinavian treatment of a salmon fillet that much resembles the cured or smoked versions of Britain or Eastern Europe, though there is no smoke used here. It can be made for a whole fish, and often is. But at home you're probably better off with just two substantial fillets. It is usually sliced very thinly (a sharp slicing knife is essential) on the bias to reveal as much of the surface of the flesh as possible and then it can be served as an appetizer with a bit of salad and a slice of lemon or as an hors d'oeuvre, perhaps on wedges of toast. While this is a very simple process, the curing takes three days, so plan ahead.

title: Public Interests; The Longest Campaign
description: There are four major Democratic candidates for mayor of New York City this year. When they get together for a forum or debate -- and this occurs virtually on an hourly basis -- you are looking at 96 years in local politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, RABBI ISIDORE
description: BARNETT-Rabbi Isidore. We mourn the death of our beloved colleague, age 94. He served pulpits in Savannah, Georgia and in the Philadelphia area, retiring from Beth Uziel in 1971. After retirement, he continued to serve as a chaplain of Inglis House in Philadelphia until his second retirement in 1988. We extend our deepest condolences to his children, Judith Winter and Arthur Barnett and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P. The Rabbinical Assembly

title: The Ice (Cream) Age
description: There's little better on a warm summer day than a cool, smooth ice cream. Here are a few of New York's top spots for a scoop or two.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Reprieve For Chaebols
description: Yielding to pressure from the 30 largest conglomerates, known as chaebols, the South Korean government put off until March 31, 2003, a deadline for their members to reduce holdings of sister companies' stock to 25 percent of equity. Critics said the decision showed a lack of will to rein in the chaebols and perk up the economy with structural reforms. With inflation running at 5.4 percent annually, according to new figures, hopes for an interest rate cut receded. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Aimster Heads Down a Path Already Taken by Napster
description: The Recording Industry Association of America asserts that Aimster, its latest legal nemesis in the fight over online music, is essentially a clone of Napster that permits the free exchange of copyrighted files over the Internet.

title: New York Lottery Picks 4 Finalists
description: The New York State Lottery named four finalists yesterday in a mandated review on its account, with billings estimated at $60 million.

title: Tours of Spain and Mexico
description: Collette Vacations is discounting three upcoming escorted tours, two of which visit Spain. There's a $120 discount on a July 11 departure of its Spain and Portugal tour. The 15-day package includes Barcelona, Madrid, Toledo, Cordoba, the Costa del Sol, Seville, Lisbon and Fatima. With 22 meals, the discounted rate is $1,529 a person, based on double occupancy. On the July 12 departure of Collette's 11-day Spanish Heritage tour, stops include Madrid, Toledo, El Escorial, Cordoba, Seville, Ronda and the Costa del Sol. Including a $100 discount and 15 meals, the price is $1,249 a person, double. And there's a $100 discount on a 10-day tour of the Copper Canyon in Mexico that departs from Tucson on June 28. Included are stops on the Sea of Cortez and a trip on the Chihuahua-Pacifico Railroad; the price is $1,329 a person, double. These prices do not include air fare. Contact (888) 344-5578 or www.collettevacations.com .

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Expansion Costs Blamed for Costco's 13% Decline in Earnings
description: The Costco Wholesale Corporation, the nation's largest chain of warehouse stores, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 13 percent as it spent more to expand and paid more for energy in California, where a fourth of its stores are situated.

title: McVeigh Lawyers, Seeing Fraud, Ask Judge for Stay of Execution
description: Lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh today asked the federal judge who sentenced him to death for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing to grant him a stay of execution, saying that Mr. McVeigh wanted to hold the government responsible for failing to produce thousands of pages of evidence at his trial.

description: Faisal Husseini, the senior Palestinian official in Jerusalem, died unexpectedly today of a heart attack, prompting an outpouring of grief from Palestinians and from Israeli doves who considered him a man of integrity and a vital interlocutor.

Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave (at city line), New Hyde Park, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, PAUL
description: RAYMOND - Paul. (1916 - 2001). Paul Raymond, beloved father of three, passed away on May 26, 2001, of heart failure-however, his warmth of heart will always remain with us. He was born with the name of Nejatollah Farrokh Tavana in Iran. When he was a baby, he survived a serious illnesshis name, Nejatollah, means ''recued by God.'' Paul had a great compassion for all living creatures and believed that all religions should be respected for their faith and belief in a higher power. Although has was born into a Jewish family, his belief was supported by his practice in the Baha'i faith. During WWII, while living in Iran, he assisted Allied Forces by helping repair a device to intercept secret messages transmitted by the Nazis. As an acknowledgement for his service, he was given papers for passage to the United States. He traveled to this country on board a naval troop ship called the U.S.S. General Butler. the troop ship was escorted by three destroyers and carried 6,000 GI's, it passed through submarine infested waters, and miraculously arrived in San Pedro, CA, on July 1st, 1944. Coincidentally, Persian Princess Sattareh Farman Farmaian was on board the same ship and her perspective is recounted in the book, ''Daughter of Persia.'' He lived in Los Angeles for two years before moving to New York where he lived for the remainder of his life. Always wanting to discover and expand his knowledge, Paul was a world traveler who spoke French fluently. He will be remembered as a hero, inventor, raconteur, world traveler, polyglot, punster, jewelry designer, entrepreneur and dancer. His baby blue eyes, charm and humor will linger with the people he touched. He is survived by his daughters, Linda Raymond of New Castle and Doris Raymond of San Francisco, son and ''daughter-in-love,'' David and Marcia Raymond of New York, as well as his sisters Madeleine Hekmat and Ghotsi Etteshamzadeh of Los Angeles. Funeral service Friday, June 1, 2001, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Burden Center for the Aging, Inc, 1484 First Avenue, 2nd floor, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVIAN, SLOMO
description: SILVIAN-Slomo. Born in Romania, died peacefully May 31, 2001. Loving husband of Cindy. Devoted brother to Butsa and her huband Herman, who reside in Israel. Also devoted uncle and great-uncle. He was very instrumental in forming an adult home association. He was an ardent supporter and generous benefactor for many years for organizations in America and Israel. We extend our deepest and most sincere sympathy at the loss of a man who was a caring friend to all. Everyone who knew him was blessed with his warmth and affection. He will be greatly missed. Funeral service will be held at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Sunday, June 3rd at 11 AM.

title: U.N. Assembly Votes to Condemn Attacks on Religious Sites
description: With the ransacked mosques and churches of the Balkans and the ruins of the giant Buddhas of Afghanistan still fresh in its memory, the General Assembly voted today to condemn all attacks on religious sites.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Strike Threat
description: The Korean Confederation of Trade Unions said it was organizing a nationwide one-day strike on June 12 to press demands like shorter work hours and a halt to the proposed sale of Daewoo Motor to General Motors. Leaders said they hope workers at 200 companies will walk out. Talks between G.M. and Daewoo's creditors are set to start Monday at a secret location. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Mets Take Lead, but It's Going, Going, Gone
description: The three-game sweep by the Philadelphia Phillies had been temporarily forgotten. The Mets were in control of a game again heading into the final innings. Mike Piazza had hit a monster home run to spark another rally.

title: Five Powers Delay Vote on Easing Iraq Trade
description: The five major powers on the Security Council agreed today to postpone for 30 days a vote on a more generous trade policy for Iraq.

description: WIEGAN-Irving. Devoted husband of Sarah. Dear brother of Cy. Beloved uncle. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, LEE
description: HAUSER-Lee. Age 84, died at home on May 25. Beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt. Educator and business woman. She was interred at Mt. Ararat Cemetery on May 27th. She will be missed by everyone she touched.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Deadlock In Midwife's Trial
description: Jurors in a suburban Chicago courtroom reported that they were deadlocked in the trial of a midwife charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a baby boy during a home delivery last August. The judge, James Booras, told the jurors to continue deliberating. Prosecutors said that the defendant, Yvonne Cryns, a lay midwife, took too long to call for help in a birth she knew was risky because of the baby's feet-first position and that the way she twisted the baby contributed to his death. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: BIDDERS FOR FINOVA RAISE PRICE OF BAILOUT OFFER
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, and the Leucadia National Corporation raised their joint offer to creditors of the Finova Group , trying to fend off a rival bailout plan for Finova, a bankrupt finance company. The Buffett-Leucadia venture, known as Berkadia L.L.C., offered unsecured creditors about 64 cents per $1 of debt before the bankruptcy filing and 3 cents for each $1 of postbankruptcy claims, according to Finova. That is up from 60 cents earlier this month and an initial offer of 54 cents. Creditors reached a separate $7 billion agreement last week with the GE Capital Corporation and Goldman Sachs Group, pitting them against management and Berkadia.

title: Of Lincolns and Pierce Arrow
description: THE Hill Climb at Mount Equinox is not the only vintage car event next weekend in Manchester, Vt. The Hildene Car Show will feature 800 collector cars judged in 38 classes, also on June 9-10.

Loving mother of Bonnie Olson, Kathleen Drucker and the late J. Scott. Dear sister of Carol Gibney. Proud grandmother of six grandchildren. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, Friday evening 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:30 AM, O.L. Mercy Church, Forest Hills. Interment Princeton Cemetery, Princeton, NJ. Donations may be made to Women in Military Service for America Memorial Foundation, Dept 560, Washington, DC 20042-0560.

title: INSIDE
description: Death and Fear in Serbia

title: A Sharp Spin Could Upset Davis Budget
description: It is no secret in politics that little things mean a lot. Newt Gingrich once shut down the federal government partly in pique over a back seat on Air Force One. Now California's Republican legislative leaders are threatening to derail passage of the state's $80 billion budget next month over a $180,000 contract for two sharp-tongued Democratic image makers.

title: 15 School Health Clinics Scheduled for Closing Get a Reprieve
description: The New York City Department of Health will pay a lump sum to allow 15 school health clinics scheduled for closing to remain open until next year, officials with the operator of the clinics said yesterday.

title: It Can't Win All The Tonys (Can It?)
description: The suspense is unbearable. For weeks Broadway insiders have been studying the heavens, reading tea leaves and consulting every type of psychic tool available to glean some hint of which show will win the Tony Award for best musical. Will it be ''Jane Eyre,'' ''The Full Monty'' or ''A Class Act''?

title: Article 2001060192980698605 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Job Cuts At Invensys
description: The British factory controls maker Invensys said it would cut 3,500 more jobs and postpone the planned public stock offering of part of its power systems unit because of the global downturn. Its share price, which had fallen by almost one half since the company bought the Dutch software maker Baan last August, rose 6 percent. Invensys had already announced 5,000 job losses among its work force of 85,000. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Drug Maker
description: The leading Australian health care and logistics company, Mayne Nickless Ltd., bid 2 billion Australian dollars ($1 billion) in stock to take over the drug maker, FH Faulding & Company. Faulding's pharmaceutical sales network, which stretches across 70 countries, would strengthen Mayne Nickless in health care and help it expand overseas, according to its managing director, Peter Smedley. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: It Takes A Thief To Outfox Another One
description: Those of us looking for the opportunity to compare a Martin Lawrence turn to a Robert Redford performance based on the same character -- Donald E. Westlake's determined bad guy John Dortmunder -- still have a while to wait. In the new film adaptation of Mr. Westlake's ''What's the Worst That Could Happen?,'' his skillful but hapless Dortmunder -- portrayed by Mr. Redford in ''The Hot Rock'' (1972) -- is transformed into the latest of Mr. Lawrence's bungling, bling-blinging protagonists in a movie career that veers from flawed master thieves (''Blue Streak'') to out-of-control cops (''Big Momma's House'').

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMURRAY, JOSEPH P.
description: McMURRAY-Joseph P. On May 31, 2001, of East Atlantic Beach, NY. Past president of Queens College, Queensboro Community College, College of New Rochelle. Beloved husband of the late Isabelle, mother of his children, and Rose Marie. Dear father of Gerald R., Joseph P. Jr., Kathleen M. Nelson, Isabelle Pullis, Kevin F., Brien A., stepson Walter G. Barker, stepdaughter Diane Crehan and the late Robert Barker. Cherished grandfather of 25 and great-grandfather of five. Reposing Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:45 AM, St. Francis de Sales R.C. Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment St. Mary Star of the Sea Cemetery, Lawrence, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends may make contributions to Queens College Foundation, Inc, in memory of Joseph P. McMurray.

title: Vallone Run For Mayor Is Official
description: Standing outside of the school he attended as a child, a few blocks from his home in Astoria, Peter F. Vallone formally announced his candidacy for mayor yesterday, saying he was the only candidate with proven experience running the city.

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Slides in May to 4.4 Percent
description: The unemployment rate showed a slight improvement in May, with its first decline in eight months, as companies cut fewer jobs than expected and more Americans gave up their job searches, the Labor Department reported today.

description: Federal prosecutors rested their case yesterday in the death penalty hearing of a bomber of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1998. The announcement came after wrenching accounts from more witnesses, including victims and family members, some flown from Kenya.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Station Executive
description: Vince Giannini, a 35-year-old Los Angeles television executive, has been appointed station manager at WPIX-TV, company officials said yesterday. As station manager, Mr. Giannini will be the second-highest-ranking executive at WPIX, a WB affiliate that is owned by the Tribune Company. He replaces Betty Ellen Berlamino, who became WPIX's vice president and general manager. For the last eight years, Mr. Giannini was the director of finance and administration at KTLA-TV, Tribune's Los Angeles station. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Bush Twins in Spotlight

title: Arlene Francis, Actress and TV Panelist, 93
description: Arlene Francis, the actress and jaunty, good-natured television personality who was a fixture on ''What's My Line?'' for 25 years, died yesterday at a hospital in San Francisco. She was 93.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Nurses To Strike
description: About 5,400 members of the Minnesota Nurses Association at seven hospitals were set to strike this morning over pay and staffing levels. Union members voted on May 17 to reject a contract offer that included an 18 percent raise over three years and set entry-level pay at $45,000. Nurses at five other hospitals agreed on contracts. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Devils Come Home but Lose Their Edge
description: Never before in his brilliant 22-year career had Ray Bourque been two victories away from raising the Stanley Cup.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Making Way For Berlusconi
description: Prime Minister Giuliano Amato formally resigned after the election of a speaker for the lower house of Parliament. That body approved Pierferdinando Casini, the leader of a small centrist Catholic party, and a coalition ally of Silvio Berlusconi, who will soon be sworn in as prime minister now that both the House and the Senate have elected leaders. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Profiling Panel Urges End to Certain Car Searches
description: The State Senate committee investigating racial profiling recommended today that New Jersey become the first state to outlaw certain kinds of vehicle searches by its state police and the first to subject troopers to the scrutiny of an outside review board.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about criticism of agreements reached by the Smithsonian Institution with large donors referred incompletely to a contract between the organization and Catherine B. Reynolds, whose foundation is giving $38 million for an exhibit to honor American achievers. Although Ms. Reynolds will choose 10 of the 15 members of a committee to select the subjects, her nominees are subject to approval of the Smithsonian's regents. If they reject any of her choices, she can nominate another.

title: Five Determined Students, Five Unusual Routes to a College Degree
description: Seventeen years ago, Gabriel Carrera was a gang member with a $200-a-day drug habit, in jail for breaking and entering. Fourteen years ago, Scott Stoffel, legally blind since birth and suddenly struck deaf, attempted suicide by running onto a busy highway.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend last Friday about the Chinese film ''The Road Home,'' directed by Zhang Yimou, misspelled the surname of an Iranian director whose work influenced Mr. Zhang. He is Abbas Kiarostami, not Kierostami.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee dropped as mild weather in Latin America improved prospects for crops from some of the world's largest growers. In New York, coffee for July delivery fell 2 cents, or 3.4 percent, to 57.15 cents a pound.

title: New Test Calls Bombing Suspect Competent
description: A psychologist hired by federal prosecutors has found that Bobby Frank Cherry, a suspect in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., is competent to stand trial.

title: Bush Aggressively Courts Catholic Voters for 2004
description: In a single week this month, President Bush went to the University of Notre Dame to quote Dorothy Day, the Roman Catholic social activist, and to St. Augustine Catholic Church in Cleveland to praise Bishop Anthony Pilla and parish volunteers ''who get up at 6 a.m. in the morning, before their job, to come and help a neighbor in need.''

title: Jaime Bentez, 92, Educator And Puerto Rican Politician
description: Jaime Bentez Rexach, a former chancellor and president of the University of Puerto Rico who from 1972 to 1976 was the island's nonvoting representative in Congress, died on Wednesday in a hospital in San Juan. He was 92.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Social Realism (In Los Angeles)

title: As California Sweats It Out, 2 Funds Profit
description: It is not hard to figure out what California's political leaders would like to do to the electric power generators and natural gas companies that they say have aggravated the state's energy crisis.

title: The Masters Link Arms In a Show of Drawings
description: It's only an arm, but what an arm! Drawn with brush point on blue paper, this slim but shapely limb is bent at the elbow and supports a supple hand slightly curved around an apple. It is -- what else? -- the arm of Eve, made in 1507 by Albrecht Drer (1471-1528) in preparation for a pair of life-size paintings now owned by the Prado in Madrid depicting the fig-leafed First Couple just before their banishment from Eden.

title: Young Liberal Law Group Is Expanding
description: A new legal group, the Madison Society for Law and Policy, hopes to become a progressive competitor to the conservative Federalist Society, a formidable force in the legal profession.

title: A Coup of Several
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A joint venture hopes to tie the product to the entertainment and create a shopping experience.
description: WHETHER it is for food courts or movie theaters, company-sponsored events or interactive activities, trips to the shopping mall have become increasingly more entertaining. Illustrating the growing bond between retail and entertainment, a top talent and literary agency and a major real estate developer are forming a joint venture.

title: Sports of The Times; Philadelphia Seems to Have the Same Destiny as the '99 Knicks
description: IT was the sight of John Thompson lumbering into the winners' locker room late Wednesday night, followed faithfully by Mary Fenlon, his trusted academic adviser, that made me think that we who devote most of our pro basketball time to the Knicks had seen this series and scenario played out before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEN, KETY
description: KOEN-Kety. On May 30, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. She is missed and mourned by her children and grandchildren Denise, Robert, David and Kate Fletcher, and her brother Jak Barkey and his family. Funeral service will be Sunday, at 12 noon, at John J. Fox Funeral Home Inc, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, JESSIE
description: STEINBERG-Jessie. On May 30, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harold, loving mother of Steven and Marcia, dear sister of Lee Weiss and Sara Levy, devoted grandmother of Barrie, Douglas, Jamie, Andrew and Peter. Service Sunday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corruption Charges Against Commander
description: The promising career of a senior police commander who built his reputation as a savvy investigator of drug-related murders was derailed yesterday when federal prosecutors charged that six years ago he staged an arrest to steal money from a drug dealer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANARICK, ALAINE
description: CANARICK-Alaine. The Merrick Jewish Centre, Congregation Ohr Torah, mourns the passing of our beloved member and extends heartfelt condolences to her husband Richard, their children Morgan, Benjamin and Lauren and the entire family. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Barry M. Lasky, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Salmon Tartare
description: Fish tartare dishes -- most often tuna or salmon -- are practically a cliche in expensive restaurants these days but rarely do you see them prepared at home, where they are a genuine treat. The one we have here has a pronounced sesame flavor to it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Westchester section on Sunday about Louis R. Cappelli, a developer involved in major projects in the county, misstated the length of his marriage to his estranged wife, with whom he has waged a publicized multimilliondollar settlement battle. They were married 18 years ago, not 15.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: RECREATION

title: From Germany's East to West, Conservative Tries to Span Gulf
description: In this quaint eastern town surrounded by lakes begins the story of the divided life of Angela Merkel, the politician who next year could become the first woman to lead modern Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL-Ike. 6/1/52-10/2/92. My young, sweet prince. Celebrating your 49th birthday. Always grieving, always loving you. Love, Mom

title: Financial Journalists Chosen For 2001 Gerald Loeb Honors
description: Floyd Norris of The New York Times and Rebecca Smith of The Wall Street Journal were among the winners of the 2001 Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about South Africa's role in handing over a defendant to face the possibility of a death penalty in the embassy bombings trial misstated the position of the country's Constitutional Court on whether he had been advised of his rights. The court could not decide; it did not agree with his lawyers that he had not been advised.

title: A Biologist's Choice Gives Priority to Students
description: When Jill Bargonetti was a postdoctoral fellow working on a tumor- suppressing protein, p53, at Columbia University, she was able to publish papers about her work in a leading journal, Cell, and other prestigious publications. Professors she worked with suggested that she continue her work at a research university like Columbia or Princeton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, IRVING
description: MOSS-Irving. May 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Evelyn, loving father of Patricia Vernam and her husband Kenneth, Michael Moss and his wife Claudia. Cherished grandfather of Sara, Daniel and Benjamin. Everyone who knew him was touched by his goodness. Funeral service Friday June 1, 2001, 1:30pm at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Training For North Koreans
description: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, visiting South Korea, said half a dozen North Koreans had been invited to get some tips on nuclear safety from Australia. The North has signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty but has not permitted a full inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency of its nuclear complex at Yongbyon, where it is suspected of having produced plutonium for warheads. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Swift Rise Seen In H.I.V. Cases For Gay Blacks
description: Young gay black men in six cities are becoming infected with the AIDS virus at the rate of almost 15 percent a year, according to a new study by federal researchers, who found the rate ''alarming'' and called for expanded prevention efforts.

title: Toll-Free Day On Parkway? Labor Day Is a Possibility
description: He won't be remembered for giving Garden State Parkway drivers a toll-free Fourth of July. The wheels of government, after all, turn about as fast as tires in a rush-hour backup on the Driscoll Bridge.

title: Politics Prevailed Over Warnings
description: Why did the architects of New York's energy deregulation plan reject warnings that deregulation could falter? The answer may lie in the economy and politics that gave rise to the plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, ROSLYN (SOLOWAY)
description: DORFMAN - Roslyn (Soloway). Passed away May 31, 2001. She is the beloved wife of Sydney H.; loving mother of William (Jancy) Dorfman and Deborah (Richard) Ashenfarb; cherished grandmother of Joshua and Jed Dorfman; devoted sister of Arnold (Joan) Soloway of Brookline, MA, and sister of the late Leon ''Chick'' (Ann) Soloway. Shiva will be held at the late residence in Tamarac, Friday and Saturday evening, and Sunday. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice. Funeral services will be held Friday, June 1, 2001, at 11:45 AM, at Star of David Cemetery & Funeral Home, 7701 Bailey Rd, N. Lauderdale, FL.

title: William J. Curtis -- Executive, 92
description: William J. Curtis, who held high posts at the Horn & Hardart Baking Company of Philadelphia and the Horn & Hardart Company in New York, died on May 16 in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 92 and lived in Point Lookout, N.Y.

title: On the Hudson, a Beacon for Ships Beckons Tourists
description: ''It's a bit like a cross between a bed-and-breakfast and camping,'' said Charles Cornwell, keeper of the Saugerties Lighthouse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about criticism of agreements reached by the Smithsonian Institution with large donors referred incompletely to a contract between the organization and Catherine B. Reynolds, whose foundation is giving $38 million for an exhibit to honor American achievers. Although Ms. Reynolds will choose 10 of the 15 members of a committee to select the subjects, her nominees are subject to approval of the Smithsonian's regents. If they reject any of her choices, she can nominate another.

title: Sigalit Landau
description: Thread Waxing Space

title: You're Special
description: To paraphrase a remark often used to describe certain country-music aficionados, American Airlines was customer relationship marketing before customer relationship marketing was cool.

title: Role as Understudy Suits Vanbiesbrouck
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 31  At age 37, John Vanbiesbrouck is in the Stanley Cup finals for the second time in his 17-season career as a goalie in the N.H.L. But he is studying this postseason from the bench, rather than from behind the mask.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Economy Shrinks
description: Slack global demand for electronics helped slow the Philippine economy's growth to 2.5 percent in the first three months of 2000, the government said, down from a 3.8 percent annual rate in the prior quarter. Electronics make up least half of Philippine exports. While many of the country's problems are not of its own making, economists say swelling public debt and political turmoil have scared off investors and amplified the impact of the global downturn. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Nuclear Power: Worth the Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Players Help Lift Miami Past the Liberty
description: Richie Adubato, the Liberty's coach, kept telling anybody who would listen that the Miami Sol would be a much improved team this season with the additions of one of Russia's best players, Yelena Baranova, and one of Australia's best, Sandy Brondello.

title: Hot Smoked Salmon Salad
description: Smoke was once a major preservative and fish required thorough treatment with it. Most salmon you purchase in stores is smoked as if preservation for some long journey was still the intent. But, of course, it isn't. Smoking today -- whether it's part of a cold-smoke approach or the hot one -- is primarily a flavoring. So we will use a light smoking technique and add other sweet, slightly exotic flavors as well. The result is a warm, gently cooked and flavored, sophisticated salmon that we slice for a room-temperature salad.

title: Allianz Defends Deal for Dresdner
description: The huge German insurance conglomerate Allianz A.G. tried to reassure nervous investors today that its $20 billion acquisition of Dresdner Bank, the country's third-biggest bank, will produce big savings and add to profits as early as next year.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Tiger by the Tail
description: And now for a wild prediction. Within 12 months President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and all their backers in the oil industry will be begging -- begging -- to revive the Kyoto protocol on climate change, the accord Mr. Bush yanked America out of after taking office.

title: Serena Williams Is Smiling Again
description: Serena Williams was in a giggly mood after her 6-0, 7-5 second-round victory against Katarina Srebotnik today. Her demeanor defused some of the tension surrounding her family of late.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, BLANKA BORI (NEE BERGER)
description: WINKLER-Blanka Bori (nee Berger). Born in Uzhorod, Czechoslovakia. Of Passaic, NJ, on May 31. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Winkler. Devoted mother of Audrey Winkler Tempest of South Orange, NJ, and Gigi Winkler Brown of Englewood, NJ, and sons-in-law Len Tempest and Adam Brown. Dear sister of Sari Lipkin of Clifton, NJ, and Rosemarie Blum of Manhattan. Loving grandmother of Olivia and Bryce Tempest and Jacob and Rachel Brown. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, on Friday at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Blanka Bori Winkler Fund for Jewish Education, care of UJA Federation of Bergen and North Hudson, 111 Kinderkamack Road, Riveredge, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLON, CAROL ANN (NEE: DILBERGER)
description: FALLON-Carol Ann (nee: Dilberger). Age 58, beloved wife of: John Vincent Fallon, mother of Brian and Beth. Sister of: Mary, Dorothy, Jean, and Charles. Memorial contributions may be made to Ovarian Cancer Research Fund.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hasbrouck Heights: 2 Arrested In Bomb Threats
description: A Hasbrouck Heights High School student and a recent graduate of the school have been charged with making false bomb threats on Jan. 3l and May 23 at the school because, the police said, the student wanted to avoid biology class and the planned dissection of a pig. The alumnus, Adrian Bermudez, 19, of Hasbrouck Heights, who graduated last year, was arrested on Wednesday, six days after the arrest of his friend, a 16-year-old boy who told the police about the biology class and whose name was withheld because of his age. A tip from fellow students led to the arrests, said a police spokesman.

title: China Stages War Drills Off Taiwan, to a Mixed Reaction
description: BEIJING, June 1  The Chinese military is staging one of the largest war drills in years this month around an island facing Taiwan, according to press accounts in China and Hong Kong.

title: SHARES OF CEC DECLINE AFTER PROFIT WARNING IS ISSUED
description: CEC Entertainment Inc., the operator of Chuck E. Cheese pizza restaurants, warned that profit this year would fall short of analysts' estimates because warm weather kept customers away in April and May, setting off a 20 percent decline in its stock price. The shares fell $10.60, to $43.30, on the Nasdaq, where they led the list of percentage losers. CEC said Wednesday that it expected full-year profit of $2.47 to $2.52 a share, below the $2.56 expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. CEC earned $1.98 last year. Sales at locations open at least a year fell 3.8 percent in April and rose 0.6 percent in May, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVENKRON, RACHEL
description: LEVENKRON-Rachel. Since June 1, 1988 we miss you very much and love you still. Your Family

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Ground Broken For Convention Center
description: Workers broke ground yesterday on a $770 million convention and retail center that Gov. John G. Rowland and other state officials said would help revitalize a moribund waterfront. Located between Interstate 91 and the Connecticut River, Adriaen's Landing is a 33-acre site that is designed to contain Hartford's first modern convention center, a hotel, stores and homes. The legislature approved $500 million in public financing for the center in May 2000, and the rest will come from private investors.

title: Appeals Court Denies Request To Release 'Vieques Four'
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit yesterday denied requests, at least for now, by four New York City politicians to be freed on bail, as they continued to appeal convictions on charges that they trespassed on a federal military installation on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques. The four men demonstrated against Navy bombing exercises there last month.

title: UNILEVER TO SELL SOME BESTFOOD BRANDS
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch food conglomerate, said yesterday that it would sell more than a dozen of the brands it acquired in the $20.3 billion purchase of Bestfoods last June. The brands generate about $400 million in annual sales and include such names as Mazola cooking oil and Argo corn starch, but Unilever said they had limited global appeal. Since announcing its plan to sell all but its biggest brands last year, Unilever has cast off or simply discontinued many products that may perform well, but are largely restricted to certain geographical markets. That shift in focus is what led to its interest in Bestfoods, whose Hellmann's and Knorr brands have been international superstars for years. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, GERALDINE
description: LONDON-Geraldine. A lifelong resident of New York City, died on Monday, May 28, 2001, in Mission Viejo, California, after a lengthy battle with cancer. Ms. London was born in Manhattan on December 28, 1909, and spent almost fifty years serving the New York City government in several capacities. Following her graduation from New York University, Ms. London embarked upon a career as a case worker in the New York City Department of Welfare. Based upon her exemplary record, Ms. London transferred to the Department of Probation as a probation officer and eventually, Court Liaison Officer. Following her retirement in 1976, and continuing until the diagnosis of her illness in 1999, Ms. London served as an elementary school teacher at numerous New York City public schools, including P.S. 132, where she made many strong friendships among the teaching and administration staff. Ms. London was predeceased by two beloved brothers, Barnard London and Lewis London, both of Westchester County. She is survived by her nieces and nephews: George and Rebecca Donnini of Mission Viejo, California; Lynn Donnini of New Rochelle, New York; Melody and Erin London of New York City; and Robert, Janet, Matthew and Danny London of Ithaca, New York. Ms. London will be dearly missed by all who had the pleasure to know her. Services will be held Sunday 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; From Summer Romance to an Urgent Reminder
description: It takes enormous courage for a filmmaker to choose a subject as cloaked in denial as the AIDS epidemic in the United States two decades after it burst into public consciousness. But that's what the documentarian and sometime actor Jay Corcoran has done in his moving and important new film, ''Undetectable,'' which examines the lives of six Boston residents taking various life-prolonging AIDS medications.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from June 1.

title: Upstart Jostles for Place In Japan's Phone Market
description: The Tokyo Metallic Communications Corporation, an upstart high-speed Internet access provider, is learning just how hard it is to carve out a viable niche against an entrenched telephone giant, even with a roster of blue-chip backers and a successful marketing campaign to its credit.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a stock split and an additional cash dividednd at Exxon Mobil mis-stated the payment date for the regular second-quarter dividend. It is June 11; the additional dividend is payable on July 11.

title: Spitzer Seeks to Force Fund-Raising Data From an Islamic Charity
description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer asked a Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday to compel one of the largest Muslim charities in the country to comply with a subpoena his office issued eight months ago, saying the charity could have ties to the militant Palestinian group Hamas.

title: 'Skank'
description: Plus Ultra

title: Crisis in the Clinics
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation, a public agency that is the medical care provider of last resort in New York City, is now withdrawing its request to the state to close 15 clinics in schools in low-income neighborhoods. The agency had made the controversial proposal to cut its costs, but city officials have since discovered that New York's health department is obligated to provide a nurse for each school if the clinics close, reducing the cost savings from shutting the clinics. Instead the city has decided to pick up some of the health agency's costs to keep the clinics open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAUCETT, JACK GRIFFIN
description: FAUCETT-Jack Griffin. On May 24, 2001, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved husband of Helena Boyer Faucett. Services will be held on Friday, June 1, at 11 AM. Interment to follow at Rock Creek Cemetery, Washington, DC. For information call Joseph Gawler's Sons, Washington, DC; 202-966-6400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMM, KARL, HEINZ WILHELM
description: ZIMM-Karl-Heinz Wilhelm. Of Bradenton, FL, on May 30, 2001. Resident of Manhasset, NY, for twenty plus years. Devoted father of Michael and father-in-law of Diane. Proud grandfather of Julia and Eric. Co-founder of Power Cooling Inc. Loved the fine arts, history, science and his gardens. Visiting at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY, Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Memorial service at 10 AM, on Saturday, June 2, at Church of Our Savior, Lutheran, Manhasset.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: As Chelsea Expands, a Host of Visions Rush In
description: THIS much is certain: the art world will have Chelsea to kick around for a few seasons more, at least. Everyone loves to complain about New York's newest art destination. It's too far from everything, especially subways. There aren't enough places to eat, especially cheaply. There's too much concrete, much of it indoors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGEN, CHARLOTTE
description: KAGEN-Charlotte. On May 29, 2001, of lung cancer at age 83. Survived by her son Jim, daughter-inlaw Laure, grandson Alex and his wife Sue of Brooklyn, NY. Granddaughter Betsy of Manhattan, her niece Nancy Weiss and family of Philadelphia, PA. Charlotte was a professional actress. In the 1940s she starred as ''The Magic Lady'' in a daily television show for children in Philadelphia. Later she was an advertising copywriter in NYC for many years. For the past 15 years she was active in democratic politics and community service here. She was honored this year by the City Council for her work. Memorial service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Ave at 80th St, on Sunday June 10, at 2:30 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to The American Cancer Society. The family can receive written tributes at www.mem.com.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: New Charges For Teacher
description: A prosecutor said yesterday that a teacher who has told police that he is H.I.V.-positive and is already accused of molesting two boys has been indicted on charges of abusing four other children. Robert Holdman, an assistant district attorney, made the statement at a hearing in the case of the teacher, Milton G. McFarlane of Poughkeepsie. Mr. McFarlane is charged with molesting six boys between the ages of 7 and 9 at Public School 78 in Baychester. None of the children have shown signs of contracting H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, a police official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNER, MILTON
description: BERNER-Milton. Special Counsel to State Senator Suzy Oppenheimer and the former Rye Town Attorney and Village of Mamaroneck Attorney, died at age 81, on May 30, 2001. Survived by sons Fred Berner of NYC, Paul Berner of Rye, and Marc Berner of Miami, FL; grandsons Michael Sackler-Berner of NYC, Benjamin and Theodore Berner of Rye; former wife Joan Berner; daughter-in-law Jacqueline Frederick-Berner of Rye; brother Bernard of Boca Raton, FL, and life partner Beatrice Newman of Rye. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 3, 5 PM, at Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Ave, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to ''Friends of Acadia,'' PO Box 45, Bar Harbor, ME 04609; or to the ''The Osborn,'' 103 Theall Rd, Rye, NY 10580.

description: ''We may have stumbled on dinosaur heaven at

description: ASIA<BR PHILIPPINES: ECONOMY SHRINKS Slack global demand for electronics helped slow the Philippine economy's growth to 2.5 percent in the first three months of 2000, the government said, down from a 3.8 percent annual rate in the prior quarter. Electronics make up least half of Philippine exports. While many of the country's problems are not of its own making, economists say swelling public debt and political turmoil have scared off investors and amplified the impact of the global downturn. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: Mary Ryan Gallery

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: The Dangers Of Chechnya
description: A helicopter carrying Russian members of Parliament out of Chechnya came under fire after crossing into the neighboring territory of Ingushetia, leaving the pilot dead. Aleksei Arbatov, deputy chairman of the defense committee and son of the longtime Soviet spokesman Georgi Arbatov, was slightly wounded. The International Committee of the Red Cross announced it is suspending aid operations in Chechnya after an employee in a marked Red Cross vehicle was wounded by Russian soldiers at a checkpoint in the capital. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Appeal for Privacy After Bush Twins Are Cited for Alcohol
description: As the police in Austin, Tex., charged President Bush's 19-year-old twin daughters today with violating Texas liquor laws, the White House beseeched reporters not to use the situation to tread too far into the family's privacy.

title: Paris Still Has Clay; Sampras Is Out Again
description: Somehow, the legendary greatness of Pete Sampras turns into a tall tale inside the gates of Roland Garros, where the clay surface makes him mortal, where the courts seem to have trap doors designed for him.

title: Politics Thickens the Molasses in Albany's Budget Process
description: The state budget is late again for the 17th year in a row.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Breakaway Region Eyes Future
description: A region of Somalia that broke away a decade ago voted on whether to remain independent, another step, the government there hopes, toward persuading outsiders to recognize Somaliland as a separate nation. The northwest province went its own way in 1991, and Somalilanders are proud of the relative peace they have maintained. But other nations have been reluctant to recognize independence because it would mean a formal division of Somalia and could encourage the many other separatist movements in Africa. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Food On The Way
description: A long-delayed deal to put a Citarella food store and warehouse in Harlem has been completed, city officials said yesterday. The food retailer paid the city $850,000 for six buildings at 126th Street between Amsterdam and Morningside Avenues. Joseph Gurrera, the owner of Citarella, said the project would include a 5,000-square-foot store opening onto 125th Street as well as a commissary, where specialty items will be prepared for the other Citarella stores, on 75th Street and Broadway and in Water Mill, on Long Island. He said renovations would take about a year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Plus: Horse Racing; Point Given On Track
description: The trainer Bob Baffert said yesterday that the Preakness winner Point Given was on track to contest the 133rd running of the Belmont Stakes next Saturday and would be shipped to Belmont from Churchill Downs on Wednesday. Baffert, however, stopped short of saying Point Given was a definite starter because of the colt's penchant for high-spirited antics.

title: Residential Real Estate; Under Conversion, the Hermitage Draws a Limelight of Its Own
description: The Hermitage, the 17-story, 130-apartment building at 41 West 72nd Street, has always lived in the shadow of its famous neighbor, the Dakota. But these days, the 74-year-old rental building is attracting attention from potential apartment buyers as one of the few prewar buildings being converted into a condominium.

title: REGULATORS BLOCK BURLINGTON GAS FIELD PURCHASE
description: The $385 million purchase of Canadian gas properties by Burlington Resources Inc. from Atco Ltd. was blocked by provincial regulators who said the deal was not in the public interest. The Alberta Energy and Utilities Board has not released specific reasons for its decision, which was made on Tuesday, a board spokesman, Bob Curran, said. Atco, which owns gas and electricity utilities in the province, needs the board's approval to sell the field, which is situated in central Alberta and has about 250 billion cubic feet of fuel. Burlington, which is based in Houston, agreed to buy the fields in December, when gas prices were a near-record $9.58 per million British thermal units.

title: Auditor Finds No Fraud In Xerox's Annual Report
description: The Xerox Corporation, whose auditors had refused to sign off on its annual report until they had rechecked the numbers, said yesterday that the auditors, KPMG, found some accounting discrepancies but uncovered no signs of fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSHTEYN, SVELTLANA, M.D.
description: FINKELSHTEYN-Sveltlana, M.D. We are saddened by the loss of our dear colleague and friend, Dr. Sveltlana Finkelshteyn. Her medical skills, humanism and sunshine personality will be greatly missed. The Medical Staff and Administration of Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD H.
description: MENDIK-Bernard H. The Board of Governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of its leader for the last decade and a giant in our industry, Bernard H. Mendik. Bernie loved and cared about New York and he played an integral part in shaping its skyline. Bernie brought wisdom, compassion and a sense of humor to all his professional and civic endeavors. We express our deepest sympathy to his lovely wife Suzy, his four wonderful children, and the entire Mendik family. Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Emeritus Steve Spinola, President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a court ruling that cleared the way for the publication of a novel that revisits the scene of ''Gone With the Wind'' misstated the number of years that will have elapsed between the death of the author Margaret Mitchell and the expiration of the copyright on ''Gone With the Wind,'' in 2032. It is 83 years, not 70; Mitchell died in 1949.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about plans by the BellSouth Corporation and others to invest in StarMedia Network, the Internet media company that focuses on Latin America, misstated the amount that J. P. Morgan Chase plans to spend and the change in the stake it will hold. The amount is $3 million, not $11 million. After additional investments from other companies, J. P. Morgan Chase's stake will shrink, not increase, to 14 percent from 17.4 percent.

title: Nuclear Power: Worth the Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Video: He Was Walking a Perilous Line
description: To get acquainted with a filmmaker as intellectually mercurial as the Iranian Moshen Makhmalbaf, one needs a good block of his work. A half-dozen Makhmalbaf films released on videotape this week by Facets International only begin to provide a grasp.

title: Five Determined Students, Five Unusual Routes to a College Degree
description: Seventeen years ago, Gabriel Carrera was a gang member with a $200-a-day drug habit, in jail for breaking and entering. Fourteen years ago, Scott Stoffel, legally blind since birth and suddenly struck deaf, attempted suicide by running onto a busy highway.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: And Now: The Other Plays

title: Omnicom Group Buys Wolff Olins
description: The Omnicom Group in New York has acquired for undisclosed terms Wolff Olins in London, a corporate brand consulting company with $40 million in revenue from clients like the Credit Suisse Group. Wolff Olins has 200 employees in Lisbon, Madrid, New York, San Francisco, Tokyo and London. It will operate as an autonomous unit of the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom.

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Offers Not Guilty Plea in Spy Case
description: A former F.B.I. agent, Robert P. Hanssen, pleaded not guilty today in federal court here to charges that he spied for Moscow for more than 15 years.

title: The Big City; First Family: A Job for Pros, Not Politicians
description: BEFORE the First Husband kicks out any more of the First Wife's staff members, before she files any more court motions against the First Good Friend, the citizens of New York must confront a painful truth. We're to blame for the mess in Gracie Mansion. We put the wrong First Family in the house.

title: Raw Marinated Salmon
description: This is going to be a kind of French sashimi, in that the fish is completely raw but we'll make a dressing for it and serve it thinly sliced. The beauty is that the whole thing, start to finish, shouldn't take more than three minutes.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Opposition Leaders Released
description: The government released the six opposition candidates who had charged President Idriss Dby with stealing the recent presidential election. The Socialist Party in France, the country's former colonial ruler, denounced the Chadian government for violating election rules to keep Mr. Dby in power. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Crab-and-crawfish fritters make the point about Jane. They're the first appetizer on the menu, and they're simple, served with spicy tartar sauce and as American as all get-out. American, of course, means melting-pot cuisine.

title: 6 Siblings Make a Lonely Stand, Minus Mother, Father and Power
description: ''This is not a standoff,'' Sheriff Phil Jarvis of Bonner County said today.

title: A Duel of Wits and Crustaceans, Round 2
description: THEY duel with lobsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICK, ELEANOR HENDLER
description: DICK-Eleanor Hendler. Beloved wife of Franklin Dick. Dear mother of Richard, Robert and Evan Dick. Dear sister of Julius, Sam and Herb Hendler. Dear grandmother of Graham and Ethan. Dear aunt. Graveside services 10:30 AM, Friday, June 1, at Union Field Cemetery, Queens, NY. For information contact Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Slumbering in the Egyptian Desert, a Titan of a Dinosaur
description: Digging at an oasis in the Egyptian desert, paleontologists have found huge fossil bones of what they say appears to have been the second most massive dinosaur that ever lived.

title: That Certain Summer, Her Life Turned Erotic
description: ''A Real Young Girl,'' a surreal voyage into adolescent sexuality written and directed by Catherine Breillat, is both a sequel and precursor to ''Romance,'' Ms. Breillat's harrowing and voluptuous exploration of a middle-aged woman's erotic life. That film's unsentimental explicitness shocked audiences in both the United States and France when it was released two years ago.

title: The Prince In Us All
description: WITH a sharing spirit uncommon among spoiled and neurotic young royals, Prince Hamlet has invited you to step directly inside his mind and take a close look at what's really going on there. And if you're any kind of lover of theater, you would be mad indeed not to take him up on it before he leaves the Brooklyn Academy of Music after tomorrow night's performance.

title: Coln Withdraws From Bronx Race And Throws His Support to Espada
description: The competition for Bronx borough president narrowed yesterday when Willie Coln, the salsa performer and onetime candidate for Congress, withdrew from the race and endorsed a former rival, State Senator Pedro Espada Jr.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Campaign Finance
description: One day before today's deadline to enroll in the city's campaign finance program, 245 candidates had signed up, most of them running for City Council seats. City officials expect a record of at least 300 to enroll by the end of the day, although a final count may not be available until next week, as the candidates need only have requests in the mail by today. Candidates for mayor and other offices who participate in the program are generally entitled to $4 in city money for each $1 they raise in small contributions. The largest number of candidates to sign up for the 13-year-old program was 256 in 1991.

title: New Center for Foster Children Echoes Changes in an Agency
description: The city's new emergency intake center for children entering foster care is set to open for the first time this evening, in a renovated landmark building of soaring arches and East River views meant to be the embodiment of changes in the child welfare agency.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Circus Goes Overboard

title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Foreign Aid
description: The government of Ange Flix Patasse received assistance from Libya and a rebel group in Congo to defeat a band of mutinous soldiers who nearly seized power early this week and are hiding in the outskirts of the capital, Bangui. Andr Kolingba, a former military ruler believed to be behind the coup attempt, told Radio France International that he had asked the soldiers to return to their barracks. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Another Feint Comes From Rahman's Camp in Planning August Bout
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, likes to think he runs the ring. But even more than usual, it looks like what he is running is a three-ring circus.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WIRE ONE TECHNOLOGIES INC., Hillside, N.J., a provider of voice, video and data equipment and services, agreed to buy GeoVideo Networks Inc., for $10.6 million in stock.

title: Helen Oakley Dance, Jazz Critic, Dies at 88
description: Helen Oakley Dance, a journalist and historian of jazz and blues, as well as a record producer, music publisher and personal assistant to musicians like Duke Ellington, Red Norvo, Chick Webb, Johnny Hodges, Bob Crosby and Earl Hines, died on Sunday in Escondido, Calif. She was 88.

title: Puffy's Protg Sentenced to 10 Years in Club Shooting
description: Aprotege and former co-defendant of Sean Combs recited Scripture in a Manhattan courtroom today before a judge sentenced him to 10 years in prison for a nightclub shooting last year that injured three people.

title: U.S. News & World Report Editor to Step Down
description: Stephen G. Smith, the top editor of U.S. News & World Report, will leave the magazine and be replaced by Brian P. Duffy, the executive editor, people at the magazine said last night.

title: Pressure in Jakarta Builds So Far in Orderly Fashion
description: Indonesia is on course to oust its third leader in three years. But unlike previous political upheavals, which were chaotic and violent, this one is unfolding with remarkable order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, RONES, BARBARA
description: BENNETT-RONES-Barbara. The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member, Barbara Bennett-Rones. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her dear husband Gary, and to all her family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Paul Seidenberg, President

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Raoul de Keyser -- 'Come on, Play It Again''
description: David Zwirner

title: California City Pins Hopes On a Big Natural Gas Field
description: This small city's fate has always been tied to the land. Now Delano is pinning its hopes on what lies beneath the land.

title: Summer Owner Wants A Vote in Both Houses; Suit Says People Can Be Residents Of More Than One Place
description: In the name of the millions of American families with city homes and country places, a New York investment banker named Harold M. Wit is using his considerable means to try to create a new right to vote.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Refinery Stake Sold
description: The Merhav Group, which had been the largest Israeli investor in Egypt, said that it was selling its minority share of a new $1.3 billion oil refinery near Alexandria. The company did not disclose the price or buyer of its stake, a 20 percent holding in the Middle East Oil Refinery company, which is majority-owned by the Egyptian government and intended primarily to supply foreign markets, including Israel. William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

title: Creating a Market for Vaccines
description: While pharmaceutical companies' agreement to lower the prices of some anti-AIDS drugs is good news, it promises little relief to the vast majority of Africans with AIDS, who live in countries with governments unable to buy these drugs even at the reduced prices. And even if the price were zero, weak health infrastructure and low levels of education would make widespread effective use of the anti-AIDS drugs difficult, as they require complicated regimens of dosage and control.

title: Plus: Rowing; Princeton Posts Fastest Time
description: On a windy day in Pennsauken, N.J., all the seeded heavyweight eight-oared varsities -- California-Berkeley, Princeton, Brown and Pennsylvania -- won their opening heats yesterday as the 99th Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championships began on the 2,000-meter Cooper River course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIAM, VICTOR K.
description: KIAM-Victor K. Dear Victor, a heart of gold and charisma, a unique combination. My hero and beloved confidante and friend. You know you were my personal and professional role model and mentor. An uncanny ability to make everyone around you feel incredibly special. You gave to all without expecting anything in return. Victor, you and Ellen have built a family that will always be my foundation. Thank you for including me in your family and heart. I will always cherish our time spent together, and your inner strength and beauty will always serve as my guide. I will love and support your family forever, and you can rest assured that they will continue to ''go for it'' in life and in tennis! Love always, Jay B. Horowitz

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Sports of The Times; Devils' Den Fills Up For Finals
description: AFTER taking some abuse about not filling their arena during the regular season, the Devils had a full house last night for Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals -- at least until Colorado took a two-goal lead.

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Slides in May to 4.4 Percent
description: The unemployment rate showed a slight improvement in May, with its first decline in eight months, as companies cut fewer jobs than expected and more Americans gave up their job searches, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Mending Fences
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowland Seeks Votes for Veto But Will Sign Emissions Bill
description: Six of Connecticut's oldest and most polluting oil- and coal-burning power plants would be required to meet the most current federal emissions standards by 2005 under the terms of a bill that Gov. John G. Rowland has said he will sign into law despite aggressive efforts by the plant owners to kill it.

title: A Dark Secret Comes to Light in Serbia
description: For two years, the people of this Danube River town kept the dark secret that has now led to the first move by Serbia's new democratic authorities to charge Slobodan Milosevic with war crimes.

title: Frustration Mounts As the Devils Sputter
description: Alexander Mogilny raced determinedly past his defender, heading toward Colorado goalie Patrick Roy when he thought he heard a plaintive voice call out to him from beyond.

title: MERCER, A CONSULTING FIRM, WILL LAY OFF 159 WORKERS
description: William M. Mercer a human resources consulting firm based in New York, said yesterday that it was laying off 159, about 3.3 percent, of its 4,800 employees in offices in the United States. The move is in response to declining customer demand in the economic slowdown, a spokeswoman said. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Salary Cap Traps Some of the Old Lions
description: N.F.L. club executives often talk about the ''good old days,'' the time before free agency sprouted in 1994, the days of no salary cap and when big dollars spent on salaries and bonuses would cost a franchise nothing more than a hefty check.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERLOCK, THE HONORABLE DULCIE, ANN STEINHARDT
description: SHERLOCK-The Honorable Dulcie-Ann Steinhardt, on Memorial Day, May 28, 2001, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved wife of the late Squadron Leader Allan Arthur Sherlock, RCAF, DFC and BAR, CD. Devoted mother of Laurene Ann Sherlock of Bethesda, MD, Victor Allan Sherlock and his wife Ruth Burns Sherlock of Greenville, SC; loving grandmother of Abigail Ann and Christopher Allan Sherlock of Greenville, SC. Mrs. Sherlock is also survived by her cousins Ambassador Peter R. Rosenblatt, of Washington, DC, Robert W. Rosenblatt of Ithaca, NY, Richard D. Rosenblatt of Rancho Santa Fe, CA, and other relatives. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC, on Sunday, June 3, from 5-7 PM. Funeral services will be held at 12 noon on Monday, June 4, at All Saints' Episcopal Church, 3 Chevy Chase Circle, Chevy Chase, MD. Interment to follow at Rock Creek Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the the United States Air Force Academy (Steinhardt-Sherlock Trophy), 2304 Cadet Drive, Suite 351, US Air Force Academy, CO 80840-5002; or the Hospital Relief Fund of the Caribbean, c/o Peter Tropper, Treasurer, 4715 Crescent St, Bethesda, MD 20816.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDES, AL
description: MINDES-Al. For a wonderful human being whose warmth, wit and charm will long be remembered. Debby and Marty Posner

title: Contributing to the Old Country
description: Recent immigrants from Latin America play an increasingly decisive role in two economies at once -- in this nation's and in the one back home. Their impact here is likely to drive the coming debate on immigration reform, as Mexico and the United States discuss the possibility of legalizing the status of millions of undocumented workers and creating new guest-worker programs. But the economic significance of immigrants' remittances back home should be considered as well.

title: Bush to Replace Chairman of Humanities Endowment
description: President Bush has decided to replace William R. Ferris as head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, choosing an expert on Italian Renaissance art as his successor, the White House announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANFREDI, ANNA (NEE PIETRAGALLO)
description: MANFREDI-Anna (nee Pietragallo). May 30, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Mario, dear aunt of Dennis and Dolph Castellano. Reposing at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St, NYC, 6-9 PM, Friday. Funeral Mass 9:30 AM, Saturday, St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: U.N. Chief Asks Businesses to Support Fund to Fight AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, appealed to American corporations today to dig into their pockets and give to a planned multibillion-dollar global fund to attack AIDS in Africa and other developing regions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DR. THEODORE
description: FELDMAN-Dr. Theodore. Patient, loving, understanding, adored husband of Judy Feldman. Deeply beloved father of Carol (Michael) Hagstedt and David (Barbra) Feldman. Loving brother of Seth Feldman. Passed away on May 30, 2001. Dr. Feldman was Chief of Orthopaedic Surgery in Peninsula Hospital Center, Rockaway Beach, NY, and retired to North Palm Beach, Florida., in 1993. We will miss you, Teddy, with all our hearts. Services will be held Friday, June 1, at 2:30 PM, at Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: A Failed Energy Plan Catches Up to New York
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, SALLY
description: GEORGE-Sally. May 31, 1991. Oh, how I miss your joy, vitality, and exhuberant love of life! My best friend for all my life, you are remembered, missed and cherished every single day. Love always, Catherine

title: 120 Groups Join to Push $10 Billion Housing Plan
description: Business and community leaders are calling on the mayoral candidates to confront New York City's housing shortage with a $10 billion plan to build 100,000 homes and renovate 85,700 others in the next decade.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Xerox Says Its Auditors Found No Signs of Fraud

title: Unemployment Claims in U.S. Are Reported at 7 1/2-Year High
description: More Americans filed for first-time unemployment benefits last week, and continuing claims reached their highest in seven and a half years, the government said today, while another report said the risks of a recession had risen.

title: Walton-Jones Friendly Feud Is All in the Family
