description: They bicker like Archie and Meathead. They're as different as Vince McMahon and Vin Scully. NBC's Steve Jones and Bill Walton act as if they're old marrieds who endure by taking separate vacations. Walton owns a backyard tepee. Jones does not.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Europeans To Sell Sprint Stakes
description: Two European phone giants, France Tlcom and Deutsche Telekom, said yesterday that they would each sell their stakes in Sprint at $19 a share. France Tlcom plans to sell 75.9 million shares and Deutsche Telekom 76.2 million shares. The combined stakes represent an almost 20 percent interest in Sprint. The two companies acquired their stakes in Sprint in 1996 and each retains a substantial stake in Sprint PCS, the parent company's wireless business. Both are seeking to pay down debts incurred last August when they acquired next-generation wireless licenses in Europe. France Tlcom, France's largest company, has plans to cut its debt by half, to 30 billion euros ($25.7 billion), by 2002. Deutsche Telekom said yesterday that it planned to issue more than a billion new shares to pay for its takeovers of two United States telecommunications companies, VoiceStream Wireless and Powertel Inc. Shares in Sprint closed at $20.31, up $1 or 5.18 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Eccentrics Who Number Even the Eggs and Pickles
description: Shifting from self-consciously earnest to self-consciously arch to just self-conscious, ''Everything Moves Alone'' has the amateurish let's-put-on-a-movie vibe that's the unfortunate backwash of such low-budget successes as ''Hollywood Shuffle,'' ''Clerks'' and ''Bottle Rocket.'' They made turning out a first feature on the cheap look a whole lot easier than it actually is.

title: Article 2001060192143281060 -- No Title
Plus: Track And Field; Stringfellow Wins N.C.A.A. Long Jump
description: Savante Stringfellow of Mississippi won his second straight N.C.A.A. outdoor long jump championship with the second- and third-longest jumps of the year. Stringfellow, a member of the United States Olympic team in Sydney last year, won with a final jump of 27 feet 1 inches at the N.C.A.A. championships in Eugene, Ore.

title: Article 2001060191608588694 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: INSIDE ART
description: More Growth For Guggenheim

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: University Is Defended
description: More than 80 corporations, unions, politicians and legal and educational groups are filing briefs supporting the University of Michigan's defense of its affirmative action policies. General Motors is one of about 30 large companies that joined the United Auto Workers, the American Bar Association and others in backing the university before the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Lower courts upheld Michigan's undergraduate admissions policy but declared the law school's illegal in two cases that many believe will go to the Supreme Court. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Shareholders Lose Out
description: Vlasic Foods International said yesterday that it expected to file, within two weeks, a bankruptcy plan that provides for no payment to shareholders. The food company, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said the $370 million sale of most of its assets to a buyout firm was insufficient to pay unsecured creditors in full. The amount owed to unsecured creditors is $210 million.

title: The Zero-Sum Tax Cut
description: As I'm sure you do all the time, I recently spent an evening browsing through some old essays from the tax-cut debates of the 1980's. What was striking about those debates, especially compared to the arguments that now surround the Bush tax cuts, was how epic they were. The supply-siders considered themselves Reagan revolutionaries. They wrote tracts with grand names like ''Wealth and Poverty'' and ''The Way the World Works.'' They believed they were leading a moral and cultural reformation, not just boosting the gross domestic product.

title: Carts, Yes. Caddies, No.
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Back at Muirfield And Two Behind Leaders
description: There is no Phil Mickelson, no David Duval, no Davis Love III at this year's Memorial Tournament. But there is Tiger Woods, and these days that is the only name that really matters.

title: Firestone Asks U.S. to Study Ford Explorer
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. asked the Transportation Department today to open a safety investigation of the Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle, contending that the Explorer's design makes it prone to rollover crashes when a tire fails.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Olympics Plan Presented
description: The committee leading New York's bid to hold the Summer Olympics in 2012 officially filed its proposal this week with the United States Olympic Committee and released it to the public. The committee's 600-page report details an elaborate plan for the Games set along a transportation network that stretches along subway and train lines from Flushing, Queens, across Manhattan to the New Jersey Meadowlands and along ferry routes down the Harlem and East Rivers to Staten Island. The committee, NYC 2012, projects that revenues from advertising, sponsorships and the sale of television rights will cover the estimated $2.35 billion cost. The bid, however, assumes that the city, the state and the Jets football team will already have built a billion-dollar stadium on the West Side of Manhattan -- a proposal that has sparked opposition -- that could double as the official Olympic stadium. Members of the United States Olympic Committee, which is considering eight locations for the 2012 summer games, plan to visit New York City on July 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, EDITH C.
description: GRUEN-Edith C. Passed away at age 73 on May 28, 2001 in NYC after many years of enduring Kidney Disease. Survived by her brother Peter also of NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc. or The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Introduction
description: In preparing this lesson about salmon, we've made some assumptions: you probably are reasonably comfortable broiling or grilling a fillet (if you want to roast or poach one whole take a look at our earlier lessons on those techniques). But you may well be a little intimidated by some of the less common approaches to the fish, especially those where the salmon is barely cooked, cured or served completely raw. In other words, exactly the sorts of dishes that bring cries of delight in the most haute of the restaurants these days.

title: Shares Up Slightly in Rebound From Technology Sell-Off
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday as investors, fresh from a sharp sell-off of technology stocks on Wednesday, spent the day hunting for bargains.

title: The Office Romance That Has All Mexico Talking
description: Martha Sahagun is the first woman ever appointed to speak for a president of Mexico. She advises him. She promotes his policies. She helped in his remarkable sucess as the first opposition politician in 71 years to break the hold of Mexico's dominant political party on the presidency.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs Forecasts Big Loss
description: Tellabs Inc., the largest maker of equipment used to manage telephone traffic, will take a bigger-than-expected charge in the second quarter for job cuts and plant and office closings. The charge will total $262 million, up from previous estimates of $150 million to $225 million, the company said. Almost half of the charge is related to reduced demand for products that deliver high-speed Internet connections on cable television lines. In April, Tellabs said that it would cut 550 jobs, about 6 percent of its work force, and it canceled a new line of switches to cut costs as its phone company customers curtailed spending.

title: Kandahar Journal; This Job Is Truly Scary: The Taliban Are Watching
description: He is a nervous man with nervous eyes, going about a nervous business. If the Taliban catch him at his secretive work they will consider him an enemy of Islam and beat him up in the street before locking him away.

title: Plus: Pro Football; The Jets Sign Rutgers's King
description: The Jets yesterday signed Walter King of Rutgers, an undrafted rookie free-agent wide receiver, one day before teams can release high-priced veteran players and delay most of the damage to the salary cap until after this season.

title: Selling Japanese on Economic Pain; Economist in New Cabinet Must Persuade Colleagues
description: Heizo Takenaka's official title is state minister for economic and fiscal policy, but his real job is sales and marketing.

title: Accounts
description: North Carolina Division of Tourism, Film and Sports Development, Raleigh, N.C., to Loeffler Ketchum Mountjoy, Charlotte, N.C., to continue as its agency after a mandated review. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Print the Recipes
description: HOT SMOKED SALMON SALAD

title: AIDS in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: 'Sex' and the Lie

title: The Darling of South Africa Dies of AIDS at the Age of 12
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 1 -- Nkosi Johnson, a frail 12-year-old with AIDS who became the darling of an infected nation, died quietly this morning after lingering for five months on the brink of death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, RABBI DR. LEON
description: KATZ-Rabbi Dr. Leon. Beloved husband of Rebbitzin Rhea Katz. Cherished father of Shimon and Nancy Katz, and Avram and Dr. Nadine Katz. Devoted brother of Rabbi Michael and Rebbitzin Hinda Katz. Adored grandfather. Served the Passaic and Clifton, NJ, communities as rabbi and rabbi emeritus of Cong. Adas Israel over 63 years. Ordained by Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, affiliate of Yeshiva University. Recipient of numerous community honors and an honorary doctorate from YU. He was buried in Israel. Mrs. Katz and children will observe shiva at her home, 32 Laurel Ave., Clifton, NJ, from Friday to Wednesday morning.

title: Begin an Inquiry Into Ulster Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHIN, JAMES P.
description: CHIN-James P. 11/6/36 to 6/1/96. Forever Loved-Forever MissedForever Remembered. Love, Elaine

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes in the Media Industry
description: Scott Allison, general manager at the San Francisco office of Connors Communications, a public relations agency, was promoted to the new post of president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, HARRIET SHAPIRO
description: FISCHER-Harriet Shapiro. Of Boca Raton, passed away May 30, 2001. Cherished treasure of her husband, Dr. Milton Fischer; her sons Mark and Steven Shapiro; her grandchildren Joe and Eva, and her sister Florence Justin. Her light lives on in all of us. Services Sunday, June 3, 11:30 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (near 91st St), Manhattan, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISNER, ROSLYN
description: MEISNER-Roslyn. Died May 29, peacefully in her sleep after a long illness. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Ivan and Roz Meisner and Howard and Karen Meisner-Weiss. Adored grandmother of Brian, Jill, Bara, Sabrina and Adam. Respected and admired for her warmth and wisdom by her legion of relatives and friends. Services Star of David Funeral Chapel, Tamarac, FL, 1:00 PM Friday, June 1.

title: The Big Three Are Taking The Yankees a Long Way
description: Roger Clemens speaks of his salad days and there is nothing good in the connotation. In the lingo shared by Clemens and his Yankees teammate Andy Pettitte, a salad day is when a pitcher's fastball is meatless and he must mix his pitch selection, as you might mix a salad.

title: Auto Sales Fell 1.2% in May, Less Than Analysts Expected
description: DETROIT, June 1 -- The enduring strength of auto sales has surprised economists every month this year and it did so again today, as sales fell only 1.2 percent from May of last year, while the General Motors Corporation unexpectedly posted a small increase in sales.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Crackdown On Sects
description: Parliament has adopted a sharply criticized bill that cracks down on sects but dropped a plan to make ''mental manipulation'' a crime, a measure that had been fiercely protested by religious groups. Under the law, courts can ban groups regarded as sects. The law also provides for sects, as well as individual members, to be punished for fraud, illegal practice of medicine, wrongful advertising or sexual abuse. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Report Says Few Poor Children Receive Adequate Preschool Education in New Jersey
description: A Rutgers University study concludes that less than 10 percent of New Jersey's poorest children receive adequate preschool education, despite a three-year-old court order that the state upgrade its programs in 30 disadvantaged districts.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: On the Bumpy Road of a Union Drive
description: The title of Ken Loach's new film dusts off a venerable slogan of the American labor movement. The call for ''bread and roses,'' as a present-day union organizer named Sam Shapiro (Adrien Brody) explains in the movie, originated among the striking textile workers in Lowell, Mass., in 1912. Those workers, many of them women and immigrants, like the Los Angeles office cleaners Sam represents, asserted their rights not only to sustenance, but to beauty as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMMEL, STEFFIE
description: SCHIMMEL-Steffie. On May 29, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Loving mother of Daniel and Roger, dear sister of Dinah. Devoted grandmother of Michael and Jason. She will be deeply missed. Service Friday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mr. Bush's Idea of Leadership
description: President Bush has now occupied the White House for a little over four months. There is much to be said for the discipline and steadiness he has brought to the job. But at this point it is also fair to raise questions about Mr. Bush's vision of the office, his ideas about the exercise of executive power and his definition of the scope of presidential leadership and responsibility. The actions and inactions of these first months contain some troubling signs. He sometimes projects an air of detachment bordering on indifference even on issues of major concern.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</B

title: National Briefing | West: California: Campaign Controversy
description: A Riverside County Indian tribe says it spent $100,000 on mailers attacking Antonio Villaraigosa, a candidate for mayor of Los Angeles, at the request of a longtime supporter of Mr. Villaraigosa's opponent, City Attorney James K. Hahn. Leaders of the Soboba band of Mission Indians say Daniel Weinstein, a consultant and friend of Mr. Hahn's urged them and other tribes to contribute. Mr. Hahn denied that the mailers were coordinated with his campaign, which would have violated election laws. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: New Video Releases
description: Traffic

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Digital Island Deal Clears A Review
description: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared the way for Cable and Wireless of Britain to acquire Digital Island, an American Internet company, for more than $300 million, officials said. The companies had been waiting to receive approval from the F.T.C. under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act; the waiting period allows commission officials and the Justice Department to consider antitrust issues. Cable and Wireless, a global telecommunications company that had about $11.5 billion in revenue last year, said May 14 that it would buy Digital Island, of San Francisco, for $340 million plus the assumption of about $50 million of debt. The companies said the merger would not require a review by the Office of Fair Trading in Britain or by the European Commission. But the companies have agreed to submit it to the United States Committee of Foreign Investment, which considers national security issues when foreign companies buy American ones.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on the Fashion page on May 22 about furniture design that is generating more excitement than fashion collections misspelled the name of a clothing label trying to make a comeback in the face of the trend. It is Jaeger, not Jaegar.

title: Trenton Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Mussina May Get Extra Rest
description: Mike Mussina could pitch Monday against Boston's Pedro Martnez for his third consecutive start, but Yankees Manager Joe Torre raised the possibility Wednesday that he might give Mussina an extra day of rest and pitch him Tuesday against the Baltimore Orioles, his former team.

title: Eathorne Starts First and Ends First
description: When A. J. Eathorne made a 45-foot birdie putt on her first hole this morning, some of her competitors in the United States Women's Open were still in bed. Eathorne had the first tee time, 7:30 a.m., and after getting up before dawn, she arrived at the first tee needing something to jump-start her day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mob Case Unfolding
description: The F.B.I. and federal prosecutors in Brooklyn yesterday unsealed a new indictment in a case against four men accused of being mob figures. The indictment adds racketeering charges and names three more defendants in the case. The indictment charges the men with looting union pension funds, extortion and loan-sharking. Prosecutors said one of the defendants, Joseph Dibenedetto, received a no-show job from one of the two construction companies named in the indictment. He was supposed to serve as a shop steward for the Cement and Concrete Workers Local 20, the authorities said. Prosecutors also said that another of the accused, Joel Goldman, falsely claimed to be an accountant and did work for one of the construction companies. The mob crew was led by Joseph Tangorra, prosecutors said.

title: Article 2001060191203742044 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Album of the Week
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: -- ''Folks, He Sure Do Pull Some Bow!: Vintage Fiddle Music, 1927-1935'' (Old Hat Enterprises, P.O. Box 10309,

title: First No-Hitter In the Atlantic
description: At the end of last season, shoulder tendinitis had almost convinced Rod Henderson that he should be content with memories that included allowing Sammy Sosa's 65th home run and a double to Mark McGwire during the pair's home run duel in 1998.

title: American Way of Death
description: ''Six Feet Under,'' HBO's new series about a family of undertakers, begins Sunday night. This dark comedy, full of dry humor and deflected emotions, centers on the Fishers, portrayed by, above from left, Michael C. Hall, Frances Conroy and Peter Krause.

title: What Goes Into a Bill? A Little Bit of Everything
description: New Yorkers are paying more than ever for electricity -- nearly 40 percent more than two years ago, depending on the month-- yet the Pataki administration says it has cut rates deeply, saving consumers $6 billion over six years.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: CANTEL MEDICAL TO BUY MINNTECH FOR $70 MILLION
description: The Cantel Medical Corporation, a leading maker of products for cleaning medical devices, agreed to buy the Minntech Corporation for $70 million to gain its equipment and chemicals for disinfecting kidney dialysis machines. Cantel, based in Little Falls, N.J., is seeking to expand its medical sterilization business by entering the fast-growing dialysis market. In the past, the company has focused on selling products for cleaning and storing endoscopes, diagnostic tools used to screen for colon and other cancers. Cantel will exchange $10.50 in cash and stock for each Minntech share, consisting of $6.25 in cash and $4.25 in equity, the companies said.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pursuing Jehovah's Witnesses
description: A Moscow judge revived efforts by prosecutors to ban the Jehovah's Witnesses, overturning a ruling that found no basis to charges that the group breaks up families and threatens individual rights. Prosecutors say the group has broken a 1997 law that establishes Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism as official faiths and requires most other religions to weather a convoluted registration process. Critics call the law a case of religious oppression; advocates, including Russia's Orthodox Church, say it is needed to keep cults from filling the vacuum created by decades of Soviet-decreed atheism. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Article 2001060190016065410 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Immigration Agency Offers Expedited Visas for $1,000
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service will start charging foreign scientists, athletes, corporate executives and other special workers an extra $1,000 to speed the processing of their temporary work visas.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Electronic Arts Fills Online Post
description: The big video game maker Electronics Arts said yesterday that Erick Hachenburg, left, had been named chief operating officer of EA.com, its online gaming unit, replacing Joe Keene, who resigned last week. Mr. Hachenburg, 35, was chief executive of Pogo.com, a game portal that Electronic Arts acquired earlier this year. Game players spend an average of 84 minutes a week playing low-tech games like bridge, checkers and poker on Pogo.com, making it one of the ''stickiest'' sites on the Web. Electronic Arts has spent millions developing online games, but has yet to turn a profit on them. It hopes to increase sales by charging monthly fees to play games and by selling online advertising. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Addenda: New York Lottery Picks 4 Finalists
description: The New York State Lottery named four finalists yesterday in a mandated review on its account, with billings estimated at $60 million.

title: Familiar Name Returns To Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam in New York, part of the WPP Group, is abandoning a name change for its direct marketing unit that had been met with widespread disdain.

title: Lyle Starr
description: Kagan Martos

title: Nuclear Power: Worth the Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Tax Shuffle: Soon You, Too, Will Pay the A.M.T.
description: CUTTING taxes is a lot of fun. So much so that the tax bill just passed includes provisions intended to force future Congresses to cut taxes again.

title: Half Man, Half Beast, But the Guy's All Heart
description: As Lily Tomlin's sexually repressed telephone operator Ernestine used to say of certain aggressive members of the opposite sex, crinkling her eyes and lasciviously flicking her tongue over pursed lips, ''The man's an animal.'' Yes, it's become almost a truism that all men are dogs. But what if that manly beast (or beastly man) is as sweet natured as Marvin Mange, the surgical hybrid embodied by an endearingly wide-eyed Rob Schneider in ''The Animal''? Well then, the Ernestines of this world need not fear for their virtue.

title: Depicting The Sport Of Kings
description: ''The horse is one of the greater miracles of nature,'' the English painter Alfred Munnings wrote in his autobiography, ''An Artist's Life.'' ''Although horses have given me much trouble and many sleepless nights, they have been my supporters, friends -- my destiny, in fact.'' Munnings devoted much of his life to capturing the spirit and likeness of individual horses for patrons including George V and Elizabeth II.

title: Late Again, Budget May Not Come at All
description: The New York State budget is late again -- for the 17th year in a row.

title: Executive Changes At 2 Agencies
description: Changes are taking place in the top ranks of two agencies.

title: Editor in Chief at Harper's Bazaar Is Forced Out
description: Katherine Betts, the successor to the celebrated editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, Liz Tilberis, was asked to resign yesterday afternoon at 4 p.m., a full year before her three-year contract is due to expire and about 23 hours after her replacement knew she had a new job.

title: MISSILE DEFENSES NEED MORE TESTS, KEY SENATOR SAYS
description: The next chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that it was highly unlikely that missile defenses would be fielded in President Bush's current term, and should not be deployed at all until repeated tests proved their effectiveness.

title: Problems With Space Station's Robotic Arm Delay Shuttle Visits
description: The next two flights of space shuttles to the International Space Station will each be delayed at least three weeks as engineers try to resolve problems with the station's new robotic arm, National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer Executive Named
description: The orthopedics device maker Sulzer Medica A.G., buffeted financially by the recall of faulty hip implants and hundreds of lawsuits, named Stephan Rietiker as its chief executive. Mr. Rietiker, a 45-year-old medical doctor, was vice president and general manager for Europe at the Central Laboratory Services unit of Covance Inc. in Geneva. He succeeds Andre Buchel, who had planned to leave Sulzer Medica, which will be spun off from its parent Sulzer in July. Sulzer Medica's stock plunged last week when it said its insurance might not fully cover costs for the implant recall. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Hanover Wants Giuliani to Pay Aide's Salary
description: Divorce lawyers for Donna Hanover, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's estranged wife, yesterday asked a court to order the mayor to personally pay $58,000 for the part-time salary of Ms. Hanover's press secretary as well as $240,000 in legal fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUSSI, MICHAEL A.
description: CERUSSI-Michael A. Died on May 30, 2001, after a prolonged illness. He was 77, and lived in Harrison, NY. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Anne; sons Michael A. Jr. of Greenwich, CT, and Thomas F. of Stamford, CT; daughters Rosemary Ferrer of Greenwich, CT, and Nancy A. McEnaney of Ridgefield, CT; a sister Julia Breitenbach of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, and eight grandchildren. A son, Ernest, predeceased him in 1994. The family will receive friends on Thursday, May 31, 2001, from 7 PM to 9 PM, and on Friday, June 1, 2001, from 2 PM to 4 PM, and from 7 PM to 9 PM, at the William Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, June 2, 2001, at 10 AM, at Our Lady of Sorrow's Church, Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY.

title: An Aesthetic of Turmoil With Sneers and Screams
description: It was a strong but somewhat mismatched bill when Idlewild and Placebo performed on Monday night at Irving Plaza. The Scottish quartet Idlewild, touring behind its first American major-label release, ''100 Flowers'' (Capitol Records), revels in energy and sincerity. Idlewild sounds like the R.E.M. of punk rock, while Placebo, led by Brian Molko, the current but definitely not the last in a long line of androgynous British rock stars, is the Rush of glam rock.

title: McCain Cementing Relationship With Democratic Opposition
description: With the Senate on the threshold of switching to Democratic control next week, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is poised more than ever to be one of the new power brokers of the chamber, is cementing critical relationships with the opposition. His guest this weekend at his vacation home in Sedona, Ariz., will be Senator Tom Daschle, the incoming majority leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, SARA
description: BLAUSTEIN-Sara. The Ratner and Popowitz families and all the employees of Joseph Ratner Company grieve with our dear friend Norman Blaustein and his family over the cold blooded and brutal murder in Israel of his beloved wife, Sara. Words are utterly inadequate to express our heartbreak, sorrow and outrage at this shocking and senseless act of terrorism. Caryl Ratner and Marc Popowitz Joseph Ratner Company, Inc.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Warning On Teacher Talks
description: A state-appointed mediator called yesterday on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Schools Chancellor Harold Levy and Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, to move more aggressively to resolve their differences on teacher salaries. Hoping to broker a settlement for the city's 80,000 public-school teachers, the mediator, Robert L. Douglas, said he was scheduling the next negotiating session for Monday. He said the parties were running out of time to reach an agreement and submit it for ratification before the end of the school year.

title: Veering From the End of Life to the Beginning, With Lucidity and Awe
description: Maybe the best thing to come from ''Sensation'' was the debut of Ron Mueck, a retiring 43-year-old sculptor from Melbourne, Australia, living in London, who stole the show for anybody who bothered to look at the art.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE<BR

title: Europe Central Bank Declines To Support the Falling Euro
description: The euro fell to a six-month low against the dollar yesterday after comments by Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, dashed expectations that the central bank would buy the currency to support it anytime soon.

title: Off Form At Start, Roy Finds Himself
description: For more than a game, Patrick Roy fumbled around for his air of invincibility as if it were loose change on the floor of a movie theater. But by the end of Game 3 tonight, he was snapping a Devils shot out of the air and holding it high in triumph.

title: Death and All the Stuff That Comes Before and After
description: In the first three minutes of ''Six Feet Under,'' HBO's new series about a family of undertakers, the father drives a hearse to the Los Angeles airport to pick up his grown son on Christmas Eve. A voice sings ''I'll be home for Christmas, if only in my dreams,'' and the lyrics have never been meant so literally: Dad is hit broadside by a bus.

title: Women, Out of Your Cars
description: Afghanistan's Taliban authorities have banned all foreign women from driving, saying such conduct is ''against Afghan traditions'' and has a ''negative impact'' on society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JESSICA
description: WASSERMAN - Jessica. Eight years old. Beloved darling daughter of Nancy and Mark. Sister to Melissa and Andrew. Treasured, loving granddaughter of Connie and Allen J. Goldstein. Only God knows why.

title: Big U.S. Fine For Mexican In Bank Case
description: Carlos Hank Rhon, one of the richest and most politically connected businessmen in Mexico, will pay a $40 million fine to settle charges that he violated banking laws when he bought Laredo National Bancshares in Texas, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: TEXAS SET TO SHIFT IN WAKE OF FUROR ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Texas, which leads the nation in executions and endured withering criticism of its death penalty system during the presidential campaign last year, is poised to make significant changes in its criminal justice laws and so, supporters of the overhaul say, create a fairer system of capital punishment.

title: Immigrants at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Babylon: Church Can Use Public Building
description: A federal appeals court, in a case involving the constitutional separation of church and state, has ruled that a church group on Long Island should be allowed to use a public building for its religious services. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in a decision announced Wednesday, said that barring the church, Romans Chapter Ten Ministries, from Babylon Town Hall was discriminatory. The church, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union, argued that nonreligious groups like the Boy Scouts could use the hall and that only the church was singled out. A town spokesman said Babylon might appeal. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From the benefits of getting new tires to negotiating for the best lease deals, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Africa: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: South African Breweries P.L.C. said fiscal second-half profit fell 18 percent as sales gains in the Czech Republic and Poland failed to offset shrinking demand in South Africa, its biggest market. The brewer said profit, excluding one-time gains, fell to $247 million, or 28.2 cents a share, in the six months that ended March 31.

title: Four Relatives and a Funeral
description: In the last year of her life, my mother had accumulated bladder cancer, emphysema, osteoporosis, macular degeneration, heart problems and an apartment in North Miami Beach. But there was nothing wrong with her hearing.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST</b

title: The Missile Shield, And a Grim Specter
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Unlikely Allies Come Together in Fight Against Muslims
description: A Web site run by militant Hindus in Queens and Long Island was recently shut down by its service provider because of complaints that it advocated hatred and violence toward Muslims. But a few days later, the site was back on the Internet. The unlikely rescuers were some radical Jews in Brooklyn who are under investigation for possible ties to anti-Arab terrorist organizations in Israel.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Seeking A Flight To Mexico
description: To capitalize on a surge of the state's Hispanic population, Mayor Ross C. Anderson of Salt Lake City is planning to travel to Mexico City next week to meet with officials from AeroMexico to discuss the feasibility of nonstop flights between there and Salt Lake. Currently, commercial airlines serving Salt Lake offer direct international flights only to Canada. The 2000 census showed that Utah's Hispanic population grew by 138 percent. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about liquor-law charges against President Bush's daughters misspelled the given name of the first lady whose former press secretary commented on news coverage of the children of politicians. She is Rosalynn Carter, not Rosalyn.

title: Webb (65) Finishes Early and Gets to Sleep Late
description: Heading into this week's United States Women's Open, much of the attention was focused on the yearlong excellence of Annika Sorenstam.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about energy deregulation in New York described the state's troubled progress in establishing a market-based system for generating and selling electricity.

title: Political Turbulence in Indonesia
description: Less than two years after he took office as Indonesia's first democratically elected leader, President Abdurrahman Wahid could be ousted from power by summer's end. Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous country and Southeast Asia's largest oil producer, is politically and economically unstable. But a legitimate constitutional process is under way that can provide for an orderly transfer of power. Mr. Wahid should refrain from a lawless attempt to retain power that could sabotage Indonesia's experiment in democracy.

title: Economy Remained Weak in May As Employers Continued Job Cuts
description: The economy remained weak in May as American employers continued to cut jobs, though at a slower pace than during the previous two months, the government reported yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This just proves that the whole country is the front line.''

title: Roadway Warns on Profit
description: Shares in Roadway, a leading trucking company, fell 14 percent today after it said that second-quarter profit would miss forecasts because less freight is being shipped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, RUTH
description: WEXLER-Ruth. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi George N. Abrahams, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAILEY, EDWARD B.
description: DAILEY-Edward B. 64, of Naples, FL, and Fairfield, CT, husband of Mary Jo, retired controller of Warnaco, and President of Dailey Associates, died on May 30, 2001. Funeral services on Monday, June 4, 2001, at 11 AM, in St. Pius X Church, Fairfield. Calling hours Sunday, June 3, from 3 to 7 PM, in the Spear Funeral Home, 39 South Benson Rd, Fairfield.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, SALLY
description: GEORGE-Sally. May 31, 1991. Oh, how I miss your joy, vitality, and exhuberant love of life! My best friend for all my life, you are remembered, missed and cherished every single day. Love always, Catherin

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Agreements Reached With Nurses
description: A nurses strike was averted after 12 hospitals in Minneapolis and St. Paul reached tentative contract agreements with thousands of nurses. Agreements involving three of the hospitals have been ratified, while the others face votes today and Sunday. The nurses union was recommending approval of all but two of the agreements. If any of the contracts are rejected, a strike could begin this morning. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Cotton Trade Violation
description: The World Trade Organization found the United States broke free- trade rules by setting a limit on cotton thread imports from Pakistan. The body's dispute-resolution panel recommended that Washington remove the restriction, which limits imports of Pakistan's yarn to just more than 11 million pounds annually. The three-person panel upheld Pakistan's claim that the United States had erred in how it determined the impact of its imports on American producers. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMBONI, CECELIA (NEE MEDVETZ)
description: ZAMBONI-Cecelia (nee Medvetz). Of New Canaan, CT, died on May 12, 2001. Beloved mother of Mary Elizabeth. She will be deeply missed by her dear cousins and by all who knew her. Sweet dreams lovely one.

title: An Upriver Battle for Votes in Peru
description: Alejandro Toledo brought his presidential campaign to the Amazon River the other night and put on a dazzling show.

title: 16 KILLED BY SUICIDE BOMBER OUTSIDE TEL AVIV NIGHTCLUB
description: A powerful explosion outside a crowded beachside club in Tel Aviv killed at least 17 people, including a suicide bomber, and injured scores late Friday night, Israeli officials said.

title: U.N. Names Special AIDS Envoy for Africa
description: The United Nations has named a Canadian diplomat, Stephen Lewis, as a special envoy for AIDS in Africa.

title: For Indians, Casinos Are No Golden Goose
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001060293995057778 -- No Title
description: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

title: Deal Is Sought for Children To Meet Giuliani's Friend
description: A judge sternly told lawyers for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Donna Hanover, his estranged wife, yesterday that if the couple could not agree by June 19 on how and when their two children would meet Judith Nathan, the mayor's friend, she would appoint a ''law guardian'' to give the children a voice in the bitter dispute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBE, NANCY L.
description: GRUBE-Nancy L. Died on May 30, 2001. Devoted employee of Jos E. Seagram & Sons, Inc, for 37 years. Beloved friend and coworker. She will be missed by many people whose lives she has touched. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 3, 2001, from 2-5 PM, with a religious service at 3 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave (at city line), New Hyde Park, NY.

title: U.N. Chief Calls on U.S. Companies to Donate to AIDS Fund
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, appealed to American corporations today to dig into their pockets and give to a planned multibillion-dollar global fund to fight AIDS in Africa and other developing regions.

title: Royal Family of Nepal Is Shot Dead in Palace
description: In a wholesale killing of royalty not seen since the deaths of the last czar of Russia and his family in 1918, the crown prince of Nepal shot the king and queen and several relatives in their palace in Katmandu last night, then killed himself, Nepalese officials said.

title: N.H.L. TV Rating Is Higher
description: The Colorado Avalanche's 3-1 victory over the Devils on Thursday night in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals generated a 3.2 Nielsen rating for ABC, 39 percent higher than the 2.3 rating for the comparable game a year ago between the Dallas Stars and New Jersey. Each rating point equals 1.02 million households.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, DIANA VAUGHAN MARVIN
description: GIBSON-Diana Vaughan Marvin. Died of cancer on May 28, 2001, at Maine Medical Center in Portland, after a brief illness. She was a sixth generation descendant of Benjamin Vaughan, who settled in Hallowell in 1797, and whose father, Samuel, married Sarah Hallowell, daughter of Benjamin Hallowell, one of the original Kennebec Proprietors. Mrs. Gibson was born on February 27, 1918, in New York City, the daughter of Langdon Parker Marvin and Mary Vaughan Marvin, and grew up in New York, with summers spent at her mother's family's house in Hallowell, and Northeast Harbor, ME. She attended The Chapin School in New York and graduated in 1936 from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson, MD, and from Bennington College in Bennington, VT, in 1942. Musically talented, Mrs. Gibson played the bassoon with the National Orchestral Association and taught music in New York, among a variety of part-time jobs. In 1943 she joined the American Red Cross, and for the next two and a half years, during WWII, she and two other Red Cross volunteers drove a 10-wheel Clubmobile truck in England, throughout France, Luxembourg and Germany, and into Czechoslovakia. After the war, Mrs. Gibson returned to New York and pursued her life-long interests in music and in art, working at the Museum of Modern Art for several years. On November 15, 1947, she married George W. Gibson of Chestnut Hill, MA. Mrs. Gibson was a long-time member of the English Speaking Union, which her father had helped found, a Director of Scholarships, Inc., which provides special educational opportunities, and a Director of the Maternity Center, a philanthropic organization. When Mr. Gibson retired, they became residents in Hallowell, ME. Mrs. Gibson took on a variety of local civic and organizational responsibilities. For several years she was on the planning board of Hallowell, and at the time of her death she was a member of the Hallowell Tree Board and of the Board of Friends of the Maine State Museum in Augusta. She inherited her mother's love of horticulture, and was a long-standing member of the Kennebec Valley Garden Club. She was also a founding life member of, and advisor to, the Kennebec Land Trust. In 1990, she donated to the Trust a conservation easement on the Vaughan Woods that protects the property in perpetuity and opened its trails for public use. Mrs. Gibson was an enthusiastic supporter of the Pine Tree State Arboretum in Augusta, ME, and was a Friend of the Hubbard Free Library in Hallowell. She was an ardent advocate for the Hallowell Historic District, and for her efforts in the community she was named Hallowell citizen of the year in 1992. Mrs. Gibson is survived by her beloved husband George W. Gibson, who lives in Hallowell, and her three children, George L. Gibson and his wife, Linda Johns of New York City, Ellen V. Gibson of Roslindale, MA, and David H. Gibson and Susan Gibson of Ballston Lake, NY. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 2nd, 2 PM, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Union St, Hallowell. For information, Knowlton and Hewins Funeral Home, One Church St, Augusta ME.

title: Sports of The Times; The Evolving Mystery Of El Duque
description: TWO hours before last night's series opener against Cleveland, Yankees Manager Joe Torre sat in the home dugout telling the assembled news media the latest tale of the mystery of Orlando Hernndez. A soft rain fell on Yankee Stadium. The rain would eventually stop, return and shorten the game, a 7-4 loss to Cleveland, to five and a half innings. This was the perfect setting to unveil the latest chapter in the mystery of El Duque.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMURRAY, JOSEPH P.
description: McMURRAY-Joseph P. On May 31, 2001, of East Atlantic Beach, NY. Past president of Queens College, Queensboro Community College, College of New Rochelle. Beloved husband of the late Isabelle, mother of his children, and Rose Marie. Dear father of Gerald R., Joseph P. Jr., Kathleen M. Nelson, Isabelle Pullis, Kevin F., Brien A., stepson Walter G. Barker, stepdaughter Diane Crehan and the late Robert Barker. Cherished grandfather of 25 and great-grandfather of five. Reposing Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:45 AM, St. Francis de Sales R.C. Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment St. Mary Star of the Sea Cemetery, Lawrence, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends may make contributions to Queens College Foundation, Inc, in memory of Joseph P. McMurray.

title: Religion Journal; A Rabbi's Look at Archaeology Touches a Nerve
description: For 400 years, the sermon has been an American art form, a spoken message for a mass audience, with references to a religious text. Some had such impact they entered literary history, as witness recent books of famous sermons by preachers from Cotton Mather to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIAL, MARGUERITE R.
description: PRIAL-Marguerite R. At Greenwich, CT, on May 31, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Frank J. Prial II. Devoted mother of Marguerite Petrie, Patricia Gillooly, Pamela James, Helen Snyder and Frank, Edward, Gerard, James, Michael and Joseph Prial. Dear sister of Virginia Gladwell, Sr. Mary Borgia, George J. Robinson and the late Patricia Priday. Also survived by 18 grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial 11 AM, Monday, June 4, at St. Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North St, Greenwich, CT. Interment Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich. Family will receive friends Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Why American Pop Culture Spreads
description: Some years ago, in the Negev Desert, Bedouin tents were equipped with small antennas. They were attached to battery-operated televisions, many of which were tuned to the American prime-time soap opera ''Dallas.'' It was unclear at first just what nomadic desert dwellers could have made over the backroom battles of J. R. or the plantation sweetness of Miss Ellie, even if the open plains of Texas could at times seem as arid as the surrounding desert.

title: California Eight Set to Defend Title
description: The University of California men's heavyweight varsity eight won its semifinal convincingly yesterday at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships in Pennsauken, N.J., moving the Golden Bears one victory away from repeating as national champions.

title: Savings for New Cruise Customers
description: There's a first time for everything, particularly when a cruise line is offering a $500 credit for new customers. To be eligible, you must book a Silversea cruise by July 27, with departures between October 2001 and June 2002. Itineraries range from 7 to 32 days, and bookings must be made through a travel agent. These savings can be combined with a 15 percent discount for paying in full at least six months before departure; guests who book and send in a deposit three months in advance save 5 percent; do it four months ahead, and save 10 percent. Silversea Cruises has a fleet of four ships and specializes in luxury-class travel. For information, contact (800) 774-9996 or www.silversea.com .

title: TV Networks Say They'll Retain An Embattled Polling Service
description: The major television news organizations have decided to retain their associations with Voter News Service, the polling consortium that they blamed for supplying bad information on election night last year.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Argentina Won't Get Pinochet
description: A Supreme Court judge rejected Argentina's plea to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet for questioning in the 1974 killing of a former Chilean army chief, Carlos Prats, and his wife in Buenos Aires. Investigators say the former dictator and six intelligence aides ordered the assassinations. General Prats opposed the coup that brought General Pinochet to power in 1973. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Article 2001060291886696479 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Article 2001060291933908714 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the discovery of fossil bones from a new dinosaur species misspelled the surname of a paleontologist on the research team. He is Dr. Peter Dodson, not Dobson.

title: Heroes, Unarmed And Unsung
description: WE are hip-deep in books and movies about the glories of serving the country, with the emphasis decidedly on the Muhammad Ali of generations, the one now known as ''the greatest.'' We have been reliving epic moments like D-Day, the flag-raising on Iwo Jima and Japan's foolish decision to declare war on Ben Affleck.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Nuclear Weapons Pact Fulfilled
description: More than 13 years after they began, Russia and the United States have destroyed the last of 2,692 nuclear missiles marked for elimination under the 1987 Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, the Foreign Ministry said. Besides silos and other equipment, Russia destroyed 1,846 missiles, and the United States 846, all with ranges between 300 and 3,000 miles. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Poverty Yardstick
description: To the Editor:

title: A MAJORITY OF ONE
description: If Chief Justice William Rehnquist resigned, Sandra Day O'Connor might be next to lead the Supreme Court. In many ways, she already does. A report by Jeffrey Rosen in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOERST, BARBARA M.
description: FOERST-Barbara M. On June 1, 2001. Loving sister of John and his wife Marion, and Catherine Linnehan. Devoted aunt of Moira and Donald Linnehan, Gerard Foerst and Kathryn Bill. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Sunday, June 3, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, June 4, 10:45 AM, at The Church of St. Thomas More, East 89th St, between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: Another Stalled Budget
description: That New York State's budget is late for the 17th year in a row is no surprise. What is cause for concern is that because of the legislative impasse over Democratic demands for more spending, Gov. George Pataki has threatened to do without a budget for the new year altogether, relying instead on an indefinite series of emergency spending measures. The effect would be to keep state spending near the level of about $80 billion for the year that ended March 31. The governor suggests that by stalling approval of a new state budget, he would actually be saving the state money by holding expenses close to previous levels.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Faith-Based Agencies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, RABBI DR. LEON
description: KATZ-Rabbi Dr. Leon. On behalf of the Bienstock family and Short Hills Caterers, we extend our deepest condolences to the Rebbitzin Rhea Katz and the entire family of Rabbi Dr. Leon Katz zt''l, who was our beloved Rav HaMachshir and dear friend for 35 years. Ben Bienstock and the Entire Staff of the Short Hills Caterers

title: Commencements; College Honors Man It Tried To Discredit
description: Fifty years ago, at the height of the McCarthy era, Brooklyn College permanently shut down Vanguard, a student newspaper, and branded the paper's 19-year-old editor ''a bad campus citizen.''

title: Restaurateur Haunted by Reports of Sick Customers
description: Ayhan Hassan, from Cyprus, stepped off an oil tanker in Los Angeles in 1972 with $1.50 in his pocket, worked his way across America washing dishes and busing tables and eventually saved enough money to open a restaurant in this hilly harbor town that reminded him of home.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Lawmaker Refuses To Recite Pledge
description: State Representative Henri E. Brooks's refusal to recite the pledge of allegiance has caused a stir in the House. Ms. Brooks, a black Democrat who represents part of Memphis, said the pledge symbolizes the colonies that enslaved her ancestors. Speaker Jimmy Naifeh asked Ms. Brooks to stand outside the chamber during the pledge if she was not going to recite it. The request drew sharp words from Ms. Brooks. ''It reminded me of the plantation when the master comes and scolds an individual,'' she said. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: One For The Road
description: Workers at a Guinness packaging plant in Dundalk voted by a majority of 65 percent to accept severance packages that include payments of up to $150,000; health benefits; and 10 years' worth of free beer. Eligible employees will receive about 14 bottles of beer a week and more on two holidays a year. In April, the workers went on strike to protest the closing of the site, which Guinness insists is no longer economically viable. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: How to Close the Achievement Gap
description: George W. Bush campaigned for the presidency criticizing ''the soft bigotry of low expectations,'' the dangerous mindset that allows black and Latino children to fall permanently behind white children who sit next to them in school. Closing this achievement gap should be a top national priority, not least because minorities make up more than a third of the public school population. But the education bills moving through Congress contain flaws that will make this goal difficult to achieve.

title: The Missile Shield, And a Grim Specter
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Falls Slightly As Economy Remains Weak

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about energy deregulation in New York described the state's troubled progress in establishing a market-based system for generating and selling electricity.

title: Giants Waive Troubled Parker
description: The Giants yesterday waived Jeremiah Parker, the little-used defensive end who is accused of aggravated manslaughter in the death of the 4-year-old son of the woman he had been living with.

title: Devils Seek to Regain Their Hunger and Appetite for Winning
description: On Thursday, after the Devils lost Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals at home to the Colorado Avalanche, 3-1, Coach Larry Robinson questioned his players' effort and challenged them to reclaim their identity.

title: Maine and the Lobster Catch
description: The Lobster Institute at the University of Maine at Orono maintains a Web site called the Lobster Cam, which shows the actual interior of a working lobster trap 60 feet off the coast of Maine. This is as close as most of us will ever come to fishing for Maine lobsters. The lobster fishery in that state is essentially becoming a closed resource. In some of its zones, the number of new fishing entrants is strictly limited. That sounds stringent, but it is one thing that has helped cause the lobster catch -- and thus, presumably, the number of lobsters -- to rise to unheard-of levels in Maine, even as fishing for other species has fallen on very hard times.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty To Securities Fraud
description: An imprisoned stockbroker who was convicted in December of plotting with a cellmate to kill a judge pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of enterprise corruption, the original matter that had landed him in jail.

title: At 32, Acquainted With Politics and High Expectations
description: THE newly minted mayor of San Antonio, fresh off a surprisingly large election victory and rushing between meetings, has paused to reminisce about a losing race in which he first earned his chops. It was 1978, and Ed Garza was young and new to politics. The voters rejected him. He thinks he might have chosen the wrong political party.

title: Seeking to Bolster His Power, Indonesia Chief Shifts Cabinet
description: Maneuvering to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid dismissed four cabinet ministers today, including the security minister, as well as the national police chief, who had opposed Mr. Wahid's threats to declare a state of emergency.

title: For Indians, Casinos Are No Golden Goose
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Is Accused of Discrimination
description: Northwest Airlines was sued by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission over accusations that the company discriminated against a job applicant with impaired vision.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Azinger Has What Singh And Woods Are Chasing
description: After two rounds at the Memorial Tournament, three former champions are at or near the top of the leader board, each with a different reason for feeling inspired heading into the weekend.

title: A Tenor Who Paints His Face and Sings Alto
description: There is a lot that's hard to forget about Antony and the Johnsons. First, there are the performance artists who usually appear with the band, one of whom is a Japanese albino hermaphodite. Then there is the shaven-headed Antony himself, a longtime veteran of the Manhattan drag-queen club performance circuit, who often appears in white face paint and women's clothing and has an unsettling stage presence in which it seems as if he doesn't know what to do with his hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, GERALDINE
description: LONDON-Geraldine. A lifelong resident of New York City, died on Monday, May 28, 2001, in Mission Viejo, California, after a lengthy battle with cancer. Ms. London was born in Manhattan on December 28, 1909, and spent almost fifty years serving the New York City government in several capacities. Following her graduation from New York University, Ms. London embarked upon a career as a case worker in the New York City Department of Welfare. Based upon her exemplary record, Ms. London transferred to the Department of Probation as a probation officer and eventually, Court Liaison Officer. Following her retirement in 1976, and continuing until the diagnosis of her illness in 1999, Ms. London served as an elementary school teacher at numerous New York City public schools, including P.S. 132, where she made many strong friendships among the teaching and administration staff. Ms. London was predeceased by two beloved brothers, Barnard London and Lewis London, both of Westchester County. She is survived by her nieces and nephews: George and Rebecca Donnini of Mission Viejo, California; Lynn Donnini of New Rochelle, New York; Melody and Erin London of New York City; and Robert, Janet, Matthew and Danny London of Ithaca, New York. Ms. London will be dearly missed by all who had the pleasure to know her. Services will be held Sunday 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave.

title: DOUBLECLICK AGREES TO BUY AN E-MAIL DIRECT MARKETER
description: DoubleClick Inc., a leading Internet advertising company, agreed to buy an e-mail direct marketer, MessageMedia Inc., for $41 million in stock, to more than double its customer base. DoubleClick, which is based in New York, said it would pay 0.0436 share for each share of MessageMedia, which values MessageMedia at about 57 cents a share, or 33 percent more than Thursday's closing price of 43 cents. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the third quarter, will give DoubleClick more than 550 clients and increase the number of delivered e-mail messages by 100 million, to 700 million a month, said Court Cunningham, vice president and general manager for DoubleClick's DARTmail.

title: Li Kwoh-ting, 91, of Taiwan Dies; Led Effort to Transform Economy
description: Li Kwoh-ting, a driving force behind Taiwan's transformation into an economic power, died on Thursday. He was 91.

title: Military's Discharges of Gays Increased 17 Percent in 2000
description: The number of gays discharged from the military rose by 17 percent in 2000 and was the highest total since the Clinton administration's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy began in 1994.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Marijuana Now Available
description: A law passed as a ballot initiative last November that allows certain patients to seek permission from the state to use small amounts of marijuana to relieve their discomfort has taken effect. Ken Salazar, the state attorney general who opposed the measure, said doctors who recommend marijuana for their patients still risked prosecution by the federal government because of a recent Supreme Court ruling that made marijuana clubs in California illegal. But proponents of the new law said the warning was a scare tactic to discourage doctors from helping their patients. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Bush's Mideast Envoy Confronts Limits of Shuttle Diplomacy
description: After more than a week of shuttle diplomacy by the United States' new emissary for the Middle East, the Bush administration is increasingly pessimistic about being able to bring a halt to the Israeli-Palestinian violence any time soon.

title: Arlene Francis, 93, Mainstay Of 'What's My Line?' on TV
description: Arlene Francis, the actress and jaunty, good-natured television personality who was a fixture on ''What's My Line?'' for 25 years, died on Thursday at a hospital in San Francisco. She was 93.

title: Politicians Bid Farewell To Moakley At Funeral
description: With all its Irish-American heart, humor, pathos and pride showing, and with such national dignitaries as President Bush, former President Bill Clinton and former Vice President Al Gore looking on, Boston laid on a mighty funeral today for one of its favorite sons, Representative John Joseph Moakley.

title: Democrats' New Map of Indiana Divides G.O.P.
description: Representatives Steve Buyer and Brian Kerns should be allies. They are both lifelong Hoosiers. They are both staunchly conservative Republicans. They represent adjacent Congressional districts in central Indiana. They are of the same generation; Mr. Buyer is 42 and Mr. Kerns is 44.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Leaving Small Businesses Behind
description: Calvin Coolidge said, ''The business of America is business.'' George W. Bush, the first president to have an M.B.A. degree, has issued a correction. If his first budget is any indication, the business of America today is big business. Small companies and individual entrepreneurs, it seems, are somebody else's business.

title: Old Traditions Meet New Growth; Corning Is Split Over a Company-Backed School Plan
description: People here have seen their future and a lot of them don't like it one bit.

title: Plant Installed To Avert Crunch Is Turned On
description: The New York Power Authority last night fired up the first of seven mini-power plants it is installing around New York City, a victory for the Pataki administration in its efforts to stave off an energy crisis this summer.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, ARLENE
description: FRANCIS-Arlene. The Board of Directors of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., mourns the death of our most valued friend and supporter Arlene Francis. For over 30 years she graced us with her presence as co-host of the UCP Telethon and through many other volunteer efforts. Thousands of people with disabilities are leading better lives due to her efforts. We remember her fondly and extend our sympathies to her family. Leo Hausman, Chairman

title: Candidate For Green's Post
description: State Assemblyman Scott Stringer, a Democrat who represents the Upper West Side, formally announced his candidacy for public advocate yesterday, saying that he looked ''forward to working within a new city government to ensure continued growth and to inspire a new generation of ideas.''

title: A Funeral in Jerusalem Arouses Palestinian Nationalism
description: Tens of thousands of Palestinians waving Palestinian flags marched through East Jerusalem today as the Israeli police stood back and watched the most fervent, open display of Palestinian nationalism in the heart of this city in more than three decades.

title: Star Wars: Is Astrology Sociology?
description: Elizabeth Teissier is well known in France as the weekly horoscope columnist for a popular television guide, the author of a half-dozen books on astrology, and the astrologer to the French president Franois Mitterrand.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hiroshima Compensation For Korean
description: A court in Osaka ordered the local government to pay a Korean survivor of the 1945 atomic bombing in Hiroshima compensation for medical care that the prefecture terminated after he left Japan to return home to Seoul. The court ruled that Kwak Kwi Hoon, 76, who was in the Imperial Japanese Army at the time, should receive about $17,000. The Japanese government said previously that the estimated 5,000 survivors of the bombing who live overseas were not eligible for benefits under laws for atomic bomb victims. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Utility Merger
description: The European Commission decided that a secondary investigation is needed in Electricit de France's attempt to buy a Spanish electricity company, Hidroelctrica del Cantbrico S.A. The competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said the first phase of the investigation determined that the proposed acquisition ''poses serious concerns that justify today's decision to start a full investigation.'' Electricit de France, which made the offer for Cantbrico through a partly owned subsidiary, Energie Baden-Wrttemberg, is the largest electricity producer in Europe and the commission is concerned about its dominance in the industry. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Workers Strike Distribution Hub That Supplies Dunkin' Donuts
description: About 150 workers at a Dunkin' Donuts distribution center in South Jersey were on strike yesterday after walking off the job Thursday night. The center stores and delivers supplies to 1,400 doughnut shops in eight Eastern states.

title: Barbara Estill Civic Leader, 93, Is Dead
description: Barbara Banning Tweed Estill, a New York civic leader, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Shares Fall
description: Royal KPN N.V. shares fell 19 percent after a report that the company, the biggest phone company in the Netherlands, plans to sell stock to shareholders to raise cash and reduce its debt. The shares fell 2.04 euros, to 8.99 euros, a four-year low, after the report, which appeared in The Financial Times.

title: Union Feuds Are Hurting Chances of Law on Wages
description: An awkward division within New York City's labor movement is hurting a campaign by several unions to secure a law that would raise wages for more than 75,000 workers employed by companies that get tax breaks or contracts from the city.

title: Layoffs at Weyerhaeuser
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, which settled a strike Thursday with workers protesting the use of nonunion labor, laid off 235 of them today at plants in Washington and Oregon because of slowing demand for paper and boxes.

title: Pipeline Fees In California Are Discussed
description: The El Paso Corporation's pipeline system might have delivered more gas to California in the last year if it had charged less for capacity on the line, a company executive said at a public hearing today.

title: Article 2001060290397854890 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: A Complex, and Friendly, Protection Racket Unravels
description: What with the bomb plot and the scrawled threats, the elegant mystery lady and the sober-suited gentlemen ringing his bell in the dead of night, Harry Rimmer still cannot quite believe the vastness of the conspiracy his friend and tenant, Akbar Shareef, constructed against him.

title: Top Editor Is Said to Depart U.S. News & World Report
description: Stephen G. Smith, the editor of U.S. News & World Report, will leave the magazine and be replaced by Brian P. Duffy, the executive editor, people at the magazine said last night.

title: Vivendi Will Acquire Houghton Mifflin for $1.7 Billion
description: Expanding its presence in the United States educational publishing market, Vivendi Universal of France announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Houghton Mifflin Company for about $1.7 billion in cash.

title: Bloomberg Ads To Announce Mayoral Bid
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican billionaire, plans to announce his candidacy for mayor on Tuesday in a television commercial in which he introduces himself to voters and says the city cannot go back to the way it once was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ABEL
description: FISCHER-Abel. On June 1st, 2001. Beloved husband of Francine. Loving father of Judy, Rick and his wife, Leslie. Dear brother of John. Adoring grandfather of Cameron and Sydney. Memorial service Sunday, 2:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Jackson Sets Steeplechase Record
description: Elizabeth Jackson of Brigham Young, a former professional ballet candidate, set an American record today in winning the first women's 3,000-meter steeplechase held at the N.C.A.A. track and field championships in Eugene, Ore.

title: Article 2001060290416421885 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: The Irish Poet's Foray Into Janacek
description: Few depictions of lovemaking on a New York stage have been more sensual than the brief, impassioned encounter between two fully-clothed concert singers underneath a dimly lighted grand piano that is the climactic scene of the director Deborah Warner's intriguing production of Janacek's ''Diary of One Who Vanished'' at the John Jay College Theater. Janacek's 40-minute song cycle from 1916 cries out for the kind of spare and simple operatic staging that Ms. Warner has given it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DR. THEODORE
description: FELDMAN-Dr. Theodore. Patient, loving, understanding, adored husband of Judy Feldman. Deeply beloved father of Carol (Michael) Hagstedt and David (Barbra) Feldman. ''Cherished'' grandfather of Elizabeth and Tracey Hagstedt and Samantha Feldman. Loving brother of Seth Feldman. Passed away on May 30, 2001. Dr. Feldman was Chief of Orthopaedic Surgery in Peninsula Hospital Center, Rockaway Beach, NY, and retired to North Palm Beach, Florida., in 1993. We will miss you, Teddy, with all our hearts. Services were held Friday at Menorah Gardens & Funeral Chapel, West Palm Beach, Fl.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hard-Line Punishment Texans Don't Support
description: It is not exactly a state secret that Texas is tough on crime. We have one of the busiest death chambers on earth and some of the toughest criminal laws in the nation. But being tough doesn't mean you have to be bloodthirsty. By passing legislation to ban the execution of the mentally retarded, the Texas Legislature proved that there can be compassionate justice.

title: Aching Toe Lands Hernndez on Disabled List
description: Orlando Hernndez trudged into the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday, turned left to drop something in his locker, then turned right and walked into Manager Joe Torre's office. The door closed behind Hernndez, and the news that he revealed to the Yankees was unsettling.

title: China Prepares Big Exercise Near Island Facing Taiwan
description: The Chinese military is mounting one of its largest war drills in years this month around an island facing Taiwan, according to news accounts in China and Hong Kong.

title: Bridgestone Split From Ford Is Seen as Most Un-Japanese
description: When the Bridgestone Corporation's Bridgestone/Firestone unit announced on May 21 that it would break off a longstanding supplier relationship with the Ford Motor Company, one widespread reaction was surprise that the company would do something so un-Japanese. The company's actions since then suggest that to some extent, that was the point -- and that it is getting across.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Rehnquist's Daughter Nominated
description: President Bush nominated Janet Rehnquist, daughter of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, to be inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services. She is currently an assistant United States attorney in Virginia and was associate White House counsel under President Bush's father. Eugene Scalia, son of Justice Antonin Scalia, was previously nominated to be solicitor of labor. Mr. Bush announced his intention to nominate 20 people to cabinet and subcabinet positions this week. Before it recessed, the Senate confirmed eight people.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Taliban Raid Red Cross Hospital
description: The ruling Taliban's religious police raided a hospital in Kandahar run by the International Committee of the Red Cross, arresting some of the Afghan workers, Agence France-Presse reported. Last month they raided an Italian-run hospital, charging that men and women were working together in a breach of the Taliban's interpretation of Islamic law. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILDE, DAVID M.
description: WILDE-David M. On May 22, 2001, in Scarsdale, NY. Graduate of Yale 1940. Beloved widower of Joan Bennett, loving father of Amanda D. Wilde and Jennifer W. Lovejoy. He will be sorely missed.

title: City Campaign Finance Program Lures Big Number of Candidates
description: The municipal elections in New York City this year have attracted a record number of candidates to the campaign finance program, with 324 enrolled as of the deadline yesterday, although that total will most likely jump even more once applications in the mail are counted.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHUBB CORP., Warren, N.J., a holding company that offers insurance, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to an additional 16 million shares of its stock. The new authorization, to expire June 30, 2003, covers 9.1 percent of the 175.2 million shares outstanding as of April 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, ROSLYN
description: DORFMAN-Roslyn. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Roslyn Dorfman, beloved wife of Sidney, an ADL Associate National Commissioner. Roslyn and Sid were staunch supporters of ADL. We extend our deepest condolences to Sid, their children, and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Avalanche's Defense Bumps Devils Aside
description: Adam Foote symbolizes the other side of the Colorado Avalanche. He showed up for a news conference today at the team's hotel with a knot the size of a golf ball on his forehead, a greenish-purple right ear and a lingering injury to an undisclosed part of his body. Foote, a fierce defenseman, knows the Devils would hammer the injury if they knew where it was.

title: Today's Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: South Africa's Small Warrior Against AIDS Dies Quietly
description: Nkosi Johnson, a frail 12-year-old with AIDS who had become the darling of an infected nation and a living indictment of the government's policies in the face of the epidemic, slipped away quietly this morning after five months on the brink of death.

title: High Rates for Argentine Bonds
description: Argentina is offering to pay interest rates approaching 16 percent to persuade investors to swap an expected $20 billion in government debt for new bonds.

title: Roddick Gives His All Against Hewitt, but Cannot Play On
description: The most likely to succeed of all the young Americans was scrambling deep behind the baseline of Center Court today when his foot slipped, his body lurched forward and his 6-foot-1 frame rolled like dice into a tarp.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FINE PRINT: The Penney Paragraph; Tax Bill Kills Obscure Rule That Aided One Company
description: Buried deep in the mammoth tax bill Congress approved last week is this sentence: ''Paragraph (4) of section 1114(c) of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is hereby repealed.''

title: Hank Ketcham, Father of Dennis the Menace, Dies at 81
description: Hank Ketcham, who fathered the cartoon character Dennis the Menace, the freckle-face scamp in droopy overalls whose mischievous childhood has endured for 50 years and amused a worldwide audience, died yesterday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 81.

title: Auto Sales Off A Mere 1.2% Last Month
description: The enduring strength of the auto market has surprised economists every month this year and did so again today, as auto sales fell only 1.2 percent from May of last year, while General Motors unexpectedly posted a small increase in sales.

title: Cheney to Step Up Action As Fund-Raiser for G.O.P.
description: Vice President Dick Cheney is stepping up his fund-raising activities for Republicans and will spend two days next week in Florida and Virginia, helping bring in more than $2 million for the party.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Pop Guide in Weekend yesterday included an outdated schedule for the Revolution Is Hip-Hop Tour. Its performance at the Olympic Theater, 851 Prospect Avenue, at Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, has been changed to June 14 at 8 p.m. The performances tonight and tomorrow night have been canceled. Information: (718) 378-1200.

title: Policyholders Push for Owners' Rights as More Insurers Go Public
description: With many mutual insurance companies restructuring so that they can issue stock, a debate over the ownership rights of policyholders has escalated, with billions of dollars at stake.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: The Emperor's New Evidence
description: Officially, Napoleon Bonaparte died of stomach cancer at the age of 51.
