But two French scientists say they have new evidence that the French emperor died of arsenic poisoning while in exile on the island of St. Helena. The scientists said strands of hair showed levels of arsenic about 35 times higher than normal. The only real question, they said, was whether the hair samples tested -- passed down through generations -- are really Napoleon's. The tests were paid for by Ben Weider, a Canadian Napoleon enthusiast who is a proponent of the arsenic theory.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANARICK, ALAINE
description: CANARICK-Alaine. Our lives have been forever touched by her friendship. She was a very special person and will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to all of the family. Rochelle, Jeff, Marc, Lianne and Jay Canarick

title: At Baruch, Levy Urges Heeding to Altruism
description: Harold O. Levy, a corporate lawyer who left a lucrative job at Citigroup last year to lead the New York City school system as chancellor, told graduates at Baruch College yesterday that financial success was hollow unless it was used ''to heed the call of social responsibility.''

title: INSIDE
description: Africa's AIDS Child Dies

title: Fifth Inning Dooms Lilly and Yankees in a Shortened Game
description: Ted Lilly was in the outfield during batting practice at Yankee Stadium yesterday when Joe Torre asked Mel Stottlemyre to give Lilly the surprising news. Stottlemyre told Lilly, a rookie left-hander, that the Yankees needed him to replace the injured Orlando Hernndez and start against the Cleveland Indians in about two hours. There was little time to prepare, little time to get nervous.

title: Strike by Flight Attendants Halts Business at Aeromxico
description: A strike by flight attendants at Aeromxico, the nation's largest airline, stranded thousands of passengers today. No sign of a quick settlement was in sight.

title: Ford May Reshuffle Management in Wake of Tire Problems
description: Struggling to regain control of tire problems in Ford Explorers that have tarnished the image of the Ford Motor Company, the company plans to announce a reshuffling of senior management, possibly as soon as next week, people close to Ford Motor's leaders said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEGANT, BELLE
description: ELEGANT-Belle. On June 1, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Harry Elegant. Last surviving child of David and Minnie Goldfarb. Survived by loving nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, June 3, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Article 2001060290493525854 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Bylaws
description: Shareholders of the Credit Suisse Group rebuffed an effort to change its bylaws to require the independence of the bank's supervisory board. The head of the Swiss pension management group, Ethos, urged a change on grounds that overlapping board directorships posed conflicts of interest. At issue was Lukas Mhlemann, who is chairman and chief executive of Credit Suisse, and serves on the board of the financially troubled Swissair. He has pledged the bank's help in a bailout, an investment that Ethos questions. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Combs Protg Is Sentenced To 10 Years in Shooting
description: A young rap performer who was a protg of Sean Combs recited the 23rd Psalm in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday, and was then sentenced to 10 years in prison for a nightclub shooting in 1999 that injured three people.

title: Allen's Game Speaks Up, Keeping the Bucks Alive
description: He entered the game harboring conspiracy theories, proclaiming boldly that the N.B.A. wanted the Philadelphia 76ers and their roster of award winners to play in the finals against the Los Angeles Lakers. He talked of poor officiating, favorable television ratings and the league's dream matchup of Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant versus Dikembe Mutombo and Allen Iverson.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits on Thursday with the State of the Art column, about lightweight laptop computers, misidentified the machine at the left. It was the WinBook X1, not the Fujitsu LifeBook S-4546.

title: The Missile Shield, and a Grim Specter
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001060292603352047 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Deaths  TORTORA, LEONARD
description: TORTORA-Leonard. At sunrise, May 31, 2001. (Retired NYC Department of Housing). Survived by his brother Richard; his son Leonard Jr; and seven grandchildren. Also survived by an extended family of loving friends. Beloved father of the late Karen. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mount Carmel R.C. Church, on Monday, at 10:15 AM. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-10 PM.

title: Saying Courts Fail the Poor, Lawyers' Group Sues the State
description: In documents filed in a lawsuit against the state, a lawyers' group has drawn a detailed portrait of a court system in which each week hundreds of poor people in New York City go to court without the legal representation to which they are entitled.

title: Women Profit Less Than Men in the Nonprofit World, Too
description: The gender gap is not just a feature of business, law and medicine. In the nonprofit sector, too, women earn significantly less than their male counterparts, according to a new study based on the fiscal 1998 and 1999 tax forms of 75,000 public charities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD
description: MENDIK-Bernard. The Advisory Board, Faculty and Students of the Real Estate Institute of New York University mourn the passing of Bernard Mendik, and extend condolences to the Mendik Family. Bernie was a friend, advisor and teacher of the Real Estate Insititute and we will miss his support and wisdom. D. Kenneth Patton, Assoc Dean

title: Article 2001060293188308894 -- No Title
description: Cyber Law Journal: Controversial Ruling on Library Filters

title: Fighting Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: One of Young Idaho Siblings Makes His Way to Custody
description: After wandering through the woods to a neighbor's house, 15-year-old Benjamin McGuckin was in protective custody today, leaving his two younger brothers and three of his sisters barricaded back inside the family home.

title: National Briefing | South: Governors Discuss Pollution Reduction
description: Four Southeastern governors, meeting with environmentalists, agreed to work together to curb pollution in the Great Smoky Mountains. The meeting, in Gatlinburg, Tenn., brought together the governors of Georgia, Kentucky, North Carolina and Tennessee. Under the agreement, the states' top environmental officers are to make recommendations on reducing smog by March 15, 2002. The Smoky Mountains contain the country's most visited national park as well as one of the most polluted. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Iraq Plan Is Put Off
description: The Security Council voted unanimously to put off for 30 days a vote on an American and British plan to lift restrictions on the sale of most civilian goods to Iraq while tightening controls on arms purchases and oil smuggling. Iraq, which opposes continued supervision of oil sales and wants sanctions lifted without admitting arms inspectors, threatened again to cut off oil sales.

title: Well, if You Don't Want the $600 . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Family Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Rallies in Dow and Nasdaq Erase Some Losses for Week
description: After a cautious reading of reports on employment and manufacturing that offered conflicting messages about the strength of the American economy, investors embraced battered technology stocks yesterday and touched off a modest rally.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Former Soviet Republics Meet
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia opened a meeting in Minsk of the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose assembly of Russia and other former Soviet republics, with an agenda that included peacemaking in Azerbaijan and Central Asia, lowering trade barriers and meeting privately with Ukraine's scandal-tarred president, Leonid D. Kuchma. Mr. Putin is also expected to hold talks with the presidents of Azerbaijan and Armenia over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of Azerbaijan that has been taken over by Armenia. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Masur Shows He Can Swing if He Has To
description: The New York Philharmonic's subscription season comes to an end next Saturday, but there are still adventures to be had. The program that Kurt Masur conducted on Thursday evening -- and that is repeated tonight and on Tuesday -- began with the United States premiere of a work by Siegfried Matthus, a German composer who has long been a favorite of Mr. Masur, and also included two works that Mr. Masur has conducted in past seasons, the Shostakovich First Symphony and Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue.''

title: Abroad at Home; The Price of Occupation
description: On June 5, 1967, Israel went to war with Egypt. Jordan and Syria joined the fighting. Six days later triumphant Israeli forces controlled the West Bank, East Jerusalem, Gaza, the Sinai and the Golan Heights.

title: Article 2001060293216188557 -- No Title
description: This just proves that the whole country is the frontline.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about college graduates who overcame exceptional hurdles misstated the role of a professor, John Helferty, in the education of a Temple University graduate, Scott Stoffel, who is legally blind and mostly deaf. Professor Helferty taught 7 of Mr. Stoffel's 50 courses, not half. The article also misstated Mr. Stoffel's major. It is electrical and computer engineering, not electrical engineering and computer science.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Clemency Requested For Boy
description: Lawyers for a 14-year-old Florida boy sentenced to life in prison for killing a 6-year-old playmate have filed a request for clemency on his behalf. Jim Lewis, a lawyer for the boy, Lionel Tate, said a petition was sent to Gov. Jeb Bush on Thursday. The next meeting of the state's clemency board is scheduled for June 14. It is unclear whether Lionel's case will be discussed at that meeting. A jury found him guilty of first-degree murder in March in the beating death of Tiffany Eunick. At the time of the murder, Lionel, who said he was imitating wrestling moves, was 12. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Budget Hamstrings Refugee Agency
description: The high commissioner for refugees said a shortage of donations from national governments would force it to end operations in the Balkans and East Timor as part of a cutback in employees and programs. The agency, which assists 22 million refugees and displaced people worldwide, is cutting almost 800 people from a staff of 4,828. Its budget fell to $931 million last year from $1.3 billion in 1995 and is expected to sink to $810 million this year.

title: U.S. May Forgo Death Penalty to Extradite Sniper Suspect
description: Justice Department officials have offered to waive the death penalty in a deal with the French government that would return an anti-abortion activist arrested in the sniper killing of an upstate New York doctor to the United States for trial, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Bucks Act Frustrated but Refuse to Acknowledge It
description: MILWAUKEE, June 1  Bucks Coach George Karl used the word frustration six times after his team's Game 4 loss to the Philadelphia 76ers on Monday. Two days later, he stormed out of his postgame interview after the Bucks dropped Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals, 89-88.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Fighting Continues
description: The government recaptured a military camp and launched a big attack on rebel positions on the outskirts of the capital, Bangui, reportedly causing many deaths and injuries. The leader of a failed coup, Gen. Andr Kolingba, and his associates are said to be hiding in eastern areas of the city. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: McCAIN WILL MEET DEMOCRATIC CHIEF FOR WEEKEND VISIT
description: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is expected to be a critical power broker with the Senate under Democratic control, is spending the weekend at his vacation home with the leader of the opposition, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Unemployment Rises
description: Layoffs in the technology and food processing industries pushed Ireland's unemployment rate up for the first time in five years, to 3.7 percent in May from 3.6 percent in April, according to the government's Central Statistics Office. Even though only one case of foot-and-mouth disease was discovered in Ireland in March, tighter controls on the handling of animals and on the exports of Irish meat and livestock did significant damage to the country's agricultural and food processing industries. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Judge Ordered To Reconsider Prison Sentence In Swindle Case
description: The sentence of a Syracuse businessman who was convicted of one of the largest financial swindles in United States history was vacated yesterday by a federal appeals court because the sentencing judge had said the actions of the businessman's wife would determine how long he spent in jail.

title: A Bad Guy? Yeah, but He's Not All Bad
description: Does Chazz Palminteri yearn to play Macbeth? Or Stanley Kowalski, Oedipus or Tevye? Or is he satisfied to portray tough guys with golden hearts or steel-trap minds? Mr. Palminteri is a playwright and director as well as a dependable actor, and if his familiar gambit helps underwrite his other artistic activities, who can complain? Besides, his tough guys are fun to watch. But even Mr. Palminteri's starring performance cannot redeem ''Boss of Bosses,'' the tepid Mafia melodrama on TNT tomorrow night.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Adding Up the Costs Of Cyberdemocracy
description: As Cass Sunstein, a professor of law at the University of Chicago, saw himself being skewered on various Web sites discussing his recent book, ''Republic.com,'' he had the odd satisfaction of watching some of the book's themes unfold before his eyes. On the conservative Web site ''FreeRepublic.com,'' the discussion began by referring relatively mildly to Mr. Sunstein's book about the political consequences of the Internet as ''thinly veiled liberal.'' But as the discussion picked up steam, the rhetoric of the respondents, who insisted that they had not and would not read the book itself, became more heated. Eventually, they were referring to Mr. Sunstein as ''a nazi'' and a ''pointy headed socialist windbag.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: New Attacks By Rwandans
description: Ethnic Hutu militiamen clashed with Ugandan troops, the latest of an increasing number of attacks by the forces who carried out the genocide against at least half a million ethnic Tutsis in Rwanda in 1994. Last month the militias, based in Congo, launched their biggest attack in three years on their home territory in northwest Rwanda. The attacks appear to be a result of steps toward peace in Congo. The Rwandan militias were recruited by President Laurent D. Kabila of Congo to fight the war there, but they appear to have lost their standing since Mr. Kabila was assassinated in January. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: The Mets and Gonzalez Prove That They Can Still Come Back
description: Dicky Gonzalez's statistics do not sparkle and, in a vacuum, would be adequate reason for his return to the minor leagues. But on a team that has underachieved all season, Gonzalez has exceeded expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGIN, WILLIAM
description: FEIGIN-William. On June 1, 2001 at age 63. Beloved husband of Nina, loving father of Robert, Andrew and Laurie, devoted fatherin-law of Linda, Alexa and Menachem, adoring grandfather of Yehoshua and Madeline. A service will be held Sunday, June 3rd., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY, at 12:45 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to the Silver Lining Foundation, 1490 Ute Avenue, Aspen, CO 81611. ''970'' 925-9540.

title: For Indians, Casinos Are No Golden Goose
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Laundering Charges for Art Dealers
description: Two New York City art dealers, Shirley D. Sack, 73 and Arnold K. Katzen, 62, have been charged with conspiring to launder $4.1 million in drug money after being apprehended in an undercover sting in Boston, federal authorities said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Teaching Assistants Strike
description: Graduate teaching assistants at the University of Washington went on strike, demanding improved health insurance and restrictions on their teaching load. The strike was called by the Graduate Student Employee Action Coalition, a branch of the United Auto Workers that represents more than 1,000 graduate teaching and research assistants. The union wants to be recognized as their bargaining agent, but university officials insist that, without state legislation, they are not authorized to grant such recognition. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Superintendent Search Continues
description: The Houston Independent School District, without a permanent superintendent since Rod Paige left in January to become secretary of education, was given a list of 66 candidates by a private consultant. School board members in the nation's seventh-largest school district reviewed the names in a closed session, though no timetable has been set for making a final choice. Hispanics, who represent a majority of the student population, are pressuring the board to name the city's first Hispanic superintendent. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: An Overcaller's Loose Lips Sink the Defenders' Ship
description: The Goldman Open Pairs at the Eastern Regional Championships, dating to 1929, ended Sunday in a rare repeat victory. The winners at the Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street, were Aaron Silverstein and Chris Willenken.

title: Airport Captives: Who Wants to Shop?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONOWITZ, GEORGE
description: ARONOWITZ-George. 15 long years of missing and loving you. You're always in our hearts. Love, Lydia, Steve, Merrill, Andrew, Julie, Adam, Todd, Jordan

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Sales Rebound
description: As creditors of Daewoo Motor try to negotiate a deal to sell the company to General Motors, Daewoo's main competitors reported strong sales growth. Hyundai Motor, which with its affiliate, Kia Motor, controls 75 percent of the domestic market, said it sold 145,664 vehicles worldwide in May, which was 14 percent more than in May 2000, while Ssangyong Motor, which specializes in sport utility vehicles, reported 7.5 percent growth in May. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: For Tories, Stiff Upper Lip As Election Hopes Plummet
description: William Hague did not seem depressed. He did not seem disheartened. As he swept through this gray northern town -- or at least through a two-block section of it -- on an election swing today, he did not even seem worried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, JEANNETTE
description: HERMAN-Jeannette. Of Jackson, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on May 16, 2001. She was owner of Cameras, Etc. in Brooklyn. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Rochelle and David Herman. Dear grandmother of Jeremiah and Danielle. Loving friend of Louis Menaker. For information, Bloomfield - Cooper, 800-247-5235.

title: AT&T to Raise Some Rates By as Much as 11 Percent
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would raise basic residential phone rates as much as 11 percent, beginning July 1.

title: Colombian Guilty in New York Heroin Ring
description: The first Colombian extradited to the United States in nearly a decade pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan federal court to charges of smuggling heroin and selling it in New York City during the late 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, EARL COOPER
description: SHAW-Earl Cooper. May 30, 2001. Loving father of Delicia ShawHitchcock and Brian Shaw. Cherised grandfather of Thomas ShawHitchcock. Brother of the late Odessa Anderson Shaw. Son of the late Edward and the late Fanny Shaw. Loving companion of Giselle DeKosinsky. Memorial service Thursday, June 7, 2001, 5:30 PM, St. Lukes Baptist Church, 139 Carroll St, Paterson, NJ; 973345-4309.

title: Rare Fuss for a Poet of the Everyday
description: One last word. How old are you, Mr. Heaney?

title: Online Cohabitation: Internet and Minitel; Videotex System In France Proves Unusually Resilient
description: Clotilde de Mersan's grandmother still fiddles with a Minitel to book a trip or find a phone number. Ms. de Mersan's mother owns a Minitel, but more often than not surfs the Web for such purposes. Ms. de Mersan herself, a 30-year-old executive at Yahoo France, has no Minitel, and uses only the Internet.

title: The Contradictions of Bush's China Policy
description: In reorienting American foreign and defense policy, the Bush administration is in danger of replacing a workable China policy with an unstable and unworkable one. Partly as an unintended consequence, but mostly by design, the administration's actions have appeared to cast Beijing as America's enemy. The expanded arms sales to Taiwan, rhetoric that enlarges the commitment to defend the island, the thinly disguised decision to make Chinese missiles a target of revised missile defense plans, the proposed shift in defense strategy from Europe to the Pacific and the call for new long-range weapons to counter China's military power have come in stunning procession. President Bush's support for trade with China cannot by itself neutralize the antagonism that Beijing leaders clearly sense.

title: In a Park Corner, a Brushoff for Smokers
description: Just after noon yesterday, Stan Kornblum was eating ice cream in the shade in the southwest corner of Bryant Park. A regular at this lush patch of green, he did not notice any change.

title: Mop and Cash Mean Mystery In a Bucket
description: John Suszko, the custodian at police headquarters in Irvington, N.J., for the last 13 years, was honored yesterday for high moral character, honesty and outstanding civic contribution. His good deed has created quite a stir -- as well as an investigation -- in the local police department and the Essex County Prosecutor's office.

title: One Developer's Power Solution: Build a Plant at the Office
description: With state officials scrambling to stave off power shortages this summer, a New York developer has come up with his own solution: building a sophisticated power plant, complete with gas turbines and smoke stacks, inside his planned West Side office complex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Salt Lake City, May 19, 2001

title: Martin Ruling Is Puzzling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cal Wins 3rd Title In a Row
description: The California men's heavyweight varsity crew shone through the clouds today, winning its third consecutive Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championship.

title: The Sea Cliff Factor: Village Helps Independent Filmmaker Reach Dream
description: MIKE LENNON, a firefighter-turned-independent filmmaker, tooled around Sea Cliff in a roofless, banged-up International Scout with rusted-shut doors and a broken accelerator pedal. Mr. Lennon, 46, had just finished filming ''The Chumley Factor,'' a 25-minute comedy he made with $5,000. He was taking the orange truck on a sort of victory lap, pointing out shooting locations and passers-by who acted in the film. He cruised by the local library, where a man shouted ''Chumley!'' and gave him a thumbs-up. ''Hey Chum!'' cheered a woman.

title: The Wizard of Odds
description: Like many people, Ernie Dahlman shows up at the office around 8:45, switches on his computer and spends the rest of the day making telephone calls. His office is nondescript, and so is he: blandly handsome, of average height, with an open, friendly expression and rimless glasses that give him a mildly intellectual look. He could be a travel agent, or a stockbroker, or perhaps a real-estate agent.

title: Private Sector; No Gloss on These Numbers
description: This has been a tough year for Conseco, the big life insurance and finance company based near Indianapolis. Under a new chief executive, Gary C. Wendt, things are looking up. But in the spirit of austerity, Mr. Wendt has decided to forgo the traditional glossy annual report with color photos and, quite often, a liberal amount of happy blather. Instead, shareholders will have to make do with the plain, number-filled document, known as a 10-K, that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires. ''Truth be told,'' Conseco said in a note to shareholders, ''we just didn't think it was money well spent to ramble on and on about the past.'' Joseph B. Treaster

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; The Village Site of Eugene O'Neill's 'Iceman' Saloon
description: The Home of Harry Hope

title: At the St. James Theater, Springtime for Poseurs
description: Perhaps the most exclusive drink in town can be had during intermission at ''The Producers,'' Mel Brooks's musical at the St. James Theater on 44th Street.

title: Schuyler Marshall, Brent Morris
description: Schuyler Leigh Marshall, the daughter of Douglas Bush Marshall and Ellyn Madigan Marshall of Bloomfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Brent Cameron Morris, the son of Zebulon Alexander Morris III and Carol Cross Morris of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. John S. Rogers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the St. George's School Chapel in Middletown, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLEN, LEON C.
description: CARLEN-Leon C. Dear husband and friend of Esta. Loving father of Elliot, and Frances. Proud grandfather of Hannah and Jane. Brother of Augusta Cutter. Loved by all.

title: Spent Nuclear Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice, Orpheus plays the lyre so beautifully that he charms the gods of the underworld into letting him take his dead wife back to earth and life. Well, as long as he can resist looking at her en route (and you know how that sort of thing usually turns out). In Marcel Camus's BLACK ORPHEUS (1959), set during Carnival in Rio de Janeiro, Orpheus (Breno Mello) is a guitarist in love with a country girl (Marpessa Dawn) who is being stalked by a man in a skeleton costume. This intensely atmospheric film, with its haunting samba score, won the best foreign-language film Oscar and the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or -- Sunday at 2 p.m and Sunday/Early Monday at 4 a.m. on Bravo.

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: CASINO SALE APPROVED
description: The sale of the bankrupt Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City cleared its last regulatory hurdle last week, when the State Casino Control Commission voted to approve the transfer of its gambling and liquor license to Park Place Entertainment Corporation of Las Vegas. Earlier in the week, a federal bankruptcy judge in Camden approved the sale as part of the Claridge's Chapter 11 reorganization plan. Under the plan, bondholders are to be repaid 83 percent of the $90.5 million they sought from the Claridge, while unsecured creditors are to get back 61 percent of their claims. Steve Strunsky

title: Sky Watch: Remarkable Precision
description: Last fall, a British scientist demonstrated that the Egyptians most likely used stars in the Big and Little Dippers to achieve remarkable precision in aligning their pyramids toward true north.

title: Of Epic Proportions
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: June 10, 2001, Sunday A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a fundraising dinner for the Robin Hood Foundation misidentified the automobile given as a door prize. It was a Jaguar, not a Mercedes-Benz.

title: Europeans Cut In With a New Jazz Sound And Beat
description: FOR years Americans have regarded European jazz with the same tolerant smile they reserve for Japanese baseball. But something is stirring in the Old World. A generation of musicians is emerging from Europe's jazz underground, and now they're raising a tolerant smile at the mention of American jazz. Talk to them about the current state of the music, and it's as if an old and dear friend has passed away. They believe American jazz is retreating into the past while Europe is moving the music into the 21st century.

title: Chinatown Reborn As a Bohemian Outpost
description: UNDER a lantern-strung walkway, gaudy signs mark musty shops stuffed with Chinese porcelain vases, marble lions and decorated screens -- seemingly a typical Chinatown street. But tucked in among the shops are spare white galleries and clothing boutiques, created by a growing colony of artists and dealers.

title: Royal Splendor in the Deep South
description: THOUGH Jackson, Miss., might not be everybody's idea of a highbrow kind of town, the city has drawn some 825,000 visitors over the past six years to two blockbuster art exhibitions and is currently playing host to a third, ''The Majesty of Spain: Royal Collections from the Museo del Prado and Patrimonio Nacional.'' The idea of bringing 18th-century royal treasures to pokey old Jackson may seem, on first glance, to be a bit of a stretch; after all, most people (at least those who live north of the Mason-Dixon line), when they think of Jackson at all, think more along the lines of Eudora Welty or the state's recent vote to keep the Confederate battle symbol on its flag than of Goya tapestries.

title: From the Knee of Her Bubbe
description: IT wasn't the usual kind of graduation.

title: Making 10,000 Miles of Stained Glass Gleam
description: For the past two years, Bob Kelly has all but lived in a trailer alongside the Princeton University Chapel -- and he is not planning to move anytime soon. As the supervisor for the university chapel renovation project, Mr. Kelly is a busy man, and that is because the university chapel is a busy place.

title: Desperately Seeking a Silver Lining
description: A rally on Friday turned what had been a bad week on Wall Street into a not-so-bad week.

title: Margot DeWitt, Daniel Good
description: Margaret Holekamp DeWitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William O. DeWitt Jr. of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to Daniel John Good, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Good of West Yarmouth, Mass. Msgr. Joseph M. O'Brien performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Chapel at the Summit Country Day School.

title: Article 2001060391250873475 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Beloved Bowling Alley Ends 42-Year Run
description: LOOKING at the weather-worn facade of the Sterling Bowl makes it abundantly clear that the establishment has seen better days. And last Thursday, those days ended for good, when Sterling closed its lanes after 42 years.

title: China's Inner Circle Reveals Big Unrest, and Lists Causes
description: A startlingly frank new report from the Communist Party's inner sanctum describes a spreading pattern of ''collective protests and group incidents'' arising from economic, ethnic and religious conflicts in China and says relations between party officials and the masses are ''tense, with conflicts on the rise.''

title: At La Salle, Tears at Reveille's Last Call
description: SABERS drawn, the last faithful band of cadets, their ranks badly thinned from prouder years past, marched across the parade field at La Salle for the final time.

title: Brooklyn Tourist
description: To the Editor: Our favorite spot in Brooklyn is the Brooklyn Bridge. The view is spectacular; the pedestrian path is wide, with another just for bicyclists. You can see the Statue of Liberty and the skyline of lower Manhattan. Restaurants in Brooklyn Heights are great, or we can eat at one of the restaurants at the World Trade Center or South Street Seaport.

title: May 27-June 2; Suicide Bomber Kills 16 In Tel Aviv Attack
description: In the deadliest terror attack since the eruption of Israeli-Palestinian violence last fall, a suicide bomber killed at least 16 people and injured scores of others outside a crowded beachside club in Tel Aviv. Most victims were teenagers and young adults who were waiting on line to enter a nightspot popular with new immigrants in the southern part of the city. As the weekend began, Palestinians braced for retalliatory air strikes.

title: Is It a Grand Idea or Just a Pipe Dream?
description: FROM Oyster Bay to Rye in Westchester in a matter of minutes without seeing the light of day? Sounds like some sort of molecular transport system straight out of ''Star Trek.''

title: Lost Bank Cards
description: To the Editor: Toni L. Kamins could have had a more succinct list of recommendations for bank card replacement. Do not leave home without a duplicate bank card in hand. Put the spare card, instead of the emergency-replacement phone number, in a place other than your wallet, and you can use it if the original card is lost (and you are sure no one else has found it and is using it).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, EDITH C.
description: GRUEN-Edith C. Passed away at age 73 on May 28, 2001 in NYC after many years of enduring Kidney Disease. Survived by her brother Peter also of NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc. or The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Los Angeles Station Tries to Be a Player for PBS
description: IN late April ''PBS Hollywood Presents,'' a new series produced by the public television station KCET, made its debut. It was a proud moment for the Los Angeles station, but the long road to ''Hollywood Presents'' -- the first dramatic program KCET had produced for PBS since 1994 -- was also a reminder of past and present embarrassments.

title: GARDENING
description: Gardening at our house still feels like a perennial act of reclamation. Perhaps it always will. Every year I imagine that the work we did in the vegetable beds last summer and fall will make it possible to plant that much sooner in the spring, and yet every May and June I feel as though I am retaking territory I had already won, and late in doing so, to boot. The problem isn't usually weeds or the snow-matted cornstalks I thought I'd gathered in November. The problem is ambition and a taste for ingenuity. The area under cultivation is always increasing, and in the established beds I seem to give in to diverging urges -- to garden as intensively and organically as I can and to give more and more formality to the look of the beds themselves. Not long ago, I planted a Union Jack of leeks and salad greens, a pleasingly futile gesture.

title: COOKING
description: ASTONISHING numbers of cookbooks are published every year. While accurate statistics don't seem to exist, the cooking sections of bookstores look to be overflowing -- which isn't surprising, given that sales of a hundred thousand copies aren't uncommon. And if the author has a television show, you can quadruple that. Both big commercial publishers and small independent presses are cranking out more and more cookbooks. There's also a continuous torrent of collections from churches, junior leagues and garden clubs -- perky little worlds frozen in time, where canned fruit, Jell-O, Lipton onion soup mix and densely layered casseroles still rule.

title: Sixers' Awards Won't Matter If They Fail to Make the Finals
description: Theirs has been arguably the finest season in the National Basketball Association. On opening night, they put the league on notice by flattening the Knicks. At the All-Star Game, their coach and top player led the East to a startling upset. At the trade deadline, they snagged Dikembe Mutombo. They have the N.B.A.'s most valuable player (Allen Iverson), its coach of the year (Larry Brown), its defensive player of the year (Mutombo) and its top sixth man (Aaron McKie).

title: Back-Seat Warriors
description: Every parent has been there: the low rumble rising from the back seat, growing in pitch and urgency as the miles tick off and patience wears thin. It's the ''Are we there yet?'' syndrome, and it's the subject of RIDE (Silver Whistle/Harcourt, $16; ages 5 to 9), a quirky, gently subversive look at life in the rearview mirror, written and illustrated by Stephen Gammell. He sets his story in the long-ago of his childhood, even though he begs us to believe: ''What you see in this book never happened in our back seat. Oh no. I just made this up. Really.''

title: Kimberly Charlton, Pablo Bedetti
description: Kimberly Erin Charlton and Pablo Ignacio Bedetti were married on Friday by the Rev. Harry Taylor at the First Congregational Church in Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Michael Hanly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Stephanie Bellin, Matthew Weinstein
description: Stephanie Joy Bellin and Matthew Jonah Weinstein are to be married today by Rabbi Irving Greenberg at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Editorial Observer; The Erosion of Political Reform in Guatemala
description: In 1978, a series of earthquakes struck Guatemala, killing 40,000 people. Among those who went to help was Sister Barbara Ann Ford, a 40-year-old American nun from the Bronx-based Sisters of Charity. Sister Barbara, a registered nurse, spent most of the next 22 years in Quiche Province, the crucible of suffering during Guatemala's civil war and the site of 344 massacres of Mayan Indians. Sister Barbara braved death threats to help the villagers get clean water, midwife training and mental health treatment. When the peace accords ending the 36-year war were signed in 1996, she helped the Catholic Archdiocese collect testimonies about wartime killings and organized the exhumation of graves and counseling to help the survivors.

title: Future Custodians
description: To the Editor:

title: Tanya Moore, John Jessop
description: Tanya Fairfax Moore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Moore of New Canaan, Conn., was married last evening to John Cooper Jessop, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Jessop of Westhampton, N.Y. The Rev. J. Barry Furey performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Taking a Big Breath, N.F.L. Tackles Yoga
description: The rookies arrived at the Giants' conditioning camp at the Meadowlands and went right to work.

title: Forecast: Increasingly Pleasant With a Good Chance of Music
description: THE elegance, charm and musical abundance that is the Caramoor Festival returns to the 100-acre estate in Katonah for its 56th summer party stretching from June 23 through Aug. 11.

title: Watching Bitterness Transform Wallflower
description: IT would be interesting to watch the Two River Theater Company's production of ''The Heiress'' through soundproof glass, forgoing the words and just letting Deborah Caney's lush costumes convey the story. The gowns she places on the title character are a show in themselves, and more to the point, they beautifully track the character's transformation: subdued at the beginning, bright and empowering by the end.

title: Getting 'Proof' to Work Is a Delicate Equation
description: FOR Mary-Louise Parker, Larry Bryggman, Johanna Day and Ben Shenkman, the Tony-nominated actors in the play ''Proof,'' the proof is in the process.

title: Katherine Oberlies, Michael O'Leary
description: Katherine Mary Oberlies, a lawyer, and Michael David O'Leary, a financial executive, were married yesterday by the Rev. Conrad Sundholm, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, at the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the dumping of contaminated material off Sandy Hook referred incompletely to the Kill Van Kull. While the channel is indeed being dredged and the material is being dumped off the coast, it is not contaminated.

title: Keeping Burglars From Stealing Summer
description: SUMMER is the time when most home burglaries occur. This is understandable because many homeowners keep the windows open during the hot weather, and the trees and bushes around the house are in full bloom and offer a screen to protect the would-be intruder. In addition, many homeowners go away for the summer, making the empty house an inviting target. You may feel safe if you live in a quiet neighborhood, but it's possible that thieves simply haven't discovered your area yet.

title: Bosom Buddies
description: AMERICAN SYMPATHY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, RUTH JOAN WIESEL GORD
description: SIEGEL-Ruth Joan Wiesel Gord of Santa Fe, NM, formerly of Belle Harbor, NY. Died on May 4, 2001, age of 86. Loving wife of the late David Harry Siegel, beloved mother of Barry Malcolm Siegel, Marjorie M. Engel, Brian Allan Siegel, devoted grandmother of Liana Laura Engel, Kyra Jacqueline and Taryn Ruth Siegel. Loving mother-in-law of Arlene Siegel and Robert Engel. ''With her sunny disposition, she was never alone.''

title: In Bridgeport, Female Artists Go Back to the Garden
description: BEYOND the Garden Wall'' takes flowers beyond their normal form, place and season -- well beyond.

title: Trying to Make Sure There's Room at the Inn
description: WEDDING parties today often involve overnight accommodations for many or all of the guests. Kevin Fitzsimmons, general manager of East Wind Caterers, knows this very well but is unable to do much about it at his two Wading River catering halls, The Estate and Country Gardens, beyond offering clients a list of local hotels and suggesting they book as soon as possible.

title: The Delinquent Summer of My Youth
description: LISTEN to songs and watch movies and you'll harbor no doubt: summer nights are filled with nothing but panting teenage romance. When everyone is 16 and beguilingly beautiful, a summer love affair blossoms on the day school ends, before snapping off, tidy as a tack, at fall's first breeze.

title: Not Dead Yet
description: Richard Liebmann-Smith's Lives column (May 13) brought to mind an experience: Some years ago, I was in a bad car accident. While I was waiting to be cut out of the car, an emergency worker covered me from head to toe with a blanket (for protection). He said to me, ''You are not dead.'' I appreciated hearing that.

title: Allyson Zazulia, Michael Diringer
description: Dr. Allyson Robyn Zazulia and Dr. Michael Neil Diringer, neurologists in St. Louis, are to be married today by Rabbi Mark Raphael at the Inn at Perry Cabin in St. Michaels, Md.

title: Life-and-Death Questions In Embassy Bombings Case
description: In reaching verdicts in the embassy bombings case, a jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan could not have been more resolute. All four defendants were convicted last week on every count brought against them.

title: He Knew What He Liked
description: ROLAND PENROSE

title: The More The Merrier
description: MERGE

title: Protests Rise in China
description: An unusual report from the Communist Party describes a wave of protests and says they may get worse as the nation opens up more.

title: The Nation; Econ 101: It's Right and It's Wrong
description: ELECTRICITY deregulation -- allowing power companies to set wholesale prices on their own -- has gone seriously awry in California. Severe shortages have led to rolling blackouts and soaring prices, with wholesale prices rising about 700 percent in a year, jolting the state's economy. Last week, Gov. Gray Davis grabbed for instant relief. When President Bush visited his state, Mr. Davis lobbied hard for federal regulators to impose a price cap on power companies -- a maximum price that wholesalers would be permitted to charge.

title: The Nation; Justice as a Morality Play That Ends With Shame
description: IN Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''The Scarlet Letter,'' the adulterous Hester Prynne was required to wear the letter A on her chest so that all would know of her unforgivable sin.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 20, about the use of safety seats for children in automobiles, referred incompletely to the 2,474 children in the United States who died in traffic crashes in 1999. They were not all passengers; the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says 750 of those children were outside cars when they died.

title: BENEFITS
description: Raising the Bar

title: May 27-June 2; A Hard Rain's Always Falling
description: The sky is falling, it turns out. On April 23, a speeding meteoroid crashed into the atmosphere and produced a blast nearly as powerful as the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima.

title: Penn Station And Landmarks
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Cambria, Eric Handler
description: Elizabeth Grace Cambria and Eric English Handler were married on Friday by the Rev. John J. Denniston at the Church of St. Patrick in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: CLASSIC TV

title: A Backyard With Sand, a Net and a Ball (Just Add Sun)
description: IT is common for people who walk the beaches of Connecticut in the summer to spot tiny puffs of sand bursting into the air as volleyball players pummel white leather balls into the ground. It is less common to see those sand puffs coming from someone's backyard.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: AQUAMARINE

title: Sarah Wittig, Christopher Blundin
description: Sarah Emily Wittig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Wittig of Lake Bluff, Ill., was married yesterday to Christopher Higgins Blundin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Blundin of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. George J. Rassas, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of Woodlands Academy in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Article 2001060391237207074 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Saudis Pick Exxon Mobil and Shell for Huge Gas Projects
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, has been chosen to lead a $17 billion gas development in Saudi Arabia, and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group will head the smaller Shaybah project, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today.

title: Funds Watch: Stock Index Funds Are Regaining Favor
description: Investors are putting increasing amounts of money into index funds, after a slowdown last year.

title: Customers Will Retaliate For Slights, Study Says
description: Have you ever been so furious at a company that you decided to boycott its products or write a letter to the company president? Has the thought of starting a Web site devoted to denouncing that company ever crossed your mind?

title: Word for Word/Nameless Dread; 20 Years Ago, the First Clues To the Birth of a Plague
description: AIDS. The acronym alone defines a generation. But 20 years ago, the disease was a puzzle. The virus that causes it was already pulsing through many thousands of people's veins, but the symptoms that define it were just beginning to emerge: the lingering malaise, the persistent diarrhea, the bluish-purple spots. Doctors began noticing a similarity of symptoms. A few gay activists sounded an alarm. But knowledge was slow to accumulate.

title: Finding Offshoots For Profit
description: POLITICAL battles over gun ownership may rage, but there's one place where there's a consensus that guns are not a growth industry: the gun industry.

title: Memoir of a Beatnik
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria DeMarco, Charles Beardsley III
description: Maria Rose DeMarco and Charles B. Beardsley III were married yesterday at Our Lady Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Anthony Rucando performed the ceremony.

title: Down the Diesel Road: Problem or Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Assembling To Put In Motion A Gathering Of Spirits
description: MICHAEL CURRY believes in spirits: devils, angels, the ghosts of children and mountaineers, and most particularly the good spirits -- an old logger, a scholar, a woman -- who have been his constant companions since he was a shy 12-year-old growing up in a logging town in the southern Oregon mountains.

title: Lott Takes Parting Shot on Eve of Senate Power Shift
description: Tossing a parting grenade as he leaves office as the Senate majority leader, Senator Trent Lott declared today that Republicans ''must begin to wage the war'' against Democrats when they take control of the Senate next week.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: These Cheerleaders Say, 'It's Better Here'
description: WHEN Denver and Dallas were competing recently with Chicago to woo the Boeing Company, which wanted to move its headquarters out of Seattle, they deployed superstar athletes to greet the company's executives. When Plano, Tex., and Jackson Hole, Wyo., sought to attract California companies disaffected by the energy shortage, they sent flashlights along with their marketing brochures.

title: Down the Diesel Road: Problem or Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place And Time To Find New Ways To Move
description: THIRTY-NINE years ago, the sanctuary of the Judson Memorial Church on Washington Square became the site of a landmark development in the international history of dance. It housed the doings of a motley band of folks in their early 20's for whom history-making was of no concern. They were simply searching for personal paths to artistic creation through bodily movement. They became known as the Judson Dance Theater, and what they did shocked the dance establishment. Ultimately, however, the impact of their discoveries forced it to move over and make room for them.

title: Liberties; Revenge, Served Hot
description: No matter how effectively you take revenge, you always leave somebody else wanting revenge.

title: Where Are Those Memory Tips?
description: OFT in the stilly night,'' Thomas Moore wrote, ''Fond memory brings the light of other days around me.''

title: Habitats/40 East Ninth Street; A Title Insurer Discovers A Love for Furniture
description: IT wasn't that long ago that Anthony Chiellino was an Ikea kind of guy. He never thought about furniture and when he needed a sofa or chair, he cared only about function and expediency. His home, an alcove studio on the Upper East Side, was a brief stopping place after long days at work in Brooklyn building his title-insurance business.

title: The Kidnapping Economy
description: The evening began at an exclusive restaurant, continued for several boozy hours at two swank bars and ended with a hot dog on a lively Bogot street. In other words, it was a pretty standard Saturday night for Alexander, 28, and his friend, a 26-year-old insurance executive. They left the hot-dog stand and were driving in the friend's Jeep Grand Cherokee through an upscale neighborhood in north Bogot when a sedan with five men inside zipped up from behind and cut them off. They were merely a block away from one of the busiest thoroughfares in the city, in front of a major hospital, around the corner from an international hotel and office complex. But at that moment on that particular morning -- April 15, 2000 -- they were very much alone.

title: Summer Has Arrived
description: SOMEWHERE around the 15th snowfall of the winter, when you're scraping ice off the windshield at 6 a.m. and mentally calculating how to reschedule your day if there's yet another school closing or delay, you probably had trouble -- at least for a moment -- remembering just why you decided to live here.

title: Text of the Email That Cost Peter Chung His Job
description: Subject: LIVING LIKE A KING

title: Real Producers Are Nothing Like Bialystock. Right?
description: It's an outrage. Eight performances a week at the St. James Theater, Max Bialy stock, the feckless antihero of Mel Brooks's musical ''The Producers,'' is dragging the good name of producers through the mud. ''I've been a lying, double-crossing, two-faced, back-stabbing despicable crook,'' he says. ''But I had no choice. I was a Broadway producer.''

title: Victims' Accounts of a Night of Horror
description: Ana Sinichkin lay sobbing in a hospital bed in a suburb of this city today, shrapnel in her leg and her hand cradled by a friend who tried to comfort her.

title: On the Defensive
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Injury to Arnott Cues Linemates' Revival
description: Fourteen seconds into the game tonight, the Devils received what could have been a crippling blow.

title: A $100 Dinner That's Not About the Food
description: The night was clear and the Bonanza Boys were hungry. But it was too early in the season for supper on Block Island, too late at night for steak in Columbia County. Ah, Cajun chicken wings in Reading, Pa.

title: Rachel Savage, Louis Nowikas
description: Rachel Savage, the daughter of Pamela and Robert Savage of Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married last evening to Louis Nowikas, the son of Leona Nowikas of Randolph, N.J., and the late Walter Nowikas. Justice Elaine Jackson Stack of State Supreme Court in Mineola, N.Y., officiated in Shelter Island Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Steven Crowson, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Katherine Pope, Richard Robbins
description: Katherine Collins Pope, a daughter of Christine and Michael A. Pope of Glencoe, Ill., was married yesterday at Blantyre, a hotel in Lenox, Mass., to Richard Edward Robbins, a son of Dr. Anthony W. Robbins of Boston and the late Jennifer Lauterbach Robbins. The ceremony was performed by John Byrne, a friend of the bride's family, who was appointed a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day.

title: Robert L. Benney, 97, Prolific Combat Artist
description: Robert L. Benney, a prolific painter and illustrator who belonged to the vanishing breed of American combat artists, died on May 14 in Boston. He was 97 and had recently moved to Boston from Manhattan.

title: Hybrid Musk Roses: Scent Above All Else
description: I LOVE just about all roses, with the possible exception of Rosa viridiflora, a horticultural oddity with blossoms that look like pale green spiders. If I had the sunny space, I would fill my property with hundreds of bushes. Love is wonderful, but passion is even better. And when it comes to roses, hybrid musks are my passion.

title: Willing to Work Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepping Off the Train Into Summer's Arms
description: SUMMER does not truly arrive until school is out. It doesn't matter whether you are actually going to school any longer or not. It doesn't matter if you are sitting in an office all day or are crammed in the middle of a three-seat bench on your way home in a commuter train. Because when you step off that train, summer has often come to the station to greet you.

title: Jill Zimmer, Samuel Simon
description: Dr. Jill Robin Zimmer, the daughter of Karen and Joel Zimmer of Alpine, N.J., was married last evening to Samuel Elihu Simon, the son of the late Arlene Simon and the late Dr. Abram Simon. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLINSON, ESTHER
description: BELLINSON-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Solomon; beloved mother of Naomi Feldman and Arthur Bellinson; beloved grandmother of Robert, Amy, Jennifer, Lisa and David; beloved greatgrandmother of Daniel, Jonathan, Lex, Maya, Sam, Johannah, Gabi, Jonah and Aviva; beloved sister of Sarah Frank, Leo Greenberg and the late Max Greenberg. Graveside service Monday, June 4, 1PM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions may be made to Hadassah. For further information call Sinai Chapels 718-445-0300

title: What About Lucy?
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Sopranos' Festival
description: To the Editor:

title: The Innocence of 'Pearl Harbor'
description: When United States occupation forces arrived in Tokyo after Japan's defeat in August 1945, Prime Minister Naruhiko Higashikuni voiced a plaintive, even pathetic wish. If the Americans would try to forget Pearl Harbor, he said, he and his compatriots would try to forget Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: My Ghosts? Not So Scary As Those Up the Street
description: It could have been coincidence, but on a sunny day last week, as Elaine Mercado drove her car with its ''Question Reality'' bumper sticker into her driveway, the sky darkened and thunder clapped overhead.

title: Residents Lose Patience After a Year Of Roadwork
description: Neighbors of Mulry Square, at the six corners of Greenwich Avenue, West 11th Street and Seventh Avenue South, braced themselves when the jackhammers and bulldozers arrived last spring. The treacherous intersection, where in 1981 two children crossing the square with their mother were crushed to death by a 12-wheel tractor, was getting a much-anticipated redesign to improve safety.

title: Drops of Diversity in a Quiet Area
description: Surely one of the most suburban parts of Brooklyn is the wrench-shaped peninsula that holds Bergen Beach, Georgetown, Mill Basin and Old Mill Basin. This area is embroidered with shady, quiet streets and mint-green lawns; down by the water, houses can sell for $1 million and more.

title: When Artists Go on Vacation, Their Work Is Rarely Left Behind
description: BY and large, artists shed the bohemian image long ago. They lead regular lives, which means that they take vacations like everybody else. But there's a problem: art is not a job, but a calling that's not easily switched off or laid aside for a time. Several New Jersey artists were asked whether they can take a vacation from art, and if not, how do they satisfy its demands when their art follows them out of the studio.

title: Take the G Train? Official Revision
description: After commuters and Governor Pataki protested proposed cuts in G train service, New York Transit voted Thursday to revise the plan. G service will be unchanged on evenings and weekends. But on weekdays it will still terminate at Court Square to make room for a new V train, and the number of cars on G trains will be reduced to four from six. But there will be more service in peak hours.

title: Babes in Adultland
description: SEVERAL times a night, smug customers will jokingly ask Barbara Sinko, a manager at the Magnolia Bakery on Bleecker Street, if they can lick a bowl of frosting. ''I don't even answer anymore,'' she said.

title: Elizabeth Lee, William Bean
description: Elizabeth Lisa Lee, the daughter of Margaret Lee of Las Vegas and Hsu Lee of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to William Bao Bean, the son of Cathy Bao Bean and Bennett Bean of Johnsonburg, N.J. The Rev. Allison M. Moore, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Letting the World Plug Into Your PC, for Profit
description: ERIC VONDRAN of Calgary, Alberta, recently received a $150 check for doing no work. He didn't have to attend a focus group or sit through a sales presentation. All he did was permit a computer company, called United Devices, to plug into his PC, and he did not even notice when it happened. For him, the payout was not small potatoes. ''It really came in handy,'' said Mr. Vondran, who is 23 and unemployed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALEINE AUSTIN
description: COHEN-Aleine Austin. Age 78, died June 2, 2001, in La Jolla, CA. Historian and educator. Formerly resided in Baltimore and in Palm Beach. Born in Woodmere, L.I. Attended Hunter College High School, Barnard College, graduated from Antioch College, Ph.D. Columbia University. Predeceased by husbands, Dr. Abraham Mufson of New York, Dr. Jonas Cohen of Baltimore. Survived by daughter Laurie Mufson of Mercersburg, PA, son Michael Mufson of Vista, CA, sister Jean Kaufer of Los Angeles, grandsons Beckett and Jonas Orion. Graveside services Salem Fields, Brooklyn.

title: Analog and Digital, Happy Together
description: In the mid-70's, Pulsar introduced the digital watch -- a clunky push-button L.E.D. screen on a gold bracelet -- for $400. A decade later the technology had become cheap and unfashionable; in the 90's it resurfaced in the form of sport watches by Nike, Timex and Casio.

title: Cheery Cosseting On Beacon Hill
description: The very terms ''town house hotel'' and ''bistro'' are suspect these days. But the Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro in Boston is the genuine article.

title: For Golf Junkies, The Perfect Fix: Driving Ranges
description: I was an avid golfer as a teenager in the 1980's, back when golf was for nerds. These days, it's cool (you can thank or blame Tiger Woods, depending on your perspective). So one day last year I dug out my old clubs and hit the driving range.

title: New Roles for Nonprofit Housing Groups
description: A CLASSIFIED ad in The Daily News last September set in motion the events that are leading Linda Hamlin to make the first housing change of her life.

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Tales of Summer in the Stock Market: True or False?
description: CALL it the battle of the clichs.

title: This Summer Game Is in Cricket Whites
description: FOR Edward Lucas, summer means cricket games in Keney Park in Hartford.

title: Brooklyn Tourist
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's article ''Playing Tourist at Home in Brooklyn'' (Frugal Traveler, May 13) was both interesting and touching. I grew up at 218 Smith Street, in a walk-up over a lamp store. My father had a kosher butcher store at Smith and Dean Streets. I went to Public School 58 on Smith Street. I always wanted to know if any of these places still existed.

title: Temptation Islands
description: SEARCHING

title: What the Designers Are Wearing
description: WHAT personal favorites do fashion designers rotate to the front of their own closets for warmer weather? Turns out, they are no different from you and me.

title: BOYS AND GIRLS WINS AGAIN
description: Boys and Girls of Brooklyn completed a sweep of Public Schools Athletic League city girls' titles, winning the outdoor championship yesterday at St. John's. The Kangaroos, who had captured the cross-country and indoor P.S.A.L. crowns, had 115 points to 84 by Paul Robeson, also of Brooklyn.

title: The Nation; What Is Golf? v. What Is a Disability
description: IN his quest through the federal courts for the right to use a golf cart on the PGA Tour, Casey Martin, who suffers from a serious and progressive circulatory disorder in his right leg, became an appealing symbol of the law he invoked, the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. But it takes nothing away from his case or the grit with which he pursued it to suggest that declarations of a sweeping victory for people with disabilities are premature.

title: Alexandra Godfrey, Stephen Walko
description: Alexandra Elizabeth Thompson Godfrey, the daughter of Nancy and Peter Godfrey of Redding, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen George Walko, a son of Beatrice and Albert Walko of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Kenneth Ballas performed the ceremony at St. Paul Evangelical Lutheran Church in Greenwich.

title: In AIDS War, New Weapons and New Victims
description: Elsie Carter's morning routine never varies. She awakens at 6:30 to feed the cats, George and Sam, named for her friends, fellow AIDS patients who died. Then she butters a slice of toast and pours a tall tumbler of orange juice -- ''to put a little something in my stomach,'' Ms. Carter explains -- as she ingests the veritable pharmacy that keeps her alive.

title: Beth Carey and Bryan Hanypsiak
description: Beth Erica Carey, the daughter of Bonnie and Christopher Carey of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Bryan Todd Hanypsiak, the son of Christine and Jerry Hanypsiak of Tonawanda, N.Y. The Rev. Carmine Rita performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville.

title: Laura Congleton, David Randall
description: Laura Helen Congleton, a daughter of Lois and Edward Blackburn Congleton of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to David Randall, the son of Laura and Francis Ballard Randall of New York. The Rev. Jane Allen Middleton, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in Waveny Park in New Canaan.

title: Commercial Property/Dylan Hotel; A New Boutique Hotel With Medieval Touches
description: THE ceiling of the room is a series of half round vaults, connected by raised ribs that rest on pillars partially emerged from the vertical walls. The window is of stained glass with illustrations suggesting strange, pseudoscientific rituals. The effect is one of a Gothic chamber in a medieval castle.

title: A Second Chance for a Landmark That Lost Its Luster, Bulb by Bulb
description: It has been called tacky and ill conceived, and likened, derogatorily, to Coney Island. But fans of the Sunnyside Arch have succeeded in obtaining money so that the structure, with its hundreds of tiny light bulbs, can once again light up the night sky.

title: Playing by the Rules
description: On a visit to the dentist, a woman throws up on a dental assistant. When she tells her husband about it, he says, ''That must have been awful for her'' -- meaning the dental assistant. The wife thinks angrily: He never feels sympathy for me.

title: Tocqueville's Private Diary
description: So thoroughly do I understand the noble American Experiment; why, then, is it that I cannot understand how to fold their infernal road maps?

title: The Gipsy Kings at NJPAC
description: The Gipsy Kings, who have sold more than four million albums in the United States to become the best-selling French act ever, carry on the musical tradition of two gypsy families from the Arles and Montpellier regions in southern France. The lead singer, Nicolas Reyes, is the son of Jos Reyes, the Flamenco singer. The Gipsy Kings, the subject of two PBS specials, play the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Tuesday. Karen DeMasters

title: Cuban Athlete May Have Defected at Games for the Blind
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C., June 2  There are two beds in the Cuban runner Daniel Jaime Pedroso's dorm room in the basement of the Herbert Center at the South Carolina School for the Deaf and the Blind. One is his. The other is neatly made, with a blanket folded at the foot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANOVER, GAIL R.
description: YANOVER-Gail R. We mourn the passing of our colleague, Gail Yanover, RN, MS. Expert clinician, teacher, leader, and steward, Gail was our partner at Mount Sinai for over 32 years. She advocated with determination and wisdom for improvement in the environments of care for patients and families as well as the nurses who serve Mount Sinai's many communities. We extend our deepest sympathy to her brother Jerald Yanover, sister Judith Elman and Gail's entire family. Thomas Smith, RN Vice President, Nursing on Behalf of the Mount Sinai Community of Nurses

title: Sailors Take Warning!
description: A Voyage for Madmen

title: Rested Webb Makes Few Mistakes to Take Command
description: On a challenging golf course that did not tolerate mistakes, Karrie Webb was nearly flawless today.

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: Jeff Goodell's article (May 13) moved me in ways I had not anticipated. I cannot imagine losing a loved one the way Patrick Reeder did, but I hope that I would ultimately possess the same courage and acceptance that he does. Reeder's path to letting go and healing further strengthened my feelings against the death penalty.

title: A Sweeter Lucinda Williams
description: Lucinda Williams has wowed fans and critics alike with her earthy, sensual, no-frills blues-derived music for two decades , and with her new album ''Essence,'' she shows no signs of letting up, although she shows signs of sweetening up. In concert, she covers the spectrum from fiery rock tunes to pining country songs, but when she gets down to her blues roots, her essence is obvious. A singer and songwriter of introspective passion, she will appear Friday at the Count Basie Theater in Red Bank.

title: The Guiding Lights
description: The club and rave fashion for glow sticks and phosphorescent body glitter, usually bought at novelty shops like Pearl River in Chinatown, has inspired its own market niche. This spring, manufacturers caught on to the craze and are packaging ''light chic'' for ravers and those who just want to look like they were up all night writhing to the music.

title: The Professors and the Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: The First Supper
description: Amanda Hesser (Style, May 13) left out some important details of that first meal at home with the neophyte gourmet. What kind of wine did her date bring? Did he ask what a guinea hen was?

title: For Artists, a Vacation Just Means a New Landscape
description: BY and large, artists shed the Bohemian image long ago. They lead regular lives, which means that they take vacations like everybody else. But there's the conundrum: art is not a job, but a calling that's not easily switched off. Several Westchester artists were asked whether they can take a vacation from art, and if not, how they satisfy its demands when their art follows them out of the studio.

title: Tax Cuts and Political Shift Threaten Bush's Plans for Military
description: Powerful political and economic forces are threatening President Bush's pledge to design a ''new architecture for the defense of America and our allies.'' While some of these forces were unleashed by the administration itself, Mr. Bush and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld seem in some ways to have been caught off guard.

title: CELL PHONES AND ACCIDENTS
description: Police officers would have to report to the state whether the drivers involved in car accidents were using cellular telephones at the time, under a bill that has passed both houses of the Legislature and is expected to be signed by Acting Governor DiFrancesco. At a time when some municipalities are considering prohibiting use of portable telephones while driving, the bill passed both houses with nearly unanimous support. The state League of Municipalities opposes the bill because of the work it would create for the local police. Mr. DiFrancesco supports the idea, said Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman.

title: Showing the Flag (Literally, Maybe) in Venice
description: THE flag that the sculptor Robert Gober found washed up on the beach one morning last summer was hardly big enough for a child to wrap itself in. Somebody had once meticulously embroidered the stars, but it was as faded as stone-washed jeans, and as frayed.

title: Live Television, Aloft
description: ON almost every commercial flight in the world these days, television means reruns of ''Friends'' and ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' or old ''60 Minutes'' segments. It is hardly the kind of programming that causes most people to forget that they are stuck in a small seat for hours at a time.

title: Andrea Kann, John Gassner
description: Andrea Lyn Kann, the daughter of Anna and Richard E. Kann of Pittsburgh, is to be married today to John Schuyler Gassner, a son of Sandra and Mark D. Gassner of Bloomfield, Conn. Rabbi Mark Staitman will officiate at the Yale Club of New York.

title: The Elephant Learns to Skip Rope
description: WOMEN in high heels scurried down the aisles of the Wisdom Lane Middle School auditorium, collecting thick scripts from men in business suits.

title: Embracing the Straitjacket
description: THE UNKNOWN

title: Our Towns; Rescuing Tom Thumb's House as Bridgeport's Children Struggle
description: IT'S easy to zip past the dilapidated house on North Avenue -- not to mention Bridgeport itself -- and avert your eyes. Many people do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMURRAY, JOSEPH P.
description: McMURRAY-Joseph P. On May 31, 2001, of East Atlantic Beach, NY. Past president of Queens College, Queensboro Community College, College of New Rochelle. Beloved husband of the late Isabelle, mother of his children, and Rose Marie. Dear father of Gerald R., Joseph P. Jr., Kathleen M. Nelson, Isabelle Pullis, Kevin F., Brien A., stepson Walter G. Barker, stepdaughter Diane Crehan and the late Robert Barker. Cherished grandfather of 25 and great-grandfather of five. Reposing Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:45 AM, St. Francis de Sales R.C. Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment St. Mary Star of the Sea Cemetery, Lawrence, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends may make contributions to Queens College Foundation, Inc, in memory of Joseph P. McMurray.

title: Jai Maitra, John Griem Jr.
description: Jai Maitra, the daughter of Yashodhara Maitra and Dr. Samaresh Maitra of Webster, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to John Michael Griem Jr., the son of Peggy C. Griem and Mr. Griem Sr.of Lake Bluff, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Kathleen E. Madigan, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Downtown United Presbyterian Church in Rochester. Yesterday afternoon, a ceremony in the Hindu tradition was performed at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in Rochester by Dr. V. V. Raman, the chairman of the Rochester Interfaith Forum.

title: The Professors and the Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: On Five New Discs, The Flavor Is French
description: HIS first appearance in the United States, together with his famous soprano wife, was hyped to a fare-thee-well. In the event, he got mixed reviews. But no one denied that he possessed good looks and a decent voice, and he used the combination to advantage for years, becoming one of the best-established French tenors of the day.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NACHIMSON, MARGARET SCHLEIFER
description: NACHIMSON-Margaret Schleifer. Your 40th birthday. Maggie, we miss you so. Your loving family and friends

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: A Perjurer's Victim, Determined to Move On

title: Joan McCormick, David Hosp
description: Joan Theresa McCormick, a daughter of Joan T. McCormick of Osterville, Mass., and the late William M. McCormick, was married yesterday to David Hosp, a son of Martha M. Hosp and Richard H. Hosp of Charlestown, R.I. The Rev. Thomas L. Rita, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Church in Osterville.

title: How Do You Make A Movie Sing?
description: Jesse Green's treatment of the death and possible resurrection of the movie musical (May 13) missed some of the most innovative recent reworkings of the genre. These include ''Topsy Turvy,'' Mike Leigh's delightful foray into the lives behind the music of Gilbert and Sullivan, and ''Cradle Will Rock,'' Tim Robbins's paean to the social theater projects of the 1930's. Baz Luhrmann isn't doing anything particularly new. There are already sophisticated models out there.

title: Political Briefing; Rumors and Concern Over Thompson Plans
description: To hear some of the rumormongers talk in Tennessee, Senator Fred Thompson is fed up with Washington and may return to run for governor, especially now that Senate Republicans are back in the minority.

title: British Dislike Of the Euro Is Eroding In Campaign
description: Voting in Britain's election does not take place until Thursday, but one significant result is already in -- a break in the country's long-standing hostility to adopting the euro as its currency.

title: BOOKSHELF: THE NEW YORKER
description: MATTERS OF STATE:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELSEN, ESTHER
description: FELSEN-Esther June 3, 1921-June 28, 1998 Remembered, missed and loved every day. Her Family

title: Imogene Coca, 92, Is Dead; a Partner in One of TV's Most Successful Comedy Teams
description: Imogene Coca, the saucer-eyed, rubber-faced comedian who teamed with Sid Caesar on NBC's ''Your Show of Shows'' and kept America's Saturday night television audiences in stitches for five years in the early 1950's, died yesterday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 92.

title: Private Sector; Dumbed Down on Wall St.: Junk Finance, With Pictures
description: It's a bird, it's a plane, it's Perelman.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: EUROPEAN AIR PASS -- Austrian Airlines has introduced a Discover Europe Pass that offers discounts on economy class travel to 73 cities in Europe and Russia. Citizens of the United States and Canada who buy a round-trip ticket to Vienna on Austrian Airlines are eligible to buy coupons good for one flight, with a minimum purchase of three coupons for a total of $349. Up to seven more coupons can be bought at $99 each. All travel must be completed within three months, with a minimum 24-hour stay at each destination. Children who accompany an adult are eligible for 33 percent off the regular coupon prices, but coupons must be requested at the time of purchase of a child's trans-Atlantic ticket. Information, (800) 843-0002 or www.aua.com.

title: First, Elvis's Guitar; Now 'On the Road'
description: LITERARY fans had fun picking faces out of the crowd at Christie's the other day, when, 50 years after its completion in a three-week typing frenzy, the 120-foot scroll on which Jack Kerouac composed ''On the Road'' was auctioned.

title: Fashion, The Show That Never Goes On
description: HERE are a few things you won't find going on today as New York heats up with Tony fever: Harry Winston bodyguards. Joan Rivers sniffing at designer labels on the red carpet. Avant-garde swan dresses. Suites at the Four Seasons teeming with makeup artists. Fashion stylists tripping out of the Cond Nast tower for last-minute fittings for the stars.

title: Devils Rally and Keep Their Grip on the Cup
description: With Jason Arnott, their first-line center, in the hospital and goalie Martin Brodeur not making crucial saves, the Devils seemed doomed. They trailed the Colorado Avalanche by a goal as the midway point of the third period approached tonight at Continental Arena. An Avalanche victory would have put Colorado a game from the Stanley Cup that the Devils have held for a year.

title: Another Round
description: MY EARS ARE BENT By Joseph Mitchell. 299 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Asking Investor to Sell a Co-op Unit
description: Q I have been a tenant in a Long Island City co-op for 20 years and was there when the building was converted. I was assembling the money to buy my apartment in 1998, when the sponsor sold all of his unsold units to an investor. I have since been trying to buy the apartment from the investor, but he refuses to sell it to me and does not give me any reasons. I even ordered an appraisal last December, to find out the market value of the apartment, and then offered to pay the appraised value. The investor says the appraisal is irrelevant and that he is not interested. What can I do to force the investor to at least quote me a price? . . . Gerard Grosof, Long Island City, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: Our cover article on the co-opting of organic foods by big business prompted urgent calls to return the movement to its roots.
