Readers said that if any good is to come from the Oklahoma City bombing, it will be in the grace with which those like Patrick Reeder have come to terms with the tragedy.

title: For a Better F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Views to Make Your Mouth Water
description: SUMMER'S lease hath all too short a date,'' Shakespeare reminds us.

title: Success Now Available in Small and Medium
description: PARIS, June 2  Last Wednesday, as usual, was Children's Day at the French Open, which meant that little people were everywhere at Roland Garros with adult- sized backpacks and innocuous mayhem on their minds: behind the trees near Court 17 laughing too loudly; grabbing for free posters at one stand, and shrieking from the bleachers inside Court Chatrier while Gustavo Kuerten played.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSSEINI, FEISAL
description: HUSSEINI-Feisal. Meretz USA mourns a man of peace and reconciliation. Condolences to his wife, family and all Palestinians and Israelis dedicated to peace. May we all see an end to violence and the murder of innocents. Harold M. Shapiro, President Charney V. Bromberg, Exec Dir

title: Sun Is Setting Over Realm of the Shoeshine King
description: Inside this smoke-filled joint, half a dozen shine men wait like hungry lions for the next customer to arrive at the door. Anyone will do. That is, anyone wearing leather loafers or wing-tipped Stacy Adams, some soft Italian-made stomps, or even women's pumps.

title: Happy Birthday, Viktor; Oh, by the Way, Checkmate
description: If you are being honored, you

title: Miami Is Just Blown Away
description: IMAGINE a scene in which thousands of lovely women are strutting the streets of an American resort city wearing nothing but bra tops, thongs and platform slides. Imagine a scene in which thousands of handsome men in Humvees and Chevy Suburbans are cruising those same streets, half-hanging out their car windows bare chested and leering. Imagine a scene in which hip-hop stars are mingling with hoi polloi, where the rapper Jay-Z shares the turquoise waters of a hotel swimming pool with 2,000 of his closest fans, where the rapper Eve goes clubbing with seemingly everyone who has ever heard her name, and where even the biggest pop stars -- Beyonc Knowles, say -- can be spotted ducking down a palm-lined sidewalk while the many male strangers convinced they will soon come to know her convey their greetings in the following fashion: ''Beyonc, yo! Holler on me, girl!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, EARL COOPER
description: SHAW-Earl Cooper. May 30, 2001. Loving father of Delicia ShawHitchcock and Brian Shaw. Cherised grandfather of Thomas ShawHitchcock. Brother of the late Odessa Anderson Shaw. Son of the late Edward and the late Fanny Shaw. Loving companion of Giselle DeKosinsky. Memorial service Thursday, June 7, 2001, 5:30 PM, St. Lukes Baptist Church, 139 Carroll St, Paterson, NJ; 973345-4309.

title: May 27-June 2; Trial Set for Accused Spy
description: Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent accused of 15 years of spying for Moscow, pleaded not guilty in federal court in Alexandria, Va. His trial was tentatively set for October. Adding to criticism of the bureau for its long failure to detect the alleged betrayal was a prison interview with an F.B.I. agent arrested for spying in 1996. Earl Pitts said he told agents then that he suspected Mr. Hanssen because he had tried to gain unauthorized access to the computer of another counter-intelligence official. James Risen

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01; And They Told Two Friends . . .
description: Many pleasing metaphors have emerged to describe the ways the transnational, time-contracting interconnectedness of the Internet has changed our lives -- it's a hive, it's a commons, it's a worldwide conversation. Little, if any, attention has been given to the idea of the global locker room. But consider the sorry tale of a young man working in Seoul for a private equity firm. His name is Peter Chung, and he wanted to tell his friends about his new apartment and his new life.

title: Better Homes and Gardens
description: DRINKING WITH THE COOK

title: A True Italian Now, Caught in a 'Beautiful Trap'
description: IN typical Italian fashion, Ferzan Ozpetek's new film, ''Blind Fairies'' (''Le Fate Ignoranti''), opens with an exquisite-looking woman being pursued by a handsome stranger. The man follows her through the spacious halls of a deserted museum as the ancient marble statues gaze like silent guests at an enchanted party. The woman rebuffs him at first, then playfully responds, her satin strapless evening gown glinting in the diffused light. Just as the viewer's mind races to the expected seduction scene, the two laugh and head for the car. They are husband and wife, but before the movie is over, it becomes clear that pretending to be strangers was the truest moment in a 15-year marriage spent pretending to know each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORTORA, LEONARD
description: TORTORA-Leonard. At sunrise, May 31, 2001. (Retired NYC Department of Housing). Survived by his brother Richard; his son Leonard Jr; and seven grandchildren. Also survived by an extended family of loving friends. Beloved father of the late Karen. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mount Carmel R.C. Church, on Monday, at 10:15 AM. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-10 PM.

title: MY FIRST JOB: SALIM A. L. BHATIA; An Early Lesson In Productivity
description: Salim A. L. Bhatia, 51, is the chief executive of MindLever (formerly the Empower Corporation), a Morrisville, N.C., company whose software lets companies train their workers online. He was a co-founder and former chief executive of BroadBand Technologies, now Pliant Systems.

title: CEMETERY; Bennington, Vt.
description: In the Bennington Centre Cemetery, Vermont's most historic, the trilling of robins and cardinals is occasionally drowned by the groans of downshifting 18-wheelers on nearby Route 9. The trucks, headed down the hill toward the new part of town, have just arrived from New York State, to the west, approaching from essentially the same direction as King George's mercenaries did in August 1777.

title: Keep That Mail Coming
description: T. Rowe Price has eliminated 200,000 duplicative mailings to investors so far this year, saving $110,000, but the cost-cutting effort hasn't gone entirely smoothly.

title: Here Come the Globe-Trotters
description: MANY people don't realize that around-the-world air fares are an astounding bargain, in some cases costing less than $1,000.

title: All-American East Coast Cruises
description: It's a small step, but American shipbuilding got a boost this spring when Delta Queen Coastal Voyages christened the Cape May Light at Alexandria, Va. The 224-passenger ship, a reproduction of an 1880's coastal vessel, was built in Jacksonville, Fla., and is now in service along the Eastern Seaboard, flying the American flag and carrying an all-American crew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGIN, WILLIAM
description: FEIGIN-William. On June 1, 2001 at age 63. Beloved husband of Nina, loving father of Robert, Andrew and Laurie, devoted fatherin-law of Linda, Alexa and Menachem, adoring grandfather of Yehoshua and Madeline. A service will be held Sunday, June 3rd., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY, at 12:45 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to the Silver Lining Foundation, 1490 Ute Avenue, Aspen, CO 81611. ''970'' 925-9540.

title: Spota Chosen to Run For District Attorney
description: Richard Schaffer, the Suffolk County Democratic leader, said last week he would support the Republican-turned-Democrat Thomas J. Spota of Brookhaven as the party choice to run for district attorney against James M. Catterson Jr., the three-term Republican incumbent.

title: Too Moderate for the G.O.P.? That's Old News in This State
description: Senator James M. Jeffords gave up on the Republican Par ty as it is constituted these days by the Southern suburbanites who run it -- turning himself into an independent.

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01: Questions for George Carlin; Oh, Happy Day
description: Q: Do you consider yourself a writer or a performer?

title: No Right Turns at the Truffles, Please
description: During peak shopping times, shoppers flow through the checkout lines at Fairway Market at a rate of nearly 1,000 an hour. The express line can snake to the front door, and the nonexpress lines, extending along the aisles, can stretch back to the fish counter in the rear. Sometimes well over 100 people are waiting for groceries to be rung up.

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Salt Lake City, May 19, 2001

title: Women Profit Less Than Men In the Nonprofit World, Too
description: The gender gap is not just a feature of business, law and medicine. In the nonprofit sector, too, women earn significantly less than their male counterparts, according to a new study based on 1998 and 1999 tax forms of 75,000 public charities.

title: It's Summer, but Somewhere Christmas Spirit Fills the Air
description: STRAINS of ''Deck the Halls'' fill the air as you stroll among rows of Christmas trees, each adorned with ornaments, one more enchanting than the next. An elaborate display of model villages tells wintry tales of skating and skiing and Old Saint Nick.

title: Adults at Disney
description: To the Editor: In ''It's a Small World, and It Rocks!'' (May 6), Jesse McKinley writes that as a 30-year-old man, he can enjoy himself alone at Walt Disney World. But he fails to address whether the Jell-O shots and scantily clad dancers in the areas he visited detract from the experience of Disney World for families.

title: COVERED BRIDGE; Ashuelot, N.H.
description: It is fitting that the word bridge is both a noun and a verb. Bridges are dynamic, incontrovertible proof to a traveler that progress is being made, that one has gotten from here to there. On a covered bridge, however, the movement is not only forward in space but also backward in time.

title: Retired at 30 From Vikings, Smith Seeks Different Goals
description: Even in retirement, the former Minnesota Vikings running back Robert Smith continues to make his quick moves. He is on the telephone, speaking to a member of the news media for the first time in months, and then, whoosh, he makes it clear he has no intention of returning to football. Then, whoosh, he sprints past a question about his plans.

title: FOOD; Shut Up And Munch
description: My mother had a theory of gaming: ''You play mah-jongg when you're young because it's mindless and you can talk about your marriage and your children. When your children are grown, you switch to canasta because it requires a little concentration, but not so much that you can't gossip about other people's marriages and children. And when you get old, you play bridge, because you've said it all and the game requires your full attention.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ELAINE OBERWAGER
description: JOHNSON-Elaine Oberwager. 81, of Somers, NY. Died at her home on May 26. Wife of the late James F. Johnson, III. Mother of Jeff Johnson and mother-in-law of Diane Johnson, both of Milford, PA. Grandmother of Christopher of Philadelphia and Alexander of Sante Fe, N.M. Memorial service at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, Somers, NY, Monday June 11, 2001 at 11AM. Interment at St. Lukes Memorial Garden. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Lukes Memorial Garden, PO Box 94, Somers, NY 10589.

title: The World Gets Tough On Fixing Prices
description: MEETING clandestinely at an airport hotel outside London, top executives from the leading makers of a crucial raw material for forging steel reached an agreement to set up a global cartel.

title: Quick! The Index!
description: The Columnist

title: Article 2001060392584181378 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Shhh! Gardens in Hoboken
description: Historians like to remind people that in 1825, John Stevens of Hoboken unveiled the first steam locomotive built in the United States, which he demonstrated on a 600-foot track near Hoboken. But lovers of camellia and chrysanthemum have Mr. Stevens, also a nurseryman, to thank for introducing these beauties to America in 1797 and 1798. The participants of today's Fourth Annual Tour of Hoboken's Secret Gardens will get to view some of the old-fashioned flowers and a few little-known gardens. Tours will leave every half-hour from the Hoboken Historical Museum, from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., and take about two hours. Tickets are $15. Information: (201) 656-2240.

title: Pathmark Workers Rally Against the Unkindest Cut
description: Rich Savner went last Wednesday from the Pathmark Stores headquarters in Carteret, N.J., to a union rally at the chain's supermarket on Richmond Avenue in Staten Island. But Mr. Savner is not a member of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. He is Pathmark's director of public affairs, and he came to the event, a protest of the company's practice of selling prepackaged meat, to learn how to rebut the union's claims.

title: Liberal Party Gives Hevesi Its Backing
description: The Liberal Party voted to endorse Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat and the city's comptroller, for mayor yesterday, calling him the ''right candidate at the right time to keep the city moving forward.''

title: 'Charlie's Angels' Trio Aims for Pop Success
description: THEY'LL sing a cappella for the asking or belt their way through fancy-footwork dance numbers.

title: Taking Chances
description: To the Editor:

title: What a Gift: Christmas All Summer Long
description: SPRING flowers are fading, summer ones about to bloom. Their gregarious groupings frame the exterior of the G&L Christmas Barn, its reindeer awash in Christmas lights, the holly above them swaying in the breeze. At the barn, tucked behind a house on a narrow stretch of Route 14 in the eastern Connecticut town of Windham, Christmas is a thriving business all year round.

title: Dipping Into Fun Like They Did in the Good Old Days
description: IN a Norman Rockwell world, the blazing days of summer would be mitigated by dips in the neighborhood swimming hole, a spring-fed escape complete with sunning turtles, leaning willow trees and a rope swing with which to arc high over the water. But as suburbs slowly swallow the earth, the ponds of childhood past have mostly been replaced by pools, often run by towns or neighborhood associations.

title: Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: It's Summer, Naturally
description: KERMIT THE FROG sang, ''it's not easy being green.''

title: Summer Sleep-Away Camp for Couch Fries
description: Take 34 unacquainted boys and girls between the ages of 12 and 14, throw them into unfamiliar territory far from home, and the result is likely to be more than a little drama.

title: For Art and Profit, On With the Shows
description: FOR the nearly 20 years that David Sekac was a machine operator in a metal works factory in Clinton, he dreamed of finding a job he loved so that he would not dread getting up every morning to go to work.

title: Freddie Trenkler, 88, Ice Skater Whose Specialty Was Comedy
description: Freddie Trenkler, a comic ice skater known for his ingenious and well-timed stumbles and falls, died on May 21 in Canoga Park, Calif. He was 88, according to the IceStage Archive of Minneapolis.

title: Swiss to Vote on Whether to Arm Their Troops
description: Posters showing row after row of cemetery crosses and slogans like ''Sacrifice our boys for foreign conflicts?'' are proliferating across Switzerland in one of the bitterest voting campaigns in memory.

title: Wild Cards
description: My family on both sides were all lake people. Dad's parents kept a place high on a dune on Lake Michigan, where you could see three lighthouses from the porch, and Mom's parents always had a house on a little lake called Magician, where they could fish and hunt pheasant. Those activities remained pretty abstract to me, except when my grandmother did it. She always outfitted herself like those photos you see of Carole Lombard, and I still have a lot of those clothes. Every winter, they'd go to Florida to fish too, and finally they bought a house there, in a one-story-hotel beach town on the Gulf side called Indian Rocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEGANT, BELLE
description: ELEGANT-Belle. On June 1, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Harry Elegant. Last surviving child of David and Minnie Goldfarb. Survived by loving nieces and nephews. Services Sunday, June 3, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: PBS and CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Jobs, a Generation Later
description: What ever happened to whiling away the summer days swimming, reading or just socializing with friends? More youths today are waiting tables, mowing lawns and ringing up cash registers than their parents did at their age.

title: I'm O.K., and Then Some
description: HEINZ KOHUT

title: From Ocean to Pond, With More Room to Swim
description: LAST spring, Martha A. Tacy, then a marketing director at the Lotus Development Corporation, was in a business meeting when she had an epiphany of sorts. ''All of a sudden,'' she recalled, ''I looked around and thought, 'What the heck am I doing here?' ''

title: WHITE CHURCHES; New Canaan, Conn.
description: I remember the archetypal white churches of New England from the days when I attended boarding school in a historic burg outside Hartford. I love their construction, clean and classic, and their steeples, which are sometimes visible from miles around, as they must have been to travelers of yore, wending their ways on horseback over hill and dale.

title: The Jackboot Has Lifted. Now the Crowds Crush.
description: MAGDALENA ABAKANOWICZ, the Polish artist, is on a roll. Her works in fiber, burlap and bronze have brought her wider international recognition in the last year. She has had five solo exhibitions in three countries -- one each in Italy and Poland and three in the United States. She has also received honorary doctorates in New York and Boston and special awards in New York, Rome and Berlin.

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: Goodell writes that Reeder believes ''grace will find its way into this tragedy. How, when, where . . . he doesn't know.'' But perhaps that grace is too close for him to recognize just now. He has come out of that crucible cooked down to bare strength and decency. I would not want to contemplate a time when I might need that example, but if it happens, I'll remember him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOPFER, WILHELMINE C.
description: KLOPFER-Wilhelmine C. In New Haven, May 31, 2001. Of 382 Central Park West, NYC. She was born June 13, 1909, in Berlin, Germany, daughter of the late, noted German Impressionist painter, Lovis Corinth and Charlotte Berend Corinth. She was an actress in Berlin Theatre in the 1930's. She was married in 1933 to Hanns Ewald Hecker with whom she had three children. Her second husband, Hans Klopfer, died in 1962. She was an author of a novel on life during World War II, ''Sechs Yahre Lang,'' an autobiography, ''Wilhelmine Corinth'' and a fictional account of a historical figure, ''Die Fahrfrau.'' Since 1965 her life partner was Russell Palin, who preceded her in death by five days; together they were award winning ballroom dancers. Survivors inlcude three children, Katherine Hecker Davis and George E. Hecker, both of Worcester, MA, and Michael H. L. Hecker of Danville, CA; four grandchildren, Zachary W. Davis, Suzanne T. Hecker, Steven L. Hecker and Serena Hecker Battles. Predeceased by a brother Thomas Corinth. Memorial service Monday, June 11, 2001, at 1 PM, in Christ Church, Park Ave at 60th St. The W. S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 504 Main St, Branford, CT. See obit at wsclancy.com.

title: Margery Fischbein, Mitchell Fried
description: Margery Beth Fischbein and Mitchell Stuart Fried are to be married today by Cantor Norman Summers at the Bernards Inn in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Warring Goals

title: At the Fed, 2 Opinions Of the Same Storm
description: ONE of the more interesting debates within the Federal Reserve has been the one between Alan Greenspan, the chairman, and Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor with a reputation as a doctrinaire inflation fighter. In recent speeches, on the same day but thousands of miles apart, they went at it again, in their indirect way.

title: Jett's Double Jeopardy
description: After an accident on the set of his television series, the teenage actor Jett Jackson (played by Lee Thompson Young, left) finds that he Silverstone, his action-star alias, have traded places in ''Jett Jackson: The Movie,'' a Disney Channel original film that has its premiere on Friday at 7 p.m.

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Free Peeks at Those Dancing Feet
description: IT'S true: Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick onstage together tonight, on your television: the devilishly incompetent Max Bialystock (''the biggest name on Broadway - 13 letters'') and the accountant with big dreams Leo Bloom (''I want everything I've ever seen in the movie''), heroes of ''The Producers,'' Broadway's biggest hit since Moses was a boy.

title: Childbirth Meets Luxury
description: Cindy Shipper rested comfortably with her newborn son, Tzvi, while his twin sister, Sarah, napped in a nearby nursery. Soon Mrs. Shipper would enjoy a fine meal, then fall off to sleep in her tastefully decorated room, complete with freshly cut flowers.

title: Before Shared Rentals
description: There was a time when bathing attire thoroughly covered the bodies of men and women, when few bathers went farther than knee-deep into the ocean and when huge, lavish hotels lined the bluff of Long Branch, attracting the well-to-do from all over. Little remains of those days except a beachfront park dedicated to the seven United State presidents who vacationed at the Jersey Shore. There is also a new book, ''Victorian Summers at the Grand Hotels of Long Branch, New Jersey,'' by George H. Moss Jr. and Karen L. Schnitzspahn (Ploughshare Press, $29.95), 120 pages of history, photographs, drawings and stereographs. The book recreates life in 10 hotels -- the United States, the Howland, the Central, the Continental, the Metropolitan, the Brighton, the Atlantic, Iauch's and the Stetson House and the Mansion House -- and takes readers on an outing to the new Monmouth Race Track. Karen DeMasters

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Big Brother Helps
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Defending Herself
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, DR. BENJAMIN C.
description: BERLINER-Dr. Benjamin C. A memorial celebration of Dr. Ben's life will be held at 11AM, Sunday, June 10, in the Chapel of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, located on Fort Washington Ave, just N. of 165th St. All those whose lives he may have touched are welcomed.

title: Marnie Davidson, John Rouse IV
description: Marian Livingston Davidson, a daughter of William A. Davidson of Washington, Conn., and the late Marian Jackson Davidson, was married yesterday to John Goldsmith Rouse IV, the son of Nancy R. Rouse of Baltimore and the late Mr. Rouse III. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: As You Cast, Watch Out for Low-Flying Planes
description: A 747 thundered down Kennedy Airport's southeastern runway, lumbering into the air just as Richard Reagan double-hauled 70 feet of fly line into the calm waters of Jamaica Bay. The plane banked to the west; Reagan stripped his line twice, and promptly hooked into another striped bass.

title: Barbara Estill; Civic Leader, 93
description: Barbara Banning Tweed Estill, a New York civic leader, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Historical Group Sees Its New Home Slipping Through Its Fingers
description: Time is running out for Paul Graziano and his supporters, who dream of giving historic old Flushing its own historical society. The problem is that their dream depends on quickly finding a way to buy a 19th-century house, costing $633,000, that would shelter the new group, the Flushing Historic Trust.

title: Alexandra Yurchyshyn, Rajesh Anantharaman
description: Alexandra lan Yurchyshyn and Rajesh Anantharaman were married yesterday by the Rev. Andrea Maier, an Episcopal priest, at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York. A Hindu ceremony will be held today at the Akbar restaurant in Edison, N.J., led by Poojari Krishna Bhattar, a Hindu priest. On Friday night, there was a Mehndi ceremony, in the courtyard of the couple's co-op building in Manhattan, where the bride's hands were painted with henna in order to celebrate her marriage and bring her good luck.

title: Once Republicans, Guyanese Immigrants Are Now Turning to the Rival Party
description: Vishnu Mahadeo, a math teacher at a middle school in Ozone Park, leaned across a booth in the Atlantic Diner on Thursday and talked about his passion: registering fellow Guyanese to vote in the United States.

title: Bucks Want Game 7 To Look Like Game 6
description: For most of five games, the Milwaukee Bucks' complaints raked across the Eastern Conference finals like fingernails on a blackboard. The Bucks spoke of conspiracy theories and sounded more concerned with winning friends and influencing referees than with beating the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: A Precocious Miler Inspires Hope for a Running Revival
description: The marquee outside South Lakes High School admonishes students not to drink and drive on prom night. It also says in athletic shorthand, ''Alan Webb now 3:53.43 mile.'' The time is even more magical than the prom, representing an achievement once thought to be as unapproachable as Babe Ruth's 60-home-run season or Bob Beamon's 29-foot Olympic long jump.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 3, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRISS, CATHERINE FAULCONER
description: FARRISS-Catherine Faulconer. Of New York City, died Friday, May 25, at Cabrini Hospital in New York. A memorial service will held Friday, at 5 PM, June 8, at First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. James G. Speer will conduct the service. She was the wife of the late Carter Wood Farriss. A native of Burlington, NC, Mrs. Farriss graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her lifetime career was in television and radio at NBC, where she was a staff writer for over 30 years. In 1985, she received an Emmy award for writing the NBC documentary entitled ''Chagall's Journey.'' She was a member of First Presbyterian Church, New York City. She is survived by a sister, Mrs. Nelson K. Reid of Burlington, three nieces and one nephew.

title: Forecast: Pleasant With Much Music
description: JAZZ violin, grand opera and what the artist Maurice Sendak calls ''a doodly life of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart'' are all part of the sixth annual International Festival of Arts and Ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORRIGAN, ETHAN
description: CORRIGAN-Ethan. June 3rd, 1962-June 11th, 2000. Love Forever.

title: TRACK CLOSES
description: Garden State Race Track is now officially closed, a victim of the legal and financial troubles of its owner, Robert Brennan, and the burgeoning of Atlantic City's casinos. Though the last day of live racing at the 59-year-old track in Cherry Hill was May 3, it continued simulcasting until last Tuesday evening. There will be a five-day auction starting June 22 of everything at the track from its barns to its restaurants' silverware. Developers hope to start work in the next several months on a $500 million housing, retail and park complex on the site.

title: Where Quaintness Isn't Skin Deep
description: IF it's possible anywhere to grab the very essence of a region in your hand it must surely be in New England. The elements seem so right, so close, so cozily familiar. From where I sit typing, without even craning my neck, I can see a classic red barn, a weathered stone wall, the white tapering of a church steeple, and -- staring into the distance now -- the mix of high meadow and hardwood forest that serves as the gentle backdrop for so much else. The distilled essence of New England, ready for bottling -- yes, it can seem that way, on a perfect spring morning like this.

title: Penalty for Health
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A NOTEWORTHY COLLECTION
description: This collection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 2000 Holiday Books issue.

title: Indian Museum
description: To the Editor: In ''A Ramble Around the Battery'' (May 13), there is no mention of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, which is in the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House at 1 Bowling Green, across from Battery Park.

title: The World: Iranian Elections; Where the Victor May Not Win
description: IMAGINE an American president standing before a cheering crowd to announce his candidacy for re-election with these words: ''Personally, I'd prefer to be somewhere else.''

title: Reckonings; Watt Price Ideology?
description: I once had a math teacher who responded to student errors by saying ''Save that answer -- I may ask that question someday.'' I thought of him after George W. Bush's apparently pointless trip to California.

title: Marlins Make Mets Look Like Winners
description: Stress-free games have been so elusive for the Mets this season that even triumphs have left them exhausted.

title: David Young Dies at 71; Painter and Friend to Jazz Artists
description: David X. Young, a painter whose rodent-infested, illegally rented loft became a citadel of jazz improvisation and experimentation in the 1950's and 60's, died on May 22 in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Keeping Track of Time
description: Mark Hamill of ''Star Wars'' fame is the voice of Larry 3000 (above left), a know-it-all robot who works with Officer Buck Tuddrussel (center) and Otto Osworth in the year 100,000,000 to prevent history from being remade in the new series ''Time Squad'' (Fridays at 9 p.m. on Cartoon Network).

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01: The Ethicist; Ankles Away
description: I play soccer for my town club team, and we are about to face our biggest rival. Their best player, a midfielder, just got over a sprained ankle. Without him, we have a great chance to win, but if he plays, we will likely lose. Some of our defensemen are talking about hitting the ankle so he gets hurt again and can't play. Is that dirty play or just part of the game? T.H., Connecticut (age 14)

title: In the Region/Westchester; Getting New Offices by Remodeling Old Buildings
description: INSTEAD of erecting new structures, real estate investment trusts and developers in Westchester County are converting abandoned office buildings that once housed Fortune 500 companies into more marketable space.

title: Big-Time Resentments In a Tiny Pocket of Queens
description: Six years ago, it seemed Meadowmere's troubles might be over.

title: An Early Document From a True Radical
description: THERE was a time, back in the 60's, when ideology mattered. Not just in politics, but in movies, too. And no filmmaker was more ideological than the Italian director Gillo Pontecorvo, who left little doubt about his sympathies when he depicted the 1954 Algerian uprising against the French in ''The Battle of Algiers'' (1966) and a slave revolt on a Portuguese-held sugar island in ''Burn!'' (1969).

title: In Control, but Losing a Grip
description: DICK CODEY had reason to feel victorious as the state's leading politicians gathered at the Doral Forrestal Hotel Conference Center in Plainsboro one night in April. Mr. Codey's political strategy -- after a year of planning and calculating -- was falling into place.

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: Jeff Goodell captured Patrick Reeder's raw suffering. His intimate, empathetic interview compelled me to read every word of an article I didn't want to start in the first place.

title: Q & A
description: Exploring Alberta

title: The Help of Strangers
description: THERE they are: stupefied on the corner of Fillmore and Broadway, not even glancing at the drop-dead views of the Golden Gate Bridge shimmering before them, but instead scrutinizing the same scene on their glossy hotel giveaway map. Though I'm out for exercise, as a longtime resident of San Francisco and a travel writer, I can't resist the urge to come to their rescue. I cross the wide avenue and offer to help.

title: A Scenic Crossing, And No Traffic Jams
description: COLONIAL farmers relied on ferries to take themselves, their pigs, sheep, cows, and horses across the Connecticut River. Now most of the old roads with the word ''Ferry'' in their names just end at the shore.

title: Spotlight on McCain
description: For the second time in about a week, Senator John McCain asserted today that he had no intention to bolt the Republican Party and run for president as an independent. All the while, some of his closest advisers floated that he, indeed, was mulling a third-party bid.

title: Article 2001060391038629999 -- No Title
Capriati Keeps Things Simple Amid Renewed Success
description: Once, there were product patches sewn on Jennifer Capriati's tennis sleeves, turning her body into billboard space for sponsors. And there were corporate appearances at every stop, turning her free time into a valuable commodity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEELEY, JOHN J.
description: FEELEY-John J. Of Summit, NJ, formerly of East Chester, NY, on June 1, 2001. Husband of Eileen Feely (nee Egan), father of Michael J. of Summit, NJ, brother of Mary F. Feeley of Brooklyn, NY. Also survived by four grandchildren John, Pamela, James and Michelle, and one great-grandson Ryan Michael Feeley. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday, June 6, 2001, at 9:30 AM, at St. Teresa of Avila Church, Summit, NJ. Visiting will be held on Tuesday, June 5, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. Interment Holy Mount Cemetery, Tuckahoe, NY.

title: For Dad and Daughters, A Three-Ring Circus
description: IN the land of the Cartwrights, winter is actually summer. All vacations, all chances to catch a breath, happen in the cold. ''You never get used to it,'' said Jerry Cartwright, flanked, as always, by women, before hastening to add that although summer vacations are as foreign to him as moon dust, he likes things exactly as they are.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERENBACH, HANNAH SMEDLEY POWERS
description: FERENBACH-Hannah Smedley Powers. Age 85, died June 1, 2001, at Evergreen Woods in North Branford, CT. Born in Conyngham, PA, on December 27, 1915. Preceded in death by her husband Carl Ferenbach. Survived by son Carl Ferenbach and wife Judy, her daughter Polly Ferenbach Franchot, two granddaughters, Jennifer and Alexandra and great-granddaughter, Elizabeth. Memorial service Wednesday, June 6, 11 AM at St. John's On The Mountain in Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers memorials preferred to the Alzheimers Association.

title: Getting a Fix on Wines
description: As summer approaches, wine and food magazines focus increasingly on Long Island wine. I've come across material in Saveur, Wine Enthusiast and Wine Spectator.

title: BackTalk; Getting Behind the Wheel, Feeding a Soon-Insatiable Desire
description: Once again, I felt the need for speed. But this time, I wanted to mash the gas myself.

title: The DVD Boost
description: To the Editor:

title: Safin Self-Destructs in the Middle of a Comeback
description: There is not a caution light or a warning signal to mark the moment when the talented Marat Safin will dissolve on the court. He does not ease into trouble as much as he plunges toward it.

title: On Back Roads, It's Stop, Chat and, Oh Yeah, Fill 'Er Up
description: IT'S a breezy summer afternoon and you have decided to venture off the main roads, perhaps in search of antiques. You're so diverted that it takes a while to realize that the gas gauge is perilously close to empty.

title: Real Horseplayer Guiding N.Y.R.A.
description: Barry Schwartz had recently been named chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Racing Association and was eager to talk about his vision for thoroughbred racing. His childhood friend and the namesake for the multibillion-dollar company they founded together, Calvin Klein, was calling from Italy to talk business.

title: Arafat Calls for Cease-Fire, Deploring Tel Aviv Attack
description: For the first time since the latest Israeli-Palestinian violence began eight months ago, Yasir Arafat made a public call this afternoon for an immediate and unconditional cease-fire and also condemned the suicide bombing that killed 18 young Israelis outside a Tel Aviv nightclub on Friday night.

title: Reporter's Notebook; New Plea in Mob Case: Not Guilty, Just Stupid
description: Aside from the quadruple bypass surgery, the ventricular arrhythmia, the cerebral vascular disease, the Basal cell carcinoma, the abdominal aortic aneurysm and the peptic ulcer, Rudy Casale has problems.

title: As if Gucci Could Get Any Hipper
description: Fendi Baguettes, silk flowers and name necklaces have all gained trend status through the miracle of air time on ''Sex and the City.'' Now, Gucci's belt bag, a logoed version of the fanny pack usually seen around the waists of train conductors and tourists, is basking in the glow, months before it's even to appear on screen.

title: Hotels on the Web
description: To the Editor: Regarding Bob Tedeschi's article ''Working the Web for Hotel Rooms'' (Cyberscout, May 13), the disclosure by the Hotel Pennsylvania in a Web listing that the rooms available for booking had not been renovated may or may not excuse his bad experience there. But that excuse does not apply in our case.

title: A Living Primer of 20th-Century Causes
description: I COULD talk about Trude Lash,'' said David Tobis, executive director of the Child Welfare Fund, a prominent social services foundation. ''But first I have to confess that I'm completely and utterly in love with her.''

title: POSTINGS: Groundbreaking Set for the Fall; For Wave Hill, A $4 Million Visitor Center
description: Wave Hill, the combination urban garden and cultural institution that graces 28 acres of the Riverdale section of the Bronx along the Hudson River at 252nd Street, will soon have something it has not had since it opened to the public in the late 1970's -- a separate visitors center.

title: Political Briefing; McConnell Says Paper Is Out to Get Him
description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, a Republican conservative up for re-election, says the state's leading paper, The Courier-Journal of Louisville, is out to get him and his wife, Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao.

title: Canada Declines Extradition Request in Missile Parts Case
description: ACanadian judge has rejected an extradition request for two men wanted in the United States for trying to buy American-made missile parts and ship them to Iran.

title: Arrest Me, Please (But Jail? No Thanks); Rediscovering the Price of Protest
description: Civil disobedience has an enduring and noble history. As long as human beings have made laws, they have broken them out of principle.

title: Too Young for Bars, Too Old for School Scene
description: I am a 19-year-old college student and live in Wantagh at home during the summer. Like some of the people mentioned in ''Babylon Cracking Down on Hot Rodders' Mecca'' [Long Island Journal, May 27], we are too young for clubs and bars but too old to go to our old high school hangouts.

title: Down the Diesel Road: Problem or Solution?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost Imbalance In Prescription Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: May 27-June 2; Investigative Fever in France
description: Are France's aggressive new investigative magistrates going to succeed in putting corrupt officials in jail? Dozens of prominent officials from across the political spectrum who are being investigated -- including President Jacques Chirac -- have new reason to think so. In a case that transfixed the nation with tales of sex and greed, prosecutors said the flamboyant former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, had arranged for his mistress to work at a state-owned oil company and then benefited from the nearly $9 million it showered on her over four years. A Paris court found him guilty of illegally accepting gifts. Mr. Duman, 78, was sentenced to six months and fined $130,000. Suzanne Daley

title: How Do You Make A Movie Sing?
description: Isn't anyone going to mention that there was a rather important 1952 movie called ''Moulin Rouge,'' with music by Georges Auric? It was directed by John Huston and starred Jose Ferrer as Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and Zsa Zsa Gabor as one of the women in his life. At least one of its songs became a favorite on the pop charts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPER, FRANCES
description: SAPER-Frances. Of Great Neck, NY, on June 1, 2001. Beloved wife of Harold. Loving mother of Gary and Myles Schumer, and motherin-law of Judy Schumer and Anne Riney. Adored grandmother of Paul, Rina and Lauren Schumer. Active in her Great Neck community for almost 50 years, she was past secretary of the Great Neck United Community Fund and longstanding member of the Great Neck Garden Club. She will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed by all who knew her. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nasau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: Curiously, my heart soared while reading about Reeder's inspirational opposition to the death penalty. It is precisely because we can feel such a desire to do violence to violent criminals that we should not.

title: How Do You Make A Movie Sing?
description: Sad that amid a multi-tude of sentimental choices (''The Sound of Music,'' ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'') there was no mention of Dennis Potter's works, which seem far closer in spirit and style to Luhrmann's film than do the traditional musicals mentioned. ''Pennies From Heaven'' and ''Lipstick on Your Collar'' (the latter with Ewan McGregor in a leading role) both employ existing pop songs, executed with outlandishly extravagant production numbers amid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSERMAN, PAULINE
description: ESSERMAN-Pauline. 101 years. Former resident of Forest Hills, died Saturday, June 2. Survived by her niece Judith Feuer and her nephew William Rosenberg, five great-nephews, one great-niece and several cousins. Beloved wife of the late Frank Esserman. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Unsettled Plains
description: Data from the 2000 census reinforces what we have known for decades now, that the population of the Great Plains -- from eastern Montana and North Dakota right down through the semi-arid states of South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma and West Texas -- has been dwindling away.

title: May 27-June 2; A New Tune on Missile Shield
description: With NATO allies sharply skeptical of missile defense and the Senate crossing over to Democratic control, the Bush administration has come to the conclusion that it does, after all, need Russia's cooperation in scrapping the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The administration is drafting incentives that might include buying Russian surface-to-air missiles for a future defensive shield. Some of the potential proposals, including joint antimissile exercises, military assistance and sharing early-warning data, were discussed in the first Bush administration and pushed by President Clinton. Both Russia and the United States concede that until proposals are on the table, there is nothing to accept or reject. Thom Shanker

title: Meaghan Reilly, Christopher Schaefer
description: Meaghan Spencer Reilly, a daughter of Margaret Connorton Reilly of Gulf Stream, Fla., and the late Dr. Philip Cullen Reilly Jr., was married last evening to Christopher Edward Schaefer, the son of Marianna and Edward Schaefer of Lafayette, Calif. The Rev. Howard V. O'Shea, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Why Chain Stores Aren't the Big Bad Wolf
description: ARE chain stores evil? I know people who think shopping at Home Depot is immoral, that Barnes & Noble is a blight. As for myself, don't get me started on Wal-Mart; every time I go to one, stocking up on stuff for my family at the lowest imaginable prices, I feel a pang of guilt.

title: Covered Calls Can Erase Some Risk
description: IF you think the equity markets are likely to drift, vacillating between the favorable impact of lower interest rates and devastating corporate earnings, you may be a candidate for strategies that offer the investment equivalent of a bird in the hand.

title: The Tax Bill Up Close: Some Facts, Some Tips
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has fulfilled his promise that every American who pays taxes will send a smaller check to Washington. But under the legislation passed by Congress and awaiting his signature, the greatest and most varied tax-trimming opportunities will go to Americans who earn the most and save the most. And people with similar incomes and even similar circumstances will get widely varying benefits, with people in higher-tax states in the Northeast and the upper Midwest faring worst.

title: Rewriting the Rules
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: May 27-June 2; 4 Convicted in Bombings Of U.S. Embassies in Africa
description: Four men were convicted in New York on charges of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, which killed 224 and wounded thousands. Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24, and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, could face the death penalty; Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, 36, and Wadih El-Hage, 40, face life terms. The trial, which began in February, offered a new vision of Mr. bin Laden's group, no less menacing than the old, but more loose-knit, at times torn by dissension and betrayal. Some members defected over salary disputes. Benjamin Weiser

title: A Mile in Their Shoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty Is All Business in Defeating Fever
description: Before the Liberty took the court at Madison Square Garden for its home opener yesterday, Joan Jett, the rock star and the team's No. 1 celebrity fan, sang ''Unfinished Business.'' Last season, the Liberty embraced that theme in pursuit of the Women's National Basketball Association title, which has eluded its grasp in the league's four years.

title: What's With the 19-Foot Head? A Sculptor Is Counting on Drivers to Ask
description: Every road has its landmarks, and the Taconic State Parkway is no different. Apple-red barns and grand overlooks of the Catskills break up the monotony of endless miles, and give weary drivers something to check their odometers by.

title: Kim Sitomer, Daniel Kahn
description: Kim Loren Sitomer and Daniel Steven Kahn will be married today by Rabbi Marc A. Gellman at Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills, N.Y.

title: Private Sector; She Gets the Last Laugh
description: Living well can be the sweetest revenge, and at the Financial Women's Association annual dinner last week, there was a lot of sweet revenge in the air. Founded 45 years ago by eight Wall Street women who were denied membership in the Young Men's Investment Club, the association drew 1,100 people to the event, which featured taped tributes from such Wall Street leaders as David H. Komansky, chief executive of Merrill Lynch, and Sanford I. Weill, chief executive of Citigroup, as well as dais guests who included Reuben Mark, chief executive of Colgate-Palmolive, and Harold W. McGraw III, chief executive of the McGraw-Hill Companies.

title: As Bowling Alleys Close, the Survivors Get Glitzy
description: EDWIN (TED) GUY has bowled for 46 years. He remembers the 1970's, when New York City supported 172 bowling alleys. The game was inexpensive, played mostly by families and leagues, and players worked hard to develop their skill.

title: Hold the Airs
description: AN AMERICAN BISTRO is the sort of restaurant that defiantly refuses to put on airs. It is what it is. Even its name is a kind of dare: more Italian-American than American, more trattoria than bistro, it was christened when the chef and owner, a homegrown Nutley guy named Ken Mahon, heard a friend say that a place with such a nondescript name could never succeed.

title: Around the Campfire, Good Times and a Good Deed as Well
description: REMEMBER sleep-away camp? Living in wooden cabins, swimming in the lake, telling stories around the campfire under a star-studded sky?

title: May 27-June 2; Putin's Arm Lengthens
description: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, toppled one of the last monoliths of the Yeltsin era: the natural gas monopoly Gazprom. Since his election last year, Mr. Putin has taken steps to rein in regional barons and to banish powerful businessmen from the corridors of the Kremlin. Gazprom, Russia's largest taxpayer, which had used its financial might to frustrate government efforts to reform it, will now be run by a Putin ally. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Albany on Your Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: A Portrait of Shattered Brilliance Comes Together
description: ON a fine spring day, with the Princeton campus in fragrant, pastel bloom, John Forbes Nash Jr., winner of the 1994 Nobel in economic science, is making his daily rounds. He spends the morning at home, working on computations for an article he is hoping to publish. About noon, he stops in at the Institute for Advanced Study, where he eats lunch and talks shop with some colleagues at the math table. Finally, in the late afternoon, he enters his campus office at Fine Hall, the mathematics building, where he is meeting a reporter for an interview.

title: A Groupie Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin Case Raises Issues On Its Impact
description: Hal Sutton, a veteran P.G.A. Tour player, wondered aloud the other day whether Casey Martin's United States Supreme Court victory last Tuesday would spur other golfers to get a golf cart, too. Any number of players have bad backs, he observed, himself included.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNAN, JOSEPH
description: HANNAN-Joseph. An advertising executive, died at New York Hospital on May 30, 2001. He was 71. Mr. Hannan was senior vice president and member of the Board of Directors at Benton & Bowles, later DMB&B, where he was responsible for the Texaco account. He introduced Texaco to a long and successful association with the Bob Hope Specials in the 1970's and supervised many of the productions. Mr. Hannan was born and raised in New York City. He graduated from the United States Military Academy, West Point, in 1952 and served in the Regular Army Airborne Infantry in Korea. From 1955-56 he was assigned Aide-de-Camp to the Superintendent at West Point after which the Army sent him to study International Affairs at Princeton. In later years he served on the U.S.M.A. West Point Board of Visitors, the highest position afforded a civilian. Mr. Hannan was a longtime supporter of St. Jude Hospital in Memphis, Tennesee and served on the ALSAC-St. Jude Board of Directors and Governors from 1992 to the present. St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is widely recognized for providing treatment to children who suffer catastrophic illness. His daughter, Alexandra Scott, of New York City, survives him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Monday, June 4, 57 PM. There will be a service at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington at 66th St., Tuesday, June 5, 9:45 AM.

title: More Heavy Metal
description: Two new sporty luxury cars are taking shape in Germany, as shown in these artist renderings. The BMW 6-series cabriolet may arrive in two or three years; a coupe version will also be offered. The next generation of the high-end Mercedes-Benz SL goes on sale in Europe this fall. It is expected to have an elaborate folding metal roof.

title: Melissa Hart, Kevin Traskos
description: Melissa Hart, a daughter of Phyllis Cox of Denver and Robert C. Hart of Houston, was married yesterday to Kevin Thomas Traskos, the son of Margaret and Richard T. Traskos of Brooklyn, Conn. Judge John L. Kane of Federal District Court in Denver officiated at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo.

title: Humans Learn a New Trick: Sharing Dinner With Fido
description: PEGGY GEISSLER'S nephew raided the refrigerator one night and ate an entire container of dog food. He wasn't acting out -- he thought it was homemade stew. Ms. Geissler, a career development consultant in Little Silver, N.J., was thawing turkey, brown rice and broccoli crowns to feed to her two West Highland terriers. ''I always used to feed my dogs only the premium brands, but if you read the labels, you still don't know what's in them,'' said Ms. Geissler, who switched to so-called human-grade pet food to try to cope with the dogs' chronic skin and digestive troubles. ''This way, I know I'm doing all I can to keep them alive as long as possible.''

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Foe of Reno Revives A Miami Fugitive's Case
description: Even in a city jaded by the antics of its public officials, the case of a former Miami-Dade County commissioner still reverberates here as one of its most bizarre.

title: Brookhaven Honored For Public Openness
description: Three years after coming under new management, Brookhaven National Laboratory has been named Organization of the Year by the International Association for Public Participation, a nonprofit group that promotes local involvement in public and private institutions.

title: Joy Mayo, Joel Robinson
description: Joy April Mayo, a freelance writer, and Joel Harris Robinson, a lawyer, were married last evening by Cantor Debra Stein at Gurney's, a resort and spa in Montauk, N.Y.

title: Travel Advisory
description: ASlice of Rome Becomes an Open-Air Museum

title: Letters on Travel
description: Lost Bank Cards

title: The Professors and the Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison Mosher, Stephen Birmingham
description: Alison Ann Mosher, a daughter of Mr. and Mr. Giles E. Mosher of Waban, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Douglas Birmingham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Birmingham of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. William Murphy, the vicar general of the Archdiocese of Boston, performed the ceremony at St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in Waban. The Rev. J. Donald Monan, the chancellor of Boston College, took part in the service.

title: Naturally
description: Pollan opened my eyes. I related particularly to the direction he took at the end of his article: I agree that genuine organic eating is a matter of choosing what you consume and choosing to support local agricultural enterprises. This is what the organic-food movement was, and still is, about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, JUDY GRAF
description: KLEIN-Judy Graf. Dear sweet Ma. Mother, daughter, sister, friend, artist and architect. Judy Graf Klein passed away in her home on June 1. She is survived by her daughters, Adina Sabrina Klein and Oleanna Joanna Graf Klein; her mother, Diane M. Graf; and her brothers, Peter M. Graf and Ronald J. Graf and their families. The space your absence creates in our hearts is as vast as the universe. The funeral will be held Monday, June 4, at 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). Donations may be made to Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, New York, NY 10014.

title: Political Briefing; No Jobless Pay For 'Fired' Legislator
description: Remember David Jaye, the Michigan state senator from the Detroit suburbs who was expelled by his colleagues a couple of weeks ago?

title: Naturally
description: Why stop with the organic Twinkie? Perhaps Big Tobacco can snuggle up to Big Organic and create the ultimate organic cigarette. After all, to paraphrase Gene Kahn, ''If the consumer wants it, then we should give it to him.''

title: The Professors and the Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Raindrops Keep Falling on Mein Head
description: The Victorian Visitors

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Southport, Conn.; Community That Guards Local Traditions
description: LOCAL affluence has polished the harbor village of Southport to a fine luster over the years. When development threatens the historic landscape, checkbooks open and the community closes ranks.

title: Journey's End
description: You are 7 years old, a farm child in Afghanistan, or you are 5, or 12. For three years the winter rains have failed, and you have watched your father harvest tiny patches of wheat only a foot high. Your milk disappeared when he sold the goat for food. Your mother began to stretch the bread flour with grass. Finally, defeated by the worst drought in 30 years, your family abandoned house and farm and started walking toward food. Your father bribed the family's way past the sealed border into Pakistan, and you joined a stream of Afghans flowing into a stretch of dust and misery now bursting with nearly 60,000 people. The place is called Jalozai.

title: Alexandra Walsh, Brendan O'Brien
description: Alexandra Margaret Walsh, the daughter of Philip C. C. Walsh of Pinecrest, Fla., and the late Margaret Ann Walsh, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts to Brendan Francis O'Brien, a son of Joyce and William O'Brien of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Eugene McKenna, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown.

title: Royal Bloodbath Suspect Is Nepal's King, for Now
description: The bizarre massacre of most of Nepal's royal family was followed on Saturday by the bizarre ascension to the throne of Crown Prince Dipendra, a love-struck young man who, by most accounts, murdered his parents and at least seven other relatives during the family's Friday night meal.

title: Nureyev as He Wanted to Be Seen
description: PBS will do Rudolf Nureyev as well as the dance public a service Wednesday night when it broadcasts, as part of WNET's ''Great Performances'' series, a digitally remastered print of ''Don Quixote,'' the historic film Nureyev made with the Australian Ballet in 1972. As a bonus, the movie is preceded by a documentary about his career, written with masterly concision by the critic Robert Gottlieb.

title: Memoir of a Beatnik
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Train, Into Summer's Arms
description: SUMMER does not truly arrive until school is out. It doesn't matter whether you are actually going to school any longer or not. It doesn't matter if you are sitting in an office all day or are crammed in the middle of a three-seat bench on your way home in a commuter train. Because when you step off of that train, summer has often come to the station to greet you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD
description: MENDIK-Bernard. Dear Bern, the world and our lives are diminished by your absence. We have always loved you and will always miss you. Our love, loyalty and support go out to Suzy and all the family. Barbara and Arny Hodas Susan and Laurie

title: Corrections
description: Travel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOHN H., MD.
description: McGOVERN-John H., MD. Retired Professor of Surgery, Department of Urology, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and past President of the American Urological Association, died on May 28, 2001, in Sarasota, FL. Born in Bayonne, NJ, Dr. McGovern built a successful urology practice in Manhattan before retiring to Long Boat Key, Fl in 2000. Dr. McGovern was a Merchant Marine veteran of WWII, a graduate of Columbia University and Downstate Medical College. He was also a member of the prestigious American Association of Genito-Urinary Surgeons. He is survived by his wife, Mary Alice; four sons, John H. Jr., Esq. of Brooklyn, NY; Dr. Robert P. of Vero Beach, FL; Ward M. of Old Orchard Beach, ME and Raymond F. of Little Ferry, NJ; two sisters, Anne Rumage of Ortley Beach, NJ; and Katherine Kalinak of Linden, NJ and four grandchildren. A memorial Mass will be held in Manhattan at St. Ignatius Loyola on Monday, June 11, 2001 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the James Buchanan Brady Foundation c/o Darracott Vaughn, MD, 525 East 68th St., New York, NY 10021.

title: The Week in Review: May 27-June 2
description: Convicted in Bombings of U.S. Embassies in Africa

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on the co-opting of organic foods by big business prompted urgent calls to return the movement to its roots. Readers said that if any good is to come from the Oklahoma City bombing, it will be in the grace with which those like Patrick Reeder have come to terms with the tragedy.

title: Stephanie Kleban, David Simon
description: Stephanie Bracha Kleban, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dennis Kleban of Potomac, Md., is to be married this evening to David Evan Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Simon of Muttontown, N.Y. Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence, N.Y.

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert H. Lyon; ICAP Select Equity Portfolio
description: ATTENTION, investors: the free ride is finally over, according to Robert H. Lyon, who runs the $52 million ICAP Select Equity Portfolio.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Michael Rips; About That Year in Italy
description: IT'S not every night that Jean-Georges Vongerichten gives up his most coveted tables in front of the open kitchen at Jean Georges for a private dinner for 29. But the guest of honor Wednesday was his friend Michael Rips, who has just published a first book, ''Pasquale's Nose'' (Little Brown), a memoir of a year in Italy.

title: Zimbabwe Doctors Flee As AIDS Crisis Widens
description: Like the rest of the country's hospitals, Mpilo Central is sick.

title: A Chef Moves Pots, Pans and His Name
description: METEOROLOGISTS may insist that we have a few more weeks of springtime left, but Hamptonites know that summer arrived last weekend. This year's crop of East End restaurants spent most of May scurrying to open in time for the official start of the season on Memorial Day weekend. Some savvy restaurateurs even jumped the gun and debuted during the quiet days of winter.

title: Headbanger's Ball
description: Fargo Rock City

title: In Public, Making Them Look at Least Twice
description: DID you know the tree of life is growing in Farmington? Or that in Bridgeport simple tools of the trade are breaking down walls stronger than brick? Were you aware that in Willimantic a 16-foot-high book is an open door, or that an aquatic core sample cascades down three stories just a few hundred feet from Long Island Sound in Groton? Did anybody ever point out the words of the 18th-century Scottish economist Adam Smith illuminating the way to greater understanding in New Britain?

title: Anne Pidgeon and William Callender
description: Anne Cordingley Pidgeon, a daughter of Susan and James C. Pidgeon of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to William Nicholas Callender, the son of Catherine and Robert L. Callender of New York. The Rev. Edward F. Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Linda Farley, Justin McMahan
description: Linda O'Donnell Farley, a daughter of Ellen and P. Robert Farley of West Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Justin Thomas McMahan, the son of Carol and Thomas McMahan of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Kaaren Anderson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Diamond Point Community Church in Diamond Point, N.Y.

title: White House and Unions Look for Common Ground
description: In a mutual recognition of reality, the Bush administration and labor unions are courting each other for help on various issues, from energy policy to improved pension rules.

title: Sandra Angulo, Hans Chen
description: Sandra Patricia Angulo, a daughter of Diana Angulo Iber of Miami and the late Dr. Luis H. Angulo, was married yesterday to Hans Harris Chen, a son of Wa Helen Chen and Chi Paul Chen of Camp Hill, Pa. The Rev. James Grubb officiated at Grace United Methodist Church in Harrisburg, Pa., and Jorge H. Angulo, a brother of the bride, took part in leading the service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 20 about Republican and Democratic efforts to find political advantage in the nation's current energy problems misstated the period of the Arab oil embargo. It was 1973-74, not during the administration of Jimmy Carter, who was in office from 1977 to 1981.

title: A stop for rice sweets and tea
description: Teahouses, or tabang, are an integral part of Seoul's social scene. They are scattered throughout the city, but an unusually large number are in Insa-dong, in the center of the city. Teahouses offer a place for people of all ages to get together and hang out. A cup of tea with a plate of traditional Korean rice sweets may be $4 to $5, and you can relax, gossip, read and people-watch as long as you like.

title: Tony Awards' New Jersey Ties
description: NEW JERSEY may be far removed from Broadway but you wouldn't necessarily know it looking at this year's list of Tony Award nominees. More than a dozen contenders have Jersey connections.

title: Ideas & Trends; Rascal or Racist? Censoring a Rabbit
description: AFTER Cartoon Network acquired the rights to all the Bugs Bunny cartoons, it announced, in early May, that it would celebrate by holding a marathon 49-hour broadcast of the entire Bugs oeuvre -- the first complete airing ever. Then the network blinked.

title: Cynthia Sulzberger, Steven Green
description: Cynthia Fox Sulzberger, a daughter of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York and the late Carol Fox Sulzberger, was married last evening to Steven Benjamin Green, a son of Joanna Green and Peter J. Green, both of New York. Rabbi Alon Levkovitz performed the ceremony at the Ark Project, a cultural center in Water Mill, N.Y.

title: Sour About Their Choices, Peruvians Are to Vote Today
description: With polls showing a tightening race and many voters disillusioned or undecided, Peru's presidential election on Sunday may yield no clear winner, but another difficult challenge for the country's young democracy, international observers say.

title: Benefit of Hamptons Without the Benefits
description: The special Long Island section of May 20 reminded me of the many enticements of summer on this island. Born here, I keep moving east to enjoy the relatively unspoiled beaches, bays and farmland that are a Long Islander's true heritage. But, contrary to an East Hampton real estate agent's comment in ''So Many Benefits, So Little Time,'' many of us are not here for the frenetic summer ''scene.'' Some rent their homes for a month or two during the summer and enjoy the East End the 10 other months of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBERG, ISRAEL
description: SILBERBERG - Israel. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of its esteemed member, Mr. David Silberberg, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert Chairman J. Ezra Merkin President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, SARA
description: BLAUSTEIN-Sara. The Ratner and Popowitz families and all the employees of Joseph Ratner Company grieve with our dear friend Norman Blaustein and his family over the cold blooded and brutal murder in Israel of his beloved wife, Sara. Words are utterly inadequate to express our heartbreak, sorrow and outrage at this shocking and senseless act of terrorism. Caryl Ratner and Marc Popowitz Joseph Ratner Company, Inc.

title: Berryhill Hangs On To Win the 1,500
description: Bryan Berryhill of Colorado State held off last year's winner, Gabe Jennings of Stanford, to win the 1,500 meters at the N.C.A.A. championships last night in Eugene, Ore. He finished in 3 minutes 37.05 seconds, the fastest time ever by an American in the N.C.A.A. 1,500.

title: Gouri Orekondy, Alexander Edlich
description: Gouri Orekondy, the daughter of Barbara C. Orekondy and Dr. Basavaraja S. Orekondy of Ballston Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alexander Ryan Edlich, the son of Marsha L. Edlich of New York and the late Stephen P. Edlich. Judge Arlene Hahn of Bronx Civil Court officiated in Manhattan.

title: STYLE & ENTERTAINING; Give 'Em A Hand
description: Of All the Gin Joints . . .''When I'm in town, we play gin every Tuesday night,'' says Pat Buckley, in the library of her Park Avenue maisonette, where without exception Johnny Galliher, Richard Heanue, Paul Wilmot and George McNeely convene for a friendly hand. Nowadays, she laments, ''everyone's gone toward gin instead of bridge, but frankly, bridge rolls your mind more. It's a better game.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, MARTIN
description: BLAU-Martin. On Thursday, May 31, of Fairfax, VA. Beloved husband of the late Cynthia Klein Blau. Father of Russell Blau and Clifford Blau and Lauren Halverson. Grandfather of Justin, Ian Blau and Christopher, Jonathan Halverson. Private funeral services Arlington National Cemetery. For information, Jefferson Funeral Chapel, Alexandria, VA.

title: HARBOR; Camden, Me.
description: When visiting Camden, Me., be sure to take a moment -- perhaps when strolling through Harbor Park, where a spirited stream cascades into a colorful, yacht-filled harbor -- to ask yourself whether there's a single Hollywood set designer today who would try to pass this off as a real location.

title: Continental Is Winning A Carry-On Battle
description: United Airlines has removed the luggage sizers it had at Dulles Airport outside Washington on a concourse it shares with Continental Airlines, but is appealing an April court decision requiring removal of the templates, roughly 14 inches wide, about 10 inches high at the center and 9 inches high at the sides.

title: Tuning In to Summer
description: HERE is a sure sign that it is summer (or at least another season pretending to be): the ice cream truck. Hear it approach with its tinkling promise of quiescently frozen carbohydrates. Hear it slow to a predatory crawl. Wait for the sound of children running, out of breath, in search of change. Say no, and hear feet stomp and whines of protest. Say yes, and hear the whoop of delight, children running to the truck, calling for it to wait.

title: Bill Passed Assuring Students' Safe Return
description: The New York State Legislature has approved a bill making school districts accountable for assuring the safe return home of students on school trips.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Snapshots of Summer Past Soothe Fears of Camp
description: When Rafaela Gonzalez's son Joseph was 9, she let him go away to the country for a three-week summer vacation. She knew it wouldn't be easy -- for her. ''I cried and cried. I'm Hispanic, and we tend to hold on to our kids,'' she said. ''It was horrible for me, but it was great for him. I realized that my child needed that experience.''

title: Takeover Targets Shine, Even During Dark Days
description: FOR investors, the major stock indexes have not been the place to be during the last seven months. The Standard & Poor's 500 has lost 12 percent and the Nasdaq is down 40 percent. Only the Dow Jones industrial average has managed to eke out a gain, of 2.7 percent.

title: Another War Is Threatening Central Africa
description: Burundi, where competition for power between an ethnic Hutu majority and a Tutsi minority has caused hundreds of thousands of deaths in several decades of sporadic fighting, may be on the brink of a new war, a Security Council mission and a leading independent conflict-prevention group warned this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUEL, FRANCES
description: SCHUEL-Frances. Loving mother of Dr. Herbert Schuel. Cherished grandmother of Victor and Barbara Schuel. Services were held June 1, 2001.

title: Montreal to Denver On In-Line Skates
description: Eric Messier, the Avalanche's industrious left wing, played professional hockey six years ago in Montreal, much like the Colorado goaltender Patrick Roy. The similarities end there.

title: Article 2001060391558252730 -- No Title
description: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

title: Article 2001060392815803241 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: ARREST IN KILLINGS
description: Breaking open a case that had frustrated the police in three states for nine years, authorities in New Jersey last week charged a 50-year-old Staten Island nurse with killing and dismembering gay and bisexual men in the early 1990's. The suspect, Richard W. Rogers, was arrested in Manhattan for the murders of a 57-year-old Massachusetts executive in 1992 and a 44-year-old male prostitute in 1993. The case rests largely on the work the of the State Police, who used advanced technology and computers to match Mr. Rogers's fingerprints with those lifted from garbage bags in which the remains of the two victims had been dumped in Ocean County. The authorities in New York and Pennsylvania are seeking evidence that would tie Mr. Rogers to at least three other murders Thomas J. Lueck

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUSE, BENEDICT W.
description: KRUSE-Benedict W. In Pasadena, CA. Author of books on education, high school journalism, biography of father, New York artist A.Z. Kruse. Survived by wife Bettijune, children, Liane and Richard Enkelis, Steven and Penny Kruse.

title: Beth Carey, Bryan Hanypsiak
description: Beth Erica Carey, the daughter of Bonnie and Christopher Carey of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Bryan Todd Hanypsiak, the son of Christine and Jerry Hanypsiak of Tonawanda, N.Y. The Rev. Carmine Rita performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville.

title: Ideas & Trends: Hi, Society; For New York's Social Swim, Money Is Always in Fashion
description: AN attractive young British journalist named Jessica Brinton came to America recently and conquered New York society -- a beach of sparkle and tinsel chronicled in the fashion pages and gossip columns of newspapers and glossy magazines. The measure of her success, like that of so many social aspirants since the advent of the rotogravure, was the velocity at which her photograph appeared in a variety of publications -- including the Sunday Styles section of The New York Times.

title: For the Love of Potatoes
description: THE BOTANY OF DESIRE

title: Personal Business Diary: Loans Among Friends
description: The stories are common enough: A parent provides a child with a car loan, a brother lends a sister money to get by after a layoff or a friend gives another friend start-up money for a business.

title: A Majority of One
description: We are all living now in Sandra Day O'Connor's America. Take almost any of the most divisive questions of American life, and Justice O'Connor either has decided it or is about to decide it on our behalf. The Supreme Court may tell us soon whether affirmative action in public universities is permissible, and if it does, O'Connor is likely to cast the deciding vote. The court is divided about school vouchers too; O'Connor's views will probably tip the scales.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Mixed-Use Project Planned for Pilgrim State Land
description: FOR more than 30 years, since the state began deinstitutionalizing patients at its psychiatric centers and auctioning off surplus property, the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood has been the subject of many redevelopment proposals, including those for an incinerator, a state prison and a major sports complex. Community opposition helped to defeat those plans, but the center -- which occupied one of the largest unused tracts in western Suffolk -- remained the object of controversy as well as litigation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the takeover of a Mexican bank by Citigroup misidentified the party whose 71 years of national dominance ended when Vicente Fox won the Mexican presidency last year. It is the Institutional Revolutionary Party, not the Democratic Revolutionary Party.

title: Pool or Gym? A Task Force Chooses Both
description: Gym or pool. Pool or gym. Members of the West 59th Street Recreation Center have spent eight years debating how to spend $2.6 million given to the center first by WABC, then by Tishman Speyer Properties in exchange for rights to build nearby. Some residents wanted to repair the outdoor pool, closed since 1990. Others lobbied for a gymnasium.

title: Firefighters Are Ready to Rescue a Space Shuttle in Distress
description: Space shuttles launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they head north. If such a shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where it can make an emergency landing is the New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Fighter Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport. There, firefighters attached to the 177th Wing will get the astronauts out in a hurry. Tech. Sgt. Joseph Bannon, one of those firefighters, talked about the rescue plans.

title: Floral Gems in Pretty Little Packages
description: GARDEN lovers in the tristate area are lucky. Horticultural showplaces like the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, Skylands and Old Westbury Gardens are within easy driving distance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHEY, JULIA A. (NEE JACKSON)
description: FAHEY-Julia A. (nee Jackson) on June 1, 2001. Born November 11, 1919. Beloved wife of the late Edward J. Fahey, otherwise known as Jewel. Dearest sister of Mary Engels. Loving mother of Sister Elaine Mary G.N.S.H. and Marilyn Ann and her husband Vincent Malanga. Cherished grandmother of Lauren Ann and Vincent Michael and his wife Elisha. Reposing at the Harden Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 209th Street. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Monday Sacred Heart Church in Bayside at 9:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Bound for Glory
description: THE MUMMY CONGRESS

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Where Mozzarella Is a Star, Not a Topping
description: John Amato, owner of Fiore's House of Quality in Hoboken, no longer gets riled when he sees the things people do to his mozzarella. ''Thirty years ago, I would've been shocked, but now I've seen everything,'' he said. ''They put mustard on it, even vinegar. You shouldn't do that because you don't want to alter its nutty, milky flavor.'' Nutty? Milky? If those adjectives never come to mind when you eat mozzarella, you've probably been eating too much of the low-grade stuff sprinkled over pizza. At Fiore's, the mozzarella ($6 a pound) is made fresh daily according to the recipe Alfonse Fiore used in 1913 when he founded the store. The process starts with whole-milk curd, which is paddled in boiling water for 20 to 30 minutes until it reaches a taffylike consistency. Cook it too long and the cheese will be rubbery; too short, and it will be bitter. How does he know when it's done? ''It's all in the feel of your hand,'' he said.
