Mr. Amato remembers delivering to Frank Sinatra's mother on Hudson Street. Shipments continued to the Sinatra home in Palm Springs until about a decade ago. Instead of topping mozzarella with mustard or vinegar, try it plain, with a little extra virgin olive oil, or with tomatoes and basil. Or come on Thursdays and Saturdays and order the daily special: a roast beef sandwich with fresh mozzarella ($7.20; $3.20 for a half sandwich). But come early, because lines have been known to stretch out the door. GRETCHEN KURTZ

title: What's Doing in Newport
description: In Newport, a longtime summer capital for jazz, mansion touring and sailing, city officials are scrubbing a colloquialism from the local lexicon  Zooport, used in the early 1990's when well-heeled weekend 20-somethings swarmed in, packing "party houses," and carousing till dawn.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Sunday reported on the popularity of current events discussion groups. It quoted Daniel A. Salmon, an educator and chairman of the executive council of Professionals and Executives in Retirement, an organization based at Hofstra University that sponsors discussions and social events for retirees. He told of having joined the group 14 years ago and said that as a result ''I have more friends now than I ever had in my life.''

title: Political Briefing: McConnell Says Paper Is Out to Get Him
description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, a Republican conservative up for re-election, says the state's leading paper, The Courier-Journal of Louisville, is out to get him and his wife, Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao.

title: Counting Small Coins Has Meant Small Profit
description: ITS business plan seems one of simple beauty: persuade people to deposit tons of coins in a nationwide network of machines, which dispense no product, and then keep 8.9 percent of all this cash as a fee.

title: Addiction to Auctions: You Have to Have a What?
description: ONE warm evening in April, Brian Doyle told his roommate, Rick Harman, that he was going out for a while. Mr. Harman thought little of it, assuming that his friend was just doing a few errands. But Mr. Doyle didn't come back for two hours and when he did, he was buzzing with adrenaline.

title: Saving Betty
description: THE first time Betty, my feisty pit bull/boxer mix, didn't run to get her dinner, I discovered her cowering on her blanket, suddenly covered in a mass of welts and unable to get up. This was shocking. She was only around 6 and hadn't had a bad-health day since I rescued her from an owner who was beating her on Third Avenue a couple of years ago.

title: Political Briefing; Helping Women Win In South Carolina
description: There are only two women in South Carolina's 46-seat State Senate and 17 in the 124-seat State House of Representatives. So no one should be surprised, say some prominent women, that studies often rank South Carolina 50th in the nation when it comes to electing women to public office.

title: The Nation: True Colors; The Confusion Over Who We Are
description: EVER since the framers of the Constitution reached a compromise to count black slaves as three-fifths of a person, racial numbers have been about political power. In contemporary America, the apportionment of political power on the basis of population, the use of race in the drawing of legislative districts and racial bloc voting have prompted people to inflate their numbers. Or at least fear their dilution. That was why several civil rights groups and the Congressional Black Caucus opposed allowing people to choose more than one race on the 2000 census.

title: May 27-June 2; A New Old Giant
description: A new dinosaur has emerged from the sands of an Egyptian oasis, apparently the second most massive species ever found. Judging by its enormous bones, the plant-eating dinosaur, named Paralititan stromeri, measured up to 100 feet from head to tail and weighed as much as 70 tons, heavier than a military tank. (Only a South American giant, Argentinosaurus, was heftier -- by some 30 tons.)

title: May 27-June 2; Nurturing a Colt's Inner Superstar
description: Wander through the back of Belmont Park this week as the finest 3-year-olds prepare for the 133rd Belmont Stakes on Saturday and you'll see some strange devices being used on the thoroughbreds.

title: Naturally
description: Pollan's article was both prescient and poetic. It really is about eating to save our local landscape -- a form of artistic expression, no less.

title: Beating the Bank: Loans Among Friends
description: The stories are common enough: A parent provides a child with a car loan, a brother lends a sister money to get by after a layoff or a friend gives another friend start-up money for a business.

title: BOOKS FOR SUMMER READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 2000. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web. www.nytimes.com/books

title: Sports of The Times; Discovering Pain Of Team Mascots
description: I'LL never forget the day the Mariner Moose broke his leg. He was doing a water-skiing shtick on in-line skates, crashed into the outfield fence and lay there quivering. We all figured the grounds crew and the medics were part of the act, until it turned out he needed screws in his lower leg.

title: Crisp, Sweet, Floral Wines Help Top Off the Season
description: PUT aside brawny reds. Except for medium-bodied reds like Beaujolais, which is delicious with grilled hamburgers, truly gratifying summertime wine drinking shifts toward serious and breezy whites and ross.

title: The Deaths That Divide Us
description: DEAR Kids:

title: Minus Starter, Yanks May Seek Relief
description: Brian Cashman's counterparts in 29 other front offices would snicker, maybe even howl with laughter, if anyone suggested that the Yankees could come up short in starting pitchers.

title: Naturally
description: Having worked on small organic farms, I'm with the ''beyond organic'' farmers. ''Organic'' should mean more than food grown without petrochemicals.

title: Enjoying Summer, Naturally
description: THE summer we fantasize about when we are shoveling two feet of snow is one of frolicking on the beach, snipping a perfect rose from the garden, and cultivating a Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue tan.

title: MONUMENT; Concord, Mass.
description: On a recent bright chilly April morning, I managed to pay a visit to the ''Minute Man'' in Concord, Mass., before the weekend bus tours arrived. Just across the North Bridge he stands, midstride on a rough granite pedestal, Daniel Chester French's notion of a warring colonial farmer.

title: Sports of The Times; The Many Scarred Faces Of the Finals
description: HOCKEY players always talk about the honor of having their names engraved on the Stanley Cup, but their faces should be there instead. Those faces with all their scars and scabs.

title: Seating Arrangements, Sort Of
description: Sid Mellman knew that the party he was planning at his Victorian summer house in this inland Cape May County town was a more-than-one-commode event.

title: Charities Think Pink
description: If green is the color of envy, and yellow the color of cowardice, then pink is the color of . . . charity. Or so it seems this season, judging from the rose-hued array of designer items, tailor-made for charities. On the heels of Ralph Lauren, who offered part of the sales from his $52 Pink Pony T-shirt to benefit cancer research, Tod's is earmarking part of its earnings from the sale of pink-trimmed driving moccasins (below, $325) for Cure Autism Now and Jobs for the Future. Last month, Anne Fontaine introduced a pink cotton shirt, available through October (left, $150 at all Anne Fontaine boutiques), with some of its sales directed to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation. Miracles and Wonders, a breast and ovarian cancer research group, will receive proceeds from sales of a pink evening watch by Corum (top, $1,250 at Saks Fifth Avenue), while Philosophy's Gift Horse nail strengthener (top, $20 at www.philosophystore .com) will benefit the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation. And Pasquale Bruni is selling a white-gold pendant with pink rhodolite stones on a pink silk cord ($850, at 212-218-7858), with some proceeds helping the charity Children's Action Network. When charity meets the worlds of fashion and Hollywood, it can become a rose-colored spectacle.

title: Turkish Delight Inspires a Sitcom in Manhattan
description: Surrounded by tacky furniture and lots of marble in a suburban mansion close to New York City sits a frustrated, balding, middle-aged man. He makes a good living, but the daily stress keeps him on edge. He has recurrent nightmares about the past, which he confides to a sensible-looking female therapist.

title: Lost Bank Cards
description: To the Editor: Reading ''Lost Bank Card: Trouble Abroad'' by Toni L. Kamins (Practical Traveler, May 6) reminded me of a trip last summer. I was robbed of my wallet and all its contents, including my passport, on Oxford Street in London.

title: The Ivy Walls Are Climbing
description: Matthew Harrigan did not need an alarm clock last semester. A construction crew working on the Genomics Institute -- with its 7 a.m. start time -- would wake him on mornings he had class as well as on mornings he did not.

title: Roy Leaves His Net and Lets Devils Back Into the Series
description: As good as Colorado Avalanche goaltender Patrick Roy has been in front of his net, he made a game-turning mistake behind it tonight when he vacated his crease to play the puck.

title: For Jazz, and the Next Generation
description: DIXIELAND music, also known as traditional or New Orleans jazz, is not something ordinarily associated with teenagers.

title: Naturally
description: Putting organics into the hands of value-neutral corporate profiteers is a sad turn of events. Organics are about life-promoting values, not stock values.

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01: On Language; Er, Um, (ahem!)
description: A well-watched Russian newscast called ''Naked Truth'' is anchored by a woman with a serious expression who slowly strips as she recounts the major events of the day. The weather forecaster is topless. Above the A.P. article about this news uncoverage, The Seattle Times carried the headline ''Russian Anchorwomen Do the Nudes, er, News.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, GRACE
description: FORD-Grace. On May 22, 2001. Loving mother of Lorette (Michael) and James (Patricia). Beloved grandmother to Sheila, Kathleen, Erica, and Adrienne. Devoted great-grandmother to Meghan and Ethan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROWER, ARNOLD
description: OSTROWER-Arnold. At sunrise, on June 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Ellen, devoted brother of Rhoma, uncle, great-uncle, greatgreat-uncle, marvelous friend. He was born with the gift of laughter and a sense of the magic of words. Above all, he was a good and gentle man. We will miss him so much. Services Monday, June 4, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St.

title: Sexual Attacks In City Schools Are Up Sharply
description: Sexual attacks in the New York City public schools are occurring at a rate of 10 per week, up sharply in the last two years and uncommonly high even after accounting for the sprawling size of the school system, the nation's largest.

title: Bringing in Public Radio, and Bringing People Together
description: BROADCASTING wasn't something Jay Allison planned on as a young man. He was more interested in acting and riding around on his motorcycle. ''I was sort of a ne'er do well,'' Mr. Allison said. But in 1977 a friend who worked at National Public Radio in Washington talked him into coming by. Intrigued, he began to stop in at night, more to hang out than to work, until his friend loaned him a tape recorder.

title: May 27-June 2; Back on Speaking Terms
description: Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, accepted an invitation from India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, to meet soon in New Delhi. The two nuclear-armed enemies have not held formal talks in more than two years. While the Indians have a range of matters to discuss, the Pakistanis want to focus on Jammu and Kashmir, the beautiful Himalayan territory at the heart of their long-standing rancor. India controls two-thirds of the disputed region, Pakistan the rest. Barry Bearak

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Concerns For Pitching Cloud a Day Of Hitting
description: Baseball has its own version of Groundhog Day, and it does not occupy a particular place on the calendar. It is that first day when the ball seems to rocket from home plate, fueled by humidity, and pitchers stand and stare into the shadow of many home runs. It felt like summer for the first time at Yankee Stadium yesterday, some hitters mentioning how great it was to see the ball really carry for the first time.

title: Governors Island Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Stops Restored, Smiles Return
description: Four bus stops cut from the B82 line in Bensonhurst were restored last weekend, after hundreds of people protested the change.

title: Board Meeting Today
description: Present-day fashion is going in so many strange directions, from the sloppiness on the street to the joke designs on Paris runways, that it appears to be ready for a nervous breakdown. This spring, a few women seen in Paris and New York are taking refuge in the Dutchess of Windsor's impeccably neat, highly polished simplicity. The style, set in motion by Mainbocher in the late 1930's in reaction to Schiaparelli's surrealistic hijinks, avoids extremes and focuses on the perfection of fit and proportion. What rules is the wearer's knowledge, confidence and uncompromising authority to know what looks correct for her figure and in her life. As the dutchess said of Paris couture: ''It doesn't matter what they show. I go into the fitting room with my fitter and change everything to what I want.''

title: The Cost Imbalance In Prescription Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Marjorie Harris and Basil Smikle Jr.
description: THREE days before May 26, Marjorie Fields Harris's wedding day, when most brides would have been busy with rehearsals and last minute arrangements, she was feverishly working the phones. Ms. Harris, the executive director and second in command of the National Action Network, the civil rights organization headed by the Rev. Al Sharpton, was trying to get her boss out of jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VENOKUR, NATALIE ANAPOLSKY
description: VENOKUR - Natalie Anapolsky. March 7, 2001. Loving wife and mother. She loved New York and was a proud Bostonian. Smart in business. Loved life. Full of laughter and loved you unconditionally. Brought love and laughter into everyones life. Helped the homeless always and gave herself selflessly to many charities. Wife of the late Harold Venokur and sister of the late Eleanor ''Tootsie'' Newman. Survived by a son Jonathan, a daughter Babette, a sister Barbara Whitman and three nieces Beth, Lori and Patty. Your laughter and your great love for us will live on forever. She was our best friend. Goodbye Mom, we'll miss you. Unveiling at a later date. Laid to rest New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: A Little Fresh Air to Whet the Appetite
description: TEN years ago it took just a few fingers to count off the number of places with outdoor dining. Most offered something special besides the food: panoramic views of a lake at the Lake Waramaug inns (Hopkins, Birches and Boulders), of a serene landscaped lawn (Roger Sherman Inn, New Canaan), of a river (Silvermine Tavern, Norwalk, and the Gelston House, East Haddam) or of the Sound (Water's Edge, Westbrook).

title: Where Heaven Touches Down
description: THE GEOMETRY OF LOVE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERG, INGOLF H.
description: LAMBERG-Ingolf H. Of Chatham, MA, died Friday, June 1, 2001. He is survived by his beloved wife Isabel.

title: Melrose Journal; 5 Dogs, 3 People and One Immaculate Bedroom
description: There have been countless stories about the rich and their dogs: about doggie day care, doggie co-op interviews, Herms dog carriers. This is a story about the animal passions of the economically average, or below average, the people who live in a one-bedroom or just one room, doubled or tripled up, on minimum wage or in the working class. These are the people for whom pets are a real luxury, both in dollars and in space, the people who could logically be expected to give up their pets when times grow tougher or apartments become even more cramped.

title: For Mets' Zeile, Power Shortage Raises Concern
description: MIAMI, June 2  The way Todd Zeile sees it, after 10 major league seasons, he can be expected to average around .268, hit 20 home runs and drive in 80 runs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROS, JANET
description: BURROS-Janet. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Janet Burros, beloved mother of Mara Sandler, who with her husband, Ricky, are devoted leaders of UJA-Federation. Ricky has been an active member of our Wall Street Division, and recently became chair of the Investment Advisors Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mara and Ricky; to Janet's husband, Robert; to her son, Chet; and to her entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHO, JIN
description: CHO-Jin. May 22, 2001. 24 years old. Everyone who knew Jin has been deeply affected by this tragic loss. He lived on the Upper East Side and worked as a real estate agent at Prince Properties LLC, while pursuing a degree in sociology. As a child, Jin emigrated from Korea to New York with his family. Jin was a loyal friend, colleague and dedicated son and brother. Jin had warmth and a passion for life. He will surely be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him.

title: Protoceratops Lays an Egg
description: Dragon Hunter

title: It Started With Eve
description: Fast-Talking Dames

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Wearers of New Shoe Styles Imagine a Benign City
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ruling Is Puzzling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Almost Famous
description: KARYN QUACKENBUSH was at the Hourglass Tavern on West 46th Street with her husband, celebrating his birthday over dinner and a glass of wine, when her beeper went off. It was 9:07 p.m. on March 14, 2000, and she knew exactly what she had to do. She had to go to work.

title: Blood, Sweat And Tears. Ah, Softball.
description: THIS is the story of the most memorable meaningless game of the season.

title: Blacks, Whites and Blues
description: LT. PAUL BRENNAN, the commander of the 34th Precinct Detective Squad in Upper Manhattan, was recalling the day 18 years ago that he got off the train at 125th Street in Harlem and began his police career, a white man in a black world.

title: A Character Actress With a Soft Center
description: MAY was a month of homecomings for Randy Graff. More than a decade after she won a Tony Award for her featured performance in ''City of Angels,'' her name was again called, this time as a nominee for best leading actress in a musical for her role in ''A Class Act,'' Lonny Price and Linda Kline's show about the life of Edward Kleban, the talented and troubled ''Chorus Line'' lyricist. Shortly thereafter Ms. Graff revisited her alma mater, Wagner College on Staten Island, where she spoke before the 2001 graduating class and was given an honorary doctorate.

title: Artists' Community Flourishes in Peekskill
description: SINCE 1991, Peekskill has been evolving into a promising artists' community. As it stands today, there are a dozen galleries and more than 100 artists with more on the way.

title: TRAVEL
description: NOTHING organizes a journey better than the pursuit of an elusive goal. For a goal, no matter how frivolous or unattainable, can lend tension to the most circuitous of trips and bring cohesion to the wildest string of anecdotes. Almost any goal will do -- or so a stack of new travel books suggests. The writer's quest can be a weighty affair: an investigation into the status of Africa's dwindling white enclaves or a comparison of post-revolutionary Iran with the country remembered from childhood. But it can also be fanciful: finding proof of the existence of the queen of Sheba or checking the accuracy of Asia's fortunetellers. The goal in question can even be a hedge.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JEFFREY SALTZMAN; Motivating Workers in Uncertain Times
description: THE weakening economy and a rising number of layoffs have left many employees wondering if they are next to be dismissed. That can't be good for morale. Corporations now have to figure out how to motivate their workers in uncertain times. Often, they turn to outside help.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Do I contribute to my 401(k) excessively? No. It's not a fatalistic thing, it's realism. I lost an awful lot of friends.''

title: Melissa Levin, Matthew Greenhawt
description: Melissa Beth Levin, the daughter of Maxine Levin and Dr. Ronald Levin of Fairfield, Conn., is to be married today to Dr. Matthew Jason Greenhawt, the son of Jan and Jeffrey Greenhawt of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Leon Waldman will officiate at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Radioactivity Slows Glen Cove Creek Plans
description: IN one of the most ambitious redevelopment projects in recent Long Island history, the city of Glen Cove has been striving for years to convert gritty, industrial Glen Cove Creek into a nautical showcase lined with shops, restaurants, promenades, boat slips, a ferry terminal and a hotel and conference center with views of Hempstead Harbor.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Birenda, 55, Ruler of Nepal's Hindu Kingdom
description: King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, who was shot to death on Friday in a massacre of Nepal's royal family, was a proud but isolated monarch whose reign began in absolutism and ended in uneasy partnership with democracy.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on May 13 misspelled the surname of the president of the American Institute of Biological Sciences, who commented on the usage of the word ''theory.'' She is Judith Weis, not Weiss.

title: A Slice of Rome Becomes an Open-Air Museum
description: Who knows how many tourists have followed the path of Audrey Hepburn as she skipped down the Spanish Steps in Rome and into the best holiday of her life? These steps, presided over by the Trinit dei Monti Church, are one of the icons, along with the Trevi Fountain and the Pantheon, of the Tridente, a triangular area in central Rome recently declared an open-air museum by city officials.

title: May 27-June 2; Indonesia Moves to Impeach
description: A long-running political drama in Indonesia entered its final act, as Parliament voted to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid. Mr. Wahid denounced the legislators for overreaching and threatened to declare a state of emergency, which would allow him to dissolve Parliament. He then dismissed his security minister, who opposed that idea. But the president also appeared to be trying to strike a deal to stay in power with his estranged vice president, Megawati Sukarnoputri. Mark Landler

title: For New Trump Neighbors, Proximity Breeds Discontent
description: Last year when Allison Smith moved into the Santa Monica Building at 345 West 70th Street near Freedom Place, she knew that a Donald Trump condominium would be built perhaps 3 to 15 feet to the west. A few weeks ago, though, she found out that the new building would loom nine inches from her kitchen and dining room windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERLOCK, THE HONORABLE DULCIE, ANN STEINHARDT
description: SHERLOCK-The Honorable Dulcie-Ann Steinhardt, on Memorial Day, May 28, 2001, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved wife of the late Squadron Leader Allan Arthur Sherlock, RCAF, DFC and BAR, CD. Devoted mother of Laurene Ann Sherlock of Bethesda, MD, Victor Allan Sherlock and his wife Ruth Burns Sherlock of Greenville, SC; loving grandmother of Abigail Ann and Christopher Allan Sherlock of Greenville, SC. Mrs. Sherlock is also survived by her cousins Ambassador Peter R. Rosenblatt, of Washington, DC, Robert W. Rosenblatt of Ithaca, NY, Richard D. Rosenblatt of Rancho Santa Fe, CA, and other relatives. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC, on Sunday, June 3, from 5-7 PM. Funeral services will be held at 12 noon on Monday, June 4, at All Saints' Episcopal Church, 3 Chevy Chase Circle, Chevy Chase, MD. Interment to follow at Rock Creek Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the the United States Air Force Academy (Steinhardt-Sherlock Trophy), 2304 Cadet Drive, Suite 351, US Air Force Academy, CO 80840-5002; or the Hospital Relief Fund of the Caribbean, c/o Peter Tropper, Treasurer, 4715 Crescent St, Bethesda, MD 20816.

title: Article 2001060393920537020 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Indian Reservations Join the Tourist Circuit
description: WHEN Vergil and Rosita Bedoni founded Totem Pole Tours 10 years ago in Monument Valley, on the Navajo Reservation straddling Arizona and Utah, they lived in an old trailer while waiting for the occasional tourist to show up to be driven through the Valley's majestic red buttes and spires. But these days so many tourists visit Monument Valley and other American Indian reservations from April through October that the Bedonis and their three children have little time for themselves.

title: Private Sector; Putting Themselves in an Institution
description: Muhammad Ali. Burkina Faso. Accenture. P. Diddy. And the Institute for Supply Management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYWARD, HOWARD BOYNTON
description: HAYWARD-Howard Boynton. 85, of Vero Beach, FL, died May 26, 2001, at Indian River Estates Medical Center. Mr. Hayward was born February 21, 1916, in Brooklyn, NY, resided in Scarsdale, NY, for 60 years. He was raised in Bronxville, NY. He was a graduate of the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, NJ, and a World War II veteran. He spent most of his career in advertising, largely with Rubin H. Donnely, and was a member of the Squadron A Club in Manhattan, NY. Survivors include his wife of 59 years, Margaret Hayward of Vero Beach; two daughters, Deanne Moynahan and Brooke Morell both of Rye, NY; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Rye. Friends may make contributions to St. Jude Childrens Research Hospital, PO Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101-9929, in memory of Mr. Hayward. Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach.

title: From Foie Gras to Kimchi, Eclectic Menus in Seoul
description: IT'S been 20 years since my last visit to Seoul, and in that time, the city has transformed itself into a sophisticated, cosmopolitan center with broad avenues that are reminiscent of Western cities. Despite the glamour of soaring skyscrapers and chic designer boutiques, its spirit remains distinctly Asian -- from the thriving all-night markets where vendors offer extraordinary bargains on every type of goods imaginable to the charming traditional teahouses where customers trade gossip, nibble on sweet rice pastries and sip fragrant tea.

description: BALLERINA!

title: ROCHE LAYOFFS
description: Despite first-quarter reports of increases in sales worldwide, the pharmaceutical giant Roche AG, the parent company of Hoffmann-La Roche, last week announced that it would eliminate 350 jobs at its United States headquarters in Nutley, as well as 500 national sales positions that report to the Nutley office. The company plans to eliminate 3,000 jobs worldwide in an effort to reduce expenses. The employees will be laid off after this week.

description: It's a bird, it's a plane, it's Perelman.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Loeb, Corey Salsberg
description: Dr. Sandra Beth Loeb, the daughter of Jill and Bernard Loeb of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Corey Andrew Salsberg, a son of Andrea and Richard Salsberg of Montvale, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar will officiate at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGGINS, ANNIE
description: WIGGINS-Annie. On May 31, 2001. Beloved mother of the late Dr. Brenda L. Wiggins. Devoted grandmother of Chantal KadhiSmith. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home (Nagel), 352 E. 87th St, between 1st and 2nd Avenues, Monday 4-9 PM. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church (145th St).

title: In Mexico, Stocks Rise As Growth Slows
description: WHEN America sneezes, the saying goes, Europe catches a cold. Using this logic, Mexico should be stricken with the flu.

title: Camden Is Ready to Rock
description: As if having 'N Sync at Giants Stadium this week wasn't enough to set every New Jersey girl's heart aflutter, radio station Q-102 has some pop-music plans of its own. Today's Q concert features a variety of Top-40 pop stars including the Latin sensation Ricky Martin and three international singing stars -- Jessica Simpson, Samantha Mumba and Nelly Furtado, who seems poised for a career as a vocalist even grown-ups would like. Also on the bill are Evan and Jaron, who perform a more thoughtful pop-rock style, and Shaggy, who has promised to bring his infectious dancehall reggae hits like ''It Wasn't Me'' and ''Angel'' down to PG-13 from their usual R-rating. Two unusual additions -- the manufactured-for-television Eden's Crush and their male counterparts, the uninspiring O-Town. Also on board, Ja Rule and 3LW. Ever wonder what heaven is to a teenager? The show starts today at 4 p.m. at the Tweeter Center in Camden. Robbie Woliver

title: True Northeast
description: VILLAGE GREEN

title: BEST SELLERS: June 3, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 20 about the film producer Jerry Bruckheimer misstated the duration of his marriage to Linda Bruckheimer. It has been 8 years, not 20 or more.

title: Summer Clothes: Defining Yourself With Favorites
description: MY all-time favorite summer clothing is a pair of faded jeans from high school.

title: Bettor's Delight Captures New Jersey Classic
description: As the horses made their way around the first turn at the Meadowlands tonight in the $500,000 New Jersey Classic, Bettor's Delight was one length behind the leader.

title: VILLAGE GREEN; Craftsbury Common, Vt.
description: A white village on a plateau: as you approach from the west, Craftsbury Common is suddenly there, rising out of the wooded slopes of Vermont's Northeast Kingdom like some modest version of John Winthrop's ''city on a hill.''

title: Flexible Airline Tickets Via the Internet
description: A new Internet service allows passengers on four airlines to transfer or sell tickets, including nonrefundable discount tickets, for less than the $100 standard charge for changes. FairAir.com, based in San Francisco, has signed one major carrier, Northwest, and three smaller ones -- America West, Midway and National -- for the service, which began May 22, and is trying to attract other carriers, said Frank Levy, the founder and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMLEY, BERNARD
description: BROMLEY-Bernard. On May 26, 2001 at age 74, of Boynton Beach, FL and Woodmere, NY. Survived by beloved brothers David and Howard and daughter Amy. Memorial service planned.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUSTER, WALLACE
description: SCHUSTER-Wallace. Wally dear, four years have passed. We miss you terribly. Your legacy has always been and always will be, how can I help? We will always love you. Your Sister Phoebe and the Entire Schuster-Lewin Family

title: Christmas Rush? Yes, It's Time
description: IT'S June 3, and not a moment too soon to think about the Christmas-New Year's holidays. In mid-March, Grand Circle Travel in Boston sent out a mailing for its first ''Christmas-themed'' trip, according to its vice president for sales, Mark Frevert. It involves seven nights on a riverboat between Nuremberg and Vienna, with prices starting at $1,395 a person. The 260 places sold in two weeks. ''I was really surprised,'' Mr. Frevert said. ''My Christmas spirit level must be low.''

title: Afghan Food That Won't Hurt the Purse
description: THE shimmering, strikinge Kabul Grill in Hicksville is a jewel of a restaurant that offers a seductive, romantic atmosphere and penny-wise prices. The highlight of this serene new Afghan spot, at 129 North Broadway (516-933-8999), is the archways that line the walls; at night when each of them is illuminated by a torch-shaped sconce that casts a subdued glow, they evoke visions of mosques and minarets.

title: The Way We Live Now: 06-03-01: All In The Family; What They Were Thinking
description: A portfolio of images of Tom Green and some of his five wives and 29 children. They were photographed at his mother's house in Salt Lake City the day after he was convicted of bigamy. He faces up to 25 years of prison at his sentencing, scheduled for June 27.

title: THE GUIDE
description: In Picasso's Studio

description: New Chinese Cottages

description: Cyber Law Journal: Controversial Ruling on Library Filters

title: Lost Bank Cards
description: To the Editor: Toni L. Kamins's article was very informative, but an important fact was not covered with regard to personal identification numbers.

title: Julia Perlmutter, Zachary Samton
description: Dr. Julia Beth Perlmutter and Zachary Samton were married last evening by Rabbi Joel Sisenwine at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: The Nation: Who Are You?; When Perception Is Reality
description: THE growing national crusade against racial profiling is being called the civil rights movement of this generation. Polls have shown that a majority of Americans believe profiling is widespread, and an even greater majority disapprove of it. Yet throughout the country, the evidence for its existence is largely anecdotal. For that reason, the first wave of legislation and public policy initiatives designed to address the problem focus on the collection of data intended to substantiate allegations of racial bias in policing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOERST, BARBARA M.
description: FOERST-Barbara M. On June 1, 2001. Loving sister of John and his wife Marion, and Catherine Linnehan. Devoted aunt of Moira and Donald Linnehan, Gerard Foerst and Kathryn Bill. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Sunday, June 3, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, June 4, 10:45 AM, at The Church of St. Thomas More, East 89th St, between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: Hooked on Fish
description: IN the predawn hours, restaurateurs and merchants arrive at the Fulton Fish Market. A few are big-name Manhattan chefs like Eric Ripert of Le Bernardin and Dave Pasternack of Esca. Others cruise the aisles in relative obscurity, hoping that whatever they take home tastes as fresh as it looks.

title: Challenge Planned to Ashcroft's Delay of Gun Control Rule
description: Gun control advocates are growing increasingly concerned that a decision by Attorney General John Ashcroft to delay putting into effect a Clinton administration regulation involving background checks of handgun buyers may be intended to weaken the program.

title: Naturally
description: We want food that is cheap, healthful, natural and convenient. But, as Michael Pollan eloquently writes (May 13), we can't have it all. I have been an organic gardener for 25 years, and the ''organic'' farming that an agri-business like Small Planet Foods practices is not organic, as I define it.

title: Laura Appleman, David Friedman
description: Laura Ilana Appleman, a daughter of Jolene W. Appleman of New York and Bernard R. Appleman of Pittsburgh, is to be married today to David Adam Friedman, the son of Bonnie and Jerald S. Friedman of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi James Prosnit is to officiate at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; As the Economy Falters, the Hotel Market Cools
description: A LACK of capital, corporate budget tightening, a dip in business travel and a slower national economy have all combined to take some of the sizzle out of the hotel market in New Jersey as well as nationally.

title: An Architectural Plan Makes People, Not Traffic, a Priority
description: Imagine strolling down Third Avenue in the Bronx. The skyline has long been notable for sky and little else. Low-rise buildings meander down the streets. Then, at the intersection of Willis and Melrose Avenues and 149th Street, visualize large billboards across the rooftops of leftover industrial buildings, perhaps even equipped with screens displaying the news, as in Times Square.

title: A Flurry of Accusations Clouds Restaurant License Disputes
description: Accusations of false documents in pursuit of restaurant licenses are at the heart of two simmering disputes in the Village.

title: Anne Pidgeon, William Callender
description: Anne Cordingley Pidgeon, a daughter of Susan and James C. Pidgeon of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to William Nicholas Callender, the son of Catherine and Robert L. Callender of New York. The Rev. Edward F. Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: After 48 Years, Designer Seating
description: When the restoration of Lever House, at 53rd Street and Park Avenue, is completed this fall, there will have a feature that was planned for the original building but never made: seating designed by the sculptor Isamu Noguchi for the outdoor plaza. Mr. Noguchi created the design, which features six black-and-white marble benches, in 1953.

title: Marketing 'Narnia' Without a Christian Lion
description: For more than a half century, ''The Chronicles of Narnia'' captivated children with tales of Aslan, a tawny lion who ruled a wintry Narnian kingdom of dwarfs, fauns and occasionally errant English schoolchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, JOANNE SOBEL
description: BLOOM-Joanne Sobel. Age 56. Passed away May 29, 2001. Devoted wife of Robert Bloom, adored daughter of Sylvia and the late Oscar Sobel, beloved sister of Barbara and brother-in-law of Mark Lichtenstein, loving mother to Darren, Brandon and Justin Mallis, caring grandmother of Ethan Greenberg. Survived by many dear relatives, inlaws and friends. Laid to rest June 1 at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Remembered for her creativity and kindness. She will be missed by all and remains in our hearts forever. Donations to American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: The World: Why Are You Here?; Britain's Race Problem
description: TWO things were striking about the aftermath of the race riots that raged through Oldham in the British Midlands last week in the midst of a national election campaign. First, none of the party leaders -- not Tony Blair, the Labor prime minister, nor William Hague, the Tory leader, nor Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats -- found it convenient to visit Oldham and speak to the people there. Second, nobody even seemed to notice.

title: STATEHOUSE; Boston
description: For many, a New England statehouse is mainly this: a great gold dome towering over marble halls packed full of enough history to torture generations of schoolchildren. Funny, though, how the history seems to get more and more interesting as one's own life lengthens. To the point that, for those too old now to get their class photographs taken on the grand staircase, the Massachusetts State House is not merely one more site on Boston's foot-fatiguing Freedom Trail but also a deep and not-to-be-missed delight.

title: STONE WALLS; Little Compton. R.I.
description: The stone walls of Little Compton, R.I., a town of 3,593 people across the Sakonnet River from Newport, have been impressing people for a long time. Thomas Church, who represented the town in the colonial legislature in the early 1700's, when it was still part of Massachusetts, told his colleagues that there were enough stone walls to reach from Little Compton to Boston, 74 miles. They refused to believe him, and Church returned home to check his facts.

title: Christina McCarron, John Harvey
description: Christina Sheppard McCarron, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James P. McCarron Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. John Harvey, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Harvey of Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. Francis G. Hilton performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: POSTINGS: Forums With Mayoral Hopefuls; Candidates On Land Use
description: On Wednesday, Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller, is to be the first of the four Democratic mayoral candidates to discuss zoning, land use and preservation issues at the first in a series of forums organized by a coalition of more than 80 neighborhood preservation groups. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, is to appear on June 13, followed on June 20 by Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, and on June 27 by Mark Green, the public advocate.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Pall Corp. Widens Plans for Layoffs

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Look to Build On Two Pieces of Good News
description: With Clint Mathis failing to score and Adolfo Valencia recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his right knee, the MetroStars have produced just one goal in their past three Major League Soccer games. As a result, they are no longer the top team in their division.

title: A New Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Acting 'King Hedley II': 'It Just Makes You Soar'
description: BY the time all the Tony Awards have been distributed at Radio City Music Hall tonight, it is possible that four of the six actors in August Wilson's ''King Hedley II'' will have hurried to the stage. Brian Stokes Mitchell, Leslie Uggams, Charles Brown and Viola Davis have been nominated for their portrayals of characters trying to make their constricted lives amount to something in Pittsburgh's hardscrabble Hill District during the 1980's. In their performances the four players get the opportunity to deliver the kind of attention-grabbing monologues that are Mr. Wilson's signature: lengthy outbursts full of passion.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Lexus SC 430; C'est la Vie: Lexus Visits the Riviera and Drops Its Top
description: BEAUTY may be in the eye of the beholder, but the look of luxury has always been defined by the affluent. How else could those clunky Chanel sunglasses be considered attractive?

title: A Rising Star Of Sauvignons
description: Macari Vineyards, on the North Fork of Long Island, is a rising star. Its 2000 sauvignon blanc is the equal of splendid Loire, New Zealand and California sauvignons.

title: A French Original In Jazz's Wider World
description: MARTIAL SOLAL, a 73-year-old Paris-based French-Algerian who might be the greatest living European jazz pianist -- and is at least the equal of any in the United States -- is up to something unusual, not to say perverse, on his new album, ''Martial Solal Dodecaband Plays Ellington.'' On many of the performances, a snatch of a familiar melody by Ellington or Billy Strayhorn will surface from out of the blue, like a song that kept going through Mr. Solal's head as he sat down to compose a piece of his own.

title: May 27-June 2; McVeigh Seeks Delay
description: Timothy J. McVeigh prefers execution to life in prison for bombing the Oklahoma City Federal Building, his lawyers say. But they have filed an appeal for a stay of his execution, which was postponed to June 11 after the F.B.I. found thousands of documents not given to his defense team. The man who confessed to biographers that he made the bomb that killed 168 people thinks ''the most important thing in his life is to help bring integrity to the criminal justice system,'' one of his lawyers said. Jo Thomas

title: The Nation; Flash! 2 Teenagers Get Attention!
description: TWO 19-year-olds go out drinking in a state where they are supposed to wait until they are 21. Unusual? Not in this world. News? None bigger, at least on the cable news broadcasts and television talk shows. The 19-year-olds' names, you see, are rather familiar. And their father, well, he lives at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: From Nest to Nest, Creating on the Fly
description: IN the 19th century, itinerant, self-taught artists often made their way to remote New England mill towns, painting on-the-spot portraits of the newly moneyed mill owners and merchants. The London-based artist Mona Hatoum, though she is far from self-taught, could be called the 21st-century version of the itinerant artist. Like many of her contemporaries, she finds both means and inspiration in a nomadic lifestyle that takes her from one international-artist residency to the next.

title: Lisa Greene, Jonathan Polish
description: Rabbi Lisa Susan Greene, a daughter of Betty Greene and Rabbi Barry H. Greene of South Orange, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Jonathan Stephen Polish, a son of Dr. Loretta Polish of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Rabbi Daniel F. Polish of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The bride's father will officiate at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., and the bridegroom's father will participate in the ceremony.

title: Where Music's Mission Is to Help Heal
description: COME spring, in this city of rich musical traditions, the thoughts of many turn to the venerable May Festival, the granddaddy of American choral celebrations, now 128 years old. It is a retreat into aesthetics and history, often seeming to have little to do with the concerns of the workaday world, and that is probably how most classical-music lovers want it these days.

title: The World; Capital Leaps Forward in China
description: WANG WENJING, a mild-mannered 36-year-old computer programmer became one of the wealthiest men in China two weeks ago, worth more than half a billion dollars. The source of his sudden riches: China's still fledgling capital markets, which until recently were almost entirely off-limits to private entrepreneurs like him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSCHHOFF, LEE R.
description: BUSCHHOFF-Lee R. Of Union City, NJ. Beloved husband of Nery. Father of Lorraine and Jason. Son of Robert. Brother of Elaine Davis. Services Monday. For information ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Easing The Moving Experience
description: SUMMER, movers say, is traditionally their busiest season. The process of moving can be a stressful ordeal, filled with unpleasant surprises about price and the damage or destruction of treasured belongings. Here are some tips for making a move go as smoothly and economically as possible.

title: Not $5-a-Head Radicchio, but Fresh Zucchini for the Poor
description: Greenmarkets have the aura of places where affluent shoppers can pick up organic radicchio at $5 a head and wildflowers at $10 a bunch. But a dispute in Sunset Park is centering on the fate of a greenmarket where up to 10,000 needy and elderly New Yorkers would be able to use coupons to buy fresh produce at reduced prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLBAUM, DR. MORRIS
description: APPLBAUM-Dr. Morris. Young Israel of Woodmere mourns the death of our member, Morris Applbaum A'H. May Hashem comfort the family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: THE TIGER RISING

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: I was both astounded and intensely moved by Patrick Reeder and others who lost loved ones in the Oklahoma City bombing and yet refuse to condone the execution of Timothy McVeigh. When people can suffer ineffable grief and come through that experience with any semblance of ''moral saneness,'' I am unable to convey how deeply I respect them.

title: Tom Daschle's Many Advisers
description: With the Democrats due to take over the Senate Wednesday morning, Senator Tom Daschle, the prospective majority leader, has been getting a lot of free advice. Formerly combative Republicans are warning him not to become a partisan obstructionist. Once rudderless Democrats are urging Mr. Daschle to lay out an ambitious agenda on health, education, the environment and defense. This weekend he will be hearing from Senator John McCain, his host for an Arizona trip that is setting off alarms at the White House. Yesterday Mr. McCain reiterated his intention to remain a Republican amid reports that he is being pressed by some supporters to bolt the party and run for president in 2004. Clearly, some major changes are already flowing from the defection of Senator James Jeffords from the Republican Party.

title: Bill of fare: sweet and spicy
description: All the following restaurants accept credit cards. Prices, calculated at an exchange rate of 1,350 won to the dollar, are estimates for a three-course meal for two with a glass of wine or beer, unless otherwise specified.

title: Back Where He Started
description: Last winter, Abdul Sankoh, a victim of Sierra Leone's machete-wielding rebels, left the amputee camp in Freetown where he was living with his wife and children and came to New York with four other double-arm amputees for prosthetics and medical treatment. He hoped to return and once again be able to provide for his family. But things haven't quite turned out that way.

title: Anne Jamieson, Kevin Waehner
description: Anne Barbara Jamieson, a daughter of Cynthia Jamieson and Dr. James Jamieson of Guilford, Conn., was married last evening to Kevin R. Waehner, a son of Susan and Glenn Waehner of New Canaan, Conn., and Fresno, Calif. The Rev. Lark d'Helen, a Congregational minister, officiated at the OceanCliff Hotel in Newport, R.I.

title: Christina McCarron and John Harvey
description: Christina Sheppard McCarron, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James P. McCarron Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. John Harvey, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Harvey of Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. Francis G. Hilton performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: A Part of Brooklyn Is With the Dodgers
description: They were born in exotic places, these two unheralded members of the Los Angeles Dodgers, places that are not the usual origin of major leaguers. Luke Prokopec, the Dodgers' surprisingly good rookie pitcher, was born in Blackwood, South Australia; Paul LoDuca, their good-hitting catcher-first baseman, was born in Brooklyn.

title: Working Around Fumes and Fury on the L.I.E.
description: IT was a fresh, windy day in May on the Long Island Expressway service road at New Hyde Park Road. Some telephone technicians were busy shifting their wires to span a recently completed temporary bridge across the expressway. A machinist operating an eight-ton pile driver was pounding steel sheeting into the ground for a retaining wall, creating cave-in protection for workers finishing the foundation for the bridge. And Tony Rodriguez, a general foreman, and Orlando Frade, a labor foreman, stood surveying their project, which will carry traffic across the expressway until a new permanent bridge is ready at the end of November.

title: May 27-June 2; Crime Rates Level Off
description: Along with the ever-rising stock market, the drop in crime that began in 1992 was one of the great success stories of the 90's. Last year the stock market finally fell to earth, and now it seems that the decline in crime also ended. An F.B.I. report found that the number of serious crimes in 2000 was nearly identical to that in 1999. The question is whether this marks a leveling off or, maybe, the start of a new upturn in crime. There are as many guesses on that as on the stock market. Fox Butterfield

title: Yale Sails Toward Varsity Status
description: In the highly competitive world of college dinghy racing, there are few schools that can surpass the legacy of the Yale sailing team. Yale has won four national championships and has produced scores of sailors who have gone on to compete at the sport's highest levels, including two former college sailors of the year, Peter Isler and Steve Benjamin.

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Advisers On Energy Report Ties To Industry
description: At least three top White House advisers involved in drafting President Bush's energy strategy held stock in the Enron Corporation or earned fees from the large Texas-based energy trading company, which lobbied aggressively to shape the administration's approach to energy issues.

title: Azinger Emerges With Memorial Lead Amid Rain and Hail
description: In his first 90 minutes of play today in the Memorial Tournament, the second-round leader, Paul Azinger, lost his two-stroke edge to Tiger Woods and snapped the shaft of his driver in two. Rain, hail, lightning and a nearby tornado warning were threatening to delay a round that had already begun four hours late. Azinger was also reeling from consecutive bogeys, including one on the par-5 fifth hole, perhaps the most forgiving hole at the Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: Private Sector; Iron and Velvet at the Exchange
description: IN March, a month after taking office, Clara Furse, chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, visited the northern England city of Leeds to meet 10 regional stockbrokers. Calling each by name, Mrs. Furse, 43, the first woman to lead the 200-year-old exchange, fielded questions with aplomb, said people who were there.

title: Stock Index Funds Are Regaining Favor
description: Investors are putting increasing amounts of money into index funds, after a slowdown last year.

title: Ideas & Trends; Pearls, From the $135 Million Film
description: A BRILLIANT man would find a way not to fight a war'' --line spoken by Mako, in the role of Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, that will remain in the Japanese version of the film ''Pearl Harbor.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, RUTH
description: WEXLER-Ruth. Died quietly with her family by her side on Friday, June 1, 2001. Beloved wife of 68 years to Jack Wexler. Loving sister to Morton Rechler. Cherished mother to Ann and son-in-law Robert Fromer and Gary and daughter-in-law Nina Wexler. Adored grandmother to Tony, Amy, Yvette and Michal Fromer, Elana and Freddy Wexler, and great-grandmother to Alex and Madelaine Fromer. She was a passionate and generous woman who opened her heart and home to many political and philanthropic endeavors. She was an active member of Israeli Bonds, Hadassah, ORT, Jewish National Fund, The Maccabi World Union and Israeli Tennis Center, Jewish War Veterans USA, and Zahal Disabled Veterans. She and her soulmate, Jack, established a national bridge tournament in Israel with that organization, and were a driving force in building Migdal Or, a school for underprivileged children in Israel, into a major institution. Her boundless energy and enthusiasm taught her family the importance of caring and commitment to the world around them. Ruth's love for art and collecting took her and Jack around the world. She was one of the earliest Art Chairs for the American Friends of Hebrew University, and was intimately involved with the Nassau County Museum of Art and Bezalel, the oldest art school in the Middle East. At 88, Ruth was still larger than life, and her wisdom, insight, imagination and candor touched all who knew her. She will be deeply missed. Services will be held at Temple Israel of Great Neck, 108 Old Mill Rd, Noon today.

title: Must Be a Matter of Taste: Diners React to a Review
description: To the Editor:

title: Debbie Reynolds, Still Kicking
description: Elbows up, fists pumping, and with that voice so big it couldn't possibly come out of that little body, Debbie Reynolds always charged right at you. In old Hollywood, they called it gumption or moxie. Ms. Reynolds seemed to will herself upon her audience. Each high step, each pleading note announced, I'm gonna make sure you love this.

title: Ghostbuster
description: FISH, BLOOD AND BONE

title: Sufferin Stereotypes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Memo to Republicans
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Savings in New Mexico
description: One of Hyatt's newest resorts, the Hyatt Regency Tamaya Resort and Spa in Santa Ana Pueblo, N.M., is offering three family-savings plans this summer. Through Sept. 30, the fourth night is free at the 350-room resort, which is near the Sandia Mountains and the Rio Grande, 20 minutes from Albuquerque. Or if parents want a second room for children 18 or younger, it is 50 percent off. And through Aug. 31, kids ages 8 to 17 can play golf free when accompanied by a paying Hyatt guest. Contact (800) 554-9288 or www.hyatt.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRATE, SALLY ESKENAZI
description: DRATE-Sally Eskenazi. On June 3, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leon Eskenazi. Loving mother of Irving, Murray and Joe. Cherished grandmother of Loren, Diane, Lynn and Nancy. Great-grandmother of Jake, Noah and Sheera. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, DR. BENJAMIN C.
description: BERLINER-Dr. Benjamin C. A memorial celebration of Dr. Ben's life will be held at 11AM, Sunday, June 10, in the Chapel of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, located on Fort Washington Ave, just N. of 165th St. All those whose lives he may have touched are welcomed.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Saturday about a street collapse in Manhattan misidentified the intersection where a large pothole remained. It was 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue, not Columbus Avenue.

title: Dramatic Reversal Adds Excitement to Regional Semifinals
description: The semifinal matches last week in the Reisinger Knockout Teams, concluding the New York Eastern Regional Championships, were as exciting as any in the 72-year history of the event. Play on Thursday and Friday was in Manhattan at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, and Manhattan Club, 27 West 72nd Street.

title: Not All News Is Bad For Pitching Rotation
description: Orlando Hernndez is seeing a foot specialist today, Roger Clemens grabbed his hamstring on Saturday and Ted Lilly walked around with an ice pack on his pitching hand yesterday. It seems as if half the Yankees' pitching staff should be wrapped in gauze.

title: Unrelated Killings Leave 4 Dead Within 3 1/2 Hours in the City
description: Four people were killed within three and a half hours early yesterday in unrelated slayings in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, the police said. Those four killings, along with the shooting death of a Brooklyn travel agent on Saturday, brought to five the number of homicides in New York City over the weekend.

title: An Icon's Birthday Has Indonesia Looking to Past
description: This Wednesday marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Sukarno, the founding president of Indonesia. After months of political intrigue involving the current president, Abdurrahman Wahid, people here are desperate for a chance to change the subject.

title: Birendra, 55, Nepal's King During Transition to Democracy, Is Dead
description: King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, who was shot to death on Friday in a massacre of Nepal's royal family, was a proud but isolated monarch whose reign began in absolutism and ended in uneasy partnership with democracy.

title: Once Hale and Hearty, He's Got the Eerie Blues
description: The blues is one of the great generous pools of American culture, so giant as to be indeterminate. (Think about how often you've heard music described as bluesy.) But your individual version of it tends to become sacrosanct. It's rare when a major figure in the blues tampers with his formula: the music's small but deep audience knows exactly what it wants to hear, and such a step is seen as a yielding of control rather than an artistic broadening.

title: Big Thinkers in a Nation Transformed by Civil War
description: THE METAPHYSICAL CLUB

title: Now Meet Jack Welch The Scribe
description: John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric, said he was not trying to sell his forthcoming memoirs when he made his public debut as an author at BookExpo, the annual book industry convention, here on Friday. He was just being himself. But if so, he appears to take to selling books naturally.

title: Webb Runs Away With a Second Consecutive U.S. Open
description: As if to punctuate her excellence, Karrie Webb birdied the final two holes of the United States Women's Open today, capping a superior performance by a special champion.

title: The Stanley Cup Show: It's 'Survivor' on Ice
description: Watching the Stanley Cup finals in recent seasons has been like watching the end of a 26.2-mile marathon on a hot and humid day. Just as runners hit the wall of physical and psychological fatigue at about the 20th mile, hockey teams also deteriorate in the fourth round of a two-month tournament. Just as the rest of a road race is run and won by elite athletes through will as much as skill, the N.H.L.'s championship round is decided in a similar test between its two best teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, DIANA
description: GIBSON-Diana. Of Hallowell, Maine. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 9, 2 PM, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Union St., Hallowell.

title: Coming Soon To an Ad Near You
description: A common place to learn about new movies is through another medium: television commercials.

title: Greenspan Expects Inflation to Stay in Check
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today that inflation was ''not a significant problem'' in the American economy, but he stressed that the Fed was keeping a close watch for signs of potential inflationary pressures.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about efforts by Buddhist groups to serve prison inmates misstated the number of convicts in touch with the Prison Dharma Network in Boulder, Colo. The network says there are thousands; 250 is the number of active members who are prisoners.

title: Market Research Moves From the Mall to the Net
description: Market researchers are spending a lot less time accosting shoppers at the mall for reactions to new products. Two of the nation's biggest packaged goods companies are moving more of their market research effort to the Internet.

title: Gene Woodling Dies at 78; Won 5 Titles With Yankees
description: Gene Woodling, whose smooth batting swing and superb play in left field helped the Yankees win five consecutive World Series championships, died Saturday at a nursing home in Wadsworth, Ohio. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNEY, MAX
description: CHERNEY-Max. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi George N. Abrahams, President

title: RUMSFELD LIMITING MILITARY CONTACTS WITH THE CHINESE
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has cut off virtually all of the Pentagon's contacts with the Chinese armed forces in a move that is prompting concern among China experts within the United States military establishment.

title: The Democratic Party's Southern Problem
description: Most people will remember the 2000 presidential election as the closest in modern American history, with one candidate winning the national popular vote and the other securing a razor-thin Electoral College majority -- and the presidency -- in a contentious recount in the State of Florida.

title: Youths Rally for Re-election of Iran's Reformist President
description: Before a cheering crowed that had gathered to proclaim their alliance with President Mohammad Khatami, Marzieh, 15, wrapped in black head-to-toe garb as required in the Islamic Republic of Iran, walked onto the podium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBBENBERG, GERTRUDE
description: LOBBENBERG - Gertrude. On June 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Otto. Loving sister of Renee Kaufman. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Regus Looks to Buy Rival In Office-Space Business
description: Regus P.L.C., which owns 360 business centers in about 50 countries, is in talks to buy HQ Global Workplaces, its largest rival, for about 650 million ($922 million), a Regus spokesman said.

title: Profile: James Kenneth Hahn
description: James K. Hahn, 50, the only son of a political family, grew up in South Los Angeles. His father, Kenneth, a longtime county supervisor beloved by his constituents, kept the family there long after white flight left the neighborhood overwhelmingly black. Mr. Hahn had a privileged childhood; he was the Dodgers' first honorary bat boy after the team moved from Brooklyn. But he also absorbed the lesson of his father's devotion to community service. After earning bachelor's and law degrees from Pepperdine University, he spent four years as a deputy city attorney and two in private practice before being elected city controller in 1981 and city attorney four years later. He has used injunctions to crack down on gangs and helped negotiate a federal consent decree for oversight of the city's troubled Police Department. But he has also been seen as a cautious plodder, and he sought the mayoralty only when term limits forced him out of his current job. His first marriage ended in divorce. He and his second wife, Monica, have two children.

title: No Runs and Little Hope As Mets Falter in Ninth
description: The Mets continue to insist that there is plenty of time to salvage their season, that their deficit has not become insurmountable. But with each day, with each series that passes, they are losing time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, RABBI DR. LEON
description: KATZ-Rabbi Dr. Leon. Religious Zionists of America Mizrachi mourns the passing of a very distinguished and devoted leader of our movement for decades. He served as Chairman of Vaad Lechinuch, founded our branches in Passaic and New Jersey. He was instrumental in attracting to our cause many supporters. We express condolences to his Rebbitzin Rivka and entire family. Rabbi Simcha Krauss, President Isrel Friedman, Executive VP

title: Immigrants Bury Their Friends, but the Hopes Live On
description: Yelena and Yulia Nelimov, teenage sisters who came from Russia to live in Israel but died in the suicide bombing in Tel Aviv on Friday night, were buried side by side here today in a row of eight fresh graves.

title: Tennyson Schad, 70, Lawyer; Founded Photography Gallery
description: Tennyson Schad, a First Amendment lawyer whose brainchild, Light Gallery, was the bold commercial showcase for contemporary photographers in the 1970's and the training ground for an unusually large number of today's gallery directors, died on May 26 in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: An American Flourish to Stuttgart's Signature
description: American Ballet Theater's final new production of the season is ''Onegin,'' John Cranko's sumptuously designed and shrewdly theatricalized treatment of one of Romantic literature's most famous well-heeled misfits.

title: Teachers' Leader Yielding on Mayor's School Role
description: New York City's powerful teachers' union is preparing to abandon its decades-old opposition to mayoral control of the city's public education system. The change of position comes as the union seeks a sizable pay increase from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has long sought control of the Board of Education.

title: Technology Incubator to Focus on India's Needs
description: For a country with $7 billion of software exports and a huge talent pool of technical workers, India has been a spectacular underperformer in inventing and creating technology that addresses domestic needs.

title: INSIDE
description: Nepal's Comatose King Dies

title: When Doctors Make Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Land Where Dressers And Bows Are Cross
description: Froth, composed of classic elements, bubbles through the Duke on 42nd Street, where the Jewish Repertory Theater is concluding its 27th season with ''A Naughty Knight,'' a new musical comedy loosely based on ''A Medieval Romance,'' a story by Mark Twain.

title: Smolenski Wins With Record Toss
description: John-Paul Smolenski, a senior from New Hyde Park High School, posted a New York state record of 223 feet 6 inches in the 12-pound hammer throw yesterday at the 45th annual Eastern States boys interscholastic outdoor championships at Iona Prep in New Rochelle. The meet drew entries from 67 Eastern high schools.

title: New Electoral Math Changing the Script In Los Angeles Duel
description: For weeks, the story line of the Los Angeles mayoral campaign has been that Antonio Villaraigosa, the charismatic insurgent seeking to become his city's first Latino mayor since 1872, stood poised to usher in a new political era in a city that is now almost half Hispanic and a nation where the Hispanic population is growing rapidly.

title: E-Commerce Report; Online billing, an idea that looked like a winner, has held its own but has not caught on in a big way.
description: AMONG all the half-baked Internet ideas that made it onto investors' plates in recent years, online billing was one of the few that seemed to offer some real nourishment.

title: For MetroStars, Tie Bears Striking Resemblance to a Loss
description: The MetroStars turned Tab Ramos's ankle sprain in the 13th minute into an opportunity today against the New England Revolution. Rodrigo Faria, who replaced Ramos, produced the only goal for the MetroStars in a 1-1 tie before a crowd of 28,628 at Foxboro Stadium.

title: 'Survivor' Suit: Test of Faith For Contestant, And Viewers
description: In the idiom of the reality television program in which he starred, ''Survivor,'' Dirk Been was sooo annoying to some of his fellow cast members.

title: Shoreham Afterthought
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Spokesman Catalogs Pranks Attributed to Clinton Aides
description: Goaded by skeptical Democrats, the White House provided additional details today of pranks and vandalism that it said had been committed by Clinton administration employees leaving office in January.

title: Profile: Antonio Villaraigosa
description: Antonio Villaraigosa, 48, was born Antonio Villar in Los Angeles and grew up in the heavily Hispanic Eastside neighborhood of City Terrace. He was 5 when his father left. He was reared by his mother, a state employee. A bright student with a self- described wild side, he dropped out of high school but later earned a college degree at the University of California at Los Angeles and a law degree from the People's College of Law. He has not passed the bar in four attempts. He worked as a negotiator for the local teachers union and later became president of the local chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. In his 20's, he fathered two daughters out of wedlock, but took an active role in helping rear his children. In 1988, he married Corina Raigosa, a schoolteacher whose name he blended with his own and with whom he had two children. The couple separated in the early 90's after he had an affair, but later reconciled. He was elected to the California Assembly in 1994. Term limits propelled him into the speaker's chair four years later.

title: Return Trip to Proust's World Stirs Personal Remembrance

I had no idea why I had done so. After all, I'd read through the unadorned Scott Moncrieff translation 40 years earlier, lying in the guest room of my Uncle Julie's house with a thermometer in my mouth for what I suspect was an imaginary fever. I read Kilmartin's touch-up in the early 90's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor's Boot, Made For Walking
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, citing pain in his heel, intends to wear a plastic orthopedic boot on his right foot for about a month. The mayor attended a rally for the state of Israel in Midtown yesterday wearing the boot. He said he was suffering from plantar fasciitis, a common cause of heel pain that results from the inflammation of a fibrous band of tissue along the sole of the foot. Mr. Giuliani said he apparently developed the condition by not being active during his recent radiation and hormone treatments for prostate cancer. ''I wasn't exercising, playing golf or running,'' he said. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: A Lawyer Who Fights for Life Over the Death Penalty
description: TIMOTHY J. McVEIGH'S plea last week for a stay of execution for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing was one more piece of evidence for Diann Y. Rust-Tierney that few defendants can be assured a fair trial in the current system that determines who receives the death penalty.

title: Belmont Looms as the Rubber Match for a Pot of Gold
description: Each trainer considers his colt a superstar. Their records are almost identical -- Monarchos has four victories in eight lifetime starts, two of them in Grade I stakes, for a bankroll of more than $1.6 million; Point Given has captured 6 of 10, including a pair of Grade I stakes, and earned more than $1.8 million. Monarchos, a compact gray, was brilliant in winning the Kentucky Derby; Point Given, a massive chestnut, just as impressive in seizing the Preakness.

title: The Fusion Makes a Major Turnaround

Under the direction of Ray Hudson, in his first full season as coach, the Fusion has turned into an elite team. Its 6-2 victory in Dallas over the Burn last Saturday was its fifth in a row and extended its unbeaten streak to eight games.

description: When the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries convenes tomorrow in Vienna, it will probably decide against increasing the amount of oil it supplies the world market. A year ago, such a move would have elicited an aria of outrage from Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ARTHUR KING
description: PETERS-Arthur King. Age 81, died peacefully at home in Bronxville on June 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Sarah Whitaker Peters, devoted father of Robert Bruce, Margaret Allen, and Michael Whitaker, loving grandfather of Philip, Elizabeth, Sarah, Griffin, Mark, and Kate. A 1940 graduate of Cornell University, he went on to serve during World War II as an officer in Army Counter-Intelligence. He later received a Ph.D. in French literature from Columbia University. During the 1970s, while running his own importing business, A.K. Peters Co., he taught French at Hunter College in his lunch hours. He was a translator, author and critic. Five of his books were published, including ''Jean Cocteau and His World,'' and ''Seven Trails West.'' He served as President and Chairman of the French American Foundation in New York from 1977-83. He was decorated with the Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government in 1978, and received the Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur in 1984. A mountaineer, he was a member of the American Alpine Club and the Alpine Club in London. There will be a celebration of life service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, NY, on Thursday, June 7, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: White House Hopes to Put More Medicare Patients in Managed Care

title: Confusion on Affirmative Action
description: Although the Rehnquist Supreme Court has severely limited the use of race-sensitive criteria in the awarding of government contracts, reapportionment and other areas, it has so far managed to avoid the debate about affirmative action in higher education. Just last week, the court declined to review a decision by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco upholding the University of Washington Law School's use of race in its admissions practices prior to a 1998 voter initiative barring such policies. But other conflicting lower-court rulings are likely to compel the justices to address the issue soon. Until they do, a major issue will remain unsettled and admissions offices at universities around the country will remain confused about their legal obligations.

title: Missile Shield Realities
description: Faced with resistance from Moscow, objections among NATO allies and opposition from Democrats about to assume control of the Senate, the Bush administration needs to reassess its missile defense plans and scale them back to a realistic level. The kinds of ambitious systems that Bush advisers have described are not technologically or politically attainable today. Clinging to these outsized concepts can only damage American diplomatic interests and delay the development of more modest and feasible missile defenses that could enhance the nation's security.

Proud grandfather of Lauren, Benjamin and Hannah. Eternal optimist and friend to all who knew him. Veteran of the Second World War, Pacific Theater. Devoted educator and administrator in Hicksville School District for 27 years. Lifelong birder and photographer, founding member of the Sialis Bird Club and the ''Gang,'' like all good scouts, he left this world a better place than he found it. title: The Old Times Square, Home for the Hopeless
description: So thoroughly has Times Square been transformed in the past decade that depictions of its red-lighted, ominously atmospheric recent past are already nostalgic. That's one effect of ''Watcher,'' a piquing but unfulfilling play by the Filipino-American playwright Han Ong receiving its premiere production by the Ma-Yi Theater Company at Cap 21 Theater. But another is to be reminded that while for native New Yorkers the sleaze at the crossroads of the world was a perverse badge of identity (the equivalent of the T-shirt slogan ''Welcome to New York -- Now Go Home''), for the newly arrived and culturally disoriented it represented entry-level opportunity.

title: Iverson Makes Sure Sixers Roar Into Finals

title: Harvard Sweeps Series From Yale

The winning time for Harvard's varsity, 18 minutes 55.6 seconds, was the fourth-fastest rowing upstream on the Thames River course at Gales Ferry, Conn., 13.7 seconds slower than the record set by Harvard in 1995.

description: The rookies arrived at the Giants' conditioning camp at the Meadowlands and went right to work.

title: Tossed Egg Provides A Moment of Levity
description: Two years ago, Martina Hingis was cast as a villain at Roland Garros for her petulant, unsportsmanlike display during her loss to Steffi Graf in the final.

title: Arafat Orders Troops to Bar Any Violence
