description: The photographs of the young Israelis who were being buried today appeared in neat rows in the morning newspapers, looking like a page cruelly ripped from a high school yearbook. The 18 faces -- a 19th victim of the Friday bombing in Tel Aviv died overnight -- formed a haunting backdrop for a tense stand-off between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Article 2001060491295934886 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Antitobacco Group Hires the Work Agency
description: The advertising committee of the Virginia Tobacco Settlement Foundation has selected Work Inc. in Richmond, to handle its first account, with billings estimated at $30 million. The decision is pending approval of the foundation's board on June 19.

title: SON OF THE POOR IS ELECTED IN PERU OVER EX-PRESIDENT
description: Alejandro Toledo, the son of a poor Andean mountain sheep herder, won the presidency today over onetime President Alan Garcia after a campaign that left Peruvians deeply disillusioned even as both candidates promised to usher in a new era of democracy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is absolutely more patient empowerment now. I say 'thank you' to AIDS activists, because they led the way.''

title: In Ulster's Political Script, Mostly Monologues Still
description: Closing time at the Silver Herring pub on the County Down coast, and drinkers stand for the playing of ''God Save the Queen.'' As the final drumroll fades in the dim taproom, they stomp their feet and shout in boozy unison, ''No surrender!''

title: Bridget Joness Apartment Envy
description: In the past eight months, I have edited this column which has featured dozens of apartments and their very involved owners. Ive come to the realization that New Yorkers relationships to their apartments are just as complex as their relationships with their significant others. So instead of just telling the story of my three major New York real estate relationships, I wrote my apartment history the way Bridget Jones might have written it:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, JUDY GRAF
description: KLEIN-Judy Graf. Dear sweet Ma. Mother, daughter, sister, friend, artist and architect. Judy Graf Klein passed away in her home on June 1. She is survived by her daughters, Adina Sabrina Klein and Oleanna Joanna Graf Klein; her mother, Diane M. Graf; and her brothers, Peter M. Graf and Ronald J. Graf and their families. The space your absence creates in our hearts is as vast as the universe. The funeral will be held Monday, June 4, at 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). Donations may be made to Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, New York, NY 10014.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: As Nepal Mourns Royals, Mystery and Confusion Linger
description: This Himalayan nation lost its second king in little more than two days when King Dipendra died early this morning of gunshot wounds in a military hospital, according to a well-placed palace official. He was 29.

title: Benefits for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Franks Aided by Back-to-Back Candidacy
description: Bob Franks, the former United States representative, former candidate for Senate and now candidate for governor, has a new favorite joke in his well-stocked cupboard of canned material. ''I knew I'd see all of you again,'' he tells supporters. ''I just didn't know it would be this soon.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, MORRIS ''MAC'', D.D.S.
description: MEYERSON - Morris ''Mac'', D.D.S. Died June 3, at 96. Beloved by many on the Lower East Side and Wynmore, FL. He is survived by his son Arthur Meyerson, M.D., three grandchildren, one greatgrandchild and his brother. Active and a leader in the Henry Street Settlement (Old Timers) and the Knights of Pythias. Services Wednesday, June 6, noon, 201 East Broadway, NYC.

title: Finance Chief's Departure Gives Mahathir a Freer Hand on Policy
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The resignation of Daim Zainuddin, widely considered to be the second most powerful politician in Malaysia, has given Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad more direct control over both the running of the government and the finances of his party, political analysts said Sunday.

title: Mrs. Sharpton Urges Soup, But Note Sustains Son Instead
description: Had a personal note of encouragement not arrived from Coretta Scott King, Ada Sharpton might have persuaded her son to have some soup yesterday.

title: Shift May Be at Hand at Fashion Magazines
description: What does the future hold for America's fashion magazines, those scented bibles whose influence can send millions of women racing to stores or the hair salon?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSHABAC, VICTOR RAHAMIM
description: MUSHABAC - Victor Rahamim. Beloved husband of Estelle for 67 years. Loving father and grandfather. Loved songs, stories, prayers, laughter. Services 12:30, today, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mr. Pataki Broadens Health Insurance
description: Gov. George Pataki brought home an important prize last week from his Republican allies in Washington. The Bush administration waived certain Medicaid rules that cleared the way for a plan that New York calls Family Health Plus, aimed at the state's working poor. The plan will help fill another gap in health coverage by expanding the Child Health Plus program that has successfully provided medical insurance for children. This expansion could offer health insurance to as many as 620,000 adults who cannot now afford coverage or who do not qualify for Medicaid, in most cases because their income is above the poverty level.

title: New Focus on an Old Nuclear Problem
description: The nuclear plant here split its first atom in December 1973. Both halves are still here.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man
description: Police officers in Vernon, Conn., a Hartford suburb, fatally shot a man yesterday after he got out of a car, approached with a knife and refused orders to halt, the state police said.

title: The Killings in Ulster
description: To the Editor:

title: A Safer Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001060492886110726 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Russell Gets Respect, But Kuerten Triumphs
description: Upon his surreal resurrection on the grounds of Roland Garros, inspired by the chanting Brazilians in the stands, Gustavo Kuerten turned the clay court into an Etch A Sketch.

title: Shift in Mayoral Race
description: On the brink of the election tomorrow in Los Angeles, the establishment candidate James K. Hahn, left, who has attracted a coalition of blacks and moderate whites, appeared to be poised to dash the hopes of the charismatic insurgent candidate, Antonio Villaraigosa, of becoming the first Latino mayor of Los Angeles since 1872. A1

title: MediaTalk; Remembering Pearl Harbor Has Its Risks
description: The number of lenses through which people are looking at the movie ''Pearl Harbor'' just keeps multiplying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIG, CHARLES
description: SELIG-Charles. Died on June 2, 2001, after a brave battle with pancreatic cancer. His life was filled with many accomplishments, both professionally and personally. He founded his own insurance firm, Selig and Sussman, Inc., and took pride and pleasure in servicing his clients. He will be remembered with much love by his wife Connie, his children and six grandchildren. He was the foundation and inspiration of his family. Services Monday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: U.S. to Keep Its Profile Low For Now in Israel Violence
description: After an intense internal debate, the Bush administration has decided that it will not send a high-level diplomatic mission to meet with the Israelis and the Palestinians but will instead press the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to act more forcefully to end the violence.

title: Article 2001060493785997409 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Gazing Into the Faces of AIDS
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, ROBERT DALE. ESQUIRE
description: McCABE-Robert Dale. Esquire, on June 2, 2001 at age 91. Devoted husband of the late Marguerite Murphy. Father of Maureen and Patricia. Also survived by nine grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Visitation 6-9pm Tuesday at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Ave, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10am, Church of Our Saviour. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, friends may make donations in Robert's name to Xavier Society for the Blind, 154 E. 23 St., NYC 10010.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Suffolk Lawmakers Meet
description: The County Legislature meets to consider the capital budget and spraying for West Nile virus. H. Lee Dennison Building, 100 Veterans Memorial Highway, Hauppauge, 9:30 a.m.

title: Article 2001060590433469965 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: One Man's Principle: One Home One Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Up on Gains by Oil Issues and Greenspan Remarks
description: Stocks rose yesterday as oil shares advanced on the prospect of higher crude prices after Iraq halted exports.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Transit Approach Is Urged
description: A group led by five former city transportation commissioners urged the next mayor yesterday to make transportation a top priority or risk slowing the city's economy. They said a commuter tax should be reinstated, more money should be spent repairing roads and bridges, and a new toll system should be established to discourage congestion. Elliot G. Sander, a former transportation commissioner, estimated that up to $9 billion must be spent over five years for proposals to build the Second Avenue subway and link Grand Central Terminal with the Long Island Rail Road. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Nearby Star Appears to Have Asteroid Belt, Society Is Told
description: Astronomers today reported finding evidence of a broad asteroid belt around a nearby star, providing a glimpse of what conditions might have been like in Earth's early solar system when its planets and asteroids were created.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Sales Executive Hired By Apogee
description: Apogee Networks is expected to announce today that it has hired Nina Aversano, a former high-ranking executive at Lucent Technologies, to oversee worldwide sales operations. Ms. Aversano resigned as Lucent's president for North American sales in October and then filed a lawsuit asserting that she had been forced out after her superiors disputed her contention that their sales targets were too optimistic. Apogee, a start-up based in Saddle Brook, N.J., and partly financed by Cisco Systems, a Lucent rival, develops billing software for communications networks.

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: SALE OF STAKE IN COLORADO COMPANY IS RENEGOTIATED
description: Katy Industries, a maker of maintenance and electrical supplies that agreed in March to sell a stake to the buyout company Kohlberg & Company, has renegotiated the transaction and increased its value. Kohlberg's KKTY Holding Company will now buy 700,000 shares of convertible preferred stock for $100 each, for a total of $70 million. The closely held KKTY agreed on March 30 to buy a stake in Katy for as much as $60 million of preferred and common stock. KKTY last month began re-evaluating its offer after Katy reported a first-quarter loss. Since the original offer, the shares of Katy, which is based in Englewood, Colo., have fallen 44 percent. Each preferred share can be converted into 16.67 shares of common stock within five years, instead of 12.5 shares under the initial terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ROBERT WALLER
description: MARX-Robert Waller. Age 72. Died suddenly May 31, 2001 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Son of the late Julian and Katherine Waller Marx. Brother of Peter and the late Julian. Father of Robin Anne Kearney, Robert W., Jr., James Marx and Antonia Maccelli. Grandfather of nine. The funeral was private.

title: Myanmar Tests Resolve of I.L.O. on Enforcing Standards
description: Nearly all governments agree smooth, seamless international trade is good and mistreatment of workers is bad.

title: 'A Previously Healthy 33-Year-Old Man': The Five Original Case Studies
description: Twenty years ago, on June 5, 1981, the Centers for Disease Control published the first report on what turned out to be the H.I.V. virus, which causes AIDS. Entitled ''Pneumocystis Pneumonia -- Los Angeles,'' the report alerted the medical community of unexplained occurrences of a deadly disease that crippled the immune systems of five men.

title: Foreign Affairs; Turkey's Moment Of Truth
description: I thought Madonna had arrived. The place was the Ulus restaurant on an Istanbul bluff overlooking the Bosporus. The commotion started with police sirens blaring. Then there was a gaggle of a dozen television cameras and reporters, flashes popping. A murmur started to spread through the restaurant. Then the doors flew open, the reporters cleared a path, and the star walked in: Turkey's minister of economy, Kemal Dervis, had arrived for dinner.

title: On Research Frontier, Basic Questions
description: In May 1999, Jim H., a young gay man living in the Boston area, arrived at an emergency room, terribly sick and frightened. He was burning with fever and spitting up blood. His throat was so swollen he could barely swallow.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Students Reprimanded For Protest
description: Four Harvard Law School students will receive letters of reprimand for their part in a campus sit-in last month, when students demanding a ''living wage'' for university employees occupied the university president's office. John D. Fitzpatrick, a Boston lawyer who defended the students at a six-hour hearing before the school's administrative board, said he was surprised that the students were given a reprimand -- considered stronger than a warning but short of suspension -- while students from other Harvard schools were treated more leniently. Officials at the law school declined to comment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday in the special summer issue of the Westchester section about what people like most about summer misstated the date of annual firefighters' parade in Katonah, N.Y. It is tomorrow, not July 4; the carnival sponsored by the Katonah Volunteer Fire Department runs tomorrow through Saturday.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks End Higher on Positive Earnings Outlooks
description: Stocks rose today as investors, buoyed by positive news from technology companies, shrugged off several disappointing reports that showed the economy was still quite sluggish.

title: Blair's Laborites: Not Lovable, but Electable
description: The Labor Party supporters were waiting excitedly for Prime Minister Tony Blair. But the tall man with the pasted-on smile and creepily earnest manner who bounded into view this morning was not the prime minister, but rather Rory Bremner, a television mimic who has made a career of lampooning Mr. Blair as an image-obsessed master of heartfelt political banalities.

title: Connecticut Lawmakers Heading for Showdown Over Budget
description: With two days left before the end of the legislative session in Hartford, Democrats remain at odds with Republican lawmakers and Gov. John G. Rowland over next year's state budget.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a furor over the Sorbonne's acceptance of a Ph.D. dissertation about astrology by lizabeth Teissier misstated the academic affiliations of two scholars who criticized her adviser. Christian Baudelot is a professor of sociology at the cole Normale Suprieure in Paris, and Roger Establet an emeritus professor of sociology at the University of Provence at Aix-en-Provence; there is no cole Normale Suprieure in Aix-en-Provence.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're also visitors today in the home of 68 endangered species and the only place on earth where crocodiles and alligators live side by side. We're kind of hoping that's the way it gets to be in the United States Congress.''

title: In This Bare-It-All Age, Bikinis Are Back
description: Leesa Leverette, an educational tester from Savannah, Ga., does not easily fit the old profile of someone who would be moved to push a credit card across a counter in exchange for a neon-peach string bikini. To begin with, Ms. Leverette is 40 and the mother of a 10-year-old. Recently though, she found herself at a swimwear shop on Tybee Island, Ga., trying on the $48 suit and thinking, ''O.K., this is acceptable -- this feels good.''

title: Revisiting Tiananmen: Envoy Saw U.S. Error in 'Cozying Up'
description: Just one month after the Tiananmen Square massacre in June 1989, the American ambassador to China told the secretary of state that he believed that the administration of the first President Bush had badly miscalculated its policy toward Beijing, newly declassified government documents show.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: High-Technology Optimism
description: India's leading software exporter, Infosys Technologies, plans to add as many as 2,000 employees. The company's chairman, N. R. Narayana Murthy, told shareholders at their annual meeting on Saturday that adding employees would help Infosys take advantage of opportunities during the current slowdown and help prepare for a recovery. Infosys, which currently employs 9,800, plans to spend $80 million to add infrastructure in the current fiscal year, which began in April, Mr. Murthy said. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWITT, JULIAN
description: LOWITT-Julian. The Board of Directors and staff of Fedcap Rehabilitation Services Inc. mourn the death of Executive Director Emeritus and Boardmember, Julian Lowitt. Julian dedicated his career to Fedcap, and the cause of independence and opportunity for people with disabilities through employment. He was a trailblazer in the field of vocational rehabilitation, nationally known and deeply loved. Julian came to Fedcap in 1960, and served as its Executive Director from 1991-94. After retirement, he became a vital member of our Board of Directors, serving as chair of the Fedcap Business Advisory Council. His guidance, dedication and humor will be greatly missed. His legacy will endure with each new business and government partnership that opens the door for people with disabilities to achieve economic independence. Our sincere condolences to his wife Bertha, daughter Sue, son-in-law Tom, and grandson Jon.

title: Moral Code Guides a Bible-Belt Barbie
description: When ''Kristin'' has its premiere on NBC tonight, it could be useful to think about Nathan Lane. You know Mr. Lane, the brilliant Broadway star of ''The Producers'' who won a Tony Award Sunday night; the comic genius who can do no wrong; the man who bombed completely in ''Encore! Encore!,'' his 1998 attempt at an NBC sitcom. (He played an opera star who moved back to the family vineyard.)

title: Frogs Chirp, Birds Sing In a Paean To Creation
description: A mockingbird was calling out from the piano, and frogs chirruped back from the nearby creek. Olivier Messiaen's hundred-minute panoply of creation, ''From the Canyons to the Stars,'' was in the right place here on Saturday night when Esa-Pekka Salonen conducted the Los Angeles Philharmonic in a performance with Paul Crossley at the piano that was the main event of the Ojai Music Festival.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped on doubts that the European Central Bank would be able to prop up the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 84.60 cents, down from 84.76 cents on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about continuing violence in the Middle East and the shooting death of a settler, Sarah Blaustein, misstated her destination when she moved from the United States last August. It was the settlement of Efrat, which is in the West Bank, not in Israel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Governor's Race Takes Shape in Virginia
description: Ending one of Virginia's most bitter nomination battles in years, Republicans have nominated Attorney General Mark L. Earley, a conservative abortion opponent, as the party's candidate for governor in the fall.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Control of Senate by G.O.P. Now Passes to the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  The Senate switched to the control of the Democrats today, with the two parties locked in intensive negotiations over the unusual mid-year power switch, including the handling of President Bush's judicial nominees. But many Republicans seemed resigned to their loss of power and in little mood to begin the new era with a bruising confrontation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Parker Has a Melanoma
description: The Giants starting guard Glenn Parker was watching television a few weeks ago, his feet up on the sofa, when his wife noticed a mole on his calf. ''I didn't think much about it,'' he said today. ''I spent so much time in the sun as a kid that I've got a lot of things on my face I was more concerned about.''

title: Riots Break Out as Nepal Gets 3rd King in 4 Days
description: Rioting erupted here in Nepal's capital today, just hours after the enthronement of a new king, this Himalayan nation's third monarch in the last four wrenching days.

title: Corrections
description: AMay 28 Op-Ed article incorrectly stated that the Manhattanville College faculty's union was recognized by a regional division of the National Labor Relations Board. The Manhattanville case, which concerns the faculty's right to hold an election on union representation, is pending before the regional N.L.R.B. It is the Manhattan College faculty that has been recognized by the regional and national N.L.R.B. offices as having the right to unionize.

title: The O'Connor Court: America's Most Powerful Jurist
description: We are all living now in Sandra Day O'Connor's America. Take almost any of the most divisive questions of American life, and Justice O'Connor either has decided it or is about to decide it on our behalf. The Supreme Court may tell us soon whether affirmative action in public universities is permissible, and if it does, O'Connor is likely to cast the deciding vote. The court is divided about school vouchers too; O'Connor's views will probably tip the scales.

title: Defense in Terror Trial Cites U.S. Sanctions Against Iraq
description: Lawyers for a man convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, sought yesterday to save their client from execution by telling a jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan that the United States government was also involved in the killing of innocents, through its actions against Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Los Angeles mayoral race between Antonio Villaraigosa and James K. Hahn omitted a word in describing the 1969 campaign by former Mayor Sam Yorty, to whom Mr. Villaraigosa likened Mr. Hahn. The Yorty campaign was considered overtly racist.

title: Demolition Men
description: Coach Larry Robinson conceded last week that it would be very difficult for the Devils to repeat as Stanley Cup champions without production from Alexander Mogilny and Scott Gomez.

title: INSIDE
description: Gunfire in Gaza

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk Is Likely to Let Homeowners Bar Mosquito Spraying
description: In Suffolk County, where opinions on how to deal with virus-bearing mosquitoes can pit neighbor against neighbor, county legislators are expected to pass a bill Tuesday giving homeowners the right to keep the county from spraying antimosquito pesticides on or near their property.

title: Medicare Shift Toward H.M.O.'s Is Planned
description: A top federal health official said today that the Bush administration would try to double the enrollment of Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations within four years.

title: Front Row
description: Sex and the Closet

title: Memoir of an Offbeat Clan Strikes a Chord
description: When Dorothy Gallagher was writing ''How I Came Into My Inheritance and Other True Stories,'' she expected that this memoir of her family -- politically radical Jewish immigrants to the United States from Ukraine -- would have limited appeal. In a recent interview, she said she assumed that it would fall into the ''black hole'' of disappearing books, as had her two previous biographies. To her surprise, it has struck a common chord in people from vastly different backgrounds. As she said, ''Protestants from the Midwest are saying, 'You're writing about my family.' ''

title: Scientists Shifting Strategies In Quest for an AIDS Vaccine
description: Seventeen years have passed since federal officials and a prominent scientist, in a moment of wishful thinking that they will never live down, stood up at a news conference and announced that an AIDS vaccine would be ready for testing in two years, and on the market in three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETZINER, NORMAN
description: PETZINER-Norman, 91, died suddenly, in his Delray Beach, FL home on June 2. He had been a long time resident of Westchester County, NY. Born in NYC, he was a graduate of Peter Stuyvesant High School and Columbia University School of Pharmacy. He had been a founding member and violionist in the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester, the Yonkers Philharmonic Orchestra and the Deerfield, FL. Symphony. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Helen, two daughters, Terre Wallach and Barbara Carman, six grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, a brother, Milton, and sister, Mildred Firestone. The service is to be held at The Riverside in Mt. Vernon, NY at 21 Broad St. Wednesday, June 6, at 12 noon.

title: In Australia, Even Foster's Is Turning to Wine
description: Australian companies are snapping up wineries here and seeking acquisitions and partnerships abroad to take advantage of phenomenal growth projected for markets overseas. Analysts and executives say the trend is part of a worldwide consolidation in winemaking and marketing.

title: The Future of an Epidemic
description: I remember standing on a beach on an overcast day in 1985, feeling as if I knew a tragic accident was about to happen and no one could hear my warnings. Now the world knows about what I feared then -- the enormous size of the AIDS epidemic -- but to look ahead from here is to feel again that not enough people appreciate how a failure to act effectively would undermine the quality of life for everyone on the planet.

title: See France by Barge
description: There are savings of $400 a passenger on French Country Waterways barge cruises from July 22 to Aug. 18 and Oct. 21 to Nov. 3. The hotel barges, which hold from 8 to 18 passengers, cruise in Burgundy, the Upper Loire and Alsace-Lorraine. The rates include all meals and wine, sightseeing and transfers between Paris or Strasbourg and the barges. Discounted rates range from $3,195 to $4,395 a person, double occupancy. Contact (800) 222-1236 or www.fcwl.com .

title: Bloomberg Announces Run for Mayor in TV Ads
description: The Republican field for mayor of New York City lost all the tidiness that party leaders had hoped for today as two men  one a perpetual candidate and the other a billionaire political neophyte  announced that they were entering the race for the party's nomination..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VRIONIS, MARY LORETTA KELLY
description: VRIONIS-Mary Loretta Kelly on June 3, 2001. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Mary Ann, George and John. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass Thursday 10am at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont.

title: Iljaz Sinanoski, Bitola, Macedonia, May 6, 2001
description: he night of April 30, while everybody was asleep, some 50 stores were burned down in Bitola, and some houses, too. It was the Macedonian youth who did it. This did not come out of the blue: two days before, eight security men -- four Macedonian policemen from Bitola and four soldiers -- were killed by Albanian rebels. But these were not only Albanian shops. They were also Muslim Macedonian and Turkish. We are Macedonians too, of Islamic faith. All in all, our family lost three out of seven shops. The people who did this came back the next day, around lunchtime, and then thoroughly looted one of them.

title: OPEC Leaves Oil Production Unchanged Despite Iraqi Cut
description: VIENNA, June 5  The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to delay an increase in production, a move that could push crude oil prices higher in coming weeks if Iraq makes good on its recent threat to keep its oil off world markets.

title: A Cut Above the Rest, With an E.R.A. Way Below
description: Pedro Martinez's record over the last five years has established him as the most dominating pitcher in the game. Here are the E.R.A. figures during that span.

title: James M. Fleetwood Jr.; Executive, 54
description: James M. Fleetwood Jr., the chairman and chief executive of LifePoint Hospitals, died on Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he was on vacation. He was 54 and lived in Nashville.

title: A Bond Forged in the Crucible
description: Hours before he signed Shaquille O'Neal to a contract in 1996, Jerry West was shaking. West, then the team president of the Los Angeles Lakers, was so worried that O'Neal would change his mind that his nerves simply took over his body, more so than at any time during his Hall of Fame playing career.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid Rejected
description: The brewer Wolverhampton & Dudley said it had rejected a $1.4 billion bid by the Pubmaster Group for its 1,750 pubs in Britain. Pubmaster, a unit of Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, already owns 2,000 British pubs. It offered 480 pence ($6.83) a share in cash and assumed debt. Wolverhampton said the price was too low. Its shares closed at 472.5 pence ($6.72), unchanged. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: In the Bronx, Fear for a Priest Last Seen at Church Thursday
description: The energetic pastor of a Roman Catholic church in the Bronx disappeared Thursday after apparently driving off in his car, the police said yesterday. The pastor, Msgr. Lamont Hamilton of Holy Rosary Church, was last seen by the church's secretary, Tessie DiTuri, who told investigators that his outfit included a beige jacket and black shoes when he left the rectory on Adee Avenue about 1:30 p.m.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Mine Shift
description: In a surprise move, the Australian miner BHP Ltd., which is in the process of buying Billiton P.L.C. for $11.6 billion, said Mick Davis, left, Billiton's chief financial officer, would resign to make way for BHP's Chip Goodyear as the chief development officer of the combined group. Mr. Davis will leave to become chief executive of the Swiss miner Xstrata, BHP said. He had been seen as an architect of the merger, which is intended to create the world's biggest mining company, and was expected to mold the strategy of the combined group. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Market Place; Questions about a software company's dealings in India.
description: THREE weeks ago it was Bulgaria. Now it is India -- where new questions have come to the surface about AremisSoft, a software company whose prospects are the subject of an intense battle on Wall Street.

title: A Chorus of Hallelujahs And Tears for a Teacher; From Finland to the Bronx and Back Again
description: Was it really three weeks ago that Johanna Grussner took 24 children from the Bronx, the members of the Public School 86 Select Chorus, to her homeland in the Aland Islands of Finland?

title: Still Setting the Tone In the Southeast; Charleston's All-Purpose Arts Festival At 25, Ever Eclectic but Newly Secure
description: A lush and decadent nightclub run by gangsters, its walls covered in plush red velvet, was the setting for a Puccini opera staged at this year's Spoleto Festival U.S.A. The characters included gun-toting thugs in tuxedos, exotic dancers in fishnet stockings and a white-slaver who branded his captives with a hot iron.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Yahoo To Sell Consumer Reports Research
description: Yahoo, operator of the most-visited site for Internet searches, will sell Consumer Reports buying guides online and get an undisclosed share of sales from the magazine's publisher. General information about cars and other products will be offered free, Yahoo and Consumers Union said in a statement. Detailed reports with performance ratings will cost $2.95.

title: Advocates for Patients Barged In, and the Federal Government Changed
description: The AIDS epidemic has profoundly altered the way government responds to health emergencies, galvanizing medical research, speeding the review of new drugs and forcing officials who make health policy to share power with patients and their advocates.

title: Storytelling As a Subplot In a Classic Ghost Story
description: It was a dark and stormy night. That isn't the first line of ''The Woman in Black,'' which begins with an agitated man in a rain-spattered overcoat entering an unlighted building, but it might as well be. The play is a shamelessly hokey Victorian ghost story, and it comes complete with misty marshes, an isolated village whose citizens bear a secret, a solitary mansion, a graveyard, spectral sightings, a shriek in the night and a lingering curse. And it is performed by two speaking actors whose talky re-enactment of events is as forthrightly about the conventions of theatrical storytelling as it is about spooks and nightmares.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Curbing Greenhouse Gases
description: Pemex, the state-run energy syndicate and the world's fifth-largest oil company, announced that it would begin a voluntary program to limit its carbon dioxide emissions. It is the first Latin American company to pledge to reduce greenhouse gases. Pemex officials said they would reduce emissions to 1 percent below 1999 levels.

title: Article 2001060590575889055 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bankrupt The Bunny
description: Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc., the publisher of the children's book ''Pat the Bunny'' and owner of the rights to the cartoon characters Felix the Cat and Underdog, filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in two years yesterday to speed the sale of the company for $170 million. In Chapter 11 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., the publisher listed $170.1 million in assets and $220.6 million in debts. The New York-based company said it would be sold to DIC Entertainment Holdings Inc. for $170 million in assumed debt, cash and commercial paper, and will become private. DIC Entertainment will gain Golden Books's library of more than 500,000 titles, including comic books and 3,000 movies, the companies said in a statement. Golden Books filed for bankruptcy protection in early 1999 in New York and emerged from that reorganization process in January 2000.

title: As Senate Shifts, Republicans Weigh Options
description: About to lose control of the Senate for the first time in more than six years, Republicans face quick and significant decisions on what tone and tactics to employ as a minority.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BONGIOVANNI, RAYMOND RAY
description: BONGIOVANNI-Raymond Ray, since 1996 we miss your dancing feet. Love Barbara and Lisa

title: Monarchy Is Still at the Heart of Many Nations in Asia
description: A reverence for monarchy has remained strong in Asia despite the modernizing trends that have transformed many countries in the region economically, socially and politically.

title: Social Security Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Through Halls to the Stage at a Graduation Concert
description: Abigail Levine drew the audience into the La Guardia Concert Hall on Thursday night with ''Thru,'' a site-specific piece set to music by Evan O'Reilly. Fifteen dancers led the way through the halls of La Guardia High School, joyously taking over the stage at the end. The three dances that followed in the 2001 Graduation Dance Concert at La Guardia, the school that was the subject of the movie ''Fame,'' made even better use of the ebullient youthfulness as well as the impressive dance skills of their casts, in a program dedicated to the Denishawn dancer Jane Sherman.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Children Receiving Psychiatric Drugs
description: A state-commissioned study to be released today reports that nearly one out of 20 children covered by Medicaid is taking psychiatric drugs like Ritalin, a stimulant; Prozac, an antidepressant; or lithium, a mood stabilizer. The study, conducted by the Yale Child Studies Center with the Connecticut Department of Social Services, reported that some of the children were younger than 4 years old.

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: No Stopping a Fit, Strong and Relentless Agassi
description: The umpire was hunkered like a gargoyle above the court, refusing to overrule a questionable ace by Franco Squillari, triggering murmurs, boos and whistles inside Center Court today.

title: Ex-Cuban Spy Deported by Mexico Asks Fox to Help Free Him
description: A former Cuban diplomat and spy who was jailed in Havana after seeking political asylum here, has asked President Vicente Fox to help him regain his freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, W. DUANE, MD
description: TODD-W. Duane, MD, June first, beloved husband of Dorothy Jane Keith. Father of George Damon Todd and Alison Keith Todd Cokorinos. Grandfather of Emily and Katherine Cokorinos. Brother of Donald Todd. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT, or Sloane Hospital for Women, Att. Dr. Roger Lobo, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 West 168th St., NYC 10033.

title: Price of Oil Rises as Iraq Halts Exports
description: Crude oil prices rose yesterday after Iraq halted exports in a dispute with the United Nations, which is considering a change to sanctions that would make it harder for the nation to import weapons components.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Robbery At Chelsea Piers
description: Three masked men with handguns stole $12,000 from a safe at a bowling alley at the Chelsea Piers early yesterday, the police said. The men surprised three employees at 1:35 a.m. as they counted the day's receipts in the manager's office on the second floor of AMF Chelsea Piers Bowl. The manager was struck with the butt of a gun and told to open the safe, the police said. All three employees were then tied up using telephone wire. The police were called when one of the men freed himself after about 40 minutes. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, JESSE (DOC)
description: SOBEL-Jesse (Doc). Beloved father and mentor to John and Bart, owner and director of Camp Winaukee for over 50 years and founder of the Winaukee Island Camp. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife, Gertrude, his children, Bart, John and Jane and to their families. The CampGroup Family

title: FLEETBOSTON TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF LIBERTY FINANCIAL
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the asset-management business of the Liberty Financial Companies for about $900 million to broaden its financial services and add clients. The company said in a statement that it would also assume about $110 million in debt. The transaction will increase the assets under management of FleetBoston's investment business to $173 billion from $122 billion. The acquisition is expected to close at the end of the third quarter. The purchase price represents a $750 million premium to the total worth of the assumed operations, the statement said. Liberty Financial said it also planned to become a unit of its controlling stockholder, the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, in a separate transaction. Under that agreement, Liberty Financial shareholders will receive $33.44 a share in cash.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Region Affirms Independence
description: Somaliland voted overwhelmingly -- 97 percent in favor -- to remain independent from the rest of the nation, according to official results from a referendum last Thursday. The region, once a British colony in the northwest of what is now Somalia, declared its independence 10 years ago and has been more stable than the rest of Somalia, although it has not been recognized by outside nations. The vote is, in many ways, a formal rejection of a Somali government formed last summer that has had trouble asserting its control over the entire country. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Asbestos Costs May Drive USG To Bankruptcy
description: The USG Corporation, a maker of wallboard, said yesterday that it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as the cost of legal settlements with victims of asbestos-related diseases rises.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Data-Storage Vendors Back Common Standards
description: Leading data-storage system vendors yesterday announced their support of industry standards aimed at making it easier for customers to mix and match certain types of storage equipment. The participants in the standards include storage the server vendors EMC, I.B.M., Compaq Computer and Hitachi Data Systems and two major suppliers of networking equipment, Brocade Communications Systems and McData. The companies negotiated the agreement under the auspices of the Storage Networking Industry Association but some association members said they were not invited to participate. ''They haven't provided any details yet,'' said Denise Shiffman, vice president for marketing for Sun Microsystem's network storage group. ''If the standards really are open, we will support them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, HARRY
description: SCHACHTER-Harry. A dear friend to all of us. A man of integrity and compassion. He will forever remain in our memories. Barry Tenzer and Family

title: Killings at Tiananmen Remembered in Hong Kong
description: Defying claims that the memory of the 1989 killings around Tiananmen Square is fading with time, nearly 50,000 people turned out here today to remember the protesters who died in Beijing.

title: When Jurors Serve Day and Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Volunteers Submit to Science
description: Thousands of people have volunteered to test AIDS vaccines. Some are gay, some straight. Many are perfectly healthy, though some act in ways that put them at risk of contracting H.I.V.

title: EDISON SCHOOLS ACQUIRES COMPETITOR IN STOCK DEAL
description: Edison Schools, a private operator of public schools, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held LearnNow for $34 million in stock to add 11 schools and $38 million in revenue. Edison will pay LearnNow about 1.4 million of its common shares and will lend the company as much as $4 million, Edison said. The purchase is expected to close on July 1. It will give Edison schools in Washington and Chester, Pa., and add 3 cents a share to Edison's earnings for its 2002 fiscal year. Both companies are based in New York.

title: Mideast Cease-Fire Strained on 2nd Day
description: A fragile new cease-fire plan was severely tested in its second day today as Israeli forces traded fire for hours with Gaza gunmen and stopped almost all goods and people from moving in or out of Palestinian communities.

title: State's Top Court Orders a Portrait of Wachtler
description: In the dark, wood-paneled courtroom of the State Court of Appeals, in the rows of portraits of past judges looking down sternly on their present-day colleagues, there is a blank space.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Politics Is In The Genes
description: William E. Simon Jr., the son of the former secretary of the Treasury, intends to make his first run for political office, seeking the Republican nomination for governor of California next year, aides said. Mr. Simon, 50, left, an investment banker who served briefly as a federal prosecutor in New York City in the mid-1980's, is expected to make a formal announcement later this year. The other announced Republican candidate is California's secretary of state, Bill Jones; Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles is also considering a run. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Manslaughter Charges Against Lay Midwife Lead to Mistrial
description: A judge declared a mistrial today in the case of a midwife charged with the death of a baby she delivered in a couple's suburban Chicago home.

title: Starting With the Secular, Ending Up With the Divine
description: Whether the work is paper cutouts, androgynous dancers or brightly colored portraits and windowscapes, Matisse's genius often speaks through deceptive simplicity. Yet in few cases is his minimalism more charged with effort and meaning than in his paintings and stained-glass windows for the Chapel of the Rosary in this medieval town near Nice. He was 81 when he completed the job. ''For all its imperfections,'' he wrote, ''I consider it my masterpiece.''

title: Article 2001060593773033802 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Currency Policy
description: Thailand's new central bank governor, Pridiyathorn Devakula, made official a sharp reversal in monetary policy, saying at his first news conference that he would try to push interest rates higher to slow foreign debt repayments and defend the nation' s currency. The government of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra appointed Mr. Pridiyathorn last week after dismissing Chatumongkol Sonakul, who had sided with the International Monetary Fund in favor of low interest rates to stimulate exports and encourage companies to borrow at home to pay off loans overseas. Mr. Pridiyathron said he wanted to slow those outflows to foreign creditors. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUAT, HELEN VICTORIA SHAPIRO
description: QUAT-Helen Victoria Shapiro. Beloved wife of the late Leon, beloved mother of Daniel and the late Joanna, and grandmother to Kevin, cherished sister of Dorothy Evslin and the late Mortimer Shapiro, and beloved aunt of Ruthy Samuel, and the Shapiro, Evslin, Lobsenz and Dayan children, died peacefully in her sleep on June 4, 2001. She was 82 years old. Family and friends will gather at her home at the Mayfair House, 96 Cuttermill Rd, Great Neck, NY, 11021 on Thursday June 14 from 25pm. Inquiries should be directed to Daniel at 518-325-1004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRD, FLORENCE
description: HIRD-Florence. Wife of Irving for 48 years, died June 4th. She is survived by three children, Anne, Linda, and Adam, and their spouses, Paul, Daniel, and Diana. She was also Nana to her twin grandsons, Alexander and Andrew. For 25 years, she had a career as a rehabilitation counselor for individuals with disabilities. Florence was a remarkable woman, with an enormous capacity for making a positive difference in every life she touched. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday June 6, 2001 at 4 P.M. at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY (516-764-9400).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, RICHARD L.
description: LEEDS-Richard L. Passed away May 11, 2001 in Camp Hill, PA. He was 88 and a former resident of Bronxville, N.Y. Survived by sons Richard L., Jr. of Mechanicsburg, PA and Thomas F. of Medfield, MA., daughter Linda L. Scott of San Juan Bautista, CA., seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. He attended Yale University and was a graduate of the Univerity of Arizona. He was the devoted husband of the late Mary Louise Gilchrist Leeds, a member of the Reformed Church of Bronxville and retired as Publisher for Blessings Corporation. Services private. Donations may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Westchester County.

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook: Transfer of Power
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  The transfer of power in the Senate means a big transfer of real estate.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: 7 Held In Church Bombing
description: The police said they had detained seven suspects in the bombing of a Catholic church on Sunday that killed 10 people in a village southwest of Dhaka, the capital. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack on Christians, a rare event in the overwhelmingly Muslim country.

title: When Death Sentences Are Reprieved
description: Save for the cane, needed because a head injury permanently impaired his balance, Kenneth Schliemann, a 71-year-old from Brooklyn, seems like many other retirees: healthy and strong, intellectually and physically active, busy soaking up all that life can offer a man of his age and means.

title: Putting a Tax Rebate to Use; Many Are Expected To Save the Money Or Pay Their Debts
description: The $45 billion or so in tax rebates and cuts that are scheduled to take effect this summer should give the economy a modest but important lift at a critical time, economists say, just as jobs remain hard to find and energy bills are draining money out of pocketbooks.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From the superiority of ground pepper to matching wine with food, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Foul Trouble Ends Home Streak for Liberty
description: The Sacramento Monarchs had the size and the speed, but for much of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, their size did them little good and their speed was negated by the Liberty's pressing defense. Then, at the end of the first half and the start of the second, the Liberty got into foul trouble, and the Monarchs awakened and ran away with an 80-63 victory.

title: Armstead's Absence Annoys the Giants
description: For many teammates, he was the emotional leader, the commanding presence on a Giants team that took an improbable ride to last season's Super Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, MARJORIE HELEN
description: McGRATH-Marjorie Helen. Age seventy-seven of Clearwater, Fla. Died Thursday, May 24, 2001 after a long convalescence from a stroke. Born in Cleveland, Ohio on October 25, 1923. Moved to Florida in 1985 from New York City.

title: The Sound of Amateurs Communing With Nature
description: The spring concert given by the New Amsterdam Singers, on Thursday in St Peter's Church at the Citicorp building, offered amateur choral singing at its best. Directors of amateur choirs have to make do, to a large extent, with what comes to them -- in this case rather few men, and most of those showing more enthusiasm than expertise. The tenors sounded strained in their most exposed music; the basses were prone to a throaty parlando.

title: LOS ANGELES BANK TO BE SOLD FOR $141 MILLION
description: The FBOP Corporation, the closely held parent of the Regency Savings Bank in Illinois and the California National Bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Bank Plus Corporation for $141 million. FBOP will pay $7.25 for each share of Bank Plus, which is based in Los Angeles. The offer is 37 percent more than Bank Plus's closing price on Friday. Bank Plus had about 19.4 million shares outstanding as of May 9. Bank Plus, the savings and loan holding company that owns Fidelity Federal Bank, said the transaction was expected to close in the fourth quarter. FBOP, based in Oak Park, Ill., also owns banks in Texas and California.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Appearances Are Deceiving

title: Cordiant Agency In German Deal
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London has agreed to acquire about 19 percent of United Visions Entertainment in Berlin, which produces live entertainment programs for television and the Internet, for about $4 million in cash.

title: Fragile Cease-Fire in the Mideast
description: It remained unclear yesterday whether the cease-fire announced over the weekend by the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, would be genuine and lasting. Mr. Arafat's public call for an immediate and unconditional halt to the violence, followed by his orders to Palestinian security forces to block attacks on Israel from Palestinian-controlled territory, were positive steps. But he acted only after worldwide revulsion at last Friday's murderous suicide bombing and under the threat of Israeli military retaliation. New gun battles yesterday in Gaza and the Palestinian Authority's failure so far to return convicted terrorists to prison left the situation precarious.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Jobless Rate Jumps
description: Unemployment has risen sharply as a three-month-old economic crisis continues to ripple across the country. The National Statistics Institute reported that 358,000 people lost their jobs in the first quarter of the year, pushing the official unemployment rate to 8.6 percent, though the real rate is widely thought to be higher. Doug Frantz (NYT)

title: Not Funny at All
description: To the Editors:

title: McCain Antics Weary Arizonans in G.O.P.
description: Tim Regan is a registered Republican who voted for John McCain in his last two Senate elections. But the other day, he jumped in his van and drove 110 miles from Phoenix to stage a protest outside Mr. McCain's cabin here in the Arizona desert.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Simplex And Toshiba Make Chip Innovation
description: The Toshiba Corporation and Simplex Solutions announced yesterday that they had developed a new way to link switches on a microchip, a breakthrough they say will improve chip performance, cut production costs and require less power. By linking chip parts diagonally, rather than at right angles, the companies say that they can more effectively connect the ever-increasing number of components on a chip. The method could eliminate the traditional grid pattern known as ''Manhattan routing'' that has dominated microchip design for years. The announcement sent Simplex shares to a 52-week high, closing at $38.20, up $10.20, or more than 36 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLEY, WALTER
description: HANDLEY-Walter. Died peacefully at home on May 31. Born in Vienna in 1904, he married Margaret Loewe in 1934 and ran both families' businesses. In 1938 he started a new life in England but came to New York as the war drew closer. In 1945 he founded Handcraft Inc. where, as a well respected designer and businessman, he was considered an asset to the menswear industry, even by his competitors. At 75, he developed a cashmere scarf division for Amicale Inc. Working until age 95, he remained a friend and mentor to his colleagues. Mr. Handley personified old-world charm and elegance and was an optimist who lived life to the fullest. He and Gretl traveled extensively. He was a remarkable man who will be missed by all who knew him; the beloved husband of Gretl, the adored father of Joan, grandfather of Michael and Daniel and father-in-law to Steven. A private funeral was held. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to VNS Hospice.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RHEOMETRIC SCIENTIFIC, Piscataway, N.J., acquired Aviv Instruments, Lakewood, N.J., to gain products used to identify proteins and drugs.

title: Executives Acquire Cleanup Company
description: American Capital Strategies Ltd., the buyout company that offered to take Roy F. Weston Inc. private in March for $51 million, said today that it had bought Weston, an environmental cleanup company, for $66 million.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: AIDS AT 20
description: A special issue of Science Times

title: Surplus of Finger-Pointing In California Energy Crisis
description: Natural gas prices have plunged in the last few months -- everywhere, that is, but Southern California. While gas in New York costs about $4 per thousand cubic feet, gas delivered to Southern California still costs more than $11 wholesale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, RAYMOND T.
description: TUCKER-Raymond T. Of Weston, Ct., originally of Brooklyn, N.Y. Devoted father of Maryann, Laura, Raymond and the late Elizabeth. Cherished grandfather of Erin Elizabeth, Allyson Marie and Margo Tucker. Caring husband of Mary. Beloved brother of Jackie, Bobby, James, Mary Stenson and Esther Gillan. Dearest uncle of Betty Jean O'Shei, Mary Ann Phillips and many special nieces and nephews. Loving friend to many, especially Lorraine Geaney. Funeral Mass at the Brooklyn Oratory at St. Bonisace RC Church, Brooklyn on today, June 5, 9:30am. For additional information call Scotto Funeral Home 718-875-2515

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORGE, VALERIE ANNE
description: GORGE-Valerie Anne. On May 26, 2001, at age 34, of Paris, France, and New York City. Treasured wife of John S. Rogers Jr., beloved daughter of Gerard and Martine. We will remember her truly courageous spirit as she endured a lengthy and difficult treatment for leukemia. Family and friends will also remember her fearlessness, dignity, and remarkable passion for life that lasted right until the end. She passed peacefully with her loved ones by her side. Her family and friends gratefully thank the dedicated doctors and staff of N.Y.U. Medical Center and the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the cancer research center of your choice and spread the word that both blood and bone marrow donation play a critical role in the battle against all cancers. Please donate in Valerie's honor. She will live forever in our hearts and memories.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bankrupt Bagel Company Bought
description: New World Coffee-Manhattan Bagel Inc. will buy the assets of the Einstein/Noah Bagel Corporation, which is bankrupt, for as much as $190 million in cash and assumed liabilities to become the largest chain of bagel bakery shops. New World, the winning bidder in Friday's auction in United States Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix, will pay $160 million in cash and assume as much as $30 million in liabilities, the company said. As Einstein/Noah's largest creditor, New World and its affiliate, Greenlight New World LLC, will receive more than $40 million. New World will gain 458 bagel stores in 29 states and the District of Columbia, giving the Eatontown, N.J., company 800 locations, it said in a statement. Included in the transaction are a factory in Los Angeles and a support center in Golden, Colo. Einstein/Noah had revenue of $375.7 million in 2000.

title: Graves Is Up For Masterton
description: Adam Graves, one of the Rangers' most popular players, was named a finalist for the Masterton trophy yesterday.

title: 3 Fake Drugs Are Found in Pharmacies
description: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating four cases of counterfeit prescription drugs making their way to pharmacy shelves, and, in some cases, being given to patients.

title: North Korea, Displeased, Said to Review Missile Pacts
description: Citing their deep displeasure with Washington, officials from North Korea have threatened to pull out of two agreements under which that isolated nation had promised to halt missile testing and to stop building nuclear reactors that could be used to produce weapons, an American academic said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, KIM
description: SHULMAN-Kim. Our hearts go out to our good friends, Claire and Mel Shulman and their family at this time of loss. Ivan Seidenber, Chair Seth Dubin, President Emeritus Alan Friedman, Director and the Board and staff of the New York Hall of Science

title: Proposed Change At Big Board
description: The directors of the New York Stock Exchange will take up a proposal on Thursday to limit activities of the floor traders known as specialists in an attempt to deal with concerns that pricing in dollars and cents, introduced this year, is disrupting trading. The Big Board's market performance committee has already approved the measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AYRE, HELEN (NEE RICE)
description: AYRE-Helen (nee Rice). In her 80th year. Beloved wife of Harry. Beloved mother of Barry and Stuart. Loving mother-in-law and best friend of Denise and Lois. Proud grandmother of Jessica, Melissa and Jake. Loving sister of Pearl Greenfield. She will be sorely missed by all who were touched by her kind and generous spirit. Services today at 12 noon at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapels, 152 2nd Ave. at 10th St.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about American Ballet Theater's new production of John Cranko's ''Onegin'' referred incorrectly to the work's first performance by an American company. That occurred in 1994 with the Boston Ballet, not in the current production.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: South Orange: Honorary Degree Criticized
description: A conservative Catholic group is urging Seton Hall University, a Catholic institution, to rescind an honorary degree recently given to an Atlanta college president who served on an abortion-rights committee. The group, the Catholic Alliance, said Seton Hall should not have presented Dr. Delores E. Cross, president of Morris Brown College in Atlanta, with an honorary doctorate during Seton Hall's May 7 commencement. A Seton Hall spokeswoman said that the university would not rescind the degree but also that it ''does not knowingly'' confer degrees on people who support abortion.

title: Seduction and Reduction On a British Campus
description: THINKS . . .

title: Stanley Cup Finals And Snowballs in June
description: They are different universes, the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. One has a national footprint, the other does not. And it may never.

title: Corrections
description: A May 28 Op-Ed article incorrectly stated that the Manhattanville College faculty's union was recognized by a regional division of the National Labor Relations Board. The Manhattanville case, which concerns the faculty's right to hold an election on union representation, is pending before the regional N.L.R.B. It is the Manhattan College faculty that has been recognized by the regional and national N.L.R.B. offices as having the right to unionize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, JOSEPH
description: GLADSTONE-Joseph. June 3, 2001. Husband of Lucia (nee Vignola), of Moorestown, N.J. Father of Corina Gladstone, Alexander Gladstone and the late David Gladstone. Brother of Sally Rock. Services Wednesday, 10:30 AM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Rd, Cherry Hill, N.J. Interment Westchester Hills Cemetery, Ardsley, New York.

title: When Jurors Serve Day and Night
description: To the Editor:

title: As Sixers Fly High, Mountain Is Looming
description: After a night of little sleep and sweet celebration, the Philadelphia 76ers took a shower of adrenaline and flew to Los Angeles emboldened for the next seemingly insurmountable challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINER, SOL
description: SCHEINER-Sol, 71. June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Loving father of Melissa, Mark, Chanie, Jonathan and Vicki. Proud grandfather of Alyssa, Rebekah, Elihayou, Dalia and a newborn grandson. Brother of Rabbis Louis and Hershal and Shirlee Shatzkes. Shiva will be at 3671 Hudson Manor Terrace, Apt 9E, Riverdale, until Sunday morning, Shiva on Friday will be at 186-36 Avon Road, Jamaica Estates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, ISRAEL
description: HURWITZ-Israel. Of Boca Raton, formerly of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Sara, father of Donald and Jules. Grandfather of Jenna, Jese, Rebecca, and Jeanette. Brother of Herbert and Rhoda. We will miss you. Graveside service Tuesday, June 5, Mt Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens.

title: Napster Is Said to Be Near Accord on Music Sales
description: The online song-swapping service Napster is close to an agreement for permission to use music from three of the major record companies in a pay version of its service, according to people close to the situation.

title: Yanks Solve Martnez, but Need Sojo for Finishing Touch
description: Pedro Martnez started the game for the Red Sox. Derek Jeter had the hit that drove in the tying and go-ahead runs for the Yankees. Mariano Rivera tried to finish the game for the Yankees, but Manny Ramirez prevented that from happening with a ninth-inning flourish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATTEM, SOLOMON
description: HATTEM-Solomon, age 87, died peacefully with his family by his side on June 2nd, 2001 in Tamarac, FL. Loving husband of 54 years to Leonore Hattem and devoted father of Esther, Albert, Gary and Dave. Also survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Former President of Uneeda Drinks and WWII combat veteran who served five years in the Pacific. A true gentleman, he will be deeply missed.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Take Me Out To The Restaurant
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation wants someone to operate a three-story restaurant built into the new Richmond County Bank Ballpark in St. George, Staten Island. The baseball stadium faces the harbor just north of the St. George Ferry Terminal and is home to a minor-league team for the New York Yankees. Opening day is June 19. The 7,800-square-foot restaurant would be open year round and would be expected to draw customers from the 11 million commuters and 1 million tourists who take the ferry every year. Bids are due on July 16, and it is hoped that the restaurant will be open before the end of this season. Jim O'Grady (NYT)

title: In Accord, Turkey Tentatively Agrees European Union Force May Use NATO Bases
description: Diplomats from Britain, the United States and Turkey have drafted an agreement that would eliminate one of the main barriers to the establishment of a new European defense force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTTOLA, JO
description: MOTTOLA-Jo. On June 2, 2001 at age 81. Beloved sister of Rita, John, Jeanne, Phyllis Sartori; devoted aunt of many nieces and nephews. Jo's successful Secretarial Service resulted in her Memoir, published in 1994 by sister, Rita, highlighting Jo's association with 68 celebrities. A woman of great knowledge of history, literature, opera and film. Her large family, friends, opera singers and doctors will miss her brilliant mind, her dry wit, the sparkle in her eyes and her devotion to all who knew her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, Tuesday, 2-5 and 79PM. Funeral Mass at St. Paul the Apostle Church, 9th Avenue at 60 Street, Wednesday, 11AM. Interment Pinelawn Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, c/o Cabrini Medical Center, 227 E. 19 St, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOHN H., M.D.
description: McGOVERN-John H., M.D. The Board of Trustees and Medical Board of Lenox Hill Hospital express sorrow at the passing of John H. McGovern, M.D., a distinguished member of our Urology Department for over 32 years. Dr. McGovern was a respected physician who was dedicated to the highest standards of medicine. The entire hospital family honors the memory of this devoted physician and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Allen H. Collins, M.D., M.P.H., President, Medical Board Valavanur A. Subramanian, M.D., Director of Surgery John Fracchia, M.D., Chief of Urology

title: When Jurors Serve Day and Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, RAINE SARAH
description: BERNSTEIN-Raine Sarah. Age 3, died suddenly on June 3, 2001. Beloved and adored daughter of Debra Cherney and Hartley Bernstein, granddaughter of Eleanor Bernstein and Rita and Walter Cherney, dearest friend of Lynette Houston. You filled our lives with love, wonder, laughter and joy. Funeral services Tuesday, June 5, 11:00 AM at Temple Israel, 112 East 75 St., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Raine Bernstein Memorial Fund, 955 Park Ave., 5W, NY, NY 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEWIS, CLARA (NEE WASSER)
description: BLEWIS-Clara (nee Wasser) of New York City, died June 4 in Baltimore, MD. Wife of the late Bernard A. Blewis. Mother of Gordon (Julie) Blewis of MD and Richard Blewis of England. Sister of Henry Wasser of NYC, NY. Grandmother of Jenna and Brian Blewis and Maria C. Blewis. Services-private. For information, Sol Levinson & Bros Inc. 800-338-1701

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: German Shells Send Town Packing
description: The 540 residents of Chtelet-sur-Retourne, a village in eastern France, are packing their bags before the arrival of experts who are to remove 170 tons of German shells from World War I found in the area recently. The residents are being told to leave for nine days. In April, 13,000 people were evacuated near Vimy in northern France so 55 tons of poison gas shells from World War I could be removed. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany; Assembly Begins Live Broadcasts
description: The State Assembly went on live television yesterday, a week after the Senate began broadcasting its deliberations live on the Internet. The Assembly's broadcast, the first of four planned for this month, fulfills a promise made by Speaker Sheldon Silver to televise the chamber by the end of the session. He said that beginning next January, all Assembly deliberations would be televised. The broadcast was seen on different channels across the state. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Conservation Pays Off
description: By turning off lamps, cutting back on air-conditioning and buying energy-efficient light bulbs and appliances, Californians helped reduce the state's electricity consumption by 11 percent last month, compared with May 2000, state officials said. The conservation was more than the 10 percent reduction Gov. Gray Davis called for, and his energy advisers had forecast that only a 7 percent reduction would be achieved. In May, the state consumed 18,616,485 megawatt hours of electricity, a drop of 2,289,362 from the same period a year earlier.

title: Nepal Imposes New Curfew as Protesters Take to Streets
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, June 5  This morning, along Ring Road, protesters lobbed bottles and burned tires, demanding the noose for whoever killed most of Nepal's royal family as they ate dinner in the palace last Friday.

title: Article 2001060593305619465 -- No Title
description: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Slower Growth In Air Travel
description: The British airport operator BAA P.L.C. said it expected slower growth this summer as concerns about foot-and-mouth disease keep tourists away. BAA, which operates Heathrow and Gatwick Airports, said passenger traffic in the year ended March 31 rose 5.8 percent. In the last two months, however, passenger traffic has slowed 1 percent. The company said it expected growth to level off at 4 to 5 percent. BAA also reported pretax profit rose 78 percent in the fourth quarter, to 78 million ($110.9 million). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Deutsch Making Management Changes
description: Deutsch in New York, now part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is making management changes.

title: President Bush and the Everglades
description: President Bush, who was in a testy frame of mind last week in California, and who has avoided New York altogether, seems to have found a big, politically important state where he can feel at ease. It is Florida, which he visited yesterday to tout his national parks initiatives. Of course, he should feel comfortable in Florida. The state gave him the White House (barely), and his brother Jeb is the governor. Moreover, an $8 billion plan to restore the Everglades, bequeathed to him by the Clinton administration, is ideologically comfortable -- a joint federal-state project that fits well with what Mr. Bush's aides are now describing as his ''new environmentalism for the 21st century.''

title: U.S. Opposes Further Delay of Execution
description: Government prosecutors asked a federal judge today to deny any further delays in carrying out Timothy J. McVeigh's execution, which is scheduled for Monday, saying ''there is no case where the death sentence is more appropriate.''

title: Bye Bye Bye To 'N Sync's Baby Bop Bubble Gum
description: In the mid-1990's America went through a dry spell of stadium concerts. Then in June 1997 U2 came marching into Giants Stadiumwith a stadium concert tour, the first in the Northeast in two years. Called PopMart, after the band's ''Pop'' album, it was intended as post-spectacle, a statement on the disposability of fast-food pop culture and its premillennial status as the Western's world's most worshiped religion.

title: TWEETER HOME ENTERTAINMENT BUYS FLORIDA COMPETITOR
description: The Tweeter Home Entertainment Group, a consumer-electronics retail company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sound Advice for $117 million to add 33 stores in Florida and Arizona. Under the transaction, each of Sound Advice's 4.07 million shares will be converted to one Tweeter share, said Anne-Marie Boucher, a spokeswoman for Tweeter, which is based in Canton, Mass. The sale is expected to close about Sept. 1. Sound Advice, based in Dania Beach, Fla., owns 24 Sound Advice stores, 5 Bang & Olufsen stores and one Electronics Interiors store, all in Florida. It also runs two Showcase stores, in Scottsdale and Chandler, Ariz., and a home theater showroom at a Sears, Roebuck store in Arizona.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Budget Methods Questioned
description: A lawsuit has been filed contending that New Jersey's proposed budget would illegally divert $90 million into the general fund that should go to bridge and road repair. The lawsuit, filed Thursday, also charges that $50 million from the Transportation Trust Fund would be used to cover deficits at New Jersey Transit. The suit was filed by five nonprofit groups, including the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. The suit names Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Department of Transportation and others.

title: Teacher Pact Still Far Off
description: On the surface, it seems like an auspicious moment for advocates of change in the New York City public schools.

title: Israelis, Palestinians and Tripwires
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, PEARL
description: KAPLAN-Pearl. The Hebrew Free Burial Association mourns the passing of Pearl Kaplan, mother of Stanley Kaplan, distinguished member of our Board of Directors. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Kaplan family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bjorn Bamberger, President, and The Board of Directors of HFBA

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about President Bush's efforts to overhaul the military misstated the Pentagon title of Rear Adm. Craig R. Quigley, who commented on review panels assembled by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld. The admiral is deputy assistant secretary for public affairs, not assistant secretary.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Natural Gas Prices Remain High in Southern California

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard To Pay Pitney Bowes $400 Million
description: Hewlett-Packard, the nation's leading PC printer maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $400 million to Pitney Bowes to settle patent technology lawsuits, one of which was scheduled to go to trial this week. That suit, involving print technology patents, was brought by Pitney Bowes in 1995 and scheduled to go to trial in the United States District Court in Connecticut. Hewlett, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it would revise its second-quarter earnings statement to reflect the settlement as a pretax charge. The patent infringement suit, which involved print technology, was scheduled to go to trial yesterday. The companies settled the suits without admitting any infringement. As part of the settlement, Hewlett and Pitney Bowes have agreed to share technology. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Ex-Executive Sues Helmsley, Charging Antigay Bias
description: After her husband, the real estate owner Harry B. Helmsley, died four years ago, Leona Helmsley tried to simplify her life, selling blocks of real estate for more than $2.5 billion and settling bitter feuds with three of Mr. Helmsley's closest associates.

title: Rule Limits Overcharging Of Roommates
description: In a case threatening upheaval for many rent-stabilized tenants in New York City, a judge has ruled that landlords may evict those who charge roommates more than a fair share of the rent.

title: Gambling On Internet Wins a Vote
description: The Nevada Legislature voted yesterday to authorize regulators to license casinos to offer gambling over the Internet, the first time a state has moved to legalize the potentially lucrative but highly controversial business of online gambling.

title: Hernndez on Surgery Watch as Team Tries Rest Cure for Toe
description: Orlando Hernndez received a cortisone injection in his left foot yesterday and will keep the foot partly immobilized for at least the next week while the Yankees wait to see if he will need surgery. The pitcher, who has an 0-5 record, has an inflamed second toe on the foot and the Yankees have wondered if he will eventually need surgery to correct a problem that he said has bothered him all season.

title: C.I.A. Chief Going to Mideast for Security Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  The Director of Central Intelligence, George Tenet, will leave within hours for the Middle East to assist efforts to bring about a lasting peace in the region, the Bush administration announced today.

title: McVeigh Execution Sought
description: Government prosecutors asked a federal judge to deny any further delays in carrying out the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, which is scheduled for Monday. Page A19.

title: The Magic of Martnez In Three Easy Letters
description: In the 1920's, Babe Ruth was baseball's dominant player. In 1921, for example, his 59 home runs were two and a half times the total for the American League's next-best home run hitter and were more than the totals of five of the other seven teams. When Ruth hit 60 home runs in 1927, he exceeded the totals of each of the other A.L. teams.

title: A Jury Orders Tobacco Companies to Pay Millions to Blue Cross
description: A federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday ordered some of the country's largest tobacco companies to pay up to $18 million to cover the cost of treating hundreds of debilitated smokers in New York, finding that the companies had lied to the public about the dangers of smoking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, MARVIN M.
description: ROSNER-Marvin M. On June 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Clare. Cherished also by nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 10am-1pm, funeral services to follow 1:15PM at Frank E, Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of 81st Street.
