title: World Briefing | Africa: Donation To Fight Meningitis
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is donating $70 million to help find a vaccine for a strain of meningitis that affects millions of Africans. The money will go to a 10-year program to find a vaccine that would give long-term protection against meningococcal meningitis, which is on the rise in the 15 sub-Saharan African countries where it is endemic.

title: Building Boom and Less Demand Make Hotel Rooms Easier to Get
description: It was just a few months ago, it seemed, that it was almost impossible to book a hotel room in Manhattan. But those days are over -- at least for now -- because of a slackening economy and a record construction boom.

title: The Need for Cooperation With Europe
description: Later this month, President Bush will take his first official trip across the Atlantic, to attend meetings with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies, the European Union and President Vladimir Putin of Russia. He can expect to encounter some disagreement, just as his secretary of state recently did. But then, Europeans disagree among themselves, and vigorously. One would have be a whirling dervish to see eye to eye with all of Europe all the time.

title: Divided Civil Rights Panel Criticizes Florida Election
description: A fractured United States Commission on Civil Rights has prepared a sweeping broadside against Florida officials over last year's presidential election, calling them ''grossly derelict'' and saying their ''lack of leadership'' led to the disenfranchisement of countless Floridians, a majority of whom were African-American.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Rumsfeld Says Air Patrols Over Iraq Are in Ever Greater Peril
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the American and British pilots who fly patrols over Iraq are under increasingly dangerous fire because of improved Iraqi defenses. He blamed China and other countries that he said had supplied the Iraqis with advanced antiaircraft technology.

title: AIDS in Africa
description: Q. Why is AIDS so prevalent in Africa?

title: Public Interests; Bloomberg Beams In
description: Michael Bloomberg is supposed to enter the race for mayor of New York today, not in the flesh but via a barrage of TV commercials. There is also a Web site, where you can dial up www.mikeformayor.org and find a photo and biography. (''The former Eagle Scout's passion for helping others comes from his strong belief that those who are fortunate have an obligation . . .'')

title: Ratings for Tony Show Remain Flat
description: Even the excitement of ''The Producers'' was apparently insufficient to draw significantly more viewers to the Tony Awards broadcast on Sunday night than had watched in the past few years.

title: Sports of The Times; History Adds An Incentive For the 76ers
description: IN what promises to be a delicious subplot to the N.B.A. finals, it has been left to the Philadelphia 76ers to slow down the Lakers' locomotive, partly in defense of their own historic ancestry.

title: Productivity in Steepest Fall Since 1993
description: The productivity of American workers declined 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the sharpest drop since 1993, as labor costs increased at the fastest rate in a decade, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 28 about the effect of a Democratic-controlled Senate on the Bush administration's foreign policy misidentified the country where John Negroponte -- now Mr. Bush's nominee for ambassador to the United Nations -- once served as ambassador. It was Honduras, not Nicaragua.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Anthony Quinn yesterday misstated the number of times he was married. It was three, not two. After his second marriage ended in divorce, he married his former secretary, Kathy Benvin, the mother of two of his children.

title: Officer Testifies on Chase In Which He Shot Teenager
description: A New York City police officer took the stand yesterday in his trial in the shooting two years ago of an unarmed Bronx teenager, providing an illuminating picture of how officers with the Street Crime Unit thought and acted in their effort to get illegal guns off the street.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Raffles Sells Stake
description: Raffles Holdings will sell 55 percent of a local hotel and retail complex to bond investors for 984.5 million Singapore dollars ($543 million), the latest in a string of Asian companies to tap the debt market as stocks slide. Raffles, known for the 114-year-old Raffles Hotel in Singapore, sold the stake in the nearby Raffles City complex to help finance acquisitions worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECHTER, RICHARD MICHAEL
description: RECHTER-Richard Michael. On June 3, 2001. Most beloved son of Melvin and Marcy. Loving brother of the late James. Devoted fiance of Audrey David. Cherished grandson of Jean and the late Arthur Meth. Services Thursday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: JUSTICES REVERSE DEATH SENTENCE OF RETARDED MAN
description: The Supreme Court today overturned the death sentence of a retarded Texas man, Johnny Paul Penry, who in 20 years on the state's death row has become a symbol of a growing national debate over executing the mentally retarded.

title: Numbers Game Leaves Mets Numb
description: As they prepare to open a three-game series in Philadelphia Tuesday night, the Mets still believe they have a chance to contend in the National League East. But they need only to look at Sunday's 1-0 loss to the Marlins for the reason they are struggling.

title: Respected Assistant Coaches Await Chance at Top Job
description: DENVER, June 4  This occurred late in the morning skate today before Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals between the Devils and the Colorado Avalanche. The Avalanche's regular players were in the dressing room while those who would not play last night were getting a little extra work with the assistant coaches on the Pepsi Center ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHNERT, ROBERT M.
description: AHNERT-Robert M. of Bushkill, Pennsylvania and Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Died on May 22, 2001 in Fort Lauderdale. He is survived by his wife Margaret, a son David, his brother Harry, and five grandchildren. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Matthews Catholic Church, Ridgeway Street, East Stroudsburg, PA at 7:00 p.m. on Wednesday, June 13, 2001.

title: Judge Hearing Custody Fight Would Keep Thai Boy in U.S.
description: A federal judge said today that a 3-year-old Thai boy detained last year while being used as a decoy in an immigrant trafficking scheme should remain in the United States.

title: Texas Death Bill Is in Hotter Spotlight
description: The decision by the Supreme Court today to overturn the death sentence of a convicted murderer, Johnny Paul Penry, perhaps the nation's most famous mentally retarded inmate, has intensified the fight in Texas over legislation that would ban the execution of murderers who are retarded.

title: Tokyo Journal; A Politician's Face Launches 1,000 Cash Registers
description: The only line that used to build up outside the headquarters of Japan's governing party was the string of black cars, some with tinted windows, that appeared after lunch as the drivers returned their bosses to the office.

title: The Fusion Makes A Major Turnaround
description: This is quite a metamorphosis for the Miami Fusion, one of Major League Soccer's weaker teams last season. Under the direction of RAY HUDSON, in his first full season as coach, the Fusion has turned into an elite team. Its 6-2 victory in Dallas over the Burn last Saturday was its fifth in a row and extended its unbeaten streak to eight games.

title: One Man's Principle: One Home One Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Ally On Trial
description: Slobodan Milosevic's former secret police chief, Radomir Markovic, went on trial behind closed doors on charges of revealing state secrets. The case against Mr. Markovic, who was arrested in February for the death of four people in a car crash aimed against the opposition leader Vuk Draskovic, appears to be connected to political killings that occurred under Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president who is now in jail. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Midas Begins An Account Review
description: Midas Inc. is beginning a review of its American creative and strategic account, with billings estimated at $60 million, after what the company described as the dismissal of the incumbent agency since December 1998, Euro RSCG McConnaughy Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: BRITISH OFFICE COMPANY CONSIDERS BUYING RIVAL IN U. S.
description: Regus, a British provider of office space, said yesterday that it might buy the FrontLine Capital Group in an all-stock transaction to expand in the United States. Regus, which owns 360 business centers in about 50 countries, said it was in talks to buy FrontLine, which is based in New York, and its HQ Global Workplaces unit, Regus's biggest rival and the largest provider of temporary office space in the United States. FrontLine, which invests in real estate and technology companies, owns 58 percent of HQ, which is based in Dallas.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Tom Cloninger was named to the new posts of president and chief operating officer at NetCreations, New York, a unit of SEAT Pagine Gialle that offers e-mail marketing services. He had been group executive at the Acxiom Corporation, Conway, Ark.

title: Article 2001060592070860347 -- No Title
description: Cyber Law Journal: Controversial Ruling on Library Filters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERVIN, JOSEPH
description: CHERVIN-Joseph. Loving husband of Suzanne, devoted father of Matthew and Erica, and Douglas and Theodore. Funeral services today 10 A.M. at I.J. Morris Inc, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY,

title: A Halfway Proposal on Schools
description: Like most of his predecessors, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has long sought legislation to give the mayor full control over the New York City school system. Opposition to mayoral control has centered largely in the teachers' union and its allies in the State Legislature. But now with contract negotiations reaching a critical point, the union's president has switched positions and advocated a modified form of mayoral control under an expanded Board of Education. The change of heart was welcome, but the proposal outlined by the union president, Randi Weingarten, does not go nearly far enough in making the mayor accountable for the city's faltering school system.

title: Riposte From Franks in Governor's Race
description: A 60-second radio commercial, ''Grace,'' was released yesterday by former Representative Bob Franks in his contest with Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey. It is running on conservative talk programs in New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia.

title: Article 2001060592944863198 -- No Title
Metro Business Briefing
description: BANKRUPT THE BUNNY Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc. , the publisher of the children's book "Pat the Bunny" and owner of the rights to the cartoon characters Felix the Cat and Underdog, filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in two years yesterday to speed the sale of the company for $170 million. In Chapter 11 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., the publisher listed $170.1 million in assets and $220.6 million in debts. The New York-based company said it would be sold to DIC Entertainment Holdings Inc. for $170 million in assumed debt, cash and commercial paper, and will become private. DIC Entertainment will gain Golden Books's library of more than 500,000 titles, including comic books and 3,000 movies, the companies said in a statement. Golden Books filed for bankruptcy protection in early 1999 in New York and emerged from that reorganization process in January 2000. (Bloomberg News)

title: From Giuliani, Words of Praise For Election Bid By Bloomberg
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he thought Michael R. Bloomberg was qualified to succeed him and that the Republican mayoral candidate and billionaire businessman ''would certainly know how to run the City of New York.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Restrictions On Church-Owned Property Appealed
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Utah appealed a federal judge's ruling in May that upheld restrictions on the Mormon Church's Main Street Plaza in Salt Lake City. The city sold the block of downtown property to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in 1999 for $8.1 million, with conditions that allow 24-hour public access but include restrictions on speech, dress and conduct. The A.C.L.U. maintains that the restrictions are discriminatory and has asked the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, to review the constitutionality of the plaza rules.

title: Mr. Toledo's Peru Posible
description: Alejandro Toledo, one of 16 children of an Andean sheepherder, who went from shining shoes on the street to teaching at Harvard, was elected president of Peru on Sunday. In a country not noted for social mobility, Mr. Toledo's rise indicates unusual perseverance, talent and luck. He will need all these qualities in the job now before him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, MARTHA
description: WEBER-Martha, passed away Sunday afternoon, June 3, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel P. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Perlman, Dr. Ellen Weber and the late Richard. Loving grandmother of Amy and Jill Perlman; mother-in-law of Alvin Perlman and Jonathan Showstack. Contributions to your chosen charity. Services today, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Bush Carries Environment-Friendly Tone to Everglades
description: President Bush today made this lush, sweaty landscape of sawgrass prairies and mangrove forests the latest setting for his bid to assure Americans that he cares about the environment, calling it a ''beautiful slice of heaven'' that demanded vigilant protection.

title: Voices From the Front Lines of Medicine
description: The following excerpts are from personal essays and oral histories by former and current government officials commenting on the AIDS epidemic. Some of the essays were collected in the book ''AIDS and the Public Debate: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives'' (IOS Press, 1995), and others are from the oral history project of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Chavez Enjoys Week In the New York Sun
description: Even more so than in other years, the Belmont Stakes is shaping up to be a race with a heavy New York flavor. There is no Triple Crown on the line, as there had been in three of the previous four years, although the $1 million race will have a sense of drama as Monarchos, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, squares off against Point Given, the winner of the Preakness.

title: Article 2001060590957049767 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Variations On a Faun And States Of Unrest
description: Just as composers sometimes write variations on other composers' themes, so choreographers can incorporate other choreographers' ideas into their works. Two such choreographic variations were offered by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: A Nominee's Views
description: To the Editor:

title: United Airlines Buys Online Marketer
description: Jumping into one of the most troubled sectors of the Internet economy, the parent of United Airlines said yesterday that it would buy MyPoints.com, an online marketing company, in a deal valued at $105 million.

title: Human Rights Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBRICK, REV. CLYDE
description: HAMBRICK-Rev. Clyde, Pastor of Green Pasture Baptist Church, 1115 Ward Ave, Bronx, NY, for 30 years, died on May 30, 2001. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Green Pasture Baptist Church Scholarship Fund in memory of Reverend Clyde Hambrick. For information Granby's Funeral Service, Inc. Bronx, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Crackdown on Illegal Tobacco Sales
description: The City Department of Consumer Affairs has confiscated 20,000 packs of cigarettes in a crackdown on unlicensed vendors, the department announced yesterday. After 4,000 inspections, said Jane Hoffman, the commissioner, the department found 28 unlicensed dealers in the city. Inspectors seized the cigarette inventory when dealers continued selling them after promising not to. Of these, 11 had since obtained licenses and paid $11,000 in fines. Seized cigarettes are returned to vendors who obtain licenses and pay penalties; those not returned in six months may be destroyed. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: The Sciences, A Magazine, Is Shut Down
description: The Sciences, the small but influential magazine published by the New York Academy of Science, has ceased publication.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CUFFE, EDWARD W.
description: CUFFE-Edward W. 2/16/36-6/5/96. A pirate between piracies-Fall River Irishman in search of original sin. He ran money like Rimbaud ran guns. Bars and cemeteries are full of good friends. He was born with the gift of laughter and with a feeling that the world was mad. This was his entire inheritance. As Dr. Johnson said of Garrick, ''His death eclipsed the gaiety of nations and impoverished the public stock of harmless pleasure.'' He has gone to where savage indignation can no longer lacerate his heart. Go traveler, try and imitate him if you can. He served liberty. We can become frozen in our attachment and fear or we can recognize the liberation of our true nature. Rage on wherever you are. The Ding Ansich Dynasty

title: Man in the News; Peru's New Leader, an 'Indian Rebel With a Cause'
description: Alejandro Toledo's election as president of Peru is the culmination of a remarkable personal journey out of poverty. But it also signifies the coming of age of a rising urban class of people with Andean Indian roots struggling to find a new identity.

title: AIDS Doctor Looks Back On a Long, Slow Climb
description: Take it from one who knows: there is no surer way to stop a party conversation cold than to tell a group of friendly strangers that you have spent a good fraction of the last 20 years taking care of people with AIDS.

title: Support, and Caution, for a School Crime-Report Law
description: Police, school and other city officials expressed near-unanimous support yesterday for a proposed law that would make it a crime for school officials to fail to report a sexual offense or other criminal act to the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, ROSE (ROSIE)
description: OSTROW-Rose (Rosie). Passed away Monday June 4, 2001. She was the devoted wife of the late Sidney Ostrow, beloved mother of Linda Lawrence, and Joan Gottlieb, and revered grandmother of Rand Lawrence, Tracy Lawrence-Brookman, Nicole and Jordan Gottlieb, as well as idolized sister of Louis Hoch, and cherished sister-in-law of Pearl Gumora, and Dorothy Ochser. Funeral service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside, Hewlett, LI at 10 A.M. Wednesday June 6th. A woman whose life was devoted to giving and receiving the unrequited love of her family.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bid To Stop Groton
description: Southern New England Telecommunications has appealed an April ruling by the Department of Public Utility Control in Connecticut that would allow Groton Utilities to build a 32-mile fiber-optic network providing Internet access and other services in the Groton area. Audrey Honig, a spokeswoman for the telecommunications company, said that as a municipally owned entity, Groton Utilities would have unfair advantages, including tax exemption. But Glenn Wilson, Groton Utilities's general manager, said that in its application the company had agreed that the project would be taxable. Groton Utilities serves 11,000 electrical customers. Tara Bahrampour

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLODGETT, CARLISLE S.
description: BLODGETT-Carlisle S., on Saturday, June 2, 2001, of Washington, D.C., and New York, NY. Beloved wife of the late Delos A. Blodgett II of New York. Mother of Kendra B. Schechter. Also survived by two granddaughters and two nieces. Memorial services will be held at a date to be determined. Interment in Lake Placid, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice. For information, call Joseph Gawler's Sons, 202966-6400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, ANTHONY
description: QUINN-Anthony. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Anthony Quinn on June 3, 2001. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Vintage Brodeur Shows Up in Time for Devils
description: Who is the better goalie in the Stanley Cup finals? Which is the better team? It is too soon to tell. This championship round will go at least one more game, maybe two, and the momentum changes from game to game. What was clear last night, however, was that Martin Brodeur led the Devils to a 4-1 victory over Patrick Roy and the Colorado Avalanche, giving the Devils a three-games-to-two lead in the four-of-seven Cup finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, TONY
description: LONG-Tony, Sculptor, May 30, in Paris. Beloved father of Natalie Conrad (Paris) and Alexander, son of Bernice, brother of John (Fairfield), companion of Mary Vogel (Cambridge), friend of Louis Asekoff, Vyt Bakaitis, Beatrice Conrad and the Vogel family. Royal Society of British Sculptors, Int. Funeral, June 6, 9:30 a.m., Pere Lachaise. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Profit
description: For the second consecutive month, Daewoo Motor reported that it had made an operating profit of several million dollars. The bankrupt company refused to disclose the profit, but a spokesman said it was slightly higher than the $5.2 million reported for April. The report coincided with the start of talks about a possible acquisition of Daewoo at an undisclosed site outside Korea by General Motors and Daewoo's creditors, led by the government's Korea Development Bank. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: A Dozen Dead In Kashmir
description: Four civilians were killed and 17 wounded when anti-India militants tossed a grenade toward a security post on a crowded street in Srinagar, Kashmir. The police said the bomb missed its target and landed in the road. In another incident, Indian officials said border guards had killed eight militants trying to sneak into Indian-controlled Kashmir from Pakistan. India has called off its unilateral cease-fire.

title: Pataki Is Said to Weigh Emergency Budget
description: With budget negotiations stalled, the State Senate majority leader said today that Gov. George E. Pataki had raised the possibility of sending a three-month emergency spending measure to the Legislature when the current one expires next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, RUTH
description: WEXLER-Ruth. We extend our sincerest condolences to Jack Wexler, Ann Fromer and Gary Wexler on the passing of their beloved wife and mother. During her lifetime, Ruth embodied the qualities of courage, dignity and grace. As a Golden Founder of the Medical Center, together with her husband, Jack, and as a member of the National Women's Division and a past Honoree, Ruth made a vital difference to the health-care needs of thousands of people in Jerusalem. She served as an exemplary role model to her children, including her daughter, Ann, who together with her husband, Robert, are Diamond Founders of the Hospital. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

title: One Man's Principle: One Home One Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001060591504528164 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: One Disease, Lived Six Different Ways
description: AIDS has struck a dizzying variety of Americans. Some 800,000 to 900,000 people of all ages, ethnicities and sexual orientations are living with the virus. Below, six people share their stories. One learned he had H.I.V. a few years ago. Several are in their second decades with the virus, having survived the days when an AIDS diagnosis meant death. One has lived with the disease her entire life.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Nurses Are On Strike
description: About 1,500 nurses at two Minneapolis-area hospitals are on strike after rejecting a contract offer. Union officials said the contract, which included a 19.8 percent raise over three years, was rejected because it did not give nurses enough control over their patient workloads. Nurses at five other hospitals voted to ratify contract agreements on Saturday and Sunday, but at four of those hospitals, nurses have requested recounts. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Bush Imposes Restrictions on Imports of Cheap Steel
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  President Bush took the first steps today toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel, handing a victory to American steel companies and unions that have long urged the government to grant relief from foreign competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, JOHN
description: O'NEILL-John. The members, officers and staff of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourn the loss of John O'Neill, retired RWDSU Vice President and RWDSU Local 3 President. His selfless devotion to the cause of working people made a difference in the lives of generations of workers at Bloomingdale's and the rest of the department store industry. He fought for the right of every worker to be treated with dignity, justice and respect. Our deepest sympathy goes to his daughter Barbara and to all the members of Local 3 whose lives he touched. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, UFCW, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum President Charlie Hall, Sr. Secretary-Treasurer Lenore Miller President Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDY, RUTH
description: BONDY-Ruth. Devoted wife of Edgar, beloved mother of Susie, Mikki, and Ron, cherished grandmother of Alana, Aviva, and Karen, loving mother-in-law of Trish. Services today, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: The Price Of Misery
description: Drought conditions have left some families so shy of cash that they have begun giving their daughters away just so they do not have to feed them, according to a study in the northern part of the country by the American branch of the charity Save the Children. Afghan families often ask for cash in return for marriageable daughters.

title: Bush Seeks Restrictions on Imports of Cheap Steel
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  President Bush took the first steps today toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel, handing a victory to American steel companies and unions that have long urged the government to grant relief from foreign competition.

title: Youths Charged After Sexual Details Go Online
description: Two male high school students in Chappaqua have been charged with harassment for posting a Web site that listed the names, phone numbers and alleged sexual exploits of dozens of their female classmates, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Joey Maxim Dies at 79; Outlasted Sugar Ray Robinson
description: Joey Maxim, a light-heavyweight champion who was the only boxer to keep Sugar Ray Robinson from finishing a fight, died last Saturday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79.

title: Reaching Beyond Symptoms to Causes of Addiction
description: THERE is something about Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal's office on the Upper West Side that makes you just want to take a load off your mind. The canvas slipcovered couches invite you to sink into them. The lamps cast a muted glow. And Dr. Rosenthal is sitting there, looking so relaxed, talking in a calm, low voice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Joining Forces With Yugoslavia
description: The defense ministers of Macedonia and Yugoslavia have signed a military cooperation accord that may allow Yugoslavia to supply equipment to its neighbor to help it fight ethnic Albanian rebels. Macedonia is fighting an insurgency in the west and north of the country, now in its fifth month. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: World Briefing | World: Food Problems In Biggest Cities
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said planners in the bulging cities of the developing world are not paying enough attention to increasing malnutrition and the lack of safe and regular food supplies for the poor. In giant cities like Calcutta and S~ao Paulo, about 70 percent of the population live in poverty, as do about half the people of most African cities, the agency said in a report for a meeting at United Nations headquarters on Wednesday. In poor countries, unacceptable slaughterhouses, poor food handling and inefficient garbage collection add to pollution and illness, the report said.

title: Princeton Honors Ex-Judge Once Turned Away for Race
description: Sixty-five years ago, Princeton University admitted the bright young son of a black father and a white mother on full scholarship. But when he showed up to register, university officials noticed the color of his skin and told him he would be more comfortable elsewhere. He sat on his trunk on the sidewalk for several hours while his father drove down from New York City to collect him.

title: When Jurors Serve Day and Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; The Tricks Involved in Being a Leader of the Pack
description: Maybe it happens in other cities, too. But it seems that New York offers its residents an incredible number of ways to earn what could be thought of as identification cards.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, HOWARD
description: GOODMAN-Howard. 8 years. Mara is married to your wonderful British son-in-law Justin Davies and our mother Ella died May 14 at age 98. We miss you and love you forever. Roni, Mara, Justin, the Goodman and Kulick Familie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, SADIE
description: REISS-Sadie. Beloved aunt and sister to Rabbi Philip Reiss and Jennie Kleiman, passed away Erev Shabbat. We will miss you. Moshe, Benyomin, Nechemiah and Isaac Reiss and families.

title: Deal's Failure Puts a Chill In the Plans Of Lucent
description: Lucent's decision last week to pull back on merging with Alcatel of France did not do much for Wall Street's waning confidence in the cash-short company. And now investors are refocusing on Lucent's need to sell its fiber optics business to keep the company in the good graces of its creditors.

title: Two Die and Dozens Are Hurt as Car and Bus Collide
description: A speeding car hurtled wildly out of control on a busy highway here this morning, racing across a grassy median and into the path of a charter bus carrying 54 members of a Pennsylvania church group on a day trip to Atlantic City, the police said. The driver of the car and his passenger were killed and dozens on the bus were injured, two critically, including the driver.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Sciences Gets $240 Million Contract
description: Computer Sciences said yesterday that it had received a seven-year, $240 million information technology outsourcing contract from Schroders P.L.C. Computer Sciences said it would manage infrastructure and application services, including desktop computing, help desk, and certain applications development and support. Computer Services had revenue of $10.5 billion for the 12 months ended March 30.

title: An Executive Opts For an 'entrepreneurial opportunity'
description: A top executive at a big agency is leaving to take the No. 2 post at a midsize agency company.

title: Abe Silverstein, 92, Engineer Who Named Apollo Program
description: Dr. Abe Silverstein, a mechanical engineer who oversaw parts of America's fledgling space program of the 1950's and 1960's, died on Friday at his home in Fairview Park, Ohio. He was 92.

title: DreamWorks Names Chief Of Production
description: Michael De Luca, who resigned as president of production at New Line Cinema in January after a dismal box-office run, has declined New Line's offer for a $100 million production deal and will instead join the rival DreamWorks as head of production.

title: A Little Chamber Opera Written for Full Orchestra
description: Carlisle Floyd's one-act opera ''Markheim,'' based on a short story by Robert Louis Stevenson, seems like a nice little chamber opera. The score gets the job done in workmanlike fashion, with set pieces broadly characterizing each of the four characters: Creach, the pawnbroker in whose shop the action takes place; Tess, his pretty young maid; Markheim, a dissolute aristocrat; and the Stranger, a Mephistophelean figure who promises him a life of pleasure. An offstage chorus sings Christmas carols -- to rather unseasonal music -- as a final Victorian touch. It's not, in fact, a chamber opera, since it's written for full orchestra; but if it were reorchestrated for a smaller ensemble, this would be a fine piece for conservatory students to cut their teeth on.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cypress Semiconductor Cuts Sales Estimate
description: Cypress Semiconductor, a maker of chips used in telecommunications equipment, said second-quarter sales would fall more than forecast as customers reduce orders. Sales will total $175 million to $185 million, down from earlier estimates of $200 million to $210 million, Cypress said in a statement. The company had revenue of $300.8 million in the year-earlier period and $262 million in the first quarter.

title: Nepal in the Family
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOAGLAND, ALEXANDER C.
description: HOAGLAND-Alexander C. June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Teresa, loving father of Valente, Antonio (Lupe) and Valeria (Luis). Cherished grandfather of Anna, Teresa, Alejandro, Felipe, Maria and Mariana. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, corner of 81st Street. Friday, June 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, June 9th, 10:30am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, JESSE (DOC)
description: SOBEL-Jesse (Doc). Your influence on us during our formative years will last a lifetime. We are so fortunate to have spent our summers with you, Puff, Bart and John at beautiful Camp Winaukee. Abbey, Adam, Jason and Michael

title: Adding Zip To Summer's Table
description: Cool materials and bright colors -- the sweet nothings of summer fashion -- are dressing this summer's tables.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMURRAY, JOSEPH P.
description: McMURRAY-Joseph P. The Queens College Community is saddened by the passing of Joseph P. McMurray, President of Queens College/CUNY from 1965-1971. After a long career in public service, he came to Queens College during a time of multiple challenges and transformations, when enrollment at the college reached a high point of 28,000. He was devoted to improving communication with the college community and reached out to involve faculty and students in making crucial decisions. He strongly supported sharing of power through their participation in an effective and collegial academic senate. He is remembered as a dedicated and courageous leader willing to confront tough decisions, and one who believed deepely in the ability of higher education to achieve a more equitable society. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Russell Hotzler, Acting Pres. & The Queens College Community

title: School Sex Attacks: A Cultural Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilliard Will Probably Need Surgery
description: The immediate future of Giants receiver Ike Hilliard will most likely be determined on Wednesday, and his agent said it does not look promising.

title: Different Budgets Bred Similar Success for Belmont Favorites
description: Anyone who has ever bred a race horse is united by an axiom that is vague and dreamy: ''Breed the best to the best and hope for the best.'' The point is that giving life to a champion is more art than science and everything from budget to luck is a factor in creating a winner of a Triple Crown race. Ask Jim Squires.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Covad Names A President
description: In a desperate attempt to stave off financial doom, the troubled high-speed Internet service provider Covad Communications has appointed Charles E. Hoffman, left, as its new president and chief executive, effective June 25. Covad's former chief executive, Robert E. Knowling Jr., resigned in October amid mounting losses. Covad reported a startling loss of $1.44 billion for fiscal 2000, and said it would delay announcing results for the March 2001 quarter until mid-June. Last week, the company disclosed that it had received notice from Nasdaq that it faced possible delisting. Mr. Hoffman, 52, was most recently chief executive and a director of Rogers Wireless Communications, Canada's largest wireless provider. Frank Marshall will resign as Covad's interim chief executive but will remain on the company's board as vice chairman. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Ohio Acts to Prevent Meningitis Spread
description: Health officials have ordered a precautionary vaccination program for 5,800 students and faculty and staff members at six Ohio schools after two high school students in Alliance died of bacterial meningitis.

title: From Dreamy To Aggressive, Sculptural All the While
description: Nancy Meehan and her company have been creating small worlds that exist in the moment, each stirred by its own mostly serene winds, for three decades. Their latest habitat is ''Timings,'' performed on Friday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

title: Dow Slides 105, Nasdaq Closes Down 16 Points
description: Stocks fell today as investors, bereft of any major economic data, cautiously stepped back after four days of gains.

title: Hague Manages to Keep a Stiff Upper Lip : The Designated Loser Slogs On in U.K. Race
description: NEWARK, England  Third in a series of articles

title: East Village Journal; Can't Stand Dry Heat? Don't Try This Bath
description: There's a glitch at the shvitz. The Department of Health turned off the water in one of the rooms at the Tenth Street Baths, and if you go downstairs to the Russian radiant heat room, where the heat usually reaches about 190 degrees, you can hear the customers hollering.

title: Article 2001060691184912834 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lutce Leaves the Past And Steps Into the Future
description: LUTCE is one of the oldest, most celebrated French restaurants in New York, a byword for refined cuisine and high style. But like many long-running shows, it has shown signs of fatigue in recent years.

title: What Politicians Those Gods Were
description: The god Apollo has the last word in ''Orestes,'' a playful and anarchic adaptation of Euripides' tragicomedy by the playwright Charles L. Mee Jr. In a voice-over, he speaks palliatively to a citizenry that has been strained by the murderous plottings and counterplottings of the descendants of Atreus, assuring his listeners that they maintain ''a civilization and a culture, a set of practices and well-known customs, values and ideals that are the rightful envy of the world.''

title: Sharon Robinson Discusses Her Father
description: Sharon Robinson held her guests' hands, put her arm around their shoulders, and cupped their chins as she spoke to them in the Great Moments Room at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Now, High Schools' Sex Gossip Is Scrawled on Web Site Walls
description: It used to be the stuff of locker rooms, bathroom walls and little black books, but sexual gossip among teenagers has been showing up lately in what some educators and others call a disturbingly powerful forum: Internet sites.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Nevada Proposal Lifts Cryptologic
description: Shares of Cryptologic Inc., which sells software that lets people place bets over the Internet, rose as much as 17 percent after the Nevada Legislature voted to allow the state's casinos to offer online gambling. The stock climbed $3.89, or 17.3 percent, to $26.41. Nevada's proposal, which must be approved by Gov. Kenny Guinn, would allow resort-size casinos in the state to apply for online gambling licenses.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Postal Service Reports Loss
description: The United States Postal Service said it lost $166 million in the third quarter of the 2001 fiscal year. The service said it had expected to earn $146 million, but a weakened economy halted the growth in mail volume, so it could lose as much as $2.4 billion by the end of the fiscal year. To help increase revenues, some postage rates will rise for the second time this year starting on July 1.

title: Race Issues Surface in School's Bid for Church League
description: A mostly black school's rejection from a mostly white Catholic athletic league has ignited controversy in this city that is both heavily Roman Catholic and in many ways still simmering with deeply rooted racial divisions.

title: McGovern Qualifies For the U.S. Open
description: Jim McGovern, a New Jersey native, was playing before family and friends yesterday as he competed in Purchase, N.Y., for one of five spots in local qualifying for the 101st United States Open, to be played June 14-17 at Southern Hills in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Shot by Shot, Capriati Buries Past
description: Jennifer Capriati had a fatigued Serena Williams dragging through the clay as if it were desert sand. But there she was, all but handing Williams a refreshment with every missed opportunity to finish off their French Open quarterfinal match. On her first match point, Capriati plopped a double fault into the net. An hour later, on two more match points, she sprayed ground strokes with timid swings.

title: For 20 Years, the Scourge of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIAL, MARGUERITE R.
description: PRIAL-Marguerite R. Our condolences and best wishes to Jim Prial, publisher of The Chief-Civil Service Leader, and to the entire Prial family. Richard A. Cook, President The Hundred Year Association of New York

title: Now a Leader, Iverson Turns Image Around
description: Allen Iverson lay on the football field, writhing in pain. He had been hit hard by two defenders after making a wonderful catch and did not think he could walk, let alone continue to play.

title: Grand Slam Events Study Increasing Seedings to 32 Players
description: Executives from the United States Tennis Association will approach the Grand Slam committee at Roland Garros on Thursday with a radical proposal to increase the number of seeded players for men and women at the United States Open from 16 to 32, a tennis official said today.

title: Commencement; At Princeton, Duty Is Tied To Privilege
description: When Tsehaitu Pitts immigrated to the United States from Eritrea in 1973, she intended to go to medical school. Instead, she wound up a single mother, working nights as a medical technologist in New Orleans and toiling ''extra, extra, extra,'' she said, to get the chance she had today: to see her eldest daughter, Martha Bathsheba Pitts, get a bachelor's degree from Princeton University.

title: West's Slump and Intifada Hit Israel's Pocketbook
description: Before last fall, the Israeli economy was in the best shape of its history. Now, battered by eight months of violence and bludgeoned by Nasdaq, it is slowing to a crawl.

title: The Pride of the Napa Valley Is Coming to Columbus Circle
description: FOR seven years, the only way to taste Thomas Keller's cooking was to make a pilgrimage to the Napa Valley -- and pray for a table at the French Laundry, his 62-seat restaurant.

title: A Significant Lift for a Long-Ailing U.S. Industry
description: The Bush administration's efforts to limit steel imports won praise yesterday from industry executives, who said the action was long overdue, while analysts predicted the actions could provide relief to an industry suffering from a wave of bankruptcies and minimal profitability.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Military Deal With Russia
description: India and Russia have agreed to develop a military transport plane and a new generation of jet fighters for India. Defense Minister Jaswant Singh said India had contracted for more than $10 billion worth of military equipment from Russia, India's biggest arms supplier, over the last four years. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Boy Hurt in Fall From Apartment Building
description: A 5-year-old boy who may have been playing in a vacant third-floor apartment fell from the Bronx building where he lives yesterday and was hospitalized in critical condition, the police said.

title: Bush Moves Against Steel Imports; Trade Tensions Are Likely to Rise
description: President Bush took the first steps today toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel, handing a victory to American steel companies and unions that have long urged the government to grant relief from foreign competition.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Filling A Hole On Long Island
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts opened its first store on Long Island yesterday. Restaurant Associates, a subsidiary of Compass Group, which runs six Krispy Kreme stores in New York City, will run the new one, in East Meadow.

title: Article 2001060690375674020 -- No Title
description: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

title: The New Balance on Capitol Hill Is Giving Some Senators Room to Move
description: The transfer of power in the Senate means a big transfer of real estate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, ERNIE
description: SANDLER-Ernie. Cherished husband of Gloria for 50 years. Loving father of Jeffrey, Stefanie and Matthew. Adored grandfather of Adam, Jonathan, Jennifer, Joshua and Cody. Dear brother of Judy and Marvin. Caring father-in-law of Barbara and Michael. President of Interstate Drug Exchange. Generous friend to all who knew him. Funeral services Thursday, 2:30 PM, Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn.

title: The O'Connor Court: America's Most Powerful Jurist
description: We are all living now in Sandra Day O'Connor's America. Take almost any of the most divisive questions of American life, and Justice O'Connor either has decided it or is about to decide it on our behalf. The Supreme Court may tell us soon whether affirmative action in public universities is permissible, and if it does, O'Connor is likely to cast the deciding vote. The court is divided about school vouchers too; O'Connor's views will probably tip the scales.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Executing the Retarded
description: Although this week's 6-to-3 Supreme Court decision overturning the death sentence of a retarded Texan named Johnny Paul Penry was decided on narrow legal grounds, it was nonetheless a significant victory for common sense and decency. The ruling is bound to add momentum to the growing national movement to end the nation's uncivilized practice of executing mentally retarded people convicted of capital crimes.

title: New York Life to Buy Union Pension Fund Manager
description: Joining a wave of consolidation among asset management companies, the New York Life Insurance Company's investment arm will announce today that it is buying a privately held San Francisco firm that is a leader in managing union pension funds.

title: No Charges for Officers In 1999 Shooting Death
description: The Justice Department has decided not to pursue criminal civil rights charges against four New York police officers involved in the fatal shooting in 1999 of a mentally disturbed man who was armed with a hammer, the United States attorney's office said yesterday.

title: As a Comrade, He Could Have Been A Contender
description: When the Italian director Gillo Pontecorvo filmed his starkly beautiful morality tale ''The Wide Blue Road'' in 1957, what remained of neo-realism, born 15 years earlier, was in the process of acquiring a grander, more operatic tinge in keeping with Italy's growing prosperity. The emergence of the Italian art cinema and of Antonioni and Fellini as world-class filmmakers was still two or three years away. It would be nine years before Mr. Pontecorvo, a dedicated Communist like so many European intellectuals in the 1950's, achieved international renown with ''The Battle of Algiers,'' an intensely political film steeped in 1960's liberationist ideology.

title: Television Ads By Schundler And Franks To Begin Today
description: With three weeks until the primary election, and with public matching funds finally coursing through their bank accounts, the Republican candidates for governor of New Jersey have taken their backroom brawl outside, where the voters might begin to pay attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEREY, ROSEMARY, O.B.E.
description: VEREY-Rosemary, O.B.E. The Board, and staff of The New York Botanical Garden deeply regret the loss of Rosemary Verey, O.B.E., the maker of Barnsley House garden, and a Distinguished Counsellor to the Board of the Garden. Mrs. Verey died last week in England at the age of 82. One of the most eminent figures in 20th and 21st Century horticulture, Rosemary was a great garden historian, garden designer, plantswoman, garden writer and teacher about plants and gardening. Through her magnificent literary oeuvre of 18 titles, her television series, and her extensive lecturing, she imparted the art and joy of gardening to a whole generation. Rosemary was a beloved member of our family, a mentor to many of us. We are all honored to have been her students and friends. Her legacy will include the Rosemary Verey Ornamental Vegetable Garden, which she designed for a beautiful site here . A memorial service will be held in September for Rosemary's American friends. We extend our most sincere condolences to her family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Gregory Long, President The New York Botanical Garden.

title: For 20 Years, the Scourge of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Guilty In '99 Shooting Of a Teenager
description: A Bronx judge convicted a police officer of misdemeanor assault yesterday for shooting an unarmed teenager two years ago while grabbing him from a moving car. The decision was unusual because judges rarely convict officers for on-duty shootings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MYER, JEROME
description: MYER-Jerome. June 6, 1991. Ten years since your passing, you are always in our thoughts. Your loving family

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Immigrants Seek Legal Status
description: Thousands of illegal immigrants flooded government offices in Athens and other cities seeking to avert deportation by providing evidence that they have lived in Greece for at least one year. The government suggests that Greece is home to about 800,000 illegal aliens, mostly Albanians. Under a new law, immigrants have from yesterday until Aug. 2 to produce documents required to establish legal residence. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: A Libretto via Ginsberg Captures a City's Spirit
description: Elodie Lauten became friendly with the poet Allen Ginsberg in the 1970's, soon after she moved to New York from Paris, and for a time she accompanied him at the keyboard when he chanted and sang. In 1996, Ms. Lauten persuaded Ginsberg to write a libretto for an opera she was planning about life in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, ROBERT D.
description: McCABE-Robert D. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Robert D. McCabe a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Navy Officer Missing in Philippines After Ambush by Guerrillas
description: A Navy lieutenant was missing on Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines late today after he was separated from a small group of American service personnel that came under fire from gunmen who identified themselves as members of a Marxist guerrilla army, Pentagon officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, DR. PAUL
description: KAY-Dr. Paul. The Department of Psychiatry, North Shore University Hospital-NYU School of Medicine, mourns the passing of our esteemed longtime colleague and friend, valued teacher, supervisor and mentor, caring psychiatrist and psychoanalyst. His teaching of the History of Psychiatry and concern for children inspired many young physicians over the past fifty years. Our heart felt condolences to Mrs. Barbara Kay and family. Jack L. Katz, M.D., Chairman Dept of Psychiatry North Shore University Hospital/ Manhasset

title: It's a Long Shot for the Sixers, but They'll Try to Sink It
description: Little Man, Big Obstacles

title: Hahn Wins L.A. Mayor's Race, Vows to Unite the City
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- City Attorney James K. Hahn, the low-key son of a beloved local political family, drew support from a rare coalition of liberal black voters and conservative whites to claim victory as the 40th mayor of Los Angeles early this morning, defeating former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, who had hoped to become his city's first Hispanic mayor in 129 years.

title: SAPPI, MAGAZINE PAPER MAKER, TO REDUCE PRODUCTION
description: Sappi Ltd., a leading maker of glossy paper used in magazines, said yesterday that it would reduce production from mills in the United States by 30,000 metric tons in the next four months. The reduction, equal to 8 percent to 10 percent of Sappi's United States glossy paper capacity, comes on top of 10,000 tons of cuts in the United States and a 70,000-ton rollback in Europe earlier this year, said Robert Hope, director of strategic development at the company, which is based in Bramfontein, South Africa.

title: Yankees Top Devils In New York Market
description: Despite the excitement of the Devils' taking a one-game lead over Colorado in the Stanley Cup finals Monday night, the Red Sox-Yankees game generated a slightly higher rating in the New York market.

title: Article 2001060691611181794 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: The Pick of a Favorite Grazing Ground
description: SOME women live for the weekend at Bergdorf's or Barneys. I prefer the Greenmarket on Saturdays, and also Wednesdays, and sometimes Mondays and Fridays, too. Like any obsessive shopper, I like to walk, look and compare. But I inevitably succumb to a few stands that have perfect food, pleasant people and fast service (no line jumping). These are my private Pradas of produce this time of year, worth the journey to Union Square even during the construction mess.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Takes First Steps To Limit Steel Imports

title: Reagan, Bush and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Superior's Role in Rwanda Horror Is Weighed
description: Sister Gertrude, once a mother superior, has been in court for seven weeks, listening to grim details about murder in the convent. She has barely moved except to bow her head, which is covered with the brown veil of the Benedictine order.

title: A Western With Real Spaghetti? In Amsterdam, It Got Third Prize
description: The second annual Rocket Clip Film Festival, a competition for budding filmmakers, was held on May 14 at the Paradiso Club here. The contestants' mission was to create a new film around an existing film soundtrack, choosing from ''La Dolce Vita,'' ''Doctor Zhivago,'' ''Run Lola Run,'' ''Trainspotting,'' ''Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence'' and a few others.

title: Our Towns; A Mystery At the End Of a Rainbow
description: IT'S making people crazy,'' Hemang Patel said from behind the counter of his family's convenience store, wearing a slightly amused smile.

title: HBO Scores On Sunday
description: No ''Sopranos?'' No problem. Or so it seems for HBO, which continued its run of record-setting series strength on Sunday nights with the season premieres of its returning hit comedy ''Sex and the City'' and its dark new comedy-drama ''Six Feet Under.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARE, ROBERT (PETER)
description: HARE-Robert (Peter). Died on June 1, 2001 at home in Sussex, England. Beloved husband of Greta, father of Alix Brooke, Margaret Davidson, Tracy, Robert and Richard Hare. Grandfather of Alix and Willing Davidson, John and Alice Brooke. Contributions in his name may be made to: Brantwood Camp, c/o St. Marks School, 25 Marlboro Rd, Southboro, Ma 01772

title: Winery Chief Executive Resigns
description: Lewis E. Platt, who left the top job at Hewlett-Packard for a second career as a Northern California winemaker, said yesterday that he was resigning after 18 months as chief executive of the winery, Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates Ltd.

title: Diamonds Aren't Forever; After Years of Chasing the Next Koufax, Scouts Are Out
description: The drizzle fell steadily, the kind of weather that makes an old man ache. The New Jersey air stank of industrial solvents. It was beautiful. It was East Coast baseball.

title: Schundler's Opening Shot
description: This 30-second commercial is the first released by Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, in his campaign against former Representative Bob Franks for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey. It is to begin running today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUFF, PEARL
description: RUFF-Pearl. Age 86, on June 4, 2001, of Wyckoff, NJ. Predeceased by her husband Arthur and son William. Survived by her daughter Jayne and Don Joseph, daughterin-law Pauline Ruff, sister Lillian Horowitz, grandchildren Victor and Laurie, Andy and Enid, Joey and Lori, Gillian, Tami and Shaun, Ali and Heath; great grandchildren Andrew, Morgan, Emme, Patricia, Benjamin and Jarrod. Services are today, 10:00 am at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC., New York, the operator of vessels for carrying crude oil, said it would purchase four tankers from Bergesen, Oslo, the world's largest gas shipper, for $321 million to meet international demand for oil.

title: Repetition + Rap = Charter School Success
description: It is a morning ritual, like prayer at a parochial school. Denniston Reid stalks across his classroom, scowls at his sixth-grade students and barks the same simple question: ''What is this?''

title: Trees vs. Produce: Clashing Greens In Union Square
description: NEW YORK is not at its most savory in summer. One of the few compensations for the brutal weather and the weird quiet is the Greenmarket on Union Square. A Saturday morning there is like a cross between a mind massage and a trip to the country, without the shrink or the jitney.

title: Wattage Where It's Needed
description: President Bush's energy plan, to its credit, takes on in a coherent way all of the supply and demand elements that make up the nation's energy system, something not attempted since the Carter administration. And as the long view demands, the plan calls for a national system of power transmission -- a national electricity grid. Our increasing use of computers, requiring ever more electricity, makes this grid an absolute necessity.

title: Ex-Council President Elected Mayor of Jersey City
description: Glenn Cunningham, a former City Council president, was elected mayor tonight, defeating the current Council president, Tom DeGise, in a race to replace Bret D. Schundler, a Republican who is running for governor.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: A New Flight Plan
description: Summertime nears, and the flying is not easy. Passengers experienced record delays in each of the past two summers, partly as a result of the air traffic system's failure to keep up with growing demand for air travel. Despite recent improvements, this summer may be no better, especially if some airlines are crippled by labor troubles. But there are heartening signs that the widespread outrage expressed by millions of inconvenienced fliers, and not a few members of Congress, may have galvanized the Federal Aviation Administration and others into formulating long-term solutions to what is not only an exasperating consumer issue but a serious economic one as well.

title: For 20 Years, the Scourge of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicaid Curb For Immigrants Is Ruled Illegal
description: New York's highest court ruled today that the state had violated the state and federal Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits to thousands of needy legal immigrants.

title: Macedonia May Declare State of War
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jun. 6  Macedonia threatened today to declare a state of war after five soldiers were killed in a rebel ambush and six more police and soldiers were wounded, in one of the deadliest attacks by ethnic Albanian rebels in weeks.

title: Two Spots, Two Missions
description: Michael Bloomberg began broadcasting a 60-second commercial in English on six New York area television stations yesterday. A 30-second spot in Spanish is being broadcast on Univision.

title: Checkers Makes Purchase
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., June 5  Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc. , a fast- food hamburger chain, plans to take over 21 restaurants in the West from CKE Restaurants , starting July 3.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Case Of McCall's Daughter
description: Larceny and other charges against the daughter of H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, were dismissed yesterday and the court records sealed. Marcella McCall, 37, a former business manager at Verizon, was arrested in March and accused of misusing Verizon credit cards and writing nearly $100,000 in bad checks, the police said. But a lawyer for Verizon said the complaint had been premature. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Broker Pleads Guilty
description: A former stockbroker at D.H. Blair & Company pleaded guilty yesterday to enterprise corruption and securities fraud, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said. The broker, Alfred Palagonia, 34, was indicted last July along with 14 others on charges that they ran the company as a criminal enterprise. Mr. Palagonia admitted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that he and other brokers conspired to keep certain stock prices artificially high by misleading customers, and sold them the overvalued stocks. Those customers lost money when the prices dropped. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Charm and Daredevil Moves In a Plea for Health Coverage
description: Life is not about how you go down but about how you get up, Twyla Tharp said in a brief speech on Sunday afternoon at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Then she strode over to embrace Homer Avila, who sat in the front row, his purple plastic crutches propped jauntily beside him.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BROKER PLEADS GUILTY A former stockbroker at D.H. Blair & Company pleaded guilty yesterday to enterprise corruption and securities fraud, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said. The broker, Alfred Palagonia, 34, was indicted last July along with 14 others on charges that they ran the company as a criminal enterprise. Mr. Palagonia admitted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that he and other brokers conspired to keep certain stock prices artificially high by misleading customers, and sold them the overvalued stocks. Those customers lost money when the prices dropped.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell after a report showed Japanese household spending fell in April and as a decline in Japanese stocks dimmed demand for the currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.35 yen, up from 119.26.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've even disconnected the lights illuminating the little statue of the Virgin Mary in my living room.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the unemployment rate in May misstated a change in the second-quarter projections by Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis. Based on the jobless numbers, the firm now expects the number of hours worked by Americans to decline about 2 percent and the economy to grow about 1 percent. It does not expect the economy over all to contract 2 percent.

title: Hewlett-Packard Says Sales Faltering This Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that sales were sluggish because corporate and consumer spending on information technology products was slowing in markets outside of the United States and Europe.

title: Latter-Day Port of Call: New York
description: THESE restaurants all serve a version of laksa. Most Malaysian restaurants also have it on the menu.

title: First Graduates at a Haven for Girls
description: Four and a half years after a New York City philanthropist founded a public school for girls in a poor Hispanic neighborhood, drawing opposition from feminists and civil libertarians, the school is graduating its first class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANGER, WESLEY A. JR.
description: STANGER-Wesley A. Jr., died of natural causes on May 23 at 92. Mr. Stanger graduated from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School in 1929. He joined Dillon, Read & Co. and in 1933 was a founder of Riter & Co., an NYSE member. He served in the U.S. Navy Reserve as a lieutenant during WWII. In the late 1970's, he joined McKay, Shields & Co., pension fund investment manager. Mr. Stanger was a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania for twenty years, and chairman of the board emeritus of both the Madison Fund and American South African Investments, Ltd. He was a director emeritus of Gulf & Western, Talley Industries and numerous other corporations. Mr. Stanger was a member of Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J. He is survived by his second wife, Natalie Williams Stanger. His first wife, Sarah McKee Stanger, died in 1975. He is also survived by his brother, Rhys L. Stanger; his sons, William M. Stanger and Robert A. Stanger; seven grandchildren; and seven great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 PM, June 16th, at the Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ 07901. No flowers please, but a donation to the University of Pennsylvania in his memory would be appreciated.

title: What a Teacher Sowed, a Test Can't Reap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEHRER, CATHERINE
description: FEHRER-Catherine of Lyme, CT, died on May 23, 2001 in NYC. She was the daughter of Mabel Vanderbilt Fehrer and the painter Oscar Fehrer. After a college teaching career, Miss Fehrer devoted her time to studying academic painting and, in particular, the Academie Julian in Paris where her father had studied. She was a benefactor of the Florence Griswold Museum, and with her sister, Elizabeth, donated land in Lyme to The Nature Conservancy. There are no survivors.

title: Turner's U.N. Fund Plans World Resource Survey
description: One of the most ambitious projects to assess global environmental damage from the rapid consumption of natural resources was announced today by an unusual coalition of scientists, corporations, foundations and international agencies.

title: Hunger, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, RUTH
description: WEXLER-Ruth. The National Board of Hadassah, The Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., is deeply saddened by the passing of Ruth Wexler, committed life member and generous member of The Society of Guardian Donors. Together with her husband Jack, Ruth established the Ruth and Jack Wexler Fellowships in Geriartric Medicine at the Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center in Jerusalem. We extend our deepest condolences to her beloved husband, Jack, their children Ann and Robert Fromer and Gary and Nina Wexler, and the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Beef Exports To Resume
description: The European Union announced that Northern Ireland could resume beef exports, which were banned under foot-and-mouth disease restrictions. The decision means the province and its $283 million animal and dairy produce business will be considered separately from the rest of Britain, where the ban continues. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: The Jets' Stadium Plans In Limbo
description: Despite the stated goal of the Jets' owner, Robert Wood Johnson IV, to move the team back to New York City, team officials acknowledged yesterday the political difficulties of building a stadium over rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Universal
description: The maker of Burberry fashions, Great Universal Stores, said full-year profit fell to 203.7 million ($294 million) from 275.1 million ($390 million), largely because of one-time charges from the sale of other businesses. But its stock rose as much as 2.8 percent as the company reported a record pretax profit of 487 million ($691 million), led by sales at its Burberry division. The company said it would proceed with a 25 percent public offering of Burberry within a year. Burberry also plans to add stores in Spain, California and Germany and to expand its floor space in Paris and New York. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Goldman Shifting 2 Executives to Lead Investment Management
description: The Goldman Sachs Group plans to promote the top two executives of its brokerage business to be the co-heads of its investment management division after John P. McNulty retires at the end of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROWITZ, SIDNEY
description: MOROWITZ-Sidney, born 1911. Beloved husband of Mildred, of Sunrise, Florida. Devoted father of five children, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Funeral 2PM Thursday, June 7th at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich, Hempstead, NY, 516-486-2500.

title: Mussina Roughed Up In the 'Easier' Game
description: Mike Mussina got to pitch the other game. There was no Pedro Martnez, no Red Sox and no endless hyping of one of Mussina's starts for the third time in less than two weeks. Mussina got to pitch the game after the momentous game. He got to face the Orioles, his former team.

title: Talks Break Down On Teacher Contract
description: Randi Weingarten, the president of New York City's teachers' union, said yesterday that contract talks with the Giuliani administration had broken down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, LILLIAN
description: BASS-Lillian. Age 86. Former resident of Woodmere, N.Y. Died Sunday, June 3, 2001 in Piedmont, California where she spent the past four years. Beloved wife of the late Ralph Bass. Loving mother of Graham, Jonathan and Anthony. Devoted grandmother of Jordan, Adam and Ethan. She was an inspired teacher and Assistant to the Chancellor of the New York City Schools in the 1970s, and a passionate gardener in her retirement years.

title: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES TO TAKE $18.5 MILLION CHARGE
description: The America West Holdings Corporation, owner of America West Airlines, expects to take second-quarter charges against earnings of $18.5 million for eliminating jobs and aircraft as the company adjusts to the slower economy. The charges cover the early return of two Boeing 737-300 aircraft, the return of five other jets when their leases expire and the elimination of about 300 jobs, the company said. The charges, which equal 55 cents a share, may result in a second-quarter final loss for the company. America West, based in Tempe, Ariz., was expected to earn 21 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, MARVIN JOSEPH
description: EISENBERG - Marvin Joseph. Died in New York City on June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Audrey Goodman. Loving father of Eric and Jane, Nina, Sally and Charley. Proud grandfather of Evan and Grace. Cherished brother of the late Raymond Woodrow, brotherin-law to Estelle, and uncle to many nieces and nephews. We will miss him and always remember his charm and intelligence. The funeral service will be held on Friday, June 8, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., (81st Street).

title: Liberties; Scrappy-Doo Spoiled It
description: Lucy and Desi did it when they moved to Connecticut. ''Bewitched'' did it when Dick York was replaced by Dick Sargent. Cybill Shepherd and Bruce Willis did it when they did it. Helen Hunt and Paul Reiser did it when they had baby Mabel. Laverne and Shirley did it when they moved from Milwaukee to Los Angeles. ''Ally McBeal'' did it when the Biscuit's frog got flushed down the toilet. ''Friends'' did it when Rachel and Ross got together for the third time. CNN did it when Darth Vader kept reminding us ''This is CNN.'' The Weather Channel did it when it started producing full-length tropical storm programs. ''Scooby-Doo'' did it when Scrappy-Doo joined the cast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MEYER
description: SHAPIRO-Meyer age 88 of Woodcliff Lake formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Husband of Dorothy, father of Alan (Susan), Robert (Helaine), Steven (Gail). Brother of Ted, Lewis, and Lillian Laskin. Beloved grandfather and great grandfather of Ronald, Jane, Lori, Adam, Amy, Matthew, Daniel, Kaitlyn and Benjamin. Services are 1PM today. Robert Schoem's Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 (East) Paramus, NJ

title: C.I.A. Chief Going to Israel In Effort to Maintain Calm
description: The Bush administration announced today that it was sending the director of central intelligence to the Middle East to meet with leaders of Israeli and Palestinian security forces, reversing a policy set when the president took office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JOHN TERRY, JR.
description: BROWN-John Terry, Jr. Of New York City died May 30th. at home of cancer. He was the son of Mr. & Mrs. John Terry Brown of Racine, Wisconsin. He was a graduate of The Choate School and Phoenix Jr. College and received a BA from NYU. He attended the Parsons School of Design and established an extraordinary reputation for detail and color. Mr. Brown was an interior decorator and designer with clients throughout the United States. In the 1960's, he coproduced plays, among them the off Broadway musical ''All In Love'' and Sean O'Casey's ''Red Roses for Me.'' He was a member of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York. He is survived by his sisters Barbara Brown Lee and Elizabeth Brown Greeley of Milwaukee. A Memorial Service will be held Thursday, June 7th at 3pm at St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Ave betw 50th and 51st Streets. In lieu of flowers the family has requested contributions be made to the Arthur B. Ashe Foundation, Broadway Cares Equity Fights Aids at 165 West 46 St., Suite 1300, NY, NY 10036, and the Milwaukee Art Museum, 750 North Lincoln Memorial Drive, Milwaukee, WI 53202. He will be missed by a legion of devoted friends.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Missing Pastor Found
description: Msgr. Lamont Hamilton, a Bronx pastor whose disappearance last week prompted alarm at his parish and a search by the police, is safe. He telephoned a fellow priest on Monday, said Joseph G. Zwilling, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Monsignor Hamilton, 48, of Holy Rosary Church in Eastchester, missed a funeral Mass on Friday and was reported missing by his brother after missing Mass on Sunday. The archdiocese declined to discuss his reason for leaving, but said in a statement that a heart ailment had been diagnosed and that he ''had been experiencing a great deal of stress.'' Citing a request from the pastor's family, the police and the archdiocese would not release his whereabouts. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Article 2001060691230644320 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: John Hartford, Composer Of Country Hits, Dies at 63
description: John Hartford, a versatile musician known for mastering banjo, playing violin, performing comedy on television and writing one of country music's most recorded songs, ''Gentle on My Mind,'' died on Monday at the Centennial Medical Center in Nashville. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, ROBERTA
description: LIPMAN-Roberta. Missed, loved and remembered by us all. You're always in our hearts. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara, Donna

title: Rebels in Colombia Free 4 in the Start of a Prisoner Exchange
description: Colombia's largest rebel group freed a badly injured police colonel and three other officers today, the first step in a prisoner exchange that could lead to the release of about 150 soldiers and police officers held by guerrillas in jungle camps.

title: Management: Behind Bars And on the Clock; Despite Low Pay, Felons Show Up Motivated
description: The workday begins on a patch of black asphalt ringed by razor-wire fence. This is where more than 200 inmates of the Eastern Oregon Correctional Institution line up at 7:45 on weekdays. They are clad in blue jeans and inspected like cattle by men with pistols and crew cuts and gray uniforms. Their names are called out, their bodies frisked.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Juror Allowed To Post Bail
description: A Manhattan judge, disagreeing with another judge, allowed a juror to post $10,000 bail yesterday for a man she had refused to convict because she believed him to be a victim of harsh drug laws. The defendant, Calvin Baker, was arrested in December 1999 and imprisoned on charges that he had sold $10 worth of heroin. After a mistrial was declared, the holdout juror, Paula Thomson, wanted to post bail for Mr. Baker, who is awaiting retrial. Justice Bonnie Wittner of State Supreme Court in Manhattan contended that bail posted by a stranger would not ensure Mr. Baker's return to court. But yesterday, Justice Brenda Soloff ruled that nothing in state law prevented the aid of strangers and that Mr. Baker could be freed once bail was officially posted. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Restructuring
description: The Swissair Group, which is struggling to recover from huge losses stemming from its expansion strategy, has announced a major restructuring program to cut costs by at least $279 million by year's end.
