The effort is aimed at ''unnecessary hierarchical levels,'' a goal that the group acknowledged in its announcement means job losses among the company's 70,000 employees. The shake-up, which will start July 1, will mean transfers and new responsibilities for management, Mario Corti, group chief executive, warned. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Some Guns Handed In
description: Residents have handed in hundreds of weapons during a monthlong amnesty ahead of the introduction of tough gun laws in the province, the United Nations police said. But NATO-led peacekeepers complained that they had confiscated more illegal weapons in raids during the amnesty period than people had turned in. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Ruling On Mohawks' Claim
description: A federal judge has rejected a state request to dismiss a land claim by the Mohawk Indians for 15,000 acres in northeastern New York. The ruling by Judge Neal P. McCurn of Federal District Court here was the first substantive action in years for a case that has sputtered along since the Mohawks filed their claim in the early 1980's, contending that state and local governments had illegally seized Indian lands 200 years ago. The Justice Department joined the case on the side of the Mohawks in 1998. In 1999, the state argued that the case should be dismissed outright because it had sovereign immunity. But Judge McCurn rejected that contention, saying that the state did not have immunity against the federal government. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST</b

title: Energy Crisis in Brazil Is Bringing Dimmer Lights and Altered Lives
description: At night, the lights on streets and beaches and in parks and tunnels are dimmed. Air-conditioners in the president's office have been turned off; nighttime sports events and concerts have been canceled. Government employees may soon be forced to shift to a six-hour work day, and private companies are talking of moving production abroad for the duration of the emergency.

title: Another Chance to Make the Sale
description: Every once in a while a successful product, having fallen on hard times, comes back to the market in modest form, more or less as an experiment, to see if the old customer loyalty can be revived. This happened with Life magazine and Ipana toothpaste. It is happening now with the Democratic majority in the Senate. We are being asked to try out a 2001 limited edition of Democratic legislative power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, DAVID F.
description: SIMONS-David F. On June 4, 2001. Loving son of Harold and Naomi (Corman) Simons. Devoted brother of Mark Simons and Bettysue Feuer. Caring nephew of Frank and Mildred Feinberg, Nat and Lorena Simons, Beth and Harry Greenberg. Loving uncle to Alan and Michael Feuer, Jesse and Emily Simons. Graveside service Thursday 10:30 am Beth David Cemetery, Elmont. Memorial contributions to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532

title: TV Notes: HBO Scores on Sunday
description: No "Sopranos?" No problem. Or so it seems for HBO, which continued its run of record-setting series strength on Sunday nights with the season premieres of its returning hit comedy "Sex and the City" and its dark new comedy-drama "Six Feet Under."

title: Lobsters at Five Paces, Knives and Egos Bared
description: THEY called it ''The Tango in Tokyo.''

title: Judge Refuses to Delay McVeigh Execution
description: Afederal judge in Denver refused today to delay the execution of Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, saying newly-released documents did not change the fact that he was guilty.

title: Springtime For Avarice At Theaters
description: AROUND the time of the Tony Awards four years ago, this column did its bit for women's rights on a matter of some urgency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 20 about China's agreement to cooperate with a United Nations agency to ease labor turmoil misstated its name. It is the International Labor Organization, not Office.

title: The Future's Paying Off Nicely for a Trend-Spotter
description: THE futurist lives and works -- she calls it cocooning, a term she coined, then stamped into the pop culture lexicon with her first best seller, ''The Popcorn Report'' -- in a 110-year-old sliver of a town house on East 64th Street. A derelict she snapped up in foreclosure and decorated to the nines, starting with the foyer's Hirschfeld caricature of herself and her pooch, Miyake (a Japanese Chin named for a favored designer of her dress-for-success wear). A showplace on which, until she adopted her daughter, Georgica, from China three years back, she lavished maternal feelings -- she believes buildings have souls.

title: Proving That There's No Business Like Ethel Merman
description: The humor and ebullience that emanate from Klea Blackhurst in her cabaret tribute to Ethel Merman are qualities that can't be faked. And they are among the reasons Ms. Blackhurst's show, in an open-ended run on Sunday and Monday evenings at Jack Rose (771 Eighth Avenue, at 47th Street, Clinton), has generated such enthusiastic word-of-mouth.

title: Hahn Wins L.A. Mayor's Race, Vows to Unite the City
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- City Attorney James K. Hahn, the low-key son of a beloved local political family, drew support from a rare coalition of liberal black voters and conservative whites to claim victory as the 40th mayor of Los Angeles early this morning, defeating former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, who had hoped to become his city's first Hispanic mayor in 129 years.

title: Labor Agreement Extension Likely
description: The N.F.L. and the players' union reached a tentative agreement to extend their collective bargaining agreement three years, through the 2007 season.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Monday, about Diann Y. Rust-Tierney, a lawyer who heads the American Civil Liberties Union's capital punishment project, misspelled the name of her Washington neighborhood. It is Shepherd Park, not Shepard Park.

title: Corrections
description: The weather report on Saturday, Monday and yesterday misstated the beginning date of the period used to chart cooling degree-days. It is Jan. 1, not July 1.

title: Of Coups and Mandates
description: To the Editor:

title: When Dreams Start to Fade There's Always Forgery
description: There is that moment between the whines of adolescence and the groans of middle age when being disaffected actually looks attractive. Witness the enduring appeal of Prince Hamlet, Jake Barnes and James Dean on the stage, page and screen. Or, more immediately, take a look at the lithe young things suffering through their mid-20's in ''The Credeaux Canvas,'' the very imbalanced but very promising new play by Keith Bunin.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Scranton Rejects Run For Governor
description: William W. Scranton III, a former lieutenant governor, said he would not seek the Republican nomination for governor next year because of family and business considerations. Many party leaders had been pressing him to enter the race, on the theory that his name recognition and money would make him a stronger candidate than the other Republican hopefuls, Attorney General D. Michael Fisher and Treasurer Barbara Hafer. Mr. Scranton's father was governor from 1963 to 1967. Democrats are expected to nominate either Auditor General Robert P. Casey Jr., also the son of a governor, or former Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: Nasdaq Leads Shares Higher, Despite Economic Reports
description: Stocks rose yesterday as investors, buoyed by positive news from technology companies, shrugged off several disappointing economic reports.

title: The Armada's Gone, Leaving a Savory Memory
description: MORE than half a century before Columbus sailed the ocean blue, China's Muslim admiral, Zheng He, sailed through the Strait of Malacca on his way to India.

title: N.B.A. Fines Bucks, Karl and Allen
description: The N.B.A. fined the Milwaukee Bucks, Coach George Karl and guard Ray Allen a total of $85,000 for their remarks about officiating during the Eastern Conference finals. The team was fined $50,000, Karl $25,000 and Allen $10,000 after the coach and player said the league would prefer to have Philadelphia in the N.B.A. finals instead of Milwaukee. (AP)

title: Tuning In the Brain Waves Of the Wild Side of Jazz
description: There's no getting in at the shallow end with avant-garde jazz. ''A person has to be prepared to accept what it is,'' said the pianist Matthew Shipp at the Knitting Factory on Saturday, the 10th night of the Vision Festival, which resumes tonight at the Angel Orensanz Center on the Lower East Side.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Finland at Bryant Park

title: Mets Get Notre Dame Righty
description: The Mets, picking 18th in today's first-year player draft, took Aaron Heilman, a right-handed pitcher from Notre Dame. They drafted in Colorado's first-round position because they lost Mike Hampton, a Type A free agent, to the Rockies last winter.

title: Gist of Italy In a Dish
description: EMILIA-ROMAGNA is the home of some of Italy's most sophisticated cuisine and three of the country's best-known food products -- Parmesan, prosciutto and balsamic vinegar. The recipe below is based on a dish from that region. It is little more than chicken sauted with pancetta and finished with balsamic vinegar, a natural-sounding combination, but one I had never eaten, let alone cooked. I created my own version.

title: Utilities Hire Ex-Chairman Of G.O.P. To Fight Suits
description: A nascent consortium of power companies has hired Haley Barbour, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee and the new fund-raising chief for Senate Republicans, to try to fend off clean-air lawsuits from the federal government.

title: Metro Business Briefing | There She Is, Smiling Seriously
description: The Miss America Pageant has hired a new television producer in an effort to give the pageant's annual broadcast a more serious air, the organization announced yesterday. The producer, Bob Bain, a former Fox Broadcasting executive, will replace Jeff Margolis, the show's producer since 1993. The replacement is one of several changes made by the company's chief executive, Robert Renneisen, a former executive with the Claridge Casino and Hotel Corporation who was hired early last year. The Atlantic City-based pageant, which started in 1921 and has been broadcast live for more than 40 years, has recently been losing viewership. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Candidates Make Bids Official In Open Race for Comptroller
description: The jockeying for position among Republicans in the wide-open race for state comptroller started in earnest today, as David B. Cornstein, a wealthy businessman, announced his candidacy and John J. Faso, the Assembly minority leader, said he had the backing of most G.O.P. county leaders.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with an article about Cuba and the difference that dollars can make in life there misspelled the name of the beach resort where tourists were shown. It was Varadero, not Valadero.

title: INSIDE
description: Florida Denounces Report

title: Santiago de Cuba Journal; In Book-Starved Cuba, Little Feasts for the Hungry
description: Among the books that Marcia Prez Castillo keeps in the lending library at her home is ''The Challenge of Liberty.'' Its very location underscores the book's theme, since she has it hidden in her bedroom. She tucked away similar volumes on democracy and dictatorships in an improvised rare books section, stashed in the ceiling under a dusty plastic sheet.

title: Mets Wake As Reed Lulls Phillies
description: In about a month, Bobby Valentine will pick the pitchers and reserves for the National League All-Star team. The Mets' manager has not thought about the duty and, for now, it would be hard for him to justify putting many Mets on the roster. But Rick Reed will be an easy choice.

title: Princeton's Racial Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLENICK, ARNOLD J.
description: OLENICK-Arnold J. Died June 4. Survived by loving wife, Bernice, devoted sons, Philip and Steven, and adored grandaughter, Jean. Memorial services June 10 at Noon, Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Beacon St, Brookline, Ma.

title: As Senate Shifts, Bush Is Expressing Optimism on Issues
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  As Republican control of the Senate abruptly ended, President Bush reached out today to Democrats and moderates in his party and, in an interview, expressed optimism about the future of his agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, KIM
description: SHULMAN-Kim. Our hearts go out to our good friends, Claire and Mel Shulman and their family at this time of loss. Ivan Seidenberg, Chair Seth Dubin, President Emeritus Alan Friedman, Director and the Board and staff of the New York Hall of Science

title: Throngs of Arabs Are Coming to Relief of Malaysia Hotels
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Help wanted: Hotel managers here are scrambling to find Arabic speakers, chefs who can cook up good Middle Eastern meals and chambermaids who understand the finer points of Islamic discretion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYCE, GERARD
description: BOYCE-Gerard. The members, attorneys and staff of Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP sadly record the untimely loss of our esteemed former partner, Gerard Boyce. Jerry's drive, can do attitude, unflagging good nature and talent as a practitioner contributed immeasurably to the growth of our firm. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, our dear friend Anna, and their children, and wish them the brilliant future he intended to provide. Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP

title: Excerpts From a Bush Interview on the Changing Landscape in the Senate
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with President Bush, as recorded by the White House:

title: Article 2001060693949408936 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: BestBuy To Offer Music Downloads
description: The Best Buy Company, the largest United States electronics retailer, will become the first traditional retailer to offer music downloads from five major record labels through an agreement with RioPort.com. Financial terms were not disclosed. RioPort.com will begin distributing music downloads to Best Buy's Web site later this year, adding to the site's music selection. Customers using the site will pay 50 cents to $2 to download singles and $12 to $16 for full-length albums, a Best Buy spokeswoman said. RioPort.com, which is closely held and based in San Jose, Calif., is the only company to have download-distribution agreements with Sony, AOL Time Warner's Warner Records, Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment, the EMI Group, and the Universal Music Group.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: An American Chef's Sweet Spin on Sushi
description: At Spread, an American restaurant with a sushi bar, some of the sushi is definitely not for purists. For one thing, it's used in a delicious dessert that borrows from both rice pudding and chocolate fondue. And it comes topped with fruit.

title: B.Y.O. Can Be Stylish
description: You're bringing a couple of good bottles of wine to a picnic, an outdoor concert or even a restaurant. When presentation counts, a shopping bag will not do. That is why there is the elegant hand-sewn two-bottle leather and polyvinyl wine satchel made by Mulholland Brothers in San Francisco. It has a removable insulated liner made of space-suit material to keep white wine chilled and red at cellar temperature, and it comes with a wine opener and a shoulder strap. It is sold by Bounty Hunter in Napa, Calif., for $259.95 plus $7.95 shipping. To order: (800) 943-9463 or www.bountyhunterwine.com. Consider it for a Father's Day, wedding or graduation gift.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: John Carter was named to the new post of senior vice president and creative director at T. G. Madison, Atlanta. He had been partner and creative director at the Atlanta office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, which closed. Also at T. G. Madison, Paige Bryars and Lara Gilmore were named to the new posts of vice presidents and associate creative directors; Ms. Bryars had been senior copywriter, and Ms. Gilmore had been senior art director, at Ogilvy Atlanta.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailers To Be Shed
description: Kingfisher said it would concentrate on its home improvement retailing division and spin off its Woolworths, Superdrug and other general merchandise stores as a separate company by the end of July. Kingfisher had been contemplating a sale of its general merchandise businesses, which have 1,600 stores and 50,000 employees, but offers from potential buyers, including private equity firms, were too low, the company said. The spinoff is intended to permit Kingfisher to focus on its faster-growing home improvement and electronics businesses, which include Castorama and Comet. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Jury Weighs Death Penalty For Bomber
description: A federal jury in Manhattan deliberated briefly late yesterday without reaching a verdict on whether to impose the death penalty on a terrorist who bombed the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1998.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA GAINS. Cocoa rose nearly 2 percent as chocolate makers took advantage of relatively low prices. In New York, cocoa for September delivery rose $18, or 1.9 percent, to $956 a metric ton.

title: Rockets Redglare, 52, Film Actor and Comedian
description: Rockets Redglare, a comedian, actor and longtime fixture on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who played characters not unlike himself in many movies, died on May 28 in Manhattan. He was 52.

title: Hahn Wins Los Angeles Mayor's Race
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  City Attorney James K. Hahn, the low-key son of a beloved local political family, drew support from a rare coalition of liberal black voters and conservative whites to claim victory as the 40th mayor of Los Angeles early this morning, defeating former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, who had hoped to become his city's first Hispanic mayor in 129 years.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: A Fitting Place for Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles Vote
description: The mayoral election yesterday in Los Angeles ended too late for inclusion in this edition. A full report about it will appear on Thursday and as soon as the results are available from The New York Times on the Web:

title: Florida Governor Calls Commission Report on Election Biased
description: Gov. Jeb Bush's office sent a scathing letter to the United States Commission on Civil Rights today denouncing its preliminary findings on the problem-plagued presidential race in Florida last November. The letter dismissed the investigation's findings as irresponsible and biased.

title: Article 2001060692904729425 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Productivity Declines 1.2%; Its Largest Drop Since 1993
description: The productivity of American workers declined 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the sharpest drop since 1993, as labor costs increased at the fastest rate in a decade, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Michael Sonnabend, 101, Downtown Art Impresario
description: Michael Sonnabend, the husband of the art dealer Ileana Sonnabend and a familiar, approachable presence on the downtown art scene, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 101.

title: Grizzled Group of 7 Hopes to Avoid Game 7
description: The Devils traipsed into Continental Arena along with the 5 o'clock shadow this afternoon, their beards having thickened while sitting in a holding pattern above Newark Airport.

title: Excerpts From a Bush Interview on the Changing Landscape in the Senate
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with President Bush, as recorded by the White House:

title: Buyer Beware for Those Considering Wells
description: The Yankee clubhouse was almost empty a few hours after Orlando Hernandez went on the 15-day disabled list with an inflamed left toe last week, but two of the Yankees who were still there held a brief conversation. Because it looked like El Duque was going to miss over a month, should the Yankees try to acquire another starter? More specifically, should they pursue David Wells of the Chicago White Sox?

title: U.S.-China Discussions
description: The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, met here today with China's trade minister, Shi Guangsheng to discuss China's longstanding bid to join the World Trade Organization. The two are in Shanghai to attend a two-day meeting of the trade ministers of the nations in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. The meeting will start today. Mr. Zoellick said that he and Mr. Shi talked about Chinese farm subsidies, but he gave little indication that the talks made progress in solving disagreements over issues that have held up China's W.T.O. membership.

title: Summer in Phoenix
description: Summer in Phoenix means discounts at major resorts. The Boulders, in the suburb of Carefree, is offering a rate of $149 a day through Sept. 5. In addition, there are a variety of package plans; the Golf and Spa Getaway, for example, includes a daily choice of two 50-minute spa treatments or two rounds of golf or one round of golf and one spa treatment; it costs $308 a night, double. For the same price, the Unlimited Golf package includes unlimited greens fees and unlimited use of the practice facilities for two people. Rates do not include tax and service charges and are subject to availability. Contact (888) 472-6229 or ww.wyndham.com/boulders .

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Charge In Air India Bombing
description: Days before completing a 10-year sentence for manslaughter, a Canadian man, Inderjit Singh Reyat, was charged as a co-conspirator in the bombing of an Air India jet in 1985, which killed all 329 people on board. He was convicted of manslaughter for the bombing of Narita Airport in Tokyo on the same day the Air India plane, on a flight from Canada, exploded over the Atlantic near Ireland. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Crackdown On Violent Fans
description: The government ordered 454 fans with a history of taking part in soccer riots to turn in their passports to the police as a guarantee that they would not be going today to Athens, where the English national team plays Greece in a qualifying match for the 2002 World Cup. The first large-scale use of new powers under the Football Disorder Act aims to curb the kind of street violence that English fans provoked in Belgium last year during the Euro 2000 tournament. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Look Busy, Feign Interest and Be Paid
description: Bored with the daily grind? Consider a job as an impersonator. It is quite the rage these days.

title: CALENDAR
description: Benefits for Palladin

title: AS SENATE SHIFTS, BUSH IS EXPRESSING OPTIMISM ON ISSUES
description: As Republican control of the Senate abruptly ended, President Bush reached out today to Democrats and moderates in his party and, in an interview, expressed optimism about the future of his agenda.

title: FEDDERS PLANS JOINT VENTURE WITH FACTORY IN CHINA
description: The Fedders Corporation, a leading maker of room air-conditioners, said yesterday that its Melcor thermoelectric unit had agreed to form a joint venture with the Quanzhou Hua Yu Electrical Component Factory in China. Melcor will invest $1.7 million in cash and equipment, as well as technical expertise, and will have a 65 percent interest in the venture, said the chief financial officer, Michael Giordano. Hua Yu will own the rest. The venture between Melcor, based in Trenton, N.J., and Hua Yu, based in Quanzhou, Fujian Province, will make temperature-control devices in China for uses that include fiber optic communications and biotechnology. Production will be at an existing plant that will be expanded as part of the venture, Mr. Giordano said. Fedders is based in Liberty Corner, N.J.

title: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online
description: The LTV Mine closed its doors in February, leaving more than 1,400 hundred workers unemployed in an area where the closest community college is 30 minutes away. It takes twice that long to get to the University of Minnesota at Duluth, the nearest four-year university.

title: Business Travel; The day of private supersonic jets may not be far off.
description: A BIG new Boeing Business Jet costs about $40 million, stripped. Add maybe $5 million more for furnishings and interior finishes and equipment, and you've basically got yourself a Boeing 737, refitted as a fancy private corporate jet.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Report On Cardinal's Slaying
description: A Roman Catholic cardinal asserted that his predecessor was deliberately killed eight years ago, not caught in a crossfire between rival drug traffickers. Cardinal Juan Sandoval I~niguez gave his report to state prosecutors. Neither they nor their federal counterparts have yet closed the case of the killing of Cardinal Juan Jess Posadas Ocampo at the Guadalajara airport on May 24, 1993. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Agencies to Suggest Changes To Ease La Guardia Delays
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in an effort to relieve congestion at La Guardia Airport, plans to suggest sharply raising landing fees or auctioning off landing slots.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Reversal On A Race
description: Lt. Gov. Bill Ratliff announced that he would not run for the position in 2002, reversing an earlier decision. Mr. Ratliff, a Republican, was elevated to lieutenant governor in a December vote by his peers in the State Senate when Gov. George W. Bush left for the presidency and Lt. Gov. Rick Perry became governor. The lieutenant governor, who presides over the State Senate, is often considered the most powerful official in Texas. Mr. Ratliff, who has won wide praise for his handling of the job, announced his candidacy two weeks ago, but yesterday he announced a change of mind, saying he does ''love policy making but I do not love politics.'' Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Government Investigators Clear Teamsters President in Michigan
description: The head of the Teamsters union in Michigan, a former mentor to James P. Hoffa, the union's president, was found not guilty yesterday of charges that he masterminded a scheme to use $30,000 in members' dues for his re-election campaign.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pressure From The Right
description: Umberto Bossi, leader of the right-wing Northern League, said his party would withdraw its support from the new government if the prime minister-elect, Silvio Berlusconi, does not choose a Northern League member as justice minister. The No. 2 official in the league, Roberto Maroni, was ruled out for the job last week, probably because he faces criminal charges related to the Northern League's past separatist activity. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Latin American Markets Show a Glimmer of Hope
description: A spate of reassuring news has brought renewed optimism in beleaguered markets across Latin America. But analysts warn that gains in Peru, Argentina and Brazil may be temporary as political and economic uncertainty continue.

title: A Monitor of Los Angeles Police Seeks to Build Power
description: In all the weighty reports and citizen commissions that have tried to reform the deeply troubled Los Angeles Police Department over the past decade, a strong, independent watchdog has been seen as the best hope for a more open and accountable force.

title: Food Stuff: With the Writers and Artists in Old Paris
description: At the Brasserie Lipp in Paris, Hemingway fans can still order the sausage and potatoes he described in "A Moveable Feast." The brasserie had been in business for 40 years when Hemingway showed up. Venerable Parisian restaurants like this, from tiny cafes to grand salons, transport diners back to a vanished world of artists and writers. An alluring 246-page guide, "The Historic Restaurants of Paris" by Ellen Williams (The Little Bookroom, $14.95), lists scores of places to tempt lovers of history and food. And there are some surprises, like the Bistrot d'a Cote on Rue Gustave Flaubert, which, though it opened in 1988, occupies the premises of a 19th-century grocery. An American Chef's Sweet Spin on Sushi

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Infineon Plans U.S. Share Sale
description: Infineon Technologies A.G., a semiconductor-making unit of Siemens that faces falling prices for its products, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise money by selling shares. Infineon said the Goldman Sachs Group would manage the sale, which would raise cash for investments, acquisitions or debt repayment. In New York, American depository receipts, representing 100 Infineon shares each. rose $1.48, or 4.4 percent, to $35.49.

title: Cadbury Is Said to Be Close to a $592 Million Deal for Orangina
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the beverage and candy company, is expected to announce today that it is near an agreement to buy the Orangina brand from Pernod Ricard for about $592 million, executives close to the deal said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Loss At Steelmaker
description: Europe's largest steelmaker, Usinor, said its first-quarter profit fell 53 percent as a glut of steel drove prices close to 10-year lows. Net income fell to 78 million euros ($66 million), or 34 cents a share, from 166 million euros ($140 million), or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. Most of the drop in the recent quarter came from a loss at Usinor's stainless-steel unit, which represents about one-fifth of total sales.

title: Sunday Editor Quits Suddenly At Daily News in New York
description: Less than three months after taking over as Sunday editor of The Daily News, Frank Lalli resigned suddenly Tuesday, saying his heart was in magazines, not newspapers.

title: Article 2001060691301698265 -- No Title
Blockbuster Settles Suits On Late Fees
description: Blockbuster Inc., the industry leader in video rentals, has agreed to settle class- action lawsuits over its policy of assessing late fees that have often cost much more than the original rental price.

title: Buyer Beware for Those Considering Wells
description: The Yankee clubhouse was almost empty a few hours after Orlando Hernandez went on the 15-day disabled list with an inflamed left toe last week, but two of the Yankees who were still there held a brief conversation. Because it looked like El Duque was going to miss over a month, should the Yankees try to acquire another starter? More specifically, should they pursue David Wells of the Chicago White Sox?

title: Excerpts From a Bush Interview on the Changing Landscape in the Senate
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with President Bush, as recorded by the White House:

title: 3 Interpublic Agencies Are Michelin Finalists
description: Michelin North America in Greenville, S.C., has narrowed a review for its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $60 million, to three agencies from six.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANNETTE
description: SCHWARTZ-Annette. Age 61, deeply beloved wife of Stanley, adored mother of Stephanie, Julie, and Michael, equally adored stepmother of Larry, Fred and Rick, cherished mother-in-law of Nir, Jennifer, Ken, Dorit, Geraldine, and Heidi, loving grandmother of Daniel, Adam, Dean, Amanda, Jason, Julia, Hanna, Ella, Avi, Akiva, Barak, and Ahava. Cherished sister of Lillianne and Wally Gurspan, Esther and Arnie Goldfarb, Bernard and Diane Gissinger, Jerry and Ruthie Gissinger. Devoted aunt to many. Words cannot express our loss. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M. ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street & Amsterdam. Shiva will be held at the Goldfarb residence: 212-724-3366.

title: Article 2001060692587592836 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: The Apple Bites Back
description: IMAGINE biting into a crisp, perfectly ripe apple. Next, imagine that piercingly pure apple flavor in a lightly carbonated, lightly alcoholic drink made subtly more complex through fermentation, and you have a tall glass of cool apple cider, a refreshing warm-weather alternative to beer or chilled wine.

title: Battered Underdog Takes On a Steamroller
description: Forfeiting was not an option for the Philadelphia 76ers. Heraldic trumpets, please: they made the flight.

title: It's Official: Democrats Rule Senate; G.O.P. Rues Day
description: The Senate shifted to the control of the Democrats tonight, the first time in its history that the balance of power changed because of a party switch instead of an election.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANZ, LOUIS
description: ROSENKRANZ-Louis. 96. A generous and caring person who loved life with intensity, brought a special love and happiness to his family and friends. We will miss him. The extended Rosenkranz Family

title: Rice Signs With Raiders To Keep Living a Dream
description: Over the last 16 years, Jerry Rice has broken every major career pass-catching record in the N.F.L. and has become perhaps the best receiver ever. Yesterday, he took his 38-year-old body across San Francisco Bay and became an Oakland Raider.

title: Still Walking a 'Fine Line Between Stupid and Clever'
description: These days, with pop groups like Eden's Crush and O-Town it's hard to tell which came first, the television show or the band. But back in 1984, when Rob Reiner made his directorial debut with the rock mockumentary ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' little did its comic stars -- Christopher Guest, Harry Shearer and Michael McKean -- suspect that 17 years later they'd still be donning long wigs (and fake cold sores, in Mr. Guest's case) and performing as Spinal Tap. But Spinal Tap, which began its life as a parody of a dinosaur rock band, has become a real-life dinosaur rock band, and in its Carnegie Hall debut on Monday night, it dragged out the old hits for the faithful.

title: Rumsfeld Pays Visit To Troops In Balkans
description: In his first foray into the Balkans, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld heard today from American troops and commanders about the difficulties of stemming ethnic fighting along the Kosovo-Macedonia border, where some Bush administration officials want to curtail the United States' role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDER, EDWARD
description: SEIDER-Edward on June 5, 2001. Beloved companion of Mathilde Sherman. Cherised father of Carole and Evin Rubin. Devoted grandfather of Martin, Maria, Leonard, Sue, Cindy and Mary. Loving great grandfather of Claire, Sara, Bradley, Adam and Allison. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Twins Think Money Before They Pick
description: The Minnesota Twins were in a rare position in baseball's draft yesterday, but they adopted a position that has become routine in recent years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Protest Broken Up
description: Riot police drove labor activists from the Hyosung Corporation petrochemical plant in the industrial center of Ulsan, on the southeastern coast. The police said 36 officers and 8 union members were injured when the police moved in on the factory, which had been held for the last 12 days by members of the militant Korean Confederation of Trade Unions. The union, which dominates the work force in a wide range of industries, including motor vehicles and shipbuilding, called the strike after the company ordered the transfer of 14 workers whose jobs had been taken over by machines. Television coverage showed fire bombs exploding in the melee. The factory makes nylon for use in tires used by Hyundai Motor, whose main plant is also in Ulsan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a gathering of children who participate in the Fresh Air Fund misstated the reason that one child, Jessica Townsend, attended. She was there to offer advice to others, not registering for a vacation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Tattoo Bill Advances
description: A bill to have all Nassau County tattoo parlors licensed by the county's Health Department was unanimously approved by the County Legislature on Monday. The bill, proposed by Legislator Vincent T. Muscarella, a West Hempstead Republican, also requires anyone under 18 to receive notarized parental consent before being branded or having body parts, except for the ear, pierced. State law bans tattoos altogether for those under 18. Concerns about disease being spread by dirty needles led to the legislation. If signed by the county executive, the law would take effect on Jan. 1. Al Baker (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Hard-to-Find Southern Specialties, Without Leaving the North
description: In a city where it's possible to find the world's most exotic ingredients, the staples of Southern cooking can be surprisingly hard to come by. ''Everyone in the neighborhood complains that they have trouble finding watermelon pickles or jalape~no jelly, and that they have to have it sent up from relatives down South,'' said Lance Moreland, with mustache, left, an owner of the new Harlem Gift Shop, 2224 Frederick Douglass Boulevard (120th Street). So, Mr. Moreland, a filmmaker, and his partners, Anthony Bowman and June Espada, created a line of about a dozen Southern condiments called Aunt Viv's Harlem Kitchen. There's a tangy green tomato relish, lush peach butter, smooth strawberry-rhubarb spread and, yes, crunchy watermelon pickles. They are made in Arkansas and cost $6 for 16 ounces.

title: New Baby, Same Old Job
description: THE acting governor of Massachusetts, Jane M. Swift, is on ''working maternity leave.'' She gave birth to twins on May 15, by Caesarean section, after her doctor affirmed that she would be awake and conscious so she did not have to sign her authority over to anyone.

title: Up on the Precipice, Bourque Plays What-If
description: Last Saturday night, Ray Bourque and the Colorado Avalanche were less than 12 minutes away from a commanding three-games-to-one lead in the Stanley Cup finals when Colorado's perennial All-Star goaltender, Patrick Roy, made the fateful decision to wander from his crease, and that turned the series around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, FRANCES
description: WEINBERG-Frances. On June 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Betty Weinberg Ellerin and Marvin. Dear mother-in-law of Milton Ellerin and Lois Paul Weinberg. Cherished grandmother of Sherry, Seth, Susan, Bruce, Stewart, Beatrice and Sidney, and her loving eighteen great-grandchildren. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Judges Refuse To Pay Tax
description: A week after the Supreme Court ruled that federal judges in Birmingham must pay an occupational tax like other taxpayers, 13 judges are still refusing to pay that tax in Jefferson County. The judges contend that the federal judiciary should be exempt from business taxes that are efforts to regulate them. But the court ruled that the tax was an effort to raise revenue and not a regulation. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Survey Offers a Look Deep Into Cosmos
description: More than a year into the most comprehensive mapping survey of the cosmos ever undertaken, astronomers today reported the first detailed results, including detection of the most distant object ever observed and a view of galaxy distribution in one thin slice of the sky out to three billion light years.

title: Wooing collegians on campus with, what else, television.
description: THERE are more than 20 million consumers ages 18 to 24, the so-called college audience. And with billions of dollars to burn, they have long been prized by advertisers and courted by the media.

title: Dutch Giant Buys Control of Mexican Insurer
description: Control of Mexico's largest insurer, Seguros Comercial Amrica, will pass from a Mexican entrepreneur, Alfonso Romo, to the Dutch banking and insurance giant ING in a deal announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHEY, JOHN KEVIN S.J.
description: FAHEY-John Kevin S.J. Beloved member of the Jesuit Community. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd. Visition Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Thursday, 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Brothers, Inc. Directors.

title: Trivia Question: Greenberg's R.B.I. Rival
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: To the Rescue
description: Is the N.B.A. suddenly NBC's weakest link?

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 20 about China's agreement to cooperate with a United Nations agency to ease labor turmoil misstated its name. It is the International Labor Organization, not Office.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Consumer-Recording Venture Announced
description: The EMI Group, a major record label, announced a venture yesterday with Roxio, a maker of CD recording software, to develop technology for consumers to use to record music from the Internet in a way that respects the label's copyrights. Terms of the deal were not announced, though EMI said it had taken a minority equity investment in Roxio, a spinoff of Adaptec Inc., which is based in Milpitas, Calif. Roxio said the technology it was developing would enable consumers to decrypt an encrypted music file and then record, or ''burn'' that song onto a compact disc. Presently, it is possible to burn music files onto compact discs in a way that does not allow record labels to control distribution or to be paid for the music. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: The Boss: My Release Is Music and Yoga
description: When I'm part of an artistic whole, standing in front of a demanding conductor, I forget that I'm a journalist and the boss of a company  which feels good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLYMAS, JOSEPH
description: CLYMAS-Joseph. On June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Laurette. Dear father of Sari, devoted uncle of George and Andrew. He will be missed by his friends, neighbors and former colleagues. Visitation and memorial service on Friday, June 8, 5-7pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, Inc, 1297 1st Ave (70th St), NYC. 212-744-3084. Donations in his memory preferred to City Meals-on-Wheels

title: 'Bells' and 'Class Act' Will Close on Sunday
description: Two Broadway musicals, ''Bells Are Ringing'' and ''A Class Act,'' are to close after their matinees on Sunday.

title: More Protests in Nepal as Inquiry Stumbles
description: This morning along Ring Road, protesters lobbed bottles and burned tires, demanding the noose for whoever killed most of Nepal's royal family as they ate dinner in the palace on Friday.

title: Watching Paris, Thinking Queens
description: Tennis fans can stand in line for United States Open tickets on Sunday morning without missing any of the men's final at Roland Garros. And they might also get to hit with Patrick McEnroe, the United States Davis Cup captain.

title: How Grasses Use People to Fight Trees
description: THE BOTANY OF DESIRE

title: Long Island Enters the Ratings Game
description: IT took the Bordeaux wine trade a thousand years or so to come up with a serious ranking of its wines: the famous 1855 classification. Long Island, or more precisely one Long Islander, is trying to do the same in less than 30. Just as the Bordeaux list has been dogged by controversy almost since it was first published, it's a safe bet that the new Long Island classification will stir up a bit of heat as well.

title: Rain May Have Washed Away the Pollen but It Can't Cure the Sufferer
description: When record-setting pollen counts sent allergy sufferers into fits of sneezing and wheezing last month, the prescription was meteorological, not medical: pray for rain.

title: Liquidation of One.Tel of Australia Is Outlined
description: One.Tel, the Australian telecommunications company backed by scions of the Murdoch and Packer families, will be liquidated and its assets sold beginning in a few days, the administrator overseeing the company said today after meeting with major creditors.

title: For 20 Years, the Scourge of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, MARCIA
description: FEUER-Marcia. Beloved by all who knew her. Left the body on June 5, 2001 after 102 well lived years.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL TO HOLD TALKS ON COMAIR PILOTS' STRIKE
description: The Comair commuter carrier unit of Delta Air Lines Inc. and its pilots' union will meet with the transportation secretary, Norman Mineta, on Friday to try to settle a strike that began more than two months ago. Mr. Mineta called the meeting at the request of Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio and members of Congress from the state, said Chet Lunner, a Transportation Department spokesman. Comair, which was the second-largest commuter carrier before the strike began March 26, is based in Cincinnati. Comair has laid off or dismissed more than half of its 5,400 workers since the strike started.

title: With Badillo Gone, CUNY Is Likely to Stay on Course He Set
description: In his four tumultuous years as vice chairman and then chairman of the City University of New York, Herman Badillo made its transformation a kind of crusade.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Levy Gives New Responsibilities To a Deputy Superintendent

title: Learn From Ellis Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALHEIMER, GRETEL HOFMANN
description: THALHEIMER-Gretel Hofmann. On June 4, 2001, two days before her 99th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of Gary. Also survived by her nieces, nephews, and cousins. Services Wednesday, 11:00 AM at The Hebrew Tabernacle Congregation, 551 Fort Washington Ave. at 185 St. Interment to follow at Beth El Cemetery, NJ. Memorial donations in her memory can be made to your favorite charity.

title: Lucent Is Said to Be Ready To Offer Buyouts to 10,000
description: Lucent Technologies plans to offer more than 10,000 managers in the United States early retirement packages in another effort by the cash-short company to cut costs, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Falls
description: Shares in the Railtrack Group, which owns the 20,000 miles of tracks and 2,500 stations of Britain's creaking railroad system, fell 17 percent to a record low after analysts calculated that the worth of the company was only a fraction of its market value. The stock slid as much as 82 pence ($1.16), to 356 pence, the lowest level since the 1996 privatization of British Rail. It closed at 364.5 pence ($5.04) after Phil Oakley and Christian Cowley of ABN Amro said in a report that the company was worth 58 pence (82 cents) a share. The shares are down 60 percent this year after a crash in October ascribed to broken tracks forced the company into an extensive emergency repair program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMOY, JUDITH LISA NEE COHEN
description: HAMOY-Judith Lisa nee Cohen. April 25, 1950-June 4, 2001 in California. Beloved daughter of the late Franklin Cohen. Survived by her mother, Selma, her sister Diane R. Davis. Judi graduated from Queens College Cum Laude in 1973. Judi, we hope you are at peace at last. You waged a heroic fight against the depression that finally over took you. You were a gifted teacher and a fine musician. You will be remembered always by those of us who loved you. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, W. DUANE, MD
description: TODD-W. Duane, MD, June first, beloved husband of Dorothy Jane Keith. Father of George Damon Todd and Alison Keith Todd Cokorinos. Grandfather of Emily and Katherine Cokorinos. Brother of Donald Todd. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT, or Sloane Hospital for Women, Att. Dr. Roger Lobo, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 West 168th St., NYC 10033.

title: Iran's Leader Says U.S., to Improve Ties, Must Ease Policy
description: President Mohammad Khatami, who is seeking to be re-elected on Friday, said today that the United States would have to change its policies toward Iran if relations are to improve.

title: No Charges Against Officers In a Shooting Death
description: The Justice Department has decided not to pursue criminal civil rights charges against four New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of a mentally disturbed hammer-wielding man in Brooklyn in 1999.

title: Falling Stars
description: It seems that each year some big star leaves some big television show.

title: Posada Can Bat, Not Catch, For a Bit
description: Yankees catcher Jorge Posada has a sprained collateral ligament in his left thumb, and he said last night that he would not catch in a game for at least the next five or six days. Posada is available to hit, but catching could aggravate the injury. After five or six days, Posada said, doctors will examine him again, and he hopes that he will then be able to wear a plastic splint and return to catching.

title: Test Here and There, Not Everywhere
description: THE federal government spends nearly $20 billion a year to aid schools and should ensure that the money is well spent. President Bush wants to do so by requiring states to test third- to eighth-grade students each year and intervene if scores lag.

title: Mr. Bloomberg Announces
description: Michael Bloomberg officially entered the New York City mayoral race yesterday with a potentially powerful theme and a formidable set of obstacles. His basic message is that his personal wealth and limited experience in the public arena are positive assets that separate him from the four politicians who aspire to the Democratic nomination -- as well as from Herman Badillo, a familiar Republican figure who plans to announce his candidacy tomorrow. But while these assets give him an aura of independence from backroom politics, they also underscore his liabilities as a political novice. His overriding task is to define himself as more than a rich man with untested campaign skills. In a field of veterans, he must convince millions of New Yorkers that he is a plausible candidate who grasps the complexities of governance and has some solid ideas about how to consolidate Rudolph Giuliani's gains while addressing the unfinished business Mayor Giuliani has left behind.

title: Where Cornelia Street's Restaurant Row Began
description: EIGHT years ago, before Mario Batali was a celebrity chef with his face all over the Food Network on television, he opened Po, a small, vivacious trattoria on Cornelia Street, a quiet little block in Greenwich Village.

title: A Melting Pot Of Italian Cooking
description: IT is rare to come across a cookbook with more than 100 pages of text before a single recipe appears. Rare, perhaps, because cookbooks have come to feed an insatiable crowd hungry for new dishes to cook, and the assurance that uncharted culinary territory remains.

title: In Shift, Germany Allows Wireless Network Sharing
description: The German agency that regulates telecommunications said today that it would allow telephone companies to cut costs by sharing parts of the network that will support the new wireless services.

title: Sitting Down With the Writers And Artists in Old Paris
description: At the Brasserie Lipp in Paris, Hemingway fans can still order the sausage and potatoes he described in ''A Moveable Feast.'' The brasserie had been in business for 40 years when Hemingway showed up. Venerable Parisian restaurants like this, from tiny cafes to grand salons, transport diners back to a vanished world of artists and writers. An alluring 246-page guide, ''The Historic Restaurants of Paris'' by Ellen Williams (The Little Bookroom, $14.95), lists scores of places to tempt lovers of history and food. And there are some surprises, like the Bistrot d' Ct on Rue Gustave Flaubert, which, though it opened in 1988, occupies the premises of a 19th-century grocery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Abuse Arrests Reported
description: Two boys, 10 and 13 years old, were arrested yesterday on charges that they had sexually abused girls in Manhattan and Queens. The police also said they were investigating a sexual attack at a junior high school in Brooklyn. The 10-year-old boy was charged with assaulting an 11-year-old girl yesterday in a hallway at Public School 197 in Harlem. The 13-year-old boy was accused of attacking a 13-year-old girl on a stairway on Monday at Junior High School 185 in Flushing. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Double Jeopardy

title: Corrections
description: The Melrose Journal article and a picture caption on Sunday, about a pet shop in a poor and working-class section of the Bronx, referred incorrectly in some copies to the breed of a dog owned by an auto mechanic. It was a miniature pinscher, not a miniature Doberman.

title: Democrats Have Power, And Familiar Quandary
description: As he made his lightning ascension to majority leader, Senator Tom Daschle sounded much like George W. Bush as he prepared to move into the Oval Office. He sounded modest, conciliatory and cooperative.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about the government response to the AIDS epidemic misstated the total amount of federal spending on H.I.V./AIDS in the 2000 fiscal year. It was $10.9 billion, not $10.7 billion.

title: Scholar With Wide View of Judaism Will Lead Reform Seminary
description: Rabbi David Ellenson, a scholar of Jewish religious thought at Reform Judaism's seminary and professional school, has been chosen as the institution's new president, its board of governors announced yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Racial-Profiling Ruling
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the New Jersey Transit police illegally used race to stop and search a black man. The ruling turned on whether the man, Marlon A. Maryland, was legally stopped and searched when he was found with a bag of marijuana in 1995. He was sentenced in 1997 to five years in prison. Lower courts said the search was legal. But the state's highest court agreed with Mr. Maryland's lawyers. The court's ruling overturns Mr. Maryland's sentence, but it was not immediately clear whether he would receive a new trial or be freed. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: HBO Still Strong on Sunday, Even Without `The Sopranos'
description: No "Sopranos"? No problem. Or so it seems for HBO, which continued its run of record-setting series strength on Sunday nights with the season premieres of its returning hit comedy "Sex and the City" and its dark new comedy-drama "Six Feet Under."

title: Apple Settles iMac Infringement Lawsuit
description: Apple Computer Inc. settled a lawsuit today with Future Power, a computer maker that was building Windows-based personal computers that looked like Apple's iMac.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Phillips's Move to Midtown Is Not Just About Space
description: After almost 20 years on the Upper East Side, Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, the third-place auction house, is moving its American headquarters to Midtown with the intention of renewing its rivalry with the much larger Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: Amazon.com Is Planning to Sell PC's for First Time
description: Amazon.com, in its first major product line expansion this year, said yesterday that it intended to start selling personal computers in the next few months. Amazon's electronics department already sells computer add-ons like disk drives and memory.

title: Market Place; A preacher of caution during the late bull market decides to open his own technology hedge fund.
description: JONATHAN H. COHEN, one of the few Wall Street technology analysts who preached caution during the bull market, is starting a hedge fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, KURT A.
description: FRIEDLANDER-Kurt A. 6/6/99. Adored husband, wonderful father. You are loved and missed every day. Nothing is the same without you. Pie and Poohsie

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Due In Court
description: A federal judge moved up to tomorrow the date for questioning former President Carlos Sal Menem on his suspected involvement in illegal arms sales to Ecuador and Croatia between 1991 and 1995. The questioning, originally scheduled for mid-July, was changed after Mr. Menem, who recently married, indicated that he might take his honeymoon in Syria, opening the possibility that he might flee. Several former aides, including his defense minister, have been arrested in the case. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Father of Robin Anne Kearney, Robert W., Jr., James Marx and Antonia Maccelli. Grandfather of nine. The funeral was private.

description: The Republican primary for mayor of New York City lost all the tidiness that party leaders had hoped for yesterday as two men, one a perpetual candidate and the other a billionaire political neophyte, announced that they were entering a now messy, peculiar race.

title: F.B.I. Agent Can Be Charged In Idaho Siege, Court Rules
description: Opening a new chapter in a case that the F.B.I. has been trying to close for years, a federal appeals court here ruled today that a sharpshooter for the agency could be tried on state charges of manslaughter in the death of a woman during a standoff in 1992 in Ruby Ridge, Idaho.

title: Sunday Editor Quits Suddenly at Daily News in New York
description: Less than three months after taking over as Sunday editor of The Daily News, Frank Lalli resigned suddenly Tuesday, saying his heart was in magazines, not newspapers.

title: THE CHEF
description: COOKING duck presents a quandary. People love the crisp skin of well-done roast duck, but they also like the boneless breast cooked medium-rare. How to accomplish both at once?

title: OPEC Maintains Output Levels, With Another Look in July
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to delay an increase in production levels, a move that could push crude oil prices higher in coming weeks if Iraq makes good on a threat to keep its oil off world markets.

title: Transportation Chief Predicts Rejection of Airline Merger
description: The secretary of transportation said today that the proposed merger of United Airlines and US Airways would not be approved.

title: Sports of The Times; Spare Parts Keep Devils Humming
description: DEPTH. Maybe more than any other reason, it's why teams win championships, especially in the collision sports in which depth is so necessary for a team to keep winning.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Paper Stake
description: In a sign of impending consolidation among Brazilian paper and pulp companies, Aracruz and Votorantim Celulose e Papel jointly bought a controlling stake in the country's second-largest pulp exporter, Celulose Nipo-Brasileira, for $670.5 million. The Brazilian mining company Cia Vale do Rio Doce auctioned its 51.5 percent stake in the company, known here as Cenibra, to focus on its core mining operations. The minority shareholder group, which includes the Itochu Corporation of Japan, has 30 days to invoke its right to buy the stake itself. Jennifer Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALICK, PAUL
description: CALICK-Paul on June 4, 2001. Age 96, of Lake Worth FL, formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband for 62 years of Gladys. Adored father of Dedee and Stephen Lovell, Terry and Harold Schottenfeld. Devoted brother of Leon and Miriam, and Bernard Calick. Loving grandfather of David and Lisa Roberts, Barry Lovell and Ellen Reinheimer, Jamie and Brian Puntin, Wendy Lovell-Smith and Colin Smith, Hope and Joshua Newman. Great grandfather of Jordan, Kasey, Rachel, Alyssa, Adam, Noah, Maya and Jacob. A founding member of Glen Head Country Club and pioneer in clothing import. Full of vitality, he possessed a winning sense of humor and warmth that endeared him to all. He will be sorely missed. Private graveside funeral to be held.

description: To the Editor:

description: PIKEN-Sally (Eliscu). Beloved wife of the late Sidney Piken and Al Ulius. Beloved aunt, great aunt, great grand aunt and friend. Loved by all who knew her, she will be missed very much. Graveside services, Thursday, 12:30 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Hahn Wins Los Angeles Mayor's Race
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  City Attorney James K. Hahn, the low-key son of a beloved local political family, drew support from a rare coalition of liberal black voters and conservative whites to claim victory as the 40th mayor of Los Angeles early this morning, defeating former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, who had hoped to become his city's first Hispanic mayor in 129 years.

title: Harold Ridley, Eye Doctor, 94, Early Developer of Lens Implants
description: Sir Harold Ridley, an ophthalmologist and developer of the operation to replace cataract-scarred lenses, died on May 25 in Salisbury, England, after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 94.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Offender List To Close For Now
description: A federal appeals court yesterday refused an emergency request to keep Connecticut's sex offender computer database open to the public. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit voted 2 to 1 to deny the request by State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal. But the appeals court said it would hear his arguments in July. Last month, a Federal District Court judge ordered the state to close its online sex offender registry, saying it did not give sex offenders the chance to challenge the posting on the Internet of their names, addresses and photographs. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Getting In the Game
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Ray of Hope For Travelers Following Signs
description: ANXIETY is a hallmark of New York. It is attainable at many convenient locations, from curbsides with incomprehensible parking regulations to Friday traffic on the Long Island Expressway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAGLIAN, BARBARA F.
description: DAGLIAN-Barbara F. On June 5, 2001. Beloved mother of Lisa, Ara Paul, grandmother of Ara Paul, Jr. and Katie, sister of Georgia Messemer. Yankee fan and friend to many, died peacefully to join her parents, friends and favorite pets in heaven. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 8, 4-6:30PM, Cornell Club, 6 E. 44 St. Expressions of memories are welcome.

title: Article 2001060793468439216 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Totowa: Suspect Sought In Crime Spree
description: The state police said yesterday that they were seeking a man suspected of assaulting a Pennsylvania state trooper, fleeing in her squad car, crashing the vehicle in the fog, killing a truck driver who apparently had stopped to help and hijacking his tractor-trailer. The accused man, Norman James, 31, is charged with murder and other crimes. Capt. Frank Simonetta, chief investigator for the case, said the police had arrested a 14-year-old boy, whose name was not released. Mr. James and the boy may have killed the truck driver, James Burt, as he stopped to offer help at the scene of the damaged police car, the police said. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Editing Himself Out
description: Less than three months after taking over as Sunday editor of The Daily News, Frank Lalli resigned suddenly, saying his heart was in magazines, not newspapers. Mr. Lalli and The News, separately, confirmed the resignation yesterday. People at The News, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Lalli, who took over the Sunday editor's job on March 15, had clashed with some of the senior editors at the newspaper over resources and the editorial direction of the Sunday paper. Reached at his home yesterday, Mr. Lalli said: ''I've decided to move on. I've spent a lot of years in magazines. I've spent some years in newspapers. And this experience at The News has convinced me that I'm really a magazine person. I've got an idea for a magazine and I'm going to devote 100 percent of my time to developing that idea.'' Ken Frydman, a spokesman for The Daily News, confirmed last evening that Mr. Lalli had resigned, but denied that there was any friction between the outgoing Sunday editor and his colleagues. ''He's very well thought of and very well respected as an editor and a journalist,'' Mr. Frydman said. Mr. Lalli came to The News as it -- and the entire newspaper industry -- was being buffeted by the sharpest advertising downturn in a decade. Last month The News laid off several reporters. His outspoken style in meetings, two people at The News said, grated on some of his colleagues. Mr. Lalli was the editor of George Magazine when it was closed by Hachette Filipacchi in January. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: The New York Front In the Energy Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Stern Setting Age Limits Aside
description: N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern still strongly believes that putting an age limit on players entering the draft will help the league prosper, but he has resigned himself to putting the issue aside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEKELBOUM, MARVIN
description: DEKELBOUM - Marvin. The members and staff of the Falls Country Club in Lake Worth, FL, wish to express their sincere condolences on the passing of Marvin, to his wife Elsie and their family. Board of Governors Kenneth Mahler, President

title: Francis Bebey; African-Music Expert, 72
description: Francis Bebey, a composer, writer and performer who was an authority on African traditional music, died on May 28 in Paris. He was 72.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From traveling in South Asia to hiking the Appalachian Trail, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: State of the Art: Putting You at the PC, Remotely
description: YOU can't call yourself a modern mobile professional until you've survived three rites of passage. First, there's boarding the flight on which you hoped to complete an important memo, and realizing that your laptop was "recharging" all night from a dead outlet. Second, there's spilling coffee into your keyboard in flight; extra credit if you're caught without a napkin and the seat-belt sign is illuminated. Finally, there's winding up in some remote and inconvenient city and discovering that you need to consult a crucial file that's nonchalantly resting on your hard drive back home.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Costs Up At Brambles
description: Brambles Industries said profit this fiscal year might fall 6 percent as costs rise at its CHEP storage pallet unit. Sydney-based Brambles, the largest supplier of pallets, expects profit in the year ending June 30 to fall to about 343 million Australian dollars ($177 million) from 364.8 million Australian dollars ($186.3 million) in fiscal 2000, the company said. Brambles said costs at CHEP, which operates a worldwide pool of 130 million pallets and containers, were rising as the company installed a new computer system, closed some pallet depots in the United States and started a plastic crate business.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Point Given Still Outside and Favored
description: Once more Point Given is considered the horse to beat, having been made the morning line favorite, at 8-5 odds. Once more the colt will break from the outside post, this time No. 9. And again his trainer, Bob Baffert, is confident the son of Thunder Gulch is the best 3-year-old in the nation and will prove so on Saturday in the final leg of the Triple Crown, the $1 million Belmont Stakes.

title: No-Smoking Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Aims to Erase Line Between Video Games and Art
description: It's official: Computer games are an art form, at least according to one museum. The Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, known as Mass MOCA, in North Adams, Mass. (www.massmoca.org), has opened an exhibition called ''Game Show'' devoted to game structures and themes in art, and has included a section on gaming.

title: Baby's First Webcast:A Visit With Family
Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYCE, GERARD R.
description: BOYCE-Gerard R. 46, died on June 4, 2001 at his home in Franklin Lakes, NJ. He is survived by his beloved wife, Anna, and three children, Lauren (10), Aidan (2), and Garrett (8 months), and two sisters, Peggy Louie Chaplin and Veronica Gunnerson. Admitted to the bar in 1983, Jerry was a partner at Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, LLP, resident in the firm's Manhattan office, concentrating his practice in tax and corporate law. He was a columnist in corporate finance for the New York Law Journal and Lecturer in limited liability company law for the New York State Bar Association. Educated at Fairleigh Dickenson University (B.S., Cum Laude, 1976), Seton Hall University (J.D., Cum Laude, 1983) and New York University (LLM in Tax, 1987). He was a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York State and American Bar Associations. Jerry was a New Jersey Certified Public Accountant (1978), and a member of The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He will be remembered for his boyish innocence and love of life. He was a mentor, a true friend and a philosopher. He framed his family's motto, ''Do The Right Thing'', and lived his life by it. In Jerry's honor, donations may be made to The Gerard R. Boyce Memorial Racing Fund, in care of Mark Limardo, Esq., Jenkins, Gilchrist, Parker, Chapin LLP, 405 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10174.

title: Can't Sit on a Laptop
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Count on That Tax Cut
description: President Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut today. But conservatives shouldn't break out the champagne just yet, nor should liberals start taking their antidepressants.

title: Versatile Holik Is Doing It All for Devils in Run to Cup
description: If the Devils lose to the Colorado Avalanche on Thursday night at Continental Arena in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals, speculation about the Conn Smythe trophy for most valuable player in the tournament will be postponed. It will be overshadowed by anticipation for Game 7 on Saturday night in Denver, which would be the first time the championship round would conclude at full length since the Rangers defeated Vancouver in 1994.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Show With Some Secrets Not Everyone Will Be Able to See
description: The ghostly self-illuminated objects above from ''Firefly,'' on view in ''Massless Medium: Explorations in Sensory Immersion'' at the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage, have yet another dimension. Pack along a Palm OS PDA, and you will see animations invisible to the unwired, via infrared beaming. ''We imposed an imaginary layer of existence,'' said Sigi Moeslinger of Antenna Design, which created the ''Firefly'' installation. This and six other works are on exhibit Thursday through Sunday, 1 to 6 p.m., through July 29. A music series starts tonight at 10 with German techno ($15). Both events are organized by Creative Time, the nonprofit arts presenter; www.creativetime.org/anch2001.

title: Tax Cuts for Now, but Their Lifetime Is Limited
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Almost nothing about the new tax law is irreversible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ROBERT WALLER
description: MARX-Robert Waller. Age 72. Died suddenly May 31, 2001 in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Son of the late Julian and Katherine Waller Marx. Brother of Peter and the late Julian. Father of Robin Anne Kearney, Robert W., Jr., James Marx and Antonia Maccelli. Grandfather of nine. The funeral was private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD H.
description: MENDIK-Bernard H. The Center for Preventive Psychiatry records with sorrow the death of Trustee Laurie Mendik's father. Our deepest sympathy is extended to Laurie and her family. Timmy Weinberg, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Delay In Skakel Trial
description: The Connecticut Appellate Court has agreed to hear an appeal by Michael C. Skakel, who is charged in the killing of Martha Moxley in 1975. He is trying to overturn a juvenile court judge's ruling earlier this year that he be tried as an adult and face a possible sentence of life in prison if convicted. The decision to hear the appeal will probably delay any trial until next year, lawyers involved in the case said. The court will probably hear oral arguments in the fall and decide by the end of the year, the lawyers said. Mr. Skakel, 40, was initially charged as a juvenile because he was 15 at the time of Miss Moxley's death. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: On Harrowing Sea Journeys, In a Bid to Escape Their Misery
description: A small boat is the center of the story Lidia Ramirez tells in her one-woman play ''I Love America.'' About halfway through this worthy one-act production at the American Place Theater, Ms. Ramirez puts a couple of folding chairs on their sides to represent the small boat, or yola, in which Dominican refugees are trying to make their way to Puerto Rico before going on to the United States. Jane Cox's lighting goes low, David Margolin Lawson's watery sound effects go loud, and for a few minutes Ms. Ramirez grabs her audience and takes them with her in reliving a truly terrifying undertaking.

title: Dashboard Miser Teaches Drivers How to Save Fuel
description: DUTCH and Swedish researchers may have an antidote for rising gasoline prices. They have developed a computer-driven dashboard display that advises drivers throughout a trip on ways to reduce fuel use.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cypress Buying Chip Designer
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a maker of chips used in telecommunications equipment, agreed to buy the closely held Lara Networks Inc. for about $225 million to expand its product line. Lara's sales last year were $25 million and are expected to rise to $70 million by 2003, a Cypress spokesman said. Lara designs semiconductors that sort and speed information in communication networks.

title: Summer Seclusion in the Turks and Caicos
description: Parrot Cay, a 58-room luxury resort on its own 1,000-acre island in the Turks and Caicos, has a seven-night Summer Seclusion package with daily breakfast and dinner, a daily massage, round-trip transfers from the airport by boat, most watersports and a picnic on the beach. Through Oct. 26, the price is $3,500 a couple in a garden-view room (a savings of $425) and $4,250 a couple in an ocean view room ($650 savings). Contact (877) 754-0726 or www.parrot-cay.com .

title: Among Code Warriors, Women, Too, Can Fight
description: WHEN Sarah Flannery was 16 in 1999, she won Ireland's Young Scientist of the Year award for her work in Internet cryptography. Although she is described in a recent book, ''The Hacker Ethic,'' as ''a 16-year-old hacker,'' Ms. Flannery, now 19 and studying computer science at Cambridge University, isn't quite sure how to feel about that description.

title: Article 2001060790615480340 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Deaths  CALICK, PAUL
description: CALICK-Paul. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Paul Calick, a cherished friend who expressed his commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes through his generosity. His beloved daughter, Diane Lovell, and her husband, Stephen Lovell, embraced Mr. Calick's devotion to our community through their extraordinary support of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Diane and Stephen; to Mr. Calick's wife, Gladys; to his daughter, Terry Schottenfeld, and her husband, Harold; to his ten grandchildren; and to his entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, KIM
description: SHULMAN-Kim. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York extends its heartfelt condolences to Queens Borough President Claire and Dr. Mel Shulman on the loss of their son. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gedale B. Horowitz, Pres. Ezra G. Levin, Pres. Elect Michael S. Miller, Exec. V.P.

title: 'Pearl Harbor' Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOAGLAND, ALEXANDER C.
description: HOAGLAND-Alexander C. June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Teresa, loving father of Valente, Antonio (Lupe) and Valeria (Luis). Cherished grandfather of Anna, Teresa, Alejandro, Felipe, Maria and Mariana. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, corner of 81st Street. Friday, June 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, June 9th, 10:30am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIKULAY, EMMIE S.
description: MIKULAY-Emmie S. Of Whitefish Bay, WI, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. May 24, 2001, age 47 years. Beloved wife of Robert. Proud mother of David. Dear grandmother of Glavens ''Meme'' David. Memorial services will be held at 11 AM, Saturday, June 9, at First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry St, Brooklyn Heights. The family will greet friends at a reception to be held 12:30-2:30 PM at the Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon St, Brooklyn Heights. Memorials to the Wisconsin Breast Cancer Showhouse, 9564 West Wakefield Ct., Bayside, WI 53217 suggested. Emmie was loved by all whose lives she touched.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONSTEIN, HENRY
description: ARONSTEIN-Henry. Think of you always, miss you. Happy Birthday. Love, Margie, Susan and Jesse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAM, EUGENE
description: ADAM-Eugene. Died Bar Harbor, ME, Monday, June 4, 2001. Officer in U.S. Military Government in World War II. A loyal and generous friend will be remembered with affection by all.

title: New State Law on Ticket Scalping
description: The State Legislature passed a ticket-scalping bill today that makes it a felony to bribe box office employees to divert tickets and raises the amount of profit a legitimate ticketholder or broker may make.

title: Republicans in New Jersey Governor Race Call for Reform
description: The two Republican candidates for governor of New Jersey grappled today over who deserved to wear the badge of ''reformer'' in their increasingly heated primary battle.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Dot-Com Slips
