description: Shares of Scoot.com, which provides Internet services for businesses, fell 24 percent after it said Vivendi Universal S.A., the large French media company, ended talks about acquiring the 78 percent of the company it did not already own. On April 27, Scoot.com said it rejected as too low Vivendi's offer to buy the remaining shares for 15 pence each. The offer was 33 percent more than the price of Scoot.com's shares on April 26. Scoot.com collects a slice of revenue from transactions between its subscribers and other businesses, but it does not make money. In March, it hired Merrill Lynch to review its options. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Price of Success In AIDS Treatment; Hospitals Confront New Therapy
description: The 20-year onslaught of AIDS has radically changed the economics of patient care, and its effects are still being felt throughout the health care system.

title: In This Best of 2000 List, It Isn't What They Say; It's How They Say it
description: The American Institute of Graphic Arts has picked 105 winners out of 4,400 entries for its selection of the best graphic design of 2000. The entrants' ''economic structures and motivations varied wildly,'' said Michael Bierut, a partner at Pentagram and the competition's chairman. Among the winners are Amphetazine, a magazine designed by the Modern Dog studio in Seattle to educate gay men about the dangers of the drug known as crystal meth; Calori & Vanden-Eynden's signage for Amtrak's Acela train service; and James Victore's promotional poster, left, for Mot & Chandon. A list of winners will be posted at www.aiga.org, and winning entries will be exhibited in November in the institute's gallery at 164 Fifth Avenue; (212) 807-1990.

title: Early Knowledge Of SAT Questions Is Investigated
description: The College Board and the Educational Testing Service are investigating how some high school students in Westchester County obtained early knowledge of some questions on a specialized college entrance exam in biology, before more than 15,000 students across the country took the test on Saturday.

title: A Normandy Landing, This One for a Film
description: The 57th anniversary of the Normandy landings drew no statesmen or generals to memorial services here today, but at least the entertainment industry showed that it still loved World War II, with a splashy beachside premiere for ''Band of Brothers,'' a 10-part HBO mini-series about an American parachute unit that is to be broadcast in the United States this fall.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Abortion Rights Group Files Suit Over Bush Family Planning Rule
description: A privately financed group that works for abortion rights overseas sued the Bush administration yesterday to challenge its rule denying federal funds to foreign family planning or health organizations that perform or advocate abortions.

title: Helping a Golfer Look Like a Pro In Order to Swing Like One, Too
description: TO say that golf is a sport that inspires a compulsion to improve would hardly do justice to the notions of compulsion and improvement.

title: Democrat Easily Wins California Seat in House
description: Diane Watson, a former ambassador and state senator, won an easy victory on Tuesday in a special election in California's 32nd Congressional District, ensuring Democratic control of the seat left vacant last December by the death of Representative Julian C. Dixon.

title: Profiting From Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Judging Covers As Artworks
description: Ever since compact disc sales started to overtake vinyl album revenue in the mid-1980's, there has been debate over which format sounds better, and the answer remains unresolved. But a new question has arisen: which looks better?

title: Accounts
description: * Foot Locker, New York, the retail footwear chain, formalized its relationship with AKA Advertising, New York, by naming AKA as agency of record on its account, with billings estimated at $30 million. AKA has handled the account on a project basis for two years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Two Sides of PowerPoint

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Arrest In Arms Case
description: A retired general who served as former President Carlos Sal Menem's army chief was arrested on charges of taking part in a plot to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. Martn Balza is the third senior aide to Mr. Menem to be arrested in the case. Mr. Menem is scheduled to be questioned in court today, and legal experts are speculating that he might be arrested.

title: Guess Which Slams Work In the Year's Biggest Game
description: Study the North-South cards shown in the diagram, and consider the slam possibilities. Which slams are possible? Which has the best theoretical chance? And which will succeed in practice?

title: Wall-to-Wall Carpeting At a Floor-Friendly Price
description: Costco, the membership warehouse known for deeply discounted prices on groceries, also offers deeply discounted wall-to-wall nylon carpeting from brands like DuPont Stainmaster and Anso. Durable nylon is a wise choice for high-traffic areas like family rooms, children's rooms and pool houses. Costco's carpets come with a 12-year warranty. Prices range from $25.83 to $35.55 a square yard for high-quality velvets, Berbers and Saxonys, as well as commercial-grade carpet. The cost includes at-home professional measuring, installation, padding and tax, all from an affiliated company, Custom Decorators, (888) 992-2773. You must be a member of Costco to use the service: www.costco.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Economist To Join Cabinet
description: President-elect Alejandro Toledo announced that he would appoint Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, an orthodox economist popular on Wall Street, to his cabinet but did not specify what post. Peruvian bond and stock prices have soared since Mr. Toledo's election victory on Sunday, and the value of the Peruvian currency has also recovered.

title: Shares Retreat Amid Doubts About Economy's Revival
description: Stocks fell yesterday as investors, without any fresh major economic data to consider, cautiously stepped back after four days of gains.

title: RAYTHEON PLANS TO CUT 470 MORE JOBS AT AIRCRAFT UNIT
description: The Raytheon Company plans to cut 470 more jobs at its commercial-aircraft unit in Kansas because of lower-than-expected deliveries of Beechjet and King Air planes. The cuts affect hourly workers and represent 4.8 percent of the unit's work force. The company said in April that it would cut 450 salaried employees at the unit, which makes business jets and turboprop planes. About 267 of those jobs will be eliminated by the end of the month, Raytheon said. Sales at the aircraft unit fell 22 percent last quarter. Raytheon expects to deliver 468 jets this year, 40 fewer than forecast.

title: The Chase Is On For Emmitt Smith
description: The stride was familiar, but the equipment was different. Yes, that was Emmitt Smith with a golf club in his hand and with a furrowed brow, vexing over his game -- golf yesterday -- but surely football soon.

title: TOYS 'R' US NAMES CHIEF EXECUTIVE TO BE CHAIRMAN
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that it had named its president and chief executive, John Eyler, as chairman. Mr. Eyler, 52, succeeds Michael Goldstein, who remains a director, the company said. Mr. Eyler became the chief executive of Toys ''R'' Us in January 2000. He was formerly chairman and chief executive of F. A. O. Schwarz. Mr. Eyler began remodeling stores last year, changing the layout of aisles and adding more exclusive items, to regain sales lost to Wal-Mart Stores.

title: Rumsfeld Says U.S. Must Be in Balkans, but Not Become Mired
description: On a day of escalating tensions in the Balkans, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he was convinced that American troops were still needed in Kosovo to stem violence, particularly along the Macedonian border.

title: Fighting AIDS in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyumen Oil Moves to Control Gas Producer
description: In the latest move in a high-stakes chess match, Tyumen Oil, a major Russian oil producer, said yesterday that it had acquired most of the debts of ZAO Rospan, a Siberian gas producer that once belonged to Gazprom, the giant state-controlled energy company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL GOLF PROPERTIES INC., Santa Monica, Calif., the real estate investment trust which owns more than 150 golf courses in 26 states, private country clubs and resort courses, has acquired the Marbella Country Club, in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., for about $12.5 million.

title: Snow, Bell and Geiger Pitch In for Sixers
description: Their tiny, fearless superstar led them to a stunning 107-101 overtime victory, but the other Philadelphia 76ers played much more than bit parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, SOPHIA
description: ABELES-Sophia. Died peacefully on June 5, 2001 at age 84 after a long struggle with rheumatoid arthritis and heart problems. Sophia is survived by her beloved husband, Joseph, her daughters Lucille and Barbara, her grandson Greg and his wife Nikki, and her great-grandchildren Nola, Lily and Ezra. She is predeceased by her beloved daughter Nancy. Sophia lived her life passionately involved in the life of her husband, her children and far reaching activities in support of education and the arts. She loved and cared for her family. She traveled with and participated in her husband's business worlds and brought a richness to the lives of everyone around the world who knew her. She loved, advised and supported her children with patience and humor. She devoted most of her life to helping the lives of others, mostly through education. She believed that helping people to receive an education was one of the greatest gifts that anyone could offer. While serving for twelve years on the Pocantico Hills School Board, she was elected to be the first female president of the Board. Prior to that, she served as the President of the PTA in Thornwood. She co-founded the first area network group of female school board members, which has grown from four members to sixty since its inception. Most recently, she served on the board of the Westchester Community College Foundation for seventeen years, during which time she served as vice president, a member of the Executive Committee and as chair of the Executive Committee. She co-founded and served for ten years on The Board of the Affiliates for SUNY at Purchase, which was formed to advance and better the life of SUNY students and provide a strong link with the community. Over thirty years ago Sophia and Joe started the Nancy Jo Abeles Scholarship Fund, which continues today to provide financial support to those qualified and motivated students who wish to further their education. She was Vice President and Chair of Programming for the Westchester Federation of Women s Clubs. She served on the Historic Preservation Committee, which conceived the two-year Westchester Landmarks Project. In 1987 she was awarded the first annual Arts In Education awards by the Council for the Arts in Westchester. She served as a trustee on the council for six years. Sophia was an accomplished gardener with a special interest in bonsai. She and Joe loved to travel, especially to Europe and Japan. Sophia was a graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College. A service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon on Friday, June 8th at 1:30 pm. The address is 21 Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552. The phone number is 914664-6800. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations in Sophia's honor can be made to the Stephen Abramson Research Support Fund, c/o Stephen Abramson, NYU Medical Center, Division of Rheumatology, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Sanctions-Busting Air Service
description: In defiance of United Nations sanctions, Royal Jordanian Airlines has resumed regular passenger service from Amman to Baghdad, the first airline to do so since commercial flights to Iraq were halted a decade ago. The state-owned airline, which began making frequent but officially unscheduled flights to Baghdad in November, will fly the route as a special charter service every Tuesday and Friday, said Wasef Azzaz, Jordan's trade and industry minister.

title: Drop Expected in Sales of Semiconductors
description: Worldwide sales of semiconductors are expected to decline this year, an industry group said today, as demand slows for the chips, which run everything from personal computers to cellular phones.

title: The Ballyhoo's Over and Britain Is Voting
description: The battle buses made their final journeys, the candidates declaimed their final speeches in rallies around the country and workers stuffed mailboxes with 11th-hour get-out-the-vote leaflets as Britain's national election campaign came to an end tonight.

title: Europeans Open Door For Hostile Takeovers
description: After marathon negotiations that lasted until early this morning, European leaders agreed today on a law that would make it easier to carry out hostile takeovers and more difficult for companies to defend themselves by selling shares to friendly shareholders.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Mexican Trucks Allowed To Operate
description: President Bush announced he would allow Mexican corporations to operate trucks and buses between points in the United States, a move that he said was required by the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Teamsters union criticized the move, saying it was another step toward opening the American border to unsafe Mexican trucks. Under Nafta, American companies can own 51 percent of transportation companies based in Mexico, with that cap to be lifted by 2004. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A Restart in the Senate
description: The Senate changed from Republican to Democratic control yesterday with elaborate pledges of cooperation and scrambling for advantage behind the scenes. But for all the forced bonhomie, it was a reassuring start that benefited from President Bush's simultaneous, if overdue, outreach to the Democrats. While Senators Tom Daschle and Trent Lott promised to work together as the new majority and minority leaders, their operatives focused on trying to establish rules to treat Mr. Bush's legislation and appointments fairly. The atmosphere was greatly improved by an apparent decision by Republicans to drop earlier threats to block Senate business if they did not get their way.

title: Strong Rally in Chip Stocks Pushes Nasdaq Up 46.27 Points
description: Semiconductor stocks rallied sharply today, leading the overall technology sector higher, as investors hoped that Intel, the world's largest chip maker, would add to the evidence that the industry's decline was ending and that sales would revive in the second half of the year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hearing For a Killer
description: An appeals court panel heard arguments yesterday on a judge's decision to free Dennis Sweeney, the man who killed a former United States representative, Allard K. Lowenstein, 21 years ago, from state supervision. Mr. Sweeney, left, was committed to a psychiatric hospital, but in recent years has been living with minimal supervision. A trial judge has released him, and Mr. Sweeney's lawyer told the three-judge panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that Mr. Sweeney had not been prescribed any psychiatric medication in years. The Manhattan district attorney and the State Office of Mental Health urged the panel to restore official supervision for Mr. Sweeney. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Flexible Displays Could Mean Body-Hugging Monitors
description: A flexible liquid crystal display that may lead to screens that roll up into a small tube for storage was announced this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOBEL, JESSE (DOC)
description: SOBEL-Jesse (Doc). You will always be a legend in our minds. We will never forget the impact you made on our lives. Uggie The Bonga! The Lorberbaum Famil

title: Tony Blair and Labor Sweep to Victory in British Polls
description: LONDON, June 7  Tony Blair and the Labor Party swept to victory in Britain's election today, sending the once mighty Conservatives to their second consecutive large-scale defeat and guaranteeing his own party its first ever reelection to a full term in office.

title: The Virtual Reviewer
description: Narrow-minded ethics wonks are harrumphing at the news that some anonymous genius in the publicity department of Sony Pictures, having found the existing stock of movie reviewers insufficiently malleable, decided to invent a fake one by the name of David Manning. The nonexistent Mr. Manning wrote highly enthusiastic blurbs (''Another winner!'') that were used in ads for two Sony releases, ''The Animal'' and ''A Knight's Tale.'' The blurbs were attributed to an actual newspaper -- The Ridgefield Press, a Connecticut weekly that by all accounts had nothing to do with the deception.

title: Economic Scene; In America, to the richest go the biggest tax benefits. So what else is new?
description: HISTORY may judge it a little odd that after the greatest accrual of private wealth in a century, the United States decided to give its richest citizens a giant tax break. But in truth, favoring the wealthy has become a habit in Washington for a couple of decades, and may help explain why so many average Americans feel the federal government does not do much for them. Even President Bill Clinton adopted policy after policy that disproportionately benefited those who made the most money.

title: Ruling Leaves Some Relieved, Others Resigned
description: After a federal judge's decision yesterday against further postponing the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, bombing survivors and friends and relatives of victims seemed hardened in their views on whether Mr. McVeigh should be put to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, MARTHA T. (NEE FRIED)
description: LEVIN-Martha T. (nee Fried). 80. Of NYC and Jamaica Plain, MA. Graduate of Julia Richman HS and Hunter College. Very much loved by her children Andy, Peri and Susanna and her grandsons Ari, Tobin and Noah. Memorial service on Saturday, 10AM at the First Church of Jamaica Plain, MA

title: Joseph P. McMurray, 89, An Expert on Housing Policy
description: Joseph P. McMurray, an expert on national and New York housing policy who was chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and president of three colleges, died on May 21 at Long Beach Medical Center on Long Island. He was 89.

title: Curating Relics of T.W.A. As It Prepares for Departure
description: IF midcentury modern is your thing, you probably covet an Eames chair. If you're into Pop Art, you'll want a Warhol. For photography connoisseurs, it may be an Edward Weston. But I'm not interested in any of that stuff. I'm going for the airport look. Specifically, a T.W.A. departure lounge, circa 1962.

title: When Weekly Finds Scandal, Beijing Purges Top Editors
description: Chinese authorities have removed the top editors of the country's most probing major newspaper, Southern Weekend, in a crackdown on its semi-independent reporting.

title: Flight Demand Is Likely To Outpace F.A.A. Efforts
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that if its major programs to improve air traffic control stayed on schedule for the next 10 years, they would increase its capacity to handle commercial flights by 30 percent but that that demand would grow even faster in some areas, including New York and Chicago.

title: (Old) Poster, Poster, Come Grace My Wall
description: ONE of my nicest birthday presents ever was a bright red cow wearing earrings.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officers Face Punishment
description: Two police officers failed to respond properly to women who reported being molested in Central Park after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade last year, a Police Department administrative judge has found. The judge, Deputy Commissioner Robert Vinal, presided at a departmental trial last month and recommended that Officer Michael Bonenfant lose 30 vacation days and that Officer Victor Rodriguez-Rivera lose 15 days. Mr. Vinal said Officer Rodriguez-Rivera's penalty was mitigated by his aid to another woman molested during the disturbance. Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik will decide the final penalties. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Who's on First? Wonder No More
description: YOU didn't have to be Manager Joe Torre last Saturday to know that Roger Clemens, the New York Yankees' star pitcher, was sailing into rough waters.

title: Program to Provide a Head Start on College
description: The Board of Education is creating a joint program with Bard College that will allow select 11th graders to start college at a special institute in Brooklyn.

title: Article 2001060793789962059 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Jets Consider Field at Jail
description: The Jets, who hope to build a state-of-the-art stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, are considering practicing this summer at a slightly less posh locale: Rikers Island.

title: British Pound Touches 15-Year Low on Talk of Entry Into Euro Zone
description: The British pound fell to a 15-year low against the dollar today and also declined against the euro, amid speculation that Prime Minister Tony Blair might push Britain into the European Monetary Union after Thursday's general election.

title: The Pooch Has the Last Word, Wiseguys
description: A neighborhood guy, call him Ray as the playwright David Rabe does, picks up a woman in a bar and takes her home, where, in the middle of their making love, his dog leaps up on the bed and interferes. The next day, angry because Ray seems to like the dog more than he likes her, the woman tells her brother that Ray made her do things with the dog and asks him for vengeance.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Abe Silverstein, a NASA official, misstated the date of the brainstorming session in which he proposed the name Apollo for the program to place a man on the moon. It was in the early years of the moon program, announced by President John F. Kennedy in 1961, not in 1969.

title: For the Guests, Or Just as a Folly
description: YOUR in-laws are due to arrive for their annual summer visit. No need to clear out a room this year. Instead, you can put a yurt in your yard or add a shed to your spread. Or pitch a tent, a tepee, even an inflatable dome. These structures are also useful as pool houses, playhouses and garden sheds. Some can be taken home immediately and assembled in less than an hour; others are custom-made and will take longer both to arrive and to assemble. All can be dismantled at summer's end. Note that the prices do not include shipping.

title: The Los Angeles Vote
description: Bill Clinton always did feel at home in Los Angeles, so it is perhaps fitting that the ghost of presidential pardons past was a point of contention, if not a decisive factor, in that city's mayoral race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYLVESTER, CLARA (NEE CONDELES)
description: SYLVESTER-Clara (nee Condeles). On June 5, 2001. Survived by her beloved husband Al and devoted sister Yorka C. Linakis retired Justice New York State Supreme Court. Clara was a remarkable lady whose quiet elegance, dry wit and warm spirit will always be remembered. She was a devout member of St. Demetrios G.O. Church, Jamaica, N.Y. and Leadership 100 of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193rd. St. Visiting hours Thursday 2-5 & 7-10pm. Funeral service Friday St. Demetrios G.O. Church Jamaica at 11:30am. Contributions may be made to The St. Demetrios G.O. Church, Jamaica, N.Y. or St. Michaels Home for the Aged, Yonkers, New York.

title: WELLS FARGO EXPECTS A $1.3 BILLION CHARGE
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the California-based bank, said yesterday that it expected to take $1.13 billion in second-quarter charges, mostly because of investment losses in the technology and telecommunications industries. The charges will amount to 65 cents a share, the company said. About $1.05 billion of the charges, or 61 cents a share, result from loss write-downs of publicly traded and private equity securities that are in the bank's venture capital portfolio, according to the company. Wells Fargo said the charges included about $80 million in losses from its auto financing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, PATRICIA (ENGEL)
description: GALLAGHER-Patricia (Engel), 62, of 9 Union St. in Plainfield, MA on June 5th, 2001. Beloved wife of Attorney Robert Gallagher. Beloved mother of Liese Howarth, Martha Shields Gallagher and Paula Gallagher Abeles. Beloved daughter of Hildegarde Engel. Beloved sister of Barbara Alkiewicz, Geraldine Kaupp and Jacqueline Payer. Funeral from Pease Funeral Home, 425 Prospect St., Northampton, Saturday, 9:30 AM, with a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's Church in Haydenville at 11 AM. Burial will be at Hilltop Cemetery, Plainfield. Calling hours are Friday, 2-4 and 7-9. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the VNA and Hospice Alliance, 168 Industrial Dr., Northampton, MA 01060.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Legislature Backs Lottery
description: The State House and Senate approved a bill that would begin a state lottery, possibly as early as November, and Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, said he would sign it. The bill establishes the lottery that voters approved in November, but lawmakers were unable to agree on how the proceeds would be spent on scholarships and schools. That decision may not be made until next year's session. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Metro Matters: Bloomberg Tries Walking the Fine Line
description: MICHAEL BLOOMBERG did well for himself yesterday, in his first foray as a real (as opposed to videotaped) candidate.

title: Any Fan's a Manager With Baseball Facts Online
description: YOU didn't have to be Manager Joe Torre last Saturday to know that Roger Clemens, the New York Yankees' star pitcher, was sailing into rough waters.

title: Willing but Wary, Irish Vote on Wider Europe
description: On the surface, a referendum in Ireland on Thursday is asking voters a basic question: should the European Union be expanded to include poorer Eastern European countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, JERRY
description: SILVER-Jerry. The Center for Preventive Psychiatry records with sorrow the death of Trustee Barbara Tavrow's father. Our deepest sympathy is extended to Barbara and her family. Timmy Weinberg, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: U.S. Warning To Businesses On Tax Protest
description: The Internal Revenue Service, faced with a small but rapidly growing tax rebellion, put small- business owners on notice today that if they refused to withhold taxes from workers' paychecks they might be prosecuted.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the comedian Imogene Coca on Sunday referred incorrectly to a Broadway production of ''On the 20th Century'' in which she appeared. It was the original one, which opened in 1978, not a 1979 revival.

title: Queens Boy, 14, Dies In Elevator Shaft Fall
description: A 14-year-old boy plunged to his death in an elevator shaft last night in the Lefrak City apartment complex in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Distributor Cuts Jobs
description: Ingram Micro Inc., the nation's largest computer distributor, said it would eliminate 1,000 jobs to try to save $30 million to $40 million annually. The company, based in Santa Ana, Calif., said the measures were a response to slowing demand. Ingram will close its distribution center in Newark, Calif., and its returns processing centers in two other California cities, Santa Ana and Rancho Cucamonga, while downsizing a distribution center in Miami. The company will consolidate product management and restructure its American sales operation, requiring a related charge of up to $15 million this quarter. Kevin Murai, president of Ingram Micro U.S., called the job cuts ''difficult but necessary.'' Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Bristol Is Said to Be Near Deal To Acquire DuPont Drug Unit
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company is close to buying the drug business of DuPont in a $7.5 billion deal that would give Bristol-Myers a larger inventory of AIDS drugs, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Growth Seen In Online Collaboration
description: The slowing economy is helping to accelerate the adoption of so-called collaborative commerce across a wide spectrum of industries, a study by Deloitte Consulting shows. A majority of the respondents to a Deloitte survey said current economic circumstances had made online initiatives more important to their companies and that they expected online commerce to have a significant impact by early 2002. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Corruption Fighter Quits Government
description: In a blow to Turkey's efforts to reduce government corruption and improve its image, Interior Minister Saadettin Tantan resigned from the cabinet and the Motherland Party rather than accept a lower-ranking position. Mr. Tantan, widely viewed as the leader of Turkey's anti-corruption drive, has accused elements of the party of trying to slow his investigations. Motherland is a junior member of the governing three-party coalition, which is trying to meet international demands for cleaner government in exchange for $16 billion in new loans for the troubled economy. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Article 2001060790499959500 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: With Attention Money Can Buy, Bloomberg Kicks Off Campaign
description: The billionaire Michael R. Bloomberg began his campaign for mayor of New York City yesterday in a Hillary Clintonesque explosion of media that left his envious Democratic competitors in his wake. From a gospel breakfast with the Harlem establishment to a walking tour of Arthur Avenue in the Bronx to a ride across New York Harbor on the Staten Island ferry, Mr. Bloomberg was trailed by a horde of reporters as he gingerly made his way through the first day of his political life.

title: Putting You At the PC, Remotely
description: YOU can't call yourself a modern mobile professional until you've survived three rites of passage. First, there's boarding the flight on which you hoped to complete an important memo, and realizing that your laptop was ''recharging'' all night from a dead outlet. Second, there's spilling coffee into your keyboard in flight; extra credit if you're caught without a napkin and the seat-belt sign is illuminated. Finally, there's winding up in some remote and inconvenient city and discovering that you need to consult a crucial file that's nonchalantly resting on your hard drive back home.

title: Coalition Builder Wins Los Angeles Mayoral Race
description: Riding the solid support of older black and white voters, City Attorney James K. Hahn emerged today as this city's mayor and quickly promised to form a government that reflected not only his coalition but also Latinos, who turned out in record numbers and had hoped to make his opponent, Antonio Villaraigosa, the city's first Hispanic mayor in more than a century.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT CHALLENGES THE PURCHASE OF DTM
description: The Justice Department filed suit yesterday to stop the 3D Systems Corporation, a maker of three-dimensional imaging systems, from acquiring a rival, the DTM Corporation. Antitrust enforcers said the $45 million purchase would lead to higher prices and reduced innovation for rapid prototyping systems, which are used to convert computer images into such three-dimensional objects as wireless phones and medical equipment. The department said the acquisition would reduce the number of competitors in the industry from three to two and give the combined company 80 percent of the market. A spokesman for 3D Systems, which is based in Valencia, Calif., had no immediate comment. A spokesman for DTM, which is based in Austin, Tex., was not available.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: No Jail For Whitewater Figure
description: David Hale, whose accusations about former President Bill Clinton helped begin the Whitewater investigation, will be spared a jail sentence on unrelated state charges. Disregarding protests by an Arkansas prosecutor, Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, has announced that he would commute Mr. Hale's 21-day jail term for deceiving state insurance regulators. Mr. Hale, at left, a businessman who accused Mr. Clinton of accepting an illegal loan, served 21 months in a federal prison for fraud under a plea agreement with Whitewater prosecutors, who said they could not prove his accusations against Mr. Clinton.

title: Slavery, Justice and Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Autos
description: Nissan Motor said it planned to increase production in North America by 70 percent in the next three years to respond faster to market demand. Nissan, which is 37 percent owned by Renault of France, plans to produce a total of 1.15 million vehicles in North America by March 2004, up from the 680,000 units it made in the year to March 2001, a Nissan spokesman, Gerry Spahn, said. Nissan is setting up a plant in Canton, Miss., to build small pickup trucks starting in 2003. Production will also be raised by a third at its Mexico and Tennessee plants.

title: Remote Keyless Entry: Staying a Step Ahead of Car Thieves
description: WHEN the car door lock was first introduced -- not long after the first car was stolen, no doubt -- it was the best technology available for the job.

title: Witness to Nepal Massacre Offers Account of Shootings
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, June 7  A survivor of Nepal's palace massacre today gave the first direct eyewitness account of the royal blood bath, describing how Crown Prince Dipendra, falling down drunk, nevertheless managed to navigate his way around a dining hall, shooting family members as he tottered.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Ships Faster Chips
description: Advanced Micro Devices, Intel's top rival in the market for personal computer processors, began selling faster models of its chips. The new versions of Advanced Micro's flagship Athlon chip run at 1.4 gigahertz, while its Durons, for less expensive home PC's, hit 950 megahertz, John Crank, its marketing manager, said. Compaq Computer and Gateway will use the Athlon chips in systems available immediately, he said.

title: Article 2001060790806694890 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Testing Links Potato Famine To an Origin In the Andes
description: A delicate piece of detective work in the collections of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew has started to cast light on the origins of the blight that caused the Irish potato famines a century and a half ago.

title: Torricelli's Lawyer Asks For a Special Counsel
description: A lawyer for Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey asked the Justice Department yesterday to appoint a special counsel to take over a federal investigation into Mr. Torricelli's activities as a guarantee against political bias in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, LOUISE ARNSTEIN
description: FREEDMAN-Louise Arnstein, Artist, 86, of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, June 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Freedman, American Painter. Devoted mother of Joel and Alan. Loving grandmother of Daniel and Katherine. Dear sister of Katherine May, Denver. Services Fri. 11:30AM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: Web Links Married Priests To Flock Adrift From Church
description: When Stephanie Krill became engaged last year, she knew exactly what kind of wedding she wanted: a traditional ceremony under a gazebo surrounded by blossoms, blessed by a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: 'Living Wage' Bill
description: In a 17-to-1 vote, the Suffolk County Legislature has approved what is known as living-wage legislation. The Legislature passed a bill Tuesday to raise the wages of workers employed by companies that have county contracts and other aid to a minimum of $9 an hour plus health benefits or $10.25 an hour without benefits. Suffolk would be the first county in the state to enact such a bill. Proponents said they could override a veto by County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, who has expressed concerns about the bill. Al Baker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rates Held Steady
description: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted to hold the benchmark interest rate at 5.25 percent, as the threat from an economic slowdown imported from the United States subsides. Recent data show that British consumers are spending more, house prices are rising and tourism is recovering from the country's worst outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that placed many rural areas off limits. To fight the threat of an economic slowdown, the central bank had reduced rates three times in the last four months, taking the key interest rate to its lowest level in seven months. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Armies of Europe Failing to Meet Goals, Sapping NATO
description: Two years after NATO vowed to improve its military forces, the organization is falling well short of its goals, leaving a yawning gap between the United States and its European allies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 9 about Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's comments in Jerusalem on Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza paraphrased erroneously from a remark he made in disputing the notion of Israelis as occupiers. He said that Egypt had occupied Gaza, and that Iraq and then Jordan had occupied the West Bank. He did not say Egypt had occupied Gaza and Iraq.

title: Rosemary Verey, 82, Dies; Grew Legendary Gardens in England and Tutored America
description: Rosemary Verey, the tough, artistic English gardener who brought the art of clipped boxwoods, laburnum walks and ornamental vegetable gardening to America, died in Chelsea Memorial Hospital in London on May 31. She was 82.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Price Wars 'Brutal,' Compaq Chief Says
description: Michael Capellas, chief executive of Compaq Computer, said competition in the computer industry had become fiercer in recent months, mainly because of price-cutting by Compaq rivals like Dell Computer and Gateway. Mr. Capellas said ''unbelievably brutal price competition'' had resulted from a drop in United States consumer confidence and reduced spending by telecommunications companies and manufacturers. ''Is it any worse than it was a few months ago?'' Mr. Capellas said. ''It probably is. The market is very, very tough.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Terror Jury Ends First Day
description: The jurors deciding whether to impose the death penalty on the Saudi man convicted last week of murder in the bombing of an American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, were sent home yesterday after their first full day of deliberation. In a note to the judge, Leonard B. Sand, the jurors requested a copy of the Koran, but the judge declined. The jury must decide the fate of Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: State Steps In to Ensure A Modernist Landmark's Future
description: Illinois is about to become the first state to own a midcentury Modernist house. Gov. George Ryan O.K.'d the purchase of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's 1951 Farnsworth House in Plano, and last week the state historical preservation agency received $6.2 million to buy the property. In modern American domestic architecture, the Farnsworth House is on a par with Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater and the Gropius House by Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer. The seller is the British Lord Peter Palumbo, who worried that a private owner would not preserve the integrity of the building and its 61 wooded acres. ''It is an absolute jewel,'' said John Bryan, founder of Friends of the Farnsworth House (www.farnsworthhousefriends.org) and chairman of Sara Lee and the board of the Art Institute of Chicago. ''We are delighted that it's in Illinois, where architecture has always been so terribly important.''

title: Attorney General Says Report Shows No Racial and Ethnic Bias in Federal Death Sentences
description: Declaring that he had ''no higher priority than protecting the civil rights of all Americans,'' Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that a Justice Department study had uncovered no intentional racial or ethnic bias in how capital punishment was administered in federal cases.

title: STUDY FINDS HEART REGENERATES CELLS
description: Medical dogma holds that damage to the heart is irreversible and that the body cannot grow new cells to replace those that die from a heart attack or other heart ailment.

title: Paper-Friendly Printer Does Not Leak Red Ink
description: Samsung Electronics made quite a few waves in the printer world last year with the introduction of a robust laser printer for $199. Now the company has improved the technology -- and kept the price the same. The new Samsung ML-1210 laser printer, still $199, can crank out 12 pages per minute and has a U.S.B. port in addition to a parallel port.

title: Essay; The McCain Middle
description: ''McCain Is Considering Leaving G.O.P.'' was a four-column headline atop the front page of The Washington Post a few days ago that sent an aftershock through Republicans already jolted by the Jeffords jump.

title: The Views Aren't for Sale, but the Furnishings Are
description: STEVEN GAMBREL and Michael Bruno wanted to open an antiques shop that would take advantage of their combined aesthetic flair. Hence, Summerstock, a stylish seasonal store in Sagaponack, N.Y., that is filled with vintage and antique home furnishings. It is set to open June 16 and closes Labor Day.

title: ARTESYN SHARES FALL AFTER IT PREDICTS A LOSS
description: Shares in Artesyn Technologies Inc. fell 13 percent after the company, which makes power-conversion products for telecommunications equipment, forecast an unexpected loss for the second quarter and said it would lay off about 600 workers. Shares of Artesyn fell $2.05, to $13.31. The company, based in Boca Raton, Fla., expects to lose 15 cents to 20 cents a share, excluding charges. It was expected to earn 3 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Artesyn will eliminate about 12 percent to 15 percent of its work force, or 600 jobs, to reduce costs, a spokesman, Richard Leland, said.

title: Chip Maker Lines Up Deal
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation agreed to buy Wireless Solutions Sweden from Allgon A.B. for about $23.5 million in cash. National Semicondictor, a maker of chips for cellular phones and personal computers, will take on an unspecified amount of the debt of Wireless Solutions.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for ''Ellington Uproar: Where Uptown Meets Downtown,'' a concert at St. Peter's Church on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, misstated the date. It is this Sunday at 8 p.m.; it was not last Sunday. Information: (212) 935-2200.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: No New Home For Hornets
description: Voters rejected a proposal that would have given the Charlotte Hornets professional basketball team a new $205 million arena subsidized by local taxes. The vote, 57 percent to 43 percent, makes it likely that the team will move after next season. The Hornets say the team is losing about $1 million a month because the current arena lacks luxury seating. Opponents of the proposal argued that the coliseum was less than 15 years old and that the city had more important priorities than replacing it. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Web Rings Connect Like-Minded Surfers
description: Q. What is a Web ring?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Philip Morris Ordered to Pay $3 Billion in Smoking Case

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Hudson River lighthouses misstated the year of a major dredging of the harbor in Saugerties, N.Y. It was done in 1927, not 1828.

title: In Paris, Clinton Puts the Whammy on Agassi
description: Of all the spectators filing into Center Court today, Bill Clinton's arrival had the strangest effect on Andre Agassi's mood ring. More than Sbastien Grosjean's shirt-flapping speed, Clinton's movements were linked to the bizarre end of Agassi's Grand Slam buzz.

title: DiFrancesco Proposes New Arena Plan for Newark
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and the owner of the New Jersey Devils and Nets announced a tentative agreement today for a $355 million arena to be built in downtown Newark and paid for largely with sales taxes collected in the area surrounding it.

title: At the Minute of Greatest Moment, All Eyes Are on the Man Who Isn't There
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, just sworn in as president pro tem, was in the chair presiding over the Senate. Senator Tom Daschle was offering procedural resolutions in his new role as majority leader. Most of the prominent senators were in their seats, including Edward M. Kennedy and Joseph I. Lieberman for the Democrats and Jesse Helms and Trent Lott for the Republicans.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Capriati Reaches French Final
description: PARIS, June 7  Jennifer Capriati had just left pockmarks in Martina Hingis's confidence, reducing Hingis, the savvy No. 1 player, to a state of confusion today during the semifinals of the French Open.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a pro-Israel rally in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the organizers. The rally was organized by a committee of six rabbis, with the assistance of a number of Jewish organizations, including UJA-Federation of New York and other chapters in the region. The federation chapters were not the main organizers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, ALICE
description: ROSENBAUM-Alice. On June 5, 2001. Loving wife of 52 years to deceased husband Ira. Beloved mother of Carol Davids and Ellen Langer. Devoted sister of Gertrude Lang and sister-in-law, Beatrice Rosenbaum. Services will be private.

title: NEWS WATCH; Luke.com if It's a Boy, Mary.com if It's a Girl
description: In Silicon Valley, even the stork has gone high-tech. Starting June 1, parents with newborns at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif., will get free Web domain names and e-mail addresses for their babies.

title: A Palestinian Battles Silence, Temporal and Moral
description: MORTALITY haunts Edward W. Said. It haunts him from the dusty streets in Gaza where Palestinians die in clashes with Israeli soldiers. It haunts him from the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, where he periodically struggles to stave off leukemia. It haunts him with the loss of his close friends, the Palestinian leaders Faisal Husseini and Ibrahim Abu-Lughod, over the past few days. And at night it haunts him when, plagued by insomnia, he fends off death's counterfeit, a brief loss of consciousness that hints of the final silence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIGIOVANNI, CONSTANCE
description: DiGIOVANNI-Constance. June 7, 1960-December 3, 1994. Happy Birthday in Heaven to my beautiful little sister, my forever friend.

title: Fulfilling Campaign Promise, Bush Signs Tax Cut Into Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Bush fulfilled a major promise of his campaign for president today, signing into law the most sweeping tax cut in two decades, which he called "the first major achievement of a new era."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPKIN, MARTIN LEWIS, MD.
description: LAPKIN-Martin Lewis, MD. Suddenly on June 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Emily. Of Palm Springs, CA, formerly of NYC. Services will be held from Palm Springs Mortuary on Tuesday, June 12 at 11:00 AM. 760-321-0994. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Epilepsy Foundation, 4351 Garden City Drive, Landover, MD 20785-7223.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Waiting for Bloom

title: Article 2001060794283164098 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Todd Gallentine was named vice president and group creative director on accounts including Marshalls and Quick & Reilly at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He succeeds Ron Wilcox, who left to become senior vice president and creative director, currently on the Citizens Bank account, at Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising. Mr. Gallentine had most recently been freelancing in New York.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AUSTRALIA

title: Exposing the Web's Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer School List May Include Many Students From Last Year
description: Half of the roughly 320,000 New York City public school students who received letters in the winter saying they were performing so poorly that they might have to go to summer school were also urged to go to summer school last year, the Board of Education said yesterday.

title: An Appraisal; New War Memorial Is Shrine to Sentiment
description: Three works of architecture in postwar Washington have challenged the status quo: I. M. Pei's East Wing of the National Gallery, Maya Lin's Vietnam Veterans Memorial and James Ingo Freed's United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. They owe their distinction to the skill with which they honor the Enlightenment concept of clear geometric form while rejecting the ornamental particularities of neo-Classical style.

title: Travel-Management Deal Said to Be Near
description: Navigant International Inc., a fast-growing supplier of corporate travel-management services, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire SatoTravel, for $45 million in cash and stock.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Embattled Road Projects Approved
description: A federal judge approved $400 million worth of road projects for the Atlanta area, ruling against environmentalists who had blocked construction since 1998, concerned about air pollution. The environmental groups wanted stricter deadlines for reducing smog-causing ozone, but Gov. Roy Barnes, a Democrat, testified that the building plan addressed pollution while preventing the chaos that would be caused if the roads were not built. Environmentalists said they would probably appeal. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLICKMAN, MORRIS
description: FOLICKMAN-Morris. On June 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Pearl. Devoted father of Rena Goldstein and Lisa Neal, and father-in-law of David Goldstein. Dear brother of Abe and Sylvia Untracht. Loving grandfather of Brett and the late Scott Goldstein; Jillian, Jennifer and Jason Neal. Service Friday, 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Tower Sets Tough Terms For Small Classical Labels
description: Tower Records, the giant chain store, is negotiating with the three largest independent distributors of classical music over the sales of specialized recordings as the music industry re-examines how to market some of its less popular releases.

title: In Mideast, Don't Equate Terror and Response
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Economic Growth
description: The Australian economy grew at a stronger-than-expected 1.1 percent pace in the first quarter. The growth in gross domestic product swung from the previous quarter's contraction, the first time the economy had shrunk in 10 years. Consumer and government spending on goods and services drove the growth, economists said. Other recent data show retail sales are rebounding, exports are rising, the housing sector is gaining strength and business inventories are being pared. That suggests the economy should pick up later this year. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Circuit City Says It Expects Results to Improve
description: Circuit City Stores Inc. said today that it expected to report better-than-expected results for its fiscal first quarter and that it planned to cut its stake in CarMax Group by 10 percent to help pay for the remodeling of its electronics stores.

title: The Mites and the Bees
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Mayor Of Jackson Is Re-Elected
description: Voters in Jackson overwhelmingly re-elected Mayor Harvey Johnson Jr., left. Unofficial returns showed that Mr. Johnson, a Democrat, defeated C. Daryl Neely, a Republican, 61 percent to 39 percent. The race was the first in which two African-Americans had faced off in a general election in the state capital. In another contest, Johnny Dupree, a Democrat, became the first African-American mayor of Hattiesburg. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: In Mideast, Don't Equate Terror and Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Birthparents
description: To the Editor:

title: New Senate Leader Urges 'Principled Compromise' As Democrats Take Over
description: Democrats took full control of the Senate today and the new majority leader, Tom Daschle, called for ''principled compromise'' to avoid gridlock in a capital where Republicans no longer hold all the levers of power. He described political polarization as ''an indulgence'' that the Senate could not afford.

title: Market Place; First Union's Bid for Wachovia Gains Momentum
description: The battle for the Wachovia Corporation seems to have tilted toward the First Union Corporation as the value of a hostile offer by SunTrust Banks has continued to decline. Given that no large hostile bank deal has succeeded in five years, some analysts and investors said yesterday that SunTrust would have a hard time reversing the momentum before Wachovia's annual meeting on Aug. 3.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the boxer Joey Maxim on Tuesday misspelled the name of his birthplace and misstated its location. It was Collinwood, not Collingwood -- a neighborhood in the city of Cleveland, not a suburb. A picture caption about Maxim's 1952 fight against Sugar Ray Robinson misstated the reason for Robinson's fall to the canvas. He had swung at Maxim and missed; Maxim had not knocked him down.

title: You're Special
description: To paraphrase a remark often used to describe certain country-music aficionados, American Airlines was customer relationship marketing before customer relationship marketing was cool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAULIN, HENRIETTE (NEE TONN)
description: PAULIN-Henriette (nee Tonn). 1908 in Detroit, MI, died May 29,2001, Lenox Hill Hospital. Widow of Boris Paulin, died 1979. Survived by daughter, Dr. Borisse Paulin, NYC; two brothers Helder and Marc Tonn of Miles City, MT; niece Elizabeth Lee Tonn Sylvis of Bozeman, MT; nephews William, Marc, Lance and Bruce Tonn; cousins Leopolda Tonn Matziol and Eleanor Klenner Buschke; two god-daughters Louise Hansen Laverde and Sri Panda, one godson Bernard Friese. Memorial service at a future date at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 122 East 88th Street, New York 10128. Please contact Ms. Rombey, 212-289-8128. Memorials to: Immanuel Lutheran Church or a child-oriented charity of your choice.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: First-Time Authors

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Toy Store Turnaround
description: The British toy store Hamleys reported a turnaround, helped by a new line of custom-made teddy bears and the refurbishment of its flagship store in London. Last year, the company put itself up for sale but said in February it had rejected offers because they were too low. The company reported net income of $4 million for the year to March 31, in contrast to a loss of about $300,000 one year earlier. Its shares were up 7 percent. Hamleys said it would convert its discount Toystack chain to Bear Factory outlets, where customers can have a bear or soft toy made as they wait for about $30. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: PANEL TELLS BUSH GLOBAL WARMING IS GETTING WORSE
description: A panel of top American scientists declared today that global warming was a real problem and was getting worse, a conclusion that may lead President Bush to change his stand on the issue as he heads next week to Europe, where the United States is seen as a major source of the air pollution held responsible for climate change.

title: What's Next: Dashboard Miser Teaches Drivers How to Save Fuel
description: DUTCH and Swedish researchers may have an antidote for rising gasoline prices. They have developed a computer-driven dashboard display that advises drivers throughout a trip on ways to reduce fuel use.

title: F.D.A. Warns Food Companies About Herbal Additives
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned companies putting herbal additives in food yesterday that their products could be illegal because the ''novel ingredients'' might not be generally recognized as safe.

title: Judge Asked For Ruling On Copyright
description: In a lawsuit that seeks to test the free speech limits of a 1998 copyright law, a group of computer scientists asked a federal court yesterday for permission to explain how it cracked the music industry's antipiracy technology for compact discs.

title: A Man for the Season: Dressing Up Summer
description: STEVEN ROBERT GAMBREL, an architect and interior designer, was driving on back roads in the Hamptons several weeks ago without his seat belt on, as though nothing bad could happen.

title: The Other New York Marathon
description: The entries for Saturday's 133rd running of the Belmont Stakes, the longest leg in the Triple Crown. The horses are listed in the predicted order of finish by Joe Drape, who handicapped the field and wrote the comments. The odds are the morning line set by Don LaPlace, Belmont's linemaker.

title: New Senate Leader Urges 'Principled Compromise' as Democrats Take Over
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Democrats took full control of the Senate today and the new majority leader, Tom Daschle, called for "principled compromise" to avoid gridlock in a capital where Republicans no longer hold all the levers of power. He described political polarization as "an indulgence" that the Senate could not afford.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Jumps From Bridge
description: A man driving over the Queensboro Bridge with his wife about 7:50 last night stopped the car, fought free of her attempts to restrain him and leaped into the East River, the police said. Police harbor units pulled the man alive from the water around 75th Street. He was taken to New York Weill Cornell Center but was not seriously injured, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was driving to Manhattan when he stopped the car. He was being held for psychiatric evaluation.

title: Berlin Journal; Spendthrift City Turns Its Icon Into a Billboard
description: Any one doubting that Germany's bustling capital has money problems need only visit the Brandenburg Gate, the august archway where President Reagan once chastised the Soviet Union and denounced the Berlin Wall.

title: Luke.com if It's a Boy, Mary.com if It's a Girl
description: In Silicon Valley, even the stork has gone high-tech. Starting June 1, parents with newborns at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif., will get free Web domain names and e- mail addresses for their babies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, FANNIE
description: COLLINS-Fannie, 101, of Jensen Beach, FL, died Friday, June 1, 2001, at Martin Memorial Medical Center, Stuart, FL. Born in Washington, D.C. she had been a resident of Jensen Beach since 1974. Prior to retirement she was a Fashion Artist for Women's Daily Wear in New York City. For more information contact Young & Prill Funeral Home, Stuart, FL.

title: M.L.S. Hits Zambrano With Fine and Suspension
description: MetroStars Coach Octavio Zambrano expected to be fined for criticizing the league and its referees, but Major League Soccer caught him by surprise yesterday. Not only was Zambrano fined $2,000, but he was also suspended for the MetroStars' next game, at Washington on Wednesday night.

title: Widespread Delays After Crash Near George Washington Bridge
description: A tractor-trailer overturned in Manhattan yesterday near the George Washington Bridge, spilling cases of Bolivian beer and tying up traffic from Connecticut to Maryland, officials said.

title: Slavery, Justice and Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: Hejduk and His Linemates Are Feeling Devils' Pressure
description: When the Stanley Cup finals began on May 26, Milan Hejduk was the leading scorer in the playoffs with 7 goals and 13 assists in 16 games. Five games later, Hejduk, the Colorado Avalanche's first-line right wing, still has seven goals and is tied for second in playoff scoring with Patrik Elias, a point behind Joe Sakic.

title: Article 2001060790260564484 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: U.S. WILL RESTART WIDE NEGOTIATIONS WITH NORTH KOREA
description: President Bush announced today that the United States would restart negotiations with North Korea on a broad range of issues, including that nation's production and exporting of missiles and its deploying of soldiers on the South Korean border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOHN H., M.D.
description: McGOVERN-John H., M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. John H. McGovern, who was a valued member of our Department of Urology for nearly half a century. Highly regarded by his peers throughout the U.S. and the world, Dr. McGovern served as president of the Society of Pediatric Urology (198081), the American Association of Clinical Urologists (1988-89), and the American Urological Association (1989-90). A graduate of Columbia University and Downstate Medical College, Dr. McGovern joined The New York HospitalCornell Medical Center in 1957 as a resident in urology and was clinical professor of urology when he retired in 1999. We extend our condolences to his wife and family.

title: Judge Refuses McVeigh's Bid For a Reprieve
description: The federal judge who presided over Timothy J. McVeigh's Oklahoma City bombing trial today rejected a plea by his lawyers to postpone his execution, even though the judge said he was shocked to learn recently about the F.B.I.'s belated discovery of evidence in the case.

title: With Attention Money Can Buy, Bloomberg Kicks Off Campaign
description: The billionaire Michael R. Bloomberg began his campaign for mayor of New York City yesterday in a Hillary Clintonesque explosion of media that left his envious Democratic competitors in his wake. From a gospel breakfast with the Harlem establishment to a walking tour of Arthur Avenue in the Bronx to a ride across New York Harbor on the Staten Island ferry, Mr. Bloomberg was trailed by a horde of reporters as he gingerly made his way through the first day of his political life.

title: In Mideast, Don't Equate Terror and Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Cisco Thinks Smaller
description: Cisco Systems, a manufacturer of computer networking equipment, is backing away from plans to take a major block of space in the proposed 37-story, 1.3-million-square-foot tower over the north wing of the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., had initially talked about having a major presence in the tower, about 500,000 square feet. That would have enabled the developers, the Lawrence Ruben Company and Vornado Realty Trust, to start construction on the project. But Cisco has been battered by a slowing economy and a drop in its stock price. ''We have decided not to seek additional space in New York City right now,'' said Steve Landon, a spokesman for Cisco. ''We are staying in New York and expect to grow there over time. We'll continue conversations about new locations.'' The company currently has about 100,000 square feet at 1 Penn Plaza, a building owned by Vornado.

title: Condemned Killer Goes on Trial for Another Convict's Death
description: The trial of one notorious murderer who stomped another condemned killer to death opened here today, with a promise of a look inside the closed society of New Jersey's death row.

title: Limit for Radioactive Leaks Is Set for Nuclear Waste Site
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had set a standard on how much radioactive waste could be allowed to leak from from a proposed repository at Yucca Mountain, Nev., opening the way for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to decide whether the site, about 100 miles north of Las Vegas, is suitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDER, EDWARD
description: SEIDER-Edward. Congregation Ezrath Israel, The Actors' Temple, mourns the passing of our esteemed Trustee, former recording secretary of many years, dear friend and long time member of over 55 years. We express our sympathy to his devoted Mattie, and to his family. He will be deeply missed. Robert Goldman, President Shelly Rothman, Vice President Noach Valley, Rabbi

title: Jersey City's Mayor-Elect Seeks Wider Prosperity
description: Over the last 20 years, developers have transformed Jersey City's waterfront on the Hudson River from a gritty industrial neighborhood to a bustling downtown of gleaming office towers and apartment buildings. Property-tax abatements and other economic incentives have lured the builders and their billions in investment over the two decades.

title: In America; Turn Despair to Hope
description: No one knows the extent of the AIDS epidemic in China. But the Times's Elisabeth Rosenthal, in a chilling report from the village of Donghu in Henan Province, noted that some Chinese doctors believed that hundreds of thousands of people in that one province had contracted the AIDS virus in a catastrophically unsanitary blood-selling scheme.

title: New Senate Chief Can Look to Past in Charting Course
description: Though the Senate has never before changed hands in the middle of a session, Tom Daschle, the new majority leader, confronts problems and opportunities similar to those that faced Bob Dole, Robert C. Byrd, Howard H. Baker Jr. and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect Denies Guilt
description: The New Mexico woman who, along with her husband, is accused of kidnapping an infant from New York more than two decades ago and raising him as her son pleaded not guilty yesterday during an arraignment in State Supreme Court. The woman, Judith Smiley, surrendered yesterday to the Queens district attorney. Justice Joseph A. Grosso freed her on $25,000 bail. Her husband, Barry, pleaded not guilty in March to the same charges.

title: Connecticut Legislature Adjourns After Failing to Approve Budget
description: The Connecticut General Assembly adjourned late tonight after failing to reach an agreement on next year's state budget.

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans New Cuts in Costs
description: Hewlett-Packard, contending that falling demand has spread to Asia and Latin America, said yesterday that it planned to further cut costs to increase the probability it can meet the earnings forecasts of analysts.

title: Student Writers Try to Duck the Censors by Going Online
description: THE election at Centralia High School looked as if it would go off without a hitch, until possible irregularities with the campaign turned up on CNN.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</b

title: Franks Emphasizes Change
description: A 30-second television commercial, ''Change,'' is the first released by former Representative Bob Franks in his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey against Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City.

title: AT&T Quits Microsoft Venture
description: Suggesting that sophisticated interactive television will remain a distant dream in the United States, AT&T's broadband division has dropped its commitment to an advanced set-top cable box that was supposed to showcase Microsoft's interactive television software.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Spraying Measure Advances
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has passed a bill to give homeowners the right to keep the county from spraying antimosquito pesticides on or near their property. County Executive Robert J. Gaffney is expected to sign the measure, making Suffolk the first government in the state to make such spraying optional. The bill, which was approved on Tuesday, allows for the creation of a ''no spray'' list to keep trucks from spraying within 150 feet of a property. Al Baker (NYT)

title: In Web Storage World, No Space at Myspace
description: ON Sunday at 8 p.m., Myspace .com disappeared. Typing in its Web address yields only an error message.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, FRANCES
description: WEINBERG-Frances. The New York Women's Bar Association extends its sincere condolences to our esteemed member, Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin on the passing of her mother. Phyllis S. Koffman, President

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 9 about Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's comments in Jerusalem on Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza paraphrased erroneously from a remark he made in disputing the notion of Israelis as occupiers. He said that Egypt had occupied Gaza, and that Iraq and then Jordan had occupied the West Bank. He did not say Egypt had occupied Gaza and Iraq.

title: U.S. Sees Some Progress With Chinese on Trade
description: The United States and China have narrowed their differences over farm subsidies, the thorniest issue holding up Chinese entry into the World Trade Organization. But many more questions must be resolved if China is to enter the global forum this year, the chief American trade official said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rightist Chief In Colombia Shifts Focus To Politics
description: Carlos Castao, commander of a right-wing paramilitary army that has terrorized villagers in Colombia for years, has resigned to oversee the group's political wing, the organization announced yesterday on its Web site.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Retrieving U.S. Plane
description: American aviation experts landed on Hainan island to begin preparations for dismantling a Navy surveillance plane after negotiators finalized details for allowing the aircraft to be hauled from Chinese territory in pieces aboard a giant cargo plane, officials said. The Bush administration had wanted the Navy EP-3E to be repaired and flown off Hainan, where it made an emergency landing after a collision with a Chinese fighter on April 1, but China insisted that the aircraft be taken apart and carried away.

title: Massacre Blasts Open Cracks at Nepal's Secretive Palace
description: This much is agreed.

title: Critic's Notebook; For Gifford, Light Was a Spiritual Subtext
description: Like other second-generation Hudson River School painters, Sanford Robinson Gifford was an admirer of Thomas Cole, the school's founder, and in Gifford's art, as in Cole's, man's triumph over nature always comes at some cost. In views of Hunter Mountain, for instance, tree stumps in the foreground are a double-edged symbol representing accelerating civilization and the loss of unspoiled landscape.

title: Addenda: Longtime Agency for Hanes Bows Out
description: Mullen/LHC in Winston-Salem, N.C., has ended its relationship with the Hanes apparel and hosiery brands after almost 20 years by declining to take part in a review for the brands' account that began a month ago. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Nuclear-Waste Plan Approved
description: The lower house of Parliament approved Kremlin-supported legislation that would allow the government to accept up to 1,000 tons of spent nuclear fuel per year from other nations, the core of a proposal by the Atomic Energy Ministry to earn up to $21 billion in the next decade by storing other nations' radioactive waste. The bill now goes to the upper chamber, which is expected to follow suit. The environmental group Greenpeace urged the United States to ban shipments to Russia of nuclear fuel that originated in the United States, saying that alone would vastly reduce imports under what it called a dangerous scheme. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, DUANE, M.D.
description: TODD-Duane, M.D., June first, beloved husband of Dorothy Jane Keith. Father of George Damon Todd and Alison Keith Todd Cokorinos. Grandfather of Emily and Katherine Cokorinos. Brother of Donald Todd. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT, or Sloane Hospital for Women, Att. Dr. Roger Lobo, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 622 West 168th St., NYC 10033.

title: PRICELINE SHARES INCREASE ON WORD OF NEW INVESTMENT
description: Shares in Priceline.com Inc., an online travel agency, rose 30 percent yesterday after companies controlled by Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing, said they would increase their stake in the company. Priceline.com shares rose $1.61, to $7.06. Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd., Li's biggest companies, will buy 25 million shares for $4.40 each from Priceline.com's founder, Jay Walker, and a trust. The two companies bought 35.1 million shares at $2.10 in February. They will be the biggest shareholders in Priceline.com, owning about 30 percent of the company. Customers of Priceline.com name the price they want to pay for airline tickets, hotel rooms and car rentals, and the company tries to fulfill the requests. Mr. Li, who became a billionaire by investing in low-priced assets, also has a joint venture with Priceline.com to run Web sites in Asia.

title: U.S. Firms May Bid for Irish Phone Company
description: Two American private equity firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Blackstone Communications Partners, indicated today that they would join the bidding for Eircom, Ireland's largest phone company.

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Help for Poor Nations

title: Telemaco and Phillies Stop Rusch and the Mets
description: The Mets might not be out of contention, but their poor start has given them no room for a letdown during the season's last four months. Every loss can rightfully be viewed as crushing, and every victory is only a small step forward. It is not an easy way to play.

title: For Some Moviegoers, a New French Blockbuster Is Too Upbeat
description: PARIS  In France, where jaded cinema buffs thought they had seen it all, filmmakers have found a new way to shock this spring. They have turned out a rare blockbuster with mainstream appeal  and some guardians of the culture are furious.

title: Rush-Hour Blues: The Transit Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URY, DENNIS W., III
description: URY-Dennis W., III, died Saturday, June 2, 2001 at his mother's home in Lee, NH. Born October 2, 1959 in NYC he was the son of Ann (Donovan) Ury of Lee and Dennis W. Ury, Jr., of Jersey City, NJ. He attended the RISD and the Chicago Art Institute. Those who wish may make contributions in his memory to the Seacoast Hospice of Exeter, 10 Hampton Road, Exeter, NH 03833

title: With Sales Up, Pathmark Posts 1st-Quarter Profit
description: Pathmark Stores Inc., a grocer that emerged from bankruptcy in September, had a fiscal first-quarter profit and said it expects second-quarter same-store sales to rise as much as 2.5 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Ties
description: Japan's second-largest mobile phone carrier, the KDDI Corporation, and the China Unicom Group, the second-largest mobile carrier in China, said they had signed a technology and roaming pact that would eventually allow KDDI customers to use their phones in China and some Unicom customers to use their phones in Japan. The agreement is based on C.D.M.A. technology developed by the San Diego-based Qualcomm Inc. KDDI has 8.7 million C.D.M.A. customers. China Unicom is building a network with a capacity for 15 million C.D.M.A. customers of its own. Only a small fraction of either of those groups will ever use their phones in the other country. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Gen X Helps Stern Look Clairvoyant
description: AS David Stern was saying, all that the new kids on the block needed was maturation and a few blinding flashes across the late May and early June sky. Hats off to the commissioner, who was right about the star quality potential of Generation X. Now if he can just do something about those overgrown adolescents from Generation Ex.

title: From a Woodland Elegy, A Rhapsody in Green; Hunter Mountain Paintings Spurred Recovery
description: The Catskills had been laid to waste. Generations of loggers, leather tanners and farmers had stripped the valleys and hilltops of their trees. Streams were clotted with the debris of a dying forest. And the mournful painting of the wreckage that Sanford Robinson Gifford produced here just after the Civil War, called ''Hunter Mountain, Twilight,'' became the woodland's elegy.

title: Both Parties Claim Support From Prekindergarten Report
description: A report on the state's prekindergarten program has become a politically charged Rorschach test, with opposing camps citing it to support their positions in the budget fight and trading accusations over how the report became public.

title: A Tax Rebate Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Masters Of the 1960's, Treading New And Old Paths
description: As a selective survey of American experimental dance, with a focus on the Judson Dance Theater of the 1960's, Mikhail Baryshnikov's new production, ''PastForward,'' may sound 40 years out of date.

title: A 'Forward Mail' Feature For Those Who Switch I.S.P.'s
description: For many Internet users, the idea of switching I.S.P.'s carries the threat of e-mail extinction because they would have to change their e-mail addresses in the process. But a new e-mail forwarding service called Re-route will unchain those who are in hate-hate relationships with their I.S.P.'s but who have been deterred from switching to new ones.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hale House Names 2 To Board
description: Two nonlawyers have joined the interim board of Hale House, the troubled children's shelter in Harlem. The six-member board named last month included five lawyers. Lorraine E. Hale, who was dismissed as president last month, had objected to so many lawyers' directing a children's services organization. Melba Butler, the executive director of Harlem Dowling-West Side Center, and Thelma Dye-Holmes, the executive director of Northside Center for Child Development, have been named to the board, Hale House announced yesterday. The state attorney general is investigating Dr. Hale for suspected financial irregularities. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: 2 Coaches and 2 Paths to a Title Showdown
