description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  With his seven championship rings, Phil Jackson is undeniably one of the most successful coaches in National Basketball Association history. But some observers are critical of him because he has always taken over teams with superior players, as opposed to building poor teams into winners as Larry Brown has done.

title: Halfway Between the Hills And Gilligan's Island
description: SOMEHOW FORM A FAMILY

title: Howard M. Packard; Former Executive, 90
description: Howard M. Packard, former president of S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. of Racine, Wis., the producer of Johnson's Wax and other home products, died on Sunday at a retirement community in Sister Bay, Wis. He was 90.

title: Metro Matters; Bloomberg Tries Walking The Fine Line
description: MICHAEL BLOOMBERG did well for himself yesterday, in his first foray as a real (as opposed to videotaped) candidate.

title: Fire and Ice Vie for Soul Of Onegin
description: How to appear both remote and alluring? That's a major problem of characterization faced by anyone dancing the title role in John Cranko's ''Onegin.'' Giuseppe Picone gave a worthy although not entirely successful interpretation of the part when American Ballet Theater presented the work on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CALENDAR
description: Four Days of Craft

title: Two Sides of PowerPoint
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sides of PowerPoint
description: To the Editor:

title: Slavery, Justice and Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Michael Sonnabend, husband of the art dealer Ileana Sonnabend, misstated his age and omitted four survivors. He was 100, not 101. Survivors included his stepdaughter, Nina Sundell of New York, and her three children.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Warmer Words On Missile Shield
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said Japan ''understood'' American policy on building a missile defense, which he said merited research. Mr. Koizumi's comments, delivered before Parliament, seemed intended to counter criticisms of the Bush administration's missile-shield plans reportedly made recently by his foreign minister.

title: Swift Condemnation of U.S. on Steel
description: Less than two months after a deal to end a punishing trans-Atlantic trade war over bananas, the United States and the European Union braced for a new conflict today over steel.

title: AIDS Fungus Drug Offered to Poor Nations
description: The Pfizer pharmaceutical company announced today that it will offer the governments of more than 50 of the world's poorest nations an unlimited free supply of a powerful drug to combat fungal infections associated with AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, MARVIN JOSEPH
description: EISENBERG - Marvin Joseph. Died in New York City on June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Audrey Goodman. Loving father of Eric and Jane, Nina, Sally and Charley. Proud grandfather of Evan and Grace. Cherished brother of the late Raymond Woodrow, brotherin-law to Estelle, and uncle to many nieces and nephews. We will miss him and always remember his charm and intelligence. The funeral service will be held on Friday, June 8, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., (81st Street).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, DR. PAUL
description: KAY-Dr. Paul. The faculty of the NYU (Medical Center) Psychoanalytic Institute and the members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Paul Kay. Dr. Kay was one of the early graduates of our Institute and was prominent and successful as a teacher and practitioner of child and adolescent psychoanalysis. Our warm condolences to the family. Michael Singer, D.O., Director, NYU Psychoanalytic Institute Robert Chalfin, President, PANY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, R.H. (DICK), JR.
description: GRANT-R.H. (Dick), Jr., age 88, of Palm Beach FL, formerly of Dayton OH, died Tuesday, June 5, 2001, in Palm Beach. Mr. Grant was president of Reynolds and Reynolds from 1941 until 1957 when he became chairman & CEO, and currently was director emeritus. He served with other business interests and civic groups: Chairman of GOP Finance Committee, Grant, Brownell & Co., director emeritus of Dayton's former State Fidelity Federal Savings & Loan Assoc., past chairman and board member of Dayton's Salvation Army, former board member of Miami Valley Hospital, the Dayton Area Chamber of Commerce and the Dayton Junior Achievement. Mr. Grant was an avid sailor and a member of The Moraine Country Club, The Miami Valley Hunt and Polo Club, Buzz Fuzz Club, Everglades Club, Sailfish Club, Key Largo Angler's Club, Chub Cay Club and Lyford Cay Club. Survived by his wife of 66 years, Helen (King) Grant; son, R.H. ''Rick'' (Mimi) Grant III of Dayton; daughter, Gail (Grant) Slingluff of NJ; 4 grandchildren; Jennifer (Pat) Robinson of CT, Melissa (Chris) Morley of N.Y.; Elizabeth (Charlie) Schroeder of Dayton; Charles (Slingluff) of CA and 8 great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 a.m. Tuesday, June 12, in Normandy United Methodist Church, 450 W. Alexandersville - Bellbrook Rd., Centerville OH, with Pastor Tom Harry officiating. Family will receive friends immediately following the services at Moraine Country Club, 4075 Southern Blvd., Kettering OH. A private burial, family only, will be held in Centerville Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Salvation Army, PO Box 7, Dayton OH 45402. For information contact Routsong Funeral Home, Kettering, OH. Condolences may be sent to the funeral home's website, via the guestbook, at www.routsong.com.

title: Another, Please, With Sugar
description: Money is the mother of sequels, and it sometimes makes book publishers and authors' heirs do some unconscionable things, like turning classics into literary pudding. Of course, there are also examples of taking those entertainments that were mushy and creamy in the first place and adding more flavors by new pastry chefs. This may not be particularly worthy, but it seems harmless enough, and can be fun. Sequels are certainly not new to book publishing. But recently they've been popping up all over. And when they come, they seem to arrive in bunches like nosegays. The latest and most striking example is the staggering plan to produce sequels to ''The Chronicles of Narnia,'' C. S. Lewis's classic seven-novel saga of a lion who ruled a kingdom of dwarfs, fauns and errant English schoolchildren.

title: New York's Uninsured
description: To the Editor:

title: The agency awards season is blooming with repeat winners -- and there's still more to come.
description: THE advertising awards season is nearing its peak as several organizations are about to present honors for effectiveness and creativity. And for those who go away empty-handed this time, there is word of new awards to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LEONARD
description: GOLDBERG-Leonard. June 5, 2001 in Southbury CT. Beloved husband of Hilda. Loving father of Linda Gratt (Stanley) and Gail Nunziata (Tom), and brother of Ethel Wolfson. Devoted grandfather of David, Jeremy, Ben and Mark. Services Friday. For information call Munson-Lovetere of Southbury, 203-263-2146.

title: 'Pearl Harbor' Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Fine for Toymaker Over Safety Defects Reports
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced yesterday that it had fined the Fisher-Price division of Mattel $1.1 million for failing to report defects in a line of toys, the largest fine the agency has ever leveled against a toymaker.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE DROPS. Gasoline fell after an industry report showed inventories last week rose to their highest level since July 1999. In New York, gasoline for July delivery fell 2.5 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 88.04 cents a gallon.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay And Terra In Marketing Pact
description: Terra Lycos of Spain will put all of the eBay Inc. auction listings on its Lycos Auctions Web site, under a multiyear marketing agreement. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Terra Lycos said the arrangement would allow Lycos users to buy and sell items on eBay, the online auction giant, directly from the Lycos Auctions site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, ERNEST
description: SANDLER-Ernest. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. mourns the passing of our beloved member, Ernest Sandler. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gloria and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, SOPHIE
description: HAINES-Sophie. Of Long Boat Key, FL on June 5. Beloved wife of the late Arland. Devoted mother of Paul Haines and Mary Ann Gauff. Dear sister of Jerome Applebome. Loving grandmother of five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Services Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ Thursday 2PM. For information ''Gutterman - Musicant'', 800 522-0588.

title: Real Writers Typed (They Didn't 'Keyboard')
description: If you saw a brimmed hat, an ashtray and a big black Remington or Royal typewriter in a 1930's movie, some big story was about to hit the streets. Chuck and Rich's Antique Typewriter Web site and online museum offers dozens of images of typewriters dating from the 1880's (typewriter.rydia.net). In addition to the classic movie models, there are early typewriters, which were more like mechanical label makers. Operating these machines, called index typewriters, was a two-step process: users turned the dial to the desired letter and then typed it.

title: Throw Away the Brooms: Sixers Stun Lakers
description: When this playoff heirloom tonight was over, Allen Iverson spoke of going through gantlets, grueling games in which sore and tired players feel more like dropping to the floor than persevering through the pain.

title: City Officials Agree on Budget With $500 Million Tax Cut
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council reached an agreement yesterday on a $39.6 billion budget that would trim the city's income and sales taxes while restoring money to libraries, cultural institutions and services for the elderly that the mayor had sought to cut.

title: AremisSoft Rebuts a Report About Staff Levels in India
description: AremisSoft, a software company, said Tuesday that it had not misled investors about how many programmers it employed or the value of its contracts.

title: NATO Fails to Close Its U.S.-Europe Gap
description: Two years after NATO vowed to improve its military effectiveness, the alliance is falling short of its goals, leaving a huge gap between the United States and its European allies.

title: Blair Leads Labor to Second Sweep Over the Tories
description: LONDON, Friday, June 8 -- Prime Minister Tony Blair and the Labor Party were headed early today toward a sweeping victory in Britain's election, sending the once-dominant Conservatives to their second consecutive large-scale defeat and guaranteeing Labor its first re-election to a full term in office.

title: Transcipt of Panel Discussion: 'The Breast Offense'
description: The NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area hosted an open panel discussion on the topic of extended nursing, based on Sara Corbett's Magazine article, 'The Breast Offense' .

title: Rising Coal Prices Could Add to Energy Woes
description: Amid the widespread anxiety about how high natural gas prices have driven up electricity prices, the rising price of coal -- which fuels most of the power generated in the United States -- has been largely overlooked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IGOE, JOHN F., SR.
description: IGOE-John F., Sr. Of Massapequa Park, NY, on June 5, 2001 (Delivery Foreman of The New York Times). Beloved husband of the late Gertrude A., devoted father and father-in-law of John, Jr., and Jean Igoe, Patricia and Patrick Pizanelli, Katherine and the late Gary Piazza, Carlene and Alex Ippolito, Michele and Stanley Sucharski, dear brother of Martin, Patricia Paz, William and Geraldine Pina, also survived by fourteen grandchildren and two great grandchildren. The family will recieve friends Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. at The McCourt Trudden Funeral Home Inc, 385 Main St, Farmingdale, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 A.M. at Our of Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Massapequa, NY. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery.

title: Macedonia Threatens to Declare State of War Against Rebels
description: Macedonia threatened to declare a state of war today after five government soldiers were killed and six soldiers and police officers wounded in one of the deadliest attacks by ethnic Albanian rebels in weeks.

title: Settlers Press Sharon to Declare War on the Palestinians
description: Furious Jewish settlers fought Palestinians this afternoon near a West Bank crossroads where an Israeli infant was wounded by Arab stone-throwers on Tuesday, and then gathered here this evening to demand a declaration of war against the Palestinian Authority.

title: Baseball by the Numbers
description: Here are some places where managers of fantasy baseball teams and just plain fans can browse all manner of statistics and other major league information and news.

title: Slavery, Justice and Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: In Town Scared by Meningitis, Relief Now Begins Setting In
description: Mayor Toni Middleton strolled the streets of his beloved Carnation City today and carefully studied the downtown lunchrooms for signs of returning life.

title: Philip Morris Seeks Backers for Tobacco Legislation
description: Three years after its last attempt to spur legislation that would have empowered the Food and Drug Administration to regulate the marketing of cigarettes, Philip Morris is shopping around the contours of a bill that would, once again, let the agency limit the tobacco industry's reach. But in contrast to its last efforts, the company is having a hard time finding Congressional backers for its plan.

title: A Jury Awards a Smoker With Lung Cancer $3 Billion From Philip Morris
description: After an emotional seven-week trial, a longtime smoker who has lung cancer today won the largest individual civil award ever levied against a tobacco company, slightly more than $3 billion from the Philip Morris Companies.

title: When TV Goes Sour
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Therapy Could Relieve Hemophilia, Scientists Say
description: A small and preliminary study of gene therapy for hemophilia indicates that the treatment appears safe and that the added genes can function for months in some patients.

title: As Fashion on Two Wheels, It's a Roaring Success
description: AT a motorcycle gathering on a Tuesday night in May at the Ear Inn on far west Spring Street, Suzanne Schick, a patternmaker for the fashion designer Betsey Johnson, roared up astride her purple 1997 Ducati M750 Monster. She wore a matching purple leather jacket. Her hair was purple, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZSTEIN, LARRY
description: SCHWARTZSTEIN-Larry. Congregation Ezrath Israel, The Actors' Temple, mourns the passing of our president Robert Goldman's beloved son-in-law, Larry. He was former financial secretary for many years, dear friend and longtime member. We express our sympathy to his beloved wife, Joy; son, Adam; daughter-in-law, Christine; grandson, Jacob Matthew; Thelma and Robert Goldman, and to his family. He will be deeply missed. Robert Goldman, President Shelly Rothman, Vice President Noach Valley, Rabbi

title: Teachers' Union to Seek Contract Arbitration
description: After the breakdown of contract talks with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United Federation of Teachers sought yesterday to get state officials involved in settling the dispute.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARECYPRESS BUYING CHIP DESIGNER The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation , a maker of chips used in telecommunications equipment, agreed to buy the closely held Lara Networks Inc. for about $225 million to expand its product line. Lara's sales last year were $25 million and are expected to rise to $70 million by 2003, a Cypress spokesman said. Lara designs semiconductors that sort and speed information in communication networks.

title: Article 2001060791015285513 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Treaty Talks With Russia
description: Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka and her Russian counterpart, Igor S. Ivanov, agreed in a telephone conversation to hold talks on signing a long-sought peace treaty that would formally end decades of antagonism between the countries over a group of islands seized by Soviet troops at the end of World War II. The two ministers plan to talk in Italy next month at the annual meeting of the major industrialized nations, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said.

title: Longtime Agency
description: For Hanes Bows Out

title: The End Of a Long Run For a Design Magazine
description: Interiors magazine, the 113-year-old journal of modern design, was closed by its publisher, Bill Communications, on Monday. ''The reasons were exclusively economic,'' said Julie Lasky, the editor in chief. ''This is a bad economy, and projections were not meeting standards.'' The June issue, its last, has articles about a performance space in South Korea designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; interiors of the homes of rap and rock stars, as seen on ''Crib'' on MTV; and a look at 'N Sync's customized coach. Interiors originated in 1888 as The Upholsterer; Industrial Design magazine was born in 1954 from an Interiors column. ''What I'd really like to do is hold an official wake,'' Ms. Lasky said.

title: Sophisticated By Design, With a Menu To Match
description: Sometimes a person doesn't feel like having dinner sitting on an egg facing neon walls. Conners Crawley Sanders of New York designed No. 9, a lush, autumnal restaurant in the East Village, as an antidote to the usual downtown glowing blobitecture. ''We wanted this to feel enduring, restrained but rich, a great classic spot,'' said Gwen Conners, one of the architects. Another architect, Jennifer Crawley, said she was aiming for a grown-up place where she could wear high heels. The result has dark furniture and walnut paneling (below right). The walnut bar is tiled in midnight blue, Rothko reds, mustard and olive. Banquettes (top right) have silk pillows. No. 9, with its equally adult menu (escargot, tuna tartare), is at 109 East Ninth Street, (212) 529-5333.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, SYLVIA (NEE SCHECHTER)
description: GREENSTEIN - Sylvia (nee Schechter) on June 6, 2001. She was predeceased by her husband Joseph. She was a loving mother of Linda and Howard Schwartz, caring grandmother of Brian and Nancy Schwartz, Lisa and David Sternberg, Andrew and Kelly Schwartz, and loving ''Bubbie'' to her great grandchildren Joshua, Jason, Lauren and Amy.

title: Bush Honors D-Day Troops At Dedication Of Memorial
description: When the 116th Regiment waded ashore at Omaha Beach 57 years ago today, 35 of its soldiers came from this small town in the shadow of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Nineteen of them died in the first 15 minutes of battle, and 2 more died later in the day.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco To Sell Sonicwall Gear
description: Shares in SonicWall Inc., an Internet security company, rose sharply yesterday after the company announced that it had signed a deal to provide encryption equipment to Cisco Systems. SonicWall already had a marketing relationship with Cisco, but the deal could help the company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., gain credibility as it seeks more large corporate customers. It says its security system removes the need for Web server computers to use their own processing capacity for encryption, improving site performance and network efficiency for e-commerce and other secure applications. Its shares rose $2.21, or 12.7 percent, to $19.96. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: For Sale: A Latin Music Legacy; Facing Bankruptcy, a Record Pioneer Draws Gratitude and Reproach
description: Long before the recent Latin music boom, Ralph Mercado became a pioneer whose passion for salsa and other tropical rhythms led to discovering a wealth of talent and raising the genre's profile.

title: Debating Europe's Future
description: European integration has been one of the great successes of the last half-century, binding together historically hostile nations in an ever closer economic union committed to a common set of democratic values. A concerted approach to this integration by France and Germany was crucial to its success. But now, as the 15-member European Union considers admitting new Central and East European members and strengthening its political unity to reflect its economic interdependence, France and Germany are not working in unison.

title: Chief Executive of Chicago Schools Resigns
description: Paul G. Vallas, the blunt-talking, bottom-line-driven manager who led the turnaround of Chicago's troubled school system and became a national role model for urban school reform, said yesterday that he was resigning after six years as the school district's chief executive.

title: 'Pearl Harbor' Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARSHAD, RUTH
description: MARSHAD-Ruth. June 7, 2000 Mom, you are always in my heart. Love, Barbara

title: Argentine Ex-Leader Seized in a Plot to Smuggle Arms
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 7  Former President Carlos Saul Menem, whose 10 years in office were marked by sweeping economic reform but also reports of government corruption, was arrested today on charges that he led a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995.

title: New Senate Chief Can Look to Past in Charting Course
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Though the Senate has never before changed hands in the middle of a session, Tom Daschle, the new majority leader, confronts problems and opportunities similar to those that faced Bob Dole, Robert C. Byrd, Howard H. Baker Jr. and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: MetroStars' Mathis Will Be Out Six Months
description: Clint Mathis, who has made an impact on American soccer in the past year with the national team, the MetroStars and Major League Soccer, tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee while practicing with the national team Tuesday and will be out of action for about six months.

title: Gillette's Chief Is Critical Of the Company's Missteps
description: James M. Kilts, the new chief executive of the Gillette Company, was critical yesterday of decisions made by his predecessors and said the problems experienced by the company in recent years were self-inflicted wounds.

title: Cendant Said To Be Close To Purchasing Travel Service
description: The Cendant Corporation, the owner of Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, is near a deal to buy Galileo International, an electronic travel reservation business, for more than $2.8 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Posada's One At-Bat Counts 4 Times
description: Jorge Posada is such a harsh self-critic of his ability to come into a game cold and hit that he almost sounds like Paul O'Neill. Posada has an injured left thumb that keeps him from catching. So instead of spending the game involved in every play, calling every pitch, Posada spent seven innings last night wandering around the Yankees' clubhouse.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Gypsies Plan To Sue I.B.M.
description: Gypsy groups said they would sue I.B.M., asserting that its tabulating machines helped Nazi Germany track and identify people killed during the Holocaust. An estimated 600,000 Gypsies are believed to have died at the hands of the Nazis. The groups plan to sue under Swiss law because I.B.M.'s German and Swiss subsidiaries were then situated in Geneva. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Through Sidewalk Cracks, Hardy Cultural Flowers Leap Toward the Sun
description: The Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center provided a home for black choreographers and performers well before their work became a staple of the New York dance scene. This month the center is celebrating its 25th anniversary with ''The Souls of Our Feet: People of Color Dance Festival'' at the Triangle Theater at Long Island University in Brooklyn.

title: Racial Unrest Explodes in Another British City; Six Are Arrested
description: Six people were arrested today after scores of youths set fire to cars and stores and threw bricks and bottles at police officers during more racial unrest in the north of England -- this time in a night of rioting in the mostly Asian section of Leeds.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hondas Recalled
description: Honda Motor said it would recall more than 100,000 vehicles made between January and April because of a manufacturing flaw in a wheel bolt. Because of the defect, a wheel bolt could break, causing the wheel to fall off, the company said. No accidents have been reported, the company said. The recall involves 19 types of vehicles, including the Accord, the Civic and the Stream, that were sold in Japan. Toyota said it was still checking to see if cars sold overseas were affected. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Venture
description: Exxon Mobil, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and BP P.L.C. were picked by China's largest oil company, the state-owned PetroChina Company, as potential partners in a $14 billion, 2,500-mile natural gas pipeline. The project will pipe gas from the impoverished Xinjiang province in the west to Shanghai. The pipeline is considered a questionable investment by most Western analysts, but helping the Chinese government brings other benefits: PetroChina has promised companies participating in the pipeline drilling rights in Xinjiang's Kela-2 gas field, the country's largest. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Bryant and Iverson Prove That Age Limits Can Often Be Tricky
description: ONE week ago, we were treated to the charming photo of 13-year-old Morgan Pressel and her proud grandpa, Herb Krickstein, just before the prodigy made her first appearance in the United States Women's Open of golf.

title: Firefighters' Union Raises Funds For Hevesi From Pension Advisers
description: The city firefighters' union has gathered at least $16,000 in contributions for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's mayoral campaign, with much of the money coming from executives who do business with the union or investment advisers to firefighter and other city pension funds.

title: Human Services Nominee's Focus on Married Fatherhood Draws Both Praise and Fire
description: When President Bush goes to a Washington hotel on Thursday to sing the praises of fatherhood, he will hail the work of Wade F. Horn, a child psychologist who has perhaps done more than anyone else in America to draw attention to the rights and responsibilities of fathers.

title: Hit or Myth
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA TO PAY $3.91 MILLION IN MEDICAID DISPUTE
description: Electronic Data Systems, the second-largest computer-services company in the nation, has agreed to pay Texas $3.91 million after the state accused the company of overcharging by millions of dollars to process Medicaid claims. Electronic Data will refund the state $3.43 million and pay a $250,000 penalty and $232,000 to cover Texas's investigation costs, a company spokesman, Ken Smalling, said. Electronic Data did not admit wrongdoing. Charges will not be filed against Electronic Data or National Heritage Insurance, the Electronic Data unit that handles Medicaid claims processing, the district attorney's office in Travis County, Tex., said.

title: June 11: McVeigh and America
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Dead or Alive'
description: Directed by Takashi Miike

title: N.A.S.D. Expels Day Traders
description: The Landmark Securities Corporation, once one of the nation's 10 biggest day-trading firms, was expelled from the securities business today for violations including misleading advertisements that minimized trading risks, regulators said.

title: BLAIR LEADS LABOR TO SECOND SWEEP OVER THE TORIES
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and the Labor Party swept to victory early today in Britain's election, sending the once-dominant Conservatives to their second consecutive large-scale defeat and guaranteeing Labor its first re-election to a full term in office.

title: Why the Democrats Wobble in the South
description: To the Editor:

title: For Publisher, Book's Drama Spills Into Real Life
description: APRIL was the cruelest month for Wendy J. Strothman, an otherwise mild-mannered Houghton Mifflin Company publisher who went to the mat hopping mad in Federal District Court in Atlanta on behalf of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' the unauthorized, heavily litigated parody -- on this plantation it's the white characters who can't walk and chew gum at the same time -- of the antebellum classic ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Killer Again Seeks Release From Psychiatric Hospital
description: The man who testified for five hours yesterday described a productive daily routine. He spoke of beginning each day with Buddhist meditation, of performing kitchen duties that included sharpening knives and of making picture frames -- all at the psychiatric hospital where he has spent the last two decades.

title: Sports of The Times; Stanley Is Rerouted To Denver
description: TO hear people talk last night, its name could have been Elvis instead of Stanley.

title: Bombs Away! War Is Heck, But True Love Survives
description: Pearl Harbor

title: Body Shop Is in Talks on Sale to Mexican Company
description: The Body Shop acknowledged today that it was in talks to sell its 1,840 health and beauty products stores to Grupo Omnilife, a rapidly growing multilevel marketing company based in Mexico.

title: Hollywood on Ice
description: Alan Cumming and Jennifer Jason Leigh, below, wrote, directed and star in ''The Anniversary Party,'' a film that puts their characters' marriage, among others, under a microscope.

title: Bourque Delivers the Speech, and Roy the Shutout
description: Knute Rockne it was not. But with his Colorado Avalanche one defeat from elimination in the Stanley Cup finals, Ray Bourque felt he had to stand up and say something to his teammates before Game 6 tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELHELM, ROBERT R. SR.
description: ADELHELM-Robert R. Sr. Of Teaneck, NJ, on June 6, 2001. Beloved husband to the late Ann T. (nee Tymon). Devoted father to Diane Adelhelm, Robert Ralph Adelhelm Jr. and Joanna Hafner. Dear grandfather to Stephanie and Joseph Hafner. Loving brother to Evelyn Hutchins, William Adelhelm and Jean Thomas. Funeral at Vorhees Funeral Home, 59 Main Street, Ridgefield Park, NJ, on Saturday, 9 AM. The Funeral Mass will be offered at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bogota, NJ, at 9:30 AM. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. If desired, contributions may be made to a hospice of your choice.

title: Thanking Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadowlands Is Loose End In Arena Plan For Newark
description: When Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco announced plans Wednesday for a proposed $355 million arena in Newark, he said he hoped to sign legislation by the end of the month that would move the New Jersey Devils and Nets to a new home there.

title: A campaign to turn a mattress maker into a 'wellness provider.'
description: IN these days when eight hours of sleep can be a luxury, Sealy Inc., the largest manufacturer of mattresses, is using a multimedia campaign to pitch the message that it is not just the quantity of sleep that matters but the quality of bedding as well.

title: AETNA CHIEF SAYS RECORD-KEEPING LAPSES COST MILLIONS
description: Because its record-keeping is poor, Aetna has been paying millions of dollars in medical claims for people whose benefits have expired, the company's chief executive told investors yesterday. Aetna, which lost $36.6 million from operations in the first quarter, is trying to fix the problem quickly, the chief executive, John W. Rowe, said. Mr. Rowe said a new system might be in place in 40 days. The company is struggling to control medical costs as it relaxes some restrictions on care under pressure from patients and physicians who have complained that Aetna pays claims slowly and requires too much paperwork. Aetna, which has about 18.3 million customers, is dropping about 10 percent of its unprofitable clients this year to increase profit.

title: Russia's New Reach: Gas Pipeline to Turkey
description: In early August, one of the world's largest and most advanced offshore platforms will slip beneath the two graceful suspension bridges spanning the Bosporus, with three feet of clearance, on its way to the Black Sea.

title: June 11: McVeigh and America
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: STELLA SOLEIL: -- ''Dirty Little Secret'' (Universal). Stella Soleil's ''Kiss Kiss'' is one of the novelty-pop highlights of the moment. With a sinuous Turkish melody, smooching sound effects and ululating harmonies, it announces the arrival of either a one-hit wonder or a wacky, interesting artist. But be warned before you pick up her debut solo album: that song, a Turkish pop hit for Tarkan (written by the great Sezen Aksu), is the exception on the album.

title: After Shift in Senate, Some in G.O.P. Are Fearing Wider Impact in 2002
description: Many prominent Republicans are worried that the unexpected switch of the Senate to Democratic control may carry enormous political consequences for their party that run far deeper than forfeiting the issue agenda on Capitol Hill.

title: O.K., Spotters, An American Lady? A Red Admiral?
description: Spotting butterflies -- the spotted sort (American Lady) right, in the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, N.Y., or any one of myriad varieties -- is becoming a growing spectator sport for a new breed of lepidopterist whose motto is ''look but don't touch.'' Lenses are in, nets are out among these enthusiasts, who have taken a page from the bird-watching crowd by using binoculars and patience to enjoy the leisurely pleasure of gazing upon their winged subjects from a safe distance.

title: William N. Copley
description: Nolan/Eckman Gallery

title: Article 2001060892247158274 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose after a spate of unexpected refinery shutdowns threatened to limit supplies. In New York, gasoline for July delivery rose 0.81 cent, or 0.9 percent, to 88.85 cents a gallon.

title: A Stanford Economist to Be No. 2 at I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had named Anne O. Krueger, a Stanford University economist and a strong proponent of global free trade, to serve as its No. 2 official, responsible for carrying out the fund's role as the world's financial firefighter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, BARBARA F.
description: HELLER-Barbara F., of Sarasota, FL, died suddenly June 1, 2001. Beloved widow of Herbert C. Heller; cherished stepmother of Herbert C. Heller Jr. (Elizabeth) and Mary Silk. Loving step-grandmother of Karen, Nina and Alice Heller; Robert and Edward Jaffee. Judge among judges of the canine world.

title: Mr. Badillo's Fourth Mayoral Race
description: With the formal entry yesterday of Herman Badillo as a Republican candidate for mayor, the lineup for replacing Rudolph Giuliani looks complete. Four major Democrats and two Republicans now compete in earnest for their parties' slots. Mr. Badillo, who first ran for mayor in 1969, bears all the virtues and scars from such longevity in New York politics. This breadth of experience, however, provides a stark contrast to Michael Bloomberg, a first-time candidate who looms as Mr. Badillo's rich and formidable opponent in the city's first real Republican mayoral primary in a dozen years.

title: Alternating Currents in Rockland; Great Connections for Power Plants, but Foes Abound
description: Finding a spot to build a power plant can be as easy as putting up a waterworks in the Sahara, but amid Rockland County's hills and meadows, developers found an oasis of resources. The county has a crisscross of natural gas lines to fuel the plants, electrical transmission lines hooked up to power grids in New York and other states, and abundant water for cooling turbines.

title: Why the Democrats Wobble in the South
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHENBACH, JACK
description: REICHENBACH - Jack. Died peacefully with his family at his side on June 7. Loving husband of Cecile Metz and devoted father of Judy Berg, Alan and Herbert. Adoring grandfather of Natalie, Alison, Samantha and Jenna. His pride in his family was his greatest source of strength. As a veteran of WWII, his service as a Lt. Col. Lead Pilot in the 15th U.S. Air Force in Italy was recognized by the Distinguished Flying Cross and Purple Heart. Having been shot down on his 33rd mission, his days as a prisoner of war were survived by courageous leadership. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services Friday, June 8, 11 AM, at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY. Memorial donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital, Office of Development, 100 Port Washington Boulevard, Roslyn, NY 11576.

title: Tory Chief Steps Down After Labor's 2nd Election Victory
description: LONDON, June 8  William Hague announced today that he was stepping down as Conservative Party leader after returns from Thursday's election showed that the party had suffered its second straight devastating defeat. Filling the new opening at the top is likely to plunge the quarrelsome Tories into fresh dispute.

title: President's Signature Turns Broad Tax Cut, and a Campaign Promise, Into Law
description: President Bush fulfilled a major promise of his campaign for president today, signing into law the most sweeping tax cut in two decades, which he called ''the first major achievement of a new era.''

title: For Dominant Clemens, The Brushback Is Back
description: It was Todd Greene's second game with the Yankees and his first as a catcher for Roger Clemens, a simple assignment as far as Greene was concerned. He felt no need to dictate pitch selection or establish his credibility. No, Greene figured Clemens would do whatever he wanted and Greene would just catch whatever he threw.

title: Subject to Review
description: Almost nothing about the new tax law is irreversible. Even before President Bush signed it this morning with great fanfare at a White House ceremony, the politicians were talking about how to revise it.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Adds A Director
description: James I. Cash, a professor at Harvard Business School and a consultant, was appointed yesterday to the Microsoft board. He is the second new director named by the company in recent weeks. Mr. Cash, 53, was the chairman of Harvard's master's of business administration program from 1992 to 1995 and has been a Harvard faculty member since 1976. He has written several books on information technology and managing information systems, and is on several other corporate boards, Microsoft said. Mr. Cash, above, joins Microsoft as it prepares an upgrade to its Windows operating system, due out in October, and tries to sell more programs for server computers and develop additional Internet software and services. Last month, Microsoft named Raymond Gilmartin, the chief executive of Merck & Company, to its board.

title: It's Big, It's Bad, It's Mutating Protoplasm
description: In ''Evolution,'' Ivan Reitman's scattershot sci-fi comedy, Orlando Jones and David Duchovny play community college science instructors who happen upon an alien life-form that threatens to take over the world. A meteor has crashed into the Arizona desert. Examining the blue-green slime that oozes from beneath its surface (''It's a rock that bleeds!''), Mr. Duchovny's character, a disgraced former Pentagon biologist named Ira Kane, discovers a colony of squirming star-shaped amoebas. These quickly mutate into more complex microorganisms, and then into computer-animated flatworms, insects, slimy lizards and angry primates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETTO, KATHRYN C.
description: NETTO-Kathryn C. On June 6, 2001, at age 72. Beloved wife of Eldo, loving mother of David, devoted daughter of the late Frank A. and Madelyne Cosgrove. Interment private. The family warmly invites friends to attend a memorial service to celebrate Kate's life at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave and 66 St, Wednesday, June 13th, 3 PM. Kate was a private person with the most generous heart whose philosophy was that only kindness matters. She valued her family and friends above all else. Her father's contribution to the building of Johnson & Johnson and the Cosgrove family's support of the Metropolitan Museum of Art made her proud, but Kate's greatest happiness came from the love of a son and husband who will miss her every day. Contributions in Kate's memory may be made to The Museum of Natural History, in honor of the Children of the City of New York.

title: Rally by Semiconductor Shares Lifts Technology Issues
description: Semiconductor stocks rallied sharply yesterday, leading the overall technology sector higher, as investors hoped that Intel, the world's largest chip maker, would add to the evidence that the industry's decline was ending and that sales would revive in the second half of the year.

title: Bronx Candidate Undeterred By Detour Into Brooklyn Jail
description: It can't be easy to run for office when you are Prisoner No. 21453-069. But Adolfo Carrin Jr. is trying.

title: Lott Steps Aside, Making a Pledge of Cooperation
description: In the opening moments of the ceremony that would formally end his role as the majority leader of the Senate, Trent Lott had reason to feel alone.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: Bond Issue
description: Bahrain said it planned to sell bonds that conform with Islamic law banning interest, in what is likely to be the first of many such sales by Arab countries looking to tap into a fast-growing market. The bonds, known as certificates of peace, have a maturity of three months and offer a share in the earnings of the state projects they will finance.

title: 2 Insiders Will Share Checketts's Old Job
description: Three weeks after the ouster of Dave Checketts as the president of Madison Square Garden, Cablevision Systems announced yesterday that it would divide his duties between Seth Abraham and Steve Mills.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: From Fossils To Forests

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKEL, SAUL HOWARD
description: HASKEL-Saul Howard. On June 7, 2001, age 80. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Survived by wife Lavita of 55 years; children Peter (Lynn), Margaret (Rene), Anne, James (Karen); grandchildren Katherine, Jacob, Jennie, Lauren, Michael, and Alexander. Long respected in the building stone industry. Columbia College, BA, '41, engineering '43. South Pacific WWII, 534th Engineers, Boat and Shore Regiment. Longtime local, regional and national Boy Scout leader. In lieu of flowers, donations to Columbia College, Class of '41 Fund. Sitting shiva Sunday, June 10, after 3; thereafter all day to Thursday, June 14, at Lavita's residence.

title: Ali-Frazier Weigh-In Is Low-Key Event
description: Jacqui Frazier-Lyde stepped onto the scale, smiled and walked out. Laila Ali stepped onto the scale, signed some autographs and walked out. That was it. No verbal sparring, nothing between the daughters of two of boxing's most famous rivals.

title: For a High-Flying Gang, An Unsettling Windfall
description: ''The Big Heist,'' Sunday's A&E movie based on the multimillion-dollar Lufthansa robbery at Kennedy International Airport in 1978, proves much the same thing that the crime itself did: it is possible to have too much wealth.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Seek, Identify and Enjoy, but Leave the Nets and Pins at Home, Please
description: We've been butterflying. We've seen Hobomok Skippers, small vivid patches of yellow, brown and orange against the intense blue and yellow of iris blooms. We've watched a bright yellow, and much larger, Tiger Swallowtail swoop in the distance. We've noted the marks on a Red Admiral's wings and tried to plumb the depths of color in a Red-Spotted Purple.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Probation In A Waco Case
description: Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, was sentenced by a federal court in St. Louis to two years of probation for withholding evidence in connection with the 1993 standoff and fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Mr. Johnston admitted in February that he had withheld from investigators one page of notes involving F.B.I. agents' use of pyrotechnic tear gas canisters during the 51-day siege. In return for his plea, prosecutors dropped charges of obstructing justice and lying to investigators and a federal grand jury. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Article 2001060893218371380 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Article 2001060892224809633 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Unknowns Off Bench Crash the Stars' Party
description: The names on the marquee are Allen Iverson, Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant, Dikembe Mutombo, Phil Jackson and Larry Brown. But over the course of this N.B.A. championship series, an unknown or two will brand his name into the public's consciousness alongside those of the stars.

title: Lawmakers Exchange Barbs Over Absence of State Budget
description: One day after the Connecticut General Assembly ended its legislative session without next year's state budget in place, leading Democrats and Republicans in the State Senate and House of Representatives offered separate post-mortems of what they had accomplished and, not surprisingly, laid blame on the other party for what they had not.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Investor Sells Texas Building
description: Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, N.J., announced this week that it had sold an office complex in San Antonio for $21.9 million, as part of a revised strategy to refocus its portfolio on the Northeast. The 15-story, 256,000-square-foot property, known as Tetco Towers, was sold to Koontz McCombs 2 Ltd., a Texas real estate company, as part of Mack-Cali's plan to sell properties in Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, Denver, Phoenix and other markets, said Mitchell E. Hersh, chief executive of Mack-Cali, a real estate investment trust. He said proceeds from sales would probably be used to buy properties between Washington and Fairfield County, Conn.

title: A Witness To Massacre In Nepal Tells Gory Details
description: A survivor of Nepal's palace massacre today gave the first witness's account of the royal blood bath, describing how Crown Prince Dipendra, falling-down drunk, nevertheless managed to navigate his way around a dining hall, shooting family members as he tottered.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Former Prisoner Loses Appeal
description: A woman who spent 25 years in prison before her murder conviction was overturned cannot sue New York State for damages, the state's highest court ruled yesterday. The Court of Appeals declined, without comment, to hear the appeal of the woman, Betty Tyson, from a lower court decision to throw out her suit. Ms. Tyson, 52, and John Duval were convicted in 1973 of murdering a business consultant in Rochester, based on confessions that they said the police had beaten out of them. In 1998, a judge found that evidence pointing to their innocence had been suppressed. Both inmates were freed.

title: Set Back Again, Mc Veigh Abandons Bid for a Stay
description: A federal appeals court today rejected Timothy J. McVeigh's request for a stay of execution, and his lawyers aid afterward that Mr. McVeigh would now abandon all efforts at a postponement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, FRANCES MCLAUGHLIN
description: HOLLAND-Frances McLaughlin. Died in Yonkers, NY, on June 5, 2001. She was predeceased by her husband of 62 years, John R. Holland, and leaves her children John F. Holland, Roschel Holland Stearns, Marlin Ebbert and Jane Holland, and her grandchildren Holly, Ward and Julie Ebbert, and Alexandra and William Jenik. Dr. Holland was a retired Pittsburgh educator and trustee of many local and national educational, cultural and social service organizations. A special light has moved from this world into another. The funeral will be in Pittsburgh. Memorial contributions for scholarships may be made to the Frances M. Holland Memorial Fund of the Community College of Allegheny County, Educational Foundation, 800 Allegheny Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15233; or The Ozanam Center of Diocese of Pittsburgh, 1833 Wylie Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15219.

title: The Presidential Tax-Cut Moment
description: Appropriately enough, President Bush signed his $1.35 trillion tax cut into law yesterday in a ceremony that looked like a campaign stop from last year. After all, a president who can get his No. 1 priority enacted within five months of taking office has accomplished something impressive politically. However, as this page has often noted, it is an achievement that comes at great cost. It will now be extremely hard to finance Mr. Bush's and the Congress's spending priorities, especially in health, education and defense. Indeed, lawmakers of all persuasions were predicting yesterday that the tax cut would have to be revised fairly soon just to fix the accounting tricks that disguised its cost.

title: New York Post Fires Newfield, Two Editors and Three Others
description: Jack Newfield, the most liberal voice at The New York Post, was fired today along with Stuart Marques and Marc Kalech, two of its three managing editors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMMERS, LEON
description: POMMERS-Leon. On June 7, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Alice Greenwood and her husband Bob. Dear brother of Bertha Katz. Adoring grandfather of Dara, David and Stephanie Greenwood. Renowned pianist and beloved teacher. Service Friday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ergonomics Hearings
description: Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao announced that she would hold three public hearings before deciding what to do regarding regulations to help prevent workplace injuries. In March, Congress repealed the ergonomics rules that the Clinton administration had adopted after 10 years of federal study. The hearings announced by Secretary Chao will be held in Washington on July 16, in Chicago on July 20 and in a California city to be designated on July 24. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: VW Holders Approve Buyback
description: Defying protests from dissident investors, including several big institutions, Volkswagen A.G. received overwhelming approval from shareholders for its plan to buy back its stock and shore up its defenses against hostile takeovers.

title: AOL Will Merge Magazines After Buying Business 2.0
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Business 2.0, the ailing new-economy magazine, and merge it with its eCompany Now magazine.

title: Feuding Agencies Settle Differences
description: A bitter legal battle between a giant public relations agency and employees who left to start their own shop in Atlanta has been settled.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SIEGMAN, HOWARD
description: SIEGMAN-Howard, 1922-2000 Howard Siegman taught dramatic literature at Hofstra University for some thirty-five years. Most references to him have to be theatrical, from Oedipus to Blanche DuBois and all the great plays in between. They made him come alive and, in turn, he did the same for them. Students cherished him for this gift as did his friends. There was more, lots more. The love he inspired comes close to saying it all

title: The O'Connor Court: America's Most Powerful Jurist
description: We are all living now in Sandra Day O'Connor's America. Take almost any of the most divisive questions of American life, and Justice O'Connor either has decided it or is about to decide it on our behalf. The Supreme Court may tell us soon whether affirmative action in public universities is permissible, and if it does, O'Connor is likely to cast the deciding vote. The court is divided about school vouchers too; O'Connor's views will probably tip the scales.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the ways people are expected to spend tax rebates carried erroneous data. It showed the change in the price of goods and services bought by consumers, not the change in consumer spending from one year to the next. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C5.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column yesterday about the commutation of a jail term for an Arkansas businessman, David Hale, for deceiving insurance regulators misstated the accusation he made against President Bill Clinton in the Whitewater matter. He accused Mr. Clinton of pressuring him to make an illegal loan, not of accepting an illegal loan.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the downturn in the Israeli economy since the outbreak of violence between Israelis and Palestinians last fall misstated the effect on Israeli banks. While most have reported steep slides in first-quarter earnings, they have not reported steep first-quarter losses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Grows
description: German unemployment rose a seasonally adjusted 18,000 in May, to 3.83 million, leaving the unemployment rate at 9.3 percent. The increase in the jobless rate, the fifth consecutive monthly increase, dashed hopes for a labor market recovery in spring. The federal labor office said the unemployment data reflected the impact of a slowdown in economic growth. Despite the poor economic news in Germany, the largest economy in Europe, the European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4.5 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Schundler and Franks Assail Each Other's Record in Debate
description: Bob Franks and Bret D. Schundler attacked each other tonight as uninformed, disingenuous and beholden to developers during a testy hourlong encounter, the first television debate in the race for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey.

title: D. B. Osborne, 103, Spence Headmistress
description: Dorothy Brockway Osborne, a former headmistress of the Spence School, a Manhattan private school for girls, died on Tuesday at her home in Concord, N.H. She was 103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, ELISE DACOSTA
description: WATERMAN-Elise DaCosta. On June 7, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Philip M. Waterman. Devoted and proud mother and mother-in-law of Philip M. Waterman Jr. and Jane, Marie W. Harris and Kenneth. Loved and admired grandmother of Philip M. Waterman III, Anne L. Waterman, Kenneth A. Harris Jr. and Ellen Harris Knoblock and Henry. Adored great-grandmother of Christopher H. Knoblock and Caroline D. Knoblock. Dear sister of Manette D. Kaufmann. Elise was a remarkable and elegant woman. She distinguished herself to family and friends by her wisdom, wit and zeal for life. Her special prescence will be deeply missed. Services will be private. Doantions may be made to the American Jewish Committee, 165 E. 56th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: Iljaz Sinanoski, Bitola, Macedonia, May 6, 2001
description: he night of April 30, while everybody was asleep, some 50 stores were burned down in Bitola, and some houses, too. It was the Macedonian youth who did it. This did not come out of the blue: two days before, eight security men -- four Macedonian policemen from Bitola and four soldiers -- were killed by Albanian rebels. But these were not only Albanian shops. They were also Muslim Macedonian and Turkish. We are Macedonians too, of Islamic faith. All in all, our family lost three out of seven shops. The people who did this came back the next day, around lunchtime, and then thoroughly looted one of them.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR LITTLE CHANGED. The dollar edged lower against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 85.07 cents, up from 84.76 cents on Wednesday. The dollar traded at 120.09 yen, down from 120.39 yen.

title: McCain's Cue to G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: City Budget Seeks More Money for Child Care, Housing and Orderly Elections
description: There is an extra serving of money intended to prevent -- or at least minimize -- chaos at the polls this year. The dollars are still there to follow up on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's promise to build more low-cost housing. And nearly 11,000 more city children will be able to get subsidized day care.

title: In a Trice, A Passionate Deflating Of a Snob
description: John Cranko's ''Onegin'' received a dazzling and deep performance from Susan Jaffe as a new Tatiana in American Ballet Theater's production on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: A City Hesitates at Political Change
description: The future didn't happen here this week. For the past few months, Los Angeles has seemed poised to become home to a new political order in America. The mayoral candidacy of Antonio Villaraigosa, a former California Assembly speaker, promised to empower a political coalition rooted in the great Latin American immigration of the past 20 years. Los Angeles was to be to the new century what New York had been to the last, and Mr. Villaraigosa was our Fiorello LaGuardia, a gifted pol off mean streets who'd formed a citywide, pro-labor legion that would redefine liberalism in America, much as New York once did.

title: Brodeur Beaten but Not Bruised
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  Martin Brodeur dropped his black duffel bag on the wooden podium in the dressing room, but instead it clunked onto his right foot. He had been shrugging off questions about possible injuries to explain, in part, an unimpressive four-goal night.

title: BOLDFACE NAME
description: Finger Adornments

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEST, RAYMOND VICTOR
description: BEST-Raymond Victor, 85, and Alan Thomson Best, 90, brothers, within hours of each other on Saltspring Island, British Columbia, May 21-22. Ray served with distinction as a bomber pilot in the RAF and RCAF, took degrees at UBC and Princeton, and taught palaeontology at McMaster and at UBC. Alan was a keen naturalist, a sculptor in Paris and England in the 1930's, a zoo curator in London and many years in Vancouver. Predeceased by brothers Vincent and Gordon, survived by brother Norman and (respectively) wives Jane and Diana, their offspring and many loving relatives. Memorial services in Ganges, July 29.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Domestic Violence Bill Passes
description: A bill imposing mandatory fines of up to $500 on those found guilty of domestic violence was approved by the New Jersey Senate yesterday and sent to Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco. Passed by the General Assembly in March, the bill would deposit the offenders' fines, potentially millions of dollars, in a newly created Domestic Violence Victims Fund. About 13,500 people are found guilty of domestic violence in New Jersey each year, the bill's sponsors said.

title: Apartheid and Its Bitter Aftertaste
description: A THIRD-GENERATION South African who bears mournful witness to the chaos of his country, William Kentridge, born in Johannesburg in 1955, is wary of the term ''political artist.''

title: Rumsfeld Outlines to NATO Fast Track for Missile Shield
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the United States is likely to deploy certain antiballistic missile systems before testing on them is completed, signaling the speed with which the Bush administration hopes to develop and use the still-unproven technology.

title: Growth in Retailers' Sales Fell Short of Expectations in May
description: Retail sales rose less than expected in May as shoppers spent less on clothing and sought bargains at discounters like Wal-Mart Stores to weather the slowing economy.

title: Article 2001060892898108746 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Napster Hires Lawyer
description: Taking two more steps toward reinventing itself as a pay subscription service, Napster said yesterday that it had hired Jonathan Schwartz, a former Justice Department lawyer, to oversee its legal affairs and that it had struck a deal with Loudeye Technologies, a company that makes music ''fingerprinting'' software. At the Justice Department, Mr. Schwartz most recently served as a deputy attorney general. ''Jonathan has an incredibly sharp legal mind,'' said Hank Barry, Napster's chief executive. ''We are thrilled to have him.'' Separately, Napster said that Loudeye, which is based in Seattle, will add information like the title, artist and publisher to digitally encoded music, permitting it to be tracked more effectively by publishers and music sellers. Terms were not disclosed. Loudeye stock rose 55 cents, or 45.5 percent, to $1.76. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: City Insists on Administrative Cuts for School Board
description: City officials reassured the Board of Education yesterday that they would allocate additional money for instruction in the next school year if the board made cuts in its administrative costs over the summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, SOPHIA
description: ABELES-Sophia. The Board of Trustees, the Foundation Board of Directors, the faculty and the students of Westchester Community College will greatly miss the warmth and caring presence of their colleague, friend and benefactor, Sophia Abeles. As an individual, and in her capacity as vice president and member of the WCC Foundation Board, her commitment to ensuring accessibility to quality public education has created a legacy that will have a lasting impact upon untold numbers of individuals for generations to come. Through her vision, leadership and generosity at the college, as well as other areas throughout the community, she taught us many lessons and unselfishly crafted extraordinary opportunities for countless men and women. We will work to ensure that her ideals and the fruits of her life's work will continue to flourish and grow. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Joe, Lucille and Barbara, and the other members of the family. Hon. Timothy S. Carey, Chairman Westchester Community College Board of Trustees Joseph N. Hankin, President Westchester Community College Jack Stadler, Chairman Westchester Community College Foundation

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Modem Acquisition
description: The consumer electronics giant Thomson Multimedia of France beefed up its range of products providing fast Internet access by acquiring the modem division of Alcatel S.A. for 456 million euros, ($386 million). Thomson Multimedia, known in the United States for its RCA brand products, is already a leader in set-top boxes and cable modems that provide Internet access via television cables. The acquisition of the Alcatel division will enhance its offering of so-called digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., technology, which offers fast Internet access via fixed phone lines. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Europeans Monitoring Mideast Cease-Fire
description: European Union security experts have been posted at two key Palestinian flashpoints to monitor efforts to maintain the fragile cease-fire between the Palestinian Authority and the Israeli government, Palestinian and European diplomats confirmed today.

title: Businesses Shut by Accidents Ruled Ineligible for Damages
description: On Dec. 7, 1997, John Whaley had finished his lunch at Burger Heaven and was strolling down Madison Avenue toward his shop, 5th Avenue Chocolatiere, when the sky fell. ''I thought somebody had bombed us,'' he said. ''It was noise and confusion and people bleeding and people running and screaming and so much dust I couldn't see.''

title: Welcome to New York. Watch Those Potholes.
description: WHAT is yellow, has three wheels and a SnoreStop sign on top? A tiny old Reliant, brought here from Britain, is cruising Manhattan as the latest form of mobile advertising.

title: Predawn Police Raid Interrupts Giro d'Italia
description: The prestigious Giro d'Italia bicycling race crashed to a halt in San Remo today after 200 police officers staged a predawn raid on cyclists' hotel rooms and team cars, searching for banned drugs and casting a new shadow over a sport still troubled by a widespread drug scandal at the 1998 Tour de France.

title: Cable Giants Block Rival Ads In Battle for Internet Customers
description: As the battle to provide high-speed Internet service heats up, the cable television giants are increasingly using a defensive tactic: refusing to sell advertising time to phone companies to promote D.S.L., an advanced telephone network technology that competes with cable modems.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a report on the presidential election in Florida by the United States Commission on Civil Rights misspelled the given name of a Florida state senator who commented on the commission's findings. He is Daryl Jones, not Darly.

title: Holik Is Shadowing Sakic, Taking Away His Spotlight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  Bobby Holik, the Devils' resident pulse-taker and designated defensive mastermind, said Wednesday that the ultimate goal can sometimes be a distraction, and the Stanley Cup definitely qualified as a distraction in the hours leading up to Game 6 tonight. Holik was to guard Joe Sakic at least one more time, and Holik has learned this week that there is more to Sakic's game than slashing speed and a trusty shot.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Work To Resume On Center
description: Construction of a Chelsea recreation center that halted under the administration of Abraham D. Beame because of the city's fiscal crisis will resume because of this week's budget agreement between the City Council and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The mayor announced yesterday that construction would resume next week on the $17.5 million center at 430 West 25th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues. After construction stopped in 1976, the site was used for storing files. The center will have a six-lane swimming pool and gymnasium, which are expected to open by December. Denny Lee (NYT)

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Desperate Avalanche Beats Devils to Force Game 7
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  Cheering Devils fans filled Continental Arena with hand-held banners and eager anticipation tonight before Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals. Some spectators brought Champagne for what they hoped would be a celebration of the Devils' second consecutive Stanley Cup championship and third in seven seasons.

title: For Torricelli's Gala, Feverish Calls and Muted Expectations
description: In the Grand Ballroom of the Marriott Glenpointe hotel, matched clusters of red, white and blue balloons tried to brighten the stage. County workers and campaign volunteers, who apparently did not buy their $1,000 tickets to the reception, filled out the crowd. After United States Senator Jon S. Corzine, the more notable politicians on hand included the Hudson County executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, and State Senator Raymond Lesniak of Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRINGI, BARBARA LEVCHUK
description: CARRINGI - Barbara Levchuk. June 6, 2001. Beloved wife of Donald, loving mother of Michael and Mark, beloved daughter of John and Veronica Levchuk, devoted sister of John and his wife Christine. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday June 11th., 9:30am, St. Iganatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St, New York City.

title: Bristol Buying Drug Unit Of DuPont for $7.8 Billion
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company agreed yesterday to acquire the drug business of DuPont for $7.8 billion in cash, bolstering the Bristol-Myers line of AIDS drugs.

title: A Mother Says Goodbye From Both Sides of Death
description: Before a single word is spoken in ''The Last Letter'' -- the one-hour play that Frederick Wiseman adapted from Chapter 18 of Wasily Grossman's Russian novel ''Life and Fate,'' written in the form of a Russian Jewish mother's last letter to her son as she awaits death at the hands of Germans in a Ukrainian ghetto in 1941 -- a white hand reaches out from behind the curtain. It is a hand from beyond the grave. Catherine Samie, the doyenne of La Comdie-Franaise, then follows her hands onto the stage. She moves forward, cups them as if holding her son's head and gives a rapturous performance.

title: South Korea Supports U.S. On New Talks With Its Rival
description: South Korea's foreign minister, Han Seung Soo, said today that the Bush administration's decision to reopen talks with North Korea would help his nation push forward with reconciliation efforts with the reclusive Communist government.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From minivan safety ratings to things that go "clunk," readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: In a Shift, White House Cites Global Warming as a Problem
description: With a new scientific report in hand that reaffirms the reality of global warming, the Bush White House readily acknowledged today that climate change was a problem but gave little clue as to what it intended to do about it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Still Out In Bombing Case
description: The jury deciding whether to impose the death penalty on a Saudi man for his role in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, went home yesterday after a second full day of deliberations without reaching a verdict. In a note to the judge, the jury sought information about the security measures that lawyers say will ensure that the bomber, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24, is not a threat to others in prison if he is spared execution. Prosecutors say that despite such measures, he remains a threat if he is sentenced to life in prison.

title: Mick O'Shea
description: Roebling Hall

title: CENDANT CONFIRMS TALKS TO BUY GALILEO INTERNATIONAL
description: Cendant, a leading franchiser, confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Galileo International, which provides computer reservations systems for travel agencies. Cendant did not disclose terms. The purchase would let Cendant, which franchises Avis rental cars and Ramada hotels, among other products and services, link its WizCom online reservation unit to Galileo's system, which connects 42,000 travel agencies to airlines, hotels and tour operators. Galileo, the No. 2 travel reservation company after Sabre, has lagged its rivals in offering services online to consumers, analysts said.

title: Cosmic Players That Could've Been Stars
description: In the cosmic cast of characters, there are shining stars and an assortment of planets orbiting some of those stars like bit players. And there are very faint objects of intermediate size, brown dwarfs, that have been stepping out of the wings with increasing and mystifying frequency.

title: Moscow Journal; Take Cover, Everybody! Spring, Alas, Is in the Air
description: As each winter draws to a close, the female balsam poplar (P. balsamifera), by far Moscow's most abundant tree, produces hundreds of sticky, sweet-smelling brown buds. Warmed by Russia's brief spring sun, the buds grow into catkins, each containing clusters of light brown, egg-shaped pods. Here are found the poplar's seeds.

title: Making a Network Of Lawyers; Small Firms Find Way To Compete With Giants
description: When his client presented Steven M. Nobil, a lawyer, with a problem involving California labor law, Mr. Nobil had a choice. He could deal with the issue from his office in Cleveland, probably costing the client, White Consolidated Industries, a few hundred extra dollars for legal research, or he could simply refer the question to a California firm.

title: Health Care Prescriptions for Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Aid For Expanding Companies
description: The New York City Industrial Development Agency will help three manufacturing enterprises expand their operations in three boroughs. All the companies plan to add employees. The agency has arranged for $1.5 million in bond financing and $551,000 in real estate and sales tax benefits for Rome Knitting Mills/Orbit Industries for the purchase and outfitting of new quarters in the Westchester Square area of the Bronx. Tri-State Surgical Supply and Equipment and H&H Laboratories, two related companies, are to receive $884,000 in similar tax breaks to buy two buildings in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Bentley Meeker Lighting and Staging is to receive $274,000 in tax benefits to buy and expand its quarters in East Harlem.

title: Devils Like the Prospect of a New Home
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  Reality is three years away but Newark is beckoning and Ken Daneyko has accepted the invitation to dream.

title: McVeigh's Lawyer: He's 'Ready to Die'
description: Timothy J. McVeigh abandoned all efforts to postpone his execution after a federal court rejected his lawyers' most recent appeal.

title: For Jeb Bush, a Likely Re-election Race About Big Brother
description: The Florida governor's race next year is almost certain to be a repeat of Bush versus Gore, though with a different Bush hoping to carry the state.

title: Bad Toe Stands Between The Giants and Hilliard
description: The Giants, together again for the first time since Super Bowl XXXV, today concluded their spring minicamp, a series of spirited drills mixed with daily reminders that the road back to the Super Bowl always seems fraught with distractions and discord.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYCE, GERARD (JERRY) R.
description: BOYCE-Gerard (Jerry) R. A beloved partner in the New York office of Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison LLP, died Monday at the age of 46 after a battle with cancer. Jerry specialized in tax matters involving all aspects of technology and emerging growth companies. He advised clients on tax aspects of complex joint ventures, partnerships, M&A deals, corporate finance and other issues. A partner at Brobeck since 1999, Jerry was well known in the New York legal community, and authored a column on eFinance in the ''New York Law Journal'' since 1993. He also was a frequent lecturer having presented seminars on a variety of topics such as New York Limited Liability Company Law, Advising Growth and Start-up Business, and Tax Aspects of Real Estate Bankruptcy. ''Jerry was a warm, caring person and extremely talented lawyer. He fought his battle with cancer with courage and dignity that inspired us all and made us proud that he was part of our firm. We will miss him greatly'', said Ken King, Managing Partner of Brobeck's New York office. ''In every way Jerry epitomized what it means to be a Brobeck partner'', said James E. Burns, Jr., Brobeck's Managing Partner. ''He made this law firm a better place from the day he arrived, and his passing has left us with a sense of gratitude that we had the opportunity to call him one of our own.'' Jerry was born on September 7, 1954, in Bridgeton, New Jersey. Prior to joining Brobeck, he was a partner at the law firm of Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP. He earned his J.D., cum laude, from Seton Hall University in 1983, and an L.L.M. in taxation from New York University Law School in 1987. He earned his B.A., cum laude, from Fairleigh Dickinson University in 1976. While Jerry was an extremely accomplished lawyer, his colleagues remember him as a dear friend. ''Jerry was a wonderful person in every respect, and he had the important things in life figured out,'' said Chris Johnson, one of his partners at Brobeck. ''He was devoted to his family. He had an effusive passion for living. He listened to problems with sensitivity and empathy, but also had a side-splitting sense of humor. He was charming. He was a moral person who tried always to do the 'right thing.' Most people are lucky to have one of these qualities. Jerry had all of them.'' A Brobeck associate, John Tolpa, had similar memories: ''No matter how busy we were, Jerry always made himself available whenever I wanted to talk. He was interested in getting to know me not only as a working colleague but as a person and friend.'' Not only was Jerry an attorney of great practical business ability, but also one of tremendous integrity and decency. He was a true friend in every respect to his colleagues at Brobeck. All of our lives have been enriched by his cheerful presence.'' said Eric Simonson, another one of his partners at Brobeck. In his spare time, Jerry was an avid participant in motorcycle racing, and also enjoyed golf, working on various home improvement projects, and most importantly, spending time with his family. Jerry was well known within and without Brobeck for his sensitivity and humor. He took particular pleasure in mentoring associates thoroughly and helping his clients navigate the rough waters of rapid growth. Jerry is survived by his wife Anna, children Lauren, Aidan and Garrett and his sisters Peggy Chaplin and Veronica Gunnerson. In Jerry's honor, donations may be made to The Gerard R. Boyce Memorial Racing Fund, in care of Mark Limardo, Esq., Jenkens, Gilchrist, Parker, Chapin LLP, 405 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10174. Funeral arrangements are pending.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Tuckahoe: In Reversal, Budget Passes
description: Tuckahoe's $15.7 million school budget, the same one defeated by voters in May by 43 votes, was passed by a 56-vote margin this week, averting a state-imposed austerity budget that could have meant cuts in staff and programs.
