With telephone canvassing and door-to-door soliciting, parents sought to lift low turnout and sway the vote. The budget passed Tuesday night 767 to 711, the third year in a row that voters reversed themselves after initially defeating the budget. Voters in Mount Pleasant will reconsider its budget on June 18.

title: Boeing Finds Wiring Damage to 10 737's; F.B.I. Is Called In
description: Boeing said today that it had found ''suspicious wire damage'' to as many as 10 737's under assembly at its plant in Renton, Wash., and the Federal Aviation Administration has asked for an F.B.I. investigation.

title: Carpet Ride Continues for Capriati
description: Jennifer Capriati had just left pockmarks in Martina Hingis's confidence, reducing Hingis, the savvy No. 1 player, to a state of confusion today during the semifinals of the French Open.

title: Stanley Kubrick, A Film Odyssey
description: When Warner released seven Stanley Kubrick films on DVD in 1999, their audio and picture quality was not up to par. Now they have been given new digital transfers and Dolby soundtracks and put in a box with Columbia TriStar's special edition of ''Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb'' (1964). The package also includes a new documentary, ''Stanley Kubrick: A Life in Pictures.''

title: Brodeur Beaten But Not Bruised
description: Martin Brodeur dropped his black duffel bag on the wooden podium in the dressing room, but instead it clunked onto his right foot. He had been shrugging off questions about possible injuries to explain, in part, an unimpressive four-goal night.

title: Rwandan Nuns Tried for Massacres in First for War Crimes Court
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium -- Sister Gertrude, once a mother superior, has been in court for seven weeks, listening to grim details about murder in the convent. She has barely moved except to bow her head, which is covered with the brown veil of the Benedictine order.

title: A Search for a Motive in the Violent Death of an Antidrug Activist
description: Wesley Hall, a longtime antidrug activist who, friends said, refused to cede his crime-ridden neighborhood in Jersey City to pushers, was on the phone in his bedroom Wednesday afternoon when someone entered his apartment. He said, ''Hold on,'' and put the phone down.

title: Paul Dietrich, 75, Innovative Architect Of Civic Projects
description: Paul E. Dietrich, an architect and founding member of the firm Cambridge Seven Associates in Cambridge, Mass., died on Saturday at a Boston hospital. He was 75.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You know the honeymoon is over when the smiling face bringing you breakfast at your front door is Tom Daschle.''

title: Sins Forgotten as Shinjo Atones in 9th
description: Tsuyoshi Shinjo plays defense aggressively and without apologies. He was mad at himself on Wednesday when he overthrew the cutoff man, his throw sailing to the right and high. But he believed he had a chance to catch the runner.

title: Fired Producer Settles Lawsuit With CNN
description: A former CNN producer's defamation lawsuit against the network, one of at least five lawsuits filed because of a June 1998 report on a secret Vietnam War-era mission by the United States Army in Laos, has been settled, it was announced yesterday.

title: 5 Police Unions to Fight Bolstering of Review Unit
description: The city's five police unions have prepared court papers to file a lawsuit, possibly as soon as today, to block the Giuliani administration's plan to expand the powers of the independent city agency that evaluates police abuse complaints, officials said yesterday.

title: Memo to Blair: Stand and Deliver
description: Tony Blair is now as powerful as any prime minister Britain has seen, but the support the public gave him in today's election is as conditional as it is overwhelming. Attached to the mighty endorsement is a weighty bill of particulars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JULIA (NEE HENCKEL)
description: LEWIS-Julia (nee Henckel). Born April 12, 1917, of Washington, DC, formerly of Long Beach Island, NJ, died on June 6, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Jerome Shapiro. She is survived by her children Jane, Judi, JeriAnn, Jeffrey, and Joshua Shapiro, and five grandchildren. Graveside burial at Princeton Cemetery on Friday, June 8, at 2 PM.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Pursuing Ex-Dictator
description: A judge has authorized that a request be made to Brazil for the extradition of former President Alfredo Stroessner. Now 88 and ailing, General Stroessner has lived in exile in Brazil since he was overthrown in 1989, and is accused of encouraging the torture and killing of political opponents during his 35 years of dictatorial rule.

title: Sorry, Pilgrims, No Absolution
description: Portraying a pair of guilt-crippled American tourists in John Guare's ''Chaucer in Rome,'' Polly Holliday and Dick Latessa give off the harsh clarity of certain black-and-white photographs. Think of Walker Evans's stark Depression-era portraits filtered through Diane Arbus's eye for the inner freak in everyone.

title: The Housing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Strike At Pepsi Bottler
description: Six hundred and fifty Pepsi Bottling Group employees spent their seventh day on strike yesterday against four New Jersey bottling plants. The Teamsters in Local 125, for plants in Piscataway, Moonachie, Asbury Park and East Hanover, walked out last Friday after their contract expired and negotiations on a new one failed. A union spokesman said that on May 31, after six years of legal wrangling over overtime pay, the union rejected a company proposal to offer back overtime wages in return for lower sales commissions. A company spokeswoman, Kelly McAndrew, said that there were a number of issues involved and that the company was continuing to serve all of its customers. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Phillips Puts Modernism In Its Portfolio
description: Phillips has now re-entered the field of 20th-century decorative arts with its auction in Manhattan on Monday of works by the ''Pioneers of American Modernism.'' The 176-lot sale represents work by a who's who of modern architects, industrial designers and craftsmen, from Louis Sullivan to Edward Durrell Stone to George Nakashima.

title: I.B.M. Stretches Silicon in New Ways to Speed Up Chips
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has figured out how to stretch silicon during standard semiconductor manufacturing, a development that is expected to allow it to start making faster, less power-hungry versions of a wide variety of microchips within two years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reorganization At Reuters
description: Reuters, the financial news company, said that it would scrap its product business units and reorganize around customer lines, including investment banking and brokerage, treasury, asset management and media. The new structure will be set in place when Tom Glocer, left, succeeds Peter Job as chief executive after Job's retirement in July. Reuters also named Philip Green, who heads its information and trading divisions, to the newly created post of chief operating officer. Geoff Weetman, chief executive of Reuterspace, and Jean-Claude Marchand, marketing director, will retire. Reuters warned in April that its growth would slow in the second quarter.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONSWORLDCOM PLAN APPROVED Shareholders of WorldCom voted yesterday to approve a restructuring that would separate the telecommunications company's stagnant long-distance business from its faster-growing data, Internet and international operations. WorldCom said a tracking stock for the old-line consumer long-distance business would be issued under the MCI Group name and MCIT ticker symbol. The company's existing stock symbol, WCOM, will reflect the performance of its core data, Internet, Web-site operating, corporate telephone and international businesses. Both stocks start trading today on the Nasdaq stock exchange. WorldCom first announced plans last November to segregate its struggling voice division from the others. Bernard J. Ebbers, WorldCom's president and chief executive, said the new structure provides "two distinct, clear and compelling investment opportunities, while serving customer needs."

title: Zambrano Fined And Suspended
description: MetroStars Coach Octavio Zambrano expected to be fined for criticizing the league and its referees, but Major League Soccer caught him by surprise yesterday. Not only was Zambrano fined $2,000, but he was also suspended for the MetroStars' next game, at Washington on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, SYLVIA
description: LEHMAN-Sylvia. Beloved mother of Marsha Quinn and Dana Groner and Stephen and Susan Lehman. Dear sister of Bess Zash, adored grandmother of Lisa Mathis, Stacey Dickman, T.J. Quinn, Katherine Quinn and Sarah Quinn. Cherished great grandmother of Dylan, Jake, Mackenzie, Blake, Liam, Eleanor, Ally and Madeline. Services today 1PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPNICK, IRVING
description: CHAPNICK-Irving. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of Irving Chapnick, past President of Temple Sinai. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Funeral at Temple Sinai, Friday, June 8, 1 PM Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Toni Wiener, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Treaty On Space Arms Proposed
description: China urged the 66 member countries of the United Nations Disarmament Conference in Geneva to begin negotiations on a treaty to ban weapons in outer space. China's envoy, Hu Xiaodi, told the group that American plans for a missile shield make the militarization of space ''an imminent danger,'' and urged countries to bar ''all space-based weapons and all weapons attacking outer space targets from earth.'' China proposed the treaty on the day Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld was in Brussels to try to sell the Bush administration plan to skeptical European allies. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEGEY, JEAN RICHARD
description: LIEGEY-Jean Richard. 72, died June 3, 2001. Born in Far Rockaway, NY, formerly of Stamford, CT, and a resident of Plantation, FL. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Angela, and their four children, four grandchildren, and many brothers and sisters. A Funeral Mass was held on June 6, 2001, at St. Gregory Church in Plantation. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall.

title: Reports Of Shortage Of Vodka Are Untrue
description: The headline in Izvestia might as well have said the world was ending. ''Vodka Factories Are at a Standstill All Across the Country,'' the newspaper bellowed yesterday, and panicky drinkers responded by crowding the Kristall factory store here and carting home vodka by the case.

title: City Coalition In Berlin Falls; Communists May Get Role
description: Eleven years after the collapse of East Germany and the fall of the Berlin Wall, the once-disgraced Communists could be on the verge of a comeback in Berlin's city administration.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Date Set For Election Showdown
description: Parliament set Sept. 9 as the date for a long-anticipated presidential election, setting the stage for a contest between the nation's authoritarian president, Aleksandr Lukashenko, and pro-democracy parties that have pledged to unite behind a single candidate. Mr. Lukashenko, who was elected in 1994 and has warned that Belarus will descend into chaos if his rule ends, has been accused of illegally prolonging his term through a sham constitutional referendum, but he remains popular among peasants. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: California Gets a Reprieve as Power Prices Fall
description: After months of baleful forecasts about California's worsening energy situation, the outlook has changed markedly, at least for the moment. Electricity prices in California have fallen sharply in the past two weeks, giving the state its first breathing room since a year ago.

title: Jordan Return a Hot Topic
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7  The topic made its way around the court today, and everybody had an opinion. Can Michael Jordan at age 38 compete with the N.B.A.'s young turks if he decides to play next season?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cable Giants Refuse to Sell Ads to Internet Competitors

title: A Veteran's Long Journey on the Front Line of AIDS
description: Take it from one who knows: there is no surer way to stop a party conversation cold than to tell a group of friendly strangers that you have spent a good fraction of the last 20 years taking care of people with AIDS.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Suspicious Hospital Deaths
description: Investigators will begin exhuming 10 bodies next week near Nocona, a small town northwest of Dallas, after officials at Nocona General Hospital reported a suspicious doubling of deaths in December and January. The authorities believe that as many as two dozen patients at the 39-bed hospital may have been given fatal doses of Mivacron, a drug used to stop the breathing process temporarily. Tim Cole, the Montague County district attorney, described the 10 bodies to be exhumed as those that were most likely to yield the drug when autopsied. No one has been arrested, but a former nurse at the hospital has been named in two suits filed against the hospital by families of patients who died. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: So Kissy-Kissy, and Then So Sharky
description: An articulate, acutely observant film like ''The Anniversary Party'' makes you realize how starved Hollywood movies are for great ensemble acting. An anthropologically detailed study of a contemporary Hollywood party that runs mildly amok, the movie has such finely woven performances that the best scenes project a convincing illusion of spontaneity.

title: A New Offer for Finova Bailout
description: The Finova Group's bonds rose today after the GE Capital Corporation and the Goldman Sachs Group sweetened the terms of the bailout offer they made to creditors of Finova two weeks ago.

title: Loyal to Two Cultures, From Chicano Roots To a New Ambiguity
description: In the spring of 1993, the traveling exhibition ''Chicano Art: Resistance and Affirmation, 1965-1985'' came to the Bronx Museum of the Arts. It opened around the same time as that year's Whitney Biennial, the political biennial that got everyone so ticked off with its emphasis on race and gender and its ''I can't imagine ever wanting to be white'' admission buttons.

title: Brown Won't Discuss Future
description: Since Larry Brown took a brief, fatigue-induced sabbatical from coaching the Philadelphia 76ers this season, speculation has been rampant that he will retire soon. Brown, who has four years and $26 million remaining on his contract, did nothing to quell the rumors today, saying that he will make a decision at the end of the N.B.A. finals against the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Lots of Finger-Pointing Over Mercury in Cars
description: WHAT do your car's high-intensity headlamps, antilock brake system, navigation screen and trunk- or hood-mounted light switches have in common? All may contain mercury, a highly toxic element.

title: Nescaf Starts Interactive Campaign
description: Nestl in Vevey, Switzerland, is introducing its first worldwide integrated communications campaign for Nescaf instant coffee, with spending estimated at $30 million, aimed at turning consumers ages 16 to 24 into users of the brand.

title: June 11: McVeigh and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Argentine President Arrested in Arms Conspiracy
description: Former President Carlos Saul Menem, whose 10 years in office were marked by sweeping economic reform but also by reports of government corruption, was placed under house arrest today by a federal judge investigating his involvement in a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995.

title: Sports of The Times; It's About Peace, Love and Triangle Offense
description: COACH PHIL here, checking in for my annual meditative chat with my favorite newspaper's worthy-of-me readership, and what better time when so many of you must be wondering, is he O.K.?

title: Death Sentence Overturned For Killer of Deliverymen
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday overturned the death sentence of one of two young men who ambushed and killed two pizza deliverymen four years ago on a dark road in northwestern New Jersey.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxurious Lofts Rising on Angled Lots in Chelsea
description: At first glance, the loft condominium buildings about to rise on 17th and 18th Street in Chelsea will appear to have little relation to one another, looking more like distant cousins, say, than siblings.

title: Coloring the Troops: Uniforms Become Cultural Touchstones
description: As the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, the venerable alternative space in Long Island City, Queens, approaches its 25th anniversary, things seem to be getting better almost all the time.

title: Yo, Adrian, Do 76ers Really Have a Shot?
description: ''Rocky'' is playing L.A. this week, rereleased by a bunch of woozy pugs from Broad Street.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Nominee Returns Donations
description: Mark L. Earley, the Republican nominee for governor, has returned $47,000 in contributions from the president of a software company whose clients include pornographic Internet sites. A spokesman for Mr. Earley, who resigned as state attorney general on Monday to campaign full time, said contributions from the businessman, Bruce M. Waldack, president of Thruport Technologies, had been sent back to ''avoid the appearance of impropriety and keep this issue from becoming a distraction in this campaign.''

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Monica Au, creative director at the Hong Kong office of Landor Associates, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, was named to the new post of client managing director and general manager. Vincenzo Perri, associate creative director, succeeds Ms. Au as creative director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAGLIAN, BARBARA F.
description: DAGLIAN-Barbara F. On June 5, 2001. Beloved mother of Lisa, Ara Paul, grandmother of Ara Paul, Jr. and Katie, sister of Georgia Messemer. Yankee fan and friend to many, died peacefully to join her parents, friends and favorite pets in heaven. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 8, 4-6:30PM, Cornell Club, 6 E. 44 St. Expressions of memories are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, RUTH C.
description: HOFFMAN-Ruth C. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Devoted mother of Kenneth L. and Harlan S. Dear sister of Zelma Bernstein. Loving grandmother of three, greatgrandmother of two. Private services will be held by Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, NJ.

title: France on Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Software Glitch Halts Trading on New York Stock Exchange
description: By ALEX BERENSON

title: For Yankees, Lapses May Lead to Changes
description: The Yankees need something, but club officials are torn in defining exactly what it is. Orlando Hernandez may return in a month but nobody really knows how good he will be when he comes back, so there is a hole in the rotation. Manager Joe Torre has used two relievers, Mariano Rivera and Mike Stanton, for a workload shouldered by three relievers last year, so there has been a season-long need for a reliever.

title: Health Care Prescriptions for Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATEAU IS BUYING CWS COMMUNITIES FOR $390 MILLION
description: Chateau Communities Inc., a leading owner of manufactured-home communities, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CWS Communities Trust for $390 million in cash and stock. Chateau will also assume $180 million in debt. CWS, a real estate investment trust based in Dallas, has 16,600 home sites mostly in Florida, Georgia and Texas. The Security Capital Group, a real estate investment firm based in Santa Fe, N.M., agreed to sell its 94 percent stake in CWS to Chateau for $290 million. Chateau is based in Greenwood Village, Colo.

title: Bloomberg Says Elections Should Be Nonpartisan
description: Michael R. Bloomberg called yesterday for a fundamental change in the way New York City elects its mayor, saying the city should eliminate political parties from the process and adopt nonpartisan elections. Mr. Bloomberg said the change would diminish what he asserted was the coercive influence of the Democratic and Republican politics on city government.

title: Badillo Opens Another Run For Mayor
description: After a record-setting political career that many believed dormant, Herman Badillo announced yesterday that he, too, wanted the city's top job.

title: Article 2001060891322056103 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: A Stern Warning on Warming
description: A National Academy of Sciences report reaffirming the threat of global warming, and declaring fearlessly that human activity is largely responsible for it, virtually requires President Bush to engage an issue he has consistently underestimated. It also provides another compelling reason for his administration to rewrite an unbalanced energy strategy that relies far too heavily on producing more of the same fossil fuels that lie at the root of the warming problem.

title: Wedding Anniversary Discount in Colorado
description: Through Dec. 31, guests celebrating a wedding anniversary at the Cliff House at Pikes Peak, a historic hotel in Manitou Springs, at the base of Pikes Peak, Colo. And the longer the marriage, the cheaper the room. The percentage of the discount  off the regular double-occupancy rates of $129 to $400 a night -- is based on number of years married (champagne and strawberries are also included). A marriage certificate is required to verify that the stay includes the anniversary date. The hotel, built in 1873, features 19th century Victorian architecture and such modern amenities as gas fireplaces and a wet bar. Contact (719) 685-3000 or www.thecliffhouse.com .

title: Home Video: Stanley Kubrick, a Film Odyssey
description: When Warner released seven Stanley Kubrick films on DVD in 1999, their audio and picture quality was not up to par. Now they have been given new digital transfers and Dolby soundtracks and put in a box with Columbia TriStar's special edition of "Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb" (1964). The package also includes a new documentary, "Stanley Kubrick: A Life in Pictures."

title: Pamela Robertson, -- Astronaut, 38
description: Dr. Pamela Hilliard Robertson, a rookie astronaut, died on May 24 from injuries sustained two days earlier in a small-plane crash. She was 38.

title: Lothar Baumgarten
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Leaving The House
description: Representative Steve Largent, a fourth-term Republican conservative, made it official: He will give up his House seat on Nov. 29 to run for governor next year. His district, centered in Tulsa, is heavily Republican, and so his departure poses little threat to the narrow Republican hold on the House. Among Republicans expected to vie in a special election to succeed him is Cathy Keating, wife of Gov. Frank Keating. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about campaigns in Northern Ireland for the British parliamentary elections misstated the surname of a councilman in the town of Kilkeel. He is Harvey Bicker, not Bickman.

title: Devils Fumble Chance at Cup
description: Cheering Devils fans filled Continental Arena with hand-held banners and eager anticipation tonight before Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals. Some spectators brought Champagne for what they hoped would be a celebration of the Devils' second consecutive Stanley Cup championship and third in seven seasons.

title: INSIDE
description: Japanese Children Slain

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, JOHN H., M.D.
description: McGOVERN-John H., M.D. The Department of Urology at Weill Medical College of Cornell University profoundly mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, John H. McGovern, M.D. Dr. McGovern was internationally recognized for his contributions to urology, especially in the field of pediatric urology. He also served as President of the American Urological Association. Dr. McGovern was a vital contributor to the Department of Urology at New York Presbyterian Hospital for over 40 years as both a practitioner and teacher. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Mary Alice and their sons. Memorial services are scheduled at 11 AM, on Monday, June 11, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave and 84th St. E. Darracott Vaughan Jr., M.D. Chairman, Department of Urology

title: Intruder Kills at Least 7 Japanese Students
description: In a crime of rare violence for this country, at least 7 schoolchildren were killed and more than 20 other people -- almost all of them children -- wounded today when an apparently deranged man burst into an elite elementary school in a suburb of Osaka and began stabbing students with a kitchen knife, the police and fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALDAHL, WESLEY G.
description: KALDAHL-Wesley G. ''Wes.'' Age 76, passed away in Dallas, TX, on June 6, 2001. He was formerly of Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 AM, Saturday, June 9, 2001, at All Saints Catholic Church in Dallas. Entombment will follow in Calvary Hill Cemetery in Dallas. For more information, call Sparkman/Dickey Funeral Home at 972-407-6070.

title: Foreign Affairs; Solving for C
description: So here's an interesting question that you hear around Europe these days: What will the Bush foreign policy be? No, no -- not what was it during the campaign, not what was it for its first 100 days, but what will it really be?

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Pact For Mickey And Minnie
description: Disney World employees who dress as Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and other characters have reached a tentative contract that allows them to wear their own undergarments. In the past, those workers, who are represented by the Teamsters union, complained that they had to wear Disney-issued undergarments, like tights and athletic supporters, tailored not to bunch up under their costumes. The workers turned in the clothing each night and picked up a different set the next day, and several said they had been afflicted by lice and scabies from wearing other people's underclothes that had not been properly cleaned. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Wheaties Inflation Indicator: Will Price Increases Stick?
description: CHEERIOS prices are up. So are AT&T's basic rates. President Bush wants to protect the steel industry.

title: Article 2001060892210326657 -- No Title
Addenda: Feuding Agencies Settle Differences
description: Abitter legal battle between a giant public relations agency and employees who left to start their own shop in Atlanta has been settled.

title: Maximum Prison Term for Killer of Social Worker
description: A judge sentenced a Brooklyn man yesterday to the maximum prison term of 25 years to life for the fatal stabbing of Amy Watkins, a graduate student from Kansas who was killed on her way home from the subway in March 1999.

title: Health Care Prescriptions for Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Reinventing the Lens For Large Abstractions
description: With or without a camera, artists have long been able to produce photographic images of startling abstraction. The cameraless photogram, for which an artist places objects on photosensitive paper and exposes them to light, has had an enigmatic allure since the earliest days of photography. Using normal cameras and lenses, photographers have also been adept at creating pictures so abstract that their subjects elude the viewer.

title: Why the Democrats Wobble in the South
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Bank Burglary
description: After months of wiretaps, satellite-assisted snooping and surveillance, the F.B.I. and city police caught a team of sophisticated burglars early yesterday as they tried to cut their way through the roof of a Brooklyn bank, officials said. Five men were arrested about 1 a.m. as they tried to cut a hole through the roof of the North Fork Bank branch at 95-02 Third Avenue in Bay Ridge. Two others were arrested later. They were each charged with conspiracy to commit bank burglary. Although they were charged only in connection with the attempted break-in early yesterday, court papers filed in the case accuse them of seven thefts and attempted thefts since December.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: More Turmoil In Congress
description: After a failed attempt to declare a monthlong recess, the president of the country's one-chamber congress, Hugo Quevedo, has resigned rather than face a vote intended to replace him on charges of corruption and administrative incompetence. The action comes with Congress's approval rating at an all-time low and follows recent incidents in which fistfights broke out during legislative sessions and tear gas was released during a debate on a disputed tax measure. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Why the Democrats Wobble in the South
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Victims in Ulster
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Remains Cautious Amid Conflicting Industry Reports
description: The Intel Corporation, a closely watched bellwether of the semiconductor industry, said today that it was on target to meet revenue projections for the quarter, but that it saw no indication that the industry had hit its nadir.

title: A Murder Mystery Bound Up With the Killing of Souls
description: TWO MURDERS IN MY DOUBLE LIFE

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Under the Sea, Damp Hakuna Matata
description: Atlantis exists in pop mythology as the ultimate demi-paradise, the kingdom of Aquaman and Prince Namor, the Submariner. It's posited as the Garden of Eden, but an Eden given a chance to spawn a population and create a fabric of enlightenment before crumbling under the weight of greed and ambition. You know, Disney World.

title: British Air and American Push for Alliance
description: The American Airlines unit of the AMR Corporation and British Airways P.L.C. are renewing efforts with the United States and British governments for antitrust immunity to closely coordinate their trans-Atlantic flights and ticket prices, AMR's chief executive, Don Carty, said.

title: Once a Mess, Canal Aspires To Beauty Now
description: Like most people who spend their days on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, a two-mile stretch of water that starts at the mouth of New York Harbor and dead-ends in South Brooklyn, Dan Kinney used to run for cover when barges came through, kicking up the putrid refuse that had settled on the bottom.

title: Power Play Provides No Early Advantage
description: The Avalanche's Dave Reid skated slowly to the penalty box as the organist at Continental Arena pushed the keys hard, playing the theme from ''Dragnet'' as if Reid were headed to the state penitentiary.

title: World Briefing | World: United Nations: $1 Million For AIDS Fund
description: A Swiss bank plans to announce today that it will give more than $1 million to the United Nations global fund for AIDS, the first such donation from an institution other than a government. The bank, Credit Suisse, plans to make that donation and also support training institutions and other projects, United Nations officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 20 Charged With Prostitution
description: A sweep of escort services led to the arrests of 12 women and eight men on charges of prostitution and promoting prostitution, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday. During a nine-month inquiry, undercover detectives telephoned escort services advertised in Russian-language newspapers and were directed to private houses in Bensonhurst, Brighton Beach and other neighborhoods, Mr. Hynes said. Some of the suspected prostitutes, pimps and madams, all of whom were arrested Wednesday, carried Russian, Chilean or Israeli passports, Mr. Hynes said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: New Offer For Legrand
description: The French electrical goods company, Schneider Electric, sweetened its offer for nonvoting shares in its domestic rival Legrand, to overcome objections by a French court that its $7 billion bid for Legrand, begun earlier this year, was illegal because it valued voting and nonvoting shares inequitably. The court ruled last month in favor of minority shareholders who sued to block the deal, arguing that it favored holders of Legrand's ordinary shares, which enjoy voting rights but lack the preferred dividend of the nonvoting shares. Schneider said the new offer, under which holders of nonvoting Legrand shares would receive two shares of Schneider plus a 55 euro payment, would cost it 363 million euros ($308 million) more than the original bid. Schneider said it would sell assets to raise the money. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: REGUS DEAL TO BUY FRONTLINE FALLS APART AS STOCK DROPS
description: Regus P.L.C., a British provider of temporary office space, ended talks to acquire the FrontLine Capital Group, a real estate investment company, after Regus's shares fell on news of the proposed deal. Regus, which is based in Chertsey, England, and owns 360 business centers in 50 countries, said Monday that it was in talks to buy FrontLine and its HQ Global Workplaces unit, the largest provider of temporary office space in the United States. A 15 percent decline in Regus's stock price the day the talks were announced ''threw off all the valuation exchange ratios'' for the proposed purchase, said Scott H. Rechler, chief executive of FrontLine, which is based in New York.

title: Forest Chief Will Make Logging Decisions
description: The chief of the Forest Service announced today that he would decide on logging and road building in a large expanse of the national forest system pending the outcome of legal disputes about the future of forest land.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Officers For Puerto Rico Parade
description: More police officers will be assigned to the National Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday in the wake of scores of sexual assaults last year. A police official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said more officers would be assigned, particularly in Central Park, the site of last year's assaults. The official said rooftop surveillance would help spot trouble and the city's alcohol ban would be more strictly enforced. Meanwhile, 12 women who were assaulted last year filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, seeking $960 million in damages from the city and the police for failing to prevent the melee. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, HAROLD, CPA.
description: PARKER-Harold, CPA. Of Hartsdale, NY, on June 5, 2001. Cherished husband of Miriam for 57 years. Loving father of Stuart, Brian and Robert. Dear brother of Violet and the late Rhea. Cherished grandfather of Dara, Tracy, Jessie, Amanda and Michael. Beloved father-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle and dear friend to many. He was deeply loved. Services Friday, 12 noon, Zion Memorial Chapel on Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck. The family will receive friends at the Parker residence during the afternoon and evening from Sunday through Tuesday.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: RADIO STATIONS SOLD Millennium Radio Group says it has agreed to buy three New Jersey stations, increasing its total in the state to six. Millennium, which is a partnership formed by UBS Capital Americas and Mercury Capital Partners, will acquire WKXW-FM (101.5) in Trenton, which reaches a large geographic area; WBUD-AM (1260) in Trenton; and WBSS-FM (97.3) in Corbin City for $110 million. All three were sold to Millennium by Press Communications. The deal is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: A Feverish Thriller That Leaves No Car Unturned
description: No Hollywood action thriller has begun quite like ''Swordfish,'' in which a cocky John Travolta, smirking at the camera, offers a jauntily erudite and cynical analysis of ''Dog Day Afternoon.'' It is such a nervy (not to mention critic-massaging) opening gambit that for a tantalizing moment this high-tech spy yarn looks to be one of the brighter progeny of ''Pulp Fiction.''

title: Jonathan Meese
description: Leo Koenig

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: A Bikini? . . . Maybe
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowman Will Return as Coach of Red Wings
description: DETROIT, June 7 (AP)  Scotty Bowman has always said he will know when it's time to step away from the bench.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: A Warning To Clergymen
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the country's military ruler, called on Islamic clergymen to stop making what he said were irresponsible statements about India that harm Muslims there and cause others to call Pakistan a terrorist state. India's prime minister welcomed the general's statements. The leaders of these hostile nations are to meet next month.

title: Jury Awards $6.4 Million In Killings Tied to Drug
description: A Wyoming jury has awarded $6.4 million to the family of a man who killed three relatives and himself after taking the antidepressant Paxil.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Middlefield: Sexual Harassment Complaint
description: Women who work at a popular attraction in Middlefield have complained to a state agency that the company tolerated a male manager's persistent sexual harassment and promoted him despite their complaints. Eighteen women left their jobs at the tourist site, Lyman Farm, known for apple-picking and pony rides, to protest the company's response, said Linda Cameron, a former customer service manager. The State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities said it was investigating. The accused manager, Frank Cavaliere, has since left Lyman and could not be reached for comment.

title: Irish Voters Strongly Reject European Union Expansion
description: DUBLIN, June 8  In a serious political embarrassment for the Irish government, figures released today showed that voters had forcefully rejected a treaty that would expand membership of the European Union.

title: The Day the Locks Stood Still
description: ALL it the Case of the Keyless Locks: For several days in March, the keyless entry systems of cars in Bremerton, Wash., stopped working. Auto dealers and parking attendants say they stopped simultaneously, as if turned off by a switch.

title: Public Interests; Going for the Gold
description: Every day, somewhere in the United States, an extremely rich person wakes up in his or her extremely large bedroom and decides that it is time to Give Something Back by running for a public office of great prestige and power.

title: U.N. Officials Revive Plan to Return Serbian Refugees to Kosovo
description: International officials in Kosovo, who are under pressure to show results, are reconsidering a plan to return Serbian refugees to the province despite shelving the idea last year because of security concerns.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit Up At Food Concern
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the large Dutch food distributor, said first-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, buoyed by acquisitions in the United States and Europe. In the 16 weeks to April 22, the company earned 316 million euros ($268 million), or 37 cents a share, compared with 230.2 million euros, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue jumped 66 percent, to 18 billion euros, compared with 11 billion euros last year. Ahold became the second-largest food distributor in the United States when it bought U.S. Foodservice last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: After the Tonys, Moving Vans

title: Metro Business Briefing | Radio Stations Sold
description: Millennium Radio Group says it has agreed to buy three New Jersey stations, increasing its total in the state to six. Millennium, which is a partnership formed by UBS Capital Americas and Mercury Capital Partners, will acquire WKXW-FM (101.5) in Trenton, which reaches a large geographic area; WBUD-AM (1260) in Trenton; and WBSS-FM (97.3) in Corbin City for $110 million. All three were sold to Millennium by Press Communications. The deal is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Senate Democrats to Press Inquiry Into High Energy Prices
description: With Democrats now in control of the Senate, its main investigating committee will focus on high energy prices. That will include conducting an inquiry into whether the federal agency that regulates electricity markets has been properly enforcing the law.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: New Video Releases
description: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

title: Article 2001060890361149539 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Stephen Wilkes -- 'Ellis Island'
description: SoHo Triad Fine Arts

title: Broadway's Electric Conductors
description: A ONE, a two, a one-two-three!'' With that time-honored call to musical arms, ''The Full Monty's'' pop overture is off and pulsing. And so is Kimberly Grigsby. Hips twitching, toes tapping, hands slicing the air, she does not merely conduct the music. She becomes the music, like one of those novelty-store mechanical flowers that shake, rattle and roll to the strains of a Top 40 tune.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about Web sites that allow users to store files online misstated the cost of one site, Xdrive. Its basic service costs $4.95 a month; it is not free.

title: Arrest Made in Sex Killing of Morristown Boy
description: A 36-year-old landscape worker was arrested today and charged with the kidnapping, sexual assault and murder of a third-grade boy who vanished on May 20 after attending a church carnival near his home, the authorities said tonight.

title: Trevino's Priorities Have Changed
description: CLIFTON, N.J., June 7  Lee Trevino has only one victory in the last three years on the Senior PGA Tour, and the reason, he says, is that the game is no longer his top priority. Trevino's preference in life these days is taking his kids to school, picking them up afterward and going fishing in between.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Warns Sales Are Slipping
description: A maker of hand-held computers, Handspring, said sales for the current quarter will be half of forecasts as demand slumps and as the company cuts prices to compete with its rival, Palm. Sales for the fiscal fourth quarter ending June 30 will be $60 million to $65 million, Handspring said, substantially below analysts' average forecast of $121.3 million. The company has reduced prices of some Visor devices to match price cuts from Palm, which is trying to clear excess inventory. Demand for hand-held computers has also weakened with the declining economy. Yesterday, Handspring introduced a promotion offering $100 off the price of a Visor Edge for any buyer who turns in a hand-held computer for recycling, effectively reducing the price to $299. Its shares slipped 10 cents, to $8.90.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about campaigns in Northern Ireland for the British parliamentary elections misstated the surname of a councilman in the town of Kilkeel. He is Harvey Bicker, not Bickman.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Some restaurants hire consultants and big-name designers to create a personality. Others simply have one. D'Artagnan Restaurant and Rotisserie not only has personality, it has character. It is odd, even a little goofy, and utterly sincere in its devotion to the products and the cooking of one of France's least-known, least-touristed regions, Gascony. As the restaurant's name suggests, it is the home of a fiery hero in ''The Three Musketeers,'' and, more important to diners, a region devoted to foie gras, armagnac, ducks, prunes and unabashed calorie consumption.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Stricter Cell-Phone Law
description: Nassau County has passed into law a ban on drivers' cell-phone use with a twist: it also outlaws dialing while driving. The law is one notch stricter than those of its neighbors in Suffolk and Westchester Counties, which ban talking on a hand-held cell phone while driving in an effort to reduce driver distractions. Drivers in Nassau, however, can turn cell phones on or off. Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, signed the bill on Tuesday. The law will go into effect on July 1 and carries fines of up to $100 for violators. Al Baker (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Pep Talk From Christie's

title: In Europe, Aircraft Unit Hampers G.E. Deal
description: As General Electric and European regulators enter a final round of meetings over the proposed acquisition of Honeywell International, the chief obstacle to approval of the deal appears to be G.E.'s aircraft-leasing division.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 26 about the visit of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to South Africa, and his meetings there with AIDS patients, misstated the nature of Washington's recent $200 million contribution to efforts to fight AIDS and other diseases worldwide. The Bush administration recently said it would contribute that sum to a United Nations fund; it has not set up its own global trust fund to fight infectious diseases.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Plan Approved
description: Shareholders of WorldCom voted yesterday to approve a restructuring that would separate the telecommunications company's stagnant long-distance business from its faster-growing data, Internet and international operations. WorldCom said a tracking stock for the old-line consumer long-distance business would be issued under the MCI Group name and MCIT ticker symbol. The company's existing stock symbol, WCOM, will reflect the performance of its core data, Internet, Web-site operating, corporate telephone and international businesses. Both stocks start trading today on the Nasdaq stock exchange. WorldCom first announced plans last November to segregate its struggling voice division from the others. Bernard J. Ebbers, WorldCom's president and chief executive, said the new structure provides ''two distinct, clear and compelling investment opportunities, while serving customer needs.''

title: Devils 2001: The Playoffs
description: Here is an archive of game stories from the Devils' 2001 postseason.

title: She Was the Fairest by Far, Ask Franz, Gustav or Oskar
description: ''I think his music is much better than it sounds,'' declares Gustav Klimt early in Bruce Beresford's ''Bride of the Wind.'' The painter (August Schmlzer), who serves as a jovial tour guide through the artistic ferment of early-20th-century Vienna, is not plagiarizing Mark Twain's famous remark about Wagner, but rather delivering his own verdict on the work of Gustav Mahler to Mahler's future wife, Alma Schindler.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRW INC., Cleveland, an automotive-parts maker that is shifting emphasis to information and telecommunications systems, has agreed to buy Network Six, Warwick, R.I., an information-technology company that specializes in child care, for $5.3 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: American's Drug Sentence Cut
description: A court in the southwest city of Voronezh reduced to one year from 37 months the prison sentence of a 24-year-old American scholar, John Edward Tobin, who was convicted in April on marijuana-related charges. The court said Mr. Tobin would be sent to a prison camp in Mordovia, south of Moscow, within six days. Mr. Tobin, a Fulbright scholar who was studying at Voronezh State University, has said he was framed by the police; Russian officials have suggested that he may be granted a pardon should he request one.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Premier Undergoes Surgery
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee successfully underwent surgery to replace his arthritic right knee at a hospital in Bombay and is expected to spend the next 10 days recuperating there. He had his left knee replaced in October.

title: T. C. Tsao, 99, Educator, Dies; Aided Taiwan Technical College
description: Tsen-cha Tsao, an engineer and educator who helped recreate one of China's leading institutions of higher learning on Taiwan, died on May 23 at home on the Upper East Side. He was 99.

title: Sixers Conspire to Give Albert's Return a Glow
description: If N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern wants to investigate and quash conspiracies, he should look no further than Wednesday's 107-101 victory by the Philadelphia 76ers over the Los Angeles Lakers in Game 1 of the finals. The result ended the Lakers' 19-game winning streak, confounded those who thought the Sixers were suitable carrion to be swallowed up in four games, made a star of the Lakers reserve guard Tyronn Lue and gave NBC the prospect of higher ratings.

title: Assault Victims Sue Over Parade Safety
description: Lawyers for 12 young women who were sexually assaulted after last year's National Puerto Rican Day Parade filed suit yesterday against the city, several senior police officials and 30 police officers for failing to prevent the melee.

title: Ilmari Tapiovaara
description: R20th Century

title: Correction: Consumer Spending
'Divided We Fall'
description: Directed by Jan Hrebejk

title: 'Let It Snow'
description: Directed by Adam Marcus

title: Lukas Returns, Followed by Ex-Assistants
description: One colt hails from Kentucky and the barn of a Hall of Fame trainer, the other is Irish-bred and conditioned by an Irish trainer. But Buckle Down Ben and Dr Greenfield have much in common: both will make their first appearance in the 2001 Triple Crown series tomorrow and are considered the least likely to capture the 133rd running of the Belmont Stakes, at least according to the morning line odds, which list them at 30-1.

title: Bourque Delivers the Speech, and Roy the Shutout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 7  Knute Rockne it was not. But with his Colorado Avalanche one defeat from elimination in the Stanley Cup finals, Ray Bourque felt he had to stand up and say something to his teammates before Game 6 tonight.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Wednesday by Joey B. Pressley, executive director of the New York AIDS Coalition, about AIDS among blacks, omitted a word from one sentence. The sentence should have read, ''The message can no longer simply be 'use a condom every time.' ''

title: ROCKWELL TO CUT 1,000 JOBS AS EARNINGS FORECAST FALLS
description: Rockwell International, the largest maker of factory-automation equipment, reduced its fiscal third-quarter earnings forecast to 45 cents a share and said it would eliminate 1,000 jobs because of slowing sales. The company, which expects automation sales to drop 15 percent, said it would take $50 million in pretax charges to cut the jobs and close plants. Sales are expected to be flat until the second half of the 2002 fiscal year, its chief executive, Donald H. Davis Jr., said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected Rockwell to earn 82 cents a share in the third quarter. Plans to spin off its Rockwell Collins avionics unit on June 29 remain on track.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLUEWEISS, HERBERT
description: BLUEWEISS-Herbert. I think about you and miss you every day. Your friend, Mort

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit Up At Luxury Retailer
description: The Swiss luxury group Financire Richemont A.G. said its operating profit for the year ended March 31, 2001, rose 33 percent, to $608 million, bolstered by the sales of jewelry and its high-end watches, which include Baume & Mercier, Piaget and Officine Panerai. The group, which also owns brand names like Cartier and Montblanc, said it plans for a 100-for-one share split, after a change in Swiss law that will allow lower nominal values per share. Jewelry sales rose 31 percent, and watch sales rose 28 percent.

title: Fighting Abuse With Abuse
description: Jennifer Lopez moved quietly across the three-story set, a mock-up of a Marina del Rey condominium, nervously sighing into a cell phone. Two movie cameras followed the action, one positioned on a landing to Ms. Lopez's right, the other hanging from the end of a remote-control arm and operated from several yards away.

title: Article 2001060891595114911 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: AT&T Drops Commitment To Cable Box
description: Suggesting that sophisticated interactive television will remain a distant dream in the United States, AT&T's broadband division has dropped its commitment to an advanced set-top cable box that was supposed to showcase Microsoft's interactive television software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, MARVIN JOSEPH
description: EISENBERG - Marvin Joseph. Died in New York City on June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Audrey Goodman. Loving father of Eric and Jane, Nina, Sally and Charley. Proud grandfather of Evan and Grace. Cherished brother of the late Raymond Woodrow, brotherin-law to Estelle, and uncle to many nieces and nephews. We will miss him and always remember his charm and intelligence. The funeral service will be held on Friday, June 8, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., (81st Street).

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: More Cutbacks by Consultants As Accenture Trims Its Payroll
description: Accenture, the consulting firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, announced yesterday that it would lay off approximately 600 employees, mainly support staff, and encourage up to 800 consultants to take voluntary sabbaticals for up to one year in an effort to control costs.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Governor Rejects Power Rationing
description: The governor of the country's third most populous state, who in 1999 declared a moratorium on foreign debt payments that set off a currency crisis, has ordered the electricity utility Minas Gerais to defy a government energy rationing plan that went into effect last Friday. Itamar Franco, a former president who has given indications that he intends to run for that office again next year, prohibited the company from imposing surcharges on energy bills or cutting service to customers who exceed consumption quotas set by the government. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: June 11: McVeigh and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOAGLAND, ALEXANDER C.
description: HOAGLAND-Alexander C. June 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Teresa, loving father of Valente, Antonio (Lupe) and Valeria (Luis). Cherished grandfather of Anna, Teresa, Alejandro, Felipe, Maria and Mariana. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, corner of 81st Street. Friday, June 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, June 9th, 10:30am at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St.

title: William Pope.L
description: The Project

title: Ryan McGinness -- 'Vocabularytest'
description: Joseph Silvestro Gallery

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Senate Shifts, So Lobbyists Who Seek to Influence Its Legislation Scramble to Shift, Too
description: James Albertine thought he had a winning strategy for selling Republicans on an issue he was lobbying, getting dry cleaners to use new carbon dioxide solvents to clean clothes. To encourage their use, he advocated tax credits for dry cleaners, a provision that could be tucked into a tax bill to help small businesses, a core Republican constituency.

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Arrested in Offshore Fund Case
description: Prosecutors charged three men with stealing millions from an offshore investment fund that is under investigation by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

title: McVeigh Prepares for Death And Awaits Move from Cell
description: His appeals abandoned, Timothy J. McVeigh today awaited the move from his cell on death row at the federal penitentiary here to the building where he will be put to death on Monday for bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, where 168 people died in 1995.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Up 3% for the Week Despite Conflicting News

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, DR. PAUL
description: KAY-Dr. Paul. The Long Island Psychoanalytic Society mourns the death of Dr. Paul Kay, a distinguished psychoanalyst and founding member. A popular supervisor and a beloved mentor, he will be remembered for his knowledge, warmth and originality. The Society members extend sincere condolences to Mrs. Barbara Kay and family.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our money would be going to farmers, but it wouldn't be going to Irish farmers; it would be going to Polish farmers.''

title: Radcliffe Heads Strong Field
description: Paula Radcliffe of Britain is going to stick with the style of distance running that got her to the 1996 and 2000 Olympics: start out fast.

title: Two Nights for the Price of One
description: Le Meridien is offering two nights for the price of one on weekends at its hotels in Boston, Dallas, Los Angeles, New York, New Orleans, Toronto and Chicago. A four-night package with discounts up to 50 percent is available at the Le Meridien resorts on Bora Bora, Cancun, Rio de Janeiro, St. Martin and Tahiti. Guests can also add two-for-one specials on meals, spa services and cocktails. The rates, which subject to availability and blackout dates, are valid through Feb. 17, 2002. Contact (877) 427-1143 or www.lemeridien-americas.com .

title: SPX, A MAKER OF INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS, TO BUY KENDRO
description: The SPX Corporation, a maker of industrial products that sold its motor unit last month, agreed to buy Kendro Laboratory Products, which makes products for the life-sciences industry, for $320 million. Kendro, which has annual revenue of more than $200 million, makes centrifuges, incubators, ovens and freezers for the pharmaceutical, biochemistry and molecular biology industries. SPX, which is based in Muskegon, Mich., is adding products to expand its Revco life-sciences unit. Kendro's incubators are used to grow cells for disease and drug research, the freezers are used by blood banks and sperm banks and the centrifuges spin blood to separate the components, an SPX spokeswoman, Tina Betlejewski, said. Kendro, which is based in Newtown, Conn., has more than 1,200 employees, and sells products under the Heraeus, Sorvall and CARR brand names.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, STANLEY, PH.D.
description: SCHIFF-Stanley, Ph.D. The Board of Directors and Executive Staff of New York Psychotherapy and Counseling Center mourn the passing of Stanley Schiff, a long time member of our Board of Directors. He was a warm, generous and loyal friend and colleague. His dedication and guidance in our treatment of mentally ill adults and emotionally disturbed children will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Rabbi Seymour Brickman President, Board of Directors Rabbi Isidore Klein, CSW Executive Director Jack Schnee, M.D., F.A.P.A. Medical Director

title: Article 2001060990113447637 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIU, CHAO, YEN
description: CHIU-Chao-Yen. Age 59, of Smithtown. On June 1, 2001. Civil Engineer for New York State DOT and formerly employed with EBASCO for nineteen years. Beloved husband of Ling-Siao, loving father of Iris and Victor. Cherished son of Chin-Yeh. Dear brother of Chia-Sheng, Shu-Yuan, Shwu-Pin, Shu-Jane, and Sue-Huei. Reposing at the Branch Nesconset Funeral Home, 725 Rt 347, Nesconset, N.Y. 631-265-9300. Visiting SUNDAY ONLY, 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM. 8 PM Eulogy. Private cremation Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about progress in AIDS research misspelled the surname and misstated the age of a man with hemophilia who has been infected for 23 years with H.I.V. He is Robert Massie, not Massey. He is 44, not 46.

title: Tottenville Captures the Title On a Homer in Extra Innings
description: For most of the game last night, the players from both teams were leaning against the fences that protect the dugouts at Shea Stadium, waiting for something to happen. Even the troop of public school peace officers and the 1,500 fans on hand spent a mostly uneventful night as the championship game of the Public Schools Athletic League between Tottenville and Monroe moved along.

title: Daschle Says Most Nominees Will Get a Senate Vote
description: Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the new majority leader, pledged today that Democrats would not engage in ''payback'' for the way Republicans stalled the confirmation of judges during the Clinton administration, saying, ''We have to break the cycle.''

title: Bush and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLANSKY, SYDELLE
description: POLANSKY-Sydelle. On June 2, 2001 in Lebanon, NH. Beloved wife, daughter, mother. Survived by sons, Steven and Larry, daughters-in-law Ellen and Jody, brother Bert and grandchildren, Benjamin, Michael and Anna.

title: AT&T Sets Spinoff Date
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had set July 9 as the date to spin off the AT&T Wireless Group as an independent company.

title: Wheelchair Is Stolen
description: For James Daly, a 52-year old Queens resident who uses a wheelchair, it was a particularly low blow. On Thursday night, the police said, Mr. Daly was approached from behind on a street corner and pushed to the ground by one or more assailants. They fled with his wheelchair and $14.

title: Journal; The Backslap Backlash
description: Washington is still aghast at how a presumed Bush team player can, by one dramatic action, expose the sham of an administration's supposedly invincible people skills and the unfairness of its policies. But such indeed has been the coup -- a ''coup of one,'' as Trent Lott might say -- pulled off by Jenna Bush.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: The Spirit Meets Sex In Mantras of Desire
description: Among her acknowledged attributes -- a genius for song craft, unassailable integrity, a voice that tears hearts -- Lucinda Williams is sexy. She could even be called a sex symbol, at least among her listeners, who are more likely to seek thrills on National Public Radio than in Maxim magazine.

title: Hedging Bets, Big Developers Back 4 Democrats for Mayor
description: About a dozen of the city's largest developers and landlords gathered at the Four Seasons restaurant recently to assess their political strategy for the mayor's race in New York, where they collectively own tens of thousands of apartments and scores of skyscrapers.

title: The Yankees Gain Needed Momentum but Lose Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte strained his left groin and had to leave the game early as the Yankees beat the Atlanta Braves, 7-4, last night. But the Yankees pitcher said afterward that he felt O.K., and mentioned the possibility that he might be able to pitch again in five days.

title: 2 Sony Executives Disciplined For Faked Praise in Film Ads
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment has reprimanded and suspended without pay for 30 days two advertising executives for their part in concocting quotes from a fictitious movie critic to promote four Columbia Pictures movies in advertisements.

title: A Progressive Past
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Narnia' With a Twist
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible Cheating Scandal Is Investigated in Michigan
description: Michigan school officials were scrambling yesterday to investigate irregularities on the state's standardized tests in what appears to be the largest of a recent spate of cheating scandals across the country as the use of high-stakes tests has risen.

title: Laila Ali Wins by Decision in Battle of Boxing Daughters
description: The latest episode in the most famous rivalry in boxing ended tonight with Laila Ali pummeling her way to a majority decision over Jacqui Frazier-Lyde.

title: Waiting for the Next Secretariat
description: The running of the 133rd Belmont Stakes today evokes mixed emotions in many. While this year's race promises to be a thriller, pitting Monarchos, the Kentucky Derby winner, against Point Given, the Preakness winner, a Triple Crown is not on the line. Racing fans are frustrated, a sentiment that has become an annual refrain. No horse has claimed the crown in 23 years. Are contemporary horses simply not up to the test?

title: Ruling May Force Schundler to Return Funds
description: An administrative law judge ruled today that Bret D. Schundler's campaign for governor might have improperly arranged for a nonprofit group Mr. Schundler controlled to spend more than $885,000 for television advertisements featuring Mr. Schundler last fall.

title: Post's New Editor Dismisses Key Members of the Staff
description: The new Australian editor of The New York Post went through his editing ranks with a scythe yesterday, firing two of the newspaper's three managing editors and two metropolitan desk editors, in addition to Jack Newfield, one of New York City's most distinctive liberal voices.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about a reorganization at Reuters P.L.C. misidentified the chief executive of the Reuterspace unit, who is retiring. He is Rob Rowley. Geoff Weetman is the company's director for human resources; he is joining the board, not retiring.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Thursday about the Columbia professor and Palestinian advocate Edward W. Said and his preoccupation with mortality misidentified the river in Greek mythology whose waters erased all memory after death. It was the Lethe. (The Styx was the river around Hades.)

title: A 55-1 Choice Wins the Acorn
description: Chris McCarron suspected he was on a fighter even if the bettors did not. As he galloped Forest Secrets onto the track for the Grade I Acorn Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park, McCarron had to keep his 3-year-old filly from hurting her escort pony.

title: Former I.R.S. Chiefs Back Tax Haven Crackdown
description: Seven former commissioners of the Internal Revenue Service urged Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill yesterday to withdraw his opposition to a proposed crackdown on Caribbean nations and others that are considered tax havens.

title: Rival Medicare Drug Plans Are Both Ruled Affordable
description: The Congressional Budget Office provided the first independent estimates today of the cost of new Medicare drug benefits, showing that the proposals of Senate Democrats and House Republicans are both affordable under the budget adopted by Congress earlier this year.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Entire Council To Visit Kosovo
description: All 15 Security Council members plan to travel to Kosovo next Friday to observe the situation as the United Nations administration in the territory prepares for a fall election there, a first step to autonomy, if not independence. The trip is another demonstration of the Council's new policy of gaining firsthand familiarity with areas on which it must make decisions. Twelve members recently visited Congo and neighboring countries in Africa. This is the first time all Council members will be out of the headquarters together. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: U.S. FIGURES SHOW PRISON POPULATION IS NOW STABILIZING
description: After growing explosively for three decades, the nation's prison population has begun to stabilize, according to new government figures.

title: Sports of The Times; Zito Still Remembers 'The Hole' at Belmont
description: THE day he was evicted, he had exactly one horse and one stall at Belmont Park. Somebody wanted that space -- somebody with considerably more cachet than he.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, EUGENE J., JR.
description: SULLIVAN-Eugene J., Jr. On June 7, 2001. Devoted husband of Margaret (nee Kelly). Loving father of Dennis, Margaret Healy, Maureen Foster, Patty Voegler, Joanne Lawler, Kathleen Martin, Jeanne Dombrowski, Eugene, Terence, Virginia Calo, and Maryanne Hinchy. Cherished grandfather of 26 and great grandfather of four. Proud US Army Veteran of WWII. Retired pressman of the NY Times. Member N.H.P. Knights of Columbus, and N.H.P. Elks. Friends may visit Sunday, 24:30, 7-9:30PM, New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Rd., New Hyde Park, NY. Mass of Christian burial Monday 9:15AM Holy Spirit R.C. Church, New Hyde Park, NY. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Fisher Breaks Out to Bedevil Sixers
description: Derek Fisher received the pass at the top of the key and focused on the rim. He was wide open, so the issue was not whether he would shoot it, but whether he would hit it.

title: Judge Nullifies Election of Ex-Minister In Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  A senior judge on Friday nullified an election victory of a member of Malaysia's governing party and criticized an apparent attempt to influence his decision, calling it an "insult to one's intelligence."

title: Shares Drop on Juniper Networks' Outlook
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as investors shed technology issues after Juniper Networks released a bleak second-quarter forecast, reigniting Wall Street's concerns about weak corporate profits.

title: Killing in Chinatown
description: A 43-year-old garment worker has been found shot to death in the bathroom of her Chinatown apartment, where she lived with her husband and two teenage children, the police said yesterday.

title: Article 2001060991355524043 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: The Next Step On Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Weakness
description: Japan's economic policy minister, Heizo Takenaka, expressed doubt about whether the country's economic pace reached the government's forecast of 1.2 percent growth for the fiscal year that ended March 31. The government is scheduled to release its report on gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the year next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDINSON, JEANETTE
description: EDINSON-Jeanette. Age 97. Died June 8. Devoted wife of the late George Edinson. Beloved mother of Constance (Philip). Grandmother of Richard (Carolyn) and Larry (Carol). Great grandmother of Jonathan & Evan. Services private.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline Agreement
description: Lufthansa ended a monthlong battle with its pilots' union and agreed to increase wages by more than 15 percent by the end of next year. The agreement came after striking pilots grounded Lufthansa's planes on three occasions and after the two sides submitted to arbitration headed by Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a former German foreign minister. Lufthansa said the deal would increase its costs by 230 million marks ($100 million) this year, but said it wanted to avoid even more damage from a prolonged battle. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Macedonia Expands Attacks Against Rebels
description: The Macedonian government intensified its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels today, despite a rebel offer of a cease-fire, pounding rebel-held villages north of the capital with heavy artillery and fire from helicopter gunships.

title: Labor Prevails (Along With Geniality)
description: NORMALLY, an event like the British elections would be a distant concern, but something about this round struck a chord.

title: Who Gets to Use the Cup as a Dance Partner?
description: Let the Stanley Cup playoffs end in high style. As long as the Devils and the Colorado Avalanche insist on forcing Game 7 of the championship round tonight in the Pepsi Center, let both teams play well at the same time. It has not happened much in this good-but-not-great series, with the latest installment a 4-0 Avalanche triumph on Thursday night in Game 6 at Continental Arena.

title: The Missing Character Links 3 One-Act Plays
description: The final installment of Ensemble Studio Theater's festival of one-act plays gets off to a drab start, but things pick up considerably when the action finally moves out of the living room and into the bathroom. And a wonderfully wry trip to the funeral parlor finishes off the evening.

title: Sexual Abuse Charge Leads o Bronx Dean's Dismissal
description: The acting dean responsible for safety and security at a Bronx high school was arrested yesterday and charged with sexual abuse after a ninth-grade student reported that he had groped her in a vacant classroom, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Cabaret Guide of Weekend yesterday for the singer Andrea Marcovicci misstated the dates on which she was being replaced by another singer at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Sam Kaufman appeared Tuesday through Thursday; he will not substitute next week. Ms. Marcovicci performs Tuesday through Saturday nights through June 30.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Western Sahara: Refugees Need Food
description: Two United Nations agencies appealed for donations of $1.2 million a month to feed about 155,000 from the disputed territory between Morocco and Algeria known as the Western Sahara. Most have been in refugee camps in southwest Algeria since 1976. The high commissioner for refugees, forced by a budget shortfall to reduce spending, is cutting $660,000 from the Western Sahara. The World Food Program also faces shortages in donations.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Bill Eases Pension Rules
description: Former Gov. Lester Maddox, the only living Georgia governor not receiving a state pension, would receive one under a bill being introduced in the State Legislature. If the bill passes, Mr. Maddox, 85, would receive a pension of less than $10,000 a year. He has not been eligible for a pension because although he was governor for four years and lieutenant governor for another four, his time in public service was less than the required 10 years. Mr. Maddox was first elected in 1966. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: For Alzheimer's Patients, Some Solace, if Not Hope; Group Struggles to Come to Terms With Illness
description: Howard Bender still looks like the man who ran that big Long Island factory. It produced shower doors and medicine cabinets and provided a living, but Mr. Bender's lasting love was the theater. He acted with local companies in every production of a musical he could find. His favorite, by far, was ''Guys and Dolls.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Rich Deal Is Off
description: Marc Rich, whose presidential pardon in January set off a political tempest, has called off a deal to sell his Swiss-based international commodities trading operation to Crown Resources of Russia. His company, Marc Rich & Company Holding, said the two parties could not agree on central points of the deal. Neither company had any further explanation. Mr. Rich, whose firm has been under scrutiny by Swiss officials to determine whether it falls under new money laundering rules, has been trying to find a suitable merger partner. An effort last year to merge with a Dutch firm also failed. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Benefits
description: Human Rights at Lincoln Center

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRESLIN, ROSEMARY
description: BRESLIN-Rosemary. 20 years in heaven. We love you and miss you very much. The Breslin Family

title: A Murderer's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: JUNIPER NETWORKS CUTS SALES FORECAST BY ONE-THIRD
description: Juniper Networks Inc., a leading supplier of data-traffic routers, cut its second-quarter sales forecast by one-third, setting off an 18 percent decline in its stock price. Sales will be as low as $200 million, instead of the $300 million to $330 million forecast previously, Juniper said. The company plans to reduce staff by 8 percent to 9 percent, about 100 employees. Second-quarter profit, excluding charges and costs like good will amortization, will be 8 cents to 9 cents a share, Juniper said. That compares with the 24 cents forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Juniper shares fell $8.50, to $38.02 on the Nasdaq.

title: Bush Trip Aimed at Winning Over Europeans
description: President Bush will carry few specific proposals when he embarks on his first major overseas trip on Monday, hoping instead that face-to-face encounters will win over Europeans skeptical of his policies and abilities.

title: Catching the Wave; Surfware Makers Rush to Cash In On a Growing Trend
description: From his salt-scented perch along the Atlantic Ocean in Narragansett, R.I., Tom Hogan has had a front-row seat for every surfing trend in the last 20 years. Mr. Hogan owns a surf shop called Warm Winds, where he sells boards, wax, sunscreen and surfer clothing. Especially, these days, the clothing.

title: Seo Starting To Look Like Million Dollars
description: The Mets hope a $1 million investment may soon be ready to show returns after nearly four years.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Ronald K. Crumpley, who killed two people and wounded six others in 1980 outside a gay bar in Manhattan, referred incorrectly in some copies to the legal finding in his case. It was ''not responsible by reason of insanity'' -- rather than ''guilty by reason of insanity.''

title: A Power in Texas Governing Finds Fault in Texas Politics
description: ANY politicians who unexpectedly walk away from high office usually find their stated motives met with suspicion if not outright disbelief. More time with the family? Right. Looking for new challenges? Sure.

title: Avalanche Hopes That Past Is Prologue
description: Wearing sandals and relaxed grins on the eve of their biggest game, the key members of the Colorado Avalanche today recalled with kid-like joy the Stanley Cups they had won. At least in their driveways and in their imagination.

title: Article 2001060993552469730 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Article 2001060990119030676 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Adjusted Swing Gives Holtgrieve the First-Round Edge
