description: Jim Holtgrieve was one of the best amateur golfers in the world two decades ago, playing for the Walker Cup team three times and for the American world amateur team twice. But he has had little success since then, and in three years on the Senior PGA Tour, Holtgrieve has had four top 10 finishes and no victories.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Video Gambling Challenged
description: Attorney General Bill Pryor filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a state law that has allowed video gambling machines in convenience stores throughout the state. He said the law, written to permit children to win prizes from amusement machines, is a loophole that allows the gambling machines to evade a ban on lotteries in the state constitution. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Ready To Ascend
description: President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi will formally give Silvio Berlusconi, the conservative media baron, a mandate this evening to form a government. Mr. Berlusconi, whose party won a solid majority in Parliament in the May 13 elections, has been selecting a cabinet. He is expected to announce the names tomorrow or Monday, then quickly be sworn in as prime minister. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Software Failure Halts Big Board Trading for Over an Hour
description: A failed software upgrade left investors unable to trade shares on the New York Stock Exchange for nearly an hour and a half yesterday morning.

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about advances by I.B.M. in stretching silicon during semiconductor manufacturing misstated the type of charge in circuits created by the absence of electrons. Such electron holes are positively charged, not negatively.

title: Inquiry Source Sees Sabotage In Damage To Boeing Jets
description: As the F.B.I. continued its investigation into wire damage in airplanes under assembly at Boeing's plant here, a person familiar with the investigation said today that the frayed and cut wires on as many as 10 of its 737's were damaged deliberately in recent weeks.

title: Homeless With AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Hedge Fund Seeks Manager Who Can Fill Some Big Shoes
description: George Soros is looking for a replacement.

title: 10,000 Plead To Be Exempt From Blackouts
description: The jockeying has begun among California businesses desperate to avoid blackouts this summer.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Shares In Fortis Sold
description: The Dutch financial services company, ING Group, said it had sold 14.7 million shares of its rival Fortis for 400 million euros to help finance its acquisition of Seguros Comercial America, Mexico's largest insurance company. ING said the transaction netted a profit of 270 million euros. After the sale, ING said it owned 5 percent of Fortis. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Bush Returns to a Familiar Iowa Farm to Laud His Tax-Cut Legislation
description: Having signed the tax bill in the White House, President Bush took his victory lap in the American heartland today, traveling to a corn and soybean farm near Des Moines to talk about the legislative success he had reaped.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND FLIGHT ATTENDANTS STILL AT ODDS
description: American Airlines, a division of the AMR Corporation, and its flight attendants have failed to reach a labor accord after four days of talks, and federal mediators will consider asking President Bush to intervene to block a strike days before the busy Fourth of July holiday, the carrier said yesterday. The National Mediation Board convened talks in hopes of negotiating a contract before attendants are allowed to walk off their jobs at the carrier on July 1, the height of the summer travel season. The board recessed talks until June 20, and said it was awaiting an economic impact study from the Transportation Department. Such a study is required before the board would ask Mr. Bush to intervene and delay a strike up to 60 more days.

title: Talking With North Korea
description: President Bush is right to resume discussions with North Korea on curbing its long-range missiles and addressing a number of other important security issues. The White House denies that its new position reflects any policy change. But it was just three months ago that Mr. Bush announced an indefinite pause in talks with the North on the grounds that Pyongyang could not be trusted to live up to any agreements.

title: A Mideast Lull That May Not Last
description: As American, European and Russian diplomats plunged into an emergency effort to cement a fragile cease-fire, Israelis and Palestinians were skeptical that this week's drop in violence could last.

title: Sports of The Times; Sixer Fans Have Geiger To Thank
description: THE games have been a sight to behold and pro basketball appears to be the apple of America's television viewing eye again. Matt Geiger, take a bow.

title: Knife-Wielding Man Kills 8 Children at Japanese School
description: A deranged man armed with a kitchen knife stormed into an elementary school here this morning and began stabbing students and teachers, a murderous rampage that has stirred outrage and soul-searching in this normally safe country. Eight children were killed and at least 15 people wounded.

title: Irish Vote Stalls Plan to Expand Europe's Union
description: Voters in Ireland threw the European Union's expansion plans into sudden disarray today by unexpectedly rejecting a European treaty that was to pave the way for 12 new members, most of them former Communist countries.

title: A Grand Operatic Approach Even for Meditative Songs
description: Some young recitalists tend to freeze on stage. This is not Rinat Shaham's problem. In a Sunday afternoon recital at Merkin Hall sponsored by the Marilyn Horne Foundation, the Israeli mezzo showed a definite operatic flair. The only drawback was that in the repertory she was performing, songs by Schubert and Poulenc, Gershwin and Ravel, operatic flair wasn't exactly what was called for.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WASHINGTON POST CO., Washington, the publisher of The Washington Post and Newsweek magazine, said its Kaplan Inc. unit of New York has acquired the closely held Prosource Educational Services Inc., St. Paul, to add educational and professional testing services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Hasidic Village Gets a Lesson In Bare-Knuckled Politicking
description: When this Hasidic village was incorporated by the ultra-orthodox Satmars in 1977, its founding fathers hoped they would be able to replicate the intensely religious and insular enclave they had fashioned for themselves in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. And to a large degree, they have succeeded, as manifested by the dozens of shuls and the predominance of Yiddish spoken on the streets.

title: Tax-Cut Expectations
description: To the Editor:

title: No Surprise This Time; Lakers Win
description: The best little man in pro basketball squirted toward the basket with 6 minutes, 21 seconds left in the third quarter. In his path stood the most dominant player in the game. If only Allen Iverson could loft his arching floater over the outstretched right arm of Shaquille O'Neal, maybe there would be something to this Philadelphia story, the one about the diminutive guard with the slingshot.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Rate Increase
description: Thailand's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate to 2.5 percent from 1.5 percent, pressing ahead with plans to defend the nation's swooning currency, the baht, by making it less cost-effective for Thai companies to borrow money at home to pay off their loans overseas. Economists and financial analysts are nearly unanimous in their disapproval of the new monetary policy, adopted after Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra replaced the country's central banker last week. Most say higher interest rates could squelch the economic recovery by raising borrowing costs for companies, shrinking margins at struggling banks and making Thai exports more expensive overseas. But financial markets confounded the doomsayers, with the baht strengthening and bank stocks rising. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Henry Michel, 76, Civil Engineer And Leader in Building Industry
description: Henry Ludwig Michel, a globe-trotting civil engineer with a 50-year career that made him a leader in the construction industry, died on May 23 at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 76.

title: White House Delays Release of Reagan Papers
description: The White House is delaying the release of thousands of pages of old presidential records that detail the confidential advice given Ronald Reagan by his aides, some of whom are now prominent officials in the Bush administration.

title: Investigator Says Administrator Ordered Social Promotions
description: A school district administrator in Harlem attempted to promote more than 50 seventh-grade students after summer school last year even though they had all failed to meet promotion requirements, Edward F. Stancik, the special commissioner for investigation for the New York City school system, said yesterday.

title: Two Backcourt Stars Relive Pickup Duels
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8  When Kobe Bryant and Aaron McKie faced off in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals on Wednesday night, it was the renewal of an old rivalry. Except this time it was McKie who had something to prove.

title: Cuttings: Turning a Bushy Plant Into a Miniature Tree
description: IN the world of gardening, a "standard" is a naturally bushy plant trained to have a clear stem capped by a mop of leaves. A miniature tree. Some gardeners love them; others will have nothing to do with them.

title: Demand Is Rising for Members of the Clergy as Fewer Answer the Calling
description: Faith Presbyterian Church, a 420-member congregation in a suburban neighborhood of Indianapolis, spent 16 months unsuccessfully seeking a new associate pastor. The pastor, the Rev. Glen Bell, made several calls himself, including one to a promising senior at a seminary 300 miles away.

title: For the State House, a Whitman for the Wall
description: There remained one last symbolic barrier for Christie Whitman to break back home in New Jersey, and she did it today, unveiling a portrait of herself that will hang in the State House along with those of her predecessors, all of them men.

title: Court Strikes Down State Ban On Sale of Cigarettes Online
description: A federal judge struck down a New York State law banning Internet and mail-order sales of cigarettes yesterday, saying the state had unduly interfered with interstate commerce.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Telecom Bids
description: Two of Ireland's most powerful businessmen, Sir Anthony O'Reilly and Denis O'Brien, raised their competing bids for the former state telephone company, Eircom. Mr. O'Brien's eIsland consortium raised its per-share offer to 1.29 euros ($1.10) in cash, valuing Eircom at 2.84 billion euros ($2.42 billion), and allowing shareholders to opt for 1.24 euros and a warrant for a share in future earnings. Sir Anthony's Valentia Consortium, which is also backed by the financier George Soros, offered 1.22 euros earlier this week but declined to provide details of its latest bid. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone Communications Partners have also expressed interest in acquiring Eircom, which says it has 80 percent of Ireland's fixed-line market. The company reported a 10 percent increase in revenue, to 2.16 billion euros in the year to March 31. Profit, however, fell 43 percent over the period because of increased competition, to 187 million euros. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Lobbyists Shift, Too

title: Not Same Glavine Or Same Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves did little last night to make their matchup with the Yankees resemble a preview of the World Series, the series' usual billing each June. This season the Braves have been more inconsistent than Tom Glavine.

title: 'Narnia' With a Twist
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, but Did Anyone Ask The Animals' Opinion?
description: The controversy came with the first daffodils in March, shortly after Peter Singer, the father of the animal rights movement, reviewed a reissue of the book ''Dearest Pet: On Bestiality'' (Verso), by the Dutch biologist Midas Dekkers, for Nerve, an online sex magazine. Three months have passed and still the sun has not set on the latest tempest surrounding Mr. Singer, the provocative author of ''Animal Liberation'' and a professor of bioethics at Princeton University's Center for Human Values.

title: Capriati at Tennis's Peak, Finally Giving It Her Best
description: A week before the French Open, Jennifer Capriati was preparing for a workout on a tennis court in Monte Carlo, eager to hear the word ''Go.''

title: No Quick Fix for California's Energy Troubles
description: The Bush administration agrees with Gov. Gray Davis of California that high California electricity prices are a bad thing. But they aren't as bad as an increase in the scope, duration and frequency of blackouts -- an almost certain result if we responded to California's electricity supply problem with the quick-fix price controls the governor advocates.

title: Russian Reiterates Stand in Favor of ABM Pact
description: The Russian defense minister said today that although his government agreed with Washington that the United States and Russia faced new military threats, it continued to view the Antiballistic Missile Treaty as the foundation for modern arms control and sees no reason to amend it, as American officials have urged.

title: Article 2001060991282717418 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: Abroad at Home; When Truth Is Treason
description: Despite all the gains for democracy in the world, in many countries anyone who wants to publish truths unwelcome to the government risks suppression and criminal punishment. If Henry Kissinger and Richard Nixon had had their way, that would be so in the United States, too.

title: Leader of Britain's Defeated Tories Steps Down, Setting Off a Tussle for the Top Spot
description: William Hague announced today that he was stepping down as the Conservative Party's leader after returns from Thursday's election showed that the Tories had suffered their second straight devastating defeat. Filling the new opening at the top promised to be a quarrelsome affair for the deeply divided party.

title: Stars Relive Pickup Duels
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8  When Kobe Bryant and Aaron McKie faced off in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals on Wednesday night, it was the renewal of an old rivalry. Except this time it was McKie who had something to prove.

title: Article 2001060993640051031 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Europe Union's Dreams Meet Electoral Reality
description: The European Union's lofty project to embrace the formerly Communist nations of Central Europe, a project that would double the size of ''Europe'' as people now think of it, collided with a serious new obstacle put up today by Irish voters.

title: Devils' Game 6 Generates 3.5 Rating
description: The Colorado Avalanche's 4-0 victory over the Devils in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals on Thursday night on ABC generated a 3.5 Nielsen rating, down 17 percent from the comparable game a year ago, when the Devils beat the Dallas Stars in double overtime to win the Cup.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Rulings on Medicaid for Immigrants Step Up the Pressure on Albany
description: Each year, Gov. George E. Pataki has a goal in mind for the Medicaid budget: lower it. Yet this year it seems that with every month that passes, that budget is pushed in the opposite direction, and there is little the governor can do about it.

title: Suspect Is Killed By the Police
description: A street corner argument in Flatbush, Brooklyn, last night ended with a man being shot and killed by the police after he had shot and injured another man, according to the police and witnesses.

title: Article 2001060992833699291 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: When Fashion Decreed Stripes A Capital Crime
description: Thinking of wearing that pinstriped suit for lunch with the boss? Or that fancy silk striped tie? Just be thankful you didn't live a few hundred years ago, when getup like that would not only have blown any chance of a raise but could very well have gotten you killed.

title: Iconoclasm and Sacrilege
description: Consider two artists. One devotes himself to what he calls ''spermatic painting.'' In his images, he explains, he tries to ''cut my furrow steadily.'' He wants his paintings to ''smell of the earth.'' And when he expresses his religious devotion, he paints a Madonna: a homely woman with skin that suggests soil, surrounded by symbols of fecundity and nature. His unorthodox approach is rejected by the art-consuming public.

title: Extra Day of Rest Helps Mets' Leiter Keep Fine Form
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 8  Bobby Valentine is not counting Al Leiter's health among the many things that could concern him now. Leiter has held up fine since returning from the disabled list on May 18, and the improvement in the Mets' rotation began when he came back.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Emissions Bill Introduced
description: Two senators from states rich in coal and oil introduced legislation that would for the first time establish targets and a timetable for stabilizing emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases, which are released mainly by burning fossil fuels. The senators, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, and Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said the legislation was necessary now that scientists had established a link between human actions and global warming.

title: The Musical Connections Of the Old Slave Trade
description: The New Orleans group Los Hombres Calientes are doing what hundreds of bands should, or could, be doing: making explicit the musical connections between port cities along the Atlantic slave route, specifically the Africa-Brazil-Caribbean-New Orleans web tightened by Yoruban culture.

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders A Sheriff To Face Trial
description: A judge has ordered the sheriff of Orange County, H. Frank Bigger, to face trial on an allegation that he failed to properly oversee deputy sheriffs accused of a range of abuses, including pocketing money from bogus raffles.

title: Nasdaq Puts High Hopes on New European Trading System
description: Nasdaq announced yesterday that it had started a trading system for its Nasdaq Europe subsidiary and that several major investment banks, including Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers, had bought shares in Nasdaq Europe.

title: British Pound Falls Further On Labor Party's Landslide
description: The British pound slipped again to a 15-year low against the dollar today, after a landslide victory by the Labor Party amplified talk that Prime Minister Tony Blair may speed the replacement of the pound with the euro.

title: THE ALLERGY PRISON
description: For more and more parents, terror lurks in every lunchbox. Are they being paranoid, or simply keeping their children alive? A report by Susan Dominus in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. 1955-1994 ''Now and forever, you are a part of me, we had a moment that will last beyond a dream. We are the lucky ones. Some people never get such ''Love'' Now and forever, I will always think of you'' but ''Life is what happens to you while we're making other plans, my beautiful, beautiful boy.'' Happy Birthday. Mommy

title: Game 7 Roadblock Threatens The Devils' Drive to the Title
description: There was no guarantee. That is not Scott Stevens's style. There will probably not be a fiery locker-room oration from the Devils' captain Saturday night before the first Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals since 1994.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sports Teams Fear Terror Attacks
description: The United States delegation to the World Maccabiah Games, the so-called Jewish Olympics, set for Tel Aviv in July, has requested a one-year postponement because of the risk of terrorism. Several other delegations have suggested that they might not attend. Despite United States warnings against travel to Israel, the West Bank and Gaza, Israel has still sought tourism, albeit unsuccessfully, and a poor showing at the games would be a blow.

title: 56 Years After a Surrender, Another Triumph in Italy
description: The town of Caserta, near Naples in Italy, was in the news in 1945. It was there that German forces in Italy surrendered to Field Marshal Sir Harold Alexander. It was in the news again a week ago, when two Italian players at its bridge club were the world winners of the second World Bridge Contest for 2001. Stelio di Bello and Luigi Ventriglia scored 74.26 percent, heading a field of 5,389 pairs playing at 259 clubs in 40 countries.

title: Negotiations Under Way On School Site
description: The New York City Board of Education is in negotiations to lease a building that would house a new Upper East Side high school after a two-year campaign by middle-class parents who say the needs of their children for an academically rigorous neighborhood high school are not being met, city officials said yesterday.

title: P.&G. Settlement For $49 Million
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that it would pay $49 million to shareholders to settle a lawsuit over its March 2000 earnings announcement.

title: French Open Repeat Is in Kuerten's Sights
description: The drama expected to unfold today when Gustavo Kuerten encountered the rising Juan Carlos Ferrero fell short of a thriller, and Parisians' hopes of an all-night celebration for Sbastien Grosjean ended in the daylight on center court.

title: Denis Whitaker, 86, Highly Decorated Canadian War Hero
description: Brig. Gen. Denis Whitaker, one of Canada's most highly decorated army officers of World War II and a military historian and sportsman, died May 30 in Oakville, Ontario. He was 86.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Braced For A Shutdown
description: With the State Legislature still unable to agree on the budget, Gov. Jesse Ventura is preparing for a possible government shutdown on July 1, the start of the state's fiscal year. The governor's staff was researching whether the state police, nursing homes and other essential services could continue to operate in the event of a shutdown. The Legislature adjourned on May 21, the constitutional deadline, without approving the two-year, $27.3 billion budget. Since then, the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-controlled Senate have made scant progress. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A highlights entry and a program listing in the Television section on Sunday for 3 p.m. last Monday were outdated. After the section had gone to press, MTV postponed the premiere of the series ''Spyder Games: A Summer Soap Opera'' until June 18 at 7 p.m.

title: Mets Rally Furiously In Ninth, Then Fizzle
description: Steve Trachsel has gotten used to games like tonight's. He earnestly chews up innings while waiting for his team to score. A couple of breaks go against him, and he ends up as the losing pitcher. Unless you are watching closely, he said, you look at the box score and say, ''Trachsel gave it up again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, REV. JOHN J., S.J.
description: BARRETT-Rev. John J., S.J. Beloved brother of Rev. Robert Barrett. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd. Visitation Sunday, 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Monday 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Bronx (718) 654-0500.

title: Whimsy, Humor and Heft Toast a Group's 30 Years
description: New-music groups flourish in New York, and quite a few of them have shown remarkable staying power, even if individual members come and go. The Da Capo Chamber Players have been exploring and helping create the modern repertory for flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano for the last 30 years, although only its flutist, Patricia Spencer, remains from the earliest days.

title: Article 2001060993082485625 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Divided Civil Rights Panel Approves Election Report
description: A divided United States Commission on Civil Rights approved a report today that said black voters in Florida were at least 10 times more likely than other voters to have their ballots rejected in last year's presidential election, and it called on the Justice Department to investigate the state's voting irregularities.

title: Patients of Brooklyn Clinic Are Sought After Outbreak of Hepatitis C
description: City health officials are trying to contact more than 2,000 patients who underwent gastrointestinal exams at a Brooklyn medical clinic, after eight patients tested positive for hepatitis C.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Annan Expected Soon
description: Ambassador Anwarul Karim Chowdhury of Bangladesh, this month's Security Council president, proposed that the Council break with recent tradition and vote this month on a second term for Secretary General Kofi Annan. The choice of a secretary general, subject to confirmation by the General Assembly, has usually taken place in the fall. Mr. Annan's term expires at the end of the year, but since he faces no challengers and all five permanent Council members -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- back him, diplomats say they see no reason for a delay.

title: BIG MARGIN IS SEEN AS LEADER IN IRAN WINS SECOND TERM
description: Early results today from Iran's election showed President Mohammad Khatami on the way to a landslide victory with more than 75 percent of the vote, an even bigger margin than his impressive triumph in 1997, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about advances by I.B.M. in stretching silicon during semiconductor manufacturing misstated the type of charge in circuits created by the absence of electrons. Such electron holes are positively charged, not negatively.

title: A Royal Ballet Feast of Nostalgia and Homage
description: Frederick Ashton has always been considered the most English of ballet choreographers. Certainly he was the most Shakespearean in that he could make the equivalent of a sonnet seem greater than an epic.

title: Mother Superior Guilty in Rwanda Killings
description: A highly unusual trial ended today when four Rwandans, two of them Roman Catholic nuns, were sentenced in a Belgian court to lengthy prison terms for war crimes committed during the mass killings in their homeland in 1994.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Poverty In Serbia
description: Almost one million people in Serbia, more than 10 percent of the population, are living in poverty after a decade of wars and international isolation, the United Nations World Food Program said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: AVADO BRANDS IN DEAL TO SELL DON PABLO'S RESTAURANTS
description: Avado Brands Inc., which runs Don Pablo's Mexican Kitchen restaurants, agreed to sell its McCormick & Schmick's seafood-restaurant chain to two closely held buyout firms for $123.5 million in cash to pay debt. Castle Harlan Inc. and Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill & Company, both based in New York, will buy the 34-restaurant chain. Castle Harlan originally sold the chain to Avado in March 1997, when it had 16 restaurants. Shares of Avado have fallen 93 percent in the last two years as the company's losses widened.

title: FLEETBOSTON TO SELL 36 NEW YORK STATE BRANCHES
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation, New England's largest bank, said yesterday that it would sell 36 upstate New York branches to Community Bank System Inc. to concentrate on the populous stretch between Buffalo and New York City. Terms were not disclosed. Community Bank System, which is based in Dewitt, N.Y., will assume $484 million in deposits and 174 employees of the branches, which are near New York's border with Pennsylvania. Community Bank said it would have 121 branches when it completes the purchase. FleetBoston is focusing on branches near the New York State Thruway, the corridor where most of the state's population lives. FleetBoston will have 348 branches in the state after the sale.

title: Tony Blair's Centrist Majority
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's resounding re-election victory on Thursday marks him as Britain's most successful politician since Margaret Thatcher. He deserves full credit for leading his Labor Party to its first re-election to a second full term in office. But his task was made easier by the blinkered anti-European stance taken by his Conservative opponents under the leadership of William Hague, who announced yesterday that he would step down as party leader. To regain credibility as a serious contender for national power, the Conservatives will have to move back toward more constructive policies on Europe.

title: Extra Officers Part of Plan To Increase Parade Safety
description: New York City and organizers of tomorrow's National Puerto Rican Day Parade outlined a series of measures yesterday designed to prevent a recurrence of the violence that followed last year's event, including assigning 2,000 additional police officers, limiting the number of marchers and requiring that all participants wear wristbands.

title: Vctor Paz Estenssoro, 93, 4-Time Bolivia Leader, Dies
description: Vctor Paz Estenssoro, who was president of Bolivia four times in a career that he began as a moderate leftist and ended as a conservative, and who went into exile three times, died on Thursday. He was 93.

title: School Board In New Dispute On Test Scores
description: The testing director for the New York City Board of Education accused a major testing company yesterday of miscalculating yet another set of scores, this time on a sixth-grade reading test in April 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Herman Badillo's official announcement that he will run for mayor referred imprecisely to his nationality. He was born in Puerto Rico, a United States commonwealth, and was thus an American citizen when he moved to New York at age 11.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Columbine Library Reopening
description: A renovated library will officially open today at Columbine High School near Littleton. The library was the site of most of the killing during the April 1999 massacre, in which two teenagers shot 12 students and a teacher. The gunmen killed themselves in the library. More than 4,000 individuals and groups helped raise the $3.1 million needed for the remodeling. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fire Destroys Missiles
description: A fire at an air-defense base 18 miles southeast of Moscow destroyed 12 S-300 antiaircraft missiles and three launchers, Russian Air Force officials said, but they denied an initial report by one television network that two missiles had accidentally launched and that the residents of a nearby town were evacuated. An air force spokesman said the fire erupted during a check of launch systems at the base, near the town of Zakharovo, and took more than three hours to bring under control. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: New Start For Toads
description: Biologists with the Fish and Wildlife Service released 1,300 hatchery-bred Wyoming toads and 1,900 late-stage tadpoles in southern Wyoming. The Wyoming toad is considered one of the most endangered amphibian species in North America. It has been protected by the federal Endangered Species Act since 1984 and is found only at one lake near Laramie. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, ELIZABETH GIBSON
description: FRANKLIN-Elizabeth Gibson on June 8th expectedly and blessedly after a short illness. Mother of John and Barbara Franklin, Gay and Brian Best and Churchill and Janet Franklin and 9 grandchildren. Services will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1848 Post Road, Darien, CT on Sunday June 10th at 2:00 PM. Memorials to St. Luke's Episcopal Church, P.O. Box 3128, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Behind a Book That Inspired McVeigh
description: The man who prosecutors said helped inspire Timothy J. McVeigh to commit the worst act of terrorism in American history lives and works on a southeastern West Virginia farm, the base for his neo-Nazi organization.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jeb Bush Announces He Will Seek Re-election
description: Beginning what is expected to be the most expensive and closely watched state campaign in Florida history, Gov. Jeb Bush announced today that he would seek election to a second four-year term next year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Chicken Crisis Eases
description: Hong Kong said it would resume importing live poultry from mainland China, a week after it slaughtered 1.4 million chickens and other birds to contain an outbreak of avian influenza. The territory had banned imports of chickens, ducks, and geese from China, although it said there was no evidence the flu virus had originated there. Japan and South Korea both banned imports of poultry from China this week. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST TEXAS: NO-SEX ORDER DRAWS OBJECTION A complaint has been filed with the State Commission on Judicial Conduct about a judge's probation order directing a 19- year-old registered sex offender to abstain from sex unless he is married. The order was issued by Judge J. Manuel Banales of State District Court after he learned that the offender, Robert Torres, who was sentenced to five years probation in 1999 for having sex with a 13- year-old girl, had since fathered a daughter with a 16- year-old girl and impregnated a 17-year-old. Mr. Torres's lawyer, Gerald Rogen, asked for an investigation into whether the order violates his client's rights.

title: Tennessee Banker Chosen As Nominee to Fed Board
description: Susan Schmidt Bies, executive vice president of the First Tennessee National Corporation, was nominated by President Bush to fill one of two openings on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, the White House said today.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: No-Sex Order Draws Objection
description: A complaint has been filed with the State Commission on Judicial Conduct about a judge's probation order directing a 19-year-old registered sex offender to abstain from sex unless he is married. The order was issued by Judge J. Manuel Baales of State District Court after he learned that the offender, Robert Torres, who was sentenced to five years probation in 1999 for having sex with a 13-year-old girl, had since fathered a daughter with a 16-year-old girl and impregnated a 17-year-old. Mr. Torres's lawyer, Gerald Rogen, asked for an investigation into whether the order violates his client's rights.

title: Guatemalan Court Sentences 3 Soldiers for 1998 Murder of Bishop
description: In a verdict human rights advocates hailed as a bold strike against official impunity, a Guatemalan court sentenced three military men to 30 years in prison yesterday for the 1998 murder of a Roman Catholic bishop. The panel also ordered that three other high-ranking officers be investigated for possible complicity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, GENE
description: HERMAN-Gene. A man with a very large appetite for life and an even larger heart. The world is less without him. Lenore Salazar

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: G.E. Meeting Delayed
description: The scheduled meeting between the General Electric chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., and the European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, has been deferred, the company said. Mr. Welch is in Brussels with a team of lawyers representing G.E. and Honeywell International to negotiate regulatory approval of their $41 billion merger. G.E. has until the middle of next week to deal with European regulators' objections to the deal. Unless G.E. abandons the deal, a final ruling will be made at the weekly meeting of European commissioners on July 4 or July 11. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Beliefs; Hiring for faith-based programs: issues may be complicated, but the public has an emphatic view.
description: However the Democratic takeover of the Senate may affect President Bush's proposal to bolster government support for religious social services organizations, it seems clear that while people generally support the plan, their most serious concern involves hiring: fear that the groups will discriminate in favor of those with their own beliefs.

title: The Rural Life; The Organic Reflex
description: For the second year in a row, all the bees in all three hives were dead when I opened them in early April. Two kinds of mites have been ravaging bee populations in the United States for the past decade, and my bees are not immune. When you open a healthy hive in midsummer, you can practically feel the frames of honey and brood cells quivering as you lift them, resonating with the pulse of wingbeats and respiration from clustering bees. The enterprise is utterly alive, the collective intact. I took that vitality more for granted than I should have. The bee colonies collapsed, the snows came, and in one of the hives this spring I found the nest of a mouse that had eaten its way into the sweet darkness and wintered over, unstung. So I began again, but in a different place, and with a renewed commitment to raise bees and let the honey take care of itself. There are two hives now, and on warm days the entrances are choked with bees.

title: House Committee Chairman Faults Inquiry on Firestone
description: Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has criticized federal regulators for investigating only the tires in a spate of tire-related rollovers of Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles. Mr. Tauzin asked regulators to study the performance of the Explorer as well as that of the Firestone tires.

title: Walter E. Rogers, 92, Texas Congressman
description: Walter E. Rogers, a Texas Democrat who served eight terms in the House of Representatives, died on May 31 at a hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 92.

title: National Briefing | Washington: 13 Nominations Announced
description: President Bush announced the names of 13 people to serve in his administration this week, and sent the nominations of 16 people already announced to the Senate, bringing to 76 the number awaiting confirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, ELISE DACOSTA
description: WATERMAN-Elise DaCosta. On June 7, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Philip M. Waterman. Devoted and proud mother and mother-in-law of Philip M. Waterman Jr. and Jane, Marie W. Harris and Kenneth. Loved and admired grandmother of Philip M. Waterman III, Anne L. Waterman, Kenneth A. Harris Jr. and Ellen Harris Knoblock and Henry. Adored great-grandmother of Christopher H. Knoblock and Caroline D. Knoblock. Dear sister of Manette D. Kaufmann. Elise was a remarkable and elegant woman. She distinguished herself to family and friends by her wisdom, wit and zeal for life. Her special prescence will be deeply missed. Services will be private. Doantions may be made to the American Jewish Committee, 165 E. 56th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: 2 Architectural Firms Chosen to Design East River Tract
description: Two New York architecture firms responsible for prominent buildings in the city have been selected to design a master plan for a mixed-use development on what is described as the largest undeveloped site in Manhattan, a nine-acre riverfront stretch south of the United Nations complex.

title: 'Narnia' With a Twist
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Step On Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Strategies Vary When It Comes to the Belmont
description: How do you win the Belmont Stakes, a race of a mile and a half, a distance few horses of any age run? The trainer Todd Pletcher intends to apply two tactics when the gates open today on the 133rd running of the Belmont, the Triple Crown's last leg.

title: A Good Job Is Hard to Find, Indeed
description: In the year 2020 every American's right to ''universal sex care'' will be acknowledged. Joe (Godfrey L. Simmons Jr.), a political theorist, understands sex care's importance -- it is, after all, ''health care for the mind, body and spirit combined'' -- but he may not be as comfortable as he says he is about the fact that his lover, Sondra (Lourdes Martin), is a successful sex worker.

title: Posada's Injury Gives Greene Opportunity to Prove His Worth
description: Todd Greene remained in the Yankees' lineup last night, catching for the third straight game. With Jorge Posada unable to catch because of a sprained left thumb, Greene has filled a dual need, helping cure the Yankees' offensive problems, too.

title: An Immigrant, a Friendly Boy, And a Murder on a Riverbank
description: As he appeared before a judge today on charges that he murdered a 10-year-old boy here last month, a Honduran immigrant was described in and out of court as an apparent illegal alien who had no steady work, little money and, at times, a chip on his shoulder.

title: A Troubling City Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York's City Council have agreed on a $39.6 billion city budget that has changed little from the risky budget proposal first offered by the mayor two months ago. The new budget retains an array of expensive tax cuts and gimmicks that create huge deficits in the years ahead. Moreover, this budget does too little to improve New York's public schools.

title: The Next Step On Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHERT, AUGUSTA
description: BORCHERT-Augusta. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of the dear Mother of our Honorary Vice President Alfred Fayer and beloved Grandmother of our President Russell Fayer. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi

title: Bloomberg Assails Rivals' Financing
description: Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday released a new television advertisement in which he defended using millions of dollars of his personal fortune to finance his campaign for mayor, and he attacked his opponents for accepting governmental subsidies and ''special interest'' money to finance their own campaigns.

title: For Poor Kids, Back to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans for the Meadowlands and for a new arena in Newark referred incorrectly in some copies to the football team that used to play in Flushing, Queens. It is the Jets, not the Giants.

title: Skip Dessert
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning a Bushy Plant Into a Miniature Tree
description: IN the world of gardening, a ''standard'' is a naturally bushy plant trained to have a clear stem capped by a mop of leaves. A miniature tree. Some gardeners love them; others will have nothing to do with them.

title: Against A.L.'s Worst, the Mets Can Do No Better
description: The Mets had taken a series from the first-place Philadelphia Phillies before coming to Tropicana Field, home of a tilted roof, synthetic grass, Dick Vitale and the worst team in baseball. Surely, it seemed, an interleague series with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays would sustain some momentum for the Mets.

title: Amy Friedman and David Appelbaum
description: Amy Elizabeth Friedman, a daughter of Sally Friedman and Victor Friedman of Moorestown, N.J., is to be married at her parents' house today to Dr. David Appelbaum, the son of Dr. Eva Hirschenstein Appelbaum and Dr. Jerome Appelbaum of Manhattan. Rabbi Andrea London is to officiate.

title: June 3-9; The Root of a Famine
description: BOTANICAL sleuths named a new suspect this week in the blight that wiped out the Irish potato crop, starved a million people and drove two million others to North America between 1845 and 1852. DNA tests of a leaf saved from that period excluded a Mexican strain of blight as a suspect and suggested another that originated in the Andean highlands and traveled to Ireland in Peruvian bat guano, imported for fertilizer.

title: Taking a Bushy Plant And Making It a Standard
description: IN the world of gardening, a ''standard'' is a naturally bushy plant trained to have a clear stem capped by a mop of leaves. A miniature tree. Some gardeners love them, others will have nothing to do with them.

title: Amy Campbell, Morgan Murphy
description: Amy Taska Campbell, a daughter of Valerie Campbell of Lloyd Neck, N.Y., and the late George Campbell Jr., was married at her mother's home yesterday to Morgan Wells Wiggins Murphy, the son of Susan and Michael Murphy of Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Dr. F. Morgan Roberts, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Casserole Brigade
description: WIDOWER'S HOUSE A Study in Bereavement. Or, How Margot and Mella Forced Me to Flee My Home. By John Bayley. 246 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUDEROV, PHYLLIS P.
description: SUDEROV-Phyllis P. Beloved wife of Richard. Devoted mother of Gail and Andrew. Loving sister of Priscilla Nitzberg. Graveside services Sunday, 3 PM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. For more information call 516487-9600.

title: June 3-9; Colombian Rebel Resigns
description: His heavy hand has for years shaped Colombia's brutal conflict, mostly in the form of widespread massacres and political assassinations. But Carlos Castao, head of the country's feared, ultra-rightist paramilitary army, has resigned, apparently in an internal shake-up within the 8,000-man organization. The details remain sketchy, but the group announced Mr. Castao had left military matters behind to focus on political organizing. Few, however, believe that the charismatic leader -- the lone face of the anti-guerrilla organization -- will soon fade from the scene. Juan Forero

title: Music Mixed With Social Messages
description: For those looking for something a bit different, there is Fishbone, a wildly eclectic rock, punk, ska band, that was ahead of its time back in 1979, when it was formed. And the band continues to be ahead of the curve. Fishbone puts on a loud, raucous show that serves up heavy doses of funk in a way most other hard-rock bands don't ever attempt to capture. Their sax-driven hyperactive performance sometimes distracts from the band's strong social messages and humor, but with so much to watch and listen to, there is no sense of loss. They perform Friday at Birch Hill Entertainment Complex in Old Bridge. Robbie Woliver

title: Vanbiesbrouck Calls It Quits
description: Saying that ''it's time,'' John Vanbiesbrouck, the backup goalie for the Devils, announced his retirement tonight after the Devils lost the Stanley Cup to the Colorado Avalanche.

title: The Busy Season
description: IT'S piano recital season again, which means that I'm engaged in the uphill battle of getting 37 elementary and intermediate students ready to perform.

title: Was This Soccer Mom a Terrorist?
description: I see no reason why Olson should not be called to account for her actions just because she has established a new life. From your article, it seems that there is enough evidence for an indictment, and Olson will have her day in court. She is certainly using the system to delay her day of reckoning. She is entitled to a presumption of innocence and to face her accusers. But let the evidence come out and let a jury decide her guilt or innocence. Too bad she didn't like county jail.

title: Iran's Volatile Experiment: Voters Elect to Proceed
description: The extraordinary voter turnout and landslide victory for President Mohammad Khatami of Iran illustrates that no matter what his failures, the vast majority of the Iranian electorate believes it still has both a stake in Iran's electoral system and at least some hope for his vision of reform.

title: The World; Arafat Is the Leader, But Who's In Charge?
description: ISRAEL'S prime minister, Ariel Sharon, makes it sound simple: If Yasir Arafat wants peace, he must halt the suicide bombings and other acts of terror and he must do it by arresting the several dozen Islamic militants on a list Israel has handed him.

title: His Gardens Grow With Love
description: IT'S hard to imagine the neighborhood cop on the beat or the fire captain saying, ''Call me at home.'' But Scott Farrington is a gardener you can call at home, and he works for the city of New York.

title: Mets' Trachsel Finds Rhythm, but Still Loses
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 9  Greg Vaughn turned to Billy Hatcher, a coach on the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, during Friday's game and offered an observation. Steve Trachsel, said Vaughn, a Devil Rays outfielder, is working a lot faster. He is attacking hitters with his fastball, Vaughn said, the way a pitcher must.

title: Living In Denial, Comfortably, In a Big Home
description: YOU would think that between the economic slowdown and the high cost of heating, people would become nervous and build smaller homes. But that is not the experience of Lee Baum, a Memphis builder. He is building or preparing to build five McMansions, including one for a doctor who is putting the home around the corner from his present big house so that his children and grandchildren will have a place to stay when they visit.

title: 'Stupid Penalties' Underscore Devils' Loss of Composure
description: DENVER, June 9  Before every game this season, Larry Robinson wrote the word discipline on the blackboard in the Devils' dressing room.

title: Was This Soccer Mom a Terrorist?
description: I met Bill Harris at the home of friends in Indianapolis in 1968, while I was in college. Bill was the childhood friend of my girlfriend's husband, and at the time, he was clean-cut, nonpolitical and his drugs of choice were Budweiser and Marlboro. He was at their house as the blind date of a mutual college friend.

title: Devils Fans Don't Lose Hope, Even as the Clock Runs Out
description: Arms crossed defiantly across the front of his lucky Devils jersey and a homemade Stanley Cup fashioned from duct tape and a stack of Tupperware containers on the barstool at his side, Larry Marino chuckled softly when asked about his beloved hockey team's chances midway through the second period of tonight's championship-deciding game seven.

title: 'Anti-Billboard' Adds a Patch of Sky
description: Not all billboards usurp the sky. Michael Krondl, an artist who lives in Stuyvesant Town, created a photographic mural of fluffy clouds and put it on a building at 47 West Street, near the Manhattan exit of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. The black-and-white ''anti billboard,'' which went up late last month, is based on a photograph Mr. Krondl took of a cloud formation that floated over New York Harbor one day last October. The image was digitally enlarged and transferred onto a 56-foot-high vinyl sign, using the same inkjet technology developed for outdoor advertisers. ''The effect,'' Mr. Krondl said, ''is to punch a hole in the skyline.'' DENNY LEE

title: White Plains Approves $75 Million Housing Complex
description: The White Plains Common Council has approved a proposal by JPI, a Texas developer, to build a $75 million apartment complex on a vacant lot on Mamaroneck Avenue. In all, the council is considering about 1,800 new apartments in the city. The Mamaroneck Avenue building will have 186 one-bedroom units and 95 two-bedroom units in an eight-story building and three-story townhouses. Rents will start at $2,000 a month for a one-bedroom apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. It has been 15 years since you left but you are always with me with everlasting love. Would that you could return. Harry

title: Julie Gold and Glen Anderson
description: WITH her auburn ringlets, alabaster complexion and azure eyes, Julie Ellen Gold looks every bit a mythological heroine. An intrepid explorer, she grew up in Brooklyn and loves to investigate the city's nether regions and dine at new restaurants before they are reviewed.

title: Rahal Brash as Ever in Formula One
description: On a recent Grand Prix weekend in the motor home of the Jaguar Formula One team, Bobby Rahal accidentally knocked over a life-sized cardboard likeness of Eddie Irvine, the team's leading driver.

title: The Dream of a Worthy Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Wild Thing' Returns
description: MITCH WILLIAMS has his concentration face on as he steps into the cage for batting practice, his cheeks glimmering with sweat in the late afternoon sun.

title: Shaken Japan Tries to Face Aftermath of School Attack
description: As families prepared to bury the eight children slain at their school here on Friday, Japan was struggling today to come to terms with the mass killing that shattered its image as a haven of safety and order.

title: Fatherly Advice To the President On North Korea
description: In an effort to influence one of his son's most crucial foreign policy decisions, former President George Bush sent to the president through his aides a memo forcefully arguing the need to reopen negotiations with North Korea, according to people who have seen the document.

title: A Pipeline Proposal for the Sound
description: A PROPOSAL to build a 40-mile stretch of natural gas pipeline across Long Island Sound between Connecticut and Long Island has divided conservation groups on both sides of the Sound, not just along state lines, but along philosophies. One side said the pipeline will hurt the environment; the other said it will help.

title: Hearing the Words
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBAKCS
description: GREENE ON CAPRI: A Memoir, by Shirley Hazzard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.) With a pervasive wariness and modesty, the novelist recalls the long, often stormy, friendship she and her husband, the Flaubert scholar Francis Steegmuller, struck up with Graham Greene, who is portrayed as a proud but prickly soul who ruthlessly disagreed with anyone who agreed with him. ''Hazzard tells of a relationship that was a treasure hunt among nettles,'' Richard Eder wrote in the Book Review last year. Her ''feeling for the landscape is incantatory.''

title: Bethany Saltman, Thayer Case
description: Bethany Ann Saltman, the daughter of Libby H. Saltman of Okemos, Mich., and Jeffrey Saltman of Glendale, Ariz., is to be married today to Thayer Stimson Case, a son of Dr. Jean Case and Dr. David Case of Bronxville, N.Y. Sensei Bonnie Myotai Treace, a Buddhist priest and the vice abbess of the Zen Mountain Monastery in Mount Tremper, N.Y., is to officiate at Opus 40, a quarry in Saugerties, N.Y., that has been turned into an an environmental rock sculpture by Harvey Fite.

title: Mildly Ambitious
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman has always been a Republican's idea of a model Democrat. When Al Gore selected Lieberman as his running mate last summer, George Bush's spokesman remarked that Gore ''has chosen a man whose positions are more similar to Governor Bush's positions than to his own.'' That was campaign hyperbole, but Lieberman had long occupied the conservative wing of his party on issues like defense spending, tax cuts, school vouchers and, notoriously, the entertainment industry. When Bush won and set about trying to define a new ideological center, Lieberman was one of the Democratic senators expected to join him there, at least on a number of key policy items.

title: Hertz Fleet Is Champagne Octane
description: Rather than renting the usual Taurus or Escort from Hertz, travelers with deep pockets can now reserve a Jaguar XJ8 or a Lincoln LS. Hertz has a new program, the Prestige Collection, in 20 North American cities offering vehicles from Jaguar, Land Rover, Lincoln and Volvo. The program, in Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Miami and Montreal, among other cities (it is expected in New York next year), guarantees renters the make and model they specify.

title: East New York: a Neighborhood Reborn
description: FOUR stops after the No. 3 IRT line rises out of its tunnel in the far reaches of Brooklyn, its elevated tracks enter East New York, looming above what was, less than a decade ago, a six-block stretch of weed-choked grassland.

title: Along the Rivers, Routes for Paddlers
description: AT a landing behind a parking lot off Route 3 in Cromwell, about a dozen people eased their canoes and kayaks into the Mattabesset River. Soon they were in a different world from the nearby cars and commerce as they paddled past quiet hillsides looking for birds and making their way toward the big freshwater tidal wetland called Cromwell Meadows.

title: Style: Weekend; Hotel Style Vs. Motel Style
description: Remember when your idea of a travel souvenir was a terra cotta pot from France or a bikini from Miami? Never mind that. Now you have to take home the room you stayed in too. Increasing numbers of travel addicts seeking to prolong that carefree holiday feeling for -- oh, say, ever -- are clamoring for hotel or motel style at home. Why not have the hand-troweled plaster walls and French windows of your favorite Provenal auberge, the heated towel bars and giant vintage bathtub of that majestic London hotel, or the retro-modern furniture and Venetian blinds of that great, cheap-and- cheerful place you stayed at on the beach? Whether it's the romantic affair of five-star-inn style or the breezy one-night-stand aura of the budget motel, hospitality style, as you might call it, not only makes you feel as if you're on a permanent vacation but also saves you from committing to any decorating decisions you might later regret. Pilar Viladas

title: Phil Schaap, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL VIOLENCE
description: New Jersey's public schools reported 21,367 incidents of violence, vandalism and substance abuse in the 1999-2000 school year, according to a report submitted by the state Department of Education last week. For the first time, schools reported incidents electronically and some categories were changed from previous years, so there are not comparable statistics from other years. The 1999-2000 data will be used as a baseline in future years. About 12,660 reports were of violent incidents and about 5,140 were of vandalism. The data showed that most incidents of violence occurred in middle schools and high schools, and that most substance abuse incidents were reported in high schools. Two-thirds of the state's districts reported five or fewer incidents. The complete report, including breakdowns by district, is on the State Department of Education Web site at www.state.nj.us/education. Debra Nussbaum

title: That Part-Time Pace
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dream of a Worthy Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sides of Mies at the Whitney and Modern
description: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe is known for his minimalist motto ''Less is more,'' but this month, New York museums can't seem to get enough of the German-born architect. The Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art are mounting concurrent exhibitions beginning June 21 that divide Mies's career into two major phases.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: WHEN YOU COME TO A FORK

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: PC, M.D.

title: Covering Ground On Commuting Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing It All Back Home
description: ''Music hath charms to soothe a savage breast,'' wrote the English playwright William Congreve. In ''Walter and Henry,'' a Showtime movie that has its premiere tonight at 8, music goes one step further, mending a family shattered by misunderstanding.

title: Was This Soccer Mom a Terrorist?
description: Iam angered by the prosecution of the alleged former terrorist Kathleen Soliah. It is strange that this woman will be tried in the same year that Bob Kerrey admits to killing civilians in Vietnam and Gerald Ford is honored for pardoning Richard Nixon's criminal behavior. It is hypocritical to pursue charges against this misguided rebel turned responsible housewife, while violence by more powerful people is forgiven or forgotten.

title: Political Briefing; Seeking a Democrat For Thurmond's Seat
description: In politics, an open seat draws candidates the way a bright light draws moths. But not the seat that will come open next year when South Carolina's nonagenarian Republican senator, Strom Thurmond, retires after 48 years of service.

title: He Wrote of Time Running Out, and It Did
description: WHEN Jonathan Larson first performed the show that was to become ''Tick, Tick . . . Boom!'' on May 18, 1990, he had been struggling for eight years to establish a career in the theater.

title: Political Briefing; Hopeful Lieberman Keeps a High Profile
description: Sometimes, it seems, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman never left the campaign trail. Since last Nov. 7, he has made numerous trips across the country, talking up the Democratic agenda, speaking up for local and state Democratic candidates and raising money to help the party.

title: June 3-9; Anything Goes
description: Never has the unpredictability of a civil jury been more impressively displayed than in the 18-page verdict finding that Philip Morris had knowingly harmed and misled a heavy smoker now ill with lung cancer. There, on the last page, in the space for punitive damages, in the Los Angeles jury's foreman's squirrelly script, was ''$3 billion.''

title: For a Dad, Videoconference Ties That Bind
description: WATCHING ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' in 1968, I marveled at the improbable scene of an astronaut making a video call to his family back on Earth. I never imagined that some 30 years later, I'd rush out of a business dinner in Hong Kong to make a videoconference call to my home in New York so that I could see my 17-month-old daughter, Noa, before her breakfast.

title: Natasha Maximoff, Peter Chandler
description: Natasha Franziska Maximoff, a daughter of Inga M. Maximoff and Richard M. Maximoff of Oxford, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter David Chandler, a son of Warren W. Chandler of Fair Haven, N.J., and the late Elizabeth L. Chandler. Mayor William E. Leonard of Fair Haven officiated on the beach in Spring Lake, N.J. On June 24, the couple will have a Roman Catholic ceremony at Burgthalschenke, a restaurant in Thal, Germany.

title: New Milford Shows Off for the Cameras
description: FOR nearly two weeks, downtown New Milford has seen life turned upside down by a heavily equipped 100-member occupying force.

description: They spent two years poring over case studies and slogging through ''Financial Reporting and Control,'' but Harvard's nearly 1,000 newly minted M.B.A.'s may best remember the salty bon mots from John F. Welch Jr., the departing chairman of General Electric.

title: Phil Schaap, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Beach Towns Evolve by Adding Year-Round Homes
description: AN oceanfront block in Manasquan has been bulldozed to make room for an enclave of 26 upscale condominiums, a move that in many ways is a metaphor for the continued evolution of the shore community in southern Monmouth County to a year-round address.

title: Same Time, Same Place
description: FEARLESS JONES

title: Anti-Abortion Activist Limited in Protest
description: A state court has ordered the Rev. John Murphy, a suspended Roman Catholic priest and anti-abortion activist, to stay off the site of a Nassau County abortion clinic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, STANLEY
description: SCHIFF-Stanley, Beloved Doctor. Funeral Sunday, 12 noon at Parkside Chapel. 9860 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01: Document; The Age of Anxiety
description: The Sesame Workshop, creators of ''Dragon Tales'' and ''Sesame Street,'' recently released a study about the lives of 6- to 11-year-olds. Last summer, researchers canvassed malls across the nation asking children to fill out these notebooks. Two hundred thirty-three children participated, drawing pictures, making collages and writing essays. Some of the children wished they could drive; others wanted to be Britney Spears or Michael Jordan for a day. But nearly two-thirds betrayed anxiety about guns, death and violence, a proportion that rose to 86 percent for 9- to 11-year-olds. Here's what six children drew and wrote in response to questions about their fears and worries.

title: The Princetonian Who Gave Bloomsday Its Place on the Calendar
description: For fans of James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' next Saturday is Bloomsday, a day of celebration. ''Ulysses'' takes place on June 16, 1904, chronicling Leopold Bloom's fictional rounds through Dublin. Princeton may seem far from Dublin, but it nurtured a book lover named Sylvia Beach, who would go on to publish the first edition of ''Ulysses'' in Paris in 1922. Beach, proprietor of the Shakespeare & Company bookstore on the Rue de l'Odeon in Paris, never let go of her ties to Princeton, remembering her hometown with affection in her memoirs. She left her papers to Princeton University when she died in 1962 and is buried in the Princeton Cemetery next to her father, the Rev. Sylvester Woodbridge Beach, Princeton Class of 1876 and pastor of the First (now Nassau) Presbyterian Church here. At Beach's grave, a Princeton professor of English literature, Maria DiBattista, spoke about Beach, Joyce and Princeton.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; For Old Union Carbide Headquarters, a Time of Flux
description: A MILE and quarter down a private two-lane road within a 646-acre tract of unspoiled forest and meadowland alive with deer and wild turkey lies the 2.1-million-square-foot former world headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation -- Connecticut's largest office building, acknowledged to be among the most architecturally significant, innovative and controversial office structures in the country.

title: Style: Weekend; The Dry Look
description: Bubble Indemnity

title: Virginia DeFina, Stephen Scott
description: Virginia Marie DeFina and Stephen Robert Scott were married yesterday by the Rev. James Yannarell at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Keep 'Em Moving
description: ORPHAN TRAINS The Story of Charles Loring Brace and the Children He Saved and Failed. By Stephen O'Connor. Illustrated. 362 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $27.

title: 'Carousel' Emerges From Darkness
description: THE 1992 London staging of ''Carousel,'' acclaimed on Broadway two years later, proved that Rodgers and Hammerstein's classic, once considered sunny, was unafraid of the dark. Suddenly it became fashionable to dwell on the fatalism, not the fantasy, of the timeless love story between Billy Bigelow and Julie Jordan.

title: Trying to Provide Art For $2 Plus $1.50 a Mile
description: IN the ''I Taxi'' comic book, the nave and befuddled superhero Taximan, a tourist from another planet, has landed on earth to discover ''the meaning of Taxi.'' His quest takes him to garages and taxi stands and inside cabs, where he spends hours gabbing with the drivers.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Projects With Artificial Lakes Transform Bare Sites
description: FOUR fountains spout giant sprays of water in the middle of a three-acre serpentine lake that meanders through the center of Victorian Gardens, a complex of 34 rental apartment buildings with more than 400 units on 42 acres in the heart of Suffolk County. The luxuriously landscaped Holtsville development, which is opening today, was once the site of a proposed industrial park in an area surrounded by sand pits.

title: Filling the Exotic Gap
description: THE second thing you notice on walking into Masala Grill is that there are quite a few customers. That's an improvement over the empty chairs of the last restaurant, Twist Rojo, that occupied this upstairs spot off the main drag of Nassau Street.

title: Sky Watch: Serpens the Snake
description: Serpens the Snake is the only constellation cut in two. The Serpents head lies west of Ophiuchus and is known as Serpens Caput; while to the east of Ophiuchus lies smaller Serpens Cauda, the tail.

title: Crushing the Klan
description: To the Editor:

title: You'll Want to Take Notes, Folks. There Will Be a Test.
description: Last week, Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, defended the administration's reexamination of evidence of global warming, challenging critics to find another instance when most of a cabinet sat ''week after week after week'' through briefings by scientists on such a complicated topic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUAT, HELEN VICTORIA SHAPIRO
description: QUAT-Helen Victoria Shapiro. Beloved wife of the late Leon, beloved mother of Daniel and the late Joanna, and grandmother to Kevin, cherished sister of Dorothy Evslin and the late Mortimer Shapiro, and beloved aunt of Ruthy Samuel, and the Shapiro, Evslin, Lobsenz and Dayan children, died peacefully in her sleep on June 4, 2001. She was 82 years old. Family and friends will gather at her home at the Mayfair House, 96 Cuttermill Rd, Great Neck, NY, 11021 on Thursday June 14 from 25pm. Inquiries should be directed to Daniel at 518-325-1004.

description: PARADISE

title: Functional Family
description: SOMEHOW FORM

title: June 3-9; . . . And in L.A., Too
description: It ranks as one of the odder alliances in all of American politics, but City Attorney James K. Hahn won the Los Angeles mayoralty with a rock-solid coalition of inner-city black voters and conservative whites in the suburban San Fernando Valley, blocking the hopes of former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa to become his city's first Latino mayor in 129 years. Latinos amounted to about 22 percent of the electorate, a new record, in a city whose total population is now almost half Hispanic, and they went overwhelmingly for Mr. Villaraigosa. But it was not enough to match Mr. Hahn, the white son of a beloved local politician who represented heavily black neighborhoods for years.

title: Blacks, AIDS And Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH/Richard P. Howard; T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation Fund
description: RICHARD P. HOWARD is a risk-averse technophobe, and while his fears might have been a handicap when dot-coms were flying high, they have given him an edge this year.

title: Putting Some Weight Behind Arbitration
description: Investors who win cases against their brokers in arbitration now have a better chance of actually receiving their awards in a timely fashion.

title: To Understand Is to Be Perplexed
Tiny Invader Becomes a Bully In Local Waters
description: TURN over almost any rock uncovered by low tide in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut and you probably will uncover a small, purplish-black alien with six colorfully banded legs and two nimble claws -- a Pacific shore crab.

title: The Refined Transformation of a Diner
description: THE sugared doughnuts at Crazy Dog in Westhampton Beach were the stuff dreams are made of: a sextet of hot, airy pillows (no center holes) escorted by ramekins of warm raspberry jam. This ultimate comfort food was just the kind of dish one might expect to find at a restaurant that once had diner in its name.

title: They've Got the Beat
description: It's advertised to ''adults and mature teenagers'' -- no training required -- and it's not part of church services. But spiritual drumming, a monthly workshop in Montclair's First Congregational Church, attracts 25 to 40 perfectly decent folk who enjoy beating with others of the same percussive bent. Their next chance is Friday at 8 p.m.

title: The 'Roswell' Army Fights for Its Show on the Web
description: WHEN Jason Katims, an executive producer of ''Roswell,'' is asked whether his show's fans are, well, a little different, he laughs.

title: Is This the Woman to Rescue Harper's Bazaar?
description: FOR nearly all of her career, Glenda Bailey, the new editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, has had the distinction of being a thorn among roses. Though smart, with a belligerent truthful streak that has helped propel her to the top of fashion publishing, she has suffered, especially in her native England, from not looking more fashionably smart. Prominent teeth flash with intermittent bursts of laughter, and her country-girl face is framed by dense, reddish curls that she has refused to straighten.

title: As Jumbo Jets Grow So Does Loading Time
description: TO air travelers, it may seem that the longest part of any trip comes after the plane has landed and everyone has stood up, waiting for the door to open so they can file out. That period is an impatient time for the airlines, too, because their planes make money only when they are flying.

title: Miami and U.S.C. Advance in Series
description: Danny Matienzo hit two home runs and drove in six runs as Miami beat Tennessee, 21-13, last night in a record-setting game that completed the first round of the College World Series in Omaha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTAGNA, PIERINA
description: CASTAGNA-Pierina, May 10, age 85 of Bronxville, NY. Born in Ruvo, Italy to Giuseppe and Francesca Orientale Mastrolonardo. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore, mother of Joseph & Vincent, grandmother of Julia, Vincent, Sal & Dawn.

title: A Model at 70: Bring On the Cameras
description: WHEN I told friends that I was meeting Carmen Dell'Orefice on the occasion of her 70th birthday, I heard a lot of wailing. She can't possibly be 70, they insisted of the model who goes by her first name. She is so gorgeous, so thin, so perfect, there's not a woman alive who can match her.

title: Missing Perpetrators
description: To the Editor:

title: The Allergy Prison
description: For Carl and Amy Nathan, milk is the enemy. They have felt that way since their son was 2 1/2 years old, when they saw him physically disintegrate in a matter of minutes after someone at a party fed him something that contained yogurt. Carl and Amy already knew Eric was somewhat allergic, because they had previously seen him respond to milk with wheezing and itching. Still, they weren't prepared for this: in the driveway, on the way to the car, he staggered, retching violently, and his face grew swollen. By the time they were in the car and on their way to the emergency room, they could tell from his gasping that his throat was closing up. ''You'd know that sound if you heard it,'' says Carl, a soft-spoken, precise man who then demonstrates: out of his mouth comes a noise like a sob, rasping and strained. Although he is a doctor, a research immunologist, in fact, he says he felt an unprecedented panic as he reached into the glove compartment for the syringe of adrenaline that was there in case of such a reaction. ''There probably isn't a part of the anatomy that I haven't injected a needle into,'' he says. ''But that's very different from being a parent, in the back seat of a car, in the dark, with your son dying in your arms.''

title: Letters: Is the Bush Team Nimble Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; A Case of Radical Surgery on Failing Schools
description: Inner-city schools have grown dramatically worse in the four decades since the economist Milton Friedman first argued for permitting children to transfer from failing public schools to successful private schools, taking public dollars with them. Critics protested that a voucher plan would bleed dollars from an under-funded system. But the Friedmanites have continued to argue for permitting children to escape failing schools while they are young enough to be saved, leaving the schools that failed them to shape up or close.

title: Uncle Junior, a k a Dominic Chianese, Sings His Album, 'Hits' (of Course)
description: THE SETTING -- Sunday brunch at the Players Club, where at the end of a long, wood-paneled room with antler chandeliers, stood Dominic Chianese, also known as Uncle Junior in ''The Sopranos.'' Only the week before, the 70-year-old actor from Belmont in the Bronx had surprised fans by singing ''Core 'ngrato,'' or ''Ungrateful Heart,'' in the season's finale. On this occasion, he had shed his bulky glasses and mob boss disposition in favor of an acoustic guitar and a song list from his new album, ''Hits.''

title: Blood, Gore And Good Fishing
description: ''Casting menhaden bait for striped bass from the rocky shores of the bays, estuaries and islands along the Atlantic Coast constitutes the highest branch of American angling,'' wrote Genio Scott in ''Fishing in American Waters,'' published in 1869. Scott then wondered whether this method was not superior to fly fishing for salmon, and if so, if it outranked any angling in the world.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In a Children's Ward, Visiting Hours Are for a Museum
description: TWELVE-YEAR-OLD Duran Rogers was grinding corn on a stone. Sadayah Stafford, 7, was examining a cornhusk doll, and Terisha Sutton, 8, was holding a conch shell to her ear.

title: Private Sector; Goodyear's Aggressive Diplomat
description: DIPLOMACY has always come naturally to Samir F. Gibara. Maybe it is because he has lived in eight countries, or maybe because he speaks six languages. Or maybe he was just born that way.

title: Political Briefing: Seeking a Democrat For Thurmond's Seat
description: In politics, an open seat draws candidates the way a bright light draws moths. But not the seat that will come open next year when South Carolina's nonagenarian Republican senator, Strom Thurmond, retires after 48 years of service.

title: For a New Line of CD's, a Future Already Clouded
description: SURELY nobody planned it this way, but just as Teldec is on the brink of disappearing as an independent recording company, out it comes with an important new CD series: New Line, devoted to contemporary music. The first four releases are available, and two of them are superb. More are due soon, including some that look exciting in prospect, and Warner Classics, the parent company, is committed at least to completing a sequence of five CD's devoted to the music of Gyorgy Ligeti. But the welcome must be tempered with uncertainty.

title: Relocation, Relocation, Relocation
description: THE first time we moved to New Jersey, we had an excuse.
