description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Voters Hand Victory To Opponents Of Peace Pact
description: The British election has rewarded Protestant opponents of the Northern Ireland peace agreement led by the Rev. Ian Paisley and punished pro-agreement forces led by David Trimble. Britain announced today that talks to put the fragile accord in place would resume next week, but the election results cast the future of the pact in doubt.

title: Pound Ridge Lawyer Heads State Bar Association
description: ''The passion gets to you -- it becomes part of your being after a while,'' said Steven C. Krane, the new president of the New York State Bar Association.

title: June 3-9; On a Losing Streak
description: RICHARD P. MATSCH, the federal district judge who presided over the Oklahoma City bombing trial, denied Timothy J. McVeigh's request to delay his execution, set for tomorrow morning. But he also said he was shocked by the F.B.I.'s belated discovery of thousands of pages of documents in the case that the government had not turned over to defense lawyers.

title: June 3-9; Chinese Contacts Limited
description: Even before the April collision between a Chinese fighter and a Navy reconnaissance plane, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was taking a skeptical look at contacts between the Pentagon and the Chinese military. Afterward, however, Mr. Rumsfeld all but severed the contacts. Chinese generals are no longer invited to seminars at the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies, a Pentagon-funded research center.

title: Amy Friedman, David Appelbaum
description: Amy Elizabeth Friedman, a daughter of Sally Friedman and Victor Friedman of Moorestown, N.J., is to be married at her parents' house today to Dr. David Appelbaum, the son of Dr. Eva Hirschenstein Appelbaum and Dr. Jerome Appelbaum of Manhattan. Rabbi Andrea London is to officiate.

title: Jennifer McGoldrick, Joshua Solomon

title: Family Hiking In Oregon's Cascades
description: DEEP in the woods six miles up from the Columbia River in Oregon, the people who made Eagle Creek Trail faced a conundrum. The trail needs to cross the creek at a point where there is a deep gorge, with a torrential waterfall on one side and plunging nothingness on the other.

title: Colorado Defeats Devils to Win Stanley Cup
description: DENVER, June 9  The Colorado Avalanche won the Stanley Cup for the second time in six seasons tonight, and its players deserved every celebratory sip they took from it. The Avalanche earned the silver trophy by storming to a three-goal lead over the defending champion Devils and securing a 3-1 victory at the Pepsi Center in Game 7 of the Cup finals.

description: SPUTNIK SWEETHEART

title: When the Hunt for a Cure Hits Close to Home
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Style: Weekend; 10 Reasons To Weekend in The Eighth Wonder Of the World
description: It's the place that discovered that barbecued chicken and blue cheese are the happiest marriage in Buffalo. It's the place where 50's design can be as bipolar as it likes and get away with it -- on one pole, kitsch, on the other, Neutra-esque grandeur. As everyone struggles to make Modernism his own, Niagara shows how that familiar vocabulary can find its unique voice; Niagara actually makes Modernism look quaint.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, misidentified Shen Xuanhai, owner of the home that is now the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant. A reader's e-mail message on May 10 pointed out that Mr. Shen was a prominent businessman and government official; he was not the Qing Dynasty palace eunuch who designed the gardens. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

title: It's a Small Jungle, After All
description: LISTEN for the sounds, my wife, Mary, had said. The animals, at night, make so much noise. It seemed like solid advice as we headed off for the Animal Kingdom Lodge, a new Disney hotel near Orlando set inside a game reserve that promised an experience reminiscent of an Africa safari.

title: Godard Night and Day Is Too Much for Some Artists
description: Ed McGowin, an artist who lives on Grand Street, returned from Tokyo two weeks ago to find his kitchen flooded with a pulsating glow. An 11-foot-by-18-foot aluminum screen had been installed in an air shaft outside his window, and playing across it was a continuous loop of dissolving video images from a 1962 Jean-Luc Godard film, ''It's My Life.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01: The Ethicist; Doggone
description: My mother-in-law, elderly and ill, is devoted to her healthy 5-year-old dog. She has asked my husband to promise that when she dies, he will have her dog put down and cremated and its ashes buried with her. We offered to care for the dog after she dies, but she declined. My husband agreed to this, claiming it gives his mother comfort, but he does not intend to keep his promise. Is this an ethical solution? -- Anonymous, Massachusetts

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURKETT, THOMAS C.
description: BURKETT-Thomas C. June 9, 1970 to December 1, 1991. May your courage inspire those silenced by fear. May your kindness inspire those silenced by greed and hardness of heart to speak the truth. And trust us, Son, though your jaw is broken, your story is told. www.thepacc.org Love, Mom and Dad

title: Researchers Make an Ultra-Tiny Chip
description: Computer researchers have fashioned infinitesimally tiny electronic switches using conventional chipmaking equipment, demonstrating that the semiconductor industry will be able to continue shrinking its basic building blocks at a torrid pace at least until the end of this decade.

title: Naked Capitalists
description: One thing is clear from Frank Rich's wry, informative article on the adult-video industry, even from statements by its executives: the indispensable electronic device of 21st-century America is the fast-forward.

title: Heart of Greed
description: IN THE FOOTSTEPS

title: June 3-9; Elections All Over . . .
description: Frontrunners dominated elections in Peru, Britain and Iran, leaving Irish voters to deliver a shock in a referendum that rejected a treaty that was to pave the way for 12 new members in the European Union, most former Communist countries. . Stunned Irish and European leaders vowed to get round the impasse and admit new members by late 2004.

title: Downside of the Sports Boom: A Growing Shortage of Fields
description: ON any spring weekend, they are stacked up like airplanes at La Guardia -- soccer teams, waiting to get on the field.

description: Concluding that New York's labor movement is operating at far below its potential, national union leaders last week approved a plan intended to make the state's unions bigger and stronger.

description: There is perhaps no easier way to get a person started than to ask about a travel horror story.

title: Investing; Can Kraft Lay Enough Golden Eggs?
description: KRAFT is America's biggest food company by almost any measure. Its brands, including Maxwell House coffee, Oreo cookies, Jell-O pudding, Velveeta, Philadelphia cream cheese, Kool-Aid and Oscar Mayer hot dogs, are consumed in most American homes, and it dwarfs its domestic competitors.

title: Jordana Wiener, Jay Berman
description: Jordana Treger Wiener, a daughter of Judith Golub Wiener and Dr. Howard E. Weiner of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Jay Lawrence Berman, a son of Sharon L. Berman and Dr. David Berman of Sands Point, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Paley is to officiate in the Pavilion Room of the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

description: The Miami Dolphins re-signed the Pro Bowl safety Brock Marion to a two-year contract.

description: THE comics may be the funny pages, but the artists and writers who create daily moments of hilarity are a lonely lot. But once a month, the members of the Berndt Toast Gang leave their cartoons on the drawing board and meet at a Centerport restaurant.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: View From the Saddle
description: WHAT, I wonder, must Butch be thinking?

title: Baltimore Uses a Databank to Wake Up City Workers
description: The four police officers were spotted sound asleep on the job, napping in two patrol cars under a bridge, in a scene that has become a graphic part of one of the more confrontational municipal management experiments in the nation.

title: What to Do If the Lights Go Out
description: HERB ROSE, a Manhattan co-op consultant, has been advising clients to prepare for the possibility of a temporary power failure in New York City this summer. Two weeks ago, Mr. Rose learned first hand that his advice could come in handy.

title: The Royles: Mum, Dad, Daughter, Son and TV
description: DAD is sedentary, miserly and averse to washing. Chain-smoking Mum, partial to greasy fry-ups, hands out candy bars for dessert. Grandma gulps down brandy as if it were lemonade. The aimless teenage son hangs out with a petty thief, and his self-absorbed older sister feels not the tiniest maternal pang at the wails of her newborn in the other room.

title: Making Art Accessible to the Disabled
description: AT first glance, Greg Scasi and Wendy Malone would seem to have little in common. Mr. Scasi, 89, is blind and lives in an adult community in Huntington Station; Wendy Malone, 13, from Rockville Centre, attends the Mill Neck Manor School for the Deaf.

title: Leaving the Law For a Hoop Dream
description: ADAM SILVER is in the throes of his busy season and though it sometimes makes him feel harried, he is never grim. That's because, day in and day out, he is living a sports fan's dream.

title: More Than Tang
description: A civilian who recently dined with astronauts paid $20 million for the privilege, and all he got to eat was space food. But in the Kennedy Space Center's new Dine With an Astronaut program, having a meal with an astronaut costs $33.25 and up, $22.65 and up for ages 3 to 11, and the food sounds a lot more appetizing. Every Wednesday at 1 p.m. and Friday at 5 p.m. through Aug. 31 at the Space Center Visitor Complex an astronaut will dine with a group limited to 100 to allow for autographs, questions and photos. Typical fare: rotisserie chicken and a chocolate Space Shuttle. Tickets: (321) 449-4444 or www.kennedyspacecenter.com.

title: Empire-Building On a Paper Route
description: WHEN you grow up in harsh economic times, as I did during the Depression, there may be a special incentive to get ahead. My father died when I was 8. I lived with my mother and my four sisters in Detroit. I was the baby. As we grew older, my sisters and I all contributed to the upkeep of the house.

title: Debating the Law
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about ''A Beautiful Mind,'' a film based on the life of the mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr., included an outdated reference to his relationship with Alicia Nash. The Nashes, who were divorced in 1963, have remarried; the wedding was June 1, after the section went to press.

title: The Eastern Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Reform Mandate
description: A huge turnout of voters in Iran gave President Mohammad Khatami the thumping victory his supporters say he needs to revive his drive for greater democracy and social freedom.

title: Cuisine as Theater In the Napa Valley
description: At a new Napa Valley cooking theater, the public can watch chefs in action, taste the results, and not worry about doing dishes afterward.

title: Money, From Another Angle
description: If anyone comes to mind as New Jersey's most zealous drumbeater for the arts, with an accent on theater, it's likely to be Laura Aden. She is not about to give up her mission, but she's switching roles.

title: Style: Weekend; Footnotes: After the Falls
description: Visiting the waterfalls that dot the landscape of upstate New York is scenic enough, but the real wonders along the Interstate are entirely man-made. Lake Luzerne, about 20 miles north of Saratoga Springs, is an ideal starting point. After enjoying the views at Rockwell Falls, cruise a few miles west to Speculator (population: 625) for a glimpse of Austin Falls. There's more to do in bustling Lake George than listen to the roar of Shelving Rock Falls. You can load up on CorningWare at the factory outlet mall, or while away an afternoon in ''The Amazing Room of Rats'' at the House of Frankenstein Wax Museum. More curiosities abound at the nearby Magic Forest amusement park: the world's tallest Uncle Sam (36 feet) and Rex, the diving horse. Driving farther into the Adirondacks, you will stumble upon Beaver Meadows Falls and Rainbow Falls in St. Huberts. Around Keene Valley, the falls (Deer Brook and Mossy Cascade) take second billing to the Noon Mark Diner, with its 25 different kinds of homemade pie. Crossing west into Saranac Lake, you'll see no falling water, but Mountain Mist Custard has been a soft-serve institution for 50 years. Polish off your blackberry custard before popping by the Robert Louis Stevenson Memorial Cottage, where on display are the author's Scottish smoking jacket and yachting cap. As you slip south of the Adirondacks and into the Finger Lakes region, make pit stops in Rome for a tour of the cheese museum and Oneida, the former home of the Oneida Community, a utopian group and the creators of Oneida tableware. In Watkins Glen, visit Hector Falls and then tour what must be the Nascar capital of the North, complete with an international race course, where speed enthusiasts (with a valid license) can learn to drive at a branch of the Skip Barber Racing School. (Skip Barber alumni include Jerry Seinfeld and Tom Cruise.) By the time you've taken in all the waterfalls surrounding Ithaca, you'll be spent. In town, you can barter with the city's own currency. But you'll have to use greenbacks for a vegetarian meal at the Moosewood Restaurant and enough gas to motor home in your new Chrysler PT convertible. Maura Egan

title: The Dream of a Worthy Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: In Belleville, the Priorities Speak Volumes
description: ON the ceiling of the reference room at the Belleville Public Library are three allegorical panels painted in an Italian Renaissance style. Together, they tell the story of a man on a quest for knowledge and wisdom. The middle panel shows the man in mortal battle with a beast.

title: POSTINGS: A Web List of Places to Hold a Reception; Have a Party In a Landmark
description: Want to have a party -- or a corporate meeting, or a reception, or most any other kind of gathering -- in a landmark or a historic building? The Landmarks Conservancy, which works to preserve historic buildings, is offering a list of 29 to choose from on its Web site, www.nylandmarks.org.

title: Iran's President Wins a New Mandate to Promote Reform
description: Election returns in Iran today gave President Mohammad Khatami the thumping victory that supporters say he needs to revive his drive for greater democracy and social freedom in the Islamic Republic.

title: What a Music Capital Deserves in a Jazz Festival
description: I'M often asked why I don't do the European jazz-festival circuit each year. The journalistic answer is that premieres -- the reason a lot of classical critics fly to foreign countries -- are few and far between in jazz. But the real reason is that most of the bands on that circuit are either from here or on their way here.

title: Letters on Travel
description: Around Ronda

title: Guiding Lights For Vegetarians
description: THREE of our grandchildren eat no red meat and one of the three is a vegan, who eats no animal products at all -- no fish, milk, butter, eggs or gelatin. We have lived with vegetarian children for so long that traveling with them is usually no problem: they can read a menu in a window and know if they can manage. But staying nourished with Jennifer the Vegan, 17 years old, involves what we might call inconvenience foods.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a fundraising dinner for the Robin Hood Foundation misidentified the automobile given as a door prize. It was a Jaguar, not a Mercedes-Benz.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Yukie Okuyama, Mahdi Kazuto Shah, Hristoula Harakas, Ellen Cornfield and Denise Johnsson, Merce Cunningham Studio, New York, March 17, 2001

title: Europeans' Rallying Cry: One Share, One Vote!
description: HENRI LACHMANN had a grand vision. By merging his company, Schneider Electric S.A., which makes electrical equipment for factories and power plants, with Legrand S.A., a maker of consumer products like plugs and dimmers, he would create a French mini-version of General Electric, with $11 billion in revenue.

title: The World: Mr. Putin, Meet Mr. Bush; Who Needs Treaties?
description: TO speak about Russia, it has been said, is to discuss the future of the world. America resumes its historic dialogue with Russia on Saturday when President Bush sits down for his first meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, and it is a broad future indeed that they will consider.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEPPARD, DR. H. L. (SHEP)
description: SHEPPARD-Dr. H. L. (Shep). As long as we live, they too will live; for they are now a part of us as we remember them. Fern

title: Sports of The Times; Point Given Reigns Without a Crown
description: HE was so shaken after he finished fifth in the Kentucky Derby that he was afraid his confusion would carry over to his horse.

title: Always Home
description: These apartments are time capsules. Their inhabitants, once active, have not been outside in months, even years. For some, frail health keeps them in; for others, staying home is a choice. ''They are all hidden upstairs,'' says the photographer David LaChapelle, who is better known for his exuberant shots of celebrities and fashion. ''They haven't had anyone except home-care workers, relatives and a few friends visit in years.'' The Chelsea-Village Program of St. Vincent's hospital in Manhattan finds attendants for them. ''Just to look at those spaces,'' LaChapelle says, ''to see what they've accumulated, was a wonder.'' These New Yorkers are isolated but not shut off; from their windows, they glimpse the bustling streets below.

title: Behind The New Gleam In Steel
description: FOR years, steel was not a compelling investment, and for a good reason: the companies did not earn much money.

title: Roxana Alger, Daniel Geffen
description: Roxana Scoville Alger, the daughter of Roxana B. Robinson and David D. Alger, both of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Asher Geffen, a son of Barbara and William A. Geffen of Tulsa, Okla. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at a house in Katonah, N.Y., owned by the bride's mother and stepfather, Hamilton Robinson Jr. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr., an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Footlights
description: From Dreams to Dances

title: Newark's Achievements Should Have Been Noted
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001061094027439840 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Memory's Curveball
description: HERE was a baseball that never soared from a swinging bat. It never plopped into the webbing of an outstretched glove. It never skipped across wet grass, got caught in a rosebush or smacked against a strike zone painted on a school's brick facade. Here was a baseball that may never have brought joy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, TILLIE
description: GOLDMAN-Tillie. Born in 1906, Tillie was a sophisticated child of the new century, an All American girl who loved NYC, FDR, George Gershwin and Central Park. We'll miss her.

title: Lauren Berkley, John Saunders
description: Lauren Elizabeth Berkley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Berkley of Greenwich, Conn., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Dr. John Kenneth Saunders, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Saunders Jr. of Timonium, Md. Judge Anne C. Dranginis of the Connecticut State Appellate Court in Hartford officiated.

title: The Nation: Johnson-Kennedy Redux; No Way to Treat a Rival
description: IN late May, four men loyal to Senator John McCain met over lunch in Washington to debate whether their man ought to remain a Republican -- or bolt the party to make an independent challenge to President Bush. The event echoed a momentous meal held nearly 40 years earlier, on the day after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, when a small band of grieving loyalists -- men like Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and John Kenneth Galbraith -- met in a private room at the Occidental Grill to consider whether Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy should try to unseat his nemesis, the new president, Lyndon B. Johnson, in 1964.

title: Jitters Over the Economy Guarantee a Long Run for the Budget Late Show
description: Most years the battle over the state budget is long and ugly, but when Gov. George E. Pataki raised the possibility of a three-month emergency spending bill earlier this week, he signaled that the impasse this year is worse than most.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Capriati Fashions French Open Masterpiece
description: There was a dramatic pause during Jennifer Capriati's career resurrection today when the vision of Kim Clijsters went from mirage to real during the French Open final.

title: Rent Is a Rail Pass, and the Super a Conductor
description: The Long Branch local chugged in here today, opening its doors to northbound passengers heading toward New York City.

title: Private Sector; From the Dad Who Has Everything
description: Stumped for a present for Dad on his special day, a week away? Amazon.com suggests the wit and wisdom of Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, in the form of a 60-minute videocassette titled ''Oracle of Omaha,'' featuring interviews with Mr. Buffett, his three children, Buffett experts and footage from the annual meeting of his Berkshire Hathaway Corporation at which he rambles on for most of a day -- to the delight of shareholders -- about his business philosophy.

title: 67 Dogs, Some Hot and Some Sly, Have Their Day
description: The competition last weekend for Park Slope's Most Outstanding Dog was decidedly fierce, though not in a rabid, growling way. Still, who could pick one winner from 67 entries?

title: Start-Up Producer Offers Chardonnay
description: A CLASSY barrel-fermented chardonnay, the first release of Sherwood House Vineyards, is being introduced on the East End.

title: Battle Continues Over Mall That Won't Die
description: SURPRISES are unlikely at Tuesday's scheduled meeting of the Oyster Bay Town Board, when its seven members are expected to vote down the Mall at Oyster Bay. But even if the developer of the proposed shopping mall loses, the deepest disappointment seems to be reserved for anyone who hopes the vote will end the most bitterly contested development dispute in recent Nassau County history.

title: U.S. Open on Public Course Creates New Breed of Hazard
description: With the United States Open golf tournament coming up this week in Tulsa, Okla., there is already a buzz here about next year's Open in New York.

title: Captive Audience
description: BEL CANTO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALPHIN, JULIA
description: CHALPHIN-Julia. On June 8, 2001, at 91 years of age. Loving mother of Gail Boyle, Norman and Marian Chalphin. Cherished sister of Evelyn Pollack. Survived by five grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren and nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be held today at 11 AM at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. For further information call ''Weinstein, Garlick, Kirschenbaum Chapels'' 1-800-556-7799.

title: Island a Battleground In the Doughnut War
description: WHAT was it that possessed Howard Citrinbaum to drag himself to 2443 Hempstead Turnpike on Tuesday at 1 a.m., a full five hours before Long Island's first Krispy Kreme doughnut franchise was to open its doors?

title: Devils 2001: The Playoffs
description: Here is an archive of game stories from the Devils' 2001 postseason.

title: On Eve of His Execution, McVeigh's Legacy Remains Death and Pain
description: His legacy, no matter how many psychiatrists and criminal experts investigate or dissect the events, relationships and disappointments that shaped him, will always be calculated in simple numbers. Timothy J. McVeigh killed, by the cowardly means of a truck bomb, 168 people -- 149 adults and 19 children.

title: Conservationists Are Divided on Cross-Sound Gas Pipeline
description: A PROPOSAL to build a 40-mile-long natural gas pipeline across Long Island Sound has divided conservation groups in New York and Connecticut, not just along state lines but along philosophies. At the heart of the disagreement is whether the project will threaten the environment or improve it.

title: The View From/Hartford; Mark Twain Tonight? Try 1,950 Nights.
description: YOU could call it the longest running show in American theater history. Hal Holbrook has been playing his one-man theater piece ''Mark Twain Tonight!'' since 1954, making this the 47th consecutive year he has impersonated the crusty humorist who is often said to be America's greatest writer.

title: Aubrey Hardwick, Clifford Shikler
description: Aubrey Neville Hardwick, a daughter of David D. Hardwick and Mary Grey James, both of Nashville, was married yesterday to Clifford M. Shikler, the son of Aaron Shikler of Manhattan and the late Barbara Lurie Shikler. Lisel Burns, the leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Grove Restaurant in Manhattan.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DON SIEGEL'S original INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS (1956) proves that it doesn't take elaborate special effects to make science fiction scary. Kevin McCarthy stars as a small-town doctor who returns from a convention to find his neighbors behaving strangely. And no wonder. It turns out they're all being replaced in the middle of the night by giant pods from outer space. Dana Wynter (whose California wardrobe -- strapless sundress by day, mink stole by night -- is memorable) hasn't been affected yet either, maybe because she's just back from Reno. Mr. McCarthy's charcter spells out the film's message: ''Only when we have to fight to stay human do we realize how precious it is to us, how dear.'' The film is based on a Collier's magazine serial by Jack Finney, who went on to write the cult classic novel ''Time and Again'' -- Thursday at 12:30 p.m. on AMC.

title: Virginia Burden, Benjamin Waring
description: Virginia Knauer Burden, a daughter of Valerie and I. Townsend Burden III of Washington, was married there yesterday to Benjamin Alston Waring, the son of J. Snowden Wainwright of Takoma Park, Md., and C. Brandon Waring of Bluffton, S.C. The Rev. Lupton P. Abshire performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church, Georgetown.

title: Oil Realm Embraces A Wired Economy
description: IT is no accident that the gleaming new Dubai Internet City free trade zone lies almost in the shadow of one of the world's most luxurious hotels, the Burj al-Arab, a billion-dollar apparition rising from an artificial island in the Persian Gulf.

title: Church Group Provides Oasis For Illegal Migrants to U.S.
description: Eight church volunteers recently trudged across a dry creek bed just north of the Mexican border hauling plastic jugs of water, taking care to sidestep the deceptively named teddy bear cholla cactus, whose fuzzy needles can pierce a leather boot.

title: Was This Soccer Mom a Terrorist?
description: Discussing Olson, Bill Harris says: ''Sara Jane was never, ever, a member of the S.L.A. It's a total falsehood. To even say she was an associate is a stretch.'' Later in the article, he says that he has ''often seen cops pick on women with children to pressure them to cooperate. . . . All she has to do is flip, and it's over. But she won't do that, because it's not right and it's not true. And now it's a battle of wills: who can hang longest?''

title: POSTINGS: New Role for a Long Island City Building; Yogurt Caps Give Way To Art
description: When Miguel Oks encountered a bleak windowless industrial building on the market in Long Island City, Queens, he saw promise for an art gallery and modern offices. Now, with two related art groups already committed to the space, the blocklong building is being gutted, and the $2.7 million project, including the purchase price of $1 million two years ago, is to be completed in October.

title: Investing Diary: Putting Some Weight Behind Arbitration
description: Investors who win cases against their brokers in arbitration now have a better chance of actually receiving their awards in a timely fashion.

title: Veteran U.S. Envoys Seek End to Executions of Retarded
description: Nine highly regarded veterans of the American Foreign Service are calling for an end to the death penalty for the mentally retarded.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Connection That Changed a Life, and Lasted
description: One sunny morning in 1972, when Louis Quinones was 6 years old, he took a train to Coram, N.Y., to meet the Bryans -- Marc, Joanne, who was pregnant, and their infant son, Shawn -- a family that to this day Mr. Quinones feels influenced his life.

title: A Suspiciously Unwieldy Rug Leads to a Tip, Then a Body
description: Several weeks ago, Pedro Morales asked a neighborhood handyman to help him dispose of an old rug. Mr. Morales, 36, and the handyman struggled with the awkward burden, hauling it out of Mr. Morales's basement apartment and stuffing it in a crawl space used for storage in his Bronx building.

title: Women Starred, but It Was About the Men
description: It was definitely about the fathers, it was sometimes about the husbands, but was it about the boxers?

title: Young Man in a Hurry Puts An Old Gambit to Good Use
description: Talk about a young man in a hurry. In the space of two weeks, 18-year-old Evgeny Postny of Israel won the National Youth Championship, the National Open Championship, got his first grandmaster norm and a prize of $3,500.

title: Jessie Carry, John Saunders
description: Jessie Virginia Carry, the daughter of Virginia S. Carry and B. Peter Carry of New York, was married yesterday to John Michael Saunders, a son of Jacqueline Meyer Saunders and E. John Saunders of Burke, Va. The Rev. Raymond M. Rafferty performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Corpus Christi in New York.

title: Kuerten Is a Bit More Serious This Time Around
description: The familiar corkscrew curls that flop atop Gustavo Kuerten's head were lopped off when he swooped down on Lisbon to take the No. 1 ranking in a whirlwind season finale last December.

title: Long Beach City Manager Takes Job at Hospital
description: BRUCE NYMAN resigned his post as Long Beach city manager last week to take a job at Nassau University Medical Center. Two months ago, the Long Beach City Council, in a measure that some opponents said made the city manager's job insignificant, created a new post that duplicated many of its duties.

title: In Gas Prices' Wake, More Bills and Bluster
description: CAMERON ALDEN, a Suffolk County legislator, has Big Oil in his sights and means to bring it down.

title: Barrie Steinberg, Paul Zinman
description: Barrie Felicia Steinberg, a musicians' manager, and Paul Pierre Zinman, a producer and recording engineer, were married last night by Rabbi Marjorie Slome at the National Arts Club in Manhattan.

title: Resignation Rocks Long Wharf Theater
description: WHEN Doug Hughes took over as artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven in 1997, he ''lit up this place.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01: On Language; Hyper
description: Forget cyber; Norbert Wiener's once-modernistic combining form is pass. And super is positively archaic, no longer the ''soupa'' used by teenagers munching subs. Get with the hot prefix of our times: hyper.

title: Whitman Withdrew Over Politics, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dream of a Worthy Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: North and South: The Great Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWARK AIRPORT PARKING
description: Another 1,200 parking spaces will be added to the mix of lots and garages being built at Newark International Airport under an agreement that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has reached with the city of Elizabeth. The city will lease 10 acres of land at the southern end of the airport for the spaces, which will connect with the terminals by shuttle. With two garages to be completed this year, total parking spaces will increase to 21,200 from the current 15,000. Elizabeth, which has long complained it is underpaid by the Port Authority for the airport land within its boundaries, will receive $3 million a year for community development, compared with the $1 million it receives now, an initial payment of $4.69 million plus $480,000 a year for the lot and a guarantee of $800,000 a year in parking taxes. Karen DeMasters

title: Hollywood East
description: GIVEN the county's proximity to New York City, a film industry in Westchester might seem, at best, superfluous.

title: Louise Mayer Sulzberger, 103; Devoted Years to Social Services
description: Louise Sulzberger, who was active in New York City social service work for many years and was a member of the New York State Commission on Aging and the community planning board for the Upper East Side, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103.

title: Ferry Services Could Ease Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying for That Fun in the Sun
description: This summer, millions of vacationing Americans will head to beaches and mountains or fly off to exotic destinations, and they will return home with plenty of memories. But there is probably one memento they wish they could leave behind -- their monthly credit card statements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLED, SYLVIA (SELMA)
description: SOLED-Sylvia (Selma). On June 8, 2001, in North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Bayside, NY. Devoted wife of the late Lou Soled. Beloved mother of Gerard (Brenda), Stephen (Ronni), and the late Carol Cohen. Loving grandmother of Amanda Soled and Julie Cohen. She will be greatly missed.

title: Article 2001061092833423050 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: A Hotel Childhood Recalled
description: STAYING at a hotel -- finding a bed turned down, fresh sheets waiting -- takes me back 50 years to the linen room under the eaves of the small hotel my father owned and managed in suburban Philadelphia. That's where Alice and Norah, the housekeepers, sorted bedding while they whispered and giggled, sneaking smokes. Beneath the window there was a flat wicker basket filled with musty blankets that needed new bindings and worn sheets that might take my mother's mending one more time.

title: Edward Wright, Who Unearthed Ancient Boats on England's Coast, Dies at 82
description: Edward Wright, whose youthful curiosity about three oak planks poking out of the English beach where he and his brother searched for dinosaur bones led to the discovery of the oldest seaworthy boats found in northern Europe, died on May 18 in a hospital in Gloucester. He was 82.

title: Friendly Fliers
description: There are no crash landings at the Tarrytown Airport, and overhead turbulence is easily circumvented with gentle maneuvering. Which may partly explain why ''Jay Jay the Jet Plane,'' about a 6-year-old puddle jumper with a heart of gold, became the Learning Channel's top-ranked children's show shortly after its premiere in November 1998.

title: Plot Thickens in Nepal as Editor Is Jailed for Printing Account of Royal Family Killings
description: The editor in chief of Kantipur, this country's largest daily newspaper, has been detained here since Wednesday in a grubby room where a bare light bulb dangling from the ceiling constitutes the main decorative touch.

title: CRIME
description: There's something endearing about smart girls who do stupid things. Take Kinsey Millhone. In Sue Grafton's clever alphabet mystery ''P'' IS FOR PERIL (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95), this California P.I. puts terrific brainwork into a complicated case of insurance fraud at a nursing care facility -- but it never dawns on her that the new guy she's dating might be a murderer.

title: That Part-Time Pace
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Old radicals still draw hot mail, pro and con, evident in the response to the article on Sara Jane Olson, aka Kathleen Soliah. Our Lives column about the extreme measures taken by a terminally ill woman to end her life prompted a conversation about palliative pain care and dying with dignity.

title: A Gauge for Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk Republicans Pick Sheriff Candidate
description: Suffolk Republicans last week named a retired county court judge, Alfred C. Tisch of Setauket, to run for county sheriff in November to succeed Patrick A. Mahoney, who is not seeking re-election following his guilty plea to federal misdemeanor charges.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY EDITION -- Like Father: Designing for 2; Because It's a Hard-Knock Life
description: Father-son teams are the winning ticket in the era of Bush II. Across the cultural board, from the Murdochs to the Sheens, pre et fils rule. So it makes sense that for Father's Day there is a flood of gear to take the twosome from beach to ballgame in style. Which means that Senior and Junior can find a way -- whether it's primary time, prime time or just time for a game of catch -- to mix and match.

title: An Antimosquito Plan the Mosquitoes Might Have Created
description: If the city wanted to stop mosquitoes from breeding in the Ridgewood Reservoir in Highland Park, it went about it in the worst way possible. So says Charles J. Monaco of the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, an advocacy group. And after talking with members of the Audubon Society, the city may now agree.

title: Firebird's Apprentice
description: DANCE WITH DEMONS

title: A Last Best Chance To Revive Camden
description: THE crowd erupts when one of the Camden Riversharks hits a home run, the ball sailing over the green wall, heading for the Benjamin Franklin Bridge looming majestically beyond the outfield. In the month since its opening, Campbell's Field, the new minor league baseball stadium on the banks of the Delaware River, has become a hot destination for mostly white, mostly suburban families looking for a fun night out and a home team worth cheering about.

title: Kimberly Cullen, Frank Cappelleri
description: Kimberly Anne Cullen, a daughter of Carol and John Cullen of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frank Nicholas Cappelleri, a son of Elizabeth Cappelleri and Dr. Dominic Cappelleri of Warwick, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Madori performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Mention Drilling, and Tourists Rush to Alaska
description: They journeyed above the Arctic Circle and beyond the Brooks Range, to a spot called Caribou Pass on the Kongakut River near its mouth at the Arctic Ocean. It was not easy, nor was it cheap.

title: The Upgraded Version: 'Rear Windows 01'
description: A USEFUL game for long car trips is If Only He Had Lived to See. If only Gregor Mendel had lived to see the first cloned pig. If only Icarus had hung on long enough to fly the Concorde. If only Zapruder had used a better-resolution camera, with more frames per second, on the grassy knoll. And if only Alfred Hitchcock had a cell phone.

title: Kara Stillmock, Andrew Albright
description: Kara Anne Stillmock, a biochemist, was married yesterday to Andrew Vernon Albright, a virus researcher. The Rev. Brigid Boyle performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia.

title: Reporter's Notebook; What Mobsters Chat About: Glory Days and Bad Teeth
description: For gangsters living the incognito life, the witness protection program can be as dull as old pencil lead. After all, wise guys love to talk, and under federal protection, whom do they really get to talk with except bartenders and waitresses at the local greasy spoon?

title: Primaries Give a Boost To the Political Process
description: Usually the Democratic or Republican nominating conventions in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are a formality. Delegates simply agree to the decisions made by the party leaders as to whose names will appear on the ballot in November. Without opposition and without other candidates challenging the party choices, there is no primary election. Party members are frequently left without a say as to who will represent them.

title: A Cautionary Tale Taken From Pulpit to Stage
description: MUSIC has never been a very effective medium for polemics. To have an impact, a polemical argument must be precise and persuasive. Music is powerful but indistinct. Propped up by rabble-rousing music, a political tract tends to sound bombastic.

title: Habitats/Elizabeth Street in NoLIta; A Portrait of the Artist As a Young Home Hunter
description: CYNICS and romantics alike would have everyone believe that there are no more young artists in Manhattan, that they have been pushed off the island by greedy landlords and rich investment bankers willing to pay $3,000 a month or more to live in old tenements.

title: Artists' Works Find A Home Environment
description: ENTER the first-floor apartment at the new Livingston Ridge development and you're sure to be impressed with the owners' art collection. Creamy walls set off the mauve tones of Hudson River landscapes. Oriental rugs enhance the colors of large-scale abstractions. The shifting light, from windows that overlook the Hudson, suffuses a triptych of floating lotus blossoms.

title: Fathers and Feminists
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Be Not Bad For Ratings
description: SINCE Shakespeare gave us singing grave-diggers in ''Hamlet,'' since Dickens gave us the asthmatic Mr. Omer in ''David Copperfield,'' since the very advent of the pine box, undertakers have been regarded with dread. Jessica Mitford's 1963 classic, ''The American Way of Death,'' released in a posthumous expanded edition last year, only increased public apprehension about funeral directors with its searing indictment of mortuary customs.

title: Jennifer Large, Garrett Wyman
description: Jennifer Anne Large, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Large Jr. of Hartford, was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Garrett William Wyman, the son of Carol S. Roberts of Doylestown, Pa., and William W. Wyman of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Charles Smith, a Congregational minister, officiated, with the Rev. James F. Hynes, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: The Last Bohemian
description: LUFTMENSCH. Superfluous man. Flneur. Beatnik. Bohemian. For a century, New York been a magnet for such economically marginal figures, whose role it was to stroll, read, reflect, write and, especially, critique the way the rest of the world lived. They have been a staple of urban life at least since the mid-19th century, when the Parisian Henri Murger wrote his novel ''Bohemians of the Latin Quarter,'' which in Puccini's hands became the opera ''La Bohme.''

title: Neighbors Say a School Is Just a Growing Bully
description: In 1974, six brownstones along West 81st Street and West End Avenue were torn down to make way for Calhoun School, a private institution teaching prekindergarten to 12th grade. Neighbors were outraged.

title: Day Isn't Consumed by Record Chase
description: There are few accomplishments left for jockey Pat Day, a Hall of Famer, a Kentucky Derby winner, a four-time winner of the Breeders' Cup Classic and one of only three riders to pass the 8,000-victory milestone. But there is one to go. One of racing's most cherished records, most victories ever by a jockey, is well within his reach.

title: Sputnik SweetheartFirst Chapter
description: In the spring of her twenty-second year, Sumire fell in love for the first time in her life. An intense love, a veritable tornado sweeping across the plainsflattening everything in its path, tossing things up in the air, ripping them to shreds, crushing them to bits. The tornado's intensity doesn't abate for a second as it blasts across the ocean, laying waste to Angkor Wat, incinerating an Indian jungle, tigers and all, transforming itself into a Persian desert sandstorm, burying an exotic fortress city under a sea of sand. In short, a love of truly monumental proportions. The person she fell in love with happened to be seventeen years older than Sumire. And was married. And, I should add, was a woman. This is where it all began, and where it all wound up. Almost.

title: Q and A
description: In Proust's Footsteps

title: Nuclear Plants Face Storing Toxic Waste
description: Hourglass cooling towers tipped with white plumes of steam have long been the icon of the American nuclear power industry. But New Jersey's nuclear operators plan to embellish those symbolic structures in the next few years: squat concrete blockhouses filled with radioactive nuclear waste.

title: Randa Soudah, Brian Rudnick
description: Randa Gabriela Soudah, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raja Soudah of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Andrew Rudnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rudnick of Lincroft, N.J. Judge William H. Walls of the United States District Court in Newark officiated at the Woolverton Inn in Stockton, N.J.

title: Article 2001061093934813537 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Phil Schaap, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: New Weekly Sees a Road Not Taken By El Diario
description: Back in February, frustrated by what they saw as the narrow focus of the Spanish-language press in New York City, four journalists left their posts at El Diario-La Prensa, New York's 88-year-old Spanish daily to establish their own weekly newspaper, Nueva Era. The first issue came out last month.

title: 3 Die and Thousands Leave Homes in Flooded Houston
description: Three people were killed here this weekend and more than 10,000 were forced to flee their homes by the tropical storm Allison, which has dumped up to 26 inches of rain in a little more than 24 hours.

title: QUICK BITE/Fort Lee; Delivering the News and Sandwiches
description: What else would you call a cafe offering newspapers and magazines plus televisions blaring with news and stock-market reports other than what Lynne and Peter Catania call theirs: the Fort Lee News Bar? The place -- until eight years ago a clothing store, and described by Mrs. Catania as an ''upscale, European-type, very Italian'' restaurant -- serves a variety of cold and hot dishes. The specialty is grilled wraps with a choice of trimmings that include mozzarella, provolone, onions, mushrooms, artichoke hearts, avocado, tomatoes, red peppers, eggplant, zucchini, olives and sun-dried tomatoes. To wash them down, Mrs. Catania recommends her ''not-run-of-the-mill coffee.'' (There are coffee beans for sale, too.) The menu also includes homemade soups, hot pasta, cold pasta salads, plus, for breakfast, scones, bagels, crumb cake, waffles and omelets. The European touch comes with the ambience: patrons reading newspapers (for sale at a front-door rack), or magazines (available at the entrance) at six tables on the corner of Main Street and Parker Avenue, as they bite into their sandwiches or sip their coffee, within ear-and eye-shot of the George Washington Bridge. On the walls are lithographs and paintings, which are for sale. The newspapers aren't delivered, but from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m., the food is. NORM OSHRIN

title: Answers That Ask Questions
description: ''Why read the classics?'' Italo Calvino asked in a 1981 essay. He had the grace to make the question real, not rhetorical, and then to supply answers that allow readers to ask more questions and to make choices of their own. Here's to the learned man (Calvino was very learned) who can be sly, even self-mocking about his erudition. It's a courtesy, a form of intellectual generosity that keeps us eager to learn and keeps the learned from getting sour or augustly stale. (I'm happy to learn in an institution, but not from one.) The classics, Calvino begins, ''are those books about which you usually hear people saying: 'I'm rereading . . . ,' never 'I'm reading. . . .' '' (I've been one of those people, I confess.) Every country has its favorites, hence its blinders and blank spots. So does every individual.

title: At the Gym, Grunts, Groans And a Discrimination Suit
description: With 80 pounds of steel hanging over his head, John Miller grimaced, groaned, then let out the kind of jarring grunt you'd expect to hear in a mirrored room packed with body builders. The only difference is that Mr. Miller, on a bench press machine at the Axiom Health & Fitness Center, had yet to lift an ounce. The contorted expressions and raspy shouts were hallmarks of his Tourette's syndrome, a neurological disorder that is thought to be hereditary and leaves its victims powerless over an unceasing barrage of physical and vocal impulses.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01; The Play's The Thing
description: The roar inside the Los Angeles Convention Center during last month's Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) would have made even a gladiator shudder. Trigger-happy commandos. Screeching zombies. Robots with howitzers. Starfighters. Formula One race cars. Sprites, pixies, Spiderman and Mickey Mouse. And overpowering all the rest, on the floor's biggest display, Madden N.F.L., the No. 1 selling title for the new Sony PlayStation 2, with tackles, groans and bodies hitting the turf at volumes loud enough, it seemed, to shake the very concrete of the convention center. I felt like a Lilliputian trapped in the TV section at Crazy Eddie's with every set turned all the way up. And that was the point. The greatest good in the latest generation of video entertainment is to be ''immersive.'' What the best games scream is, ''Let me swallow you!''

title: And Still Living
description: ''A painter can say all he wants to with fruit or flowers or even clouds. I should like to be the Saint Francis of still life,'' Edward Manet remarked in 1875. Such reverence for tabletop arrangements of edible and decorative objects might sound odd coming from the French painter who repeatedly scandalized the art world with his confrontational portraits of prostitutes and such. Yet the art historian George Mauner persuasively argues in MANET: The Still-Life Paintings (Abrams, $39.95) that the germ of his revolutionary thinking can be located in his potent and sensuously painted images of oysters, peonies, and dead rabbits. Long considered an inferior genre to history painting by the French academy, still lifes accounts for some 20 percent of Manet's output and also appear as central elements in his figure paintings, which Mauner posits are as much still lifes with figures as the other way around. Rejecting grand narratives as ''all that rubbish,'' Manet found still life objects ripe for pure painting invested with emotion -- an idea carried on by modernists like Cezanne, Picasso and Rauschenberg. Increasingly homebound by illness before he died in 1883, Manet painted still lifes almost exclusively, in part for convenience's sake. Yet Mauner reminds us that Manet's earlier comment about fruit and flowers -- whose fleeting glories are traditional reminders of death in still life arrangements -- was anything but casual. Manet choose still life as the means to communicate most honestly as he stared down his own mortality. Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOAGLAND, ALEXANDER C., JR.
description: HOAGLAND-Alexander C., Jr., passed away on Monday, June 4, 2001. Born in Perth Amboy, New Jersey in 1927, Mr. Hoagland was a distinguished member of the Bars of New York and Mexico and practiced law in both jurisdictions. He graduated from Harvard University in 1950 and Harvard Law School in 1955, and joined the New York office of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle LLP in 1957, with whom he was associated until his death. In 1963, he moved to Mexico, where he spent most of his career, establishing an international and business law practice. Although he spoke no Spanish when he went to Mexico, he became fluent in the language and in 1973 received his Degree of Law from Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico. He became one of the first non-Mexicans to be admitted to the Mexican Bar. Mr. Hoagland was a keen student of legal, political, social and foreign policy developments in Mexico, and helped create the Division of Comparative Law, Section of International Law and Practice of the American Bar Association. He contributed countless working and scholarly papers to various law courses and seminars, including the publication of Company Formation in Mexico (1972, 1980). Mr. Hoagland is survived by his wife, Maria Teresa (Piti) Saldivar Hoagland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENARD, JAMES
description: BENARD-James. 61, died peacefully in his sleep in his wife's arms on June 6, 2001, after a difficult struggle with cancer. He was the cherished husband of Mary Lou Kolipinski; beloved father of Marie Perry and her husband Andrew, James John Benard and his wife Hilary Hamann; and the adoring grandfather of Vee Thayer, Emmanuelle and Rainier. Dear brother of Mary Minsky. Beloved brother-in-law and uncle to many. He was deeply loved. He attended the University of Buffalo and earned a J.D. from the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1964. He was an attorney with the Legal Aid Society prior to going into private practice. He was on the Supreme Court and Homicide Panels of the Assigned Counsel Plan for the First Judicial Department, where he was renowned and respected for his integrity and vigorous representation of the indigent. He was a cheerful, sensitive gentleman who will be profoundly mourned. The family will receive friends at a memorial gathering at the Benard residence at 430 East 86th Street, Apartment 10C, from 6 to 9 PM today.

''Then they announced a different result, he panicked, ran away, and I realized the red light on his camera was not on, and he was not shooting,'' he told a Czech reporter afterward.
