What better spot to escape to on a romantic weekend?

title: Plugged
description: DOWN THE HIGHWAY The Life of Bob Dylan. By Howard Sounes. Illustrated. 527 pp. New York: Grove Press. $27.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, EVELYN BERG
description: LERNER-Evelyn Berg. Age 88, on June 8, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Martin E. Lerner. Loving mother of Joan Stein and Norma Lerner, mother-in-law of Robert Stein and George Schwartz, grandmother of Amanda, Elizabeth, Andrew and David. She will be missed.

title: A NIGHT IN WITH -- Malini and Mohan Murjani; Exercise in Family Chic
description: TOMMY HILFIGER remembers Malini Murjani as a little girl, playing the junior fashion critic on visits to the Broadway office of her father, Mohan Murjani, Mr. Hilfiger's key original financial backer. ''She was probably 8 or 9 and would say, 'I like that,' or 'I don't like that,' '' Mr. Hilfiger said on Monday night. ''Even then she had a sense of style.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Oldsmobile Bravada; Born Under a Bad Sign
description: LIKE a character in a Greek tragedy whose thread of life was prenatally spun, measured and cut by the three Fates, the new Oldsmobile Bravada was condemned to death even before it was born.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYCE, GERARD R.
description: BOYCE-Gerard R. 46, died on June 4, 2001 at his home in Franklin Lakes, NJ. He is survived by his beloved wife, Anna, and three children, Lauren (10), Aidan (2), and Garrett (8 months), and two sisters, Peggy Louie Chaplin and Veronica Gunnerson. Admitted to the bar in 1983, Jerry was a partner at Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, LLP, resident in the firm's Manhattan office, concentrating his practice in tax and corporate law. He was a columnist in corporate finance for the New York Law Journal and Lecturer in limited liability company law for the New York State Bar Association. Educated at Fairleigh Dickenson University (B.S., Cum Laude, 1976), Seton Hall University (J.D., Cum Laude, 1983) and New York University (LLM in Tax, 1987). He was a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York State and American Bar Associations. Jerry was a New Jersey Certified Public Accountant (1978), and a member of The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He will be remembered for his boyish innocence and love of life. He was a mentor, a true friend and a philosopher. He framed his family's motto, ''Do The Right Thing'', and lived his life by it. In Jerry's honor, donations may be made to The Gerard R. Boyce Memorial Racing Fund, in care of Mark Limardo, Esq., Jenkins, Gilchrist, Parker, Chapin LLP, 405 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10174.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, ELISE DACOSTA
description: WATERMAN-Elise DaCosta. On June 7, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Philip M. Waterman. Devoted and proud mother and mother-in-law of Philip M. Waterman Jr. and Jane, Marie W. Harris and Kenneth. Loved and admired grandmother of Philip M. Waterman III, Anne L. Waterman, Kenneth A. Harris Jr. and Ellen Harris Knoblock and Henry. Adored great-grandmother of Christopher H. Knoblock and Caroline D. Knoblock. Dear sister of Manette D. Kaufmann. Elise was a remarkable and elegant woman. She distinguished herself to family and friends by her wisdom, wit and zeal for life. Her special prescence will be deeply missed. Services will be private. Doantions may be made to the American Jewish Committee, 165 E. 56th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, DAVID MONTGOMERY
description: HART-David Montgomery on May 22, 2001, in Garrucha, Spain. Age 74. An anthropologist, Mr. Hart was the author of several books on the Berber-speaking peoples of Morocco. Born in Philadelphia, Mr. Hart lived in Morocco for almost 20 years while performing research and then resided in Spain. He was pre-deceased by his wife of many years, Ursula Cook Kingsmill. Mr. Hart is survived by a brother, Dr. Brandon Hart of Massachusetts, and a sister Sarah Brodsky of Yonkers, NY; three stepchildren, Carrol Johnson of Oxford, England, Christine Rosenkrantz of St. Petersburg, Florida, and Stephen Boycott of Namaimo, Canada.

title: June 3-9; Attack at Japanese School
description: At least 8 schoolchildren were killed and at least 15 people were wounded when a deranged man burst into an elementary school near Osaka and began stabbing students and teachers with a kitchen knife. School officials subdued him and turned him over to the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETTO, KATHRYN C.
description: NETTO-Kathryn C. On June 6, 2001, at age 72. Beloved wife of Eldo, loving mother of David, devoted daughter of the late Frank A. and Madelyne Cosgrove. Interment private. The family warmly invites friends to attend a memorial service to celebrate Kate's life at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave and 66 St, Wednesday, June 13th, 3 PM. Kate was a private person with the most generous heart whose philosophy was that only kindness matters. She valued her family and friends above all else. Her father's contribution to the building of Johnson & Johnson and the Cosgrove family's support of the Metropolitan Museum of Art made her proud, but Kate's greatest happiness came from the love of a son and husband who will miss her every day. Contributions in Kate's memory may be made to The Museum of Natural History, in honor of the Children of the City of New York.

title: JERSEY CITY MAYOR
description: Jersey City voters elected their first black mayor last week. Glenn D. Cunningham, a former city police captain and council president, resigned as the United States marshal for New Jersey to succeed Mayor Bret D. Schundler, who is seeking the Republican Party's gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Cunningham, who will be sworn in July 1, beat the current council president, Tom DeGise, in a runoff election after they were the top vote-getters in the city's initial five-man nonpartisan election on May 8. The two Democrats each carried three wards, but Mr. Cunningham, who received 53.2 percent of the vote, had overwhelming support from black voters, following a campaign in which he promised to link development along the Hudson to improvements throughout the city. Steve Strunsky

title: The Disappearing Store, and the Aftermath
description: Anita Rubin is traipsing through the streets of Midtown. There are more than 300 businesses on her list. She will visit each one and tell the story of what happened. She expects the process to take a month, perhaps two. She has been to 80 offices so far.

title: Idyllic Beach Incites Battle Over Access
description: FEW sports generate greater devotion among their followers than surfing and fishing. Call into question public access to one of the East Coast's best places for catching waves or fish, and tempers are bound to flare.

title: Chicago Journal; Teams' Fans in the Grip Of a Crosstown Series
description: Miguel Torres stood in the upper deck dangling a little stuffed bear in a White Sox uniform from the end of a noose, mercilessly taunting the people around him.

title: Point Given Hits Stride to Capture Belmont
description: Nothing slowed Point Given, the prohibitive 6-5 favorite, in the 133rd running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday.

title: A Bright Ros From the Midi
description: Mediterranean brightness bounces out of Fortant de France's 2000 white merlot, a refreshing low-key ros. This salmon-pink wine -- spicy, delicate, with subtle fruit-salad flavors -- is intended as an aperitif and for surf meals.

title: A Winner Etched in Tears
description: The Colorado Avalanche won the Stanley Cup for the second time in six seasons tonight, and its players deserved every celebratory sip they took from it. The Avalanche earned the silver trophy by storming to a three-goal lead over the defending champion Devils and securing a 3-1 victory at the Pepsi Center in Game 7 of the Cup finals.

title: As Biotech Crops Multiply, Consumers Get Little Choice
description: Despite persistent concerns about genetically modified crops, they are spreading so rapidly that it has become almost impossible for consumers to avoid them, agriculture experts say.

title: June 3-9; June Showers
Men, Increasingly, Are the Ones Claiming Sex Harassment by Men
description: The managers at a used-car dealership were notorious for telling lewd jokes and teasingly groping the salesmen who worked there, according to a lawsuit brought on the salesmen's behalf.

title: Article 2001061091357130123 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: Putting Their Chips Down On an Arena for Newark
description: Arena politics makes strange bedfellows. How else to explain the alliance between State Senator William Gormley, the powerful Republican from Atlantic County, and State Senator Sharpe Jame -- who also happens to be the mayor of Newark.

title: Barbara Brooks, Douglas Andrews
description: Barbara Arline Brooks and Douglas Whitmore Andrews were married yesterday by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn.

title: Article 2001061092275124191 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: The Moral Compass on Campus; Taking a Stand Often Means Having to Say You're Sorry
description: We live, it seems, in an age of contrition. Pope John Paul II has apologized for 2,000 years of errors by the Roman Catholic Church. President Bill Clinton went to Africa to apologize for America's role in enslaving Africans. Germany is paying reparations to Holocaust victims. And now come the universities.

title: Kew Gardens Journal; Crossing at Peril of Life and Limb (and a $10 Fine)
description: At a rear entrance to Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, two lines begin forming well before 8 on weekday mornings. One group is summoned by love, the other by the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARR, INA BERNSTEIN
description: SHARR-Ina Bernstein. Died May 26th, 2001, after a devastating illness. Theatrical agent, casting executive and manager. Beloved wife of the late Jules. Survived by Sherrin, Kathie, Daniel, Candace, Ruby Hersch and many loving friends. Memorial service to be arranged in Los Angeles in July.

title: Not Just Shakespeare As Stratford Expands
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company has added the Summerhouse to its existing three theaters in Stratford-on-Avon, 100 miles northwest of London.

title: Influential Designer To Receive A Tribute
description: At 93, Olin Stephens shows few signs of slowing down. Two weeks ago, Stephens, the most influential naval architect of the last century, jetted over to Bermuda for a short visit. Yet another of his regular trips to Europe is just around the corner.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Two Sides of Mies at the Whitney and Modern

title: Our Towns; Profile in Courage: The Diary of a Field Trip Chaperon
description: WEDNESDAY, 7:52 a.m. -- The rolling classroom embarks on a rite of spring: the overnight class trip. Seventh graders bound for Williamsburg, Va. Opening exercises begin with the traditional ''100 Bottles of Beer on the Wall'' sung at 200 decibels. The lyrics, after all this time, have not lost (or gained) appeal.

title: A Straight Approach to a New Engine
description: A BLUE V-8 engine, autographed by dozens of workers, greets you at the doorway of the Flint Engine South plant. It was the last of 45 million small-block V-8's built at this site, in a factory that was razed to make way for Flint South, a clean, quiet, modern plant where General Motors is making the Vortec 4200 that powers the 2002 Oldsmobile Bravada, GMC Envoy and Chevrolet TrailBlazer.

title: Article 2001061090116659777 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: SAVING MILLY

title: Last Right
description: Palliative care is a field of medicine that has the mission of relieving suffering and improving quality of life. Such care is not exclusively for people at the brink of death but should be incorporated early into the treatment plan, along with life-prolonging or curative therapy, in order to maximize quality of life at all stages of an illness.

title: Missile Shield Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Investing; Hope for AIDS Vaccine Fuels a Stock's Ascent
description: SHARES of VaxGen, a small biotechnology company that has developed an experimental AIDS vaccine, have soared recently, despite skepticism among researchers and many investors about the company's main product.

title: Battered Veterans on Both Sides of Colombia's War Unite to Seek Peace
description: Oscar Buitrago was a hard-charging army captain when a false step put him on top of a rebel land mine, which blew off his foot. His adversary in Colombia's cloud-shrouded mountains, Alberto Cullar, was a crafty guerrilla militiaman whose face was shredded by gunfire from government security forces.

title: Robinson's Call for Discipline Falls on Devils' Deaf Ears
description: Before every game this season, Larry Robinson wrote the word discipline on the blackboard in the Devils' dressing room.

title: DataBank; A Week of Puzzles but Few Answers
description: Uncertainty was the theme on Wall Street last week. With a paucity of economic news and major company announcements, investors had few tea leaves to read.

title: Fashion Flower
description: This spring, the flower -- live, silk or beaded -- has reappeared attached to a ribbon choker. Wearing blossoms was a favorite custom through the ages, providing fragrance for the wearer. In 18th-century France, a fresh flower was often worn at the neck or in the cleavage. In the early 20th century, Edwardians had sprays of orchids dripping from their shoulders. This style turned into the corsage, which some mothers of the bride have discretely removed to the handbag. Others wear them at the waist or on the wrist. The current idea originated with Tom Ford, who made the flower choker his signature at his first Saint Laurent ready-to-wear show last fall, and women at his second show, in March, adopted the look with their daytime pantsuits. One wearer, top right, innovatively floated a fresh gardenia from an invisible nylon fishing line.

title: Last Right
description: In Carrie Carmichael's Lives column (May 20), the suicide of her friend was a brutal tragedy and points to many defects in the way dying patients are cared for in this country. Why wasn't she in a hospice program? Why wasn't her treating oncologist able to provide effective palliative care? Why wasn't she in a support group? Why wasn't Carmichael able to assist her to find effective treatment and support and, failing that, to explore gentler ways to hasten her death?

title: Poola Poola: A Yale Club Reprieve
description: The Yale Club has postponed a plan to renovate its athletic facilities until next year, relieving some members who feared that renovations might eliminate the 86-year-old pool at the club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the effects of the new tax-cut law misstated the tax treatment of estates after 2010 -- the year that the estate tax is scheduled to be repealed but also the last year in which the law applies. Unless Congress acts, the maximum amount that an individual can leave without estate tax being owed as of Jan. 1, 2011, will be $1 million, not $675,000.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Dr. Christine Sheppard, 50 Curator of ornithology, the Bronx Zoo

title: Very Artificial Intelligence
description: THINKS . . .

title: TRANSIT TECH SETS RECORD IN RELAY
description: Transit Tech of Brooklyn set a meet record in the boys' 4x400-meter relay with a time of 3 minutes 13.91 seconds yesterday in the New York State Boys' and Girls' Outdoor Interscholastic Championships at the Mitchel Athletic Complex in Uniondale. It was one of five victories by New York City schools in the six relays.

title: Maxine Paetro, John Duffy
description: Maxine Abbe Paetro and John Andrew Duffy were married yesterday at the bride's home in Amenia, N.Y. Elizabeth K. Shequine, a town justice of Washington, N.Y., officiated.

title: Why Niagra Now?
description: It's the place that discovered that barbecued chicken and blue cheese are the happiest marriage in Buffalo. It's the place where 50's design can be as bipolar as it likes and get away with it -- on one pole, kitsch, on the other, Neutra-esque grandeur. As everyone struggles to make Modernism his own, Niagara shows how that familiar vocabulary can find its unique voice; Niagara actually makes Modernism look quaint.

title: BENEFITS
description: Human Rights at Lincoln Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LILY
description: BERMAN-Lily. Died on June 4 in Bridgehampton. She brought joy to all who knew her, especially Lewis, Amanda, Meredith Berman, Michelle Marchildon and Anne MacIntosh and all her friends at Park East. Memorial contributions may be directed to Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, Office of Public Affairs for the Cancer Program, Ithaca, NY 14853-6401.

title: Teaching the Middle East To Mind Music and Step
description: The United States is on its way to another enormous trade deficit this year, but don't blame the Arthur Murray Dance Studios. The company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., is exporting its ballroom-lesson franchise at an increasingly quick pace -- especially to the Middle East.

title: Laurel Watts, Torrance Robinson
description: Laurel Elizabeth Watts, the daughter of Martha and John Watts of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Torrance Webster Robinson, a son of Barbara Paul Robinson and Charles Raskob Robinson of Manhattan. The Rev. Cheryl P. Anderson performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn.

title: Blacks, AIDS and Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Naked Capitalists
description: Frank Rich (May 20) deftly exposes yet another of our monumental hypocrisies. Everyone I know has a collection of porn cached away somewhere, but only in rare moments of candor will anyone admit to it.

title: Concert Settings Fit for a Romanov
description: Summer is concert season at prerevolutionary country estates in the Moscow area, and visitors can expect to hear a wide range of performances in grand surroundings.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken
description: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.''

title: Sara Shorey, Peter Gebhard III
description: Dr. Sara King Shorey and Peter Ten Eyck Gebhard III were married yesterday by the Rev. Aaron F. Usher, an Episcopal priest, at the New York Yacht Club in Newport, R.I.

title: An Uncomfortable Debate
description: ORIGINALLY founded as a parish and named for a Congregational minister, Brookfield is not a place typically associated with shops selling X-rated videos and sexual aids. But town leaders are considering whether to create a business district that would allow such shops, an issue that has everyone from grandmothers to a Roman Catholic priest talking about sexual devices and pornographic films.

title: Kristi McCormick, Brent Nemetz
description: Kristi McCormick, the daughter of Riesa McCormick of Tampa, Fla., and Frank McCormick of San Antonio, is to be married today to Brent Nemetz, the son of Linda Mansour of Searingtown, N.Y., and Jerold Nemetz of Amityville, N.Y. Rabbi David Gelfand is to officiate at the home of Palma and Joe Troiano, an aunt and an uncle of the bride, in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Pataki's Role as a Pitchman Becomes a Political Target
description: For years, Gov. George E. Pataki has been one of New York's most familiar salesmen, pitching everything from New York tourism to children's health insurance to energy-saving appliances, in television ads paid for with tens of millions of dollars in state funds.

title: Zito Is Too Familiar With Finishing Second
description: For a guy who has made a habit of being a runner-up in the biggest race in New York, the trainer Nick Zito was in a pretty good mood after the Belmont Stakes yesterday. Maybe that was because he knew he was beaten by an exceptional horse. Or maybe it was because he was getting used to such things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, PEARL
description: KAPLAN-Pearl, on June 3, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Barbara Hanover and Stanley. Loving grandmother of Lauri Toobi, Jonathan, David and Tracey Cianciulli; Michael, Gary and Daniel Kaplan. Proud great-grandmother of Jordyn, Michael, Daniel and Noah Hanover; Melissa, Caryn, Benjamin and Zachary Kaplan. Sister of Jerome and Milton Reisman, Esther Spigelman and the late Helene Fleschner, Herbert Reisman and Evelyn Paleg. Burial was on Har Hamnuchot, Jerusalem.

title: Liberties; She's Not Really Ill . . .
description: I usually avoid sweeping generalizations.

title: A School For Toddlers Shuts Down
description: CHAPPAQUA Country Day School graduated its last class on Friday. The 4-year-olds, who wore caps and gowns to receive their diplomas, probably didn't appreciate the significance.

title: Wedding on the Wall
description: THE high-speed blender of American culture has produced its share of monstrosities like frozen ''bagels'' filled with strawberries and cream cheese in supermarkets and a half-scale Eiffel Tower with slot machines at its feet in Las Vegas, to name two.

title: Dana Lee, Mark Elliott
description: Dana H. C. Lee and Mark M. Elliott were married yesterday by the Rev. Albert Azrak at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in White Plains.

title: June 3-9; Ex-Argentine Leader Held
description: Carlos Sal Menem made history as Argentina's president between 1989 and 1999, selling off much of the bloated state bureaucracy, pegging the value of the peso to the dollar to control hyperinflation, and reorganizing the army to become a major player in United Nations peacekeeping operations. Now he has made history again, as the first democratically elected president arrested under another democratic government, on suspicion that he led a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. If formally charged and convicted, he could be sentenced to 10 years in jail. Clifford Krauss

title: Correspondence/History Lessons; All White, All Christian And Divided by Diversity
description: MY grandmother Hulda Pieper Willenburg, proper and prim as she was, would have been horrified at a recent description of her home. But there it was, in The Des Moines Register: someone calling Carroll County and two other prosperous farming areas in western Iowa ''very nondiverse in their ethnic background and their religious background.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Page 3 of the Travel section today, about the Culinary Institute of America at Greystone in St. Helena, Calif., refers incorrectly to the institute's restaurant in some copies. It has been open five years; it is not new.

title: Why Niagara Now?
description: It's the place that discovered that barbecued chicken and blue cheese are the happiest marriage in Buffalo. It's the place where 50's design can be as bipolar as it likes and get away with it -- on one pole, kitsch, on the other, Neutra-esque grandeur. As everyone struggles to make Modernism his own, Niagara shows how that familiar vocabulary can find its unique voice; Niagara actually makes Modernism look quaint.

title: Being John Malkovich, Director and Campagnard
description: ON a Sunday morning at the foot of the Luberon mountains in southern France, John Malkovich opened the gate to his converted farmhouse, ducking away from the rain. Tall and elegant in weekend clothes, he led the way into his high-ceilinged, eat-in kitchen. Padding about in squeaky butter-colored leather shoes, he made cappuccino and small talk about the bare grapevines outside the windows. The bum luck of the stormy skies.

title: The Future of American Terrorism
description: Timothy McVeigh is no martyr and is not going to become one. Judge Richard Matsch's refusal to stay Mr. McVeigh's execution, which is scheduled for tomorrow, may, for a time, add some fuel to the far-right theory that Tim McVeigh is merely a pawn in an expansive conspiracy led by a group of John Does that may even have had government involvement. But only a small fringe will cling to this theory for long.

title: Naked Capitalists
description: Rich trips over himself trying to portray por-nographers as gee-whiz folks peddling little more than harmless titillation. Let's get real. In its least offensive form, pornography presents sex without relationships, commitments or consequences. At its worst, pornography presents as entertainment violent and aggressive behavior toward women. Kiddie porn, bestiality and rape are no longer on the fringes of the adult commercial-sex industry but are among the most sought-after materials. Does the hooker have a heart of gold too, Mr. Rich?

title: Naked Capitalists
description: Rich's subjects spoke of protecting their children from the knowledge of what they do for a living. Who is there to protect the families of men lured away by the easy availability of online porn and the fantasy life it promises?

title: Leigh Ornstein, Stuart Gold
description: Leigh Tracy Ornstein and Stuart Bruce Gold are to be married today. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein is to perform the ceremony at the Candlewood Inn in Brookfield, Conn.

title: Where Everyday Golfers Can Feel Like Pros
description: So you, the everyday golfer, want to play a United States Open course with those fast greens and that thick rough?

title: For the Prudent Son, All Risky Bets Are Off
description: THERE is no way that the television sportscaster Bob Costas, at 5 feet 7 and 49 years of age, could compete on a basketball court against Shaquille O'Neal, the star center of the Los Angeles Lakers. But Mr. Costas once went one-on-one against Shaq in an investment contest. And lost.

title: Wisteria's Beauty Can Turn Ugly
description: Reading ''With Wisteria, Patience, Patience, Patience'' [Cuttings, May 27], I felt my divided feelings toward the beautiful monster plant. Under very close supervision, its vines can be a truly decorative addition to a landscaping design. They can also choke to death the mature dogwoods, Japanese plums, forsythias, azaleas and rhododendrons in my backyard.

title: In East Camden, Scars of Urban Strife Fade
description: THE most striking thing about East Camden is what's missing. The burned-out buildings and grafitti-ridden storefronts that fill the city's other neighborhoods are scarce on the blocks around Woodrow Wilson High School and Dudley Park. In their place are houses with flower-filled planters, painted front doors and debris-free porches, the kinds of touches that people living in neighboring suburbs take for granted but that are an anomaly in the state's poorest city. While developers and city planners are busy trying to figure out how the success of Camden's waterfront may spill over to the depressed inner city, this neighborhood has worked to bring itself back, largely because of the efforts of the St. Joseph's Carpenter Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENENDEZ, SERAFIN S.
description: MENENDEZ-Serafin S. Died June 1, 2001, in Miami, FL, after a long struggle with cancer. A former resident of Wesport, CT, he will be remembered fondly by his family and many friends. He is survived by his daughters Lydia L. and Melanie Menendez of Fairfield, CT, his brother, Hugo Menendez, sisters, Gisela Barton and Carmen Diaz and his mother Maria E. Menendez of Alameda, CA.

title: Phil Schaap, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks, AIDS And Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Where New Theater Is Coming In From the Cold; Chinese Welcome a Break From Old-Style Drama
description: THE Beijing Children's Art Theater is usually a place for puppet shows and children's plays, its comfortable purple seats filled with pampered only children and doting parents. But this winter the stalls were packed with snuggling young couples and chattering college students, there to see one of the hottest shows in town, the China premiere of ''The Bedbug'' by Vladimir Mayakovsky.

title: Obstacles to China's W.T.O. Entry Eased in Talks With U.S.
description: American and Chinese trade negotiators said today that they had resolved most of the remaining issues that have held up China's entry to the World Trade Organization, including the degree to which China can subsidize its farmers as a member of the trade group.

title: How to Take Back Our Analog Brains
description: WE have outsourced our brains.

title: Elizabeth Shepherd, Robert Buccini
description: Elizabeth Lyn Shepherd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Shepherd Jr. of Virginia Beach, was married last evening to Robert Edward Buccini, a son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Robert Buccini of Greenville, Del. The Rev. Roberto Balducelli performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Santa Maria Assunta in Positano, Italy.

title: Las Vegas
description: Since at least 1947, when Bugsy Siegel bet that a strip of desert highway could become a resort destination, Las Vegas has been a place of perpetual reinvention. The 90's saw the nation's fastest-growing metropolitan area try to restyle itself as family friendly, with theme parks, good restaurants and fantasy hotels, in addition to gambling and other grown-up vices.

title: Unrest Is in the Air
description: For years, North Jersey residents have pressed lawmakers to find ways to reduce aircraft noise from Newark International Airport. Now, with the Federal Aviation Administration considering a sweeping redesign of the most congested airspace in the country, residents in southern and central New Jersey complain that the one proposal under discussion -- rerouting air traffic over the ocean -- would merely push the problem in their direction.

title: Lives; No Tears for Frankie
description: I was in the fifth grade when Frankie died. It was 1971. My whole class planned to attend the funeral, since we knew him. My father thought going might give me nightmares, but I insisted. I had never seen a dead person before. Most of all, I wanted to be sure that the little creep would never touch me again.

title: Carrying a Wealth Of Forgotten Steps In His Hip Pocket
description: ON Wednesday Frederic Franklin, the distinguished dancer and ballet master, will reach another birthday: his 87th. He might take five minutes out of a work hour to acknowledge it.

title: Streetscapes/Columbus Avenue From 72nd to 77th Street; Small and Elegant 19th-Century Apartment Houses
description: IN the 1880's and 90's the small apartment houses of Columbus Avenue from 72nd to 77th Street strove to outdo one another in elegance. Now, for the sake of historic preservation -- since 1990 the blocks have been part of the Upper West Side-Central Park West Historic District -- some of the buildings are being stripped of layers of paint that were added later.

title: Where New Theater Is Coming In From the Cold; Daring New Plays Find An Eager Russian Audience
description: THE biggest popular hit of Moscow's current theater season is a show the critics trashed with glee. While audiences are packing the 1,200-seat theater where it is performed, reviewers greeted its opening this winter with the verbal equivalent of rotten eggs and tomatoes.

title: Once So Hot and Now, Can It Be Again?
description: JACKIE O., Cher and Elizabeth Taylor shopped there; Andy Warhol was a regular; Truman Capote signed books in the window; and Joey Arias, the flamboyant performance artist, liked the slippery floors. ''They were perfect for sliding across to catch shoplifters,'' he said.

title: From the Streets to Suburbia: The Iverson and Bryant Game
description: They started jabbering at each another in the final seconds. The irascible Philly guard with the tattoos, heart and serrated edge, exchanging words with the ultracompetitive suburbanite who spent his formative years in Lower Merion, Pa.

title: Alfresco Angels
Paid Notice: Deaths  FUND, DOROTHY
description: FUND-Dorothy. Died June 1, 2001, in Hollywood, FL, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Bert Fund. Loving sister of Anne Kaplan. Cherished aunt of Cynthia Kirsch and Robert Wellins. Adored grandaunt of Christopher and Alex and great-aunt of Jake, Max and Zachary. Aunt Dotty is deeply missed by her family and all who knew her.

title: Breathless Bourque Completes His Quest
description: Over 22 seasons in the National Hockey League, and for most of his life, Ray Bourque had played out this moment in his head, over and over and over again.

title: A Showcase
description: To the Editor:

title: Adapting the Horrors Of a Kafka Story To Suit Glass's Music
description: WHEN Philip Glass first proposed the idea of doing an opera based on Franz Kafka's short story ''In the Penal Colony,'' I couldn't even remember if I had read it. But that didn't matter. I was intrigued. I have collaborated with Philip for many years, and I am always interested in what he has on his mind. He described it as a ''pocket opera,'' a small ensemble piece that would have a run in a theater as opposed to a few performances in an opera house.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Jackpot's Running Low For a Lottery Winner

title: Marla Levine, Scott Defrin
description: Dr. Marla Risa Levine, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Levine of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married today to Scott Michael Defrin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Defrin of Manhattan. Rabbi Gerald Skolnik is to perform the ceremony at Temple Judea in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: No Safe Haven
description: A MEMOIR OF MISFORTUNE By Su Xiaokang. Translated by Zhu Hong. 329 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: An Apartment Complex Seeks a Touch of Home Rule
description: Wilma Johnson has been living in the 38-building Diego Beekman Houses since June 1975, and she has been organizing its tenants for almost as long, seeing the federal low-income housing complex through management crises and crime waves. ''I had a mission, and I kept on going,'' she said. ''Everybody told me it wasn't going to do any good, but I kept on going.''

title: June 3-9; Time Really Is Money
description: Do video stores really want tapes back on time? Of course not -- no more than credit-card companies want you to pay any more than that reassuringly affordable ''minimum amount due.'' No, those video late fees are the megastars of the bottom line. In one recent quarter, the fees accounted for fully a sixth -- roughly $200 million -- of Blockbuster's revenues. The chain just settled class-action lawsuits involving its hefty late fees, which it says it has lowered, but the cash will go only to -- you guessed it -- the lawyers. Customers, if they go to the trouble, get rental coupons.

title: Last Right
description: Carmichael's essay raised a troubling issue. Is it one's right to involve others in the actual act of one's dying?

title: Tales of Greed in Post-Soviet Russia
description: MARKETS have short memories, and the mourning of the latest boom-gone-bust is usually brief. In the nearly three years since Russia defaulted on its debt, investors have moved on -- first to the dot-com frenzy in the United States and then to its fizzle. Russia's derring-do tales of billions made and lost, of gun-toting tycoons and panic spreading across the globe have long since slipped from the headlines.

title: LIPA Sets Deadline For New Power Station
description: The Long Island Power Authority has set a June 21 deadline for proposals to build new generating units to produce a total of nearly 80 megawatts of electricity at a 47-acre site adjacent to the defunct Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: The World: New Math; Going Along, But Not Getting Along
description: NOW is the time for healing, for working togeth er, for above all -- bipartisan cooperation. It is the time for peacemaking dinners at the White House, for changing the tone in Washington (again) for graceful losing and humble winning. For everything just short of joining hands and singing ''Kumbaya.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, BUDD
description: KELLER-Budd. He will be greatly missed by Bee, his wife of 56 years, his sons Richard and Jeffery, his brother, Gerald, and Barbara. Graveside service at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, N.J. Monday, June 11, 11AM.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: Natasha Maximoff and Peter Chandler
description: Natasha Franziska Maximoff, a daughter of Inga M. Maximoff and Richard M. Maximoff of Oxford, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter David Chandler, a son of Warren W. Chandler of Fair Haven, N.J., and the late Elizabeth L. Chandler. Mayor William E. Leonard of Fair Haven officiated on the beach in Spring Lake, N.J. On June 24, the couple will have a Roman Catholic ceremony at Burgthalschenke, a restaurant in Thal, Germany.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is a bit ironic, but interest in Arctic wildlife seems to spike up whenever we've had a pro-oil Republican administration in the White House.''

title: End of a Magazine
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Translate Theme Park
description: THE new Universal Studios theme park in Osaka, Japan, has won almost immediate popularity, drawing more than a million visitors since its opening on March 31. This turnout far outpaces the park's target for its first year.

title: Food; Winged Victory
description: It is conceivable that more Buffalo chicken wings are sold in America than bottles of beer -- which is impossible. But certainly everyone born after 1964 has a favorite rendition. Buffalo's contribution to the world includes the Bills, half of Niagara Falls, the playwright A. R. Gurney, wings and my friend and America's No. 1 dinner guest, the actor, folk-art collector and Buffa-liste, Oliver Clark. (He is a native.) When queried about wings, Oliver wrote:

title: Political Briefing; Squabbling Continues Over Virginia's Map
description: Representative Rick Boucher, a Democrat, has held the Ninth Congressional District seat in southwestern Virginia for 10 consecutive terms. But Virginia Republicans have long insisted that at heart it is a Republican district and should be theirs because its voters are so conservative.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREMER, WILLIAM F.
description: BREMER-William F. We are celebrating your 79th Birthday tonight in the style you'd appreciate...with Mom, good food and wine! Love, Annette

title: Thomas Middelhoff Has a Hunch
description: Thomas Middelhoff, chairman and chief executive of the media giant Bertelsmann, kicked off his crusade to save Napster on the afternoon of Oct. 31 last year in the ballroom of the Essex House hotel on Central Park South. Before a crowd of journalists and camera crews, Middelhoff mounted a dais with Shawn Fanning, Napster's 19-year-old founder. Everyone knew Fanning: the bashful cult hero who had brought free music to the masses, the embodiment of the libertarian ethos of the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on May 13, about 71st Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, referred incorrectly to the Metropolitan Museum's acquisition of the interiors of two 18th-century French rooms from the former Herbert N. Strauss home. The rooms were donated by the Strauss family, not purchased.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY EDITION -- Like Father: Designing for 2; Big and Little Hand
description: Father-son teams are the winning ticket in the era of Bush II. Across the cultural board, from the Murdochs to the Sheens, pre et fils rule. So it makes sense that for Father's Day there is a flood of gear to take the twosome from beach to ballgame in style. Which means that Senior and Junior can find a way -- whether it's primary time, prime time or just time for a game of catch -- to mix and match.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the New Jersey Republican Party's difficulties misspelled the surname of a candidate for governor. He is State Senator Bill Schluter, not Schulter.

title: From Russia, With Paint and Politics
description: FORBIDDEN ART: THE POSTWAR RUSSIAN AVANT-GARDE'' at the Bruce Museum may have a lurid title, but the art itself is frequently buoyant, playful and sweet. It's also frequently less than compelling. However, it compensates for this with historical, political and cultural content.

title: Little Scandal, But Lots Of News Of Commerce
description: Queens Business Today, a new weekly newspaper, is short on scandal and long on profiles of bank managers squeezed between reams of advertisements for local businesses. To some, it may be the city's least dynamic read. But its existence is intriguing. Has Queens become such a commercial center that it needs its own business newspaper?

title: Forbidden Apple Surprises The Field
description: With all eyes on the top filly Perfect Sting and the favored King Cugat, Forbidden Apple sneaked away from the field on his way to a front-running three-quarter-length victory yesterday in the $400,000 Manhattan Handicap at Belmont.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 10, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCARAMUZZO, ANGELO
description: SCARAMUZZO - Angelo. The Board of Governors, the members and the staff of Glenn Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved longterm Caddy Master and Ranger (Pops) and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his family. There were none of us he did not touch and we will all miss him. Board of Governors Lowell Kwiat, President

title: The Nation; Government By Wish List
description: WHEN President Bush signed into law the tax cut he had championed since the start of the race for the White House a year and a half ago, it marked a political victory of the first order.

title: A Still Life In Motion
description: IN Europe, the past is always close. But there is one place in Denmark where it seems astonishingly close: an ancient fishing village, almost untouched by time, hugs the placid sea just a few miles from Denmark's capital. The small town of Dragor is, in fact, closer to Copenhagen's airport than Copenhagen itself is.

title: Alma Mahler, as Ever In a Musical Shadow
description: ALMA MAHLER, the wife of the composer Gustav Mahler, apostrophized as Vienna's most famous lover, a talented musician in her own right, was a fascinating, contradictory and sometimes maddening figure. She was romantically allied with some of the major creative figures of early 20th-century Vienna: along with Mahler, Walter Gropius, Franz Werfel, Oskar Kokoschka and others. She had to give up her own art early on -- Gustav compelled her to stop composing when they married -- and was therefore fated to be defined in terms of her unrealized potential. She left great letters and diaries (heavily edited to cast her in a more favorable light before posterity), rather self-serving memoirs, and 14 published songs, most written before her marriage at 22.

title: Rats!
description: To the Editor:

title: He'd Prefer Not To
description: BY THE SEA

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-10-01: Testimony; Boundary Markers
description: The human traffic from Mexico into the United States reached a grim peak last month when 14 out of a group of 26 men died of exposure in the desert near Yuma, Ariz. (More than 100,000 illegal immigrants are caught crossing the border every year in this area.) Here, several people in Yuma County whose lives were touched by the deaths in May reflect on the dangerous migrations nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ARTHUR JR.
description: MARX-Arthur Jr., age 79, of Naples, FL, a Brown University graduate, served in the U.S. Marine Corp during World War II, veteran of Iwo Jima and Saipan, he was an avid fisherman and a Specialist on the American Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife Emilie (Hyman) Marx, a son and daughter-in-law Arthur and Molly Marx. He was predeceased by a son and daughter Alfred H. and Kathryn Marx, loved and missed by family and friends. The family has entrusted care and services to Hodges Funeral Chapel, Naples, Florida 34103, 941-261-1237.

title: Sarah Moulin, Stephen Youngwood
description: Sarah Maryline Moulin, a daughter of Evelyne and Bernard Moulin of Neuilly, France, was married there on Friday to Stephen Michael Youngwood, a son of Judith and Alfred Youngwood of New York. Michel Deloison, the deputy mayor of Neuilly, which is near Paris, officiated at the city hall. A religious ceremony will be held today at Synagogue de Neuilly-sur-Seine. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and Rabbi Alexis Blum will officiate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 13 of the Travel section today about the Universal Studios theme park in Osaka, Japan, refers incorrectly in some copies to the number of theme parks in that country. It is more than 60, not more than 120.

title: Swiss Vote on Church Laws Is Reawakening Old Ghosts
description: GENEVA, June 9  Mention the Vatican and Switzerland in the same breath, and people immediately think of the Swiss Guards, whose medieval halberds, plumed helmets and colorful tunics are known the world over.

title: Nan Kim, Peter Paik
description: Young-Nan Nancy Kim and Dr. Peter Yoonsuk Paik were married yesterday in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Kil Sang Yoon, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the South Presbyterian Church. Afterward, at the reception, the couple had a traditional Korean formal greeting ceremony at Estherwood, a house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: THE GUIDE
description: New Haven Festival

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRINGI, BARBARA LEVCHUK
description: CARRINGI - Barbara Levchuk. June 6, 2001. Beloved wife of Donald, loving mother of Michael and Mark, beloved daughter of John and Veronica Levchuk, devoted sister of John and his wife Christine. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday June 11th., 9:30am, St. Iganatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, RANANA (NEE GOLDBERG)
description: BENJAMIN-Ranana (nee Goldberg), on June 7th, 2001 at age 82. Born in NYC, formerly of Great Neck, NY and a resident of Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of Joseph for 60 years, dear sister of Natalie and Joseph. Devoted mother of David, Laura and Daniel, loving grandmother of Alexander, Nicholas, Geoffrey, Andrew and Joshua. A pioneer in Origami in America and author of several Origami books. Her love, kindness, friendship and enthusiasm for life are a tremendous loss. Funeral arrangements private.

title: A Real Humanism
description: To the Editor:

title: An Olympics of Cooperation Rather Than Competition
description: NO single theme could possibly characterize the huge Third International Theater Olympics now running in Moscow through June 29, although one -- unusual collaborations between composers and theater directors -- has had special resonance.

title: June 3-9; Offer for North Korea
description: After a three-month review, the Bush administration moderated an earlier tough posture and said it would restart talks on a range of security issues with North Korea. But the White House outlined a stringent approach that the North Koreans may find hard to swallow. President Bush said that he would seek to win reductions of North Korea's huge troop deployment along the demilitarized zone, as well as an end to its production, deployment and export of missiles. He said he would not seek to renegotiate a six-year-old accord that is intended to provide North Korea with two light-water reactors. South Korea welcomed the initiative as a step toward moving along its stalled reconciliation process with the northern leader, Kim Jong Il. No word from North Korea.

title: Mr. Ashcroft's Skimpy Report
description: There is ''no evidence of racial bias in the administration of the federal death penalty,'' Attorney General John Ashcroft declared last week upon issuing a Justice Department report that purports to settle the issue. But the report does no such thing.

title: Suzanne Osman, Karl Maier
description: Dr. Suzanne Lynn Osman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eli Osman of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Karl J. Maier, a son of Maria Palmowski of Marcellus, N.Y., and Walter Maier of Marietta, N.Y. Rabbi Brooks R. Susman will officiate at the Park Savoy catering center in Florham Park, N.J.

title: Danielle Dubin, Peter Manion
description: Danielle de Bourbon Dubin, a daughter of Maria Elvira de Bourbon Dubin of New Canaan, Conn., and Ronald N. Dubin of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Anthony Manion, a son of Nancy and Donald Manion of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Gundrey of the Church of Antioch performed the ceremony at the Loretto Chapel in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY EDITION -- Like Father: Designing for 2; Me and Dad, Skater Dude
description: Father-son teams are the winning ticket in the era of Bush II. Across the cultural board, from the Murdochs to the Sheens, pre et fils rule. So it makes sense that for Father's Day there is a flood of gear to take the twosome from beach to ballgame in style. Which means that Senior and Junior can find a way -- whether it's primary time, prime time or just time for a game of catch -- to mix and match.

title: Private Sector; Answering His Own Tough Questions
description: Dieter Zetsche, the Chrysler Group president, assumed that he would be pelted with questions last week when he addressed the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit.

title: Unbalanced Schedule Breeds Familiarity
description: What a strange week on the schedule this will be. Pedro Martnez will not be pitching against the Yankees. It will mark the first time in four weeks that the Yankees will not face the pitcher they have seen so often that he has become simply Pedro to them.

title: June 3-9; The Devastation of AIDS
description: As the world marked the 20-year milestone in the fight against AIDS, one young symbol of that battle, the engaging Nkosi Johnson, 12, was buried in South Africa, after a short life that he dedicated to telling his story of infection and asking others not to isolate victims of the disease.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for GEORGE WARRINGTON; Amtrak, Pulled in Two Directions
description: AMTRAK is again in serious financial trouble, and last week, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta disclosed that the railroad was trying to mortgage part of Penn Station in New York to make ends meet until the next fiscal year begins in October. He suggested that the railroad consider giving up its national system and concentrate on the East and West Coasts, plus service from Chicago to Detroit, New Orleans and a few other cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWAL, GERTRUD
description: KOWAL-Gertrud. Died on June 7, 2001, at age of 100. Dearly beloved mother of Michael. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, NETTINA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Nettina. We will love and miss you forever. Priscilla Shayne and Betsy

title: Bush Is Revising Energy Policy to Address Global Warming
description: Barely three weeks after the White House issued President Bush's new energy blueprint, some top officials are backing away from its projections of how much coal, oil and gas the United States will burn in the years ahead.

title: Quality Time
description: AS GOOD AS

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY EDITION -- Like Father: Designing for 2; Beauty Secrets Of the Dugout
description: Father-son teams are the winning ticket in the era of Bush II. Across the cultural board, from the Murdochs to the Sheens, pre et fils rule. So it makes sense that for Father's Day there is a flood of gear to take the twosome from beach to ballgame in style. Which means that Senior and Junior can find a way -- whether it's primary time, prime time or just time for a game of catch -- to mix and match.

title: A Falling Gauge of Volatility May Be Bad News for Stocks
description: PROFESSIONAL options traders, like sailors and fishermen, are always watching for a break in the weather. The barometers they follow closely are gauges of volatility, or fluctuations in the prices of stocks and options.

title: Marisa Brett, Eric Fleegler
description: Dr. Marisa B. Brett, a daughter of Leslie and Barry Brett of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Eric Fleegler, a son of Kathy Fleegler and Dr. Earl Fleegler of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: Vieques Mayor Praises Jailed Protesters
description: The mayor of the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, Damaso Serrano, joined about 75 other officials and protesters yesterday at a rally outside a Brooklyn detention center where four political leaders are jailed for civil disobedience on the island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VENOKUR, NATALIE ANAPOLSKY
description: VENOKUR - Natalie Anapolsky. March 8, 2001. Loving wife and mother. She loved New York and was a proud Bostonian. Smart in business. Loved life. Full of laughter and loved you unconditionally. Brought love and laughter into everyones life. Helped the homeless always and gave herself selflessly to many charities. Wife of the late Harold Venokur and sister of the late Eleanor ''Tootsie'' Newman. Survived by a son Jonathan, a daughter Babette, a sister Barbara Whitman and three nieces Beth, Lori and Patty. Your laughter and your great love for us will live on forever. She was our best friend. Goodbye Mom, we'll miss you. Unveiling at a later date. Laid to rest New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Letters
description: THE RUNNER'

title: Was This Soccer Mom a Terrorist?
description: Sara Jane Olson says she ''wants her life back and wants this all to go away.'' And Bill Harris, the 1970's revolutionary, says the Symbionese Liberation Army ''was a bunch of amateurs,'' and he wishes everyone would forget (Maryanne Vollers, May 20). I remember the S.L.A.'s reign of terror. If they were amateurs, they were vicious amateurs who left behind them a trail of destruction.

title: Habitats/NoLIta; A Portrait Of the Artist
description: In search of a reasonably priced apartment, Chris Kelly finds that luck and perseverance pay off -- as does a bit of Mandarin.

title: Roy and Bourque Close Off the Ice, Too
description: DENVER, June 9  The pair had spent 17 days together playing for Team Canada at the 1998 Nagano Olympics, and, on the last day of competition, they wished it were longer. After more than 13 years of facing each other, Patrick Roy and Ray Bourque wondered, not very realistically, if they would ever get to wear the same sweater in the National Hockey League before their careers ended.

title: Nassau Comptroller Sees Budget Surplus
description: The Nassau County comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, announced that the county was likely to end the year with a budget surplus of close to $75 million, but he waved a warning flag about projections in the budgets of the next three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAPIER, EVELYN (NEE ZEIGER)
description: SCAPIER-Evelyn (nee Zeiger). Died May 28, in New York. Born in Chicago, she was the daughter of Moishe and Bessie Zeiger. In 1946, she married Dr. Joseph Scapier, a pioneer in cancer research, who, after being awarded the Legion of Honor, was brought to New York from the Pasteur Institute in Paris to head up cancer research at what is now known as Memorial Sloan-Kettering. She was later married to Harry Katz, a writer, until his death in 1987. From 1956 to 1981, Mrs. Scapier was Director of Development at the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute and from 1981 to 1990 she was Program Director for Bar Ilan University. From 1992 until just before her death, she worked independently selecting projects she felt important and of benefit to mankind. Mrs. Scapier lived most of her life in Manhattan and was well-known among her friends and in the community for her unfailing kindness, generosity and infinite willingness to help those in need. Mrs. Scapier is survived by her brother Martin Zeiger of Albuquerque, her daughter Jane Thomas of Puerto Rico, her son Bruce Scapier of Santa Monica, CA; four grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Services to be announced at a later date. For information call Riverside Chapel at 212-362-6600.

title: PULSE: FATHER'S DAY EDITION -- Like Father: Designing for 2; The Pocket Porsche
description: Father-son teams are the winning ticket in the era of Bush II. Across the cultural board, from the Murdochs to the Sheens, pre et fils rule. So it makes sense that for Father's Day there is a flood of gear to take the twosome from beach to ballgame in style. Which means that Senior and Junior can find a way -- whether it's primary time, prime time or just time for a game of catch -- to mix and match.

title: The Spirit of Woodstock Survives in Glen Cove
description: BUSINESS-SCHOOL professors say that every successful company has a Founding Myth, a legend that connects the company's origins with a mission greater than the mere hunt for profits. Think of Henry Ford, who assembled cars for the masses, or Sam Walton of Wal-Mart, who became America's storekeeper.

title: Study Traces Rise In Radiation
description: A study of about 500 baby teeth from Suffolk County children showed that levels of strontium 90 in the teeth rose by 40 percent from the early 1980's to the mid-1990's, an antinuclear research group said last week.

title: New World Disorder
description: AMBASSADOR OF THE DEAD

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about students at the School of American Ballet misspelled the name of an award given to those of outstanding promise. It is the Mae L. Wien Award, not May.

title: A Holy Place in China Fights for Its Life, Body and Soul
description: The 133 residents of this remote mountain hamlet know they live almost in paradise.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Comverse Technology Sets Record for Quarter

title: Palestinian Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Town, Gown, Surround Sound
description: The struggle of downtown movie theaters to hang on in the shadow of 18-plexes at the mall has been largely a losing one. But when the downtown is Princeton and the owner of the the building is Princeton University, the theater has a better than fighting chance. The university has paid more than $1 million to redo the interior of the Garden Theater, which opened in 1920 on Nassau Street -- the exterior is protected by rules of its historic district -- and it reopened this month. There, patrons can watch movies in stadium seating and amid surround sound, munching on popcorn with real butter. Running a downtown movie house in a multiplex world ''is not a financially viable situation in many cases,'' said Louise Stepens, whose business leases the theater. ''But it will be good in Princeton.'' Anne Ruderman

title: Success on Track Leads To Sales in the Showroom
description: In 1901, Henry Ford had what should be called a pre-Nascar moment. It incidentally accelerated the 20th century. Desperate to raise money, Henry built a 26-horsepower horseless carriage with an amazing top speed of 72 miles per hour. He called it ''Sweepstakes'' and challenged the top cars of the day to race. It was the last time he was an underdog.

title: Untamed Sounds From Well Beyond the Margins
description: LAST month, I heard David Bowie's 1969 glam-rock classic ''Space Oddity'' as if for the first time. I'd heard the song on the radio before, of course; however, coming as it did, not from Mr. Bowie but from a choir of elementary school kids in a remote farm community in northern Canada, this was something new.

title: Melissa Luckman, David Keller
description: Melissa S. Luckman, the daughter of Sharon Gersten Luckman and Peter Luckman, both of Manhattan, was married last evening to David Elliot Keller, the son of Elaine and Fred Keller of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Against Improvisation
description: To the Editor:

title: Style: Weekend; Marilyn Slept Here
description: Cathy knocked on the door, but no one answered. One thing Cathy and Roy knew was that when you deliver narcotics, people are happy to see you. That much she'd learned practically in her crib. She leaned close to the door, tapped and murmured, ''Nembutal for Marilyn Monroe.''

title: Shopping, Its Own Reward
description: It is often said that one has to spend money to make money, but participants in the Born to Shop tour offered by the Hotel Meurice in Paris have to spend money to spend more money. Each Thursday, the program begins with breakfast and a lecture by Suzy Gershman, author of the Frommer ''Born to Shop'' guides, followed by a walk to the Rue St.-Honor, the Monoprix Opra store, the stores in the gardens of the Palais Royal, the mall at the Louvre and the souvenir stands of the Rue de Rivoli. There's also a morning coffee break, lunch and afternoon tea at the hotel, and a lecture on perfumes. Purchases can be made with what's left after paying the tour fee: $450 for hotel guests, $500 for others. Information: (33-1) 44.58.10.10 or on the Web at www.meuricehotel.com.

title: Last Right
description: Carmichael's decision to write candidly about her role in her friend's ''choice in dying'' was admirable. She should be entirely at peace with herself about the assistance she gave. Her friend's desperation might not have been such if we had a realistic attitude toward choice in dying. There is support available through the Hemlock Society.

title: The Dream of a Worthy Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Premier Jazz Players at Home Here
description: MUCH of New Jersey is a bedroom community for New York City, and some of those bedrooms are in the homes of talented musicians from the world of jazz, a close-knit community where everybody knows everyone else and artists and audiences alike feed off each other's love of the music.

title: The Dazzling Age That Was a Tiny Lady's Preserve
description: TODAY, the very word Victorian suggests stuffiness, prudery, chastity, traditionalism, sentimentality and a host of other supposedly conservative attributes. And yet during the reign of Queen Victoria from 1837 to 1901, Britain not only built an empire ''where the sun never set'' but also spawned extraordinary technological, scientific and social innovation. Even Victoria, that tiny figure who wore mourning black for half her life, was apparently quite unlike the stern disapproving matriarch of her historical image.

title: Hincapie Goes for Bicycle Racing Glory
description: Bicycle road racing looks so glamorous: the hundreds of thousands of passionate spectators who line the course for the Tour de France; the Champagne sprays from the victory stand; the shiny, featherweight $5,000 bikes ridden to the finish at 45 miles an hour. But how enchanting can a sport be when most of the riders on elite teams are known by the cruel French job description of domestique?

title: A Mecca for Film Buffs
description: IT started as a familiar suburban complaint: former Manhattanites grousing about the numbing sameness of the movies at the multiplexes, 100 screens and nothing to see.

title: Lights, Camera, Strike!
description: The actors who were seeking a living wage and health coverage have little to do with the Matt Damons and Madonnas, the elite few with managers, lawyers, publicity agents, hairdressers, etc. (The Way We Live Now, George Packer, May 20).

title: SLOW GROWTH IN 90'S
description: Despite a low unemployment rate and an increase in new jobs, New Jersey ranked near the bottom among states in terms of economic growth during most of the 1990's, according to a report released by the federal Department of Commerce last week. New Jersey ranked 42nd in growth in the gross state product, which is a measure of the market value of goods and services produced by labor and property, increasing by 2.9 percent from 1992, when recovery from the 1990-1991 recession first began, to 1999. The national average was 4.0 percent, with the fastest-growing states in the West. New Jersey's slowest growth areas were in construction and manufacturing. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALOM, JOE
description: SHALOM - Joe. Philanthropist, Died at 83. The Board of Directors of Ozar Hatorah expresses their heartfelt sympathy and condolences on the passing of international Jewish Philanthropist, Joe Shalom. Mr. Shalom died of a heart attack on Thursday, June 7th at his home in Deal, New Jersey. Mr. Shalom, a native of Brooklyn, was the son of the late Isaac Shalom. The senior Mr. Shalom was world renowned for his philanthropic work in Jewish education. As President of Ozar Hatorah, an international educational network founded by his father, Joe succeeded in helping to educate over 400,000 children in North Africa, Europe and the Middle East over the past 40 years. His leadership will be intensely missed. He is survived by his wife Natalie, his sons Isaac and Robert, his daughter and son-inlaw Leslie and Nissim Beribie, his daughter Valerie, his sisters Muriel Attie and Norma Hedaya, his brothers Stephen and Hank and his grandchildren Natasha Shalom and Yvonne Beribie.

title: Back When Bikini Was Just the Name of an Island
description: THE metal racks of hooks are bereft of the thousands of numbered brass locker keys they once held. The room from which wool bathing suits were dispensed is empty. But there is an aura of beach history at the decrepit Jacob Riis Park Bathing Pavilion, and the public will soon get to see how, in a major renovation, the National Park Service wants to bring that history back.

title: Arielle Epstein, Aryeh Kieffer
description: Arielle Yaakova Epstein, a daughter of Jane Geller Epstein and Rabbi Jerome Epstein of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married today in Rockleigh, N.J. to Aryeh Chanan Kieffer, the son of Melinda Mishkin Kieffer and Rabbi Samuel Kieffer of Weston, Fla. The bride's father will officiate, with the bridegroom's father, at the Rockleigh Country Club.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about crowds that flooded Miami Beach over Memorial Day weekend misidentified the maker of a shearling coat shown on a runway as part of Urban Fashion Week, one of the activities that drew the visitors. It is Ecko, not Enyce.

title: Corrections
description: A rendering in the Postings column last Sunday showing a visitors center planned for Wave Hill in the Bronx was reproduced in mirror image. The greenhouse and gardens should have been at the right.

title: Fluent in the Languages Of Lithe Bodies in Motion
description: WHEN Jim Simpson, the founder and director of the Flea Theater in TriBeCa, first saw Nicholas Leichter dance, he knew instantly, he said, that Mr. Leichter would be right for his unconventional theater. Home to off-beat plays, concerts and performance artists, the Flea is a challenge for most dance companies because it has no proscenium or wing space and the audience is right there on the same level. But Mr. Leichter's combination of hip-hop style, postmodern craft, cross-cultural theatricality and a desire to blur the boundaries between performers and viewers works to his advantage in the Flea.

title: A Nation Out of Time
description: Shortly after Christmas last year, I traveled to Nepal as one of the many tourists who seek out its Buddhist sites. Everyone I spoke to in India warned me against the trip. A few days earlier, the Nepalese media had reported an Indian film star's having made derogatory remarks about Nepal. Rioting followed in Katmandu; Indian shopkeepers and tourists had been attacked.

title: Jeneve Brooks, Stuart Klinger
description: Jeneve Ruth Brooks and Stuart Philip Klinger are to be married today by the bride's father, Dr. Harold L. Brooks, an American Baptist minister, at Middle Collegiate Church in New York. He is to be assisted by the Rev. Gordon R. Dragt, a Dutch Reformed minister, and by Rabbi Jonathan Woll.

title: Ex-Officer Off Tough Beat Seeks to Free the Innocent
description: With the palm of his hand, Michael S. Race pushed open the door of the Brooklyn courthouse, and there, standing under a spring sun and drawing their first breaths of freedom in 14 years, were Anthony Faison and Charles Shepherd: innocent men, home from serving time for someone else's murder. Mr. Race smiled.

title: Death Be Not Proud
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: McVeigh Is Executed for Oklahoma City Bombing
description: Timothy J. McVeigh, a disgruntled Army veteran who went on to declare war on the United States government by blowing up a federal building in Oklahoma City in 1995, killing 168 people, was executed by lethal injection this morning at a federal prison in Terre Haute, Ind.

title: Stocks Fall After Warnings
description: Stock prices fell today, pulled down by selling in the technology sector, after two more companies forecast weaker-than-expected quarterly results, stoking investors' fears about the sluggish American economy.

title: It Must Be June: The Lakers' Horry Comes Alive
description: PHILADELPHIA -- Robert Horry deposited the most vicious of dunks on the head of Dikembe Mutombo with 8 minutes 57 seconds left last night, a right-handed slam that made most of the fanatical 20,900 people at the First Union Center sit down in disbelief, a basket that sent the rangy Laker forward spiraling out of control to the floor.

title: Lawyer Says McVeigh Appears Calm and Prepared to Die
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 10  Timothy J. McVeigh spent his last full day of life today in a 9- by 14- foot holding room, writing letters, and waiting. "His temperament is very even," said Robert Nigh Jr., one of Mr. McVeigh's lawyers, after spending time with his client this afternoon. "He is calm. He is himself. He is prepared. Quite frankly, he is ready to die."

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a call by a group of veteran American diplomats for an end to executions of the mentally retarded in the United States misstated the execution date set for Juan Raul Garza. It is June 19, not the 18th.

title: Power Applies Pressure, but Can't Score
description: They both had chances, and in the end, the Power and the Bay Area CyberRays were nearly even in several categories. The Power's shots were a little stronger, a little more on target, and they made Bay Area goalkeeper LaKeysia Beene work a little harder, but they didn't result in a goal.

title: MacCulloch Feels Sore but Satisfied
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10  Todd MacCulloch had played his finest game of the postseason, grabbing offensive rebounds and scoring on putbacks over Shaquille O'Neal. He had defied logic by outrunning the Los Angeles Lakers to score on a fast- break dunk, and had dazzled onlookers by spinning around O'Neal and scoring on a soft left-handed finger roll.

title: Compressed Data; Internet Commercials With a Television Finish
description: Boil down all the complaints that advertisers have raised about pitching their wares on the Internet and you find the central criticism: they wish the Internet could be more like television.

title: Planning the Digital Smorgasbord
description: Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, is not an effusive man. To begin a recent interview at the company's Manhattan headquarters, he was asked about his company's vision.

title: Virgin Mobile Is Said to Agree To Sprint Deal
description: In its first foray into the United States telecommunications market, Virgin Mobile has reached an agreement with the Sprint Corporation to create a joint venture, people close to the companies said today.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Yukie Okuyama, Mahdi Kazuto Shah, Hristoula Harakas, Ellen Cornfield and Denise Johnsson, Merce Cunningham Studio, New York, March 17, 2001

title: For Kuerten, Red Clay Turns Into Gold
description: The familiar drumbeat from the partying Brazilians had begun to echo across the grounds of Roland Garros today when their own Gustavo Kuerten stripped off his shirt on the center court podium and slipped into a Guga original.

title: High School Runner Faces Unusual Challenges
description: Royal Mitchell is a typical elite high school runner in many ways: he has run impressive races and he won his conference title in the 200 meters in 21.70 seconds in April, qualifying for the national Adidas Outdoor Championships this weekend in Raleigh, N.C. But there is something about Mitchell, who is from South Carolina, that sets him apart. He is partially blind.

title: Mets Enjoy a Laugher In Their Sorry Season
description: Down by the far end of the visitors' dugout, Darryl Hamilton and Todd Pratt noticed something funny about their manager. Bobby Valentine, standing at the other end, had his hat turned sideways, the brim hanging over his left ear. Rally caps in the second inning?

title: Dazzling Donovan Leading Earthquakes
description: Landon Donovan is starting to display the attributes that many feel will make him the cornerstone of the San Jose Earthquakes in Major League Soccer and for the United States national team. Since he became a regular with the Earthquakes after he was signed by the league earlier this season, San Jose has gone 10 games without a loss.

title: Article 2001061193417428048 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Switzerland Narrowly Votes To Arm Troops
description: Swiss voters, by a wafer-thin margin, today approved arming soldiers taking part in international peacekeeping missions and allowing their citizen army to train with NATO forces.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Article 2001061191866362718 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: A Parade With Pride And Police
description: A river of faces and banners, rippling. A tumult of salsa and sequined dancers. Delegations from Mayagez, Ponce and San Juan. White lapel ribbons to remember bombed Vieques. And everywhere the red, white and blue flags of Puerto Rico -- on T-shirts, sweatbands, head wraps, cheeks, even polished fingernails.

title: Hope Against Hope
description: Many years ago, my Hasidic uncle, Rabbi Chaim Bukiet, taught me this particle of Talmudic logic. Two men lose something, say their wallets, at two o'clock. Both men say to themselves, ''It's gone,'' at four o'clock. The only variable is that the first wallet was found by a stranger at three o'clock, and the second by another stranger, or even the same stranger, at five o'clock. The first wallet must indeed be returned to its original owner, but the second belongs to the lucky stranger because it has since been renounced.

title: Dark Side of Security Quest: Squalor on an Atoll
description: Several times a year, these tiny Pacific islands witness a light show more spectacular than almost any offered by nature, when a gaggle of ballistic missiles, minus their warheads, streak in low, roaring through the night sky and hurtle into the nearby lagoon.

title: Sports of The Times; Philadelphia And Lakers Intertwined
description: WITH 55.2 seconds left in the third quarter of Game 3 last night, Dikembe Mutombo, the Philadelphia center, left the game for a breather and received a standing ovation. It was the sort of sympathetic ovation a home crowd reserves for a David doing a mammoth job against an insurmountable Goliath.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No one wants to get rich off someone's death. But at the same time, I think the families, survivors and rescuers have challenged us to tell this story.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Price of Natural Gas Falls For Southern California

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Dies In Apartment
description: A 7-year-old boy died in Brooklyn yesterday after officers found him unconscious with his head caught between a window and a window guard, the police said. The police answered an emergency call at 376 South Third Street in Williamsburg about 8:45 p.m. and found the boy, who was not identified, in a third-floor apartment. He died 45 minutes later at Woodhull Medical Center, the police said, adding that the medical examiner's office will investigate the cause of death. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, EVELYN BERG
description: LERNER-Evelyn Berg. Age 88, on June 8, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Martin E. Lerner. Loving mother of Joan Stein and Norma Lerner, mother-in-law of Robert Stein and George Schwartz, grandmother of Amanda, Elizabeth, Andrew and David. She will be missed.

title: Article 2001061190443114705 -- No Title
Lakers Take Lead Over Sixers in N.B.A. Finals
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10  With 2 minutes 21 seconds remaining tonight, the X factor was eliminated, turning the N.B.A. finals into a fair fight for the first time. The Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal, barreling backward into the lane and slamming elbows into the face of a retreating Dikembe Mutombo, was called for his sixth foul. That left Game 3 to be decided by the perimeter superstars, Allen Iverson and Kobe Bryant.

title: Collapse In Finals Gnaws At Devils
description: With a clenched jaw and weary eyes, Scott Stevens expressed his disappointment, delivering terse, halting sentences Saturday night.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Critic's Choice movie page in the Television section on May 27 misidentified the actor seated beside Jos Ferrer in the 1952 film ''Moulin Rouge.'' He was Christopher Lee, not Jean Landier.

title: John McKay, U.S.C. and Buccaneers Coach, Dies at 77
description: John McKay, who coached the University of Southern California football team to four unofficial national championships, then coached for nine seasons with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, died yesterday at a hospital in Tampa, Fla. He was 77.

title: Follow That Guppy
description: The bloodhound is famous for its ability to track prey (or missing persons) over long distances, up, over, around and through just about anything. But the bloodhound, it turns out, has nothing on the European catfish.

title: Ways to Define A Diverse Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, THOMAS P.
description: ROBINSON-Thomas P. June 9, 2001, at age 81. Cherished husband, father, brother, grand- and great-grandfather, and friend; university administrator; educator; history scholar; and quintessential New Yorker. An incomparable and unforgettable man of great spirit and wit. Viewing Tuesday, 25 PM and 7-9 PM, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. Memorial service Wednesday, 11 AM. Call (212) 475-2024.

title: U.S. Drug Indictment Chronicles King of Cancn's Fall
description: Millions of Americans know the Mexican resort of Cancn as a pleasure dome promising cheap tequila and hot spring breaks, where English is widely spoken, dollars gladly taken and the hamburgers taste like home.
