description: GHOST SOLDIERS

title: Uneasily, Oklahoma City Welcomes Tourists
description: The Oklahoma City National Memorial, the emotional center of this city that has waited so long for Timothy J. McVeigh to die, was built by committees, their tasks prosaic and profound. One chose the wording of the memorial's mission statement. Another has tried to protect the grass.

title: McVeigh Escorted to Death Chamber
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 11 - Just after dawn this morning, Timothy J. McVeigh was escorted a few steps from a holding cell to the death chamber and prison officials began preparing for his execution for blowing up a federal building in Oklahoma City in 1995 and killing 168 people.

description: To the Editor:

title: Solar Flares Raise Concern Over Safety of Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  In Greek legend, Icarus flew too close to the sun and crashed when its heat melted the wax that held his wings together. That idea seems quaint, but now some scientists think the Greeks may have been right to fear flying too close to the sun.

title: An African Boosts U.S. Running
description: Training in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., at 7,000 feet in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, Mebrahtom Keflezighi runs mile after mile even as his body pleads for relief. Afterward, to soothe his swollen muscles, Keflezighi stands waist deep in a creek of freezing water from melted snow.

title: Essay; J. Edgar Who?
description: The breakdown in F.B.I. procedures that delayed Timothy McVeigh's execution may have been the last straw for Louis Freeh. The nonpartisan former agent and judge who was such a thorn in Janet Reno's partisan side decided to retire two years before his term was up.

title: Missile Shield Point Man Does Not Shy From Tough Sell
description: IN his narrow office in the West Wing of the White House, Stephen J. Hadley keeps two small mementos. One is a cluster of models of every American intercontinental ballistic missile, from the Titan to the Peacekeeper, a reminder of his final days at the Defense Department in 1992, when he helped begin talks with Russia over sharing technology to build a missile defense system.

title: Sports of The Times; Sakic a Starting Point In Remaking Rangers
description: JOE SAKIC took the Stanley Cup from Commissioner Gary Bettman, glanced at the cameras, and then the captain of the Colorado Avalanche spun and handed the huge silver chalice to Ray Bourque.

title: Conservatives In Iran Face Reassessment Of Reforms
description: Supporters of President Mohammad Khatami's attempts to create a freer, more democratic Islamic republic in Iran said today that his overwhelming re-election victory should prompt his conservative opponents to reassess their attempts to frustrate change.

description: Timothy J. McVeigh spent his last full day of life today in a 9- by 14-foot holding room, writing letters, and waiting. ''His temperament is very even,'' said Robert Nigh Jr., one of Mr. McVeigh's lawyers, after spending time with his client this afternoon. ''He is calm. He is himself. He is prepared. Quite frankly, he is ready to die.''

title: Court Restricts Heat-Sensor Searches
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court today reiterated the right of privacy in the age of technology, ruling in an Oregon drug case that the police cannot use a heat-seeking device to probe the interior of a home without a search warrant.

title: U.S. Cutbacks in Yemen
description: The State Department has reduced the personnel at its embassy in Sana, Yemen, and has suspended services to the public there, citing an increased threat since the attack last October on a United States Navy vessel in Aden, Yemen's main port.

title: In Loss, Holdsclaw Shows Even 19-Point Lead Is Not Safe
description: Lucky for the Liberty that Chamique Holdsclaw wasn't 100 percent today.

title: Louise B. Sulzberger, 103, Dies; Devoted Years to Social Services
description: Louise B. Sulzberger, who was active in New York City social service work for many years and was a member of the New York State Commission on Aging and the community planning board for the Upper East Side, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103.

Hero of the greatest generation that liberated Europe. Always in our hearts. For information call: Prospero Brothers, 718-449-2700.

description: Sheila Leyne, co-director for the public relations group at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named senior vice president and director for public relations. She takes over duties that had been handled by Peter Greer, who left to become public relations principal at VIA Inc., Portland, Me.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' in Weekend on Friday misstated the surname of a Disney cartoon character to whom the film's animated hero, Milo, was likened. He is Ludwig von Drake, not Ludwig von Duck.

description: Internet merchants have never done a great job with shipping and handling costs. Early on, some e-tailers displayed shipping charges at the last possible point in an order, then extracted exorbitant fees for the privilege of putting, say, a Rambo video in the mail.

description: The Yankees signed Mike Mussina last winter to give them yet another ace starting pitcher and to provide them with the man to pitch the big game. Manager Joe Torre had already been sold on Mussina's determination the past few seasons, and a pair of strong early starts reinforced his opinion of his new pitcher.

description: An article by The Associated Press in some editions on Thursday about federal income tax rebates misstated the number of states that tax them. It is eight; Alabama was included in error.

description: An unusual coalition of advocacy organizations and individuals in fields from pediatrics to politics is again asking marketers to stop advertising on Channel One, the division of Primedia that broadcasts daily programs and commercials to about 12,000 schools nationwide.

description: BOSTON, June 10  A poll shows Matthew Maxwell Taylor Kennedy, a son of Robert F. Kennedy, in a dead heat with two state senators in the race to succeed United States Representative Joe Moakley, who died last month, and another poll has him trailing one of the lawmakers.

description: Israeli officials have let loose an outpouring of resentment against Jews in the diaspora for canceling or postponing trips here, fearing terrorism.

title: Road to Repeat Isn't Paved With Home Cooking
description: PHILADELPHIA -- Kobe Bryant parted two defenders and levitated toward the rim. He was trying to halt a Philadelphia run with a breathtaking dunk in the third quarter when Dikembe Mutombo challenged him. Mutombo clearly caught Bryant's right arm, almost pinning his wrist against the backboard  a foul that caused him to clank the attempt off the rim.

title: Author and Theologian Elected Leader of Presbyterian Group
description: The Rev. Jack Rogers, a widely published theologian and former seminary official, was elected moderator, or top officer, of the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), at a meeting of its policy-making body on Saturday night.

description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has sent a scathing letter to the United States Commission on Civil Rights denouncing what he terms the ''faulty analysis'' and ''political bias'' of its report blaming him and other Florida officials for the state's presidential ballot debacle.

description: In his first five months in office, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld ensconced himself in his Pentagon office to rethink defense policy in sphinx-like silence. But that changed last week during his first extended trip to Europe for the Bush administration.

description: The price of natural gas sold into Southern California has fallen sharply the last week after both the free fall in electricity prices and the expiration of a pipeline contract held by the El Paso Corporation that is the subject of an inquiry by federal regulators.

title: Candidate Hoping New York Is Newest Bloomberg Market
description: If New Yorkers know anything about Mike Bloomberg (and most apparently don't), it is that he is a really rich guy. A billionaire, maybe. A businessman who claims that he can run the city as mayor because he has run his own company.

title: The Reform Tide in Iran
description: Mohammad Khatami's overwhelming re-election as Iran's president Friday is heartening proof that the Iranian people have not given up on his promises of increased personal freedoms and respect for the rule of law. It would have been understandable if reform voters had begun to weary after four years in which Mr. Khatami's efforts were systematically thwarted by conservative clerics. Some more militant reformers had even called for a boycott to protest the disappointingly slow pace of progress. Instead, Iranians wisely turned out in convincingly large numbers to reaffirm their insistence on social and political change. Final results show Mr. Khatami winning a remarkable 77 percent of the vote, even more than he did in 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENOWITZ, SOPHIE
description: MENOWITZ-Sophie (1914-1979). Gone but not forgotton these many years. We think of you always. Love from your family who meant so much to you.

title: Louisianians Coping With Continued Rain
description: As Houston began to dry out, the drenched residents of southern Louisiana continued to sandbag and pray today, hoping that the remnants of Tropical Storm Allison would not linger in a region that has already been deluged by five days of heavy rainfall and spot flooding.

title: Domestic Violence Law Set to Be Renewed
description: In 1994, soon after Gov. George E. Pataki took office, lawmakers enacted a measure that required police officers to arrest anyone suspected of domestic abuse -- regardless of whether their victims wished to press charges. The law is set to expire next month, and efforts to expand its scope and make it permanent have engendered broad unusual agreement among lawmakers from across the political spectrum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTLEMAN, EVA
description: HITTLEMAN-Eva. Of Long Beach, passed away peacefully on June 9, 2001. Widow of Charles Hittleman. Mother of Warren, Sandra, Karen and the late Arnold Hittleman. A cherished grandmother, she will be missed by Jerry, Bruce, Linda, Laura, Jude, Matthew, Greg, Neal, Chanie, and Carly. Loving great-grandmother to Jessica, Aaron, Zoe, Naamah and Maya. Eva will be especially remembered for her love of life, for all the years she generously, enthusiastically and purposely volunteered in numerous organizations, for her devotion to Temple Emanuel, and for all the work she accomplished in her community. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name can be made to the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County.

title: History and Timothy McVeigh
description: In late 1994, Timothy McVeigh wrote a letter to the American Legion. ''Does anyone even study history anymore?'' he asked. The word ''study'' was in capital letters, and the sentence closed with three question marks. Mr. McVeigh was 25 years old and only a few months away from entering history himself by blowing up the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people. Today, he is to be put to death for his crime in a federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., the first person to be executed by the federal government since 1963. Into a saline drip, a technician will inject, in sequence, drugs to induce unconsciousness, stop breathing and cause cardiac arrest. Twenty-four witnesses will attest to whatever they can attest to -- the fulfillment of the sentence, the prisoner's manner of dying, the silence of the procedure itself.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Air Travel's Next Generation
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has announced a 10-year, $11 billion plan to modernize the air travel system and reduce snarl. The plan is great as far as it goes. It is an amalgam of dozens of incremental improvements. Many are already working on a trial basis, and each will do a little good. For instance, a new runway at a busy airport can add 1 percent to overall airline traffic capacity. The F.A.A. proposes building new runways at 15 busy airports. Together it says its measures should add 30 percent to total system capacity by 2010.

title: U.S. LOSING STATUS AS A WORLD LEADER IN CLIMATE SCIENCE
description: In little more than a decade, the United States has fallen significantly behind other countries in its ability to simulate and predict long-term shifts in climate, according to a wide range of scientists and recent federal studies.

description: Hopes for a NASA mission to study Pluto have been hanging by a thread lately, one stretched about as thin as the planet's atmosphere. The Bush administration's budget contains no money for a Pluto spacecraft, meaning a long-planned and expensive project is essentially dead.
