title: Opposites Attracted To Strauss
description: Kurt Masur's waning tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic might be described as the search of musical opposites for common grounds. ''Don Juan,'' which opened the orchestra's final subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, seemed to justify every success and misstep that might have occurred along the way.

title: Taipei Weighs TV Network Tied to China
description: With more than a dozen all-news channels on the television dial, the last thing this compact country would seem to need is another one. Yet if Taiwan gives final approval, Phoenix Satellite Television will begin broadcasting its Chinese-language news channel here as early as July.

title: MediaTalk; Gumbel and Ebony Argue Over Recent Remarks
description: Bryant Gumbel gave a speech a couple of weeks ago about the responsibilities facing educated and successful African-Americans. Ebony magazine is not too happy about it.

title: Magazine for Teenagers Benefits in Publishing-Internet Marriage
description: If you do not know who Lil Bow Wow is, or that Uncle Kracker is Kid Rock's D.J., or to whom Enrique Iglesias dedicated his first solo album, or why that cute girl in gym class will not talk to you anymore, you are probably not a reader of Teen People, or its Web twin, TeenPeople.com.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: PRESIDENT FACING SKEPTICAL EUROPE ON TRIP THIS WEEK
description: Across Europe, there is little love of America's new president and a growing perception that the United States, under his leadership, is looking out only for itself these days -- polluting the skies, breaking treaties and flirting with new arms races.

title: Korea's Future King?
description: To the Editor:

title: Power in Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Federal Web Sites Friendly to Disabled Users
description: Not that anyone thought this was possible, but the Web sites of the federal government are about to become less interesting. And from at least one perspective, that may be good.

title: Pataki Orders a Shift Toward Renewable Energy
description: Gov. George E. Pataki ordered today that state buildings get 20 percent of their electricity from renewable energy sources like solar or wind power by 2010, an effort that environmentalists lauded as the most ambitious of its kind in the country.

title: Patents; A new system uses TV instead of mirrors to help drivers see while backing up their cars.
description: SEEING where you are going while backing up a car is difficult -- the driver's perspective is limited and distorted. But three inventors from Minnesota say they can improve that by taking away a car's rear view mirrors.

title: Equifax to Buy Stake in a Software Vendor
description: In an alliance to be announced today, Equifax, the world's largest credit reporting agency, will invest $5 million in Seisint, a start-up vendor of computer software tailored to high-speed analysis of large databases, and deploy Seisint's technology.

title: White House Memo; Global Realities Redefine Bush's Agenda
description: When President Bush announces on Monday that he will seek millions of dollars for new research into the causes of global warming, and will try to renegotiate an international accord on the problem, it will mark yet another example of how global and domestic politics have forced him to back away from the hard-line pronouncements of his first five months in the White House.

title: Girls of the Ghetto, Students of a Harsh Finishing School
description: In the scene that opens Kia Corthron's ''Breath, Boom,'' a teenage girl is viciously beaten by her best friends, a startling introduction to the code of behavior that governs the world of the play. And even though it takes place in the Bronx, for most theatergoers the setting will seem like a foreign country if not another planet.

title: Compressed Data; Defying the Meltdown's Lessons, a New Dot-Com
description: Some people might say starting a new Web venture in the current market is crazy -- and that opening a Web site devoted to original content is even more foolhardy, given Wall Street's generally cool reception to such ventures.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Shot To Death
description: A woman was killed and a man was shot and wounded yesterday in an apartment in Washington Heights, the police said. The police did not release the names of the victims, and they said they were not certain of the motive for the shootings. Neighbors said they heard a scream and several gunshots coming from the apartment, at 260 Fort Washington Avenue. The woman, 23, was shot in the head, and the man, 52, was shot in the buttocks. The police said the man was in serious but stable condition at Harlem Hospital Center. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOLAFIA, LEE
description: ABOLAFIA-Lee, 84, after a long and courageous struggle with M.S. Beautiful and cherished wife of the late Ralph. Loving mother of the late Rochelle, and Sondra Blank. Mother-in-law to Benjamin Blank. Adored grandmother of Stacy Lee, Dean, and Steve. Greatgrandmother to Rachel, and Jacob Raphael. Her charm, beauty and wit will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Thomas F. Irvine, 78, Dean at Stony Brook
description: Thomas F. Irvine Jr., the founding dean of the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, died on June 2 at his home in St. James, N.Y. He was 78.

title: A King Visits Queens, and Ghanaians Rejoice
description: The elderly men in summer suits leaving little Victoria Joy's christening party at Terrace on the Park in Queens on Saturday evening were not sure what was going on in the lobby. All marble and mirrors, it was, at this very moment, the epicenter of an eye-popping African ritual.

title: MediaTalk; Legal Battle Increases Interest in Book Sequel
description: The trustees of Margaret Mitchell's estate may be wishing they had left well enough alone.

title: MediaTalk; The Executive Author Confronts Corporate Sprawl
description: Like other moguls in an era of intertwined alliances among media conglomerates, John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric, faces some delicate decisions about the publication of his memoirs: how to promote his book without doing too many favors for his company's competition.

title: Computer Virus Scouts for Child Pornography
description: A new rogue computer program, possibly intended to perform a public service, has raised thorny legal questions and seems sure to fuel the debate over computer privacy.

title: The Slam Woods Seeks Was Devised by Palmer
description: High above the Atlantic on his way to the 1960 British Open, Arnold Palmer was chatting with Bob Drum, the Pittsburgh sportswriter who followed him almost everywhere in those years. Drum lamented how the surge in pro golf had erased the possibility of matching the Grand Slam that Bobby Jones had created in 1930 by winning the United States Open and Amateur, and the British Open and Amateur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, MAGGIE
description: WOLF-Maggie. Age 45. Beloved wife of P. Geoffrey Lowney, mother of Sam. Marketing Vice President, Polaroid. Graduate of Greenwich High School 1973, Yale 1977, Columbia Business School 1984. She was a delight to everyone lucky enough to know her. Services June 12, 2 PM, at First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church, Concord, MA. Memorials to Wellness Community, 1320 Center St., Suite 305, Newton, MA 02459.

title: U.S. Pushes for Cease-Fire in Middle East
description: Washington's director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, sought Israeli and Palestinian approval of a formal cease-fire plan today as the two sides rancorously accused each other of making a bad faith effort to pursue a truce.

title: Cendant Deal for Travel Service Is Near
description: The Cendant Corporation moved closer yesterday to a deal to buy Galileo International, an electronic travel reservation business, for about $3 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the talks said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, ANNA M.
description: FALK-Anna M. On June 10, 2001. Beloved wife of George Falk, M.D. Dear sister of Dorothy Benson, Alex Karas and Joseph Dexter. Longtime member of the nursing staff of New York Hospital and Hospital for Special Surgery. Graduate of Long Island College School of Nursing and Master's of Nursing, NYU. Funeral services private.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Interim Cancer Study
description: A radiation research group has released data from a long-term cancer study showing that levels of the radioactive carcinogen strontium 90 in baby teeth collected from 544 children in Suffolk County rose 40 percent from the early 1980's through the mid-1990's. The Manhattan group, the Radiation and Public Health Project, said last week that cancer diagnosed in children under 10 increased by 49 percent in the same period. To collect more teeth and continue the study, called the Tooth Fairy Project, local scientists and citizens are seeking $60,000 from Suffolk and Westchester Counties. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Housing Official To Retire
description: After nearly five years as the state commissioner of housing and community renewal, Joseph B. Lynch is retiring at the end of this month. Gov. George E. Pataki praised his record, including the raising of $2.4 billion in public and private money to build 21,700 homes for low- and moderate-income people. Mr. Lynch was previously an official at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. A successor was not named. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, ESTELLE, NEE SCHWARTZ
description: BRILL-Estelle, nee Schwartz. Most beloved wife of Malcolm, devoted mother of Michael (Patricia) and Judith (Joseph) Artusa. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Samantha, Sabrina, Benjamin and Laura. Loving sister of Frank (Simone) and Martin (Adrienne) Schwartz. You will always be in my thoughts and heart forever. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article on Thursday about a gathering on a Normandy beach for a screening of ''Band of Brothers,'' a coming HBO mini-series about an Army paratroop unit, misstated the location of Berchtesgaden, the town near Hitler's Alpine retreat, Eagle's Nest, which the unit captured in 1945. The town is in southeastern Germany near the Austrian border, not in Austria itself.

title: Schroeder Requires Extra Holes To Capture His First Senior Title
description: John Schroeder trotted up to the final hole in regulation hoping to take second place in the N.F.L. Golf Classic, but there was a much better finish in store for the son of the former tennis star Ted Schroeder, winner of the 1942 United States championship and the 1949 Wimbledon.

title: When in Atlanta, Click As the Atlantans Click
description: On the Web, ''it's a mixed bag when it comes to localized content.''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Unpopular Fee Makes Activists Of Hog Farmers
description: Dale Leslein is a longtime hog farmer, a Republican who never joined anything, not even the Future Farmers of America when he was in high school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALOM, JOSEPH I.
description: SHALOM-Joseph I. Son of Isaac and Alice Shalom, a family outstanding in worldwide philanthropy in Jewish education and aid to Israel. Co-founders of Sephardic Heritage Foundation which has distributed over 240,000 Hebrew and English prayer books all over the world. Our deepest condolences to his wife and family and to his brothers and sisters. Sam Catton, President Sephardic Heritage Foundation

title: American Teams Compete For a Chance to Play in Bali
description: The final of the United States Bridge Championships, formerly known as the International Team Trials, began yesterday in Memphis, with the winner due to be one of two American teams to play in the World Championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October. After 15 deals of a scheduled 120, Nick Nickell and his team of world champions led by 11 imps against a group headed by Russ Ekeblad.

title: Text of President Bush's Remarks on Global Climate
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 - Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush today on global climate, as recorded by the White House:

title: Knoblauch Rests Twisted Ankle
description: Chuck Knoblauch remained out of the Yankees' lineup for the second straight game last night because of the right ankle he twisted on Friday. Manager Joe Torre said Knoblauch could have played against the Atlanta Braves and was available to pinch-hit, but Torre decided to give him the night off, providing Knoblauch with three straight days of rest, including today's off day.

title: Summer Discounts in Grenada
description: Grenada, which is at the southern tip of the Windward Islands just off Venezuela, says that it lies outside the Caribbean's hurricane belt. But just in case anyone has any doubts, some of its resorts are offering summer discounts. For example, the Flamboyant Hotel, on Grand Anse Beach, has a seventh-night-free promotion from May through October; daily rates are $85 to $285 a night. Contact (473) 444-4247 or www.flamboyant.com . The Rendezvous Beach Resort has a one-week package through Dec. 15 that combines a three-night voyage to the Grenadines on its 50-foot catamaran (with three staterooms; all meals on board included) and four nights at the hotel. Cost: $2,450 per couple. Contact (473) 444-3040 or www.rendezvousresort.com . The Grenada Board of Tourism, (800) 927-9554 or www.grenada.org , has a complete listing of participating hotels.

title: Accounts
description: Global Beverage Systems, Latrobe, Pa., to Marc USA, Pittsburgh, as the first agency of record to handle the Le Nature's beverage brand. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Ways to Define A Diverse Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Koreas to Permit Regular Road Travel Across Border
description: North and South Korea have agreed to open the first regular ground route between the two countries as a result of negotiations between top executives of the Hyundai Group and North Korean officials on reducing the cost of tours to the North.

title: Article 2001061190148351036 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Lyricism and Ecstasy Still the Storms of Life
description: Monte/Brown Dance celebrated its 20th anniversary last week at the Joyce Theater, honoring a ripe old age for a modern-dance company. Elisa Monte and David Brown have matured too, both as choreographers and performers, as a triumphant gala opening-night benefit on Tuesday proved.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Insurance Premiums Fall
description: Insurance premiums for New Jersey drivers dropped an average of 3 percent last year, according to a study released last week by the state's Department of Banking and Insurance. It is the second consecutive drop in annual rates, which are now at the lowest level since 1991, the study said. Drivers' premiums averaged $955 last year, down from $985 in 1999. Insurance premiums became a campaign issue in 1997, when Gov. Christie Whitman was narrowly re-elected. The Legislature passed an automobile insurance bill in 1998 that required companies to curb premiums. William Beaver (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, JUDITH L.
description: KANE-Judith L. Loving mother, grandmother, aunt, sister, teacher, counselor, writer, sculptress, and friend. Services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre today at noon.

title: Dutch Ship Offers Abortions; To Make Ireland Its First Call
description: A privately financed Dutch ship, equipped to carry out abortions in international waters near countries where the procedure is banned, is ready to set sail from here on its first voyage on Monday.

title: A Digital Dream Factory In Silicon Valley; Pixar's New Digs Coddle Animators, Writers and Tech Heads
description: Steve Jobs stood just inside the main entrance to Pixar Animation Studios, gazing across the broad atrium, flanked by sandblasted-steel bridges, that forms the main artery of the building. Dozens of Pixar's 550 workers -- animators, computer technicians, writers, accountants -- bustled around him, chatting, listening to music on earphones, some riding metallic scooters.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: David Clark was named to the new post of vice president for advertising sales at MTV Networks International, New York, part of the MTV Networks unit of Viacom. He had been chief operating officer at Shanah.com, New York.

title: Leading a Porterhouse Ballet; For Decades, a Guiding Hand Where Steak is Art
description: For a man with little formal education, a sturdy pair of legs and an inbred sense of fastidious elegance, there is no better occupation than that of a steakhouse waiter.

title: INSIDE
description: Rocky Mideast Talks

title: NBC's Negotiator and 'Fixer' Will Retire
description: During his career, he negotiated deals with Katie Couric and Elvis Presley; he counseled Tom Brokaw, Tim Russert and virtually every other star at NBC News; he helped bring top executives like Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, and Andrew Lack, the president of NBC, into the network, and he staunchly pushed for the elevation of Jeff Zucker to the job of chief programmer.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Jury Access to Islamic Books Is Debated
description: If you had walked into Courtroom 318 of the Old Federal Courthouse in Manhattan one day recently, you might have thought you had mistakenly stumbled into a university religious studies course.

title: In a Pit With 400 Rats, but Who's Counting?
description: It's come to this: In the wake of the famous rat-eating episode in the first ''Survivor,'' one of its lesser clones has contestants being eaten by rats, put into a gravelike pit and covered with 400 of the squirming vermin. A player who lasts four minutes there moves into the next round of ''Fear Factor,'' the latest cheapo reality game tossed at viewers supposedly desperate enough in the summer to watch junk like this.

title: Article 2001061191795273716 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LILY
description: BERMAN-Lily. Died on June 4 in Bridgehampton. She brought joy to all who knew her, especially Lewis, Amanda, Meredith Berman, Michelle Marchildon and Anne MacIntosh and all her friends at Park East. Memorial contributions may be directed to Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, Office of Public Affairs for the Cancer Program, Ithaca, NY 14853-6401.

title: Bringing Classical Art A Hip-Hop Influence
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem has described itself as classically American in advertisements for its ''Bring It On Home!'' season at the Apollo Theater, this company's first appearance at that Harlem landmark. The three signature works that this black ballet troupe presented on Friday night lived up to that label, suggesting a core truth about the enterprise.

title: Cassadaga Journal; Progress and Religion Clash in Florida County
description: This quiet village, secluded despite its proximity to Interstate 4 between Daytona Beach and Orlando, is a place that people seem led to -- at times, in a cosmic sense.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Lake Placid: 3 Charged In Counterfeiting
description: Two men and a woman have been charged with making counterfeit money with their home computer, the police said. George W. Setzer, 41, Michael Davis, 30, and Enid Montalvo, 26, were charged last week with forgery. The three are accused of scanning small-denomination bills into their computer, printing them on their home printer and trying to pass them as real money, said Patrolman William Moore. The bills totaled more than $1,000, Patrolman Moore said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, DAVID
description: BIDERMAN-David. Yeshiva Beth Abraham-Slonim of Jerusalem mourns the untimely passing of David Biderman. Condolences to his wife and children. Our hearts go out to his parents Ben and Nechama, loyal supporters of our Yeshiva, whose acts of kindness for others are unsurpassed. Yeshiva Beth Abraham of Jerusalem Jacob Dyckman, President Rabbi Yehuda Weinberg, Israeli Representative Dina Dyckman, President Women's Division

title: In Mexico, Publisher Finds New Players But Old Secrecy
description: From this city on the edge of the desert, three generations of the Junco family battled Mexico's powerful ruling party to run their newspaper, El Norte, without government interference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, BUDD
description: KELLER-Budd. On June 8, 2001. Graveside service at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, New Jersey, today at 11AM.

title: McVeigh Execution Denounced in Europe
description: By SUZANNE DALEY

title: Is This the Woman to Rescue Harper's Bazaar?
description: FOR nearly all of her career, Glenda Bailey, the new editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, has had the distinction of being a thorn among roses. Though smart, with a belligerent truthful streak that has helped propel her to the top of fashion publishing, she has suffered, especially in her native England, from not looking more fashionably smart. Prominent teeth flash with intermittent bursts of laughter, and her country-girl face is framed by dense, reddish curls that she has refused to straighten.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a call by a group of veteran American diplomats for an end to executions of the mentally retarded in the United States misstated the execution date set for Juan Raul Garza. It is June 19, not the 18th.

title: Scripted Execution Contrasts With Bloody Oklahoma Bombing
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 11  No terror-twisted chaos. No bloody pandemonium. Not even any blood.

title: Latest Omnicom acquisition shows continuing interest in shops with nontraditional specialities.
description: A MONTH after Peter Arnell, chairman and chief executive at the Arnell Group in New York, bought back a majority stake in the agency from the Draft Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, he is selling the entire agency and two siblings to the Omnicom Group.

title: Red, White and Blue Finish In the U.S. Championship
description: Today for the first time in the 17-year history of the United States pro cycling championship, the three riders on the victory podium were Americans.

title: Italian Names His Cabinet, a Rainbow of the Right
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi formed Italy's 59th postwar government today, with a cabinet that balances his need to reward political allies with his desire to reassure European partners.

title: A Friendship Founders Over Suit by Woody Allen
description: For years, Woody Allen's business manager, Stephen Tenenbaum, had quietly urged Mr. Allen to examine the financial accounts of eight films he had made in the 1990's. Mr. Allen was reluctant to do so, his friends said, because the films were financed by Jean Doumanian, his closest friend for 30 years and someone he spoke to at least two or three times a day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ESTELLE
description: GOLDMAN-Estelle. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of our esteemed member, the beloved mother of our devoted member Beth Goldman Solomon. We extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTHERS, MARTHA D.
description: STOTHERS-Martha D. Died May 7, 2001. A memorial service will be held on Sat, June 16, 12:30 pm, at Point O' Woods. Casual Attire.

title: Bouncing to the Salsa And Playing to the Crowd
description: The six major candidates for mayor of New York paid tribute to the rising political power of Hispanic voters yesterday, marching for two miles in the noontime heat in the National Puerto Rican Day Parade. They bounced to salsa music, rallied potential supporters in Spanish and demanded an end to United States military bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques.

title: Researchers Turn Compound Into Superconducting Wires
description: Less than half a year after a metallic compound was discovered to be a superconductor, scientists have developed a practical technique for making wires out of it.

title: Schumer Proposals Address Shortage of Office Space
description: A blue-ribbon panel led by Senator Charles E. Schumer is set to unveil an ambitious plan today that will call for the creation of 60 million square feet of office space over the next 20 years for 300,000 new workers. The plan calls for a combination of condemnation, tax breaks, transit links and zoning changes to create expanded business districts in Downtown Brooklyn, Long Island City in Queens, and on the far West Side of Manhattan.

title: Point Given Not Great Yet, but He Could Be
description: It is clear by now that the Saudi prince Ahmed bin Salman, Bob Baffert and Gary Stevens believe their extraordinarily talented colt, Point Given, should have swept the Triple Crown. They are disappointed, as a good many racing fans are, especially after the 3-year-old that the owner, trainer and rider call the Big Red Train rolled like one to demolish a fine field by 12 1/4 lengths in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Stephan Weiss, 62, Fashion Empire's Other Half
description: Stephan Weiss, a sculptor and painter who with his wife, Donna Karan, founded one of America's leading fashion houses, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 62 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ways to Define a Diverse Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Debate: Malthus vs. Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Refusing To Save Africans
description: Giving the back of his hand to the suffering of millions, a key Bush administration official is opposing any extensive use of the life-extending anti-AIDS drugs in Africa, insisting that the health care infrastructure is too primitive and that Africans, in most cases, are incapable of following the regimen.

title: Energy Debate: Malthus vs. Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shvitz Case Set For Hearing
description: An administrative judge is set to hear the case of the Tenth Street Baths. On Wednesday, the judge will hear from the bath owners, who are appealing a Health Department decision to turn off a source of water in the hot sauna. Last month, the department ruled that the water used to cool customers could instead heat up and scald them.

title: Tropical Storm Leaves 16 Dead In 2 Gulf States
description: As storm-weary residents emerged from their waterlogged homes here today, they faced highways littered with jackknifed 18-wheeled trucks, roads lined with abandoned cars, trash and tires and whole neighborhoods underwater.

title: Signs of Devils' Demise Snowballed
description: It would be unkind to call Devils goalie Martin Brodeur a sore loser in the traditional sense of the expression. His personality is too sweet, and he does not lose that often. But something about him had to hurt Saturday night. Why else would the medical trainer leave the bench to visit him in front of the Devils' net in the third period of Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals?

title: Air Conditioning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: As Storm Moves On, 2 States Tally Damage
description: Under sunny skies and with a less than a 30 percent chance of more rain forecast, southeast Texas and Louisiana began drying out today after a weekend of flooding caused by remnants of a tropical storm that left 22 people dead in the Houston area.

title: THE McVEIGH EXECUTION: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK -- THE COVERAGE; The Oklahoma Bomber's Final Hours Are Hardly Television News's Finest
description: Timothy J. McVeigh ''made himself a name,'' the daughter of an Oklahoma City bombing victim bitterly told Katie Couric yesterday. It was the right answer to the wrong question: ''Are you worried that he will be viewed as a martyr?'' It is not martyrdom but fame that the television coverage has helped him achieve, turning him into a celebrity while pretending not to.

title: Nokia Issues a Surprise Profit Warning
description: LONDON, Jun 12  Nokia, the world's leading maker of mobile phones, warned today that its earnings and sales would fall short of estimates in the second quarter, surprising investors and roiling markets across the Europe and the United States.

title: More Falling Behind on Mortgage Payments
description: With energy costs and unemployment rising, the number of Americans who are behind on their mortgage payments has increased sharply in the last year.

title: Mets' Missing Ingredients Were a Recipe for Disaster
description: It has astonished the Mets, this collapse of a season, and their architect does not believe he should have seen the cracks. Nobody else did, after all, and maybe there were no cracks to see.

title: AOL Joins Chinese Venture, Gaining a Crucial Foothold
description: AOL Time Warner said today that it was teaming with Legend Holdings, China's largest computer maker, in a joint venture to develop interactive services for what many people say will one day be the world's largest Internet market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSEL, CHARLES JACOB
description: KASSEL-Charles Jacob, seventysix, of Cresskill, NJ. Beloved husban of Miriam, his wife of fortyseven years. Devoted father of Kenneth and Kerul, model fatherin-law of David Leeman: dear brother of Helen Goldstein. Born November 20th, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY, Chuck served in the Navy in World War II as a Chief Petty Officer in the South Pacific and was called back during the Korean War. He graduated from University of Missouri with a Bachelors of Electrical Engineering Degree, then worked for RCA teaching others to repair radios and televisions. He and his brother-in-law founded American Lace Mills, a textile mill in Hackensack, NJ, which they operated for twentyeight years. He was also instrumental in managing the family's commercial real estate in Hackensack. Chuck then pursued a Masters Degree in Clinical Nutrition from University of Bridgeport in CT. He volunteered weekly at the Emergency Room of Englewood Hospital for over twelve years, was a member of Temple Beth El for over forty years, was active in the UJA for many years, and was a member of Montammy Golf Club since its inception in 1969. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Charles Kassel Memorial Fund at Temple Beth El. Service at 10 AM, Wednesday at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ, 07624; 201-768-5112. The family will accept visitors at 216 Sunrise Court, Rivervale, NJ; call 201475-1647 for directions.

title: U.N. Review Criticizes Director Of Its Drug and Crime Program
description: Investigations of the United Nations Office of Drug Control and Crime Prevention in Vienna found today that poor management was costing the office money and talent, leaving the staff demoralized and often in the dark about decisions made at the top.

title: Giants Lose Montgomery for Season
description: Giants running back Joe Montgomery, whose career both as a collegian and as a professional has been beset by injury, ruptured his left Achilles' tendon yesterday and will miss the 2001 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, HAROLD DEAN
description: GIBSON-Harold Dean. Age 74, on June 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of Patrick & Leslie and their spouses Bonnie and Edward Maluf. Adoring grandfather of Celia, Nicholas, Sofia and Eric. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM with service Friday 9:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Arts Student's League of New York, Victor D'Amico Institute of Art (The Art Barge) in Amagansett, NY or the American Cancer Society.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Yukie Okuyama, Mahdi Kazuto Shah, Hristoula Harakas, Ellen Cornfield and Denise Johnsson, Merce Cunningham Studio, New York, March 17, 2001

title: Sleeker by 14 Pounds, Sharpton Fights On
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, somewhat trimmer after fasting for two weeks in a Brooklyn jail cell, has kept himself busy behind bars.

title: Clinton Hearing on Cancer Taps Into a Deep-Seated Anxiety on Long Island
description: In the first public hearing she has led since being elected to the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton came to Adelphi University here today to wade into a subject of intense local interest: whether breast cancer and other diseases have any environmental causes.

title: Origin of an Arctic Species: The Tourist
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ESTELLE
description: GOLDMAN-Estelle, 79. Died June 10, 2001. Born NYC, March 15, 1922. Loving mother of Melvin, Edith and Beth Goldman, and grandmother of Alissa, Jonathan and Kiran Goldman, Shlomo & Daniel Hoffman, Tess, Joseph and Lia Solomon, and great-grandmother of Leah Hoffman, and Elliott Ede. Loving sister of Adele Cherrick, Hannah Woloch and Miriam Eidelsberg. Services held. Donations may be made to AMIT Women or to RAMAZ School.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Challenge To Governor
description: State Senator Patrick J. O'Malley, below, a conservative Republican from the southern Chicago suburb of Palos Park, said he would seek his party's nomination for governor in next year's primary contest, whether or not Gov. George Ryan, a Republican moderate, seeks a second term. Polls indicate Mr. Ryan is in trouble with voters because federal investigators have uncovered evidence of corruption in the state's driver's licensing department when he was secretary of state. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDEWERELD, SIMON
description: ALDEWERELD-Simon, 1909-2001, died peacefully at his home June 9, 2001. Survived by his wife Kitty and his niece Jacky. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, June 12th, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: PATENT-INFRINGEMENT VERDICT UPHELD AGAINST MEDTRONIC
description: A federal appeals court has upheld a $47.8 million patent-infringement verdict against the Sofamor Danek Group unit of the medical technology company Medtronic Inc.. The case involved the design of a device to straighten spines. AcroMed, a unit of Johnson & Johnson of New Brunswick, N.J., said it owned the rights to the patent design created by AcroMed's founder, Dr. Arthur D. Steffee. A federal jury found in May 1999 that Danek willfully infringed on the patent and awarded $32.9 million in damages. The judge later increased the damages to $47.8 million to account for postverdict damages and interest. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington upheld the verdict and award on Friday. Medtronic based in Minneapolis, said it would take a one-time charge of $52 million for the judgment plus interest, and that it was considering its legal options.

title: Officers Leave Mylan in Dispute
description: Mylan Laboratories Inc., a maker of generic drugs, said today that its president and its chief financial officer had resigned after a clash over ''corporate culture.''

title: In the Prairie Heartland, a Wealth of Shorebirds Gathers
description: Standing at the edge of an enormous freshwater marsh, a visitor is overwhelmed at the vast expanses of cattails, mudflats and abundant bird life reminiscent of the tidal wetlands that line the barrier islands of the Carolinas and the Gulf Coast. Yet the nearest ocean is well over a thousand miles away. For this is a naturally occurring but carefully managed inland sea, set in a flat landscape surrounded by hundreds of miles of lush grass and farmland.

title: ARTS ABROAD: Toronto, That Familiar Screen Face; As Movie Production Booms, a New Vitality Is Tempered by Location Fatigue
description: Sylvester Stallone is working out in the health club at the Four Seasons Hotel. Down the street, the singer Bono is sipping cappuccino in an outdoor cafe. Sophia Loren is having a news conference at the Windsor Arms Hotel to talk about her newest picture, ''Between Strangers,'' written and directed by her youngest son, Edoardo Ponti. At Trattoria Sotto Sotto on Avenue Road, Robin Williams, Michael Douglas and Liam Neeson are sitting at a corner table, eating pasta.

title: Article 2001061294246775205 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: ACOMPROMISE ON BILTMORE BLOCK Neighborhood leaders have reached a compromise with developers who proposed to renovate the historic Biltmore Theater, on 47th Street near Eighth Avenue, in exchange for permission to increase the height of an apartment building they plan to build next to it. The deal, which goes before Community Board 5 on Thursday, calls for the building to be limited to 55 stories instead of the 61 stories originally proposed by the development team, led by the Jack Parker Corporation. Councilwoman Christine A. Quinn, who oversaw the negotiations, said she would fight to restrict the height to 53 stories when the project comes before the Council. The developers' spokesman, Martin McLaughlin, said they had agreed to pay about $14 million of the projected $20 million cost to renovate the Biltmore, which has been closed since 1987. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: The Residue Of Faith And Fury
description: My sister had yellowish skin and a yellow cast to the whites of her eyes. She was feverish and listless and wouldn't eat. She ended up in a hospital, where the diagnosis was hepatitis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, BARBARA AUGUSTA
description: HERMAN-Barbara Augusta. On June 10, 2001. Beloved daughter of Lucille and the late Carl. Dear sister of Mark. Loving aunt of Shem. Services today, 12:30 PM, Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., Bronx, at 167 St.

title: Genome Project Rivals Trade Notes, Cordially
description: The two rival teams that decoded the human genome met on neutral ground last week to exchange notes on the merits of their respective approaches. The meeting, from which the teams' leaders were absent, was conducted by the computational biologists on each side in a cordial atmosphere that gave little hint of the tense and often acrid three-year race in which they had been involved.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Women's Wear Daily Site Dismisses 13
description: WWD.com, a Web site that generated new content and also took content from its mother publication, Women's Wear Daily, dismissed 13 employees yesterday. Rochelle Udell, the president of Fairchild's Internet division, told WWD.com staff members yesterday that they would no longer be employed by Fairchild -- even though several of them had come from Fairchild's print division to start up WWD.com. Andrea Kaplan, a Fairchild spokeswoman, said that the decision came after the Fairchild Internet unit decided to merge at least part of its operations with Advance Net, the Internet operation of Cond Nast. Cond Nast and Fairchild are both owned by Advance Publications. ''It is being restructured so that Advance Net can supply automated content,'' Ms. Kaplan said. Ms. Udell did not return a phone call seeking comment. Alex Kuczynski (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Studying Smoking And Young People
description: Cigarette advertisements ingrained positive attitudes about tobacco among young people through images emphasizing popularity, coolness and relaxation, and the risks presented in anti-smoking messages were often overlooked, a new report has found. The study, conducted by the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania, was based on interviews with about 2,600 people between the ages of 14 and 22. Although roughly 80 percent of respondents said they thought smoking was addictive, about 60 percent said they thought quitting would be easy or at least possible for most people who tried.

title: Suharto in Hospital After Collapsing
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 12  Former President Suharto of Indonesia was taken to a hospital in Jakarta this afternoon after he collapsed at his home from what a doctor called dangerously low blood pressure and a weak heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GERTRUDE
description: COHEN-Gertrude. On June 9th, 2001 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Harry. She will be missed by her daughters, Barbara Zelner and Myra Borchard, their husbands, Martin and William, and her grandchildren, Bennet, Emily, Jillian and Thomas. Services private.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: F.B.I. Shooting Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says it is reviewing the fatal shooting on May 31 of Aaron Roberts, a 37-year-old black man, by a white Seattle police officer. Several inquiries are also under way at the city level concerning the shooting, which had prompted several protests and calls for an independent investigation. Mr. Roberts was killed after a late-night traffic stop; the two officers involved say the man had pinned one of them to his car and was driving off at high speed. Mr. Roberts's relatives and other protesters dispute the account and say there was no justification for the shooting. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Fantasy Baseball: Cubs-Red Sox Series
description: If only the season didn't have so many games to play. If only this could be the last week of September. If only the standings would remain as they are today. If, if, if. So many ifs stand in the way. But if we believe hard enough, the way children have kept Tinker Bell alive forever, maybe we could get the most fantastic World Series matchup any mind could conjure: the Boston Red Sox versus the Chicago Cubs.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Stop The Music, Envoy Says
description: Tunisia took umbrage in the Security Council at an unusual attempt by diplomats to liven up meetings of technical experts looking at lists of what items may not be exported to Iraq under a revised sanctions program. The envoys had been opening each technical session -- not held in the Security Council chamber -- with music, each day from a different member nation. The selections ranged from European rock to Chinese classics. Ambassador Noureddine Mejdoub asked the Council president ''to stop such jokes.'' He said that the unhappiness of the Iraqi people and the credibility of the Council should dictate restraint.

title: Metro Business Briefing | More Growth For Flowers.com
description: 1-800-Flowers.com in Westbury, N.Y., said last week that it had acquired the Children's Group, a direct marketer of children's gifts including natural material toys, games and dolls, from Foster & Gallagher in Peoria, Ill., in a cash deal valued at $4.7 million. The Children's Group, which has two brands, HearthSong in Rohnert Park, Calif., and Magic Cabin Dolls in Viroqua, Wis., will operate as an autonomous unit of 1-800-Flowers.com. The Children's Group, with revenue estimated at $30 million, is the third acquisition of a nonfloral direct marketer for 1-800-Flowers.com in three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTILL, BARBARA
description: ESTILL-Barbara. Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., mourns the passing of Ms. Barbara Estill, a very distinguished leader and beloved friend. Ms. Estill served on our Board for 25 years, where she focused on programs for the elderly and public social policy. Her generous support and myriad contributions to the Federation will be long remembered. Our sincerest and heartfelt condolences are extended to her family.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From fritatta recipes to setting up a home bar, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Chief Executive Leaving Finnish Phone Company
description: Kaj-Erik Relander, the chief executive of the Finnish mobile telephone company Sonera, resigned his post today, the latest casualty in a purge that has already forced out most of the company's directors.

title: Charles Sews Up Fashion, De la Renta Sows His Garden : War of Roses, And Parterres
description: WADDESDON MANOR, England  It is a battle royal. Hoes, rakes and spades at dawn. On one side of the garden fence is Prince Charles, who famously talks to his plants, has a green thumb, nurtures wild flowers and has just shown off an Islamic-style patio at England's Chelsea Flower Show.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: DVD Price Inquiry
description: The competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said his department was investigating why the prices of digital videodiscs cost more in the European Union than in the United States. The commission is examining the coding system that film production companies and the makers of digital videodisc equipment use to limit sales of discs to one or another geographical region. Such a system could be a smoke-screen to allow companies to maintain artificially high prices, Mr. Monti said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Connoisseurs of Chaos Offer A Valuable Product: Randomness
description: In an age when most people seem obsessed with bringing order to their lives -- with Day-Timers, Palm Pilots, and even professional anticlutter specialists to wrestle their closets and junk drawers into line -- a Web site in Switzerland has been offering a very different service: providing the world with randomness.

title: Yaltah Menuhin, 79, Pianist in Musical Family
description: Yaltah Menuhin, a pianist and the younger sister of the violinist Yehudi Menuhin, died on Saturday, The Times of London reported. The Times did not report where she died. She was 79.

title: LTV ASKS COURT TO ELIMINATE SOME RETIREE BENEFITS
description: The LTV Corporation, a large steel maker, asked a bankruptcy court yesterday to terminate labor agreements and eliminate some retiree health benefits, and said it would cut about 800 jobs so it could avoid closing operations. The company, based in Cleveland, filed the motion with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Youngstown, Ohio. The changes are needed to save 7,700 jobs in the steel operations, LTV said. It said it had not made money in the last three years because it cannot compete against lower-priced imported steel and minimills.

title: Europeans Approve Amgen Anemia Drug
description: Amgen said today that it had received approval to sell a longer-lasting version of its anemia drug EPO in Europe, setting the stage for a fierce marketing battle with Johnson & Johnson, which now sells EPO there.

title: Harry Zohn, Brandeis Professor, 77
description: Harry Zohn, an educator, writer and translator of important works of German literature, died on May 3 at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 77 and most recently lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Acer Spinning Off Units
description: Acer Inc., a Taiwan computer maker, will spin off its manufacturing units to form a separate company in July as part of a restructuring plan started last year. The new company will run all of Acer's computer-making units, said the co-chief executive, Simon Lin, who oversees Acer's manufacturing businesses and will manage the new company. Acer hopes to sell shares in the company within three years.

title: Centers Play Rough, and That's Just on an Off Day
description: Shaquille O'Neal believes Dikembe Mutombo plays in the Nothing But Actors league. After calling the Philadelphia center a flop artist on Sunday night, he implored Mutombo today to stop whining and start playing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, THOMAS P.
description: ROBINSON-Thomas P. June 9, 2001. Plans have changed, and there will be no viewing Tuesday. Memorial service Wednesday, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. Call (212) 475-2024.

title: Excite@Home Receives Financial Infusion
description: The troubled At Home Corporation said yesterday that it had arranged a $100 million private investment in the form of a five-year convertible note from Promethean Asset Management and Angelo, Gordon & Company. The two New York investment management companies have made a specialty of lending to ailing technology concerns at unusually stringent terms.

title: A Fighter Wearing Suspenders
description: Two 30-second television commercials, titled ''Imagine'' and ''Who You Fight For,'' were released yesterday by James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, in his campaign for governor of New Jersey. He is unopposed in the Democratic primary, but since he is free to spend up to $5.9 million, he is placing self-promotional ads. These are to run on broadcast stations in New York and Philadelphia at a cost of $1.9 million until the June 26 election.

title: The President's Trip And the Values Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations Break Off After 4 Hours
description: Israeli and Palestinian security officials met for four hours tonight, and according to a Palestinian involved in the talks, failed to reach an agreement over an American-initiated proposal that would extend a fragile and partial 10-day-old cease-fire.

title: Bulgaria Opens School Doors for Gypsy Children
description: Linka Shankova, a Gypsy mother in her 20's, is taking part in an unusual experiment intended to lift the lot of her people in Bulgaria, and indeed across Eastern Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFSKY, WILLIAM L.
description: RAFSKY-William L. June 11, 2001. Husband of Selma (nee Chafets) of Philadelphia. Father of Lawrence C. and the late Robert A. Rafsky. Grandfather of Sara Rafsky. Services and interment private. For information Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks, Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALOM, JOSEPH
description: SHALOM-Joseph. From the children, Isaac, Robert, Leslie, and Valerie, from his grandchildren, Natasha and Yvonne, his son-inlaw, Nissim Berrebi, his brothers, Stephen and Henry, his sisters, Norma and Muriel, who mourn the loss of their dear father, grandfather, in-law, and brother, Joseph Shalom who passed away suddenly and serenely on Thursday evening, June 7, 2001. Joe always spoke succinctly, felt deeply, wrote eloquently, and was aways available to anticipate and answer every person's need whether an intimate relation or a casual acquaintance. He was patriarch of the Shalom family, who carried on the lofty traditions initiated by his father and mother, Isaac and Alice Shalom. His compassion and guidance will be sorely missed.

title: No Rest for the Parents of the Parent of 'Rent'
description: Most evenings at 8, Al Larson listens to his son. From the orchestra section of the Jane Street Theater in Greenwich Village, he listens to Jonathan Larson's fears at turning 30, his frustrations over a foundering career as a musical-theater composer, his temptation to ''sell out'' for a lucrative job in advertising. Around 9:30, when Mr. Larson listens to a recording of Stephen Sondheim telling Jonathan that he has a promising career ahead, he sometimes wipes away a tear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, ROSE MARIE
description: ALEXANDER-Rose Marie. 100. Loving matriarch of the Weinbaum family. Survived by her son Dan, daughter-in-law Lou, grandchildren Dana, Dan, Jr., and David, great grandchildren Sarah, Emily, Alex and Ethan and special grand niece Tracy. Visistation Tuesday 7-9pm. Services Wednesday 11:30am The Riverside, 76th St & Amsterdam. Contributions to your favorite charity.

title: The President's Trip and the Values Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Is Ready to Supply A Phone in Every Computer
description: Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system for PC's goes further than ever before in commandeering the capabilities of the most widely used desktop tool in America: the telephone.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Royal Massacre Inquiry Winding Up
description: The chief justice of the Supreme court and the speaker of the lower house of Parliament are due to finish their investigation into the June 1 massacre of much of the royal family by Thursday and to present their findings to the new king, Gyanendra. Testimony of surviving witnesses has been videotaped, officials close to the palace say. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: THE McVEIGH EXECUTION: THE OVERVIEW; McVeigh Dies for Oklahoma City Blast
description: With the sting of a needle in his right leg, Timothy J. McVeigh was sedated, injected with poison and executed today by the government he so despised, a quiet end for the man who sent 168 people to their deaths in screams, flames and crushing concrete.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Royal, Changing Ballet for a Changed Britain
description: There will always be an England and, like England, the Royal Ballet is very much in flux. On the company's current mini-tour, new dancers and new ways of dancing have upset old images of the Royal past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASSEN, MICHAEL DAVID
description: CHASSEN-Michael David. On June 10, 2001, of Yardley, PA. Husband of Susan, father of David, Craig and Patricia, son of Zita, and brother of Bruce of NYC. Previous general partner of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg of NYC, and a former member of New York Stock Exchange. Memorial service will be Thursday, 11 AM, First Presbyterian Church of Morrisville, 661 N. Pennsylvania Ave., Morrisville, PA. Calling hours on Wednesday, 4-8 PM, at FitzGerald-Sommer Funeral Home, Yardley, PA.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Hot Stellar Winds Captured by X-Ray Orbiter
description: Ever since Galileo in 1610 pointed a new-fangled telescope at Jupiter and discovered its four large moons, astronomy has advanced in tandem with new technologies of observation, and never more so than today.

title: Tax Rebate Will Bypass Many, Study Finds
description: More than one-quarter of all American adults will not get a tax rebate this year. Altogether, nearly 40 percent will not get the full amount of $300 for individuals and $600 for couples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTAGLIA, TULLIO F., MD
description: TARTAGLIA-Tullio F., MD, 79, a graduate of The Chicago Medical School, and a decorated Korean War veteran, died June 10. Dr. Tartaglia was a licensed physician for 50 years and a past-President of the NY Society of Internal Medicine, Bronx Chapter, and the Bronx County Medical Society. A devoted husband to Dolores, he is survived by his 4 children, Lydia, Joseph, Alfred and Gregory, and his grandchildren, Laura, Andrew, Christina, James, Julia, Sarah and Alexandra. For information call Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISHUK, SOLOMON
description: ZISHUK-Solomon. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Dr. Linda and Dr. Rande Lazar of Memphis, TN, Sheila and Bruce Warshaw of Fairfield, CT, David and Sharon Zishuk of Concord, NC. Loving grandfather of Lauren, Brent, Morgan, Tamara and Joel. Dear brother of Molly Sultan of FL. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''Gutterman's'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Exploring the Diabetes-Depression Link
description: No one is sure why, but diabetics appear to be twice as likely to suffer from depression as those without the disease, and the incidence is even higher in women, a new study shows.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Warning: Nicotine Can Inhibit Healing
description: Smokers who need spinal-fusion surgery in their necks may be in for an unfortunate surprise: their habit, already associated with other health problems, may also make the surgery less successful, a new study reports. Researchers, writing in a recent Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery, said smokers healed to a lesser degree and also needed more pain medicine.

title: President Says The Retarded Should Never Be Executed
description: As he prepared to leave for Europe, President Bush said today that an individual who is mentally retarded should not be executed, addressing an issue that has sparked sharp criticism overseas. But an aide said the comment did not represent a shift in Mr. Bush's position.

title: Practice Bomb Missed Target And Set Fire, Officials Say
description: An arson investigation yesterday revealed the likely source of a fire that burned more than 1,600 acres of pine forest near Little Egg Harbor Township in Ocean County on Sunday: a New Jersey Air National Guard practice bomb gone astray.

title: Bush Defends His Policies on First Day of Europe Visit
description: On the first full day of his European tour, President Bush today confronted some of the issues that divide the United States from its friends across the Atlantic, but said there are many more things that hold Europeans and Americans together.

title: THE McVEIGH EXECUTION: OKLAHOMA CITY; Execution on TV Brings Little Solace
description: A few minutes after 7 this morning, the 232 people who had come to watch Timothy J. McVeigh die on closed-circuit television fell silent. The blank screen flickered awake, and the face that had been so haunting and so hateful to everyone in the room came into focus. He seemed, they said, as if he were only a few feet away.

title: Halfway through 2001, there are few signs that the media economy has hit bottom.
description: THE first half of 2001 is drawing to a close with few if any signs that the weakening of the advertising and media economies will reverse itself anytime soon.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Theorists of Inner Space Look to Observers of Outer Space
description: The Big Bang, David Schramm, the University of Chicago cosmologist, liked to say, is the poor man's particle accelerator: in its detritus, which after all includes the whole universe, are the effects of energies and processes unattainable on Earth. If astronomers looked closely enough at the sky, he maintained, they could test theories and phenomena that were beyond the power and the budgets of physicists to recreate in their laboratories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, ESTELLE, NEE SCHWARTZ
description: BRILL-Estelle, nee Schwartz. Most beloved wife of Malcolm, devoted mother of Michael (Patricia) and Judith (Joseph) Artusa. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Samantha, Sabrina, Benjamin and Laura. Loving sister of Frank (Simone) and Martin (Adrienne) Schwartz. You will always be in my thoughts and heart forever. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, KENRY
description: CRAWFORD-Kenry. Of Hackensack on June 7, 2001. Survived by many relatives, friends and coworkers at Channel WNET 13 of New York. Cremation private.

title: THE McVEIGH EXECUTION: THE SCENE; Calm at Execution Site and Silence by McVeigh Prove Unsettling for Some
description: No terror-twisted chaos. No bloody pandemonium. Not even any blood.

title: A Memorial To Kubrick, In All His 'Movieness'
description: ''People who love Stanley's movies are mostly movie people,'' says Richard Schickel, Time magazine's film critic, in a new documentary about Stanley Kubrick. ''They're just looking at what's in the frame, what's the movieness of the movie. They of course love Stanley in a very uncomplicated way.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Museum To Return Artifact
description: The Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago announced that it would return a totem pole to an Indian tribe in Alaska. The 27-foot totem pole was among the museum's most treasured artifacts and was taken during an expedition in 1899 from a village abandoned by the Tlingit tribe. The Field Museum, which has one of the largest Indian collections in the country, will return the pole to the Tlingit Native American Nation in Cape Fox, Alaska. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, CHARLES C., MD.
description: HOGAN-Charles C., MD. October 5, 1921 to June 7, 2001. Memorial service in September, date will be announced.

title: Senate Defeats Bill to Fund Vouchers for Private Schools
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Apparently sounding the death knell for federally financed education vouchers, the Senate this afternoon defeated an amendment permitting low-income parents in 10 cities to use taxpayer dollars to send their children to private and religious schools.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Thursday about an announcement by President Bush on Mexicans' operation of transportation services in the United States misstated his decision. Mr. Bush said he would let Mexican corporations own or buy trucking and bus operations based in the United States. Although his decision would open the transportation market to Mexicans, Mr. Bush did not say he would let Mexican-based trucking and bus companies operate in the United States.

title: Bush to Insist on Ethanol Use in California
description: The Bush administration has decided to force California to use ethanol as an antipollution fuel additive, a move that the critics say could result in an increase of at least 5 cents a gallon at the pump this summer in that state.

title: The Energy Is Abundant, The Turnover Treacherous
description: The Children's Orchestra Society, founded by Yo-Yo Ma's father, Dr. Hiao-Tsiun Ma, has been around since 1962. Its members haven't, though.

title: Rangers, in Switch, Sign a 21-Year-Old
description: The Rangers, long known for signing thirtysomething free agents, may have marked the beginning of a new trend yesterday. They signed the 21-year-old free agent left wing Barrett Heisten, a first-round pick of the Buffalo Sabres in the 1999 draft.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Army Battles Severe Drought
description: With the Korean Peninsula suffering its worst drought in 100 years, the army said 110,000 troops would help farmers build new ditches to carry water to parched rice paddies while the air force and navy transport emergency supplies of water and equipment. In North Korea, the state-run press agency said no harvest was expected from hundreds of thousands of drought-stricken acres. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Wahid Reshuffles Cabinet to Aid Indonesian Economy
description: BANGKOK, June 12  In his latest bid to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia shuffled his economic team today, reassigning a chief minister who had clashed with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Dreams Lead All the Way To Havana; Medical Scholarships Are a Gift From Castro
description: The brave, the proud, the few. The Marines? Not for Mirtha Arzu, though the lure of scholarship money almost led her to enlist a year ago in the Bronx. Instead, she joined an even more select group of adventurers: the first Americans to study medicine in Cuba courtesy of President Fidel Castro.

title: Carefree Lovers, Frisky and Frolicking
description: ''Don Quixote,'' that giddy old romp, made a rollicking return to the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday night when American Ballet Theater presented it for the first time this season.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Former Kremlin Aide Back In Court
description: Pavel Borodin, the former Kremlin property manager under investigation for money laundering, maintained his silence during his second appearance before Geneva justice officials since he was freed on $3 million bail in April. He is accused of laundering an estimated $25 million in kickbacks in return for lucrative construction contracts awarded to Swiss companies. He says he is innocent.

title: Crime and Psychotherapy
description: Re ''Therapists Reveal Their New Obsession: 'The Sopranos' '' (May 29):

title: National Briefing | West: California: Lead In Bullets Threatens Condor
description: Biologists aiding in the reintroduction of California condors into the wild say the giant birds are being threatened by lead from bullets, which scientists believe was the primary reason they were driven 28 years ago to the brink of extinction. Four condors have died in the past year, and an additional 13 have been treated to remove potentially lethal levels of lead. Condor specialists believe that the birds fed on carcasses of animals killed by gunfire, swallowing lead pellets or bullet fragments that slowly poison them.

title: Article 2001061293332535186 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Bloomberg Backs School Uniforms and Teacher House Calls
description: The billionaire Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that if he won the mayoralty, he would require teachers or other school employees to visit the homes of all 1.1 million public-school children in New York City at least once a year.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for the ''Three Mo' Tenors'' concerts at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan misstated the dates. They are today and Wednesday, not Wednesday and Thursday.

title: When Mammograms Can Do Harm
description: A new study calls into question the wisdom of routinely encouraging frail, elderly women to undergo mammograms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, KERMIT L.
description: PINES-Kermit L. 84, On June 10 after a long illness. Devoted husband for 61 years to Toussia, beloved father to Jeffrey, Jonathan, Deborah. Grandfather to Kate, Emily, Giulia, Abigail. Great grandfather to Zachary and Tyler. Please make any contributions to Medical Student Financial Aid at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, RHEA
description: GARBER-Rhea. On June 11, 2001 at age 91. Beloved wife of Harry. mother of Barbara and Allen. Grandmother of six. Services are on Tuesday, at 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Front Row; A Dangerous Chalice for Young Designers
description: While most women could not tell you that Bruce is a clothing line or, more specifically, that it is a line meant to evoke a woman who spent her girlhood dreaming of becoming Mrs. Joey Ramone, most in the fashion world could quickly arrive at a description that would be pretty close.

title: Talks in Jerusalem
description: Israeli and Palestinian security officials met for four hours yesterday, but failed to agree on a proposal to extend their fragile cease-fire. Again, death cast its pall: an Israeli baby hit by Palestinian stone throwers died.

title: NEIMAN MARCUS WARNS OF LOSS BECAUSE OF PRICE-CUTTING
description: The Neiman Marcus Group Inc., a retailing business that includes the Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman chains, said yesterday that it would have an unexpected loss in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year as it reduces prices more than planned to get rid of slow-selling goods. The loss will be 10 cents to 15 cents a share in the period, which ends July 28, Neiman Marcus said. The company was expected to earn 10 cents a share, the average estimate of seven analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. The group's Class A shares fell 56 cents, to $33.74 a share. The company is based in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Solutions for Gridlock at La Guardia
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Federal Aviation Administration are proposing innovative market-based solutions to the imbalance between limited capacity and voracious demand for air service at La Guardia Airport. Congress and the airline industry should work with regulators to perfect, then institute, these solutions.

title: In President's Words: 'A Leadership Role on the Issue of Climate Change'
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush today on global climate, as recorded by the White House:

title: Tunnel Vision; Taking a Chance on Love and the No. 4
description: Among good places for making a romantic connection, the New York City subway has long ranked down around the bottom of the list, just above jail or the proctologist's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, PATRICIA JANE
description: CORNELL - Patricia Jane. (1925-2001). A gentle and glowing star of stage and family, went peacefully to her rest on Friday, June 8, 2001, in Santa Monica, CA, 75. With sister Shirley, Pat starred with Olsen and Johnson from 1939 to 1948 when she became an executive at J. Walter Thompson. A ninth-generation American, she descended from Jacques Campeau, who traveled with Champlain. Pat's great-grandmother, Louise Leasia, organized the first Catholic Mass in the Saginaw Territory and spoke 11 Indian dialects. Born in Detroit to Michael Basso & Clara Louise Leasia, she was a talented dancer and inventive comedienne, who with her sister Shirley joined Olsen and Johnson in her teens and traveled with them for nine years to every city on the KeithOrpheum Circuit. After the war, Pat appeared on the Milton Berle Show and studied shorthand to land a job at J. Walter Thompson where she produced the Kraft Radio Theater, Rudy Vallee & Edgar Bergen shows. In her greatest starring role, she was mother to her beloved family. She married noted insurance lawyer M.A. ''Pete'' Cornell of Pasadena, CA, & raised her two proud boys, Peter and Christopher. Generous philanthropists, the couple became known as ''Mr & Mrs Santa Claus,'' famed for the Christmas decorations at homes in Pasadena and Huntington Harbor, CA. Pat's superb gourmet cooking and warm hospitality made every guest feel like an old friend. Pat was an anchor and harbor to her family, gentle and gracious, intuitive and insightful, centered and stable, inventive and loving. There is no measure to the sadness felt by her beloved husband Peter, her sister Shirley, children Peter and Christopher, her niece Pati, her great niece and her three grandchildren. It is tempered only by the sure knowledge that throughout her life she lived it to the fullest and gave to others far more than she received. Services are today at Pacific View Memorial Park in Newport Beach, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROCKER, EDNA
description: STROCKER-Edna. Our memories of your joy, vitality and love of life will be remembered and cherished always. Rose and Harold Rosenberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNELLI, HOPEY (NEE DUKA)
description: INNELLI-Hopey (nee Duka) of Jericho, LI, was called to the service of the Lord on June 11, 2001. Beloved wife of Frank T. Loving mother of John F., Michele I. Cox, Hope Schwab and Frank T. Jr. Dear sister of Doris Smile-Mezin, Eleanor E. Newton, the late Daniel, and the late Helen Mustello. Cherished grandmother of Jared, Tyler, Makenzie, Katherine (Kate), James, Daniel & Giovanni. Fond mother-in-law of Holly, Rick, Kaipo and Maggie. Adored aunt of many. Hopey lived in Bayside, NY in a twenty-one room house (believe that it was once the Japanese Embassy.) The Duka family lived there until the death of her mother Sadie. Hopey loved being a mother and an interior designer and a household decorator. A lady of class, Hopey filled her life and those around her with beauty, dignity, grace and love. A beautiful lady who was optimistic with humility and inspired whomever her life touched to feel warm and good about themselves. She never disrespected anyone for any reason regardless of race, religion, disability, sex or economic status. She will be missed dearly by all those who love her. Friends may call Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Hicksville Chapel, 47 Jerusalem Ave (2 Blocks south L.I.R.R., corner W. Marie St). Mass Wednesday 9:45 AM at St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, Brookville. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers please make donations in Hopey's name to St. Paul the Apostle Sr. Adult Club or St. Paul the Apostle Marion Guild.

title: Big Talk From Little Guys Spices Series
description: Mitch Kupchak, the Los Angeles Lakers' general manager, called it the most physical game he had seen in a long time. Phil Jackson, the Lakers' coach, called it a scrum match. The Philadelphia 76ers called it a war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the fatal shooting of a man by the police after he had shot another man gave a misspelled name in some copies for the Brooklyn street on which the events occurred. It is Nostrand Avenue, not Norstrand.

title: Hughes Warns of a Slower Rate of New Subscribers for DirecTV
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation, the unit of General Motors that owns the satellite broadcasting service DirecTV, warned yesterday that it was adding new subscribers at a considerably slower rate than it had previously forecast.

title: Diesel Engines Get Spotlight in Fuel-Efficiency Contest
description: Each of the 16 Chevrolet Suburban sport utility vehicles in a barnlike garage at the General Motors vehicle testing center here is painted a different bright color and festooned with the logos of sponsoring corporations. But the Suburbans are here not for a road race but for a different kind of competition: to see which can emit the least amount of global-warming gases.

description: It was about the size and weight of a large paper clip. It may have been an ancestor of all modern mammals.

description: J. C. Furnas, a writer and social historian, died on June 3 at his home in Stanton, N.J. He was 95.

title: People
description: * Dennis Miller, chairman and chief executive at Publicis in the West, Seattle, part of the the United States operations of the Publicis agency owned by the Publicis Groupe, resigned, the agency said, declining to elaborate. Randy Browning, president and chief marketing officer, and Kevin Kehoe, president and chief creative officer, will assume Mr. Miller's duties and retain their current titles.

Savage, a professor of computer science. While he is skeptical about fighting such attacks with generally available security software, he did not directly discuss Microsoft's approach to combating them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMMERS, LEON
description: POMMERS-Leon. His friends, colleagues, and students from The Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College, mourn the death of Leon Pommers, consummate musician, devoted teacher, warmhearted friend, and perfect gentleman.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rent Board To Hold Hearing
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board has scheduled a hearing tomorrow for the public to discuss proposed increases for rent-stabilized apartments. Last year, a week after an emotional public hearing, the board approved a 4 percent increase for one-year leases and a 6 percent one for two-year leases, the largest increases since 1996. The board is now proposing increases of 3 percent and 5 percent. The meeting is scheduled for the Schomburg Center at 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street. Testimony on apartments is scheduled from 1:15 to 6 p.m. and 8:15 to 9:45 p.m. Speakers can register in advance at (212) 385-2934, extension 0, or sign in at the hearings. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Newest Pain Killers Deserve a Closer Look
description: What do stock analysts know about medical research? Last month Wall Street got nervous about the safety of two of the hottest prescription drugs on the market, Celebrex and Vioxx, after a company-sponsored study suggested that they might increase susceptibility to heart attacks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a headline in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about the sale of restaurants by Avado Brands referred incorrectly in some copies to the division being sold. It is the McCormick & Schmick's seafood chain, not Don Pablo's Mexican Kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDY, JACOB (JERRY), DR.
description: LANDY-Jacob (Jerry), Dr. Devoted husband of Libby. Adored father of Bonnie Ackley, Michael Landy, James CarlsenLandy, and Victoria Green. Loving father-in-law of Martin Ackley, Anne Landy, Beverly CarlsenLandy, and J. Lynn Green. Cherished grandfather of Kris, Jeff, David, Erik, Danielle, Jeremy, Cindy, Cheryl, and Nathan. Dear brotherin-law of Florence Apar. Services Wednesday, 12:15 PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: From Soulful to Opulent, In a Spirit of Fellowship
description: Bargemusic remains enjoyably buoyant. On Saturday evening the program offered at this bobbing platform beneath the Brooklyn Bridge was of piano quartets by Mozart and Brahms, with Frederic Chiu at the keyboard. These two works were separated by Dohnanyi's appealing Serenade for string trio, to give Mr. Chiu a rest and focus attention on his excellent colleagues: the violinist Carmit Zori, violist Scott Lee and cellist Peter Wiley.

title: Sports of The Times; The Coach And the Kid From Philly
description: THE high school coach stayed home Sunday night and was not sorry he did, though Kobe Bryant scored the late runner in the lane and the Lakers escaped with a 2-1 N.B.A. finals lead. Gregg Downer just couldn't be party to his city chanting vulgarities at one of its own, and his guy at that.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Software Share Offer
description: The Temenos Group, a Swiss company that makes banking software, said it and its existing investors would sell shares in an initial public offering that would value the company at as much as $941 million. The Geneva-based company, which makes software for 300 banks and financial services companies including Merrill Lynch & Company, plans to sell 10.8 million shares, and existing shareholders will sell about 1.9 million shares. The company will use the proceeds from the offering to repay at least half of a $60 million loan from Deutsche Bank, and keep $50 million for acquisitions and expansion in the United States and Japan. The shares, in one of the largest technology stock floats in Europe this year, will be priced at $14 to $17. The final price is to be set on June 25 or 26, when trading is to start on the Swiss Stock Exchange.
