description: MAIT-Harold. We cherish your spirit and our memories. Love you forever. Janet, Josh, Jenny and David

title: Carbon Monoxide Isn't Always a Killer
description: Carbon monoxide gas is best known as the silent killer that seeps odorless into homes or cars when there are venting problems with an engine or burner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOND, SIMON (SASHA)
description: BOND-Simon (Sasha). The family of Simon Bond wishes to thank all of the people who attended his funeral and, in particular, to express our appreciation to Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schneider, who consistently and faithfully were in touch with Simon Bond and worried about him, to Dr. Norman Lamm, who was his moral and spiritual guide, to Rabbi Sol Roth, who was his religious advisor, to his friend, Rabbi Arthur Schneier and to his Doctor, Martin Fox.

title: Newark Arena Talk Spurs Anger Over Meadowlands
description: When Gov. Christie Whitman, on her last day in office, unveiled a plan for a new sports arena for Newark, her successor, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, complained that the plan was doomed because it did not include a redevelopment plan for the Meadowlands, where the Continental Arena will go dark if the New Jersey Nets and Devils depart for Newark.

title: Three Parties In One Night: Sounds Like Nerd Heaven
description: Since an obsession with computers grew from a trait of nerds in the 1980's to a chief preoccupation of much of the country in the 90's, so-called geek culture has been infiltrating American culture. Yesterday's outcasts, depicted in movies like ''Revenge of the Nerds'' wiring a sorority house with a hidden camera, became the jet-setters of the late 90's, making millions doing the same thing on Webcam sites. This decade, if geek savvy isn't a sure shortcut to fortunes anymore, it's at least a passport into an exciting artistic underground, epitomized in events like Burning Man, an annual gathering of the tribe into a temporary self-sustaining art, music, dance and technology community in the Nevada desert.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Compromise On Biltmore Block
description: Neighborhood leaders have reached a compromise with developers who proposed to renovate the historic Biltmore Theater, on 47th Street near Eighth Avenue, in exchange for permission to increase the height of an apartment building they plan to

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Peregrine Systems Buying Competitor
description: Peregrine Systems Inc., a 20-year-old software

title: Deutsch to Close Office in Boston
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York, in its first significant contraction, said yesterday that it would close its Boston office, which has been open only since July 2000, on July 11.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELOT INC., Norwalk, Conn., a seller of lottery tickets on the Internet that said in March it might not continue doing business, has agreed to buy FreeWorldLottery from the closely held PlasmaNet Inc., for $16.9 million in stock and assumed debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIA, MAY H.
description: MARIA-May H. Died on June 8, 2001, in Austin, Texas. She was the first woman to receive a Ph.D in mathematics in 1929 from Rice University in Houston, Texas. In 1938 she married Dr. Alfred J. Maria and both taught at Brooklyn College. She is survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral services June 13, 2001 at 10 A.M. Cook-Walden Funeral Home, 6100 N. Lamar Blvd. Austin, Texas. Memorials may be made to Fondren Library, Rice University, P.O. Box 1892, Houston, TX. 77251-1892

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Volunteering For Tax Credit
description: The State Senate has passed a bill that would give tax credits to people who donate goods or services, including volunteer time, to troubled public schools. The bill was part of a package designed to help schools that have low test scores and high dropout rates. Under the legislation, a single person could qualify for a tax credit of up to $100. The maximum credit for a couple is $200 and $5,000 for businesses. To qualify for the maximum tax credit for volunteering at a school, a taxpayer would have to donate at least 40 hours. The measure is now being considered by the House. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, JOHN S., M.D.
description: McCABE-John S., M.D., 66. Retired Chief of Thoracic Surgery and past Chairman of the Division of Surgery of Washington Hospital, Washington, PA. Died on June 1st, 2001 in Vero Beach, FL. Born in NYC, Dr. McCabe built a successful thoracic and cardiovascular practice in southwestern Pennsylvania before retiring to Vero Beach. Dr. McCabe served in the US Navy during the Viet Nam era. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Prep, LeMoyne College and NYU Medical School. He is survived by his wife, Marian; his son, Andrew, of Washington, DC; a daughter, Elaine, of Vero Beach; a sister, Terese Cerni, of Scarsdale, NY; & a brother, Stephen, of Springfield, NJ and Vero Beach. A memorial mass and funeral will be held in Manhattan at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Ave., on Friday, June 22nd, at 10 AM. Memorial donations in Dr. McCabe's name may be made to the Religious of Jesus and Mary-Haiti Fund, Provincial Offices, 3706 Rhode Island Avenue, Mount Rainier, MD. 20712

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ELLA J.
description: KAHN-Ella J., one hundred and three years old, died peacefully in her home on Saturday, June 9, 2001. Beloved mother of Herbert Kahn and Carol Colen. She is survived by her grandchildren Judy Kruger, Susan Colen-Fowler, Rick Kahn and Ken Colen and four great grandchildren.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Nato's Expanding Umbrella
description: NATO began a two-week exercise in the Black Sea with five East European and former Soviet nations, some of which are candidates for NATO membership. Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine and Georgia sent soldiers to the training mission, which involves 4,000 troops from those nations and six NATO members, as well as the International Committee of the Red Cross. Bulgaria and Romania are candidates for the next round of NATO admissions.

title: Anatomy of a Bagel
description: Q. How many calories are in a plain, sesame or poppy seed bagel from a New York coffee shop? What are the ingredients and nutritional value?

title: Unhappy Steinbrenner Names Names
description: George Steinbrenner has always been willing to make changes when necessary, to plug holes in the Yankees' roster, to spend money. But Steinbrenner committed hundreds of millions of dollars in the off-season, and yesterday he sounded as if what he wants now is for his expensive position players to start producing runs, and he specifically mentioned Derek Jeter, David Justice, Tino Martinez and Chuck Knoblauch.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Currency Falls
description: The pound fell to a 16-year low against the United States dollar despite assurances by the government that its policy with regard to the euro had not changed. Jack Straw, left, Britain's new foreign secretary, said the country's euro policy remained unchanged, producing a brief recovery in the pound from a 15-year low set last week after the re-election of Prime Minister Tony Blair. Mr. Blair has said the government will decide within two years whether a referendum should be held on scrapping the pound. By the end of London trading, the pound had weakened once again and fallen to $1.3755. The moves reflected a trend among investors to link the pound to the euro in dollar-trading.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: East Side Church Closes
description: A 150-year-old Catholic church, one of Manhattan's oldest, was closed last week because of a defect in one of its walls, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday. St. Brigid's, on Avenue B on the Lower East Side, was deemed unsafe for use after its rear wall was discovered to be pulling away from the rest of the building. Joseph G. Zwilling, the spokesman for the archdiocese, said repairs to the building would cost over $600,000, more than the parish can afford. He said a committee would be formed to discuss options. Services are being held in the church's neighboring rectory chapel and school. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Devils Step Back and Look Ahead
description: The Devils fell one victory short of defending the Stanley Cup, but neither Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager, nor Coach Larry Robinson would call the season a success.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Layoffs For Tool-maker
description: Hardinge Inc., a maker of metal-cutting and tooling products, laid off about 115 workers, or 12 percent of its North American workforce, to reduce costs as machine tool sales decline. The layoffs at its main plant in Elmira, N.Y., were immediate and almost evenly divided between production and administrative workers, said Richard Simons, the company's chief financial officer. The employees will be able to return once the market for the machines improves, he said.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Bush Will Continue to Oppose Kyoto Pact on Global Warming
description: President Bush made clear today that he had no intention of reversing his opposition to a global warming accord supported by the European leaders he will meet with this week. And he strongly suggested that any new accord would have to bind developing nations, especially China and India, to the kind of commitments that would be made by the United States.

title: THE McVEIGH EXECUTION: THE REACTION ABROAD; Almost as One, Europe Condemns Execution
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, ALICE
description: WEINBERG-Alice. On June 9. Beloved wife of the late Stanley. She will be remembered for her kindness, generosity, humor and commitment to volunteerism. She will be missed by her four children, six grandchildren, and all who knew her. For further information call ''Sinai Chapels'' 800-446-0406.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: More Changes At Space.com
description: Space.com, the Silicon Alley multimedia company that bundles astronomy-related content, continues to shake up its work force. The company said it was laying off employees, but officials would not say how many. In addition, two senior vice presidents have resigned, a spokeswoman said, as the company reorganizes and streamlines its operations because of ''the recent softening of the advertisement market and business conditions.'' Since it began in 1999, Space.com has had three rounds of layoffs. In April, the site's founder, Lou Dobbs, quit to return to CNN as a financial news anchor. The spokeswoman said that the staff cuts would be limited to the company's Internet operations, while its publications, Space News, Starry Night and Space Illustrated, would be unaffected.

title: Shares Decline as Outlook for Technology Stirs Concern
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, pulled down by selling in the technology sector after two more companies forecast weaker-than-expected quarterly results, stoking investors' fears about the sluggish economy.

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday carried an outdated reference to the singer today through Saturday at Arci's Place, at 450 Park Avenue South, in Manhattan. It is Rob Evan, not Alexandra Billings.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Oil Pipeline Study
description: The Bush administration has authorized money for a study on a $2.8 billion oil pipeline from the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to the Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan. The new senior adviser for Caspian Basin energy diplomacy, Stephen Mann, signed the $346,000 grant, from the United States Trade and Development Agency to Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company. The grant will pay for a study to evaluate potential routes for Kazakh oil to link up with the pipeline. The study will also examine whether Kazakhstan's only Caspian port, Aktau, can handle heavy tanker traffic.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: DataSynapse Raises New Revenue
description: DataSynapse, a New York City-based developer of software allowing companies to put temporarily idle desktop and server computers to work on large processing problems, said yesterday that it had raised $15 million in new venture capital financing. DataSynapse software, an example of what is known as peer-to-peer distributed computing, links idle computers over corporate intranets. The new investment came from Bain Venture Capital, Intel Capital and the venture capital arm of First Union, the bank that was DataSynapse's first major customer.

title: Putting a Price on Organ Donations
description: Experts dispute the merits of putting price tags on human organs. Under one plan, heirs of the donors would be offered tax credits against their inheritances. Gale Scott interviewed two people involved with the issue, and the following are edited excerpts of those interviews.

title: Market Place; Citing Economy and Debt, Warnaco Files for Chapter 11
description: The Warnaco Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, blaming the economy and its heavy debt load, among other things, for its problems.

title: Top Court Gives Religious Clubs Equal Footing in Grade Schools
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that public schools must open their doors to after-school religious activities, including those that involve young children, on the same basis as any other after-hours activity that school policy permits.

title: Office Rents Fall for First Time Since 1993
description: Office rents fell for the first time since 1993 in the first quarter as Internet, computer and technology companies laid off workers and gave up space, according to a study.

title: Advertising Council Names Chairman
description: The Advertising Council in New York, which coordinates public service campaigns for Madison Avenue, has named as chairman for a one-year term Edward T. Reilly, 54, president and chief executive of the American Management Association in New York.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Cambodian-Americans On Trial
description: A trial began for 29 Cambodians and 3 Cambodian-Americans accused in a late-night attack on government buildings last November. One of the Americans, Richard Kiri Kim, told the court he led the group in an attempt to overthrow the government. The other two are being tried in absentia. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Critic's Notebook; True Chic: Ever Rarer Even in Its Natural Habitat
description: I don't know about men, but there's nothing better for a woman's ego than looking like a million bucks when it costs you only 50. Let me tell you what I mean. I used to have the longest hair, down to the middle of my back, and one day in the 1970's, between one class and another at Barnard, I took the bus down to 54th Street, marched over to Kenneth -- he still had his salon in that town house off Madison -- and said, ''Chop it off.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTHERS, MARTHA D.
description: STOTHERS-Martha D. Died May 7, 2001. A memorial service will be held on Sat, June 16, 12:30 pm, at Point O' Woods. Casual Attire.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS MORE INFORMATION ON CASINO COMPANY DEAL
description: Harrah's Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had asked for information on the company's plan to buy Harveys Casino Resorts as the agency reviews the sale's effect on the casino market in Lake Tahoe, Nev. Harrah's, based in Las Vegas, agreed in April to buy Harveys from the real estate firm Colony Capital L.L.C. for $675 million. The companies said they were responding promptly to the F.T.C.'s second request for information. Harrah's proposes to link its casino in Lake Tahoe with the Harveys casino there, said Harrah's spokesman, Gary Thompson. Harveys, based in Lake Tahoe, also owns casinos in Iowa and Colorado.

title: The Frequent Flier And Radiation Risk
description: In Greek myth, Icarus flew too close to the sun and crashed when its heat melted the wax that held his wings together. That idea seems quaint, but now some scientists think the Greeks may have been right to fear flying too close to the sun.

title: Sex, Lies and More Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Secrets of a Survivor

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: President Warns Foreigners
description: Facing what he called ''an avalanche of attacks on all fronts,'' President Hugo Chvez has threatened measures to silence foreign critics. ''I have given instructions that from today onward, any foreigner who comes here and says anything offensive against the nation or the government or the president or the people will be expelled from Venezuela,'' Mr. Chvez said in a speech to foreign businessmen and diplomats. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: 2 Charged In Hospital Scheme
description: Two men pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they bilked St. Vincent's Hospital out of more than $55,000 over three years. Armando Robles, the owner of Allied Communications, a telephone communications company based in Connecticut, and Mark McKierman, the hospital's former supervisor of communications, face first-degree larceny and conspiracy charges. Mr. Robles and Mr. McKierman are accused of overbilling the hospital for equipment and services and splitting the profits between them, according to an affidavit filed by Gregory Zigmont, an investigator from the office of the chief state's attorney. Another court date has been set for July 2, said Timothy Moynahan, Mr. McKierman's lawyer.

title: Dazzling Donovan Leading Earthquakes
description: LANDON DONOVAN is starting to display the attributes that many feel will make him the cornerstone of the San Jose Earthquakes in Major League Soccer and for the United States national team. Since he became a regular with the Earthquakes after he was signed by the league earlier this season, San Jose has gone 10 games without a loss.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lodi: Elderly Man Found Dead
description: An 87-year-old man who kept his apartment door unlocked was found dead Sunday night, apparently the victim of a beating. A neighbor had not seen the man, Edwin Parker, a retired laborer who lived alone, for several days, said Sharyn J. Peiffer, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor. The police found signs that Mr. Parker had been severely beaten, Ms. Peiffer said. An autopsy has not yet been completed. ''We're certainly treating it as a homicide,'' Ms. Peiffer said. ''That couldn't have happened from a fall.'' Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Peacekeepers in Kosovo Seize 19 Macedonia Rebel Suspects
description: NATO-led peacekeepers in Kosovo said today that over the weekend they detained 19 men suspected of belonging to the ethnic Albanian rebel army fighting government forces in Macedonia.

title: Wahid Reshuffles Cabinet to Aid Indonesian Economy
description: BANGKOK, June 12  In his latest bid to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia shuffled his economic team today, reassigning a chief minister who had clashed with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Article 2001061291393269113 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSSHOLDER, TERRY
description: MOSSHOLDER-Terry, 53, passed away of cancer on May 6. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 14 at 4 PM at the Park Avenue United Methodist Church on 106 East 86th St. A reception will occur at the church following the Memorial Service. Ms. Mossholder was a resident of New York City, where she was employed at American Express Tax and Business Services as a financial proofreader. She is survived by a sister, Judith Mossholder, of Chicago, IL. The interment will take place at the Masonic Cemetery in Des Moines, IA.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Mad Cow Disease Hearing
description: The City Council has scheduled a hearing on requiring city meat vendors to certify that meat sold to schools, centers for the elderly and other city services meet federal standards intended to prevent the occurrence of the human form of bovine spongiform encephalopathy. Committee room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7210.

title: Overlooking AIDS Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding Weights and Losing Weight
description: Many women who want to lose weight turn first to machines like the Stairmaster or the treadmill, while regarding strength training as a matter of toning muscles, building strength and staving off osteoporosis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot In Leg
description: A 42-year-old Brooklyn man suspected of groping two girls in his apartment was shot yesterday, the police said. There have been no arrests, but the police are seeking to question a member of the girls' family. The injured man, Marvin Henry, was shot in the left thigh on Sunday afternoon as he sat on a park bench across from his apartment at 2678 Linden Boulevard, the police said. Detectives were later told that two girls, ages 6 and 8, who live in Mr. Henry's building, had accused Mr. Henry of molesting them on Friday. After his release from Brookdale Hospital, Mr. Henry was arrested on sexual abuse charges. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Troubled in Los Angeles
description: To the Editor:

title: Proselytizing in the Schools
description: Barely a year after its proud decision refusing to allow organized student-led prayers before public high school football games, the Supreme Court lurched alarmingly in the opposite direction yesterday. It did so by allowing a religious use of public schools that will pose a far more serious practical threat to principles of religious neutrality and church-state separation.

title: $2.47 Billion Wins Bidding For Eircom Of Ireland
description: After six months of uncertainty, Eircom, Ireland's former state phone monopoly, accepted a $2.47 billion takeover bid from an investor group led by the prominent Irish businessman Sir Anthony O'Reilly and backed by the financier George Soros and Goldman Sachs.

title: Mr. Bush's European Debut
description: President Bush's five-day trip to Europe this week is shaping up as an important test of his foreign affairs leadership. It is the first major journey abroad for one of our least-traveled modern presidents, and could thus give him a fuller and firsthand understanding of the leaders and issues animating the European Continent. It also comes at a time when European leaders are distressed by the administration's early go-it-alone style on issues ranging from missile defense planning to the Kyoto treaty on global warming.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Sheila Leyne, co-director for the public relations group at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named senior vice president and director for public relations. She takes over duties that had been handled by Peter Greer, who left to become public relations principal at VIA Inc., Portland, Me.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Rebels Kill Official
description: Separatist guerrillas assassinated another official of Chechnya's pro-Russian government, riddling a village administrator with 17 bullets and shooting his wife in the legs. Ludman Madalov, the administrator of Valerik village, died in his home despite a Russian government effort to shield officials from assassins by giving them pistols and up to five guards. Some Chechen officials have quit in fear for their lives. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, JERRY
description: HARRIS-Jerry. A born and raised New Yorker, adulthood a Floridian, passed away June 9, 2001. He was my cousin and best friend. Rest in peace. Jules

title: Fashfile : A London Exhibition For 'Jar's'
description: LONDON  In a major coup, London will stage the first exhibition of the work of Joel Rosenthal, the greatest living jeweler, an American who has worked discreetly out of Paris under the name of "Jar's" since 1978. The show, which had originally been planned for the Musee des Arts Decoratifs in Paris, where Rosenthal's refined work in exuberantly colored gemstones is already in the permanent collection, will now open instead in spring 2002 at Somerset House in a deal pulled off by Jacob Rothschild.

title: Several Mets Meet Bush
description: Most of the Mets stayed in Florida yesterday on the off day before the team's game tonight in Baltimore. The seven who did not had a day they will never forget.

title: Justices Say Warrant Is Required In High-Tech Searches of Homes
description: In an important declaration of the constitutional limits on new privacy-threatening technology, the Supreme Court ruled today that the use by the police of a thermal imaging device to detect patterns of heat coming from a private home is a search that requires a warrant.

title: Aging With Burgers and Fries
description: To the Editor:

title: Players Are Complaining? It's the Open
description: The 72-hole test called the United States Open does not begin until Thursday, but some complaining has already begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHAN
description: WEISS-Stephan. Born September 16, 1938. Died on June 10th, 2001. Beloved husband of Donna Karan, father of Corey Weiss, Lisa WeissKeyes and Gabrielle Karan and grandfather of Mackenzie, Miles, Mercer, Etan and Maya Rose. An exceptional creator and co-founder of Donna Karan International, his wit, charm, intelligence and forward thinking impressed all who knew him. He will live on through the many whose lives he touched with his goodness and humanity. Funeral services will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to The Karan-Weiss Foundation, dedicated to benefiting medical research, education and the arts, C/O Urban Zen, LLC, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10018.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAUSMER, MORRIS
description: ZAUSMER-Morris. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Robert Zausmer and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: The Print:Human vs. Computer
description: PARIS  It is an argument as old as the machine age, but now conducted in cyberspace: Can a computer ever be as sensitive or light-handed as man/ woman?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about reactions abroad to President Bush and to American events that perplex Europeans misstated the action taken against his twin daughters recently under Texas liquor laws. The twins received misdemeanor citations; they were not arrested.

title: Fading Resource / Overfishing Feeds a Crisis : A Spanish Town's Livelihood Dies
description: BARBATE, Spain  Vincente Virue wanted to be a fisherman so badly that he used his older brother's ID to start working on a ship when he was 12, two years younger than the legal minimum age.

title: The Regulatory Signals Shift; F.T.C. Serves as Case Study of Differences Under Bush
description: Timothy J. Muris, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, watched with his newly assembled staff from the back of the crowded room last week as his predecessor, Robert Pitofsky, delivered his valedictory address after six years leading the agency.

title: INSIDE
description: Rebels Say American Is Dead

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Ruling on Limits on Surveillance Technology
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that the police must obtain a warrant before using a heat-sensing device to search for illegal activity in a home. The vote in Kyllo v. United States was 5 to 4. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote the majority opinion, and Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the dissent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRY, CAROL BERNSTEIN
description: FERRY-Carol Bernstein, 76. Peacefully ended her own life on June 9, 2001 as she was suffering from cancer and advanced lung disease. A resident of Rye, she was the widow of Daniel J. Bernstein and W. H. Ferry. She leaves two children, Katherine and John Bernstein, and four stepchildren, Dennie LaTourelle, Fay Bisno, Robin Ferry, and Lucien Ferry. Contributions to the Correctional Association, 135 East 15 Street, NY NY 10003, or Wespac, PO Box 488, White Plains, NY 10602, would be gratefully welcomed. A memorial gathering will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 60 Street, New York City, on Wednesday, June 27, 2001 at 5:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, GEORGE T.
description: SIMON-George T. A Jazz Memorial Service celebrating the life of Grammy winner, George T. Simon (1912-2001), featuring the music of Dr. Billy Taylor, Helen Merrill and others, will be held at 1 PM, on June 14, 2001 at Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, entrance on 54th Street.

title: Max Kennedy, Citing Family, Pulls Out of Race for House
description: Maxwell Taylor Kennedy unexpectedly announced today that he was giving up his months-long flirtation with a run for Congress. He had looked into his three young children's eyes, he said, and decided that this was the wrong time to enter politics.

title: Israel's Business Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Profit
description: Daewoo Motor announced an operating profit for last month of $10.4 million. The figure, twice as high as the operating profit reported by the bankrupt company in April, was expected to improve the bargaining position of the company's creditors in talks with General Motors. Although the company still lost $20.4 million in the first five months of the year, company officials said they hoped to show a profit for the year. Negotiators for General Motors and Daewoo Motor's creditors are working on a memorandum of understanding that will form the basis for final talks that would give G.M. control of the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Harassment Recourse
description: To the Editor:

title: For Depressed Women, a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeman Wins Commercial Honors
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York won the most honors in the agency category at the 10th annual show sponsored by the Association of Independent Commercial Producers in New York, honoring work on television commercials.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Too Close an Encounter

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Sworn In
description: Silvio Berlusconi took the oath of office yesterday as prime minister of Italy's 59th government since 1945 and prepared for his first step onto the international stage at NATO and European Union summit meetings this week. The conservative media baron heads a cabinet that includes Umberto Bossi, the right-wing leader of the Northern League, as minister of reform. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Williams's Anguish Receding Slowly
description: Yesterday would have been the birthday of Bernie Williams's father. Bernabe Williams Sr. would have turned 74, and his son, the Yankee center fielder, realized on Sunday that he would have spent much of the past week deciding what gift to buy his father, what card to express his feelings. At some point yesterday, Williams would have telephoned his parents' home in Vega Alta, P.R., to wish his father happy birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLINARI, GEORGE F.
description: MOLINARI-George F. (Co-owner of Frank's Restaurant, 85 10th Avenue, Manhattan). Beloved husband of Liza (nee Crane). Devoted father of Peter, Matthew and Victoria Leigh. Loving son of Gloria (nee Poggi) and the late George. Dear brother of Regina Marks, Christopher, James and Steven. Reposing at Martin Hughes Funeral Home, 530 Narrows Rd. South, Staten Island. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 PM and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral mass Thursday 10 AM at Our Lady of Good Council Church. Interment in Moravian Cemetery, Peter C. DeLuca, Director. In lieu of flowers please call 718-447-0873.

title: A Young Pitcher Tries to Re-enter the Zone
description: In the early morning sunlight, the baseball tossed into the cloudless blue sky looked like a mini-moon that had lost its way. It went up and up, sailing well over the head of the intended receiver, a middle-aged coach with a catcher's mitt. The strong, loose-limbed young pitcher who had thrown the ball watched the flight with some dismay. It was not the first time he had seen a ball take off as though it contained a maddening inner spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNER, JERRY
description: STERNER-Jerry. Dear Jerry, we will miss you. Pat and Fritz

title: Guarding Underwater Treasures
description: Blue and lime green waters as far as the eye can see, brilliant in the strong spring sunshine, make this one of the most remote national parks in the continental United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about reactions abroad to President Bush and to American events that perplex Europeans misstated the action taken against his twin daughters recently under Texas liquor laws. The twins received misdemeanor citations; they were not arrested.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil climbed as storm damage at Texas refineries raised concern that gasoline supplies might be disrupted. In New York, crude oil for July delivery rose 71 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $29.04 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, TRUDY
description: HERSH-Trudy. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Sandra Domnitz and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Foreign Affairs; Zorba the Euro
description: Greece provides a wonderful laboratory for the most interesting clash going on around Europe today -- the clash between two grand theories. One is Francis Fukuyama's notion that with the triumph of liberal democracy and free-market capitalism over all other systems, history has ended -- in the sense that if your country wants to prosper now there is only one road. And the other is Samuel Huntington's ''Clash of Civilizations'' -- the notion that culture matters in how, or whether, a country adopts capitalism or democracy, and that the cultural and religious fault lines of old will become the new fault lines of the post-cold-war world.

title: New Merger Rules Force Railroads to Give Assurance of Competition
description: Federal regulators yesterday adopted tougher standards for mergers among major railroads that will force the few remaining rail freight companies with more than $250 million in yearly revenue to give written assurances that combining their operations will actually increase competition.

title: Citigroup to Face Class-Action Suit
description: A federal judge has certified a group of class-action cases against the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup Inc., allowing former employees in four states to move ahead with claims that the company confiscated employee wages.

title: The President's Trip And the Values Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Hepatitis Suit Filed
description: Four days after city officials disclosed a hepatitis C outbreak at a Brooklyn clinic, two clinic patients said yesterday that they were suing the clinic. City officials said eight patients at the Bay Ridge Endoscopy and Digestive Health Center had tested positive for hepatitis C, a potentially serious liver disease, but that the disease was unlikely to spread to the general population. Deborah Postler, one of the original eight patients who tested positive for hepatitis, and her husband, Stephen, who is still being tested for the illness, filed their class-action suit for unspecified damages in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Dr. Vincent Rovito, the clinic's owner and a defendant, could not be reached for comment.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Wednesday, about the futurist Faith B. Popcorn, whose best seller, ''EVEolution,'' is being published in paperback this month, misstated her age. She is 58, not 54.

title: Stellex Files Bankruptcy Recovery Plan
description: Stellex Technologies Inc. has filed a bankruptcy recovery plan that the company, an aerospace and military contractor, says will enable it to emerge from Chapter 11 as an independent company.

title: Brazil in the Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNETLEGAL BATTLE OVER INTERNET MUSIC ESCALATES A recording industry trade group filed a countersuit in a Manhattan federal court Friday against a group of Internet broadcasters in an intensifying legal battle over the payment structure for music played on the Web. At issue is whether Web broadcasters that allow users to personalize the music they hear should require a separately negotiated license from the record companies or whether they should be eligible for compulsory licensing like traditional radio. The Recording Industry Association of America, which represents some of the music industry's biggest labels, has argued that Web broadcasters like MTVi , MusicMatch and Xact Radio provide services that violate the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. Through their trade group, the Webcasters said last week that they were "disappointed that the recording industry has chosen to initiate another in a long line of lawsuits." Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: For Depressed Women, a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Stifled Campus Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Conservative Candidate Enters City's Mayoral Race
description: Terrance M. Gray, a lawyer from Queens, announced yesterday that he was running for mayor with the support of the city's Conservative Party. He attacked Michael R. Bloomberg as a Democrat masquerading as a Republican in his own bid for mayor, and pledged to run a full-throated campaign to fill what he said was an absence of conservative voices in this year's crowded mayoral field.

title: 2 Interpublic Agencies Are Reorganizing
description: Two agencies are making organizational changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, TILLIE
description: GOLDMAN-Tillie. Born in 1906, Tillie was a sophisticated child of the new century, an All American girl who loved NYC, FDR, George Gershwin and Central Park. We'll miss her. Survived by daughter, Barbara Londin, sons, Marc and Tony Goldman, daughter-in-law, Janet, grandchildren, Victoria, Rick, Robert, Cara, Jessica, Scott, Joey, Thea, Charlie, Lydia and Jonathan, great-grandchildren, Sophie, Zoe, Jake and Joshua. Benefactor of Brandeis University, the Israel Museum, Yeshiva University, Metropolitan Museum of Art and Kibbutz Eilon.

title: An Expert on Health Care Evaluates His Own Case
description: Through his research on quality assessment in medicine, Dr. Avedis Donabedian of the University of Michigan became internationally known for his emphasis on the way the health care system functioned and how it might be improved.

title: Birth Control, From 'Womb Veils' to Lysol
description: ''Devices and Desires: A History of Contraceptives in America,'' by Andrea Tone, Hill and Wang, $30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIN, ESTHER
description: KUNIN-Esther. On June 10, 2001. Born on May 25, 1902. Loving wife of 51 years to the late Julius Kunin. Cherished mother of Leonard Kunin & the late Yvette Abramowitz. Beloved grandmother of Jeffrey and Chavi Kunin, Marc and Naomi Kunin, Lori and Shalom Huberfeld, Amy and Myron Eagle, Karen and Abbi Neuman. Great-grandmother of 12. Shiva will be observed at the Kunin residence until Sunday morning, June 17.

title: Article 2001061293026519461 -- No Title
Conoco Plans Asian Expansion
description: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest oil company in the United States, said today that it would spend $50 million a year in Malaysia to build 20 gasoline stations a year for the next three to four years.

title: Europe Seems More Open To G.E. Merger
description: The General Electric Company's $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International Inc. has a ''reasonable chance'' of winning European approval, the head of the European Commission's antitrust department said today.

title: Lauder Media Company Faces a Federal Inquiry
description: A company owned by Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics heir and former New York City mayoral candidate, is under investigation by federal prosecutors over allegations that it paid at least $1 million in bribes to Ukrainian officials for a valuable television license, according to lawyers and Justice Department documents.

title: In Virginia, Young Conservatives Learn How to Develop and Use Their Political Voices
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The art of selling conservatism as compassion is taught here, a few miles from the White House, at boot camp for young conservatives who aspire to power.

title: 42 Arrested During Fracas After Parade
description: Hours after Sunday's National Puerto Rican Day Parade, an event that by most accounts was a glowing success, the police became embroiled in a series of confrontations with several hundred revelers who kept the celebration going in their Bronx neighborhood.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR LITTLE CHANGED. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 85.05 cents, down from 85.07 cents on Friday. The dollar was unchanged at 120.69 yen.

title: Hearing 'The Iliad' With a Co-Creator's Ears
description: The work of the British poet Christopher Logue has always been ear theater, from his first book more than 50 years ago. The poems are full of snatches of story in many voices that demand to be heard, not read. So it can be no accident that he fell captive to ''The Iliad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSBARDT, HAROLD (NAPPY)
description: GROSSBARDT-Harold (Nappy). Co-Founder of Colony Records on Broadway. Loving husband of Estelle, devoted father of Michael and Alan and their wives Leslie and Jo and proud grandfather of A.J. Dear brother of Dorothy, Jerry and the late Ernie. Funeral in Florida.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Kimes Extradition Hearing
description: Sante Kimes, a grifter serving 120 years in an upstate New York prison for the murder of a Manhattan socialite, will appear on Wednesday in a Westchester court to fight her extradition to California. She and her son Kenneth, who has already been extradited, are to stand trial there on murder charges and could face the death penalty if convicted. Ms. Kimes, 66, is expected to argue that a different woman with the same name is the one sought by California officials. A judge noted that because the California warrant has differing birth dates, Ms. Kimes, who is known to have used multiple identities, is due a hearing. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Jury May Be Divided on Death Penalty in Embassy Case
description: A federal jury in Manhattan signaled yesterday that it might be unable to reach a unanimous decision on whether to impose the death penalty on a Saudi man convicted of 213 counts of murder in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Kenya.

title: Women Stretched Thin In the 'Vanity-Free Zone'
description: GETTING A LIFE

title: Addenda: Deutsch to Close Office in Boston
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York, in its first significant contraction, said yesterday that it would close its Boston office, which has been open only since July 2000, on July 11.

title: Tracing Origins of All Arthropods Great and Small
description: SO what it boils down to, the mad scientist was asked -- after a dazzling, dizzying disquisition tumbling through DNA, genomes, phylogeny, taxonomy, sequence matching, time warps, string edits, macromolecules, trilobites and later arthropods, ray tracing problems, how you can tell which medieval monastery a manuscript was copied in by the errors, mostly spelling, the monks kept making and the 280 powerful slave servers chained together in the basement -- is that lobsters and bugs are related?

title: Inquiry Widens Over Supply Of Natural Gas to California
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, reversing an earlier decision, agreed yesterday to examine whether the El Paso Corporation, the nation's largest natural gas pipeline company, skewed the bidding for a large amount of pipeline capacity to ship gas to California so that its own subsidiary would win the auction.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ALLIED HOLDINGS, Decatur, Ga., named Hugh E. Sawyer president and chief executive, succeeding Robert J. Rutland, who remains chairman. Mr. Sawyer had been president and chief executive at Aegis Communications Group.

title: For Depressed Women, a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; A Room And a View (Libertarian)
description: DOES Joan E. Mazzola deserve to join the list of New York's 10 Worst Tenants? That is a tricky moral question. She may be an illegal profiteer, but it can also be argued -- in fact, it has been argued by an eminent philosopher -- that her actions have been promoting the greater social good.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sony And Universal Rename Music Service
description: Sony Music Entertainment and the Universal Music Group said yesterday that they had renamed their online subscription service Pressplay, and said they planned to start it in late summer, even as questions linger about just how harmonious the relationship between the record labels is shaping up to be. The service, expected to offer on-demand music on a subscription basis, had been known as Duet, but the parties said that was merely a working title. The service is scheduled to go head-to-head with subscription services born out of MusicNet, a competing service under development by the three other record labels, EMI, BMG and AOL Time Warner, in partnership with RealNetworks. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Article 2001061293642649250 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: Auto Dealers Are Accused Of Cheating 286 Buyers
description: New Jersey officials sued 16 car dealerships owned or operated by the same businessman today, accusing them of cheating customers out of $350,000 over the past six years.

title: Lawsuit Cites Contradictions in a Rare Retirement Benefit
description: For thousands of retired police officers, firefighters and correction officers in New York, the city's most oddly structured and awkwardly named retirement benefit -- the Variable Supplement Funds -- is a fruit of maturity more valued than early-bird specials or afternoon naps.

title: Front Row; Viva Fashion!
description: Not cherry, not fire engine, not flame -- the signifying color for urban streets this summer is flag red. Worn jauntily in the form of pedal pushers, baggies, slit skirts and the now-obligatory bra top, it is always in tandem with something crisply white. The combination could be called yachty, patriotic, Sara Murphy in Juan-les-Pins, or else an unwitting nod to the superhip boutique hotel, the Townhouse in Miami, decorated by the supercool India Mahdavi.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Millennium Radio Buys Again
description: While yet to broadcast a sound, the newly formed Millennium Radio Group L.L.C. said yesterday that it was continuing efforts to build a nationwide network, with the planned acquisition of five more stations in New Jersey. Millennium, an Amherst-based partnership between the Swiss bank UBS A.G.'s UBS Capital Americas unit and Mercury Capital Partners, jointly announced its formation and the acquisition of three stations in March. Last week, it announced it would acquire three more stations and an operating agreement for a fourth, all in New Jersey. Yesterday, Nassau Broadcasting Partners in Princeton confirmed that it had agreed to sell Millennium five stations clustered along the Jersey Shore, WJLK-FM, WADB-AM, WOBM-FM, WOBM-AM and WBBO-FM, for $90 million cash. All the deals must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Phasing Out Nuclear Power
description: The government signed an agreement with power companies that calls for shutting down nuclear power plants during the next 20 years. Anti-nuclear critics say the plan will take too long to carry out; supporters of nuclear power warn that it could deprive the country of an important way to reduce greenhouse gases from coal-burning generators.

title: Four Injured, One Critically, In a Shootout In Brooklyn
description: Wild gunfire erupted yesterday evening on the streets of East New York in Brooklyn, leaving four men injured, one critically with a wound to the jaw, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVITT, FAY. A. W.
description: LEAVITT-Fay. A. W. On June 11, age 89. Beloved wife of Saul M. Married June 21, 1942. Mother of Leonard James. Grandmother of James and Keith Dorsette and Marcel and Vera James. Sister of Pearl Harris and sister-in-law of Sam Harris of Cherry Hill, NJ. A woman of valor. Friend to all. Member of Town and Village Synagogue. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADDAD, MARY LOU (NEE SCORSONE)
description: HADDAD-Mary Lou (nee Scorsone). On June 10, 2001, after a long illness. She has been a teacher at P.S. 142 in Manhattan since 1984. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Jamil R. Haddad, three sons, Ralph, John, and James, and five grandchildren. She is also survived by her mother, Mary, and her brother, John Scorsone. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass will be on Monday June 18, at 10 A.M. at Saint Anselm R.C. Church, Bay Ridge, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Mary Lou Haddad Memorial Fund at P.S. 142.

title: Management Firm Formed
description: Sarah Ketterer and Harry Hartford, who resigned last week from the Los Angeles office of Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, have opened a new money management firm, Causeway Capital Management L.L.C. Ms. Ketterer, Causeway's chief executive, and Mr. Hartford, its president, will serve as co-chief investment officers at the new firm. Causeway, based in Los Angeles, will focus mainly on managing assets for institutional investors, including pension plans and endowments, the company said. At Merrill, Ms. Ketterer and Mr. Hartford led a team that managed about $3.5 billion in international equity assets, including the Mercury HW International Value Fund.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was almost like the Devil was inside him looking at us.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Two More U.N. Workers Charged
description: Two more employees of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees in Nairobi have been charged with extorting money from people seeking to resettle in the United States and Europe. Three arrested in April are also accused of threatening to kill the American ambassador and four other people. More than 20 workers have been suspended. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Article 2001061294186377560 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Stock Analyst Conduct Code Due
description: The Securities Industry Association is set to release a code of conduct for stock research today that will urge Wall Street firms to limit ties between analysts and their investment banking businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SEYMOUR
description: GOLDBERG-Seymour, 87. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. On June 10, 2001. He is a graduate of Townes & Harris, City College of N.Y. and St. John's Law School. He was Master of the John Hancock Lodge #

title: For Depressed Women, a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: New Manhattan High School Is Planned, but It Has Critics
description: The Board of Education is planning to create an old-fashioned neighborhood high school, once considered an endangered species, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, under an agreement announced yesterday by the Board of Education and a group of elected officials.

title: Well, Their Names Are Similar, So That's a Start
description: In October 1988 Richard E. Byrd Jr., the son of Admiral Byrd, the polar explorer, was discovered dead in a Baltimore warehouse. After boarding a Washington-bound train from Boston, where he lived, to attend a ceremony honoring his father, he had gotten off at the wrong stop and been missing for nearly three weeks. Age 68 and evidently suffering from Alzheimer's disease, he had wandered around the city and eventually died of malnutrition. A janitor in the same warehouse where he died had chased him out several days earlier.

title: Bill to Tighten Bankruptcy Gets a Push
description: Legislation that would rewrite the nation's bankruptcy laws and make it harder for people to erase their debts has begun to advance again on Capitol Hill, a result both of the Democratic takeover of the Senate and a renewed lobbying campaign for the bill by banks and credit card companies.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Legal Battle Over Internet Music Escalates
description: A recording industry trade group filed a countersuit in a Manhattan federal court Friday against a group of Internet broadcasters in an intensifying legal battle over the payment structure for music played on the Web. At issue is whether Web broadcasters that allow users to personalize the music they hear should require a separately negotiated license from the record companies or whether they should be eligible for compulsory licensing like traditional radio. The Recording Industry Association of America, which represents some of the music industry's biggest labels, has argued that Web broadcasters like MTVi, MusicMatch and Xact Radio provide services that violate the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. Through their trade group, the Webcasters said last week that they were ''disappointed that the recording industry has chosen to initiate another in a long line of lawsuits.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Quixotes All, From Kindly to Fussy
description: Young love and aged cupidity took over the ballet stage yet again on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House with the American Ballet Theater production of ''Don Quixote.'' This ''Don Quixote,'' staged by the company director Kevin McKenzie and Susan Jones, has retained a great deal of the sunny good humor of Mikhail Baryshnikov's 1978 version for Ballet Theater.

title: 'Constructive Criticism We Must All Heed'
description: Dr. Gilbert Omenn, chief executive of the University of Michigan Health System, wrote this assessment of Dr. Donabedian's views:

title: Justices' Ruling Is Good News to Small Town's Pastor
description: To the Rev. Stephen D. Fournier, religion was never the issue when he sued the local school district five years ago for refusing to allow a children's Bible-study group from his church to meet at school after classes.

title: UNIT OF OFFICE DEPOT PLANS SALES PUSH IN SWITZERLAND
description: A unit of Office Depot Inc. plans to sell office supplies in Switzerland through direct-mail advertising and over the Internet, Office Depot said yesterday. The unit, Viking Office Products, is setting up a center with 30 employees to take telephone orders and a warehouse to serve Switzerland's German- and French-speaking regions, Office Depot said. Viking plans to mail 240,000 catalogs listing 3,500 products later this year or early in 2002 and will also set up a Web site. Office Depot is based in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Profiling Report Released
description: The State Senate Judiciary Committee is urging that New Jersey become the first state to outlaw consent searches, in which police officers ask drivers' permission to search their vehicles. In its 116-page report on racial profiling, the committee said that as early as 1994, minority-group drivers underwent ''consent searches at inordinately high, indeed, disparate rates.'' The committee urged Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, left, to ban the searches by executive order. Senate Democrats said the report did not go far enough because it did not propose legislation to outlaw the searches should Mr. DiFrancesco fail to act. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JULIUS
description: GOLDSTEIN-Julius. Died June 7, 2001, in Petworth, England, at 83. Artist, teacher, quintessential New Yorker, irreverent wit, baseball enthusiast, ardent movie goer, cherished friend and colleague. He will be much missed. Hunter College Arts Department

title: Warming Threat Requires Action Now, Scientists Say
description: In his speech on climate yesterday, President Bush said that a basic problem with the Kyoto Protocol, the proposed international pact for curtailing global warming, was that it laid out a timetable for cutting releases of heat-trapping gases before the threat posed by a buildup of those gases was clearly understood.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank Shares Fall
description: Shares in Banca di Roma fell 2.4 percent amid concern about the resignation of Carlo Salvatori as chief executive of the bank, Italy's fourth largest. The stock fell 0.10 euro, to 4.09 euros, its lowest level since January 1998. Mr. Salvatori, who turns 60 in July, stepped down Friday after just six months as chief executive, citing personal reasons.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: ACOMPROMISE ON BILTMORE BLOCK Neighborhood leaders have reached a compromise with developers who proposed to renovate the historic Biltmore Theater, on 47th Street near Eighth Avenue, in exchange for permission to increase the height of an apartment building they plan to build next to it. The deal, which goes before Community Board 5 on Thursday, calls for the building to be limited to 55 stories instead of the 61 stories originally proposed by the development team, led by the Jack Parker Corporation. Councilwoman Christine A. Quinn, who oversaw the negotiations, said she would fight to restrict the height to 53 stories when the project comes before the Council. The developers' spokesman, Martin McLaughlin, said they had agreed to pay about $14 million of the projected $20 million cost to renovate the Biltmore, which has been closed since 1987. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Philadelphia Journal; A Tentative City's Chance to Reach High
description: The Phillies are in first place, but fans are indifferent. Baseball can wait. The N.B.A. finals are here, and this city is all Sixers, all the time.

title: Where the Money Goes
description: To the Editor:

title: San Alberto Journal; Local Cry: An Awful Lot of Brazilians in Paraguay
description: The billboard on the outskirts of town announces the dates of dances and bingo games, but in Portuguese rather than in Spanish. Most products on sale in local supermarkets are of Brazilian origin, as is the mayor and many leading business owners.

title: BUSH'S COMMISSION ON SOCIAL SECURITY MAY PROPOSE CAPS
description: The co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission said today that they would probably have to propose politically difficult steps like raising the retirement age and reducing cost of living adjustments when they make recommendations to the White House for restoring the system's long-term financial health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, MAX
description: ROTHENBERG-Max. Died peacefully at his home in Miami Beach, Fl. Devoted husband of the late Judith; beloved brother of the late Anne and Charles Rothenberg; father of Peter; proud grandfather of Daniel and Jason; loving uncle of Arthur and Nancy and great uncle of Richard, Robert and David. Graveside services Tuesday, 11am at Mt Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: More People Falling Behind On Mortgage Payments

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, STANLEY
description: SCHIFF-Stanley. Round Dune Coop, East Quogue, NY, mourns the loss of our dear friend. Gale Spitalnik, President

title: Public Interests; Dr. Pangloss, I Presume?
description: Explaining the Bush administration's enthusiasm for nuclear power plants, Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill recently said: ''If you set aside Three Mile Island and Chernobyl, the safety record of nuclear is really very good.''

title: The Tenacious Hold Of Repression in Iran
description: As Mohammad Khatami campaigned across Iran before his re-election last Friday, claiming his government never compromised on its pledge to establish democracy, one of his closest aides was attacked in his car by hard-line vigilantes, a man accused of spying for the United States was executed and a woman was stoned to death for staring in lewd films.

title: Stocks Mount Impressive Rebound After Morning Slump
description: The stock market recovered this afternoon from an early sell-off, with its leading indexes ending the day with little change, as investors regained their footing after Nokia became the latest technology company to warn that its earnings and revenue would be weaker than Wall Street was expecting in the second quarter.

title: Engaging With Russia
description: During his trip to Europe, President Bush is sure to face questions from Europeans about where Russian-American relations are going. Strategic issues presently dominate the way the American and Russian governments deal with each other. But over time this focus needs to, and is likely to, broaden.

title: A Loser Neither Bloody Nor Unbowed
description: Just as the quadrennial Van Cliburn International Piano Competition was heading into its final weekend in Fort Worth, a star of the 1997 Cliburn, Jan Gottlieb Jiracek, turned up at Alice Tully Hall to give a dazzling performance of the Liszt E flat major Concerto with the Riverside Symphony. Mr. Jiracek was a favorite among critics and other music professionals as well as with the audience in 1997, and he was the clear winner in an informal press room poll, but the jury apparently thought otherwise. That he was not awarded one of the top three prizes seemed proof that the mechanisms for selecting the most original and exciting players in competitions are fatally flawed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, STEPHEN E.
description: ROSEN-Stephen E. Died on June 7, 2001, at age 53. Daddy to Zoe Allison Rosen, and friend to many. Celebration of the life of Stephen Rosen will be held at The 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, Warburg Lounge, at 4:30 P.M., Thursday, June 14th.

title: For Depressed Women, a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Row: A Dangerous Chalice for Young Designers
description: While most women could not tell you that Bruce is a clothing line or, more specifically, that it is a line meant to evoke a woman who spent her girlhood dreaming of becoming Mrs. Joey Ramone, most in the fashion world could quickly arrive at a description that would be pretty close.

title: Sequestering Juries
description: To the Editor:

title: Partnerships Restore City Parks, Within Limits
description: Four years ago, Madison Square Park in Manhattan was woefully run-down, with broken benches and a dust bowl of a lawn. Today, when the park reopens after four years of renovations, the historic fountain off East 23rd Street will again spurt water and a new reflecting pond will shimmer on the park's opposite end. The six-acre, 19th-century square has been planted with 15,000 shrubs, flowering plants and trees.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: RealNetworks In Deal With Cisco
description: RealNetworks said yesterday that Cisco Systems Inc. had agreed to incorporate RealNetworks audio and video broadcasting technology into Cisco products that deliver sound and video over the Internet. RealNetworks makes software and other technology that enables companies to distribute various audio and video formats over the Internet. Cisco also agreed to market technology from RealNetworks to Internet service providers to help network providers speed up the distribution of large audio and video files. Shares of Real Networks dropped 42 cents on Monday, closing at $11.67. Cisco fell 11 cents, closing at $20.38. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Hawaiian Cruises
description: The Hawaiian word for thank you is mahalo, and American Hawaii Cruises may leave a few passengers saying that with its Mahalo Fares, available on seven-night cruises on its 860-passenger Independence out of Kahului, Maui, from April 7 through Dec. 29. The fares start at $659 a person, double occupancy, for inside cabins and from $709 for ocean-view cabins. This does not include air fare, port charges or taxes. They are subject to availability and cannot be combined with early-booking discounts. The Independence stops at Hilo and Kona on Hawaii, Honolulu, and Nawiliwili on Kauai. Information: (800) 765-7000 or www.cruisehawaii.com .

title: Implausibly on Tape: Women's Final in Paris
description: There is no fairness in NBC's carrying the French Open men's final live but the women's final on tape.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Bush Calls Vote Report Dishonest
description: Gov. Jeb Bush attacked a report criticizing the contested presidential election in his state as ''intellectually dishonest.'' The report by the United States Commission on Civil Rights, released on Friday, said the Florida officials ignored problems that denied the right to vote to countless residents, most of them black. Governor Bush said the report ''needlessly fosters racial disharmony.'' ''The time for meaningless and divisive finger-pointing over last year's election is over,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Friday about a deal in which Loudeye Technologies will help Napster distribute music online referred incorrectly to Loudeye's involvement with ''fingerprinting'' software, which assigns each music file a unique identifier. Loudeye will provide a digital music library that works with the software; it will not make the software.

title: Is This the Woman to Rescue Harper's Bazaar?
description: FOR nearly all of her career, Glenda Bailey, the new editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, has had the distinction of being a thorn among roses. Though smart, with a belligerent truthful streak that has helped propel her to the top of fashion publishing, she has suffered, especially in her native England, from not looking more fashionably smart. Prominent teeth flash with intermittent bursts of laughter, and her country-girl face is framed by dense, reddish curls that she has refused to straighten.

title: Crime and Psychotherapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Protest Against New Textbooks
description: Hundreds of people gathered in Tokyo, locking arms and singing ''We Shall Overcome'' to protest the adoption of textbooks they say whitewash Japan's World War II history. The protesters, who included Japanese, South Koreans, Chinese and Filipinos, surrounded the Education Ministry to denounce the middle-school books. China and the Koreas have demanded that Japan reject or amend them. Howard French (NYT)

title: Learning the Hard Way
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about New York's laws against domestic violence misstated actions taken last week by the State Senate. It voted to make permanent a law requiring police officers to arrest anyone suspected of domestic abuse. And it applied the mandatory arrest provision to all domestic partners, including same-sex couples. The Senate did not extend antidiscrimination laws to lesbians and gay men.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Wear to Work? Facing the Casual-Dress Quandary
description: Can casual wear affect professionalism in the office? The verdict is still out on that question, but some people are wondering if the jeans-are-O.K. culture that spread in the late 1990's from the dot-com world to mainstream workplaces has gone too far.

title: LIFE FOR TERRORIST IN EMBASSY ATTACK
description: A terrorist convicted of 213 counts of murder in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Kenya will be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole because a federal jury in Manhattan said it was deadlocked yesterday on whether to impose the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGERSON, RICHARD
description: SIGERSON-Richard. Died peacefully at home on June 12, 2001, aged 84. Adoring husband of Yola Miller Sigerson, father of Andra Patterson, Adam, Gabriel and Davitt Sigerson and grandfather of Julia, Andrew, Lio, Jennifer and Milena. Science writer, editor and publisher; founder of the Medical and Pharmaceutical Information Bureau; founding editor of The Sciences, for the New York Academy of Sciences; editor and publisher of Medical Opinion and Review, Geriatric Focus, Hospital Focus, Issues and Science Fortnightly. The fiercest intelligence, the strongest spirit, the most loving heart-he took such intense pleasure in living. Friends and family will meet on Friday afternoon. For information please call Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 212-289-2221.

title: The Checks Are Bouncing At 'Bells Are Ringing'
description: Closing a Broadway show is never easy, but the final days of the revival of ''Bells Are Ringing'' were apparently especially rocky, with a rash of bounced checks causing hostility between the musical's producers and its cast and crew.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Teenage Pregnancy Rate Falls
description: The rate of teenage pregnancy in the United States in 1997 dropped to its lowest level in 20 years, new figures from the National Center for Health Statistics at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show. Teenage pregnancy dropped 19 percent from its peak in 1990, to 94.3 pregnancies per thousand teenagers from 116.5. The decline was attributed to increased use of condoms and implantable contraceptives, as well as a leveling-off in sexual activity. The figures cover 1990 to 1997, the latest years for which complete data is available. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about tax rebates this year misstated the amount to be received by those entitled to only a partial rebate -- that is, people who owed some taxes but had taxable income below $6,000 (below $10,000 in the case of a single parent or $12,000 for a couple). The check will be 5 percent of their taxable income for 2000, not 5 percent of their 2000 tax bill.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: 18 Accused In Drug Ring
description: Culminating a months-long investigation, federal authorities yesterday arrested 18 people accused of selling crack cocaine from a cafe and private home in South Norwalk. The arrests were part of a joint effort between the South Norwalk police and the United States attorney's office in Connecticut to cut into the sale of crack in that part of the state, said John A. Danaher, the United States attorney in New Haven. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: The Battle for Purity on Long Island
description: THE grapes have barely begun to grow in Long Island's vineyards this year. Even so, there are ample signs that the whole young industry is in a state of vigorous ferment. Not in the wine cellars, but in the winery offices, around dinner tables and over lunch in local restaurants. At issue is what constitutes Long Island wine.

title: Wanna Escape the Life? Not a Chance, Mate
description: At the start of ''Sexy Beast,'' Gal (Ray Winstone), a heavyset, middle-aged English hoodlum, is enjoying a carefree retirement on the Mediterranean coast of Spain. Yes, a boulder has tumbled into his swimming pool, smashing the tilework and narrowly missing Gal himself, but this seems more like an inconvenience than an ill omen. Gal spends his time sunbathing on his patio, dining out with his friends, Aitch and Jackie (Cavan Kendall and Julianne White), and dancing in the moonlight with his beloved wife, Deedee (Amanda Redman). He's happy to have left England (''What a toilet!'') and the dodgy life he led there.

title: Computers Here, There, Everywhere
description: WHILE I.B.M. , Microsoft and Sun Microsystems are seeking to transform the Internet, academic researchers are undertaking more fundamental design projects that are closer to the view of transparent software and Xerox's pervasive computing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, HYMAN
description: WEBER-Hyman. Beloved husband of 63 years, devoted father, brother, uncle, grandfather, and great grandfather. Services 2 P.M. Wednesday, June 13, 2001 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Malaysia's 'Great Builder' Faces Growing Dissent
description: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia  As he nears the anniversary of two decades in power, Mahathir bin Mohamad spends most of his time in a newly built, green-domed office overlooking the beginnings of a grand city being built from scratch.

title: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; Flying Higher In Cheap Seats
description: IN the three years since SouthTrust Bank's most frequent travelers began booking their corporate travel online, the company has enjoyed what it described as ''significant savings.'' And three months ago, after allowing -- encouraging, actually -- those employees who travel on business to book online, the bank, based in Birmingham, Ala., found that the percentage of those who used the service soared to about 40 percent from about 1 percent.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Tea is the Beverage in Residence
description: To the Japanese, tea is a serious subject, and this month and next Takashimaya, the Japanese department store at 693 Fifth Avenue (55th Street) is devoting its ground floor to it. There are Japanese iron tea pots ($65), Chinese pottery teapots ($45 and up), tea canisters with hand-painted decorations ($45 and up), cherry bark tea scoops ($5), books about tea, vintage photographs of tea plantations, and dozens of fine Japanese and Chinese teas.

title: It's Lights, Camera, Economic Analysis!
description: FROM where Kate Bohner was standing, E*Trade Group did not appear to have reinvented electronic communications.

title: Sixers Looking for a Repeat of History
description: Allen Iverson zoomed around the Spectrum today, stopping, starting and slicing as if he were shaking defenders. But Iverson was not on the court with the ball in his hands. He was in a golf cart, wearing a skullcap, dark shades and a smile.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: An Honor And A Barb For Yeltsin
description: President Vladimir V. Putin decorated his predecessor, Boris N. Yeltsin, with a new medal marking his service to the nation, but not before noting implicitly that Mr. Yeltsin's nine-year tenure failed to improve people's lives. ''Everything we endured over the last decade,'' Mr. Putin said, ''shows one thing: any reform only makes sense when it serves the people.'' Mr. Yeltsin received the medal, the Order of Merit of the Fatherland, First Grade, at a ceremony marking Russia Day, an observance of Russia's 1990 declaration that it would pursue democracy within the Soviet Union. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTS, NATHANIEL N.
description: HERTS-Nathaniel N. Attorney, died peacefully on June 11, at the Jewish Home for the Aged in New York City just before celebrating his 93rd birthday. A memorial gathering will be held Saturday, June 16, 11 AM at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring St., NYC.

title: Governor to Seek Harsher Penalties for Perjurers in Criminal Cases
description: Responding to notorious cases of innocent people being convicted of crimes on the basis of false testimony, Gov. George E. Pataki plans to propose tougher penalties for perjury in criminal cases, aides to the governor said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, JUDITH
description: RICHARDS-Judith. Congregation Beth Elohim and all the participants in the Early Childhood Center record with profound sorrow the passing of their beloved teacher, Judith Richards. Memorial service to take place at the Temple House on Monday June 18th at 10:00AM. For information please call 718-499-6208.

title: Meter For Meeting The Reaper
description: IF you somehow knew the hour of your death in advance, would you be prepared with a poem to help you embrace the moment?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, BUDD
description: KELLER-Budd. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Budd Keller. Bee and her late husband Budd had been members since 1975. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to his family. Bernard Steinweg, President Leonard Golub, Secretary

title: Would-Be Goliaths Fall Back on Their Inner Davids
description: LIKE so many other high-technology companies during the boom, MicroStrategy thought of itself as more than a mere business. Instead, its executives spoke of themselves as the advance guard of a revolution in the way that we all live, work and play.

title: Is This the Woman to Rescue Harper's Bazaar?
description: FOR nearly all of her career, Glenda Bailey, the new editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, has had the distinction of being a thorn among roses. Though smart, with a belligerent truthful streak that has helped propel her to the top of fashion publishing, she has suffered, especially in her native England, from not looking more fashionably smart. Prominent teeth flash with intermittent bursts of laughter, and her country-girl face is framed by dense, reddish curls that she has refused to straighten.

title: The 18th: Gimmick Or Just Tough?
description: While work continued to be done on the 18th green at Southern Hills Country Club today, United States Golf Association officials and the course superintendent insisted that the hole would play fairly in time for Thursday's opening round of the United States Open.

title: Article 2001061393608220760 -- No Title
description: Who's on First? Wonder No More

title: Political Cruise Missiles by Mail; Finely Honed, Exquisitely Personal, Deliberately Mean
description: There are some things you just can't say on television.

title: Wobbling on Campaign Finance
description: In the 10 weeks since the Senate passed the McCain-Feingold legislation, the drive for campaign finance reform has gone quiet. That is about to change. In a month or so the House is expected to take up the issue, and there are ominous signs that the pro-reform coalition is fraying. Some waverers are Republicans, including a few who declared themselves reformers and welcomed Senator John McCain into their districts to campaign for them. Others are members of the Congressional Black Caucus. In addition, some self-proclaimed reformers want to change the bill in ways that are likely to kill it. It is time for the waffling to stop.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
