description: An article yesterday about remarks by President Bush opposing the execution of mentally retarded criminals referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of such people executed in Texas since 1976 and omitted attribution for the statistic. The number is six, not seven, according to supporters of legislation banning such executions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Electrocution Death
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn girl was apparently electrocuted yesterday morning when, after a shower, she touched a metal bed frame that investigators suspect was electrified by a frayed cord along the floor, the police said. The girl, Sade McCall, who lived at 2079 Pacific Street, was pronounced dead on arrival at St. Mary's Hospital about 6:50 a.m., the police said. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner, said an autopsy would be performed today to determine the exact cause of death. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: When Few Knew the Code, They Changed the Language
description: THEY were young, in their 20's and early 30's, brimming with energy and optimism, a tightknit team. Their goal was to simplify programming and open up computing to more people. The industry consensus was that they were trying the impossible. They suffered setbacks and disappointments. A six-month timetable for completion became nearly three years.

title: SUNY Project Seeks to Place More Teacher Graduates in New York City Public Schools
description: About 5,000 prospective teachers graduate from the State University of New York each year, but the number of those who do their student teaching in New York City is in the dozens, and the number who take teaching jobs in the city is also small.

title: World Briefing | World: A Pledge On Child Labor
description: Three countries pledged to end the worst forms of child labor within 10 years, the International Labor Organization said. El Salvador, Nepal and Tanzania agreed to take part in a plan to stop the use of children in commercial sexual exploitation as well as in other perilous situations like mining or scavenging at rubbish dumps. The effort is intended to follow terms of a 1999 treaty to tackle the problem of 250 million children between 5 and 14 who are forced to work, often in dangerous situations. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Nexell-Baxter Transaction
description: Nexell Therapeutics Inc. agreed to transfer rights to the company's cell therapeutic development products to the health care unit of Baxter International Inc. unit and, as a result, will lay off about 60 workers. Terms were not disclosed. The company, a leading maker of medical supplies, will get sales, marketing and distribution rights for Nexell's cell processing products. If the agreement is completed, Nexell will dismiss about 66 percent of its work force of 90 and will shut a sales office in Brussels, a spokesman, Tad Heitmann, said. Nexell, which is based in Irvine, will get royalties on Baxter's sales of its products and will reduce expenses.

title: Big Fund Shifts Into Technology
description: The Fidelity Magellan Fund raised its stake in technology investments for the first time in eight months in April and cut its cash holdings in half.

title: Fish and Chips, Sauced With Acid Jazz
description: BAD English food is an old joke, and quite out of date, judging by how well I ate the last time I was in London. Yet the smirks persist, perhaps for good reason, at least when dealing with traditional English dishes.

title: Direct to You From Rajasthan
description: LOVE the sound of Panamanian molas, those colorful fabric panels with their handstitched charms? Like the idea of Haitian tin sculptures? African carved soapstone dishes? Indian beaded necklaces?

title: A Genteel Fellowship Turns Fractious; Money Matters Are Questioned At the National Arts Club
description: The annual meeting of the National Arts Club last month was even more fractious than usual. ''Aldon, your days are numbered!'' someone cried, according to witnesses. The speaker was referring to O. Aldon James Jr., the club's temperamental president. ''The National Arts Club is in its Golden Age!'' yelled another. ''It is our finest hour.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSEL, CHARLES JACOB
description: KASSEL-Charles Jacob. Seventysix, of Cresskill, NJ. Beloved husban of Miriam, his wife of fortyseven years. Devoted father of Kenneth and Kerul, model fatherin-law of David Leeman: dear brother of Helen Goldstein. Born November 20th, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY, Chuck served in the Navy in World War II as a Chief Petty Officer in the South Pacific and was called back during the Korean War. He graduated from University of Missouri with a Bachelors of Electrical Engineering Degree, then worked for RCA teaching others to repair radios and televisions. He and his brother-in-law founded American Lace Mills, a textile mill in Hackensack, NJ, which they operated for twentyeight years. He was also instrumental in managing the family's commercial real estate in Hackensack. Chuck then pursued a Masters Degree in Clinical Nutrition from University of Bridgeport in CT. He volunteered weekly at the Emergency Room of Englewood Hospital for over twelve years, was a member of Temple Beth El for over forty years, was active in the UJA for many years, and was a member of Montammy Golf Club since its inception in 1969. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Charles Kassel Memorial Fund at Temple Beth El. Service at 10 AM, Wednesday at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ, 07624; 201-768-5112. The family will accept visitors at 216 Sunrise Court, Rivervale, NJ; call 201476-1647 for directions.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Governor Sends Wife On Trade Trip
description: Citing unfinished business in the Legislature, Gov. Gary Locke canceled his planned trade mission to France this week and said his wife would serve as head of the state's trade delegation instead. Mr. Locke, a Democrat, will stay behind in Olympia, where legislators are in their second special session. The trade mission is intended to promote state products, including Boeing airliners and Eastern Washington wine. Mr. Locke said jokingly that his wife, Mona Lee Locke, was better suited to lead the mission because she was once an exchange student in France. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Msn To Work With Loudeye
description: Loudeye Technologies, which makes software to broadcast audio and video on the Internet, said it would provide music samples to MSN, the online service owned by Microsoft. The financial terms were not disclosed. Loudeye, which has relationships with all five major record labels as well as more than 800 independent labels, will offer 100,000 song samples to MSN sites. Two weeks ago, Loudeye, which is based in Seattle, signed a similar agreement with the America Online service of AOL Time Warner to provide music samples and other digital media services. Last week, it struck a deal to help the online song-trading service Napster identify and weed out copyrighted songs. Loudeye shares rose 22 cents, or 14.6 percent, to $1.73. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, SETH LEE
description: ZUCKER-Seth Lee. Died peacefully at home on June 11, 2001. Loving husband of Barbara (nee Singer). Devoted father of Evan, Adam, Richard, and their wives Paula Eisenhart, Amy Mereson, and Joan. Proud grandfather of Cameron, Alex, Gabriel, Emma, and Eli, friend of many. Seth had a special spirit that will be greatly missed by all. Contributions may be sent to Visiting Neighbors Inc, or to Cabrini Hospice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBECK, GERTRUDE M.
description: ROBECK-Gertrude M. Formerly of New York and New Canaan; at her home in Pacific Palisades, California; on May 30, 2001, after a short illness. She was 83. Trudy was born in Muskegon, MI, and grew up in Pasadena, CA. She attended the Bennett School, Millbrook, NY, and graduated from UCLA, where she met and later married her husband of 55 years, the late Peter M. Robeck. The Robecks lived in New York and New Canaan from 1956 until they retired to California in 1994. Trudy is survived by her daughter, Torrey Robeck, of New York, son Stephen and his wife Susan of Los Angeles, and granddaughter Loren Robeck. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 14, 3:00 PM at St. Matthew's Church, Pacific Palisades, CA. In lieu of flowers, Trudy asked that donations in her memory be made to The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, for the Ashcroft Watch Fund, 810 Seventh Avenue, New York, New York 10019.

title: A Brush, a Mouse, a Canvas: Mixing Paint and Pixels
description: FOR John Fekner, a pixel is as good as a drop of paint.

title: Recipe: Insalata Pantesca (Pantelleria Salad)
description: INSALATA PANTARESCA (PANTELLERIA SALAD)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Joseph P. McMurray, a New York housing policy expert and college president, misstated the date of his death. It was May 31, not 21.

title: Ratings Move Up
description: Through the first three games of the N.B.A. finals, NBC's 12.3 rating is 18 percent better than the rating a year ago when the Lakers played Indiana.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Burlington: Fatal Flight
description: The student pilot on one of two small planes that collided in midair last summer, killing all 11 aboard the planes, had apparently taken an over-the-counter cold medicine that can cause drowsiness, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a new report. The report did not discuss the cause of the collision and did not say the cold remedy impaired the pilot, Jason J. Wismer, 20, of Bensalem, Pa. Traces of doxylamine, an antihistamine that can cause drowsiness or dizziness, and pseudoephedrine, a decongestant that can cause excessive stimulation, were found in the kidneys and liver of Mr. Wismer. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: On the Eve of Extinction: 4 Years of High School
description: Rumor has it that high school lasts four years. Don't believe it.

title: The Boss: I Voraciously Crave Energy
description: There are two quotes engraved into leather that sit on my desk: "No Whining" and "It Can Be Done." Depending on how things are going, they face out or in toward me.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Insurance Fraud Ring Alleged
description: Three insurance companies filed a lawsuit yesterday against a group of doctors, dentists and others whom they accused of operating a no-fault automobile insurance fraud ring in New York City and Long Island. The companies -- Allstate, Progressive and Encompass -- accused the 26 defendants of staging accidents and running diagnostic and acupuncture centers that were ''medical bill mills,'' churning out claims for procedures that were unneeded or never performed. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, was the third insurance industry suit in the last 16 months in the state charging similar practices. It comes as many insurers in the state are seeking large rate increases, citing the costs of sharply rising auto-insurance fraud. The lawsuit seeks $36 million in triple damages. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Suharto Collapses; Taken to Hospital
description: Former President Suharto of Indonesia was taken to a hospital in Jakarta this afternoon after collapsing at his house from what a doctor called dangerously low blood pressure and a weak heart.

title: A Hot-Dog Cart That Knows Its Way Around the Kitchen
description: Chefs' fingerprints are all over the newest food cart in Madison Square Park at Broadway and 23rd Street. The hot dogs are imported from Chicago. They've been boiled with allspice, bay leaves, onions and garlic. The 10 toppings include the finest dice of green peppers and onions as well as fresh tomatoes, lettuce, relish, chilies and cucumbers; the final garnish is a dusting of celery salt. The popcorn is seasoned with sage, rosemary and garlic; the iced tea is brewed of leaves from T Salon. The Chipwich knockoff has coffee ice cream in the center, and the brownies are moist with coconut.

title: How the Arrival of Artificial Light Changed Everything
description: The Bible says that God's first command was ''Let there be light.'' Yet despite all the time that has passed since then and the mighty efforts of scientists, artists and philosophers to understand the nature of light, it remains mysterious. We know little more about it than Benjamin Franklin, who once wrote in frustration, ''I am much in the dark about light.''

title: Head of Swiss Anti-Money Laundering Effort Quits
description: By ELIZABETH OLSON

title: Don't Dismiss Lakers' Heart In the Finals
description: Although America is tired of reading it, the pro basketball team from this city has a lot of heart. In fact, they have so much heart and are afflicted with so many injuries, it is a wonder the 76ers are not referred to as Aorta Iverson and the Fibrillating 76ers, or A.I. and the E.R.'s.

title: Software's Next Leap Is Out of the Box
description: JOHN SEELEY BROWN, a scientist at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, turns to the German philosopher Martin Heidegger for a description of the next frontier in software: a blind man is not conscious of the cane he uses as a separate entity, Heidegger wrote, but regards it as an extension of his hand.

title: Sixers' Hill Refuses To Excuse His Play
description: Struggling to climb out of the offensive sinkhole he has created for himself, Tyrone Hill turned defensive today.

title: SOFTWARE; They Give It Away, Get Plenty Back
description: RECORD companies have watched in horror recently as consumers have turned their nicely packaged CD's into MP3 files and set them loose online. But a corner of the software industry has thrived for years by embracing that same loss of control: instead of selling shrink-wrapped boxes, why not distribute products in digital form and watch them spread?

title: Can Anyone Give Woods a Game?
description: Tiger Woods sat comfortably in his chair today, like a king sitting on his throne.

title: Skip the Climbing Wall: This Start-Up Just Wants to Hang On
description: A FEW weeks ago, Michael Hejtmanek sat in the tiny conference room of his fledgling company -- the same room he shares with two other companies -- and talked about timing. He shies away from calling his lousy.

title: Phillips Has the Touch In Leading the Liberty
description: Tari Phillips knew she had helped the Liberty beat the Charlotte Sting last night at Madison Square Garden. But she had no idea how well she had shot in the 79-70 victory.

title: THE BOSS; I Voraciously Crave Energy
description: There are two quotes engraved into leather that sit on my desk: ''No Whining'' and ''It Can Be Done.'' Depending on how things are going, they face out or in toward me.

title: G.E. to Offer Light Bulb That Rival Calls Inefficient
description: General Electric will unveil a new light bulb today that the company says will make colors appear more vivid. But a competitor accuses the company of acting irresponsibly.

title: China Policy Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS UP. Natural gas rose on beliefs that warmer weather would increase demand for use in electricity generation. In New York, gas for July delivery rose 12.2 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $4.301 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASSI, MICHAEL F.
description: SASSI-Michael F. Died of heart disease in Boston, MA on June 10, 2001 at age 67. Beloved husband of 39 years to Christina, loving father to daughters Christina and Gabriella, doting grandfather to Matthew, Katarina and Natasha, devoted son of the late Caroline and Michael, and beloved brother of Ann and Caroline. Mike was a bighearted, generous powerhouse of a man whose loss will be felt keenly by all who knew and loved him. A native New Yorker, he earned a BA from St. John's University and an MBA from the Wharton School of Finance. After 30 years at Chemical Bank, he retired as Senior Vice President of Trusts & Administration. Later he was a Senior Vice President at Lynch & Mayer, and finally a consultant for Trainer Wortham & Co. He was one of the founders of the Winston Preparatory School in NYC. A superb financial investor and advisor, he truly loved his work and cared deeply about his loyal clients. He was known for his integrity and his strong sense of ethics. He gave generously and quietly to numerous charities. Donations in his memory may be made to the Winston Preparatory School. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be arranged in NYC in July.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ruling On 'Absentia'
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday threw out the conviction of a drug defendant who never received the court's notice of his trial date and was convicted in absentia, or while absent. After his arrest by troopers on cocaine possession charges in April 1995, the defendant, Lawrence Whaley, lost touch with his lawyer and did not respond to a court notice mailed to an Ohio address he had already left. In overturning a lower court decision upholding the 1997 conviction, the unanimous high court ruled that when a defendant unknowingly does not receive actual notice of the trial date, the judge cannot conclude that he waived his right to be present. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Military Review Emphasizes Need for Services to Respond Jointly
description: The Pentagon today gave additional indications of how it might restructure its forces, urging the services to operate jointly to respond more effectively in the opening hours of a conflict and saying that the Army needed to streamline its command structure, possibly by eliminating divisions.

title: FORD CREATES UNIT TO INCREASE SALES OF BOAT ENGINES
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would set up a division to try to increase the company's sales of engines for boats. The company will open a marine division in September in Kennesaw, Ga., the company said. Ford plans to build a 42,000-square-foot center for the division's offices and operations. The Ford unit will work with Sterling Performance Engines on adapting engines for marine use. Ford sells automotive engines to other companies, which convert them for marine use and sell them to boat builders. The division plans to do the conversion work itself, said a spokeswoman, Karen McDowell.

title: Doing Hard Time in the Holding Cell
description: A scene in the second act of ''Soon My Work'' finally lights up the play with the talent and promise of the International Wow Company and its artistic director, Josh Fox, who wrote and directed this street drama in defense of the disenfranchised. The scene takes place in a police holding cell in Manhattan, populated by a mixed bag of down-and-outers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALOM, JOSEPH
description: SHALOM-Joseph. The Management and Employees of I. Shalom & Company, Inc., and Jordan Accessories mourn the passing of our President and mentor, Joseph Shalom, whose fairness and generosity touched all who were in contact with him. To Joseph, personal relationships and compassion superseeded economic and business expediency. He was a warm and generous friend, and our Company and industry will long remember his enduring virtues.

title: I Earn My Wings Under the Plane
description: Recently a pilot grabbed me and said he thought we had a problem with a hydraulic leak on the right wing. He was right. This is not a major job -- it involves changing an O-ring -- but it's dangerous. You can lose a finger if you're not careful, and the hydraulic fluid is caustic. I've had it leak into my eye.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Accusations Of Forced Labor
description: Two leading human rights groups said the military government in the former Burma continues to employ forced labor in a practice that was recently condemned by the International Labor Organization. The groups, Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, said the authorities had failed to enforce their own law, passed last October, that bans forced labor. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Bringing Home A Taste of Sun And Seacoast
description: DISCOVERING salted capers was almost worth the price of the plane tickets to Pantelleria. The island produces them in staggering quantities, and they are fatter, firmer and far more flavorful than those flaccid little specimens packed in jars everywhere else. Salt preserves capers, while vinegar essentially cooks them. The difference is astounding.

title: Polaroid to Cut 2,000 Jobs
description: The Polaroid Corporation, acknowledging that its ailing instant photography business is unlikely to recover, said today that it would cut 2,000 jobs, at least half in Massachusetts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRY, CAROL BERNSTEIN
description: FERRY-Carol Bernstein. The spirit of Ms. Ferry's lifelong dedication to social justice will continue to inspire us. Center for Constitutional Rights

title: Senate Rejects Tuition Aid, a Key to Bush Education Plan
description: The Senate defeated an amendment today that would have permitted low-income parents in 10 cities to use taxpayer dollars to send their children to private and religious schools.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Trying to Stop Execution Cite Flaws in Bias Report
description: Lawyers for Juan Raul Garza, who is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday, filed a petition today with the Justice Department criticizing Attorney General John Ashcroft's conclusion in a study last week that federal death sentences have been imposed without racial or ethnic bias.

title: Pushing His Missile Plan in Spain, Bush Calls Arms Treaty a 'Relic'
description: President Bush today began his first overseas trip since taking office with his most fervent pitch yet for his plan to build a missile defense shield, dismissing a 1972 arms treaty that stands in the way as obsolete and irrelevant to a post-cold-war world.

title: Mets Soundly Defeat the Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, June 12  Bobby Valentine has tried clubhouse speeches and individual huddles. He has worn a rally cap and offered bold predictions for his team. All of it has been part of an effort to coax the Mets into believing they can win. Most of it has not worked.

title: France Debates Bill That Would Strip Its President of Immunity
description: The National Assembly debated a bill today that would strip President Jacques Chirac of his immunity from prosecution and lay him open to charges of corruption.

title: Charges Near In Bombing At Saudi Base, U.S. Aides Say
description: After a five-year inquiry that at times seemed near collapse because of disagreements with Saudi Arabia, American authorities said today that they were close to bringing charges against Saudi militants for the 1996 truck bombing at the Khobar Towers apartment building that killed 19 American airmen.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Fatal Shooting
description: A passer-by was fatally shot last night when a suspect's gun went off during an encounter with police detectives trying to arrest him, the Hempstead police said. The officers approached the suspect, who was wanted in a Memorial Day weekend slashing, about 8 p.m. in front of an apartment building at 99 Terrace Avenue to arrest him, said Lt. Michael McGowan. But the suspect resisted and pulled a semiautomatic handgun out of his waistband as the detectives struggled with him, Lieutenant McGowan said, and a bullet struck a man crossing the street nearby. The wounded man, 47, was taken to Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, where he was pronounced dead. Additional charges were pending against the suspect. The police did not release names of the suspect or the victim. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Bond Sale Seems to Signal Easing of Argentine Crisis
description: In a sign that Argentina's financial crisis has begun to ease, the government succeeded today in auctioning $700 million in treasury bills at far lower interest rates than it has been forced to pay in recent months.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Rob Austin, managing partner for client relations at Work Inc., Richmond, Va., was named to the new post of executive vice president and chief administrative officer.

title: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; To Nail the Sale, E-Mail's Too Slow
description: THINK of instant messages and the image that comes to mind is more likely that of a teenager typing a gossipy chat note than that of an office worker using it for business purposes. But the very thing that makes instant messaging so useful at home -- namely, fast communication -- makes it equally valuable as a business tool. Do you need to ask your supervisor a question while you are on the phone with a client? Shoot the boss a text message that pops up on her computer screen right after you click ''send,'' and you can have her response within seconds.

title: New Tools Are Born To Orbit Around EBay
description: THE exponential growth of the auction company eBay remains, even in the wake of the Nasdaq crash, one of the more notable success stories of the new economy. Less well known, however, are the many companies that have profited by supplying eBay's customers with everything from imaging services to insurance to appraisals.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: $2.1 Million Award In Hantavirus Case
description: A federal judge in Santa Fe awarded $2.1 million to the family of a 23-year-old Navajo man who died of hantavirus after a federal Indian hospital in Shiprock, N.M., failed to diagnose it in 1998. The judge, Martha A. Vzquez of Federal District Court, found the hospital negligent for not making any effort to assure that emergency room workers were trained in diagnosing hantavirus. The hospital is in the Four Corners region, where hantavirus, which is often deadly, was discovered on this continent in 1993. The dead man, Hardy Haceesa, above, was known as the Navajo Michael Jordan for his skill in basketball. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Time Inc. Said to Pursue Leading British Magazine Publisher
description: Looking to expand its presence abroad, Time Inc., the magazine publishing business of the AOL Time Warner media company, has held talks with IPC Media Ltd., Britain's largest publisher of consumer magazines, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Addenda: ING Group Reviewing U.S. Assignments
description: The ING Group in Amsterdam, a financial services and insurance company, said yesterday that it had begun a review for an agency of record to handle marketing and branding assignments in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNER, JERRY
description: STERNER-Jerry. Died on June 11. Beloved husband, father, brother and most generous loved friend to so many whose lives he touched. He will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday, 11:45 AM, Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Vacation Offers For Councilman Are Scrutinized
description: An investigation by the Manhattan district attorney found that a consultant at the center of a building corruption inquiry regularly relied on Thomas V. Ognibene, the leader of the City Council's Republican delegation, for political clout at City Hall and in Albany, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Israel and Palestinians Seek Ways to Expand Cease-fire
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 13  Palestinians and Israelis today accepted a formal cease-fire and began the delicate search for ways to carry out an American-brokered agreement extending the truce, which has reduced violence over the past 12 days.

title: If You Like This Story, Click Here to Pay Me
description: THE financing dried up, Web advertising was not generating enough money, and there were no potential investors in sight. So I did what all good Americans should do in time of need: I begged. Almost anybody with a Web site can do the same.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: State To Invest In Tobacco Stocks
description: Gov. Jeb Bush and two other Republican officials who control the state's nearly $100-billion retirement fund voted to lift a four-year-old ban on investments in tobacco companies. The ban pushed by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, in 1997, resulted in the sale of more than $800 million in stocks, believed to be the largest divestiture of tobacco holdings. Five states -- California, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York and Vermont -- have some limits on tobacco investments. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Our Towns; Some Dread Late Budget, Some Don't
description: IF you are a connoisseur of state capitals (and heartfelt sympathies if you are), then you know that each has its own character.

title: G.O.P. Congressman Will Support Democrats' Patients' Rights Bill
description: In a blow to President Bush, a key House Republican has decided to support patients' rights legislation that Senate Democrats are bringing forth as their first signature bill since they took control of the Senate.

title: De La Hoya Focuses on History
description: Oscar De La Hoya, the Golden Boy, knows that his reputation needs some polishing. So for more than a month, he has been chopping wood in the mountains near Los Angeles and wearing two-pound boots while he runs. No more recording sessions. No more cavorting with Hollywood stars. No more running away from opponents in the ring.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Subway Foes Turning Up The Heat
description: THINGS are starting to sizzle just in time for the annual interleague theatrics between the Mets and Yankees -- a matchup most definitely not be repeated this October, by the way.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Acquisition
description: China's Hong Kong-listed oil refiner, Sinopec, said it would buy Sinopec National Star, China's No. 4 oil company, from its parent for 6.45 billion yuan ($779 million). It said the purchase was intended to add to the listed company's oil and gas production and give it more stable earnings. Sinopec will also assume National Star's net debt, which was about 2.68 billion yuan at end of last year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Lyme disease, although a problem, is not nearly as big a problem as most people think. The bigger epidemic is Lyme anxiety.''

title: Play Now, Pay Later: The 'Shareware' Business
description: RECORD companies have watched in horror recently as consumers have turned their nicely packaged CD's into MP3 files and set them loose online. But a corner of the software industry has thrived for years by embracing that same loss of control: instead of selling shrink-wrapped boxes, why not distribute products in digital form and watch them spread?

title: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; Of Marshmallows And Tax Agita
description: FOR those who notice it at all, sales tax conjures images of fractions and aggravation. For an increasing few, sales tax is an area where the Internet's promise of inexpensive, near-instant convenience may be turning into reality.

title: Death Decree Could Have Troubled U.S. Muslims
description: Although a Saudi terrorist was saved from the death penalty by the deadlock of a New York jury yesterday, American Muslim leaders said the man's trial still posed difficult political and religious questions.

title: Article 2001061393957641997 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Mets' Valentine Turns Up the Heat
description: Things are starting to sizzle just in time for the annual interleague theatrics between the Mets and Yankees  a matchup most definitely not be repeated this October, by the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, MARK S. M.D.
description: ROTHENBERG-Mark S. M.D. Age 97. Died June 11 after a long illness. Devoted husband of Ann for 63 years. Beloved father of Judy and Dr. Robert Podell. Adored grandfather of Dr. Debbie and Ari Fishkind and great-grandfather of Aaron Benjamin Fishkind. Dedicated physician for 71 years and loved by all his patients. Shiva at the Podell residence.

title: Pariah to Pitchman: The New Iverson
description: Mainstream? Nah.

title: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; Taking a Meeting Over the Internet
description: SOMETIME between the Industrial Revolution and the invention of the day planner, meetings became the order of the average workday -- as in, ''I have back-to-back meetings'' or ''I have to fly to Philadelphia for a meeting'' or ''Let's meet next week.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHTER, VIVIENNE THAUL
description: WECHTER - Vivienne Thaul. Passed away at age 91, at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City on June 12, 2001. At the time of her death, she was a Professor of the Psychology of Creativity at Fordham University, and its Artist-inResidence. Vivienne was a star whose light shone brightly and will continue to shine through her beautiful works of art and the wonderful memories of her that her countless friends, colleagues and students have. She was married to Nathan Wechter, M.D., who died in 1969. Her survivors include her beloved daughter, Robyrta Rapoport and son-in-law, Bernard; her devoted grandson, Michael Rapoport and his dear wife, Deborah. Survivors also include her cherished sister and brothers: Jeanne Kaplan and Perez Rosenthal and Elliot Thaul; and her four great grandchildren, Rebecca, Abigail, Serena and Solomon Jonathan. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Wednesday at 1:00 PM. The family will receive relatives and friends at the residence of her daughter in New York City beginning Thursday 1:00 PM until Friday 5:00 PM.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: SUEZ BUYS OUT EXXON MOBIL'S STAKE IN CHEMICAL VENTURE
description: Suez, a global water company, said yesterday that it had bought the Exxon Mobil Corporation's 40 percent stake in a chemicals venture, taking full control as it seeks to increase sales to the petroleum industry. The venture, Nalco/Exxon Energy Chemicals, operates in 80 countries and had sales last year of $500 million. The purchase terms were not disclosed.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: State Senators Want Tiebreaker
description: Seeking a mathematical solution to a political problem, two state senators have proposed adding a 99th member to the State House, which now has 98 and is deadlocked in a 49-49 split between the two parties. The split, which means the chamber has co-speakers and dual control of several major committees, has left the Legislature stalled over the state budget and a long-term plan to deal with traffic congestion. The new-member proposal, which will face an uphill battle for passage, was introduced by senators frustrated by the House deadlock. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Court Keeps Editor In Jail
description: A court ordered the editor and two publishing executives of the country's largest newspaper held until Friday when the government is required to file formal charges against them. The men were arrested June 6 after Kantipur published an article by a Maoist rebel who asserted that the massacre of the royal family on June 1 was a foreign-inspired conspiracy. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Pick a Hobby, And There's A Web Site
description: WHEN the Historical Museum of Barbed Wire and Fencing Tools opened in 1991, it was probably the biggest thing to hit the Texas Panhandle town of McLean, population 850, since Interstate 40 replaced Route 66. But barbed wire fanciers still had a communications problem: serious collectors were as dispersed as maverick steers on the open range.

title: Faiga Teitelbaum, 89, a Power Among the Satmar Hasidim
description: Faiga Teitelbaum, who achieved unusual influence for a woman among the Satmar group of Hasidic Jews, died on June 2 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Judge Refuses to Step Out of Mayor's Divorce
description: A judge yesterday refused to remove herself from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's contentious divorce case, saying that she was not biased against the mayor or his friend Judith Nathan, and that her judgment was not colored by the incendiary remarks swirling around the dispute.

title: Dress-Down Is Down if Not Quite Out
description: At the height of the dot-com boom, Raymond Nasr felt like a fashion misfit. Everyone else at work seemed to be wearing jeans and sports shirts, and there he was, resplendent in his blue double-breasted jacket, dress shirt with knotted cuff links, dress slacks and red bow tie.

title: Recipe: Caper Salsa
description: Time: 15 minutes, plus overnight soaking

title: Slaves and Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about a securities industry code of conduct for stock research misstated the position held in the 1980's by Roy Smith, a professor who commented on it. Now an investment banking professor at New York University, he was formerly a partner in the corporate finance department of Goldman, Sachs, not head of its equity department.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Streets Are Still Mean, Study Finds. Or Just Ask Your Shocks.
description: A follow-up study on the conditions of New York City's streets has found that the teeth-rattling prevalence of potholes, manhole covers and the like has remained fairly steady, or perhaps more apt, as undulating as ever.

title: Business Travel; Corporations have put the brakes on spending for trips.
description: AFTER scrutinizing domestic hotel revenue and occupancy data for the first three months of this year, Robert Mandelbaum confidently predicted last month that while the industry looked a little wobbly as business travel sagged, growth would most likely continue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MICHEL, HENRY L.
description: MICHEL-Henry L. The family of the late Henry L. Michel Chairman Emeritus of Parsons Brinkerhoff, who passsed away on May 23, invites former associates and friends to a memorial gathering on June 18 at Columbia University, St Paul's Chapel, 116th & Broadway, at 4 PM. Contributions can be made to the Columbia School of Engineering Assn, 500 West 120th St, mail code 4718, NYC 10027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGDEN, MARY EVERSLEY
description: OGDEN-Mary Eversley, 85. Of Merwin Ave. Milford, CT died on June 11, 2001, in Branford, CT. Mrs. Ogden was born on September 8, 1915, in Setauket, L.I., New York to the late Eversley and Margherita Abbey Kyburg Childs. She is the widow of the late Richard A. Ogden of Darien and New York City. Mrs. Ogden was very active in her community, and was a member of Wee Burn Country Club, Milford Yacht Club, the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, the Daughters of Cincinatti and the Society of the Mayflower Descendents. Mrs. Ogden is survived by her sons Charles Eversley Forsdick of Wethersfield, CT, Lawrence Alden Forsdick of Marina Del Ray, CA and Arthur R. Forsdick of Wethersfield, CT, sister Margherita A. Fidao of Boulder, CO and Setauket, NY, brother Henry G.E. Kyburg Jr. of Lyons, NY, grandchildren Laureen Eversley Brandner, Tamra Lynette Holda, Randall Stewart Forsdick, Amanda Childs Forsdick, Douglas Clewell Forsdick, Katherine Lockwood Forsdick, Christopher Edmund Forsdick, & Heather Abbey Forsdick, and great grandchildren Ashley, Ryan, Scott, Molly, JJ, Luisa, Otto and Kelvin. Mrs. Ogden is predeceased by a brother Henry Abbey Childs, formerly of Darien. Smith Funeral Home, 135 Broad St, Milford, CT is handling the services, which will be private. Donations may be made to the National Society of Colonial Dames, Main St, Wethersfield, CT, Westminster School, Simsbury, CT or Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Road, Branford, CT. 06405.

title: Cloning Colonial Williamsburg; Nonprofit Groups Expand Their Universe of Products
description: For years, Colonial Williamsburg has sold copies of furniture and plates displayed inside the museum's restored and reconstructed 18th-century homes. Now consumers can buy copies of the houses themselves.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about the new headquarters of Pixar Animation Studios misstated its location. As the article said, it is in Emeryville, Calif., east of San Francisco across the bay, not in Silicon Valley to the southeast.

title: Metro Business Briefing | 'Do Not Call,' But They Did
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board says it has received 1,100 complaints of violations of the state's ''do not call'' telemarketing law, which went into effect April 1. About 1.5 million households have signed up for the free coverage under the law, which forbids companies to make most kinds of sales solicitation calls to state residents on the list. Violators can be fined up to $2,000 for each prohibited call. The list is updated quarterly, and those wishing to add their names for the next update -- which will bring them coverage beginning in August -- must do so no later than Friday, by calling (866) 622-5569 or registering through the Internet at www.consumer.state. ny.us. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Gobbling Energy And Wasting It, Too
description: One of the more contentious issues President Bush is discussing with European leaders during his trip this week is his stance on global warming. When Mr. Bush decided to abandon the Kyoto Protocol -- because of its ostensibly unrealistic targets and the pressures it would put on American industry and private households -- he generated a worldwide backlash, particularly among European allies. With good reason: A closer look at the numbers shows that if the economy of the United States operated as efficiently as those of Europe and Japan, American energy consumption and greenhouse emissions would fall dramatically -- to even less than the emission levels envisioned in the Kyoto treaty.

title: And One to Travel
description: CUISINART has done some math. People who love coffee want a machine that makes good coffee. (Which means a thermal carafe coffee maker.) And people who love coffee sometimes want to take it with them. (An insulated travel mug.) If the company makes a machine that combines both, people who love coffee will buy it.

title: Toyota to Introduce Another Hybrid Engine
description: Hoping to expand on the modest success of its Prius hybrid gas-electric car, Toyota Motor announced a new hybrid engine system today that it said was simpler, cheaper and more versatile, though not as stingy with fuel.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Teacher Retirements Ahead of 2000 Total

title: EchoStar and G.M. In Talks on DirecTV
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation and the General Motors Corporation said they were in preliminary discussions about a possible merger of EchoStar and Hughes Electronics' DirecTV unit, according to a court filing by the companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBEY, ALBERT, MD.
description: ABBEY-Albert, MD. Died peacefully on June 11, 2001. Physician extraordinaire, person extraordinaire. His wisdom and compassion will be missed but never forgotten. Beloved husband and soulmate of Joan, proud father of Jonathan, Seth and Joshua, and graduate of Harvard '60. He won because in Heaven there is no illness. Donations in his honor may be made to Dr. Albert Abbey Fund, c/o St. Barnabas Medical Center, St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, NJ 07039.

title: Crazy Eddie Appointment
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the discount electronics chain, said today that it had named Ted Vagelos, a Priceline.com executive, president and chief operating officer. Mr. Vagelos, who was president of Priceline's long-distance unit, will be responsible for business operations, including Crazy Eddie's telephone sales center, Web site and customer service tools, the company said. The company, based in Rahway, sells home electronics over the Internet and through a toll-free telephone number. A newly formed Crazy Eddie bought the rights to the company in March from DJR Holdings L.L.C. The chain earlier went bankrupt and its co-founder and namesake, Eddie Antar, was convicted of securities fraud.

title: Ali-Frazier Attracts 100,000 Buyers
description: The Laila Ali-Jacqui Frazier Lyde pay-per-view bout last Friday night attracted an estimated 100,000 buyers at $24.95 each, according to In Demand, the fight's distributor.

title: Criminal Justice on a Global Scale
description: In the last few weeks, almost unnoticed in the North American press, the case against General Augusto Pinochet of Chile entangled Henry Kissinger. A judge in Paris sent officials to the Ritz hotel, where the former secretary of state was staying, to serve him with a request to appear in the judge's chambers to answer questions about American involvement in Chile almost 30 years ago. Mr. Kissinger declined to attend, citing obligations elsewhere. He flew on to Italy. Days earlier, a judge in Argentina, investigating a series of political killings around Latin America that have been linked to General Pinochet, had announced that he would be seeking Mr. Kissinger's testimony.

title: Todd Sweeney, 82, Is Dead; Briton in Vital D-Day Raid
description: Col. Todd Sweeney, who commanded a platoon of glider-borne British infantrymen in a storied raid that captured two vital bridges in the first moments of D-Day, died June 4, The Times of London reported. He was 82.

title: Geoffrey Zakarian
description: A PLATE of food has to have balance. For example, a mild fish like skate mustn't be overwhelmed by the side dishes. They should have personality and color, but they also have to be subtle.

title: A City Parks Revival
description: With great fanfare, Madison Square Park reopened yesterday, offering a quiet and elegant refuge in Manhattan's bustling Midtown. The facelift for this 19th-century oasis is a credit to civic-minded neighbors and corporations, which raised enough money and pushed enough of the right levers for a quick and thorough restoration of the six-acre park near the old Flatiron Building. But the revival of Madison Square is also a vivid reminder of the shabby state of many of the public parks elsewhere in New York City. The restoration of these vital public spaces is an issue that ought to rank much higher on the agenda of every mayoral candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTEL, RUTH C.
description: SETTEL-Ruth C. On June 11, 2001. Beloved wife of Elmer. Devoted mother of Margot Robinson and stepmother of Jim and Howard. Mother-in-law of Ann, Inhee and Jack. Cherished grandmother of Josh, Zack, Tony, Liz, Joanne, Katie and Douglas. Loving grandmother. Services Wednesday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Jordan Limits Entry of West Bank Palestinians
description: In what it called a temporary toughening of its immigration rules, Jordan is making it harder for Palestinians to enter from the West Bank, sparking protests from the many Palestinians who have relatives and business commitments in Jordan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTAGLIA, TULLIO F., MD,
description: TARTAGLIA-Tullio F., MD, 79, a graduate of The Chicago Medical School and a decorated Korean War veteran, died on June 10. Dr. Taraglia was a licensed physician for 50 years and a past president of both the New York Society of Internal Medicine, Bronx Chapter, and the Bronx County Medical Society. A devoted husband to Dolores, he is also survived by his four children, Lydia, Joseph, Alfred and Gregory, and his grandchildren, Laura, Andrew, Christina, James, Julia, Sarah, and Alexandra. Visiting hours, Wednesday, 7-9, Thursday 2-4, 7-9. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. Service on Friday, 10 AM, Resurrection Church, Rye, New York.

title: The World's View of Executions
description: One of the things President Bush will discover as he makes his way through Europe this week is that America's moral authority as a global champion of individual and human rights is being seriously undermined by the nation's reliance on the death penalty. Indeed, when Mr. Bush attends a European Union summit meeting tomorrow, he will be visiting an organization that bars admission to any nation that has not banned the death penalty.

title: Article 2001061390788714739 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Transformed By Spices
description: MORE often than not, it is the seasonings that give recipes a national identity, not the main ingredients or cooking technique. And if you need convincing of this notion, here it is, in the form of a simple shrimp and tomato dish.

title: In Bush's Words: ABM 'Prevents a Full Exploration of Possibility'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar after their talks yesterday in Madrid, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. Prime Minister Aznar's remarks were provided by a interpreter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALEWITZ, SAMUEL
description: GALEWITZ-Samuel. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Peer-to-Peer Grows Up And Gets a Real Job
description: DEPENDING on one's view, the downloading of shared music files through services like Napster either popularized or demonized the technology that allows personal computers to be linked into one virtual machine over the Internet. Yet while the recording industry accuses the file-sharing music services of copyright infringement, other information-sensitive industries are praising the technology's ability to save time, money and stress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORROW, PETER
description: MORROW-Peter. The family would like to thank all his friends and acquaintances for the Mass Cards. Your outpouring of condolences was a great comfort. Madeline Poli

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about remarks by President Bush opposing the execution of mentally retarded criminals referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of such people executed in Texas since 1976 and omitted attribution for the statistic. The number is six, not seven, according to supporters of legislation banning such executions.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA AND EXULT FORMING A JOINT VENTURE
description: Automatic Data Processing, a payroll processing company, has agreed to invest as much as $50 million in Exult, and the two companies have formed a venture to jointly sell their human-resources services, they said yesterday. Automatic Data will buy $20 million of Exult shares, based on the average per-share price for the last 30 days, the companies said. Automatic Data agreed to buy an additional $30 million of stock in the ''next few years'' if the venture's sales meet expectations. Exult, based in Irvine, Calif., is developing a service that would help large corporations use the Internet to manage human resources. Automatic Data is based in Roseland, N.J.

title: The Best Revenge
description: And yet, the writer thinks, the wrong is so rightable, the critics' reasoning so weak! He sees this clearly and, being what he is, writes his thoughts down. If he is unlucky and has no one to stop him before he clicks the Send button, he publishes them. And so, one day not long after the book has come out and disappeared, we flip to his byline with the pleasing anticipation that a literary personage is about to make a fool of himself.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans for a Newark arena and redevelopment of the Meadowlands misspelled the name of the Bergen County executive. He is William Schuber, not Shuber.

title: In an Age of Guidebooks, A Taste Of Undiscovered Italy
description: MY first dinner on the Sicilian island of Pantelleria was like waking in a dream. I had fallen into bed in late afternoon after enduring four flights over 18 hours and was lured back among the living only by the seductive smells of good things getting better as they roasted: potatoes with rosemary and olive oil; grouper with sage, mint, parsley, basil and garlic. When I wandered dazedly to the table, a big bowl of penne with the potent local pesto of tomatoes and capers was also waiting, along with good, rough vino bianco.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Far From the Rhone
description: NOT that long ago, viognier was a hot grape in California. It wasn't destined to be the next chardonnay, but it was thought of as an alternative white for in-the-know wine drinkers. But several obstacles have blocked the path to stardom for this grape that was once obscure.

title: At Murrow High, a Feeling of Freedom Prevails
description: In the 1980's, rebellious teenagers used to scrawl an ''A'' for anarchy on high school walls in hopes of inciting chaos and revolution. To the casual observer, Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn might look like the answer to their prayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, STEPHEN A.
description: ROSEN-Stephen A. Died on June 7, 2001, at age 53. Daddy to Zoe Allison Rosen, and friend to many. Celebration of the life of Stephen Rosen will be held at The 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, Warburg Lounge, at 4:30 P.M., Thursday, June 14th.

title: A Mixed Day for Biotech Products
description: Two leading biotechnology companies reported contrasting news today in their efforts to diversify their narrow product lines.

title: When a Day's Work Still Doesn't Count
description: New York City students on welfare often meet resistance when they try to use work-study jobs and internships to satisfy their welfare work requirements, even though a new law lets them do so, legislators and advocates for the students say.

title: E-Business
description: The challenges of moving software onto the Internet. Plus: articles on marketing, finance and shopping.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Talks With Bangladesh
description: Indian and Bangladeshi officials began talks to try to resolve problems along their 2,500-mile border, including an incident in April when 16 Indian border guards were killed. There are small enclaves of each country within the other. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Topanga Journal; Town Fights to Balance Safety and Personality
description: To get some insight into the community tucked into the steep walls of rock and chaparral here, you need look no farther than the geraniums flourishing on top of a roadside barrier near the town center.

title: Management: Ford Embraces Six Sigma
description: Twenty years ago, when an invasion of Japanese imports threatened the American automobile industry, the Ford Motor Company led a quality revival based on the management philosophy of W. Edwards Deming, who was controversial then and is out of fashion now.

title: N.F.L. Adds Later Starts to Schedule
description: The National Football League will experiment with later starting times for some of its late regular-season and playoff games in an attempt to attract more viewers to the broadcasts.

title: Cairo Journal; For the Pious and Perplexed, Dial-a-Sheik Service
description: The first caller, at 4:55 a.m., wanted to know when the Prophet Muhammad was born and the second, at 5:05 a.m., wondered if he had any siblings, while the third, at 5:21, asked whether Islam considers masturbation a sin.

title: First Man Goes on Trial in Killings at Manhattan Muffin Shop
description: Two men who shot their way out of a botched robbery in a Manhattan muffin shop left behind a ''mountain of evidence,'' a prosecutor told a jury in opening statements at their trial yesterday. The evidence included a wig and a track suit from their disguises, pistols and an ammunition clip, and numerous witnesses who saw detectives chase them through congested streets.

title: Soccer Team Is Negotiating For Stadium At Aqueduct
description: The owners of the MetroStars are negotiating with state and city officials over plans to build a 25,000-seat soccer stadium at Aqueduct, the tired Queens horse track where Man o' War became a racing legend 81 years ago.

title: Transcript of Panel Discussion: 'Naked Capitalists'
description: The NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area hosted an closed panel discussion on the adult film industry, based on Frank Rich's Magazine article, 'Naked Capitalists' .

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Separatist Tensions Ease
description: The government said it would begin removing checkpoints that limit travel between the tiny former Soviet republic and its eastern province, Trans-Dnestr, which is controlled by pro-Russian separatists. The nation broke apart in a 1992 war; relations have warmed since February, when Moldova voters installed a Communist government that has made peace there a priority. The two sides remain split over whether Trans-Dnestr should be independent. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Go-Between for Chefs And Family Farms
description: ON the way to the Manchester, N.H., airport last Wednesday night, August Schumacher Jr. stopped by the Neseankeag Cooperative farm in Litchfield, near the airport, to pick up a box of Asian greens that included pea tendrils, Chinese chive blossoms and Cambodian spearmint. The next morning, he delivered the exotics to Ten Penh, an Asian-inspired restaurant in Washington.

title: Wall Street Firms Endorse Ethics Standards for Analysts
description: Moving to counter the growing belief among investors that Wall Street research is biased, obfuscating or downright untrustworthy, the nation's largest securities firms announced guidelines yesterday to shore up the ethical and professional standards for their analysts and other employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, GENEVIEVE C.
description: JACKSON-Genevieve C. Of Fishkill, NY died June 8, 2001. She was 89. Born April 6, 1912 in Tampa, Florida to Frank and Loretta Mapp Glover. A bandleader and entertainer in the 1930's and 1940's with jazz bands in the South, Florida Collegians and The Original Inkspots in Harlem. She raised her family in the Bronx from 1947-1997. Lived in Nanuet, NY from 1997-1999. After retirement, she was a loving fulltime wife and mother, an excellent cook, master at crochet and embroidery. She was married to her late husband Pat Jackson from September 30, 1943 until his death March 6, 1998. She is survived by her daughters Mrs. Harolgen Chestnut of Mitchellville, MD and Theresa P. Jackson, M.D. of Spring Valley, NY, son-in-law MSGT. Mose Chestnut, Jr., grandson Patrick Darryl Chestnut, granddaughter Audrey Yvette Chestnut, great grandchildren Linton Tre'Mark, and Edward Glenn, and great - great - granddaughter Lania-Renee. Reposing Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Sniffen Segala Funeral Home, 235 Route 59, Spring Valley, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 10 AM at St. Joseph's Church, North Main Street, Spring Valley. Interment Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Windgate of Dutchess Rehabilitation Center, 3 Summit Court, Fishkill, NY 12524.

title: Mining Firms Reap the Benefits of Being Late Adopters
description: ANDY FULTON works in a business that is as old-school and basic as you can get. As vice president of the international division of ME International, he sells what are called cast wear parts for stone crushers at mining sites. Ore mixed with stone is pulverized by these large crushing machines, and after a while the coverings of the crushing machines wear out. That is where ME International comes in with its custom-made parts for worn machinery.

title: ING Group Reviewing U.S. Assignments
description: The ING Group in Amsterdam, a financial services and insurance company, said yesterday that it had begun a review for an agency of record to handle marketing and branding assignments in the United States.

title: Olive Oil, Served With a Splash
description: Ilo, the new restaurant in the Bryant Park Hotel, 40 West 40th Street, has an eye-catching way of pouring extra virgin Tuscan olive oil on a plate for dipping bread, or drizzling Da Vero oil from California on whole roasted fish or in the bowl of seafood in broth called the Tidal Pool, below. Waiters use an aceitera (pronounced ah-seh-ee-TAIR-ah), a handblown clear glass carafe and siphon made by Emilio Rabal, a craftsman in Spain.

title: Trivia Question: A Bad Year for Boston
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: How Big Is Our Endowment? Ask Me at the End of the Month
description: AS the director of trusts and investments administrator of Berea College in Kentucky, Barry D. Poynter has a lot of money to invest, almost $800 million. But do not ask him exactly how much his portfolio is worth. He finds that out once a month through the mail.

title: Robeson Junior Stars At the Eastern States
description: Erica Alston, a 16-year-old junior at Paul Robeson High School in Brooklyn, won the long jump at 18 feet 2 inches, the 100-meter dash in 12.83 seconds and ran a leg on the winning 400-meter relay team (47.39 seconds) last night in the Eastern States Girls Interscholastic Championships at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, N.Y.

title: EQUIFAX APPROVES SPINOFF OF PAYMENT SERVICE UNIT
description: Equifax, a consumer credit reporting company, said yesterday that its board had approved a plan to spin off the company's credit card processing and check-transaction business. Equifax will distribute shares of the unit, named Certegy, on July 7 as a dividend to shareholders. Each shareholder of record on June 27 will receive one share of Certegy for every two shares of Equifax held. Equifax is spinning off the payment services unit, which is growing faster than the rest of the company, to make its operations easier to understand and its stocks more attractive. Certegy will start trading on the New York Stock Exchange on July 9. Plans to spin off the unit were first announced in October. Equifax will also cut its quarterly dividend to 2 cents a share from 9.25 cents after the spinoff to raise cash for acquisitions and investments.

title: Report Rejects Disciplining Of Parks Officials in Wildfire
description: A little more than a year after the worst wildfire in New Mexico history, the National Park Service issued a report yesterday that recommends against disciplining any park service employees who started the fire as a prescribed burn.

title: PRINTER WARNS OF LOWER YEARLY EARNINGS AND CUTS JOBS
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a large printer, said yesterday that its profit would fall further this year than expected, and it would cut another 250 jobs as demand for commercial printing services lags. Earnings will be $1.60 to $1.75 a share before restructuring charges and one-time items, down from its already-reduced estimates of $1.95 to $2.10 a share, the company estimated. The company is reducing its work force 5 percent, to 33,000, this year, including previously announced cuts, said a spokeswoman, Vera Panchak. Donnelley said earlier this year that it would close plants in Iowa and Florida and cut almost 1,000 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYRICK, HERBERT
description: WYRICK-Herbert, 83. Of New York City, on June 9. A musician, NYC public school teacher and WWII army veteran. Survived by sisters, Mary Olson and Margaret Wyrick. A memorial service will be held in Knoxville, TN.

title: Nokia Lowers Forecasts; Its Shares Dive
description: Nokia of Finland, the world's leading maker of mobile phones, warned today that its sales and earnings would fall short of estimates in the second quarter, surprising investors and sending the company's stock down more than 22 percent.

title: Sinn Fein's Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSKY, MARK
description: LIPSKY-Mark. The Merrick Jewish Centre, Congregation Ohr Torah, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Dr. Mark Lipsky, and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dr. Gail Sherry, their son, Scott, and the entire family. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Barry M. Lasky, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMESON, REV. FRED BEAVER CHIEF
description: JAMESON-Rev. Fred Beaver Chief. Born January 15, 1955, passed away at Queen Anne Post Office on June 8, 2001. Funeral ceremony will be offered at Bonney-Watson, 1732 Broadway on Capital Hill, Wednesday, June 13, 2001 at 10:00 AM. He is survived by his mother, wife, son, brothers, sisters, and many relatives.

title: Strikes Cancel Many Flights At 2 South Korean Airlines
description: South Korea's two major airlines canceled two thirds of their flights today, as pilots and ground crews answered a call by the tough-talking Korean Confederation of Trade Unions to join a general strike at companies across the country.

title: Nets Look to Make a Deal
description: Two weeks before the N.B.A. draft, the Nets are pursuing trades and soliciting offers for their No. 7 pick. But no deal is imminent, Nets President Rod Thorn said yesterday.

title: Valentine Says Mets Are Plagued By Doubt
description: Bobby Valentine has tried clubhouse speeches and individual huddles. He has worn a rally cap and offered bold predictions for his team. All of it has been part of an effort to coax the Mets into believing they can win. Most of it has not worked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFSKY, WILLIAM L.
description: RAFSKY-William L. Greatly admired, respected and loving uncle, a true role model and a statesman and civic leader of immense accomplishments. To our dear aunt Selma, to whom he was an adoring husband of sixty years, to his devoted son Larry and special granddaughter Sara, we extend our heartfelt sympathies. He was a unique human being and will be sorely missed. Lainie and Victor

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Spend the Extra $150 on Chocolate
description: Swissair and Sabena will take $150 off an economy-class round-trip ticket to either Switzerland or Belgium for flights between Sept. 1 and Dec. 14, as long as the ticket is purchased by June 30. The fares are good from 10 United States gateways, including Newark, Kennedy, Chicago, Los Angeles, Miami, San Francisco, Washington and Boston. To book the fare, call (800) 967-5855 and refer to the fare code RQ426Y. This discount cannot be combined with other offers or used on a sale fare. Various airport fees and taxes add $63; seats are limited.

title: Article 2001061390898826071 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Providing Fixer-Uppers With Tips, Tools and T.L.C.
description: DAYS before moving into a dilapidated 1904 Victorian house in Portland, Ore., last summer, Cindy Banks posted a frantic note on the Internet.

title: 3 Hurt in Police Car Crash
description: A police car racing to a report of gunfire collided with another car yesterday at 60th Street and 17th Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn, sending a 62-year-old woman who was crossing the street to the hospital, the police said. The woman suffered a broken arm and a fractured pelvis, and was in stable condition at Lutheran Medical Center.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Job Slowdown Continues
description: New Jersey's economy continued to slow down in May, as the number of jobs fell by 2,600 and the unemployment rate edged up slightly, according to the State Department of Labor. The unemployment rate, adjusted for seasonal factors, rose to 4.3 percent from 4.2 percent. The national level is 4.4 percent. A year ago, the state's jobless rate was 3.7 percent. May was the third straight month of job losses. Jobs have declined by 9,100 since peaking in February. While most losses have been in manufacturing, service jobs have declined by 3,500. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, KERMIT, M.D.
description: PINES-Kermit, M.D. The faculty and staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Dr. Kermit Pines, who passed away Sunday, June 10, 2001. A highly regarded educator, researcher, and clinician, Dr. Pines dedicated his entire medical career to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and its community, serving both the university and hospital in a variety of appointments for over 40 years. He will be sincerely missed by the students, patients, and colleagues whose lives he enriched through his expertise. We will cherish his memory, and promise to continue the legacy of medical excellence that he embodied. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Pines family. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Vice-President for Health and Biomedical Sciences, Dean of the Faculty of Health Sciences Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons Thomas Q. Morris, M.D. Senior Associate Vice-President for Health Sciences Vice Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

title: Recipe: Ravioli Dolce
description: RAVIOLI DOLCE

title: As Japan's Economy Slows, A Push for Bank to Do More
description: A day after the release of statistics showing the Japanese economy to be far weaker than expected, pressure began mounting on the central bank to expand its role in stemming the slide.

title: In Virginia, Young Conservatives Learn How to Develop and Use Their Political Voices
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The art of selling conservatism as compassion is taught here, a few miles from the White House, at boot camp for young conservatives who aspire to power.

title: Keeping Their Day Jobs, Dabbling in Dot-Com Dreams
description: The flood of people giving up their day jobs to join dot-coms switched into reverse a long time ago. But there are still plenty of dot-com dabblers out there -- people who are developing Internet businesses in their free time for the creative outlet, to promote social causes or even to try and make enough money to leave their day jobs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose on speculation the European Central Bank will buy the currency to support it after a 10 percent drop this year. In New York, the euro settled at 85.31 cents, up from 85.05 cents on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, GEORGE T.
description: SIMON-George T. A Jazz Memorial Service celebrating the life of Grammy winner, George T. Simon (1912-2001), featuring the music of Dr. Billy Taylor, Helen Merrill and others, will be held at 1 PM, on June 14, 2001 at Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, entrance on 54th Street.

title: It's Ballroom Dancing, Preteen Style
description: The ballroom dance competition began as any dance competition might, with the introduction of contestants and a quick prance around the stage for the many couples who hoped to outstep everyone else and take home the first-place prize.

title: Three more agencies tell of problems they are having because of the slowdown in the economy.
description: IN ANOTHER sign of the significant effects the slowing economy is having on Madison Avenue, three agencies and agency companies described difficulties yesterday that included the restatement of financial goals and results as well as layoffs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about flooding in the Houston area misstated the surname of a Brazoria County judge who commented on the damage. He is John G. Willy, not Will.

title: Making Programs Like Water: Free and Transparent
description: TIM O'REILLY, the chief executive of O'Reilly & Associates in Sebastopol, Calif., is known as the publisher of technical books whose whimsical covers, sporting animal woodcuts, belie the denseness of the subjects inside. One of O'Reilly's all-time best sellers, for instance, is a manual for the Perl programming language.

title: Article 2001061393202804748 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Government Offers Paternity Leave
description: The government has decided that fathers, too, need time off to be with their newborn children. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has announced that starting next year fathers will be able to take two weeks of fully paid paternity leave. Mothers are already entitled to six weeks. The new measure, which will cost an estimated $90 million a year, is to be submitted to Parliament in the fall. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Paris Talks Will Address Plan Revising Iraq Sanctions
description: Meetings today and Wednesday in Paris bringing together technical experts and officials from the five major powers on the Security Council are expected to give the first clear indication whether a revised oil-sales plan for Iraq stands a chance of being approved soon, diplomats said on Monday.

title: Market Place; Nasdaq Says New Pricing Has Cut Investors' Costs
description: The switch to pricing stocks in pennies on the Nasdaq market has substantially reduced trading costs for small investors, according to data released by the Nasdaq yesterday.

title: War Memorial Builder Has Link to Nazi Era
description: One of the two American companies selected last week to build a World War II memorial on the Mall is owned by a German construction company that used concentration camp labor during World War II.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lucent Credit Rating Is Cut To Junk Status by S.& P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHAN
description: WEISS-Stephan. Born September 16, 1938. Died on June 10th, 2001. Beloved husband of Donna Karan, father of Corey Weiss, Lisa WeissKeyes and Gabrielle Karan and grandfather of Mackenzie, Miles, Mercer, Etan and Maya Rose. An exceptional creator and co-founder of Donna Karan International, his wit, charm, intelligence and forward thinking impressed all who knew him. He will live on through the many whose lives he touched with his goodness and humanity. Funeral services will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to The Karan-Weiss Foundation, dedicated to benefiting medical research, education and the arts, C/O Urban Zen, LLC, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10018.

title: New Pots That Brew, Not Burn
description: JUST about everybody has experienced it: you make a pot of coffee, get distracted, leave it on the heating element too long. And 15 minutes later, that velvety, bracing cup of coffee has turned into something acrid -- liquid cinder in your mouth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Stock Swindle Is Alleged
description: Federal prosecutors announced the indictment yesterday of four men who are accused of bilking investors in an Internet company founded by Stan Lee, the creator of the Spiderman comic book series, out of more than $25 million. The defendants -- Stephen M. Gordon, 50, Charles Kusche, 47, Peter Paul, 52, and Jeffrey Pittsburg, 57 -- artificially inflated the stock of Stan Lee Media Inc., then sold it for a profit, the prosecutors said. Mr. Lee, who also created the Incredible Hulk and the X-Men comic series, was not involved in the case. Stephanie Stephenson, an executive assistant to Kenneth Williams, the chief executive officer of Stan Lee Media Inc., said neither the company nor its employees had any comment on the case. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROCKER, EDNA
description: STROCKER-Edna. Delaire Country Club announces with deep regret the passing of our esteemed member, Edna Strocker, and extends their sincerest sympathy to her husband Stanley and her beloved family. Mal Levenson, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, EDWARD
description: EISEN-Edward, 79, of Lecanto, Florida, formerly of Franklin Square, New York, passed away on June 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father to David & Karen Eisen, Richard & Andrea Eisen, April & Roger Leavy, Robin & Stephen Perkins, Barbara & Ronald Taub. Adoring grandfather to Brett, Alexandra, Joshua, Noah, Lisa, Jeff, Tara, and Amelia. Loving great-grandfather to Taylor. Donations may be made to The Jewish Community FoundationEdward Eisen Memorial Fund. 9901 Donna Klein Boulevard, Boca Raton, Florida 33428 or Hospice of Citrus County. 3350 Audubon Park Path, Lecanto, Florida 34461.

title: Wahid, Trying To Hold On, Shuffles Cabinet Again
description: In his latest move to try to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia shuffled his economic team today, reassigning a chief minister who had clashed with the International Monetary Fund.

title: With Rebels Near Macedonian Capital, Talks Are to Begin
description: Here in Macedonia's capital, with government troops facing ethnic Albanian rebels just a few miles away and with delicate negotiations among political factions about to begin, people are growing increasingly tense.

title: Role of Arms Accords
description: To the Editor:

title: Longtime Computer Designer Leaving Disney Research Unit
description: In the wake of a round of corporate belt-tightening at the Walt Disney Company, an influential group of programmers led by the computer designer Alan Kay is leaving the company's research division, where the team has worked on an educational programming system for the last five years.

title: Lyme Disease Is Hard to Catch And Easy to Halt, Study Finds
description: Lyme disease is very difficult to catch, even from a deer tick in a Lyme-infested area, and can easily be stopped in its tracks with a single dose of an antibiotic, a new study shows.

title: Recipe: Chinese Vegetable Soong
description: CHINESE VEGETABLE SOONG

title: Technology Briefing | Software: CMGI Closing Ad Software Unit
description: CMGI, the struggling Internet holding company, said yesterday that it would close AdForce, the online advertising software company it acquired last year for $500 million, after searching unsuccessfully for a buyer. Three other units remain on the block -- Activate, which broadcasts audio and video over the Internet; Navisite, which operates Web sites; and Navipath, which provides private networks. AdForce was partly owned by Sun Microsystems, Compaq and Novel, which had each invested $20 million. A CMGI spokeswoman declined to say how much of the $15 million to $20 million in costs from the shutdown these other companies would cover. Also yesterday, CMGI said it had lost $963.3 million in the quarter ended April 30, compared with a loss of $428 million a year earlier. The company said it now expected revenue to stay constant in the fourth quarter rather than the 3 to 5 percent increase it had forecast. The company has $785 million in cash. If it is unable to sell more units, it expects the cash to decline to $650 million by the end of July. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Chairman Resigns At DDB in Chicago
