description: The Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that Alan Pilkington, chairman since February 1995, would retire. He will be succeeded by Bob Scarpelli, who will also continue as United States chief creative officer.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Edwin Shapiro; Jewish Leader, 80
description: Edwin Shapiro, a former president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, an American Jewish refugee agency, and a leader in other Jewish organizations, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Branch Davidians Shed No Tears for McVeigh
description: Their ranks are small these days, outnumbered by the 80 crape myrtles planted at the Mount Carmel compound to commemorate each of the Branch Davidians who died here eight years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADIR VOIP TECHNOLOGIES, Newark, a software company, has agreed to buy the NetSpeak Corp., Boca Raton, Fla., for $46.5 million to $48.2 million to add software for sending telephone calls and video over the Internet.

title: Revisiting a Venture Capital Conference a Year Later
description: AUSTIN, Tex. -- WHEN a speaker at this year's Texas Venture Capitalist Conference talked about how dot-coms went wrong last year, thinking, for instance, they could "turn gardeners into online couch potatoes," there was more than a little squirming in the audience. After all, one investor said, about half the people in the room had put money into Garden.com, a local and highly publicized failure.

title: Flood Tunneled Into Houston's Cultural Heart
description: Barry Mandel, director of the downtown Theater District Association, stood outside Jones Hall today, home to the Houston Symphony, and listened not to violins but to the groan of a generator pumping water from the flooded bowels of the auditorium. Below, the music library may be ruined. Instruments are floating in chest-deep water.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Banking Consolidation
description: HypoVereinsbank, Germany's second-biggest bank, said it might close as many as 90 branches to cut costs at the consumer banking unit after earnings dropped. The bank plans to combine some of its own outlets with those of the Vereins-und Westbank and Norisbank units, said a spokesman, Thomas Pfaff. He would not say how many jobs would be cut. The chief executive, Albrecht Schmidt, left, who has shut 300 branches since 1998, is cutting costs as revenue growth slows and overhead rises.

title: Article 2001061393494165507 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, HAROLD DEAN
description: GIBSON-Harold Dean. Age 74, on June 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of Patrick & Leslie and their spouses Bonnie and Edward Maluf. Adoring grandfather of Celia, Nicholas, Sofia and Eric. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM with service Friday 9:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Arts Student's League of New York, Victor D'Amico Institute of Art (The Art Barge) in Amagansett, NY or the American Cancer Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an accident near the George Washington Bridge referred incorrectly to the effect on traffic. The eastbound lanes of an expressway that links the bridge to the Alexander Hamilton Bridge, which leads to the Bronx, were shut for four hours. The Washington Bridge was not closed, though backups lasted more than four hours.

title: INSIDE
description: Insurer May Quit New Jersey

title: Miscellany
description: * Euro RSCG Worldwide, a unit of Havas Advertising, acquired for undisclosed terms majority stakes in an interactive agency in Argentina, WhyNet, and two Polish marketing agencies, Dialog and Marketing House. They will be renamed WhyNet Euro RSCG Interaction, Euro RSCG Dialog and Euro RSCG Marketing House.

title: Criminal Justice on a Global Scale
description: In the last few weeks, almost unnoticed in the North American press, the case against General Augusto Pinochet of Chile entangled Henry Kissinger. A judge in Paris sent officials to the Ritz hotel, where the former secretary of state was staying, to serve him with a request to appear in the judge's chambers to answer questions about American involvement in Chile almost 30 years ago. Mr. Kissinger declined to attend, citing obligations elsewhere. He flew on to Italy. Days earlier, a judge in Argentina, investigating a series of political killings around Latin America that have been linked to General Pinochet, had announced that he would be seeking Mr. Kissinger's testimony.

title: There's Silicon in Them Thar Hills, or Will Be Soon
description: IN the 1860's, this Mormon settlement lost its bid to be a transcontinental railroad stop. This time, it is smack dab on the tracks of technological progress.

title: Shares Outlast an Early Sell-Off to Close Little Changed
description: The stock market recovered yesterday from an early sell-off. The main gauges ended little changed, as investors regained their footing after Nokia became the latest technology company to warn that its second-quarter earnings and revenue would be weaker than expected.

title: Closing of Hiring Site Reflects Tensions Over Latino Workers
description: Six weeks after Suffolk County rejected a proposal to create a community support center where Hispanic day laborers could wait for work each morning, a similar battle has broken out here in neighboring Nassau County.

title: New Champion's Trial in Round 2
description: It was the boxer's turn to watch his ex-promoter take the hard knocks.

title: Bush Administration Is Split Over Stem Cell Research
description: A battle is raging within the Bush administration over whether to prohibit federal support for biomedical research that uses cells derived from human embryos, federal officials say.

title: A Posthumous Hit Parade For Ever-Serene Perry Como
description: Tranquillity is one musical quality that has earned scant critical respect in the annals of American pop. For decades, terms like Muzak and elevator music have been affixed contemptuously to sounds deemed too soft and complacent to be taken seriously in a culture obsessed with upward mobility and the grinding friction it produces.

title: Lasso a Wild Horse And a Posse of Helpers
description: WHEN Melissa Scott bid on a set of collectible models of wild horses on eBay, she could tell what she was buying. But bidding $1,315 on an actual mustang on a different Web auction was another matter.

title: 'I Think You're a Monster' And Other Interview Lines
description: There is a huge difference between a good idea for a series and a good series, and the distance between them has rarely been as evident as it is in ''The Beast.'' The show takes an incendiary concept -- a television news channel and Webcast that follow their own reporters' lives as well as actual news 24 hours a day -- then loads on red-hot references to Timothy McVeigh, yet still seems hollow and tame.

title: Liberties; Inside Al Gore's Head
description: Talk about Goofy meets Goya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLERSTEIN, ROSE
description: WALLERSTEIN-Rose. 93. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Mother of Barbara and Edward Bickel, Stanley and Sara-Ann Wallerstein. Sister of Jean and Irving Perfit, Julie and Helen Rosenberg. Grandmother of Susan and Stephen Scherr, Jeffrey and Cynthia Wallerstein, Shari Bickel and Todd Cutler, Allen and Karen Bickel. Loving great grandmother of ten. Services Thursday, 11 AM, at Schwartz Bros., Queens Blvd and 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERCIER, LOUIS F.V.
description: MERCIER-Louis F.V., 86, of Westport, CT former picture editor, Holiday Magazine 1946-65, died June 7, 2001. Funeral services are private. Donations may be made to the St. Labre Indian School in care of Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230.

title: The Death of McVeigh: A Time to Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, REBECCA S.
description: RUDNICK-Rebecca S., 48. Was drowned on June 2 in Papua New Guinea when the boat on which she was a passenger capsized and sank. She was a Visiting Professor of Law at Boston College. The author of numerous papers in the taxation area, she was a ''floating'' professor whose 14 appointments in the nation's law schools and as Prof-in-Residence at the IRS totaled more than any other tax specialist. She also held a variety of overseas appointments, and was an Advisor to the IMF. She was raised in Bakersfield, CA, received her J.D. from the University of Texas, and her B.A. from Willamette University. She served as law clerk to the Hon. Charles Schwartz, Jr., U.S. District Judge for the E.D. of Louisiana. A member of the New York, California, Texas, and Louisiana bars, she practiced law in New York for six years at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. She was an accomplished sportswoman, who made frequent diving, fly fishing, and skiing expeditions throughout the world. She is survived by her husband, Robert Anthoine, also a tax attorney who frequently taught with her, and 8 half-brothers and sisters. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, Bakersfield, CA, on June 18 at 11 AM. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rebecca Rudnick Memorial Scholarship, Bakersfield High School, 1241 G Street, Bakersfield, CA. 93301.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, JOHN PATRICK
description: PORTER-John Patrick. June 11, 2001, age 69. Beloved husband of Karen Lea, devoted father of Marianne, cherished grandfather of Robert, Joseph, Tamer and Danny, loving brother of William Porter. A recipient of 5 Bronze Stars during the Korean War and a noted psychotherapist in the metropolitan area for many years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday, June 14, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, June 15, 10 AM at St. Monica's Church, East 79 St, between York Avenue and First Ave., NYC.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kidnapping Case Unresolved
description: The Queens district attorney and lawyers for Barry and Judith Smiley, left, a New Mexico couple accused of kidnapping, agreed yesterday that a court-appointed financial expert should determine the couple's ability to pay restitution. However, they were unable to strike an overall plea bargain on the charges against them. They are accused of kidnapping an infant 22 years ago in New York and raising him as their son. The child's biological father, Anthony Russini, wants them to stand trial, but the district attorney and lawyers for the couple said in court yesterday that plea negotiations would continue. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Soccer Indictments Sought
description: A congressional committee investigating corruption in professional soccer has recommended that 32 team managers and player agents be indicted, including Ricardo Teixeira, president of the Brazilian Soccer Federation. The panel has also urged that Eurico Miranda, who is president of the national champion Vasco da Gama club and a member of Congress, be impeached for illegally diverting team funds to finance his election campaign. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: For the Love of Pasta, a Director Moves Into Macaroni
description: FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA -- filmmaker, winemaker, restaurateur and food buff -- had barely arrived at the Morisi-Coppola Pasta factory in Brooklyn last Friday when he asked John Morisi, whose parents started the company in 1940, if he could put a pot of water on to boil for ravioli.

title: Salute to a Rights Campaigner Who Gave Genocide Its Name
description: One hundred years after his birth, a largely forgotten immigrant from Poland who coined the word genocide and pushed a convention outlawing it through the General Assembly is being honored here, thanks to a small human rights institute in New York campaigning to keep his story alive.

title: 2 SIDES IN MIDEAST ACCEPT U.S. PLAN FOR A CEASE-FIRE
description: Israel and the Palestinians have accepted an American cease-fire proposal after six days of intensive mediation by the director of central intelligence, American officials said early this morning.

title: Goldman Sachs Creating Board to Help It Do Business in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, June 13  The Goldman Sachs Group is expected to announce on Thursday that it has created a blue-chip advisory board for its Japanese operations, with members including Thomas S. Foley, the former House speaker and until recently, United States ambassador to Japan, and Nobuyuki Idei, chief executive of the Sony Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, KIM FREDERIC
description: SHULMAN-Kim Frederic, 45. Passed away on June 1, 2001 of a cerebral hemorrhage. He leaves a son, Daniel, his parents, Claire and Mel Shulman, a brother, Dr. Larry Shulman, and a sister, Dr. Ellen Baker. Services were held on June 5 in California. He will be in our hearts forever. Contributions may be sent in his memory to The Jimmy Fund at Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 1309 Beacon Street, Brookline, Massachusetts 02446.

title: If You Hate Web Ads, You Can 'Just Say No'
description: HATE Internet ads? Are those pushy pop-ups increasing your annoyance level? There is a way to fight back.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Phone Company Slowdown
description: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's biggest phone company, cut its forecast of profit growth for the year in half, citing a drop in market share and price cuts. The company's stock fell 9 percent, the largest decline since it began trading in 1997. The company expects pretax profit to increase 5 percent in the year ending June 30, compared with a March forecast of 10 percent growth. It forecast fiscal second-half pretax profit to be little changed from a year ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Wireless Share Buyback
description: Rogers Communications Inc. offered to repurchase outstanding Class B shares in Rogers Wireless Communications Inc., Canada's No. 2 mobile-phone company. Rogers Wireless shareholders will get 1.1 shares of Rogers Communications, a Rogers Wireless spokeswoman, Heather Armstrong, said. The price is a 24 percent premium to Rogers Wireless Class B shares, based on the five-day average of 27.14 Canadian dollars ($15.92) a share, she said.

title: I.B.M. Plans To Expand An Alliance In Germany
description: International Business Machines and SAP, the German business software giant, are planning to substantially broaden their longstanding, if not always smooth, partnership over the next three years.

description: WEST

title: Spencer Is Recalled And Bragg Is Claimed
description: George Steinbrenner and Joe Torre insist they are not ready to panic and that a trade is not necessary to fix what ails the Yankees. Yesterday, the Yankees began making more subtle changes. Outfielders Henry Rodriguez and Robert Perez were designated for assignment, outfielder Shane Spencer was recalled from Class AAA Columbus and outfielder Darren Bragg was claimed on waivers from the Mets. And the Yankees may be ready to address their sagging bullpen and fifth starter spot.

title: Lucent's Credit Rating Downgraded by S.& P.
description: Standard & Poor's lowered the credit rating of Lucent Technologies to junk status in a move yesterday that may make it somewhat more costly for the beleaguered company to borrow money.

title: Franks Urges Notification on Abortions
description: Bob Franks, running for governor as a Republican who supports abortion rights, urged the State Legislature today to approve an amendment to the State Constitution that would require parental notification for minors seeking abortions.

title: Judge Says Some Employers Must Cover Contraceptives
description: In the first court ruling on the issue of gender equity in drug coverage, a federal judge in Seattle said yesterday that the Bartell Drug Company, a family-owned drugstore chain, discriminated against women when it excluded prescription contraceptives from its employee health plan.

title: Article 2001061391335898494 -- No Title
Of Steppes And Songs, Mongolia's Treasures
description: Americans can't help thinking of Asia as the East, but Mongolia, on the stretch of plain between China and Russia, is really a Wild West, a perennial frontier now evolving from purely nomadic to increasingly urbanized.

title: Senate Backs Stiffer Rules On Driving While Drunk
description: The State Senate passed a bill today that tightens the definition of drunken driving but attaches stiffer penalties, making it less likely that a compromise will be reached with the Assembly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, ROSE MARIE
description: ALEXANDER-Rose Marie. 100. Loving matriarch of the Weinbaum family. Survived by her son Dan, daughter-in-law Lou, grandchildren Dana, Dan, Jr., and David, great grandchildren Sarah, Emily, Alex and Ethan and special grand niece Tracy. Visitation Tuesday 7-9pm. Services Wednesday 11:30am The Riverside, 76th St & Amsterdam. Contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Cool Gift Wrapping That Packs a Crunch
description: CHOPSTICKS are fine, in their place. But Asian chefs have an even better delivery system for savory morsels of grilled meat, curried fish or stir-fried vegetables: the lettuce wrap. Spoon some filling into a leaf of iceberg lettuce, romaine -- even radicchio -- fold it and roll, and forget about other silverware.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, ROGER W.
description: WADE-Roger W., 82. Died peacefully at home in Kissimmee, FL. on June 7th. Roger was a pioneer in the audio-visual production field with his company, Roger Wade Productions. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Theodosia Sedgwick, Carolyn, Roger, Jr. and Alexander. Dear brother to Dorothy Beckstrand, Clifford and the late Elizabeth. Adored grandfather to nine grandchildren and a great-grandchild. Donations may be sent in his name to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held on July 8th at Scarborough Presbyterian Church in Briarcliff Manor, New York.

title: For Brunches or Breakfasts Of an Almost Wild Sort
description: How do you gather the eggs of wild turkeys? You raise the birds in pens, as Quattro Farms in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., does. The turkeys, wild in name only, are smaller and leaner than their familiar cousins. Their eggs are pinkish, speckled and larger than chicken eggs (comparison above), with bigger yolks and a richer, sweeter flavor. Sam DeMarco, the chef at Merge, 142 West 10th Street, serves them poached atop the turkey hash at Sunday brunch ( $15). Quattro Farms is selling the eggs for $3.50 a dozen at the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturdays through early July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREXLER, SHIRLEY
description: DREXLER - Shirley. Elmwood Country Club acknowledges with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Shirley Drexler.

description: AUSTRALIA<BR AUSTRALIA: PHONE COMPANY SLOWDOWN

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO BUY ROOFING MATERIALS COMPANY
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, has agreed to buy a maker of roofing components for $378 million. The investment company will buy MiTek, of Chesterfield, Mo., Rexam of London, MiTek's parent, announced yesterday. Rexam said it would use the proceeds to repay debt.

title: Japan and Tobacco Revenue: Leader Faces Difficult Choice
description: For pushing through an ordinance banning cigarette vending machines from the streets of his tiny town a few hundred miles north of Tokyo, the World Health Organization wanted to bestow an award on the mayor of Fukauramachi in honor of No Smoking Day last month.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Yukie Okuyama, Mahdi Kazuto Shah, Hristoula Harakas, Ellen Cornfield and Denise Johnsson, Merce Cunningham Studio, New York, March 17, 2001

title: Twists, Stops and Turns With a Passion for Surprise
description: The American Dance Festival opened its annual summer season over the weekend with high-power performances by Garth Fagan Dance. And on Sunday night Mr. Fagan received the 2001 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award at a ceremony in Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Chelsea Gallery Building Replacing Former Shop
description: A former truck repair shop on 10th Avenue in Chelsea is to be torn down and replaced by a six-story building geared to gallery and fine arts tenants in what brokers describe as the first nonresidential construction in recent memory in the far-west section of the neighborhood.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEEDS, MORTON
description: LEEDS-Morton. June 13, 1984. We remember with love. Always in our hearts

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Tax Break Ends
description: Foreign companies operating in China will soon lose their preferential tax treatment there. Beijing plans to equalize tax policies and put in place a uniform 25 percent corporate tax rate. That is less than the 33 percent that Chinese companies pay now, but more than the 12 percent to 15 percent levied on foreign concerns. The new tax system is expected to take effect when China joins the World Trade Organization. The country's entry to the organization is expected later this year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EDWIN
description: SHAPIRO-Edwin. Died peacefully in his sleep after a long struggle with cancer. Beloved husband of Dena, loving father and father-inlaw of Steven/Sharon & Len/Bilha and the late Richard. Adored grandfather of Ronen, Oren, Alon, Reuven and Samuel. Respected stepfather of Alan and Renee Zellner. Also survived by his former wife Claire Zucker Shapiro, his brother Milton and sister Lillian Kushel. A graduate of CCNY. Longtime director of Camp Sequoia in Rock Hill, NY. Past President of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), United States Association for International Migration (US Aim), American Camping Association (NY section) and Association of Private Camps, Treasurer, Member of Executive Committee, Overseer, of CARE, Chairman B'nai B'rith Hillel Commission, Chairman of the Executive Committee of NY Association of New Americans (NYANA) and a member of the American delegation to the Emergency 65-country parley on the Indochinese Refugee Crisis held in Geneva in 1979. Ed will be sorely missed by his family and friends, generations of campers and counselors of Camp Sequoia, the refugees he so vigorously worked to help and his many colleagues in Jewish philanthropy, human rights affairs and children's camping. Services Wednesday, June 13th, 1:15PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Shiva to be observed by Dena and family at 140 East 83rd St. Wednesday, June 13-Friday June 15 from 3PM, and Steve and Len will continue shiva on Saturday night, Sunday and Monday at 191 Hamilton Rd., Chappaqua, NY. Donations may be made to the Richard Alan Shapiro Memorial Scholarship Award, c/o HIAS, 333 Seventh Avenue, 17th floor, New York, New York 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, MICHAEL HARRISON
description: COHEN - Michael Harrison. 1971-1990. Time has not diminished our sadness or our love for you. Mom, Dad & Charles

title: Sports of The Times; Father's Strong Hand Has Been the Guiding Force in O'Neal's Life
description: PHILLIP HARRISON finished a meandering conversation over tea yesterday morning. Now he was ready to leave for a West Indian restaurant. Before he left, Harrison dropped a bombshell. ''I used to be an altar boy,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, TILLIE
description: GOLDMAN-Tillie. The Board and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and the Israel Museum, Jerusalem, are deeply saddened by the death of their friend, Tillie Goldman. Tillie was one of the original Founders of the Israel Museum and a supporter for four decades. Our condolences to Barbara, Marc and Tony. Teddy Kollek, President I.M. Judy Steinhardt, Co-Chair, A.F.I.M.

title: 'Artemis Fowl': Fairies in the Garden
description: We interrupt this New York Times Book Review for a special bulletin: There are fairies at the bottom of the garden. They are armed and dangerous. This latest invasion occurs in a fantasy called ''Artemis Fowl,'' by an Irish writer, Eoin Colfer. Stylishly packaged in a jacket of golden foil, each page subscripted with a second text in invented runic letters, the book follows in an oddly resilient literary tradition of fairy interference in human affairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, PATRICK J.
description: McKENNA-Patrick J. Pressman for forty-seven years. Native of Tydavnet, County Monaghan Ireland. Devoted husband of Keelin (nee Carlos) and the late Kathleen. Loving father of Karen McKenna Young, Michael and Patrick. Proud Grandpa of Kerry Rose, dear brother of Mary McKenna, Mena Powers, Chrissy Waters and Eddie McKenna of Ireland. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing at Leahy-McDonald Funeral Home, Atlantic Avenue at 111 Street, Richmond Hill, New York. Mass Friday 10AM, Church of the Holy Child Jesus. Interment is at St. Andrew's Cemetery. Sag Harbor, New York. Visiting 2:30-4:30, 7-9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERMAN, SOLOMON
description: PETERMAN-Solomon. Of Toms River, N.J. (formerly of NY, NY), father of Roberta Peters Fields, Metropolitan Opera soprano, on Monday, June 11. Age 93. A dear sweet person who loved his family dearly and had a great sense of humor. He will be missed tremendously but will forever be in the hearts of his family and friends. Beloved husband of the late Ruth (nee Hirsch) and Sarah (nee Wallach) Gordon Peterman. Loving father of Roberta Peters Fields and stepdaughters Judith Gordon Cook and Linda J. Sclarow. Cherished grandfather of Bruce and Paul Fields and step-grandchildren Dr. Gabriel Cook, Benay Taub, Jonathan Cook, Andrea Sclarow and Benjamin Sclarow. Adored great grandfather of Julie Robin, Jessica and twins Remy and Noah Fields & step great-grandchildren Matthew, Eliana, Joshua, Kian, Samarah and Darian. Funeral service Wednesday, June 13, 10:A.M. at Congregation B'nai Israel, 1448 Old Freehold Road, Toms River, NJ. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Congregation B'nai Israel or to the American Cancer Society. For information, Belkoff-Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Lakewood, New Jersey.

title: Judge Issues Mixed Rulings In Suits Against H.M.O.'s
description: A federal judge in Miami yesterday partly dismissed lawsuits that challenged the managed care practices of six big health insurers but said he would allow plaintiffs to amend their cases.

title: U.S. Suit Says French Trains Took Victims To the Nazis
description: Victims of Nazi Germany and Vichy France have gone into federal court in Brooklyn to pursue a new target -- the French national railroad.

title: Wrong Numbers Need Not Mean Summer School
description: Carol Spivack received a recorded telephone message from Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy late on Friday telling her that her son, Mark, was at risk of being held back a grade unless he attended summer school.

title: Watching Bush's Language, and Television
description: PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH, like the rest of us, has probably never given much thought to ''public intellectuals.'' But if he did, it is a sure bet he wouldn't invite busloads over for a barbecue.

title: Police Units Used Proper Force In Bronx Fracas, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the chairwoman of the local community board yesterday rejected complaints of excessive police force during a rowdy Bronx street celebration on Sunday, saying officers had acted properly to quell a volatile mob.

title: Postmodern and Post-Belgian
description: IF the food were better at Midway, a brasserie manque in the far West Village, I would be more willing to make the trek to its charming neighborhood, a remnant of a bygone Greenwich Village. A handful of tiny single-family homes with lush gardens strewn with children's playthings snuggle behind protective fences. Shade trees line the streets. Shops are small and inviting. The area is so appealing that I was only mildly surprised to hear of a woman who lived on the Upper East Side, in River House, and traveled to her ''country house'' in the far West Village on weekends.

title: Auto Insurer Plans to Quit New Jersey
description: The State Farm Indemnity Company, New Jersey's largest insurer of motorists, said today that it planned to withdraw from the auto insurance business in the state. The company cited persistent losses and accused state officials of dragging their feet on an eight-month-old request for a rate increase and on long-promised reforms.

title: Sputtering Yanks Lose On Disputed Home Run
description: Manager Joe Torre knew by the reaction of his players that something was wrong in left field in the 12th inning last night. The Yankees would not have protested so much if they were not sure that Mark Smith's shot into the left-field seats had been foul.

title: Taliban's Eradication of Poppies Is Convulsing Opium Market
description: The unexpected success of the Taliban in Afghanistan in eradicating three-quarters of the world's crop of opium poppies in one season is leading experts to ask where production is likely to spring up next.

title: Jeb Bush Signs Bill Barring Executing the Retarded
description: Joining a rising number of states that prohibit the execution of individuals who are mentally retarded, Gov. Jeb Bush extended the ban to Florida today under a bill he signed into law.

title: Camacho to Fight in Brooklyn
description: Lou DiBella, a Brooklyn-born boxing promoter, is so passionate about his hometown that he named one of his dogs after the borough and vowed to bring boxing back to its ``rightful place.''

title: All Puffed Up and Ready to Go
description: AS you come up from the Grand Street subway station, at the northwest corner of Grand and Chrystie Streets, you will see her: a young Asian woman standing by her grocery store shopping cart, in the shade of a row of telephone booths.

title: Europe's East Sees AIDS On the March
description: It did not seem pleasant for Krystyna Sokolowska to put her life on display -- the youthful year of heroin addiction that led to catching the virus that causes AIDS, to shuffling around homes for the infected that were never popular with scared neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MOLLIE G.
description: WEISS-Mollie G., 92. Died Monday at Nathan Adelson Hospice. She was born September 29, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY. A homemaker, she was a three year resident of Las Vegas and a member of Free Sons of Israel, F.D.R. Chapter, B'nai B'rith and Forest Hills Jewish Center. She is survived by her daughters Barbara Chozahinoff of NY, and Las Vegas, Eilene Weiss of West Hollywood, CA, son Monroe of New York City, sisters Mary Smookler of Torrance, CA., and Sylvia Ross of New York City, brother Julius Marmor of Long Island, NY and four grandchildren Dan, Sharon, Sasha and Piper. Services will be at 1:00 PM today at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY. The family request memorial donations to be made to Nathan Adelson Hospice, 4141 Swenson Street, Las Vegas, NV. 89119.

title: Loews Seeks to Sublease One Theater and Sell Three Others
description: Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation, the dominant movie theater chain in New York, is trying to sublease its four-screen State Theater in Times Square and sell three run-down movie theaters in the region: the Elmwood and Cinema 5 in Queens and the Hampton Arts in Westhampton Beach, N.Y., company officials said yesterday.

title: Bank Bid Is in Line With Singapore's Goals
description: Singapore's efforts to have its banks combine into heftier financial players appeared to bear fruit today, when the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation announced an unsolicited cash bid of 4.8 billion Singapore dollars ($2.65 billion) for the smaller Keppel Capital Holdings.

title: Education Study Finds U.S. Falling Short
description: Teachers in the United States earn less relative to national income than their counterparts in many industrialized countries, yet they spend far more hours in front of the classroom, according to a major new international study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIMMEL, GRETA
description: SHIMMEL-Greta, on June 11,2001. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of Judith Algaze and Howard Shimmel. Adoring grandmother of Sarah, Samantha, Jason and Evan. Funeral service today, 11:30AM, Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76 Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the Japanese film ''Dead or Alive'' in Weekend on Friday misstated the title of a Korean police thriller released last year with which it was contrasted. It is ''Nowhere to Hide,'' not ''Nowhere to Run.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hightstown: 2 Women Become Captains
description: Twenty-six years after a woman was first sworn in as a New Jersey trooper, the state police for the first time promoted two women to captain yesterday. The two women, Capt. Gayle M. Cameron (left, with her father) and Capt. Lori A. Hennon-Bell, were cadets together in 1980. There are 90 women in the 2,663-member state police force, said Sgt. Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the force. Two black men and two Hispanic men were also among the 27 officers promoted in a ceremony presided over by the state police superintendent, Col. Carson Dunbar. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: NBC Heartened by 'Fear Factor' Debut
description: Many television critics expressed sheer contempt for ''Fear Factor,'' the new NBC reality program in which contestants are challenged to perform extreme stunts -- like climbing into a pit filled with rats -- for a cash prize.

title: Addressing Alzheimer's
description: To the Editor:

title: In City's Primary Campaign, The Cry Is 'Sign on the Line'
description: They lurk on street corners, stalk you in the subway, follow you to your door and confront you outside the supermarket. They are New York City's latest nuisance, although they see themselves as the foot soldiers of democracy. They are petition carriers, and, since hundreds of people are running for public office, suddenly they are everywhere.

title: Kraft Offering Priced at $31, Above Estimate
description: Kraft Foods priced its initial public offering above the high end of its preliminary price range last night, indicating that underwriters led by Salomon Smith Barney and Credit Suisse First Boston had persuaded investors to ignore a highly unusual criticism of the offering by an analyst from Goldman, Sachs.

title: Article 2001061391980434065 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SEYMOUR
description: GOLDBERG - Seymour. The Board of Governors and membership of Ridgeway Country Club express their deepest condolences to Bella Goldberg and family upon the passing of Seymour Goldberg, a founding member of the club. Peter Arest, President

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Signing Up the Experts

title: The Tomato That Came To Dinner
description: Mom and Kid is a dish set for children decorated with an illustration from the book ''Play With Your Food,'' by Joost Elffers and Saxton Freymann. A whimsical mother tomato and her baby are reproduced on a plate, a bowl and a cup. The three-piece melamine set ($15.95 each) is dishwasher-safe and is also available with an image of a school bus carved from a melon. Other pictures from the book appear on adult-size dinner plates ($6.95), individual bowls ($5.95) and a serving tray ($18). At Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street). Uno Mundo, 23 East 20th Street, has the three-piece set. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: A Dangerous Border
description: The government called on neighboring Uzbekistan to disclose the location of anti-personnel mines planted along the border between the countries after two people were seriously wounded. The injuries were the latest in a string of accidents in which shepherds and other people from Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have stepped on mines that Uzbekistan said it had planted along its borders to keep out Islamic insurgents. There was no immediate response from the Uzbeks. Doug Frantz (NYT)

title: Rangers Get Serious About Their Youth
description: After four consecutive seasons of missing the playoffs, the Rangers' task is to replenish their minor-league system.

title: Wheeling and Dealing
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Political Memo; Bloomberg's Challenge: Be a '93 Giuliani, but in '01
description: Of all the candidates seeking to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, no one is trying to tie himself as closely to the outgoing mayor as Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: A Top Swiss Official Resigns In Money-Laundering Dispute
description: In a fresh embarrassment for Switzerland's efforts to convince the world that it is not a repository of dirty money, the head of a government office fighting financial crime abruptly resigned today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EDWIN
description: SHAPIRO-Edwin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Edwin Shapiro, a cherished friend and an extraordinary leader in the Jewish community. He touched the lives of a record number of Jewish immigrants through his work at HIAS and the New York Association for New Americans (NYANA), both beneficiaries of UJA-Federation. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife, Dena; to his sons, Steven and Len; to his five grandchildren, and to his entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Ex-Dictator Faces Inquiry
description: Acting on a lawsuit filed last week by 11 indigenous communities, a court ordered prosecutors to investigate Efran Ros Montt, the former dictator and current speaker of the Congress, on charges that he masterminded the massacres of tens of thousands of people during the country's civil war. As a legislator Gen. Ros Montt, who ruled in 1982 and 1983, is immune from prosecution but Judge Marco Posadas said that an investigation should proceed and that any revocation of immunity would be considered later. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Challenging Course, Even For Woods
description: Nobody has ever shot lower than 63 at the United States Open. And according to Lee Westwood, nobody will shoot 63 at Southern Hills Country Club this week.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, TATHIANA S. (TOMI)
description: KLINGER-Tathiana S. (Tomi). Died Tuesday, June 12, 2001 in Concord, NH. Devoted wife of Dr. Leo Klinger for 61 years. She is survived by her husband, her children and their spouses: Ann and Dana Turner of Austell, Ga., Charles and Carol Klinger of Honeoye Falls, NY and Bernard and Eda Klinger of White Plains, N.Y. Beloved grandmother of Maria and Daniel Barr, David Follman and Michael and Rebecca Klinger. Born on June 8, 1913 in New York City to Boris and Celia Shapiro. She graduated from NYU with a degree in economics. From 1940 to 1972 she lived in Rochester, NH serving on the School Board, Business and Professional Women, the Visiting Nurse Board and many civic organizations. Known to many as ''Ma Klinger'' she delighted in her hobbies of quilting, knitting, needle crafts and baking ''kurls.'' She will be greatly missed. Funeral service at Temple Beth Jacob, Concord, NH on Thursday, June 14th, at 2 PM.

title: JUDGE LETS FINOVA PROCEED WITH RECOVERY PLAN
description: A bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., ruled yesterday that the Finova Group could proceed with a $7.35 billion recovery plan proposed by Warren E. Buffett and the Leucadia National Corporation. In approving the plan's disclosure documents, the judge, Peter J. Walsh, overruled an objection by the GE Capital Corporation and the Goldman, Sachs Group. Finova's creditors rejected a $7.25 billion offer by GE Capital and Goldman, Sachs on Friday in favor of the higher offer from the venture by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the company run by Mr. Buffett, and Leucadia. Finova, based in Finova, Ill., will receive a $6 billion loan from the venture.

title: Soul-Searching at the Milestone Age of 30
description: Time did not pass quietly for Jonathan Larson. The man who created the rock opera ''Rent'' -- and who died at 35, two weeks before that show opened, of an aortic aneurysm -- seems to have lived his life and composed his music to the rhythm of some cosmic metronome, noisily decapitating the seconds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Elderly Couple Attacked
description: The police said yesterday that they were investigating a knife attack on an elderly Staten Island couple and an assault with a hot iron on the couple's home-care attendant. Investigators said a man and woman knocked on the door of the couple, whose names were not released, at 6:45 p.m. Tuesday, and were let in by the attendant. The intruders then pulled a knife, tied all three victims with duct tape and burned the attendant on her lower back before fleeing with cash and jewelry. The couple, both in their 80's, were treated for minor injuries at the scene. The attendant was treated at St. Vincent's Staten Island Hospital. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 24 about the White House's overruling of Secretary of State Colin Powell's choice to head the Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration included an erroneous State Department reference to the White House's proposed appointee, John M. Klink. He and Secretary Powell had indeed met -- briefly, in Mr. Powell's office on May 17, as Mr. Klink was being considered for the post.

title: O'Neal Powers Lakers to Verge of a Repeat
description: In hindsight, the riveting drama and surprising competition that had made these National Basketball Association finals so captivating probably ended when Shaquille O'Neal got riled in Game 3.

title: EVICTION NOTICE
description: Yet another online storage site is ending free service. I-drive (www.idrive.com) has announced it will no longer offer space for users to store files at its own site; instead, it will license its software to other companies. I-drive users have until Monday to remove their files.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, GEORGE
description: ABRAMS-George. 1919-2001. Internationally recognized lettering artist, type designer and book collector, died Thursday, June 7, in Great Neck, New York. As a founder of George Abrams Alphabets, Inc, he designed the logo mastheads for several popular magazines, including Saturday Evening Post, Ladies Home Journal, House Beautiful, Newsweek and the first edition of Sports Illustrated. Logo designs for corporate entities included B. Altman, Godiva Chocolates, Ford Thunderbird, and many others. Among his better known typefaces designed by George Abrams was Abrams Augereau and Abrams Venetian. The Venetian type was gifted to the Royal Danish Court for their exclusive use. His book collecting interests were varied, from incunabula to the Russian avant-garde. Abrams also lectured students world wide on the art of lettering and typeface design. He was a fellow of the Morgan Library, honorary fellow of the London Society of Typographic Designers, active in the New York Typophiles and the Grolier Club of New York. He is survived by his four children: Jeffrey, Vicki, Nancy, and Lauren & eight grandchildren, Ryan, Eric, Bryan, Kevin, Corey, Courtney, Dana, and Tyler. A memorial celebration will be held Saturday, June 16, 2001, at 6:30 PM at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th St, New York.

title: No Marquee Names, No Plush Seats, but What a Bargain
description: A few months ago a serious and smart young acting student from the Atlantic Theater Company School asked his classmates and me, ''How do we get people to believe that something that costs $5, $10 or $15 is worthwhile?'' Worth the travel time, of course, and (always the implicit or explicit question) worth seeing instead of a movie? It's not just a theater question; it's a question people committed to live performance minus marquee names bang their heads over. How do you lure people who aren't already devotees to that small opera company, that new-music group playing in a loft, that poetry reading or the dance company they've never heard of?

title: Article 2001061493763161011 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about real estate developers' support for multiple mayoral hopefuls in New York misstated the location of the 101 Club, where the Real Estate Board has held political cocktail parties. It is 101 Park Avenue, between East 40th and 41st Streets, not at 34th Street.

title: Nickell Team Wins Title And Will Compete in Bali
description: After a tense conclusion to the final match in the undefeated bracket, one of the world's most famous teams won the United States Bridge Championship Monday night, earning the right to play in the Bermuda Bowl at the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October. Playing in Memphis, Tenn., Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell began the final set of 15 deals trailing by 7 imps. A stretch drive gained them 28, and victory by 21. Before the final session, the match was close throughout, with 11 imps the biggest lead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURBAGE, HAROLD P., JR.
description: BURBAGE-Harold P., Jr., June 14, 1984. Oh for the touch of a vanished hand and the sound of a voice that is still. Stu

title: Goldman Sachs to Create an Image-Shielding Japan Advisory Board
description: The Goldman Sachs Group is expected to announce on Thursday that it has created a blue-chip advisory board for its Japanese operations, with members including Thomas S. Foley, the former House speaker and until recently, United States ambassador to Japan, and Nobuyuki Idei, chief executive of the Sony Corporation.

title: Some Russians Are Alarmed At Tighter Grip Under Putin
description: It is not an easy thing to quantify, much less to prove. But among intellectuals and advocates of a democratic Russia in the Western mode, a gnawing concern is arising that the relative freedom from state surveillance and restriction that citizens have relished in the last decade may be drawing to a close.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRIGUE, SHEILA KATHLEEN
description: GARRIGUE-Sheila Kathleen. Died June 9, 2001 at her home in Chappaqua. A memorial will take place at 4:00 P.M. Monday, June 18 at the Presbyterian Church of Mt. Kisco (914-666-7001). Contributions in Mrs. Garrigue's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021; or A-Home, 241 Lexington Avenue, Mount Kisco, NY 10549.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, BRINY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Briny. A woman for all seasons. Your grandchildren and your children will never forget you. All our love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPSON, DOROTHY
description: PHILIPSON-Dorothy. Died June 11, 2001. Loving mother, grandmother, and great grandmother. Survived by two sons, Michael and Robert Friedman, her sister, Martha Philipson, and six great grandchildren. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Hardware Retailer
description: Wesfarmers Ltd., the Australian conglomerate that owns the Bunnings hardware and home center chain, offered $1.14 billion in cash and stock for Howard Smith Ltd., owner of the rival BBC Hardware chain. The two retail units have 13 percent of the Australian market; their parents also have distribution and industrial products units that would fit together well, analysts said.

title: World Briefing | World: Saving Sturgeon, And Caviar
description: Four former Soviet republics bordering the Caspian Sea agreed to protect the dwindling population of caviar-producing sturgeon. The illegal catch of sturgeon in the four republics -- Russia, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Azerbaijan -- is more than 10 times as high as the legal catch because of a breakdown of controls after the collapse of the Soviet Union. The countries agreed to coordinate the legal trade and to stop poachers. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Tactics for Privacy in a City of Snoops
description: THERE are more telescopes sold in the New York City metropolitan region than in any other part of the country, said Darin Stephens, product line manager for astronomical telescopes at Bushnell, a leading manufacturer. And that in a place so bright one can hardly see the stars. Want to take a guess what all those scopes are pointed at?

title: Article 2001061490246879357 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Blacks Warn Of Boycott
description: A group of black ministers have threatened to boycott a Sept. 10 summit meeting on racial profiling because Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and other officials have rejected policy changes, including an end to so-called consent searches in which state troopers ask permission of motorists before beginning a search. They said blacks and other minority groups were stopped more often than others for such searches. The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, president of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey, said, ''If you're going to maintain the status quo, we don't need a summit for that.'' Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLWARTH, GEORGE E.
description: WELLWARTH-George E. Died June 11. Internationally renowned scholar of contemporary drama, beloved husband of Pamela, mentor to countless students. Flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!

title: Metro Matters; Bloomberg Pays His Way; Who Paved It?
description: MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG says he's different. But New Yorkers aren't, and it's hard to believe that they will buy his argument that he is rejecting the city's campaign financing system out of altruism. This is supposed to endear him to skeptical voters?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Real Estate Sale
description: British Telecommunications said it had agreed to sell certain real estate assets to Telereal Holdings, owned by Land Securities Trillium and the William Pears Group, for 2.3 billion ($3.2 billion). The company also said it had named David Varney, the former chief executive of the BG Group, as chairman of its wireless division. Mr. Varney will help in spinning off B.T. Wireless later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERF, KATE
description: CERF-Kate. Died June 12 after a short illness. Devoted wife of the late Hans. Beloved mother of Steven. Adored aunt and cousin. Funeral service at Parkside Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard on June 14 at 9 A.M.

title: Seton Hall Dorm Fire That Killed 3 Was Set, Investigators Say
description: Seventeen months after three freshmen perished in a dormitory fire at Seton Hall University, arson investigators said today they had concluded that someone intentionally started the fire, by igniting a paper banner in a student lounge.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From renting villas in Italy to preventing seasickness, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: One Got Life, One Got Death
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Artist Who Tosses and Turns
description: The artist Susan Cianciolo, left, closed Run Restaurant (an art installation that served meals) and moved on to Run Home, an offshoot of her Run Store (an art installation that sold things). If all of this makes you want to run back to bed, Ms. Cianciolo has a canvas for you there, too. The hand-screened Run Home Graph bed sheet and pillowcases, designed by Laura Genninger, come with a fabric pen so the buyer can write and draw on the sheets. For those who need help, there's a suggested illustration/reference insert. ''It's open to free interpretation,'' Ms. Cianciolo said. A full flat sheet and two pillow cases ($160) to order from (212) 260-8654 or alohalg@earthlink.net.

title: Article 2001061490965816437 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: A Dismal Record on Executing the Retarded
description: How does the Bush administration view executing people with mental retardation? When asked this week, President Bush said: ''We should never execute anybody who is mentally retarded. And our court system protects people who don't understand the nature of the crime they've committed nor the punishment they are about to receive.''

title: Shanghai Journal; Political Power Grows From the Point of His Pen
description: ''Only with the sunshine of ethics will trees be evergreen.''

title: No More Foal Deaths, But No Firm Answers
description: An appearance of normalcy has returned to central Kentucky's thoroughbred breeding farms. Mares are again grazing in the pastures, accompanied by their spindly legged foals. Yearlings are being groomed for the coming sales.

title: Role Players With 76ers Little Help For Big 2
description: The Philadelphia 76ers boast the league's most valuable player and the league's four-time defensive player of the year. But the drop-off after Allen Iverson and Dikembe Mutombo is deceivingly treacherous. The Sixers stumbled tonight when their role players -- hampered by injury and fatigue -- were unable to support their stars.

title: Genome Research Pioneer to Buy Drug Maker
description: Celera Genomics, the company that unraveled the human genome, said yesterday that it would buy Axys Pharmaceuticals for about $174 million in stock, a move intended to help Celera expand into the drug business.

title: France and Germany Caution Bush on Missile Defense Plan
description: Leaders of the Atlantic alliance clashed today over President Bush's challenge to three decades of conventional wisdom about European security, with the heads of France and Germany contradicting Mr. Bush's declaration that there was a ''new receptivity'' to his plan for a missile defense shield.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Shabby Satellites
description: The head of Russia's space agency told Parliament that nearly 70 of Russia's 96 orbiting satellites -- most with at least some military function -- are so old that they are unreliable and that new ones are launched so infrequently that some functions may lapse altogether. Yuri Koptev said Russia launches only about one satellite every two years compared with three or four annually in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE SUEUR, JOE
description: LE SUEUR-Joe. On May 14, 2001. Man of letters. Dear friend of the late Patsy Southgate and Frank O'Hara. Loved by many whose lives he touched. ''I am lonely for myself/I can't find a real poem/if it won't happen to me/what shall I do'' Frank O'Hara,''At Joan's'' 1959

title: Hamptons Renters Can Be Choosers
description: FROM stately homes to waterfront cottages, the houses of the Hamptons are strutting their stuff with their usual lan. But this season, their scissored grounds sport lawn ornaments not seen in recent years: ''for rent'' signs.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Harry Zohn, an educator, writer and translator of German literature at Brandeis, misstated the date of his death. It was June 3, not May 3.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: mong Code Warriors, Women, Too, Can Fight" (June 7) gives the impression that programmers who are women are a rarity. But though they may be rare among the hacker set, they are very common in the internal programming departments of large corporations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a rebel group that is holding Americans and others hostage in the Philippines misspelled its name in some copies. It is Abu Sayyaf, not Abu Dayyaf.

title: Retail Sales Rise, Holding Recession at Bay
description: Retail sales rose last month after increasing more in April than first reported, a sign consumers are still willing to spend and keep the economy out of a recession.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bond Plan Scrapped
description: Hynix Semiconductor, which has been trying to raise $1.25 billion to ease its debt burden, said that it had dropped plans to raise part of it by selling $350 million in high-interest bonds; the whole amount will come from stock sales instead. Analysts said Hynix Semiconductor might have to price the stock at a deep discount. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Verizon's Plans For New Jersey
description: Verizon Communications may ask in the next few weeks for New Jersey's endorsement of its plan to sell long-distance service in the state, an executive said yesterday. Verizon needs the endorsement of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities and approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer the service, the executive, Dennis M. Bone, said. Mr. Bone is state president of Verizon New Jersey. Verizon, which is based in New York, will file its application after state regulators complete a two-year examination of local-phone networks, perhaps within two weeks, Mr. Bone said.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Baptists Convene, and Turn to Family
description: The Southern Baptist Convention gained 489 churches last year, bringing the total of its member congregations to nearly 42,000. Those churches reported 415,000 baptisms, the second-highest number in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHRWASHEL, MORRIS
description: OHRWASHEL-Morris. The Board of Directors of 360 East 72nd Street Owners, Inc. extend their heartfelt condolences to esteemed Board member and Officer, Norman Ohrwashel on the death of his beloved father. Harvey Rothenberg, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONDOVCSIK, MARYANN
description: ONDOVCSIK-Maryann, 56. Of Brooklyn, NY, died Tuesday, June 12th, 2001 at Connecticut Hospice, Branford, CT. Born in Sewickley, PA. she is the daughter of Paul Ondovcsik Jr. of Ambridge, PA and the late Anna (Syka) Ondovcsik. She lived her adult life in NYC. Maryann was a graduate of Ambridge Area High School, PA, Class of 1962 and Pratt Institute, NYC, Class of 1966. Besides her father, she leaves her sister, Jane Ondovcsik of Rocky Hill, CT. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday at 10 A.M., in The Church of Our Saviour (38th and Park), Manhattan, NY. Interment will follow in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Friends may call Friday from 8 A.M. to 9:45 A.M. at the Dimiceli & Sons Inc. Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue (31st and Lexington), Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, 1785 Massachusetts Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20036.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Seeking Roots Of Conflict
description: The government said it would set up a version of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission to investigate the deadly anti-Tamil riots in 1983 that marked a turning point in the ethnic conflict between the majority Sinhalese and the minority Tamils. More than 60,000 people have died in the civil war. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Privacy Protection
description: ''The Fourth Amendment draws a firm line at the entrance to the house.'' So declared the Supreme Court on Monday in an important 5-to-4 ruling. The ruling reaffirmed the basic right of privacy that Americans are constitutionally entitled to enjoy in their own homes in an era when high-tech devices make it possible for police to snoop without any physical intrusion.

title: For Hand-Held Computers, An Even Handier Keyboard
description: For users who find the Palm organizer's handwriting recognition program, Graffiti, more like spaghetti, the small external keyboard has been a lifesaver. The new Fellowes PDA Pocket Keyboard, a joint effort by the Cirque Corporation and Fellowes Manufacturing, is about half the size and half the price of the other attachable keyboards for Palm-based hand-helds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JERRY, HAROLD A. JR.
description: JERRY-Harold A. Jr. We mourn the death of Harold A. Jerry, Jr., a passionate advocate for the East's last great wilderness, the Adirondack Park. A former state senator, he served three decades on the Public Service Commission, and on numerous conservation organizations. Governor Nelson Rockefeller appointed him to lead the effort that created the Adirondack Park Agency in 1968, a landmark in Adirondack protection. His heart was in the Adirondacks, and he lived his life with an absolute and single-minded urgency to protect the freedom of our few remaining untamed places. Our condolences to his family. The Adirondack Council, The Adirondack Nature Conservancy/ Adirondack Land Trust, The Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks

title: Wars Enlist Young Legions, Report Says
description: More than half a million children under 18 are in government armies or guerrilla groups around the world, with 300,000 of them in actual combat, according to a report published here this week to coincide with an international meeting on children's rights.

title: F.D.A. Delays Lilly's Drug To Treat Sepsis
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that regulators would take three months longer than expected to review a drug to treat sepsis, delaying a product Lilly needs to make up for slowing sales of the antidepressant Prozac.

title: National Briefing | Washington: U.S. To Help Aids Fund
description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced a bill to contribute $700 million to a global fund to fight AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. The fund was proposed by the Secretary General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan. The Bush administration made an initial pledge of $200 million, which would be covered by the bill introduced by Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, and backed by Senators John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts; Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: G.E. Chief Courts Europeans on Acquisition of Honeywell
description: In talks that illustrate the power that European regulators increasingly hold in American corporate deals, General Electric's chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., met twice today with the European competition commissioner in an effort to win approval for G.E.'s $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International.

title: Court Affirms Earlier Ruling To Move Up Killer's Parole
description: A rare deadlock on the New Jersey Supreme Court means that a teenager who confessed to murdering an 11-year-old boy in his Jackson Township, N.J., neighborhood will be eligible for parole after serving 30 years, rather than after 59 years.

title: Real Life, Real Emotion
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline's Profit Warning
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. warned that its profit could fall 30 percent short of its earlier forecast of 1 billion euros ($853 million). Lufthansa, Europe's biggest airline, said its profit would be reduced by 125 million euros because of the agreement it reached last week with its pilots. Strikes, higher fuel costs, air traffic control restrictions and the weakening economy also affected results, Lufthansa said. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Daily News Tries Flattery to Woo Back Grocery Ads
description: The Daily News has been in a bind for close to seven weeks. Ever since it published a series of articles saying many city supermarkets were too dirty to meet state standards, all but one of the city's major supermarket chains have refused to advertise in the newspaper.

title: Councilman's Actions Factor in Inquiry
description: A consultant to the building industry has sketched a stark picture of political influence peddling by a well-connected city councilman, charging that the official helped him fix government variances, jobs and investigations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRY, CAROL BERNSTEIN
description: FERRY-Carol Bernstein. The Board and Staff of The Correctional Association of New York mourn deeply the loss of their friend, colleague, and guide in the effort to create a just and humane society. Carol's intelligent insights and passionate beliefs were rare. Her courage in acting on them in life and in death were utterly unique. The world is a lesser place without her.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Brokerage Operators To Pay $800,000 In S.E.C. Settlement
description: Two men accused of operating an unregistered New York brokerage firm agreed to pay a total of $800,000 to settle the charges, federal authorities said today.

title: Polaroid to Cut 2,000 Jobs; Instant-Photo Woes Are Cited
description: The Polaroid Corporation, acknowledging that its ailing instant photography business is unlikely ever to recover, said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 jobs, at least half in Massachusetts. The cuts are in addition to the 945 jobs Polaroid said it would eliminate in February. Together the cuts will reduce the global work force of Polaroid, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., to 5,500 by the end of next year.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE<BR FRANCE: INSURER INVESTIGATED

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Lawyers and Accountants Expect Windfall From Estate Tax Repeal
description: The tax-cut bill that President Bush signed into law last week contains a costly surprise for the 17 million or so Americans with a net worth of $500,000 or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, KIMBERLEY REESE
description: WILSON-Kimberley Reese. With Roth Capital Partners in Los Angeles. Died on Monday, June 4, 2001, in Illinois, at the age of 39. Survived by her mother Marily Purkiss Wilson, sister Durinda and brothers Murray and Craig. Services will be held at 2:00 P.M., Friday June 15, at the Corona Del Mar Congregational Church.

title: Imprisoned in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Visiting Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Server Sales Shrink
description: The hotly contested worldwide market for the computers known as servers because they support networks of desktop machines and other devices shrank to $13.3 billion in the first quarter, down 4 percent from $13.8 billion a year earlier, according to the International Data Corporation. A sharp 16 percent decline in the United States, to $5.2 billion, overshadowed gains overseas, said I.D.C., a market research firm based in Framingham, Mass. I.B.M., the worldwide market leader with a 25 percent share, and fifth-ranked Dell Computer, with a 7 percent share, were the only major companies to report worldwide revenue growth from the first quarter of 2000. Only Dell managed an increase in domestic revenue.

title: Feelings for Open Spaces, None for Crowded Areas
description: John Jasperse loves to create his own private choreographic worlds. But because what happens in those realms often seems unexpectedly related to everybody's ordinary world, his dances about them can rivet the attention.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Raphael Lemkin, the legal scholar who coined the word ''genocide,'' misstated the interval between his flight from Poland and his parents' death in the Holocaust. While Mr. Lemkin did not know when they died, the interval could not have been nearly a decade. He fled in 1939, six years before the end of World War II.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Strike Ends
description: Korean Air has settled a two-day strike by 1,400 of its 1,800 pilots with a promise to employ fewer non-Korean pilots. Ground crews at Asiana remained on strike. Coordinated walkouts at other companies continued, but the number of workers on strike nationwide has dwindled. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Colors of a Lost Empire Are Reborn, Digitally
description: IN the dying years of imperial Russia, Sergei Mikhailovich Prokudin-Gorsky undertook a great photographic experiment: commissioned by Nicholas II, Prokudin-Gorsky traveled the country from 1905 to 1915, documenting the sights, flavors and especially the people of the Russian empire, then displaying the results with an experimental three-color projector.

title: One Got Life, One Got Death
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Last-Ditch Aid Effort
description: The World Food Program is in last-minute negotiations with the ruling Taliban to save a bakery project that has fed nearly 300,000 people, mostly widows and their children, in Kabul. The United Nations agency says it will have to close the bakeries tomorrow if the Taliban do not rescind the order to stop using women to conduct household surveys of food needs. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: For Movie Tickets, No Need to Suffer
description: WHEN the pollsters from Gallup compiled a list a few months ago of the 20 most admired people of the past century, I once again felt out of touch with American culture.

title: One Got Life, One Got Death
description: To the Editor:

title: To Woofers, Add Lights
description: HOME theater buffs already have a mind-boggling array of woofers, subwoofers and accompanying gadgetry to make their rooms rumble when they watch movies. Now a company in Boston is developing a digital lighting system to add visual enhancements.

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: The President's Serenade Tour

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Robert Allen, president and chief operating officer at Modem Media, Norwalk, Conn., is taking a leave of absence for what the agency described as personal reasons; it is likely to last several months. Mr. Allen's duties will be shared by executives including Marc Particelli, chief executive. Modem Media is 46 percent owned by True North Communications.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sentencing Hearing For Teenage Hacker
description: A Montreal youth court began a sentencing hearing for the teenage computer hacker who uses the name Mafiaboy. The 16-year-old pleaded guilty on Jan. 19 to 56 charges that he used computers throughout America to block communication with some of the busiest commercial sites on the Internet. His lawyer, Jan Romanowski, suggested the computer attacks were meant only to test the resilience of the target sites. Citing a presentencing report, he quoted the youth as saying he could have blocked Internet traffic on the ''entire East Coast of the United States.'' The prosecutor, Louis Miville-Deschnes, acknowledged that the boy made no attempt to damage computers or to retrieve or manipulate confidential data. ''He just wanted fame,'' Mr. Miville-Deschnes said. The boy, whose name cannot be released under Canadian law, faces a maximum penalty of two years of detention and a $1,000 fine.

title: Convict Turns Court Recess Into 5 Hours of Freedom
description: The verdict was in: guilty of defrauding investors of $16 million. But rather than wait to see if he was going to jail, the defendant made a premature exit yesterday from a federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan.

title: Swiss Drug Maker Moves to the Brink of a Product Leap
description: With a 95-year history, global leadership in infertility treatments and the No. 1 spot among Europe's biotechnology companies, Serono International can be excused for a bit of frustration that it is not more widely known and esteemed. The company hopes the big splash it plans for Thursday in the field of prion detection will win it a place in the spotlight.

title: A Positive Culture For Making Profits; Buoyed by Mergers, Medical Labs Await Era of Gene Testing
description: Not too long ago, medical laboratory companies were as sick as many of the patients whose blood and urine they tested.

title: De La Hoya Focuses on History
description: Oscar De La Hoya knows that his reputation needs some polishing. So for more than a month, he has been chopping wood in the mountains near Los Angeles and wearing two-pound boots while he runs. No more recording sessions. No more cavorting with Hollywood stars. No more running away from opponents in the ring.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Cuts Staff By 18%
description: Integrated Device Technology Inc., which manufactures high-performance chips for networks and telecommunications, said that it would eliminate about 900 jobs, or 18 percent of its total work force, in response to falling demand for semiconductors. ''The industrywide inventory correction and slowdown in customer demand necessitate that I.D.T. adjust its operating costs and production capability to levels currently required by the markets we serve,'' said Jerry Taylor, Integrated Device's president and chief executive. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said most of the jobs to be eliminated were in its factories in Malaysia and the Philippines. The reductions are expected to save the company about $11 million a year. Shares of Integrated Device fell $1.31, to $33.25. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: From the Levant to Brazil, or Vice Versa
description: The Ethos Percussion Group offered an engagingly open-minded miscellany on Monday evening at Merkin Hall. One of the players rather abashedly suggested in his introductory comments that there might be a kind of a thread running through the program, a thread of rhythmic energy traveling from the Islamic world through Moorish Iberia to Brazil. But the syncopated rhythms could equally have gone rattling back the other way, from the New World to the Old, for it would be hard now to find a musical culture that has not been touched by the sounds of the Americas.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: 'Important Work' On Iraq Sanctions
description: Technical experts and diplomats studying lists of goods that the United States does not want Iraq to buy without prior approval ended two days of talks in Paris saying that they had completed ''some important work'' but that negotiations would go on at the United Nations and in capitals. The Security Council must agree on the lists before a new ''oil for food'' program allowing Iraq to import most civilian goods can begin.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN HALT TO EXERCISES ON VIEQUES ISLAND
description: The Bush administration will announce on Thursday that it will halt all military exercises and aerial bombing runs on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques by May 2003, reversing the Navy's long-running insistence that no other locale is suitable for battle simulations, senior officials said tonight.

title: Report Outlines the Abuse of Foreign Domestic Workers
description: When Juana Condori received the job offer back home in Bolivia, it seemed like a dream come true -- fly in an airplane for the first time, live in the United States, work for a diplomat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dibrienza Announces Candidacy
description: City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza formally announced his candidacy for public advocate yesterday with a daylong tour of the five boroughs. ''The public advocate should fight for the people in all our neighborhoods in all five boroughs -- not just for Wall Street but for Main Street,'' he said outside a community center in Brooklyn. Mr. DiBrienza, a Democrat who is the chairman of the Council's General Welfare Committee, is the fourth major candidate to announce his candidacy. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: For the End, Companions With a Bit of Distinction
description: In his new play ''Every Day a Visitor'' Richard Abrons strikes a praiseworthy blow for the individuality of the elderly. As one resident of the fraying Bronx retirement home that is this comedy's setting says, ''Age profiling should be illegal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ARTHUR
description: JACOBS-Arthur. Age 86. Beloved husband of the late Florence. On June 11, 2001, after a prolonged illness. Father of Marilyn Platt and Joan Levy. Shiva will be at the Platt residence through Monday morning.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Air Executive Fired
description: The state-owned Irish airline Aer Lingus has fired its chief executive, Michael Foley, after an investigation into charges of sexual harassment. Mr. Foley denied the accusations, which were made by his former assistant and an employee's representative on the board. While neither of the two committees investigating the charges found him guilty of gross misconduct, one determined that ''Mr. Foley's position as chief executive is untenable,'' the company said. The chairman, Bernie Cahill, will serve as chief executive until a replacement is found. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, SELDA
description: PLOTKIN-Selda. Dearly beloved daughter of the late Rabbi Benjamin and Helen of Jersey City, NJ. Most cherished and devoted twin sister of Eda. Member of Congregation Emanuel of Jersey City, NJ. Life member of Hadassa, master teacher, beautiful, talented, accomplished and committed to the cause of social justice and striving for a better world. Her vibrant presence has enriched our lives. Services private on June 14, 2001. Contributions to the Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin Memorial Fund at the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York City.

title: When the Cubicle Has a Crankshaft
description: BRUCE JONES is a real estate agent with a spiffy new car, and he's eager to prove what it can do.

title: Debating Reality: An Online Hoax Is Not a Pox
description: LAST winter, on a subway train thick with commuters, I watched a man asking for spare change. Above the general absorption in newspapers and Walkmans, the voice of one woman rose. Speaking within earshot of the panhandler, although not directly to him, she wondered aloud whether she should give money, whether ''this guy is for real.''

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolling Storage Space Without Air Pockets
description: Traveling between New York, Paris and Hong Kong led the architects Francois Bourdin and Meiling Leung to pick the airline trolley as their muse when they founded Resin Design. The R line of lightweight aluminum carts on wheels can store sweaters, CD's, dishware and more. ''These aren't exactly the same as airline trolleys, but we have them manufactured by a Singapore company that makes similar ones for the airline industry,'' Mr. Bourdin said. The Quarter cart, right, is $1,100 (12 1/4 inches wide, 26 high and 21 3/4 deep). Resin, 250 West 88th Street; (646) 244-4750. BONNIE SCHWARTZ

title: Economic Scene; The curbs on steel trade demonstrate the faults of courting special interests.
description: GEORGE W. BUSH has often declared that free trade brings prosperity. He advocates extending the North American free-trade zone to all democracies in this hemisphere. He appears to have a deep conviction that free trade is right and good.

title: U.S. and D.C. to Curb Police Use of Force
