description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Attorney General John Ashcroft today announced an agreement between the Department of Justice and the Metropolitan police to enhance law enforcement in the capital and prevent the use of excessive force by officers.

title: Energy Agency Is Set to Monitor Prices in West
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to approve a plan proposed by Congressional Republicans that would significantly expand the agency's efforts to limit electricity prices in California and other Western states.

title: Kimes Unexpectedly Ends Her Fight Against Extradition to California
description: Sante Kimes, the grifter serving 120 years for the 1998 murder of a wealthy Manhattan woman, today ended the fight against her extradition to California, where she faces a murder charge that could result in the death penalty.

title: Conservative Group Mails a Postcard Attack on Franks
description: As if Republicans in New Jersey weren't already getting enough direct-mail advertisements from the party's two candidates for governor, a conservative Washington group has entered the fray with the first in a series of postal attacks on Bob Franks, the standard-bearer of the state party's moderate wing.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Poor Bargain Gets Worse
description: Connecticut's largest phone company plans to raise rates for what it calls its least desirable calling plan, a spokeswoman for the company, Southern New England Telecommunications, said yesterday. Beginning July 1, the company's customers who pay per minute will pay up to 37 cents a minute for in-state calls, up from 35 cents a minute, and up to 37 cents a minute for state-to-state calls, up from 27 cents per minute, the spokeswoman, Beverly Levy, said. The plan, which the company calls its default plan, is already the company's most expensive for callers, used by customers who do not respond to the company's attempts to switch them to one of several discount plans, Ms. Levy said.

title: Looking for Fuel Bargains? Boot Up Before Gassing Up
description: People who drive 20 miles out of their way to save a penny on a tank of unleaded may now save a trip by visiting www.gaspricewatch.com. That Web site tells users where the cheapest gasoline is within a 20-mile radius of any ZIP code.

title: 2-Way Radios: Digital Tethers That Cover Miles
description: WALKIE-TALKIES have graduated from backyard toys to digital assistants that let hikers communicate across several miles, let parents keep up with children in the neighborhood or let people at one end of a water park talk to friends or family at the other end. Today's walkie-talkies, called Family Radio Service two-way radios, have been popular for some time, but recent models have added new capabilities. Many can warn you of approaching severe weather, and some include an FM radio in case you become bored with nature or nearby amusements.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BANDOLIK, HARVEY
description: BANDOLIK-Harvey. June 14, 1993. Love and miss you. Pauline

title: Central America Fallout Stalls U.N. Pick
description: John D. Negroponte has found himself in many sticky situations over the course of his long diplomatic career. He worked on the peace agreement that ended the war in Vietnam. He directed the State Department response to the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. He tried in vain to keep United States troops in Panama.

title: When a Clutch Hit Is Needed, It's Shinjo Time
description: The pivotal moments of a season, Bobby Valentine believes, reveal themselves as important only after the year is over. It is only in retrospect, he says, that a team can tell which games made a difference to the end result.

title: Making a Man Out of a Mac: Adding Gigabytes to an iBook
description: With iMovie being shipped with every Macintosh iBook and promoted in television advertisements, the 10-gigabyte hard drive that comes as standard equipment with the unit will quickly prove inadequate for anyone trying to edit even a short digital movie.

title: In the Ateliers Of Harlem
description: YOU know the neighborhood is changing when Citarella moves in. Its owner has just closed a deal to open a fine-food store on 125th Street near Amsterdam Avenue and a huge warehouse and commissary on 126th Street. It's actually a return home -- the original store was in Harlem until 1940, when it moved to 75th Street on the Upper West Side.

title: MetroStars Flat Without Mathis
description: The MetroStars lacked personality and flair without the injured Clint Mathis last night. They played poorly and lost by 2-1 to D.C. United before a crowd of 11,581 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tory Leadership Battle Begins
description: Michael Portillo became the first Conservative to enter the race for party leader to succeed William Hague, who announced that he was stepping down after the Tories lost their second straight landslide election to the Labor Party of Prime Minister Tony Blair. Mr. Portillo, a one-time protg of Margaret Thatcher, has evolved into a social liberal with an acknowledged homosexual past who says the party must be more inclusive and allow room for those who do not share his opposition to the European common currency. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberate Picked By German Cable Company
description: Liberate Technologies, a maker of software for Internet appliances, said yesterday that its software would be used by Kabel Hessen, the first major German cable company to offer interactive television. The German company's selection of Liberate was a blow for its bitter rival in the market, Microsoft. Microsoft recently started a new service with TV Cabo Portugal and is experimenting with a cable company in the Netherlands. Last week, however, AT&T's broadband division shelved a project to build a set-top cable box using Microsoft's interactive television software. Liberate said Kabel Hessen's digital interactive television service would be accessible to more than 250,000 households in the Frankfurt region by the end of 2001. On Tuesday, Liberate announced the formation of an alliance that includes some of the largest makers of chips and television software. The group will design Linux-based software for set-top boxes that deliver TV programming to homes, aiming to create a lower-cost product than the one from Microsoft.

title: St. John's Chooses New A.D.
description: St. John's looked no further than its own administration to choose a new athletic director.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 1 about six Idaho children who barricaded themselves in their house after their mother was charged with child neglect referred incorrectly at one point to their father's cause of death. As noted elsewhere in the article, the father, Michael McGuckin, died of malnutrition and dehydration. Although he had multiple sclerosis, he did not die of it.

title: INSIDE
description: Following Giuliani's Script

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALOM, JOSEPH
description: SHALOM-Joseph. The Management and Employees of I. Shalom & Company, Inc., and Jordan Accessories mourn the passing of our President and mentor, Joseph Shalom, whose fairness and generosity touched all who were in contact with him. To Joseph, personal relationships and compassion superseeded economic and business expediency. He was a warm and generous friend, and our Company and industry will long remember his enduring virtues.

title: Ebay University: Part School and Part Tent Meeting
description: SALT LAKE CITY -- IT was 9 a.m. on a Sunday here. Hundreds of people had gathered, mostly middle-aged or older, though there was an occasional young couple who had brought their toddler.

title: Strain of Fourth-Grade Tests Drives Off Veteran Teachers
description: A growing number of fourth-grade teachers in New York City are seeking other assignments, saying they cannot stand the pressure of administering the high-stakes state tests that have become a defining feature of fourth grade, school officials around the city say.

title: One Got Life, One Got Death
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Higher Wages
description: British data showed wage increases rising at an annual rate of 5.2 percent in April, deepening concerns about inflation and quashing speculation that the Bank of England may lower interest rates. Officials are concerned that the weakness of the pound could push up inflation, which is 2.4 percent, a three-year high. The National Statistics Office said wage increases in the three months before April had been 5 percent. The jobless rate stayed at 3.2 percent, a 26-year low. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Wal-Mart to Sell Cosmetics Line
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has started selling cosmetics under its own label to compete with brands like Cover Girl and Jane for teenage customers.

title: Only a Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about a review begun by the ING Group for its advertising account misstated the name and affiliation of the agency that has handled ING's account since November. It is Jordan McGrath Case & Partners, not Jordan McGrath Case & Partners Euro RSCG. It is part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising, not the Euro RSCG Worldwide division.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS INC., Troy, Mich., the world's largest auto parts maker, will sell an industrial engine parts plant in Cheltenham, England, as the company reorganizes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESHEL, JOSEPH
description: MESHEL-Joseph. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Joseph Meshel, father of our devoted members and parents of our Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School, Jeffrey and Joyce Meshel. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: In Her Hands, Human Rights Is Hot Box Office
description: BRUNI BURRES remembers when she used to get ''the pat.''

title: A Small Piece of Success For British Railroading
description: It is not often that Britain's railroads generate good news, but sometimes they do -- if only in miniature.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Investigated
description: French police officers investigating PanEurolife, an insurance company based in Luxembourg that is suspected of tax evasion, have questioned the chairman of the French insurer AXA, Claude Bebear, left, and its chief executive, Henri de Castries. In 1997, AXA acquired PanEurolife as part of its purchase of Union des Assurances de Paris, but later sold the stake in PanEurolife to Nationwide Holdings of the United States. Executives of PanEurolife, including the managing director, Jacques Drossaert, are being investigated over a suspected scheme in which investors made deposits in French postal savings accounts that were then transferred to Luxembourg and converted into life insurance policies, enabling the policy owners to avoid taxes on the investment income. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: The Wildlife Next Door
description: Last Sunday morning at 8:35, Edward O. Wilson, the Harvard biologist, was exclaiming over a small rock along a wooded path in this leafy Boston suburb. The rock was covered with ants.

title: One Got Life, One Got Death
description: One Got Life,

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airlines To Offer Onboard Access
description: Boeing said it had reached an agreement with three airlines, American, Delta and United, to provide passengers with two-way broadband Internet connections, including access to e-mail, live television, shopping and travel information, and news. The high-speed data service for commercial aircraft, called Connexion, was originally announced by Boeing in April 2000. Boeing and the airlines will contribute money and certain intellectual property to develop the system. A spokesman for Boeing said he expected the service to cost about $20 an hour initially but that rates could drop as use picked up. In addition, the airlines might use the system to offer some free options that might provide information on flight arrivals, departures, delays and cancellations, he said. The airlines plan to equip 1,500 airplanes with the technology by the end of 2002.

title: Several Roster Changes For Yanks
description: The Yankees thought the 13-game homestand nearly at its end might propel them into first place. Instead, it has propelled them into immense changes, with more alterations to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSIEN, KIA KWEI
description: TSIEN-Kia Kwei. Beloved father of Dawn Tsien, devoted husband of the late Lois Ing Tsien, and loving brother of Lily Sze, Daisy Shih and Maud Chow, passed away peacefully at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center on June 8, 2001 from complications arising from a fall. Born in Beijing, China on July 27, 1918, he became one of the earliest members of the Secretariat of the United Nations, starting out as a translator and rising to the post of Deputy Assistant Administrator of the U.N. Development Programme. In this capacity he served the U.N. and many nations of the world with tireless effort, impeccable tolerance and profound respect for all cultures. He was mentor to a host of younger colleagues at the U.N. He will be missed most for his modesty, his erudition and his generosity to all. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Saturday, June 23rd, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Trees for the Future.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Professor Charges Bias
description: A New York University professor charged yesterday that he was denied tenure because he supported a unionization drive by graduate students in 1999. Joel Westheimer, an assistant professor of education, said that although his department had unanimously recommended tenure, a dean's committee recommended against it. He said that he and his department would appeal to the university president. A university spokesman, John Beckman, said he could not comment until the process was completed. Graduate students won unionization rights in 2000. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Sony's Bare-Bones PC: Don't Call Me Audrey
description: Despite consumers' earlier indifference toward stripped-down computers mainly intended for Internet access, Sony today begins selling its own offering, eVilla. Perhaps to avoid unpleasant associations with Internet appliances like Audrey, by 3Com, which was withdrawn from the market in less than six months, Sony prefers to call the $500 eVilla a ''network entertainment center.''

title: Trenton Projects Shortfall Totaling Almost $1 Billion
description: With just over two weeks to go until the deadline for New Jersey's next budget, the DiFrancesco administration acknowledged today that the state is facing a shortfall of nearly $1 billion.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bloomberg Dot-What?
description: An Internet site for the posting of complaints about American corporations, celebrities and political figures can continue to use a Web address that denigrates Michael R. Bloomberg, the New York City mayoral candidate, according to a ruling a week ago. Mr. Bloomberg's company, Bloomberg L.P., contended that the Web address was confusingly similar to its own, including Bloomberg.com, which offers financial news and data. But an arbitration panel that decides disputes over Internet domain names ruled that the protest site has a First Amendment right to use the name. The protest site, which is run by Dan Parisi, a pornography publisher, uses many addresses created by adding to the names of companies or politicians a slang expression of contempt associated in other contexts with baby bottles. No challenge of the decision is expected.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Brothers Who Enjoy 76ers' Ride
description: THERE'S a reason you thought you saw double last night when the camera turned to the 76ers' bench. The assistant with the unmistakable family resemblance whispering into the head coach's ear from behind was Herb Brown, four and a half years Larry's senior.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shares of Kraft Edge Up In First Day of Trading

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about the work of the Dutch designer Paul Mijksenaar in overhauling directional signs at Kennedy Airport misattributed the design of a new information booth there. It is by CommArts Inc., not by Mr. Mijksenaar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, GARY
description: MONTGOMERY - Gary. The Council and Staff of Actors' Equity Association mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Gary Montgomery, a devoted member and Councillor of the Association.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Gore Office In Nashville
description: Former Vice President Al Gore said he would open a permanent office in Nashville on July 20. His political future remains uncertain, but Mr. Gore will teach at Fisk University in Nashville and Middle Tennessee State University in nearby Murfreesboro in the fall. He taught at the universities this spring, as well as at Columbia University in New York. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLETTE, RUDOLPH THOMAS
description: KLETTE-Rudolph Thomas, Born June 20, 1913 in NYC. Retired from the NYC Fire Department. In 1947, he was awarded NYC Fire Department Award for Valor and NY Maritime Silver Medal for Bravery. He was predeceased by wife Rita (nee Concannon). Surviving are children, Jack and Mary; sister, Amelia Newman; grandchildren, JT and Margaret; nephews, Robert and Edward Peters; and niece Patricia Theryoung. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on June 16, at 10AM, St. Frances of Rome Church, Bronx, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIKOLIS, ARTIE
description: NIKOLIS-Artie. On June 12, at age 74. A longtime resident of Port Washington, NY, she owned Festival of Food. Beloved wife of the late Peter. Devoted and cherished mother of Bill, Anna, Phillip (Sally) and the late Gary. Loving sister of George Kosefas and dear cousin of George & Mary Mihalakos and many others. She leaves behind her most beloved grandchildren, Faye, Corinne, Patrice, Harry, Anastasia and Alexander. She will forever be in the minds and hearts of those she touched. Funeral service will be held on Thursday, June 14th, at 11:30 AM at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Hempstead, New York.

title: What You Can't See, Seen
description: If you like to ponder questions on the scale of how many Web sites can fit on the head of a pin, there is a fine collection of electron microscope images to examine at MicroAngela, an online collection (www.pbrc.hawaii

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 6 about Michael Sonnabend, the husband of the New York art dealer Ileana Sonnabend, misstated his contribution to ''The Titan,'' a 1950 documentary film about Michelangelo. The credits cited him for art interpretation; the script was by Norman Borisoff.

title: Showtime Launching Boxing Series
description: Showtime is starting a program that will feature bouts between relatively unknown boxers and is aimed at drawing younger viewers.

title: Critics Say Sheriff Is the Law; In Bucolic Putnam County, an Election Stirs Passions
description: To outsiders, Putnam County may be a blur of picturesque reservoirs and postcard-perfect towns astride the Taconic State Parkway between Westchester and the upper Hudson Valley. But behind that tranquil facade, some residents say, lurks a gothic world of mischief and innuendo enveloping a controversial sheriff who has been compared to both Clint Eastwood and J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRENE
description: COHEN-Irene, 91. Passed away June 13. A Hunter College graduate and NYC school teacher, she also worked in department store personnel. She moved to Florida in 1971 via the Bronx and Forest Hills. Survivors include her son, daughter-in-law, two granddaughters, niece and cousins.

title: Estate in Mexico Settles With S.E.C.
description: The estate of Jos Luis Ballesteros, once a vice chairman of the Mexican construction company Grupo Mexicano de Desarrollo, has promised to pay the United States government more than $3.7 million, representing what the Securities and Exchange Commission said were his family's insider-trading profits, the S.E.C. said today.

title: Messengers That Carry Big Bundles
description: THE first time I heard of an instant message was in 1994, when an old friend suggested that we stop blasting e-mail back and forth across America Online and have a proper online chat. The next night, when I booted up my Mac at the agreed hour and signed on to AOL, a tiny window popped up so my friend could say, ''Hey.'' We proceeded to spend two hours, he in Iowa and I in New York, in what can only be called a state of Intense I.M.

title: Wall Street Tepid to Kraft In First Day Of Trading
description: After raising $8.68 billion in the nation's second-largest initial public offering ever, Kraft Foods Inc. faced a lukewarm reception in its first day of trading yesterday, suggesting that persistent concerns about the economy continue to chip away at investor enthusiasm for new entries to the stock market.

title: Wylie Dufresne
description: IN formal restaurants, lobster is always served out of the shell. A claw might float in a rich broth, or the tail might be served as an entree.

title: Chicago Buries Bozo. Time Passed Him By.
description: Bozo is dead. At least the red-nosed clown with flaming hair and floppy blue shoes who entertained this city for 40 years and several generations is on his way to that great Big Top in the sky.

title: Camacho To Fight In Brooklyn
description: Lou DiBella, a Brooklyn-born boxing promoter, is so passionate about his hometown that he named one of his dogs after the borough and vowed to bring boxing back to its ''rightful place.''

title: Q & A
description: Q. If I sign up with a high-speed Internet service provider, can I still use America Online even though I won't be dialing into it with one of its phone numbers?

title: A Pied--Terre Designed By a President; F. D. R. Never Slept Here, But Entertained Dignitaries And Enjoyed Rendezvous
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt was more than the nation's longest-serving president and wartime leader, social reformer, sailor, fisherman, dog lover and stamp collector in chief.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Hog Tax May Be Blocked
description: The House Appropriations Committee approved an amendment to the appropriations bill that would block a tax on hog farmers. Representative Marcy Kaptur, Democrat of Ohio, offered the amendment. Last fall hog farmers voted against the tax on sales of live hogs that is used to pay for pork advertising, but the Bush administration overturned the vote. Hog farmers have asked a federal court to force the Agriculture Department to respect the results of the referendum. The National Pork Producers Council denounced the amendment.

title: Tales of Hardship, From Tenants and Owners
description: In an annual ritual venting over regulated rents in New York City, more than 100 tenants and landlords took the microphone in Harlem yesterday to tell their woes and argue over what increases the Rent Guidelines Board should adopt next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, ROBERT J.
description: SWEENEY-Robert J., 33. Of New York City. Son and stepson of Arlene and Marcis Brencsons. Son and stepson of Christopher and Cheryl Sweeney. Brother of Gillian E. Sweeney. Stepbrother of Chris Brencsons. Prayer services, on Friday June 15 at 11 AM at LeberLakeside Funeral Home, Landing, NJ (973) 398-3000. Visiting, 10-11 AM prior to prayer services at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations in loving memory to your favorite charity.

title: Florida Republicans See a Visit By President as the Latest Slight
description: Republican lawmakers from Florida are furious at the White House, saying it bungled opportunities to cultivate a state that has a high-profile governor's race next year and is vital for President Bush's electoral fortunes in 2004.

title: Software Turns Office PC's Into a Searchable Network
description: Is there something embarrassing on your office computer? In the next few weeks, AltaVista will start shipping new software that has the capacity to search through every file on your machine, rsums and cover letters included.

title: Nets Castoff Chases Championship With 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 13  It was the longest, darkest week of the winter and after being cut by the struggling Nets, Kevin Ollie did his best not to fall into a December funk. Today Ollie, a reserve point guard for the Philadelphia 76ers, cannot help but smile and shake his head at his good fortune.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGERSON, RICHARD
description: SIGERSON-Richard. Died peacefully at home on June 12, 2001, aged 84. Adoring husband of Yola Miller Sigerson, father of Andra Patterson, Adam, Gabriel and Davitt Sigerson and grandfather of Julia, Andrew, Lio, Jennifer and Milena. Science writer, editor and publisher; founder of the Medical and Pharmaceutical Information Bureau; founding editor of The Sciences, for the New York Academy of Sciences; editor and publisher of Medical Opinion and Review, Geriatric Focus, Hospital Focus, Issues and Science Fortnightly. The fiercest intelligence, the strongest spirit, the most loving heart-he took such intense pleasure in living. Friends and family will meet on Friday afternoon. For information please call Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 212-289-2221.

title: Market Place; Hedge Funds Face Shortage Of Top Talent
description: Many investors who devoted the late 1990's to making money are now more interested in keeping what they have left.

title: HARLEM STYLE: AT HOME WITH -- Fred Brathwaite; A Town House Hips and Hops
description: IN the living room of his Harlem town house, Fred Brathwaite was wrestling with the great chaise conundrum.

title: Macedonia Seeks Political Shelter From Winds of War
description: The president's security chief warned today that Macedonia was racing toward war, even as political leaders prepared for three days of intensive talks to try to end five months of conflict with ethnic Albanian rebels.

title: Article 2001061492859253445 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Sex-Gossip Case Dropped
description: Two young men who posted the rumored sex lives of female classmates on their Web site will not be prosecuted, Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney for Westchester County, said yesterday. The youths, both 18 and students at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, faced charges of aggravated harassment and penalties of up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. But Ms. Pirro's office determined this week that there was insufficient evidence to prosecute. The Web site was a ''high-tech version of gossip,'' Ms. Pirro said, and while it was offensive, it was protected by the First Amendment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Article 2001061490147499192 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, JUDY C.
description: ROSENTHAL-Judy C. June 14, 1996. ''And what is so rare as a day in June?'' You. Mom

title: Free Stay in Istanbul (With Purchase of Cruise)
description: Aseven-night cruise through the Aegean can be strenuous, what with all that sightseeing, dancing and standing on buffet lines. So it helps to spend a couple nights resting up before, or recovering afterward. Two nights in the Istanbul Hilton are included at no extra charge by Windstar for passengers on 12 of its seven-day sailings on the Wind Spirit and Wind Song June 30 through Aug. 18. The cruises run from Athens to Istanbul or in reverse and cost from $3,247 a person, based on double occupancy and including port taxes; air fare is extra. Information: (800) 258-7245 or www.windstarcruises.com .

title: Environmental Groups Claim To Have Vandalized Banks
description: One bank branch on Long Island had 13 of its windows smashed. Two others had their outdoor A.T.M.'s smeared with glue. And at least three of the banks that were damaged overnight Tuesday were painted with graffiti protesting animal testing: ''BNY Kills Puppies,'' ''Stop the Torture'' and ''Investors in Murder.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHAN
description: WEISS-Stephan. Born September 16, 1938. Died on June 10th, 2001. Beloved husband of Donna Karan, father of Corey Weiss, Lisa WeissKeyes and Gabrielle Karan and grandfather of Mackenzie, Miles, Mercer, Etan and Maya Rose. An exceptional creator and co-founder of Donna Karan International, his wit, charm, intelligence and forward thinking impressed all who knew him. He will live on through the many whose lives he touched with his goodness and humanity. Funeral services will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to The Karan-Weiss Foundation, dedicated to benefiting medical research, education and the arts, C/O Urban Zen, LLC, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10018.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Signs Of Improvement
description: In another step toward the resumption of normal life in Congo after more than four years of war, United Nations peacekeepers will help vaccinate 12 million children against polio. This will be the second round of vaccinations. On another front, two Uruguayan river patrol boats arrived in Congo, allowing commercial traffic to resume on the Congo River, the most important lifeline in a country almost devoid of roads. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Roaming the World With a Translator in Your Pocket
description: TRAVELERS of the future may still carry foreign language phrase books. But in a few years they may also load software onto their pocket computers that permits real-time, simple conversations with their foreign hosts.

title: ABC's of EBay: Auction, Bid And Conquer
description: IT was 9 a.m. on a Sunday here. Hundreds of people had gathered, mostly middle-aged or older, though there was an occasional young couple who had brought their toddler.

title: Not So Rare
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Set to Study Death Penalty In More Depth
description: The Justice Department said today that it would undertake a comprehensive study of the federal death penalty to determine whether the system is racially or ethnically biased.

title: A Restaurant Goes With the Flow
description: The restaurateur Danny Emerman asked Thomas Leeser, a Manhattan architect, to design Bottino (warm wood paneling) in Chelsea, Bot (acid-green walls and magenta plastic tables) in NoLIta and now Glass, a minimalist bar that opens on June 27 two blocks from Bottino. Instructed not to compete with Bottino, Mr. Leeser obliged with a curvy sheetrock ceiling and wall, above, that flows into curvy fake leather seats. ''This is like the inside of an airplane, with seamless materials morphing into each other,'' Mr. Leeser said. Glass, also owned by Fernando Henao, is at 287 10th Avenue (26th Street); (212) 904-1580. And ladies, watch what you do at the bathroom mirror: passers-by on the street can see you at the sink. ELAINE LOUIE

title: A Social Worker's Care
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Next: Roaming the World With a Translator in Your Pocket
description: TRAVELERS of the future may still carry foreign language phrase books. But in a few years they may also load software onto their pocket computers that permits real-time, simple conversations with their foreign hosts.

title: Victim Poll on Violent Crime Finds 15% Drop Last Year
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that violent crime fell 15 percent last year, the largest drop on record, a finding that puzzled some criminologists because it came only two weeks after the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported that serious crime remained stable in 2000, ending an eight-year period of significant declines in crime.

title: Visiting Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: 18th Nervous Breakdown? Green Groomed
description: While United States Golf Association officials insisted that the problems with the 18th green at the Southern Hills Country Club had been all but alleviated, some players were taking a wait-and-see approach, wondering how the hole would play when the United States Open begins Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, RICKY
description: HELLER-Ricky. A woman of valor. www.sewtime.com/Ricky

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Care Labor Contract
description: The Giuliani administration and 1199, the health care workers union, announced yesterday that they had reached a 27-month labor agreement calling for job security and a 4 percent raise in the first and second years. New York's Health and Human Service Union, 1199/SEIU, represents 1,830 city employees, including pharmacists, dietitians and laboratory technicians at various city agencies as well as the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. The contract largely mirrors that of District Council 37, the largest union of municipal workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: * Norimco, Toronto, which is distributing in North America a new brand of footwear made in Iceland called X18, to Rotter Kantor, New York, as the agency of record to introduce the brand in North America. Billings were estimated at $7 million.

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Uneasy Partners Seek Ways to Make Mideast Truce Last
description: Palestinians and Israelis began the delicate search today for ways to carry out the American-brokered agreement reached earlier in the day to extend the truce that has reduced Middle East violence during the last 12 days.

title: Tax Shelter Crackdown
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Immigrants To Testify In Smuggling Case
description: Eleven Mexicans who survived a trek across an Arizona desert that killed 14 other illegal immigrants last month will be temporarily permitted to remain in the United States. Michael Shelby, a federal prosecutor in Phoenix, said the 11 young men were released from custody on Monday and given permits allowing them to remain in Arizona, perhaps for several months, so they could testify against a man charged with smuggling them. Once that case is resolved, they will be deported, Mr. Shelby said. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Ireland's No to Europe
description: The poster child of European integration is an ingrate. That was the reaction across much of Europe last week when Irish voters rejected a treaty aimed at enlarging the European Union. In a nation that has benefited greatly from E.U. membership, the referendum's result was an embarrassing surprise to the political establishment that had backed a ''yes'' vote. The issue needs to be resubmitted to the voters, and may well be approved if the government campaigns vigorously for it.

title: Ali-Frazier Attracts 100,000 Buyers
description: The Laila Ali-Jacqui Frazier Lyde pay-per-view bout Friday night attracted an estimated 100,000 buyers at $24.95 each, according to In Demand, the fight's distributor. Ali won by decision. Richard Sandomir

title: Essay; Bush Unifies Europe
description: Western Europe was unified for two generations by a fear of the Soviet Union. Now that Russia's economy is dependent on high oil prices, its population plunging to half that of the U.S., and what's left of the Red Army mired in Chechnya, the glue holding together Europe's fragile supranational identity is resentment of the unrivaled power of the United States.

title: DANAHER TO ACQUIRE MICROTEST FOR $74 MILLION
description: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Microtest Inc. for $74 million, expanding its line of equipment that monitors computer networks. Danaher said it would pay $8.15 a share, almost double Microtest's closing share on Tuesday. Microtest's network measurement business will be combined with Danaher's electronic-testing unit, Fluke Networks. Danaher, based in Washington, has not decided if it will keep Microtest's disk-storage business. Microtest, based in Phoenix, had 2000 sales of $44.6 million.

title: The Mideast Negotiations
description: The Bush administration's first venture into high-level mediation in the Middle East has been rewarded with an encouraging, though still tentative, truce agreement brokered by George Tenet, the director of central intelligence. If yesterday's accord takes root, it could mark a turning point. What had been a fragile, day-by-day cease-fire has been reinforced with new arrangements for cooperation between Israeli and Palestinian security forces. As a result, an eventual return to peace talks has again become a subject for serious discussion.

title: Another Cooling Sound To Drown Out the Heat
description: THERE is an air-conditioner, in perfect working order, in my bedroom window. By this weekend, when the temperature is expected to hit the mid- to upper 80's, its hum will be my summer musicale. But this year, for the first time, there will also be a whirring sound.

title: Living Big With Bach In a Variety Of Spaces
description: The New York City Ballet's salute to Bach on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater was as near to perfect as programming can get. To start, there was ''Brandenburg,'' Jerome Robbins's last ballet and one of his most compelling, set to excerpts from the third, second, first and sixth concertos. Everything is here: serene order, theatricality and an unabashed sweetness of temperament.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: More Pressure On Fujimori
description: A congressional committee investigating former President Alberto K. Fujimori, who fled to Japan last fall, has called on him to answer charges that he was involved in human rights violations. Congress will determine whether the charges should be pursued. In another congressional report, the new armed forces chief, Gen. Miguel Medina, was accused of illegal actions in an arms deal with Russia in 1996. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Visiting Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Man Killed By Roller Coaster
description: A maintenance worker at Lake Compounce amusement park died early yesterday morning after being struck by the roller coaster. The ride, Boulder Dash, was being tested without passengers before the park's opening. It was unclear why the man, Wilfredo Martinez, 23, was on the tracks. Park officials and the state police are investigating the accident, said Richard Bisi, the park's director of marketing.

title: U.S. Finds No Allergies to Altered Corn
description: Government scientists said yesterday that they had found no evidence that any people had had allergic reactions to the genetically modified StarLink corn.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Require Tests for School Deficiencies
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In a victory for President Bush, the Senate today overwhelmingly passed a bill to require annual school testing and penalize failing schools if they do not improve.

title: American Contingent Will Participate in Maccabiah Games
description: American officials decided yesterday to send a team to the Maccabiah Games in Israel next month despite concerns about terrorism. However, one official, Ron Carner, said he expected that only 250 Americans instead of the anticipated 700 would elect to compete in 35 sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, EDITH (NEE BROWN)
description: FISHER-Edith (nee Brown). On June 12. Devoted wife of the late Charles Fisher. Loving mother of Bert and Sylvia Fisher and the late Adrienne and Bobby Whitehead. Adoring grandmother of Robert and Amy Fisher and Jeffrey and Nicole Fisher. Cherished great grandmother of Marlie, Gabriel and Dillon. Beloved sister of the late Shari Brown, the late Harry Brown, the late Frank Brown and the late Zara Brown. Service Thursday at 10 AM at Agudath Sholom Cemetery, Stamford, CT.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: Small Town Madeleine

title: A study looks at an eagerly sought but hard-to-reach group.
description: BOMBARDED by media messages since they were born, consumers 21 to 25 years old are a particularly difficult group for advertisers to reach. But as these consumers begin to spend money, they are also much sought after by marketers, who are looking for ways to understand them better.

title: Carol Bernstein Ferry, 76, A Supporter of Leftist Causes
description: Carol Bernstein Ferry, who with her first and second husbands gave millions of dollars of inherited wealth to support causes like the Black Panthers, prisoners' rights and opposition to the Vietnam War, took her own life early Saturday morning at a retirement home in Rye, N.Y. She was 76.

title: Only a Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Escape At Rikers Reported
description: A man awaiting trial on burglary charges escaped from a makeshift jail building on Rikers Island early yesterday morning, but officials said late yesterday that they believed he had not left the island. The man, Carlos Zufriatequi, 29, slipped out of the Adolescent Reception and Detention Center about 4:30 a.m. When asked where Mr. Zufriatequi, who is 5 feet 2 inches tall, might be, a Rikers spokeswoman replied, ''He could be under something.'' Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Samuel Conn was named to the new post of vice president for business development at Vertical Alliance, Norristown, Pa., a Web development services company. He had been director for marketing at Baxter Hemoglobin Therapeutics, Denver. Also at Vertical Alliance, Craig Deans was named to the new post of senior vice president for sales and marketing. He had been vice president for marketing and business development at plaNet, Denver, which was acquired by the NCR Corporation.

title: Comair and Its Striking Pilots Reach a Tentative Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Comair and its striking pilots reached a tentative agreement today, on the 81st day of a strike, raising the prospect that the airline, which flies as the Delta Connection with hubs in Cincinnati and Orlando, Fla., could begin partial service again soon.

title: Article 2001061493959206719 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: It Doesn't Have to Be Old to Be Vintage
description: If you are looking for a modern, moderately priced classic-style sofa upholstered in wool, there is no need to wait 12 weeks for a custom-made piece. Nor to buy something used. Karazona Cinar, who sells vintage furniture at his downtown store, White, is offering new wool sofas inspired by a 1954 Florence Knoll design. A 63-inch-long love seat is $850; an 84-inch-long sofa, $1,000. (A new Knoll costs $7,500 for a 90-inch sofa with its lowest-grade fabric.) Mr. Cinar's sofas come in charcoal gray, off-white, navy blue, orange, burgundy, brown and terra cotta. White, 85 White Street (Broadway); www.whiteonwhite.com. or (212) 964-4694. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Review-Board Study
description: More than two years after it began reviewing the Police Department's stop-and-frisk practices, the Civilian Complaint Review Board released its report yesterday. A draft was completed more than a year ago, but it was held up by political wrangling between the board and the Police Department, several board members said. The report found that the police stopped and searched blacks at a much higher rate than they did whites. But the department said that the 1,346 cases examined by the board was not representative of the more than 250,000 stops recorded by the police. The report was based on complaints from citizens who said they had been stopped between January 1997 and March 1999. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Tired of Crowds and Bores? Go by Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, HAROLD DEAN
description: GIBSON-Harold Dean. Age 74, on June 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of Patrick & Leslie and their spouses Bonnie and Edward Maluf. Adoring grandfather of Celia, Nicholas, Sofia and Eric. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM with service Friday 9:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Arts Student's League of New York, Victor D'Amico Institute of Art (The Art Barge) in Amagansett, NY or the American Cancer Society.

title: Rookie Comes Through In a Long Relief Role
description: Glendon Rusch trudged off the mound in the fourth inning tonight, perspiring heavily in the 90-degree heat. He had suffered another personal setback in his quest to regain last season's form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAGIN, RALPH
description: FAGIN-Ralph. On June 13, 2001 at age 94. Beloved husband of Sophie. Dear brother of Theodore. Stepfather of Miriam and her husband Barry. Grandfather of Elliot and Rachel. Uncle of Beth. Graveside service today, 1 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Two Goliaths, And Neither Is the Bad Guy
description: Within 55 seconds of the opening tip, Shaquille O'Neal wheeled his dump-truck frame into the key, Dikembe Mutombo backpedaled to keep up with his counterpart, and the two largest men left standing in the N.B.A. collided in midair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SEYMOUR
description: GOLDBERG-Seymour. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with sorrow the loss of its esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife Bella and to the entire family. Alfredo F. Borodowski, Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Bernard Dienstag, Cantor Katherine Teich, President Steven Chill, Chairman

title: Viktor Hamburger, 100, Dies; Embryologist Revealed Architecture of Nervous System
description: Viktor Hamburger, an experimental embryologist who mapped much of the delicate pas de deux executed by the developing nervous system and the tissue it controls, died on Tuesday in St. Louis. He was 100 years old and lived in nearby University City.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST</B

title: Transcript of Judge James P. Gray's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, June 12, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Judge James P. Gray, author of "Why Our Drug Laws Have Failed and What We Can Do About It." This discussion was the first in a series organized by forum participants.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Raphael Lemkin, the legal scholar who coined the word "genocide," misstated the interval between his flight from Poland and his parents' death in the Holocaust. While Mr. Lemkin did not know when they died, the interval could not have been nearly a decade. He fled in 1939, six years before the end of World War II.

title: Armey to Press Opposition to Net Wiretaps
description: Whatever happened to Carnivore? That's the question that Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, has posed in a letter to Attorney General John Ashcroft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, MIRIAM I. (MUNTER)
description: HELLER-Miriam I. (Munter). Entered into rest June 12, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Florida. Loving sister of Susanne Weisberg. Cherished aunt of Peter and Victoria Weisberg, Marge and Steve Sylvestri, Judith Leibowitz and Stuart Samuels. Great-aunt of Derek, Rachel, Ted, Sara and Scott. Dear friend of Kim. Services were held in MA., and interment in Brooklyn, NY. Expressions of sympathy may be donated to the Richard Weisberg Creative Arts Scholarships Fund, 7 Crestwood Road, North Reading, MA, 01864.

title: Efforts to Ease Drug Terms Stall in Albany
description: Efforts to reach a deal to relax New York's drug sentencing laws have stalled, leaving some proponents worried that no revisions will be made this summer.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Monday, about Stephen J. Hadley, the deputy national security adviser, misspelled the surname of a Cornell diplomatic historian from whom he acquired his interest in foreign affairs. The historian is Walter LaFeber, not Lefeber.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Mayor Taking Credit for Court, Golden Says
description: Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was continuing a ''personal vendetta'' by not inviting him to the groundbreaking that morning of what will be the largest courthouse in the state. The site of the $600 million building, for the criminal division of State Supreme Court and Brooklyn's Family Court, is only blocks from Mr. Golden's office in Borough Hall.

title: In Tulsa, the Heat Is on the Players and Fans
description: TULSA, Okla., June 14 - At least Lee Westwood, ranked No. 5 in the world, had a sense of humor about Tiger Woods being such a heavy favorite as the United States Open got under way this morning.

title: All Smiles as Citizen Hanover Shows Up at Gracie Ceremony
description: Donna Hanover appeared calm yesterday morning at her first public Gracie Mansion event since her estranged husband, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, expelled her from her position as first lady of New York and installed an official hostess, Irene R. Halligan, in her place. Everyone was on good behavior, more or less, including Mr. Giuliani himself.

title: Fair Game: A Critic's Book
description: From the perspective of many writers, the critic's path seems a journey between antipathies to (or even celebrations over) the blemishes of others' work, with an all-too-infrequent stopover at genuine admiration. Can anyone conceive, without trying it himself, how difficult it is for a critic to write a book? Right out there are his own literary flaws and weaknesses, ripe for exposure. The critic is waiting to be ambushed.

title: Backing Sought for Offshore Tax Initiative
description: Tax officials from the United States and other countries ended a meeting here today and returned home to seek political agreement for proposals under which the United States and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development would cooperate on reducing tax revenue lost to offshore havens.

title: Bush and European Leaders Still Split on Global Warming
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, June 14 -- President Bush and European leaders expressed sharp differences and conflicting intentions today about global warming at a summit meeting of the European Union and the United States.

title: Thrillers
description: On Tuesday night the American Film Institute revealed its list of the 100 most thrilling American movies, selected from 400 nominations by some 1,800 people in the movie business. What those numbers boil down to is the intensely subjective experience of the individual moviegoer, who gladly forks over the price of a ticket and popcorn to sit in a darkened theater and enjoy the esthetic version of a defibrillator's shock. Nearly everyone who loves movies knows the worrisome feeling that begins with the opening credits of ''Alien,'' which placed sixth on the list, or the almost unbearable level of tension in ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' which placed fifth, or even the need to look away from the screen at the two crucial moments in ''Psycho,'' which came in first.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BLOOMBERG DOT-WHAT? An Internet site for the posting of complaints about American corporations, celebrities and political figures can continue to use a Web address that denigrates Michael R. Bloomberg, the New York City mayoral candidate, according to a ruling a week ago. Mr. Bloomberg's company, Bloomberg L.P., contended that the Web address was confusingly similar to its own, including Bloomberg.com, which offers financial news and data. But an arbitration panel that decides disputes over Internet domain names ruled that the protest site has a First Amendment right to use the name. The protest site, which is run by Dan Parisi, a pornography publisher, uses many addresses created by adding to the names of companies or politicians a slang expression of contempt associated in other contexts with baby bottles. No challenge of the decision is expected.

title: Hard Money, and Soft
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRY, ELINORE
description: GARRY-Elinore. Died at Connecticut Hospice June 13th with her family at her side. Loving wife, mother and grandmother. She fought the good fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, ARLENE STAM
description: SHERMAN-Arlene Stam. Of Manhattan, died in her daughters' arms on June 12, 2001. Born May 8, 1927, Arlene was predeceased by her parents, Jacob Stam and Ida Kerbel Stam, and her eldest sister, Shirley Stuart. Mrs. Sherman was the managing partner of Arstam Realty, a former teacher, an active member in the Jewish community, and an avid lover of the arts. She is survived by two daughters, Janet Sherman and Jackie Sherman Kim and her husband Fred; sister and brother-inlaw, Hannah and Chuck Forster, and many loving friends. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. The family will receive friends at her residence after the burial and from 1 to 5 until Sunday. Memorial donations may be made to National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine, 535 Fifth Ave, Suite 600, NYC 10017.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Plan To Ease Jail Crowding
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman said the state would not meet a court-ordered Monday deadline to remove more than 2,800 state inmates from county jails. Instead Mr. Siegelman said he intended to outline a plan today to ease the crowding. Under state law, prisoners must be removed from county jails within 30 days of sentencing. The number of state inmates remaining in county jails after sentencing jumped from 1,964 when the deadline was imposed to 2,819 on Tuesday. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: The House Votes Strongly in Favor of Putting Pressure on Sudan
description: The House expressed outrage today at Sudan's government for its involvement in human rights abuses by voting to bar foreign oil companies that do business there from raising capital in the United States or listing their securities in American financial markets.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Early Childhood Education Hearing
description: A New York Assembly public hearing on early-childhood-education programs. Assembly Hearing Room, Room 1923, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 9:30 a.m. Information: (518) 455-4881.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods Are a Threat to Woods
description: IN the 101st United States Open, the threats to Tiger Woods's reign are not necessarily named Duval, Mickelson, Garcia, Els or Singh. They are named bald cypress, sweet gum, bur oak, pin oak, green ash and sycamore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a letter yesterday about the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh misstated the given name of the writer. He is Tim Ledwith, not Ted.

title: New Shelter Seeks to Place Asylum-Seeking Families in More Hospitable Surroundings
description: Just off a tree-lined country lane nestled among lush rolling hills, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is trying to put a kinder, gentler face on a piece of its oft-maligned system of jails and detention centers that house 20,000 undocumented immigrants every day.

title: Where Minimalism Is a Calling
description: A CHORUS of Leicas and video cameras clicked and whirred as the procession of robed monks started down an oak-lined alle. They paid no attention as they shuffled along chanting in Czech and Latin with their long white cowls dusting the dirt road. Four young monks hoisted a hefty foundation stone, and an abbot in a golden miter took up a portable microphone and intoned his benediction.

title: 'Lord of the Rings,' Soon at Burger King
description: The Burger King Corporation in Miami, part of Diageo, and New Line Cinema in New York, part of AOL Time Warner, have agreed on a worldwide promotional program centered on the New Line release in December of the first of three planned ''Lord of the Rings'' films. Although terms were not disclosed, the deal is being called the largest ever for New Line in terms of financial commitment and scope.

title: Big Smuggler Of Cocaine Is Arrested, Mexico Says
description: One of the biggest drug suspects in Mexico, who officials say smuggled billions of dollars of cocaine to the United States under the protection of a Mexican governor, has been arrested after years of impunity, the attorney general's office said today.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Escape From the Beltway

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimism Recedes as Europe Faces Long-Term Issues
description: Confronted by ever more numerous signs of slower growth and rising prices, European leaders are once again brooding about long-term ''speed limits'' on their economies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Strip-Search Settlement
description: People illegally strip-searched by jail guards after being arrested for minor offenses in Manhattan and Queens in 1996 and 1997 will receive $250 to $22,500 each, according to the terms of a settlement approved yesterday by a federal judge. The searches may have involved as many as 65,000 people. The city stopped such searches after a class-action suit was filed and in January tentatively agreed to the $50 million settlement approved yesterday. Checks may be mailed as early as autumn. Stephanie Flanders (NYT)

title: KGA Shuts Its Doors After a 22-Year Run
description: KGA Advertising in Middletown, Conn., which at its height had more than 40 employees and billings estimated at $35 million from clients like Bob's Stores and Pilot Pen, has closed after about 22 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHTER, VIVIENNE THAUL
description: WECHTER - Vivienne Thaul. Passed away at age 91, at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City on June 12, 2001. At the time of her death, she was a Professor of the Psychology of Creativity at Fordham University, and its Artist-inResidence. Vivienne was a star whose light shone brightly and will continue to shine through her beautiful works of art and the wonderful memories of her that her countless friends, colleagues and students have. She was married to Nathan Wechter, M.D., who died in 1969. Her survivors include her beloved daughter, Robyrta Rapoport and son-in-law, Bernard; her devoted grandson, Michael Rapoport and his dear wife, Deborah. Survivors also include her cherished sister and brothers: Jeanne Kaplan and Perez Rosenthal and Elliot Thaul; and her four great grandchildren, Rebecca, Abigail, Serena and Solomon Jonathan. Services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Wednesday at 1:00 PM. The family will receive relatives and friends at the residence of her daughter in New York City beginning Thursday 1:00 PM until Friday 5:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REKOSH, WILLIAM
description: REKOSH-William. Beloved husband of Goldie, loving father of Linda Tashman, cherished grandfather of Adam and Jamie.

title: Ad Spending Expected to Grow at Its Slowest Rate in a Decade
description: Aleading forecaster of advertising spending has confirmed fears that 2001 is likely to bring the slowest growth in that closely watched economic indicator in a decade.

title: Defense Dept. Panel Seeks Changes to Keep Military Personnel
description: An advisory panel to Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the military was losing too many of its most experienced and skilled people because of low pay, poor housing and rigid retirement rules, and it called for a sweeping overhaul of longstanding Pentagon personnel policies to stem the losses.

title: In America; Treated Like Trash
description: Velda Gonzlez may be 68 years old, the vice president of the Senate in Puerto Rico and a grandmother several times over. But none of that mattered to U.S. Navy officials who treated her like trash, which is the same way they've treated so many others who have been arrested for protesting the Navy's bombing exercises on the island of Vieques.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Surprise Verdict In Spy Case
description: A state security court acquitted a 34-year-old engineer, Sherif al-Filali, accused of spying for Israel. With sentiments running high against Israel in Egypt, the verdict came as something of a surprise but the judge noted that Mr. Filali had come forward to say he thought he had been duped by a Russian he met outside Egypt. The Russian was sentenced in absentia to life in prison with hard labor. Israel has denied involvement. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Adventures With Dragons And Monkeys
description: ANYONE who thinks a lone knight can slay a dragon with just his sword has never tried to kill a dragon. In Heroes of Might and Magic: Quest for the DragonBone Staff, you must set out to find a powerful dragon-killing staff so you can defeat your kingdom's enemy, Malazak. To find it, you must explore a variety of lands, battling rogues and villains with the assistance of human and supernatural troops.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Broadcaster
description: The television broadcaster Granada P.L.C. said a slowdown in advertising and investment in digital services led to a half-year loss. For the six months that ended March 31, Granada said it lost 71 million ($97 million), in contrast to profit of 290 million ($398 million) in the period a year earlier. Revenue was 779 million ($1.06 billion), compared with 717 million last year. The results excluded the Compass Group, a catering company that Granada spun off this year. Advertising revenue was down 5.4 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Struggling Yankees Get Fat on the Expos' Svelte Irabu
description: Hideki Irabu crossed paths with Jorge Posada on Tuesday and bowed politely to his former catcher, saying hello in English and smiling, simple gestures that encompassed most of Irabu's communication during his three years with the Yankees.

title: Man Who Killed 2 Outside Gay Bar Remains Mentally Ill, a Jury Finds
description: A State Supreme Court jury ruled yesterday that a man who shot and killed two people and wounded six others outside a Greenwich Village gay bar in 1980 is still mentally ill, a decision that will probably derail his efforts to be transferred to a less secure psychiatric institution.

title: Yank Prospect Is Back After Mystery Ailment
description: There is one Nick Johnson mystery that may never be solved. For now, though, the Yankees will concern themselves only with the more pleasant mystery of how good a hitter Johnson may one day be.

title: Special Lighting Effects for the Stereo
description: HOME theater buffs already have a mind-boggling array of woofers, subwoofers and accompanying gadgetry to make their rooms rumble when they watch movies. Now a company in Boston is developing a digital lighting system to add visual enhancements.

title: Article 2001061494095863816 -- No Title
description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: Couples Explore a Ruin as a Response to the Crucifixion
description: The New York City Ballet was in a sweetly melancholy mood when it danced Peter Martins's ''Stabat Mater'' on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Grading the Teachers, and Winding Up in a Corner
description: Gary He doesn't seem like the kind of student who would become the object of his teachers' collective wrath. Gary, a junior at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, is, by many of his peers' accounts, a diligent student who has earned good marks. But recently, the skinny, quiet 16-year-old has been threatened with a lawsuit and the prospect that his teachers will refuse to write college recommendation letters for him.

title: Defendant Tells of Robbery Gone Wrong Above a Deli
description: The robbery above the Carnegie Deli last month was supposed to be easy and without weapons, a defendant told the police in a statement released at his arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bottler Seeks Partner
description: Ram Mungale, the chief executive of Parle Bisleri, India's leading water bottler, has confirmed that the company is looking for an international partner and has talked to Groupe Danone of France and Nestl of Switzerland. Bottled water sales are growing at 70 percent a year in India. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Tests For A Polygamist
description: A lawyer for Tom Green, the husband of five women and father of 29 children who recently became the first Utah man in 50 years to be convicted on state bigamy charges, is trying to block state efforts to have Mr. Green undergo a psychological and sexual evaluation before he is sentenced on June 27. The lawyer, John Bucher, said that the state was trying to show Mr. Green in the least favorable light before a judge determined a prison term. Mr. Green is facing up to five years for each of four bigamy counts and one count of nonsupport. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: American and North Korean Diplomats Hold Talks in New York
description: Diplomats from the United States and North Korea met in New York today for what the State Department called a useful beginning to a dialogue between the two countries.

title: The President's Serenade Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Another G.M. Investment In Fuel Cell Development
description: General Motors signed a 25-year partnership today to work on hydrogen production, storage and refueling as part of its plan to mass-produce cars that run on fuel cells, which make electric current without combustion.

title: Accord on Giving Victims More Clout in Son of Sam Law
description: The governor and legislative leaders reached an agreement today to amend the so-called Son of Sam law to make it possible for crime victims to sue criminals not just for profits from book and movie deals but also for virtually any money they receive while in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIN, RICHARD
description: ROBIN-Richard. Son of the late Henri Rabinowicz and Sophie Romanus Rabinowicz, died peacefully on June 12, 2001 at 88 years of age. His stories of pre-WWII Europe, then fighting the Germans as a French Cavalry Officer or working, after the fall of France, on behalf of displaced persons and Jewish refugees as Director of the ''Camp des Milles'' (JDC/HIAS) outside Marseille, and being among the last to escape Free France before it fell to German occupation, never ceased to amaze his friends and family. He became a USA citizen in the Army and used his linguistic talents working for the Office of War Information Agency, continuing his career in the Air Force and Army. Loving and devoted husband of Therese for 58 years, beloved father to Jacky and Jeffrey, doting and proud grandfather of Scott and Mark. His story telling, wit and charm will be missed. Visitation Thursday, June 14th 7-9PM and Services Friday, June 15th 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva will be observed at the Clyman residence on Saturday, June 16th from 8PM-10PM and Sunday 5PM9PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

title: Editor Quits TheStreet.com, Partly Over Policy Concerns
description: The financial news Web site TheStreet.com announced the resignation of its editor in chief, Dave Kansas, yesterday. The resignation came amid tensions within the newsroom over the company's efforts to augment its financial journalism with new sources of revenue, including the sale of specialized research to institutional investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, RABBI AARON S.
description: GOLD-Rabbi Aaron S. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. He served several pulpits in Wisconsin, Nevada and California. From 1974 until he became rabbi emeritus in 1992, he served Tifereth Israel Synagogue in San Diego. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Jeanne and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: For General Managers, It's Produce or Perish
description: The Cleveland Indians made it look easy. They moved into a new park, Jacobs Field, in 1994 and began winning division championships the following season. Teams have been trying to duplicate their success ever since.

title: Nasdaq Ends Down 3.7 Percent
description: Stocks prices fell sharply today, led down by the technology sector, as investors turned skittish after another round of dismal forecasts from corporate America.

title: Lag in Appointments Strains the Cabinet
description: Ordinarily, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill would send a deputy to a conference of the Asian Development Bank. But there was no one to send, so he made the 10-hour trip to Honolulu himself.

title: A Bit of Silliness In the Hamptons
description: It should be no news that there are follies in the Hamptons; this time they are architectural. On Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., there is a self-guided tour of five properties in Southampton, Bridgehampton and East Hampton, each with whimsical pavilions or houses, a k a follies, including a Moroccan-style tent and a house built in a former dairy barn. The tour is in conjunction with a show, ''Follies: Fantasy in the Landscape,'' at the Parrish Art Museum. On Saturday there is a symposium on follies, and in the evening, a dinner and auction of renderings (above, detail of a David Linley watercolor). Symposium and tour, $150; all events, $400 and up. Reservations required. Parrish Art Museum, Southampton, N.Y.; (631) 283-2118, ext. 33. SHELLY FREIERMAN

title: NEWS WATCH; Looking for Fuel Bargains? Boot Up Before Gassing Up
description: People who drive 20 miles out of their way to save a penny on a tank of unleaded may now save a trip by visiting www.gaspricewatch.com. That Web site tells users where the cheapest gasoline is within a 20-mile radius of any ZIP code.

title: The Art World Returns to Venice, Dipping en Masse Into Nostalgia
description: Contemporary art has always thrived on the herd instinct, and when the herd gets wind of an event worth seeing, everybody comes. Love it or hate it, few serious contemporary art followers would dare miss a Venice Biennale, arguably one of the most important platforms for contemporary art. At this, the 49th Biennale, some 30,000 people turned out for the three preview days specially held for the art world in advance of the Biennale's formal opening to the public.

title: Article 2001061490078676161 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: ENVELOPE MAKER CUTS 1,200 JOBS AND CLOSES 9 PLANTS
description: Mail-Well Inc., the nation's largest maker of envelopes, said yesterday that its second-quarter revenue would miss forecasts and that it would lay off 1,200 workers, or 7.5 percent of its work force, and close nine plants. Second-quarter earnings will be 4 cents a share, down from a previous estimate of 8 cents, Mail-Well said. The company, based in Englewood, Colo., earned 21 cents a year earlier, and expected to earn 25 cents to 30 cents this year. Mail-Well also said it will sell its label and printed-office-products units. Production will be shifted from the envelope plants being closed to 27 other factories. The company's stock fell $1.15 yesterday, or 19 percent, to $4.85 a share.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At the age where they should be wanting to wait for tickets for Bozo, they're playing those little video games in their hands. Kids want fireworks, kids want smoke. They want something more.''

title: A Visual Arts College Views Baltimore's Future
description: Even John Waters would be hard-pressed to include Baltimore in a list of cities with progressive architecture. But the glowing and faceted $12 million Brown Center (a model above), the Maryland Institute College of Art's first new academic building in almost 100 years, could put Baltimore on that list. The architect Charles Brickbauer said the 62.5 degree angles of the building were ''in logical response to the geometry of the site,'' meaning the skewed city grid. ''I can't do something that doesn't have order,'' he said. ''I can't just throw a Frank Gehry curve at it.'' Mr. Brickbauer, who once worked with Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson, is a partner in Ziger/Snead & Charles Brickbauer in Baltimore. He designed the Baltimore-Washington International Airport passenger terminal.

title: This Is the Seat For a Rum Drink
description: It was 1957 when John Caldwell, 19, created an outdoor chair for Californians who hated the wrought-iron look from back East. It took Margaret Nowell, a New Yorker who worked at Brown Jordan, the manufacturer, to name the icon-to-be. Mr. Caldwell recalled: ''She said, 'John, what do you think of the name Mai Tai?' I had no idea what a mai tai was. I said I thought it sounded terrific.'' Now Design Within Reach is reintroducing the powder-coated, tubular-steel-framed Mai Tai collection; $300 to $725 from www.dwr.com or (800) 944-2233.

title: Entertaining Foreigners In Victorian England
description: THE VICTORIAN VISITORS

title: Jingles All the Way
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: As Rivals Steam Forward, Oracle Christens a Database
description: The Oracle Corporation, seeking to solidify its lead in the database market amid persistent competition from I.B.M. and Microsoft and in the face of difficult economic conditions, formally introduced the next generation of its own database software today.

title: Phil Frost
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RICHARD M.
description: SCHWARTZ-Richard M. Devoted and loving husband, son, father, brother, uncle and friend; died on June 13, 2001. He is survived by his wife Juliann, his father Ralph, his children Allison, Christopher, Jonathan and Emily; his brothers Stephen and Leo and sister Elsa. Funeral services will be held at 10:30AM Friday, June 15th at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, N.Y. Family and friends will be received Friday through Sunday at the Schwartz home on 44 Woodland Drive, Rye Brook, New York.

title: Japanese Grab a Lead In Luxury-Car Sales
description: BERNARD DUBIN, a Philadelphia architect and a lifelong fan of European cars, ran out of patience this winter with the cost of repairs for his 1990 Audi. Although he considered replacing it with another Audi, he bought a 2001 Acura 3.2TL instead.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: The Big City; In 80's, Fear Spread Faster Than AIDS
description: IN July of 1988, at the height of the AIDS epidemic, the estimated number of cases in New York City suddenly plummeted. The city health commissioner soon needed police protection.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Famous Slackers of Senior Year
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Waste Settlement
description: The Metalclad Corporation, a California-based waste management company, said the Mexican government had agreed to pay $15.6 million as compensation for lost profits in an out-of-court settlement after a Canadian court ruled in favor of the company. Last month, the Supreme Court of British Columbia upheld a ruling by a North American Free Trade Agreement panel that Mexico violated a law protecting foreign investors by blocking Metalclad from constructing a waste dump in northern Mexico. The case was heard in Canada as a neutral venue under Nafta rules.

title: Panel Faults Progress of Prison Health Care
description: Medical treatment given to 13,500 city inmates is not improving as quickly as city officials had hoped when they hired a Tennessee-based, for-profit company six months ago to revamp medical and mental health services at Rikers Island, officials on an oversight board said yesterday.

title: Police Killings of Israeli Arabs Being Questioned by Inquiry
description: A formal inquiry this month into the police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October has raised questions about several of the shootings, particularly whether the police needed to fire live ammunition. It has also served as a platform to air what Israeli Arabs say is discrimination that has gone on for decades.

title: Puerto Ricans Question Vieques's Future
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 14  Befitting an island whose political relationship to the United States has long been disputed, reaction to President Bush's decision to end the Navy's bombing practice runs on Vieques was met today with skepticism about its timetable, timing and intent.

title: Parlaying a Gift Into a Gig Honoring Ol' Blue Eyes
description: THE show, an homage to Frank Sinatra, must go on tonight, and tomorrow is matinee day, a doubleheader, so the humidifiers are hissing away at full throttle in Bill Boggs's one-bedroom aerie on Central Park South. In the midst of a giddy, three-week, Mittyesque stint as a replacement vocalist-raconteur in ''Our Sinatra,'' the Eric Comstock invention now running in the Reprise Room at Dillon's, Mr. Boggs has an instrument to protect, and we're not talking about his grand piano.

title: F.B.I. Agent To Be Spared Prosecution In Shooting
description: A week after a sharply divided federal appeals court ruled that an F.B.I. sharpshooter could stand trial in a 1992 shooting in Ruby Ridge, Idaho, the county prosecutor there announced today that he would not proceed with manslaughter charges against the agent.

title: The Extra Mideast Mile
description: To the Editor:

title: Lockwood de Forest
description: Richard York Gallery

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Fighting The Priest Drain
description: Warning that too many third-world priests trained in Europe are staying there for lifestyle reasons, the Vatican has issued a pamphlet clarifying how priests and missionaries should be deployed to help their own people at home. Cardinal Josef Tomko, who heads the Vatican's office for evangelization, noted that European parishes where priests are scarce compound the problem by recruiting Asians and Africans. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: The Un-Clinton and the Un-Yeltsin
description: George W. Bush and Vladimir Putin have this in common: They got where they are by promising to be unlike their larger-than-life predecessors. Both say Russian-American relations will also be different, based on hard-boiled scrutiny of national interests, not on personal ties dressed up as grand strategy. So, when the un-Clinton meets the un-Yeltsin tomorrow, post-cold-war diplomacy officially enters its post-heroic phase. Visionary, big-guy bonhomie is out; small-bore practicality is in.

title: Tony Smith -- 'Paintings and Sculpture, 1960-65'
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: American Team Will Participate
