description: American officials decided yesterday to send a team to the Maccabiah Games in Israel next month despite concerns about terrorism. However, one official, Ron Carner, said he expected that only 250 Americans instead of the anticipated 700 would elect to compete.

title: Stakes in Weak French Carriers Add to Swissair Woes
description: Swissair, trying for months to stabilize its seriously shaky finances, may see its troubles worsen drastically as soon as Friday by a threatened bankruptcy filing by the two French airlines in which Swissair has a major stake but not management control.

title: G.E. Purchase Of Honeywell Now Appears Near Collapse
description: General Electric's planned acquisition of Honeywell International appeared near collapse today after G.E. said that its final concessions would probably not satisfy European regulators.

title: More Lean, Less Mean, Floors Swept And So Clean; Having Hot Coffee Helps Bring Order In the Court
description: A quiet revolution is afoot at 100 Centre Street, America's busiest criminal courthouse. It is being led by men with mops.

title: Indexes Drop as Poor Forecasts Pull Technology Down
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by the technology sector, after another round of dismal forecasts from corporate America.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL GAINS. Heating oil rose on speculation that inventories will be left low as refiners concentrate on making gasoline. In New York, heating oil for July delivery rose 3.14 cents, or 3.9 percent, to 83.28 cents a gallon.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</B

title: Handle With Care: You Could Be Their Next Lunch
description: Now that the major television networks have completed their seasons, attention can be paid to the stunts on cable. The Weather Channel began the summer with ''StormWeek,'' reveling in the terror of tornadoes, hurricanes, blizzards -- the deadlier the better. Starting Sunday the Food Network is running a weeklong series of programming under the banner ''Taste the Adventure,'' with the Survivor II contestant Keith Famie (also a chef) as the host -- with a sweepstakes, for further enticement. Next month the History Channel presents ''Ride 'Em Cowboy Week.'' In August the Discovery Channel returns with its biggest event, the 14th edition of ''Shark Week,'' which attracted 22 million viewers last year.

title: In a Brash Yet Refined School, Everyone Belongs Together
description: It could be argued that the last thing New York museums need is more great paintings by the premier talents of the School of Paris: Picasso, Matisse, Braque, Mir and company. The collections of the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum would seem to satisfy every conceivable need, and then some.

title: FLORIDA BANK TO EXPAND ITS PRESENCE IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The FNB Corporation, a Florida bank with branches in Pennsylvania and Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Promistar Financial Corporation for $418 million in stock to expand in Western Pennsylvania. FNB will exchange 0.926 share of its stock for each share of Promistar. Promistar, based in Johnstown, Pa., has 72 branches in western Pennsylvania. It will add 10 when it completes its purchase of the First National Bank of Herminie, Pa. FNB, based in Naples, Fla., has 43 branches in western Pennsylvania. The acquired Promistar offices will operate under the First National Bank of Pennsylvania name. At least eight branches will be closed or sold.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lawrence: Scores Canceled
description: The Educational Testing Service said yesterday that it was canceling the scores for 1,000 students from 11 high schools in New York and Connecticut who took the SAT II biology test on June 2. There were no allegations of improprieties, but some students received the test from a tutor and shared it with others, apparently without knowing that it would be the actual test. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Panel Finds Earlier Autism Tests Will Lead to Better Treatment
description: School systems should try to identify autism in children as young as 2 through regular screening programs like those used to test vision and hearing, a report from the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.

title: China Said to Sharply Reduce Emissions of Carbon Dioxide
description: In the debate on global climate change it has long been a given that China, with its huge population and endless coal reserves, would overtake the United States early this century as the biggest source of the atmospheric pollution that scientists believe is warming the planet.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Sotheby's Finds Room for Fun

title: British Airways Makes Deal To Sell Its Discount Carrier
description: After three months of negotiations, British Airways said today that it had reached an agreement to sell Go, its discount airline subsidiary, for 110 million ($153 million) to 3i, a venture capital firm, and Go's senior managers.

title: The 'Traffik' Before 'Traffic'
description: With ''Traffic'' already on tape and DVD, now comes ''Traffik,'' the 11-year-old British television production from which Steven Soderbergh's film was adapted. On June 26 Acorn Media will release the six-hour miniseries on cassette and disc, and from start to finish the complex and riveting predecessor, shown on PBS in this country, takes no back seat to its formidable American offspring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, DORIS (NEE STOUT)
description: FITZGERALD-Doris (nee Stout). On June 13, 2001. Former Dean of Manhattan Community College. Beloved wife of the late John T. Devoted mother of Ellen, Jean and Gerald. Memorial visitation will be held Tuesday 5-7 pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20 St.), NYC. Interment private. Doris was respected by her peers, beloved by her students, and will be missed by all.

title: United Airlines Contract Talks to Resume
description: United Airlines is scheduled to resume talks Monday with the machinists union on a contract for baggage handlers, customer-service agents and reservations workers in an attempt to avert a strike.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Sonia Gandhi To Visit U.S.
description: Sonia Gandhi, president of the Congress Party and widowed heir to the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, will make her first trip to the United States as leader of the opposition to the Indian government. She will speak at the Asia Society in New York on June 26 and to the Congressional India Caucus on June 27. She will be accompanied by Manmohan Singh, the former finance minister who is the party's most important voice for economic liberalization. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Album of the Week: Travis's 'The Invisible Band'
description: TRAVIS: "The Invisible Band (Epic)." It's been hard to form a solid opinion on Travis. The band's first single, the guitar- heavy, inanely catchy, perfectly produced "All I Wanna Do is Rock," was one of the freshest, most promising British independent releases of 1996. Its breakthrough album, "The Man Who," also had a great sound. But at the same time it seemed derivative, leaving some wondering if Travis was supposed to be Radiohead for dummies or Oasis for smart people. On its third album, "The Invisible Band," Travis proves that it's a band with staying power and takes a step further toward establishing its own sound.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Bank Executive
description: In a rare appointment of an outsider to a senior position, the Bank of Ireland Group hired Michael Soden, the general manager of global business and personal financial services at National Australia Bank, to become chief executive when Maurice Keane retires from the post in February. Mr. Soden, 54, is expected to return to his native Dublin from Australia in September and begin serving as chief executive-designate. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Testimony in Murder Trial Centers on Rules of Death Row
description: The rules and meager pleasures of life on death row were the focus of testimony today as the murder trial of a condemned prisoner ended its second week.

title: On a Lighthearted Trek, With Family on His Mind
description: As Felix (Sami Bouajila), a freewheeling gay dockworker of Arab descent, tries to find his father in ''Adventures of Felix,'' a slight comedy-drama, he wanders into a whole new family.

title: Deep U.S.-Europe Split Casts Long Shadow on Bush Tour
description: President Bush and European leaders expressed sharp differences and conflicting intentions today about global warming at a summit meeting of the European Union and the United States.

title: 2 California Utilities On Divergent Paths
description: Hanging on one wood-paneled wall of John E. Bryson's office at Edison International is a sepia-colored 1920's photograph of two utility workers perched precariously above a raging waterfall, clutching thin wires as they measure the depth of the rushing water that threatens to sweep them away.

title: Deal for Honeywell In Doubt, G.E. Says
description: General Electric's proposed $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International appeared near collapse after G.E. said that its final concessions would probably not satisfy regulators in Europe.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-And-Mouth, Again
description: Army units were recalled to curb new outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in areas of Somerset and Devon that had been free of the contagion. The spread has shaken government claims that the four-month-old epidemic that has resulted in the slaughter of more than three million farm animals is dying out. Government experts now fear it will continue until the end of the year. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Senators Seek Inquiry Into Leaks About Investigation of Torricelli
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee asked the Justice Department today to investigate the source of leaks to news organizations about the department's criminal investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Louis Quinones, a former participant in a Fresh Air Fund program, misstated the given name of his mother. She is Judy Quinones, not Ruby.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Combs Trial Figure Arrested
description: The man known as Scar who witnesses said instigated the gunfight that led to the trial of Sean Combs, the rap impresario, was himself arrested yesterday and charged with a federal weapons offense. The man, Matthew Allen, was accused by federal prosecutors of having a gun inside his car during a Brooklyn traffic stop on New Year's Day. Mr. Allen had been scheduled to appear as a witness at Mr. Combs's recent trial, in which Mr. Combs was acquitted, but he was never called.

title: Graves Honored After Tough Season
description: In perhaps his final public appearance representing the Rangers, Adam Graves conducted himself at the National Hockey League awards ceremony tonight the way he always has in his decade in New York: with humility and grace.

title: Baltic States Seek Bush's Help in Joining NATO as Political Insurance Against Russia
description: Ten years ago last January, Soviet tanks and machine gunners stormed the central television studios and broadcasting tower of this Baltic capital, killing 15 people and wounding hundreds, as the Red Army tried to put down the wave of independence movements that was tearing the Soviet Union apart.

title: INSIDE
description: Asthma Study Volunteer Dies

title: Toward an Era of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Watts -- 'Photography Into Sculpture'
description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUEN, FRANCIS WILLIAM
description: BRUEN-Francis William. On June 14, 2001. Retired member of the N.Y.C.P.D. Born in Manhattan, NYC, January 13, 1918, and a resident of Vinegar Hill, Manhattan, for forty-two years, prior to moving to Stuyvesant Town, NYC. Father of none, and godfather of many. Predeceased by his mother, Elizabeth (nee Reynolds) and father, Bartholomew, both of Mohill, County Leitrim, Ireland, and by brother, Gerard and sister, Rita. Visitation at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, New York, Saturday & Sunday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Emeric's Church, 740 East 13th Street, NY, NY between Avenues C & D Monday 9:30 AM. Interment to follow in family plot at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Taking The U.S. Plane Apart
description: A six-member United States team has begun dismantling a damaged EP-3 surveillance plane that made an emergency landing April 1 on the southern island of Hainan after colliding with a Chinese jet, American officials said. Under an agreement with Beijing, the plane's wings and tail will be removed and the pieces will be flown out by two giant cargo planes, rented from a Russian company. Navy officials say they expect it will take nearly four weeks to complete the work. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, PAULINE
description: ROSEN-Pauline. Age 81. On June 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving Rosen. Mother of Murray, Bobbe (Paul) Carton. Grandmother of Jeffrey (Lauren), Craig (Kim), Caryn Carton, Daniel (Anna) and Christopher Rosen. Great grandmother of Amy, Andrew and Mickey. Graveside service June 17th, 10AM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Jerry Sterner, 62, Playwright; Wrote 'Other People's Money'
description: Jerry Sterner, a businessman turned playwright who wrote the Off Broadway hit ''Other People's Money,'' died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 62.

title: In Our Yard, for a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: American Human Rights Worker Survives Attack in Guatemala
description: A researcher for the human rights group Amnesty International was attacked in Guatemala at a hotel during a failed kidnapping attempt, her colleagues said today.

title: Pilots Reach Tentative Deal With Comair
description: Comair and its striking pilots reached a tentative agreement today, on the 81st day of a strike.

title: Home Video: The 'Traffik' Before 'Traffic'
description: With "Traffic" already on tape and DVD, now comes "Traffik," the 11-year-old British television production from which Steven Soderbergh's film was adapted. On June 26 Acorn Media will release the six-hour miniseries on cassette and disc, and from start to finish the complex and riveting predecessor, shown on PBS in this country, takes no back seat to its formidable American offspring.

title: Nortel Expects a Huge Loss in 2nd Quarter and Will Lay Off 10,000
description: Nortel Networks of Canada said yesterday that it expected to report a loss that would be one of the biggest in corporate history, increasing concern over the troubled telecommunications industry.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: SECOND BRANCH FOR DORAL BANK Doral Bank plans to open its second Manhattan branch next week, the latest move in its effort to fill in gaps left by New York's biggest banks. The branch is scheduled to open on June 21 at 4246 Broadway in Washington Heights, officials from the Doral Financial Corporation , owner of Doral Bank, said yesterday. The company, based in Puerto Rico and listed on the Nasdaq, opened its first Manhattan branch last year at Park Avenue South and 27th Street. It plans to open branches in Co-op City, the Bronx; Astoria, Queens; and Sunset Park, Brooklyn, before the end of this year. Doral and other smaller banks are flocking to the region to compete with Chase and Citibank. The new branch will be open seven days a week, offering evening hours Monday through Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about obstacles to Senate confirmation of John D. Negroponte as ambassador to the United Nations misspelled the name of a former secretary of state who supports it. He is George P. Shultz, not Schulz.

title: 2 Guilty Pleas Are Expected In MindArrow Stock Fraud
description: The owner of a stock transfer agency and an associate are to plead guilty to federal fraud and money-laundering charges for counterfeiting 1.1 million shares of MindArrow Systems, a software company, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDERS, RALPH FRANKLIN
description: KANDERS-Ralph Franklin. Died peacefully at home on June 14, 2001 surrounded by his beloved wife of 44 years, Jeanne, and his children. Son of Beatrice Kanders and devoted and cherished father of Warren, Beatrice Kanders Hoffman, Jonathan, Alan, Emily and grandfather to Alexander, Zachary, Sarabeth, William, Chloe and Abigail. Born on November 30, 1921 in Manhattan, he graduated from Cornell University in 1942 and New York University School of Dentistry in 1946. He practiced periodontics in Montclair and Convent Station, NJ. He served on the dental teaching staff of Mountainside Hospital and Morristown Memorial Hospital in NJ. He established the Kanders Foundation to promote his philanthropic interests in education, the arts and science. He was an extremely warm and generous man whose thirst for learning and devotion to higher education helped many individuals and institutions. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Ralph F. Kanders Memorial Scholarship at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Guccione Giving Up Real Estate
description: Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse magazine, appears to have given up on developing two lots in Atlantic City. Officials say he is selling the lots under threat of a sheriff's auction, after having posted them as collateral for a loan on which he later defaulted. Mr. Guccione's office at General Media in Manhattan declined to comment. But James B. Kennedy, executive director of the New Jersey Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, said his agency agreed to pay Mr. Guccione $7.6 million for a 3.5-acre, commercially zoned site near the Atlantic City Expressway. For the short term, he said, the site will provide parking for the city's two convention centers. Officials said the agency's bid of $2.6 million on the second lot, a 2.3-acre casino-zoned parcel along the boardwalk, fell $500,000 short of a bid by an undisclosed buyer. Proceeds of the sales will satisfy $14 million of the $28 million owed by Mr. Guccione to Kennedy Funding Inc. of Hackensack, N.J., said Joseph Wolfer, Kennedy Funding's chairman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay in Circuits yesterday about implications of an online hoax misspelled the names of two people whose views were cited. They were Kristin Thomas (not Kristen), a fiction writer in Chicago, and Wendy Kimbel (not Kimbell), a legal assistant in North Carolina.

title: Man Charged With Killing 7 Chicago Women
description: The police said today that they had uncovered a serial killer who had murdered and sexually assaulted seven women, including two Bosnian immigrants lured to their deaths by the promise of jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORMAN, BERTRAND SEYMOUR
description: DORMAN-Bertrand Seymour, 86 years young. Died peacefully on Tuesday, June 12th, 2001 at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. Mr. Dorman, an outstanding New York insurance broker for over 50 years, lived in Allenhurst, NJ. Devoted husband of Judith; loving father to Jill Garfunkel, C. Dorman, Andrea and Lance Phox; adoring grandfather to Sara Naomi Phox; tender and devoted brother to Marjorie Glickman of NYC. Bert had a special relationship with his nieces, nephews and their families. A longtime partner with his father at Jack Dorman & Son, and last associated with Channing Associates, Bert was known for the personal attention and caring he gave to every client. Donations may be made to Jewish Family and Children's Service, Asbury Park, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special E-Business section on Wednesday about the use of the Internet by mining companies misspelled the name of a consulting and software company whose chief executive, E. Russell Braziel, commented on progress. It is Netrana, not Netrona.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about summer school in Chicago misstated the number of students ordered to attend because they failed promotion requirements. It is about 70,000; the total enrollment, 245,000, includes students attending voluntarily in programs like band and sports camps.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Lernout Figure To Be Extradited
description: Gaston Bastiaens, the former chief executive of the speech technologies company Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, has agreed to be extradited to Belgium, where he faces insider-trading charges. Charles Swartwood, a federal magistrate, signed the extradition order and denied bail to Mr. Bastiaens, left. The judge's order said Mr. Bastiaens had agreed to surrender to the Belgian authorities and would be handed over on Tuesday, a spokeswoman with the United States attorney's office in Boston said. Mr. Bastiaens, 54, was arrested last month in Massachusetts on a Belgian warrant accusing him of insider trading, stock-market manipulation and violation of bookkeeping laws.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Expanding Alliance
description: At a summit meeting in Shanghai, the Shanghai Five -- Russia, China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan -- became the Shanghai Forum, as Uzbekistan joined the alliance formed five years ago in reaction to mounting terrorism along China's western border. The six countries agreed to fight Islamic separatism and create the model for a new political order in Central Asia. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend last Friday misattributed the design of the Swaged-Leg Chair of the 1950's. It was by Charles Pollock, an employee of George Nelson Associates, not by Mr. Nelson himself.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend last Friday with a review of ''Roger Newton: Hypnotize,'' at the Roth Horowitz Gallery in Manhattan through June 23, was reproduced sideways. The arcs in Mr. Newton's untitled photograph from 1999 should have appeared at the top.

title: Article 2001061591766737296 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, JACK
description: KRAFT-Jack. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, N.Y., mourns the loss of a longtime and devoted member. We will all miss seeing him on Shabbat mornings. To Sara, Dr. Howard, Rhonda and their families, our deepest sympathy and condolence. May his memory be a blessing. Laurence A. Feldman, President Myron M. Fenster, Rabbi

title: Sunshine, Blue Skies and, Oh Yes, Gloom
description: Bluegrass, a genre of songs that tend to be obsessed with mortality, has been granted a large life extension in recent years. The Dixie Chicks brought banjo-picking back to country radio, hippies are turning to bluegrass as the ultimate jam music, country stars like Dolly Parton are specializing in bluegrass albums and the Joel and Ethan Coen movie ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' spawned the first bluegrass CD to top the country charts in recent memory.

title: Fraud Suspect's New Case
description: Christopher Rocancourt, the man who has admitted soaking the rich in the Hamptons last summer by passing himself off as a scion of the Rockefeller clan, has been indicted on charges he swindled $100,000 from a woman.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I hate to put my phone bill in the mail because it takes forever, and this person puts a $46 million ticket in the mail?''

title: West Bank Bloodshed Spoils Effort for Firm Cease-Fire
description: Bloodshed marred efforts today to solidify a truce between Israelis and Palestinians. But both sides still seemed prepared to pursue efforts to end nearly nine months of violence.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hopewell: Helicopter In Emergency Landing
description: Six passengers aboard a Manhattan-bound helicopter suffered minor injuries early yesterday during an emergency landing near the Trenton-Mercer Airport, reportedly in heavy fog. The passengers were treated at hospitals and released, the authorities said. Inspectors from the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board are investigating the 1:40 a.m. incident. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: 'Lost and Found'
description: Apex Art

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Developer Choices Narrowed
description: Officials say they are in the last stages of selecting a developer for a major part of a proposed $771 million convention and retail center. Workers broke ground last week on the center, Adriaen's Landing, a 33-acre project intended to revitalize the riverfront. But the state recently broke ties with Casden Properties, a development group based in Los Angeles that was going to design stores and luxury residences for the complex. Officials overseeing the project said a new developer would be announced soon.

title: Wall Street's Analysis Put on the Defensive at a Hearing
description: Wall Street was put squarely on the defensive today as Congressional hearings into the conflicts among brokerage firm research analysts opened here.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From breaking in a new car to the best SUV for the Puerto Rican climate, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Article 2001061590480475140 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, HAROLD
description: GIBSON-Harold. On behalf of our organization and the many children of our community whom we serve, we send sympathy to the family of our Founder and Chairman, without whose vision we would not have succeeded. Yorkville Youth Association

title: Luis Gonzlez Palma
description: Robert Mann Gallery

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Earnings Beat Estimates
description: The publishing software maker Adobe Systems Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings and sales exceeded Wall Street expectations. Adobe earned $121.5 million, or 34 cents a share, well above analysts' consensus forecast of 29 cents a share. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $344.1 million from $300.1 million in the quarter a year earlier. ''Given the tough economic environment, I am extremely pleased with Adobe's financial results in the quarter,'' Bruce R. Chizen, the chief executive, said. The company did, however, make careful statements about its future, warning that second-quarter weakness in North America and Europe was expected to continue in the third quarter. ''Additionally,'' said Murray J. Demo, its chief financial officer, ''we are factoring in a potential slowdown in Asia.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Alabama Governor Offers Plan to Ease Crowding in the Jails
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman outlined a $6.8 million plan today to alleviate jail crowding by removing state inmates and creating more prison cells within a year.

title: Where Even A Not-Good Book Can Be Not Bad
description: The term beach book may sound like an innocent designation, but we all know what it really is: an excuse. It's what you say when caught red-handed with ''Beyond the Valley of the Dolls'' by someone who is rereading ''The Mill on the Floss.'' It's the justification for putting off quality time with Balzac and Flaubert in favor of the gustatory noodlings of Peter Mayle, whose vision of Gallic culture exists on a somewhat less exalted plane.

title: Accounts
description: Spartan Stores, Grand Rapids, Mich., which owns, operates and distributes products to supermarkets, drugstores and convenience stores, consolidated its media planning and buying account, with billings estimated at $23 million, by naming CIA USA, Chicago, part of the CIA Medianetwork unit of the Tempus Group, to handle that assignment. Previously, Blackwood Media Management, Rockford, Mich., had handled media planning and buying for stores owned by Spartan, while stores to which Spartan distributes merchandise had handled media internally or through their own agencies.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Weighing In On California Energy Suit
description: Attorney General Mike McGrath has filed a friend-of-the-court brief in a California lawsuit that seeks a court order compelling the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to set reasonable rates for wholesale electricity. Mr. McGrath cited job losses since prices went up and warned of a potential ''devastating impact'' on the state's economy. A three-judge panel has denied the California request, and Mr. McGrath joined in asking the full Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to hear the case. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Puerto Ricans Question Vieques's Future
description: Befitting an island whose political relationship to the United States has long been disputed, reaction to President Bush's decision to end the Navy's bombing practice runs on Vieques was met today with skepticism about its timetable, timing and intent.

title: Swedes Have a Litany Of Complaints for Bush
description: Most days, Kiffa Alverfors attends college classes, intent on getting a job in media relations. But today she was among thousands who marched through the streets of this city protesting a visit by President Bush.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Former Party Head Joins Law Firm
description: Joseph J. Andrew, the national chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1999 to February of this year, has been named a partner in the corporate mergers and acquisitions department at the Manhattan law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. Mr. Andrew, who was also named chairman of the law firm's global public affairs group, will be based in New York and Washington.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Second Branch For Doral Bank
description: Doral Bank plans to open its second Manhattan branch next week, the latest move in its effort to fill in gaps left by New York's biggest banks. The branch is scheduled to open on June 21 at 4246 Broadway in Washington Heights, officials from the Doral Financial Corporation, owner of Doral Bank, said yesterday. The company, based in Puerto Rico and listed on the Nasdaq, opened its first Manhattan branch last year at Park Avenue South and 27th Street. It plans to open branches in Co-op City, the Bronx; Astoria, Queens; and Sunset Park, Brooklyn, before the end of this year. Doral and other smaller banks are flocking to the region to compete with Chase and Citibank. The new branch will be open seven days a week, offering evening hours Monday through Friday. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Stake
description: The debt-laden British Telecommunications was reported to be considering selling its 21.7 percent stake in the LG Telecom Company of South Korea to Telesystem International Wireless of Canada. The move would be the latest in a series by British Telecommunications meant to reduce its $40 billion debt mountain; the debt has forced the company to raise capital with an emergency issue of discounted equity and to sell assets, including real estate and stakes in other phone companies. The South Korean company said three-way talks on the proposed sale were under way, but a British Telecommunications spokesman declined to comment. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Waiting For Webb
description: Colorado Democrats are waiting to learn whether Mayor Wellington E. Webb of Denver intends to challenge Senator Wayne Allard, a Republican, in his bid next year for a second term. Mr. Webb, whose third four-year term ends in 2003, has said only that he is considering a run, which has left at least two other Democrats hedging their plans. Attorney General Tom Strickland and Representative Mark Udall have indicated interest in running. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Standings Aside, What Matters Is Momentum
description: Andy Pettitte starts the Yankees' 65th game tonight while Al Leiter pitches the Mets' 67th, and in baseball's 162-game season the true statistical value of the outcome will be about six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about toughening regulatory standards for mergers of railroad companies misstated the name of a trade association that is critical. It is the American Chemistry Council, not the American Chemical Council.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Crowding Leads To Sentencing Changes
description: The House approved legislation reducing sentences for drug convictions and eliminating mandatory sentences for many nonviolent crimes. The bill, approved in a 65-to-35 vote, was a response to crowding in state prisons. The measure allows judges to sentence nonviolent offenders to jail or probation. Gov. Mike Foster, a Republican, has said he supported the bill as a means of saving $60 million a year. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Stay Two Nights, Get One Free
description: Through Sept. 2, there's a free night's stay and breakfast when guests stay two consecutive weekend nights at participating TownePlace Suites and SpringHill Suites, two Marriott brands. Pets are welcome at the TownePlace Suites. The deal is subject to availability, and there are blackout dates. Taxes and tip are extra. To find out which hotels are participating, call (800) 228-9290 or visit www.marriott.com .

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Steps Up Criticism Of Tires Made by Firestone

title: Volunteer in Asthma Study Dies After Inhaling Drug
description: A healthy volunteer died recently after inhaling a drug in a federally financed asthma study conducted by Johns Hopkins University, officials said yesterday. The volunteer's hospitalization after inhaling the drug led the institution to suspend the research.

title: Wall Street's Conflicted Research
description: Congress held a hearing yesterday on the inherent conflict between the ability of Wall Street firms to make independent analyses of companies that investors can rely on, and their need to attract investment banking clients who may not appreciate candid analysis. Perhaps not so coincidentally, on Tuesday the securities industry's trade group issued a set of voluntary guidelines to address the issue. They represent a healthy acknowledgment that Wall Street faces a serious credibility problem and could help mitigate the worst abuses. But something more than a voluntary pledge may be needed to protect the integrity of the market and the interests of unsuspecting investors.

title: P.& G. to Shed Some Businesses and Take $1.2 Billion Charge
description: Procter & Gamble said today that it would report a second-quarter loss because of the $1.2 billion in after-tax restructuring charges that it is taking as it cuts its work force and sheds under-performing businesses, including its Oil of Olay line of cosmetics.

title: AREMISSOFT CALLS OFF DEAL FOR COMPANY IN CYPRUS
description: AremisSoft, a software company with operations in Eastern Europe, said yesterday that it had ended plans to take control of L. K. Globalsoft.com. AremisSoft planned to increase its stake in Globalsoft, a software company based in Cyprus, from 7.1 percent to 59.5 percent in a four-stage deal worth more than $330 million. Yesterday's announcement came two weeks after AremisSoft said it would pay GlobalSoft $109 million in cash and notes to complete the first stage of the transaction. AremisSoft said it had canceled the deal because the government of Cyprus had asked for information that could have delayed the transaction. The announcement was made after the close of trading.

title: Both Sides Attack Bush Plan To Halt Bombing on Vieques
description: President Bush's compromise plan to halt the Navy's bombing exercises in Puerto Rico came under intense attack today, both from critics who said it did not go far enough and from Congressional allies of the Pentagon who said it undermined military readiness.

title: The Boom Boom Tomb
description: In ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider,'' Angelina Jolie, below, takes a video-game heroine to a bigger screen.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Government Isolates Dissident
description: Human rights advocates in Tashkent said that one of their colleagues, Yelena Urlayev, had been moved to a closed ward in a psychiatric hospital to deny her access to fellow activists and her lawyers. Ms. Urlayev has been undergoing compulsory psychiatric treatment for two months after taking part in public protests against the government. Hospital authorities said she had been moved so her medical condition could be evaluated. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: 1814 Banner Is Grounded
description: The Smithsonian Institution said today that the Star-Spangled Banner, the 188-year-old flag that inspired the words of the national anthem, has become too fragile to hang on display.

title: General Says Missile Shield Needs Money And Prudence
description: The head of the Pentagon's missile defense program warned Congress today that accelerating development of a missile shield, as President Bush has urged, would be a mistake without meticulous planning and a major infusion of money.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Yank Prospect Is Back After Strange Injury
description: There is one Nick Johnson mystery that may never be solved. For now, though, the Yankees will concern themselves only with the more pleasant mystery of how good a hitter Johnson may one day be.

title: Medicare Agency Changes Name In an Effort to Emphasize Service
description: The Bush administration announced today that it had renamed the agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid in the hope of repairing its image as a bureaucratic behemoth.

title: Decision Postponed on TV Ads Paid for by Schundler Group
description: At an emergency hearing, the commission that enforces New Jersey campaign finance laws said today that it needed more time to consider a dispute over television ads featuring Bret D. Schundler that were paid for by a nonprofit educational association he controls.

title: Hey, Guys, Wanna See A Babe Swing a Bungee?
description: Sitting through the lavish and dumb action spectacular ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider'' is about as much fun as watching someone else play a video game. The lavish part comes in the visuals; this movie looks like an 11-year-old American's dream version of Europe.

title: Article 2001061593557096816 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Both Sides Attack Bush Plan to Halt Bombing on Vieques
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  President Bush's compromise plan to halt the Navy's bombing exercises in Puerto Rico came under intense attack today, both from critics who said it did not go far enough and from Congressional allies of the Pentagon who said it undermined military readiness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, EDWARD J.
description: BAILEY-Edward J. On June 13, 2001 at age 68. Loving father of Paul and Mark. Devoted brother of Lois Lehman. Graveside service Friday, June 15, 2:30 PM at B'nai Jacob Memorial Park, New Haven, CT. Memorial service in New York City to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Environmental Defense, 257 Park Ave. S, NY, NY 10010 or Paul & Lisa Inc, PO Box 348, Westbrook, CT. 06498.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADBELL, CHARNA
description: RADBELL-Charna. We mourn the passing of our dear friend who possessed a remarkable passion for life. Possessed with intelligence, beauty and charm, she was an inspiration to us all. Not only will our thoughts be with her when hiking in Aspen, but when faced with life's obstacles we will always find strength and determination through her memory. We express our deepest condolences to her parents, Arlene and Larry, and her sister and brotherin-law, Nicole and Jason Rabin. Allison, Jennifer, and Adrienne Sands

title: Deal Seen Near to Spare Life of F.B.I. Spy Suspect
description: Prosecutors and lawyers for Robert P. Hanssen, the former F.B.I. agent charged with espionage, are close to a deal that would spare Mr. Hanssen from the death penalty in exchange for a sentence of life in prison and his full cooperation, law enforcement officials said today.

title: House G.O.P. Rushes to Get A Rights Bill Before Rivals
description: House Republican leaders rushed today to write a bill defining patients' rights, and said they hoped to push it through the House before the Senate completed work on a rival bill favored by Democrats, who want to set much more stringent standards for health insurance plans.

title: Council Delays Bill on Reporting of Sex Offenses in Schools
description: The City Council's Education Committee delayed action yesterday on a proposed law that would make it a crime for school officials to fail to report a sexual offense or other criminal act to the police, after some private school groups objected to how the law would apply to their schools.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Son Of 'Stuart Little'

title: A Lewis and Clark Romp (Or Stomp) Over History
description: A romp may not have been what Lewis and Clark thought their exploration of the West was, but the Talking Band turns it into one. ''Bitterroot,'' written by Paul Zimet, uses well-worn theatrical tricks to create an innocent-looking musical that, as is usual with this company, is anything but.

title: A Detective's Broken Heart, And Lots of Cheating Ones
description: ''Russian Doll,'' Stavros Kazantzidis's moribund Australian comedy about romantic failure, is crummily conceived and has an odd yellowish tint: it's a piece of white bread slathered with margarine. Harvey (Hugo Weaving), a small-potatoes private investigator, drags his tired carcass around as if he were a sleep-deprived new father. But he has nothing to celebrate: he's morose because he has found out that his girlfriend, Alison (Helen Dallimore), has been cheating on him.

title: Franks Comes Out Swinging in New Jersey Governor Debate
description: From his first breath tonight, Bob Franks laced into Bret D. Schundler with an unrelenting intensity in the second televised debate between the Republican candidates for governor of New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Happy 8th anniversary in heaven, Grandma. You are always in my thoughts. Love, Michael.

title: Court Upholds Conviction In Vote Fraud By Candidate
description: From the start, there was nothing ordinary about the case of John Kennedy O'Hara.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about the spread of HIV infection among intravenous drug users in Eastern Europe carried an erroneous figure for Russia. While statistics vary, the latest United Nations estimates suggest that intravenous drug users account for 50 percent to 80 percent of new infections in Russia, not 11 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, FRANCES ''SUE'' (NEE GILLMORE)
description: WILLIAMS-Frances ''Sue'' (nee Gillmore). On June 13, 2001. Of Dunwoody Village. Beloved wife of the late Richard Norris Williams, II. Survived by three sons Duane N. of Ft. Myers, FL, Richard N., III of St. Davids, PA, Quincy N. of Haverford, PA & a daughter Frances Sue Ganoe of Princeton, NJ. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and eleven greatgrandchildren. Memorial service 11AM, June 18th at the Chapel at St. David's Church, 763 Valley Forge Road, Wayne, PA. Memorial donations may be made to the Southeastern Pensylvania Chapter of the American Red Cross, 2221 Chestnut St, Philadelphia, PA 19103

title: Modernism on the Cte d'Azur, Dream Space for the 20th Century
description: Ah, the French Riviera! Supersaturated with light, scenery and glamour; a freewheeling playground for the rich, the chic and the talented, a dream destination for tourists, it was the ultimate resort of the first half of the 20th century.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Assault On Subway
description: A 40-year-old man was punched in the face and robbed of a Walkman yesterday by two teenagers who shouted antigay epithets at him on the No. 4 train in the Bronx, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released because the case was classified as a possible bias incident, was not seriously injured, the police said. His attackers were a 14-year-old girl, who was arrested and charged with assault and robbery, and an 18-year-old man, who fled. The police withheld the girl's name because she is a minor. The attack happened about 2 p.m. at the Burnside Avenue station.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGERSON, RICHARD
description: SIGERSON-Richard. Died peacefully at home on June 12, 2001, aged 84. Adoring husband of Yola Miller Sigerson, father of Andra Patterson, Adam, Gabriel and Davitt Sigerson and grandfather of Julia, Andrew, Lio, Jennifer and Milena. Science writer, editor and publisher; founder of the Medical and Pharmaceutical Information Bureau; founding editor of The Sciences, for the New York Academy of Sciences; editor and publisher of Medical Opinion and Review, Geriatric Focus, Hospital Focus, Issues and Science Fortnightly. The fiercest intelligence, the strongest spirit, the most loving heart-he took such intense pleasure in living. Friends and family will meet on Friday afternoon. For information please call Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 212-289-2221.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Governor Recommends Canadian Drugs
description: After a court struck down a state plan to help older residents afford medications, Gov. Howard Dean offered a short-term solution: Go north. Many Vermonters already take buses to Canada to buy drugs or order them from Canadian pharmacies through their doctors. The state had been extending its Medicaid drug discount to some older residents and families who were not eligible for low-income health plans, but a federal appeals court, acting on a lawsuit filed on behalf of drug companies, blocked the plan last week. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Ken Lum
description: Andrea Rosen

title: Free Speech Advocates Laud Decision on Student Site
description: First Amendment victories come in many forms. Sometimes they're easy to spot -- like when a judge's strikes down a law because it violates the freedom of expression. Less obvious, but perhaps just as important, are little acts of prosecutors -- such as the decision earlier this week by the district attorney of Westchester County, N.Y., Jeanine F. Pirro, to forego prosecuting two high school students who were arrested for their involvement in the creation of a Web site that contained names, telephone numbers and alleged sexual exploits of dozens of their female classmates.

title: Article 2001061593003692408 -- No Title
Chicago Uses Preschool to Lure Middle Class
description: CHICAGO  As a preschool teacher, Ivette Bustos has clear goals for her charges: to learn to write their names, count to 10, tie their shoes and skip.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANLEY, KATHERINE
description: HANLEY-Katherine. June 15, 1994. The memory of our lovely mother will live on in our hearts forever. The Children

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Budget Stalemate Broken
description: A long stalemate over the state budget was broken when House Republicans said they would allow a vote on the $23 billion plan approved by the Democratic-controlled Senate last week. Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, had suggested that a partial government shutdown loomed if the two-year plan was not in place by June 30. Republicans called the budget excessive, but said they wanted to avoid a shutdown. ''We wanted a bipartisan agreement,'' said Clyde Ballard, a Republican who is co-speaker of the evenly divided House. ''But realizing the governor is a Democrat, the Senate's Democrat and we're 50-50 in the House, that means we're one-half of one-third of the process.'' Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Irwin Shines Bright On a Stormy Day
description: The first round of the United States Open was suspended by rain and lightning, but the most turbulent developments occurred on the golf course.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about obstacles to Senate confirmation of John D. Negroponte as ambassador to the United Nations misspelled the name of a former secretary of state who supports it. He is George P. Shultz, not Schulz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARTIN C.
description: MURPHY-Martin C. Age 31. Of NYC. Died unexpectedly on Monday, June 11, 2001. He was employed by Watson-Guptill Co., NYC

description: One thing is for sure: There will be more tests. Lots more.

title: City Tells Its Firefighters Not to Food-Shop on Duty
description: When tenants in Union City, N.J., ran across the street last month to the neighborhood firehouse because their row houses were going up in flames, no one answered the door. The three firefighters on duty were at a nearby supermarket, shopping for groceries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, BAYARD DOMINICK
description: STOUT-Bayard Dominick. On June 14, 2001 at home in Rumson, NJ. Husband of Ruth nee Maney Stout (married 55 years). Father of Ethel Stout Chapin, William Lee Stout, Hope Stout Connors and Mary Stout Lawrence, uncle of Richard John Maney, grandfather of fourteen, great grandfather of seven. Memorial services to be held on Monday 10:30 AM at St. Georges by the River Episcopal Church, Waterman Avenue, Rumson. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA. 01275; St. Georges Church, Waterman Avenue, Rumson, New Jersey 07760; or the Riverview Medical Center Foundation, One Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701, would be preferred.

title: Sports of The Times; Sorry, No Red Numbers For Woods
description: UP above, a cooling wind churned charcoal gray clouds across a sullen sky. The ''weather warning'' had emptied the metal grandstands at Southern Hills, and with thunder rumbling in the distance, a horn honked a suspension of play in the 101st United States Open as Tiger Woods, a surprising three over par in yesterday's first round, was about to study an 8-footer for par on the 10th green.

title: Showdown On Wall Street; Banks Are Getting Business At the Expense of Elite Firms
description: When Kraft Foods sold shares to investors this week in the second-largest United States initial public offering, it did so without any help from Merrill Lynch & Company, the firm that employs the most stockbrokers. Merrill also did not play a leading role when Lucent Technologies sold $3.6 billion of stock in a spinoff of its Agere Systems unit in March.

title: G.O.P. Reports an 'Impasse' Over Senate Reorganization
description: Senior Senate Republicans said today that they had hit an impasse in talks with the new Democratic majority leader over organizing the Senate because of disputes about how to handle judicial nominees. They called for the issues in contention to be brought to the full Senate floor for a vote.

title: Macedonia Seeks NATO Troops to Help Disarm Albanian Rebels
description: Macedonia formally asked NATO today to send troops to help it disarm ethnic Albanian rebels, if terms are reached to end the ethnic Albanian insurgency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, KERMIT, M.D.
description: PINES-Kermit, M.D. The Board and Staff of The Riverdale Mental Health Association express their deep sorrow on the death of Dr. Kermit Pines, beloved father of our President, Deborah Pines. We extend our most sincere sympathy to the Pines family. Marie-Jeanne Gwertzman, President Elect Joyce M. Pilsner, Exec Director

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The dollar fell after the National Association of Manufacturers said it would press the Bush administration to relax its support of a strong dollar. In New York, the euro settled at 86.24 cents, up from 85.36 cents.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Suspect Arrested In Homicide
description: An antidrug crusader who was found shot dead and surrounded by cocaine vials appears to have been killed by a jealous spouse rather than vengeful drug dealers, the authorities said yesterday. Milton Bland, 44, of Jersey City, the estranged husband of a woman dating the victim, was charged with murder after he was seen leaving the victim's apartment, prosecutors said. The victim, Wesley J. Hall, 39, was a block association president active against the local drug trade. Mr. Bland's lawyer said his client was not guilty.

Putin, the Russian president, here this afternoon and extended an offer of closer friendship, along with a request: that Russians look beyond a landmark 1972 treaty and bless Mr. Bush's plans for a missile defense shield.

title: Kafka's Pen? A Branding Iron
description: Franz Kafka is taking notes. In the intricately mannered production of ''In the Penal Colony,'' Philip Glass's somber and stately new opera, the famously cryptic writer can be found scribbling away with dour concentration on most available surfaces: bedsheets, the floor, the backs of chairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, ROSE
description: CHARNEY-Rose. Died June 13, 2001. Beloved mother of Barbara Schreier and Jordan Charney. Adored grandmother of Randy, Larry, Gayle, Allison and Daniel. Cherished great-grandmother of Jason, Adam and Jake. A long time performing member of the Kadimah group of Haddassah. Graveside services will be held at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Queens Sunday, June 17 at 10:30AM.

title: Kazakhs Given Tax Amnesty In Move to Bring Money Home
description: Almost as long as there have been taxes, there have been tax dodges, often based on stashing money beyond the tax collector's jurisdiction. Developing countries tend to have an especially hard time keeping capital from fleeing, or attracting it back once it has flown.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Clamor Continues Over Regents
description: Controversy continued over the state Regents examinations yesterday. At 17 alternative schools in the city, copies of the English test arrived on the day of the test, rather than the day before, as is the usual practice. The later delivery was prompted by concerns about potential tampering after last month's demonstrations against stricter graduation standards. In 2003, students will have to pass five Regents exams. About 140 students rallied outside the Beacon School in Manhattan. Lynette Holloway (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Harvard Trio

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Suspect Must Provide Samples
description: A state judge ruled that one of two teenagers charged with killing two Dartmouth professors must provide samples of his hair, blood and handwriting to prosecutors. Prosecutors want to compare the blood and hair of the teenager, Robert Tulloch, 18, to evidence found at the crime scene and his handwriting to that in a notebook found in his bedroom that described surveillance. The state is seeking to try the second youth, James Parker, who was 16 at the time of the Jan. 27 killings, as an adult. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Mexico City Journal; Pummeling the Powerful, With Comedy as Cudgel
description: When Jesusa Rodrguez is on onstage, on camera, in the streets protesting the latest outrage -- she may be the most powerful woman in Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROFFMAN, MORT
description: BROFFMAN-Mort. Academic and Business Leader. Morton H. Broffman, respected academic and business executive, died on June 10, 2001 in Tuscany, Italy at the age of 80. Mr. Broffman had a distinguished career in academia, and later went on to a very successful career in business. He developed one of the first successful national franchise models for retail business. Mr. Broffman grew up in New York, and received his Bachelor's Degree from CCNY. He earned Master Degrees from NYU and Harvard University, and a PhD in Economics from Harvard. He served on the faculty at numerous universities, and was a Teaching Fellow and Assistant to the Dean at Harvard. Mr. Broffman later went into business, and was recognized as an expert in the development of strategic business plans. He served as CEO or COO for a number of prominent companies, including United Brands, American Biltrite, and John Morrell Co. As a senior executive with Rayco Manufacturing in the early '60's, he developed one of the first successful models for national franchising of retail operations. Mr. Broffman also was a board member of numerous organizations, including Save the Children, Native American Public Telecommunications, and Building Materials Distrubutors, Inc. At various times, Mr. Broffman lived in New York City, Chicago, San Francisco, and Delaware. However, he and his wife had a special love for Italy, where they had a home. He is survived by his wife Jeanine Bianco, a brother and two sisters, his children Michael and Jane, and numerous grandchildren, nieces and nephews.

title: Orioles and Injuries Put an End to the Mets' Streak
description: Even before the Mets played tonight, they learned they would be without Edgardo Alfonzo and Timo Perez, hurting their chance to extend their winning streak. Facing adversity is nothing new for the Mets this season, and when they rallied tonight against the Orioles, they gave themselves hope of entering the weekend series against the Yankees with a first for this season: a four-game winning streak.

title: U.S. Vows More Scrutiny of Health Ads on Net
description: Banding together to broaden their reach, the Federal Trade Commission and the Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that they were stepping up enforcement actions against companies marketing fraudulent health products over the Internet.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: KRAMER - Rebecca. Loving mother of Miriam and Bertram. Cherished grandmother of Martin, Janet, Glen, Larry and Jennifer. Great grandmother of Jesse and Emma. Service today 12 PM at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Producer Prices Rise Modestly; Sales by Businesses Decline
description: Prices paid to producers rose less than expected in May, restrained by lower costs for food, autos and computers, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 'The Anniversary Party': So Kissy-Kissy, and Then So Sharky
description: An articulate, acutely observant film like "The Anniversary Party" makes you realize how starved Hollywood movies are for great ensemble acting. An anthropologically detailed study of a contemporary Hollywood party that runs mildly amok, the movie has such finely woven performances that the best scenes project a convincing illusion of spontaneity.

title: One Love, One Heart, Or a Sweatshop Economy?
description: The term ''globalization'' is so tinged with rosy one-world optimism that it's easy to assume the essential benignity of an economic philosophy whose name vaguely connotes unity, equality and freedom. But as Stephanie Black's powerful documentary ''Life and Debt'' illustrates with an impressive (and depressing) acuity, globalization can have a devastating impact on third world countries. The movie offers the clearest analysis of globalization and its negative effects that I've ever seen on a movie or television screen.

title: 'Truth,' or One Version of It
description: This 30-second commercial, ''Truth,'' is the latest by former Representative Bob Franks in his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey against Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City. It began broadcasting yesterday.

title: Progress in the Long, Strange Trip Toward a Monument to Woodstock
description: Peggy Beischer showed up here prepared to fight a proposal for a performing arts center that would commemorate the famous music festival where 400,000 lucky revelers wallowed in the mud and gyrated to the music of Jimi Hendrix, Jefferson Airplane and the Who 32 years ago.

description: FORTUNA-Alice Caulfield, 81 died June 8 in her home in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. She leaves her daughter Elizabeth B. Foerster of Escondido, CA. Stepdaughter Susan J. Fortuna of Orange Park, FL, her sister Marie Martinez of Forest Hills, NY, as well as six loving grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Feel-Good Ode to Ol'-Time Music
description: A number of songs performed in ''Down From the Mountain,'' a documentary by D. A. Pennebaker, Chris Hegedus and Nick Doob, are about the promise of life after death. If you have any affection at all for traditional American music, the movie itself, which opens today at the Screening Room, is pretty close to heaven.

title: Loews Gets More Time to Develop Buyout Plan
description: The Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation, the movie-theater chain, persuaded a bankruptcy judge yesterday to allow more time to develop an $850 million buyout plan that unsecured creditors oppose.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Real Estate Payout
description: The British real estate concern, the Canary Wharf Group, said it would return capital to shareholders earlier than expected, because its development of a financial center along the Thames is ahead of schedule. The company said it would begin using 450 million ($626 million) of its cash reserve to buy back shares. The stock price hit a peak in October, but has since declined over concerns that an economic slowdown could hinder development plans. Canary Wharf also said it would seek approval at its shareholder meeting in November to carry out a restructuring plan that would free excess capital. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: He's an Impostor, and That's the Least of It
description: ''Dirty Cop No Donut,'' Tim Ritter's cinma vrit spoof of reality cop shows, pretends to be an incendiary ''found'' documentary exposing the crimes committed by a sadistic cocaine-fueled bully impersonating a police officer.

description: Randy Keisler returned to the major leagues last night with a reformed perspective and a reshaped pitching repertory. What he lacked was a belt. The midnight blue leather left in his locker did not quite fit, so Keisler asked his teammate Ted Lilly if he could try his -- and Lilly's did not work, either.

We are profoundly grateful for the friendship, leadership and direction she gave to us and to our organization, and to the larger communities of Clinton and Chelsea. She will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy to her family and her other friends and colleagues. Board of Directors and Members Women's Interart Center, Inc.

title: Harper Collects Rings And Dispenses Wisdom
description: He was flicking through channels the other night, looking to break the monotony of another playoff grind. Ron Harper suddenly put down the remote, paused and watched the images unfold in his hotel room.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sales Growth Slows
description: The luxury department store operator Harvey Nichols Group, known for its flagship outlet in London's Knightsbridge district, said falling tourist numbers and transportation disruptions were hurting sales. Sales at stores open at least 12 months rose 2.5 percent in the first 10 weeks of the financial year, down from a rate of 3.1 percent a year earlier. The company blamed foot-and-mouth disease, as well as transportation strikes.

title: 2 Plead Guilty In Funneling Of Kickbacks In Bridgeport
description: Two close associates of Mayor Joseph P. Ganim have pleaded guilty to federal charges that they paid bribes worth hundreds of thousands of dollars to an elected official in Bridgeport since 1995, though federal prosecutors today did not describe that official by name.

title: Still Waiting for Happy Recap
description: Bob Murphy was at home after calling the Marlins-Mets game on WFAN with Gary Cohen on the afternoon of May 27 when the symptoms of pneumonia ''overcame me, with just no warning at all,'' he said yesterday. During the first two and a half days of his hospitalization, Murphy, the Mets radio announcer, was heavily sedated.

title: A Stagger Has Replaced 76ers' Swagger
description: The confidence that inspired Allen Iverson to clap his hands and strut out of the Staples Center last week is long gone. The swagger that led him to tell Kobe Bryant, ''Wait till we get to Philly,'' has vanished.

title: Saying 'it's a lot worse than I thought,' a top forecaster lowers his expectations a second time.
description: ROBERT J. COEN, considered the leading forecaster of advertising spending, has confirmed widespread worries that 2001 is likely to bring the slowest growth in a decade to that closely watched economic indicator by revising his estimate for the year sharply downward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, MARY PENFIELD
description: HOPKINS-Mary Penfield, age 86. Formerly of NY, on June 13, 2001 at Fairfax Hospital, Falls Church, Virginia. She was the daughter of the late Walter Lane Hopkins and Anna Lamb Hopkins. She is survived by her niece Nancy Hopkins. Interment private.

title: Foreign Affairs; They Hate Us! They Need Us!
description: Reading about all the anti-Americanism President Bush has encountered on his trip to Europe, I was reminded of the 1970's Randy Newman song ''Political Science.'' Its main verse was: ''No one likes us -- I don't know why. / We may not be perfect, but heaven knows we try. / But all around, even our old friends put us down. / Let's drop the big one and see what happens . . . Asia's crowded and Europe's too old. / Africa is far too hot / and Canada's too cold. / And South America stole our name. / Let's drop the big one. There'll be no one left to blame us.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Lift For Kremlin's Man
description: The Kremlin's candidate for governor of far-eastern Primoriye Province, who finished a distant third in first-round elections last month, won a new second chance when a regional court threw the second-place finisher off the ballot. The ruling will pit President Vladimir V. Putin's envoy to Primoriye, Gennadi Apanasenko, against the front-runner, a popular businessman named Sergei Darkin, in the final vote this month. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: $46 Million Lottery Ticket Was in the Mail. Honest.
description: For all those who have suffered from the check-is-in-the-mail syndrome, here is sweet revenge.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Group Seeks Surcharge
description: A cabdrivers organization, worried about the rising cost of gasoline, wants to add a 50-cent fuel surcharge to fares. The group, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, said that instead of netting an average $75 per 12-hour day, drivers were going home with $60. ''If airlines and landlords are able to raise prices because of increased costs, why not working-class taxi drivers?'' said Bhairavi Desai, their spokeswoman. But the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said it would need detailed data before it would consider the request. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNIVERSAL COMPRESSION HOLDINGS , Houston, has agreed to acquire the closely held Louisiana Compressor Maintenance Co., Houma, La., for $25 million.

title: Vieques Convictions Upheld
description: Within hours of the Bush administration's announcement that it would halt bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques in two years, a federal appeals court in Boston yesterday upheld the convictions of the Rev. Al Sharpton and three other New York City politicians who were arrested there last month for trespassing on a federal military installation.

title: Ford Has Harsher Words For Latest Recalled Tires
description: Stepping up its feud with Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., the Ford Motor Company said today that some of the tires it began replacing last month failed even more often than those recalled last autumn.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For the last seven years, Diane Forley has run Verbena as a one-woman show. Her highly personal interpretation of Mediterranean cuisine, with its heavy reliance on Middle Eastern spices, has won her a loyal following.

title: Vallone Seeks Halt on Plan For Building Inspections
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone called on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday to halt plans to transfer inspection and enforcement functions from the Department of Buildings to the Fire Department, even as 40 Buildings Department employees prepared to move into fire headquarters next week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker Cuts Jobs
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company, said it would cut 1,455 jobs, mainly in Britain and Ireland, and sell a factory employing 720 more in Scotland as it seeks to save money. Martin Sutton, a company spokesman in London, said the cuts represented the most substantive element of a cost-saving review that began after the $68 billion merger last December of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. Facing the same pressures as other drug giants to lower manufacturing costs and share research budgets, GlaxoSmithKline said it was looking to cut $2.2 billion in costs by 2003. Mr. Sutton said further job cuts were likely among the company's 100,000-member work force, affecting plants outside Europe and the United States.

title: Famous Slackers of Senior Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | People: Job Market Remains Tight
description: An estimated 600,000 jobs for information technology workers in the United States are unfilled, and nearly 25 percent of technology managers say that retaining employees is their biggest problem, according to the META Group, a technology research firm based in Stamford, Conn. The labor market was even tighter a year ago, though, before the economy slowed. META calculated then that a million technology jobs were unfilled and 40 percent of the managers rated hanging onto workers as their dominant concern. The projections are based on an annual survey of 500 large American companies. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BON, FANNIE
description: BON-Fannie. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Loving mother of Susan and Herbert, Nona and the late Ira. Cherished grandmother of David and Jennifer, Margot and Tom, Elizabeth, Lisa, Wilson and the late Sera. Service on Sunday 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

title: $52 Million for Lawyers' Fees In Nazi-Era Slave Labor Suits
description: Lawyers who represent Nazi-era slave laborers split more than $52 million in legal fees yesterday for work on a case that will bring Holocaust victims $5,000 to $7,500 each.

title: Famous Slackers of Senior Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; Sisyphus in D.C.
description: Remember back when governors were trendy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHAN
description: WEISS-Stephan. Born September 16, 1938. Died on June 10th, 2001. Beloved husband of Donna Karan, father of Corey Weiss, Lisa WeissKeyes and Gabrielle Karan and grandfather of Mackenzie, Miles, Mercer, Etan and Maya Rose. An exceptional creator and co-founder of Donna Karan International, his wit, charm, intelligence and forward thinking impressed all who knew him. He will live on through the many whose lives he touched with his goodness and humanity. Funeral services will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to The Karan-Weiss Foundation, dedicated to benefiting medical research, education and the arts, C/O Urban Zen, LLC, 570 7th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10018.

title: A Tender Lady Explores Mountains and Their Music
description: Infused with the twang of Appalachian mountain music and aglow with picture-postcard images of North Carolina's rugged inland landscape, Maggie Greenwald's ''Songcatcher'' is a sweet, lyrical ode to rural America in the early 1900's. The film, which stars Janet McTeer as a fearless musicologist who ventures into the wild to unearth a trove of Americana, also has a staunch political agenda built into its story. Those politics, unfortunately, stiffen the movie, too often lending it the feel of a high-minded essay.

title: SCHLUMBERGER ACQUISITION EARNING LESS THAN EXPECTED
description: Schlumberger, which acquired the British computer services company Sema in April, said yesterday that revenue from the new business had been lower than expected because of a slowdown in the telecommunications industry. The Sema businesses are expected to break even in the first six months under Schlumberger, the company said. Schlumberger, a large provider of oil field services, acquired Sema, which helps businesses set up computer systems, on April 6 for about $5 billion. Analysts have been skeptical about Schlumberger's push into areas unrelated to oil field technology. Schlumberger has headquarters in New York and Paris.

title: States Taking Steps to Rein In Excesses of Judicial Politicking
description: In more than a dozen states in recent months, legislators, governors, courts or citizens' groups have begun efforts to limit the role of campaign politics in the selection of state judges.

title: Misrepresenting the ABM Treaty
description: Arguments over the merits of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty between Washington and Moscow have been a feature of President Bush's European trip this week and could affect the atmosphere of his meetings tomorrow with Russia's president, Vladimir Putin. The Bush administration would have Americans believe that the treaty is a discredited cold-war relic that bars the way to a new era free from fear of nuclear missile attack. That is bad history and bad policy.

title: Antonio Murado -- 'Icescapes'
description: Lucas Schoormans

title: Sharpton's Debt in Brawley Defamation Is Paid by Supporters
description: More than two years after the Rev. Al Sharpton was found to have defamed a former prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case, the $65,000 damage award entered against Mr. Sharpton by a Dutchess County jury has been paid in full.

title: Bush Presses to Expand NATO Eastward
description: WARSAW, June 15 -- President Bush called today for an Atlantic Alliance that stretches all the way to Russia's borders, delving more emphatically and aggressively than any of his predecessors into a matter guaranteed to make Moscow nervous.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Apartment Homicide Suspects
description: Three 20-year-old men accused of killing and dismembering two tenants so they could take their Inwood apartments were arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court and charged with murder, robbery and burglary. In written statements to the police, the suspects detailed how they drained the bodies of blood and, as the bodies stiffened, cut off the hands and heads with a saw. The suspects, Bernard Perez and Rahman Williams of Inwood and Jason Walker of Brooklyn, all pleaded not guilty.

title: Places for a Parade
description: To the Editor:

title: The Extra Mideast Mile
description: To the Editor:

title: Nepal Gives 'Synopsis' of Massacre by Drug-Addled Prince
description: Before he massacred the king, the queen and most of the rest of Nepal's royal family, Crown Prince Dipendra was not only tipsy from whiskey but also high on ''a special kind of cigarette prepared with a mixture of hashish and another unnamed black substance.''

title: In the Putin Talks, Bring Up Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | People: AOL Names Global Policy Chief
description: AOL Time Warner named Robert M. Kimmitt executive vice president for global and strategic policy, effective on July 1. The company said Mr. Kimmitt, who was president of Commerce One Inc., would become a member of AOL's executive committee. He replaces George Vradenburg, who will now serve as an adviser to the company.

title: Ach, Such Industrious Romantics
description: PAINTING of the Romantic age and of the contemporary moment have much in common. Both are infatuated with aberrant beauty and uninnocent visions of childhood. Both get by on a flair for style but are also shy and self-conscious, as if they had a secret life.

title: Article 2001061592799731487 -- No Title
description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: A Car Design At Age 19 Set a Career
description: One of the liveliest sessions at the recent 51st International Design Conference in Aspen, Colo., was an automobile design seminar on Saturday titled ''Car Talk.'' American designers from Detroit's major car companies listened to a German engineer discuss Mercedes's best-selling European mini, the Smart Car, while an America engineer based in Munich touted the improvements in a new BMW. Many people in the room knew one another, but few recognized the 90-year-old man at the table until he identified himself.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Conflict Rules Proposed
description: The state's Executive Commission on Ethical Standards proposed new conflict-of-interest rules yesterday, prompted, in part, by controversy over a cranberry grower whose case was overseen by a former business associate. The rules, which could go into effect in January, detail circumstances in which officials must disqualify themselves from cases. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Financial Consolidation
description: A bidding war for Singapore's smallest financial institution, Keppel Capital Holdings, appeared to be under way after Keppel and United Overseas Bank said they were in talks about a possible merger. On Wednesday, Singapore's Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation announced an unsolicited bid of 4.8 billion Singapore dollars ($2.65 billion) for Keppel. Singapore's government has been urging its five banks to consolidate, suggesting that foreign competition would leave room for only two major domestic banks in Singapore. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Jeff Weiss -- 'The Big Boys Are Coming'
description: Laurence Miller

title: Residential Real Estate; In Old Flower District, A New Luxury Building
description: Housing continues to sprout in Manhattan's former flower district. Now nearing completion is a 39-story rental building that is the tallest and among the largest in the area, which stretches along the Avenue of the Americas in the 20's.

title: Brad Kahlhamer -- 'Almost American'
description: Deitch Projects

title: Serenading That Inner Child With Smiles Instead of Tears
description: Pop psychology has drilled it into us that each person has a quivering, vulnerable inner child who needs tender love and protection.
