But I prefer the singer Rob Evan's jauntier, less lachrymose version of the same concept. He calls his cabaret act, which plays at Arci's Place through June 23, ''The Kid Inside.'' The title comes from a great but little-known theater song composed by Craig Carnelia for the 1982 Broadway flop ''Is There Life After High School?'' It is the high point of his show.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICASMEXICO: WASTE SETTLEMENT The Metalclad Corporation , a California-based waste management company, said the Mexican government had agreed to pay $15.6 million as compensation for lost profits in an out-of-court settlement after a Canadian court ruled in favor of the company. Last month, the Supreme Court of British Columbia upheld a ruling by a North American Free Trade Agreement panel that Mexico violated a law protecting foreign investors by blocking Metalclad from constructing a waste dump in northern Mexico. The case was heard in Canada as a neutral venue under Nafta rules.

title: Trading Firm And Its Chief Agree to Fines
description: The day-trading firm All-Tech Direct and its chief executive, Harvey I. Houtkin, have agreed to pay $525,000 to settle charges of improper margin lending and misleading advertising, regulators said.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; No Rose-Colored Glasses In Lands Ravaged by War
description: If you're searching for rich, complicated reality in movies instead of the usual escapist fluff, you need look no further than the Human Rights Watch Film Festival. The most morally engaged, socially far-reaching annual film series to play New York, the festival, which opened its 12th season last night with a benefit screening of ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' offers a different kind of global tour, conducted without the usual rose-colored glasses and tourist distractions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, MIRIAM (MIMI)
description: BLOOM-Miriam (Mimi) 76 years old. Died on June 13, 2001. Beloved wife of Hal for 56 years. Devoted mother of William and Karen, Michael & Beth and Jon & Monique. Cherished grandmother of Jacey, Barry, Melanie, Jennifer, Nicole, Samantha, Colette and Tyler. Dearest sister of Naomi and Sholom Staiman. The best ever. Services Friday, 11:30AM at ''RiversideNassau North Chappels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, New York.

title: Herbert Woods, Consort of a Soul Food Queen, Dies at 76
description: Herbert Woods, who stayed modestly in the shadows as his wife, Sylvia, played center stage as Harlem's ''Queen of Soul Food'' at their famous restaurant, died on Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Mount Pleasant, N.Y.

title: Defense Chief to Propose Change in Course for Military
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld is planning to scrap the Clinton administration's guiding strategy for the military and replace it with four principles that range from assuring allies to defeating enemies, a senior defense official said today.

title: New York City Still Adds Jobs, but Shows Signs of Slowdown
description: The national economic slowdown that crept through New Jersey and upstate New York this spring has finally reached New York City's job market, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor.

title: Laura de Santillana
description: Barry Friedman

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'Shape of Things' To Come

title: Blustery Conditions Present New Demands
description: Phil Mickelson was one of the fortunate players who completed his round, and at even-par 70, he was in excellent position heading into the second round of the United States Open.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Focus On Officers' Use Of Force
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft announced a new effort by the Department of Justice and Washington police to improve law enforcement and prevent the use of excessive force by officers. In 1999, at the request of Mayor Anthony A. Williams and Chief Charles Ramsey, the Justice Department's civil rights division reviewed the city's policing practices and determined that officers used excessive force in a number of cases.

title: Do-Ho Suh
description: Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARY S.
description: O'CONNOR-Mary S. Age 88, passed away on June 10, 2001 at Meadow Lake in Hightstown, NJ. Mrs. O'Connor was born in New Britain, CT and resided in Elizabeth, NJ for many years before moving to Meadow Lakes in June of 1996. Mrs. O'Connor is an alumnus of the Oxford School in West Hartford, CT and graduated from Smith College in 1935 before embarking upon a dynamic and illustrious career in business and a life of service to many community organizations. Mrs. O'Connor had a extensive career with IBM Corporation, one which began in 1935 when she was among the first 25 women employed for Sytems Service work and was assigned to the Newark office where she assisted salesmen in serving customers. Mrs. O'Connor later served as Personnel Manager at IBM World Headquarters in NYC and Systems Service Manager for the United States. In 1943 she was promoted to the corporate level as the first woman Assistant Vice President of the Company. Mrs. O'Connor visited almost every corporate office in the United States and Canada in this position while she worked with IBM's sales, service and engineering personnel and the corporation's customers. Furthermore, Mrs. O'Connor was appointed Director of the United Jersey Bank-Central of Elizabeth, NJ, becoming one of the three, first, women bank directors in New Jersey, before serving as the Director of Fundamental Investors, Inc. and Anchor Growth Fund of Los Angeles, CA. She also served as Trustee and Secretary of the Nathan R. Leavitt Foundation, and she was a member of the Board of Directors of Washington National Life Insurance Company of New York. Moreover, Mrs. O'Connor had the distinction and honor of being appointed by New Jersey's Governor Hughes to the Commission on the Status of Women. Tireless in her efforts and assuming active, leadership roles within Union County community agencies, Mrs. O'Connor was a member of the Mental Health Association, the United Way and the Junior League. She most recently held the position of Director of the Board of Directors of the Eastern Union County Chamber of Commerce, representing the Women's Division. During her ten years of service to the Elizabeth Public Library, she served as President and Secretary. She was also Incorporator and Trustee of the United Fund of Eastern Union County. In addition to her community work, Mrs. O'Connor formerly served the Alumnae Association at Smith College where she served as Treasurer and Finance Chair between 1966 and 1972. Mrs. O'Connor's husband Martin B. O'Connor, who was a prominent New Jersey attorney, predeceased her in 1959. Mrs. O'Connor is survived by several nieces and nephews: Elizabeth A. Schultz of Lawrence, KS; Howard S. Schultz and his wife Tamra of Swartz Creek, MI; Martha P. Howland and her husband William C. of Riverside, CT; Richard R. O'Connor, Jr. and his wife Sena of Westfield, NJ and Martin B. O'Connor II and his wife Jane of Harding Township, NJ. Also surviving Mrs. O'Connor are many grandnieces and grandnephews, including Martha Crawford of Grand Blanc, MI; Lucy Hightree and her husband Norman L. of Chicago, IL; Katherine S. and Lauren B. O'Connor of Harding Township, NJ; and Richard R., Robert I., Ryan W. and Reed M. O'Connor of Westfield, NJ. In addition, there are two great grandnieces and one great grandnephew, Hillary, Mallary and Timmy Crawford of Grand Blanc, MI. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, June 22, 2001, at 11:00 AM, at Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ. Contributions may be made in Mrs. O'Connors's memory to Smith College, Museum of Art, 33 Elm Street, Northampton, MA. 01063.

title: In Tulsa, Rain Is Over but Confusion Is Not
description: TULSA, Okla., June 15 - Nothing creates more confusion in the United States Open golf tournament than a thunderstorm that forces a carryover of the first round into the start of the second round and beyond.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Back To School After Quake
description: More than 400,000 children whose schools were destroyed in the earthquake in the western state of Gujarat in January are returning to the classroom for the first time. A $7 million contribution from Unicef helped rebuild 2,000 schools and fill them with blackboards, pencils and crayons. Experts hope the educational routine will help traumatized children return to normal. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Gas Price
description: The Thai subsidiary of Unocal agreed to review its terms for natural gas sales to Thailand. Unocal is Thailand's largest gas supplier, with its concessions in the Gulf of Thailand accounting for about 30 percent of the country's total power demand and $500 million in revenue for the company last year. Because the price Thailand pays Unocal for the gas was established before the depreciation of the baht in 1997, the cost to Thailand has risen sharply. Now, electricity prices are soaring and Thai officials have been pushing to renegotiate contracts with gas suppliers. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Storage Technology Reports Canceled Orders
description: The shares of Silicon Storage Technology slid $1.45, or 13.6 percent, to $9.22, after the company, a maker of memory chips for computers and consumer products, said order cancellations would hurt second-quarter profit and sales. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., cut its sales forecast to $60 million to $68 million, against $103.2 million a year earlier. Profit will be zero to 3 cents a share, Silicon Storage said, adding that it would ''drastically reduce'' production of the silicon wafers used to make chips. The company had been expected to earn 6 cents a share in the quarter. It earned 24 cents a year earlier, adjusted for a split.

title: XEROX TO CUT 1,500 JOBS AND SOME PRODUCTS
description: Xerox plans to stop making personal copiers and desktop inkjet printers and to eliminate 1,500 jobs as part of its plan to cut $1 billion in costs by the end of the year. Xerox will discontinue the products within six months, its president, Anne M. Mulcahy, said. The machines are intended for use in small offices and homes. The decision will add 10 cents a share to earnings in the second half, Ms. Mulcahy said. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., had a pretax loss of $82 million last quarter, and the company expects a similar loss this quarter.

title: Goldman Adds Unit Aimed At Individuals
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it would buy Epoch Partners, an online investment bank created by three Internet brokerage concerns, gaining access to a broader range of individual investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EDWIN
description: SHAPIRO-Edwin. The American Camping Association-New York Section (ACA-NY) is deeply saddened by the loss of Edwin Shapiro, former owner of Camp Sequoia and a leader in the camping profession for many decades. We appreciate his enormous contribution to the camp experience and we extend our deepest sympathy to his family. The Board of Directors ACA-NY

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Julianne Moore; Discovering The Devil Is In the Details
description: THE camera sweeps with a creeping, predatory slowness over the towers of the East Side of Manhattan, sliding up Fifth Avenue along Central Park's billowy treetops and then turning, moving across the Great Lawn and the reservoir, up along the side of the San Remo apartments on Central Park West, then pausing again, dipping and now gliding like a hawk over the pinnacles and protrusions of the Dakota. All the while, the credits of ''Rosemary's Baby'' appear on the screen in the pretty script you might see on a greeting card or a baby-shower invitation. And the music is a woman's voice intoning a lullaby that is at once beautiful and sad, like something a young mother might sing over a baby's grave.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Slowdown Seen
description: The European Central Bank lowered its forecast for economic growth in the 12 member nations using the euro this year, and raised its estimate for inflation. The 12 countries may grow as little as 2.2 percent in 2001, while consumer prices rise at least 2.3 percent, the bank said in its monthly report for June. Faster inflation will make it difficult for the bank to lower interest rates to stimulate economic growth, the bank's chief economist, Itmar Ossing, said.

title: California, Rising, Passes France By
description: Forget those occasional contests in which a California cabernet beats out a French Bordeaux. Here is a real blow to the chauvinism of the nation that invented the word: La Belle France has been bumped from fifth place among the world's economies by the Republic of California.

title: Paul R. Carey, 38, Adviser To Clinton About Congress
description: Paul R. Carey, a top aide to President Bill Clinton and later a Securities and Exchange commissioner who campaigned for the rights of individual investors, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 38 and lived in Washington.

title: Aid for Dissidents in Cuba
description: After four decades of isolation and repression under Fidel Castro's Communist rule, Cuba's surviving democrats would seem to be worthy candidates for American sympathy and support. Washington's 39-year-old trade embargo has scarcely helped their cause, and a fresh new American approach is surely needed. But proposed legislation in Congress that for the first time would provide direct financial support to internal Cuban dissidents would be likely to do more harm than good.

title: Sports of The Times; All Eyes Are Now On Lakers' 6-Footer
description: IF status were stock, the Lakers' Tyronn Lue would be through the roof.

title: Will 'Business Judgment' Rule Again in Delaware Courts?
description: INVESTORS, beware. The legal climate for protection of shareholder rights is getting much more chilly.

title: The Extra Mideast Mile
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Guilty Pleas in Briberies Dim Hopes for Bridgeport
description: Just when some people here were starting to feel good about this city, the bombs are dropping again on Bridgeport, unleashing charges that could be more damaging to its long-term vision of itself than any explosive device.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHILDREN'S COMPREHENSIVE SERVICES INC., Nashville, a provider of juvenile-justice services that had $127 million in sales last year, said it was in talks to sell the company for about $43.3 million. An unidentified group has proposed to buy the company for $6 a share in cash.

title: Morgan's Double-Eagle Helps Him Set Record
description: It was easy for Gil Morgan to feel at home as he stepped onto the course at the Tournament Players Club at Jasna Polana yesterday morning in Princeton, N.J.

title: Article 2001061692569097835 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Sports of The Times; Dominating O'Neal Reigns Unchallenged
description: SHAQUILLE O'NEAL woke up this morning as the emperor of an emerging new order in the N.B.A. The Lakers' indomitable center put an exclamation point on a sensational final series last night by scoring 29 points, grabbing 13 rebounds and blocking 5 shots as Los Angeles defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 108-96, to win its second consecutive N.B.A. championship.

title: Chinese Test New Weapon From West: Lawsuits
description: When Chen Wei and Zhai Yao were abruptly fired last year from jobs at a hip, glossy magazine, they could have quietly packed their desks and left -- it would have been the traditional Chinese response to an embarrassing situation.

title: Lakers Complete Record-Setting Romp Through the Playoffs
description: After hitting the pothole that sneaked up on everyone in Game 1 and then having their supremacy and heart questioned en route to Philadelphia, the Los Angeles Lakers arrived at their appointed destination tonight.

title: Catholic Bishops Adopt a Call for Action on the Climate
description: While stopping short of endorsing any particular prescription, America's Roman Catholic bishops voted unanimously today to issue a statement calling for immediate action to mitigate the effects of global climate change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGET, EVELYN
description: PAGET-Evelyn. Of Manhattan. Cherished daughter of the late Mayer and Ettie Paget. Beloved aunt, sister-in-law, cousin and friend. She was a very intelligent, compassionate & cheerful person, a mentor to many health professionals. Her spirit and vitality as well as her bravery will be remembered by all those she touched. Graveside service on Sunday, 11 AM, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing. Contributions to Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, N.Y., or a charity of your choice. For information, call ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: Article 2001061693730378825 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell sharply on concerns that a retooling of FTSE International's global stock indexes would prompt investors to sell Japanese shares. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.08 yen, up from 121.38.

title: PRESIDENT URGING EXPANSION OF NATO TO RUSSIA'S BORDER
description: President Bush called today for an Atlantic Alliance that would stretch all the way to Russia's borders, delving more emphatically and aggressively than any of his predecessors into a matter guaranteed to make Moscow nervous.

title: CONSECO TO ISSUE $400 MILLION IN NOTES TO RETIRE DEBT
description: Conseco, the life insurance and finance company based near Indianapolis, said yesterday that it planned to issue $400 million in senior notes due in 2008, with the proceeds to be used to retire bank debt in December. In March 2000, Conseco said it was writing down the value of securities on the books of the former Green Tree Financial Corporation, which it acquired in 1998 for $6 billion. The acquisition left Conseco with a heavy debt load and made it difficult for the company to borrow money. The new debt issue suggests that the debt reduction plan put in place by Conseco's chairman, Gary Wendt, has eased concerns about the company's ability to repay its $7.9 billion of debt.

title: Sports of The Times; Interleague Gimmick Looking Old
description: WHERE is Ichiro? Wouldn't it have been fun if, by some cosmic lottery of schedule-making, Ichiro of Seattle had played against Shinjo of New York in a duel of single-named phenomenons from very far away?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DEENA SUSAN
description: SCHWARTZ-Deena Susan. 7/15/ 48-6/16/98. 3 years/3 million tears. Love forever, Mom and Dad

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Refinery Purchased
description: Russia's second-largest oil producer, the Yukos Oil Company, bought more than a quarter of a Lithuanian oil refinery, managed by Williams International of the United States, according to Bloomberg News. Yukos agreed to pay $75 million for a 26.85 percent stake in the refinery, which is called Mazeikiu Nafta and is the only refinery in the Baltic States. Yukos, which beat an offer by a rival Russian oil company, said it would guarantee crude oil supplies for 10 years to the refinery, the agency reported. Williams owns a 33 percent stake in the refinery, which it bought two years ago for $150 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: PHONE GEAR MAKER EXPECTS HUGE LOSS AS SLUMP SPREADS
description: Nortel Networks of Canada said yesterday that it expected to report a loss that would be one of the biggest in corporate history, increasing concern over the troubled telecommunications industry.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Funds Raised
description: Hynix Semiconductor said it had raised the $1.25 billion it needed to persuade creditors to roll over more than $4 billion in debts due this year. The company, formerly Hyundai Electronics, said it had earned the money by selling global depository receipts but had to settle for 24.5 percent less than the price of the shares on the Korean Stock Exchange. The sale appeared to have provided a short-term respite for Hynix, a distant second to Samsung Electronics, but the company still had to confront the question of how to make a profit in a depressed semiconductor market. Hynix shares fell 11.6 percent during the last week. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Former Rising Star on Wall Street Is Arrested in Arms Sale Inquiry
description: An undercover investigation into suspected arms sales led to the arrest this week of a man who was once a rising star on Wall Street and a promising player in the resurgence of Harlem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, BROTHER AZARIAS PETER
description: WALSH-Brother Azarias Peter, FSC, 83, of Lincroft, NJ on June 15, 2001. Brother of James J. and Thomas J. Walsh, Mary E. Casella, and Catherine C. Franklin. Also survived by two nephews and two nieces. The wake will be held at De La Salle Hall, 810 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft on Tuesday from 2:00-4:00 and 6:30 to 8:00 PM. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at De La Salle Hall on Tuesday at 8:00 PM. The interment will be held at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY on Wednesday at 11:00 AM. Memorial donations to De La Salle Nursing Development, 810 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, NJ 07738 would be appreciated. For any further information contact Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold, New Jersey.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Taking Up Traffic
description: With passage of a budget finally behind them, state lawmakers turned to a plan to deal with traffic in the Seattle-Tacoma area. They have been prodded by the business community: the region's transportation mess ''impairs the company's ability to hire and retain people,'' the Microsoft chairman William H. Gates III said in a letter to lawmakers.

title: Iverson Thinks He's Still the M.V.P.
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15  The same news media that named Allen Iverson the league's most valuable player by an overwhelming margin questioned him Thursday on his selection. With Shaquille O'Neal dominating the postseason, Iverson was asked who he would give the award to now.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Rates Unchanged
description: Bank of Japan policy makers left interest rates near zero and refrained from increasing money supply, resisting pressure from the government to loosen credit after the economy shrank in the first quarter. Bonds and stocks fell as the unanimous decision signaled that the central bank was unwilling to add more money to the economy until the government spells out plans to cap spending and forces banks to write off their worst loans.

title: Source to Sell Five Properties
description: The Source Interlink Company, which has purchased nine companies in the last three years, plans to sell five properties obtained through the acquisitions for $25.3 million to reduce debt and increase its working capital.

title: Reading and Math Scores Show Little Progress Citywide
description: After two years in which schools officials celebrated gains in standardized test scores, a new round of reading and mathematics results released yesterday painted a much more modest and ambiguous picture of progress in New York City public schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JEROME
description: COOK-Jerome. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Jerome Cook. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Sheila and family. Peter J. Baum, President Gail H. Tarlowe, Secretary

title: Demonstrators Clash Sharply With Police In Sweden
description: Swedish police were bracing for fresh protests today after 12 hours of rioting on Friday left dozens injured, hundreds arrested and the center of this quaint historic city looking like a war zone during a summit meeting of European Union leaders.

title: Computer Consulting Firm Lowers Forecast
description: DiamondCluster International Inc., which advises companies on computer and communications systems, cut its fiscal first-quarter sales forecast as much as 19 percent today because of weak demand in North America and Europe.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction in Puerto Rico to the decision by the Bush administration to stop bombing practice on the island of Vieques referred incorrectly in some copies to Velda Gonzlez, a Puerto Rican lawmaker who was arrested during an April protest. She is a Puerto Rico senator -- not a territorial one, because the island is a commonwealth.

title: Shares Fall on Slow Growth in Phone Equipment Sales
description: Stocks fell yesterday as Nortel Networks said it was taking a $19.2 billion charge and sees no ''meaningful growth'' in customer spending on new phone equipment until the second half of 2002.

title: A Dad at the Final Frontier
description: Things may be getting easier for me and my kind. In the last 10 years the number of fathers acting as primary custodians of children under 18 rose 62 percent -- there are now 2.2 million of us, accounting for 2.1 percent of all American households. Of course, national statistics are one thing and the midday grocery aisles are quite another.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about Uzbekistan's joining China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikstan in a regional group that met in Shanghai misstated the group's name. It is the Shanghai Cooperation Organization; it was formerly the Shanghai Forum.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: First Slave Labor Payments
description: The first payments from a $4.4 billion fund of the German Foundation to compensate former slaves and forced laborers for the Nazis were made to victims' organizations, officials in Berlin said. The foundation transferred $44 million to the United States-based Jewish Claims Conference, $25 million to Poland and $24.5 million to the Czech Republic. Under an international accord reached last year, it is up to national organizations to make payments to claimants.

title: Judge Unseals Court Ruling On Leaks in Torricelli Inquiry
description: A judge in Newark yesterday unsealed his earlier ruling that found a Justice Department official may have leaked confidential grand jury information in the federal investigation of campaign fund-raising by Senator Robert G. Torricelli in 1996.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Acquisition Approved
description: A $7 billion bid by Schneider Electric S.A. of France for a domestic rival, Legrand S.A., is expected to proceed after the French stock market regulator gave the green light to a sweetened offer by Schneider to minority shareholders of Legrand shares. In May, a French court voided Schneider's original bid because the offer to holders of ordinary voting shares was 43 percent greater than that to owners of nonvoting shares, which enjoy a preferred dividend. Schneider was forced to raise the offer, reducing the premium for ordinary shares to about 20 percent, after a French association of minority shareholders, with the backing of institutional investors, took the case to court and won. The combined company, with about $11 billion of revenue, will be the world's largest manufacturer of low-voltage electrical products, from factory motor controls to household plugs and dimmers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Public Fight Over Private Property
description: A fistfight broke out in Parliament after a government official presented a draft bill on private ownership of land. Communist members of Parliament, who oppose private land ownership, tried to block the official from making his way to the podium to present the legislation, and then drowned out his speech with shouts. Despite the protest, the bill was approved on the first of three required readings.

title: For the Future of Vieques, Look to Hawaii
description: For decades the Navy strafed the island with gunfire. Ordnance exploded on windswept hills and bright blue reefs. After a lengthy political struggle that included arrests and illegal occupation by activists, islanders got what they wanted. The Navy stopped bombing and withdrew from the land.

title: Corrections
description: The Beliefs column last Saturday, about hiring by religious organizations that receive government support for social services, misstated the name of an agency with a nonprofit affiliate that hires staff members largely without regard to religion. It is Lutheran World Relief, not Lutheran World Service.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Games Will Go On
description: The Maccabiah Games, known as the Jewish Olympics, will take place as scheduled in Tel Aviv in July despite security concerns. Only half the previously expected 4,000 athletes will attend but the large United States delegation, which considered pulling out, has decided to take part as a gesture of solidarity with Israel and to help keep the quadrennial event going. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

title: Yankees Leave the Mets Tangled Up and Blue
description: The stakes were surely different than they were the last time the Yankees and the Mets played. But the critical moment in last night's Subway Series game occurred at the same place and with the same participants as it did back then, in the final game of the World Series. Mike Piazza and Jorge Posada, tangled up at home plate. Advantage Yankees, again.

title: FALSE FILINGS BY SBC COMMUNICATIONS ARE INVESTIGATED
description: Regulators said they were investigating more admissions by SBC Communications that it filed false information as it sought government approval to sell long-distance phone service in Kansas and Oklahoma. On April 13, SBC told the Federal Communications Commission it submitted incorrect information on fast Internet lines and the agency started investigating. In a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit yesterday, the F.C.C. cited a June 8 letter in which SBC said details about computer systems rivals use might also be inaccurate. The agency said it was looking into that data.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLONER, CRAIG ALAN
description: KLONER-Craig Alan. Died June 15, 2001 at Mt. Sinai. Survived by his wife Christine, parents Ida and Irving Kloner. Memorial service Tuesday, June 19, 2PM, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telephone Contract
description: The Swedish telecommunications giant Ericsson signed an agreement to supply $850 million in equipment and services to Chinese telecommunications operators. Ericsson said China, which has 100 million mobile phone users today and is likely to have 300 million by 2005, could soon surpass the United States to become the company's biggest single market. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER WARNS IT WILL MISS FORECASTS
description: The International Rectifier Corporation said demand for its computer chips for power supplies had weakened and its fiscal fourth-quarter sales would miss forecasts. Sales in the period ending in June will range from $179 million to $193 million, down from $276 million last quarter, the company said. It had previously forecast sales of $237 million to $257 million. First-quarter sales are expected to be unchanged from the fourth, the chief executive, Alex Lidow, said in a statement. International Rectifier, based in El Segundo, Calif., reported quarterly sales of $232 million a year earlier.

title: Former Mayor of Camden Is Sentenced for Corruption
description: A federal judge today sentenced former Mayor Milton Milan to seven years and three months in federal prison for bribery, racketeering and money laundering while in office, saying that Mr. Milan had made his troubled city a laughingstock.

title: One Woman's Year In the Spotlight's Heat; Friends Call Judith Nathan Stunned By the Media Circus of New York
description: Judith Nathan's cocker spaniel had been under the weather for weeks. And so last month Ms. Nathan checked her dog, Matilda, into an animal hospital on East 62nd Street in Manhattan.

title: The 'Office' Is a Grind to Foes
description: Jamaica's national team has gone 50 soccer games without losing at its stadium here. There is so much pride in that record that locals call the stadium The Office.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Wife Says Suspect Told a Priest 20 Years Ago of Aiding Soviets
description: The wife of the spy suspect Robert P. Hanssen has told the authorities that he confided to her and to a Roman Catholic priest approximately 20 years ago that he had begun supplying information to the K.G.B., government officials and others involved in the case said.

title: On Pro Basketball; Bryant Completes His Journey at Home
description: The young adult from nearby Lower Merion began giving his teammates high-fives as he waltzed back toward the bench with 10 minutes 44 seconds remaining. However loud and personal the jeering was, Kobe Bryant phased out the noise and smiled as he took a seat for his final rest on the final night of the N.B.A. season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, PAUL ROBERT
description: CAREY-Paul Robert, Commissioner-United States Securities and Exchange Commission passed away June 14, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Paul Robert Carey was born October 18, 1962, the beloved seventh son of Former Governor Hugh L. Carey and the late Helen Owen Carey. His two brothers Hugh L. Carey, Jr. and Peter G. Carey predeceased him. He is survived by his loving family and friends including his brothers and sisters: Alexandria McManus (Hank), Christopher (Bonnie), Susan Dempsey (Marty), Michael, Donald, Marianne Hayes (Dennis), Nancy Cassidy (Tom), Helen O'Neill (Martin), Bryan (Catherine), Kevin (Mary Jo), Thomas (Amy), his loving nieces and nephews Peter Hugh, Eileen, Tom, Beth (Bryan), Erich, Kate, Susie, Ted, Maureen, Hugh, Donnie, Owen, Delia, Thomas Hugh & Elizabeth. Many loving friends, including his close friend Jackie Chorney, also survive him. Paul was a graduate of the Doane Stuart School and Colgate University. After a career in Institutional Equities, Paul joined the Clinton/ Gore 1992 Presidential Campaign, as Northeast finance director. In the new administration, he worked in the White House as Special Assistant to the President for legislative affairs, handling banking, financial services and securities matters, primarily working with the United States Senate. He also worked on judicial selection and handled Senate confirmation for many administration nominees. In 1997, Paul was nominated and confirmed to serve as Commissioner of the Securities Exchange Commission. While at the Commission Paul Carey led the Commission's efforts to provide information to lawmakers regarding the privatization of Social Security. He also served as liaison to the North American Securities Administrators Association. Paul lived life to the fullest and continued his public service each day of his life. As a member of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as well as in his service in the White House administration of President Bill Clinton, Paul strived to make life better for all of those whom he touched and for those less fortunate. Paul was a man of great accomplishments, stature and elegance. Paul loved to travel to distant parts of the world and was well received wherever he called including a number of United States Embassies. Most recently, Paul took great joy in attending the investiture of the Cardinals in Rome, including Edward Cardinal Egan of the Archdiocese of New York. From the earliest days, Paul held an affection for the developmentally disabled. As a child, he provided loving care to the developmentally challenged at Camp Shelter Island and as a young man he worked with physically challenged skiers in Windham, N.Y. As a son, a brother, an uncle and a friend he brought a whole new meaning to the fun that life has to offer and shared it with everyone he touched. Paul's strength, love and generosity will continue with the Carey family and his friends forever. With God's grace he gave and received as much love as anyone could ever have dreamed of or desired in life. The family wishes to thank all the caregivers, nurses and doctors who cared for and treated Paul during his lengthy illness. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that Paul be remembered by donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 or St. Gabriel's Spiritual Center for Youth, P.O. Box 3015, Shelter Island Heights, NY 11965. A mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10:00 AM on Monday June 18, 2001. Viewing will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Saturday and Sunday from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM and from 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM. For inquiries contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at (212) 288-3500. We Know. The Carey Family

title: Plain-Talking Bush Is Using His Charm On European Stage
description: When President Bush first spotted Prime Minister Tony Blair in Brussels on Wednesday, he broke into a smile, indulged a mischievous impulse and offered him a greeting less formal than the ones the British leader usually hears.

title: Long-Term Power Deals Scrutinized in California
description: Aides to Gov. Gray Davis today released details of the $43 billion in contracts that California has signed with 18 companies to supply much of its power over the next decade, prompting a debate over whether the contracts have managed to stabilize the state's electricity market or whether Mr. Davis has locked residents into overpaying for power for years to come.

title: Time for Bloom to Resume His Everlasting Odyssey
description: ''Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed. A yellow dressing gown, ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him by the mild morning air. He held the bowl aloft and intoned: 'Introibo ad altare Dei.' ''

title: Mexican President to Ask Oklahoma Governor to Halt an Execution Next Week
description: Citing a violation of international law that has been at the center of several unsuccessful death penalty appeals, President Vicente Fox of Mexico is pleading for the life of a Mexican man scheduled to be executed on Tuesday in Oklahoma. But this time, it appears that officials may be receptive to the appeal.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I guess I'd be at the

title: Too Slow an Exit From Vieques
description: President Bush was right to recognize on Thursday that the Navy's continued use of the island of Vieques, off Puerto Rico, was politically untenable. But his decision to let aerial and ship-to-shore bombing continue there until May 2003 in the face of intense local opposition is unrealistic. The current exercises, which will include several days of bombing runs next week, should be the last.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001061690946468149 -- No Title
Impasse on Gases: Who Moves First?
description: In recent days, President Bush has repeatedly said a major reason for his rejection of a proposed agreement to stem global warming is that it would require industrialized countries to cut heat-trapping gas emissions while exempting developing countries from similar obligations.

title: VLASIC FOODS, MAKER OF PICKLES, FILES BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: Vlasic Foods International, the nation's leading pickle maker, filed a bankruptcy plan under which, as expected, unsecured creditors would be only partly repaid and shareholders would receive nothing. The plan would distribute proceeds from the $370 million sale of most of its assets to the buyout firm Hicks, Muse Tate & Furst Inc. Money received from several smaller asset sales would also be used to pay creditors. The sale to Hicks, Muse's Pinnacle Foods unit, which was completed in May, included Vlasic's signature pickle business, Open Pit barbecue sauce brands and North American frozen food business. Vlasic, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., sought protection from creditors in January in bankruptcy court in Delaware, citing $458.3 million in assets and $649.9 million in debts.

title: Sky Watch: The Summer Solstice
description: Thursday will be a busy day on the celestial calendar. First, at 3:38 a.m. Eastern time, is the summer solstice, as the Sun reaches that point farthest north of the celestial equator. Daylight now lasts longest and the nights are shortest.

title: A Win for Contraception
description: A federal trial judge in Washington State ruled this week that a local family-owned drugstore chain had engaged in unlawful sex discrimination by excluding contraceptive coverage from its employee health plan. As a technical matter, the ruling is binding on only that one company. But the ruling -- the first time a court has addressed the issue of gender equity in drug coverage -- sets a legally solid precedent that may well encourage more health coverage of contraceptives nationwide. The issue caught fire a few years ago after it was discovered that many employers who excluded women's prescription contraceptives from coverage chose to pay for Viagra, the prescription drug to treat impotence in men.

title: Sony Admits It Used Employees as Bogus Fans
description: Still reeling from revelations that its advertising department had concocted a phony film critic and used him to promote four Columbia Pictures releases, Sony Pictures Entertainment has now admitted that two of its own employees posed as ordinary moviegoers in on-the-street interviews to promote another Columbia release last summer.

title: Running for Office, One Door at a Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001061692533268964 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Corrections
description: A diagram on Tuesday with an article about a Supreme Court ruling on the use of thermal imaging to detect an indoor marijuana-growing operation misspelled the name of a data source. It is the Tillamook County Sheriff's Office, not Tillamooc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIN, RICHARD
description: ROBIN-Richard. Loving husband of Therese, devoted father to Jacky and grandfather to Scott and Mark Sean. Friend and fatherin-law to Jeffrey Clyman. His rich and fulfilling life is an inspiration to all who knew him. We shall miss the warmth of his fellowship. Melanie and Philippe Radley, Karen and Cooke Rand

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrests In Chechnya Killings
description: Nineteen Russian soldiers were arrested for the suspected murder of several civilians in the separatist republic, the Interfax news agency reported, citing a pro-Russian Chechen official. Russian officials said only that Russian soldiers had killed several Chechens who the soldiers said were stealing oil, and that the incident was being investigated. Chechens and human rights groups have accused the Russian military of widespread abuses during their war with rebels.

title: U.S. to Investigate Death in an Asthma Study
description: Federal health officials said yesterday that they would investigate the death of a healthy volunteer in an asthma experiment at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

title: With Woods Struggling, the Open Is Just That
description: Three players who have not won a tournament this year were tied for the lead. Tiger Woods was nine strokes behind, looking confounded instead of confident, with his chance to win his fifth consecutive major championship in serious jeopardy.

title: Day 2 of a Mideast Truce Sees Few Violent Incidents
description: The second full day of an Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire ended tonight without reports of serious violence, but the two sides continued to accuse each other of not doing enough to cement the still shaky truce.

title: Shelf Life; The Harem Is the Exotic Dancer In a Historical Peep Show
description: There is no escaping the harem. In the last 500 years of European literature and art, it has been both commonplace and mysterious, often invoked, almost never known. In its Arabic origins, the word harem refers to the sacred, the forbidden; its European synonym, seraglio, combined the Italian word serrare (to lock up or enclose) with the Turkish-Prussian paray (palace). Witness accounts, many of them spurious, promised to reveal -- always for the first time -- what was really going on in these sacred palaces where the Ottoman sultan enclosed his hundreds of concubines, whether jealously seeking a place in his bed or whiling away the time soaking in heated baths or seductively reclining on silken divans.

title: EGYPT ON TRIAL
description: With the prominent Arab intellectual Saad Eddin Ibrahim in jail, the government of President Hosni Mubarak stands to come under international scrutiny. A report by Mary Anne Weaver in The Times Magazine.

title: Power Failure Disrupts Georgetown
description: When the power went out for the powerful this week in Georgetown, Mike Murphy, a Republican strategist new to the neighborhood, could not resist a gibe.

title: Every Home Has a Junk Drawer; His Held a $46 Million Treasure
description: Calm, easygoing and worry-free were the words that came up most often today when Melvin B. Milligan's neighbors tried to describe him: a mild-mannered computer technician who lives here with his wife and son in a modest two-story house with a backyard patio and barbecue pit.

title: In a First, U.S. Team in Bali Will Have a Woman's Touch
description: For the first time in 36 years, a woman will represent the United States in the Bermuda Bowl when the world championships are played in Bali, Indonesia, in October.

title: Making a Case For the Right To Be Different
description: When the United States Supreme Court ruled last year that the Boy Scouts of America could exclude gays, Justice John Paul Stevens said that the majority had made a mistake. The real issue in the case, Justice Stevens wrote in his dissent, was that a respected longtime scout had decided not to hide his sexual orientation. ''His openness is the sole and sufficient justification for his ostracism,'' Justice Stevens wrote, which amounts to ''a constitutionally prescribed symbol of inferiority.''

title: Circuit City Quarterly Profit Tumbles 82%
description: The earnings of Circuit City Group fell 82 percent in its just-ended quarter, as slack demand for computers caused sales to decline more than a fifth.

title: Amos Perlmutter, 69, Expert On Middle Eastern Affairs
description: Amos Perlmutter, a Washington-based political scientist, author and commentator on Middle Eastern affairs, died Tuesday at a hospital in Washington. He was 69.

title: Europe Electronics Maker Expects a Loss
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's biggest electronics manufacturer, warned today that it was losing money in the current quarter and might finish the year in the red because its semiconductor business was slumping. It was the second warning in three months.

title: McDonald and Bretina Take Lead at Grand Prix Dressage Championship
description: Despite a severe case of nerves for the rider and hives for the horse, Debbie McDonald of Hailey, Idaho teamed up with the German-bred mare Bretina and scored 70.326 percentage points in the Grand Prix Special Test to take the lead after the first two phases of the Grand Prix Dressage Championship at the team's annual Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Faith in Stamp Affirmed

title: Sequestered, a Jury Understands Its Duty
description: There are brighter faces in New York State criminal courts these days -- in the jury boxes, at least. With the abolition last month of the mandatory sequestering of all juries deliberating criminal cases, there will be less shuttling to hotels and fewer restless nights under the eye of watchful guards. This may be good. But when I passed through the metal detectors at 100 Centre Street for jury duty in Manhattan last year, I had no idea of the role sequestration could play in a verdict.

title: Article 2001061691055543848 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Reward Is Offered in Theft Of Early Painting by Chagall
description: A custodian vacuuming the carpet in one of the exhibition halls at the Jewish Museum hardly paused last Friday when a small screw was sucked up and rattled its way up into the belly of his vacuum cleaner.

title: Franks's Attacks in Debate Reflect a Much Closer Race
description: When he entered the race for governor in April, the conventional wisdom was that Bob Franks would coast to victory over Bret D. Schundler in the Republican primary. But Mr. Franks's performance in Thursday night's debate -- a nonstop, wall-to-wall assault on his rival's record and honesty -- was anything but that of a front-runner.

title: Running for Office, One Door at a Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Softens Public Financing Criticism
description: Under attack by his Democratic opponents and proponents of campaign finance reform, Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday backed away from his criticism of the city's campaign finance program. But he suggested that the system should be changed to require officials to disclose contributors they meet with, in person and by telephone, to guard against influence peddling.

title: Makanda K. McIntyre, 69, Jazz Performer and Educator
description: Makanda K. McIntyre, a jazz saxophonist, flutist and player of reed instruments who began recording in the early 1960's before beginning a 40-year career as a beloved jazz educator, died on Wednesday at his Harlem apartment. He was 69.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, 55 years ago we became best friends. Miss you so muchyour love, your wisdom, just you Malvin. Love always, Audre

title: Fix the Flaws in School Reform
description: The White House has declared victory on school reform based on two seriously flawed education bills that have finally emerged from the House and Senate. The flaws need to be fixed in conference. In addition, the lofty rhetoric of reform will come to nothing unless the White House and Congress agree to put some real money behind the twin goals of rebuilding failing schools and closing the achievement gap that exists between white students and the minority children who will soon make up the majority of the American work force.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hybrid Push By Toyota
description: Fujio Cho, president of Toyota Motor, said yesterday that he wanted to step up production of gasoline-electric hybrid vehicles to at least 300,000 annually, 10 times the current level, by 2005. He spoke at the unveiling of a hybrid version of the four-wheel-drive Estima minivan, which uses a system similar to Toyota's Prius hybrid sedan and not the cheaper but less energy-saving new hybrid engine Toyota announced earlier this week. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: From Giuliani, a Pitch to Put Parties Aside
description: New York City should have nonpartisan elections like Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston and other major cities, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, as he announced that he had established a new Charter Revision Commission to examine rewriting election rules, and to consider a list of other changes in the structure of city government.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, BAYARD DOMINICK
description: STOUT-Bayard Dominick, on June 14, 2001 at home in Rumson, NJ. Husband of Ruth Maney Stout (married 55 years). Father of Ethel Stout Chapin, William Lee Stout, Judith Stout, Hope Stout Connors and Mary Stout Lawrence, uncle of Richard John Maney, grandfather of fourteen, great grandfather of seven. Memorial services to be held on Monday 10:30 AM at St. Georges by the River Episcopal Church, Waterman Ave., Rumson. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA. 01275; St. Georges Church, Waterman Ave., Rumson, NJ 07760; or the Riverview Medical Center Foundation, One Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701, would be preferred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDERS, RALPH FRANKLIN
description: KANDERS-Ralph Franklin. Died peacefully at home on June 14, 2001 surrounded by his beloved wife of 44 years, Jeanne, and his children. Son of Beatrice Kanders and devoted and cherished father of Warren, Beatrice Kanders Hoffman, Jonathan, Alan, Emily and grandfather to Alexander, Zachary, Sarabeth, William, Chloe and Abigail. Born on November 30, 1921 in Manhattan, he graduated from Cornell University in 1942 and New York University School of Dentistry in 1946. He practiced periodontics in Montclair and Convent Station, NJ. He served on the dental teaching staff of Mountainside Hospital and Morristown Memorial Hospital in NJ. He established the Kanders Foundation to promote his philanthropic interests in education, the arts and science. He was an extremely warm and generous man whose thirst for learning and devotion to higher education helped many individuals and institutions. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Ralph F. Kanders Memorial Scholarship at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York.

title: Officer Accused Of Cocaine Use
description: A New Jersey police officer faces criminal charges that he used cocaine and had consensual sex while on duty, with a woman who had gone to Police Headquarters to report a dispute.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Editor Charged But Released
description: The editor and two publishing executives of Kantipur, the country's largest daily newspaper, were formally charged with sedition for printing an article by a Maoist rebel who called the royal massacre a foreign-inspired conspiracy. All three men were released, but instructed to appear in court on July 16. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Vendors Feel They've Been Struck Out
description: A few weeks ago, Anna Ellison, who owns a furniture store on the site of what was in happier days the Luna Park amusement area at Coney Island, got a call from the city reminding her it was time to renew her dealer's license.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, MAKANDA KEN
description: McINTYRE-Makanda Ken. Born September 7, 1931, made his transition June 13, 2001. Peerless composer, arranger and multi-instrumentalist of music in the African American tradition, he inspired multitudes. Son of Jamaican parents, Arthur A. McIntyre and Blanche C. Stewart, he grew up in the South End of Boston, Mass. He leaves his second wife, Joy Rosenthal McIntyre, and his sons, Kenneth A. McIntyre, Jr. and Kheil A. McIntyre, and two grandchildren, Aaron B. McIntyre and Rachel E. McIntyre. Services will be held today at St. James Presbyterian Church, 409 West 141st Street (at St. Nicholas Ave.) at 11:00 am, viewing at 10:00. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to EHMC Foundation/ Dizzy Gillespie Fund for Jazz Musicians, Englewood Hospital, 350 Engle St, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: Small Jets' Big Stake in a Strike; Comair Pilots' Pay Seen as Key to Future of the Planes
description: If the pilots' strike at Comair, the largest regional unit of Delta Air Lines, does not end soon, industry analysts have repeatedly warned, it could cause the entire division to shut down. Or if the strike, 83 days' old today, ends with huge raises for the pilots, it could make the operation of small regional jets so expensive that Delta and other airlines would stop the recent rapid growth in their use.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: 'Abortion Ship' Docks
description: A Dutch trawler outfitted as a floating abortion clinic docked in Dublin. But the Women on Waves organization, which favors abortion rights, abandoned its plan to peform abortions for Irish women in international waters 12 miles off the coast because it does not have the proper license from the Dutch authorities. Abortions are illegal in Ireland unless giving birth threatens the mother's life, and more than 6,000 Irish women go to Britain every year for the procedure. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Article 2001061692696143290 -- No Title
description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Insurance Units Sold
description: AMP Ltd. sold its insurance units in Australia and Britain as it turned its focus to fund management. Suncorp-Metway Ltd., Queensland's biggest car and home insurer, will buy AMP's Australian general insurance unit for 1.24 billion Australian dollars ($650 million) to expand into the nation's most populous state. AMP will also sell its British general insurance business for 211 million Australian dollars to Churchill Insurance, a unit of Credit Suisse First Boston, after taking out 87 million Australian dollars in capital.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Dispute Blocks Food Aid
description: The World Food Program suspended production of bread that has been feeding nearly 300,000 people, mostly widows and children in Kabul. The United Nations agency has demanded that women be allowed to conduct household surveys to determine needs; the Kabul-area Taliban leaders, reflecting regional splits between hard-liners and more moderate elements in the movement, say they will not permit women to do that work. In other cities, the baking projects continue. The Taliban have asked for more talks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page E5 of the Arts section was omitted from some copies on Wednesday and replaced by a duplicate of F5. The missing page carried a music review of Mongolian song and dance at Symphony Space; a Critic's Notebook article about the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C.; a theater review of ''Soon My Work,'' on the Lower East Side; and the conclusion of a film review of ''Sexy Beast.'' The articles are available on the Web at www .nytimes.com/reprint. The page may be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@ nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</B

title: Pettitte and Justice Added To Crowded Disabled List
description: Joe Torre reached into Andy Pettitte's glove in the fourth inning last night, pried the baseball out and dispatched Pettitte to the dugout for medical attention. Quite suddenly, the Yankees had a huge hole in their starting rotation.

title: Piazza Hesitates and Is Lost
description: Mike Piazza rumbled from first to second base, stopped and stared out to right field, appearing uncertain. Todd Zeile's fly ball in the eighth inning had already bounced off the warning track, but Piazza did not know that, so he waited and searched for the ball. Then Piazza continued for third, and after that it got worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airline Bankruptcy
description: The French air carrier, AOM/Air Libert, the only domestic competitor of Air France, filed for bankruptcy protection after efforts to find a buyer and trim its work force failed. Swissair Group, which owns 49.5 percent, said it had set aside $390 million for its share of the cost of revamping or closing AOM/Air Libert, but analysts said the final bill could be much higher. EasyJet, a low-fare European airline, said it might offer to buy AOM/Air Libert's landing slots at Orly Airport in Paris. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, HERBERT
description: WOODS-Herbert. We mourn the passing of Herbert Woods who possessed a remarkable passion for life. He was an inspiration for all of us. We express our deepest condolences to wife, Sylvia, and children Van, Kenneth, Bedelia and Cresette. He will be greatly missed. Irving and the Schatz Family

title: Bush in Europe: An Uneasy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning a Friendlier Face to Iran
description: In the presidential election this month, Iranians voted overwhelmingly in favor of reform and democracy. The landslide victory of Mohammad Khatami, the candidate identified with reform, provides an opportunity for the United States to respond to the Iranian people's desire for change. The current stalemate in American-Iranian relations does not serve overall American interests. The United States should relax its economic sanctions against Iran and take other steps to foster an improved relationship, without weakening efforts to advance Middle East peace and prevent terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer's Sales Up
description: Britain's largest supermarket chain, Tesco, said first-quarter sales rose 14 percent, driven by nonfood items like compact discs and phone cards. In the 12 weeks to May 19, sales at British supermarkets open at least a year rose 6.7 percent. The company said total sales grew 9.8 percent in Britain and 50 percent abroad. British supermarkets have been cutting prices to draw customers, and Tesco said it would begin another wave of price cuts Monday on 700 products. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Bush in Europe: An Uneasy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Appealing a Ruling Aiding Victims of A-Bombs
description: The Japanese government is seeking to overturn a court ruling early this month that provided the first compensation for survivors of the 1945 atomic bombings in Hiroshima and Nagasaki who now live overseas.

title: Abroad at Home; The Closed Mind
description: What President Bush has been telling European leaders this week can be readily summed up: I am not going to do anything about global warming because it needs more scientific study. But I am going to act urgently to develop a missile defense system although none have any proven scientific basis and every test so far has failed.

title: World Briefing
description: UNITED NATIONS

title: David Spedding Dies at 58; Headed British Spy Agency
description: David Rolland Spedding, who rose to head the Secret Intelligence Service, or M.I.6 -- a position immortalized by the author Ian Fleming as the espionage supremo known only as M -- died on Wednesday. He was 58.

title: Bush in Europe: An Uneasy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Secretary Asks Congress To Cancel Vote for Vieques
description: The secretary of the Navy said today that he would ask Congress to cancel a referendum among the residents of the Puerto Rican island of Vieques to determine whether they want American forces to continue to train there.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Testing The Watery Limits
description: The Defense Ministry said a small North Korean freighter had crossed a line in the Sea of Japan that the South has long claimed as marking its territorial waters. The ship, carrying bicycles from Japan, crossed what South Korea calls the Northern Limit Line on Thursday night, about 90 miles east of Jeojin. The vessel identified itself, said the ministry, and sailed on toward North Korea. On Wednesday night, another Northern cargo ship strayed across the line but veered away when challenged. The North has called for revisions of the boundary and for access to the straits between South Korea and Cheju island. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Baby Gifts Go Elsewhere
description: Not that she didn't like the Tiffany plates from the governor of California or the little T-shirts from the Nevada legislators, but Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift has had to give up many of the 200 baby gifts she received after having her twins last month. Ms. Swift is forbidden by state laws from accepting gifts worth more than $50 from anyone other than family and friends. Most of the gifts, valued at about $10,000, are going to the Department of Social Services to help other families. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Lear Gets a Break From Supreme Court Justices Who Think the Play's the Thing
description: The case before the highest tribunal might have been called Lear v. the Thankless Daughter. Or, in a capital that has seen palace intrigues, family discord and debates about character flaws, ''Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about Uzbekistan's joining China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikstan in a regional group that met in Shanghai misstated the group's name. It is the Shanghai Cooperation Organization; it was formerly the Shanghai Forum.

title: GENERAL SEMICONDUCTOR SAYS IT EXPECTS LOWER SALES
description: General Semiconductor said demand for its power-management components remained weak and second-quarter sales would be lower than in the first. Sales are expected to fall as much as 17 percent this quarter from $102 million in the first quarter, a spokesman, Jonas Leddington, said. The company, based in Melville, N.Y., had forecast sales to be unchanged to slightly lower. Profit is expected to be 1 cent to 3 cents a share. Slower-than-expected demand is hurting profit, though customers are canceling fewer orders. Also, the number of new orders increased in May and early June from April, the chief executive, Ronald Ostertag, said in the statement.

title: U.S. Doesn't Want to Join Any NATO Mission Into Macedonia
description: The Bush administration has told its NATO partners that it does not want to take part in a NATO military mission that the Macedonian government has requested for the disarming of ethnic Albanian insurgents, senior administration officials said today.

title: Religion Journal; Episcopal Dissidents Look to Expand
description: In a ceremony in Singapore last year, two Anglican archbishops -- one from Africa, the other from Asia -- shocked leaders of the Episcopal Church by consecrating two Episcopal priests as bishops.

title: P.& G. to Abandon Some Product Lines and Report Quarterly Loss
description: Procter & Gamble officials said yesterday that they had been too patient and too ambitious with some businesses. So the company will abandon big initiatives including its Olean fat substitute and Oil of Olay line of cosmetics.

title: Judge Rules That Tyson Must Complete Takeover of IBP
description: A Delaware state judge ruled yesterday that Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry producer, had no legal grounds for withdrawing its $3.2 billion offer to buy IBP Inc. and ordered Tyson to complete the deal.

title: Jackson Can Stand With the Greats
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15  We interrupt this regularly scheduled playoff game between the Lakers and 76ers to bring you another annual installment of "Phil vs. Red." This is about generational pride, gargantuan egos and, most important, the title of Greatest Coach Ever.

title: School Shooting a Part of Him, a Valedictorian Moves On
description: AEMON CANNON is certain about little as he contemplates life after graduation from Santana High School. But one thing the big-limbed, bright young man says he knows for sure is that when he leaves this tough San Diego suburb and enters the University of California at Santa Barbara in the fall, he will join the juggling club. And if there is no juggling club, he will start one, as he did here.

title: Telecom Woes Force Nortel to $19 Billion Loss
description: NEW YORK  Nortel Networks, the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker, said it would post a stunning loss of $19.2 billion in the second quarter and fire 10,000 workers because demand had dried up for high-capacity telecom equipment.

title: Article 2001061692263125465 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the televised debate between candidates for the Republican nomination for New Jersey governor misstated the rule on using props. In fact they are prohibited. Bob Franks broke the rule by brandishing papers to discredit Bret D. Schundler, and Mr. Schundler responded in kind.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nortel Expects to Report $19 Billion Loss in Quarter

title: Bush Urges Putin to Approve Plans for Missile Shield
description: BRDO PRI KRANJU, Slovenia, June 16  President Bush sat down with Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, here this afternoon and extended an offer of closer friendship, along with a request: that Russians look beyond a landmark 1972 treaty and bless Mr. Bush's plans for a missile defense shield.

title: 3 Officials Charged With Corruption in Al Capone's Old Fief
description: The top official of this Chicago suburb where Al Capone once reigned was arrested by federal agents today along with a former police chief and a former town treasurer, all accused of making Cicero ''a personal piggy bank'' by siphoning off more than $10 million from the town's insurance program.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Guilty Plea In Debate Case
description: Juanita Yvette Lozano, 31, a former office manager for President Bush's media adviser, Mark McKinnon, in the presidential campaign, has pleaded guilty to mail fraud and perjury in the case of some debate preparation materials stolen and sent to a member of Al Gore's campaign last September. Prosecutors contended that Ms. Lozano mailed the material to former Representative Tom Downey, Democrat of New York, who was helping Mr. Gore prepare for a debate with Mr. Bush. Ms. Lozano did not reveal her motive. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Woods's Close Call Doesn't Faze Him
description: Until Tiger Woods finished his second round with a one-over-par 71 today for a total of 145, he appeared to be on the bubble for the 36-hole cut in the 101st United States Open. But later he sounded as if he had never thought about missing the cut, only about what he must do to get into contention for Sunday's final round.

title: Cuttings: A Land Rush for Compost in the City
description: IT looked like a gathering of the nations two Sundays ago, on the parking lot of Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Only these delegates weren't talking global warming, but shoveling deep, dark compost as fast as they could.

title: California Vintner Buying Finger Lakes Land
description: Betting on the future of the Finger Lakes wine region, a major California grape grower is buying 105 acres of a 346-acre dairy farm on Seneca Lake to convert the land into a vineyard.

title: Japan Promotes Treaty on Global Warming, but Keeps Its Options Open
description: Japan's foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, said today that Tokyo would work ''to the last moment'' to persuade the United States to support the Kyoto Protocol to curb global warming.

title: Helping New York Grow
description: For decades, New York City struggled to arrest a long-term economic decline and prevent jobs from going to the suburbs. Today the city faces a new set of problems resulting from an improved economy: businesses that want to expand in the city but lack the space to do so. This week Senator Charles Schumer and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin issued a report urging that the city employ its zoning, taxing and condemnation powers to speed office construction within its borders, particularly the West Side of Manhattan in Midtown. It was a welcome suggestion that should help stir an overdue debate on development priorities.

title: Book-Starved in a Storied Land
description: When Mansoura Ezz Eddin wanted to get her first collection of short stories published, she proceeded the way most aspiring writers do in the Arab world. She paid for it herself.

title: Crackdown on Trucks Leaves Piles of Trash in New York
description: A crackdown by Pennsylvania authorities on trucks hauling garbage has delayed large shipments of trash from the New York region, clogging transfer stations and leaving, in some cases, piles of garbage stacked outside restaurants, supermarkets and other businesses in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYER, RUTH M. KOBLER
description: DYER-Ruth M. Kobler. Sculptor, of Ridgefield, CT. On June 14th, 2001. At the age of 79. Wife of Carlus E. Dyer. Mother of Karen Reiser and Andrea Bagg. A Memorial Service will be held Monday, June 18, 2001 at 11AM at the South Salem Presbyterian Church, South Salem, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Bethel Health Care Resident Trust Fund, C/O L. Plumb, 13 Park Lawn Drive, Bethel, CT 06801.

title: In Mideast, C.I.A. Chief Wins Trust Across a Bitter Divide
description: George J. Tenet's success this week in helping to forge a cease-fire, however fragile, between the Palestinians and Israelis was not the first time he had been able to bridge a gap between warring factions.

title: Boston Journal; Minder of Misplaced Apostrophes Scolds a Town
description: They jump out everywhere at John Richards, silent testaments to the declining standards of our time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, PAULINE
description: ROSEN-Pauline. Age 81. On June 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving Rosen. Mother of Murray, Bobbe (Paul) Carton. Grandmother of Jeffrey (Lauren), Craig (Kim), Caryn Carton, Daniel (Anna) and Christopher Rosen. Great grandmother of Amy, Andrew and Mickey. Graveside service June 17th, 10AM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Inmates on Alabama's Death Row Lack Lawyers
description: All but two states with the death penalty guarantee prisoners a lawyer for the full range of appeals allowed by the legal system. In Alabama and Georgia, however, there is no guarantee of a lawyer after the direct appeal of a conviction, and prisoners have only inconsistent access to a legal process that frequently overturns death sentences.

title: Ritzenhein Captures Third 2-Mile Title
description: Dathan Ritzenhein of Rockford, Mich., broke his year-old meet record while capturing his third straight national two-mile title last night in the Adidas high school championships in Raleigh, N.C.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Suspected Crime Matriarch Seized
description: 50-year-old woman accused of being the boss of one of biggest organized crime clans in the Naples region was arrested yesterday. Maria Licciardi, who was arrested while driving her car near Naples, had been on the run since 1999 and was one of Italy's 30 most wanted fugitives. She is accused of directing prostitution, smuggling and extortion rings. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURLAN, ROSLYN
description: KURLAN-Roslyn. Died on June 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Herbert and Fran Kurlan, Norman and Kim Kurlan and Arlene and Jack Levine. Cherished grandmother of eleven. She was a master bridge player and a world traveler. She will be in our hearts forever. Services Sunday 12 Noon at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY

title: Europe Opens Door for G.E., Just Slightly
description: Amid signs of political pressure from the United States, the European Commission said today that a ''limited opportunity'' remained for General Electric to offer more concessions to win approval of its planned $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International, even though the deadline for new concessions had passed.

title: Fuel With a Dark Past Has a Bright Future
description: Switch on a light somewhere in the country and the odds are one in two that it will be powered not by oil, natural gas, uranium, water, wind or anything else but by coal, that Industrial Revolution-era fuel that seems, at least for now, to have reclaimed a 21st-century future.

title: Apartment Rentals in Paris
description: To really absorb all that Paris offers, it helps to experience the city as a Parisian would  which means, for example, staying in a private apartment rather than a hotel. And from July 15 to Aug. 30, Paris Sejour Reservations is taking 10 percent off its rates on over 600 fully equipped apartments throughout the city. Non-discounted rates range from $80 to $180 a night for a studio, $100 to $200 for a one-bedroom unit, $140 to $280 for two bedrooms and $300 and up for three bedrooms. The minimum stay is five nights, and remember that much of the citizenry of Paris is away on vacation in August, which can be a boom or a bust, depending on how you see it. Information: (313) 587-7707 or www.psryourhomeinparis.com .

title: Beneath the Froth, Serious Surprises
description: Richard Tanner's ''Soire'' is the final premiere of the New York City Ballet's season. To call it yummy, scrumptious and delicious might suggest an overdose of sugar in either the choreographer or the viewer.

title: Mideast Finger-Pointing
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing City Charter, Cha, Cha, Cha
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI created yet another commission yesterday to take a whack at the City Charter, New York's wordy constitution. The groans of ''Oh, no, not again'' could be heard all the way from Tottenville in Staten Island to Wakefield in the Bronx.

title: McDONALD'S EXPECTS DROP IN PROFIT TO DEEPEN
description: The McDonald's Corporation's second-quarter profit will fall more than expected because of declining currencies including the euro, higher costs and consumer concern about mad cow disease in Europe. McDonald's said its earnings would be 34 cents to 35 cents a share, below the 38 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. McDonald's earned 39 cents a year earlier. The weakening of currencies against the dollar will cut profit by 2 cents. McDonald's also spent more on beef, labor and energy, analysts said, while Europeans ate fewer hamburgers out of fear they may get the human form of mad cow disease. McDonald's chief executive, Jack Greenberg, said he expected ''significant improvement'' in the second half.

title: Storms Result In Flight Delays
description: Air traffic at La Guardia Airport and Newark International Airport was delayed by up to four hours early last night by a line of storms that clogged runways at airports across the Midwest and South, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Social Security Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. and Its Leader Are Popular With Poles
description: Like many Poles, Wladyslaw Rancman spent some time in the United States. His favorite idiomatic expression, in entertainingly warped Chicagoese, appears to be ''by the way.'' As in: ''His father is more smart, by the way.''

title: Congressman Seeks Hearing On Bush Aide
description: Turning the tables on Republicans who spent eight years investigating the Clinton White House, the ranking Democrat on the House Government Reform Committee has demanded details of dealings that Karl Rove, President Bush's senior adviser, had with a variety of companies in which he was an investor.

title: Heart Goes Only So Far
description: The Philadelphia 76ers had been at their best this season when desperate, and, facing elimination from the N.B.A. finals tonight, there was no more urgent moment than this one.
