title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies yesterday with an article about tuition-based prekindergarten classes in 15 Chicago public schools was published in error. It showed children and a teacher at the Von Humboldt Child Parent Center in Chicago, which is not among the participating schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ROSALIND
description: KATZ-Rosalind. On June 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother of Toni Katz. Dear sister of Sylvia Barash. Graveside services Sunday.

title: Even Torre May Lack Job Security
description: Simply pondering that it could happen is shocking. Not even George Steinbrenner could be so bold, so crazed. Could he? There is no way Steinbrenner could let go Joe Torre as manager of the Yankees after Torre has helped them snatch four World Series titles in the past five years. Is there? The scenario is not as ludicrous as it sounds.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Council Extends Congo Mission
description: The Security Council extended the peacekeeping mission in Congo for another year, buoyed by a cease-fire that has lasted four months and small but steady steps toward settling the issues that brought half a dozen nations into the war. There are 2,400 United Nations monitors and peacekeeping troops in Congo, and more may be sent if the situation continues to improve. A force of up to 5,537 has been authorized.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Help For Migrants
description: American and Mexican officials agreed at a meeting in Tucson to measures to aid migrants trapped in dangerous conditions along the border and to prosecute smugglers. The measures, including better mapping of remote desert areas, increased patrols and better cooperation between Mexican and American officials, came in response to the deaths in May of 14 Mexicans abandoned by smugglers in an Arizona desert. The United States Border Patrol said it would temporarily assign three more helicopters to Arizona and move more than 50 agents to areas near danger zones. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BENJAMIN H.
description: BROWN-Benjamin H. Of Cambridge, June 12. Beloved husband of Marguerite D. Brown. Father of Timothy B. Brown of Beirut, Lebanon. Stepfather of Elspeth MacDonald and Mark Woodcock of New York. Also survived by two grandchildren and four step grandchildren. Memorial service at a future date. Donations to a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Bush's Vision: 'We Will Not Trade Away the Fate of Free European Peoples'
description: Following is an excerpt from a speech by President Bush yesterday at the Warsaw University Library in Poland, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Running for Office, One Door at a Time
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Learning Network Files for Chapter 11
description: Caliber Learning Network Inc., the online training provider backed by Sylvan Learning Systems Inc., filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors because of continuing losses and mounting debts.

title: Dennis Puleston, 95, Environmental Leader
description: Dennis Puleston, a naturalist, boat designer and yachtsman who, as founding chairman of the Environmental Defense Fund, played a leading role in getting the insecticide DDT banned in the United States and many other countries, died June 8 at his home in Brookhaven, N.Y. He was 95.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS FALL 2.6%. Soybeans fell as forecasts for warm, wet weather in the Midwest improved prospects for a bumper crop this year. Soybeans for July delivery fell 12.25 cents, to $4.585 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: I'm Running for Office. Don't Bite Me.
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Six Nations Tighten Ties
description: The leaders of China, Russia and four Central Asian nations agreed to increase trade and investment and have stronger security ties. Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan joined China and Russia to form the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, replacing a loosely knit forum set up in 1996 to resolve border disputes and fight rising Islamic militancy. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Article 2001061692043707861 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRY, CAROL BERNSTEIN
description: FERRY-Carol Bernstein. The board and staff of the A.J. Muste Memorial Institute mourns the passing of this gracious woman and, with her late husband, Ping, was one of our original supporters. Our deepest condolences to her family and friends.

title: Genocide on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: 10-Year-Old's Crime Tests Limits of Megan's Law
description: J. G., as he is identified by New Jersey's courts, is 16, trying to finish high school and hoping to clear his record of something he did when he was 10. But that may be impossible, because J. G. committed a sex offense, and for sex offenders the rules are different.

title: Lyme Disease, Fear and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Use Of Islamic Law Widens
description: An 11th northern state, Bauchi, began carrying out strict Islamic law, or Shariah, after appointing 63 Islamic judges yesterday. Almost a third of the country's 36 states now use Shariah, which is not recognized by the federal government.

title: Florida Voting Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the two architectural firms chosen to design a master plan for an East River tract misstated the name and affiliation of a building designed by Peter Eisenman. It is the Aronoff Center for Design and Art at the University of Cincinnati, not the Aronoff Center at the University of Ohio in Cincinnati.

title: Investing; The Planners Pounce on the Tax Cut
description: EVEN before President Bush signed the tax-cut law on June 7, financial services companies began deluging investors with advice on how they should change their planning.

title: Another Obituary on Ladies' Mile
description: MARY G. CLOSE was a woman of substance. A woman who more often than not wore a thick string of pearls. A woman who set two forks for dinner on weekdays, and took a single-malt scotch at sundown until her 94th year.

title: Watching Grass Grow, a Suburban Pursuit
description: ONE day, soon after James Barszcz moved into his house in Maplewood, a car with the town seal emblazoned on it pulled up and a man got out. ''He kind of swaggered over and said, 'I think you should trim those hedges and cut your grass a little closer,' '' Mr. Barszcz said.

title: Life With Father Isn't What It Used to Be; Unwed Dad: Marriage Is Just a Maybe
description: WHEN my girlfriend of only six months pulled me into her bathroom and showed me the telltale second pink line on a home pregnancy test, the last thing either of us thought about was marriage. We were still disentangling ourselves from recent exes, other marriage proposals (hers) and various bad habits (mine). Our thoughts ran toward, Are we even going to have this baby? How can we? Are we ready for this?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAITZNER, MORRIS
description: WAITZNER-Morris. September 17, 1914-June 3, 2001. Loving husband of Sonja. Beloved father of Steven. Dearest brother of Rose Behr.

title: A Range of a Chef's Skill Put on Display
description: VIROT

title: Article 2001061793267793440 -- No Title
description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: CODE OF THE WEST By Aaron Latham. Simon & Schuster, $26.

title: In Small-Town America, A Big Media Market
description: MOST media moguls have built their empires on metropolitan dreams. Daniel Hammond is aiming to make it big by reaching the nearly 40 million Americans -- like those in this town of 3,000 east of Cincinnati -- who are served by small-town newspapers.

title: Taking a Spin With a Pro
description: PROUD of its heritage in world rally racing, Subaru is marketing its Impreza WRX to a select group of enthusiasts, though few of them will take a car to its limits. Tim O'Neil will.

title: 'Snow White' Shows a Darker Side
description: HEINZ HOLLIGER is probably still better known as an exceptional oboist than as a composer. But ECM's imminent release of a recording of his opera ''Schneewittchen'' (''Snow White'') -- his biggest work of recent years, completed in 1998 -- should help shift that imbalance.

title: It's Crowded At the Top, But Woods Is Way Back
description: The first three days were unpredictable, and the final round could be fascinating.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WATCHING Brad Pitt is always a pleasure, but it's particularly enjoyable in Terry Gilliam's wonderfully nightmarish 12 MONKEYS (1995). As a very rich mental patient, Mr. Pitt is wild-eyed with some interesting physical tics and a tendency toward irrational but entertaining outbursts; the role earned him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor. The film's lead, Bruce Willis is a time traveler from the future sent back to research the viral war of 1996 that killed most of the human race and sent the survivors underground for decades. Madeleine Stowe is the psychiatrist who doesn't believe a word he says - Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

title: Annan Urges Mideast to Make Peace Move
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, today urged Israelis and Palestinians to take advantage of a crucial moment to move toward resuming peace talks in the violence-plagued region.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ARTEMIS FOWL

title: Revisiting Film's Biggest Stories
description: THANKS to the Oscar success of ''Gladiator,'' a flurry of historical and biblical epics from the 50's and 60's have become available on DVD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, LOUISE (LISEL)
description: KAYE-Louise (Lisel). On June 16, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leo Kaye, loving mother of Tom Kaye. Adoring mother-in-law to Vivian Kaye. Devoted grandmother of Juliet Kaye and dearest friend to Lenora Johnson. A courageous, independent, sweet inspiration to all those who knew her.

title: Tall and Lonely, They Have No Eyes To Distract Them
description: JILL GALLINI'S willowy dolls are haughty looking and nearly seven feet tall. Their hair is red, green or yellow and spiky, their arms are bared and seemingly poised to move, and their bodies are bent and wrapped in skin-tight dresses, covered with thick, embroidered stitches.

title: Archive of the 101st United States Open
description: Here is an archive of the Times' complete coverage of the 101st United States Open at Southern Hills Country Club in Tulsa, Okla.

title: June 10-16; Conflicting Crime Statistics
description: Is crime up, or is it down? The Justice Department released a report saying that violent crime fell 15 percent last year, its largest drop on record -- two weeks after the F.B.I. released one saying that overall crime remained steady last year compared to 1999, and violent crime increased 0.1 percent. The answer to the conflict lies in how the reports measure crime. The new one includes simple assaults, which are the largest category of crime. The F.B.I. only includes more serious crimes like murder, rape and robbery, which are far fewer.

title: No Headline
Op-Art
Personal Business Diary: Not Everyone Cares About the Internet
description: An estimated 400 million people around the world log on to the Internet every day  a huge audience, without a doubt. But it is actually a drop in the bucket, considering that billions more have not heard of the Web or have no intention of using it soon. And that includes many people in developed counties like the United States, Canada and Sweden.

title: Complications
description: As a surgeon who has performed more than 200 live-donor kidney operations and cadaver organ recoveries, I am concerned by the reluctance of ethicists to advocate rewarding living kidney donors or the families of cadaver donors (Michael Finkel, May 27). In the current system, the donor often pays travel expenses and then loses wages and vacation time while recovering from the surgery. Such disincentives need to be removed to encourage the heroic act of donating an organ. Furthermore, payments to individual donors would in no way alter the bond I feel with these patients or my admiration for them. The suggestion that rewarding their gifts reduces these persons to commodities supposes that the surgeon can remove himself from the sacred pact of caring about the patient. He cannot.

title: Mussina's Strong Start Sets Up Happy Ending
description: The potential tying run was at second base in the eighth inning yesterday. Mike Stanton was on the mound, Robin Ventura was at the plate, and Mike Mussina would not watch. Leaning forward in the visitors' dugout at Shea Stadium, Mussina dropped his chin and stared at the ground.

title: Under the Spell of a Culture Opposite to the West's
description: WHAT is it about the idea of Tibet and Tibetan Buddhism that has come to so fascinate Westerners? Why fix on this harsh land whose religion and people are in so many ways the antithesis of all that the Promethean West represents?

title: The Year Flip-Flops Ran Riot
description: A definite pattern is emerging this summer in the form of printed flip-flops for both men and women. Rubber flip-flops in sunny stripes and animal and floral patterns (right, top and bottom, $5.50 at Old Navy), slides in camouflage prints ($9.50 at Gap) and flip-flops in Hawaiian-style patterns ($14.50 for men, $18 for women at J. Crew) all make chic footprints at moderate prices. So do mock Gucci and Louis Vuitton logo flip-flops at Ricky's drug store ($7.99). American Eagle Outfitters gets fancier with straw wedge thongs for women, embroidered with pastel flowers and vines ($24.99), and Olive & Bette offers flip-flops in camouflage (above, center, $45) and others with thick rubber soles in lobster and ribbon prints ($45). And to complement a picture-perfect pedicure, Anya Hindmarch has satin slides with old-timey postcard prints of buoyant bathing beauties and smiling couples posed in front of roadsters ($175 from www.style.com).

title: The End of the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonald, Bretina Take the Lead
description: Despite a severe case of nerves for the rider and hives for the horse, Debbie McDonald of Hailey, Idaho, teamed up with the German-bred mare Bretina and scored 70.326 percentage points in the Grand Prix Special Test to take the lead after the first two phases of the Grand Prix Dressage Championship at the team's annual Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the National/International Arts Guide on May 27 for the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France misstated the dates. They are July 6 to July 29, not June 1 to July 31.

title: PUTIN URGES BUSH NOT TO ACT ALONE ON MISSILE SHIELD
description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin cautioned President Bush today about developing a missile defense shield without Moscow's consent, telling Mr. Bush that such an action could seriously strain relations between the two countries.

title: Though Neighbors May Blanch, An Impala Will Remain Whole
description: In addition to a private theater and climate-controlled wine cellar, the Impala, a new luxury condominium on 76th Street at First Avenue, features a life-size bronze replica of the building's namesake. But it turns out that the impala is just a little too anatomically correct for some neighbors.

title: First Meeting Between Bush and Putin
description: Following are the statements and answers yesterday by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after their meeting, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, Inc. Mr. Putin's statements were made through an interpreter.

description: DALY-Reverend James Aloysius, S.J. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation Monday, June 18, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Murray Weigel Chapel, Tuesday, 11:30 AM. For more information contact Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 718-654-0500

title: The Spook
description: LITTLE AMERICA

title: Break in Talks Between AOL And Microsoft
description: Negotiations between AOL Time Warner and Microsoft abruptly ended yesterday after the two sides could not agree on the issue of AOL's strategic partnership with RealNetworks, a Microsoft competitor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALBIN, HARRY
description: MALBIN-Harry. Lovingly remembered on Father's Day and every day by daughters, Diane and Hermine

title: Chain Stores: Friends or Foes?
description: To the Editor:

title: P.S.
description: Mined is a new style book that will be published twice a year by Levi's Vintage and Red Label lines in collaboration with Tank, a hip British magazine. A pseudo-cerebral step up from magazine-style catalogs, like the ones Abercrombie & Fitch puts out, Mined hawks no wares. Instead, it offers articles on politics, music, art and, yes, fashion. Designed to look unfinished, it has no cover and a threadbare spine. What you get are clumps of pages perforated around the edges, which are meant to be pulled open to reveal their contents. There are also blank pages and connect-the-dot spreads, which allow readers to personalize their copies, much like their jeans.

title: CAR-SALES FRAUD CHARGED
description: The State Division of Consumer Affairs last week sued 16 dealerships controlled by Robert G. Ciasulli of Kinnelon in what officials said is was the biggest auto fraud prosecution in state history. The suit involves complaints by 286 consumers since 1995, alleging 500 instances of 42 types of violations of state and federal laws, ranging from bait-and-switch tactics to misrepresenting mileage. The suit seeks $350,000 in restitution and more than $2 million in penalties. Steve Strunsky

title: For Vieques, 2 Years Is a Long Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools' Difficult Search For 'Just Right' Standards; Some Ask If It's Fair to Treat All Students Alike
description: It's a kind of educational Goldilocks syndrome.

title: The Boys in the Writers' Room
description: EVER since Ellen Morgan -- and the actress who played her, Ellen DeGeneres -- announced to the world four years ago that they were lesbians, gay characters have been popping up in the homes, offices and coffee houses of sitcom America, to the delight of some and the utter horror of others. But a quieter, though equally important, shift has taken place behind the scenes, in the production offices and writing rooms where television characters of every sexual persuasion are born.

title: Private Sector; Not His Kind of Day in Court
description: Boris Becker, 33, who retired from professional tennis two years ago, has become another victim of dashed dot-com hopes. Sportgate, an Internet site in which he held 55 percent of the stock, filed for protection from creditors in bankruptcy court last Monday in Munich. Mr. Becker, a three-time Wimbledon champion, provided the name recognition, but his partners complained that he showed no interest and refused to invest much money.

title: Education Bill May Omit Its Provision on Boy Scouts
description: A provision in the education bill that would strip federal financing from school districts that deny Boy Scout troops equal access to schools is likely to affect few districts, if any, and may not make it into the final version of the bill, legislative and education officials said on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBAM, BERTHA
description: ALBAM-Bertha. On June 14, 2001, in her 94th year. Loving aunt of Aliza Adler. Service Monday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: On the Menu: Modified Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Flagging? Don't Tell the Publicists
description: No doubt, here is something that most public relations executives would not mind publicizing: 2000 was the best year for the public relations industry.

title: Sarah Treffinger, Larry Latson Jr.
description: Sarah Elizabeth Treffinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Treffinger of Verona, N.J., was married there yesterday to Larry Allen Latson Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Latson of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Michael Hanly performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTERDAM, ALBERT J.
description: AMSTERDAM-Albert J., 79. Of Key West, and Alexandria Bay, NY; formerly Syracuse, NY, born Philadelphia, PA. Son of Florence and Jules. Attended Columbia High School, Maplewood, NJ. and the U of Virginia. U.S. Army Air Corp; businessman Amsterdam Brothers; Amsterdam Orchards; Titan Tug and Towing; founder and operator of Curry Mansion Inn in Key West. Predeceased by his son Bruce. He is survived by his wife, Edith Lehr Amsterdam; daughter Carol Fornari, Brooklyn; Patsy Amsterdam and son Philip Amsterdam, Syracuse, NY; six grandchildren. Brother of Stanley Amsterdam and Shirley Notkin of West Orange, NJ. Donations to Key West Symphony, P.O. Box 774, Key West, FL. 33040.

title: L.A. Stories
description: PRIVILEGED SON

title: Television Overproduced Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Vieques, 2 Years Is a Long Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Participant in Commission Questions Article's Account
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; In the Urge to Merge Brands, No Pitch Is Too Crazy
description: THE dealmakers at the Licensing 2001 International trade show in Manhattan last week scurried around the gaudy booths featuring giant images of Spider-Man, Harry Potter and the Rock, looking for the next great marriage between household product and well-known brands.

title: Envisioning a Necklace of Green Along the Harlem River
description: Cy Adler, a retired oceanographer and urban walkaphiliac (lover of city hiking), has an idea for making a new, really big park. The concept is simple. Take all the parks strung along the Harlem River on both the Manhattan and Bronx sides and link them together with greenways for bikers and hikers.

title: Life With Father Isn't What It Used to Be; Nuclear Dad: Last of My Kind
description: AS the new census returns came in recently, many Americans were shocked and disappointed to learn that nuclear families -- man, woman, assorted progeny living under a single roof -- now make up less than one-quarter of the households in the United States. Well, not me. Viewing marriage as a sort of emotional endurance test, and parenthood as a brutally demanding, financially ruinous, yet emotionally fulfilling decathlon, I am proud of the fact that my wife, my 17-year-old daughter, my 14-year-old son and myself have been able to stay the course and remain ''nuclear'' in the truest sense of the word. Even though I strongly suspect that they all secretly hate me.

title: A Fishing Trip With an Agenda
description: IT was at Big Sand Lake in northern Minnesota, a family vacation place I hadn't seen for more than 30 years, in a rowboat I am certain I had used in the 1960's, above the sandbar where my grandfather -- my idol, now deceased -- had taught me to fish, during a moment where three generations of infrequent fishermen gloated over the size of a new catch, on the last day of our vacation, that my son, Blake, 14, first heard me swear.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLSTEIN, HARVEY L.
description: PERLSTEIN-Harvey L. Daddy Dear, our 41st Father's Day without you makes us so sad. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADBELL, CHARNA
description: RADBELL - Charna. Beloved daughter of Arlene and Larry. Cherished sister of Nicole and Jason Rabin. Loving aunt of Morgan Paige Rabin. To our hero who taught us more than we taught her, you will be in our hearts and thoughts forever. We love you. Donations in her memory to the Charna Radbell Private Foundation, 134 Harborview South, Lawrence, New York 11559, would be appreciated.

title: Chain Stores: Friends or Foes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saying 'Buy' as They Sell
description: To the Editor:

title: A Better Mobile Home
description: What is it about British writers and their success with literature for children? Alison Lurie, in her entertaining book ''Don't Tell the Grown-Ups: Subversive Children's Literature,'' offers an idea: ''Perhaps the phenomenon can be traced to the Romantic movement and the value put on childhood by writers like Blake and Wordsworth, which suggested to men and women of genius that writing for and about children was a serious and worthy occupation.'' Whatever the explanation, Allan Ahlberg's story THE SNAIL HOUSE (Candlewick, $13.99; ages 4 to 8) will take its place on the picture-book shelf of that wonderful tradition. For many years Ahlberg collaborated with great success with his artist wife, Janet, who died in 1994; together they created such delightful books as ''Each Peach Pear Plum'' and ''The Jolly Postman: Or Other People's Letters.''

title: Going Marketing
description: To the Editor: I read with a smile Lesley Quinn's essay ''Playing the Market, Internationally'' (May 13), describing her experience as a shy grocery shopper in France.

title: Article 2001061792294840438 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Reviving a Fallen Star
description: Robert Bertelson had big shoes to fill when he took over the Fidelity Aggressive Growth fund from Erin Sullivan in February 2000. Ms. Sullivan left Fidelity to open a hedge fund. That was auspicious timing, considering that her heavy bets on the technology sector had made Fidelity Aggressive Growth a top performer.

title: Funds That Focus On Truly Liquid Assets
description: NO matter how obscure an investment may be -- even one like wine, which most people do not even consider an investment -- someone will start a mutual fund devoted to it.

title: American Men Earn a Valuable Point
description: Effective support on defense by the midfielders and brilliant goalkeeping by Kasey Keller helped the United States withstand Jamaica's dangerous attack in sweltering heat and humidity to earn a scoreless tie this afternoon in a World Cup qualifying game.

title: The Struggle Of the Black Artist To Dance Freely
description: FREE TO DANCE,'' a richly resonant new documentary from PBS, shows how black dance artists honor their heritage and transform their responses to society into glorious dancing. It also challenges the conventional wisdom that modern dance was a creation of white choreographers.

title: The Nation; Sliced Another Way: Per Capita Emissions
description: European leaders and private environmental groups have long pointed to the United States as the largest single source of carbon dioxide emissions, which most scientists link to a global warming trend. President Bush last week pointed out that although the United States is the world's biggest emitter, it also provides the most goods and services to global markets.

title: A Mercury Warning Is Issued
description: SIGNS warning fishermen about high levels of mercury in fish have gone up around the state, cautioning them that they should limit the amount of fish they eat.

title: Going Marketing
description: To the Editor: Lesley Quinn seems to take pride in her ability to survive a marketing experience in France by advanced pointing and nodding techniques. I am amazed that a person planning to stay for an extended period in France had not learned some simple words and phrases such as the numbers 1 to 10, and the like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATT, LEO
description: BLATT-Leo. Died peacefully June 15, 2001, in his 90th year. He was predeceased by his brothers Charlie and Milton. He is survived by his sister Molly Cohen, brotherin-law Bob Cohen, sisters-in-law Marie and Jennie, many nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews and great-grandnieces and great-grandnephews.

title: Uncommon Scents
description: Just as scented candles and sacks of potpourri have been wearing out their welcome as beach-house hostess gifts, shopkeepers have conveniently come up with alternatives. This summer, the warm spicy scent of amber abounds -- amber cubes from L'Occitane ($22 at the chain's boutiques); amber pebbles from Ct Bastide ($30 at www.eluxury.com); and an amber ball, a carved wooden globe that contains amber crystals, from L'Artisan Parfumeur ($75 at Barneys New York). Striking a similarly stony note, Island Thymes offers beach rocks infused with fig leaf and cassis in a clever wooden box ($30 at Bergdorf Goodman).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, STANLEY
description: LEWIN-Stanley. Dear friend, we will miss you so much. Your caring, charm and warmth will never be replaced. You were the best. Stanley, Caryl Laurie, Ellis, Dean, and Cathie

title: Showing Them the Ropes
description: For teenagers who want to be a tennis champ or a computer whiz, there are camps. And for those who want to be a masked marauder in tights who bellows at booing crowds, there's Camp I.W.F. The initials are for Independent Wrestling Foundation, a West Paterson outfit that puts on pro wrestling events and runs the four-day camp for those aged 13 through 17, June 26 to 29. A. J. Sparxx, who describes himself as ''commissioner of the I.W.F. on camera,'' says campers will learn some stationary moves like arm twists but won't perform ''power moves,'' the ones that involve picking up your opponent by the waist of his tights and slamming him backward over your head. There are pointers on being a referee (hint: don't watch while things get dirty) and a manager (making threats is a useful skill). Sorry, no stage names, costumes or music. Those come well into the year-round I.W.F. training program. Information: (973) 345-7745.

title: The Fugitive
description: KILLING PABLO

title: Tea Is Served, but Not to Worry: No Bags!
description: THE British had it right. Afternoon tea can be a great restorative, a picker-upper after a day of frenzied activity. Of course, to tea purists (like us), authentic tea means loose tea freshly brewed and steeped in a heated pot, along with boiling hot water. It does not mean tea bags, no matter how fancy the label or compelling the name.

title: If you go
description: Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, Perio Point Road, Beals, Me. 04611; (207) 497-5769. Open daily 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. May through November.

title: Susan Snyder, Jason Banfelder
description: Dr. Susan Elizabeth Snyder, the daughter of Clifford W. Snyder of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Ruth Lewit Snyder, is to be married this evening to Jason Robert Banfelder, the son of Robert J. Banfelder and the stepson of Donna E. Derasmo of Riverhead, N.Y. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport will officiate at Studio 450 in Manhattan.

title: Waiting To Go On
description: WHEN the American Stage Company in Teaneck, spiraling into debt, canceled the second half of its season in March, arts executives across New Jersey double-checked their books and counted their blessings.

title: For Caddies, a View of the Racial Divide
description: WHEN Tiger Woods arrives at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison this week, he'll have no lack of fans in the caddie shack, where Woods's dominance is a point of pride among many of the black caddies.

title: REST-STOP PRICES
description: A study by two Rutgers professors confirms what is probably obvious to New Jersey toll-road drivers: motorists pay more for gas and food there than they would if they got off at the nearest exit. Jocelyn Crowley and John A. Spry did first-hand research May 17 through May 21 and found gas prices to be at least five cents per gallon higher on the New Jersey Turnpike, Atlantic City Expressway and Garden State Parkway than at the nearest off-highway gas stations. Similarly, food prices tended to be much higher on the toll roads. Ms. Crowley recommended allowing off-road establishments to advertise on the toll highways and putting more, competing vendors in rest areas. Robert Strauss

title: On Pro Basketball; Lakers' Toughest Task Was Handling Issues
description: Through all the hardship the strife between Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant, the litany of injuries, the way they misplaced their championship aura like a set of car keys -- the Lakers did something truly astonishing this season, something they could not have even imagined possible when this turbulent ride began.

title: On the Menu: Modified Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: Back in the Arms Of the Art World
description: ROB PRUITT just wants people to like him again. A rising star in the early 1990's, Mr. Pruitt was on everybody's A list until a politically controversial exhibition brought his career to a halt. Now, nearly a decade later, his appealing blend of pop art and light-hearted conceptualism is winning back hearts in the art world.

title: BackTalk; Constant Companion In Cycling Is Suspicion
description: To many sports fans, the American cyclist Lance Armstrong appears invincible. He beat testicular cancer and won the Tour de France twice, and he is favored to win it for the third straight time next month. But since his first Tour victory, in 1999, Armstrong has also been the focus of a whispering campaign suggesting his performances have been aided by drug use.

title: The World; Ssh! They're Arguing!
description: THE whole episode would have gone unnoticed if a Reuters reporter had not caught a diplomat toting a boom box into a Security Council meeting called to wrestle with long lists of what Iraq may or may not be allowed to buy. The diplomat, Carne Ross, had suggested that the slogging would be made easier by a few minutes of introductory music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDERS, RALPH FRANKLIN
description: KANDERS-Ralph Franklin. Died peacefully at home on June 14, 2001 surrounded by his beloved wife of 44 years, Jeanne, and his children. Son of Beatrice Kanders and devoted and cherished father of Warren, Beatrice Kanders Hoffman, Jonathan, Alan, Emily and grandfather to Alexander, Zachary, Sarabeth, William, Chloe and Abigail. Born on November 30, 1921 in Manhattan, he graduated from Cornell University in 1942 and New York University School of Dentistry in 1946. He practiced periodontics in Montclair and Convent Station, NJ. He served on the dental teaching staff of Mountainside Hospital and Morristown Memorial Hospital in NJ. He established the Kanders Foundation to promote his philanthropic interests in education, the arts and science. He was an extremely warm and generous man whose thirst for learning and devotion to higher education helped many individuals and institutions. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Ralph F. Kanders Memorial Scholarship at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York.

title: Kelly Lee, Hamburg Tang Jr.
description: Kelly Hee Gyung Lee, the daughter of Jung Hee Lee and Choong Koo Lee of Cerritos, Calif., is to be married today to Hamburg Tang Jr., a son of Miranda Wong Tang and Mr. Tang Sr. of Manhattan. The Rev. John I. Moon will perform the ceremony at the Beverly Hills Presbyterian Church in California.

title: Barbara Cook at Harms Center
description: For Barbara Cook, who made her Broadway debut 50 years ago and her Carnegie Hall debut 25 years ago, the music of Stephen Sondheim was a later-in-life interest. Her new CD, ''Barbara Cook Sings Mostly Sondheim,'' was recorded in February at Carnegie Hall and was a match waiting to happen. Ms. Cook's artistry inhabits a song, and Mr. Sondheim's lyrics are worthy of being lived in. Ms. Cook's Sondheim collection is the centerpiece of her John Harms Center show in Englewood on Saturday at 8 p.m. She will also appear at Paper Mill Playhouse on Sept. 25. Alvin Klein

title: The Nation; A President's Wish: Never Accused of a Lack of Caricature
description: KENNEDY was too handsome, Carter too nice, the elder Bush too bland, Reagan too Teflon, and Clinton, well, too cute. But Nixon was a caricaturist's ideal. A ski-slope nose, bulbous jowls, five o'clock shadow, and a widow's peak -- these were cartoon exaggerations waiting to erupt and his misdeeds only added to the allure.

title: Lacking a Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Elaine Schechter, David Herscher
description: Elaine Judy Schechter, an anthropologist and writer, and David Samuel Herscher, a publicist, are to be married today by Rabbi Zevulun Charlop at the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Going Marketing
description: To the Editor: I certainly enjoyed and identified with Lesley Quinn's charming piece. She should, indeed, be admired for so accurately counting up her coins in francs.

title: On Maine's Wilder Shores
description: MAINE prayed for tourism and so God created all those outlet malls in the southern part of the state, the campsites at Baxter State Park to the north, and in the east Bar Harbor with its fudge emporiums, T-shirt stores and the high-speed ferry to Canada. That is right and proper and just the way the world should be.

title: Don't Rename a Street Merely to Aid a Builder
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Hoffman, Jonathan Hyman
description: Susan Vogel Hoffman, a daughter of Anita Vogel Hoffman of New York and David L. Hoffman of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married today at her mother's house in East Hampton, N.Y., to Jonathan Arthur Hyman, a son of Valerie Hyman and Dr. Allen I. Hyman of New York. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler is to officiate.

title: Bent's Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior Discount
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: STILL CAN'T SEE NOTHIN' COMIN'

title: Matching Steps With the Bulls
description: FEW images seem so quintessentially Spanish as that of a flamenco dancer, torso lifted, back arched, arms tracing a slow arabesque through space, and that of the bullfighter in his suit of lights, cape in hand, poised before a magnificent animal. Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana draws on both traditions for its newest production, ''Mano a Mano,'' which will have its New York premiere on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater.

title: Article 2001061794111577445 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSIEN, KIA KWEI
description: TSIEN-Kia Kwei. Beloved father of Dawn Tsien, devoted husband of the late Lois Ing Tsien, and loving brother of Lily Sze, Daisy Shih and Maud Chow, passed away peacefully at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center on June 8, 2001 from complications arising from a fall. Born in Beijing, China on July 27, 1918, he became one of the earliest members of the Secretariat of the United Nations, starting out as a translator and rising to the post of Deputy Assistant Administrator of the U.N. Development Programme. In this capacity he served the U.N. and many nations of the world with tireless effort, impeccable tolerance and profound respect for all cultures. He was mentor to a host of younger colleagues at the U.N. He will be missed most for his modesty, his erudition and his generosity to all. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Saturday, June 23rd, at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Trees for the Future.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: DOCUMENT; The Study of O.
description: This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: ''Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon,'' developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was ''to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism.'' Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

title: Shakespeare Visits Duke's Palace in Parma
description: Imagine having a room in your house in which you could build a 4,000-seat theater. That's what Duke Ranuccio I Farnese de Porto did in 1618 at his Pilotta Palace in Parma. He emptied out the armory in his new house, and had the architect and engineer Giovanni Battista Aleotti build a magnificent wooden theater, covered in frescoes and equipped with movable scenery (an innovation at the time).

title: Desert Dangers
description: To The Editor: The photo of the tourists on the desert safari with Letters to the Editor on May 13 was beautiful, but painful for me to see. A very dear friend of mine died of sunstroke on April 12 on a desert trek in Mauritania. She had been camel riding and walking, and the temperature when she died was 115 degrees. She was 41 and in good health.

title: One View of Clemens
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ikea Scrapping Plans for Store Amid Resistance by Neighbors
description: The Swedish furniture retailer Ikea, whose stores are so large that they provide customers with maps, has outlets in Russia and China, in Slovakia and Saudi Arabia. But it does not have a store in New York City, and for now, it will not.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01; They Also Served
description: My favorite character from the old sitcom ''M*A*S*H'' was Corporal Klinger. Growing up, barely knowing what homosexuality was, I was mesmerized by an ugly, hairy, little man in the Army wearing large floral dresses and boas. It took a while, but eventually I figured out why he was doing it: he was trying to be discharged! The United States Army being a relatively sensible place, at least in the ''M*A*S*H'' fantasy about the Korean War, he was forced to stay. In some inchoate way, I took that to be a feature of the way civilized people behaved -- even at war. Eccentrics, I mused, aren't always threats. They can even be assets.

title: Infamous Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Nouveau, Deco And the Fine Arts
description: 'Reflections of Opulence'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVNANIAN, HRAIR PHILIP, PH.D.
description: HOVNANIAN-Hrair Philip, Ph.D. May 25, 2001. Age 81. Beloved father of Janice Moore, Joan and John. Physicist, biomedical engineer. Pioneer in medical/dental uses of fiber optics research; contributor to technical and professional journals; patentee in field; member numerous professional associations. Past president/ board member, Armenian Missionary Association of America. Moderator, deacon (many times), trustee; Armenian Evangelical Church of New York. Memorial service June 24.

title: Of Politics, Free Markets, And Tending To Society
description: WHEN President Bush rejected the pleas late last month of Gov. Gray Davis of California to impose price caps on Western electricity rates, the president used the language of Economics 101 to argue that price controls would be a dangerous interference with the free market. ''Price caps do nothing to reduce demand,'' Mr. Bush said, ''and they do nothing to increase supply.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Subaru Impreza WRX; A Wolf in Sheep's Sheet Metal
description: HERE'S a car to confound the best efforts of an auto insurance underwriter. Four doors, four cylinders, a lumpy exterior artlessly troweled over compact proportions -- on paper and in person, the goggle-eyed Subaru Impreza WRX looks as tame and safe as, well, an insurance underwriter.

title: Peace Breaks Out in Conflict Over Nobel Statue
description: A truce has been called in the war at Theodore Roosevelt Park over where to place a granite pillar to honor American Nobel laureates. After more than a year of meetings amid objections that the statue was too tall, too pink and too close to traffic, Community Board 7 has approved a location. The pillar, commissioned and paid for by the Swedish Consulate, will stand between West 79th and West 80th Streets, beside the back entrance of the American Museum of Natural History. The statue will have Nobel's face etched on one side. It is to be installed in the fall. KELLY CROW

title: STYLE; Bird Land
description: You find them in sorry clusters on almost every street corner, scavenging for food, existing on handouts, scattering in fear at the approach of a stranger -- the disrespected street pigeon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, REBECCA S.
description: RUDNICK-Rebecca S., 48. Was drowned on June 2 in Papua New Guinea when the boat on which she was a passenger capsized and sank. She was a Visiting Professor of Law at Boston College. The author of numerous papers in the taxation area, she was a ''floating'' professor whose 14 appointments in the nation's law schools and as Prof-in-Residence at the IRS totaled more than any other tax specialist. She also held a variety of overseas appointments, and was an Advisor to the IMF. She was raised in Bakersfield, CA, received her J.D. from the University of Texas, and her B.A. from Willamette University. She served as law clerk to the Hon. Charles Schwartz, Jr., U.S. District Judge for the E.D. of Louisiana. A member of the New York, California, Texas, and Louisiana bars, she practiced law in New York for six years at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. She was an accomplished sportswoman, who made frequent diving, fly fishing, and skiing expeditions throughout the world. She is survived by her husband, Robert Anthoine, also a tax attorney who frequently taught with her, and 8 half-brothers and sisters. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, Bakersfield, CA, on June 18 at 11 AM. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rebecca Rudnick Memorial Scholarship, Bakersfield High School, 1241 G Street, Bakersfield, CA. 93301.

title: Detroit
description: The United States auto industry, always on a roller coaster, seems to be swooping downward again. Each week seems to bring news of cutbacks at factories, rising gasoline prices, or safety concerns that threaten to slow car sales. But the sluggish economy isn't getting in the way of a wave of festivities planned to mark Detroit's 300th birthday this summer.

title: June 10-16; Iran Re-elects Khatami
description: Iranians re-elected President Mohammad Khatami with 78 percent of the vote, reflecting once again the desire of an overwhelmingly young population for more political and social openness. But it remains to be seen whether his powerful conservative opponents will soften. Nazila Fathi

title: Kathleen Conlon, Tyler Miller
description: Kathleen Ella Conlon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Conlon of Smyrna, Del., was married yesterday to Tyler Fulton Miller, a son of Kay Z. Miller and John Robinson Miller III of New York. The Rev. Elizabeth Vandegrift performed the ceremony at the First and Central Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Frank O. Sutton, a United Methodist minister, took part in the service.

title: Jane Cowen, Minard Hamilton
description: Jane Candace Cowen, the daughter of Ellen Cowen of Westport, Conn., and Arthur Cowen III of New York, was married yesterday to Minard Seidl Hamilton, a son of Jean Hamilton and Dr. Richard H. Hamilton of New York. William Sanchez, the village justice of Rhinebeck, N.Y., officiated at Montgomery Place, a historic house in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Single Dads Wage Revolution One Bedtime Story at a Time
description: Alan LaBranche reads ''Dr. Mouse, Bungle-Jungle Doctor'' with his 8-year-old daughter, Julian, for about the 43,000th time. He discusses his 11-year-old daughter Eleanor's plea to go to a weekend evening party that might, she admits when pressed, include boys. He slices cantaloupe in a kitchen where the calendar on the refrigerator door is packed with roller skating and soccer and chorus dates.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 13 with an article in the Neighborhood Report pages about the 70th reunion of the Hunter College class of 1931 misidentified two members. The woman at the left was Tessie Karper, not Sophie Bobb. The woman at the center was Mollie Polinsky, not Rose Apfelberg. A classmate's letter dated May 17 pointed out the error; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Investing; A Hospital Chain Rises as Managed Care Suffers
description: HARD times for managed care companies have meant surging profits for Tenet Healthcare, the country's second-largest hospital chain.

title: DataBank; Troubles Take a Heavy Toll on Optimism
description: Even for patient investors, last week was a test.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit On Police Promotions
description: A suit alleging that the Suffolk County Police Department favors Irish Catholics in its promotion practices has been dismissed by a federal judge who said the appointees were qualified for the advancements.

title: Fair Lawn's 'Steel Pier' Wins Awards
description: Anyone who didn't get to Fair Lawn High School's production of ''Steel Pier'' this year apparently missed an eyeful, at least if the sixth annual Rising Star Awards are any indication.

title: Woods Absent From Crowd at Top of U.S. Open
description: TULSA, Okla., June 16  The first three days were unpredictable, and the final round could be fascinating.

title: A House Where History and Folk Musicians Share the Spotlight
description: ONE of Westchester's oldest surviving homes, the Hammond House, is sharing the spotlight with a number of folk-oriented musical artists at a concert series through the summer.

title: MSC Plans to Write Off 4 Internet Investments
description: The MSC Industrial Direct Company (NYSE: MSM) in Melville plans to write off $10.3 million, or 14 cents a share, on four investments in Internet start-ups.

title: Chain Stores: Friends or Foes?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Home for True Film Buffs
description: IT started as a familiar suburban complaint: former Manhattanites grousing about the numbing sameness of the movies at the multiplexes, 100 screens and nothing to see.

title: Egypt on Trial
description: LATE ONE EVENING LAST SUMMER, Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a prominent Egyptian-American civil rights advocate and one of the Arab world's leading social scientists, was working in his study - a spacious one, on a quiet, tree-lined street in the suburb of Maadi, one of Cairo's most fashionable neighborhoods. The room was bursting with books, stacks of papers, family photographs and half-finished cups of tea. On that particular evening, the 61-year-old professor of sociology was alone in the house: his American-born wife, Barbara, was out of town; his son, Amir, was out with friends; and his daughter, Randa, was at her own home with her husband and Saad Eddin's second, recently born grandchild. It seemed unusually quiet, the professor thought to himself. Evening prayers had recently ended at the adjacent Victory College mosque, and the worshipers had left. With their departure, all noise, all sounds, seemed to have come to an end.

title: As Economy Sours, Divorce Rate Rises
description: IN his 32 years as a divorce lawyer on Long Island, Stephen W. Schlissel of Mineola said he had never interviewed more potential clients than he had in the last three months.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Restoring Historic Buildings for Commercial Use
description: WHEN Douglas Horst began tearing up the floor of a derelict 100-year-old building in Cold Spring Harbor that he had purchased two years ago, he found what would turn out to be one of its most beautiful assets. Under the layers of worn carpeting, plywood and old tiles, the building, which originally was a feed and grain store, had 8-inch-wide planked wooden floors.

title: On the Menu: Modified Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Europe Builds Itself Up At Bush's Expense
description: THOUSANDS of protesters chanted against President Bush during his stops in Spain, Belgium and Sweden last week, some baring their rear ends; European leaders spoke condescendingly of America's president; the European press depicted him as a cowboy hayseed. In other words, from the European perspective, the Bush visit could not have gone better.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 28 about the demise of the manual transmission misstated the year Porsche began offering its Tiptronic system, a clutchless transmission that lets a driver shift gears manually. It was 1989, not 1998.

title: Health System Weighs New Ventures
description: Six months after emerging from the largest bankruptcy ever for a not-for-profit health system in New York, Episcopal Health Services of Bethpage is considering new ventures.

title: Piazza Needs to Think About a New Position
description: Mike Piazza rose out of his crouch, pumped his arm back and fired a throw to second base. The ball landed about 15 feet in front of the base and bounced to Rey Ordez, who applied a late tag on Derek Jeter. A dejected Piazza tilted his head to the right, like someone who had locked his keys in his car, then put his hand on his hip, like someone waiting for AAA to show up.

title: Not Your Father's Soviet-Era Factory
description: THERE is a new sign hanging at the entrance of the Gorky Automobile Factory, one of Russia's biggest carmakers, located 260 miles east of Moscow: ''The Buyers of Our Cars Pay Our Salaries.''

title: Hotel Power Surcharge Spreads to Other States
description: The surcharge added to hotel bills in California, Washington and Oregon three months ago, in response to power outages and the soaring cost of electricity and natural gas, didn't take long to show up in much of the rest of the country. Hotels in at least a dozen other states have also imposed surcharges, which typically range from $2.50 to $4 a night. But it is a whopping $5 a room per night at all Marriott hotels in Manhattan, $5 at the chain's full-service hotels in Long Island and $3.50 at Courtyards in Long Island and Westchester.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBAKCS
description: WHITE TEETH, by Zadie Smith. (Vintage International, $14.) This first novel, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, is a cross-cultural stew of voices, tones and textures, as is the immigrant-filled London neighborhood it portrays. It manages to be at once a large-scale family saga, a sly inquiry into race and cultural identity and a tenderhearted satire on religious frictions. ''Smith holds it all together with a raucous energy and confidence,'' Anthony Quinn wrote in these pages.

title: So Far, Not So Bad
description: In a poem commemorating a college roommate, now dead, John Updike writes that ''he had become a learned grump, and I / a literary Mr. Sunshine.'' And indeed Updike does often seem to be lighthearted, at least in his verse; in another poem in AMERICANA: And Other Poems (Knopf, $23), he explains how he was extracted with difficulty from ''the reluctant loins of a Pennsylvania lass'' but, once out, ''resolved to have what fun there was -- candy, / the comic strips, the opposite sex, and golf.'' Like an Oxford shirt, these poems (many of them sonnets) are lightly starched and well pressed, and there are references throughout to life's petty tribulations, the aches and aggravations all flesh is heir to, even if they come across as almost impertinent to an Anglo-Saxon Protestant male with a strong sense of privilege (especially one who has made his reputation examining the aspirations and anxieties of that set). On the whole, the sun is shining down on Updike's America, and almost everything can be seen in a way that's positive or at least amusing. The body, usually an object of an older writer's rage and contempt, is portrayed here as a better friend to us than the mind, since it's always healing. And when, in his series of poems about hotel life, he writes that ''the TV remote / waits by the bed like a suicide pistol,'' he makes death seem little more than a change of channels. There's no escaping our fate, of course; in the end, ''this world brave with hellos turns all goodbye.'' Until then, Updike says, a courtly cheerfulness would seem to be our best bet. David Kirby

title: West Hempstead Votes To Keep Its Name
description: After two years of debate, residents of West Hempstead have resoundingly rejected a proposal to change the name of their hamlet.

title: Can Fatherhood Be Optional?
description: Not every sex distinction promotes sex inequality, but most do. The Supreme Court denigrated parents of both sexes last week when it upheld, by a bare 5-to-4 majority, a law that makes citizenship automatic for children born abroad out of wedlock if their mothers are American citizens but not if their fathers are. In this ruling, the court refused to recognize fathers' connections to their children when they are substantial, and it took mothers' connections for granted as a fact of nature. This distinction on biological grounds entrenches unequal social assumptions into equality law -- promoting women's disadvanrage even as it favors them.

title: Amy Kurtz, Charles Lansing IV
description: Amy Ruth Kurtz, a daughter of Marilyn Kurtz of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. Robert Kurtz of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married today to Charles Bridgen Lansing IV, a son of Mary and John Lansing of Dellwood, Minn. Judith Wank, an adjunct leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, is to officiate at the Belvedere Mansion, an inn in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

description: Around Ronda

description: IT looked like a gathering of the nations two Sundays ago, on the parking lot of Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Only these delegates weren't talking global warming, but shoveling deep, dark compost as fast as they could.

title: Glick Is Back, as Embarrassing as Ever
description: EVEN if you have never heard of Jiminy Glick, the Hollywood reporter who is the host of ''Prime-time Glick,'' a weekly series that has its premiere this week on Comedy Central, you'll recognize him instantly.

title: To the French, Femmes Over 50 Are Still Fatale
description: MOMENT from a current French film: a woman in red, viewed upside down, lies on a bed in erotic reverie, caressed by two pairs of hands belonging to two otherwise invisible men. Usually, such carnal mischief would center on a pneumatic young actress. In fact, the figure in this scene, from ''Under the Sand,'' is Charlotte Rampling, age 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, MURRAY
description: GOLDIN-Murray. June 15, 2001. Loving husband of the late Stephanie. Cherished brother of Dr. Julius Goldin (Anne). Devoted uncle. Services today, 12:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

description: On the Bronx street where 11-year-old Tamiqua Gutierrez was raped and killed, members of a church group gathered the other day to pray to a makeshift memorial of candles, saints and an image of the girl's face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISSKIND, CAROL TOCCI
description: SISSKIND-Carol Tocci. On June 13, 2001. Beloved mother of Samantha and Jake. Wife of David. Daughter of Mary and Dominic Tocci and sister of Annette, Vincent and Joanne.

title: Word for Word/Hawaiian Hula Lyrics; Roach-Eaten Hankies and Arctic Winds: You Call That Paradise?
description: THE question may strike you at some quiet moment on your Hawaii vacation -- under a banyan tree maybe, when the sun starts melting into the Pacific and when a last long pull on your straw yields only the clinking of ice and a low, mournful gurgle.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01; What They Were Thinking

description: Writers' Conference

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEDEMAN, ROB
description: HEDEMAN-Rob. November 19, 1954 to June 14, 2000. Treasured memories imbedded in our hearts forever. With love from R.M.H. and Shirley Bruce, Cindy and Ray, Robert and Jason, Harriet and Ted, Jay and Nancy, Ellen and friend

title: Britain Returns to Cup Wars With a Plan
description: When it comes to losing streaks, it's difficult to conjure one longer or more futile than the one established by Britain in the America's Cup. In 1851 the British lost to a scrappy American boat in what would prove to be the inaugural Cup regatta, and history has repeated itself time and again in the ensuing decades.

title: Wines Well-Suited for Cooling Off
description: PUT aside brawny reds. Except for medium-bodied reds like Beaujolais, which is delicious with grilled hamburgers, truly gratifying summertime wine drinking shifts toward serious and breezy whites and ross.

title: Erica Lumire, Michael Howard
description: Erica Piaf Lumire, a daughter of Bianca Lumire and Dr. Richard Lumire of New York, was married last evening to Michael Gary Howard, a son of Joanne Howard and Dr. Gary D. Howard of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of All Souls in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part in the ceremony.

description: To the Editor: The article on Ronda mentions Antonio Ordez, one of Spain's great bullfighters, but does not tell readers that the ashes of Orson Welles are buried on Seor Ordez's rural property.

title: Orbitz Takes Off, in the Spotlight
description: INTERNET companies have earned their share of criticism in the last few years, whether through hubris or incompetence. But arguably no dot-com has been subject to as much scrutiny before its debut as Orbitz, the new online travel agency owned by five of the nation's biggest airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE SUEUR, JOE
description: LE SUEUR-Joe. On May 14, 2001. Man of letters. Dear friend of the late Patsy Southgate and Frank O'Hara. Loved by many whose lives he touched. ''I am lonely for myself/I can't find a real poem/if it won't happen to me/what shall I do'' Frank O'Hara, from, ''At Joan's'' 1959

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ROSALIND
description: KATZ-Rosalind. On June 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother of Toni Katz. Dear sister of Sylvia Barash. Graveside services Sunday.

title: Boys Seek Records, but Girls Set Them in National Meet
description: Alan Webb of Reston, Va., and Dathan Ritzenhein of Rockford, Mich., raced for the records, but it took four girls from Brooklyn to achieve a breakthrough Friday night in the Adidas high school championships at North Carolina State.

title: Susan Iammartino, Ross Burhouse
description: Susan Ellen Iammartino, the daughter of Eileen and Nicholas R. Iammartino of Columbus, Ohio, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to James Ross Burhouse III, the son of Susan M. Burhouse of Sayville, N.Y., and Mr. Burhouse II of Bohemia, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Shutting Down The Competition
description: IT was early in the season but national prestige was on the line in this meeting of two of the country's best high school lacrosse teams. Yorktown was playing Ward Melville on Long Island, where it had not won in 20 years, and had rallied from a 5-1 deficit into a 5-5 tie. But now all might be for naught.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, GEORGE CARY
description: TURNER-George Cary. Died peacefully at home on June 15, 2001, at the age of 63, surrounded by his family. An innovative leader and insightful visionary in the insurance industry, his integrity, wisdom, and influence will be sorely missed. Beloved husband of Kathleen Streeter, devoted father of Stephen (Gretel) and Carrie Gordon (Donald), treasured stepfather of Megan Streeter, and adored grandfather of Gabrielle, Connor, Ethan and Ryan. He is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Joan and Bob Derrenbacker of Fayetteville, NY, and his aunt and uncle, Dr. Richard and Tommie Turner of Southbury, CT. A resident of Westport and Fairfield, CT, since 1968, George was born on May 23, 1938, in NYC, the son of Dr. Joseph Cary Turner (Dean of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University in 1960) and Eleanor Purvis Turner. He was educated at the Rectory and South Kent Schools, Hobart and William Smith Colleges and earned an MBA from Columbia University. George was the leading agent at the Pierz Agency (Darien/Norwalk, CT) of The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company and recognized as an inspiration in the industry. He was also founder and president of Turner Financial, Inc. We are all richer for having had George in our lives and will hold him in our hearts forever. We will miss his special brand of intensity, competitiveness and love. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 23, 2001, at 10:30 AM, at the Greens Farms Congregational Church, 71 Hillandale Road, Westport, CT. The family requests that all donations be sent to the American Lung Association of the State of Washington, c/o of John Siegel, 2625 Third Avenue, Seattle, WA 98121. Proceeds will be used to establish the George Cary Turner Research Fund for Pulmonary Fibrosis. For more information, please visit George Cary Turner's profile on the American Lung Association of Washington's website at www.alaw.org/georgeturner. You can also contact John Siegel, Director of Major and Planned Gifts, either at 206-441-5100, ext 37, or john@alaw.org.

title: Bridesmaids To the Fore
description: June weddings continue in traditional style, as shown by three brides, top right, and young attendants in white, left. But the bridesmaids show signs of changing to contemporary fashion. A few daring bridesmaids, and even brides, are wearing backless dresses. Other bridesmaids are dressing in casual sportswear. Wraparound sleeveless tops with long taffeta skirts and Burberry bags, right, were seen at a formal English wedding where the men were wearing morning suits. And the bridesmaids at bottom right wore knitted halter tops with satin skirts. For members of wedding parties, top row left, it was a time of ceremonial dressing up.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Molly Sims; 26 Candles and a Loud Room
description: IT was a tale of two cities: one in which perfect women with glossy hair wear skintight evening dresses, and another in which young men had that ''Wayne's World'' look, with odd facial hair, sleeveless sweatshirts and baseball caps. The city of the second part had an air of ''they walk among us'' disbelief about being in the same room with the city of the first part.

title: INSIDE
description: Plan for Greenhouse Gas

title: Sally Randall Andrew Brunger
description: Sally Alexis Randall and Andrew Barr Brunger were married yesterday by the Rev. Douglas Ousley at Trinity Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: SOAPBOX; As the Belt Tightens
description: MY children have a schedule this summer that is fundamentally different from that of most of their friends. While the other children on our block are signed up to go to a couple weeks of camp here, a week at the shore there, a plane trip to Grandma's in the middle, my three are expecting to do: nothing.

title: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book
description: She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.

title: Light, White, Just Right
description: If any German white is welcome as an aperitif and with light summer meals, it's the '99 Riesling Dry from Immich-Batterieberg, a producer that created it for Mosel restaurants.

title: J.F.K. Becoming A Bit Friendlier
description: The airport travelers love to hate, J.F.K., is being made more lovable despite itself. The current case in point is the grim old International Arrivals Building, which is being knocked down and peeled away from its central site behind the control tower, where the glamorous new Skidmore, Owings & Merrill-designed Terminal 4 is mostly up and mostly running.

title: Investing Diary: At the Big Board, the Future Is Late
description: Right where, right when?

title: The Coming Of Tiger
description: WHEN the news hit the driving range at the Westchester Country Club that Tiger Woods had officially committed to playing this week's Buick Classic here, Mark DiBuno took out a yardage finder and zeroed in on the stately homes nearby.

title: The Mighty Dells at NJPAC
description: The Mighty Dells have been recording since 1956, when ''Oh What A Night'' hit the million-selling mark. Recipients of the Rhythm and Blues Foundation's Pioneer Hall of Fame Award, the Dells' tumultuous career, in which they had seven gold singles and three gold albums, was featured in the movie ''The Five Heartbeats.'' They have now teamed with Millie Jackson, whose latest album, ''Young Man, Older Woman,'' on Jive Records continues her ribald career. Also on the Classic Soul Jam bill tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark are the Manhattans, with original singers Gerald Alston and Blue Lovett, who were inducted into the Rhythm and Blues Hall of Fame in 1999. Karen DeMasters

title: June 10-16; Education Bill Passes
description: The Senate handed President Bush a victory, overwhelmingly passing a bill to require annual school testing and penalize failing schools that do not improve. The bill increases the role of the federal government in local schools, providing money to the worst ones and allowing parents to move children to other public schools or have them receive tutoring. If a school is still failing after five years, it must change its staff, allow the state to take over or become a charter school. The bill must be reconciled with the House's version.

title: The World; Suddenly in Sudan, A Moment to Care
description: FOR the nearly two decades that civil war has eaten away at Sudan, killing millions and uprooting many of the living, the United States has remained mostly immune. Another war, another country, file it away in the back of the mind.

title: No Sooner Said

title: Low on Offense, MetroStars Hold Earthquakes Scoreless
description: Octavio Zambrano, coach of the Metrostars, knew his team's offense would struggle when forward Clint Mathis was lost for the season with a knee injury, but he did not expect it to disappear completely.

title: STATE FARM
description: State Farm Indemnity Company said last week that it wanted to stop selling auto insurance in the state, citing financial losses and a politicized regulatory environment. The company, which with about 800,000 policies in New Jersey is the state's biggest car insurer, says it loses $1.23 on every dollar collected in premiums. State officials said bad business decisions, not government regulations, have caused the company's troubles. Annie Ruderman

title: Alicia Jennings, Michael Mershon
description: Alicia K. Jennings, an NBC researcher in Washington, and Michael D. Mershon, a Congressional press secretary, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Luis Len performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Great Expectations
description: One Friday, my husband and I were heading uptown for dinner. We hailed a cab, and I slid inside. On the seat was a small black rectangle that looked like a wallet, though I couldn't believe it was. What you actually find in cabs are old newspapers and single gloves, no matter what they first look like. I picked it up: it was a wallet, smooth black leather worn by use. It was packed, dense, loaded with someone else's life, and it was in my hands.

description: EISENSTEIN - Enid Rosalinde. June 17, 1953-May 12, 1977. Beloved daughter Without you No rose can grow No leaf be green if never seen Your sweetest face; No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything Be kind or fair, and you no where. Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends

Goldfluss, a former acting justice of State Supreme Court, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts in New York.

title: Power Aiming to Wrest First Place From Charge
description: The circumstances are similar to the teams' first meeting. The Philadelphia Charge (5-2-2) is No. 1 (again). And the New York Power (4-1-4) would like to be.

Millard of New York. The Rev. Alfred V. Ricci performed the ceremony at St. Gregory the Great Roman Catholic Church in Warwick, R.I.

description: WIN or lose in this 101st United States Open, Tiger Woods's stature is such that, no matter what he shoots, it's compared to the legends.

title: Fuel Economy
description: Choice Hotels cast its eye upon the pump and decided its summer promotion would be gasoline. So until Aug. 31, families reserving in advance, paying with a MasterCard and staying two nights at a Comfort, Quality, Clarion, Sleep Inn or MainStay Suites brand hotel, receive a plastic card good for $5 worth of gas. The cards are good for six brands: BP Amoco, Arco, Citgo, Exxon, Shell or Tesoro. But hurry: the way gas prices are rising, by the end of summer, the cards may be good for about two gallons each. Choice reservations: (800) 424-6423 or www.choicehotels.com. BETSY WADE

title: Private Sector; Career Spin Control: Nice Work if You Can Get It
description: When Lucent Technologies dismissed Deborah C. Hopkins as chief financial officer last month after the company reported huge losses and the Securities and Exchange Commission began investigating its books, she left with a pretty good package.

title: Complications
description: Perhaps it is those of us with two healthy kidneys who are the privileged, regardless of economic status. And the disadvantaged are those who need to rely on somebody else's kidney for survival.

title: Gardens That Tell Stories
description: I LOOK for the owner's personality in a garden, clues that can be as revealing as, say, the contents of a bureau drawer, like a curling photograph or a shedding feathered fan. What do they say about this person? The best gardens have stories to tell. I wasn't sure what we would discover when my husband, Bill, and I toured gardens in northern Brittany last July.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: SOAPBOX; Location, Location, Location
description: LIKE most Westchester moms, I moonlight, sans pay or gratitude, as chauffeur to the most demanding of clients -- those smaller people who share my last name and address.

title: Mickelson Is in Reach Of First Major Victory
description: During what Phil Mickelson described as the ongoing saga of his trying to win his first major championship, he was asked after his two-under-par 68 today what it was like with Tiger Woods not lurking on the leader board at this 101st United States Open.

title: Manhasset Divided Over Homage to Officer
description: IF there is hallowed ground in well-to-do Manhasset, it is along an old-time downtown thoroughfare called Plandome Road where veterans and other local heroes march on Memorial Day. Now a request for street signs dedicating part of the road to the memory of a slain officer the police say has been too long overlooked is touching off the kind of fireworks once reserved for the Fourth of July.

title: Habitats/Buckingham Towers in Yonkers; A Practical Couple Finds Co-op Worth Waiting For
description: ALTHOUGH Morenike and Herman Williams married last October, they didn't start living together until February, when after months of looking they bought a co-operative apartment in Yonkers.

title: At Fort Worth Zoo, Texas in Six Easy Steps
description: Since Friday the eight-acre Texas Wild exhibit at the Fort Worth Zoo has made it easy to see the flora and fauna of the state's six major geographic regions.

title: Letters
