Morey of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Brian Kevin Carroll Neligan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Patrick Neligan of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: Listings in the special summer issue on June 3 for two events at the Hammond Museum and Japanese Stroll Garden in North Salem misstated the dates. The Asian Arts Festival is on July 22, not June 3, and the Norm Hathaway Big Band performance is on Aug. 3, not June 8.

title: Lifelong Learners
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES STILL HIGHEST
description: Despite making some progress in holding down automobile insurance rates, New Jersey continued to rank No. 1 among the states in car insurance rates in 1999, as it had for the previous four years, according to a survey released last week by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. New Jersey drivers spent an average of $1,034 on automobile insurance in 1999 compared with $988 by residents of Washington, D.C., and $943 by residents of New York State, the next two highest rates. Still, New Jersey had the largest percentage decrease in rates between 1998 and 1999 with an average decrease of 9 percent. Karen DeMasters

title: Nora Cameron, Andrew Gillies
description: Nora Christian Skye Cameron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan M. Cameron of Washington, was married there yesterday to Andrew Thacher Gillies, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald L. Gillies of New York. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church Georgetown.

title: This Mouse Knows Its Owner's Hand
description: FOR many computer users, memorizing log-on names and passwords is as daunting as keeping up with software upgrades. The

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: PHENOMEN; The Smart Way
description: Americans are proud of our supersize way of life -- from our biggie fries to our gargantuan S.U.V.'s. But with gas prices likely to top $3 a gallon and growing gridlock in our cities, could the time be right for a radically downsized car? MCC Smart GmbH -- a subsidiary of DaimlerChrysler -- hopes so. It's considering bringing its ultracompact cars Stateside.

title: Letting Silence Speak of Anguish In Strindberg
description: WE are bound to each other by crimes and secrets and guilt,'' confesses one of the tormented characters in August Strindberg's ''Ghost Sonata.'' This web of anguish is a constant invisible presence throughout Ingmar Bergman's stark production of the Swedish play that opens on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Although the characters often inhabit isolated areas of a mostly empty stage, their aching silences make it clear that they will never free themselves from the painful threads of memory that link them to one another's fates.

title: Ovid in Exile
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GIRLHEARTS

title: Two Leaders: Retelling a 'Productive' Exchange
description: Following are excerpts from the statements and answers yesterday by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after their meeting, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, Inc. Mr. Putin's statements were made through an interpreter.

title: Getting Aid From Courts For Tenants
description: ONE of the most powerful tools a tenant can use to get a landlord to make repairs is a legal filing known as an H. P. action.

title: Jennifer Roth, Lauren Krieger
description: Deputy Mayor Jennifer Paige Roth of Los Angeles and Dr. Lauren Eric Krieger, an orthopedic surgeon, will be married today at their home in Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Mordechai Finley will officiate.

title: German Witnesses To German Horrors
description: MAURICE PHILIP REMY, a documentary maker, was at a reception not long ago, talking to two women in their 60's. Like Mr. Remy, they were German. When Mr. Remy told the women he was writing and directing a television series about the Holocaust, they had vehement -- and opposite -- reactions.

title: Article 2001061791850504019 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Hotel Stocks Confront A Travel Slump
description: TRADITIONALLY, the leisure traveler is the first to postpone or curtail plans when the economy sags. But this year, the business traveler, a much bigger spender, has inflicted the most damage on the nation's hoteliers.

title: Dissent, Fewer Cases and the 'Use Tax'
description: QThe day after the Supreme Court's 5 to 4 decision to halt the recounting in Florida, Justice Thomas had an engagement with some high school students to discuss the workings of the court. He stated that even when justices disagree with each other, they always state, "I respectfully dissent!" Justice Ginsburg, in her dissenting opinion, did not add respectfully to her dissenting opinion. Either Justice Thomas misled the students or worse yet, he did not bother to read the other decisions of the court. Which one do you think it was?

title: Creeping Modernity Galvanizes Reluctant Preservationists
description: For residents of 12th Street in Astoria Village, where the single-family homes date from the Civil War, the call to arms came last year. That was when the house next to Maria Corso's was sold and demolished, and a multiple-family pink brick dwelling, distinctively prefabricated in look, went up. Residents are now organizing to seek a historic district designation from the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: For Vieques, 2 Years Is a Long Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Kara Carbone, Gregory Ivancich
description: Kara Carbone, the daughter of Mary Lou and Raymond Carbone of Colts Neck, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Gregory Michael Ivancich, a son of Mary and Gregory Ivancich of Beach Haven, N.J. The Rev. Charles Wrightington performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: For Nonprofits, Ventures Are Knotty
description: To the Editor:

title: OUT THERE -- Venice; Art, Commerce and Tons of Parties
description: AS Venice shimmered beneath a pale full moon last week, it was gridlock time on the Grand Canal, with water taxis laden with American plutocrats and their couture-clad inamoratas racing from palazzo to palazzo to attend dinners and receptions to mark the opening of the 49th Venice Biennale. Also making a splash was a gaggle of more than 350 New York swells and assorted European royals, in town for Venetian Heritage, a four-day, $4,000-a-head extravaganza of private tours and black-tie balls.

title: June 10-16; Another World of Flood Damage
description: Tropical storm Allison -- which pounded the Texas and Louisiana coasts with rain -- killed 22 people, flooded more than 27,000 homes and wrought an estimated $2 billion in property damage in the Houston area alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONDRICK, ROBERT
description: KONDRICK-Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Kondrick, associated with The Times from 1982 to 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODHEART, KENNETH
description: GOODHEART-Kenneth. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Kenneth Goodheart, associated with The Times since 1976.

title: Language Lessons
description: To the Editor: On May 6 the Travel section published a letter by Benjamin Rifkin commenting on the article by Francis X. Clines, ''An Archipelago Called Russian'' (April 8), which described the instruction offered by my school, the Specialized Language Training Center.

title: In a Season of Parties, Words of Concern
description: AS soon as Robert Maher, the principal of Briarcliff High School, learned the date of the senior prom, to be held at Windows on the World, he started calling Manhattan clubs where students were likely to congregate to tell them the date and remind them that the students are under age.

title: Zambia Strives to Lure Victoria Falls Visitors
description: THE way this town has taken to touting Victoria Falls, slapping its image on every new tourist brochure, you'd think that the the spectacular waterfall was right here in Livingstone. The funny thing is, you'd be right.

title: The Cool War
description: I've had the pleasure of staying at one of Schrager's hotels (the Mondrian in Los Angeles) and of looking in at two others (the Delano in Miami Beach and St. Martin's Lane in London). For me, they were like spending time in a very pleasant dream. Lots of white expanses broken up by whimsical touches -- vases full of giant lollipops, a large-scale chessboard, fresh green apples in every room, music playing in the pool. The only negatives we experienced were that, after a fabulous dessert and coffee at St. Martin's Lane, we tried to take a photo to capture the moment and were rudely told to stop. When we apologized and said we weren't photographing the hotel but ourselves, we were threatened with a lawsuit and shown the door. A similar thing happened in Los Angeles. Perhaps the recent struggles with the W chain have caused this paranoia. But not everyone is a corporate spy, Mr. Schrager.

title: What's My Sign? A Seven-Story L.E.D.
description: The coolest thing about Gene McCarthy's job is getting to tell people what it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, ROSLYN
description: LEFKOWITZ-Roslyn. Formerly of Laurelton, New York, and resident of Boca Raton, FL, after a short illness. Beloved wife of David for 65 years, loving mother of Lynn (Steve) Axelrad and Charles Lefkowitz. Adored grandmother of Stacy (Cory) Robins, Andrew Axelrad, Marni Axelrad, Randy Lefkowitz and Corey Lefkowitz. Cherished sister of Evelyn (Merv) Shopenn. Contributions in her honor to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL, 33486 are appreciated.

title: Opera (and Language) Festival
description: On principle, Opera Festival of New Jersey's performances used to be only in English, but that's all over now. The advent of English supertitles freed Princeton's monthlong opera festival to become a language festival as well. This year's sole production to be sung in English is Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' which opens at the McCarter Theater on Saturday. Gluck's ''Orfeo and Euridice,'' Puccini's ''Turandot'' and Dallapiccola's unfamiliar ''Prigioniero'' -- a prison piece from World War II thath shares a double bill -- are in Italian. The double bill's other half, ''Bluebeard's Castle'' by Bartok, is in Hungarian. Leslie Kandell

title: Father's Day Labor
description: FATHER'S DAY? It's really no big deal to Tony Sosa, 28, who admits, ''I was always a bit of a mama's boy.'' Mr. Sosa, a Mount Kisco resident by way of Los Angeles by way of Mexico, is waiting for a van to pull over and offer him a day's work.

title: Is It the Traffic or the Black Hats?
description: WHEN Rabbi Yoseph Geisinsky learned seven years ago that an 8.74-acre slice of sloping waterfront property in this village was being sold at auction, he thought it would be the perfect place to plant the vast synagogue, school and cultural complex he envisioned.

title: South Korea Nudges North Toward New Talks
description: CHEJU, South Korea, June 16  In an idyllic atmosphere far removed from the political wars of the capital, President Kim Dae Jung today got the kind of endorsements he wanted for an inter-Korean peace effort that is at risk of stagnating.

title: The Cool War
description: Ian Schrager's planned Astor Place Hotel looks like something the great Spanish architect Antonio Gaudi (1852-1926) might have designed. Gaudi drew inspiration from tree trunks, and Schrager's hotel resembles a monumental, tessellated tree trunk, rent by a fissure in the earth and nicked at the top by lightning. From a distance, the windows suggest a Gaudian mosaic of glass fragments.

title: Country's Bumpy Road to Broadway
description: WHEN Reba McEntire leaves the cast of ''Annie Get Your Gun'' this Friday, Broadway will bid a wistful farewell to its first genuine sweetheart of the rodeo. Other country singers have starred on Broadway -- most notably, Mac Davis and Larry Gatlin, who took over the title role in the 1991 ''Will Rogers Follies.'' But Ms. McEntire is the first to turn in a legendary star performance in the grand, stentorian tradition of Ethel Merman, who originated the role of Annie Oakley.

title: Morgan Maintains His Lead At Instinet After Rain Delay
description: The first time rain and lightning visited the Tournament Players Club at Jasna Polana in Princeton, N.J., yesterday, Gil Morgan had to wait out a delay of 53 minutes, pondering his first big mistake of the Senior PGA Tour's Instinet Classic.

title: Dining Out; A View, and Portions Big Enough to Share
description: IF location determines the success of a restaurant, Sunset Cove has it made. The indoor restaurant with a wide patio occupies an apron of land at the Hudson River's very edge and within a strong throw of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Chains of Love
description: THE RIGHTS OF DESIRE

title: The Art Of Lounging
description: With so many Manhattan artists moving to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it seems only fitting that a bit of Williamsburg should move into Manhattan's art district. Open, a new lounge at 11th Avenue and 22nd Street, was inspired by the mellow parties that go on late at night in the converted Brooklyn warehouses colonized by artists. ''We would hang out with our friend D.J. Victor Calderone, who's one of the investors, and his loft felt so homey and relaxed, we thought it would make a great bar,'' said Greg Malpy, an owner of the lounge. Open has a sleek retro look influenced by Scandinavian modern design and Expo 67 in Montreal. (One of the owners is Canadian.) The floor is poured concrete, the bar is laminated blond wood, and the ''living room'' has a spare red seating system and metal cocktail tables on which Bjork, a neighbor, has been known to tap out tunes. In further keeping with the Williamsburg vibe, drink prices are low for Manhattan ($7 for cosmos; $5 for beer), and the tunes are ambient lounge. On warm evenings, floor-to-ceiling glass walls slide open onto the street. It is already becoming a must stop on the gallery circuit.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Broadway-Flushing, Queens; Gracious and Diverse, With Good Schools
description: A QUIET residential enclave just north of busy Northern Boulevard and not far from the commercial whirl of downtown Flushing, the Broadway-Flushing neighborhood of Queens is known for large gracious houses set behind spacious front lawns, sidewalks that are shaded by a profusion of maple, oak, tulip trees and beech, and residents determined to keep their neighborhood intact.

title: HOPE FOR CAMDEN
description: A report made public last week by a foundation that focuses on disadvantaged families and youth found that Camden, though blighted and suffering from numerous ills, could recover by taking a comprehensive, long-range approach and tapping regional resources. ''While Camden's situation is difficult and complicated, it is not necessarily hopeless,'' stated the report, the result of a three-month study conducted for the Annie Casey Foundation, based in Baltimore, by the McKinsey & Company consulting firm. The report recommended eliminating the city's structural deficit, encouraging private-sector investment, public financing to rebuild the infrastructure and strengthen local government. Jill P. Capuzzo

title: Shoreham Energy Plant Is No Done Deal
description: It is time that LIPA stopped all of this piecemeal plant-building and siting and exploitation of the financial difficulties of certain communities while compromising the health, safety and quality of life of the communities' residents. It is time for the fossilized plans of the past to be put aside along with the fossil fuel plants, and for new, alternative, renewable, clean, safe energy sources to be invested in and developed.

title: June 10-16; Easing Mideast Strife
description: After nearly a week in the Middle East, the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, won Israeli and Palestinian acceptance of a plan that aims to cement a fragile cease-fire. Both sides are skeptical of each other's intentions and doubt the truce will last. But Israel began pulling back some tanks and loosening some restrictions on Palestinian movement, and the Palestinians began restraining gunmen and putting out the word that the cease-fire should be honored. Violent incidents continued but declined. Deborah Sontag

title: INVESTING WITH/Robert A. Schwarzkopf And Sandi L. Gleason; Kayne Anderson Rudnick Small-Mid Cap Fund
description: AMERICA'S biggest blue-chip companies were once small businesses -- the kind that Robert A. Schwarzkopf and Sandi L. Gleason want for their $69.2 million Kayne Anderson Rudnick Small-Mid Cap fund.

title: Broker Helps Families With Autistic Children
description: Four years ago, Susan Berman and her husband, Neil, decided to move their family from northern Westchester closer to Manhattan to shorten Mr. Berman's commute. Like most families, they were not only looking for a new home, but also a new school district. But finding the right one was complicated because their son, Eric, has autistic spectrum disorder, which means he needs speech and occupational therapy.

title: Complications
description: Not one of the patients described in Michael Finkel's article was in danger of dying. In each case the choice to pursue the option of buying an organ from a poor person was based on a perceived quality-of-life issue. In each, there were sound medical reasons for continuing dialysis permanently or while waiting for a cadaver kidney.

title: SETON HALL FIRE
description: Acting Essex County Prosecutor Donald C. Campolo announced last week that investigators believe the deadly Seton Hall dormitory fire in January 2000 was intentionally set and that his office is likely to file charges of arson and homicide. Tests confirmed the theory that a paper banner was set on fire, he said. The fire, on the third floor of Boland Hall on Seton Hall's South Orange campus, killed 3 freshmen and injured 58 other students. Mr. Campolo did not identify any suspects. John Holl

title: A First for I.B.M: On-Site Day Care
description: CELESTINA BEAKES looked like a cherub as she napped in her crib at the Country Children's Center here, a vision of serene babyhood.

title: A Company Tested And Found Wanting
description: THE money pit that was once the telecommunications industry became a yawning crater last week. On Friday, Nortel Networks, a company that only a year ago epitomized stock market glamour, said a significant reduction in purchases of its equipment would result in a $19.2 billion loss in the second quarter.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about river trails for kayaking and canoeing misstated the name of a river that will be part of an extensive trail starting next summer. It is the Still River, not the Sill.

title: Bringing Dad Up to Speed
description: AROUND 1971, Bill Gates was trying to explain the fixation that would become his career to his dad. ''The word 'software' appeared in our family vocabulary when he was 12,'' said William H. Gates Sr., a lawyer, who runs his son's charitable foundation. ''I didn't have the slightest idea what he was talking about. I still don't understand it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JUDITH HOFFMAN
description: GREENBERG-Judith Hoffman. Born 1920 in Chicago. Died on June 14. University of Chicago class of '47. She lived 50 years in Greenwich Village. Daughter of the late Dr. I.M. Greenberg and Claire Hoffman, sister of the late Suzanne Paul. Survived by her brother and sister-in-law Dr. Nathaniel and Anita Greenberg, four nieces Deborah of Anchorage, AK, Rachael Gross of Evanston, IL, Sharon & Rebecca of Chicago, two nephews Stephen Paul of Sacramento, CA., and Jonathan Paul of Garrett Park, MD, three grand nephews and one grand niece. She was active in civil rights, environmental and landlord-tenant issues.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Shakespeare Visits Duke's Palace in Parma

title: The Nation; As Crime Ebbs, Top Court's Privacy Rulings Flow
description: IN the clash at the Supreme Court last week between old-fashioned personal privacy and newfangled law enforcement technology, few people predicted privacy would be the clear-cut winner. But it turned out that way when the court ruled that the police need a warrant to aim a thermal imaging device at the outside of a house to look for patterns of heat that could suggest indoor marijuana cultivation.

title: In First Year, a Tough Balancing Act for Egan
description: In the parlor of a large Midtown home, the chairs are straight backed and the paintings museum worthy. At one end stands a white-upholstered armchair, reserved for the pope when he comes to town. At the other end, on a small table near the door, sits a four-cornered red hat, signaling a cardinal is in residence.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 3 about diversification in the gun industry referred incorrectly to an opinion expressed by James Hall, editor of Guns & Gear magazine. He said that diversification was a logical step for gun manufacturers because they were profit-oriented companies, not because that was a key to their survival.

title: Americans of Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgette Bennett and Leonard Polonsky
description: LAST year, during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day, Joshua-Marc Tanenbaum and Ann Kern were seated in the hot tub of the Aspen home of Dr. Leonard S. Polonsky, when he and his good friend Dr. Georgette F. Bennett slid into the tub with a laugh.

title: A Flurry of Fairways Takes Up Residence Around the State
description: WHILE golfers crowd Connecticut's links for another season, developers are busy planning new courses. Some of the projects will mix fairways, greens and clubhouses with housing developments. Two of the more ambitious projects, both in Litchfield County, will not.

title: A Stealthy Pursuit Of the Striped Bass
description: What is so rare as a day in June (with apologies to the poet James Russell Lowell)?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about storing nuclear waste at plants in New Jersey misstated the location of the Oyster Creek nuclear generating station. It is in the Forked River section of Lacey Township, not Toms River.

title: The Learning Game
description: Adults can take their cues from the preschool playmates Cassie, Ord, Zak and Wheezie in ''Parent Tales From Dragon Tales,'' an hourlong special that has its premiere today at noon on Channel 13. Using messages from ''Dragon Tales,'' as well as videotapes of children's daily activities and commentary by child development specialists, the show illustrates how the series' educational curriculum can be integrated into family life.

title: Pitiful, Helpless Giant
description: THE FED

title: Alexandra Parsons, Kevin Wolfe
description: Alexandra Maud Parsons and Kevin Francis Wolfe were married yesterday by the Rev. Patrick Holtkamp at the Zion Episcopal Church in Douglaston, Queens.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Demand Is Growing for High-End Rentals
description: JODI SHERMAN and David Fishgold moved into their new home late last month: a former factory on the Yonkers-Tuckahoe border that is being converted into one of Westchester's most expensive apartment buildings. The couple's willingness to pay top dollar for an apartment outside of Manhattan is representative, real estate brokers say, of a growing demand in the county for high-end rentals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTY, ANNE M.
description: CARTY-Anne M. On June 15, 2001. Head nurse of the operating room at New York Hospital. Beloved sister of Anthony and Brian and sister-in-law to Madeline. Loving aunt of Cristin, John, Melissa, Denise, Leslie, Justin and Jill. Visitation Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 3rd Ave at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Patrick's Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Diabetes Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Jennifer Ishiguro, Warren Thio
description: Jennifer Yayoi Ishiguro, the daughter of Mutsuko and Sadao Ishiguro of Gardena, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Warren Wen-Ren Thio, the son of Drs. Keng-Gii Tai and Anthony Thio of Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Barnes, a Swedenborgian minister, officiated at the Wayfarers Chapel in Palos Verdes, Calif.

title: Sequins And Roses
description: June 11: The New York City Ballet's 17th annual Dance With the Dancers, at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, raised $300,000. In keeping with the theme ''1001 Nights,'' many of the 800 guests wore Arabian-inspired costumes.

title: Gunmen Rob Midtown Clothing Store
description: Two armed men walked into a Gap clothing store in Midtown Manhattan just before it closed Friday night, herded employees into the back and took the day's receipts, about $14,000, the police said yesterday.

title: Where It's All About Liquidity
description: The well-dressed detective let out a little groan in the back corner of the bar.

title: Forget About Efficient Markets. Let the Sun Shine In.
description: IF you still believe in efficient markets, consider this: City by city, according to a new study, stock markets rise more often on days when the sun shines in the morning than when skies are overcast. And, the study concludes, the New York Stock Exchange is among the most weather-influenced markets in the world.

title: June Brides In Full Bloom
description: Last year brought embellished denim and bags in embellished straw. This year, embellished wedding gowns have made their way to the racks. White may still be the classic, but some designers are adding touches of floral embroidery, beading and appliqu in pastels and vivid gemstone tones. At Saks Fifth Avenue, an ivory duchess-satin gown from Ulla Maija (left) has three large silk peonies in rosy gradations from peach to cranberry affixed to the back ($3,800), and a strapless Empire gown by Christos has an appliqu of ruby red flowers scattered at the bust and hem ($2,100). At the Kleinfeld bridal salon in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, a narrow A-line organza gown by Marisa is embroidered with a silver and lilac floral cascade ($1,800). And in Bergdorf Goodman's bridal department, posies are in full bloom -- beaded in blue on the bodice of a Wearkstatt strapless dress, appliqud in pastels on a Reva Mivasagar gown ($1,450) with matching coat ($2,850) and embroidered in white on a peach gown by Carolina Herrera ($10,000). That's not a bouquet you can throw.

title: At This Concert, Everybody's a Critic
description: IT'S one thing to review a concert. It's another to report on it. Since the New York Philharmonic's search for a new music director to succeed Kurt Masur next year, culminating in the controversial appointment of Lorin Maazel, raised existential questions about the orchestra's role, self-definition and relation to its community, I thought it might be interesting to deconstruct the critic's role as well. The idea was to document a concert not through a critic's eyes but from the perspectives of everyone else involved: conductor, musicians and audience.

title: Death Penalty Falls From Favor as Some Lose Confidence in Its Fairness
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Russell M. Saunders, Stuntman in Movies, Is Dead at 82
description: Russell M. Saunders, whose daring stunts in more than 100 movies overshadowed even his acrobatic antics on Santa Monica's fabled Muscle Beach, died on May 29 at a nursing home in West Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Complications
description: The subject of paid, unrelated kidney donation raises enormously complicated ethical issues, but the reality is that it accounts for very little of the transplantation activity going on in the world at present. Altruistic living donation in the United States is increasing, and even living, undirected kidney donation, where the donor is anonymous, is starting in several centers here.

title: How to Run the World in Seven Chapters
description: DOES AMERICA NEED

title: Melinda Toporoff, Joshua Eisenman
description: Melinda Toporoff and Joshua Jo Eisenman are to be married in New York this evening by Rabbi Daniel Green at Park View at the Boathouse, a restaurant in Central Park. Rabbi Bernard Eisenman, an uncle of the bridegroom, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: June 10-16; Lowdown on Lyme
description: Find a deer tick on your body? Even if you live in a Lyme-disease infested state, like New York, New Jersey, Connecticut or Massachusetts, it turns out that your chances of getting Lyme disease are only 3 percent, and you can slash them to .4 percent with a single dose of an antibiotic. Other new research, released by the New England Journal of Medicine, shows that symptoms sometimes attributed to chronic Lyme disease -- fatigue, problems with memory and thinking, shooting pains -- may have nothing to do with it. Gina Kolata

title: The Nation: Blue Sky; Sure, It's Rocket Science, but Who Needs Scientists?
description: AT a news conference in Madrid last week, a puzzled journalist's question to President Bush expressed, with mathematical concision, the growing suspicion in the scientific community that it carries no more weight with the administration than do the American League baseball standings with the average Basque:

title: The Hippest Guy on the Planet
description: A GRAND GUY

title: Cruelty to Animals Must Not Be Tolerated
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalking Dr. Steere
description: Last year, Dr. Allen Steere, one of the world's most renowned medical researchers and rheumatologists, began to fear patients. It was not so much the ones he had treated, though he occasionally had to worry about them too, but the ones who had started to call his office, threatening him, claiming he was responsible for their suffering. They insisted that he was denying them treatment for an acute form of chronic Lyme disease, a strand of the ordinarily more modest infection that they believed slipped into the bloodstream undetected and remained there for years, causing joint pain, chronic fatigue, suicidal depression, paralysis and even death. Affirming their diagnoses were a growing number of patient advocacy groups, practitioners and psychiatrists who argued that the disease had become a full-scale epidemic, a modern-day plague crippling thousands of Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, RITA FEIGE DE
description: HAIM-Rita Feige de. June 2nd, 2001 in Argentina. Wife of Erico. Mother of Eduardo and Liliana. Mother-in-law of Graciela and Sergio. Grandmother of Natalie, Sophia, Magali and Denise. We love and miss her so much. Her charm and wisdom will be missed by all who knew her.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: THE VILE VILLAGE: A Series of Unfortunate Events. Book the Seventh. By Lemony Snicket. Illustrated by Brett Helquist. HarperCollins. $9.95. (Ages 8 to 12) Beware. The adventures of the three Baudelaire orphans continue in yet another lugubrious and hilarious installment. Their guardian explains the meaning of aphorism, and then sends them to a village to be raised.

title: A Missing First Hour
description: To the Editor:

title: Conferring Diplomas, Receiving Validation
description: IN their most traditional experience at the Ross School, 42 students, clad in blue caps and gowns, were scheduled to march down the aisle to the strains of ''Pomp and Circumstance'' this weekend as the first high school graduates of a private school known for an innovative curriculum and a lavish application of money.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Whitney Ostberg, Christopher Hayden
description: Whitney Allen Ostberg, a daughter of Judith and Richard Ostberg of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher Douglas Hayden, the son of Andrea and John Hayden of Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Robert Corin Morris performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: Planning Ahead, or Not
description: Many women take an active role in protecting their physical well-being and that of their loved ones -- they keep smoke detectors in their homes or buy cars with safety features. When it comes to financial security, they are less vigilant, particularly if they are part of the baby-boom generation, a survey says.

title: If Your VCR Still Blinks, Stick to Hide and Seek
description: THERE'S hidden treasure under the boardwalk in Wildwood. And on Sourland Mountain near Belle Mead. And in the brush at Washington Crossing State Park. The invasion of the geocachers is well under way.

title: Shoreham Energy Plant Is No Done Deal
description: Re LIPA's proposed new power station to be constructed in Shoreham [In Brief, June 10]:

title: A New Plan to Capture Greenhouse Gas
description: Each day, 5,000 tons of compressed carbon dioxide flow from a natural gas plant in central North Dakota beneath the prairie, through 200 miles of pipes, to an oil field in Saskatchewan.

title: Carrie Donovan chats up Marjan Pejoski
description: Most designers are sort of timid when it comes to using feathers -- a few here, some there. It is only the daring ones who go full-blown, you should pardon the expression, like this man Marjan Pejoski.

title: Ship Planning to Offer Abortions Makes Waves, but Hits Shoal, at Irish Port
description: Dr. Rebecca Gomperts, wearing a beige shawl, cut a modest figure as she ventured onto the deck of a trawler on the River Liffey, where she faced an assembly of cameras and microphones unseen in Dublin even for the likes of Bono and U2.

title: Linden Singer, Dereck Messana
description: Elizabeth Linden Singer, the daughter of Marilee L. Greenwald of New York and the late Malcolm S. Singer, was married last evening to Dereck Gregory Messana, a son of Jewel D. Messana and Philip Messana of Malibu, Calif. Frederic S. Berman, a retired acting justice of State Supreme Court, officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Baffert Suspended for 60 Days
description: Bob Baffert, who trained Point Given to victories in the Preakness and Belmont Stakes, was suspended for 60 days because of a positive morphine test on one of his horses.

title: The Global Warming Gap
description: President Bush's overseas trip has done nothing to narrow the gap between his administration and Europe on global warming. For their part, the Europeans accept the overwhelming scientific consensus that man-made gases are heavily responsible for the warming of Earth's atmosphere. They believe that the consequences are likely to be calamitous unless the industrialized world commits itself, as it did in the Kyoto accord of 1997, to binding reductions in greenhouse gases. Yesterday, they also agreed to push ahead with ratification of the accord by the end of the year. Mr. Bush questions the science, insists that mandatory reductions in emissions will undermine the American economy and overstates the obstacles presented by developing nations like China.

title: The World: Murder Inc.; Tony Soprano Goes Home
description: ''BADA BING.'' Even in Italian, it sounds like an appropriately rhythmic name for a strip joint. And ''Pussy'' still works as an incongruous nickname for a hulking thug.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: GEORGIA UNDER WATER

title: Monet's Hay
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stable Economy, but for How Long?
description: IN Russia, a country where governments and economic programs used to change with the seasons, the economy for a third consecutive year is consistently -- and curiously -- stable.

description: Annisia Rose Cialone, a daughter of Donna M. Cialone of White Plains and Paul C. Cialone of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to James Henry Cornell Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornell Sr. of Toms River, N.J. The Rev. John Graf Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Park Savoy, a caterer in Florham Park, N.J.

title: A Stylish Ros
description: If the television chef Emeril Lagasse tasted successive vintages of Wlffer Estate's ros, he would doubtless say that, in the stylish 2000 edition, the winemaker Roman Roth had kicked up the flavor a notch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, HERBERT
description: WOODS-Herbert. The Board and Staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels express condolences to Sylvia and the entire Woods family on the death of Herbert Woods. Sylvia and Herbert, a warm and loving couple, were one of the first to open their hearts and their doors to help us feed New York's homebound elderly. Bob Tisch, President Gael Greene, Founder and Chair Marcia Stein, Exec. Director Citymeals-on-Wheels

title: Time to Catch Up
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Get Into 'The Producers'
description: 'If you're Bill Clinton, we've got tickets. Ditto for Fidel Castro. But not George W. Bush.'' So says Rocco Landesman, lead producer of the hit show (The Way We Live Now, May 27). The arrogance is mind-boggling but hardly unusual. In recent years, one cannot watch talk shows or interviews with celebrities without hearing pompous comments on how they feel politically. Barbra Streisand, Alec Baldwin and Robert Redford never miss a chance to educate us unfortunates.

title: Move Again? Not This Time.
description: IF the State Department of Transportation decides to build a new Metro North train station in Orange, state and town officials are going to have to figure out what to do about 81-year-old Sylvester Salemme, who is vowing to stay in his modest ranch-style home that would be right in the middle of an access road to the station.

title: Private Sector; A Day-or-Night Flight Plan
description: His company's stock may not be so highflying these days, but Larry Ellison can soar in his $38 million Gulfstream V private jet just about any time he likes.

title: Rethink Iran Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain and Argentina Find Themselves in Tangle Over Airline
description: Few countries in the world have closer relationships than Argentina has with its motherland, Spain.

title: Sports of The Times; It's No Fun Being a Met When the Yankees Are in the Ballpark
description: HOW demoralizing it must be to be the Mets right about now. Interleague baseball has done them no favors whatsoever, giving them six extra games with a team that executes so well, particularly when necessary.

title: Seeking an End And a New Start In the Case Of Etan Patz
description: The court session on Tuesday in Lower Manhattan is expected to be so routine that Stanley K. Patz has no plans to attend. But in a tormented life, like the one Mr. Patz has endured for the last 22 years, things that hurt too much sometimes find hiding places in the routine.

title: June 10-16; Vieques Fight Continues
description: President Bush tried to defuse the nasty debate over the Navy's bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques by offering a compromise that would halt the exercises by May 2003. But the plan satisfied no one. The bombing exercises' critics, who want an immediate halt, are vowing to step up protests, while military supporters on Capitol Hill, who believe the Navy needs the site, warn that concessions will only encourage residents living near other training sites to wage similar fights. Raymond Hernandez

title: Where J-Lo Lookalikes Abound, Some Women Want No Part of It
description: Like many other places in the city and beyond, the Bronx is full of young women who are trying hard to look like Jennifer Lopez, the sexy, fleshy superstar who grew up in the Castle Hill neighborhood.

title: The Man Who Would Be Spano
description: LAWRENCE I. HOROWITZ enjoys a thriving general law practice, handling cases from house sales to homicides. He is married with two young children, and recently organized a 40th birthday party for his wife and 75 guests. He likes to putter around the house in Chappaqua when he is not working and even helped build an addition to his previous home.

title: OPINION; A Childhood Rent and Rescued
description: I BEGAN my talk with fourth through seventh graders in Old Westbury by asking the children to share their earliest memories. Many hands went up. A holiday meal at grandma's. Learning to ride a tricycle.

title: POSTINGS: Guilty Verdict in Case of Missing Lighting Fixtures; Artifacts to Return To Grand Central
description: Fifteen original oak-leaf-and-acorn rosette lighting fixtures taken from Grand Central Terminal during its renovation four years ago and later offered for auction on eBay are soon to be released from a courthouse evidence room in Orange County, N.Y., and returned to the station -- to replace their replacements.

title: June 10-16; Talk That's Not Cheap
description: He may not have Air Force One at his disposal anymore, but former President Bill Clinton has still been traveling the world with a vengeance, mixing highly paid speaking engagements with do-good events.

title: Sports of The Times; Croce Could Give Knicks Needed Pizazz
description: WHEN Pat Croce wants your attention and financial support, he at least is prepared to earn it. Grab your hand. Ask your opinion. Climb aboard the highest soapbox and lead you in impassioned cheer.

This year Anika graduated from Brearly and is off to Vassar. The five others are doing just fine. You would be proud of your legacy. Schuyler, Henry and Betsy, Ted and Jonanna, Sam and Caroline, Miles and Jennie

description: THE closing of the American Stage Company was not the only disturbing news to hit New Jersey's arts community recently.

Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, participating.

title: If Fans Stay Away, So Does Music
description: FROM here it's like watching a tennis match. Every two years, the premier American early-music festival and exhibition takes place in Boston, where the 2001 outing ends today. Every other year, it moves to Berkeley, Calif. New York, meanwhile, leads an impoverished early-musical life, with little of the music itself and few quality performers like those who have elsewhere carried the aesthetic of period instruments and performance practice to later repertories and broader audiences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, SHIRLEY
description: ALPERT-Shirley. Of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. died on June 12, 2001. She is survived by her daughters June Streisand and Barbara Grossman. Graveside service at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. on June 21, 2001 at 10:30 AM.

description: In recent years, as cellular phones have become ubiquitous, New Yorkers have been known to complain about the dearth of pay telephones on their streets.

title: Exploring the Gamut Of Contemporary Art
description: FOR the last 15 years, there has been no one dominant movement or style in visual art. The current exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art here, ''Breaking the Rules: Art 2001'' illustrates this point by featuring art from the tristate area created since 1996.

Rabbi Judith Lewis will officiate at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York, with Pandit Annand Mohan, a Hindu priest, taking part.

title: Hearing Noises Through the Vents
description: Q I live in a prewar co-op in Manhattan. There are metal vents in the bathrooms and the kitchen through which I can hear conversations and various noises from other apartments in the building. I have brought this situation to the attention of management, but it said there is nothing that can be done. Do you have any suggestions as to how this noise can be stopped or at least dampened? . . . Alana Fishberg, Manhattan

title: Life Along the Loue
description: AT various times we'd glimpsed it from the T.G.V. or the auto route: a pleated landscape of forests and farms, with flashes of rivers and steep-roofed villages. It was Franche-Comt, the region of France northeast of Lyon.

title: Liberties; The First Farmeress

title: Tension Lingers After Union Vote
description: IT came down to a vote too close to call: 119 service employees at Lawrence Hospital here said yes to joining the 1199 Service Employees International Union; 124 said no. With 14 contested ballots sealed and uncounted, it could have gone either way.

title: Milosevic Foe Is Accused Of Corruption
description: Six months after he made his move to seek independence for Montenegro, the republic's president, Milo Djukanovic, is looking increasingly embattled, with his effort to break away from Serbia failing and his personal standing under attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ARTHUR JR.
description: MARX-Arthur Jr. Age 79, of Naples, FL, a Brown University graduate, served in the U.S. Marine Corps during World War II, veteran of Iwo Jima and Saipan, he was an avid fisherman and a Specialist on the American Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife Emilie (Hyman) Marx, a son and daughter-in-law Arthur and Molly Marx. He was predeceased by a son and daughter Alfred H. and Kathryn Marx. Loved and missed by family and friends.

description: ''When you're from a reservation, you're being judged before anyone meets you. The recruiters see us from a Hollywood stereotype of the drunken Indian. They think we're lazy, not worth the scholarship.''

description: Europe used to worry about the German Question. Now it has a British Question. Will Britain at last fully commit to Europe? And, with the growing autonomy of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, what will remain of the old United Kingdom?

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 28 about the demise of the manual transmission misstated the year Porsche began offering its Tiptronic system, a clutchless transmission that lets a driver shift gears manually. It was 1989, not 1998.

description: STOKVIS-Joseph William. Happy Father's Day to the best there ever was. You gave us much love daily & you are loved constantly. All our love always, Irene, Paul and Jonathan Land

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on the market in kidneys drew mail weighing in on the pros and cons of payment for organs and expressing concerns for the long-term impact of losing a kidney on donors' health. Readers who have stayed in Ian Schrager's hotels graded them on style and service.

title: Canadians Lean Toward Easing Marijuana Laws
description: As the government puts the finishing touches on regulations that will make Canada one of the first countries to license marijuana growers, deepening public tolerance for the drug is clearing the path to legal reforms that could make Canada much more permissive of marijuana than the United States.

title: The Park as Hollywood East, With Stars Blossoming
description: If you happened to picnic with a gaffer or jog past a best boy in the past six months, chances are you did so in Central Park. The area was flooded with film crews this spring, and at least six studio features were shot in the park last month, compared to about 20 in all last year.

title: High Praise, Low Pay
description: For four years, Kim Coligan Bortner has attended Woodcrest Elementary School in Cherry Hill every day with Dan Wrinn. She likes to tell Dan that she is his hands and he is the brains.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A 'Measure for Measure' That's Caged in the Open Air
description: TO many who follow her work, the theater of Mary Zimmerman lingers in the mind for its images. Her own favorite among them -- developed, as is customary with her productions, in close collaboration with her design team -- is a room covered with the name Odette, written hundreds, perhaps thousands of times on the walls and mirroring the erotic obsession of Swann, the man who occupies that room. Other viewers recall the soul-easing spell cast by the simple lowering of a tree branch after a storm at sea, or the sight of mythic sirens dressed in flaming red.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: No Energy Atonement
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Continues Retreat From Campaign Commercial
description: Further distancing himself from an advertisement in which he appeared to criticize the city's campaign finance system, Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would ''absolutely'' accept public matching money if he were not in a position to finance his mayoral campaign himself.

title: The Breast Offense
description: Responding to Sara Corbett's article (May 6) about Kym Smythe's choice to nurse her 4-year-old twins, your letter writers (May 27) offered a broad defense of the right of mothers to breast-feed. (Several implied that it is a duty to do so.) However, the issue of breast-feeding older children is more complex than your correspondents seem willing to admit. At some point, the benefits of breast milk become more tenuous and the issue arises of whether nursing is continuing for the child's benefit or because it gives pleasure to the mother. One can disagree with recent cases where outsiders have intervened in parental decisions about nursing toddlers. However, there may be some point at which society might step in because nursing is clearly no longer necessary or beneficial and is perhaps harmful.

title: Science Fiction
description: Ursula K. Le Guin has returned to Earthsea. This is very good news indeed. Le Guin, one of modern science fiction's most acclaimed writers, is also a fantasist of genius. The archipelago of Earthsea, where wizards wield power by speaking the ''true names'' of people and things, is among her finest creations, on a par with the planet called Winter, the setting for her best-known science fiction novel, ''The Left Hand of Darkness.''

title: BEST SELLERS: June 17, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Evolution of Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: June 10-16; Paying for the Pill
description: In a victory for women's-rights groups -- and all working women who spend hundreds of their own dollars a year on birth-control pills -- a Federal judge in Seattle ruled that Bartell Drug Co. engaged in sex discrimination by offering health insurance that covered male employees' basic health needs, but excluded the prescription contraceptives that women use. The judge said that under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, ''the law is no longer blind to the fact that only women can get pregnant, bear children or use prescription contraception.''

title: Putin Urges Bush Not to Act Alone on Missile Shield
description: BRDO PRI KRANJU, Slovenia, June 16  Russian President Vladimir V. Putin cautioned President Bush today about developing a missile defense shield without Moscow's consent, telling Mr. Bush that such an action could seriously strain relations between the two countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSI, URICO M.
description: ROSSI-Urico M. Age 85. Born in Waterbury, CT. Died Thursday, June 14, 2001 in Winter Park, FL. Mr. Rossi was a Professor of Music at Indiana University from 1948-82. He was first violinist of the Berkshire String Quartet, in residence at Indiana University and Music Mountain in Connecticut. He attended Juilliard and Eastman Schools of Music, and Yale University. He is survived by his wife Hazel, daughters Paula, Lisa, Gina and Carla, and his sister Mrs. John C. (Melba) Coolidge in MA.

title: Across the Street, Newark Is Not Forlorn
description: To the Editor:

title: You Say Clutter, I Say Canopy, Let's Call the Whole Thing Off
description: Four years ago, Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge asked merchants along West 72nd Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues to remove their canopies, several of which were illegal, so she could spend $400,000 to spruce up the block with new parking meters, granite curbs and ornate street lamps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBEIN, I. LEO, M.D.
description: FISHBEIN-I. Leo, M.D. Died June 10, 2001. Psychiatrist in Miami Beach, Florida. Survived by his wife Elizabeth, daughters Karene Gruen and Anne Block. Five grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Services private.

title: Generation X, Still Undecided
description: NEARLY a decade ago, I wrote an article for a Boston newspaper about ''Post-Parchment Depression,'' the malaise that afflicts young college graduates when they suddenly realize that they are facing the rest of their lives and have no idea what to do next.

title: QUICK BITE/South Orange; Another Kind of Hip-Hop
description: Mathilda shuffled into the dark room. The regulars stirred, surprised by the sudden intrusion of daylight. But they saw who had entered, offered warm greetings, and went back to their drinks. Because at Bunny's, ''a 90-year-old grandmother walks into a bar'' isn't the setup to an old joke; it's business as usual.To celebrate his grandmother's birthday, Allan took Mathilda to her favorite place, Bunny's. She ordered a beer, a meatball sandwich and a slice of cheesecake. The staff made everyone feel welcome -- Mathilda, Allan, his wife, Jill, and even their 18-month-old daughter, Willa. Though Bunny's is close to Seton Hall University, it's not the sticky surfaces, plastic beer cups and guys in backward baseball caps that might be expected. The long, old wooden bar along the wall, the ornate tin ceiling and a string of lights along the walls create a homey feel. It's perpetually Easter, with bunny representations everywhere. Booths line the wall opposite the bar, and a larger dining area is in the back. (A separate front door leads into a smaller, more sedate dining room.) The menu features a wide range of pasta, pizza and seafood. No entrees cost more than $12.95, and most are significantly less. Like Mathilda, I had a meatball sandwich ($4.75), a pint of beer ($3) and the creamy cheesecake ($3.50). The sandwich was delicious, with fresh ground beef, rich marinara sauce and a soft roll. Thanks for the recommendation, Mathilda, and a belated happy birthday. JACK SILBERT

title: Doubts Over Radioactivity And Cancer Rates
description: I was surprised that The Times gave any credence [In Brief, June 10] to the amateurish baby-teeth study by the statistician Jay Gould and the physicist Ernst Sternglass. Here's an example of the kind of ''scientific'' claims they make. Their sponsoring group, Standing for Truth About Radiation, advised by Mr. Gould, recently charged that the Millstone nuclear plant in Connecticut and the now shut-down research reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory were responsible for Suffolk County having the highest number of childhood cancer cases in New York State.

title: Michelle Kuhn, John Burke III
description: Michelle Teresa Kuhn, a daughter of Edda Kuhn of Southport, Conn., and Robert Kuhn of Newport, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Joseph Burke III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J. Msgr. Michael Allegro performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Newport.
