description: GOTTLIEB-Seymour. Of Burlington, MA, June 9, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Buddy Gottlieb, loving father of Laura DeSimone and Roy Gottlieb, devoted grandfather of Jenna McLaughlin and Chris DeSimone. In lieu of flowers donations to American Hospice Foundation, 2120 L St, NW, Suite 200, Washington, D.C. 20037.

title: Hey, Is This a Party or a Business Meeting?
description: STUART EPSTEIN skimmed the batch of invitations on his desk and pulled out one for June 30, a benefit for the Phoenix House, a drug rehabilitation center on the Upper West Side.

title: Sixers May Face Off-Season Changes
description: When it was over Friday night, more than half of the 20,890 fans stayed around to chant praises for their valiant though defeated warriors. A highlight film of the Philadelphia 76ers' dramatic march to the N.B.A. finals played on the Jumbotron, and some in the First Union Center watched through tears, as if it were the end of an era rather than the end of a season.

title: It's Already Over for Team That Can't
description: Twenty minutes after another exasperating loss in a numbing season, the clubhouse was deserted. The plush leather recliners that swivel 360 degrees were still, the six televisions that allow viewers to watch sports highlights from every corner of the spacious room were silent, and no one stopped to read the inspirational banners on the walls, with sayings like: ''Without faith, nothing is possible. With it, nothing is impossible.''

title: Allegro con Plastic Lobster
description: SVIATOSLAV RICHTER

title: June 10-16; God, After School
description: For the first time, the Supreme Court applied to elementary schools its view that speech with a religious message cannot be excluded from a public forum where speakers with other messages are permitted. The 6-to-3 decision gave a chapter of the Good News Club, a Christian organization that seeks to evangelize young children, the right to meet in the Central School in Milford, N.Y., after school. The dissenters objected that the activity was better described as worship, not speech, but Justice Clarence Thomas's majority opinion indicated that the distinction made little difference. Linda Greenhouse

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: The Ethicist; Antisocial Security
description: Hypothetically, would it be unethical to place a security firm's lawn signs around my front yard even though I have not installed its security system? These fake 'caveats' would discourage intruders, and the security firm would get free advertising for its product. So who's hurt? James Morgan, New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Spins, Jumps and Stunts
description: Encino, that capital of San Fernando Valley culture, has opened Pedlow Field Skate Park, an 8,500-square-foot public skateboard facility that's the first of its kind in Los Angeles. It's free and has all sorts of concrete ramps and takeoff points. Open noon to sunset weekdays, 10 a.m. to sunset weekends at 17334 Victory Boulevard, off the Ventura Freeway.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Commercial Property; Web Services Take Measure Of Markets
description: A YEAR ago, some real estate executives thought they knew how the rapidly developing Internet technology was going to transform their industry. Real estate was going to be standardized so it could be traded like stocks, bonds or commodities. The vision was that a Nasdaq-like market would develop that would bring efficiency to a highly fragmented market.

title: A Roller-Coaster Loophole
description: The American roller coaster has come a long way since Coney Island's Switchback Railway, which stood only 50 feet tall when it opened in the spring of 1884. Today's high-speed rides can be more than five times as high and go more than 80 miles per hour. While nobody wants to end the thrill of these popular rides, a roller coaster should only seem dangerous. The recent death of a woman while riding a California roller coaster, other injuries on rides around the country and even a few medical reports linking subsequent brain injuries to high-speed rides suggest that the amusement park industry needs stricter oversight and that riders need stronger protections.

title: Complications
description: While generally well balanced, the article perpetuates a misconception in the statement that ''there is no evidence to show that donating a kidney endangers a person's health in any significant way.'' Reports of kidney disease developing in people who have lost one kidney are largely overlooked by transplant professionals. The need for a second kidney later in life, when hypertension, diabetes or renal disease may develop, is usually understated.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats' Divisions Have G.O.P. Smiling
description: Besides the special House election in Virginia on Tuesday, the Old Dominion has another closely watched contest: its governor's race. And last week, that race took a notable turn.

title: Making the Most of Free Compost
description: IT looked like a gathering of the nations two Sundays ago, on the parking lot of Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Only these delegates weren't talking global warming, but shoveling deep, dark compost as fast as they could.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSBERG, HARRY
description: WACHSBERG-Harry. A renaissance man who loved life, his wife Denise, his daughter Claudie, sonin-law Edward and grandchildren Sabrina and Jonathan, family and friends. May he rest in peace. We love you. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Monday, June 18, 9:30 AM.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; In Memory of a Father, An Invitation to Children
description: Susan and David Leeper are parents with their hands full, balancing two careers while caring for three children and a menagerie of cats, dogs and goats. They are usually on the run, shuttling between school, playdates, church services and karate lessons -- and the rural homestead they call Paradise Leep is a country mile from most conveniences, down the sweet-smelling roads that wind through Bethlehem, Conn.

title: Amber Rickert, Ethan Smith
description: Amber Skye Rickert, the daughter of Polly Young-Eisendrath of Worcester, Vt., and Richard Rickert of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Ethan Hannay Smith, a son of Mary Riley Smith and Anthony R. Smith of New York. The Rev. Joy A. M. Mills, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Highland Lodge in Greensboro, Vt.

title: Exploring the Mysteries of the Parrots of Edgewater
description: A colony of monk parakeets that has taken up residence in large nests in three or four trees in Edgewater can be heard long before they are seen. When they come into view, the bright green birds, much bigger than the pet-store variety, seem unsuited to the busy business district that surrounds the tiny park across where they have built nests. The monk parakeets, a type of wild parrot, have been in the neighborhood for several years. Brian Moscatello, a member of the New Jersey Bird Records Committee of the state Audubon Society, has been keeping an eye on the parakeets to determine if they should be included in the official list of resident birds of New Jersey. Mr. Moscatello, who is also director of the Tenafly Nature Center, recently talked about them.

title: Opponents of Stables Want Neither Hide Nor Hair
description: Larry Marshall said the private stable on 78th Street near Dumont Avenue where he kept his two horses, Petrone and Red Velvet, didn't have a name. ''You do that,'' he said about naming, ''and the city comes after you.''

title: A Project's Enemies Prefer Their Village Nice and Low
description: In Greenwich Village, a neighborhood fiercely proud of its low-rise character, the prospect of even a relatively small new building can prompt an outcry. And at the moment, the community is in full battle mode over a proposed six-story apartment house that Duell Management wants to erect at Greenwich Avenue and West 10th Avenue, in the heart of the Village.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: On Language; The Politics Of
description: Think of Ronald Reagan, and his phrases evil empire and there you go again and make my day come to mind, along with the derogations star wars and morning in America.

title: The Close Reader; The Best Revenge
description: Who can forget Tom Wolfe's essay ''My Three Stooges,'' published last year in the collection ''Hooking Up''? The Larry, Curly and Moe of the title were John Updike, Norman Mailer and John Irving, who had dared to criticize Wolfe's 1998 novel ''A Man in Full'' as insufficiently literary. What was memorable wasn't Wolfe's analogy; it was the violence of his language. Updike and Mailer were ''senior citizens'' with barely the energy to extrude reviews from their ''exhausted carcasses.'' Irving's ''sexagenarian jowls shuddered.'' It was a letdown at the end when Wolfe pretended he was just making a point he has made before, which is that American novelists have failed to seek their subject matter in the world around them. The point had seemed to be to start a celebrity death match.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PAMELA
description: MOORE-Pamela. Pam, you have been a role model and inspiration to all lucky enough to have known you. We will never forget your courage. May God grant you eternal peace. Abbi & Paul Neuthaler

title: Robot for Mars? Easy A Steam Pipe? Hard
description: STEVE GOREVAN is comfortable on Mars. He understands the gravity there, he knows what the atmosphere is like, and he even has a feel for what may be lurking under the surface. But parts of his hometown, New York, still make him nervous.

title: The Week in Review: June 10-16
description: Bush's European Tour

title: Susan Guerrera, Eugene McCarthy
description: Susan Maria Guerrera, a daughter of Laura Guerrera of Garden City, N.Y., and Clifford Guerrera of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, is to be married today to Eugene Albert McCarthy, a son of Cathy and Eugene McCarthy of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, will officiate at Fox Hollow, a catering business in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Jin Li Teo, Marston Allen
description: Jin Li Teo, a daughter of Hua Yang Teo and Eng Guan Teo of Dallas, was married last evening to Marston Allen, the son of Nan Allen of Summit, N.J., and the late Louis L. Allen. The Rev. Ann Keeler Evans, an ecumenical minister, officiated at One Market, a restaurant in San Francisco.

title: Boeing Plays an Aerial Wild Card
description: VISITORS to this year's Paris Air Show, which opens here today, will be able to walk around, inside, and through Boeing's Sonic Cruiser, a futuristic new passenger jet that would fly just shy of the sound barrier. They can marvel at the sleek new twin-engine plane, with its tapered fuselage, delta-shaped wing and unusual front stabilizer.

title: Decorating Company Opens New Store
description: Lanera Decorating, a company specializing in window treatments, has moved from White Plains, where it had been based since 1964, to a space nearly twice the size in Mamaroneck. It has also opened a Hunter Douglas Window Fashions Gallery.

title: Poulin Wins Pairs After a Switch
description: Larry Poulin drove Ziggy and Conyer to his sixth United States Equestrian Team national pair driving championship at the team's Festival of Champions yesterday in Gladstone, N.J. The victory made Poulin the leading candidate for the United States team that will compete in the world championship for pairs in Riesenbeck, Germany, in August.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Rare Twister

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

title: June 10-16; McVeigh Executed
description: Timothy J. McVeigh, 33, was executed by lethal injection for killing 168 people in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing. He made no final statement. Some survivors and relatives of the victims attended the execution at the federal prison in Terre Haute, Ind.; many more watched on closed-circuit television from Oklahoma City.

title: Article 2001061793277785822 -- No Title
Noise Footprint Grows, But Slightly, at Republic
description: When it was discovered last year that intolerable noise levels from Republic Airport in Farmingdale had come within 150 feet of an adjacent residential neighborhood south of the airport, airport officials took steps to correct it. The newest noise level report for the year 2000 shows mixed results.

title: Not Everyone Cares About the Internet
description: An estimated 400 million people around the world log on to the Internet every day -- a huge audience, without a doubt. But it is actually a drop in the bucket, considering that billions more have not heard of the Web or have no intention of using it soon. And that includes many people in developed counties like the United States, Canada and Sweden.

title: Bush and Putin Look Each Other in the Eye
description: Whatever happens now, for good or for ill, a new era in America's relations with Russia began today.

title: In a Place Full of Babies, A Store That's a Natural
description: Tracie Jerry, a Fordham mother, remembers the day six months ago that she stood in the diaper aisle of a local grocery store with her 18-month-old son, Bryce, comparing price tags on packages of Pampers, Huggies and Luvs.

title: An Exodus of Migrant Families Is Bleeding Mexico's Heartland
description: The quaint houses on Pancho Villa Street tell lies with their fresh coats of paint, rooftop satellite dishes and swing sets out back.

title: Crdoba Caliph's Home Displays Islamic Art
description: A millennium ago, the Spanish city of Crdoba, under the tolerant rule of the Arab Umayyad dynasty, rivaled Rome, Constantinople and Cairo for elegance, sophistication and learning. In 929, Emir Abd al-Rahman III proclaimed the Caliphate of Crdoba and a decade later, artisans and masons brought from around the Muslim world were hard at work creating Madinat al-Zahra, the caliph's adminstrative complex of ornate palaces, magnificent mosques and public baths just outside the city, named for his favorite wife.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNE, JAMES A.
description: BROWNE-James A. Although a year has passed, not a day goes by that you are not loved, cherished, and remembered. You will be forever in my heart. Love always, Kathye.

title: Hometown Boy Strikes Out on His Own
description: THE Bay Street Cafe in Sag Harbor is the restaurant equivalent of a starter house. That term is often applied to a small, charming, slightly down-at-the-heels abode that a young couple can afford to live in a few years before moving to larger, grander quarters. Four years ago, Peter and Pam Miller laid claim to the restaurant and ran it as the All Seasons Cafe before going to their present, more spacious digs on Main Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 29 about former Senator Bob Kerrey and his participation in a Vietnam War mission in which civilians were killed misstated the location of a Vietnamese island where another of Kerrey's missions took place. It was Hon Tam Island near the bay of Nha Trang, not in Cam Ranh Bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAGHER, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: MEAGHER-Joseph William. On June 16, 2001. Dear husband of Lee, loving brother of Ruth Powers and the late Robert, Walter and Agnes Meagher. Devoted uncle to his nephews and nieces. Author of ''Through Midnight Streets,'' ''The Tenement of Dreams'' and ''Tippy Locklin.'' ''He was my North, my South, my East and West, My working week and my Sunday rest...''

title: Free to Choose Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard Strehler, 76; Studied the Causes of Aging
description: Dr. Bernard Louis Strehler, a biochemist and gerontologist who investigated and described the physical causes of aging, died on May 13 at a nursing home in Agoura, Calif. He was 76.

title: Our Towns; Without a Little Dirt, It Just Wouldn't Be the Garden State
description: IF you are keeping score at home, note that the relief pitcher is taking a beating.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Sarah Maryline Moulin referred incorrectly at several points to the bridegroom's surname, which the couple will use. He is Stephen Michael Youngwood, not Youngblood.

title: A Team Grows in Brooklyn
description: ''I want to pitch,'' wails Aida, tears streaming down her cheeks. Never mind that the pint-size 9-year-old can't throw a ball more than about eight feet in front of her. In Nickelodeon's ''On the Team,'' a weekday documentary series that starts tomorrow at 6:30 a.m., viewers will discover that when it comes to children and baseball, no dream is too great - or too far.

title: Karen Nordhoff, Samuel Smith
description: Karen C. Nordhoff and F. Samuel Smith were married yesterday evening at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Constance Jordon-Haas officiated at a candlelight ceremony.

title: Publisher Sues County Clerk Over Legal Ads
description: A YONKERS newspaper publisher has accused County Clerk Leonard N. Spano of steering legal advertisements away from his eight weekly newspapers after they accused Mr. Spano of incompetence.

title: Political Briefing: Racial Issue Lurks in Virginia Race
description: The special House election on Tuesday in Virginia's Fourth District has been hailed as providing an early reading on next year's Congressional elections. That is probably a stretch. But one party is certain to claim early bragging rights.

title: June 10-16; Loss Leader
description: It is one of the biggest losses in corporate history: Nortel Networks of Canada lost $19.2 billion this quarter. The bulk of the loss reflects the accounting of the plunge in value of some of the once high-flying technology companies Nortel had acquired in recent years. The loss cast a pall over the telecommunications industry, which is struggling with an austere financing climate and a string of bankruptcies of debt-ridden startups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PHILIP
description: SMITH-Philip. 90 years old. Of Tamarac, FL. Died peacefully on Friday, June 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Doris for 61 years. Loving father of Jeffrey, Barrie, Michael and Rita. Devoted grandfather of Melissa, Adam, Rebecca, Andrew, Joshua, Zachary, Jonathan and Bryce. Great-grandfather of Samuel. Dear brother of Sylvia Rubenstein, and Pearl and Robert Goldberg. Service on Sunday, 11:15 AM, at Riverside, 180 West 76th Street, NYC.

title: A Boring Technician
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FANNIE IN THE KITCHEN

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: MISS GARNET'S ANGEL

title: This Story Has Legs. And Feet. And Toes.
description: THE Komodo dragon, the world's largest living lizard, is a ferocious carnivore,'' Bob Elliott explained patiently on the phone the other day from his summer house in Maine. ''It is found on the steep-sloped island of Komodo in the lesser Sunda chain of the Indonesian archipelago, and the nearby islands of Rinja, Padar and Flores.''

title: This Time Against Mystics, the Liberty Makes Sure It Stays in Control
description: Both teams remembered what happened the last time they played: the Liberty had dominated most of the game, but a late second-half run by the Mystics almost took the victory away. The Liberty wanted to make sure it didn't happen again.

title: For a Fighting Machine, A 'Bad Girl' Image Is Good
description: IT'S not hard to imagine Angelina Jolie as an action hero, particularly for those who might have seen the 1993 futuristic thriller ''Cyborg 2: Glass Shadow,'' her first real film role. In the movie, a 17-year-old Ms. Jolie plays a beautiful, gun-toting, kick-boxing, lifelike super-robot who runs away from her creators when she learns she's been designed for evil purposes. Though her acting in ''Cyborg 2'' is still in it's trial-and-error stage, it contains the seeds of her performance style today. Even as a big-eyed teenager with waist-length hair, Ms. Jolie had a tough, can-do quality about her, as if she didn't have to wait for any man to get the job done. She also knew, even then, how to fill up the screen with her presence. Ms. Jolie, though, had a visceral reaction to her B-movie debut.

title: In This Death Penalty Case, the Choices Were Too Few
description: On Tuesday, the federal government is scheduled to conduct its second execution in less than two weeks, after there were none for a generation. Juan Raul Garza will be put to death for several drug-related murders he committed a decade ago. One could argue that Timothy McVeigh's exceptional crime made him a likely candidate for execution in any society that employs the death penalty. But the Garza case forces us to confront troubling questions about not only the general fairness of a capital punishment system that has a disproportionate impact on African-Americans and Hispanics, but also the fairness of depriving Mr. Garza of a basic protection that every other federal inmate on death row has received.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ELEONOR
description: MORRIS-Eleonor. A pioneer social worker who retired from the U.S. Administration on Aging in 1980, passed away June 1, 2001, from complications following surgery. She was 87. A celebration of her life will be held Wednesday, June 27, at the Laura Parsons Pratt Conference Center, 281 Park Ave. So., at 22nd St., from 4-7 PM.

title: An International Court
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 17, 2001
description: Weeks

title: IN THE SHADOWS: A special report; Off-Field Hurdles Stymie Indian Athletes
description: Just below the Painted Desert in eastern Arizona, a tin smoke shop marks the entrance to the Fort Apache Reservation. With a right turn at a casino, Highway 73 begins an 18-mile plunge into the heart of the Apaches' tribal land.

title: The Nation: Weird Science; A Cool Idea to Save Earth
description: AS the nation once again reaches for an iced tea to rub against its forehead, the chat turns inevitably, if listlessly, to global warming, the artificial raising of the planet's thermostat.

title: Airport Updates Offered To Cell Phone Users
description: Information on airport delays, which the Federal Aviation Administration has been providing to travelers through the Web site www.fly.faa.gov since April 2000, is now being offered to travelers who have cell phones or pagers that are set up to receive e-mail; users simply register an e-mail address on the site. This means that travelers not carrying their computers and thus unable to sign onto the Internet can get a report on their wireless devices about an airport they are scheduled to use.

title: Bulgaria, Voting Today, Looks Kindly on Ex-King
description: The nation he briefly ruled has gone through a heated election campaign, and the former king of Bulgaria, Simeon II, has become the first monarch in post-Communist Central Europe to enter active politics, yet he still comes across as more of a regal lord than a stumping politician.

title: Taming Wildwood
description: Ocean City has its Miss Crustacean Pageant honoring the cutest hermit crab on the Boardwalk. And a race, the King of Klutz, to determine which one can skitter the fastest. These peculiar summertime competitions can't be attributed to too many gin and tonics, since Ocean City is supposed to be dry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERENBURG, SAUL J.
description: ERENBURG-Saul J. Of Boca Raton, FL on June 12, 2001. Beloved husband of Freida. Loving father of Barry (Nancy) & Steve (Renee) Erenburg and Ilene (Mark) Scheinbart. Cherished grandfather of Jodi, Danny and Brad. Dear brother of George Erenburg. Services were held in FL. Information ''Gutterman's'', 1-800-992-9262.

title: Search for Rikers Island Inmate Is Expanded
description: Law enforcement officials yesterday extended their search for a Rikers Island prisoner to the mainland and have ended the extra security measures that were ordered when he escaped on Wednesday.

title: June 10-16; Bush's European Tour
description: President Bush and European leaders made little effort to conceal significant differences over global warming, capital punishment and missile defenses as he visited there for the first time since taking office.

title: Article 2001061792325332538 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: On the Menu: Modified Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Plenty of Kennedys To Sustain a Dynasty
description: Max Kennedy's decision not to run for Congress in Boston has prompted a spate of articles and commentaries on whether the Kennedys have seen their best days in American politics.

title: Amid Dark Imagery, Elements of Surprise and Surrealism
description: IT is refreshing when an artist in his mid-70's displays more energy and imagination than many younger painters, especially when both of these qualities are well-disciplined. The artist in question is Jerry McLaughlin who is showing 26 recent paintings at MaryLou Fischer's Carriage House Gallery in Guilford.

title: A Confident Garca Is Ready for Woods
description: TULSA, Okla., June 16  Sergio Garcia loved his position heading into today's third round of the United States Open, at two under par (138), tied for fourth place with Stewart Cink, just two strokes off the lead shared by Mark Brooks, Retief Goosen and J. L. Lewis at four under par (136).

title: Mystic Seaport to Display F.D.R.'s Sailboat
description: ON Aug. 10, 1921, Franklin Delano Roosevelt spent the day sailing with his wife, Eleanor, and two sons on Cobscook Bay, Maine, even stopping to fight a small forest fire that had broken out ashore.

title: Political Briefing; Recall John McCain? Forget About It
description: About those efforts in Arizona to recall Senator John McCain.

title: Lisa Harman, G. Gooder
description: Lisa Russell Harman, the daughter of Mary-Love Harman and William Rittenhouse Harman of New York, was married last evening in Brookville, N.Y., to Grenville MacDonald Gooder III, a son of Linda Gooder of Princeton, N.J., and Mr. Gooder Jr. of New York. The Rev. Allan Byron Ramirez performed the ceremony at the Brookville Reformed Church.

title: Navy and Protesters Ready for Next Round
description: Carlos Ventura sat in the shade and watched as his brother Angel strung together a fish trap from tamarind tree branches and chicken wire. Once the fish swim through the funnel-like entrance, the fishermen say, no amount of energy will ever let them escape.

title: Court Filing Challenges Amnesty for Christie's
description: When charges of collusion between Sotheby's and its archrival Christie's first surfaced in 1997, top officials at Christie's repeatedly denied to lawyers that the company had hired to conduct an internal investigation that any improper conduct had taken place, according to court papers quoting a confidential report to the European Commission.

title: Has DiFrancesco Learned From Whitman's Mistakes?
description: The portrait of Christie Whitman hung in the State House recently is utterly lifelike in more than one respect. It shows her desk as spotless.

title: A Wider Street Is (a) Safer (b) More Congested
description: Time seems to have forgotten Columbia Street, a tattered roadway at the western edge of Cobble Hill where ghostly trolley tracks and Belgian blocks that once paved the road can still be found poking through the worn asphalt.

title: Seeing Another Age On Separate Stages
description: SUDDENLY, fleetingly, in Fairfield County, a theater fanatic's crazy dream has leaped into real time. Two esoteric plays, each charting another age, another world, are happening in professional productions on two separate stages here.

title: June 10-16; Life for Embassy Bomber
description: The Saudi terrorist convicted of bombing the American embassy in Kenya in 1998 was sentenced to life imprisonment after a federal jury in Manhattan said it was deadlocked on whether to impose the death penalty. The jury did not reveal how it was split in the case of Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 24, but noted that 10 of its 12 members had found that executing al-'Owhali could make him ''a martyr.'' On Tuesday, the same jury will consider a second death penalty case, against Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, who bombed the American Embassy in Tanzania. The attacks killed 224 and wounded thousands.

title: How to Get an Autograph (Value $2,000)
description: In the dark of the parking garage of his Los Angeles apartment complex, Michael Wehrmann, 35, digs through the trunk of his rented, anonymously respectable black Mercury Grand Marquis. A pretty young woman approaches. ''Every time I see you, you're looking in your trunk,'' she says, unabashedly flirting. ''What's in there?'' He glances at her, blushes and looks back in the trunk, at the professional equipment of an in-person autograph collector -- 3,000 unsigned photographs (filed by name: ''Robert De Niro . . . Yvette Mimieux . . . Julia Roberts . . .''), four electric guitars (you never know where Sting will pop up) and assorted sports equipment (for those days when he runs into Arnold Palmer or Muhammad Ali).

title: Two Leaders Talk About a 'Productive' Exchange
description: Following are excerpts from the statements and answers yesterday by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after their meeting, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Putin's statements were made through an interpreter.

title: Political Briefing; Preparing Just in Case Jesse Helms Bows Out
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, a conservative Republican mainstay on Capitol Hill, says he is not ready to announce whether he will seek re-election next year. But reports from the state say national party leaders have begun feeling out possible candidates just in case.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: KARLMARX.COM

title: At This Rate, Maybe Lloyd's of Long Island?
description: For the first time in its 300-year history, Lloyd's of London is selling more insurance in the United States than at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, CONSTANCE MOELLER
description: NICHOLS-Constance Moeller. On June 11, 2001. Born in NYC, lived in West Hartford, then Essex, CT. Beloved mother of Constance Nichols Detwiller and Marcia Nichols Trook, also survived by four grandchildren and a niece. Memorial service June 24, 2PM, Old Lyme Congregational Church, CT.

title: Missed Putts Have Woods Searching for Miracle
description: TULSA, Okla., June16 -- After a solid round by Tiger Woods at the United States Open, his chance to win remained slim, but not impossible.

title: Ideas & Trends: When Lies Kill; In China, the Right to Truth Meets Life and Death
description: THEY were a pitiful sight here the other day, four adults and three children from the distant countryside, wandering through Beijing looking scruffy and slightly dazed. Several were already ill from their H.I.V. infections. They had boarded a train and arrived in the capital in hopes that someone, somehow could help.

title: Elizabeth Meyer, Peter Pernebo
description: Elizabeth Susan Meyer and Peter Ingvar Pernebo were married yesterday at the Swedish Church of New York. The Rev. Jan Kesker performed the ceremony.

title: Woods Needs a Miracle After Putting Falters
description: After a solid round by Tiger Woods at the United States Open, his chance to win remained slim but not impossible.

title: For Immigrant Chinese, a Hard Lesson in an Old Ruse
description: Barely scraping by after arriving from Fujian, China, in the 1990's, Shenghua Cao and his wife, Chunying Chen, paid $800 to a company in Queens to cut through red tape and get his niece an American visa.

title: In a Kaleidoscope of Remembering and Forgetting
description: PROJECTED on a small medicine chest attached to the wall, a man's face drawn in charcoal emerges to the sound of running water. Soon the face seems to dissolve into the interior of the cabinet, and over the next few minutes strange and elliptical hand-drawn images rapidly appear and disintegrate there as well. A tiny man walking across a ravaged landscape leaves in his wake smudgy traces that morph into jars on the shelves. A bird flapping into the sides of the cabinet transforms into a fish revolving around a globe propped in a field. Phrases like ''Doomed Sailor's Chilling Note'' flash intermittently. Finally, a man rests his head against a woman's naked torso -- a less clinical form of chest that supplies comfort.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE NATURE OF WATER AND AIR

title: Catholic Diocese Ordains Six Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre ordained six new priests in recent ceremonies at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre, the largest number in recent years.

title: Backing Up the Schools On Irvington Dress Codes
description: To the Editor:

title: Look to Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients Without a Country: Who Pays?
description: ANY minute now, the men and women of Congress will hunker down to discuss prescription-drug benefits under Medicare, and the rights that Americans should have if they are enrolled in H.M.O.'s.

title: Talking Union
description: HANDS clasped behind his back, a copy of El Diario tucked under his arm, Manuel Escobar stood on a crumbling, weed-tufted sidewalk in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in April, staring across the street at a sprawling green building. Through the dark, yawning entrance, payloaders and backhoes could be dimly seen, lurching and digging amid 15-foot-high dunes of garbage as though searching for prey. Every so often, a seagull fluttered out of a swirl of paper scraps, shrieking.

title: Clare Chapoton, Ashby Anderson
description: Clare Eastham Chapoton, the daughter of Sarah and John Chapoton of Washington, was married yesterday to Ashby Danford Anderson, a son of Mary and Robert P. Anderson Jr. of Noank, Conn. The Rev. James M. Donald performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Letters
description: EUROPEAN JAZZ

title: June 10-16; Herbal Scrutiny
description: Federal regulators, particularly at the Food and Drug Administration, are intensifying scrutiny of companies selling herbs and dietary supplements. The agency has taken aim at companies for inflating the benefits of supplements, and challenged food manufacturers that put herbs in foods to prove that the ingredients are safe. The actions stem from concerns that emerging science on herbs indicates potential side effects, such as interference with prescription drugs, that are rarely on herbal products' labels.

title: Marriage of Flavors
description: FROM the specials on the compact, ever-changing menu at Joe & Maggie's Bistro, a dining companion chose an appetizer salad. On arrival it reminded her, she said, of antipasto put through a shredder: lettuces, good Gorgonzola cheese, sweet and hot peppers and crusty bread, chopped into a cheery confetti within a rousing vinaigrette.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the small 19th-century apartment houses on Columbus Avenue in the 70's, misspelled the name of the one on the southeast corner of 76th Street. It is the Aylsmere, not Aylesmere.

title: Overproduced Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Free Lodging for Transient Tenants; Baby Falcons Are Hatched Atop Tower
description: The newest tenants in one of the office towers along Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront are three peregrine falcon chicks, hatched in May atop 101 Hudson Street, which at 42 stories is the tallest existing office building in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTHONY, NATHAN
description: ANTHONY-Nathan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nathan Anthony, associated with The Times from 1962 to 1984.

title: The Word That Strikes Fear in a Neighborhood's Heart. (Sshhh.) It's Starbucks.
description: Had Gregory Vena, a young man whiling away his Monday morning in a Bedford Avenue cafe, heard the Williamsburg rumor?

title: Business; For Busy Art Dealers, the Fair's the Thing
description: WHEN 53,000 art collectors, curators and other art lovers descended on the Swiss city of Basel to take in the world's largest art fair, which began on Tuesday, 260 art dealers were there with their best offerings -- and an additional 640 wished they were. That is precisely how many art dealers were on the waiting list, said Samuel Keller, the manager of the fair, which is called Art Basel.

title: From Dead Bank To Red Bank
description: It was the mid 1980's, and downtown stores were being forced out of business by the invasion of sprawling new malls, the population was slipping and the commercial and residential tax base was eroding.

title: When Summer Movies Understood the Season
description: I GOT to interview Elia Kazan once. This was more than 20 years ago, in Boston, on a very warm day in June. Kazan said, ''Come on, let's get out in the air.'' So we stretched out on the grass of the Common together, watching the girls go by. His rough, walnut hands kept playing in the grass with twigs and leaves, or feeling the ground. It made me think of a couple of his own films:

title: The View From/New Haven; A Passageway for Fish And a Lesson in Nature
description: IN an unlikely location, behind the parking lot of a shopping center on Whalley Avenue in New Haven, the West River Fishway is enabling anadromous fish to swim upstream to their spawning grounds for the first time in more than 200 years. The fishway is also boosting the ecosystem and helping city dwellers, including young students, connect with a natural environment that is so close yet often goes unnoticed.

title: Back When Hair and Harmonies Were Slick
description: MARTY JOLTIN, who owns the Printing Store in the careworn part of Times Square, insists that he long ago tucked away his dreams of fame and fortune. But ask him about the Vocal Lords, and he swiftly pulls from the chaos of his desk a black-and-white photograph of the four teenage singers from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, all slick pompadours and genial bravura, sporting silver jackets with enormous black satin lapels.

title: Connecticut Company Seeks Egg Donors
description: The Center for Advanced Reproductive Medicine, based in Norwalk, Conn., is looking for egg donors for its offices on Maple Avenue in White Plains and on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-17-01: SALIENT FACTS; Flaming Out
description: Last summer, it seemed the entire West was ablaze. On Aug. 14 alone, 3,123 wildfires scorched 619,980 acres, sending up 70-foot-high walls of flames. Firefighting, like war, is an open-checkbook operation: Congress appropriates as much as is necessary to battle the flames. For 2000, the grand total came to more than $1.6 billion. Expect that checkbook to be strained again this year. ''Draw a line from San Francisco to Salt Lake City,'' says Rick Ochoa, the chief meteorologist for the National Interagency Fire Center. ''North of there, it could be a hot season.'' Typically, fire season doesn't get going until July. But it has come early this year because snowpacks were at about 40 percent of normal across much of the West. So all it takes is a strike of lightning to turn bone-dry trees to tinder.

title: In a Realm Less Grand, A 'King' Still Grooves
description: BEHIND the stage you can see the kitchen, where cheeseburgers flying Hard Rock Cafe flags are picked up by waitresses in very short, very tight white uniforms. One waitress wears a flashing red taillight right where you'd expect a taillight to be, and the shiny plastic disc bobs in and out behind the seven men onstage like an angry firefly.

title: Even More Riches
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; To the Rescue, Quietly, at Hyundai
description: FINBARR O'NEILL, the chief executive of Hyundai Motor America, can attend an auto show without even drawing a second glance. That is fine with him.

title: NEW ACCUSATIONS AGAIN PUT FOCUS ON ROGER CLINTON
description: On the morning of Aug. 10, 1998, a Texas entrepreneur walked into an Embassy Suites Hotel in Dallas and was escorted into a meeting with Roger Clinton and two business associates. The men wasted no time on small talk.

title: Some Free Agents Make Impact
description: Alex Rodriguez is doing his part, the one he is being paid $252 million over 10 years to do, but he is making no impact on the Texas Rangers this season. No one could make an impact on the Rangers this season.

title: Wendy Chen, Alvin Wong
description: Wendy Chen, a daughter of Nancy Yu-ping Lin of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Alvin Wong, the son of Maria and David Wong of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Bill H. C. Lee, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.

title: Honey, I Loathe the Kids
description: GETTING A LIFE

title: Berlin's Young Chefs Open the Windows Wide
description: BERLIN is not one of those places you visit with eating as a goal, which makes the surprise of its superb restaurants that much more welcome. And Germany's reunited capital is following in the footsteps of New York and London, where imported cuisines are generally preferable to indigenous ones.

title: Friends Keep Watch Over Grand Collection
description: IN a hidden pocket of Stratford where time has stood still, the antique collections of two brothers are housed in 20 architecturally odd buildings on 32 rolling farm acres in what is now called the Boothe Memorial Park & Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, IRENE B.
description: HARRIS-Irene B. On June 15. Beloved wife of Bernard for 61 years. Survived by Bernard, nephew David and niece Doris.

title: Owner of Avis and Days Inn Seen Buying Travel Service
description: The Cendant Corporation, which owns Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, is expected to announce Monday that it has agreed to acquire Galileo International, an electronic travel reservation business, for slightly more than $2.9 billion in cash and stock, according to executives close to the talks.

title: New York's Other Identity: Paradise for Bird-Watchers
description: Paul Kerlinger gets funny looks when he talks about the wonderful bird-watching in New York City. "They think New York has nothing but concrete and tall buildings," he said. "They don't believe we have any wildlife in the city."

title: A Future So Bright, He's Already Seen It
description: WHILE he was in the studio recording his second solo album, ''Gold,'' Ryan Adams ran into Bonnie Raitt. ''I know who you are,'' she told him. ''The it kid. The next thing.''

title: No Headline
Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, DR. BERNARD.
description: BROOKS-Dr. Bernard. Beloved husband of the late Hortense. Devoted father to Janice Heller, Kenneth and the late Alan Brooks. Dear father-in-law to Jack Heller. Loving grandfather to Robert Heller, Hilary and Michael Brooks. Services Monday, June 18, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Dr. Brooks' name can be made to Peninsula Hospital Center, Beach 51st St and Beach Channel Drive, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

title: Kate Sheils, Frank Taubner
description: Kate Fitzgerald Sheils, the daughter of Clare and Harold I. Sheils of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frank Kurtis Taubner, the son of Candice and Frank F. Taubner of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Msgr. Dennis P. Keane performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALAZOUDIS, NOTIS
description: GALAZOUDIS - Notis. Beloved husband of Demetra (nee Chios), died on Friday, June 15, 2001, at his home in Singer Island, FL. A funeral service will be held in West Palm Beach, FL, with the interment to take place in Bala Cynwyd, PA. We invite you to visit, sign the Remembrance Registry Guestbook and share a memory at www.Quattlebaum.org.

title: Aerin Kwait, Jonathan Taubin
description: Aerin Rose Kwait, a daughter of Stephanie and Robert Kwait of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening to Jonathan Scott Taubin, a son of Phyllis and Matthew Taubin of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at Estherwood, a house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Gordon Quite Precisely Back on Top
description: Jeff Gordon's mechanics were just about finished preparing his bright blue Chevrolet for a qualifying run Friday, but not quite. His crew chief, Robbie Loomis, strode around the back of the car and pounded on the spoiler with the heel of his hand, as if that would make the car even the teeniest bit more aerodynamic.

title: Molly Lukins, Brian Burke
description: Molly Jana Lukins, a daughter of Sheila Lukins and Richard Lukins, both of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Brian Gerard Burke, a son of Delia and John Burke of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Right Rev. Mark Serna, the Roman Catholic abbot of Portsmouth Abbey in Rhode Island, performed the ceremony at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Talk-to-Yourself Radio
description: If you had been negotiating the Los Angeles freeways during drive time a few months ago, your radio might have picked up what sounded like a standard talk-radio host laboring to turn the day's headlines into spittle-launching controversy. The host was a man named Phil Hendrie, and the story he was milking involved a Minnesota toddler who nearly froze to death after wandering out into subzero cold in not much more than his diaper. As with any media bubble, variations of the story surfaced within 24 hours, making it seem like another alarming American trend, the kind in which AM-radio hosts go headhunting for someone to blame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ROBERT MICHAEL
description: COHEN-Robert Michael. On June 14, 2001. Beloved father of Corine and Beth. Older brother of James. Loving grandfather of Jackson. He will be greatly missed. Service Monday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Taming of the Lot
description: YOU do know that the Lot is the most difficult river in France to navigate, don't you?'' the boat-rental manager said as he pulled out the waivers and releases to be signed before he would hand over the keys. ''They say that if you can do this one, you can do any of them.''

title: Flight Patterns
description: As any grande dame will tell you, feathers are not for the birds.

title: An Unflattering Photograph For a Theatergoer
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the My First Job article last Sunday, in which Robert Ross, the founder of the Ross University School of Medicine on Dominica, described his boyhood work delivering newspapers, carried an erroneous credit for the writer who worked with him on the article. She was Jenny Holland, not Judy Tong.

title: Aunt Julia . . .
description: My mother likes to claim that I became a food writer because she used to feed me applesauce in my highchair while she watched Julia Child on TV. I don't remember this. (My mother also watched the tipsy Galloping Gourmet, and now I like wine, so who's to say?) My first impression of Julia came almost a decade later when I saw Dan Aykroyd impersonate her, bleeding to death while hacking up a chicken on ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Gays Enjoy the Night at a Prom of Their Own
description: AFRAID of being gawked at because he is gay, Carlos Luis Collazo didn't go to the senior prom two weeks ago at his high school in Manhattan. He went to the movies and out to dinner with his boyfriend instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, PAUL ROBERT
description: CAREY-Paul Robert, Commissioner-United States Securities and Exchange Commission passed away June 14, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Paul Robert Carey was born October 18, 1962, the beloved seventh son of Former Governor Hugh L. Carey and the late Helen Owen Carey. His two brothers Hugh L. Carey, Jr. and Peter G. Carey predeceased him. He is survived by his loving family and friends including his brothers and sisters: Alexandria McManus (Hank), Christopher (Bonnie), Susan Dempsey (Marty), Michael, Donald, Marianne Hayes (Dennis), Nancy Cassidy (Tom), Helen O'Neill (Martin), Bryan (Catherine), Kevin (Mary Jo), Thomas (Amy), his loving nieces and nephews Peter Hugh, Eileen, Tom, Beth (Bryan), Erich, Kate, Susie, Ted, Maureen, Hugh, Donnie, Owen, Delia, Thomas Hugh & Elizabeth. Many loving friends, including his close friend Jackie Chorney, also survive him. Paul was a graduate of the Doane Stuart School and Colgate University. After a career in Institutional Equities, Paul joined the Clinton/ Gore 1992 Presidential Campaign, as Northeast finance director. In the new administration, he worked in the White House as Special Assistant to the President for legislative affairs, handling banking, financial services and securities matters, primarily working with the United States Senate. He also worked on judicial selection and handled Senate confirmation for many administration nominees. In 1997, Paul was nominated and confirmed to serve as Commissioner of the Securities Exchange Commission. While at the Commission Paul Carey led the Commission's efforts to provide information to lawmakers regarding the privatization of Social Security. He also served as liaison to the North American Securities Administrators Association. Paul lived life to the fullest and continued his public service each day of his life. As a member of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission as well as in his service in the White House administration of President Bill Clinton, Paul strived to make life better for all of those whom he touched and for those less fortunate. Paul was a man of great accomplishments, stature and elegance. Paul loved to travel to distant parts of the world and was well received wherever he called including a number of United States Embassies. Most recently, Paul took great joy in attending the investiture of the Cardinals in Rome, including Edward Cardinal Egan of the Archdiocese of New York. From the earliest days, Paul held an affection for the developmentally disabled. As a child, he provided loving care to the developmentally challenged at Camp Shelter Island and as a young man he worked with physically challenged skiers in Windham, N.Y. As a son, a brother, an uncle and a friend he brought a whole new meaning to the fun that life has to offer and shared it with everyone he touched. Paul's strength, love and generosity will continue with the Carey family and his friends forever. With God's grace he gave and received as much love as anyone could ever have dreamed of or desired in life. The family wishes to thank all the caregivers, nurses and doctors who cared for and treated Paul during his lengthy illness. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that Paul be remembered by donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021 or St. Gabriel's Spiritual Center for Youth, P.O. Box 3015, Shelter Island Heights, NY 11965. A mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10:00 AM on Monday June 18, 2001. Viewing will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Saturday and Sunday from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM and from 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM. For inquiries contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at (212) 288-3500. We Know. The Carey Family

title: New Faces, Same Result in the Subway Series
description: They gathered their belongings and got on board last winter, new passengers in the Subway Series. Mike Mussina and Kevin Appier, two reliable veterans who throw a lot of innings and win a lot of games, signed as free agents to play in New York. Yesterday they showed they fit right into the Yankees-Mets rivalry.

title: The Proms Missed In Favor of Social Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: For Vieques, 2 Years Is a Long Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Shepherd, Jos Montemayor
description: Elizabeth Halliday Shepherd and Jos Montemayor de Manzano are to be married today on Grand Isle in Vermont. The Rev. David D. Wright, a Congregational minister, is to officiate at Grand Isle Lake House, a hotel.

title: A Blame Game Hurts Both Ford and Firestone
description: EARLY on the morning of May 21, senior Ford Motor executives met with Bridgestone/Firestone officials at Firestone's headquarters in Nashville. Since the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires on Ford Explorers in August, after tire blowouts and vehicle rollovers, Ford had been analyzing the safety of the roughly 13 million Wilderness AT tires, made by Firestone, that were still in use on Explorers and Ford trucks. ''We wanted to get into a discussion at that time'' about tire safety, said Ken Zino, a Ford spokesman.

title: In Greenland
description: To the Editor: The article ''Where Icebergs Are Born'' by James Brooke about Greenland (May 20) brought back memories of working as a private contractor for the Air Force in Sondrestromfjord (Kangerlussuaq) and Narsarsuaq for six- to eight-month periods from 1953 through 1955.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In; Broadway-Flushing
description: A quiet area not far from busy Northern Boulevard, it remains a single-family enclave in part because of deed covenants from long ago. By Diana Shaman 7

title: From Tears to Triumph for Spencer at Shea
description: Shane Spencer's face was crimson and sweat dripped down his cheeks 20 minutes after the Yankees' game against the Mets Friday night. He'd been running around chasing fly balls in muggy Shea Stadium, repeatedly challenged in his first major-league start in 341 days. "I am tired," he admitted.

title: Elizabeth Burnham, Joseph Murphy III
description: Elizabeth Anne Burnham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Burnham of Ocean Reef, Fla., was married last evening in Beaver Creek, Colo., to Joseph J. Murphy III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy Jr., also of Ocean Reef. The Rev. Dr. Randy J. Simmonds, a Baptist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Chapel at Beaver Creek.

title: Bsmt Vu, No Spc
description: FOR those of you who are still green when it comes to looking for New York apartments, here's advice from someone who has been there. Like everything else in this city, apartment success requires perseverance and dedication, and a little help from an insider can't hurt, either. Here are some commonly used apartment-listing adjectives, followed by their actual meanings. Happy hunting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RUTH
description: KAHN-Ruth. Age 75. Beloved mother and grandmother, community leader and neighborhood activist, distinguished psychiatric social worker and advocate for human services. She raised two daughters as a single mother after the early death of her cherished husband Dr. Seymour Lion Kahn, and was a tireless advocate for social and political causes. A spirited woman of great style, intelligence, compassion, humor and integrity, she leaves behind the legacy of a more livable Chelsea. Daughter of the late Louis and Rachel Lesselroth, she is survived by her daughter Karen and son-in-law William Baskett of Northampton, England, daughter Janice and grandchildren Jill and Robb of Chestnut Hill, MA. Contributions may be sent to the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, or Volunteers of America of Greater New York. Memorial service, July 22, 4-6 PM, at Holland House, 351 West 42nd Street.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Atlantic City's Boardwalk Hall Gets a Makeover
description: AMID the glittery casinos lining Atlantic City's boardwalk stands its historic convention center, a 1929 Roman Renaissance building that lost its luster in the last two decades as larger, more contemporary centers opened and siphoned away visitors.

title: New York's Education Shortfall
description: New York City's budget, approved earlier this month by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the City Council, deals a tough hand to New York State's lawmakers, now struggling to finish their own tardy budget in Albany. The city's budget shortchanges city schools and bounces financial responsibility for education to the State Legislature. Even the city's most unwavering allies in Albany are stumped. How do you make everybody else in the state contribute to improving city schools if New York City isn't contributing enough in the first place?

title: The Cool War
description: I have stayed in several of Ian Schrager's hotels and found his employees to be beautiful but incompetent (Meryl Gordon, May 27). When I travel, I want a clean, quiet room and decent service. If I want to be part of a show, I'll join the circus.

title: Streetscapes/Billboards; The Battles Over Outdoor Ads Go Back a Century
description: EARLIER this year, the City Council passed legislation intended to limit the spread of billboards. Predictably, the rules pleased those who seek a less commercialized city, but irritated the owners of large signs -- just as had been the case a century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASHMAN, GERARD
description: TASHMAN-Gerard. Died June 12, Ithaca, NY, after a long illness. Formerly resident of Woodmere, Long Island. He was loving father and father-in-law to Dr. and Mrs. John Spencer Tashman & Jeffrey Tashman, and grandfather to Joshua William, Hannah Elise and Katherine Clarke. A Memorial service Ithaca, June 23.

title: State Wants New Station, But Where to Build It?
description: THE nine miles of tracks between the Milford and New Haven railroad stations is the longest stretch without a stop along the Metro-North line in Connecticut. Just check the schedule. It is three or four minutes between most stops in the state, but the trip between Milford and New Haven is 15 minutes, climbing to 18 minutes on some trains.

title: Cowboy Junkies in Red Bank
description: The Cowboy Junkies might not be the most upbeat band, but their country-tinged rock is so original and hypnotic, you might not even notice; it doesn't get more molasses-slow moody. Margo Timmon's radiant and languorous vocalizing is a riveting experience. They're joined by Martin Sexton, whose pliant voice ranges from bark to falsetto. He is also one of the most skilled songwriters on the alternative new-folk scene (although, musically, he is all over the map, including jazz, rock and blues). He can be introspective in one song and wildly panoramic in the next. They perform on Friday at the Count Basie Theater in Red Bank. Robbie Woliver

title: Personal Business; The Nursing Home With Everything (for a Price)
description: ROBERT A. RUSSELL remembers well the first two nursing homes he visited six years ago as he searched for a place for his elderly father, who suffered from advanced stages of Parkinson's disease.

title: G.E. Calls Its $45 Billion Bid For Honeywell All but Dead
description: Jeffrey R. Immelt, president of the General Electric Company, pronounced its proposed $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International all but dead today, but said that G.E. would wait to receive a final judgment from the European Commission next month.

title: The Rich, Intense-Flavored Food of India
description: THE Indian enclave in Hicksville is growing, with its own supermarkets, movie theaters, video stores, caterers, beauty parlors and especially restaurants. There are probably more Indian restaurants in Hicksville today than there were on the whole Island just a few years ago.

title: BackTalk; Journal of Discovery Travels a Base at a Time
description: Henry Dunow, still small and bookish at 47, wondered last year if he was man enough to coach the West Side Little League team of his 7-year-old son, Max. What does ''man enough'' mean? And don't you qualify just by being a father? Dunow invites us to watch his answers slowly unfold in a poignant, revealing and useful essay on sports and fatherhood, ''The Way Home: Scenes From a Season, Lessons From a Lifetime,'' just published by Broadway Books.

title: A Vision of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Kristina Feil, Joseph Shaffer
description: Kristina Kelly Feil, a daughter of Margaret and Kurt Feil of Lake Elmo, Minn., was married yesterday in Mastic, N.Y., to Dr. Joseph Jacob Shaffer, a son of Serena Bass and Dr. David Shaffer, both of New York. Arthur Dobrin, the leader of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, officiated at the country home of Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, who is the bridegroom's stepmother.

title: Ripples From a Running-Track Collision
description: IT is the call every sports official most fears making: a disqualification. Especially one in an important event.

title: Around Ronda
description: To the Editor: The article ''Up, Down and Around Ronda'' by Amanda Hesser (May 27) was accurate, if somewhat faint in its praise at points. My family visited Ronda last year on the advice of a resort concierge, and the two-hour scenic drive from Marbella was rewarded with one of the finest experiences we've had in three visits to Spain.

title: Making a Better World Through Fashion
description: IT'S a great night because it's truly the industry, it's people who dedicate their lives to fashion,'' Cynthia Rowley said with missionary fervor on Thursday, as hundreds of celebrities, semicelebrities, demicelebrities and assorted examples of glamour flotsam came floating down a paparazzi gantlet outside Avery Fisher Hall. The occasion was the 20th American Fashion Awards -- fashion's Oscars -- where the people who make the world's best shoes and dresses give one another prizes for helping to keep the rest of us from looking like contestants on ''Let's Make a Deal.''

title: Hoop Dreams
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Laughing in a time of tears: High-octane Yellow Pages, where Lassie can seek advice.
description: AFTER the gloomy economic news that emanated last week from Madison Avenue, a few laughs might be welcome. And that's what an agency known for cheeky campaigns delivers with its first work to promote the offline and online telephone directories of Verizon Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, ESTHER
description: KATZENSTEIN-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Manfred. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Maud and Rabbi Solomon Carlebach, Rabbi Edwin and Ruth Katzenstein, Joan and Rabbi Shaya Thau. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother, sister-in-law and aunt. Shiva until Friday afternoon at 720 Fort Washington Ave., Apartment 1W, New York City.

description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: 'Swan Lake' in a German Countryside
description: Kevin McKenzie's staging of ''Swan Lake'' from last year returned to American Ballet Theater on Friday night with Julie Kent in the dual role of Odette-Odile and Angel Corella as her hapless Prince Siegfried.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about the scrutiny faced by literary critics and editors when they write books of their own, referred incorrectly at one point to ''American Chica: Two Worlds, One Childhood,'' by the editor Marie Arana. As noted elsewhere in the column, it is a memoir, not a novel.

title: Entrepreneurs Stump for Their Voting Devices
description: This may be one of the most unusual trade shows in America, one where vendors are hawking democracy itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, BENJAMIN
description: MOSS-Benjamin. Born November 13, 1961, in Boston, MA, died June 7, in Prescott, AZ. He was a superb guitarist, a computer systems analyst, ardent tennis player, fan and officiator who was beloved by all children as well as family and friends. He is survived by his father Simon and mother Margaret of Houston, and brothers Alex of Philadelphia, Nat of Brooklyn, NY, and Jacob of Washington, DC, and three nieces, Abigail, Leila and Nina. The family requests that contributions in Benjamin's name be sent to human rights organizations and centers for the protection of abused women and children.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORVINO, VERONICA
description: CORVINO-Veronica. Born June 18, 1935, died Nov 7, 1999. To my faithful and trusting wife, your loving husband and children, Paul, Paul, Jr., Ron, Karen, Janet and seven Grandchildren We miss you very much, Nana

title: Woods Feels Relieved Tournament Is Over
description: TULSA, Okla., June 17  Tiger Woods was not shocked, but he acknowledged that he was frustrated. After a final-round 69, Woods's major-championship winning streak ended at four as he finished at three over par (283, 74-71-69-69), in a four- way tie for 12th place at the United States Open.

title: 4-Year Effort To Collect Data On Book Sales Is a Step Closer
description: Book sales figures -- the crucial element in best-seller lists and in the reputations of authors and publishers -- have always been an extremely hard-to-determine, closely guarded secret.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Use of Force in Guarding Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court today added an extra layer of protection for police officers accused in suits for damages of using excessive force.

title: Putin Urges Global Pressure To Disarm Rebels in Kosovo
description: Russia and Yugoslavia said today that Kosovo was the main cause of instability in the Balkans and urged world leaders to ensure that Albanian ''terrorists'' in Kosovo and the region were completely disarmed.

title: Bringing a Workingman's Perspective to a Union's Helm
description: THE first question for Leo Gerard is what happened to the big, bushy, salt-and-pepper beard that made him look part Burl Ives, part Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. In February, when he was sworn in as president of the United Steelworkers of America, the beard dominated his face.

title: One Pause and Rudd Ruins Gordon's Reverie
description: Jeff Gordon had driven hard to run alone in the sweet, clean mountain air this afternoon, far in front of the traffic and the troublesome turbulence. He wanted to stay on the track for as long as he could. He wanted to wring as many laps out of each tank of gas as possible.

title: Buddhism Blooms Amid the Forests Of the Catskills; Ancient Cures for Modern Ills
description: Until six years ago, James Frechter rose at 9 each morning, put on a dark suit and the mandatory tie and took the subway to Wall Street to begin another long day as an associate lawyer with Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the renovation of Madison Square Park misstated the decline in New York City's spending on parks in the last 15 years. It has been 17 percent, not 30.

title: Shining Future Of Fiber Optics Loses Glimmer
description: In the last two years, 100 million miles of optical fiber -- more than enough to reach the sun -- were laid around the world as companies spent $35 billion to build Internet-inspired communications networks. But after a string of corporate bankruptcies, fears are spreading that it will be many years before these grandiose systems are ever fully used.

title: Three Firefighters Die as Store Explodes in Queens
description: An explosion tore through a burning building in Astoria, Queens, yesterday, killing three firefighters and critically injuring one as it tossed bodies onto the street and sent down a cascade of bricks and debris. At least 48 other rescue workers and two civilians were injured, officials said.

title: Sad Tales of the Pacific Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PEARL KLUGER
description: SIEGEL-Pearl Kluger. Died June 12, 2001, at home. Professor of American History and social activist. Devoted wife of the late Charles Siegel, beloved mother of Roberta Columbus and mother-inlaw of Ronald, cherished grandmother of Eric and Nikki. A scholar of the past who was ahead of her time, she is remembered with love and admiration.

title: Metro Briefing
description: HAMILTON: COLGATE PRESIDENT RESIGNS After only two years on the job, the president of Colgate University resigned unexpectedly last week. The president, Charles H. Karelis, did not explain his decision or say whether he had a new job, said James Leach, his assistant. The resignation was not discussed at the last meeting of the university's board, Mr. Leach said. Jane Pinchin, provost and dean of the faculty, will serve as interim president until a successor is named, which could take up to nine months. The two previous presidents, Neil R. Grabois and George Langdon, each held office for about 10 years. (AP)

title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Canarsie, Brooklyn; 'For Sale' Signs Greet Newcomers
description: ''A house to the Caribbean man is something very important,'' Samuel E. Palmer was saying. ''He has to have a house, as opposed to an apartment. Whatever happens, the house comes first, so you can have a family and your friends can meet there. So when I came here, the desire also was to achieve this house, this houseness.''

title: Sixth-Grade Dunce
description: Most people were disappointed and shocked by the recent revelations of errors in standardized test scores. To think that some people were barred from school advancement or even graduation because of mistakes by the corporations that grade the tests! These companies should be held accountable. But I must confess: I read this news with a high degree of personal interest.

title: The Dirt at Shea Slows Things Down
description: Some Yankees noted the thick bog of dirt around first base at Shea Stadium, conditions that they felt made it hard to get a jump. One player held up a stack of two folded towels to demonstrate the depth of the loose and damp soil around first. In any event, the Yankees have not been stopped: they stole six bases in the first two games of this series.

title: Varied Events at New Jersey Arts Center
description: A celebration of the 75th anniversaries of the births of Miles Davis and John Coltrane and appearances by the Kirov Orchestra and the Chicago Symphony are among the events scheduled for the fifth season of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.
