description: To the Editor:

title: Milbrett's Two-Goal Effort Gives Power a Share of First
description: The New York Power did not let a downpour or a first-place opponent stop it from assuming a share of the top spot in the Women's United Soccer Association.

title: Unlikely Allies Press to Add Conservation to Farm Bill
description: A coalition of more than 100 environmental and hunting organizations, from the Sierra Club to the National Rifle Association, is trying to turn the measure that will set farm policy for the coming years into the major conservation act of this Congress.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY: None

title: Corrections
description: An article in the World Business section on Thursday about the contrasting fortunes of British railroads and a maker of miniature trains misstated the year the railroads were privatized. It was 1996, not 1986.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Nursing Home Hearing
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on staffing at state-licensed nursing homes. Committee room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 788-7116.

title: Fidelity Ending Ties To Its Main Agency
description: Fidelity Investments is parting ways after more than four years with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The agency had handled the bulk of the Fidelity account, totaling $120 million to $150 million. Neither Fidelity nor the agency would give figures for Hill, Holliday's part, including retail mutual funds and brand development.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, named several executives to new posts, working on the Northeast retail account of Verizon Wireless. Al Barbalatt was named traffic manager; he had been traffic manager at the Bozell Group, New York, a unit of True North Communications. Scott Heller and Joseph Scopazzi were named print production managers; Mr. Heller had been print production assistant at Deutsch in New York, owned by Interpublic Group of Companies, and Mr. Scopazzi had been print production manager at Doremus & Company in New York, part of the Omnicom Group. Joseph Jennings was named assistant media planner; he had been assistant media planner at the Lord Group in New York, a joint venture of Dentsu and the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group. And Tara Sweeney was named broadcast traffic manager; she had been project manager at the Wieden & Kennedy New York office.

title: Plague of Crickets Does $25 Million Damage to Crops in Utah
description: ''I've got a war on my hands here,'' Scott Overson said, climbing off his all-terrain vehicle.

title: Vieques Advocate Turns From Violence of Her Past
description: A white-haired woman sat at a picnic table at the makeshift village where protesters gather every day to plan strategy against the Navy's military maneuvers here. Not far from her was a sign that spelled out the rules, including ''Zero Violence.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANLEY, JOHN M.
description: MANLEY-John M. April 4,1919June 18, 1999. It has been two years since you left, and you are missed. Love you forever. Carla

title: Outlook for Spending Drives Down Stocks
description: Stocks of big agency companies fell on Friday as additional signs emerged that the slowdown in advertising spending growth would continue well into the year.

title: Essay; Putin's China Card
description: ''I like Old Joe,'' said F.D.R. about Joseph Stalin. Carrying on that self-deluding tradition of snap judgments, George W. Bush looked into the eyes of Vladimir Putin, announced, ''I was able to get a sense of his soul,'' and after two heady hours concluded he was ''straightforward'' and ''trustworthy.''

title: Law Offices In California Make Cutbacks
description: A number of leading West Coast law firms, especially those that grew rapidly in serving the dot-com boom in Silicon Valley, have quietly responded to the economic slowdown with job cuts, pay cuts and other cost-saving efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, NORMAN R., MD.
description: BLOCH-Norman R., MD. Of East Hampton, NY, died Sunday, June 17, 2001. He was 86. Norman graduated from CCNY in 1936 where he received a B.S. in chemistry. He received his M.D. in 1942. He served as a captain in WWII. He was a general practitioner before specializing in OB/GYN. He was affiliated with and taught at many hospitals in the Bronx and Manhattan. Norman was an accomplished artist, fisherman, boater, linguist and humorist. He is survived by his loving wife Sylvia Leiter Bloch, his children Mitchell R. Bloch of Edgemont and Terry Heine of Carmel, three grandchildren, a brother and a sister. He will be missed and was loved by all who knew him. Services will be held Tuesday at 10 AM at Temple Bet Am Shalom, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment will follow at The Green River Cemetery, East Hampton, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | Manhattan: Fire Causes Loss Of Cable Service
description: A fire in the downtown Manhattan offices of Time Warner Cable last night caused customers in parts of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens to lose television service for about two and a half hours.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, OSCAR RYDER, JR.
description: BARRETT-Oscar Ryder, Jr. 94, of Bronxville on June 5, 2001. Married 72 years to his beloved wife Amanda, died February 4, 2001. Father of Audrey B. Bower and the late Parker C. Barrett, grandfather of six, great-grandfather of nine. Interment Bedford, NY.

title: 'Ivan the Terrible' Lives, Survivor of Stalin's Wrath
description: Running counter to the grand intellectual pursuits of 20th-century music was a fainter plea for plain speaking. Rigor, complication and experiment exercised power over the community of composers, but a desire for the simple, the familiar and the comforting never went away, like a shadow government in the politics of musical style biding its time and gathering members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, JULIUS
description: REISS-Julius. Died June 14 at age 93. He was a union organizer and man of great intellect and heart. He is survived by his wife Gertrude, his children Helen, David and Andrew, and his grandchildren Emily, Peter and Joshua. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 24, at 2 PM, at Park Slope Jewish Center, 14th Street and 8th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Metro Matters; Even if It Fails, This Bill May Succeed
description: EVER wonder what our lawmakers do while waiting around for Albany's leaders to make a deal on the budget? It is 11 weeks late, with no resolution in sight.

title: Addenda: Fidelity Ending Tie to Its Main Agency
description: Fidelity Investments is parting ways after more than four years with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The agency had handled the bulk of the Fidelity account, totaling $120 million to $150 million. Neither Fidelity nor the agency would give figures for Hill, Holliday's part, including retail mutual funds and brand development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, JUDITH
description: MOSES-Judith. 61, died at home on June 16. Survived by husband Harry; daughter Anne, son-in-law Ray Buffalo, and granddaughter Violet of San Francisco; and mother Elaine Weil of Philadelphia. Funeral private. There will be a memorial service to be announced later. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Committee to Protect Journalists in New York.

title: Compressed Data; Computer Tax Benefit Favors Top Brackets
description: A little publicized provision of the new tax law is meant to help people buy computers, educational software and Internet access for school-age children. Anyone may create an account for a child in kindergarten through 12th grade, but only one account is allowed for each child.

title: Roll the Credits, Cue the Soundtrack
description: ''Moulin Rouge,'' starring Nicole Kidman, has received only lukewarm reviews. But the film's soundtrack, featuring vocals by Ms. Kidman and others, is hot. The ''Moulin Rouge'' soundtrack was No. 3 on the June 16 Billboard magazine album rankings.

title: Equity Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Article 2001061892727466566 -- No Title
THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves; Amid a Sea of Faces, Islands of Segregation
description: The New York region has grown more polyglot than ever, from its West Indian cricket leagues and live-poultry dealers to its sari boutiques. But some analyses of the 2000 census show that it is also more segregated than many other places -- a kind of archipelago, its enclaves like islands, each with its own distinct racial or ethnic topography.

title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Runyon Heights, Yonkers; Oasis for Blacks Born of Exclusion
description: It could be any other Cape Cod sitting in any other stretch of Yonkers. Prim siding. Shades discreetly drawn. Tasteful exterior dcor. Nevertheless, Milton Holst clucks his tongue disapprovingly, shakes his head and -- like some Mr. Blackwell of residential housing -- slowly points out blemishes that might be invisible to any eye but his own: front steps in disrepair. Scraps of litter by the curb. Plastic trash cans threaten Mr. Holst's suburban sidewalk still life.

title: Mets Get Hopes Up With One Victory
description: All riiiiiight, the Mets are on their way. In the throes of season-long death minutes before midnight last night, the Mets resuscitated themselves, rallying for six runs in the eighth inning and an 8-7 victory over the Yankees. Without question, the Mets will soar in the standing on the flight of the monstrous home run Mike Piazza crushed over the left-center-field fence.

title: George Abrams Dies at 81; Was a Master of Typefaces
description: George Abrams, an artist and type designer whose distinctive logotypes spelled out household names like B. Altman and Godiva Chocolates, died on June 7 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 81 and lived in Great Neck Estates, N.Y.

title: G.M. Will Oppose Efforts To Tighten Fuel Efficiency
description: General Motors is taking a stand against efforts to raise federal fuel-economy standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKE, JAMES (JIM)
description: DUKE-James (Jim). Of Diamond Grange, Portadown and Clonskeagh. June 15th, 2001. Retired Principal of St. Andrew's College. Sadly missed by his beloved wife Veronica, sister Karleen and a wide circle of friends. Funeral Service this Monday morning at 11 o'clock in Sandford Road Church Of Ireland followed by cremation immediately afterwards at Mountjerome Crematorium, Dublin, Ireland.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I had taken everything out of my locker. I've put it back in, though.''

title: Cover Story; Oh, How Far A Magazine Will Go To Stimulate Newsstand Sales
description: Back in March, Owen McKibbin's booker at Ford Models called him at home in Santa Monica, Calif., and told him to get ready for a Men's Health cover shoot. He would have a little less than three months to prepare.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Morgan Upsets Himself, Then He Wins as Expected
description: Gil Morgan did not break any records today as he did last year, when he won the Senior PGA Tour's Instinet Classic, or as he had on the first two days of this year's event. Instead of the spectacular, Morgan settled for a workmanlike effort mixed with a little bit of luck to defend his title.

title: Article 2001061891289185975 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Linda Eatherton was named executive vice president and director for the global food and nutrition practice at the Chicago office of Ketchum, part of the Omnicom Group. She succeeds Betsy Gullickson, who became executive vice president and global counselor at the Ketchum office in San Francisco. Ms. Eatherton had been vice president for public and industry communications at Dairy Management Inc., Chicago.

title: Aid We'd Rather Not Receive
description: The news recently arrived here of the Helms-Lieberman Cuban Solidarity Act of 2001, which would allocate $100 million in aid -- financial assistance, medical supplies, office and communications equipment -- to Cuban independent and nongovernmental organizations and victims of political repression. While we do not doubt that the intention of the legislators is to ''provide increased, decisive support to the democratic opposition in Cuba,'' we feel that Cuban dissidents on the island have to say: ''No, thank you. Not in this way.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Vindictive Open Has Made Its Return
description: THE Open is the Open again. When Tiger Woods won it by a record 15 strokes last year with a 12-under-par score, that had to be the Pebble Beach Aberration, not the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOBRER, JEAN
description: DOBRER-Jean. June 18, 1954- August 18, 2000. Dear Jeannie, I miss you everyday. I can't imagine spending June 18 without calling or seeing you. Love, Nina

title: A Candidate for the F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: War of Words Heats Up Between Airbus and Boeing
description: The simmering rivalry between Airbus Industrie and the Boeing Company boiled over here today when Nol Forgeard, the chief executive of Airbus, lashed out at comments made by Harry C. Stonecipher, Boeing's vice chairman, in an interview with a French newspaper.

title: Judith Moses, 61, Producer and an Advocate for Reporters' Rights
description: Judith Moses, a television news producer and teacher who also worked to expose the abuses confronted by journalists working on dangerous assignments abroad, died at home in Manhattan on Saturday. She was 61 and lived in Manhattan and Kent, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAPPIER, BILL
description: FRAPPIER-Bill. Dear friend, business partner and confidant, you were the better half of the ''odd couple.'' You have left a hole in our hearts and lives that will never be filled. We love and miss you. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to your family. Barbara and Mark Goldsmith

title: E-Commerce Report; EBay's entry into the market for assisting small companies poses challenges for rivals.
description: FOR companies looking to sell e-commerce services to small businesses, last week may well be remembered as a turning point. The shift began on Monday, when eBay announced it was stepping into the market by selling easy-to-build Web stores and listing them on its site for $10 a month, starting today.

title: U.N. Sanctions Didn't Stop Iraq From Buying Weapons
description: Two American arms control experts, combing through unpublished reports by a disbanded arms inspection commission, say they found evidence that Iraq continued to buy prohibited weapons or parts long after United Nations sanctions were imposed in 1990.

title: Getting There Proves Harder Than Victory
description: The Liberty spent more time in airports than playing basketball over the last 24 hours, but tonight the team was able to shrug off the weariness produced by a series of travel delays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PHILIP
description: SMITH-Philip. To a brother-in-law who was more like a brother and an uncle who was always there for us, he will be in our hearts forever. Gladys and Stanley, Frank and Nancy, Mitchell and Ronda, and Stuart

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHLBERG, JOSEPH
description: WOHLBERG-Joseph. Of Denville, NJ, on Tuesday, May 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna (nee Getzoff) for 54-1/2 years married. A brother-in-law of Mr. and Mrs. Lester (Martha) Getzoff of New York City, NY. An uncle of Vera Miller of Guilderland, NY, Barbara Zylberman of Melbourne, Australia, and Steven Getzoff of Riverdale, NY. Mr. Wohlberg died at the Franciscan Oaks Health Center Denville, NJ, after a brief illness. He was born in Budapest, Hungary. He came to NYC in 1919. He received his undergraduate and masters degree from City College of New York, where upon Mr. Wohlberg taught Greek and Latin as well as classical literature until his retirement. In 1997 he moved to Denville, NJ. Mr. Wohlberg was an U.S. Army veteran of WWII. All are invited to attend a gathering of remembrance at Franciscan Oaks, 19 Pocono Rd, Denville, NJ, June 24, at 1 PM. For more information call Norman Dean Home for Services, Denville, NJ (973)627-1880.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Harbor Ferry Plan Advances
description: Plans for a New York Harbor ferry loop moved one step closer to reality last week with $300,000 in city financing for a series of ferry stops in Brooklyn. The money, which was included in the city's new budget approved last week, will pay for the design of docking facilities in Red Hook, Bay Ridge and at Fulton Ferry Landing. Ultimately, the $18.5 million loop is to include 25 stops in New Jersey, Staten Island, Manhattan and Brooklyn, with boats running clockwise and counterclockwise around the harbor every 15 to 20 minutes. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Vindictive Open Has Made Its Return
description: TULSA, Okla. -- The Open is the Open again. When Tiger Woods won it by a record 15 strokes last year with a 12-under-par score, that had to be the Pebble Beach Aberration, not the United States Open.

title: Violence in the Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Before a Rendezvous With the Muse, First Select the Music
description: I've never willingly written a word without listening to music of some sort. Right now I'm listening to Debussy's Sonata for Cello and Piano. When pushed by deadlines I've sometimes been obliged to work in silence, on a train or plane or in a cafe. (A Walkman I don't like, since its penetrating sound, piped directly into the cranial bones, is too aggressive and inescapable: booming aural earmuffs.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DR. JOHN J.
description: COLLINS-Dr. John J. Died at his home in Blauvelt, NY, on June 16, 2001, at the age of 92. Born in NYC in 1909, Dr. Collins served as a professor of history at Fordham University for 40 years and was also a consultant to numerous independent tanker unions for more than 50 years. From 1950 until the early 1970's, Dr. Collins owned and operated Birch Brook Day Camp in Palisades, NY. He is survived by his daughters Suzanne Collins Broidrick, Jeanne Collins Donovan and Anne Collins, and his grandchildren Emily Broidrick, Michael, Maura and John Donovan, and Jessy and Jenny Medvene-Collins. His wife, Agnes Gerrity Collins, died in 1963, and his daughter Claire in 1994. He was also predeceased by his brother William. Friends may call at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY, on Tuesday, June 19, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, June 20, at 10 AM, at St. Catharine's Church, 523 Western Highway, Blauvelt, NY. Burial to follow at Maryrest Cemetery, Darlington (Mahwah), NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Fordham University, 441 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY 10451, or a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSBERG, HARRY
description: WACHSBERG-Harry. A renaissance man who loved life, his wife Denise, his daughter Claudie, sonin-law Edward and grandchildren Sabrina and Jonathan, family and friends. May he rest in peace. We love you. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Monday, June 18, 9:30 AM.

title: Early Results Show Ex-King Leads Vote In Bulgaria
description: The former king's party was leading in Bulgarian elections early today, even though it appeared to fall short of its declared goal of a clear majority, dealing a heavy blow to the political forces that have governed Bulgaria since the collapse of Communism in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIN, ANTOINETTE, PH.D.
description: SOBIN-Antoinette, Ph.D. In Honolulu, Hawaii, on June 12, 2001, on the eve of her 85th birthday. Retired NYC Board of Education and Deputy Director of Labor Relations for the City of NY. Beloved wife of the late Irving Sobin. Devoted mother of Dennis Sobin and Judy Sobin. Loving grandmother of Emma and Vance Lime, Antoinette Lilley, Darrin and Mylene Sobin and Teague Sobin. Dear sister of Rose Schiavone. Also survived by her dear friend Clifford Spellman. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick, LI. Funeral Mass Cure of Ars R.C. Church, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations will be accepted to the Antoinette A. Sobin Scholarship Fund.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about President Bush's lighthearted manner of conducting diplomacy in Europe misidentified Jacques Chirac. He is the French president; the prime minister is Lionel Jospin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMMERMAN, SONIA ''SUNNY''
description: AMMERMAN-Sonia ''Sunny''. Of Floral Park, NY, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Devoted wife of the late George. Beloved mother of Ronnie and Arthur Kirsch of Alpine, NJ, and Carla and Mark Kutsher of Monticello, NY. Cherished grandmother of David and Laura Kirsch and Zach Kutsher and Jennifer Fauchier. Dear sister of Martin Rubin of West Hempstead, NY. Graveside service 1 PM today at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pine Lawn.

title: Car Rental in Europe
description: Gasoline is pricey enough in the United States, so imagine the cost in Europe. Kemwel Holiday Autos is adding more than a few drops in the bucket (or in this case the fuel tank) with rebates of up to $50 on gasoline for European car rentals of 14 days or more. The offer applies to midsize cars (which, remember, will go through fuel faster than smaller models), and bookings must be made by Aug. 31, for travel through Dec. 31. Participants must mail in their receipts and mention the code GASPR. Information: (800) 678-0678 or www.kemwel.com .

title: INSIDE
description: Criticism of Bush Diplomacy

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Cordial Rivals: How Bush And Putin Became Friends
description: The warm rapport shown between President Bush and the Russian president, just one day after Mr. Bush declared that he wanted NATO to expand up to Russia's border, represented a significant achievement for the Americans, a senior official who helped plan the Bush trip said today.

title: Steps Fast and Slow, but Always Clear
description: When American Ballet Theater repeated its program of Tchaikovsky tidbits on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Ashley Tuttle and Ethan Stiefel took over the leading roles in George Balanchine's ''Theme and Variations,'' the evening's longest complete work. The performance was both admirable and peculiar.

title: The 'Brotherhood' Feels Its Loss Keenly
description: Yesterday was supposed to be John Downing's last day at Rescue Company 4 in Woodside, Queens, before he, his wife and two young children headed to Ireland for a long-awaited vacation.

title: Owner of Avis And Days Inn Seen Buying Travel Service
description: The Cendant Corporation, which owns Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Galileo International, an electronic travel reservation business, for slightly more than $2.9 billion in cash and stock, according to executives close to the talks.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Poulin Wins Pairs After a Switch
description: Larry Poulin drove Ziggy and Conyer to his sixth United States Equestrian Team national pair driving championship at the team's Festival of Champions yesterday in Gladstone, N.J. The victory made Poulin the leading candidate for the United States team that will compete in the world championship for pairs in Riesenbeck, Germany, in August.

title: Nominee's Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Sad Tales of the Pacific Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Webb's Leg Helps His School Set Record
description: With Alan Webb running 3 minutes 59.8 seconds on his 1,600-meter anchor leg, South Lakes High of Reston, Va., shattered the national record in the distance medley today in the conclusion of the Adidas outdoor high school track and field championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOZAK, AARON
description: KOZAK-Aaron. Died on June 16th, 2001, surrounded by his wife Patricia Kozak, his son Jeffrey Kozak and his daughter Ellen Kozak. His spirit and zest for life will never be forgotten by those who loved him. Services Monday, June 18th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 15  She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.

title: Lake Titicaca Journal; On a Lily Pad, Life Is Lush, but Watch Your Step
description: The Uro Indians say they got a bad rap.

title: BAN ON EXECUTION OF THE RETARDED IS VETOED IN TEXAS
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas today vetoed legislation that would have banned the execution of the mentally retarded, a move that runs counter to a trend among states that have the death penalty.

title: Patents; Inventors focus on making credit cards easier to carry and easier to process.
description: CREDIT card companies are aggressive in luring new card holders, offering incentives to persuade people already carrying a wallet full of cards to use one creditor's card over another's. They dangle lower interest rates and frequent-flier miles. Now some inventors have recently won patents that may make some of the cards themselves easier to handle than others.

title: Discreet War Brews in Public Radio in Los Angeles
description: SANTA MONICA, June 17  During the racial upheaval here in 1992, reporters rushing to file breaking news reports for National Public Radio had to wait in a corridor outside the bureau's lone recording studio for arts interviews to finish taping.

title: Europe Sees Bush's Trip Exceeding Expectations
description: As the dust settled on President Bush's first official visit to Europe, many experts and newspapers on the Continent called his five-country excursion a success, at least compared with what they had expected.

title: Rikers Escapee Doesn't Get Very Far: He's Found Inside a Jail Wall
description: A practiced burglar with a wiry build, Carlos Zufriatequi managed to pry a floorboard from a Rikers Island bathroom early Wednesday, slither through a grimy crawl space and emerge beneath the open sky.

title: Sometimes The Gods Deal From The Bottom
description: There are bridge deals that make a player feel that the gods of the game are capriciously and meanly against him or her. It is sometimes possible to find a silver lining, but on the diagramed deal the discovery took three days.

title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Breezy Point, Queens; Bounded by Gates, Over a Toll Bridge
description: Getting to Breezy Point, at the far western tip of the Rockaway Peninsula, has the feel of an equestrian event: every few feet, there is another gate to jump.

title: No Goals, No Complaints, No Worries for U.S. National Team
description: The United States national team had little time to savor the accomplishment of earning a valuable point in Jamaica on Saturday. The Americans will play Trinidad and Tobago on Wednesday night in another qualifying game for next year's World Cup finals in Japan and South Korea.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Saturday about President Bush's lighthearted manner of conducting diplomacy in Europe misidentified Jacques Chirac. He is the French president; the prime minister is Lionel Jospin.

title: Brooks Rescued By Bizarre Events
description: In the Southern Hills clubhouse, Mark Brooks, who had three-putted the 18th hole for a 70 and a four-under-par total of 276 in the 101st United States Open, was watching television at his locker today as Retief Goosen three-putted from 12 feet after Stewart Cink had three-putted from 15 feet. And suddenly Brooks, to his surprise, was in an 18-hole playoff Monday with Goosen.

title: MediaTalk; Amazon's Chairman Tries the Literary Life
description: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder and chairman of Amazon.com, made his debut as a literary critic last week, displaying both his taste in reading and, to those watching closely, a certain gratitude.

title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Edison, N.J.; Amid Strip Malls, Indian Expansion
description: The attackers carefully coordinated their late-night assault. They lobbed a dozen eggs last month at Pradip Kothari's home in Edison, N.J., his car and the travel agency he owns a few miles away on Oak Tree Road, the thriving South Asian shopping hub that old-timers derisively call ''Little Calcutta.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROSELYN
description: MILLER-Roselyn. 82, of Coconut Creek, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, and Cranberry, NJ, died peacefully at home on June 16, 2001. She was the adored wife of Saul. Cherished mother of Emily Miller Budick and Lawrence D. Miller. Mother-in-law of Sanford Budick and Wendy Miller. Grandmother of Rachel Elmakeyes, Ayelet Sharon, Amanda and Laura Miller and the late Yochanan Budick and great-grandmother of Chananel and Michah Elmakeyes. She will be deeply missed by all.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Olinville Journal article yesterday referred incorrectly in some copies to the time elapsed between the killing of Tamiqua Gutierrez in the Bronx on May 8 and the arrest of Clarence Moss, the suspect. It was two days, not three weeks.

title: The Dirt at Shea Slows Things Down
description: Some Yankees noted the thick bog of dirt around first base at Shea Stadium, conditions that they felt made it hard to get a jump. One player held up a stack of two folded towels to demonstrate the depth of the loose and damp soil around first. In any event, the Yankees have not been stopped: they stole six bases in the first two games of this series.

title: North Korea Dismisses Offer by the U.S. to Resume Talks
description: TOKYO, June 18  In its first official reaction to American proposals to resume bilateral talks, North Korea has dismissed a Bush administration request that the issue of conventional forces be included along with nuclear and ballistic missile control questions.

title: Israelis Kill Protester, 12, Palestinians In Gaza Say
description: A 12-year-old Palestinian boy was shot and killed today by Israeli soldiers during a demonstration in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian hospital and security officials said. It was the fifth fatality in the five-day-old cease-fire.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 5 about Abe Silverstein, a NASA official, misstated the date of the brainstorming session in which he proposed the name Apollo for the program to place a man on the moon. A correction in this space on Thursday placed the session in the appropriate time period -- the early 1960's, not 1969 -- but left the date imprecise. NASA records say the session took place in January 1960.

title: France by Barge
description: Barge cruises are a popular way to see France, and Premier Selections has a package price on a six-night trip Sept. 22 through Burgundy on La Litote, a 10-cabin hotel barge. The total price, with air fare from New York or Boston, two nights in a three-star Paris hotel and all ground transfers, is $2,499 a person based on double occupancy. That price, Premier Selections says, is a discount off the $3,070 that all the components would cost separately. Also thrown in are 500 frequent-flier miles on Continental. The barge trip, which follows the Upper Canal de Bourgogne from Auzerre to Ancy-le-France, includes all meals, wine with lunch and dinner, open bar, shore excursions and wine tastings. Information: (800) 234-4000 or send e-mail to ps@premierselections.com .

title: Compressed Data; Tags Could Help Keep E-Book Links Alive
description: Proponents of electronic books have been talking for years about the flexibility of digital information. They envision readers of e-books being able to click on a footnote or an offhand reference to another book and immediately view a copy of the citation in question.

title: Torre Goes to Bullpen, And Comes Up Empty
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre navigated around his weak middle relievers all season, and when he absolutely needed them for the first time last night, they showed why he had avoided them all this time.

title: WATER SPORTS; Rips, Curls and Hanging by 10
description: In 1997, Marcus Austin, a young waiter in Florida with a passion for water sports, bought a one-way ticket to the Hawaiian island of Maui. He was in search of his version of paradise, where a new sport called kitesurfing -- also known as kiteboarding -- was starting.

title: Omnicom Merging 2 New York Units
description: The Omnicom Group is merging two of its agencies based in New York after one of them lost business and laid off employees.

title: A Strange Name and Other Burdens
description: JUNIPER TREE BURNING

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 4 about reprocessing nuclear fuel included an element incorrectly among those that can be recovered for reuse in reactors. Lawrencium cannot be recovered for that use.

title: Without Woods, NBC's Ratings Drop
description: With Tiger Woods retreating from contention, NBC's overnight rating for the third round of the United States Open on Saturday fell 15 percent to a 5.5, from a 6.5 last year.

title: MediaTalk; Even Host Is Offended By Talk on Imus Show
description: Don Imus, the provocative talk show host, has been criticized for allowing insensitive and racially charged statements on his show on WFAN-AM. Mr. Imus has long insisted that he is an equal opportunity offender and that the spontaneous quips on his show are satirical and not personal or racist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTER, ROSE (BRADY)
description: FELTER-Rose (Brady). Died peacefully at the age of 103, on June 14, 2001. Born in the year that NYC was incorporated, through three different centuries, Rosie witnessed the City evolve from the gaslights and the first car on the streets of Greenwich Village to high speed internet access through her television. A lifelong Democrat (''Tammany Hall or no hall at all''), Rosie was a poll watcher for many years and avidly followed the local and national political scenes. On her 100th birthday, she received personal messages from the President, Senator Ted Kennedy, the Governor and the Mayor and a ceremonial inscribed brick from Stuyvesant Town where she resided since it opened 50 years ago. Although she was a widow for most of her life and only had one child, the late Joseph Harold, who retired as an Army Colonel after 32 years of active duty around the world, her progeny is remarkable. She had nine grandchildren, including a career Army officer, two doctors, a business woman, a lawyer, an interior designer, a nurse, an independent film maker and a web site designer, and at last count, 25 great-grandchildren and four great-great-grandchildren. When asked to explain her longevity, Rosie would respond ''I guess the good Lord doesn't want me and the devil is afraid I'll take his job.'' Contributions may be made in Rosie's name to the Immaculate Conception Church, where she was a parishioner for over 50 years, 414 East 14th Street, NY, NY 10009. A Mass of Celebration will be held at the church on Wednesday at 10 AM. Family will receive friends at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Q & A / Michael Graff : Bombardier's Focus on 2 Core Markets Pays Off
description: Bombardier Aerospace in Canada has a catchy phrase about itself: It says it is the world's largest aircraft manufacturer after Boeing and Airbus. Last year Bombardier topped its own output record by delivering 370 aircraft, almost all of them regional passenger planes or business planes. The company's revenues rose last year to $10.6 billion, up 30 percent over 1999. It amounts to a convincing comeback for a company that was on the rocks in the 1980s. It then gambled on the potential market for spiffy regional jets  which handily paid off in the 1990s. The course charted now by this fast-climbing company was outlined to the IHT's Joseph Fitchett by Michael Graff, chief executive officer of Bombardier Aerospace.

title: Woods Feels Relieved Tournament Is Over
description: Tiger Woods was not shocked, but he acknowledged that he was frustrated. After a final-round 69, Woods's major-championship winning streak ended at four as he finished at three over par (283, 74-71-69-69), in a four-way tie for 12th place at the United States Open.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Rozie Hendricks, Galesburg Ill., Feb. 10, 2001

title: Easygoing Words and a Hard Line
description: Over the last week, as President Bush pinged from country to country and prime minister to president, he was in some senses the epitome of diplomatic etiquette.

title: Amid New York's Sea of Faces, Islands of Segregation
description: The New York region has grown more polyglot than ever, from its West Indian cricket leagues and live-poultry dealers to its sari boutiques. But some analyses of the 2000 census show that it is also more segregated than many other places  a kind of archipelago, its enclaves like islands, each with its own distinct racial or ethnic topography.

title: Yanks Get Expos' Reliever in Trade for Two Minor Leaguers
description: DETROIT, June 18 - The Yankees, moving to fill a bullpen hole that was exposed in Sunday's dramatic loss to the Mets, tentatively agreed to trade two minor leaguers to the Montreal Expos in return for the veteran reliever Ugueth Urbina, according to several major league executives. But Urbina, who has a recent history of arm trouble, first must be cleared by the Yankees' medical staff.

title: Piazza Powers Unplugged Mets
description: The Mets had gone from looking hopeless and bewildered to simply seeming insignificant. They were being blown out in their home park by the Yankees, whose fans had cheered loudest and longest, overtaking Shea Stadium again.

title: Writers on Writing
Shakespeare's Darkness Is Flooded With Light
description: It is alarming, you must admit, to see a grown man suddenly discover that he has a sex drive. Billy Crudup takes us through such a moment with appalled eyes and gritted teeth in the spry new production of ''Measure for Measure'' in Central Park. And while Mr. Crudup is a handsome fellow, it is definitely not a pretty scene.

title: Economist Joins Times Editorial Board
description: Daniel Altman, an economics correspondent for The Economist magazine, is joining the editorial board of The New York Times today. His appointment as an editorial writer was announced by Howell Raines, editorial page editor.

title: A Fertile Farm Region Pays Its Jobless to Quit California
description: After decades of trying to cobble together a living in the Central Valley -- cleaning budget motel rooms, picking vegetables in the boiling hot summer, emptying bedpans for homebound elderly people and, lately, scraping by on a $616-a-month welfare check -- Lorrie Gedert decided enough was enough.

title: The Elegant Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Collapse of Talks With AOL Could Imperil Microsoft

title: A Feast Too Far Puts Powell In Gear
description: Mike Powell, the world record-holder in the long jump, is competing again after a four-year retirement. His decision to subject his 37-year-old body to the rigors of competition and training came last November after eating too much on Thanksgiving.

title: The Series: A Year at Speed
description: Robert Lipsyte delves into the world of auto racing in this series that follows the sport, its safety, sense of family and popularity. Here is complete archive of the articles in this series up to the most recent column.

title: Sad Tales of the Pacific Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCSWEENEY, EDWARD F. III.
description: McSWEENEY-Edward F. III. This year marks the 10th anniversary of your having prematurely departed the company of family and friends. So, babycakes, today at noon, at your old Racquet Club haunt, Carl, David, Murray, Stanley & I will host a luncheon gathering of some 40 of that still devoted company and, supported by the generosity of another 40 or more ''nearest and dearest'' who can't be there, will launch the naming of The Edward F. McSweeney III Memorial Terrace of the new Holbrook Arts Center at your beloved Milbrook School. Ten years later, the circle is completed. Love ya. Your pal, JPK.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, RUTH
description: JACOBI-Ruth. Died June 16, 2001, in Staten Island Hospital, from complications from two surgeries to repair a fractured hip. Devoted wife of 45 years of the late Sidney Jacobi who died on the same date in 1983. Beloved mother and grandmother of Ronna and Dr. Bernard Telsey, Joshua Telsey, Dr. Jonathan and Dr. Mary Telsey, and Mordecai, Carole, and Scott Jacobi. Caring sister of Gertrude Bonime and Anne Jacobi, and the late Miriam and Benedict Wolf, Dr. Mendel Jacobi, Victor Pascal, Celia Shilane, Alec Shilane and Dorothy Katz. Loving friend of Ruth Baker, Lillian Freilich, loyal companion Virginia Wilson, and the late Leon Shapiro. A number of physicians in Great Neck, NY, practiced the art, compassion, and diginity of medicine while caring for our mother and grandmother, prior to her Staten Island hopitalization. They are Dr. Lisa Berger, Dr. Barry Root, Dr. Douglas Goldberg, Dr. Richard Blanck, and, indirectly, Dr. Robert Ganeles. Ruth Jacobi retired as a reading teacher and library-media specialist in the NYC public schools. She was past president of the Staten Island Chapter of Hadassah. In her husband's memory, she endowed a cancer research grant at Hadassah Medical Center, Jerusalem, Israel, and funded an annual scholarship at Technion University, Haifa, Israel. Donations in loving memory of Ruth Jacobi can be made to Hadassah, 98 Cuttermill Rd., Great Neck, NY 11021.

title: Kitesurfers Reaching New Heights to Find Thrills
description: In 1997, Marcus Austin, a young waiter in Florida with a passion for water sports, bought a one-way ticket to the Hawaiian island of Maui. He was in search of his version of paradise, where a new sport called kitesurfing  also known as kiteboarding  was starting.

title: AOL and IPC Break Off Talks on Deal
description: Talks between AOL Time Warner and IPC Media Ltd., a British magazine publisher, have broken down after the two companies could not agree on a price, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, DR. BERNARD
description: BROOKS-Dr. Bernard. Beloved husband of the late Hortense. Devoted father to Janice Heller, Kenneth and the late Alan Brooks. Dear father-in-law to Jack Heller. Loving grandfather to Robert Heller, Hilary and Michael Brooks. Services Monday, June 18, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Dr. Brooks' name can be made to Peninsula Hospital Center, Beach 51st St and Beach Channel Drive, Far Rockaway, NY 11691.

title: When Children Go to War
description: In Myanmar, the army recruits street children as young as 10 for use as human minesweepers. In Ethiopia, government forces press-ganged thousands of secondary school students and used them in human wave attacks across minefields in the border war with Eritrea. In Iraq, thousands of children under 15 have joined the Saddam Lion Cubs, learning how to use small arms and engage in hand-to-hand combat. In Sri Lanka, young Tamil girls hailed as ''Birds of Freedom'' by that country's Tamil insurgency, have been trained as suicide bombers.

title: Actors' Talks Center on Journeymen Shortchanged by Pay of Stars
description: When Joe Howard played the role of a pharmacist in the 1993 movie, ''Grumpy Old Men,'' starring Walter Matthau, Jack Lemmon and Ann-Margret, he asked for, and was paid, a day rate of $750, about $300 over union scale at the time.

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Business Briefing column on Thursday about the Lechter's housewares chain misstated an action by the United States Bankruptcy Court. It approved the company's debtor-in-possession plan, not a reorganization plan.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC IN REVIEW
description: Contemporary Works

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVE, NANCY (NEE LOEW)
description: LOVE-Nancy (nee Loew). On June 8, 2001. Born November 24, 1927, San Francisco, CA. Longtime resident of NYC. At one time public relations representative for Barbara Walters, Alex Hailey, Hal Linden and others. She was an active member on the Board of the Hudson Guild for a number of years. Her many friends will miss her. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Berber Unrest Threatens Algeria's Government
description: Two months of slowly mounting protests by the Berber minority exploded last week into the biggest popular outpouring since independence in 1962 when thousands of Algerians seized the chance to vent their own grievances against the government.

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

title: Two Sides Rally to Shape Social Security Discussion
description: When Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill appears in New York on Monday to promote President Bush's plan to add private investment accounts to Social Security, his audience will be executives from Wall Street firms and big corporations, many of whom think such a change would be good policy and good business.

title: Poignant Personal Stories In the Point-and-Shoot War
description: The limitations of Lee Grant's new documentary, ''The Gun Deadlock,'' are apparent in the title: the debate over regulation of firearms in the United States is indeed a deadlock, each side entrenched, arguments so familiar that viewers can practically recite them along with those on camera.

title: Aerosmith, Relishing The Third Incarnation
description: Twenty-five years ago Aerosmith, the headliner Saturday at Jones Beach, was the epitome of ordinariness.

title: Venerable Tutor Drops In, Eyes Twinkling
description: American Ballet Theater presented two fine performances of ''Swan Lake'' on Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Document: The Study of Oprah
description: This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: "Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon," developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was "to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism." Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, LEW
description: TEITELBAUM-Lew. My sweetheart, my darling, my husband and my beloved best friend. Two years have now passed & the pain of missing you has hardly diminished. How I long to see you, hear you and touch you once more. My excellent strong man, I will miss you and love you forever. Your Sook

title: The Right Patients' Bill of Rights
description: Back from his European tour, President Bush this week faces what could be a bruising political battle against his old nemesis John McCain and a united Democratic front as the Senate begins to debate a patients' bill of rights. So far, the president is on the wrong side of this fight, both on the merits and as a political matter. He ought to reconsider his opposition to empowering people to seek meaningful redress from their health care plans when they are wrongly denied medical coverage.

title: Outdated Drug Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Aaron Green, 84, Architect Who Worked With Wright
description: Aaron Green, an architect in the San Francisco Bay Area and an associate of Frank Lloyd Wright in the 1940's and 50's, died on June 5 in San Francisco. He was 84.

title: In America; When the Bombing Ends
description: There was always a disconnect between the serene beauty of the island of Vieques and the stunning violence of the bombardment that would pound parts of the island when the Navy practiced its combat maneuvers.

title: The Path From Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Longwood, Bronx; Ending Up At Home
description: It was not choice that landed Rosalia Almonte in Longwood almost two decades ago. Nor is it choice, exactly, that keeps her there. It is necessity, dependence and a dearth of alternatives -- and, after years in this mostly Latino and relatively impoverished corner of the South Bronx, some comfort in belonging.

title: Article 2001061890767199784 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: As Bush Replaces Prosecutors, a Formidable One Stays On
description: Nearly five months after President George W. Bush was sworn into office, his administration has begun to replace dozens of top federal prosecutors, ousting Democratic appointees across the country and installing Republican selections.

title: Tchaikovsky in Full-Fledged Variation
description: Ballet music and Tchaikovsky may be synonymous, but the ''Tchaikovsky Spectacular'' presented by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House did not serve this composer all that well. The matching of George Balanchine's ''Theme and Variations'' and the third act of the ballet classic ''Sleeping Beauty,'' which opened and closed the program, did suggest the divergent uses to which Tchaikovsky's music can be put. But the center section of divertissements was a decidedly unspectacular and exhausting hodgepodge.

title: Aid We'd Rather Not Receive
description: HAVANA  The news recently arrived here of the Helms-Lieberman Cuban Solidarity Act of 2001, which would allocate $100 million in aid  financial assistance, medical supplies, office and communications equipment  to Cuban independent and nongovernmental organizations and victims of political repression. While we do not doubt that the intention of the legislators is to "provide increased, decisive support to the democratic opposition in Cuba," we feel that Cuban dissidents on the island have to say: "No, thank you. Not in this way."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAGHER, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: MEAGHER-Joseph William. On June 16, 2001. Dear husband of Lee, loving brother of Ruth Powers and the late Robert, Walter and Agnes Meagher. Devoted uncle to his nephews and nieces. Author of ''Through Midnight Streets,'' ''The Tenement of Dreams'' and ''Tippy Locklin.'' ''He was my North, my South, my East and West, My working week and my Sunday rest...''

description: To the Editor:

title: Author to Sue U.S. Over Book On China's Nuclear Advances
description: An American expert on China's nuclear arms establishment plans to sue the United States government today to end its 18-month delay on publication of his 500-page memoir, which the government says contains federal secrets.

title: Compressed Data; Sign of Hard Times In Silicon Valley
description: It's another sign of the times in Silicon Valley: Autodesk, a leading maker of software for computer-aided design, has ended its Friday afternoon beer bust for programmers.

title: Thai Premier, on National TV, Fights Charge of Corruption
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 18  He talked of his mother. He said he was ready to die for his country. He said he had been confused. He said he was so rich that "it is just impossible for me to keep track of my fortune."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURLAN, ROSLYN
description: KURLAN-Roslyn. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

description: To the Editor:

title: Anguish at 18: Three Contenders and Nobody Wins Open
description: What was an epic battle for 17 holes today became a nightmare on the 18th green.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; Pain May Not Be Over for Telecommunications Equipment
description: The meltdown continues. And despite investors' hopes, it may not end any time soon.

title: A Growing Rivalry Derails AOL Talks For Microsoft Deal
description: The collapse of talks between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner this weekend was rooted in Microsoft's strategy of making its new operating system the tool to provide a wide range of tightly integrated services directly to computer users, an area AOL has dominated for years.

title: Remnants of Deadly Storm Drench Mid-Atlantic, Flooding Roads and Testing Patience
description: The soggy remnants of Tropical Storm Allison slowly pinwheeled across the Middle Atlantic states yesterday, flooding roads, topping off streams and testing patience in the New York metropolitan region before sweeping north and beginning a sluggish turn out to sea.

title: Article 2001061893384866591 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: For Alfonzo's Brother, Brooklyn Is the Big Time
description: After he orchestrates practice for yet another day under the relentless Florida sun, Edgar Alfonzo addresses what will soon be a different situation for him. Alfonzo, the older brother of Mets second baseman Edgardo Alfonzo, is set to begin his second season as a manager in the team's minor league system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, STANLEY
description: LEWIN-Stanley. Of Harrison, NY. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Devoted father of Bruce Lewin and Jamie Meadow and Mark (husband). Grandfather of Stacey and Matt Meadow. Services Monday, 1 PM, at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue (914) 835-2850.

title: Convicted Ex-Aide in France Says 2 Others Knew of Graft
description: PARIS, June 18  Three weeks after being convicted on corruption charges, Roland Dumas, a former foreign minister, has lashed out at two ministers in France's governing Socialist Party, saying both were well aware of the illicit use of money at the Elf Aquitane oil company, which was then state owned.

title: A Promising Start With Russia
description: The quick rapport struck between President Bush and Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, during their initial meeting Saturday exceeded even optimistic expectations, all the more so considering the rhetorical chill that briefly crept over relations between Washington and Moscow earlier this year. On Saturday, Mr. Bush seemed genial and at ease, although his comment that he had looked Mr. Putin in the eye and found him an ''honest, straightforward man,'' whom Americans can trust, struck some observers as nave. Even so, Mr. Putin, whose usual steely demeanor recalls his long years as a Soviet K.G.B. operative, visibly warmed to the personal chemistry of the occasion.

title: Brazilians Argue Over Digital TV Format
description: If Brazil's television broadcasters have their way, even a traffic jam on the highway will not keep commuters from missing a minute of the evening soaps.

title: SENATE CONSIDERS PATIENTS' RIGHTS IN TEST WITH BUSH
description: The Senate opens debate this week on the regulation of health maintenance organizations, putting protections for more than 170 million Americans with private health insurance at the center of the first test of strength between President Bush and the newly ascendant Senate Democrats.

title: In Albany, It's Not Begun Till It's Over
description: Like almost every other deadline in Albany, the end of the legislative session on Wednesday is something of a fiction. Unless unexpected political shifts occur, lawmakers will go home without passing a budget, now 11 weeks late, or reaching agreement on most major bills before them.

title: Now for Tonight's Movie Special, The Gripping Story of . . . Click!; Busy Lives, Cable and Sameness Threaten the Network Film
description: Nearly 50 years ago writers like Paddy Chayefsky, Rod Serling and Horton Foote created the personal dramas that became a hallmark of television's golden age.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SINGER, REBECCA
description: SINGER-Rebecca. Two decades today. Missed greatly and always loved in our hearts. Love, Vivian

description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Burn, Baby, Burn!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, EDWARD J.
description: BAILEY-Edward J. On June 13, 2001, at age 68. Loving father of Paul and Mark, and father-in-law of Rory. Devoted brother and brother-in-law of Lois and Bruce Lehman. Memorial service on Thursday, June 21st, 5:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell on a report that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries raised production in May. In New York, crude oil for July delivery fell 96 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $27.55 a barrel.

title: Sifford Helps Recruiting Of Minority Children
description: Ever since Tiger Woods burst onto the PGA Tour six years ago, people interested in the game have asked: where is the next Tiger Woods?

title: Washington Group's Chairman to Lend Company $10 Million
description: Dennis R. Washington, chairman of Washington Group International, one of the country's largest construction companies, has agreed to lend his company $10 million while it is restructured under bankruptcy protection, Mr. Washington said in an interview today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gang Leader Sentenced
description: Pedro Mendez, 32, a leader of a faction of the Latin Kings street gang, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to three to six years in prison after pleading guilty to third-degree drug sales. Mr. Mendez, of Bushwick, Brooklyn, was arrested in September with gang members who the police said were running a drug and weapons ring.

title: With a Push and Nudge, Young Dancers Gain Confidence
description: Is it possible to measure the impact of the arts in a child's life? When theater or music programs are cut in a school, how much will it matter? If a couple of Broadway actors visit a classroom, does it make a difference? Isn't what happens at home what really counts?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Melvin B. Milligan, who won a $46 million lottery jackpot, misstated the date on which he mailed his winning ticket to headquarters in Trenton. It was June 7, not June 14.

title: North Korea Rebuffs U.S. on Troop Talks
description: In its first official reaction to American proposals to resume talks, North Korea has dismissed a Bush administration request that the issue of conventional forces be included along with questions of nuclear and ballistic missile control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKLEY, HELENA J.
description: HACKLEY-Helena J. Mother of four children, Emilia Fanjul, Anthony May, Helena Martinez & Sherlock Hackley, Jr., grandmother of eight grandchildren and one great granddaughter, died Monday, June 18, 2001, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mrs. Hackley was born in Paris, France, on September 1, 1922, the daughter of the late Dr. Theodore Johnson and Emilia Aguilera of Havana, Cuba. She graduated from The Ethel Walker School and Vassar College with a degree in chemistry. Mrs. Hackley lived most of her life in the city she loved best, New York City. Here she devoted her time as an active volunteer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center beginning in 1974. She served on the Administrative Board of The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering and most recently was a member of The Society's Advisory Council. During her years at MSKCC, she headed, initiated and participated in many programs to improve patient care, especially for children with cancer. Visiting hours for Mrs. Hackley will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street on Tuesday, June 19 from 6PM-9PM. Mass service will be held on Wednesday, June 20th at 11 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church on 66th St. and Lexington Ave. The burial will take place at 11:00 A.M. on Thursday, June 21st at Hillcrest Memorial Cemetery in West Palm Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions for Helena Hackley to support ovarian cancer research may be sent to The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Federal Officials Chosen
description: The head of a group that lobbies for oil development in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge has been named by Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton as her special assistant for Alaska. The appointment of the lobbyist, Cam Toohey, the director for the past five years of Arctic Power, based in Anchorage, drew denunciations from environmental groups and Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who called the appointment ''an ethical oil spill.'' Ms. Norton also announced the appointment of Drue Pearce, a former State Senate president and a drilling proponent, as a senior adviser on Alaska issues. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Broker Sentenced For Fraud
description: The stockbroker serving up to 25 years in prison for plotting to kill a Manhattan judge received an additional sentence yesterday of three to nine years for stock fraud, the crime that originally landed him in jail. The stockbroker, Stuart E. Winkler, pleaded guilty to one count of enterprise corruption for defrauding investors while working as the chief financial officer of A. S. Goldmen & Company, a New Jersey brokerage firm. In December, he was found guilty of plotting the killing of Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The judge was unharmed. Mr. Winkler, of Morganville, N.J., was sentenced by another Supreme Court judge, Carol Berkman. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Media Companies Expect to Meet Estimates
description: Large media companies announced yesterday that they expected to meet analysts' earnings estimates but did not expect advertising revenue, which has been sliding, to rebound much, if at all, this year.

title: Today's Dads: A New Breed?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Article 2001061990460940123 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Consumer Prices Rise
description: European consumer prices jumped at an annual rate of 3.4 percent in May, the fastest they have climbed since the introduction of the euro more than two years ago and much faster than the targets set by the European Central Bank. The new data was not entirely a surprise, because Germany and France had already reported sharp increases in consumer prices. But the data made it unlikely that the central bank would reduce interest rates any time soon, even though growth has slowed sharply in most European countries. The steepest increases were for food, which climbed at an annual rate of 5.9 percent, in part as a result of efforts to contain foot-and-mouth disease. But ''core'' inflation, excluding food and energy prices, also climbed at a fairly steep rate of 2.1 percent. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Public Interests; Taking The Cure
description: Just before the Civil War, a schoolteacher named Mary Waterbury went to a resort in Elmira, N.Y., for a ''water cure.'' This involved being wrapped in a lot of wet sheets, and it was the sort of thing 19th-century Americans regarded as relaxing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: 2 Groups Help Sway Texas Governor on Veto
description: By vetoing a bill that would have banned the execution of mentally retarded death row inmates, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sided with an influential group of district attorneys and with vocal victims' rights advocates who argued that the bill would allow murderers to avoid the death penalty.

title: Showdown Looms as Democrats Move to Burst G.O.P. Budget
description: With Democrats now in control of the Senate and House Republicans eager to find money for their favorite hometown projects, Congress appears to be ready to try to bust the federal budget for next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSFISCH, REGINA
description: WEISSFISCH-Regina. Died June 17, at 87. Refugee from Czechoslovakia to Ecuador 1939, migrated NY, U.S. 1961. Survived by George, Eva, Harry; grandchildren, George, Robert, Maura, Daren; daughters-in-law, Jane, Sandra.

title: Compromise Proposed on Contraception Coverage
description: All but declared dead three months ago, a sharply contested measure that would require health insurance companies to cover contraception has suddenly resurfaced. On Sunday evening, the Senate Republican leadership quietly introduced a compromise bill that would permit religious groups to opt out of such a mandate but would let their employees pay for birth control coverage.

title: Afghan Rulers To Let Women Carry Out A U.N. Survey
description: After a yearlong standoff, the Taliban government of Afghanistan has agreed to let the World Food Program employ local women to survey the food needs of the most vulnerable households in the country, which is suffering the effects of drought and famine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORNMAN, IRENE
description: CORNMAN-Irene. Beloved friend. Naomi

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Hartford, a provider of high-technology products in aerospace and building industries, said its Pratt & Whitney jet engine unit had won maintenance and service contracts from United Airlines of the UAL Corp., Chicago, which owns the second-largest airline, valued at $400 million over five years.

title: Chancellor Orders Hiring Freeze At School Board's Central Office
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has ordered an immediate freeze on hiring of administrators at the Board of Education's central offices, according to a memorandum released by the chancellor's office yesterday.

title: LIBBEY AGREES TO ACQUIRE A MAKER OF KITCHEN GLASSWARE
description: Libbey, North America's largest glassware maker, agreed yesterday to buy the Anchor Hocking glassware business from Newell Rubbermaid for $332 million. Anchor Hocking, which makes baking dishes, drinking glasses and specialty glass products, had sales of $216 million last year. Libbey, based in Toledo, Ohio, said the purchase would add 10 cents to 15 cents a share to earnings after the first year of ownership and provide tax savings of $5 million a year. Libbey sells mostly to institutional users like bars, hospitals and cruise ships, and wants to increase its retail sales. Anchor Hocking sells to department stores, warehouse clubs and grocery and drugstores.

title: A Healing Power
description: To the Editor:

title: NUVEEN TO BUY SYMPHONY, AN INSTITUTIONAL FUND MANAGER
description: The John Nuveen Company, the mutual fund and money manager, said it would buy Symphony Asset Management for $210 million to expand its business with institutions and wealthy investors. Nuveen, which is based in Chicago, said it would acquire Symphony, which manages $4 billion in stocks and bonds primarily for institutions, from Barra Inc. and Symphony's management. Symphony, whose clients include Stanford University, Princeton University, the International Monetary Fund and the Walt Disney Company, specializes in ''market neutral'' investment strategies intended to produce steady returns regardless of market fluctuations

title: Wonderland In Motion, With a Nod To Vaudeville
description: Alice danced happily into Wonderland when the New York Theater Ballet presented ''The Alice-in-Wonderland Follies'' on Friday afternoon at Gould Hall.

title: The Quest to Be Cool in High School
description: Kieran Culkin doesn't look much like his famous brother, Macaulay; instead, he has the air of a baby Robert Downey Jr. Andy Dick has gone over the top and beyond as a high school drama teacher who makes Chris Elliott's 30-something newsboy on ''Get a Life'' seem like a paragon of self-knowledge. Henry Krakowski (Kyle Sabihy) may be the first high-school-age television character who is fat, smart (so smart that his teachers hate him) and extremely cool. Whether this all adds up to a viable television series is questionable, but ''Go Fish,'' which has its premiere tonight on NBC with back-to-back episodes, is certainly worth a look. Possibly two.

title: Today's Dads: A New Breed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Useful Legacy Of Nuclear Treaty: Global Earphones
description: Though the Senate voted two years ago to reject a treaty that bans nuclear testing, one of its provisions is alive and thriving: the global network of sensors meant to listen for clandestine nuclear blasts.

title: Sharon Faces New Pressure As 2 Drivers Are Killed
description: Two Israeli drivers were killed today in shootings in the West Bank. But Prime Minister Ariel Sharon rejected demands by Jewish settlers that he call off Israel's tentative truce with the Palestinians and respond to drive-by attacks with military force.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about a call by a cabdriver organization, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, for a fuel surcharge on fares misspelled the given name of its spokeswoman in some copies. She is Bhairavi Desai, not Bhalravi.

title: Article 2001061993555924392 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Economy Weakens
description: Thailand's economic growth rate slowed to 1.8 percent in the first quarter of 2001 from 3.2 percent a year earlier, its slowest rate in two years, as exports, manufacturing, consumption and investment all weakened. The National Economic and Social Development Board, a state-run research group, predicted that growth would continue to slow in the second quarter before rebounding in the second half of the year. Thailand's central bank recently raised interest rates to defend the Thai currency, a move economists say is expected to slow expansion further. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Studies Show That Kids Are Solicited Online
description: One in five children who regularly go online is approached by strangers for sex, according to a new study. Yet most of the young people say they are not bothered by the messages and to ignore or block them, another study says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHER, MILDRED (MICKEY)
description: TEICHER-Mildred (Mickey). Died in Miami, FL. on June 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Morton for 60 years. Cherished mother of Phyllis and Alvin Goldman, Oren Teicher and Alison Greene. Proud grandmother of Elizabeth, Mattis, Mark, Carrie, Jessica and Zachary. Devoted daughter of the late Esther and Morris Adler. Sister of the late Samuel & Herbert Adler. Sister-inlaw of Bunny Adler, Sylvia Adler & Gerald Teicher. Loving aunt and great aunt to her many nieces and nephews. Former resident of New Rochelle, N.Y. She earned her Bachelors in Art History at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill & her Masters degree in Jewish Studies at Barry University, Miami. A Jewish Art Historian, she served as the Director of the Beck Museum of Judaica, Beth David Congregation, Miami. Services at Bet Am Shalom, 295 Soundview Ave, White Plains, New York, Wednesday, June 20, 10AM. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Mount Pleasant, N.Y. Shiva will be held at the Teicher home, 10 Richbell Road, White Plains, NY.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 Communications Cutting Jobs
description: Level 3 Communications, the operator of a large fiber optic communications network, said yesterday that it would cut 1,400 jobs, or nearly a quarter of its work force, as the company faces a bleak sales outlook over the next two years. Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., also said that it expected revenue from the sale of capacity on its network to decline almost 40 percent and that it would take a $100 million charge related in part to the job cuts. Long-haul communications networks are struggling with steep sales declines after a feverish buildup in capacity. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAREZKY, MONROE URIS
description: SAREZKY-Monroe Uris. Died June 4, surrounded by his loving family. Born in Brooklyn in 1918, son of Eugene and Gussie Uris Sarezky. Mr. Sarezky was a key player in Fairfield County's building boom beginning in the 1950's. His firm, Monroe Construction Co. built high-rise apartments in Stamford and Bridgeport, CT, and a nursing home in Greenwich. In 1963 he founded the Stamford Apartment Owner's Association which helped overcome obstacles to Fairfield County's development. He was a founder of First Stamford Bank in 1972 and served as a director until it was acquired by Peoples Bank. Mr. Sarezky played semi-professional baseball prior to entering Johns Hopkins University at age 16. He graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1938 and in 1940 married Roslyn Nevas of Stamford, a Goucher College graduate. In April 2000 the couple celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary. After graduation, Mr. Sarezky supervised construction of Manhattan apartment buildings and government housing in Washington DC, Virginia, Maryland and New York State, for Uris Brothers Builders. Between 1943 & 1945 he saw combat in the Pacific as the gunnery officer on the destroyer USS Childs. In 1997 he was formally honored as a ''walking advertisement for the value of a liberal arts education'', by Johns Hopkins for his lifelong support of his alma mater. No less an important part of his life was his quiet generosity to individuals & families he encountered who were struggling financially. His love of travel took him & his wife from their Palm Beach residence to over 150 countries, and in 1994 Mr. Sarezky journeyed to The North Pole. He was an accomplished photographer of exotic landscapes & wildlife, and lectured on his North Pole excursion. He was a longtime patron & member of The Kravis Center in Palm Beach. He is survived by his wife; sons Michael, a physician, and Laurence, an attorney & writer; daughter Louise, a graphics artist; daughters-in-law Virginia Smith & Sheryl Sarezky; his sister Carol Smith of Manhasset; his brother Michael Sheldon of Stamford; and grandchildren Ethan, Kevin, Daniel & Jonathan Sarezky. He will be profoundly missed by his loving family and the many others whose lives were enriched by his warmth, guidance, generosity & humor. Donations in Mr. Sarezky's memory may be made to The Richard Rosenthal Hospice Residence, Shelbourne & W. Broad Streets, Stamford, CT 06902.

title: Fewer Options for Older Cancer Patients
description: How aggressively to treat cancer in the elderly is a difficult question, but researchers from the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan who reviewed data on chemotherapy for colon cancer patients suggest that caution may be overdone.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Utility Merger Moves Forward
description: Shareholders have agreed to a merger of the RGS Energy Group and the the Energy East Corporation. RGS is the parent of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation; Energy East's companies include the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, the Connecticut Natural Gas Corporation and the Southern Connecticut Gas Company. The merger, which both companies' shareholders approved on Friday, is to be completed early next year, subject to state and federal regulatory approval. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We offer our cooperation. We offer to work jointly. If there is no need that such joint work is needed, well, suit yourself.''

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Robert Heyssel, 72, Ex-President Of the Johns Hopkins Hospital
description: Dr. Robert M. Heyssel, a former president of the Johns Hopkins Hospital who oversaw a major expansion there and worked to improve the delivery of health services, especially to the poor, died on Wednesday in Seaford, Del., where he lived. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, STANLEY
description: LEWIN-Stanley. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Stanley Lewin. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 360networks Loses Major Contract
description: In yet another sign of difficulties among operators of fiber optic networks, 360networks has lost an important contract with Impsat Fiber Networks of Argentina. The loss adds to the woes of 360networks, which missed a $10.9 million bond interest payment last week. The value of the contract was not disclosed. 360networks also said yesterday that it had abandoned plans to acquire NetRail, an Internet service provider. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: The Web as Dictator Of Scientific Fashion
description: If the endlessly accelerating pace of scientific research is riding the telecommunications revolution, then why did physicists, historians and philosophers meet here recently at an isolated lodge where cell phones generally do not work and many of the rooms have no phones at all, let alone speedy Internet connections?

title: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 15  She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.

title: As the Day Wanes, Missing the Cuban Sun
description: IN CUBA I WAS A GERMAN SHEPHERD

title: Document: The Study of Oprah
description: This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: "Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon," developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was "to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism."
