Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

title: Unrest in Algeria
description: For most of the last decade, Algeria has been riven by one of the world's most brutal civil wars. As many as 100,000 people have died in a struggle between the army and Islamist insurgents. Now, although the war is largely isolated in rural regions, the country has been rocked by mounting social unrest that exploded last week in the largest popular demonstrations since 1962.

title: New Arena Hinges on Deal For an Old One
description: The ground rules are simple: to complete a deal to build a new arena in Newark, officials must also put together a deal for the future of the Meadowlands sports complex, which would lose the Nets and Devils and their Continental Arena if an arena is built in Newark.

title: Mets Awaken To the Reality Of Their Plight
description: You would not know it by the score of the Mets' victory over the visiting Montreal Expos, who played virtually the entire game without their best player, but maybe the Mets did get jolted in their weekend series with the Yankees.

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, JEROME
description: TAYLOR-Jerome, 82. Died June 17, after a courageous struggle with cancer. He leaves a devoted family, wife Norma, son Richard, daughter and son-in-law Joanna and Jack Lester, grandson Sam and sister Betty Merino. He will be missed by his many friends and relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENARO, R. JOHN
description: DENARO-R. John. May 11, 2001, of heart failure. Age 56. Beloved son of Mary Denaro and partner of David Cawley of Brooklyn. Organist and Choir Director, St. Saviour's RC Church, Brooklyn. Director Park Slope Singers and member Stonewall Chorale. He is greatly missed by friends, family and the many Brooklyn communities he has served.

title: Argentina Moves to Overhaul Peso's Peg to the Dollar
description: Argentina has announced a complex set of new economic policies, including the installation of multiple exchange rates, a move that effectively amounts to a devaluation to help the country's exporters. But the plan was met by sharp criticism on Wall Street and roiled markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, MAURICE
description: MORRIS-Maurice. June 17, 2001. Survived by his daughter Fiona (Zane Dick), granddaughter Marissa Dick. Graveside services on Friday, 2 PM in St. Michael's Cemetery, East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Today's Dads: A New Breed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Defibrillator Test Trips Up Doctors
description: A study published this month in The British Medical Journal posed a simple question: ''Do doctors position defibrillation paddles correctly?'' The answer was apparently not.

title: Tunnel Vision; Bags of Joy, Pungent And Lucky
description: Officially, of course, it will always be the B train.

title: Godmother of Punk Rock Is No Comeback Kid
description: PATTI SMITH appears quietly inside Caffe Dante in Greenwich Village, her gray-streaked hair dripping wet and stringy around her long, angular face from the Sunday morning downpour. She isn't carrying an umbrella. And her soaked appearance isn't on her mind at this early hour.

title: An AOL Executive Is Under Suspension During Investigation
description: America Online has suspended Eric Keller, a top deal maker, pending an investigation of his involvement with PurchasePro.com, a troubled software company, executives close to the matter said yesterday.

title: Article 2001061992131186880 -- No Title
Doing Business in the Senate
description: The organizing process undertaken by the Senate every two years usually occurs with little fuss. But with a newly constituted Senate now in Democratic control, what used to be a routine housekeeping chore has become a focus of partisan impasse. Republicans are demanding a ban on a parliamentary tactic employed in the past to block some judicial nominations, and they are seeking guarantees that all Supreme Court nominations will be brought to the Senate floor, even if they are rejected in committee. This is a case that can be resolved with some good will. Democrats should give in on one but not both the Republican requests.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Second Hat In Tory Ring
description: Iain Duncan Smith, the Conservative Party's military spokesman, became the second candidate for Tory leader to succeed William Hague, who is stepping down after the party's loss in the June 7 election. Mr. Duncan Smith represents the party's right wing and has the backing of Lady Thatcher, the former prime minister. He seeks to block the front runner, Michael Portillo, a one-time Thatcher protg who has evolved into a social liberal. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: A Flashback, Very Orderly, To the France Of Louis XIV
description: The French dislike our forests. The randomness disturbs them: the fallen branches, the uncleared underbrush. At home an overpowering symmetry rules the lovely green spaces of Paris as it did French opera 325 years ago. Nature, human or otherwise, will not be trusted to manage its own affairs, and ''Thse'' -- as put on by the Boston Early Music Festival at the Copley Theater this afternoon -- reminded us of that. Think of this Lully opera in terms of the Parc Monceau, emotions manicured like a row of hedges.

title: Casinos Recast Prison Town as a Boom City
description: Joliet's listless black canal once carried treated sewage from Chicago, 40 miles to the north, through the core of a decrepit downtown where gangs roamed freely. Well into the 1980's, with the city's steel and machinery factories vanishing, unemployment reached 20 percent. About the only noteworthy thing left in Joliet was its maximum-security state prison.

title: A Doctor's Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: Several G.O.P. Senators Back Money for Stem Cell Research
description: Several Republican senators are urging President Bush to authorize the use of federal money for medical research that involves cells derived from human embryos.

title: Father's Day Heroes
description: Harry Ford was the father of a grown daughter and two younger sons, Brian Fahey the father of three young sons, including twins, John Downing the father of a young daughter and son. All three men died Sunday, on Father's Day, in the worst disaster to hit the New York City Fire Department since three members of Ladder Company 170 died in a fireball in Brooklyn three years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Officers In Murder-Suicide
description: An off-duty narcotics detective fatally shot his girlfriend, also a police officer, before killing himself at her Bronx apartment Sunday night, the police said yesterday. The detective, Edwin Patten, 30, reportedly used his service revolver to shoot Officer Stacie Williamson, 28, a four-year veteran, three times in the chest during an argument. Detective Patten, a seven-year police veteran who lived in Yonkers, then shot himself in the head, the police said. Both officers were assigned to the Bronx narcotics division, and according to the police had been dating for about a year. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about growing competition in public radio misidentified the producers of the program ''Car Talk.'' It is produced by a production company with the ironic name Dewey, Cheetham & Howe and by WBUR, both in Boston, and is distributed by National Public Radio; it is not produced by Minnesota Public Radio.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about the American Fashion Awards, presented on Thursday in New York, misidentified the category in which Sean Combs was a nominee. It was the Perry Ellis Award for Men's Wear, presented to a newcomer, not the Men's Wear Designer of the Year.

title: Handicapping Reactors by the Numbers
description: To provide more electricity and less carbon emission, the Bush administration has revived talk of nuclear power, with top officials discussing the possibility of hundreds of new reactors.

title: Goosen Puts Panic Button Away and Wins Open
description: For Retief Goosen, today wasn't only about winning. It was about redemption. It was proof that his confidence wasn't shattered by his meltdown Sunday on the 18th green when he missed a putt from 18 inches, a gaffe that temporarily cost him the United States Open and forced today's 18-hole playoff against Mark Brooks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENTON, JOSEPH RABB
description: DENTON-Joseph Rabb. Great friend to many, lecturer, engineer. Peacefully at home, April 27, 2001. Farewell for a space.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Clemens Makes Recovery Quick for the Yanks
description: The shocking home run that beat the Yankees late Sunday night was a conversation piece today, the players unanimous in their agreement that Mike Piazza's rocket off Carlos Almanzar was even longer than the monster shot he hit off Ramiro Mendoza in 1999.

title: An Ex-Convict Is Charged With a Killing
description: The Suffolk County police said today that they had charged an ex-convict with killing a 29-year-old woman who vanished before work last week and whose bludgeoned, sexually abused body was found a day later in the woods near the Deer Park railroad station.

title: COMPANY THAT INVESTIGATES JOB APPLICANTS WILL BE SOLD
description: Automatic Data Processing, a payroll processor, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Avert, which investigates job applicants, for about $81 million. Automatic Data of Roseland, N.J., agreed to pay $22 a share, 26 percent above Avert's closing share price on Friday. Avert, based in Fort Collins, Colo., had sales last year of $17.5 million.

title: A Top Five Accounting Firm to Pay $7 Million Over Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today brought civil fraud charges against Arthur Andersen in the first such case filed against a Big Five accounting firm in more than a decade. Andersen settled the charges and agreed to pay a penalty of $7 million, the largest ever assessed against an accounting firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAPPIER, BILL
description: FRAPPIER-Bill. Dear friend, business partner and confidant, you were the better half of the ''odd couple.'' You have left a hole in our hearts and lives that will never be filled. We love and miss you. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to your family. Barbara and Mark Goldsmith

title: Norway's Statoil Offering Fails to Impress Investors
description: It is the ninth-largest publicly traded oil company in the world, at a time when crude oil prices have almost tripled since the end of 1998. It holds dominion over a vast portion of oil and natural gas below the North Sea. It supplies a large share of the natural gas used in Europe.

title: CONSECO REDEEMS $550 MILLION IN DEBT-CUTTING EFFORT
description: The insurer Conseco has redeemed $550 million in public debt on schedule. Under Gary Wendt, its chairman, Conseco has repaid $1.5 billion of the $2 billion it planned to repay by year-end. The company, based near Indianapolis, ran into trouble last year when problems at its consumer-lending unit heightened concern about its ability to repay its debt. It still must repay $478 million in bank debt and $54.3 million in public debt by the end of the year. Mark Lubbers, a Conseco spokesman, said yesterday the company planned to repay the outstanding debt soon after it completes a $400 million debt offering.

title: Cannelton Journal; Waiting for Extraterrestrials to Land in the Mines
description: From his front-porch perch atop Mount Olive at the Blue Skies Home for the Elderly, Paul Wilshire recalled laboring down in the coal mines the old way, the antique way, with a low-tech mule named Susie.

title: Like a Kite, Grounded But Soaring To the Skies
description: Undisputed greatness can get to be a bore. On Sunday at Madison Square Garden, Bono looked into the adoring crowd and made it seem as if he recognized every face. And his lifelong band mates -- the Edge, Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen Jr. -- turned each song into a musical rocket ship aimed heavenward. It was what everyone expects from U2, the designated hitter on Team Rock 'n' Roll, now that this band has come to its senses after some years of self-doubt, returning to irreproachable grandeur.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the responses of Edison International and the PG&E Corporation to California's energy crisis misidentified the executive who is campaigning to convince the public that a settlement with lawmakers is preferable to bankruptcy. He is John E. Bryson, the chief executive of Edison; Robert D. Glynn Jr. is his counterpart at PG&E.

title: Giving Credit to Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glimpse Of the New, An Echo Of the Past
description: History was in the air on Saturday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, though not, perhaps, in an expected way. The festival's 69 seasons of presenting and developing dancers and choreographers were embodied in the fine performing in this opening gala program, by two first-rate solo dancers and members of Buglisi-Foreman Dance and the Limn Dance Company. A little-seen 1961 solo by Jos Limn, reconstructed for the program, proved to be a historical curiosity at best.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Solectron Reports A Loss
description: The Solectron Corporation, the a large electronics manufacturer, said yesterday that it had a loss in its fiscal third-quarter and expected profit and sales this quarter would fall because of slowing demand. The company also plans to cut 12,600 more jobs by the end of the quarter. The loss was $185.7 million, or 28 cents a share, for the period ended June 1. In the year-earlier quarter, the company had net income of $119.7 million, or 19 cents. The company said orders have slowed as customers, which include International Business Machines. and Cisco Systems, buy fewer routers and switches. Solectron cut 8,200 jobs, a 10 percent reduction, in the quarter and announced plans to close a factory in Georgia to reduce costs. The layoffs planned for this quarter combined with the earlier one will reduce the company's staff by 26 percent, to 59,200.

title: Justices Allow Prison Journalist To Have a Retrial
description: The Supreme Court refused yesterday to reverse a lower court's decision that effectively granted a new trial to Wilbert Rideau, who became a crusading prison journalist after being convicted of murder in a 1961 Louisiana bank robbery.

title: Accounts
description: Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone, expanded its relationship with the Irvine, Calif., office of Campbell Mithun, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, by naming the agency to handle its reorganized account for an enlarged Western region. Campbell Mithun was previously the agency of record for the Southwest. Billings for the combined account were estimated at $40 million.

title: Article 2001061990009258931 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Hidden in the World of Medicine, Discrimination and Stereotypes
description: It is obvious from even a cursory look at history that doctors sometimes act with prejudice. Consider that as recently as the early 1960's, before major civil rights and Medicare legislation, black women were housed in separate maternity wards. Or that 10 years ago, in some places, AIDS patients could not find a surgeon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, KITTY F. (NEE MACRAE)
description: CAMERON-Kitty F. (nee MacRae) age 97, June 16th, 2001 in Exeter, NH. Beloved wife of the late Duncan, a retired Captain of NYPD. Loving mother of Mary of Exeter, NH. Funeral Mass in NH, interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: A Class of Teaching Fellows, Preparing to Learn on the Job
description: More than 1,200 people from other professions reported for duty yesterday for the second year of the New York City Teaching Fellows program, which provides a crash course in teaching and pays for the participants to get the master's degree required for certification.

title: Court Gives More Protection To Officers Sued Over Force
description: The Supreme Court added an extra layer of protection today for police officers accused in suits of using excessive force.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Greenwich Village Bank Robbed
description: A fleeing robber prompted the evacuation of the West Fourth Street subway station near Washington Square yesterday and caused minor injuries to six people, including two transit officers, when he opened a money bag containing exploding red dye that emitted caustic fumes, the police said. The man, who was still at large last night, had demanded money from a teller at the Dime Savings Bank at 340 Avenue of the Americas shortly after 2:30 p.m. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: A Voice Soothes Workers at Lunchtime
description: Singing in a church is a tough business. The echoey acoustics of your average church act like an amplifier that can blur a slender and controlled thread of music into an imprecise blob of sound, hovering just outside the singer's range of control. Given the delicate nature of that control and the size of the sound that results, the experience can be likened to pushing a load of bricks uphill with a bamboo rod.

title: Brutal Interpretation of a Judge's Ruling
description: This is a 30-second commercial, ''Wrong,'' released by former Representative Bob Franks in his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey against Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City. It began running yesterday.

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Stop and Shop Begins A Broadcast Review
description: The Stop and Shop Companies, which operates more than 300 supermarkets in five Northeastern states, is beginning a review for its broadcast advertising account. That account has been handled for more than 20 years by the Boston agency now known as Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising.

title: Larger Loss Forecast at American and T.W.A.
description: The AMR Corporation, the owner of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines, will report a far greater quarterly loss than expected and will begin retiring aging airplanes ahead of schedule to cut costs, the company said yesterday.

title: Requests From a Juror
description: To the Editor:

title: Graffiti Artists and Bialy Makers; The Smithsonian Gathers a Few of New York's Unsung
description: With eight million people to pick from, Nancy Groce winnowed it down to 200. She lined up Andrew Rosenwach to handle the water tower. She picked out Steve Ross to make the bagels. She wanted a bus driver, and she figured, how can you go wrong with Tony Palombella? He works the 96th Street crosstown route, loves to joke around, tell stories. She got Bio and friends for the artwork.

title: OBSERVATION
description: Coral Reef Survival

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, HEDWIG (NEE SIMON)
description: MARX-Hedwig (Nee Simon). Died June 18, 2001 in her 95th year, after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's. She is survived by her daughter Ellen Kramer and much loved and wonderful son-inlaw, Burt, with whom she resided the last years of her life. She will forever be remembered for her great indomitable spirit and love of her family. Unselfish & devoted wife of the late Max, mother of Gerard her late beloved son. Dedicated grandmother of Judith and husband Kevin, Daniel and wife Michelle, and Eric and devoted daughter-in-law Silvia, all of whom she loved with unending joy and pride. At her request services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, AGATHA WELSCH KESSLER
description: SPITZ-Agatha Welsch Kessler. Beloved wife of Benjamin Spitz, mother of Lawrence Kessler, grandmother and great-grandmother. A teacher of English at Flushing High School for 30 years and a good companion of her many friends in her retirement. The funeral will be at 1 PM on Tuesday, June 19, at Parkside Funeral Home, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Sniping Mets Should Look In the Mirror
description: There were about a dozen players and two reporters in the Mets' clubhouse yesterday when an angry, booming voice erupted from one corner and disrupted the calm. Armando Benitez, shirtless and wearing long underwear and with a gold chain around his neck, complained loudly about teammates who had been quoted anonymously while criticizing Timo Perez.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Computer Sciences Names President
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer services company, has named Edward Boykin president and chief operating officer. Mr. Boykin, a 35-year veteran of the company, was head of the financial services group. His promotion will give Van Honeycutt, the chairman, more time to focus on strategy, the company said. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Flammable Liquids Suspected in Fatal Blast
description: Although it may be some time before investigators determine the precise cause of the explosion that killed three firefighters in Queens on Sunday, fire officials said yesterday that early indications pointed to flammable liquids that were stored in a basement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILNER, JAMES
description: MILNER-James. Beloved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Mary Wittner and Robert Milner their spouses Andrew Wittner and Saralee Milner. Cherished grandfather of Pamela D'Alexander, Diane Wittner and Steve Wittner, and their spouses Jon Acheson, Doug D'Alexander and Jane Wittner. Adored great grandfather of Baird, Gabriel, Domenic, Steven and Beth. Died quietly in his sleep in his 94th year leaving a legacy of quiet strength, implacable moral standards and a 75-year history of giving musical joy. We mourn his passing and cherish his memory.

title: Weighing In on Bagels
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Asiana Walkout Ends
description: A six-day walkout at Asiana Airlines, Korea's second-largest airline, ended as ground crew workers agreed on a 4.5 percent pay increase and a 6 percent increase in allowances, far below their original demands. Asiana, which had canceled most of its domestic flights, promised to return to normal service by today. The strike ended four days after a two-day walkout of pilots of Korean Air, the country's largest airline. Four pilots, including the leader of its union, were arrested last weekend, accused of instigating an illegal strike. The walkouts were part of a nationwide general strike that has virtually collapsed amid lack of public support. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Greece's Adaptability
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: Trahan, Burden & Charles, Baltimore, formed a consulting alliance with CIA USA, New York, to use its media planning and buying services. CIA USA is the American division of the CIA Medianetwork unit of the Tempus Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIANCARDI, DOMINICK
description: BIANCARDI-Dominick, proprietor of Biancardi Meats, Bronx, NY. On Sunday, June 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Randazzo). Loving father of Anne DeSousa, Anthony and Maria Fealey. Beloved grandfather of Nina, Nicholas, James, Joanna & Francesca. Fond brother of Louise Abbitable & Anthony. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, Wednesday at 9:30 AM. A Mass of Christian Burial St. Frances de Chantal at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The New York Presbyterian Hospital, Division of Hematology/Oncology, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021, Attn: Roy Silverstein, MD would be appreciated.

title: Hilliard Has Foot Surgery, Reducing the Giants' Anxiety
description: Ike Hilliard, who led the Giants in touchdown receptions last season, underwent what the team termed successful foot surgery yesterday, but he will miss training camp and possibly the team's season-opening game Sept. 10 at Denver. The surgery brings to a close a peculiar, puzzling chapter, one that had team officials fervently, but in the end fruitlessly, trying to contact Hilliard this winter in an effort to assess the problem with his right foot.

title: Silver Recasts Himself as Amiable, Even Open, After Ouster Attempt
description: When the Assembly Democrats meet these days in the Capitol, before they get to the policy debates or the questions of political tactics, Speaker Sheldon Silver announces legislators' birthdays.

title: Jennifer Moyer; Publisher, 52
description: Jennifer Moyer, president of Moyer Bell Ltd., book publishers, died on June 10 at her home in Wakefield, R.I. She was 52.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABLONDI, ITALO H.
description: ABLONDI-Italo H. On Saturday, June 16, 2001 at the John Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Unalane C. Ablondi of Alexandria, VA. Father of Leigh Mary Helvie of Ann Harbor, MI, Kim Ablondi of New York City and Phillip Carter Ablondi of New York City. Grandfather of Anna Karia, Peter and John Helvie. Friends may call at the Demaine Funeral Home, 520 South Washington St, Alexandria, VA. on Tuesday, June 19 from 2-4 and 6-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on June 20 at St. Mary's Catholic Church, 310 South Royal St., Alexandria, VA. at 10:30AM. Interment Ivy Hill Cemetery, Alexandria, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, in C/O Gastric Cancer Research, 124 Park St S.E., Vienna, VA. 22183.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Developer Gives To Wharton
description: William L. Mack, a real estate developer, has given $10 million to the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania to create a new technology center, the university announced yesterday. The William and Phyllis Mack Center for Technological Innovation will support the research and publishing of faculty members, create an endowed professorship and support a student-run conference. Mr. Mack, a Wharton alumnus, is president of the Mack Organization, which develops warehouses, and chairman of the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Cranford, N.J.

title: Foreign Affairs; Cease-Fire Umpteen
description: Even thinking about writing a column about an Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire is a dangerous thing. It's dangerous because you know it could end at any moment -- while you're writing, after you've sent your column in, even after it's printed in the paper but before it's delivered to your door -- and you'll end up looking foolish. Nobody in his right mind writes about cease-fires in the Middle East. But I can't resist this one.

title: 4 Top Officers Leave San Francisco Office
description: The four top executives at the San Francisco office of the British agency Leagas Delaney are leaving, they said, because of disagreements over the course of the agency.

title: PRICEWATERHOUSE CLOSING OR SELLING 10 OFFICES
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm, said yesterday that it was closing or selling as many as 10 offices around the country. The move is part of an effort to concentrate on major markets, said a spokesman, David Nestor. Most of the partners at the affected offices will join the acquiring firms, relocate or retire, he said. The firm also said that because of the economic slowdown, employees of its consulting arm would receive minimal pay increases and that raises would reflect individual performance. According to the e-mail announcement on salary increases that was distributed internally last week, some employees may receive no raise at all. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: New Yorkers, Nature Is All Around You
description: To the Editor:

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dana Wechsler Linden, Emma Trenti Paroli and Mia Wechsler Doron; Offering Comfort and Information To the Parents of Preemies
description: When Dana Wechsler Linden and Emma Trenti Paroli exchanged nervous glances in a neonatal intensive care unit, they never expected that they would be embarking on a four-year career journey together.

title: Talking the Talk, Sometimes in Spanish
description: In a crowded mayoral race where every vote counts and Latinos could be a deciding voting bloc, the six men who want the city's top job are vying for their piece of the Hispanic vote and collecting endorsements from Hispanic leaders as if they were badges of honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSBERG, HARRY
description: WACHSBERG-Harry. It is with profound regret that we mourn the passing of our life long friend and associate, Harry Wachsberg. Michael Werdiger Inc. Richard Werdiger Alan Kleinberg

title: Dressed as Tooth Fairy, I.R.S. Will Drop a Note to Millions
description: The letter is written in the congratulatory tone of a college acceptance letter or a telegram to a sweepstakes winner. The message is certainly appealing, a welcome surprise given that the letterhead will read: Internal Revenue Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DAVID J.
description: GOLDBERG-David J. Of Lawrenceville, NJ on June 18, 2001. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Daniel (Holly) Goldberg and Debra (Joseph) Bernier, dear brother of Shirley Rosenberg, Jacob, Edward and Rose Goldberg. Cherished grandfather of Pamela, Sophia, Benjamin & Bryan. Services Wednesday 1 PM at Har Sinai Temple, 491 Bellevue Ave., Trenton, NJ. Mourning period Wednesday and Thursday at the residence. For information Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400.

title: Yemen Arrests Suspects in Plot on U.S. Agents for Bomb Case
description: A group of suspects have been arrested in Yemen in connection with a possible terrorist plot against F.B.I. and United States Navy personnel investigating the bombing there last year of the destroyer Cole, a senior government official said tonight.

title: World Briefing
description: Europe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOZAK, AARON
description: KOZAK-Aaron. We have loss a very special and true friend and celebrate his life for everything he brought to ours. We will remember his sparkling eyes always. Our deepest sorrow to Pat, Ellen and Jeffrey. Suzanne and Sandy Schlesinger and Tom Gannon

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Interest Rates Cut
description: Israel's central bank cut interest rates yesterday by a fifth of a percentage point for the second time this month, an expected move that lowered nominal lending rates to 6.8 percent. Government and business leaders had urged a sharper reduction, after reports of a worsening economic slowdown and a two-thirds drop in foreign investment for the year. William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

title: U.S. AGENCY WIDENS ITS CURBS ON PRICE OF POWER IN WEST
description: Broadening their efforts to rein in California's power crisis, federal regulators today ordered that restraints on electricity prices be applied at all hours and extended to 10 other states across the West.

title: China Justice: Swift Passage To Execution
description: Nothing in Hao Fengqin's abbreviated life suggested that she would end her days on an execution ground.

title: Today's Dads: A New Breed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Monitor For Hate Groups
description: The Anti-Defamation League, a division of B'nai B'rith, started a Web site yesterday to provide information to law enforcement agencies about hate groups. The league's director, Abraham Foxman, left, said the site -- www.adl.org/learn -- would help the police identify hate groups' symbols, track their meetings and rallies, and obtain background information on their leaders and publications.

title: A Geisha, a Successful Novel and a Lawsuit
description: In 1992 Mineko Iwasaki was a retired geisha living quietly with her husband and daughter in the hills of Kyoto when a young American author named Arthur Golden called upon her with an unusual request. He was researching a book on geishas and wanted her help.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. Missed so much on your birthday. Wish you could share our joys. Remembered with love. Gene, children and grandchildren

title: Sam Jethroe Is Dead at 83; Was Oldest Rookie of the Year
description: Sam Jethroe, a star center fielder of the Negro leagues who was named rookie of the year while with the 1950 Boston Braves at age 32 and is the oldest player ever to receive the award, died last Saturday at a hospital in Erie, Pa. He was 83.

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer Medica Profits
description: Sulzer Medica, Europe's largest maker of orthopedic products, said that additional costs for the recall of faulty hip joints the company supplied in the United States could hurt profits. More than 1,900 people have undergone surgery to replace the Inter-Op shells, or hip joints, up from 1,700 last month when the company warned its insurance would not cover the costs of compensating patients. The company, which is set to be spun off from the Swiss industrial group Sulzer next month, estimated that it could cover the additional costs from cash reserves. But those costs could soar because of the 800 lawsuits filed against the company as of the beginning of June. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Memorial for Milt Hinton
description: Friends and colleagues of the jazz bassist Milt Hinton will appear at a musical tribute to him on Sunday at 4 p.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights. Mr. Hinton died at 90 in December.

title: Franks Ad About Fund Receives Upbeat Reply
description: Aiming at primary voters squarely in the gut, former Representative Bob Franks began running a television commercial today that accuses Bret D. Schundler, his opponent in next week's Republican primary for governor of New Jersey, of ''taking money from needy children'' to promote his political ambitions.

title: Letters: A Healing Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Geraldine Ferraro Fights Blood Cancer
description: She remembers hearing the word thalidomide half a lifetime ago, when she was a young mother in Queens and it was a pharmaceutical scourge that maimed children.

title: 5-Nation Pact Is Step Toward 'Open Skies'
description: SINGAPORE  The United States and four other Pacific rim nations say that they have broken significant new ground by concluding the first multilateral accord to liberalize air transport based on "open skies" principles.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Melvin B. Milligan, who won a $46 million lottery jackpot, misstated the date on which he mailed his winning ticket to headquarters in Trenton. It was June 7, not June 14.

title: Spacecraft's Supercamera Captures Earth in All Its Detail
description: From its orbit 440 miles above Earth's surface, NASA's Terra spacecraft has been providing a clearer, more colorful view of the planet.

title: 3 States Plan a Court Fight On Air-Conditioner Efficiency
description: New York, California and Connecticut and several environmental and consumer groups are going to court to try to stop the Bush administration's decision to weaken efficiency standards for central air-conditioners.

title: Bear Pairs
description: Q. Can the polar bear mate with the brown bear to produce fertile offspring? Is the polar bear Ursus maritimus or Thalarctos maritimus?

title: JETBLUE, A LOW-FARE CARRIER, MAY BUY 48 AIRBUS CRAFT
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation, the low-fare airline based in New York, said yesterday that it would buy as many as 48 planes worth $2.5 billion from Airbus Industrie. JetBlue said it was placing orders for 30 150-seat A-320's, giving Airbus a lift against the Boeing Company. The airline also took options for 5 aircraft and purchase rights for another 13. JetBlue, which began flying last year, now serves 14 cities from Kennedy International Airport. JetBlue has 14 A-320's, and expects to take delivery of another 7 this year and 10 a year beginning in 2002.

title: The Mariners' Neptune
description: Gord Ash never envisioned Pat Gillick really retired. ''I don't think anyone thought he'd go fishing and play golf,'' said Ash, the Toronto Blue Jays' general manager. ''That's not the way he relaxes.''

title: Article 2001061990074087914 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: One Family's Heritage of Illness
description: Only recently have doctors and researchers begun thinking of autoimmune syndromes as a kind of boxed set, rather than as a series of distinct disorders. And in some families, it seems, a predisposition to autoimmunity is a box packed by Pandora.

title: Sun's Missing Neutrinos: Hidden in Plain Sight
description: After three decades of searching, physicists have tracked down subatomic particles that have eluded them for 30 years. The particles, it turns out, were right there all the while but had hidden themselves as if by magic.

title: Technology Stocks Rise a Bit on Oracle Outlook
description: Technology stocks rose modestly today as investors reacted positively to an upbeat earnings report from Oracle, which said it expected its business to pick up in the second half of the year.

title: Bush, Putin and the Missile Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerez Journal; Candidate Lives in U.S., but So Does Half the State
description: At first sight, the muscular, chocolate-colored steed intimidated Andrs Bermdez. He had not sat on the back of a horse in more than 25 years, since he left a nearby farming settlement, climbed into the trunk of an old Buick and sneaked illegally into the United States in search of work.

title: Exxon Is Preparing Return To Rebel Area in Indonesia
description: Exxon Mobil said today that it was preparing to resume operations in the Aceh province of Indonesia after an expensive three-month disruption that prompted a military offensive by the government to restore security to the rebellious area.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Gay Minister Suspended
description: A United Methodist bishop in Seattle suspended a minister who recently disclosed his homosexuality. National United Methodist leaders last year formally banned ordination or pastoral appointment of gay clergy. But many delegates at the church's Northwest conference wept or rose in empathy when the Rev. Mark Edward Williams, of Woodland Park Methodist Church in Seattle, went public last week about his sexual orientation, thus prompting his suspension. Earlier this year another minister at the church was suspended after she disclosed a homosexual relationship. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Article 2001061992595187435 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Executions Continue
description: President Bush has signaled that he has no intention of rethinking his unquestioning support of the death penalty, thus leaving it to the states and the Supreme Court to review, and curtail, its application. Over the past week the president has defended this country's reliance on capital punishment against sharp criticism during his trip to Europe, weighed in with comments on an effort in Texas to ease execution practices, and refused to intervene to delay the federal execution of Juan Garza, a convicted drug trafficker and murderer. Mr. Garza is scheduled to die today, just one week after Timothy McVeigh became the first person put to death by the federal government in 38 years.

title: Front Row; A slimmer Karl Lagerfeld makes his concession to fashion.
description: Last Thursday night, as heated fashionistas made their way into Avery Fisher Hall for the industry's annual awards, Marc Jacobs idled outside with friends to watch a newly svelte Karl Lagerfeld make his entrance with an entourage.

title: Article 2001061992323925845 -- No Title
description: Gearing Up for the Car Office

title: Ferraro Is Battling Blood Cancer With a Potent Ally: Thalidomide
description: She remembers hearing the word thalidomide half a lifetime ago, when she was a young mother in Queens and it was a pharmaceutical scourge that maimed children.

title: In Once-Lost Books, the Code Behind Indian Rock Art
description: Throughout the Great Plains, images of men, horses and a nomadic way of life have been scratched into rock walls, a pictographic record whose precise meaning has long been a mystery to modern eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, PAUL
description: CAREY-Paul. You were a rainbow: rare and wonderful. Mary Nicholas Washington

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROME, IRWIN H.
description: ROME-Irwin H. Of Oak Ridge, TN, died June 17, 2001. Survived by wife Doris and son James of Oak Ridge, daughter Carol de Fritch and sister Maryl Poole, both of New York City. Private services were held.

title: Researchers Piecing Together Autoimmune Disease Puzzle
description: Whether it's through drinking too hard or driving too fast, or picking fights with fists or pistols, men as a rule are said to engage in more self-destructive behaviors than women.

title: For Eczema Sufferers, New Relief and Old Myths
description: Ask the millions of parents whose children have had the hereditary skin condition eczema and many will report that the first ''trick'' their babies learned was how to scratch the intensely itchy lesions against the crib sheets. Some will even say that the itchiness kept their babies from sleeping through the night.

title: Italian Chief Worried About Summit Protests
description: Worried about a repetition in Italy of the violent protests that occurred at a European Union meeting in Sweden last weekend, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said today that he wanted to open a dialogue with demonstrators who are planning to march at the Group of 8 summit meeting in Genoa next month.

title: A Routine Fire, Then a Blast And a Mayday From Inside
description: Father's Day was just another shift for three firefighters in Queens, a languorous day, at least for a while. Harry Ford was tackling a crossword puzzle and Brian Fahey was eating his lunch while Irish music played on a radio. At another firehouse not far away, John Downing was studying for a lieutenant's examination, sipping a soda and drawing on a cigar.

title: Scientists Try to Explain the Cold, Mysterious Era of 'Snowball Earth'
description: About 600 million years ago, the icy reach of glaciers stretched to the tropics. That much scientists agree on. The rest -- how this happened and its effects on life -- is debated.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Cause and (Opposite) Effect

title: Correction; Judge Dismissed All but One of Torricelli's Claims
description: A federal judge has ruled that Senator Robert G. Torricelli failed to prove that prosecutors repeatedly disclosed confidential information to reporters about an investigation into his personal and campaign finances. The judge did find that in one instance Senator Torricelli presented enough evidence of a possible leak to warrant further examination by the court.

title: Dumas Claims 2 Jospin Aides Knew of Payoffs In Elf Scandal
description: PARIS  Facing a prison sentence in the Elf corruption scandal, France's former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, accused two heavyweights in Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's Socialist cabinet of having known about Elf's foreign payoffs when they were made in the 1990s.

title: FINALS RATINGS UP
description: The five-game victory by the Lakers over the 76ers in the finals produced a 12.1 Nielsen rating for NBC, a 4 percent improvement from last year, when the Lakers beat Indiana.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Fuel Riots
description: Strikes and riots greeted a 30 percent rise in fuel prices, which was long demanded by the International Monetary Fund as one reform needed to revive the economy. Truck drivers in eight cities went on strike and university students threw rocks, burned tires and blocked roads in the capital. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Supreme Court To Review Case That Redefined Patent Doctrine
description: Accepting an important patent case, the Supreme Court agreed today to review an appellate decision that according to an unusually broad array of industry, educational and intellectual property groups has seriously undercut the value of many current patents and patent applications.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Advertiser Cuts Share Price
description: The big French outdoor advertising group J. C. Decaux cut the price of shares it will offer by 20 percent after gray market trading suggested that demand was weaker than expected. But Decaux, which is owned and managed by the Decaux family, still hoped to raise about a billion euros, or $864 million, to reduce its debt and pursue acquisitions by offering more than the 22 percent of the shares it originally planned to sell. Roughly 100 companies in Europe have proceeded with initial offerings so far this year, in contrast to 320 in the period last year. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Holbrooke Has New Role: Leading Fight Against AIDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 19  Five months after he left the United Nations as the United States ambassador, Richard C. Holbrooke is bounding back into the international arena, this time on behalf of the fight against AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARLAPIANO, ELEANOR
description: PARLAPIANO-Eleanor. Died on June 14th, 2001. Survived by her sister, Anne Lee; niece, Joanne; nephews, Michael and Terence, and her aunt, Claudia Val. May she rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RYAN, COL. GENE E.
description: RYAN-Col. Gene E. Nine years today. A toast to you. Fly high, love. Ro

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Dispute Over Skeleton Is Back In Court
description: The fight over Kennewick Man, a 9,300-year-old skeleton found on the Washington shoreline of the Columbia River five years ago, will re-enter the courtroom today. A federal magistrate is scheduled to hear arguments from Indian tribes that say the skeleton is an Indian's and should be reburied in a tribal ceremony and from scientists who say that his ethnic origins remain unclear and that the bones should be available for further study. The skeleton is regarded as one of the oldest and most complete ever found of one of the North American region's earliest human inhabitants. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | DDB Wins the Lottery
description: The New York Lottery said yesterday that it would return its high-profile advertising account to the agency that created the familiar and popular campaigns carrying the theme ''Hey, you never know.'' The lottery named the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the assignment. DDB New York had handled the account for 12 years before it went to the New York office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, in 1998. At that time, cost savings were a reason given for the move to Grey; the lottery office in Schenectady said the latest switch was being made for creative, technical and cost-savings reasons. The lottery spends about $60 million annually on advertising. DDB New York was awarded the assignment for three years plus three one-year optional renewals. The switch, effective in October, came after a review that is required every three years. The review, which began in December, had been narrowed to DDB New York; Grey; Bates USA in New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group; and the New York office of the Wolf Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DR. JOHN J.
description: COLLINS-Dr. John J. Died at his home in Blauvelt, NY, on June 16, 2001, at the age of 92. Born in NYC in 1909, Dr. Collins served as a professor of history at Fordham University for 40 years and was also a consultant to numerous independent tanker unions for more than 50 years. From 1950 until the early 1970's, Dr. Collins owned and operated Birch Brook Day Camp in Palisades, NY. He is survived by his daughters Suzanne Collins Broidrick, Jeanne Collins Donovan and Anne Collins, and his grandchildren Emily Broidrick, Michael, Maura and John Donovan, and Jesse and Jenny Medvene-Collins. His wife, Agnes Gerrity Collins, died in 1963, and his daughter Claire in 1994. He was also predeceased by his brother William. Friends may call at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY, on Tuesday, June 19, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, June 20, at 10 AM, at St. Catharine's Church, 523 Western Highway, Blauvelt, NY. Burial to follow at Maryrest Cemetery, Darlington (Mahwah), NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Fordham University, 441 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY 10451, or a charity of one's choice.

title: U.K. Firm Finds Niche in 'Discount' Satellites
description: GUILDFORD, England  If you wanted to send up an earth observation satellite, you could try it NASA's way; the U.S. space agency's Landsat MSS, built for $200 million, provides six-color, medium-resolution imaging across an 80-kilometer swath of the planet's surface on each orbit.

title: After more than 40 years, Wrigley is set for a flashy return to Times Square.
description: ANOTHER classic American brand, Wrigley, is to return to Times Square with a splashy, oversized illuminated billboard known in outdoor-advertising circles as a spectacular.

title: The Big City; Home Equity Is Where His Heart Is
description: BERNARD BEAL was standing on East 163rd in the South Bronx, looking up at the home in the projects he didn't get.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From making pesto without a food processor to recommendations for sweet wines, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Plant Dispute Continues
description: Negotiations between the Enron Corporation and government officials in a dispute over a power plant have made little headway, officials said. The dispute has brought construction of Phase II of the 2,184-megawatt power plant in the Indian state of Maharashtra to a standstill. Wade Cline, managing director of the Enron-backed Dabhol Power Company, said the problem was caused by the ''continuing payment defaults'' by the plant's sole customer, the utility in the Indian state. Mr. Cline said the lack of payments had made it difficult for Dabhol to pay contractors, including Bechtel, General Electric and Enron Engineering. Enron has a 65 percent stake in the $2.9 billion Dabhol project, India's highest foreign investment to date. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULLER, FRIEDA (NEE FRANKOVITS)
description: SCHULLER-Frieda (nee Frankovits) died at home June 17, shortly after her 98th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Otto E. Schuller, cherished mother of Susan M. Vock, beloved mother-in-law, grandmother and adoring greatgrandmother. We will always remember her independent spirit and great generosity. We will love her forever and ever. A graveside service will be held at Mount Ararat cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, Tuesday, June 19th at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDUM, MARION M.
description: BRANDUM-Marion M. Of Bronxville, N.Y. on June 17, 2001. Sister of the late Elizabeth Brandum and John J. Brandum. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday, June 20th, at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Life With God, Articulated; A Monk Swimming in the Stream of Books and Bees
description: Brother Rmy Rougeau could smell the nectar. Even now, in the hush of an abbey cloister, with the prairie road too muddy to reach the hives. He could imagine the sweet boozy scent of honeybees quickening like roiling clouds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETT, JENNIE
description: ZARETT-Jennie. Died peacefully at age 93 on June 18, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Zarett, loving mother of Pearl Doblin and Shirley Gale. Devoted grandmother of Debra (Marc) Rich & Larry Gale. Great grandmother of Alec Rich. She will be missed. Services private.

title: HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES BUYS 4 HOTELS FROM MARRIOTT
description: Hospitality Properties Trust announced yesterday that it had acquired four hotels from Marriott International for $101.5 million and would lease its 35 Marriott-managed hotels to a new taxable subsidiary. Hospitality, based in Newton, Mass., bought a 356-room Marriott in Kauai, Hawaii; a 295-room Courtyard by Marriott in Emeryville, Calif.; a 135-room TownePlace Suites hotel and the 114-room SpringHill Suites hotel in Renton, Wash. Marriott will manage all 35 hotels through 2019, Hospitality said. Hospitality will lease the 35 hotels to a new taxable subsidiary, taking advantage of this year's REIT Modernization Act, under which real estate trusts that own hotels no longer have to lease properties to outside managers. The hotels were previously leased to Marriott. Hospitality now owns 228 hotels in 37 states.

title: Article 2001061990970778520 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Prosecutors Seek Death for Second Bomber
description: Prosecutors will begin again today to try to persuade a federal jury in Manhattan to impose the death penalty on a terrorist in the embassy bombings case.

title: Opposing the Scouts' Antigay Policy
description: Steven Cozza is a natural for media stardom: he's handsome, well-spoken and knows how to pretend a camera isn't mercilessly gauging his performance. He acquired national recognition three years ago at age 12 when he began a campaign to force the Boy Scouts of America to accept boys who were openly gay.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bulgaria: Monarch's Party Dominates
description: With almost all the votes in the Sunday election counted, the fledgling political movement of Simeon II, the former king, has apparently won half the 240 seats in Parliament, more than double the number of its nearest rival, the Union of Democratic Forces, led by Prime Minister Ivan Kostov, which got 51. The former Communists will have 48 seats and the Party for Rights and Freedoms, which represents the Turkish minority, 21. President Petar Stoyanov appealed to Simeon in a televised address to the nation to form a coalition government, saying, ''Even if you can govern alone, it is better to use the success, the resources and experience of other political forces and other personalities.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Neil Vander Dussen, Officer at Sony of America and at RCA, Dies at 69
description: Neil Vander Dussen, a former president of the Sony Corporation of America, died on June 9 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga. Mr. Vander Dussen, a resident of Bluffton, S.C., was 69.

title: Physics' Big Puzzle Has Big Question: What Is Time?
description: When philosophers debate the nature of time and space, a listener is liable to walk away muttering something like ''Whoa. . . .'' On the same question, a technical exchange among scientists is more likely to elicit a ''Huh?'' A conference here this month brought together both camps to explore that question -- which happens to lie at the heart of the most important unsolved problem in physics -- in the hope of bringing forth a satisfying ''Aha!'' of discovery.

title: Thai Prime Minister Denies Graft Charges
description: He talked of his mother. He said he was ready to die for his country. He said he had been confused. He said he was so rich that ''it is just impossible for me to keep track of my fortune.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Forced To Close
description: Independent Insurance, a British insurer whose market value stood at $1.4 billion at the beginning of the year, said it would liquidate because of unidentified losses. Trading was suspended on June 11 after the company said it was investigating reinsurance contracts. It also canceled plans to sell new equity and said it would not write new policies. By that time its market value had fallen to about $270 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: You're Getting Sleepy . . . but Why?
description: People wondering if their chronic sleepiness is a sign of a serious sleep disorder can go to one of more than 90 Web sites that offer a brief, simple questionnaire.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday included some performers erroneously among those who will appear with Patti Smith in a tribute to William Blake at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday. Stanley Kunitz, Galway Kinnell and Nancy Willard appeared at a separate event on Friday.

title: Oracle Beats 4th-Quarter Expectations By a Penny
description: The Oracle Corporation reported today that its earnings slightly exceeded analyst expectations even though revenue from licensing its software had dropped off from the same period a year ago.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Cos Cob: Train Service Disrupted
description: Tens of thousands of commuters on the Metro-North Railroad's New Haven line were stranded during last evening's rush because of fallen electrical wires near the Cos Cob station, officials said. The wires became ensnarled in a train's overhead extension arm just after 5:30 p.m. The fallen wires also knocked out a circuit that affected service in Westchester County. Some passengers were stranded for up to three and a half hours, while others were able to transfer to a shuttle bus. No injuries were reported. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; The Playoff That's Fair And Square
description: IF this had been the Masters, the British Open or the P.G.A. Championship, Mark Brooks would have won. But this was the United States Open, the last bastion of the 18-hole playoff in major tournament golf, so Retief Goosen won.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUENTHER, JOHN L.
description: GUENTHER-John L. Died peacefully, on June 17, in his 91st year. Predeceased by his wife, Catherine; devoted and proud father of Ian, Colin and Hector, and loving grandfather of six. Passionate writer and publisher of poetry and other works. Memorial service Tuesday, June 19, 6 PM, at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. Memorial gifts to Westchester Poetry Fund at Westchester Community Foundation, 470 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Sports of The Times; New Boys Are Coming to Brooklyn This Summer
description: BOBBY OJEDA grew up a Dodger fan. The other Dodgers. The ones out west. He came by it naturally, through the fervent partisanship of his Uncle Arthur.

title: Oil Scandal Won't Die In France
description: Three weeks after being convicted on corruption charges, Roland Dumas, a former foreign minister, has lashed out at two ministers in France's governing Socialist Party, saying that both were well aware of the illicit use of funds at the Elf Aquitaine oil company, which was then state-owned.

title: Messy Consequences
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SLIDES. The yen fell after the Bank of Japan became more pessimistic with its June economic outlook, signaling the country may be lapsing into a recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.36 yen, up from 123.08.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Unionist Likely To Quit
description: The president of Sinn Fein, Gerry Adams, said it was unlikely that the Irish Republican Army would begin disarming in time to forestall the threat by the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble to resign as first minister, and thereby halt the power-sharing government. Mr. Trimble says he will step down July 1 unless there is movement by then. The two men spoke after meeting at 10 Downing Street with Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: People
description: Lee Hill, president at the Chicago office of Draft Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named to the added post of president of Surge at Draft Worldwide, a new unit offering promotional, retail and event marketing services that is being formed by combining the promotional marketing arm of Draft with two other units, Group 3 and KBA.

title: Yankees Are Ready To Kiss MSG Goodbye
description: Madison Square Garden is destined to be $30 million richer by Friday yet much poorer for losing the right to carry Yankee games on the MSG Network after this season.

title: Airbus Paves the Way for Assembling a Giant
description: PARIS  So complex are the workings of the European airplane manufacturer Airbus Industrie that it had to set up its own cargo airline to deliver parts to its assembly plants in Toulouse and Hamburg. Now it is also about to get its own highway across southwest France to deliver oversized sub-assemblies for its projected 550-seat A380 superjumbo.

title: U.S. Businesses Turn to Europe To Bar Mergers
description: American companies intent on preventing rivals from merging are increasingly complaining to European regulators in preference to more permissive officials in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SYLVIA
description: SHAPIRO-Sylvia. On June 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Robin Jones and Robert Shapiro. Loving grandmother of Alison and Lisa Shapiro and Melanie Jones. Graveside services Wednesday, 11 AM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, MINNA
description: BARNETT-Minna. Died June 17, 2001. She was a former New York City school teacher and served in the Office of Education Liaison during the Lindsay administration. She is survived by Molly and Irwin Feigin; Elaine Rubin; Malcolm, Judy and Jen Barnett and Radha and Izare Mohammed. Contributions to Hunter College, AJC or Women's City Club.

title: Bombing, and Protesting, Resume on Vieques
description: The faint roar of jet fighters returned to this disputed island today, as the Navy resumed bombing practice after arresting 14 protesters who had slipped into the firing range to demand an immediate end to the military maneuvers.

title: Addenda: 4 Top Officers Leave San Francisco Office
description: The four top executives at the San Francisco office of the British agency Leagas Delaney are leaving, they said, because of disagreements over the course of the agency.

title: Therapists Are Sentenced In Girl's 'Rebirthing' Death
description: A Colorado judge sentenced two therapists to 16 years in prison today for their roles in suffocating a 10-year-old girl last year during an effort to simulate her birth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARY S.
description: O'CONNOR-Mary S. Age 88, passed away on June 10, 2001 at Meadow Lake in Hightstown, NJ. Mrs. O'Connor was born in New Britain, CT and resided in Elizabeth, NJ for many years before moving to Meadow Lakes in June of 1996. Mrs. O'Connor is an alumnus of the Oxford School in West Hartford, CT and graduated from Smith College in 1935 before embarking upon a dynamic and illustrious career in business and a life of service to many community organizations. Mrs. O'Connor had a extensive career with IBM Corporation, one which began in 1935 when she was among the first 25 women employed for Sytems Service work and was assigned to the Newark office where she assisted salesmen in serving customers. Mrs. O'Connor later served as Personnel Manager at IBM World Headquarters in NYC and Systems Service Manager for the United States. In 1943 she was promoted to the corporate level as the first woman Assistant Vice President of the Company. Mrs. O'Connor visited almost every corporate office in the United States and Canada in this position while she worked with IBM's sales, service and engineering personnel and the corporation's customers. Furthermore, Mrs. O'Connor was appointed Director of the United Jersey Bank-Central of Elizabeth, NJ, becoming one of the three, first, women bank directors in New Jersey, before serving as the Director of Fundamental Investors, Inc. and Anchor Growth Fund of Los Angeles, CA. She also served as Trustee and Secretary of the Nathan R. Leavitt Foundation, and she was a member of the Board of Directors of Washington National Life Insurance Company of New York. Moreover, Mrs. O'Connor had the distinction and honor of being appointed by New Jersey's Governor Hughes to the Commission on the Status of Women. Tireless in her efforts and assuming active, leadership roles within Union County community agencies, Mrs. O'Connor was a member of the Mental Health Association, the United Way and the Junior League. She most recently held the position of Director of the Board of Directors of the Eastern Union County Chamber of Commerce, representing the Women's Division. During her ten years of service to the Elizabeth Public Library, she served as President and Secretary. She was also Incorporator and Trustee of the United Fund of Eastern Union County. In addition to her community work, Mrs. O'Connor formerly served the Alumnae Association at Smith College where she served as Treasurer and Finance Chair between 1966 and 1972. Mrs. O'Connor's husband Martin B. O'Connor, who was a prominent New Jersey attorney, predeceased her in 1959. Mrs. O'Connor is survived by several nieces and nephews: Elizabeth A. Schultz of Lawrence, KS; Howard S. Schultz and his wife Tamra of Swartz Creek, MI; Martha P. Howland and her husband William C. of Riverside, CT; Richard R. O'Connor, Jr. and his wife Sena of Westfield, NJ and Martin B. O'Connor II and his wife Jane of Harding Township, NJ. Also surviving Mrs. O'Connor are many grandnieces and grandnephews, including Martha Crawford of Grand Blanc, MI; Lucy Hightree and her husband Norman L. of Chicago, IL; Katherine S. and Lauren B. O'Connor of Harding Township, NJ; and Richard R., Robert I., Ryan W. and Reed M. O'Connor of Westfield, NJ. In addition, there are two great grandnieces and one great grandnephew, Hillary, Mallary and Timmy Crawford of Grand Blanc, MI. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, June 22, 2001, at 11:00 AM, at Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ. Contributions may be made in Mrs. O'Connors's memory to Smith College, Museum of Art, 33 Elm Street, Northampton, MA. 01063.

title: Blue Shirt May Help Prevent Red Body
description: The Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology kicked off beach season with two studies on sunburn. One suggests that a good way to avoid that red-all-over-look is to wear a T-shirt dyed blue.

title: Gotham Holdings is an illustration of just how volatile loosely regulated hedge funds can be.
description: WHILE many hedge funds cushioned the impact of last year's market decline, there were some spectacular failures.

title: A Suspect in Yale Murder With Top Pentagon Clearance
description: The washed-out image on his Pentagon security badge is of a defeated-looking James Van de Velde, the former Yale University lecturer, college dean and still the only suspect the police have named in the unsolved killing of a popular Yale student three winters ago.

title: N.H.L. Draft Could Turn Into a Swap Meet
description: What figures to be a busy summer for the Rangers and the Islanders could heat up this weekend at the N.H.L. entry draft in Sunrise, Fla. The Islanders have the 2nd pick over all, the Rangers have the 10th. But both teams expect a flurry of activity before the draft begins Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about allegations that prosecutors improperly leaked information about the investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli's campaign and personal finances referred incorrectly to a judge's ruling on the issue. The judge, John C. Lifland of Federal District Court in Newark, found that the senator had not presented evidence of widespread leaking of grand jury material to the press. The judge found one possible violation and said he would decide whether to order an investigation after considering further evidence from both sides. A corrective article appears today, on Page B9.

title: Europe Officials Appear to Bend Some on G.E. Deal
description: The European Commission appeared to narrow the distance today between what General Electric has offered and what the commission has demanded for approval of G.E.'s $45 billion aerospace merger with Honeywell International.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Former Lucent Scientists To Stand Trial
description: Two scientists dismissed from Lucent Technologies and their business partner are tentatively scheduled to stand trial in January 2002 on federal charges that they collaborated to pass Lucent secrets to a company owned by the Chinese government. The three men pleaded not guilty yesterday at their arraignment in Newark on charges of stealing Lucent voice and data technology for a joint venture with Datang Telecom Technologies Ltd. The two former Lucent scientists are Hai Lin and Kai Xu. The third man is Yong-Qing Cheng, a vice president of an optical networking vendor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEGIBOW, DAVID H.
description: MEGIBOW-David H. Of New Milford, NJ on June 17. Cherished son of Edythe Megibow. Devoted father of Terri and Andrew Megibow. Dear brother of Laura Van Winkle. Loving grandfather of Melissa, James, Alexis and Evan. Services will be held at ''GuttermanMusicant'', Hackensack, NJ, on Tuesday, June 19 at 11:30 AM.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNETF.T.C. ACTS AGAINST INTERNET SCHEMES The Federal Trade Commission has filed suits in Oklahoma and Illinois against companies it said were running unlawful Internet operations. The commission asked that a federal judge in Tulsa, Okla., shut down SkyBiz.com , which the agency said used the sale of online tutorials on Web-based products as a cover for a pyramid scheme that bilked consumers around the world out of more than $100 million. The F.T.C. has also filed suit in Federal District Court in Chicago asserting that www.Rhinopoint.com tricked consumers into revealing personal and financial information. The site, which is now defunct, offered to pay Internet access fees to consumers willing to join its "network"  at a one-time cost of $10 to $16  by completing questionnaires and monthly marketing surveys. The F.T.C. said the company paid fewer than 5 percent of more than 50,000 people who signed up.

title: CENDANT TO BUY A TRAVEL RESERVATION COMPANY
description: The hotel and rental car giant Cendant Corporation will pay $2.9 billion in cash and stock for Galileo International, the second-largest travel reservation company. Cendant will pay cash and stock worth $33 a share for each Galileo share, a 10.7 percent premium over Galileo's closing price on Friday, and assume $600 million in debt. Galileo, based in Rosemont, Ill., had sales of $1.64 billion in 2000 and is second to Sabre in the travel reservations field. Cendant, based in New York, owns the Days Inn, Howard Johnson and Ramada brands, and had sales of $3.93 billion in 2000.

title: In Albany, No Budget Deal but a Month's Worth of Money
description: As Republicans and Democrats blame each other for the lack of a budget agreement, the State Legislature appropriated $9.7 billion today to keep the government running for the next month.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Property Tax Rebates Double
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed a bill yesterday that will give a second annual rebate to those who pay property taxes. This year's average check of $500 is more than double last year's $240; the average is expected to reach $600 next year. Begun in 1999 under Mr. DiFrancesco's predecessor, Christie Whitman, the rebate program is intended to offset rising property taxes.

title: Jarrett Still Chasing Gordon for First
description: Dale Jarrett hoisted himself from his brown stock car Sunday after a sweaty four-hour run and said his bruised ribs did not feel sore for the first time in almost a month.

title: SNAP-ON, MAKER OF AUTO REPAIR TOOLS, WARNS ON PROFIT
description: Snap-On, a maker of hand tools and diagnostic equipment for the auto repair industry, lowered its second-quarter earnings forecast because of declining sales of hand and power tools, and said it would close two North American plants to trim costs. Earnings before special charges will be about 40 cents a share, well off the 67 cents expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/ First Call. The company, which is based in Kenosha, Wis., did not say which plants would be closed or how many employees would be affected, but said it would take a related charge of $18 million to $23 million, or 23 cents to 29 cents a share, in the second quarter.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: U.S. Under-20 Team Faces a Tough Climb
description: After Sunday's stunning 1-0 loss to China, the United States under-20 national team faces an uphill climb in the FIFA World Youth Championship. It plays Chile tomorrow and Ukraine on Saturday in Mendoza, Argentina.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Officials Appear Conciliatory on G.E. Deal

title: A Novartis Drug Fails To Win F.D.A. Approval
description: Novartis, Europe's third-biggest drug maker, failed to win United States approval for Zelnorm, a new treatment for irritable bowel syndrome. Regulators questioned the medicine's safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, JOSEPH R.
description: SPECTOR-Joseph R., attorney. Born April 16, 1923, died June 17, 2001. Former corporate council for Singer Corp and Vice President and General Council for UMC Inds. and Crane. Graduate of Dartmouth College '46 and Cornell Law School '52. Survived by his lifetime companion of 54 years, Ralph ''Pat'' Paterline of New York, and his brother Samuel I. Spector of Rome, Georgia. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Liver Foundation for Research, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 603, New York, N.Y. 10038, are requested.

title: Today's Dads: A New Breed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Linda Eatherton was named executive vice president and director for the global food and nutrition practice at the Chicago office of Ketchum, part of the Omnicom Group. She succeeds Betsy Gullickson, who became executive vice president and global counselor at the Ketchum office in San Francisco. Ms. Eatherton had been vice president for public and industry communications at Dairy Management Inc., Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, ELAINE
description: JACOBI-Elaine. Of New York City, on Saturday, June 16, 2001, age 82. Wide of the late Sidney Jacobi. Devoted mother of Dana Jacobi. Beauty was her life. Sitting at Elaine's home, June 21 and 22, after 2 PM.

title: Yankees Close to a Deal For the Expos' Urbina
description: The Yankees, moving to fill a bullpen hole that was exposed in Sunday's dramatic loss to the Mets, tentatively agreed to trade two minor leaguers to the Montreal Expos in return for the veteran reliever Ugueth Urbina, according to several major league executives. But Urbina, who has a recent history of arm trouble, must first be cleared by the Yankees' medical staff.

title: PUTIN SAYS RUSSIA WOULD ADD ARMS TO COUNTER SHIELD
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said today that if the United States proceeded on its own to construct a missile defense shield over its territory and that of its allies, Russia would eventually upgrade its strategic nuclear arsenal with multiple warheads -- reversing an achievement of arms control in recent decades -- to ensure that it would be able to overwhelm such a shield.

title: Prevention, if Not Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Corporate Tax Rate Cut
description: Russia's government said it would slash its corporate tax rate, one of the most radical changes yet in its overhaul of the tax system. The government proposed reducing the corporate tax rate by about a third, to 25 percent. To soften the effect on the budget, the government will cancel all corporate tax breaks. The change was given tentative approval by a committee in the lower house of Parliament on Friday. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Progress in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson and IBP Resume Talks On Their Plan For a Merger
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry producer, said today that it had renewed talks to acquire IBP, the giant beef processor, just two and a half months after calling off the merger.

title: Lott Seeks Delay on Patients' Rights Debate
description: Senate Republicans threatened today to hold up debate on a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights, saying they needed more time to study changes made by Democrats in the last few days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, BEATRICE S.
description: FREEDMAN-Beatrice S. Born June 20, 1909 to Jennie and Louis Sheiman. Died on June 16, 2001. Loving wife of the late Jerome. Adored mother of Lee, Vivienne, and Ruth. Devoted grandmother of Jill, Bruce, Andrew, Georgia, David, and Leah. Cherished great grandmother of Ryan, Erica, Alexander, Jared, Isabel, and Jalynn. Loving sister, sister-in-law, and aunt. She devoted her life to the achievement of peace and social justice. Funeral services 10:30 A.M. June 20, 2001, Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Acts Against Internet Schemes
description: The Federal Trade Commission has filed suits in Oklahoma and Illinois against companies it said were running unlawful Internet operations. The commission asked that a federal judge in Tulsa, Okla., shut down SkyBiz.com, which the agency said used the sale of online tutorials on Web-based products as a cover for a pyramid scheme that bilked consumers around the world out of more than $100 million. The F.T.C. has also filed suit in Federal District Court in Chicago asserting that www.Rhinopoint.com tricked consumers into revealing personal and financial information. The site, which is now defunct, offered to pay Internet access fees to consumers willing to join its ''network'' -- at a one-time cost of $10 to $16 -- by completing questionnaires and monthly marketing surveys. The F.T.C. said the company paid fewer than 5 percent of more than 50,000 people who signed up.

title: 60 Percent Off: Can Labor Day Be Far Behind?
description: One afternoon last week, a painter visiting New York from Sydney, Australia, found herself engaged in the kind of self-analysis that can be provoked only by an encounter with a pair of gold Fendi mules reduced to about half their original price of $700. The painter wondered if she might have inside her -- behind the demure black glasses and the brainy-looking Comme des Garons dress -- the kind of woman who would slip into a pair of mules decorated with jeweled lizards, to meander around a swimming pool.

title: Prominent Historian Admits He Misled Students Into Believing He Served in Vietnam
description: Joseph J. Ellis, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian whose latest book, ''Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation,'' has been a national best seller for 26 weeks, admitted yesterday that he had misled his students at Mount Holyoke College into believing that he was an airborne soldier in Vietnam when in fact he never served in Vietnam.

title: Pilot Isn't Beach-Bound
