description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANDSEN, BIRGITTA
description: FRANDSEN-Birgitta. We mourn the sudden passing of our cherished friend, Bitten. Her longtime friendship and devotion to SWEANY and her inspiration, joy and gloreous love of life will always follow us. She has joined her beloved Brownie. We extend our deep symapthy to her family. Memorial at Church of Sweden, 5 E. 48 St, N.Y. 6:30PM Thurs., June 21.

title: Bonus From Rejected Treaty
description: A network of sensors, the legacy of a nuclear test ban treaty rejected by the Senate, is a boon to scientists. Science Times, Page F1.

title: Nike Trying New Strategies For Women; Company Seeks Merger Of Athletics and Fashion
description: She called herself the Yogini. She could twist her body in all kinds of ways. She stood on her hands on a hardwood floor and arched her back until her feet touched her head. Her body quivered like a plucked guitar string.

title: Learning to Love Carrots, Early
description: Mothers may or may not be able to teach their babies French in the womb, but they apparently can help them develop a taste for carrots by drinking carrot juice during pregnancy, an article in the current issue of Pediatrics reports.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Gambling Lawsuit
description: John J. Farmer Jr., the New Jersey attorney general, filed suit yesterday against three offshore Internet operations for providing what authorities said was illegal gambling available to under-age wagerers. State investigators, in a 15-month operation, opened accounts and bet on virtual card games, casino games and professional sports. They also watched as three teenagers placed bets. Gambling on such games is illegal in New Jersey, except for Atlantic City.

title: Joe Darion, 90, Lyricist of 'Man of La Mancha'
description: Joe Darion, the lyricist for ''Man of La Mancha,'' whose inspirational ballad, ''The Impossible Dream,'' became one of the most beloved pop anthems of the 1960's, died on Saturday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 90.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New.Net Adding More Domain Names
description: To expand the universe of Internet addresses, the New.net registry plans to add 10 new domain names to its existing roster of 20 alternative extensions. New.net, which is backed by the struggling Internet incubator Idealab, is adding the suffixes .arts, .school, .church, .love, and .golf, among others that consumers can buy as part of Internet addresses. However, New.net's addresses exist outside the Internet's main domain name system, so not all Internet users can call up Web sites using those addresses. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Death-Penalty Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Fabricated History

title: Microsoft Has Patch For Security Flaw
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it was issuing a software patch for a troubling security flaw in its Windows NT 4.0 and Windows 2000 server operating system programs.

title: Bush Rejects Clemency for Drug Lord Set to Die Today
description: President Bush rejected a clemency plea today from Juan Raul Garza, a former drug kingpin convicted of three murders, clearing the way for his execution on Tuesday morning.

title: America's Hispanic Future
description: The Spanish-language television network Univision has been putting up billboards all over New York City. One in particular struck me, given the census figures showing Hispanics to be the country's largest minority. It called Univision as ''American as flan.'' (Flan, for those Americans devoted to apple pie, is a custard.) The ad made me wonder about the significance of this newest challenge to the American melting pot.

title: British Telecom Makes Good On Promise to Slash Its Debt
description: British Telecommunications completed an $8.3 billion rights issue today and sold an Indian investment, allowing the company to make good on its promise to cut debt sharply.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Rozie Hendricks, Galesburg Ill., Feb. 10, 2001

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ayatollah Backs Media Inquiry
description: The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, intervened in favor of reformers who had been blocked by conservatives over an inquiry into the financial affairs of the state-run radio and television, ordering the inquiry to go forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, ESTHER
description: KATZENSTEIN - Esther. Our worldwide family mourns the loss of a dear and special lady, whose kindness touched so many, both in Eretz Yisrael and in her own community. Modesty & acts of tzedekah graced her life. For more than fifty years she was tireless in her efforts to provide quality health care to the people of Jerusalem. A supporter of the Ladies Auxiliary, she worked alongside her late husband Manfred, who was one of the original founders of the American Committee. Golden Founders of the medical center, the Katzensteins generously supported the Annual Dinner and Annual Concert. Our sincerest condolences to Maud Carlebach, Rabbi Edwin Katzenstein and Joan Thau. May they and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: Both Sides Now: New Way That Clouds May Cool
description: Though the scientific consensus says that humans are warming the earth by adding heat-trapping gases to the air, there is continuing uncertainty about the possible cooling influence of clouds.

title: New Chiefs Named at Rockport and Lauren
description: Reebok International Ltd. named new presidents for its Rockport and Ralph Lauren businesses after the head of the Ralph Lauren unit resigned.

title: Defense Mechanisms
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: IN SHIFT, U.S. OPENS EFFORT TO SETTLE TOBACCO LAWSUIT
description: The Bush administration took the first step today toward seeking settlement of the multibillion-dollar civil lawsuit against the tobacco industry. Attorney General John Ashcroft notified lawmakers that he had named a team of lawyers to explore the possibility of a settlement of the Justice Department's suit, department officials said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bluefly Cuts Staff By One-Third
description: The online seller of discounted designer apparel Bluefly Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 32 jobs, or one-third of its work force, as part of a plan to reach profitability in the fourth quarter of 2002. The New York-based company, which is backed by the investor George Soros, will take a pretax charge of $600,000 in the second quarter. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: New Senate Leader Agrees to Hold Votes on 2 Judicial Issues
description: In an effort to break an impasse over the organization of the Senate, the new majority leader said today that he would hold votes later this week on two Republican proposals concerning the treatment of judicial nominees.

title: Studies Detail Solicitation Of Children for Sex Online
description: One in five children who go online regularly is approached by strangers for sex, according to a new study. Yet most of the young people say they are not bothered by the messages and ignore or block them, another study said.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESEL, MEL
description: RIESEL-Mel. Beloved husband, son, brother, brother-in-law and uncle. A kind, caring, decent human being who was genuinely liked and respected by all who knew him. They don't make 'em any better. He left a void that cannot be filled. Donations in his memory may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

title: The Boy Scout Amendment
description: If the latest soundings on Capitol Hill can be trusted, a malicious anti-gay amendment sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and narrowly approved by the Senate last week will not in fact survive to become part of the final version of the education bill to which it was attached. But the bigotry reflected in the 51-to-49 vote on the measure has stained the Senate.

title: 6 Women Sue Wal-Mart, Charging Job and Promotion Bias
description: Six female employees of Wal-Mart Stores filed a federal lawsuit yesterday, accusing the company of engaging in widespread discrimination against women.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Combating Drug Crimes
description: The Legislature has passed a law meant to combat the rise in crime related to OxyContin, a prescription painkiller that some there now call Down East heroin. The measure, which Gov. Angus King Jr. has already signed, tightens the system of keeping track of prescriptions to prevent forgery and fraud. The bill also adds ''club drugs'' like Ecstasy to Maine's roster of illegal substances, imposing heavy penalties for holding or selling them. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Zoos are trying to raise their profile, and the environment's.
description: MORE than 130 million visitors each year pass through the gates of the 196 North American zoos and aquariums accredited by the American Zoo and Aquarium Association, but few have probably heard of the group or of A.Z.A., the abbreviation used to refer to it.

title: Who's No. 1?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vouchers Dead, Alternatives Weak
description: TO win backing for his education bill, President Bush abandoned private-school vouchers for pupils in low-scoring public schools. He then pledged to find other ways to support private education.

title: A Tragic Fire, And Its Fighters
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The June 16 op-ed page misidentified James Schlesinger as defense secretary under Jimmy Carter. He was defense secretary under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford and energy secretary under Mr. Carter.

title: Hidden Camera Tricks
description: After some promising early results for its first efforts with reality shows, NBC may include a reality series on its signature Thursday night lineup in the fall.

title: U.S. Executes a Second Killer in a Week
description: A Texas man convicted of three drug-related murders was put to death by lethal injection today at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., the same place Timothy J. McVeigh was executed last week.

title: A Triumph At Home, Too: The Seafood Plateau
description: IF you watch the professional at the raw bar -- powerful hands moving with frightening speed, shucking oysters and clams, and then delicately constructing that breathtaking plateau of seafood, building the creation higher and higher -- it can work against you. You begin to believe you could never possibly do that.

title: Document: The Study of Oprah
description: This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: "Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon," developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was "to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism." Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

title: Going to the Hamptons Can Be a Picnic
description: Brown-bag it to the Hamptons? Yes, but only if there's a touch of class to it. Both Cos and Xando Cos, the chain of sandwich bars, and D'Artagnan, the restaurant and shop, are offering food to hungry jitney passengers. Cos makes a picnic for two ($25 plus tax) that includes sandwiches made from its wonderful focaccia-like bread (and a large list of fillings), chips or salad, beverages and sweets like brownies or cookies. It comes in a box with utensils. It should be ordered 24 hours in advance from any Cos shop for delivery to the Hampton Jitney stop at 40th Street near Third Avenue, or from (212) 739-7171. Picnics can also be picked up at the Cos shop at 685 Third Avenue (41st Street).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, HUXLEY V.
description: MITCHELL-Huxley V. Was born in Dominica, W.I. on June 15, 1926 and died June 16, 2001. Huxley is survived by his wife, Audrey, and their three children: Victoria, Dennis, Lynne and their spouses, Richard, Akiyo & Anthony. He also leaves behind five grandchildren: Sean, Sheldon, Ryan, Kyle and Devyn as well as his niece, Bernadette (daughter of his sister, Mabel) and her three children, Courtney, Jason and Jeremy. Additionally, Huxley will be greatly missed by a multitude of family and friends both in the Dominica and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, EVALYN A.
description: CLARK-Evalyn A. A Poughkeepsie, NY resident and professor emerita in history at Vassar College, died peacefully June 17, 2001 at age 98. For information by mail C/O Margaret Wright at Clark address. A memorial service will be in the fall. Services by Parmele Funeral Home, Poughkeepsie.

title: Drones and Lightning Bolts In a Slow March to Ecstasy
description: Audiences these days are conditioned to the long crescendo. The slow growth over the last 10 years of rave culture, jam bands and qawwali music -- just three music styles that have made inroads into American consciousness -- is a sign that the old Western pop-performance rhetoric of up-tempo, then ballad and so on, isn't nearly as strong as it used to be.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Shares Mixed Despite Early Bump in Technology Sector
description: Technology stocks rose modestly yesterday as investors reacted positively to the earnings report from Oracle, which said it expected business to pick up in the second half of the year.

description: WEST</B

title: Questions Over Who Is Boss At Tyson Foods
description: On March 28, Donald J. Tyson, 70, the senior chairman of Tyson Foods Inc., and two retired former executives met at the company's headquarters in Springdale, Ark., to decide the fate of Tyson's pending merger with IBP, the giant beef processor.

title: G.O.P. Wins House Seat in Virginia
description: Republicans won an off-year test of strength yesterday in a special House election in Virginia as State Senator J. Randy Forbes defeated State Senator L. Louise Lucas, a moderate Democrat, as both parties marshaled major resources in search of a bellwether for next year's campaign for House control.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2nd Trial In Watkins Death
description: The second trial in the killing of Amy Watkins got under way yesterday in State Supreme Court, with prosecutors saying that Felix Rodriguez, 21, acted as a lookout while another man plunged a kitchen knife into Ms. Watkins's back. The other man, David Jamison, 28, was sentenced this month to 25 years to life in prison for the 1999 stabbing. Mr. Rodriguez is facing second-degree murder charges. Mr. Rodriguez's lawyer, Steven J. Chaikin, said no evidence or witnesses linked his client to the killing, and he suggested that Mr. Rodriguez's confession had been coerced by the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTRAND, MARION BARRETT (MRS. JOHN J.)
description: BERTRAND - Marion Barrett (Mrs. John J.) of Greenwich, CT, died on Monday, June 18, 2001. She is survived by her daughters, Barbara (Mrs. T. Brock Saxe) of New Canaan, CT, Marion (Mrs. Robert K. Eagan) of Harrison, NY, and her daughter-in-law, Linda (Mrs. Charles B. Bertrand) of Palm City, FL. Her husband, John, died in 1982, and her son Charles in 2000. She was the sister of Gertrude (Mrs. Arthur Davidson), Ruth (Mrs. Jack Lande), and Edward J. Barrett. She is also predeceased by her sister Helen (Mrs. Stephen P. Glennon) and her brother, Dr. Charles V. Barrett. Mrs. Bertrand is survived by 11 grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, NY on Wednesday, June 20, 5PM-8PM. A Mass of Christian Burial, St. Michael's Church, North Street, Greenwich, CT, 10 AM Thursday. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Vincent's Hospital, North Street, Harrison, New York, would be appreciated.

title: NBT BANCORP AGREES TO BUY CENTRAL NATIONAL BANK
description: NBT Bancorp Inc., which has 77 bank branches in New York and Pennsylvania, has agreed to buy the rival Central National Bank and its parent, the CNB Financial Corporation, for $140 million in stock. NBT, based in Norwich, N.Y., will pay 1.2 shares, valued at $18.30, for each share of CNB, based in Canajoharie, N.Y. That is a 33 percent premium to the Monday closing price. Donald Brass, president of CNB, will retire after the transaction closes, which is expected in the fourth quarter.

title: Bush to Meet With Sharon, Keeping Arafat at Arm's Length
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel will meet with President Bush at the White House next week, the second time the two have held face-to-face discussions since Mr. Sharon's election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, JOYCE (NEE STAUBER)
description: TURNER-Joyce (nee Stauber). Of Cresskill, NJ (Managing Editor, College Textbooks at Simon & Shuster). Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Caren Turner and Stuart Turner. Dear sister of Beatrice Pullman. Loving grandmother of Hallie, Kelly, Michelle, Nathan and Matthew. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ, Thursday 11 AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Sells Alstom Shares
description: Alcatel, a big European maker of phone equipment, sold 12.2 million shares of Alstom, a French engineering company, raising 390.4 million euros ($336.4 million) and shedding its remaining stake yesterday. Alcatel sold the shares at 32 euros ($27.57), it said in a statement. Alstom shares fell 0.3 euro (26 cents), to 32.4 euros ($27.92), valuing it at about 7 billion euros ($6.03 billion). After the markets closed, Marconi P.L.C. said it planned to sell its 12.2- million-share stake in Alstom.

title: Invitation to an Arms Race
description: Last Saturday President Bush and Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, talked hopefully about bridging the differences between Washington and Moscow on missile defense. On Monday Mr. Putin indicated what might happen if they did not. If Washington withdraws from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, he warned, Moscow will set aside its 1993 nuclear arms reduction treaty with the United States and put multiple warheads on its missile force.

title: TV Notes: Games to Clash on Syndication
description: Both shows come from England; both shows have become prime-time hits; and in the fall they will even face off against each other on Monday nights.

title: Games to Clash On Syndication
description: Both shows come from England; both shows have become prime-time hits; and in the fall they will even face off against each other on Monday nights.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Livery-Cab Insurance Snag
description: An insurance flap has threatened to force thousands of New York City's livery-cab drivers off the road by July 1, according to Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers. But the State Insurance Department said yesterday that most would not lose their insurance. The problem stems from a decision last month by Highlands Insurance Group that canceled 9,000 policies because, it said, the insurance agent who sold them was not authorized to do so. Meanwhile, another insurance company, Sureco, canceled 2,000 policies because, it said, its agents issued the wrong policies. The Insurance Department ordered both companies to reinstate 7,000 of the policies. An attorney for PRG Brokerage Inc. in Franklin Square, which sold the Highlands policies, said the company is an authorized agent and will go to court to contest Highland's cancellation. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: MANAGEMENT; A Poet Taps Into the Disillusionment of Managers
description: On a recent Friday morning, David Whyte is met with uncomprehending stares as he recites Rainer Maria Rilke's poem ''The Swan'' in its original German to 150 managers at a business conference here.

title: Worried Over Soft Money, G.O.P. Readies Major Gala
description: In what Republicans fear may be a last chance to raise huge amounts of soft money donations before they are banned, the party is making final preparations for a multimillion-dollar extravaganza next week starring President Bush.

description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

description: Shareholders of True North Communications in Chicago voted overwhelmingly at a brief special meeting yesterday to approve its acquisition by the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

description: YOU know how to whistle, don't you?'' Lauren Bacall says to Bogie in ''To Have and Have Not.'' ''You just put your lips together and blow.'' I used to think that about tasting wine.

description: I GUESS it's just in my blood to be a pain,'' Angelo Falcn reflected happily. ''I'm always busting chops.''

description: Big Accounting Firm to Pay $7 Million in Fraud Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENT, HAROLD H., JR. MAJ. USAFR (RET.)
description: LENT-Harold H., Jr. Maj. USAFR (Ret.) (Bud or Buddy to his family and friends). Died on June 14, 2001, age 78. He was born and grew up in Peekskill, NY. In World War II he served as a navigator with the 15th Air Force in Italy, completing 35 combat missions, for which he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with 3 Oak Leaf Clusters. After the war, he studied Economics at Cornell and Columbia Universities, earning a B.A. from the former and an M.A. from the latter. For the next 30 years, he served in the Federal Civil Service, mostly with the Central Intelligence Agency. He is survived by his ever-loving wife Claire, four children he is most proud of, nine grandchildren, and his brother and sister. Inurnment will be made on July 10th in the Arlington National Cemetery Columbarium.

title: Trivia Question: Power in the Motor City
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Skyscraper Sold
description: An American real estate company, the Lone Star Fund, has agreed to buy Seoul's largest building, known as the I-Tower, for $510.5 million from Hyundai Development. The building, still under construction, was to be the headquarters of the Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, but the group's financial troubles and dissension among the Chung family, the Hyundai Group's founding family, halted that plan. Hyundai Development is now independent of the Hyundai Group. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Senate Debates Measure on Patients' Rights, but Republicans Resist a Swift Vote
description: The Senate began debate today on a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights, but Republicans resisted swift action on the measure, saying they needed more time to study it.

title: Unification Is a Bout Removed for Judah
description: It has been half a year since Zab Judah of Brooklyn stepped into the ring. That is a long time for a 22-year-old champion not to be throwing punches. Judah, known as Super, was waiting for the big bout to materialize, the unification fight with Kostya Tszyu in the 140-pound division. The biggest fight of his career, he called it. He waited and waited and waited.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Cement-Additive Plant Opens
description: A $50 million plant in Camden, N.J., built by St. Lawrence Cement Inc. went into operation this week after a federal appeals court reversed a preliminary injunction against its opening. The plant had been losing $500,000 a week since Judge Stephen J. Orlofsky of Federal District Court in Camden issued the injunction on April 19 pending the outcome of a suit filed by neighbors of the plant, said Brian Montag, a lawyer for St. Lawrence, which has its corporate offices in Mount Royal, Canada, near Montreal. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, lifted the injunction, allowing the plant to begin its operation, grinding slag into a powdery cement additive, on Monday. The appellate court is expected to rule next month on St. Lawrence's motion to dismiss the suit. If it is not dismissed, Judge Orlofsky will hold a trial to determine whether the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection violated the federal Civil Rights Act by granting a permit for the St. Lawrence plant. The plaintiffs say the plant will further pollute the mostly black and Hispanic neighborhood, Waterfront South, in which they live. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Veto Day
description: Gov. Rick Perry vetoed 82 bills on the final day allowed by law, June 17, in what critics are calling the Father's Day Massacre. The vetoed legislation included a bill that would have provided contraception and cancer screening to poor women and created a public advocate for health insurance. Sponsors said the bill would have attracted more federal matching funds and improved medical care for H.I.V.-infected people and the mentally ill. Mr. Perry, a Republican whose vetoes were applauded by at least one conservative group, said the bill would have driven up expenses in future years. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Easing Reins On Prisons
description: A federal district judge who has monitored the state's prisons for nearly 30 years has eased his control over the system. The judge, William Wayne Justice, released the prison system from federal oversight on issues including crowding, staffing, discipline, health care and death row. But he ordered prison officials to address some problems further, including abusive guards, inmate-on-inmate violence and the treatment of mentally ill inmates. Judge Justice's oversight stems from a 1972 lawsuit. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Waiters Who Deliver More Than Food
description: Diversity of Dance

title: Cries of 'Save the Suckerfish' Rile Farmers' Political Allies
description: Not since the snail darter has a creature so infuriated -- and inspired -- conservatives around the country. The all-but-inedible, bottom-feeding suckerfish, which makes its home in a lake that feeds this normally fertile agricultural valley, has become the latest rallying cry in the battle to rewrite the Endangered Species Act.

description: To the Editor:

title: Doing the Shuffle
description: HBO usually takes pride in disdaining the ratings strategies and pressure that dominate the thinking of network programmers. But the channel's building strength as a series power on Sunday night has apparently changed all that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOZAK, AARON
description: KOZAK-Aaron. We have lost a very special and true friend and celebrate his life for everything he brought to ours. We will remember his sparkling eyes always. Our deepest sorrow to Pat, Ellen and Jeffrey. Suzanne and Sandy Schlesinger and Tom Gannon

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HILTON HOTELS CORP., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it was spending $600 million to have its Grand Vacations Co. unit build time-share resorts in Orlando and on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Boulud West

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Voter Intimidation Found
description: Voter intimidation and other election law violations continued in Passaic in the May 8 primary, according to a court-appointed federal monitor. The monitor, Walter Timpone, a former assistant United States attorney whose appointment grew out of a federal voting rights suit, said some poll workers improperly refused to give out provisional ballots when valid registration could not be confirmed. He also said election challengers hired by candidates shouted at voters, when such challengers are not supposed to talk to voters at all. Mr. Timpone will monitor the June 26 primary. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: A Neighborly Cafe Brightens Up a Corner in Queens
description: THE gloomy corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 53rd Street in Queens is an unlikely spot to find a lively and unusual restaurant like La Flor Bakery and Cafe. In the shadow of the elevated No. 7 train tracks, surrounded by depressing bars and shops that repair vacuum cleaners and fix flats, La Flor has become a culinary center for the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, DR. RUTH LEDER
description: SHAPIRO-Dr. Ruth Leder. On June 17, 2001, at age 81. Psychologist. Beloved stepmother of Richard Shapiro and his wife, Patricia, and step-grandmother of Seth and Alex. Also survived by her nephew Drew Leder and her companion for fourteen years, Jacques Solta. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, June 20, 1-6PM. Interment is private. Memorial service July 7th, 2001. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Gauging Interest In Loans
description: Chinese bankers are in New York to gauge investor interest in about $2 billion of nonperforming loans and real estate assets from one of China's largest state banks, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. The China Huarong Asset Management Corporation, set up to liquidate the bank's bad debts, expects to auction the assets at the end of the year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Article 2001062092542943924 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Wood Smoke Rising: A Tangy Bouquet for the Home Grill
description: THE primal scent of meat cooking over a wood fire cannot be matched on gas or charcoal grills. The wood smoke adds its own irresistible flavor to the food, and the dry heat imparts a crisp crust and sears in the natural juices.

title: In the Greenmarkets, a Gentle Stand-In for Spinach
description: Only last summer, lamb's-quarters were an oddity in the Greenmarkets. This year just about any stall worth its arugula sells the flat-leaf greens, also known as pigfoot, wild spinach or, in Mexican cuisine, quelites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, SHEILA
description: O'BRIEN-Sheila. On June 19, 2001. Daughter of the late Ben O'Brien, Sgt. Major and Armorer of the 7th Regiment, and the late Anne (nee McIntyre) of Castelrea Co. Roscommon, Eire. Also predeceased by Mary Appel and Frances and Richard O'Brien. Survived by nephew Ben O'Brien of Redondo Beach, CA, cousin Rose Moore of Co. Wicklow and Sean McIntyre of Southdown, Castelrea and many Borstelmann cousins, as well as dear friends, Mary Reavely and Sara Reale of NY. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service Inc., 1297 First Ave, NYC on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, 10 AM at St. Monica's RC Church, 411 E. 79 St, NYC. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Disease Is Big Setback For Brazil Cattle Region
description: This is gacho country. Gently rolling pasture stretches in all directions as far as the eye can see, empty save for herds of grazing cattle, a few traditionally garbed cowboys on horseback and the occasional tree.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spray Sickens 13 In School
description: Two adults and 11 children at Public School 191 on the Upper West Side were sickened yesterday when a student discharged a canister of Mace, a form of tear gas, the police said. The student, an 11-year-old girl in special education, reached into her purse at 10:30 a.m., when she uncapped the irritant, apparently by accident, the police said. It was unclear why the girl carried the canister. The students, a teacher and a parent were taken to St. Mary's Hospital, where they were treated for inflamed eyes and throat and released.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: MG Rover Acquiring Italian Car
description: MG Rover, the British auto company, said it would buy the Italian maker of the Mangusta sports car from its parent, Qvale Automotive of the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. MG Rover said it planned to start a luxury sports car code-named MG X80 next year based on the engineering of the Mangusta. Kevin Howe, chief executive of MG Rover, said the model would give the company a greater presence in the United States. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, NORMAN
description: WEISS-Norman, June 18, 2001. Longtime resident of Lauderhill, Fla., recently of Long Beach, NY, beloved father, grandfather, brother and friend, of sudden illness. Donations to the charity of choice or the Tiger Woods Foundation Inc., 4281 Katella Avenue, Suite 111, Los Alamitos, CA 90720. Include information for acknowledgement. There will be no funeral service.

title: Troubles Tarnish a Once-Shining African Airline
description: Only months after France's African colonies gained their independence in 1960, they sounded a clarion call to African sovereignty and unity: they would pool their meager resources and create an airline of their own.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Friday about the 2002 election for the Senate in Colorado misidentified Tom Strickland, a Democrat who has indicated interest in running. He is a former United States attorney, not the state attorney general.

title: Elevating Butter to an Art Form
description: Buttering your toast can become an exercise in breakfast art with the Butter Dispenser, made by Max Space Inc., a company in Kansas City, Mo., that usually makes shoe racks. That might explain the efficient yet hardly trend-setting design of this plastic gadget, which can accommodate a whole stick of butter.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Princeton Review I.P.O.
description: Princeton Review Inc., which sells tutoring services and books to help students prepare for standardized tests, sold 5.4 million shares yesterday in an initial public offering of stock priced at $11, raising $59.4 million. The company, which is based in New York, said it hoped to pay down its debt and possibly to buy out tutoring services operated by franchise owners. But the bulk of the growth strategy outlined in the company's filings involved expanding the Internet services provided through two Web sites, www.homeroom.com and www.review.com. The shares closed at $9.50. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Ripken, the Iron Man, to Retire at Season's End
description: The man who moved into the starting lineup in 1982 and stayed longer than the man who came to dinner is going to leave Sept. 30. Cal Ripken, who didn't miss a game for more than 16 seasons, declared yesterday, ''I'm retiring and I'm not going to play baseball anymore.''

title: Spain Court Refuses to Extradite Man G.M. Says Took Its Secrets
description: The Spanish High Court yesterday refused to extradite Jos Ignacio Lpez de Arriorta, the Spanish executive accused of misappropriating trade secrets when he left a senior post at General Motors in 1992 to join Volkswagen. The court ruled that the charges against Mr. Lpez were not serious enough to justify handing a Spanish citizen over to the United States.

title: RAYTHEON RECEIVES $200 MILLION IN ORDERS FOR PLANES
description: The Raytheon Company said it had received more than $200 million in orders for about 35 aircraft, including 10 of its new Premier I business jets. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., said it received orders for 15 Hawker business jets, 7 Beech King Air turboprops and 2 Beach Barron airplanes at the Paris Air Show. The orders could help lift the performance of Raytheon's aircraft unit in Wichita, Kan., where sales fell 22 percent in the first quarter to $637 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: Readers' Conversation With Ernest Dahlman
description: NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area hosted Ernest Dahlman, a professionl gambler profiled in William Grimes's Magazine article, 'The Wizard of Odds.' .

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Teenage Hacker Shows No Remorse
description: The courtappointed author of a presentencing report told a Canadian judge that the Montreal teenager known as Mafiaboy, left, who cannot be identified under Canadian law, showed no sign of remorse, despite having admitted to hacking into at least 75 computer networks and pleading guilty to hobbling five Internet sites in February 2000. ''He's still trying to justify what he did,'' Hanny Chung, the report's author, said. The court official recommended that he spend five months in close custody, perform 120 hours of community work and pay a fine of 1,000 Canadian dollars ($650). But the prosecutor, Louis-Miville Deschnes, argued that five months' detention was insufficient. Robert M. Frank (NYT)

title: House Hearings on Ford and Firestone Clarify Little
description: The dispute between the Ford Motor Company and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. over tire safety carried over into Congressional hearings today and became even more muddled when the committee chairman said he had information showing Ford might be replacing Firestone tires with brands that are even less reliable.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Disco Toll Rises To 21
description: A 15-year-old girl died of wounds in the suicide bombing of a Tel Aviv disco on June 1. Yevgenia Dorfman's death brought to 21 the number of young Israelis killed. The bombing led to international pressure on Yasir Arafat and pushed him to declare a cease-fire. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

title: Going Clubbing With Attitude
description: Sarah Skaggs Dance Company

description: To the Editor:

title: Manute Bol's Fall From Grace
description: Young men from the south of Sudan are shooting hoops in a rundown court on a sweltering evening in downtown Khartoum. They pound a cheap ball on the cracked tiles as a few hundred boys and girls watch the game, shouting, chatting and flirting.

title: Article 2001062092140897586 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: City May Be Forced to Use Paper Ballots in Election
description: Legislation to change an election law is hung up in the bitterly divided politics of Albany, threatening the crowded September primary in New York City with the chaos of paper ballots.

title: Neil Vander Dussen, 69, a Sony Executive
description: Neil Vander Dussen, a former president of the Sony Corporation of America, died on June 9 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga. Mr. Vander Dussen, a resident of Bluffton, S.C., was 69.

title: At Last, Action on California
description: After months of dithering, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission took some potentially meaningful steps on Monday to contain the wholesale price of electricity in California and elsewhere in the Western United States. Anxious not to be seen as caving in to public pressure or abandoning its fidelity to the free market, the White House described the new policy as ''consistent with where the president has been all along.'' Gov. Gray Davis of California, for his part, said the policy did not go far enough, and of course only time will tell whether it does. But to many others, including Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the move amounted to the first significant federal intervention in the California wholesale market since the crisis began last year. Ms. Feinstein withdrew her own price-cap bill pending the outcome of the new plan.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Japan High-Speed Service
description: Yahoo Japan, a unit of the Softbank Corporation, will offer high-speed Internet service at sharply reduced prices starting this month in Tokyo and spreading to the rest of the country in August. Working with a broadband service company, BB Technologies, that is also owned by Softbank, Yahoo Japan will offer the high-speed asymmetric digital subscriber line, or A.D.S.L., connection for a monthly rate of 2,280 yen ($18.55), about half that charged by its Japanese rivals. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: I Once Had E.F. Hutton's Ear
description: My grandmother had a tremendous impact on me. We had a large hierarchical family of Italian heritage. Where you sat at the table for Sunday dinner was very important. My grandfather sat at the head of the family. My grandmother sat at his right. From the time I was old enough to sit in a chair I always sat next to her, even though it was more family protocol for my mother or one of my two aunts to sit next to her. My 11 cousins and my aunts were extremely upset that I refused to move from the chair. My grandmother made me feel important and special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, CHARLES W.
description: FRANKEL-Charles W. Age 78. Of N.J. Husband of Trudy, father of Larry and Nancy Gerber. Brother of Ruth Low. Beloved grandfather of Joshua and Adam. Services are 12:30 PM today, Robert Schoem's Menora Chapel, W-150 Rt 4 (East), Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A highlight and a program listing in the Television section on Sunday for 10 p.m. tomorrow on WLIW have become outdated. ''Terry Fox: Marathon of Hope'' has been postponed until October or later. The replacement is ''How to Live Forever, With Gary Null.''

title: For These Popsicles, Get Out Your ID Card
description: You have to be 21 to buy Lisa Kaine's Happy Hour Popsicles (really!) because they are spiked with alcohol. Ms. Kaine, the owner of the Bee and the Buttercup, a quirky bakery, confectionary, gift and flower shop at 138 East Third Street, makes them in flavors like mango pure, which gets a boost from dark rum, and peach nectar, which is infused with mint and a buzz of Champagne. I found those two more refreshing than the richer coconut-lemon grass sorbet doused with vodka, or chocolate with Irish cream liqueur. There is also apple with applejack.

title: Debate on Patients' Rights Sends Lobbyists Into Battle
description: Legislation defining patients' rights in a world of managed care, which the Senate began debating today, has triggered a brutal political war among health insurers, doctors, trial lawyers, consumer groups and employers.

title: Federal Order Fuels a California Dispute
description: Most sides involved in California's energy crisis called the decision by federal regulators to place tighter limits on the wholesale price of power a positive if limited step, but its primary impact was to intensify what has become a bitter nationwide battle between Republicans and Democrats.

title: Rising Reds From Tuscany
description: CHIANTI is the most familiar red wine from Tuscany, but it is far from the only one. The many others range from the exalted Brunello di Montalcino to the almost unknown Morellino di Scansano.

title: Creative Destruction and the Web
description: Companies that supply, build and operate fiber optic networks are burning. Level 3 Communications, groaning under an $8 billion debt load, is cutting 25 percent of its staff. Last week 360networks ominously delayed an interest payment. Nortel Networks of Canada could lose $19.2 billion -- yes, billion -- in the current quarter.

title: Mideast Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, STANLEY
description: LEWIN-Stanley. Our heartfelt sorrow to the family. Our dear friend has left a void which will remain forever. Carol and Bernie

title: Loving the Job and Even the Risk, but Acutely Feeling the Cost
description: They were washing their trucks and smoking cigars yesterday morning at the station house. They were trying to forget about the funerals.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Diamond Sales Down
description: De Beers said its sales of rough diamonds in the first half of the year slumped to $2.62 billion, down 26 percent from a record high last year because of falling demand in the United States, the world's biggest market for the cut and polished stones used in jewelry. The sales report was the first since De Beers went private last month in a $19 billion takeover led by the Oppenheimer family and the miner Anglo American. Each owns 45 percent of De Beers. De Beers said full-year sales would be $4.8 billion. De Beers sells about 65 percent of the world's rough diamonds and produces some 45 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Europe Is Said To Be Closer To G.E. Rebuff
description: The European Commission has proposed rejecting the General Electric Company's $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International in a ''draft decision'' that it distributed to European Union members, executives close to the commission said yesterday.

title: Colorado Is New Battleground For Halting Bilingual Education
description: Fresh off successful campaigns to end bilingual education programs in California and Arizona public schools, Ron Unz has turned his efforts to Colorado, where a local group announced plans today to collect signatures for a ballot initiative next year.

title: Article 2001062093359213549 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, ELAINE
description: JACOBI-Elaine. Of New York City, on Saturday, June 16, 2001, age 82. Wide of the late Sidney Jacobi. Devoted mother of Dana Jacobi. Beauty was her life. Sitting at Elaine's home, June 21 and 22, after 2 PM.

title: Regulators' Order Could Bring Broad California Power Accord
description: An order by federal regulators that power generators enter settlement talks with the State of California could open the door to a sweeping compromise of the financial issues in the state's power crisis, energy industry analysts and executives said today.

title: CALENDER
description: Proving the Rule

title: Amalia Mendoza, 78, Singer Of Soulful Mariachi Ballads
description: Amalia Mendoza, a diva of mariachi music whose dramatic performances brought fans to tears on both sides of the United States-Mexico border, died here on June 11. She was 78.

title: Gucci Group Reports Disappointing Quarterly Results
description: In a sign that an aggressive strategy may have left it dangerously exposed as the world economy slows, the luxury goods maker Gucci Group N.V. reported disappointing first-quarter results and lowered its sales and profit forecasts for the year. The rising cost of revamping Yves Saint Laurent, which Gucci bought in 1999, was a major factor in the shortfall, the company said.

title: Goldman Earnings Decline; Lehman Posts an Increase
description: Yellow lights flashed on Wall Street yesterday as two big investment banks reported distinctly different results for the last quarter but shared a cautious outlook for the rest of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, PAUL R.
description: CAREY-Paul R. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America extend their deepest sympathy to the Hon. Hugh L. Carey and his family on the loss of a beloved son and brother. We were thankful for Paul's friendship and support of New York City's Scouts. He will be greatly missed. John F. McGillicuddy, President Daniel R. Gasparo, Scout Executive

title: Stem Cell Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Excite@Home Gets Yet Another Infusion
description: Continuing to adjust to leaner times, the At Home Corporation said yesterday that it had raised $85 million in the form of a refund on telecommunications network capacity that it bought in 1998 from its majority owner, AT&T.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Killing Geese
description: Despite chants of ''goose killers! goose killers!'' from animal-rights protesters, Seattle officials rounded up several dozen Canada geese at a park and prepared to gas them to death. Droppings from the birds have overrun parts of the park, causing numerous complaints, the city said. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Ex-Diplomat To Lead Group In AIDS Battle
description: Five months after Richard C. Holbrooke stepped down as United States ambassador to the United Nations, he is returning to the international arena to try to persuade companies to join the fight against AIDS.

title: Sports of The Times; Torborg Rediscovers The Pain
description: WHEN you're up in the broadcasting booth, the knot in the stomach belongs to somebody else. Jeff Torborg is reliving that exquisite agony of seeing games blow apart, the way the Expos tossed away a 4-1 defeat at Shea Stadium last night for their 12th loss in 18 games since Torborg took over.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Urbina Deal Falls Through, So Yanks Still Seek Reliever
description: The Yankees' tentative deal for Montreal reliever Ugueth Urbina fell apart this evening after both Urbina and a Yankees minor leaguer, Brandon Knight, flunked physical examinations. The Yankees are back in the market for bullpen help.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The picture is destroyed, and nobody will know the whole picture.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Future May Be More Uncertain For Technology
description: With the Nasdaq composite index up 23 percent from its April lows, investors are clearly betting that the worst is over for technology stocks. But according to an extensive new report from Merrill Lynch that examines the financial results of 37 technology favorites, those bets may be premature.

title: Specter of a Rearmed Japan Stirs Its Wartime Generation
description: It did not take long, after he was shipped out to New Guinea as a 20-year-old infantryman to fight in a series of ferocious battles against advancing Allied forces in 1943, for Shigeru Mizuki to conclude that Japan's Pacific war was absurd.

title: French TV Closes a Long Chapter on Belles-Lettres
description: When Bernard Pivot began presenting his weekly book program here in 1973, French television still felt a responsibility to educate the public about culture. Today, with even government-owned channels bending to the dictates of ratings, Mr. Pivot's offering is almost an eccentricity, a program designed for an elite minority of older viewers who like to spend after-dinner on Fridays listening to writers discuss books and ideas.

title: A Tragic Fire, And Its Fighters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZORN, IRIS SEGAL
description: ZORN-Iris Segal-June 20, 1998. ''not a day goes by'' Jo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, CANTOR ERWIN
description: HIRSCH-Cantor Erwin. On June 18, 2001. Beloved husband of Martha, with whom he not only shared a wonderful life but a career. They worked together for over 50 years as Cantor and organist for Congregation Habonim bringing beautiful prayer and music to all. Loving father of Judi Travis and her husband, Bob, and David and his wife, Jill. Cherished grandfather of Jared and his wife, Jen, Emilie, Becky and Jason. Dear brother of Warren and his wife, Bibi. Services Thursday, June 21, 12 noon at Congregation Habonim, 44 West 66th Street.

title: Editors' Note
description: Articles on June 12 and last Sunday examined reactions abroad and at home to the continued use of the death penalty in the United States. The first article, written in Paris, spoke of widespread condemnation but quoted a French political scientist who said that attitude was centered ''among the elite.'' The article also pointed out that French opinion divides 50-50 in surveys on the death penalty and quoted several European voices who support it. The later article cited interviews and polls showing that while Americans' support for the penalty is eroding, a majority still favor it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRALL, ESTHER
description: BRALL-Esther, May 30, 2001. A passionate activist for human social and political causes. Loving mother of Martha Clayton and Sheila Wiener and devoted grandmother of Greg Clayton, Erik and Marc Wiener.

title: Artwork by Holocaust Victim Is Focus of Dispute
description: A bitter international scandal has erupted in a city in Ukraine, about 30 miles from the Polish border, where last month workers from Yad Vashem, Israel's main Holocaust museum, chiseled five fragments from a newly discovered series of wall paintings. They are the last known work of Bruno Schulz, a Polish Jewish writer, artist and Holocaust victim.

title: Managing Editor of The Times Will Become Op-Ed Columnist
description: Bill Keller, the managing editor of The New York Times for the last four years, will become a columnist for the Op-Ed page and a senior writer for The New York Times Magazine in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, KITTY F. (NEE MACRAE)
description: CAMERON-Kitty F. (nee MacRae) age 97, June 16th, 2001 in Exeter, NH. Beloved wife of the late Duncan, a retired Captain of NYPD. Loving mother of Mary of Exeter, NH. Funeral Mass in NH, interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Boeing Move
description: Only about half of the nearly 500 Seattle-based employees of the Boeing Company who have been asked to transfer to new headquarters in Chicago are likely to make the move, said Harry Stonecipher, the company's vice chairman. Speaking at the Paris Air Show, Mr. Stonecipher said Boeing would offer the transfers to other company employees first and then look in the Chicago area. The company is expected to begin operations at the new headquarters right after Labor Day. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Korean Peninsula: Sorting Out Shipping
description: South Korea's maritime minister, Chung Woo Taik, urged a pact between North and South Korea to permit ships from each country to sail closer to the other's coast. Meanwhile, he said, South Korea would continue to challenge North Korean ships whenever they enter the strait between the south of the peninsula and Cheju Island, or cross the northern lines that have divided North and South Korean waters since the Korean War. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 15  She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.

title: Which Wood?: A Pinch of Mesquite
description: CONSIDER wood the spice of barbecue: different woods impart different flavors. Here is a guide to some of the most commonly available woods for grilling. Softwoods like pine and spruce should be avoided  they send up too much soot and resinous smoke. And never use processed wood like plywood or pressure-treated lumber, which can give off toxic chemicals.

title: When the Sea Reaches for the Sky; A Favorite Of France Seduces New York
description: YOU do not forget the first time you have a plateau de fruits de mer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORGE, ELAINE (NEE BIENENSTOCK)
description: LORGE-Elaine (nee Bienenstock). Loving mother of daughter Dana and son Richard; grandmother of three grandchildren and great-grandmother of two; former wife of Carl Gurgold; sister of Arthur Bienenstock. Graveside service today at 1 PM, Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Queens.

title: Relief Isn't on the Way, And Bats Are Little Help
description: It would not have mattered tonight if the rookie Randy Keisler held runners a little better, if the bullpen prevented a late-inning rout, or if the Yankees had completed their trade for Ugueth Urbina. The knuckleball of Steve Sparks made those imperfections irrelevant.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET MP3.com that were only one-tenth of the intended $3 million. The $296,873 verdict announced in April was considered a low amount for TVT Records , which had sought $8.5 million against MP3.com for copyright infringement. But after reading news accounts of the award, jurors contacted United States District Judge Jed Rakoff to say that the total was incorrect. Judge Rakoff determined that the jurors intended the award to be around $2.9 million, but that a division error by one of the jurors led to the lower amount. Judge Rakoff said a retrial was the only reasonable alternative. The retrial is rescheduled for Nov. 5, two months after Vivendi Universal is to have completed its acquisition of MP3.com for $372 million. The acquisition could change the dynamic of the conflict. "It's good for us to have an opposing company that values copyright as strongly as we do," said Steve Gottlieb, chief executive of TVT Records. Jeffrey A. Conciatori, a lawyer for MP3.com, said the company was considering an appeal. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Conclusive Proof: Where There's Smoke . . .
description: GRILLING with wood should not be frightening, but it is not without challenges. A bed of wood embers is enough for 15 or 20 minutes of grilling, as opposed to 40 to 60 minutes with charcoal. To grill for extended periods or to cook large quantities, the fire must be restoked  and the fresh chunks of wood will burst into flame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFMANN, ADELE D., MD.
description: HOFMANN-Adele D., MD. A pioneer in adolescent medicine, extraordinary mentor and loving mother, Dr. Hofmann died June 15, 2001, at the age of 74. Hofmann graduated from Smith College and University of Rochester Medical School, and went on to direct pediatric programs at both New York University and Bellevue Hospital Center before relocating to California where she was affiliated with Children's Hospital of Orange County and University of California, Irvine. Among her many notable publications is ''Adolescent Medicine'', a leading textbook in its field. Hofmann was a Charter member & President of the Society for Adolescent Medicine. She also founded the Section on Adolescent Medicine for the American Academy of Pediatrics. In 1988, the Outstanding Achievement Award in Adolescent Health of the American Pediatrics, which Hofmann had received in 1984, was renamed The Adele Dellenbaugh Hofmann Award in Adolescent Health. Always a lover of travel and photography, Hofmann spent much of her later years traveling the world and photographing people. Dr. Adele Hofmann is survived by her cherished children, Annie Gardiner of California and Peter Hofmann of Connecticut. West Coast memorial services will be held at the Dana Point Yacht Club (949-493-8100) in Dana Point, CA on Sunday, July 1st from 6:30 -9:30 PM. East Coast memorial services will be held in October. Please visit www.adolescenthealth.org for details. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the 8% Early Intervention Program for high-risk youth and their families. Make checks payable to PCAA and mail to: 8% Early Intervention Program, c/o PCAA, 909 North Main Street, Santa Ana, CA 92701. Donations can also be made to the Nature Conservancy at www.nature.org

title: Editor's Note
description: Articles on June 12 and last Sunday examined reactions abroad and at home to the continued use of the death penalty in the United States. The first article, written in Paris, spoke of widespread condemnation but quoted a French political scientist who said that attitude was centered ''among the elite.'' The article also pointed out that French opinion divides 50-50 in surveys on the death penalty and quoted several European voices who support it. The later article cited interviews and polls showing that while Americans' support for the penalty is eroding, a majority still favor it.

title: Food Stuff: In the Greenmarkets, a Gentle Stand-In for Spinach
description: Only last summer, lamb's-quarters were an oddity in the Greenmarkets. This year just about any stall worth its arugula sells the flat-leaf greens, also known as pigfoot, wild spinach or, in Mexican cuisine, quelites.

title: Critic's Notebook; Wyant's Landscapes Depict Nature, Grand and Intimate
description: Though his name rings few bells today, Alexander Helwig Wyant once achieved fame as a painter of naturalistic landscapes -- a bit on the somber, elegiac side, to be sure -- inspired mainly by views in the Adirondacks and later in the Catskills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABLONDI, ITALO H.
description: ABLONDI-Italo H. On Saturday, June 16, 2001 at the John Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Unalane C. Ablondi of Alexandria, VA. Father of Leigh Mary Helvie of Ann Harbor, MI, Kim Ablondi of New York City and Phillip Carter Ablondi of New York City. Grandfather of Anna Karia, Peter and John Helvie. Friends may call at the Demaine Funeral Home, 520 South Washington St, Alexandria, VA. on Tuesday, June 19 from 2-4 and 6-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on June 20 at St. Mary's Catholic Church, 310 South Royal St., Alexandria, VA. at 10:30AM. Interment Ivy Hill Cemetery, Alexandria, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, in C/O Gastric Cancer Research, 124 Park St S.E., Vienna, VA. 22183.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AVERILL, BRETT
description: AVERILL-Brett. July 23, 1957-June 20, 1995. My darling Brett, for now and forever, I'll always love you. Bill

description: Neighborhood Name Watch

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: On the Streets, Singing by Their Wits
description: Sonhador and Peneira, a musical duo who appear sporadically in the documentary film ''Saudade do Futuro,'' are an indefatigably hardy team of entertainers who live by their wits on the streets of So Paulo.

title: Even When Absent, Woods Takes Spotlight
description: Tiger Woods is not expected to arrive at the Westchester Country Club, site of this week's Buick Classic, until Wednesday. But Woods does not have to be at a golf tournament to dominate the conversation, or to elicit a pointed comment from a contemporary about Woods's dominance.

title: Recipe: Rouille
description: ROUILLE

title: U.S. Agency Plans to Hire A Specialist On Gay Issues
description: The Agriculture Department is advertising for a ''gay and lesbian program specialist'' who would help improve working conditions for the agency's gay employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, CHARLES C., M.D.
description: HOGAN-Charles C., M.D. The Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine and the faculty, staff and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Charles Hogan. We are grateful to him for his contributions to the psychoanalytic understanding of psychosomatic illnesses and eating disorders. We remember him as a gentle and thoughtful man. We extend our sympathy to his wife Nina and his children, Matthew, Carlton and Noelle. Robert A. Glick, M.D. Director, Psychoanalytic Center Vivian Pender, M.D. President, APM

title: Judge Objects to F.A.A. Plan for No-Bid Contract to Lockheed
description: An administrative law judge has found that the Federal Aviation Administration's intention to give a huge air traffic control modernization contract to the Lockheed Martin Corporation without competitive bidding is premature. The judge said he based the ruling on the fact that the agency had only a vague idea of how the new system would function.

title: Corruption in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF
description: I WANTED to offer a cheese course before dessert in my restaurant. But presenting a cart with 20 or so cheeses wouldn't work for me. On the other hand, it seemed too pedestrian to just put wedges of five cheeses on a plate with a bunch of grapes.

title: Five One-Acts Depicting The Lives of The Entitled
description: In Amanda Beesley's quietly riveting one-act play ''The Stolen Child'' a young married couple sit side by side in wooden chairs and, addressing each other and the audience, tell the story of their African honeymoon. The setup suggests they are speaking to a therapist or, as Ms. Beesley's script specifies, to a jury, but either is appropriate. The issue at the heart of their story is guilt.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Currency Policy
description: Uruguay will allow its currency to weaken at a faster pace to offset a falling currency in Brazil and a devaluation for trade in neighboring Argentina. The Uruguayan peso will be devalued at a rate of 1.2 percent a month, up from a rate of 0.6 percent. The band in which the peso trades against the dollar was also widened to six percentage points from three percentage points, said Alberto Bension Salinas, Uruguay's minister of economy and finance. Uruguay wants to accelerate the pace of the currency's devaluation to help exporters compete with Brazil and Argentina, its main export markets.

title: Councilman Denies Improperly Helping Building Consultant
description: City Councilman Thomas V. Ognibene acknowledged yesterday that he had made calls on behalf of a building industry consultant who is at the center of a corruption inquiry. But the councilman said that his efforts were nothing out of the ordinary and that he never accepted gifts from the consultant.

title: Paints in Tow, in Pursuit of the Flume; Artists Set Out to Recapture Rocky Vision of Adirondacks
description: It was nearly 4 p.m. by the time they saw the distinctive white rocks along the Opalescent River, suggesting that the goal was finally at hand. But Catherine Minnery's legs were aching by then after more than six hours on the trail, and the strong afternoon sunlight -- though perfect for painting -- was about to fade. The muddy, root-strewn hike back to camp would be treacherous after dark. Time was running out.

title: Silenced at Stuyvesant
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Green Criticizes Mayor
description: Public Advocate Mark Green, who is a Democratic candidate for mayor, accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday of pressuring police officials to ''short-circuit'' the internal investigation of the shooting of Amadou Diallo, contending that the mayor's public comments nearly exonerated the officers involved before a decision not to discipline them on April 27. Mr. Giuliani dismissed Mr. Green's accusations. ''The fact is that the case is long over with, and the fact is that we are in the middle of a mayoral race,'' the mayor said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Assault And Robbery At Home
description: Two gunmen followed a 32-year-old man into his home in Jackson Heights yesterday and tied the man up along with another man and two women who were inside, the police said. The assailants sexually assaulted one of the women, who is 18, and fled with an undetermined amount of cash, the police said. The police did not identify the victims or provide many details of the robbery, which happened about 5 p.m. They described the gunmen as being in their 30's. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: The Lesson of When to Give Aid to Free Markets
description: Three weeks ago George W. Bush addressed a sympathetic audience of business executives at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles and declared that his administration ''will not take any action that makes California's problems worse, and that's why I oppose price caps'' on electricity.

title: $160 Million Newark Plan Focuses on New Housing
description: A private foundation seeking to revive part of Newark's blighted downtown is to unveil a $160 million plan on Wednesday for luxury apartments and retail development to help transform the area into a round-the-clock neighborhood, people familiar with the plan said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, HILDA
description: HALPERN-Hilda. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the mother of its esteemed member, Mr. Baruch Halpern, & extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert Chairman J. Ezra Merkin President

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Nuclear Questions For North Korea And Iraq
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said it was unable to verify that North Korea and Iraq are not diverting nuclear material for military purposes. The agency said it could not confirm North Korea's insistence that it had produced only a few grams of plutonium because inspectors had not been given sufficient access. (The C.I.A. thinks North Korea could have produced enough for two nuclear weapons.) The agency also cannot say if Iraq is eliminating any nuclear weapons program because Baghdad has not admitted inspectors since December 1999. Christopher S. Wren (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Going National, and Farther North, in Harlem Retailing
description: The neighborhood adjacent to Broadway in the upper 130's is packed with apartments and the streets teem with people, but most street-level retail stores are of the mom-and-pop variety, offering a limited variety of goods and services.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Bigger Slice Of Taxes
description: Gov. Kenny Guinn signed a measure intended to help balance the state budget and finance a raise for teachers by directing to the state all the taxes collected by rental car companies. Under the old law, the state got only part of the tax revenue, with the rest going to the rental companies. The new law provides $23.5 million over two years for teachers' salaries, and would allow car rental agencies the option of a 3.5 percent surcharge on all rentals, to make up for the lost money. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: France and the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Iron Man Retires
description: Cal Ripken Jr. was always a throwback to a time when growing up did not entail growing disillusioned with one's sports heroes. Ripken, the indestructible Baltimore Orioles shortstop who brought a fearsome bat to a position mainly known for slick fielding, has decided to retire at the end of this season, at the age of 41.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Faulty Roller Coaster Sensor
description: A faulty sensor caused last week's breakdown of a roller coaster at the Lake Compounce amusement park that left riders stranded midride, officials said. The roller coaster, the Zoomerang, was not the coaster, the Boulder Dash, that malfunctioned last Wednesday and struck and killed a maintenance worker. The cause of that accident is still being investigated. In the Zoomerang incident, 26 passengers were suspended 60 feet in the air Thursday when the braking system failed. Florence Sinow, a spokesman for the state fire marshal, said no one was hurt and that the ride later passed safety tests.

title: Best Buy's Profit Slides 24% in Period
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn., June 19 (Bloomberg News)  The Best Buy Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit fell nearly 24 percent, but that the slowing economy did not drag on earnings as much as expected.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Trade Dispute With Japan
description: China has placed high duties on imported Japanese cars, mobile phones and air-conditioners in retaliation for duties Japan put on Chinese vegetables and other farm products. Japan raised tariffs on Chinese leeks, shiitake mushrooms and reeds used to make floor mats in an effort to protect farmers from cheap imports. The trade battle is a harbinger of troubles to come after China joins the World Trade Organization, and trade with the rest of the world increases. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Harold A. Jerry Jr., 81; Helped Preserve the Adirondacks as Forever Wild
description: Harold A. Jerry Jr., a past New York State public service commissioner who played a major role in a state plan to save the Adirondacks from overdevelopment, died on June 9 at his home in Albany. He was 81 and also lived in Speculator, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Sunday Q&A column on June 10 about the campaign for elections to the British parliament misstated the number of seats in the House of Commons in 1997. It was 659, not 651.

title: Behind Rancor, a Clash of Ideas In New Jersey's G.O.P. Primary
description: So far, the Republican primary campaign for governor here has focused more on personal attacks and tactical arm wrestling than on any deep philosophical differences.

title: RealNetworks Goes After Bigger Piece of Media Library Pie
description: RealNetworks plans to release software today that it hopes will convince media companies to distribute their vast libraries of music, movies and books over the Internet and enable RealNetworks to capture a portion of the hundreds of billions of dollars consumers are expected to spend on such products.

title: 19th-Century Charm Saved in 21st-Century Stacks
description: It seemed like business as usual Saturday for the Ottendorfer library, a little East Village literary outpost an inch shy of 20 feet wide. A small cluster of people gathered on the stoop, waiting for the doors to open. Matt Vigil, 32, was looking for a quiet place to study. Molly Hall, 33, wanted to check the job listings.

title: Payments Begin for Laborers Forced to Work for the Nazis
description: Rancor mingled with relief as thousands of Nazi-era slave laborers began receiving payments yesterday from a $4.5 billion German compensation fund, more than half a century after the fact and following years of legal wrangling and delay.

title: Where Pigs Get Licenses To Fly
description: THE first thought is something like, uh-oh, this is it: the end of days. Hell must have finally frozen over. Or maybe someone should check to see if lions are lying down with lambs all over the world.

description: Time: 10 minutes 1/2 cup ketchup

title: At Buick, Synergy Is Spelled Woods
description: There is no better recipe for a golf tournament's success than the presence of Tiger Woods, who is playing at the Buick Classic in Harrison, N.Y., for the first time since 1997, when he finished in a tie for 43rd place.

title: Talks Stalled Over Rights Of Albanians In Macedonia
description: Four days into intensive political negotiations to end the conflict with ethnic Albanian rebels, Macedonia's leaders were no closer to a solution today than before they began, foreign diplomats said.

title: Sports of The Times; Graceful Game Is Robbed Of Its Finesse
description: THE single most striking moment in the N.B.A. finals was not Allen Iverson, the Sixers' irrepressible guard, scoring on a big shot in bumper-to-bumper traffic. Nor was it Kobe Bryant, the Lakers' legend-in-progress, coolly sweeping along the baseline for a gorgeous up-and-under lay-in, or Derek Fisher or Robert Horry sinking improbable and game-deciding 3-point shots from what seemed as far away as Saskatchewan.

description: WINE AND WAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARION, JOE
description: DARION-Joe. Joe Darion and I created the score for ''Man of La Mancha.'' We became parents of a classic. We shared many things, including a birthday (January 30th). I am forever grateful that he shared his creative life with me and I will remember him forever. Rest in peace, Joe. Mitch Leigh

title: Why Juan Won't Save; Financial Services Industry Fails to Reach Many Hispanics
description: Guadalupe Avita has been living in the United States for 10 years, but only recently opened a bank account.

title: Article 2001062092782766508 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANSER, HOWARD
description: TANSER-Howard. On June 17, 2001. Beloved son of the late Harry and Ethel Tanser. Loving brother of Julie Keye and her husband Chip. Dear uncle of Elizabeth. Cherished stepson of Corinne Tanser. Services Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Scaling Back On Education
description: Lagging tax revenues have convinced Gov. Gray Davis that he has to cut more than $500 million from his education spending proposals, including some programs he had called his top priorities. Davis aides said the governor had agreed to abandon his hope of extending the middle-school year, along with other programs for elementary and secondary schools and community colleges. Mr. Davis had vowed to increase education spending by 6.4 percent, despite the state's energy problems and projections of a slipping economy. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Assessing Blame In Fatal Crash
description: The train crash outside Paddington in October 1999, which killed 31, could have been avoided if Railtrack, the network operator set up in the privatization of Britain's aging and underfinanced railways five years ago, had acted on safety complaints about the site, a Government report said. The inquiry found that new train drivers were not taught the route in and out of Paddington, one of London's busiest stations, and concluded that ''the safety culture in regard to training was slack.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Teach a Child: Many Yardsticks
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Greenmarkets, a Gentle Stand-In for Spinach
description: Only last summer, lamb's-quarters were an oddity in the Greenmarkets. This year just about any stall worth its arugula sells the flat-leaf greens, also known as pigfoot, wild spinach or, in Mexican cuisine, quelites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAUDOIN, JOHN PAUL
description: BEAUDOIN-John Paul. We deeply regret the passing of John Paul Beaudoin, survived by his loving wife Jeanne, father to Vivian Agrusa, Jessica, Jennifer and Julia Beaudoin. Brother to Claude Beaudoin and grandfather to John Ross and Francesca. He was born in Manchester, NH, joined the navy in 1950, served his country in the Korean War in the submarine service as a radio operator. John received his undergraduate degree at Westchester University in Westchester, PA. He was a Fulbright scholar at the University of Lyon at Lyon, France. He started his teaching career in Chester, PA and came to Long Island to teach French and coach varsity tennis for the East Meadow school district for over 20 years. He was the quintessential educator who embraced his students as teacher, confidant and friend. After retiring in 1987 and living a full life for most, John took on the family responsibilities of raising his three beautiful daughters. John died on June 18, 2001 at North Shore University Hospital. He is sadly missed. Services Wednesday 9AM at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel, Woodbury, LI. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, Long Island.

title: Teach a Child: Many Yardsticks
description: To the Editor:

title: Teach a Child: Many Yardsticks
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Appoints Lawyer for the Giuliani Children
description: An exasperated judge appointed a law guardian yesterday to give the two children of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Donna Hanover a voice in the couple's increasingly rancorous and protracted divorce.

title: Lovers United in Decadence and Rottenness
description: The Royal Ballet whirled out of a ''Swan Lake'' mini-festival here: As Odile, the imposter who seduces Prince Siegfried, the young Spanish ballerina Tamara Rojo added an amazing quadruple turn to the triple fouetts she had already executed beyond the call of duty. Her Siegfried, the magnificent Cuban dancer Carlos Acosta, responded in kind with the whiplash speed of his turns  la seconde.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, MADELINE D. (''DOLORES'')
description: SLOAN-Madeline D. (''Dolores''). Of Pelham, NY on June 14. Born in Brooklyn on June 16, 1925, she married Edward P. Sloan (d. 1970) in 1949 and lovingly raised their children, Edward, Peter, Pamela and Laura in St. Catherine of Genoa RC parish. She moved to Pelham in 1989 where, as ''Grammy'', she happily cared for her grandchildren and their friends.
