She is survived by her children, their spouses and nine grandchildren who ask that anyone wishing to honor her life make a contribution to Angela House, Inc. 3323 Steuben Ave, Bronx, NY 10467, a home for single mothers and their children.

title: Officials Think Horseplay Led to Deadly Fire
description: New York City fire investigators believe that one of the deadliest fires in the Fire Department's history can be traced to a purely accidental cause: two teenage boys, roughhousing on Father's Day, knocked over a can of gasoline in the backyard of a hardware store in Queens.

title: Mourning Far and Wide for Firemen
description: The city's firefighters began gathering yesterday to remember their lost colleagues at viewing services for two of the three firemen who lost their lives in Sunday's blaze.

title: The Shucker's Art: Practice, Practice
description: IT'S easy to tell when clams and oysters are fresh -- their shells are tightly closed, and you will not be able to pry them open with your fingers. Which means they're alive.

title: On 100th Anniversary, a University Feels Reinvigorated
description: At the parties and conferences last week celebrating the 100th anniversary of Rockefeller University, the mood was congratulatory. In just a century, Rockefeller researchers had developed vaccines against meningitis, discovered that genes are made of DNA and demonstrated the connection between cholesterol and heart disease. And its laboratories were percolating with new experiments on AIDS, cancer, obesity, lupus and other modern-day scourges.

title: Liberties; The Girl Who Vanished
description: I was an intern for a congressman when I was 17. Nothing lurid ever happened.

title: Donald J. Cram, 82, Is Dead; Shared Nobel Chemistry Prize
description: Dr. Donald J. Cram, who shared the 1987 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for synthesizing molecules that mimicked some of the chemical reactions of life, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 82.

title: Recipe: Scallop Ceviche
description: Time: 30 minutes 1 pound very fresh sea scallops, cut into 1/4-inch dice

title: Recipe: Prepared Horseradish
description: Time: 10 minutes 1 small horseradish root

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Challenger For Jeb Bush
description: State Senator Daryl L. Jones, a one-time nominee for secretary of Air Force, became the first Florida Democrat to say publicly that he woud challenge Gov. Jeb Bush in 2002. Mr. Jones, 46, is a Miami lawyer and Air Force Academy graduate whose nomination was rejected by Senate Armed Services Committee in 1998 after questions were raised about his flying record in the Air Force Reserve. Other Democrats said to be considering running include former Attorney General Janet Reno, Representative Jim Davis of Tampa and Pete Peterson, the outgoing United States ambassador to Vietnam. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Kenji Yoshino, a professor at Yale Law School, misidentified the publication where an article of his is about to appear. It is The Yale Law Journal, not The Law Review.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday with an article about the National Dance Institute, which provides instruction to children, misstated the day on which it would be the subject of a film broadcast by PBS. The program is tonight; it was not last night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Herbert Woods, who helped his wife run Sylvia's Restaurant in Harlem, misidentified the town where he lived. It was Mount Vernon, N.Y., not Mount Pleasant.

title: ATLAS AIR WILL CUT 200 JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: The air cargo carrier Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings said yesterday that it would cut 200 jobs and idle as many as six aircraft at its air-freight unit. Atlas, based in Purchase, N.Y., also said that it expected to miss earnings forecasts because of a drop in demand and would probably break even this quarter and earn 90 cents to $1.10 a share for the year, excluding one-time charges. Atlas was expected to earn 49 cents this quarter and $2.24 for the year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Atlas plans to take a second-quarter charge of as much as $50 million to cover severance and other items. The reduction of 200 ground-crew workers follows the layoff last month of 105 pilots and flight engineers.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Carnival in Venice: Arty, Artful, Artless
description: Minus the art mob that jams the press preview and briefly creates the illusion that this might actually turn out to be a vast attraction beyond contemporary-art circles, the latest Venice Biennale, No. 49, has quickly become what all biennales become, an oasis of calm and predictability on the margins of a city that blessedly doesn't change much, either.

title: Bloomberg Says He Knows Just the Place to Put All Those Political Reporters
description: Michael R. Bloomberg's fledgling mayoral agenda may still be a work in progress, but he apparently has some distinct ideas about where the political press should be: far away from him.

title: ACCOUNTING FIRM TO PAY A BIG FINE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission brought a civil fraud complaint against Arthur Andersen yesterday in the first such case filed against a Big Five accounting firm in more than a decade. Andersen settled the suit and agreed to pay a penalty of $7 million, the largest ever assessed against an accounting firm.

title: Governor and Assembly Reach Tentative $26.5 Billion Budget Accord
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and top Democrats and Republicans in the General Assembly said today that they had reached a tentative agreement on a two-year, $26.5 billion state budget. They said they were hopeful that the state House of Representatives would pass the budget by the end of the week and send it to the Senate.

title: Sierra Leone Is Swamped By Graft, Ex-Aide Says
description: The former finance minister of Sierra Leone said in an interview this week that while the country has begun to make some progress in restoring peace and rebuilding itself after years of intermittent civil war, corruption threatens to undercut both economic and democratic development.

title: Will the Real Billy Elliot (Movie Muse) Please Relev
description: At a recent meeting of senior staff members at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Michael M. Kaiser, the president, welcomed a shy, slight, short-haired man who was seated at the head of the table.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Nude Photos Returned
description: A federal judge yesterday ruled that nude photographs of two girls, ages 3 and 8, taken by their grandmother are not pornographic and must be returned to the woman. But the judge also ruled that the Montclair Police Department and the Essex County prosecutor's office cannot be sued for violating the free-speech rights of the grandmother, Marian Rubin, 66, when they filed child endangerment charges that were later dropped. A lawyer for the county, Robert C. Scrivo, called the decision a ''win-win,'' although he said an appeal had not been ruled out. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Dinner and a Show and a Hotel Room
description: The Doral Park Avenue Hotel has taken a traditional combination -- dinner and a Broadway show  and added a third element: a night in one of its deluxe double rooms. The package, good through Sept. 3, costs $399 excluding tax. There's a choice of orchestra seats to "Cabaret" for evening performances Tuesday through Friday and Sunday, or matinees on Saturday or Sunday. The pre-theater dinner, at the hotel's 70 Park Bar and Grill, includes appetizer, main course, coffee, dessert, tax and tip. And at check-in, there's a bottle of champagne. The price, which is for two, is good any night of the week but is subject to hotel and ticket availability. The 188-room hotel is at 38th Street and Park Avenue. Information: (877) 993-6725 or www.doralparkavenue.com .

title: Our Towns; Fire Tragedy Comes Home To Suburbs
description: USUALLY, the endless asphalt carpet of the Long Island Expressway is enough to separate a firefighter and his family from the chaos of New York City.

title: Seattle Journal; An Unlikely Protest at a Starbucks
description: After a white police officer here fatally shot a black man late last month, the aftermath followed in many ways a sadly familiar refrain.

title: Heavyweights Still in Court For the Fight Before the Fight
description: Mike Tyson is expected to return to the ring in August or September, but whether he will fight Lennox Lewis will be determined by negotiations that are still going on between HBO and Showtime.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 50 More Fighter Jets
description: The air force is ordering more than 50 F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin. The purchase, worth $2 billion, will be financed largely by American military aid. The jets will be delivered between 2006 and 2009, after completion of an earlier order for 50 F-16's placed in 1999, the defense ministry said. When Israel recently used F-16's to bomb a Palestinian jail in Nablus, some critics in Congress said the attack violated a stipulation that the jets be used only for defense. Israel called the attack a legitimate move against terrorism. William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

title: 2 Boys' Horseplay Is Linked to Blaze Deadly to Firemen
description: New York City investigators believe that one of the deadliest fires in the Fire Department's history can be traced to an accident: two teenage boys, roughhousing on Father's Day, knocked over a can of gasoline behind a hardware store in Queens.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Will Meet With Sharon

title: Berenson Found Guilty of Collaborating With Peruvian Guerrillas
description: LIMA, Peru, June 20 - Lori Berenson, the 31-year-old New Yorker who has been held for more than five years in Peruvian prisons on terrorism charges, was found guilty today by a civilian court of collaborating in a foiled terrorist plot to take the entire Peruvian Congress hostage five years ago.

title: Driver Who Tossed Dog Is Convicted of Cruelty
description: When Sara McBurnett's Subaru Legacy bumped into a black sport utility vehicle on a rainy road near the San Jose International Airport, she expected a quick exchange of insurance information and, perhaps, a police report.

title: Executive to Lend Millions To Construction Business
description: Dennis R. Washington, the chairman of the Washington Group International, one of the nation's largest construction companies, has agreed to lend his company at least $10 million while it is restructured under bankruptcy protection, Mr. Washington said yesterday.

title: Dance in Review
description: Going Clubbing With Attitude

title: Death Declaration Ends Hunt for Etan Patz
description: The 22-year search for Etan Patz officially ended yesterday in a Manhattan courtroom, where a judge granted the father's wish and pronounced the child, who disappeared when he was 6, legally dead.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: New League Has the Stars, But It Also Wants the Fans
description: Why, in a time of folding leagues like the Continental Basketball Association, the International Hockey League and the XFL football league, would anybody start a professional circuit for lacrosse, a sport few Americans understand and fewer care about?

title: Accounts
description: * Rossignol, Williston, Vt., the United States unit of Rossignol S.A., to Modernista, Boston, to handle print advertising for skis and other snow gear, which had been at WideOpenSpaces, Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at less than $1 million. Media planning and buying are handled in-house. WideOpenSpaces continues to handle Web site development for Rossignol.

title: 46 New L.I.R.R. Locomotives Must Go Back for Repairs
description: All 46 of the new locomotives that pull the Long Island Rail Road's double-decker commuter trains must be sent back to the manufacturer so cracks that have developed in the steel frames supporting their engines can be repaired, railroad officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: New Title, Then Summit With India
description: The military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf will be sworn in as president today, ahead of a July 14-16 summit meeting in India with Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Islamabad news agency reports said. The reports, quoting senior government officials, said the move was intended to enhance the general's standing. The summit announcement yesterday said it would begin with a ceremonial welcome in New Delhi, then move to what India's foreign ministry described as ''a retreat'' for the leaders at Agra, 150 miles south. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline in Business Day yesterday about the expectations of four media companies for their financial performance this year misstated the number that said they were likely to meet Wall Street forecasts. It was three; the Washington Post Company did not make a prediction.

title: Brooklyn Team Makes Its Debut
description: The Brooklyn Cyclones made their debut in the New York-Penn League last night with a 2-1 victory over the Jammers in Jamestown, N.Y.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Violent Inmates
description: The Department of Corrections wants to put its most violent inmates in a two-year behavior modification program that would strip them of all privileges. The plan, which will be submitted to the Legislature after July 1, would use a carrot and stick approach with up to 380 prisoners, said Margot Bach, a spokeswoman for the department. Privileges like phone calls would be restored, depending on the inmate's participation in a violence prevention program. Steve Fama, an advocate for prisoners, said the proposal was too punitive, raising the risk that it would backfire. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: A Tragic Fire, and Its Fighters
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: UNITED NATIONS

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Advertising Educational Foundation, New York, presented awards to three executives at its annual Honors Night. David Bell, chairman and chief executive at True North Communications, was honored in the agency field. Michael W. Gunn, executive vice president for marketing and planning at American Airlines, was honored in the advertiser field. And Janet L. Robinson, senior vice president for newspaper operations at The New York Times Company and president and general manager for The New York Times, was honored in the media field.

title: World Briefing | The World: Thou Shalt Not Get Away From It All
description: Urging believers not to ''take a rest from ethics'' while on holiday, Pope John Paul II deplored the rise of ''sophisticated holiday resorts that are cut off from any real contact with the host countries.'' The pope, who issued his letter on World Tourism Day, also warned that the search for ''superficial exoticism'' could lead to sex tours that exploit women and children. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: The Latest From Gucci:A Skimpier Bottom Line
description: PARIS  An abrupt profit warning from Gucci Group sent shock waves through the fashion industry Tuesday, suggesting that the days of wine and poses may be over for the luxury sector.

title: From One Baker to Another: Amy's Bread Answers a Call
description: Call it the muffin connection. When Jean Kahn decided to close her bakery-cafe, Les Friandises, at 972 Lexington Avenue (70th Street), to work with her husband, Rafet Senturk, in Dalga, his new Turkish seafood restaurant on East 62nd Street, the first thing she did was to call Amy Scherber, the owner of Amy's Bread, whom she knew professionally. It was not hard to persuade Ms. Scherber to take over the place for a branch of her Chelsea and Ninth Avenue bakeries. You'll recognize the turquoise-striped awning, like the one shading Amy's Bread at Ninth Avenue and 46th Street. And you'll also recognize Ms. Scherber's signature semolina breads, black olive twists, layer cakes and sandwiches. New at this store are wedges of quiche, $4, and hearty salads with vegetables, grains, chicken and fish, $6 to $7.

title: Spoofing Familiar Genres In a Search for Laughs
description: In the summer of 1977 Norman Lear developed ''Fernwood 2-Night,'' a satire of talk shows, spun off from ''Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman,'' a satire of soap operas. One of the guests was Paul Reubens, who later became famous as Pee-Wee Herman.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Mistrial In MP3.Com Suit
description: A federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in a case in which a mathematical error by a jury resulted in damages against MP3.com that were only one-tenth of the intended $3 million. The $296,873 verdict announced in April was considered a low amount for TVT Records, which had sought $8.5 million against MP3.com for copyright infringement. But after reading news accounts of the award, jurors contacted United States District Judge Jed Rakoff to say that the total was incorrect. Judge Rakoff determined that the jurors intended the award to be around $2.9 million, but that a division error by one of the jurors led to the lower amount. Judge Rakoff said a retrial was the only reasonable alternative. The retrial is rescheduled for Nov. 5, two months after Vivendi Universal is to have completed its acquisition of MP3.com for $372 million. The acquisition could change the dynamic of the conflict. ''It's good for us to have an opposing company that values copyright as strongly as we do,'' said Steve Gottlieb, chief executive of TVT Records. Jeffrey A. Conciatori, a lawyer for MP3.com, said the company was considering an appeal. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, FRANCES SHAPIRO (NEE MESSINGER)
description: STERN-Frances Shapiro (nee Messinger). 84, died on June 19 at her home. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Julius R. Shapiro and the late Irving Stern. Loving mother of Albert, Steven and Susan Shapiro. Adored grandmother of Julia, Daniel, Rebecca, Sara and Ethan. Loving mother-in-law of Ruth Ann and Susan and grateful friend of Roger. She was always unselfishly devoted to her extended family and many friends. Service at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, NY on Friday at 11 AM, June 22. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice of Bergen Community Health Care, 400 Old Hook Road, Westwood, NJ 07675 or the American Cancer Society. For information call Clark Associates Funeral Home, 914-232-3033.

title: History on the Half Shell: The Plateau in Paris
description: ON the night of Dec. 20, 1927, some 2,500 revelers made their way to the Boulevard Montparnasse to celebrate the opening of La Coupole, the vast brasserie that was to become emblematic of lighthearted Paris in the 20's, les Annes Folles.

title: A Seasoned Team and Tuscany
description: ON my first four visits to Beppe, I kept wishing the chef, Cesare Casella, would stop lavishing his attention on the patrons in the dining room and get back to the kitchen, where he needed to lavish attention on the cooks, who seemed bereft of the most basic skills: frying, roasting, boiling and seasoning.

title: Camby Has Game Plan For Helping A School
description: Seldom have so many children begged to go to the principal's office.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Lottery Battle
description: Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, said a tentative compromise on how to spend profits from a newly created state lottery was in trouble and he threatened to veto the reapportionment bill supported by Republican leaders of the Legislature. The House speaker, David Wilkins, a Republican, accused Mr. Hodges of using the lottery issue to throw the reapportionment issue into the courts in hopes of getting a better deal for Democrats.

title: Green Accuses Mayor of Derailing Diallo Inquiry
description: Public Advocate Mark Green accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday of pressuring police officials to "short-circuit" the internal investigation of the shooting of Amadou Diallo, contending that the mayor's public comments nearly exonerated the officers involved.

title: Getting Over the Fear-of-Speaking Hump
description: Maria Vizzi knew she was in trouble. Again. Two years ago, Ms. Vizzi, then a sales representative for a Web site for insurance agents, was about to begin a speech to a group of risk managers at a conference when her body revolted. ''My throat began to tighten up,'' said Ms. Vizzi of Manhattan. ''My palms began to sweat. And my face and neck turned so red that I wished I'd worn a full-body sari.''

title: Recipe: Lemon-Tabasco Dipping Sauce
description: LEMON-TABASCO DIPPING SAUCE

title: HANCOCK TO BUY LIFE DIVISION OF CANADIAN INSURER
description: John Hancock Financial Services Inc. has agreed to buy the Canadian life insurance unit of the Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group for $153 million to expand its annuity and savings products businesses. John Hancock, based in Boston, said it would add $87 million to its annual premium income through the acquisition. The sale is expected to be completed in October and is being carried out by Hancock's Maritime Life Assurance unit. Royal Sun sells universal life insurance, deferred annuities and savings products. John Hancock, the investment-management and financial-services company, has been building its retail life insurance and investment products business through acquisitions.

title: Evoking Memories Of Cherished Ones
description: Richard Daniels

title: But Not for Prime Time
description: CBS and NBC have reversed policies prohibiting condom advertising, joining Fox as national broadcast networks that now at least officially agree to sell commercial time to brands like Trojan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Waiting For The Missing Tory
description: Battle lines are drawn in the Conservative Party leadership race: three declared candidates opposed to adopting the euro as Britain's currency, Michael Portillo, Iain Duncan Smith and David Davis, are waiting to see if former Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke, who is pro-euro, will enter the contest. Mr. Clarke, the most popular, is delaying his decision until next week. Tory members of Parliament will choose two finalists to put before the 350,000 party members later this summer. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE BRITAIN: MG ROVER ACQUIRING ITALIAN CAR MG Rover, the British auto company, said it would buy the Italian maker of the Mangusta sports car from its parent, Qvale Automotive of the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. MG Rover said it planned to start a luxury sports car code-named MG X80 next year based on the engineering of the Mangusta. Kevin Howe, chief executive of MG Rover, said the model would give the company a greater presence in the United States.

title: A Time for Frankness On AIDS and Africa
description: In the special United Nations session on AIDS next week, there will be much discussion about international aid, about drugs and vaccines. But there is likely to be too little said about what is the primary means by which AIDS is spread in sub-Saharan Africa: risky heterosexual sex.

title: Arguments on Death Penalty For 2nd Convicted Terrorist
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers clashed before a federal jury in Manhattan yesterday over whether a terrorist who bombed the American Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in 1998 should be sentenced to death.

title: Natal Journal; A Has-Been Wonders How to Honor What Was
description: Watching fishermen repairing boats on the banks of the river here, it is hard to imagine that Life magazine could ever have called this place ''the wartime crossroads of the world.'' Or that the United States War Department in 1942 designated Natal ''one of the four most strategic points in the world,'' along with Suez, Gibraltar and the Bosporus.

title: Encore! Encore! For a Star Of Summer
description: CONNOISSEURS know corn bread has a shelf life just slightly longer than a souffl. Hot out of the oven, it reaches perfection in those few heartbeats between the moment you get the butter slathered on and the second it starts to fall apart as you take the first bite.

title: One Round And Out For Greene
description: Maurice Greene is the Olympic and United States champion and the world record-holder (9.79 seconds) in the 100-meter dash, making him the world's fastest human.

title: Stocks Finish Higher After Struggling Earlier
description: Alate rally in the technology sector led the stock market higher today after a choppy session in which investors considered conflicting signals about the prospects for corporate earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOYD, ANDREW LESLIE, PH.D.
description: FLOYD-Andrew Leslie, Ph.D. Economist, Travel Consultant. May 22, 2001. Born Laszlo Endre Fenyo; Szeged, Hungary, Sept 5, 1920. Beloved husband of Elizabeth McFall Floyd, loving father of Laszlo and Istvan Fenyo, loving grandfather of Zsolt Fenyo. Andrew cherished his family, his many friends and his garden. He loved to travel, and his sudden death in Paris came after a very happy fortnight, spent wandering through Brittany with his wife. Mount Hope Cemetery, HastingsOn-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBB, DOROTHY LAURA
description: COBB-Dorothy Laura. Died June 16, 2001 at home, at the age of 99. Born in Staten Island, NY in 1901, the daughter of Merton Raleigh Cobb and Elsie Hathaway Cobb. Retired head librarian of the St. Agnes Branch of the New York Public Library. Dorothy was a loyal and active participant in the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New York and in St. Michael's Parish, for many decades. She was an inspiration and friend to many members of the Clergy & Laity. A funeral service will be held at 2:00 PM on Friday, June 22 at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Music and Arts at St. Michael's Church.

title: David Sylvester, 76, Art Critic Who Championed Modernism
description: David Sylvester, for many years an influential critic, exhibition organizer and shaper of opinion in the international modern-art field, died on Monday in London. He was 76 and lived in London.

title: Agoos Is at the Heart of the U.S. Defense
description: He was part of the World Cup team in 1998, when the United States finished last among the 32 nations in the finals. This time around, Jeff Agoos is the anchor of the American defense and wants to earn some redemption for the national team.

title: Food Radio: Sizzling or Scrambled
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago I was home reveling in NPR's ''All Things Considered'' at cocktail hour when a food segment was announced. It had been so long since I had heard anything culinary on the air that I happily pulled my wineglass closer to the stereo and settled in to be entertained, if not enlightened.

title: Bickering Is Fraying The Ties That Bind
description: The Mets promoted the notion yesterday that a full day of meetings on Monday had extinguished the infighting that developed as players were quoted over the weekend criticizing teammates, particularly Timo Perez.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Yankees Try Pickoff Move
description: The New York Yankees want Teligent Inc. to either pay for its billboard at Yankee Stadium or let the Yankees sell the space to someone else. Teligent, a provider of wireless communications services that sought protection from creditors in Bankruptcy Court last month, agreed earlier this year to pay $515,000 for a 23-by-27-foot billboard, full-page advertisements in team publications, parties in suites at the stadium, tickets and a home-plate ceremony for a company charity program. It has already paid half of the amount due. If Teligent cancels the deal later in the season, it would ''cause significant harm'' because the Yankees may be unable to find a replacement, the team said in papers filed Monday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. A Teligent spokeswoman, Tita Thompson, declined to comment on the case.

title: Rights and a Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman With a New View of Culture
description: At the end of June, the United Nations will hold an unprecedented special session on how to combat AIDS, and a Muslim woman from conservative Saudi Arabia will be in the thick of the debate.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Offers Optimistic Outlook
description: In an effort to deflect from itself widespread concern over a capacity glut among operators of large fiber optic communication networks, Qwest Communications reaffirmed its sales estimates for 2001. Qwest, which is based in Denver, said yesterday that sales would rise this year by as much as 14 percent, to $21.7 billion. Qwest has been buffeted by bandwidth price declines through its acquisition of U S West Inc., which provides steady revenue from local telephone operations in 14 states in the western United States. The company's shares rose $1.45, or 4.8 percent, to $31.27. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Web-Based Appliance Control
description: I.B.M. and National Semiconductor said yesterday that they would team up to develop products providing Internet-based remote control of home appliances. The Shanghai General Electronics Group and C. P. Technology of Taiwan have already committed themselves to the home-networking platform to be developed by I.B.M. and National Semiconductor. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Business Travel; Despite the current slowdown, there is some optimism that corporate spending will pick up.
description: STOCK analysts, usually a pretty astute group but never a bunch you'd want to actually trust with the rent money, are in full lamentation mode these days about the hotel and airlines businesses.

title: The Expos' Horrid Eighth Hands the Mets Another Victory
description: The Mets have not willed themselves to victories this week as much as they have gladly accepted them. On Sunday night, the Yankees' depleted bullpen squandered a five-run lead against the Mets. On Monday, the Montreal Expos lost their best player in the first inning and the Mets squeaked out a victory.

title: Waiting for the Organizing Fairy To Wave Away the Office Clutter
description: BACK when I commuted to what my children called a ''real office,'' my workspace was relatively neat. Not compulsively so, mind you, but organized enough that I could find most things eventually. Home, on the other hand, was a challenge. I like to describe it as ''lived in.'' Translated that means ''the boys' snow boots still scatter the front hallway come July.''

title: Recipe: Seafood Salad
description: Time: 15 minutes 2 pounds cooked shrimp, lobster, crab, conch, mussels, clams, octopus and/or squid

title: Strong Feelings
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Twists of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Dressed for the Park, in Alligator Skin
description: It's probably just a baby, and the parks commissioner has assured visitors to Central Park that it is not a danger.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, RHODA
description: NEWMAN-Rhoda. We miss you and the new arrival will also. Robert, Bobby, Leni, Nancy, Scott, Jenny, Lauren, John, Alice, Ron, Sara, Lizzie, Meg, and Davi

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, ROBERT DOUGLAS
description: MILLER-Robert Douglas. June 21, 1970-June 21, 1996 Remembered with love today and every day. Mom, Dad and Rachel

title: Powell Going To Mideast As Cease-Fire Seems in Peril
description: The White House announced today that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell would travel to the Middle East next week to help shore up the teetering cease-fire and try to push the Israelis and Palestinians on a path toward political talks.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Adele Hofmann, 74, Pediatrician Who Shaped Adolescent Care
description: Adele Dellenbaugh Hofmann, a pediatrician who helped tailor medical science to the needs of teenagers, died on Friday at a hospital in Newport Beach, Calif. She was 74 and lived in nearby Laguna Beach.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Toshiba To Cut Production
description: The Japanese electronics giant Toshiba said it would trim semiconductor production at four plants in the next two months to reduce costs amid a decline in orders for chips used in mobile phones and personal computers. Toshiba will suspend production at a transistor plant in Hyogyo prefecture for 19 days beginning in late July, and will also shut a chip plant in Fukuoka prefecture for 13 days beginning on Aug. 3.

title: Evaluated on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Design Is Heading: The Signs Say Downtown
description: Downtown Los Angeles becomes more design-centric every day. The Southern California Institute of Architecture (known as SCI-Arc) recently moved from Marina del Rey to East Downtown. Nearby, a remodeled warehouse at 811 Traction Avenue has become home to Form Zero, a modish design and architecture book store, and to Gallery 1D, an exhibition space showing furniture by students at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena. The chair at right is by Jonatan Damian, a recent graduate. It is made of aluminum and Kevlar, and is called Elytra; $600 from Mr. Damian at (626) 403-3943. Behind the Elytra chair are other student pieces. The show continues through Saturday (5 to 8 p.m.). Information: Peter Di Sabatino at Art Center, (626) 396-2220.

title: Mortgage Applications Index Drops 7.8%
description: An index measuring applications for mortgages fell last week from the highest level in a month, reflecting declines in refinancing and purchases, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHMIDT, MIRKO BRACO
description: GOLDSCHMIDT - Mirko Braco. The Board of Trustees and all Members of the Association of Yugoslav Jews USA, mourn the passing of our Vice President, Treasurer, Board of Trustees, Mirko Goldschmidt. Who died June 20, 2001 in NYC. A man of great wit and humanity. We shall forever cherish his memory. Services Thurs. 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Emanuel Salom, Vice President Assoctn. of Yugoslav Jews in USA

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the investigation of the Queens fire in which three firefighters died on Sunday misstated the surname of an owner of the hardware store where it occurred. He is Randy Gordon, not Spencer.

title: Is There Life After AOL
description: AN overprotective parent. Comfortable old shoes or pajamas. A bad marriage. People who subscribe to America Online, America's largest Internet service provider, use a variety of metaphors to describe their feelings about it. Like McDonald's, the fast food purveyor that people love to hate, AOL has many ambivalent customers.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: EASTMAN KODAK DELAYS $650 MILLION DEBT SALE
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it was delaying a $650 million debt sale because of an anticipated bankruptcy-protection filing by a customer. Kodak, which did not identify the customer, said the filing would not hurt its earnings, but the delay would force it to take a second-quarter charge of $75 million. Kodak, based in Rochester, planned to sell $500 million in five-year notes and $150 million in 15-month notes, said Paul Allen, a Kodak spokesman.

title: NATO IS PLANNING MACEDONIA FORCE
description: NATO is planning to send a force of up to 3,000 troops to Macedonia to disarm ethnic Albanian rebels if a political settlement is reached to end the insurgency in the troubled republic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 11 about European perceptions of American leadership under President Bush misstated the political affiliation of Daniel Cohn-Bendit, leader of the 1968 student uprising in France and now a member of the European Parliament, who accused the United States of making unilateral decisions on behalf of the world. He is a member of the French Green Party, not the German one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNES, ERWIN S.
description: GAYNES-Erwin S. Of North White Plains, NY, on June 18. Beloved husband of Janet. Dear father of Judy Sabastian and the late Barry Gaynes. Grandfather of Michael Sullivan, Adam & Scott Sabastian. Great-grandfather of Michael. Associated with Hargro, Inc. for many years. Funeral service Thursday, 12 noon at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment, Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to Dr. Oster's Cancer Research Fund c/o Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, NY, NY 10032.

title: Shinjo on D.L.; Escobar Is Called Up
description: Alex Escobar has started six games for the Mets, and the team lost them all. Some five weeks later, the Mets are still below .500, but they are winning more and the expectations for Escobar's return, after Tsuyoshi Shinjo went on the disabled list yesterday, are not as great.

title: Article 2001062191236981930 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Some Conflicts Arise at Hearing On Ford Replacement-Tire Issue
description: A government agency briefed members of a House committee this afternoon on the safety of the tires that the Ford Motor Company is using to replace those made by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. after the committee chairman said the automaker might be using tires with even higher failure rates than the Firestones.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From restaurants in Miami to vineyards in Bordeaux, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: F.B.I. Analyst Is Charged With Theft Of Documents
description: Federal prosecutors have charged an F.B.I. security analyst and a former agent from the F.B.I.'s office in Las Vegas with stealing classified information and selling it to mob figures and lawyers in New York and elsewhere, according to court papers and lawyers involved in the case.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Tracking Stock
description: Tracking shares in the Sony Communication Network Corporation began trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange at a 10 percent discount to the price of 3,300 yen ($26.84) set before its first public offering. The stock, which is the first tracking stock to trade in Japan, closed at 2,950 yen. Sony Network provides access to the Internet in Japan. The Sony Corporation raised 10.1 billion yen ($82 million) from the sale of the tracking stock. Sony's chief financial officer, Teruhisa Tokunaka, said in a statement that it would take more time for the market to judge the value of the new security. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Technology Issues Rise; Market's Direction Seems Unclear
description: A late rally in technology issues led the stock market higher yesterday, a choppy session in which investors pondered conflicting signals about the prospects for corporate earnings.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the struggle over the Wagner Festival in Bayreuth, Germany, misstated the title of Eva Wagner-Pasquier, who has at least temporarily taken herself out of the running for the leadership. She is an artistic adviser at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France; the director there is Stphane Lissner.

title: 20-Year Sentence for New Yorker After 2nd Terrorism Trial in Peru
description: Lori Berenson, the 31-year-old New Yorker who has been held for more than five years in Peruvian prisons on terrorism charges, was convicted tonight by a civilian court of collaborating in a foiled terrorist plot to take the entire Peruvian Congress hostage. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, KITTY F. (NEE MACRAE)
description: CAMERON-Kitty F. (nee MacRae) age 97, June 16th, 2001 in Exeter, NH. Beloved wife of the late Duncan, a retired Captain of NYPD. Loving mother of Mary of Exeter, NH. Funeral Mass in NH, interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Article 2001062191252500041 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Game Boy, at 12, Gets Broad Shoulders
description: Nintendo has a knack for no-nonsense product names. In 1989, the company named its first portable game machine the Game Boy (instead of something more politically sensitive, like Game Youth or Game Teenager)  a bald- faced acknowledgment that most of its audience is male. In 1998, Nintendo followed up with the Game Boy Color, whose name, once again, told the whole story.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In School Rape
description: A former custodian at an intermediate school in Upper Manhattan was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape of a 14-year-old girl. The custodian, Angel Daza, 30, was also charged with endangering the welfare of a child. It was not immediately clear whether the girl was a student at Intermediate School 52, where Mr. Daza had worked. The police said Mr. Daza had several encounters with the girl away from school grounds from October 2000 through March 2001. Mr. Daza was dismissed on May 2 because of the investigation. Neither he nor his lawyer could be reached for comment. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Get Hold of Yourself, Lieutenant
description: ON a quiet street in a village in the Balkans, an accident suddenly puts an American peacekeeping force to the test. A Humvee has hit a car, and a child who has been injured in the collision lies unmoving on the ground. A medic leans over him. The child's mother cries out. A crowd of local residents gathers in the background. How they will react is anyone's guess.

title: AT&T Wireless Narrows Review
description: AT&T Wireless, which is to be spun off next month from the AT&T Corporation, has further narrowed a review for its account, with billings estimated at $400 million.

title: Pakistan's Military Ruler Declares Himself President
description: Twenty months after toppling Pakistan's civilian government and assuming unbridled power under the misleadingly modest title of chief executive, and less than a month before flying to India for a crucial summit meeting, Gen. Pervez Musharraf today followed the pattern of three of Pakistan's military rulers over the last 50 years and appointed himself president and formal head of state.

title: A Delicate Nuclear Balance
description: At his press conference in Moscow after he met with President Bush in Slovenia, President Vladimir Putin of Russia indicated his interest in a compromise on amending the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty to allow an American missile defense. But he also indicated, forcefully, that this must be a genuine compromise, taking Russian concerns into account, or Russia would retaliate with a major expansion of its nuclear arsenal. This tough stance was inevitable. From the Russian point of view, it is an effort at balance.

title: Radio Host Says His Criticism Led to Canceling of Program
description: Gerson Borrero, the editor in chief of El Diario La Prensa, said yesterday that his weekday radio program had been taken off the air because he had refused the requests of station managers to stop criticizing three regional members of Congress.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell after Japan posted its smallest trade surplus in eight years, indicating that Asia and the United States are buying fewer Japanese products. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.74 yen, up from 123.04.

title: Making the Leap From a Game To the Movies
description: TOMB RAIDER'' will go down in history as the first movie that was based on a video game but wasn't unwatchable garbage. The video game curse placed on films like ''Mortal Kombat'' and ''Double Dragon'' has been lifted, and the industry has now stretched its tentacles into yet another part of popular culture.

title: Essay; Scalia On Privacy
description: ''The question we confront today,'' wrote Justice Antonin Scalia in an opinion that places him up there with Louis (the right to be let alone) Brandeis, ''is what limits there are upon this power of technology to shrink the realm of guaranteed privacy.''

title: Segarra Is Re-elected President Of the City Board of Education
description: Ninfa Segarra was re-elected to a yearlong term as president of the New York City Board of Education yesterday, giving Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani continuing control of the board in his final months in office.

title: As Nets Plan, Marbury Feels Out of the Loop
description: Stephon Marbury, the Nets' All-Star point guard, has felt distanced from the team's draft and summer plans and is resigned to the possibility, albeit remote, that he will be traded.

title: Summer Barely Here, And Sales Beckon
description: SOME people go to the beach to relax with a good book. Others hit the summer sales, where especially good buys await this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Injured Man At Fire Scene
description: Firefighters responding to a report of a fire on the first floor of 1455 Atlantic Avenue in Crown Heights yesterday discovered that a man had been left there tied up, the police said. The man, 31, had a cut on his throat, a chest injury and second- and third-degree burns, the police said. He was in stable condition at New York Weill Cornell Center. The police did not release his name. Officials said the fire, which was not serious, was considered suspicious. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: House G.O.P. Drafts Bill Expanding Patients' Right to Sue
description: House Republican leaders, fearing defections on the issue of patients' rights, have drafted a bill that goes further than President Bush would like in allowing consumers to sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Game Boy, at 12, Gets Broad Shoulders
description: NINTENDO has a knack for no-nonsense product names. In 1989, the company named its first portable game machine the Game Boy (instead of something more politically sensitive, like Game Youth or Game Teenager) -- a bald-faced acknowledgment that most of its audience is male. In 1998, Nintendo followed up with the Game Boy Color, whose name, once again, told the whole story.

title: Addenda: Wieden Executive Leaving Agency
description: Matthew Seiler, managing director at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy , is leaving after only 13 months. A former top Wieden & Kennedy executive was named to replace him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ATLAS AIR EMPLOYEES AUTHORIZE STRIKE IF TALKS FAIL
description: Pilots and flight engineers at Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings voted yesterday to give their union authority to strike if negotiations with Atlas failed to produce a contract. More than 98 percent of the pilots who voted gave the Air Line Pilots Association approval to strike. Atlas and the union, which represents about 740 Atlas workers, began talks 13 months ago on what will be their first contract. The vote comes as the carrier, based in Purchase, N.Y., is cutting its work force, idling planes and hiring pilots in Britain for lower pay. Atlas said Tuesday that it would lay off 200 workers and earn less than analysts forecast in the second quarter and for 2001 because of declining demand. Atlas shares fell $2.31, to close at $14.46 yesterday.

title: Fire Officials May Hire Consultants on Fatal Blast
description: Faced with a complex investigation into an explosion that ripped through a Queens hardware store on Sunday, fire officials said yesterday that they might hire consultants to help review evidence from the blast, which killed three firefighters.

title: Sniffing Out Updates? One Bloodhound May Do
description: Q. Is there any way to tell if the programs on my computer are all the current versions?

title: Twists of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001062191925454891 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Entrepreneur to Begin Proxy Fight for Computer Associates
description: Sam Wyly, a billionaire Texan, plans to begin a proxy fight today to take control of Computer Associates, the struggling software company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Rural West Virginia Winning Over Health Care Workers
description: When the coal company doctors took down their shingles as the mining camps died off, the people of Appalachia settled in for long years of what they do well, stoic suffering amid the neighborliness of the hills as the level of health care spiraled further toward the bottom nationally.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: To Sea With Planks, Not Plastic
description: ON May 8, a 60-foot schooner named Rebecca was launched from Vineyard Haven Harbor, with a Champagne christening and an antique prop plane laying a celebratory circle of smoke in a perfect blue sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, IRVING
description: LEIBOWITZ-Irving. Loving best friend of Sylvia. Loving brother of Muriel and Harry Arkoff and beloved by Arlene, David, Jonathan and Peter Levine, and Wendy and Mike Nirenberg. Services are today at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY at 11:00AM.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Merger Has Grandfather Clause
description: Astoria Graphics, an 85-year-old graphic arts company based in Manhattan, is merging with Zale Koff Graphics, a company known for making posters and brochures for Democratic Party politicians. Zale Koff, started in 1972 by a grandson of the founder of Astoria Graphics, will become a division of the older company, which recently expanded its operations and moved to new TriBeCa offices. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: An Actress and the City (Beyond All That Sex)
description: IT is 7:45 p.m. on a steamy Friday in Manhattan, and the doors to the trailers that shelter the principal actresses of HBO's bed-hopping hit, ''Sex and the City,'' are snapping shut like mechanical jaws: time for the lunch break on the East 19th Street set. And quitting time for Cynthia Nixon, the veteran stage actress who plays Miranda Hobbes, the hardheaded, redheaded corporate lawyer lately dabbling in celibacy (daring behavior on this libido-baring show) after a slew of dud romances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, CHARLOTTE Z.
description: BERNSTEIN-Charlotte Z. Of Elmwood Park, N.J., died on June 20 at the age of 71 after a long illness. She was retired from Ramapo College of N.J. where she worked for many years as an administrator in the Human Resources division. She is survived by her loving husband, Jules, her daughters Ellen and Hildy, and her grandson, Noah. Services 11:30 AM Friday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4West), Fairlawn, N.J. Visitation 7-9PM today. She was loved by many.

title: Article 2001062193058169217 -- No Title
Home Seller Agrees to Make or Pay for Repairs
description: A Queens real estate company accused of defrauding as many as 2,500 first-time home buyers by selling them dilapidated houses will be required to fix the properties or reimburse customers for the expenses they incurred making repairs, the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, said yesterday.

title: The Hothead Hypnotized, And Other Tales of Romance
description: The New York City Ballet offered both explicit and implicit dramas in movement on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Limited Promise For Cancer Vaccine
description: The Corixa Corporation said new data gathered by following patients for a longer time show that its cancer vaccine does not provide a statistically significant improvement in disease-free survival of patients with melanoma, contradicting results announced last year. But it said that the drug, Melacine, does prolong survival in patients with particular immune-system genes. The company, based in Seattle, said it was talking with the Food and Drug Administration about whether the drug could be approved for use in the 60 to 70 percent of melanoma patients with those genes. If not, the company might drop the drug. If the F.D.A. agrees with Corixa, Melacine could become the first cancer vaccine to be approved in the United States. Such vaccines do not prevent cancer, but stimulate the immune system to fight the cancer once it has appeared. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Vinyl and Cork, Afoot and Fashionable
description: DESIGNERS and floor-covering manufacturers are finding new ways to use old reliables like vinyl, canvas and cork to add durability (and style). Washable floor materials with bold graphics, strong textures and bright colors hold up well in all seasons, especially summertime, when sandy feet and muddy paws abuse surfaces under foot.

title: Major Insurers May Pull Out Of New Jersey
description: Companies insuring almost a third of New Jersey's drivers are considering withdrawing from the state, escalating the battle over auto insurance, which continues to be one of the most charged issues in a state with the highest premiums in the country.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs Falls On Profit Warning
description: Shares in Tellabs, the largest maker of equipment used to manage telephone traffic, plummeted after the company announced that sales and earnings would fall far short of expectations. The company said late Tuesday that sales for the current quarter would be about $500 million, more than one-third below previous expectations. Tellabs shares fell $5.16, to $16.04, a 52-week low. The company, based in Lisle, Ill., is among telecommunications companies hit hard by declining orders. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Varadero Journal; Just Watch the Golfers Frolic in Proletarian Cuba
description: A brass plaque on Xanadu, once the Du Pont family's luxurious Cuban beachfront mansion, now reads ''Varadero Golf Club, 40th Anniversary Year of the Triumph of the Revolution, October 26, 1999.''

title: Leading Chinese Filmmaker Tries for a Great Leap to the West; Will a Zany Satire Be a Breakthrough for a Popular Director?
description: In an ancient temple of the Forbidden City, once the site of emperors' funerals, Feng Xiaogang delayed filming the other night as he shouted through his megaphone for still more giant billboards to be erected and still more balloons to be strewn about.

title: Jostling on the Highway; Internet Providers, Aspiring to Serve
description: Major Internet service providers and the packages and features they offer:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBESKIND, NACHMAN (NIEMELE)
description: LIBESKIND-Nachman (Niemele). Age 92; a self-taught artist who passionately embarked on an art career at age 72. Best friend and beloved husband of Dora Blaustein Libeskind who predeceased him in 1980 and inspired him to pursue art during her long illness. A survivor of the Holocaust and Russian labor camps who never lost hope in humanity. Ardent Yiddishist & graduate of the Vladimir Medem Shule in Lodz, Poland. Son of Ruchla Laja and Chaim Haskell Libeskind, brother of Jacob, Natan and Pessl Libeskind who perished in the Holocaust. Also brother of Rozia Libeskind Brojges, survivor of Auschwitz, who predeceased him. Devoted father (Tinek) of Annette Berkovits, Senior VP of the Wildlife Conservation Society in NY and Daniel Libeskind, world renowned architect of the Jewish Museum in Berlin. Loving fatherin-law and best buddy of David Berkovits & Nina Lewis Libeskind. Amazing role model and grandfather of Jessica Dawn Ursell, Captain USAF, Jeremy Haskell Berkovits, Lev Jacob Libeskind, Noam Isaac Libeskind and Rachel Dora Libeskind. Grandfather-inlaw of Major Steven Ursell, USAF. Great grandfather to-be of Michael J.M. Ursell. His teachings and love will remain in the hearts of his family and friends. His life was a lesson on how to live life to its fullest. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions in his name can be made to: Simon Wiesenthal Center, Tribute Department, 1399 South Roxbury Drive, Los Angeles, California 90035, 310553-9036, 800-900-9036 (toll-free from within the US), 310-553-4521 (fax), (Please be sure to mark on front of check ''memorial gift in honor of Nachman Libeskind''), information@wiesenthal.net. Services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, NY, NY. 212-769-4400, on Friday, June 22nd at 12:30 PM.

title: Retooling Products So All Can Use Them
description: TECHNOLOGY developers are being forced to rethink products from photocopiers to software to meet some new requirements from one of their biggest customers: the federal government.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Gains Driven by Consumer Products
description: The twice-annual ranking of the world's 500 fastest computers, being issued today, shows that the United States still has a significant lead in building powerful supercomputers.

title: Two Bebop Veterans, So Different, So Alike
description: The singer-songwriters Bob Dorough and Dave Frishberg, who performed together for the first major show of the JVC Jazz Festival at the Kaye Playhouse on Tuesday night, make a pretty classic pair of wet and dry personalities: Abbott and Costello, or maybe Penn and Teller.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Chairman of Disney's Studios Resigns to Return to Broadway
description: Peter Schneider, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, unexpectedly announced today that he would leave the company to set up a new Broadway production company.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: High-Profile Envoy For Unicef
description: Shawne Fielding, whose occasional flamboyance sometimes shocks the Swiss government, which her husband represents in Germany, has joined Unicef as a fund raiser, her management agency said. The former Miss Texas, 31, the wife of Thomas Borer, Switzerland's ambassador to Germany, caused an uproar last month when photos in a German magazine showed her in a tight miniskirt on the embassy roof. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Corning: Disputed School Plan Approved
description: Despite months of intense opposition, an ambitious plan to build a state-of-the-art high school and renovate two existing schools was approved Tuesday night. Opponents had said that Corning Inc. intimidated residents by suggesting that the company -- which is supplying $60 million of the plan's $76 million cost -- would reduce local spending if the plan was not approved. John W. Loose, the company's chief executive, said, ''Actions that were based on honorable intentions have been misunderstood.''

title: Plan to Study Atlantic Drilling Is Abandoned
description: Facing opposition from New Jersey lawmakers in both parties, the Bush administration abandoned a plan today to study the impact of oil and gas drilling off the coast of New Jersey and other Eastern Seaboard states.

title: Growing PC's Into Supercomputers, All in a Row
description: SAY you have a couple of Pentium computers in your house, linked by a fast Ethernet connection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, HOWARD
description: ROSEMAN-Howard, 74. On June 19th, 2001. Loved stage, movies and New York sports teams. Graduated NYU & Brooklyn Law. Former Law Clerk New York State Supreme Court. Survived by wife Jill, sister Barbara, daughters Sandi, Wendy and Ilene and stepchildren Alan, Howard & Amy & fifteen grandchildren. Services today 1:30 PM, Robert Schoem Funeral Home, Paramus, NJ.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Checking Checkup
description: A consumer watchdog group said yesterday that a survey of bank branches throughout New York State found that virtually all heeded or nearly heeded state guidelines as to the deposit, balance and other requirements of the low-cost checking accounts they offered. But the group, the New York Public Interest Research Group, contended that more than half of the 62 branches of 30 banks it surveyed did too little to promote such accounts, which a 1994 state law required banks to make available. Michael P. Smith, president of the New York Bankers Association, said he had not seen the survey, but added that ''our association supported the law in '94 and supports it today.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Guilty Plea By Gunman
description: Robert W. Pickett, the former Internal Revenue Service employee accused of firing a gun outside the White House on Feb. 7, pleaded guilty to one charge of carrying a pistol without a license. To a charge of assaulting a federal officer, Mr. Pickett entered a plea under the Alford doctrine -- not a full admission of guilt but a concession that enough evidence exists for a conviction. The deal calls for Mr. Pickett to serve three years in prison and three years' probation, and pay $200. Mr. Pickett, 48, of Evansville, Ind., is accused of firing two shots before pointing his handgun at Secret Service officers. A sentencing hearing is set for July 31.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Julia Child Leaving Cambridge
description: Cambridge is about to lose an institution almost as hallowed as Harvard University. Julia Child, whose historic house on Irving Street has often been the set for her television cooking shows, has decided to move to her native California. Mrs. Child, who is 88 and grew up in Pasadena, plans to live in a retirement village she has long visited in Montecito. She will leave her 19th-century house to Smith College in Northampton, Mass., her alma mater. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Tokyo Displays Mixed Feelings at Premiere of 'Pearl Harbor'
description: TOKYO, June 21  The first screening of the movie "Pearl Harbor" in Japan today didn't quite have the roar of the original event, but that was not for want of trying.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE PLUNGES. Gasoline fell after the American Petroleum Institute reported that supplies rose for the ninth straight week. In New York, gasoline for July delivery fell 6.34 cents, or 7.4 percent, to 79.03 cents a gallon.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Sentencing For Arson
description: A former volunteer firefighter in Springdale was sentenced Tuesday to three years in prison for setting a factory fire in December. Walter Dagostino, 27, pleaded guilty to one count of first-degree arson for starting a fire at the Yale and Towne building, where he was a security guard. No one was hurt. Michael Inzitari, 23, another fireman and Mr. Dagostino's alleged accomplice, has pleaded not guilty to arson charges and is awaiting trial, said the state's attorney, Gene Callahan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXSTEIN, BLANCHE B.
description: EXSTEIN-Blanche B. On June 19, 2001. Beloved wife of Louis. Loving mother of Michael and Lida, and Ted and Patti, adored grandmother of Jeremy, Adam, Isabel, Max and Benjamin. Dear sister of Richard Bloch. Services Thursday, June 21, 10:30 AM at Temple Emanu'El, 5th Avenue at 56th St. Donations to the R. Taub Cancer Research Fund, C/O Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Transcript of Kevin Zeese's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Wednesday, June 20, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Kevin Zeese, President, Common Sense For Drug Policy . This discussion was the second in a series organized by forum participants.

title: South Africa's Failure on AIDS
description: In the global fight to provide third-world AIDS sufferers with affordable medicine, many important battles have taken place in South Africa. Protests against high drug costs there helped to spark a revolution that dramatically brought down the price of drugs in poor nations and led pharmaceutical manufacturers to withdrew a lawsuit against South Africa's Medicines Act, widely hailed as a step toward getting drugs to poor AIDS sufferers.

title: A Vigorous Urban Tug of War For Ireland's National Theater
description: In the opening days of the 20th century, theater had the power to galvanize the Irish public, and nowhere more so than at the Abbey. As the national theater of Ireland, the Abbey still revels in its rabble-rousing history, and programs boast of how audiences rioted at the premiere of Synge's ''Playboy of the Western World'' in 1907, and again in 1926 at O'Casey's ''Plough and the Stars.''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: What's Oregano?

title: Predraft Trade by Nets Unlikely
description: Calling a predraft trade unlikely, Rod Thorn, the president of the Nets, is holding the No. 7 pick and waiting to see how the landscape changes before next Wednesday's N.B.A. draft.

title: 500 Riot in Belfast; 15 Officers Injured
description: Riots erupted today between Roman Catholic and Protestant groups in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Crowds that totaled more than 500 people hurled stones and gasoline bombs at each other and the police. At least 15 officers were reported injured.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rates
description: British interest rates are likely to remain steady or rise after the Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted 8-to-1 to keep the benchmark rate at 5.25 percent this month. After three rate cuts earlier in the year, largely in response to the economic downturn in the United States, minutes from the bank's monthly meetings on June 5 and 6 said that the United States slowdown had so far been less severe than expected and that a further cut in British rates would heighten inflationary pressures. Since the bank's deliberations, data have shown British wages, prices, home-buying and consumer demand are all rising.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rise and Fall of the Queen's English
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Holes and a Fabled Past
description: WHEN her husband, J. Seward Johnson, died in 1983, Barbara Piasecka Johnson was left with a 46,000-square-foot neo-Classical villa and only a few dogs to keep her company. Her 140-acre estate, made up of woodlands and gently rolling fields in far western Princeton, was lying mostly unused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, FRANK
description: RUSSO-Frank. On June 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Antoinette. Loving father of Linda. Dear brother of Roslyn Vaccaro, Alfred and Ronald. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Inc, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockvile Centre, NY, today 2-4, 7-9 pm. Religious service 11 am Friday at Macken's. Interment VA National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 W.168th St., NYC 10032 in his name would be appreciated.

title: Stage-Struck or Not, This Furniture Is Going Back to the Shop
description: A daughter feels a murderous rage toward her mother. What better place for such a Spelling-esque plot than a Modern house in California? That was Marsha Ginsberg's setting for an updated version of Richard Strauss's ''Elektra'' at the Long Beach Opera. ''I liked the idea of putting a dysfunctional family in a new vision of how families should live,'' Ms. Ginsberg said. Her stage set, above, was inspired by the works of Edward Killingsworth, the architect, who happens to live in Long Beach. Much of the furniture was rented from Xcape, a shop specializing in midcentury furniture. Since the opera ended its run on Saturday, the pieces are back on sale at Xcape. The seafoam sofa is $1,500, the Danish dining table is $600 and the dining chairs with original rush seats are $250 each. Xcape is at 3324 East Broadway, Long Beach; (562) 433-9911.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the slowdown in the economy reaching New York City's job market misstated the occupation of Paul A. Bernard, who suggested that things would only get worse. Mr. Bernard, who advises companies on executive development and layoffs, is a consultant, not an economist.

title: An Accord Finds a Fit in a Special Case
description: New York's most prestigious team competition, the Reisinger Knockout, is normally completed shortly after Memorial Day. This year the final was postponed because some players were committed to the United States Bridge Championships, formerly the International Team Trials.

title: Merger-Busting in Europe
description: Jeffrey Immelt, president and chairman-elect of General Electric, says his company's chances of merging with Honeywell, another electronics and aircraft technology giant, have virtually evaporated. Though the interested parties are two American companies, and American regulators have approved the deal, the European Commission is blocking the union because of its perceived potential for dampening competition in global markets. If G.E. and Honeywell were to go ahead without the commission's approval, fines or bars to selling could result.

title: 2 Judges Do Battle in an Immigration Case
description: Nearly one million Americans have typically been waiting six months or more for immigration authorities to process a marriage visa that leads to permanent residency for their noncitizen spouses.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Hopes Grow in Brooklyn and Staten Island
description: The Staten Island Yankees and the Brooklyn Cyclones are in the big city but still a long, difficult journey from the big leagues.

title: Black Writers Get New Help
description: Until recently the vigor to publish writing by black authors has come mostly from the top, from traditional book publishers. This has been a fascinating and somewhat surprising development, driven by starvation in the industry for new sources of book consumers and the sudden realization that black people are hungry for reading relevant to them. But equally intriguing are the growing number of elaborate workshop programs to encourage blacks to write professionally. Which could be described as action from the bottom.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Queen's English
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There Life After AOL?
description: An overprotective parent. Comfortable old shoes or pajamas. A bad marriage. People who subscribe to America Online, America's largest Internet service provider, use a variety of metaphors to describe their feelings about it. Like McDonald's, the fast food purveyor that people love to hate, AOL has many ambivalent customers.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Tax Rebates Seen For Lawn Mowers
description: People who cut their lawns may be about to cut their taxes, too -- though not by much. Lawmakers are completing a bill to give Oregonians who use ''power lawn mowers, leaf blowers, chain saws and similar implements'' a refund of the state gasoline tax, which is 24 cents a gallon. Proponents say the Oregon Constitution requires that gasoline taxes from road users must be spent on roads, and that other users are eligible for rebates. An average homeowner would be eligible for about 48 cents a month in rebates. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: News in a Huge Grinder of Translation
description: THERE is a fine line between news and entertainment on a new Web site that translates hundreds of the world's newspapers into English. Consider this headline translated from The Beijing Daily: ''Sells which roast the dried bean curd girl.'' From The Okinawa Times comes this gripping lead: ''The light where the body of the strong so stainless steel material is sluggish is shot.''

title: Before and After the Sprawl
description: The choice between old-fashioned city streets, where homes, businesses, parks and schools intertwine, and

title: Third Official Pleads Guilty In Bridgeport Bribery Scheme
description: For the third time in the past eight days, a close associate of Bridgeport's mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, has pleaded guilty to federal bribery charges linking an unnamed ''elected official'' to a scheme to extort hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash, merchandise and meals from companies seeking lucrative municipal contracts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Dr. Donald J. Cram, who shared the 1987 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, misstated the given name of a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who described Dr. Cram's manipulation of molecules. He is Dr. M. Frederick Hawthorne, not Patrick.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Charges In School Incidents
description: A 13-year-old student at Public School 214 in West Farms was charged with trying to sodomize a fellow student, an 11-year-old girl, in the hallway of their school yesterday, the police said. In another incident yesterday, a teacher at Public School 200 in Harlem, Anthony Manly, 50, was charged with assault after arguing with a 12-year-old student, the police reported. The argument escalated into a fight, the police said, and the boy suffered a bruise to his head. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: More Cold Water on Japanese Hopes
description: Hopes that economic growth will soon revive in Japan are receding, with new statistics showing the nation's trade surplus contracting sharply and the government poised to conclude that the country will fall far short of its previous 1.7 percent growth forecast for the year.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about new music styles misstated the number of Glenn Branca's symphony for 100 electric guitars, ''Hallucination City.'' It is Symphony No. 13, not No. 3.

title: Growing PC's Into Supercomputers, All in a Row
description: Say you have a couple of Pentium computers in your house, linked by a fast Ethernet connection.

title: Presentation Hardware Has Split Personality
description: Golf fans who want to watch the Monday playoff round instead of finishing the quarterly report might consider a new liquid crystal display monitor from Samsung. The Samsung Sync Master 210T accepts both traditional analog television signals and digital feeds from computers or D.V.D.'s. A remote control provided with the display would allow users to, say, superimpose a live TV feed of Tiger Woods's bunker shot in one corner of their work screens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNORR, MARCIA E.
description: KNORR-Marcia E. Of Freeport on June 19, 2001. Saved by Grace in God's loving arms now. Until we meet again. Retired teacher of 35 years from Rockville Centre school system. Beloved wife of the late Albert, loving mother of Jay and Sue. Proud grandmother of Jonathan, Cristina, Alex, Nickie and Jessica. Family will receive friends at Hungerford & Clark Inc Funeral Home, 110 Pine St, Freeport . Religious service Thursday 8PM. Funeral Friday 10AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9

title: I.R.S. Guide Focuses on Consultants
description: The Internal Revenue Service is teaching its auditors how to uncover tax cheating by self-styled business consultants and by corporations that use former employees as consultants to avoid withholding income, Social Security and Medicare taxes.

title: A Mean Streak Zings The Clueless and Hapless
description: Mamas, don't let your babies grow up to be W.W.F. stars. Of course, you may not be able to stop them from trying, and making fools of themselves on ''Tough Enough,'' a new MTV series that will take 13 men and women, send them to a World Wrestling Federation training camp and reward two with W.W.F. contracts.

title: Less Baseball Is More
description: Why is the concept of cutting a few teams from Major League Baseball viewed as threatening and radical? That was the big question hanging over last week's owners' meeting. While he made no firm statement on the subject, Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, reiterated that contraction of baseball is a viable option.

title: Accounts
description: * Dial Corp., Scottsdale, Ariz., to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its personal cleansing account, for the Dial, Tone and Coast soap brands, which had been handled for 21 years by offices of another Omnicom agency, DDB Worldwide. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 11 about the high-tech United States Army base on the Marshall Islands in the Pacific Ocean misstated the location of Bikini Atoll. It lies about 200 miles northwest of the Kwajalein Atoll, not east. The article also misstated the size of the island of Ebeye. It is slightly more than one-tenth of a square mile, not three square miles.

title: Franks Attacks After Results Of New Poll
description: Conceding that he faced an uphill battle in the Republican contest for governor of New Jersey, Bob Franks today called Bret D. Schundler an ''extremist'' whose ''radical'' stands against abortion rights and gun control would make him unelectable in November against the Democrat, James E. McGreevey.

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline and a front-page article on Saturday about President Bush's appeal for the expansion of NATO to Russia's borders misstated the alliance's current reach. Two of the existing 19 members  Norway and Poland  border Russian territory, so an expansion would not be the first move to carry the alliance there.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Baker Surges
description: Shares of Grupo Bimbo, the world's third-largest maker of bakery products, rose 15 percent after it offered to buy back up to $570 million worth of its shares. Bimbo's shares closed at 16.14 pesos, a 10-month high and up from 14 pesos Tuesday. It was the biggest one-day gain since the company first sold shares in Mexico in 1994. The company, based in Mexico City, said on Tuesday that it planned to buy back as many as 300 million shares at 17.25 pesos ($1.90) each to take advantage of low share prices. The company, which has operations in 16 countries, expects to complete the repurchase by mid-August.

title: For Mets, 4 in a Row And a Burst Of Optimism
description: When the scoreboard is all that can offer hope, it is never too early to start watching it. So, the Mets have noticed what is happening in the National League East. They do not see any team running away. They see a shaky leader and an uncertain perennial champion. They see opportunity in spite of themselves.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: A Challenger For Baucus
description: Buoyed by his party's success last year when Republicans won elections for Montana governor, the Senate and the state's only House seat, Mike Taylor, a state lawmaker since 1996, said he would oppose Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat who will be seeking a fifth term next year. Mr. Taylor, 60, a businessman from Lewistown, became a leading proponent of tax cuts, sponsoring legislation that cut business property taxes to 3 percent from 6 percent. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Moratorium On Plant Construction
description: Gov. Paul E. Patton has declared a six-month moratorium on applications for power plant construction, saying he needs time to study whether the state already has more new plants under way than the environment and power grid can safely handle.
