Governor Patton noted that applications for 24 plants were pending in the state. Environmental groups said those plants should be included in the moratorium, but Mr. Patton said that he was not sure if the state had the authority to stop power plants under construction. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: States Expecting to Lose Billions From Repeal of U.S. Estate Tax
description: Even as they deal with declining revenue growth from a softening economy, states are scrambling to plan for the potential loss of $50 billion to $100 billion over 10 years from the repeal of the federal estate tax enacted last month.

title: Do Not Compare Settlers and Bombers
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugee Chief Is Criticizing Western Europe
description: On the first World Refugee Day, the chief of the United Nations agency charged with caring for the world's 21 million refugees criticized wealthy West European countries and Australia today for increasingly closing their borders to those fleeing war and persecution.

title: L.A. Gets Winning Walk in the 9th
description: LOS ANGELES -- Arizona rookie reliever Erik Sabel hit Eric Karros with a pitch with the bases loaded in the ninth to force home the deciding run as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Diamondbacks 4-3 Wednesday night.

title: A Ship Full of Pop References, From Viagra to Disney's 'Aida'
description: If any Gilbert and Sullivan operetta bears the stamp of New York, it is surely ''Pirates of Penzance,'' which, for all show business purposes, had its world premiere engagement at the Fifth Avenue Theater, where it opened on Dec. 31, 1879.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Promoting Tourism In North
description: Eager to guarantee tours to North Korea, the South's National Tourism Organization and the Hyundai Asan Corporation reached an accord that calls for the government to provide $70 million a year to subsidize tours to Mount Kumkang, on the eastern end of the demilitarized zone that has divided the peninsula since the Korean war. Cho Hong Kyu, president of the tourism organization, said the investment of public funds would ''contribute to improving inter-Korean relations both in economic and political terms.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Deal For Asset Manager
description: UBS Asset Management said that it had agreed to acquire RT Capital Management Inc., the institutional asset management business of the Royal Bank of Canada, for no more than $230 million. The deal, which is expected to be completed by Sept. 30, is subject to conditions that were not disclosed. RT Capital will then be renamed Brinson Canada, in line with the other UBS Canadian units of Brinson Partners and Brinson Advisors. When the deal is completed, UBS will add RT Capital's $20 billion in managed assets to the $2 billion it now manages for 21 clients in Canada. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: What's Next: Growing PC's Into Supercomputers, All in a Row
description: Say you have a couple of Pentium computers in your house, linked by a fast Ethernet connection.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: One Dead In Fire
description: A blind man was killed and his mother critically injured when a fire spread through their Williamsbridge apartment early yesterday, the authorities said. The man, Patrick O'Loughlin, 43, died of smoke inhalation. His mother, Thelma O'Loughlin, 75, was in critical condition at Jacobi Hospital last night. Her daughter, Peggy Novellino, 44, jumped from a first-story window and was treated for minor injuries. The fire is under investigation, but a frayed or overloaded extension cord is thought to be responsible. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Talks on Macedonia Conflict at an Impasse
description: Talks aimed at ending the conflict here between the government and ethnic Albanian rebels deadlocked today, with each side blaming the other, and President Boris Trajkovski turned to NATO and Western diplomats for help in breaking the impasse.

title: As 2 Die, Israel Suspends Military Moves
description: Israel's diplomatic and security cabinet authorized plans for military operations against the Palestinian Authority today, but officials said the plans would be held in abeyance to allow the week-old American cease-fire plan more time to work.

title: New Jersey Transit Train Derails; 27 People Aboard Are Slighty Hurt
description: A four-car commuter train with about 400 passengers derailed here this afternoon, leaving 27 people with minor injuries, New Jersey Transit reported.

title: Bishops and 16 Senators Differ on Poultry Pay
description: In an unusual clash, 16 United States senators are at loggerheads with 18 bishops from various denominations because of a Labor Department enforcement action that could cost the poultry industry nearly $350 million in back wages.

title: Never Got to Cut the Cake but Always a Bride
description: ''Miss Havisham's Fire,'' the opera Dominick Argento drew from the most unfulfilled of Dickens's ''Great Expectations,'' has been cold a long time. More than 20 years have passed since its unfortunate New York City Opera premiere. But now a vivid production by Opera Theater of St. Louis and a magnificent central performance have rewarded this composer for his patience and rewarded the stage director James Robinson for his faith in the piece and his persistence in perusading Mr. Argento to reconsider the score and tighten its seams. ''Miss Havisham's Fire'' rekindled is the hit of Opera Theater's 26th season.

title: Business Leaders Visit Bush at White House
description: As the White House defended several recent private meetings with corporate executives who have important issues before the government, scores of other executives from the Business Roundtable came to see President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and other top officials today.

title: Judge Rejects Plan by Belgian Software Maker
description: A commercial court in Ieper, Belgium, rejected a reorganization plan by Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products today, saying that it was too vague and that it favored some creditors over others.

title: 'Rebirthing' Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, EMEK
description: PERRY-Emek. Born 1932. Original voice of Kol Israel. Writer, producer, and director. Survived by his daughter Ruti Perry and grandchildren, Leor and Yael Friedman.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Limits On South Korean Fishing
description: Japan will ban South Korean boats from the Kurils area. The islands are claimed by Japan but controlled by Russia. They ''are within the exclusive economic zone and under Japan's sovereignty,'' said Tokuyuki Sudo, of the Fisheries Ministry. The Kurils, to the north, were seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. The dispute has prevented Tokyo and Moscow from signing a peace treaty ending the war. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Infineon Warns of a $500 Million Loss
description: Adding to the mounting evidence that the electronics industry is in a broad slump, Infineon Technologies A.G. of Germany warned yesterday that it would lose more than $500 million in the current quarter, and that its revenue from computer chip manufacturing had fallen more than 30 percent.

title: Oil Pipeline to Turkey Backed by Chief of BP
description: Sir John Browne, the chief executive of the BP Group, said today that the Baku-Ceyhan oil pipeline from Azerbaijan to a port on Turkey's southeastern Mediterranean coast would be built and operating by the end of 2004, the strongest public backing the project has yet received.

title: Is There Life After AOL?
description: An overprotective parent. Comfortable old shoes or pajamas. A bad marriage. People who subscribe to America Online, America's largest Internet service provider, use a variety of metaphors to describe their feelings about it. Like McDonald's, the fast food purveyor that people love to hate, AOL has many ambivalent customers.

title: Disturbing Numbers for Mr. Bush
description: During last year's presidential campaign, George W. Bush made much of his willingness to listen to the American people. But the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows a White House increasingly and alarmingly out of touch with what Americans are thinking. One result is a downturn in Mr. Bush's overall approval ratings at precisely the moment that they might be expected to rise. There is also disenchantment with Mr. Bush on specific policy matters, particularly involving economic fairness and the environment.

title: Start Building, And Sometimes It's Hard to Stop
description: Moshe Safdie didn't rest long after the completion of the first buildings of the Skirball Cultural Center in 1996. The Skirball, a Jewish institution on the West Side of Los Angeles, grew so quickly that new buildings were needed, and Mr. Safdie, a Boston-based Israeli architect, was asked to design them, too.

title: U.S. Makes Quick Work of Trinidad and Tobago
description: It took the United States 74 seconds to impose its will against Trinidad and Tobago in a World Cup qualifying game tonight. Jeff Agoos, the anchor of the defense, lofted a long pass from midfield to Ante Razov running into open space soon after the opening kickoff and Razov left-footed a shot for a goal that led the United States to a 2-0 victory at Foxboro Stadium before a crowd of 32,211.

title: Bloomberg Leans Toward Extending Leases on Airports
description: Michael R. Bloomberg separated himself yesterday from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's ongoing war with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, saying at a breakfast and later on a golf course that the conflict was bad for business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS, New York, has reduced its stake in Flag Telecom Holdings, Hamilton, Bermuda. Verizon sold 15 million shares to Tyco International.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Metro Business Briefing | Telephone Access Fees Attacked
description: State consumer advocates in New Jersey and New York urged on Monday that their states' telephone regulators cut the fees that Verizon Communications charges other companies needing access to its lines to provide competing local phone service. In New Jersey, Blossom A. Peretz, the ratepayer advocate, called on the Board of Public Utilities to reduce Verizon's charges for such access to less than $10 per line a month, from the $16.21 the board set in 1997. That fee was voided last year by a federal judge saying that they have been set in an arbitrary and capricious manner. Bruce Cohen, general counsel for Verizon New Jersey, said yesterday that Ms. Peretz was asking his company to ''subsidize our competitors'' by providing them access ''at a rate below our cost.'' In New York, the attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, urged the Public Service Commission to adopt access-fee cuts recommended by an administrative law judge. Cliff Lee, a Verizon New York spokesman, said his company would respond in a brief that it would submit to the commission. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Coping With Homework and a Bear Market
description: Stock Club met every Thursday afternoon at 2:45 in Room 144 of John P. Stevens High School. It generally wrapped up after an hour so students without cars could catch the 4 p.m. school bus home.

title: An Outdoor Collection For Those Who Collect Outdoors
description: Even in a moderate climate like the one here, summer is the time to spruce up outdoor spaces. The coffee table below (useful for serving casual buffets or for displaying plants) is part of the first collection of outdoor furniture by Judy Kameon, a landscape designer, and Erik Otsea, a photographer. The Plain Air line of powder-coated aluminum furniture also includes a padded bench and a side table with a choice of glass tile tops. The coffee table (48 inches long, 18 inches wide and 15 inches high) is $600 to $700 depending on the choice of tiles, which come in white, aqua, green, light cobalt and orange. The pieces are on sale at Outside, 442 North La Brea Avenue, (323) 934-1254 or through www.plainair.com.

title: Economic Scene; Despite real concerns, gauging work hours is not a problem in measuring productivity growth.
description: HAVE you ever noticed that George Jetson has a much easier life than Fred Flintstone? To economists, the reason is obvious: thousands of years of productivity growth. Because productivity growth melts away problems of inflation, budget deficits, unemployment and stagnant income, there is great interest in knowing whether the upturn reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics since the mid-1990's will persist. Thus the 1.2 percent decline in productivity last quarter, if it is more than a cyclical blip, is worrisome.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Stagecoach
description: Britain's largest bus and rail operator, Stagecoach Holdings, reported a loss for the year that included a write-down of its business in the United States. Stagecoach, which owns South West Trains and 49 percent of Virgin Rail in Britain, said it lost 316.5 million ($443 million) before taxes, in contrast to a pretax profit of 182.3 million last year. The loss includes a 376 million write-down of good will, the difference between the purchase price and the fair value of a company's assets, related to its 1999 purchase of Coach USA. Shares rose 11 percent in part because the company said the worst of its problems in the United States were behind and because it raised its annual dividend by 4 percent, to 3.8 pence.

title: Text: Bush's Statement on the Indictments
description: Following is a statement by President Bush in Birmingham, Ala., released by the White House Press Office:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, E. BRAINARD
description: GRAVES-E. Brainard, 96, died peacefully June 18, 2001. Late residence, Providence, RI and Little Compton, RI. Predeceased by his wife Frances Peckham Smith. Graduate of Phillips Andover Academy 1923; Yale University Class of 1927. Service to be held Saturday, June 23 at 10:30 AM, Swan Point Chapel, Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the Phillips Academy, 180 Main Street, Andover, MA 01810, C/O Trustees of Phillips Academy.

title: Coca-Cola Joins AIDS Fight in Africa
description: Coca-Cola, Africa's biggest employer, if affiliates are counted, says it will use its resources to combat AIDS on the continent.

title: MUSIC COMPANIES SEEK LIQUIDATION OF NATIONAL RECORD
description: National Record Mart, a music retailer, said yesterday that it had been forced into bankruptcy court by suppliers, including the music units of Vivendi Universal and the Sony Corporation, to which it owes $18.7 million. National Record, based in Carnegie, Pa., said five music distributors asked the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania in Pittsburgh to liquidate the company to pay for compact discs, tapes and albums supplied by the music units of Vivendi, Sony, Bertelsmann EMI Group and AOL Time Warner. National Record said the filing came during a restructuring of the 131-store chain, which operates under the names National Record Mart, NRM Music, Waves Music, Music Oasis, Vibes Music and Music X. The company has 20 days to respond.

title: Article 2001062190188542203 -- No Title
description: Ibelieve this is an unjust decision. I am innocent.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Reports On Cellular Growth
description: A study by the Federal Communications Commission showed that 3 percent of mobile phone users had only wireless links last year, and more callers are choosing to buy mobile phones instead of installing conventional copper wires in their homes. In a report to Congress, the F.C.C. said 12 percent of callers signed up for wireless service rather than installing a second or third conventional line. Mobile phone subscribers increased 27 percent last year, to 109.5 million. The average price of a United States call fell to 21 cents a minute from 28 cents in 1999, and the average number of minutes used in a month rose to 255 from 185. The average local wireless bill increased to $45.27 from $41.24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUTHNER, PATRICIA
description: LEUTHNER-Patricia. On June 19, 2001 of New Hyde Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Patricia Munhall, Donna Forte, William and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Thomas, Brian, Kara, Dennis and Craig. Great grandmother of Gabriella and Nicole. Funeral mass Thursday 9:05 AM at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church, New Hyde Park, NY. For information, please call R. Stutzmann & Son, Inc. Funeral Home. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Self-Checkout at Kmart
description: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that the Kmart Corporation would install NCR's self-checkout systems at 1,300 stores by year-end to let shoppers scan, bag and pay for goods without assistance.

title: Governor Faults U.S. on Energy Refunds
description: In heated testimony before a Senate panel, Gov. Gray Davis of California accused federal regulators today of allowing power companies to ''bilk our state'' of billions of dollars.

title: Metro Business Briefing | On The Waterfront, A Boom
description: Despite a sluggish national and international economy, cargo volumes in the Port of New York and New Jersey increased by more than 13 percent in the first quarter of this year, the Port Authority announced yesterday. According to United States Census Bureau data, total cargo imports and exports rose to 4,866,000 metric tons this year from 4,288,000 metric tons during the same period last year. The total value of the cargo was estimated at $22 billion. Neil D. Levin, the Port Authority's executive director, said that increased trade with Asia helped the port flourish during the economic slowdown.

title: Article 2001062192693956439 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Willie Turnesa, Last Brother In Golfing Family, Dies at 87
description: Willie Turnesa, the youngest of the famous golfing Turnesa brothers and the last surviving brother, died Saturday at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 87.

title: A Round to Savor for Giuliani and His Son
description: Tiger Woods may never enter politics, but he left a good first impression on New York City's mayor.

title: McEnroe Still Backs Sampras
description: John McEnroe said yesterday that the seven-time champion Pete Sampras is still the man to beat at Wimbledon, which starts next week.

title: Broad Review of F.B.I. Is Set As Senate Begins Hearings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today held the first in a series of hearings into managerial and investigative lapses at the F.B.I., as Attorney General John Ashcroft announced a wide-ranging review of the troubled law enforcement agency.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Air Strike
description: Pilots at two of the three major Japanese airlines staged a strike, forcing the cancellation of some flights. A walkout at Japan Air System in which the flight crew union demanded a higher summer bonus grounded 172 flights. The company said that flight services would resume today. Workers also struck Japan Airlines, but the company said its flight schedule was unaffected since management pilots covered for the missing crew members. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Document: The Study of Oprah
description: This past semester, the history department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign offered a new undergraduate course: "Oprah Winfrey, the Tycoon," developed and taught by Prof. Juliet E.K. Walker. According to Walker's description, the purpose of the interdisciplinary course was "to critically examine and analyze Winfrey's activities in the building of her entertainment empire within the context of the impact of a multiplicity of societal, cultural and economic factors in the post-modern information age propelled by a new technology in the New Economy of Global Capitalism." Fourteen students completed the class. Herewith, a sampling of their term papers, the first forays into the nascent field of Oprah Studies.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Rozie Hendricks, Galesburg Ill., Feb. 10, 2001

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, RABBI BERNARD
description: MANDELBAUM-Rabbi Bernard. Adoring and deeply loved husband of Marcelle (Rettner) and the late Judith (Werber), z'l; beloved brother of Ethel Salwen, the late Abraham, z'l, the late Dorothy Septimus, z'l; loving and cherished father of Joel and Kayla, Dasi and Paul Schlup, David, Debra, Lyman, Naomi and Neal Rosenblum; Devoted and beloved stepfather of Roberta and Joseph Nachmias, Ron and Karen Rettner, Raphael Rettner; joyous grandfather (''Sabi''), step-grandfather, and greatgrandfather. For funeral and shiva information, please call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,(212) 769-4400 Contributions may be made to Amit Women or to Edah.

title: New Little GlowGuard Makes Game Boy Glimmer
description: Spoiled by expensive hand-held computers, some reviewers are complaining that the lack of a backlighted screen on Nintendo's new Game Boy Advance makes playing games less fun than, say, entering data into a Pocket PC version of an Excel spreadsheet.

title: Quite New but Already a Part Of the Old Neighborhood
description: When Richard Aldriedge designed a 900- square-foot guesthouse for John Stein in Venice, Calif., he opted for a scheme that embodied the playful character of the beachside neighborhood. ''My intention was to make a building that could fit nicely into Venice, that was also a little bit fanciful,'' Mr. Aldriedge said. To this end, Mr. Aldriedge, who is based in Santa Monica, mixed a contemporary, abstract aesthetic with the scale and craftsmanship of older buildings in the neighborhood. Built at a cost of $100,000, the guesthouse is linked by a bridge (above) to the client's main residence. Downstairs is a garage; upstairs, a study and sleeping alcove.

title: In America; The Confession
description: Earl Washington Jr. was both brain-damaged and mentally retarded. He grew up in a hard-drinking, violent family in rural Virginia in the 1960's and 70's. He performed dismally in school and dropped out when he was 15. On a good day, his I.Q. could be measured in the high 60's. On at least one occasion, his score was 57. Reciting the alphabet was too tough for him.

title: Who'll Win Her Little Heart? Duck Puppets or Barbie?
description: A THEORY OF RELATIVITY

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Historian To Drop Class
description: Joseph J. Ellis, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, will stop teaching a class on Vietnam and American culture at Mount Holyoke College because he lied about his war record. The history professor apologized for telling his students and others that he had served in the Vietnam War. The Boston Globe reported on Monday that Mr. Ellis had spent his three years in the military teaching history at West Point. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: City Must Pay AIDS Patients For Nights Without Shelter
description: In her second rebuke to the Giuliani administration for its treatment of homeless people with H.I.V. or AIDS, a state judge has found the city in contempt of a court order guaranteeing them immediate housing, and has ordered payment to 17 sick people for nights spent without shelter.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Browser Expands Beyond English
description: In an effort to expand the language capabilities of the Internet's address system, Microsoft and VeriSign said users of Microsoft's Internet Explorer Web browser could now reach Internet addresses by typing Chinese- or Japanese-language characters. Using technology from RealNames, version 5.0 or later of Microsoft's Web browser will automatically render the characters as addresses recognizable by the domain name system, without requiring the use of special software. As the company responsible for the databases containing the .com, .net and .org addresses, VeriSign is also managing the testing phase for what are known as internationalized domain names, or Internet addresses that contain foreign-language characters. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Man Wrongly Jailed Is Arrested in Rape
description: A Brooklyn man who was wrongly jailed for 11 years and then freed was arrested yesterday in the rape and robbery of a woman in her Prospect Heights home last month.

title: The Plant Men of Alcatraz
description: PLANTS, like buildings, hold memories. They are flourishing beneath the cellblock here on Alcatraz, this famously foreboding rock, as they have since military days, when this island -- buffeted by winds and currents -- was a fortress defending San Francisco Bay. The sweet scent of honeysuckle mingles with the salty air. The old warden's house, now a ruin overtaken by a fugitive garden, looks like an Aubusson carpet of roses and nasturtiums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, ROBERT J.
description: QUINN-Robert J., 79 of Larchmont, NY died June 20, suddenly after knee surgery. Retired from CBS News in 1986 after a long career as a TV News Director, he was the original director for ''Face the Nation'', which began in 1954 with late Sen. Joseph McCarthy as its first guest. In 1962 as Operations Director for ABC News, he gathered together a roster of correspondents, artists and technicians to rival the already established CBS & NBC News divisions. In 1964 he returned to CBS News to direct the network's ''CBS Morning News'' for 14 years, covering all political conventions, elections and many primaries during his tenure. He produced remote broadcasts from Key West, FL during the Cuban Missile Crisis. He covered the famous shoe -banging episode of Nicita Krushev at the UN. He also covered the first space shots from Cape Canaveral in the early 60's, and the famous pictures of JFK viewing the Mercury Space Capsule. He was considered one of the first ''seat-of-the-pants'' directors. His career began at WTOP, Wash. DC in 1951 when it was owned by the Washington Post. In 1953 he married Nancy Jones who survives him along with daughters Brigid and Erin and sons Sean and Christopher and a grandson. Since retirement he engaged in passionate hobbies as an amateur artist, a world wide traveler & museum enthusiast, an amateur figure skater and the publisher of ''Figure Skating Pins'', a unique pictorial guide of international figure skating competitions. Visiting will be Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY. Mass Saturday 10 AM at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLI, MARY NEE O'DONNELL
description: NOLI-Mary nee O'Donnell. Of Sayville, on June 19, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Robert V., cherished mother of Suzanne, Robert (Denise), Carol (Ralph) DellaRatta, and Mary (James) Maloney, loving grandmother of Christine, Caroline, Nicholas, Kelly, Christopher, Kieran and Erin, dear sister of John (Barbara) O'Donnell. Visitation at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington Station, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass on Friday at St. Patrick's RC Church, Huntington. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Joseph's College, Brooklyn Campus, Brooklyn, New York 11205.

title: State of the Art: Game Boy, at 12, Gets Broad Shoulders
description: Nintendo has a knack for no-nonsense product names. In 1989, the company named its first portable game machine the Game Boy (instead of something more politically sensitive, like Game Youth or Game Teenager)  a bald- faced acknowledgment that most of its audience is male. In 1998, Nintendo followed up with the Game Boy Color, whose name, once again, told the whole story.

title: Do Not Compare Settlers and Bombers
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. In Remote Management Venture
description: I.B.M. said it had struck an alliance with NetSolve, a remote network and security management provider, to offer a range of network services to its customers. The deal, to be announced today, is part of I.B.M.'s strategy to persuade customers to purchase information technology like software and data storage as utility-like services over the Internet. The companies say such transactions will help customers increase the reliability of computer systems, reduce overall network costs and simplify the adoption of new technologies. As part of the alliance, I.B.M. and NetSolve will provide remote management services for the Memphis school district's computer network, which includes 180 school and administrative sites and more than 2,000 devices.

title: Ethanol Plan Fails to Reduce Use of Gasoline
description: A report prepared for Congress by the Bush administration recommends continuing federal incentives for ethanol-fueled vehicles. But it does so despite finding that the program has failed to live up to either of its goals: reducing gasoline consumption and substantially increasing the use of alternative fuels.

title: Hevesi and Vallone Collecting Big Sums From Intermediaries
description: Two Democratic candidates for mayor have raised an unusually large portion of their campaign war chests through intermediaries who delivered bundles of checks that far exceed the limit they could have donated as individuals.

title: Instant Messaging Is a Hit Among Most Online Teenagers
description: If it was not already clear that today's teenagers should be dubbed Gen-I.M., the results of a survey of their online habits may clinch it.

title: DRUG COMPANY'S STOCK FALLS AFTER PARTNER DROPS OUT
description: Shares of Inspire Pharmaceuticals fell 21 percent after Genentech dropped its rights to a class of respiratory drugs the companies were developing together. Shares in Inspire, which is based in Durham, N.C., fell $2.96, to close at $11.45. Inspire will regain the rights to both INS365 Respiratory, being tested for chronic bronchitis, and INS37217 Respiratory, being tested for cystic fibrosis. Inspire said Genentech's decision would not delay the testing.

title: BUSH LOSES FAVOR DESPITE TAX CUT AND OVERSEAS TRIP
description: Despite his first overseas trip as president and the passage of his sweeping measure to cut taxes, President Bush's standing as a leader on both domestic and foreign fronts has diminished considerably, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Battles Cuts In Spending For Disasters
description: In an awkward struggle that pits the White House against its usual allies in holding down government spending, the Bush administration is insisting that House Republicans reinstate hundreds of millions of dollars they had cut from politically sensitive disaster relief projects.

title: Eight Days in Egypt
description: Misr Travel has two eight-day trips to Egypt focusing on Cairo and the archaeological sites in the Nile Valley, with departures on Sept. 11 and Nov. 20. The price, $1,826 a person in double occupancy, includes round-trip air fare from New York on EgyptAir, four nights in the Ramses Hilton in Cairo, three nights on a Movenpick Nile cruise ship, flights within Egypt, all meals on the ship and daily buffet breakfast. Also in the price are guided tours of the Pyramids, Egyptian Museum and all major sites between Luxor and Aswan. A side trip to the temples at Abu Simbel is $220 extra. Also not included are visa fees and tips to guides and drivers. Information: (800) 223-4978 or www.misrtravel.org .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, JOHN F.
description: MAXWELL-John F., 79. Of Clifton, NJ on June 18. Beloved husband of Eliane (Halimi) Maxwell, dear father of Ronald F. and John ''Ted'' Maxwell, devoted grandfather of Olivia, Jonathan, Christopher and Timothy Maxwell, loving brother of Margaret Maxwell. Graduate of Muhlenberg College, 1st Lt. US Army Air Corps WW II North Africa-Italy, retired electronic engineer ITT, Nucleonics, Datascan and Digital Computers. Funeral Saturday 11 AM at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 65th and Central Park West, NY, NY. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visiting Saturday 9-10 AM, at Allwood Funeral Home, 660-670 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ.

title: Designed to Pry: Building a Better Fishbowl
description: AT a West Village deli last winter, Petra Barchi got an unexpected earful. She had been working 24-hour days in the neighborhood and needed a cup of coffee. The man behind the counter wanted to dish. Some big TV show, he confided, was destroying everything inside the building next door.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALFANDRE, JULIAN E.
description: ALFANDRE-Julian E. 6/21/40-9/7/97. You died before the branches of your tree would grow so well to embrace the world and make it a better place. How elated and honored you would be. How treasured you are. How every day missed. Rachel, Jimmy, David and Natalie

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I believe this is an unjust decision. I am innocent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, JOANN DALLAS
description: CONNELL-JoAnn Dallas. Died after a courageous battle with breast cancer on June 18 at Kendal in Kennett Square, PA. She is survived by five children, Thomas Hilbert, Jefferson Joseph, Ann Dallas Clarke, Nancy Day Connell, Abigail Sanford Connell and nine grandchildren. JoAnn lived in Princeton, NJ for thirty years. She attended Smith College and received an MFA from Columbia University. She was a world traveler, an opera lover, a docent of the Princeton Art Museum, and worked at the Institute for Advance Studies Library at Princeton University. In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Fines For News Media
description: The National Tax Service announced fines totaling $388 million against 23 national news organizations for tax evasion. Editors of the three biggest newspapers, Chosun Ilbo, Joong-ang Ilbo and Dong-A Ilbo, said the fines were an effort to curb their criticism of President Kim Dae Jung, who has called for ''media reform.'' The opposition Grand National Party denounced the tax inquiry as intimidation, while Mr. Kim's Millennium Democratic Party said the outcome proved the opposition's claims false. The Fair Trade Commission plans to announce the results next month of a separate investigation against monopolistic practices by major newspapers. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Powell to Visit Mideast

title: A Contentious Sky Over Air New Zealand
description: Tensions are mounting in the tangled triangle of rival ambitions surrounding Air New Zealand.

title: U.S. Courts Become Arbiters Of Global Rights and Wrongs
description: Last year, five Chinese natives sued the former Chinese prime minister, Li Peng, in an American court for his role in the Tiananmen Square crackdown that killed hundreds of civilians in Beijing.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Pilot Job Action
description: Pilots at Cathay Pacific Airways voted to begin an ''industrial action'' on July 1 if the carrier did not reach an agreement on salaries with their union. A spokesman did not say what steps the pilots might take, but in a previous dispute in 1999, hundreds called in sick, forcing Cathay Pacific, based in Hong Kong, to cancel most of its flights. The pilots want Cathay to cancel a third year of pay cuts.

title: Runyan Finds Success In Move Up to 5,000
description: For most of her track and field career, Marla Runyan has been regarded more as an oddity than as a world-class athlete, a legally blind runner who has survived the rigors and hazards of competition. But her progress in the past year has been remarkable, and she is favored in the women's 5,000 meters, the last of the 38 finals in the national outdoor championships Thursday through Sunday.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Conviction In Stabbing Case
description: A 54-year-old man charged with stabbing a columnist for The Indianapolis Star was convicted of attempted murder in Marion County Superior Court. The convicted man, Scottie Edwards, faces 20 to 50 years in prison for wounding the columnist, Lynn Ford, 42, who suffered a collapsed lung. Mr. Ford, an editor at the newspaper, reportedly had been dating Mr. Edwards's former wife when the attack occurred in February. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Yankees Are Tripping Over Themselves, Not the Tigers
description: Adrian Hernndez made his first start in the major leagues tonight and you couldn't have blamed him had he looked giddily around the field, wide-eyed, and wondered if he was surrounded by impostors.

title: Streaming From Home Into Your Car Stereo
description: Motorola and SimpleDevices are joining to do for the car what TiVo has done for the television set, and connect the home stereo to the Internet at the same time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, FRANCES SHAPIRO (NEE MESSINGER)
description: STERN-Frances Shapiro (nee Messinger). 84, died on June 19 at her home. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Julius R. Shapiro and the late Irving Stern. Loving mother of Albert, Steven and Susan Shapiro. Adored grandmother of Julia, Daniel, Rebecca, Sara and Ethan. Loving mother-in-law of Ruth Ann and Susan and grateful friend of Roger. She was always unselfishly devoted to her extended family and many friends. Service at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, NY on Friday at 11 AM, June 22. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice of Bergen Community Health Care, 400 Old Hook Road, Westwood, NJ 07675 or the American Cancer Society. For information call Clark Associates Funeral Home, 914-232-3033.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York: Prisoner Search Cost $900,000
description: The search for an escaped Rikers Island prisoner who eluded police trackers for four days cost the city around $900,000 in overtime pay, Sandra Smith, a spokeswoman for the Department of Correction, said yesterday. The prisoner, Carlos Zufriatequi, was discovered missing on Wednesday and was caught on Sunday hiding between layers of bricks and insulation in a wall of an empty building.

title: Article 2001062193340555893 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: Coast-to-Coast Search Continues for Reliever
description: The Yankees could rekindle trade talks for Montreal reliever Ugueth Urbina, but it would seemingly take a major concession from one side or the other. It appears more likely the Yankees will pursue other options to fill their need for a right-handed reliever, pursuing someone like Oakland's Jason Isringhausen or Detroit's Todd Jones or Anaheim's Troy Percival.

title: Chelsea Clinton, Still a Closed Book
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 15  She may be the ultimate anomaly of the multimedia age, a household face whose voice has so seldom been heard that she could be a silent movie star. She was not yet 13 when she first slipped onto the national stage in her parents' shadow, and at 21, having traveled the world at her parents' side, she is barely better known.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ALBERT
description: GINSBERG-Albert. On June 20. Loving husband of Pearl. Devoted and loving father of Liane, Larry, Hilary. Cherished grandfather of Sean, Sara, Daniel, Heather and Josh. Services are today 1 P.M., at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Do Not Compare Settlers and Bombers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Says Exxon Aided Rights Abuses
description: A human rights group sued Exxon Mobil in federal court yesterday, accusing the company of complicity in human rights abuses committed by state security forces that protect its large natural gas field in Indonesia.

title: Ask Not for Whom This Bell Tolls; It Doesn't. Instead, It Shines.
description: The Jelly Bell hanging lamp, above, by Martin Bilben of Los Angeles, is made of two layers of transparent and red acrylic molded into a 12-inch-diameter shape with inlaid purple acrylic ($600). Mr. Bilben, a self-taught designer, says he hopes his line of Plasticratic lamps will provide an alternative to retro everything. The lamps are sold at Built, 1626 Silverlake Boulevard; (323) 661-8293. Mr. Bilben's work can also be seen at a new restaurant, Joya, 242 North Beverly Drive. Plasticratic: (323) 465-7365.

title: Layden Is Looking At Cook of St. John's
description: The latest in the long line of ballyhooed New York City point guards worked out for the Knicks yesterday. The Brooklyn native Omar Cook, a high school all-American at Christ the King and an all-Big East performer at St. John's, was one of four guards to put his skills on display at Purchase College.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Checks by the Batch For 2 in Mayor Race
description: The campaigns of two of the four Democratic candidates for mayor are receiving large portions of cash through a practice called bundling, in which intermediaries deliver bundles of checks to a campaign. The total amount of the checks far exceeds the limit for donations by an individual. The practice, which is legal, is playing a bigger role in the mayor's race because stricter limits have been placed on contributions.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Refiling Planned For Peyote-Use Lawsuit
description: A civil rights lawsuit dismissed by a federal judge this week will be refiled in a Utah court on behalf of the leader of a local church that uses peyote in religious ceremonies, said a lawyer for the church, the Oklevueha EarthWalks Native American Church. The church leader, James Mooney, is charged in Utah County with distributing peyote. The county attorney has said that because Mr. Mooney does not belong to a federally recognized tribe, he is not covered by legal provisions allowing the use of peyote. Gustav Niebuhr (NYT)

title: Trying to Sparkle Among the Hip
description: Perrier was once a status symbol, as much a badge of the trendy yuppie of the early 1980's as red suspenders or a color-coded Filofax organizer.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Financing Report Lifts Stock
description: Shares of the At Home Corporation, which does business as Excite@Home, jumped 42 cents, or 22 percent, to $2.32 after the company, the top provider of Internet service over cable television lines, said it would receive $85 million from AT&T. AT&T, the company's largest investor, is refunding money it previously received from At Home as an advance payment to use the AT&T network for 20 years.

title: Scientists Trace Onset of Malaria
description: Malaria, a leading cause of death in the world, is not the ancient affliction it might seem but a comparatively recent scourge that dates back only to the era when human societies first practiced agriculture.

title: Twists of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, CYNTHIA
description: WILSON-Cynthia, 48. Of Manhattan, accomplished singer, on June 17, 2001. Majoring in music and minoring in writing at Sarah Lawrence while also studying at Juilliard, she got her BA degree, was a runner-up at The NYC Division of Miss America Competition, and went on to appear in musicals on & off Broadway. She was writing a musical comedy before succumbing to cancer. Daughter of the late C. Philip Wilson, M.D., she is survived by her mother, Christine, brothers, Scott and Marc, nephew, Eric, niece, Julia, & loving cousins, aunts, and uncles. A Memorial Service will be held at The Congregational Church in Old Lyme, CT, Saturday, July 14 at 3 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be sent to The American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELICE, HENRY ''JACK''
description: FELICE-Henry ''Jack'', 86. A retired bandleader, songwriter, tv director and winner of several Emmy awards at WPIX & WNYE, died June 18th in Charlotte, NC. He is survived by his wife, Catherine, and seven children.

title: Federal Government Says It Smashed Major Drug Ring With Mexico's Help
description: Working closely with Mexican authorities, federal officials have broken up a smuggling operation that shipped tens of millions of dollars worth of cocaine and marijuana from Colombia and Mexico into the United States, the government said today.

title: Interior Dept. Halting Plan For Grizzlies In 2 States
description: The Interior Department said today that it was abandoning a Clinton administration plan to reintroduce grizzly bears into the isolated wilds of Idaho and Montana, in what was to have been a bid to help grizzlies, a threatened species, toward recovery.

title: Union Says Verizon Broke Organizing Accord
description: Hundreds of union protesters rallied yesterday at the headquarters of Verizon Communications in Manhattan, asserting that the company was violating a labor contract in which it agreed not to fight organizing drives at nonunion operations.

title: New York Professor Is Nation's Next Poet Laureate
description: Billy Collins, distinguished professor of English at Lehman College at the City University of New York, was named today as the nation's next poet laureate.

title: Wieden Executive Leaving Agency
description: Matthew Seiler, managing director at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, is leaving after only 13 months. A former top Wieden & Kennedy executive was named to replace him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Alternative-Fuel Program Fails to Reach Its Goals

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Woody's Film Helps the Cause

title: Sports of The Times; Shooting For a Stop On the Tour
description: HOW many teenagers ever receive from their father an offer of a round with Tiger Woods?

title: Market Place; Honeywell Torn Between Deal and Independence
description: Earlier this year, Honeywell International's chairman, Michael R. Bonsignore, expressed confidence that his company's efforts to integrate with the General Electric Company would pay off quickly once the deal was completed.

title: When You're Young and in Love, Sing
description: The love problems of 20-somethings are the consuming interest of ''I Sing,'' a new musical as earnest and immature as the subject suggests. The show is a collaboration among college pals, three young graduates of Northwestern University -- Eli Bolin (music), Sam Forman (lyrics) and Benjamin Salka (direction), all credited with the book and now living in New York City. And it is about three young men who are new to New York and the two young women they become entangled with in varying combinations.

title: Bomber Helped Stab Guard, Jury Is Told
description: A correction officer in Manhattan who was stabbed in the eye last fall while guarding terrorism suspects in a federal jail told colleagues after the attack that he ''gave them a fight,'' said an officer who recalled his words yesterday.

title: Online Maps for Here, There and Everywhere
description: THANKS to the Internet, a man can now engage in the most embarrassing of all activities in the privacy of his own home: asking for directions.

title: Niagara Falls and Buffalo Proposed as Casino Sites
description: The Pataki administration and the Seneca Indian Nation have struck a deal to build two Las Vegas-style casinos in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, and possibly a third elsewhere in western New York, the governor said in a surprise announcement late this afternoon.

title: Toward a Patients' Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Barton Mumaw, 88, Dancer; Member of Ted Shawn Troupe
description: Barton Mumaw, a member of Ted Shawn's pioneering all-male dance company of the 1930's and a performer in many modern-dance and musical theater productions, died on Monday in Clearwater, Fla., his home for many years. He was 88.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about federal efforts to settle a multibillion-dollar lawsuit against the tobacco industry was truncated in some copies. The last paragraph should have read: ''But cigarette companies have repeatedly denied that they misled the federal government about their knowledge of the health hazards of smoking or that they manipulated nicotine levels.''

title: Yanks Pay $30 Million To End Deal With MSG
description: Mark the calendar: the MSG Network's last Yankees game will be Sept. 30 against the Baltimore Orioles.

title: News in a Huge Grinder of Translation
description: There is a fine line between news and entertainment on a new Web site that translates hundreds of the world's newspapers into English. Consider this headline translated from The Beijing Daily: "Sells which roast the dried bean curd girl." From The Okinawa Times comes this gripping lead: "The light where the body of the strong so stainless steel material is sluggish is shot."

title: Article 2001062190996255789 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Colonel Charged in 1992 Prison Massacre Goes on Trial in Rio
description: Nearly nine years ago, a military police riot squad swept into Latin America's largest prison to quell a routine fight between rival gangs. The result was what human rights groups and even the Brazilian government itself describe as the worst massacre in the country's history, with at least 111 prisoners killed, most as they cowered in their cells.

title: Vernon Downs: Track on Its Last Legs
description: The racetrack was about as fit for duty as a broken-down horse.

title: In Albany, Criticism for a Day That Will Live in Futility
description: By this evening, nearly everyone had given up on reaching agreement on any major bills today, a deadline that was supposed to be the final day of the legislative session. Even Gov. George E. Pataki, after issuing recommendations for voting reforms, left the capital by helicopter for Niagara Falls, where he announced three casino gambling plans, all requiring legislative approval, which will take even more time.

title: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion
description: MARINA DEL REY, Calif. -- On a quiet street in a village in the Balkans, an accident suddenly puts an American peacekeeping force to the test. A Humvee has hit a car, and a child who has been injured in the collision lies unmoving on the ground. A medic leans over him. The child's mother cries out. A crowd of local residents gathers in the background. How they will react is anyone's guess.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mark Darling was named vice president for marketing at Subaru of America, Cherry Hill, N.J., succeeding Bill Cyphers, who was named vice president for sales, taking over duties that had been handled by Fred Adcock, executive vice president. Mr. Darling had been vice president for brand strategy at American Isuzu Motors, Cerritos, Calif.

title: ALLSTATE SELLING GERMAN AND ITALIAN AUTO DIVISIONS
description: The Allstate Corporation, the second-largest auto insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it was selling its start-up auto insurance businesses in Germany and Italy to Direct Line, a London subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland. The price was not disclosed. The German unit, with 117,000 policies, was started in 1997. The Italian business, with 27,000 customers, started last year. The companies need ''a significant investment of capital,'' said Edward M. Liddy, the chief executive of Allstate, ''and we believe that greater potential for Allstate exists in North America.'' Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Cold Water Flow From Arctic to Atlantic Is Falling, Study Finds
description: Scientists have detected a substantial drop in the last 50 years in the flow of cold deep sea water leaving the Arctic and pouring into the Atlantic between Iceland and Scotland.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Where Vincent Price Went to Hide
description: DESPITE his workaholic ways, my father, Vincent Price, could also be madly adventurous and wonderfully offbeat. As a result, my childhood was full of surprises -- one of the best of which was the home on wheels called the Clark Cortez.

title: Fourteen People Indicted in Khobar Towers Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A federal grand jury returned a 46-count indictment today charging 13 Saudis and a Lebanese man, who officials said were supported by Iran, with a truck bombing at the Khobar Towers apartment building in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American airmen and wounded nearly 400 others in 1996.

title: Fed Chief Tries To Head Off Skittishness Among Lenders
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that more businesses have had trouble repaying bank loans as the economy has slowed, but he urged lenders not to overreact by cutting off credit to healthy borrowers.

title: New York City Is Making Its Case for the 2012 Games
description: NYC 2012 has spent the past two and a half years building a case to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympics in the city, the New Jersey Meadowlands and Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Path to Redemption (Limited-Time Offer)
description: THERE is a perfectly reasonable explanation for why I parked a block from a crowded plant nursery one day last week and dodged whizzing trucks as I ran across the double yellow warning lines of a busy thoroughfare for the sole purpose of buying four measly packs of seedlings.

title: Japan Rejects European Report on Mad Cow Disease
description: TOKYO, 20 June - The Japanese government has asked the European Commission to withhold a report that says mad cow disease could potentially develop there as it did in Europe.

title: Rent Board Votes Bigger Increases For Landlords
description: Without warning, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board reversed itself last night by imposing increases one percentage point higher than it proposed a month ago: 4 percent for one-year lease renewals and 6 percent for two-year leases.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and a front-page article on Saturday about President Bush's appeal for the expansion of NATO to Russia's borders misstated the alliance's current reach. Two of the existing 19 members -- Norway and Poland -- border Russian territory, so an expansion would not be the first move to carry the alliance there.

title: Experts Tell Council That Wait For Mammograms Is Worsening
description: Health care experts told a City Council committee yesterday that women in some parts of New York can expect a three-to-four-month wait for mammograms, critical tests in the early detection of breast cancer, and that the problem is likely to become worse.

title: Oh, Brother: Toledos Are Fine Featherweight Friends
description: David Toledo said he would not fight his older brother, Frank. A bout between the two would not happen, even if it meant becoming a world champion, unless there were a payday beyond their expectations.

title: Article 2001062193948507064 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIMAN, MOLLIE
description: KLEIMAN-Mollie. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the mother of our esteemed member Zelda Goldsmith and extends to her and the family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE COLA, JOSEPH P.
description: DE COLA-Joseph P. Beloved husband of Julia. Devoted father of Philip, Joseph, Vincent and Paula. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Andrew Avellino RC Church on Saturday 9:15 AM. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Nativity Mission, 204 Forsythe St., New York, NY 10002, or charity of choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLESTINO, FRANK S.
description: POLESTINO-Frank S. St. John's University School of Law mourns the death of longtime Professor of Law Frank S. Polestino. Professor Polestino served the School of Law from 1972 till his death on June 18, 2001. May he rest in peace.

title: Big Contract To Embraer From Brazil
description: Empresa Brasileira de Aeronatica, or Embraer, said today that it had won a contract to provide as many as 100 large regional jets to the Brazilian airline TAM Lineas Areas.

title: First the Mexicans, Then the Food; A Fast-Growing Group Now Feeds Itself and the Region, Too
description: When Juanita Bravo came to New York in 1970 to work in a textile factory, a Mexican could not find so much as a decent tortilla in this town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, IRWIN E.
description: FRIEDMAN-Irwin E. Prominent Bridgeport attorney, died June 18th at the age of 90. Mr. Friedman served as municipal court judge for the town of Trumbull, was a member of the Connecticut Civil Rights Commission and became chairman in 1957. A 1932 graduate of Boston University School of Law, Mr. Friedman joined his brother Samuel in the law firm of Friedman and Friedman in Bridgeport. He was married to the late Ruth Wells Friedman. He is survived by his wife, Micheline Friedman, his daughter Wendy Brest of Stamford, his son Gary Friedman of Muir Beach, California, and three stepchildren, Roger Bonvini of Sandy Hook, Anita Ignaszewski of Stowe, Massachusetts, Robert Bonvini of Newton and eight grandchildren.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Queen's English
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Apartment Project Detailed
description: Construction could begin as early as next spring on the first major residential development in downtown Newark in a decade, said officials of the New Newark Foundation. They introduced the developers and detailed the first phase of a $160 million retail and residential project for the city. With rents ranging from $1,200 to $1,600 a month and 24-hour concierge services, the loft-type apartments in the now vacant Hahnes Department Store building and adjacent Griffith Piano Company building are meant to attract upscale tenants. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDWELL, CAROL A.
description: CALDWELL-Carol A., 49. Of Philadelphia, PA, formerly of New York City passed away peacefully at her home on June 15, 2001. A graduate of Chestnut Hill College, Chestnut Hill, PA, she was currently Assistant to the Director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art and previously was affiliated with Wildenstein & Co. and Christie's in New York City. Surviving are her beloved parents, Robert W., Jr. and Marion Caldwell of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL; loving sister and brothers Diane Lopez (George) of New York City; Robert W., III (Deborah), nephew Robert W., IV of Chatham, NJ; Brian E. of Houston, TX; and John G. (Jeanne) and nieces Alexandra and Sophia of Jacksonville Beach, FL. Memorial Mass celebrating her life will be held at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, followed by inurnment in the church's Columbarium Chapel. If desired, donations in memoriam may be sent to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Kodak Backs Video Conversion
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had invested $2.5 million in YesVideo of San Jose, Calif., which converts consumers' videotapes into CD's and DVD's. The agreement gives Kodak an equity stake in the privately held YesVideo, and a seat on its board. Kodak already offers YesVideo's video-to-digital conversion service at about 4,000 retail locations in the United States that use Kodak processing laboratories for print film. ''The immediate opportunity is for Kodak to exploit the non-U.S. distribution of YesVideo's service,'' said Ted Lewis, a senior vice president at Kodak.

title: Puccini's Opera, So Subtle, For 45,000 in the Park
description: When you're selecting an opera to perform outdoors for thousands of people, you want something blunt, with large choruses and a rousing finale. ''Tosca,'' by contrast, is an intimate piece -- one of the greatest documented interpretations of Act II revolves around movements of Maria Callas's eyes -- and it ends, in concert, with the soprano standing alone onstage.

title: Cuisine Art
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Venture Buying Spanish-Language Portal
description: The MSN unit of Microsoft says its Internet venture with Telfonos de Mexico has agreed to buy the closely held Spanish-language Web network Yupi Internet to attract Hispanic users. Terms were not disclosed. The move comes as Microsoft increases its competition with AOL Time Warner. Telmex, Mexico's largest telephone company, and Microsoft's T1msn Internet unit in Mexico will start a Spanish-language portal called Yupi/ MSN. Microsoft is trying to build its MSN Internet business with more consumer services as it tries to catch up with AOL's America Online. The number of Hispanics in the United States almost doubled during the 1990's, according to Census data.

title: For a Sports Bridesmaid, a Blissful Union
description: As it nears a deal to build a $250 million arena and bring the National Basketball Association's Vancouver Grizzlies franchise to town, perhaps this city can be forgiven the fever pitch of emotions that have played out here during the last three months.

title: 'China Without Borders'
description: Goedhuis Contemporary at Sotheby's New York

title: With Braves Up Next, The Mets Fall Flat
description: One thing at a time, please.

title: Misunderstood But Marvelous
description: Harry Strano plans to teach families how to build refuges for what he believes are some of the most beautiful and fascinating winged creatures to sweep across the summer sky. But leave the birdseed at home: these flying marvels are bats.

title: Case of Murder On Death Row Goes to Jury
description: A lawyer for a prisoner on death row who is charged with killing a fellow inmate told a jury today that his client had acted in self-defense in the jail attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYWARD, MARIAN MCCOMB
description: HAYWARD-Marian McComb. Of Cornwall, CT and Exeter, NH, formerly of Montclair, NJ, on June 20, 2001, in Exeter, at age 88. Widow of Charles Eccleston Hayward, predeceased by her son, Charles E. Hayward IV. Survived by her son, James McC. Hayward, and his wife Martha, of Ipswich, MA, and by two grandchildren, Emily Donovan Hayward and Elias Eccleston Hayward, also of Ipswich. Memorial service on Saturday, June 23, at 11 A.M. at First Church of Christ, Congregational, 25 Main Street, Sharon, Connecticut. Contributions may be made to Westover School, 1237 Whittemore Road, Middlebury, CT. 06762 (www.westoverschool.org), or to ACTS 29 Ministries, 1900 The Exchange, Ste 170, Atlanta, GA 30339 (www.a29.com).

title: Blue Cross Reaches Deal With Top Foes Of For-Profit Switch
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which has been seeking permission from New York State to convert to a for-profit company for five years, has made a giant leap toward that goal by striking a deal with the loudest, most powerful opponents of the conversion. The company, which originally said that it would set up a $1 billion charitable foundation to help provide health care for the state's poor, has told hospital leaders that it will now press the State Legislature to give half the money to hospitals.

title: Wilpon Expected to Buy Doubleday's Share of Mets
description: In a transaction perhaps only weeks away from completion, Fred Wilpon will buy Nelson Doubleday's 50 percent share of the Mets, then divide that portion among a group of highly influential New York entrepreneurs, several people familiar with the development said yesterday.

title: Abusing Their Power Because They Can
description: The pertinence to contemporary New Yorkers of ''Sus,'' a 1979 drama by the English playwright Barrie Keeffe, is unassailable. The play is about the police interrogation of a black man who has been mistakenly arrested for the murder of his wife, and his treatment by the cops makes it clear that as much as anything else his race marks him as guilty.

title: A Duty to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. to Issue Air Rules To Protect Park Vistas
description: The Bush administration is preparing to issue rules on Friday to clamp down on old coal-fired power plants that are the chief culprits in the haze that has spoiled the vistas in many national parks and wilderness areas, leaving the worst blight in Acadia National Park in Maine and the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLIN, ROSE (NEE WEINSTEIN)
description: KARLIN-Rose (nee Weinstein), 97. Wife of the late Kalman Karlin. Dear sister of Louis and the late Miriam and Meyer. Adored aunt of Ely (Shirley), Chester, Daniel, Elliot (Susan), Myra (Herbert), Larry (Diane) and Warren (Kathryn). We will miss you. KARLIN-Rose. Respected stepmother of Sharon Chernoff; wife of the deceased Kielman Karlin; adoring grandmother of Helene Schorr and Michelle Chernoff.

title: 'Larger Than Life'
description: Center for Figurative Painting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISFELD, JOAN H.
description: REISFELD-Joan H. Of Marco Island, FL, passed away on June 20th, 2001. Born in Astoria, Queens to Estelle and William Streim, Joan was a graduate of New York University. She was a wonderful wife for 54 years to Mort, a caring and loving mother to her children, Rona and Donald, & grandmother to Daryl, Lauren and Sean. Joan was a social worker, teacher, swimming instructor & volunteer for the Nassau Center for Emotionally Disturbed Children and Temple Emanu-El of New York. The family suggests that donations be made in her memory to the American Juvenile Diabetes Association. Funeral services held today at 1:45 PM at Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Article 2001062290809365964 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: State Grants Reprieve To Ailing Harness Track
description: Vernon Downs, the embattled harness track in upstate New York, has been granted an extension of a temporary license until the end of the year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Five Opposition Lawmakers Freed
description: In its latest concilatory gesture, the military government of the former Burma released five opposition lawmakers who had been detained since 1998. Eight others were released last Thursday. Another 22 remain confined in government guest houses. The members of Parliament were elected in 1990 but the new Parliament was never convened. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From testdriving convertibles to tvs for minivans, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Webb Advances; Greene Ties Meet Record in 100 Meters
description: Eighteen-year-old Alan Webb wants to get to the top in track and field. Maurice Greene is already there and shows no signs of leaving. Between them, they turned in the most notable performances today as the four-day national outdoor championships began at the University of Oregon's Hayward Field.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Killers of British Toddler to Be Freed
description: LONDON, June 22  The government said today that two British teenagers who kidnapped and killed a toddler when they were 10 have cleared their final hurdle for parole and are to be released imminently with newly constructed identities.

title: George Ortman -- 'The Models, an Imitation'
description: Mitchell Algus Gallery

title: 2 Democrats Running for Mayor Return $77,000 in Contributions
description: Two Democrats running for mayor are returning about $77,000 in campaign contributions delivered in batches by a prominent New Jersey developer and a Manhattan hotel executive after ethical questions surfaced about the gifts.

title: Gene Study Dates Malaria To the Advent of Farming
description: Malaria, a leading cause of death in the world, is not the ancient affliction it might seem but a relatively recent scourge that dates only to the era when human societies first practiced agriculture.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Schools Facing Layoffs
description: Nearly 1,000 school employees face layoffs, their union, the Camden Educational Association, said yesterday. It said that hundreds of instructional assistants, clerks and security workers had received letters from the school district stating that their positions were in jeopardy. Bart Leff, a district spokesman, said the potential layoffs were due to inadequate state financing. But the State Department of Education said the district had enough financing and was overstaffed. ''The positions that the district will be eliminating are simply not necessary,'' said Peter Peretzman, a department spokesman.

title: Wildlife of the World, Unite!
description: Back in his ''Saturday Night Live'' days, Eddie Murphy used to do a wicked impersonation of Bill Cosby, all gums and eyebrows and fuddy-duddy diction. The gods of popular culture clearly have an impish sense of humor: 20 years later the irreverent bad boy has grown up into a faster-talking, more excitable Cliff Huxtable.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Murder Loophole Closing
description: The New Jersey Senate and General Assembly voted unanimously yesterday to close a loophole that exempts murderers from the 1997 No Early Release Act. The legislation was passed in response to a New Jersey Supreme Court decision last week that Samuel Manzie, a convicted murderer, could not be sentenced under the tougher regulations, Senate leaders said. The parole act requires that violent criminals serve 85 percent of their sentences before they become eligible for parole. Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco said he would sign the legislation by the end of the month.

title: Up, Down, All-Around and Quite Silly Besides
description: When it came to photography, angle was everything at the Bauhaus, the school of modern art and design founded by Walter Gropius in 1919, which occupied three German cities in succession -- Weimar, Dessau and Berlin -- before being snuffed out by the Nazis in 1933. Photos were snapped from above, from below, from close up and from oblique angles. They were taken upside down and sideways, through windows, through gratings, through a camera and not. But in Bauhaus photography there was one prevalent angle that many people forget: the silly one.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Retailer's Profit Is Up
description: The Swedish retailer Hennes & Mauritz said that profit rose 37 percent in the three-month period that ended on May 31, setting off a 17 percent rise in its stock price. Profit increased to 1.02 billion kronor ($95 million) from 743 million kronor a year earlier. Sales were up 39 percent, to 11.76 billion kronor ($1.09 billion), driven by new stores. Hennes & Maurtiz opened 49 stores in the last six months and plans 50 more openings for the rest of the year, as it expands in the United States and Europe. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Fairy Tale Recounted As a Surreal Brainteaser
description: Tom Tykwer's mathematically elegant film ''The Princess and the Warrior'' hangs a heavy load of metaphysical baggage on the story of a nurse in a mental hospital whose life is miraculously saved by a criminal on the lam. Shy, beautiful Sissi (Franka Potente), while wending her way to the bank one afternoon on the streets of Wuppertal, is hit by a truck. As it turns out, Bodo (Benno Frmann), the handsome stranger who saves her, has been planning to rob the same bank that was her destination.

title: Skeptical Senators Question Rumsfeld on Missile Defense
description: Senate Democrats sharply questioned Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld today about the high cost and unproven effectiveness of a national missile defense system, and they raised deep concerns about the administration's threats to withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty if the Russians refused to amend it.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Temporary Latex Site
description: Latex Foam Products, whose factory in Ansonia, Conn., burned down last month, is preparing to open a temporary plant, a company official said yesterday. The official said that until a lease was signed, he could not confirm an article in The Connecticut Post yesterday that the new location would be in Naugatuck, Conn., but he said it would be in the Naugatuck Valley region, which includes Naugatuck and Ansonia.

title: Bike Race, Short on Sponsors, Is Postponed Until Next Year
description: The city's first professional bicycle race, a fund-raising competition planned for this summer with Lance Armstrong and other top cyclists, will have to wait until next year, organizers said yesterday, because of difficulties in securing the financing.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Public Interests; You've Got Mail
description: Only about a month left until we get our $300 rebate checks from the federal government. Everybody's a winner! I just want to say right here and now that I don't intend to quit my job, although I do hope to buy my parents a new house and perhaps travel.

title: Plan Calls for Meadowlands To Become Family Complex
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco today unveiled an ambitious 10-year plan for redeveloping the Meadowlands sports complex as a family entertainment, recreation and shopping destination, as well as advancing a host of other projects in the area and linking them all with long-sought rail connections and improved roads.

title: What's Animated And What's Not?
description: The explosive success of the computer-animated ''Shrek,'' which opened in mid-May and has become the biggest hit of the summer season so far, has reinforced the common wisdom in Hollywood that audience tastes have been shifting from more traditional animated films like the Walt Disney classics toward computer-generated animation.

title: For Sale: African Art, In Abundance
description: ''You have to know how to get rid of ideas that turn out to be wrong,'' said Hubert Goldet (1945-2000), a Parisian who collected contemporary paintings as a young man, then switched to African tribal art for the rest of his life.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland To Decide On Air Bill
description: Gov. John G. Rowland is to announce today whether he will sign into law or veto a bill to tighten emissions standards on Connecticut's six most polluting coal- and oil-burning power plants. Mr. Rowland must act by midnight or the bill automatically becomes law. He had postponed a decision as letters criticizing the legislation came in from both the power plants' owner, NRG Energy Inc., and a regional director of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Rowland said he was concerned that passage of the bill would leave the state short on power this summer. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Poet of Life's Quiet Spaces Is Thrust Into Spotlight
description: A 60-year-old smiling public man.'' The line, written by one poet, William Butler Yeats, is recollected by another, Billy Collins, 60 himself. It comes to mind as he sits in the sterile tranquillity of an office at Lehman College, where he has taught for more than 30 years. He has just finished holding, of all things, a news conference, and the tension between public and private is written on his face, which smiles, then sags wearily, smiles, then sags.

title: Ol! Ol! Flamenco And Bulls
description: Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana is an admirable company that preserves traditional Spanish dances and uses them in new ways. In ''Mano a Mano,'' which it presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, Antonio Hidalgo choreographically united bullfighting with flamenco dancing.

title: The Force Is With the DVD
description: With names and numbers erupting on DVD, studios are weighing in with their most prized possessions. On Tuesday Fox announced the Oct. 16 release of ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace,'' the first of the four ''Star Wars'' films to appear on compact disc. On Oct. 9 the three ''Godfather'' films will be available from Paramount.

title: Mies's Dreams With Windows
description: MIES IN BERLIN'' and ''Mies in America'' -- two major museum shows dreaded by many, especially by me -- have turned out to be surprisingly good. They actually do what they set out to do: present a picture of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe we haven't seen before. Rather than repackaging this great German modernist (1886-1969) as a field marshal of reason, obsessed with compressing all of human existence into uniform, three-dimensional grids, these two shows depict Mies as a supervisor of fantasy: an interpreter of the 20th century's deepest dream of itself.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Strip: Cease-Fire Holds
description: Palestinians in the Gaza Strip lobbed a large-caliber mortar shell at a border crossing into Israel and fired antitank grenades at Israeli troops near the border with Egypt, lightly wounding a soldier, the army said. In the West Bank a fragile cease-fire held, but Palestinians reported that Jewish settlers burned cars, wheat fields and an olive grove in an area where a settler was shot dead on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Science Times on June 12 about a proposed ban on fishing at Dry Tortugas National Park misstated the park's acreage. It is more than 64,000 acres, not 6,000.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Professor Investigated
description: Mount Holyoke College is opening an investigation of Joseph J. Ellis, the prize-winning historian who has admitted lying to students and reporters about serving in Vietnam. Professor Ellis has apologized, but the college said misleading students in the classroom is a serious matter. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERSTEIN, RUTH S.
description: FEUERSTEIN-Ruth S., 97. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Hallandale, FL, died on June 21, in Somerset, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Murray M, Mrs. Feuerstein was a 6th grade elementary school teacher in the NYC School system for 35 years. A dedicated life member of Hadassah, she received a National leadership award. She ran fundraising events for the Jewish Federation of Broward County and for the Democratic party. She was co-president of the Residents Council at the Central NJ Jewish Home, Somerset and was a bat mitzvah there in May. Survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Frances and Daniel P. Gold; a granddaughter, Suzanne Gold; a grandson and granddaughter - in - law, Nicholas and Marcy Gold; and two great grandsons.

title: JUDGE RECALLS COMPANY OFFICIAL IN GAS PRICE INQUIRY
description: The El Paso Corporation's chairman, William A. Wise, has been ordered back before a federal energy regulatory judge for the second phase of a hearing into whether the company manipulated California natural gas prices. Mr. Wise testified before an administrative law judge, Curtis Wagner, last month as part of an investigation into whether El Paso's pipeline subsidiary sold more than a billion cubic feet of pipeline capacity serving California to its merchant energy subsidiary so the buyer could withhold gas shipments and drive up prices in the state. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission permitted Judge Wagner to broaden the investigation to include whether the pipeline subsidiary showed favoritism in awarding the contract to the merchant energy unit.

title: The Pride and the Glory In a Western of Sorts
