description: A large part of the appeal of ''Himalaya'' comes from the breathtaking beauty of its setting, the mountainous, sparsely populated Dolpo region of Nepal. Exquisitely filmed in Cinemascope, a format whose wide frames and panoramic angles emphasize the lonely grandeur of the landscape, the movie offers an intoxicating dose of armchair tourism, like a National Geographic pictorial brought to life.

title: Getaway Drivers, Take Note: This One's Made for You
description: Watching daring, high-tech criminals in action, I have the same thought that probably occurs to other moviegoers: if these guys just held on to some of the money they spend on equipment, they wouldn't have to turn to a life of crime. Many such thoughts may drift through your consciousness -- in fact, your very consciousness may drift -- during ''The Fast and the Furious,'' a routine crime drama that deserves its generic title.

title: Rahman Must Fight Lewis or Sit for 18 Months
description: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday barred Hasim Rahman from fighting any other boxers for a year and a half unless he fulfilled a contractual obligation to give Lennox Lewis a rematch.

title: John Baldessari, Jeff Koons and Tom Wesselmann
description: Sonnabend

title: Foreign Affairs; I Love the E.U.
description: More and more these days when I return home from trips abroad and my wife asks me how it was, I find myself answering, ''You know, honey, the wheels aren't on tight out there.''

title: More Acting And Details Add to a Plot
description: The dancers of American Ballet Theater turned in generally first-rate performances of ''Swan Lake'' on Monday and Wednesday nights at the Metropolitan Opera House. But the brightest star was the production itself. Kevin McKenzie, Ballet Theater's artistic director, has opened up this classic and brought fresh new life to it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Body Shop Sales Fall
description: The health and beauty products retailer, Body Shop International, said sales at stores open at least one year fell 1 percent in the three-month period that ended June 2. Same-store sales fell 2 percent in Europe and the Middle East; dropped 1 percent in Asia, Britain and Ireland; and were unchanged in the Americas. Total sales rose 3 percent, as the company opened 35 stores in the quarter.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a requirement that medical students in West Virginia receive training in rural areas referred incorrectly to an institution that participates. It is West Virginia University, not the University of West Virginia.

title: Strindberg's Eerie World Of Lost Souls
description: DECAY is an irresistible force in Ingmar Bergman's exquisite, hideous and altogether stunning production of August Strindberg's ''Ghost Sonata,'' currently haunting the Brooklyn Academy of Music. You can almost smell the flesh rotting in this fantasia on mortal corruption and deceit from the Royal Dramatic Theater of Sweden. Yet even as you flinch, you are unlikely to look away.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Observation column of Science Times on Tuesday about solar eclipses misstated the best viewing spot for the total eclipse that will occur on Dec. 4, 2002. It will be in the Indian Ocean, not in the Pacific.

title: The Battle Over the Murals of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Serendipity for a Freewheeling Group
description: Bang on a Can commissions plenty of music for its resident ensemble, the Bang on a Can All-Stars, and for the most part, it follows the usual procedure, which is to fill out grant forms or solicit private backing. But the organization also takes a grass-roots approach, asking its audiences for contributions -- anything from pocket change to substantial amounts -- to its People's Commissioning Fund. The fund covers the cost of four works, which are presented in an annual concert.

title: 2nd Night of Protestant-Catholic Rioting in Belfast
description: Clashes between Roman Catholic and Protestant residents of Belfast, Northern Ireland, continued for the second consecutive night tonight.

title: Rage Against the Fed; Interest Rates Put Student Stock Club in a Malaise
description: Nirav Patel couldn't get over it. He was a wordy person. Agitated, he had even more to say. ''He's a genius,'' he conceded to Anish Vora, his best friend. ''But he also does retarded things. This goes down as retarded.''

title: No Panache, No Pomp, No Problem
description: The venerable greasy spoon may be little more than a Hopperesque memory, but a few redoubts still exist. A connoisseur of these egalitarian haunts visits some favorites.

title: F.C.C. Chief Seeks Hiring Rules
description: Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he would seek to write new rules to encourage television, radio and cable-TV companies to recruit women and members of minority groups.

title: In the Galleries
description: Willie Cole

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: 250 New Soldiers
description: The first group of 250 soldiers graduated from a training academy as East Timor prepares for full independence next year. Its defense force is to grow to 1,500 soldiers, many of them former guerrillas who fought for independence from Indonesia, which was achieved in a referendum two years ago. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lab Technician Charged
description: A Health Department employee was charged yesterday under a new law, after he allegedly performed a gynecological examination though he is licensed only to draw blood. The law allows prosecutors to pursue criminal charges even though consent was given by the subject of a procedure. The employee, Peter Foster, 33, works at the Midtown Court, drawing blood to test for sexually transmitted diseases. But on Monday, he persuaded a patient to let him give her a vaginal examination, injuring her in what Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, called a sexual assault. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Man Convicted in Fatal Accident
description: A jury in Brooklyn convicted a 21-year-old man of second-degree murder yesterday in a car crash that killed two people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POST, SHELDON
description: POST-Sheldon. September 5, 1936June 25, 1988. Founder Chelsea Pines Inn. Chairman NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Board, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah. As we begin Gay Pride weekend it is important to remember those in the gay community who were lost in the still raging AIDS war. Sheldon was an out and proud gay man who dreamed of a better world and fought to make his dream come true. He was a beloved companion, son, brother, uncle, friend. Please join Tom Klebba and me in a moment of reflection this weekend as we recall those who have gone too soon: Mark Fuschetti, Peter Monette, Gary Olde, Jon Flaherty, Gary Brubach, Benn Brown and Wayne Kell, Tom Bradley, Garon Douglas, Jay ''Peggy Sue'' Farrar, Dean X Johnson, Allan Kendric and Ron McSwiggen, Bob Levine, Eddie Peters, Quinton Johnson, Norman Sweet, Eddie Tilchen. ''Not a day goes by, not a blessed day...'' Sheldon, my love, know that you will always be missed and cherished. All will be remembered and celebrated as long as we live. Jay Lesiger

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Julie Bauer, a managing partner at the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, owned by the Publicis Groupe, was named equity director for the agency's Sony account across Europe. She will relocate to London. Ms. Bauer succeeds William Leach, who is leaving, the agency said, to take a sabbatical.

title: I.L.O. Code Would Protect Employees With H.I.V.
description: The International Labor Organization, in a campaign to fight workplace discrimination against people infected with the AIDS virus, is expected to adopt a code of conduct today for businesses, governments and workers.

title: HOUSE VOTE STALLS GULF DRILLING PLAN
description: The House voted today to temporarily bar the Interior Department from leasing the waters off the Florida Panhandle for oil and gas exploration, a setback to the Bush administration's energy strategy.

title: Franks Proposes an Overhaul of New Jersey's Property Taxes
description: Tackling the nettlesome issue of high property taxes for the first time in his campaign for governor, Bob Franks today proposed freezing tax assessments for as long as people own their homes, a change that could revolutionize the way municipalities and school districts finance operations.

title: Album of the Week
description: TRAVIS: ''The Invisible Band (Epic).'' It's been hard to form a solid opinion on Travis. The band's first single, the guitar-heavy, inanely catchy, perfectly produced ''All I Wanna Do Is Rock,'' was one of the freshest, most promising British independent releases of 1996. Travis's breakthrough album, ''The Man Who,'' also had a great sound. But at the same time it seemed derivative, leaving some wondering if Travis was supposed to be Radiohead for dummies or Oasis for smart people. On its third album, ''The Invisible Band,'' Travis proves that it's a band with staying power and takes a step toward establishing its own sound. (The band performs on Monday night at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.; Tuesday night at the Virgin Megastore in Union Square; and Wednesday night at Jones Beach.)

title: Weak Demand Helps Reduce Trade Deficit
description: The trade deficit narrowed in April as imports of business equipment, consumer goods and other items fell more than exports, government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMPEL, REEMA
description: GAMPEL-Reema. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Reuben Gampel. Loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother of Ezra and Manette, Benjamin and Miriam; Mordechai and Neshe, Moshe and Sara & Rebecca Esther, Elisheva and Stephanie; Hannah and Abe. Sister of Solomon Nathan & Helen Jacob. For shiva please call 718983-0980 or 914-375-0466.

title: U.S. Returns An Ex-Judge To Mexico
description: The case against Ernesto Daz, a judge turned fugitive, stands out even in Mexico, a nation weary of official corruption and impunity.

title: Carroll O'Connor, Embodiment of Social Tumult as Archie Bunker, Dies at 76
description: Carroll O'Connor, an actor trained in Shakespearean drama who achieved his greatest triumph playing Archie Bunker, television's malapropian, working-class bigot from Queens, died on Thursday at a hospital in Culver City, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Malibu, Calif.

title: IRAN LINK IS CITED
description: A federal grand jury returned a 46-count indictment today charging 13 Saudis and a Lebanese man, who officials said were supported by Iran, with a truck bombing at the Khobar Towers apartment building in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American airmen and wounded nearly 400 others in 1996.

title: New Plays? New Drought
description: You want musical revivals? We've got musical revivals: ''Into the Woods,'' ''Oklahoma!'' and ''The Boys From Syracuse,'' to name a few. You want new musicals? Got 'em: ''Mamma Mia,'' ''Thou Shalt Not'' and ''Urinetown'' are all to open on Broadway by the end of the year. And old plays? They're covered, too: six revivals planned for the fall. Heck, the first production of the season, ''Major Barbara,'' is already in previews at the American Airlines Theater.

title: An Alternate Reality Made of Cartoons
description: With violence, betrayal, depression and politics, the Japanese anime feature ''Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade'' is not a kids' cartoon. ''Jin-Roh'' is reminiscent of Ralph Bakshi's ''American Pop'' because its characters are rendered in a similar way, closer to reality than the usual cartoon.

title: Relying on Hard and Soft Sells, India Pushes Sterilization
description: Like a preacher at a tent revival, Chandrababu Naidu, one of India's most powerful politicians, summoned parents with big families to the front of the crowd so he could publicly scold them and urge them along the road to sterilization.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fourth Tory In Race
description: The Conservative Party chairman, Michael Ancram, became a surprise fourth contender in the race to succeed William Hague, who is stepping down as leader after the overwhelming Tory loss this month. Mr. Ancram offered himself as a candidate who can unify the divided party. Already announced are two right-wingers, Iain Duncan Smith and David Davis, and a moderate, Michael Portillo. Conservatives in Parliament will choose two candidates for a party vote this summer. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Gail Collins Chosen to Head The Times's Editorial Board
description: Gail Collins, a columnist on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, was named editorial page editor yesterday. She will succeed Howell Raines, who will become executive editor in September.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Mahathir's Foreign Targets
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad opened the annual meeting of his party, the United Malays National Organization, with an aggressive two-hour speech that criticized the largest opposition party, the foreign press, foreign traders and major lending institutions. Several times he referred to those who do not support him as ''idiots.''

title: Justice for Khobar Towers
description: With the five-year statute of limitations about to run out on some counts, a federal grand jury has returned indictments against 13 Saudis and one Lebanese in the 1996 terrorist truck bombing that killed 19 American airmen and injured nearly 400 others at the Khobar Towers residential complex in Saudi Arabia. Although not all the suspects are in custody in Saudi Arabia and none are yet in the United States, a measure of judicial accountability now seems likely for this crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMBARDI, EVELYN DAWN
description: LOMBARDI-Evelyn Dawn. Dear friend, we will miss you always. Terry and Gene Lang

title: Macedonian Military Steps Up Its Assault of Albanian Rebels
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 22  Macedonian forces launched a heavy offensive today against Albanian rebel positions just north of the capital, Skopje, breaking the tentative cease-fire in the southern Balkan republic and leaving diplomatic efforts for a peace agreement in tatters.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell on concern the government's proposals to cut spending and push banks to write off loans would slow Japan's economy. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.42 yen, up from 123.74 on Wednesday.

title: The Enemy Is AIDS, And Complacency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DOROTHY (NEE BRINDEL)
description: FRIEDMAN-Dorothy (nee Brindel), on June 20, 2001. Loving sister of Billy and his wife, Ruth. Dear friend of Dulce and Rebecca. Interment will be in Reedsville, PA.

title: Myth of Alligator Is Dispelled When Team Captures Caiman
description: The Central Park alligator, which has mesmerized New Yorkers all week, was captured easily and efficiently last night, in the glare of dozens of television news cameras -- and just in time for the 11 o'clock news.

title: In Hazy, Humid Houston, the Mosquitoes Are Winning. Big.
description: Clarence Watkins, a head lineman for Reliant Energy, the local utility, considers himself at war.

title: Budget Leaders Reach Pact, Keeping Rebates
description: Legislative budget leaders said today that they had reached agreement on a new spending plan for New Jersey that preserves two election-year property-tax rebates without increasing other taxes or fees.

title: Able Hero With Nerves (And Body) Of Steel
description: ''W.I.S.O.R,'' the title of Michel Negroponte's witty, information-packed documentary, is an acronym for Welding and Inspection Steam Operations Robot. The eight-foot-long, 700-pound device, which has 12 legs, was recently created by Honeybee Robotics to go underground and repair New York City's decaying steam system. Built in the late 19th century and consisting of pipes ranging from 16 to 45 inches in diameter, the system, spanning 103 miles below the streets, is one of the miracles of modern technology.

title: Spain, Portugal and Morocco
description: Through October, Petrabax Vacations is dropping prices on nine different escorted tours of Spain, Portugal and Morocco. The discounts, which can range as high as $360 a person, are for two people traveling together and are for land costs only (air fare extra); tours range from 8 to 18 days and cost $638 to $1,443 a person. The longest and most expensive: the 18-day Grandioso, through Spain and Portugal, has five departures June 16 to Oct. 13. The shortest: Heart and Sol, eight days in Spain with stops in Madrid, Cordoba, Seville, Granada, Toledo and Aranjuez. There are five departures June 16 to Oct. 13. Information: (800) 634-1188 or www.petrabax.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, BERNARD
description: MANDELBAUM-Bernard. Never was there a friend more beloved nor so endeared. We enjoyed his love and appreciated his wonderful attributes for over 50 years. Our sympathy goes to his entire family. Nat & Estelle Roth

title: CHANGES IN MANAGEMENT PREDICTED AT FORD
description: Ford Motor's leaders are putting the finishing touches on some management changes in preparation for a board meeting next month, people close to the company said this week. W. Wayne Booker, 66, Ford's vice chairman, and Henry D. G. Wallace, 55, the chief financial officer, are expected to retire, something both men have been wanting to do for personal reasons, these people said. Martin Inglis, 50, the vice president for Ford brand operations in North America, is the top candidate to replace Mr. Wallace, while Nick Scheele, 57, the chairman of Ford of Europe, will replace Mr. Inglis. Ford declined to comment. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: The Battle Over the Murals of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DYNEGY CORP., Houston, a power and natural-gas trader, said it planned to buy back as much as $250 million, or 6 million shares, of common stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISSELSON, WILLIAM J.
description: NISSELSON-William J. On Tuesday, June 19, 2001 at age 56. Chief Operating Officer of Sound One, Inc., Bill Nisselson was a major figure in the New York post-production film world. Widely admired for his support of the independent film community, his warmth, generosity and humor touched the lives of many in and beyond the film industry. He is survived by his wife Susan Diederich, his mother Herta Danis, his sister Jane Assimakopoulos, his step-daughter Alana Vidal and his nieces Anna Papaioannou and Daphne Assimakopoulos. Services at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 Street, New York, N.Y. on Thursday, June 28, 2001 at 6:00PM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Independent Feature Project at 104 West 29th Street, New York, New York 10001.

title: National Briefing
description: MIDWEST</B

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Convention Site Developer Chosen
description: The selection of a developer to design and build the major part of Adriaen's Landing, a proposed $771 million convention and retail center, was announced yesterday. The developer, Capitol Properties Associates, was chosen from 10 candidates after the state dropped another developer last month. Capitol Properties owns Constitution Plaza, a major retail center in Hartford. The state will contribute $12 million toward the new plan, which includes 240 luxury apartments and 170,000 square feet of stores and restaurants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 13 about an effort to sell several Loews movie theaters in the New York region included an erroneous opening year provided by a real estate agency for the Elmwood, in Elmhurst, Queens. Originally known as the Queensboro, it opened in 1928, not 1910.

title: A New Tax-Cut Rampage
description: After passing an unfair and unaffordable tax cut last month, Congress ought to have gotten tax cuts out of its system for awhile. But now, with White House encouragement, Republican leaders are talking about enacting yet another round of tax bills that would use up what little is left of the federal surplus over the next 10 years, squandering any chance at all of doing more for health, education and the environment. The proposed cuts would be attached to separate pieces of legislation raising the minimum wage and reforming health maintenance organizations. In offering them, lawmakers are setting a grotesque new standard for irresponsible budgeting.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Media Crackdown
description: In the second stage of a crackdown on the news media, the Fair Trade Commission announced fines of $18.6 million against 13 news organizations it said had engaged in unfair trading practices. Major newspapers critical of the government of President Kim Dae Jung for his efforts at reconciliation with North Korea as well as his economic policies got the biggest penalties. Dong-A Ilbo, Korea's third-largest newspaper, was fined $4.77 million. A day earlier, the National Tax Service imposed nearly $400 million in penalties on 23 media organizations accused of tax evasion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: ICAHN REVOKES $181 MILLION BID FOR NATIONAL AIRLINES
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn has withdrawn his bid of $181.5 million to buy National Airlines out of bankruptcy after the airline's board rejected the offer last week, Mr. Icahn's lawyer said yesterday. Mr. Icahn offered $22.5 million, assumption of $43 million in ticket liability and $100 million in operating money as part of his bid for National, said Edward Weisfelner, a New York bankruptcy lawyer representing Mr. Icahn. National's board refused to present the bid to the bankruptcy judge overseeing the airline's Chapter 11 reorganization, Mr. Weisfelner said. National, based in Las Vegas, filed for bankruptcy protection in December.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Liberty to Buy Some Deutsche Telekom Cable Systems
description: To further expand its holdings overseas, the Liberty Media Corporation, controlled by John C. Malone, is acquiring cable TV systems with 10 million subscribers from Deutsche Telekom for about $4.7 billion.

title: Roger Clinton Paints Himself As Easy Target
description: Eager to dispel the notion that he had done anything to be ashamed of, a feisty Roger Clinton told Larry King last night that he thought his 1985 conviction on cocaine charges and year spent in a federal penitentiary made him an ''easy target'' for those who wanted to get former President Bill Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a finding that New York City was in contempt of a court order for its treatment of homeless people with H.I.V. and AIDS misstated the date of the order at one point. It was issued in 1999, not last month.

title: McEnroe Still Picks Sampras
description: John McEnroe said yesterday that the seven-time champion Pete Sampras is still the man to beat at Wimbledon, which starts next week.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Adoption Rights Passed
description: The House passed a bill that would give future adopted children the right to information about their birth parents when they turn 19. The information would include a copy of their birth certificate, information on their biological parents' social and medical histories, and why they were given up for adoption.

title: A Rite That Bonds the Generations
description: Freud is famous for wondering, ''What do women want?'' He might have asked a much tougher question: ''Why do men fish?''

title: Art and Oil Are at Center of Montana Fight
description: As remote as this place seems here in south-central Montana, a rambling valley of sagebrush and towering rocks far from any town, one is never truly alone. Looking on from scores of vantage points are colorful images of men and animals, among other illustrations, that were painted on the rock walls perhaps 1,000 years ago.

title: In the economic slump, Madison Avenue carries on. Deals, new campaigns and layoffs.
description: AMID the pervasive gloom on Madison Avenue, the business of advertising goes on as large accounts change agencies, campaigns are approved and deals are made. But the economic slowdown is still having its effects as additional agencies lay off employees.

title: New Global AIDS Fund May Copy TB Drug-Buying Plan
description: The price of drugs for tuberculosis fell by more than one-third when the World Health Organization set up a program for buying them in bulk and asked drug companies to compete against one another to offer the best price, agency officials said yesterday.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Pledge

title: Chicago's Preschools
description: To the Editor:

title: KODAK MAKES SALE OF $650 MILLION WORTH OF DEBT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company sold $650 million of debt yesterday after delaying the sale for a day because of a bankruptcy-protection filing by a customer. Kodak sold $500 million of five-year notes at $998.10 per $1,000 face amount to yield 6.42 percent, or 1.75 percentage points more than United States Treasury securities of comparable maturity. The company also sold $150 million of 15-month notes with a floating interest rate. Kodak, based in Rochester, said Tuesday that it would take a $75 million second-quarter charge for bills not paid by Wolf Camera Inc., the Atlanta-based operator of more than 500 retail stores.

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was John O'Neil.

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was John O'Neil.

title: Article 2001062290300807725 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Sports of The Times; Soccer Lads About to Be Discovered
description: WE were driving back to Boston on Wednesday night from the latest United States soccer victory. You know, another 2-0 bombardment of one of those pesky Caribbean nations that used to torment the Yanks.

title: Predraft Trade By Nets Unlikely
description: Calling a predraft trade unlikely, Rod Thorn, the president of the Nets, is holding the No. 7 pick and waiting to see how the landscape changes before next Wednesday's N.B.A. draft.

title: Hopes Grow In Brooklyn, Staten Island
description: The Staten Island Yankees and the Brooklyn Cyclones are in the big city but still a long, difficult journey from the big leagues.

title: Ward on Top, This Time Without Controversy
description: At last year's McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship, Wendy Ward held a share of the lead after three rounds and trailed by only one stroke on the final day when she suffered a freakish misfortune on the 13th green.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about repairs planned for the Long Island Rail Road's new locomotives misstated the number that had developed cracks in the steel frames supporting their engines. It is several, as the article said, not all 46.

title: Bob Franks in New Jersey
description: Republicans in New Jersey face an unambiguous choice in next Tuesday's gubernatorial primary between a Republican moderate and a candidate with strident and untested views. Bob Franks is clearly the better qualified of the two. Mr. Franks has shown himself to be a pragmatist with the experience and temperament to carry the party's banner admirably in the November election.

title: Pondering Terrorist's Execution, Jury Weighs Notes Found in Cell
description: A federal jury in Manhattan was read notes yesterday that prosecutors said were found in a jail cell last fall and involved a plan by inmates charged with terrorism to take hostages and possibly free other prisoners.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Battle Over the Murals of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Joint Venture
description: Hynix Semiconductor, struggling to get creditors to roll over $4 billion in debts, is forming a joint venture with two Chinese companies to produce a type of liquid crystal display. Final terms have not been determined, but Hynix said it would sell its unit that makes the display panels to the joint venture for $400 million to $700 million, with $350 million of it in cash and the rest in an equity stake. The partners are the Beijing Orient Electronics Group, based in Beijing, and the Cando Corporation of Taiwan. The unit will make display panels known as thin-film transistor liquid crystal displays, a business that accounted for 4.2 percent of Hynix's sales of $8.2 billion last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; All Aboard? Designers Want to Put Generation Y in Box Cars
description: THE decidedly youngish crowd filing into the blink-182 concert at Roseland in New York a few weeks ago wore spiky hair and baggy pants. T-shirts bearing parodies of logos and brands were much in evidence. Tide became Jive; Snickers became Slackers. Honda had sponsored blink-182's tour and raffled off a silver Civic coupe, featuring the band's logo, which stood in front of the hall.

title: The Longest Ballot
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001062290376222214 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: American Tower Increases Loss Estimate
description: The American Tower Corporation, an operator of about 14,000 wireless communications and broadcasting towers in North America, said today that losses for the second quarter and the year would be larger than expected because of lower revenue at its Verestar unit.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Biotech Drugs Show Promise as Psoriasis Treatments
description: New drugs made using biotechnology will soon offer what could be the first safe, long-term treatments for psoriasis, doctors at a conference devoted to the disease said yesterday.

title: U.S. Report Faults Agency That Oversees Investor Claims
description: The Securities Investor Protection Corporation, set up to protect the nation's investors from theft or fraud if their brokerage firms collapse, has significant deficiencies, according to a study by the General Accounting Office released yesterday. In addition, the Securities and Exchange Commission, charged with oversight of the corporation, has been lax in its scrutiny of SIPC activities, the report said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I told a co-worker, 'You know, we need to get these mosquitoes and find out how they get in the building, ride up the elevator, go up to the 27th floor and find me.'''

title: McNabb Won't Run From Demands
description: The spotlight radiates on Donovan McNabb, and it is hot. With the Eagles' final minicamp recently behind them, and with their training camp debut set for July 27, McNabb has been shuttling between interviews, photo shoots and fund-raisers, mindful to keep football at the forefront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRY, CAROL BERNSTEIN
description: FERRY-Carol Bernstein. Manhattanville College and the Connie Hogarth Center for Social Action mourn the passing of Carol Ferry, activist and philanthropist for peace and social justice. We will sorely miss her intelligence, passion and courage.

title: Dads Love the Praise
description: To the Editor:

title: DREYFUS WILL PAY $20.5 MILLION TO SETTLE LAWSUIT
description: A federal judge has approved a $20.5 million settlement of a shareholder lawsuit that accused a former fund manager for the Dreyfus Corporation of buying stock for two mutual funds in companies whose shares he also owned. The settlement, approved by Judge Harold Baer of United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, settles accusations that Michael Schonberg, the former manager of the Dreyfus Premier Aggressive Growth Fund and the Dreyfus Aggressive Growth Fund, engaged in front-running, which is prohibited because it creates a potential conflict of interest. Dreyfus, the mutual fund unit of the Mellon Financial Corporation, agreed last year to pay $3 million to settle civil charges in the case. Dreyfus did not admit wrongdoing in either case.

title: India's Place at the Table
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Announces a Developer For a Complex at Its Former Plant
description: Five years after shutting its automotive assembly plant on the Hudson River here, the General Motors Corporation today announced its selection of a development partner for a project that would include housing, shops, office space and a hotel conference center.

title: Dance's Black Stream
description: Without black artists, American dance would have been very different. The PBS documentary ''Free to Dance'' traces black performers and choreographers from pioneers including Katherine Dunham and Alvin Ailey to young talents like Sheri Williams, above, of the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Trade Accord With U.S.
description: Vietnam began the process of ratifying a trade agreement with the United States, sending it to the president, who now can submit it to the National Assembly. On June 8, President Bush signed the agreement in Washington and sent the bill to Congress for approval. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Shlunkendorf Journal; To Mesmerize a German, You Take Asparagus . . .
description: Schlunkendorf is not a name evocative of things of beauty, but the white asparagus that grows here is beautiful indeed and has ignited passions that Germans tend to reserve for music.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Bill Supports Power Plants
description: The Legislature approved a compromise plan to encourage the building of power plants. The bill removes obstacles for utilities to build their own power plants in Iowa and allows municipal utilities to jointly build plants. It has been 18 years since a large power plant was built in Iowa. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Hiro Yamagata
description: Ace Gallery

title: Will This Slowdown Spare Housing, or Just Hit It Late?
description: THIS time, it is different.

title: 3 Die and 15 Are Injured in Brooklyn Row House Fire
description: Three people were killed and 15 others were injured -- seven of them firefighters -- when a crowded Brooklyn row house caught fire while its occupants were asleep early yesterday.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Court Blocks Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court blocked the execution of a triple murderer scheduled to die today pending a review of claims that mentally retarded murderers should not be executed. The inmate, Glenn William Holladay, 51, was convicted in the 1986 shooting deaths of his former wife, her boyfriend and a 16-year-old neighbor. The Supreme Court is considering a case from North Carolina that deals with executing mentally retarded inmates, and Mr. Holladay's lawyers contend that he is mentally retarded. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Home Video: The Force Is With the DVD
description: With names and numbers erupting on DVD, studios are weighing in with their most prized possessions. On Tuesday Fox announced the Oct. 16 release of "Star Wars: Episode 1  The Phantom Menace," the first of the four "Star Wars" films to appear on compact disc. On Oct. 9 the three "Godfather" films will be available from Paramount.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: League To Let School Play
description: After a month of debate over a decision by a mostly white Roman Catholic athletic league in Chicago to deny admission to the predominantly black St. Sabina grammar school on the city's South Side, the league reversed its decision. In May, the league voted not to accept St. Sabina. Those who rejected the school said they were concerned about safety at games. St. Sabina's priest said the vote betrayed racism. On Wednesday, the league members said they were now satisfied with the safety of the games. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Manager And Collector
description: At the same time there were all those Andy Warhol sightings at flea markets, antiques shops and rummage sales in the 1970's and 80's, Frederick W. Hughes, Warhol's business manager for 25 years, was doing his own shopping.

title: Familiar Shadow In Golf Deal
description: When the PGA Tour completed its current four-year television deal in 1997, Tiger Woods was one month removed from winning the Masters.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Raised
description: The Central Bank Monetary Policy committee of Brazil raised interest rates 1.5 percent to 18.25 percent in an effort to stem inflation caused by a weakening currency. With the real under pressure from fears of a possible devaluation in neighboring Argentina and from a severe energy crisis at home, which is expected to reduce economic growth by as much as half this year, the committee has raised the benchmark rate three percentage points since March.

title: Just Our Imaginations, Running Away
description: Having been chastised by the eminent historian Joseph Ellis for fictionalizing the story of my life in ''Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan,'' I suppose I should feel some satisfaction at the news that he has fictionalized his own. Actually, I feel no joy in Professor Ellis's discomfiture, only a profound sense of unsurprise. Well, of course he's woven the fabric of his life partly out of whole cloth and partly out of the shot silk of fantasy. Don't we all? Can any of us gaze into the bathroom mirror and whisper, ''I never made anything up''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMARATA, ''MONTY''
description: CAMARATA-''Monty''. Berkeley Heights, N.J. Monroe ''Monty'' Anthony Camarata died June 19, 2001 after a long illness. He died at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., surrounded by his family. Monty was the son of Charles and Dorothy (Holtzman) Camarata. He was born and grew up in Newark, N.J. He graduated from Seton Hall College in South Orange, N.J. and Rutgers School of Law-Newark in Newark, N.J., and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII. He owned and operated clothing stores throughout Bergen County, N.J. Monty was a member of the Bergen County Chapter of the Optimists Club, & a frequent volunteer at the Betty Bacharach Rehab Hospital in Pomona, N.J. He was devoted to his wife and daughters, and loved music, especially opera. Throughout his life, Monty rescued and cared for homeless animals of all kinds. He appreciated flowers and gardens, and enjoyed the simple pleasures of everyday life with his family and friends. He is survived by his wife of fiftysix years, Jeannine (Honnegger) Camarata, and two daughters, Roberta Renard of Summit, N.J. and Jessica Camarata of Denver, CO. A private service was held on Thursday, June 21st for the family at Saint Rocco's Church in Newark. In Monty's memory, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: Themes and Variations, From Funk to Volcanic
description: The saxophonist Joshua Redman's new album, ''Passage of Time'' (Warner Brothers), is conceived as a 54-minute suite, and his quartet played it in its entirety during a JVC Jazz Festival concert on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: Finding Greasy Spoons: To Eat, Not Dine
description: The small coffee shop with a behind-the-counter grill, a simple menu and plain fare is not easy to find in Manhattan these days, but a few persist, including these:

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was John O'Neil.

title: Two Firefighters Are Mourned With Tears and Crisp Salutes
description: With solemn pageantry and ritualized precision, two New York City firefighters were buried yesterday, mourned by their colleagues and families and eulogized for their bravery in losing their lives battling a burning neighborhood hardware store that exploded on Father's Day.

title: Deadlock Over Budget Shows Change In Minnesota
description: Minnesota's reputation as a place that is always Scandinavian clean and orderly is in danger -- at least the part about things always being orderly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIANCARDI, DOMINICK
description: BIANCARDI-Dominick. We will all miss your honesty, decency, thoughtfulness, your wit and style, and your knowledge. Rest in peace, dear friend. Gail and Bruce.

title: Where the Written Word, From Persia to Brooklyn, Gets Respect and Care
description: Books can be short-lived objects. They become lost, worn out, burned and rained on. Many just molder away on the shelf. But some are lucky enough to end up in libraries like the one at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, where they lead active lives and receive, when needed, conservational T.L.C.

title: Morgan Stanley's Earnings Decline 36%
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said yesterday that its profit fell 36 percent in the second quarter of its fiscal year as a slump in stocks slowed underwriting, mergers and equity trading. Nevertheless, the earnings beat Wall Street forecasts.

title: Residential Real Estate; Chelsea Is on the March Northward
description: A 12-story mixed-income rental building is nearing completion at the northeast corner of West 30th Street and Ninth Avenue, continuing the northward push of housing in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood.

title: Micrel Warns on Profit
description: Micrel Inc., which makes chips used in cell phones, computers and fiber optic equipment, said second-quarter profit would fall more than expected after orders declined. Micrel will break even in the second quarter or have a ''slightly positive'' profit, excluding acquisition-related costs of $10 million, the company said in a statement. Micrel had been expected to earn 5 cents a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. It was the second consecutive quarter that Micrel reduced its profit estimate. Chip makers are slowing production and laying off workers as customers use inventories that grew amid a slowdown in economic growth. Shares of Micrel, based in San Jose, declined $2.61, to $25.20. Shares have dropped 49 percent in the last year.

title: Bush Demands Senate Changes On Patient Bill
description: President Bush threatened today to veto the patients' rights bill now on the Senate floor. Democrats vowed to forge ahead with the legislation and accused Mr. Bush of standing with the health insurance industry against the American public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLESHNER, GALLIE
description: FLESHNER-Gallie. Age 87. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Lenore Braverman and her husband Ernest and Joyce Kaplan and her husband Melvin. Dearest Grandma of Randi Manoleas and her late husband Billy, Peter Braverman, Stacie Magnus and her husband Steven, Lisa Shapiro and Jessica Klein and her husband Joel. Wonderful great-grandma of Alyxandra Magnus. Devoted sister of Loretta Isler and the late Rosalind Stern. Contributions to Congregation Agudath Achim Anshe Chesed, 641 Delafield Avenue, Staten Island, New York, 10310 or Congregation B'Nai Jeshurun, 275 Martling Avenue, Staten Island, New York 10310.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Ministers Oppose Gay Stance
description: Thirty-two United Methodist ministers in eastern Ohio signed a statement dissenting from the 8.4-million-member denomination's position that homosexuality is ''incompatible with Christian teaching.'' In 2000, the church's top policy-making body affirmed prohibitions on ordaining gay clergy and blessing same-sex unions. Gustav Niebuhr (NYT)

title: Yugoslavia Stalls on Aiding War Crimes Court
description: Opposition from its Montenegrin partners forced the Yugoslav government today to withdraw a bill regulating cooperation with the international war crimes tribunal, a move that might actually hasten the extradition of former President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Court Reverses Ruling On a U.P.S. Tax Shelter

title: 2 Courts Reject I.R.S. Efforts to Limit Tax Shelters
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta yesterday reversed a 1999 ruling that United Parcel Service engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes each year since 1984.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Beach Policy Complaint
description: A new beach policy at Cove Island Park has rankled at least one longtime Stamford resident, William F. Buckley Jr. Mandatory parking permits used to be sold daily, but are now sold only on the weekend, in part to discourage nonresidents from using the beach, said Frank M. Fedeli, who handles citizen complaints for the park. Mr. Buckley, who has been a Stamford resident for 50 years, said he was frustrated on a recent Monday when he and a friend could not get a permit. ''Are others aware of this bureaucratization of Stamford life?'' he wrote in a June 13 letter to The Stamford Advocate. ''Shall we mount a crusade?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, DR. RUTH LEDER
description: SHAPIRO-Dr. Ruth Leder. On June 17, 2001, at age 81. Psychologist. Beloved stepmother of Richard Shapiro and his wife, Patricia, and step-grandmother of Seth and Alex. Also survived by her nephew Drew Leder and her companion for fourteen years, Jacques Solta. Interment is private. Memorial service July 7th, 2001. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: John Lee Hooker, Bluesman, Is Dead at 83
description: John Lee Hooker, the bluesman whose stark, one-chord boogies were some of the feistiest and most desolate songs of the 20th century, died yesterday in his sleep at his home in Los Altos, Calif., said his agent, Mike Kappus. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HARRY B.
description: STEIN-Harry B. Passed away on June 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Fischbach). Devoted father of Juliet Stein, Susan and Martin Danoff, Nina and Irwin Wolf. Cherished grandfather of Linda and Michael Perrella, Deborah Chesbrough, Stephen Salee and Hans Lupold, Douglas Danoff, Jennifer Danoff and Michael Bernstein. Adored great grandfather of Samuel and Joseph Perrella. A mighty oak has fallen. A giant in the lumber business for over 75 years; the Founder of Huntington Materials and Chairman of Bayport Lumber Corporation; a graduate of New York University & its Business School; the Founder and Past President of Temple Beth-El in Huntington, L.I. and former Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Suburbia Federal Savings and Loan Association. He died quietly in his sleep in his 93rd year leaving a legacy of quiet strength, and immplacable moral standards, dignity, intellect and love for his family and friends. He was the patriarch of our family and we love him forever and cherish his memory. The funeral will be held on Sunday, June 24th at Riverside Funeral Home, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 516-487-8600

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rebates Go To Child Support
description: Federal tax rebate checks for about 70,000 people are expected to be withheld by the federal government because of back child support, the state's welfare agency said. About 644,000 child-support cases were in arrears last year, a spokeswoman for the agency said. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a requirement that medical students in West Virginia receive training in rural areas referred incorrectly to an institution that participates. It is West Virginia University, not the University of West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TISCHLER, DAVID
description: TISCHLER-David. Gifted mathematician, dedicated Dad, beloved son of Ed and Sara, cherished twin to Susan, forever missed, forever loved. Katy and Danny

title: Metro Business Briefing | Manufacturing Zones Proposed
description: New York's manufacturing sector employs about 250,000 people -- not so much in the smokestack industries of the past, but in printing houses, bakeries and other small businesses. These days, however, land zoned for manufacturing is often used for other purposes, like superstores, forcing many manufacturers to compete for increasingly costly space. A report released yesterday by the Municipal Art Society and the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development calls for creating manufacturing zones, where residential and commercial uses would be banned or restricted. The report also urges the city to provide incentives to keep manufacturers from leaving, including help in reducing noise, fumes and odors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMANN, DE BARANYAVAR PETER
description: ULLMANN-de Baranyavar Peter. It is with deep sadness that we have to announce the death of our beloved brother, brother-in-law and uncle, died on June 17, 2001 in New York. Born on August 21, 1929 in Budapest, Hungary. Survived by Elisabeth von Merey, nee Baronesse von Ullmann, children and grandchildren, Karin Baroness von Ullmann, nee Baronesse von Oppenheim, Ilona Countess von Krockow, nee Baronesse von Ullmann and family Georg Baron von Ullmann and family. Funeral service and burial will be held at Cemetery Melaten, entrance Piusstrasse in Cologne, Germany on Friday, June 29, at 12:00 PM.

title: Councilman Got Gifts, Says Witness In Trial
description: Councilman Thomas V. Ognibene acknowledged yesterday that he had accepted an upgrade on a Hawaii hotel room and a set of fishing poles from a building industry consultant who is at the center of a corruption inquiry. He said, however, that he did not ask for the items and did not consider them gifts.

title: Giuliani Supports Rent Board On Approval of Larger Increases
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani supports the Rent Guidelines Board's last-minute decision for higher rent increases for the 2.3 million residents of rent-stabilized apartments, his aides said yesterday, citing rising energy costs.

title: A Curious Young Scholar And His Objects of Passion
description: Atlantis:

title: Pride, Hope and Hardship In the Land of Cotton
description: ''It's a different world here,'' says Reggie Barnes, superindendent of the West Tallahatchie School District in the Mississippi Delta. Mr. Barnes, whose patience and discipline seem to mask a deep reservoir of anger, is one of the heroes of ''LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton,'' a moving documentary by Susan Froemke, Deborah Dickson and Albert Mays les that opens today at the Quad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ALBERT
description: GINSBERG-Albert. The Officers and Directors of Chamah, the international organization to provide education and humanitarian aide for Russian Jewry, note with deep sadness the passing of our dear friend, Albert Ginsberg. His contributions to Russian Jewry and the State of Israel is unparalleled. His kindness and gentle heart will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Pearl Ginsberg, Liane, Larry, Hilary and grandchildren. Sanford Bruckner, Chair Emeritus Mitchell Benerofe, International Chairman Paul Sirotkin Moshiach Chudaitov Binyomin Malachovski Hillel Zaltzman Executive Committee Chamah New York Jerusalem Moscow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILNER, JEAN
description: MILNER-Jean. Died at her home at age 91 shortly following the passing of her beloved husband, Jimmy. Beloved mother of Mary Wittner and Robert Milner and mother-law of Saralee Milner and Andrew Wittner. Cherished grandmother of Diane Wittner and Jon Acheson, Pamela and Doug D'Alexander, and Steve and Jane Wittner. Adored great grandmother of Gabriel, Baird, Dominic, Steven and Beth. She died as she lived, with humor, strength and fully possessed of her extraordinary intellect.

title: Masters Coverage Will Be Expanded
description: The Augusta National Golf Club has tended to hold to the traditions of the Masters, never allowing 18-hole broadcast coverage. CBS has started its Sunday coverage at 4 p.m. Eastern with the leaders at about the fifth hole.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE FALLS. Gasoline dropped after a pipeline stopped accepting new shipments from the Gulf Coast to the East, a sign of abundant supplies. In New York, gasoline for July delivery fell 1.94 cents, to 77.09 cents a gallon.

description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Dr. Rodolphe Coigney, 89, Hero Of Wartime French Resistance
description: Dr. Rodolphe Lucien Coigney, a French resistance hero who near the end of World War II helped persuade Heinrich Himmler, the SS chief, to release French women held in the Ravensbrck concentration camp, died on June 6 in New York. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROFF, ISRAEL
description: STROFF-Israel. On June 21, 2001. Longtime dearest companion of Joan Bernstein. Loving father of Reggie Waldren and her husband Peter. Services today at 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: State Is Expected to Limit Drivers' Use of Cell Phones
description: New York would become the first state in the nation to ban the use of hand-held cellular telephones while driving, under a bill the governor and legislative leaders agreed to late tonight.

title: Willie Cole -- 'Game Show'
description: Bronx Museum of the Arts

title: Caspian Ban Gives Iran a Caviar Corner
description: ASTRAKHAN, Russia  The UN's wildlife-protection arm on Thursday banned the fishing of sturgeon from most of the Caspian Sea and its rivers as of next year, leaving Iran with a monopoly on legal caviar until the other four countries that border the sea prove they are stemming the massive poaching trade.

title: Bush Leans Against Support for Stem-Cell Research, Aides Say
description: Under pressure from anti-abortion groups and Roman Catholic leaders, the White House is leaning toward revoking regulations issued by the Clinton administration that allow federally sponsored biomedical research using cells from human embryos, administration officials say.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft XP Draws A Warning
description: The state prosecutors who joined the United States Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft said they found the software maker's new operating system ''troubling'' and potentially anticompetitive. Two of the attorneys general, Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and Tom Miller of Iowa, said they were concerned about Microsoft's plans to bundle new features into the Windows XP operating system. Microsoft is appealing a breakup order by a federal judge who found that the company had illegally maintained a Windows monopoly. A ruling by the appeals court could come at any time. The attorneys general have ''no current plans for a second lawsuit'' against the software maker, they said in a statement.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Credit Cards For College Students
description: Public forum on merchandising credit cards to State University and City University students. Room 1920, 19th floor, 250 Broadway, near City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Information: (518) 455-2024.

title: Parents of Missing Intern Ask Her Lawmaker Friend for Help
description: The parents of Chandra Ann Levy, the government intern whose disappearance more than seven weeks ago has attracted national attention because of her friendship with her hometown congressman, announced today that they were opening a private investigation and urged the legislator, Representative Gary A. Condit of California, to meet with them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Steel Purchase
description: The largest steelmaker in China, the Baoshan Iron and Steel Company, said it would buy the world's second-largest steelworks from its parent for 17.9 billion yuan ($2.2 billion). The company said it would use both cash and loans to pay for the plant, which will increase its output by a third, to an annual 10 million metric tons. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Softbank Buying Access Provider
description: The Softbank Corporation said it had acquired more than two-thirds of the financially troubled Tokyo Metallic Communications Corporation, gaining a larger foothold in a high-speed Internet access market that is expected to grow to as much as 35 billion yen ($283 million) by March. Softbank, which is based in Tokyo and is the biggest Internet investor in Tokyo, did not provide details of the purchase. Softbank plans to provide high-speed services to individual users and is investing in Internet start-up companies focusing on broadband delivery. ''Broadband is a business area where we should place our top priority,'' said Masayoshi Son, above, the billionaire founder of Softbank.

title: House Panel Reprimands A Democrat On Finances
description: The House ethics committee today issued a written rebuke to Representative Earl F. Hilliard, Democrat of Alabama, for a variety of campaign-finance abuses, including converting thousands of dollars in campaign donations to personal use.

description: Brian Cashman makes phone calls the way a fly fisherman casts his line, over and over, mostly without ever feeling a pull at the other end, occasionally sensing a tug, and maybe, once or twice a summer, landing a whopper.

title: The Big City; Some Pointers From a Letter Never Written
description: Ashbel Green, Professor Ellis's editor and a vice president at Knopf . . . said Professor Ellis had once considered writing a book about Vietnam. Mr. Green said he did not encourage that idea in part because there had been so many books on Vietnam and in part ''because I've had experience with authors who go totally out of their territory and don't do as well.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Long-Distance Petition
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it had requested federal approval to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania. Verizon is barred from offering long-distance and data services to its local customers unless it can prove that competition exists in the local telephone market. A Verizon spokesman said about one million telephone lines in Pennsylvania -- roughly 14 percent -- were served by competitors. The Federal Communications Commission must rule on the application within 90 days. The F.C.C. has cleared the way for the company to offer long-distance service in New York and Massachusetts. Verizon is also seeking clearance in Connecticut.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Judge Authorizes Lottery Payout
description: A state court judge ruled on Wednesday that 23 Atlanta-area cab drivers, all of them originally from Ghana, could collect the $49.4 million jackpot they won in a May 4 lottery drawing. Another judge had ruled that the money could not be paid pending the resolution of a lawsuit filed by seven other Ghanaian cabbies who claim to have participated in the lottery pool that bought the ticket. The lawsuit has yet to be settled. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Be Content With Small Change
description: No one picks up pennies anymore. I thought the market downturn would change that, but I find more of them than ever, and at a minimum a found penny is a lucky penny. Three or four times a week I find a penny that people just walk right by. I checked my impression with a friend who lives in Washington, and he reports that near where he works, at 19th and M, there is a low wall where panhandlers sit. He's picked up pennies on the sidewalk there that they don't bother with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, JOHN P.
description: McMAHON-John P., 64. Of Katonah, NY. Died on June 16, 2001 in London, England. Senior Dean at the Harvey School, Katonah. Brother of Joseph G. McMahon of Crofton, MD., and Janet Clinton of NYC and New Orleans, LA. Brother-in-law of Kay McMahon of Crofton, MD. Uncle of Joanne Dimson of Chappaqua, NY, and Susan, Beth, Joseph, Paul, Matthew and Rosemary McMahon all of Crofton, MD. Memorial visiting hours will be at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, Route 202 and Route 100, Somers, NY on Tuesday June 26 from 7-9PM. Memorial Service will be held at St. Lukes Episcopal Church on Wednesday at 4:30PM. Interment will follow at St. Lukes Memorial Garden. In lieu of flowers contributions in memory may be made to John P. McMahon Scholarship Fund, c/o Carolyn Harting, Esq, POB 218, 456 Old Post Road, Bedford, NY 10506.

title: Nuanced Conflict Over Euro in Britain
description: It was billed as a major pronouncement on currency policy from the freshly reelected Labor government. Bankers and dignitaries from the City, Britain's Wall Street, gathered last night to hear Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown lay out what he called a ''considered and cautious'' approach to jettisoning the pound and adopting the euro.

title: U.N. Agency Won't Ban Caspian Sea Caviar
description: To the delight of epicures but the annoyance of ecologists, the United Nations agency that oversees trade in endangered species today rejected a ban on Caspian Sea caviar proposed by a scientific advisory body.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond Net Up 28%
description: Bed Bath & Beyond Inc., the home-furnishings retailer, said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 28 percent because sales climbed as a slowing economy forced competitors out of business.

description: ERNST-Howard L. Died unexpectedly on June 18, 2001. Funeral arrangements are pending.

description: MALLON-Wanda. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our beloved & devoted secretary for over 40 years, Wanda Mallon. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Toni Wiener, President

title: Schools Ignore Plan to Thwart Sex Abuse
description: Seven years after a citywide commission recommended steps to prevent the sexual abuse of students in the public schools, many of the panel's most important recommendations, including better background checks of prospective teachers, have yet to be put into effect.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Term Limit Repeal On Ballot
description: The New Orleans City Council called a referendum to determine whether the city charter should be changed to allow Mayor Marc H. Morial to seek a third term. The Council acted after determining that Mr. Morial had collected more than the 10,000 signatures needed to get a referendum on the ballot. The referendum will be held on Oct. 20; if it passes, Mr. Morial can run next year. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: 'Four Abstract Classicists'
description: Gary Snyder

title: The Black Stream of Modern Dance
description: It has been 14 years since the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., began ''Black Tradition in American Modern Dance,'' a project to preserve and disseminate classics by black American choreographers. One element of the program was to underwrite revivals of those classics.

title: Third Auto Insurer Files to Pull Out of New Jersey
description: A day after the news that a second New Jersey auto insurer had filed plans to leave the state, state regulators confirmed today that a small insurer had received permission to stop accepting new customers.

title: Emap of Britain Draws Bids In Sale of U.S. Magazines
description: Emap, the British publishing company, received formal bids -- the largest slightly more than $550 million -- for its United States magazine business yesterday, including titles like Motor Trend and Teen, executives close to the auction said.

title: Leif Kath
description: DCA Gallery

title: Bush to Act on Park Pollution
description: The Bush administration is preparing to approve a Clinton-era plan to clamp down on pollutants from power plants that have spoiled vistas in many national parks. Page A15.

title: Flaws Seen in System For Child-Item Recalls
description: A consumer advocacy group said yesterday that 18 percent of the 595 hot lines set up for recalled children's products since 1990 no longer functioned properly.

title: Phone Stake In Russia Held by Soros May Unravel
description: A $1.9 billion investment in a Russian telephone company, half of which came from the American billionaire George Soros, may soon unravel if a crucial partner bails out as threatened.

title: A DREAM FOR BROTHERS
description: Joe McDonald and his brother Brian are hoping that history will put them in the company of Jesse Owens, Jackie Robinson, Arthur Ashe and Tiger Woods.

title: CABOT OIL AND GAS AGREES TO BUY CODY FOR $230 MILLION
description: The Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation, a natural gas explorer and producer, agreed to buy the Cody Company for $230 million in cash and stock to increase gas and oil reserves in Texas and Louisiana. Cabot will pay $168 million in cash and $62 million in stock or cash at its option. The purchase will increase Cabot's oil and gas holdings by 16 percent, adding 166 billion cubic feet of gas and oil reserves. Cabot is based in Houston. Cody, which is based in Denver, has a daily production of about 50 million cubic feet, which comes mainly from natural gas.

title: 'Pearl Harbor' in Japan: Love or War?
description: The first screening of the movie ''Pearl Harbor'' in Japan today did not quite have the roar of the original event, but that was not for want of trying.

title: Carter's Advice to Piazza: Consider a Position Switch
description: Gary Carter was diplomatic yet direct while discussing the possibility of Mike Piazza switching from catcher to another position. Carter has been there. He knows what it is like to catch 100 games or more for 12 straight seasons. He knows what it is like to undergo eight knee surgeries and have more dents on his body than a steel drum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, LEWIS B.
description: SCOTT-Lewis B., 80. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, died June 15. Formerly Officer and Director of AAA in NYC until 1980. Graduate of New York Law School, 1960.

title: Paolo Taviani, 88, a Founder of Italy's Republic
description: Paolo Emilio Taviani, a wartime resistance fighter and a founding father of the Italian Republic and the Christian Democratic Party that dominated it in the postwar era, died on Monday in Rome. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HILDA
description: LOEB-Hilda. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to the families of our departed member. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was John O'Neil.

title: Macedonian Military Steps Up Its Assault of Albanian Rebels
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 22  Macedonian forces launched a heavy offensive today against Albanian rebel positions just north of the capital, Skopje, breaking the tentative cease-fire in the southern Balkan republic and leaving diplomatic efforts for a peace agreement in tatters.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Forecast
description: Europe's leading chemical company BASF A.G. warned that it would miss its earnings target for the second quarter and would have to cut capital spending and close facilities. The cutbacks are a result of higher prices for oil and other raw materials and cautious purchasing by its customers amid the global economic slowdown, BASF said. BASF, which is based in Ludwigshafen, Germany, said its operating income would be flat this quarter, but it still expected operating income to rise 10 percent for the years from 2000 to 2002. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: The Weather Takes a Big Lead After the First Day at the Buick
description: The first day of summer was wet, long and frustrating at the Buick Classic.

title: The Greasy Spoon Loses the Grease and Gains a Certain Distinction
description: One Sunday afternoon recently I took the A train to nearly the end of the line, near Dyckman Street. I had been invited to a play in a church auditorium featuring my grandchildren Benj and Ellie. On Dyckman Street I stopped at a local coffee shop for the caffeine fix that is basic good sense when you're about to undergo two and a half hours of children's theater. Luck was with me: I stumbled into the Cloisters Diner, a stellar greasy spoon.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: European Union: A Deal With China
description: China has agreed to open its markets further to European companies in service industries like insurance, telecommunications and retailing as it prepares to join the World Trade Organization. The agreement expands access for chain retailers; allows new competition in maritime, aviation and transportation insurance; and lifts restrictions on selecting telecommunications joint-venture partners. China may now gain membership as soon as November, a spokesman for the trade group said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the special E-Business section on June 13 with an article about the development of the Fortran computer language was published in error. It showed the first programming class for the I.B.M. 704 computing system in 1956, not the I.B.M. team that developed Fortran in the late 1950's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the movie stuntman Russell M. Saunders on Sunday omitted the given name and occupation of a woman who commented on his career. She was Paula Boelsems, his longtime acrobatic partner.

title: A Realist's Reflections on Foreign Policy
description: DOES AMERICA NEED A FOREIGN POLICY?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Visor Maker's Stock Surges
description: Shares of Handspring, the manufacturer of the Visor line of hand-held computers and phone modules, rose 75 cents, or 15.6 percent, to $5.56, as the company began selling the Visor in South Korea. In addition to other Asian markets, including Singapore, Hong Kong and Taiwan, Visors are sold in North America, Europe, Australia and New Zealand. In April, the company said that third-quarter earnings rose 261 percent from a year earlier. On Wednesday, DataQuill, based in the British Virgin Islands, sued Handspring and the Kyocera Wireless Corporation. The lawsuit, filed in federal court in Chicago, asserts that Handspring's Visorphone and Kyocera's Smartphone use DataQuill's technology. ''We just received notice of it Wednesday afternoon and we're investigating it,'' said Allen Bush, a spokesman for Handspring.

title: New-Era Banks Slip Into the Past; Traditional Wall Street Firms Still Make the Investment Rules
description: Few people have been as driven to knock over the big apple cart on Wall Street as David S. Pottruck, co-chief executive of the Charles Schwab Corporation.

title: Hilliard-Fassel Feud Takes a Bitter Turn
description: The circumstances of Ike Hilliard's recent foot surgery -- already puzzling and controversial -- have also conveyed a touch of the mysterious because of Hilliard's silence. Today Hilliard finally sought to explain himself. His comments, however, will probably not calm the situation or assuage the increasingly strained relationship between Hilliard and the Giants.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: There's an unstated law that says that every new boutique hotel must have its own restaurant, even if it means putting the kitchen in a converted broom closet. This is one bit of New York synergy that won't stop synergizing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPP, LEO
description: LIPP-Leo. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend, died in Sarasota, FL on June 18, 2001. We will miss his warmth, constant friendship and love of life. He mentored many during his years as a leader in the jewelry industry, and was a leader of his community during his retirement. He will be loved and long remembered by those around him. Surviving are his wife Stella, daughter Karen Janowski and husband Ben, son Bruce and wife Colleen, grandchildren Peter Janowski and Chloe Lipp, brother Halley and sister Pearle Gordon. Memorial service held June 22nd in Sarasota. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Monitors Say China Pushes Tibet Monks From Study Site
description: Thousands of Tibetan monks and nuns have been forced to leave a thriving religious study center in the remote mountains of Sichuan Province, along the eastern edge of ethnic Tibetan territory, according to international rights monitors and local officials.

title: Diesel Campaign Wins at Cannes
description: A campaign for the Diesel apparel brand meant to parody a Eurocentric world view has won the Grand Prix in the press and poster competition at the 48th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France.

title: Undermining the Tobacco Case
description: The Bush administration has shown a troubling propensity for putting the interests of industrial campaign backers before its duty to protect public health. The latest case in point is the Justice Department's curious announcement that it will attempt to settle the huge lawsuit against the tobacco industry brought by the Clinton administration two years ago, explaining in part that it thinks the case is weak.

title: Speaking for Themselves With Tears and Laughter
description: ''High school is definitely not like in the movies,'' says a blue-gowned and mortarboarded valedictorian toward the end of ''Chain Camera.''

title: Merck Lowers Earnings Estimates, Citing Slow Sales of Vioxx
description: Merck & Company, one of the world's largest drug makers, warned Wall Street today that its profits would be lower than expected because a popular painkiller had stopped gaining market share.

title: The Enemy Is AIDS, and Complacency
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Producers Are Willing to Talk With Justice Dept.
description: Some of the nation's big tobacco companies said yesterday that they were willing to sit down with the Justice Department to discuss the possibility of ending the government's multibillion-dollar lawsuit against them.

title: People
description: Gerry Frascione was named president and chief executive at BBDO Canada, Toronto, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, succeeding Michael Fyshe, who left in February to ''pursue new life opportunities,'' as the agency described it. Mr. Frascione had been president and chief executive at the Wolf Group Canada, Toronto.

title: Court Rejects Former United Way President's Pension Claim
description: William V. Aramony, the former president of United Way of America who is in federal prison for stealing from the charity, is not entitled to $2 million in supplemental retirement benefits he claimed under an employment contract, a federal appeals court ruled in a decision made public yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINIKES, JACK
description: MINIKES-Jack. On June 20th at the age of 86. In memory of my father, who died as he lived, quietly and kindly. A devoted husband to our mother Kitty, and her constant companion for over 62 years. A man who appreciated what he had, did not envy, and basked in the glow of his children, Michael and Stewart, his grandchildren, Peter, Joanna, Alison, and Julie, and his great grandchildren, Hannah and Sarah. Dad, you set the standard for humility and simplicity that leaves an indelible mark on our entire family. We will miss you dearly. Memorial contributions may be made to the Mount Sinai Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development.

title: Lawmakers Are Ambivalent On Pataki's Casino Proposal
description: Senate Republicans overcame division in their ranks over casino gambling late this evening and approved a Pataki administration plan to allow the Seneca Indians to build as many as three Las Vegas-style casinos in western New York complete with the state's first slot machines.

title: Article 2001062291997329366 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: TWO SENIOR MANAGERS RESIGN FROM KNIGHT TRADING
description: The Knight Trading Group said yesterday that two senior executives had resigned, and that it might have to dismiss up to 6 percent of its 660 employees. John Hewitt, the president of Knight's market making business, and the firm's technology head, David Shpilberg, left the company to pursue other interests, the company said. Knight may eliminate 30 to 40 jobs to help reduce costs as trading revenue declines, its chief executive, Kenneth D. Pasternak, said. Mr. Pasternak said job cuts would not include traders because their compensation was directly linked to their ability to generate revenue. Knight, a leading market maker on Nasdaq, has been hurt by the conversion to decimal pricing from fractions because the spreads between bids and offers has narrowed.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Maddox Denied Pension
description: A Senate committee refused to change state pension laws to give former Gov. Lester Maddox an annual stipend of less than $10,000. Mr. Maddox, 85, is not covered by the pension system. Mr. Maddox served eight years in office. The pension law requires a public official to hold office for at least 10 years to receive a pension. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Judah and Tszyu Look Past Their Bouts
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn., June 22  The fight was shaping up to be a family affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGEL, REUBEN
description: KAGEL-Reuben. October 18, 1902 to June 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Kathryn & the late Sylvia Kagel. Loving father, grandfather and great-grandfather. A wonderful teacher and role model. He viewed life with wit and wisdom.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Not everybody wants to be a United States senator when you look at the financial constraints and the exposure implications and the family consequences. There is not a huge pool.''

title: The Tongues the Stranger Spoke Were Twisted
description: Following is an excerpt from ''A Murder, a Mystery, and a Marriage,'' by Mark Twain:

title: U.S. and Mexico to Improve Border Safety
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The United States and Mexico announced several steps today to improve safety along the California border, including a pilot program to arm Border Patrol agents in San Diego with nonlethal weapons that launch marble-sized pepper pellets to disperse crowds.

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKER, EILEEN
