description: DICKER-Eileen. June 22, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Chaplain Herman Dicker. Loving mother of Anna & Eli. Adoring grandmother of Shelley and Michael (Edelstein) and Sarah and Jeremy (Dicker). Cherished aunt, sister-in-law, mother-in-law & cousin. Her quiet, steady strength guided and nurtured her family, her inner resolve led to professional accomplishments, and her literary flair was inspirational. She will be missed dearly. Services Sunday, June 24, 2001, 1 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY; 718-445-0300.

title: Rumsfeld to Seek $33 Billion Rise for Military, and Critics See Too Much and Too Little
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will propose increasing the Pentagon's budget for next year to $329 billion, an increase of $33 billion over President Bill Clinton's last military budget, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, ABE
description: HERTZ-Abe. Beloved husband of the late Fay. Adored father of Eileen and Howard Grunther, Karen and David Freedberg. Cherished and loving Poppy of Richard and Kelly, Scott and Lisa, Andrew and Elissa. Loving great-grandfather of Sam and Adam. A man of great character and generosity. An unsurpassed devotion to family is his living legacy. Service Sunday, 1 P.M., ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Macedonia Launches an Offensive Against Albanian Rebels
description: Macedonian forces launched a heavy offensive today against Albanian rebel positions just north of the capital, Skopje, breaking the tentative cease-fire in the southern Balkan republic and leaving diplomatic efforts for a peace agreement in tatters.

title: F.D.A. REJECTS WYETH APPLICATION FOR BONE DRUG
description: Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories said yesterday that regulators had rejected an application for approval of its bone-fracture treatment because of questions about a clinical study. The Food and Drug Administration turned down Wyeth's application for marketing approval of the product, known as rhBMP-2/ACS and designed for use in helping heal fractures of long bones. The F.D.A. said it had questions about the study's design and the interpretation of the clinical results, Wyeth said. Wyeth is a division of the American Home Products Corporation of Madison, N.J.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Possible Senate Candidate Named
description: The state Democratic Party chairman, Dick Harpootlian, said Alex Sanders, president of the College of Charleston, would be a Democratic candidate for the Senate seat held by 98-year-old Strom Thurmond. Mr. Sanders said only that he was ''seriously considering'' entering the race, and would not decide until after retiring as college president in September. The only announced candidate for the seat is a Republican, Representative Lindsey Graham.

title: In Reversal, Rowland Vetoes Bill to Cut Emissions at 6 Power Plants
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, after considering a decision for weeks, today vetoed a bill that would have forced Connecticut's six oldest and least efficient power plants to cut emissions of smog-forming sulfur dioxide and ended the plants' ability to buy federal emission credits from other, cleaner plants in the Northeast.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: New Car-Search Procedures For Police
description: Under a federally mediated agreement to prevent racial profiling by the police, officers in St. Paul will inform drivers who have been pulled over that they can refuse to let their cars be searched, though officers will not need permission if they have a strong suspicion of a crime. Officers will also give business cards to drivers and a center will be set up to take any citizen complaints against officers. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Article 2001062393258559561 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil rose after the OPEC secretary general said the group saw no need to increase production at a meeting in July. In New York, crude oil for August delivery rose 27 cents, to $26.83 a barrel.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Israel Raises Its Glass To Desalination; Water, Water Everywhere Just Waiting For Price to Drop
description: In an old Middle Eastern curse, enemies and miscreants are scornfully told to ''drink from the sea.'' But for decades now, the wealthy but arid nations of the Persian Gulf have been drinking ocean water, purifying it with the world's biggest desalination plants.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Severance Deal
description: Gerald Corbett, the former chief executive of Railtrack, the operator of Britain's railroad tracks and stations, received a severance package of $1.4 million when he resigned last November after a fatal crash and just days after an official inquiry cited Railtrack for a ''lamentable failure'' that led to a another fatal train wreck in 1999. Mr. Corbett was chief executive at the time of both the 1999 accident, which killed 31 people, and the crash last year, in which 4 people died. News of the severance package brought protests from survivors and labor union leaders who termed it grotesque and said it should be paid back because it rewarded failure. Mr. Corbett, now chief executive of the Woolworths division of the retailer Kingfisher, made no public response to the criticism. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Gator in New York City? To Him, It's Just a Lizard
description: Deep in bayou country, 67-year-old Easton DeHart is the man to turn to when an alligator gets in the way of things. Just this morning, he came to the aid of a used car salesman worried about one reptile that had taken a shine to his dealership.

title: Braves Trade Rocker To Indians
description: John Rocker, the Atlanta Braves' closer who gained notoriety two years ago for published remarks that were ethnically and racially offensive, sparking a firestorm of protest and condemnation, was traded to the Cleveland Indians, the team announced last night.

title: After Helping Jews, A Paper Saves Itself
description: Even The Aufbau's new editor admits it: some of its friends wonder if the newspaper, founded in New York by Jewish refugees from Hitler 67 years ago, is still necessary. '' 'Der Mohr hat seine Schuldigkeit getan, der Mohr kann gehen,' as they say in German,'' Lorenz Wolffers told an audience this month, quoting a famous line from Schiller. '' 'The Moor has done his duty, the Moor can go.' ''

title: National Briefing | Washington: No Problems Found In Military Balloting
description: A Defense Department investigation of overseas military voting found that no systemic problems led to the disqualification of hundreds of absentee ballots in last year's presidential election, Pentagon officials said. The audit was ordered last year after some ballots were rejected because they lacked a postmark or a signature, or for other irregularities. The issue became heated in the recount of Florida's ballots. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: They Send This Clown Into the Water
description: As the central figure in Murphy Guyer's ''World of Mirth,'' Sweeney the clown belongs to one of storytelling's most time-honored tribes. He's a bitter Bozo, a compulsively condescending philosopher drunk, with a bilious wit and a strychnine laugh, not to mention a white mask and a painted smile. From his perch inside a tall cage, on a collapsible platform above a dunking pool, he presides over the midway of a rundown itinerant carnival.

title: A Hip-Hop Guide to Loving 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: Benvolio wears camouflage pants, with one leg rolled up to his knee. The Capulets' illiterate male servant constantly listens to his Walkman. The Prince wears a headset. The young people of Verona act out basketball moves, whoop their hellos and practice their martial arts moves. A lot of hip-hop is happening in Theaterworks/U.S.A.'s well-acted, throbbingly high-energy production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Lucille Lortel Theater. And when Juliet is told that Paris (a loser who, like the grown-ups, wears suits) wants to marry her, Juliet throws up.

title: U.S. Loses a Trade Dispute With Europe
description: A World Trade Organization dispute panel ruled today that a United States tax subsidy for businesses violated international trade rules.

title: Democrats Spot Weaknesses In DiFrancesco's Budget Plan
description: A revised state budget of $22.9 billion was formally introduced in the New Jersey Legislature late Thursday night, featuring millions of dollars of election-year property-tax rebates, a $1 billion surplus and, Democrats asserted, millions in questionable revenues.

title: Raytheon Venture Gets Pentagon Work
description: A joint venture by the Raytheon Company beat teams lead by the Computer Sciences Corporation and DynCorp Inc. for military work worth as much as $1.7 billion to support Air Force and Navy training ranges in Nevada, Utah and California.

title: Tony Danza Shows How Prime Time Starts at 50
description: Tony Danza understands the value of simply being yourself, or I should say, being your best, most charming self on the stage. The popular television star, who is appearing at Feinstein's at the Regency, does many things in his new cabaret act, none of them brilliantly but none embarrassingly. He sings a lot, tap-dances some, plays a little jazz piano (''Take the 'A' Train'') and even picks up a cornet to burp out a moody ''Angel Eyes.''

title: Evalyn A. Clark, 98, Historian at Vassar
description: Evalyn A. Clark, a retired Vassar College history professor who was an early member and former president of the Berkshire Conference of Women Historians, died on Sunday in Beacon, N.Y. She was 98 and lived in Poughkeepsie.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Art in Review column of Weekend on June 8 about William N. Copley's show at the Nolan/Eckman Gallery through next Friday misidentified the poet who wrote ''The Face on the Barroom Floor,'' also known as ''The Face on the Floor,'' which inspired some Copley images. He was Hugh d'Arcy, not Robert W. Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, MARGARET
description: AMES-Margaret. On June 22, in Elizabethtown, NY. A classics scholar and author who taught at Riverdale Country School and Hunter College, she is survived by husband Russell of Westport, New York, children David Foley of San Francisco and Barbara Foley of East Orange, NJ, and three grandchildren. Memorial contributions to the Ballard Park Foundation, Westport, New York 12993.

title: Hispanic Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: As G.O.P. Race Goes to Wire, Many New Jerseyans Yawn
description: By geography and temperament, this resort city of saltwater taffy and boardwalk arcades would seem far from the tumult of state politics. But amid the charm of the Victorian homes lining Columbia Avenue, Richard and Rita Klineburger have posted a political missive on their front door: ''We are friends of the unborn,'' the sign says. ''The natural choice is life.''

title: Women in (and Out of) the Workplace
description: With all the working women in America, from off-the-books housekeepers to cabinet members, and with all the issues that face them, you'd think Arlene Hutton would have had an easy time coming up with topics for her new production, ''Women @ Work.'' But of these 11 short sketches, most of which are set in offices and stores and studios, only a couple are about work itself.

title: Judge's Reversal Puts an East Village Group Closer to Eviction
description: In February, the Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center convinced a Manhattan Civil Court jury that it should be allowed to stay in its building on East Ninth Street in the East Village. The building had been auctioned off by the city in 1998 with a deed restriction specifying that it house groups that serve the community.

title: Games With Devil Rays Cure Most Yankee Ills
description: Twenty percent of the Yankees' remaining games will be played against Tampa Bay, and considering the Yankees' performance debt in the first three months of this season, playing the Devil Rays is the equivalent of being granted a huge inheritance. They just have to make sure they do not blow the stash of games.

title: Turkish Court Bans Religious Party, Main Opposition Force
description: Turkey's messy political system suffered another jolt today when the country's highest court banned the religious-oriented Virtue Party. The court said the main opposition party violated a law that prohibited religious activities that could undermine the secular government.

title: Mets Clobbered In Weak Sequel Against Braves
description: At least two things were missing last night when the Mets and the Atlanta Braves rekindled their rivalry at Shea Stadium: the outrageous Braves reliever John Rocker, who was traded to the Cleveland Indians during the game, and any hint of significance or competitiveness.

title: Killers of British 2-Year-Old Win Parole
description: The government said today that two British 18-year-olds who kidnapped and killed a toddler when they were 10 have cleared their final hurdle for parole and are to be released imminently with newly constructed identities.

title: Clutter, Clutter, Everywhere . . . Help!
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: A Vote For The U.N.
description: Parliament voted overwhelmingly in favor of joining the United Nations, strengthening the government's plan to put the issue to a referendum in 2002. Most lawmakers agreed that membership would not infringe on Swiss neutrality. Although the United Nations' European headquarters are in Geneva, the Swiss voted 3-to-1 in 1986 not to join. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Umpire Is Forced Out, But Details Are Sketchy
description: Continuing to take a hard-line approach with umpires, Major League Baseball forced Al Clark, a 26-year veteran, to resign yesterday, other umpires said. The reason, they said, was misuse of airplane tickets and his major league credit card.

title: China's Once Undisputed Business Gateway Now Has Competition
description: For the 200 or so businesspeople who jammed a hotel ballroom for a conference here, it was a typically Chinese affair. Dry speeches, the swapping of business cards, and a marathon banquet, with dutiful toasts to the shiny future of this southern Chinese city once known in the West as Canton.

title: U.S. COURT UPENDS PLANS TO IMPROVE CELLULAR SERVICE
description: A federal appeals court threw into chaos plans to upgrade cell phone service across the country when it found yesterday that the government had illegally confiscated the wireless spectrum licenses of NextWave Personal Communications, which lost them after it went into bankruptcy.

title: Minister Wants Artwork Revised or Removed
description: The director of the widely admired visual arts program at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine ordered yesterday that a Buddhist-influenced artwork either be revised or be removed from the cathedral's baptistry, prompting two well-known artists to say they would pull their works from a group exhibition focusing on spirituality around the world.

title: S.& L. Giant Is Reported to Be Suitor of Dime of New York
description: Patience pays handsomely.

title: Roadside Campaigners
description: To the Editor:

title: Teams Trying To Trade Will Have The Chance
description: Will the Rangers trade their top draft pick 10th over all -- along with prospects and some current players to Philadelphia for Eric Lindros? Will the Islanders trade the No. 2 pick and other assets to Ottawa for Aleksei Yashin or to Buffalo for Michael Peca? Are the Rangers after Yashin and Peca as well? Or will both New York teams compete instead for Jaromir Jagr, the N.H.L. scoring champion?

title: Article 2001062391932061440 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Judah Defending Title Against Vester
description: Zab Judah defends his International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight title against Allan Vester of Denmark tonight at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn.

title: WAL-MART TOLD TO PAY VENDING COMPANY $51.5 MILLION
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. lost a legal dispute with a Missouri vending machine company and was ordered to pay it $51.5 million. A state court jury in Missouri awarded $1.5 million in compensatory damages and $50 million in punitive damages to the closely held Service Vending Company. Service Vending said that Wal-Mart had unfairly required it to remove vending equipment from Wal-Mart stores before the machines could be sold to another company. Wal-Mart of Bentonville, Ark., said it would appeal. Bill Wertz, a spokesman for Wal-Mart, said that after Wal-Mart ended a contract with Service Vending, it had the right to have the vending machines removed within 10 days. Service Vending wanted to keep the machines in place while they were being sold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFERY, BARRY J.
description: JEFFERY-Barry J. On June 20, 2001. Adored husband of Teddy. Father of Paul (Sandy) and Bruce Richard (Harvey Hayashida) Jeffery. Grandfather of David (Sandy Dorset), Eric (Kirabeth). Greatgrandfather of Kayla, Dana and Madeline. Visitation tonight, 7:30PM-9PM, ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Graveside service Sunday, June 24, 2001, 11:30AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Stem-Cell Research Is Truly 'Pro-Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in Weekend yesterday for ''The Magic Flute,'' to be sung in English at the Opera Festival of New Jersey in Princeton through July 29, referred incorrectly to the other operas in the series. They will be sung in their original languages.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Article 2001062393714057784 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Forecast
description: Bayer A.G., Europe's third-largest chemical maker, said earnings from its polymers business were lagging year-earlier results because of rising raw material costs and the slowing economy. ''Bayer, like many competitors, has only partially been able to pass on price rises to the market,'' said Werner Spinner, board member in charge of polymers. The unit, which makes plastic in car bumpers and compact video discs, contributes a third of sales.

title: A Wrong Turn on Patients' Rights
description: The Congressional debate over a patients' rights bill has mostly concerned the right to sue managed care companies: the Kennedy-McCain bill makes this right more expansive than the Frist-Jeffords bill does. That debate misses the point. Either bill, or any similar one, will make a bad situation worse.

title: Bush and Kyoto Accord
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: 5 Sentenced To Life For Terrorism
description: In Cambodia's biggest terrorism trial, five men, including three Americans of Cambodian descent, were sentenced to life in prison for an attack on Nov. 24 that they said was meant to overthrown the government. Two Americans, tried in absentia, were Chhun Yasith, 43, a tax accountant, and Thong Samien, 60, a travel agent, both from Long Beach, Calif. Richard Kiri Kim, 51, of Oregon, was the only American in custody. Twenty-five others received long prison terms. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Living Up to His Name, Tricky Flips His Moods
description: It is often hard to tell that ''Blowback,'' the recent album by the innovative and unpredictable English musician Tricky, is actually a Tricky album. Typically, a Tricky album is about secrecy and paranoia, with whispered vocals, buried hip-hop beats and muddy melodies.

title: Ulster Troops Enforce End to Riots
description: The security forces were ready tonight. Nearly 30 armored vehicles and 200 British Army soldiers stood at the ends of Ardoyne Road, where Roman Catholics and Protestants clashed for two nights this week.

title: A Pressured Franks Pushes Tax Plan, 4 Days Before Primary
description: Bob Franks and Bret D. Schundler sprinted into the final weekend of their battle for the Republican nomination for governor today with Mr. Franks on the defensive, pushing his hastily announced plan to limit property tax increases, while Mr. Schundler expressed confidence that his message was winning over primary voters.

title: Black Pastor Reveals Shift Of Attitude in Birmingham
description: For a moment on Sunday, the pastor forgot where he was, or so he said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New F.B.I. Director, Temporarily
description: Louis J. Freeh stepped down as F.B.I. director and Attorney General John Ashcroft said the bureau's deputy director, Thomas J. Pickard, would serve as acting director until President Bush selects Mr. Freeh's successor. Mr. Pickard, left, is a 26-year F.B.I. employee who headed the Washington field office and the national security division at its New York office, where he helped supervise investigations into the World Trade Center bombing and the crash of TWA Flight 800. David Johnston (NYT)

title: The Mets and the Yankees Have Dogs in This Fight
description: Hot dogs rarely make headlines, except when unusual items are discovered among their ingredients or when they stand at home plate to coo over their 500-foot home runs.

title: Article 2001062391775955472 -- No Title
description: ST. LOUIS -- Though President Bush claims that tax rebate checks will make virtually every American family $300 or $600 richer by the end of summer, 34 million American adults or 26 percent, will be getting no checks at all. And another 17 million, or 13 percent, will get only a partial rebate.

title: Sara Lee Corp. Pleads Guilty In Meat Case
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, one of the nation's largest makers of hot dogs and supermarket deli meats, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor charge that it had produced and distributed tainted meat that sickened scores of consumers and was linked to about 15 deaths.

title: A 2nd Child-Death Case Begins In Texas as the First Proceeds
description: A woman charged with methodically drowning her five young children made her first court appearance here today as police officers about 90 miles east, in Orange, Tex., investigated a possible copycat case involving the death of 6-week-old twins this morning.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the indictments of 13 Saudis and a Lebanese man in a truck bombing at the Khobar Towers apartment building in Saudi Arabia in 1993 misidentified the country to which the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh, traveled during the investigation. It was Saudi Arabia, not Iran.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kuril Islands: Dispute Entangles Korea
description: South Korea is being drawn into the whirlpool of Japan's long dispute with Russia over the Kurils, which were seized by Soviet troops at the end of World War II and are administered by Russia, but are claimed by Japan. The official Voice of Russia Radio said South Korean fishing boats were welcome in Kuril waters under a bilateral fishing agreement, but Japan's Fisheries Ministry insisted earlier in the week that it would not license South Korean boats to fish in Japanese waters if they also fished off the Kurils. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Anlong Veng Journal; Praying to Pol Pot, Seeking Health and Good Luck
description: Only the buzz of cicadas and the croaking of frogs break the silence here in the remote Dangrek Mountains. The damp monsoon air is filled with black butterflies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the world's fastest supercomputers referred incorrectly to two of them. The second-fastest is an I.B.M. supercomputer used for scientific research at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, not a military machine. The military supercomputer at Los Alamos ranks No. 6; it is not among the four fastest.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: New Head Of National Assembly
description: Nguyen Van An, 63, was unanimously nominated by the Politburo to become the new head of the National Assembly, replacing Nong Duc Manh, who was promoted to the top job as head of the Communist Party. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Combat With Less Scolding and Bullying
description: In the Kings County Shakespeare Company's ''Taming of the Shrew'' under Liz Shipman's direction, it is the play that is disciplined into civility, with only a slight misstep. Ms. Shipman uses part of Shakespeare's opening scene that is routinely ignored in modern productions. But instead of making the play a stunt by amateur performers to confuse an addled sot, she has a lush reel from the street into the theater where the actors talk him into taking the role of Petruchio. It seems to me this diminishes the distancing effect Shakespeare intended by making ''Shrew'' a play within a play.

title: Sales Sluggish For Key Drug From Merck
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that its profits for the second quarter and year would be lower than expected because sales of its painkiller Vioxx were not growing as fast as expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAHL, GUNNAR ANDREAS
description: DAHL-Gunnar Andreas. On Saturday, June 16, 2001, age 80. Retired UN staff member. Memorial service on Saturday, June 30, 11 AM, at the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East 74th Street, NYC.

title: Lincoln Constance, 92, Expert Who Classified Farm Products
description: Lincoln Constance, a world-renowned botanist who helped explain the cell structure and chromosomes of some agricultural mainstays, died on June 11 at a hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, DR. RUTH LEDER
description: SHAPIRO-Dr. Ruth Leder. On June 17, 2001, at age 81. Psychologist. Beloved stepmother of Richard Shapiro and his wife, Patricia, and step-grandmother of Seth and Alex. Also survived by her nephew Drew Leder and her companion for fourteen years, Jacques Solta. Interment is private. Memorial service July 7th, 2001. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Boeing Criticized
description: The European environment commissioner, Margot Wallstrom, criticized an executive of Boeing as being nonchalant about the environmental effect of the company's proposed high-speed jet. Ms. Wallstrom criticized comments made by Harry Stonecipher, vice chairman of Boeing, in a recent interview with The Times of London in which he accused critics of the so-called Sonic Cruiser as riding the environmental bandwagon. Ms. Wallstrom said the hour saved on a trans-Atlantic flight would not be worth the 35 percent increase in fuel use and the increase in carbon dioxide emissions that Boeing projects for the plane, which will travel at 95 percent of the speed of sound. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Offshore Exploration Blocked
description: Judge Claudia Wilken of Federal District Court in Oakland blocked any effort to explore oil and natural gas deposits off the central coast until the federal government conducts environmental reviews and the state approves a plan. No drilling has been conducted since 1989, and no immediate plans for new rigs are pending, but the state and the Natural Resources Defense Council sued to block even preliminary exploration after the Clinton administration extended dozens of leases in 1999, arguing that the state had the right to review any plan. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Dodgers II, but It's Baseball; The Game Is Back in Brooklyn, on a Smaller Scale
description: The Slavin brothers, Irish boys from the neighborhood, were discussing the topic of the day at Farrell's tavern in Windsor Terrace.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit By Fired Controllers Denied
description: A federal judge has ruled that about 3,600 air traffic controllers dismissed in 1981 by President Ronald Reagan cannot continue a joint lawsuit accusing the federal government of improper delays in rehiring them. Judge Donald Middlebrooks of Federal District Court in Miami ruled late Wednesday that the controllers, fired for engaging in an illegal strike, must first take their claims to federal agencies. In 1993, President Bill Clinton said the controllers could reapply for jobs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: MASCO PURCHASES 3 HOME-IMPROVEMENT COMPANIES
description: The Masco Corporation, which makes Delta faucets, acquired three closely held businesses with combined annual sales of $500 million to increase its line of home-improvement products. Terms were not disclosed. Masco bought Milgard Manufacturing Inc. of Tacoma, Wash., which makes vinyl window accessories and fiberglass windows and sliding doors. Masco also purchased Resources Conservation Inc. of Stamford, Conn., a maker of water-saving shower heads, and D-Scan Inc. of South Boston, Va., a maker of ready-to-assemble furniture.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the search for subatomic neutrino particles from the Sun referred imprecisely to scientists' means of detecting the neutrinos, albeit indirectly. Monitoring a form of hydrogen called deuterium, scientists detected the electrons that were emitted when the neutrinos transformed neutrons within deuterium atoms into protons; scientists did not detect the splitting of deuterium into neutrons and protons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPSHIE, GERALDINE
description: LIPSHIE-Geraldine. Happy Birthday, Bubby. We miss you so-o-o-o-o-o much. Norm, Lois, Greg, Susan, Tamara, Perry, Amy, Malcolm, Cara and all your Grandchildren

title: Learning to Love Language in a Bilingual School
description: All around the country over the past two weeks, graduating students have marched into auditoriums to applause. At one school in my neighborhood, the chorus that followed ''Pomp and Circumstance'' was ''Himno a las Amricas.'' At a time when other cities with sizable Hispanic populations are in turmoil over how to educate their children, Oyster Bilingual Elementary is a public school where parents -- whether native speakers of Spanish or of English -- camped out for several nights last spring to get their children in.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Rainbow Gathering Crackdown Sought
description: Legislators asked the Forest Service to crack down on a group that is camping in Boise National Forest in preparation for a large Independence Day gathering. The agency denied a permit sought by the Rainbow Family, which espouses peace and environmentalism, to set up the main camp and has issued $100 citations to campers for breaking rules intended to protect a sensitive fish habitat. As many as 20,000 people are expected to attend the Rainbow Gathering. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, RABBI BERNARD
description: MANDELBAUM-Rabbi Bernard. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. He served the Jewish Theological Seminary with distinction as professor of midrash, director of its Religio-Psychiatry Institute, and, from 1966 until 1972, as its president. He is the author of a critical edition of the midrash, ''Peskita de Rav Kahana''. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Marcelle, children, Joel, David, Debra, Lyman, Dasi Schlup and Naomi Rosenblum, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Delay in Sale Of PepsiCo Line
description: The sale by PepsiCo Inc. of its All Sport sports drinks to the closely held Monarch Company has been delayed, as PepsiCo continues talks with antitrust enforcers about its proposed purchase of the Quaker Oats Company, maker of the top-selling Gatorade.

title: Journal; Death With Commercials
description: On Monday June 11, NBC broadcast a new show that The Wall Street Journal condemned as ''the most depressing, nauseating and just plain disgusting'' TV premiere ever. George Will called it ''televised degradation,'' and Ted Koppel went so far as to convene a ''Nightline'' to address the question of whether it might ''move us any closer to the end of civilization.''

title: Sripati Chandrasekhar, Indian Demographer, Dies at 83
description: Sripati Chandrasekhar, an Indian demographer and government minister who fought a tireless and so far losing battle to reduce his country's soaring population, died on June 14 in San Diego, Calif. He was 83.

title: Men & Health: Lessons of the Heart
description: Three men share their tales of surviving heart problems with humor, courage and the best medicine. Plus news on chronic anger, heart rates and checkups.

title: Pilot Killed When Plane Crashes in Greenwich
description: A pilot was killed yesterday when his plane crashed in Greenwich, Conn., after an aborted landing attempt.

title: Article 2001062392322312296 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPFER, IRA
description: TEPFER-Ira. Of Ft. Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Eleanor, loving brother of Sylvia Schanker, adored uncle of Joseph, Marjorie, Robert, Marjorie, Steven and Howard. Graveside services on Sunday, 11:15AM, at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Acquired
description: Furthering its ambitions to expand in Britain, GE Capital, the financial services arm of the General Electric Company, has agreed to buy National Mutual, a British insurer, for 570 million ($807 million), the companies said. National Mutual, which began reviewing its status in March, said its 160,000 policyholders would receive 500 each as compensation for loss of their membership status. The company said policyholders who have so-called with-profits plans would get additional payments totaling about 290 million in the form of enhanced final bonuses. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Bigger Rise Is Sought In Military Spending
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld will seek a Pentagon budget for next year of $329 billion, $18.4 billion above what President Bush proposed in February and $33 billion over President Clinton's last defense budget. Republicans in Congress called the request insufficient and Democrats called it unreasonable.

title: Indian Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about House approval of a measure to postpone new leases for offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of representatives who voted for it. There were 247, not 267; 164 voted against it.

title: Talks on Future Of Government In Ulster Falter
description: Northern Ireland's fractious politicians today tried -- and failed -- to find ways to salvage a government that appeared on the point of collapse. Adding to the sense of unease was the fact that the talks occurred after two nights of the worst rioting between Protestants and Roman Catholics here in years.

title: Paris in the Summer
description: For those who can wait until the summer rush is over, European vacations can be much more affordable. For example, France Vacations will drop the price on its five-night packages to Paris, which include round-trip air fare from Newark Airport, to $639 a person, based on double occupancy, Sept. 1 to Oct. 31. The five nights accommodations, including daily breakfast and city tax, are in two-star hotels that are away from the city center, so expect to ride the Metro and don't expect too many comforts. The hotels available for the lowest rate include the JdP Montparnasse in the 14th arrondissement; the Lyon-Mulhouse, in the 11th; the Moulin Vert, in the 14th; the Roma Sacre-Coeur, in the 18th; and the Square d'Anvers, in the ninth. To see pictures of all the hotels, visit www.francevacations.net . The package costs $689 from Atlanta, $709 from Houston, $729 from Miami and $759 from Chicago and Los Angeles. Call (800) 332-5332.

title: Spain Arrests Terror Suspect Said to Be Linked to bin Laden
description: Spanish police officers today arrested an Algerian man who was wanted on terrorism charges in France and Germany, and who is thought to have ties to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi dissident accused by the United States of masterminding the bombings of American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998.

title: Beliefs; From a Christian weekly, a list of four works on religion whose influence is called harmful.
description: Books for the beach. Books for holiday gifts. Ten best books of the year. One hundred best books of the century. The lists go on.

title: Woods Gets It Done When He Needs It Most
description: An exhausted Tiger Woods sat by his locker this afternoon, perspiration on his face, a towel around his neck. When Woods was asked how he felt, his mood brightened.

title: IRISH LIFE WILL SELL 2 OF ITS 3 AMERICAN DIVISIONS
description: Irish Life and Permanent P.L.C., a leading financial services company in Ireland, said it would sell two of its three insurance businesses in the United States to a unit of the Protective Life Corporation for about $253.1 million. Irish Life will sell the Iowa-based Inter-State Assurance Company and the Illinois-based First Variable Life Insurance Company. The transaction is expected to close in October and add 2 cents a share to fourth-quarter earnings, Irish Life said.

title: INSIDE
description: Dime Savings in Talks

title: U.S. Refuses New Counsel In Torricelli Investigation
description: The United States Justice Department has rejected Senator Robert G. Torricelli's request that a special counsel be appointed to take over the criminal investigation into his personal finances and fund-raising practices during his 1996 campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a proposal to elect a new board for Computer Associates misstated the given name of one proposed director. She is Cece Smith, not CeCe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: South Korea: Stake Sold
description: The Hyundai Merchant Marine Company has begun selling off its equity in Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest manufacturer of merchant ships. The company, previously Hyundai Heavy's largest shareholder, with a stake of 12.5 percent, said it had sold 2 million of its 9.4 million shares for $47.6 million on the Korean Stock Exchange and will sell the rest this year. The withdrawal of Hyundai Merchant, part of a process in which Hyundai Heavy will exit the Hyundai group, leaves Chung Mong Joon, sixth son of the late Hyundai founder Chung Ju Yung, as Hyundai Heavy's largest shareholder, with 10.3 percent of equity. Mr. Chung is chairman of the Korean committee organizing next year's World Cup in Korea and Japan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNESA, WILLIE
description: TURNESA-Willie. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on June 16, in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Cranberry Growers Told to Cut Yields
description: The Department of Agriculture yesterday imposed the strictest limits on the nation's cranberry crop in at least 30 years, in an effort to reduce a surplus that is more than half of a full year's harvest.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Down
description: German business confidence fell to a two-year low in May, according to the latest monthly survey of 7,000 companies by the Ifo Institute. The two components of the Ifo index, the assessment of business expectations and the current situation, fell by about 1.5 points, to an overall index of 90.9 points. The new data seemed to support recently published forecasts by economic institutes that economic growth will be less than 2 percent this year.

title: Sports of The Times; No Rocker, No Bombs, No Contest
description: THE only sign of the crackle that normally accompanies the Mets and the Braves was the pair of dogs sniffing their way through the Atlanta clubhouse long before last night's game.

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY: LESSONS OF THE HEART

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Glitch Gives New Meaning To 'Cut Off From the Table'
description: In the early years of the game, there was a weird conclusion to a match in France. Ely Culbertson took his team to Paris and played against the best French players. As the match drew to a close, the scores were virtually tied. Culbertson and his partner had a good result, collecting a 300-point penalty, but the cards were replaced wrongly in the board. The Americans now had the same cards in the replay.

title: Undermining the City Campaign Law
description: By most accounts, New York City has one of the best campaign finance systems in the country. Thus it is distressing to see the system undermined by mayoral candidates in both major parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, DORIS
description: FEIN-Doris. On June 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Peter. Cherished grandmother of Maggie and Jake. Devoted aunt of Gloria and April. She will be profoundly missed. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HARRY B.
description: STEIN-Harry B. Passed away on June 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Fischbach). Devoted father of Juliet Stein, Susan and Martin Danoff, Nina and Irwin Wolf. Cherished grandfather of Linda and Michael Perrella, Deborah Chesbrough, Steven Salee and Hans Lupold, Douglas Danoff, Jennifer Danoff and Michael Bernstein. Adored great grandfather of Samuel and Joseph Perrella. A mighty oak has fallen. A giant in the lumber business for over 75 years; the Founder of Huntington Materials and Chairman of Bayport Lumber Corporation; a graduate of New York University & its Business School; the Founder and Past President of Temple Beth-El in Huntington, L.I. and former Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Suburbia Federal Savings and Loan Association. Died quietly in his sleep in his 93rd year leaving a legacy of quiet strength, implacable moral standards, dignity, intellect and love for his family and friends. He was the patriarch of our family and we will love him forever and cherish his memory. The funeral will be held on Sunday, June 24th at 11:30am at Riverside Funeral Home, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 516-487-9600

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Purchase
description: The British cigarette maker Gallaher Group said it had agreed to pay $1.8 billion in cash and assumed debt to buy Austria Tabak, one of Europe's last remaining national tobacco businesses, which was founded in 1784 as the tobacco supplier to the Austro-Hungarian empire. The acquisition will make Gallaher, the maker of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, Europe's fourth biggest, with 8 percent of the market and annual worldwide sales of 120 billion cigarettes. Gallaher's stock fell by as much as 6 percent after it said it would issue new shares to finance some of the deal, under which it will buy the Austrian government's 41.13 percent stake at 85 euros a share and offer other holders the same amount later. The purchase price represented a 9 percent premium on Thursday's closing price of Austria Tabak.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Appeals Court Rules F.C.C. Illegally Seized Licenses

title: Symantec Warning Sends Shares Down
description: Shares of Symantec fell 37 percent today after it said fiscal first-quarter sales and profit would miss forecasts.

title: A White Alderman Who Wants to Join a Black Caucus
description: HE'S the white guy who wants to be a member of the City Council's black caucus.

title: Cuttings: Colorful, Low-Maintenance and All-Season
description: IN many ways, William T. Gotelli was a man ahead of his time. In the years following World War II, when landscaping across the nation primarily consisted of swaths of colorful annuals, he became passionately attached to conifers.

title: Lori Berenson's Sentence
description: Lori Berenson was convicted on Wednesday and sentenced to 20 years in prison, minus time served, by a three-judge civilian court in Lima for her involvement with Peru's Tpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement in the mid-1990's. Although the evidence suggests she may indeed have aided the violent Marxist guerrilla group, the sentence is unduly harsh in light of her marginal role in the conspiracy and the case's tainted and tortuous history. Ms. Berenson, a native New Yorker, has already been imprisoned under harsh conditions for more than five years, and her case was manipulated by the corrupt Fujimori regime. President-elect Alejandro Toledo and the Supreme Court should acknowledge this history, and end her prison ordeal.

title: Milbrett's First Hat Trick Lifts the Power
description: In her third multigoal game of the season, Tiffeny Milbrett scored the first hat trick of the Women's United Soccer Association's inaugural season. Milbrett led the Power to a 3-1 victory tonight over the Boston Breakers before a crowd announced as 5,056 at Mitchel Athletic Complex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Ex-Workers of Generator Testify on Power Output
description: Three former workers at a plant operated by one of the biggest power producers in California testified today that the company shut production units in what they said was an apparent effort to drive up electricity prices.

title: Court Rules for Trump in Casino Case
description: Two Indiana men recruited by Donald J. Trump to lend a ''Hoosierized'' flavor to his bid for a Lake Michigan riverboat casino have lost their chance for a big payoff.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Indian Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Seek a Compromise On Patients' Rights Measure
description: Senators began serious bipartisan negotiations today to resolve the concerns of Republicans who fear that a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights would expose employers to costly lawsuits by patients aggrieved over the denial of care under employer-sponsored health plans.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Taking Aim At The Governor
description: Seven months after the Democrats won control of the State Senate for the first time in 40 years, the chamber's president, Stan Matsunaka of Loveland, said he was considering a run for governor next year. Gov. Bill Owens, a popular Republican, has not announced he will seek another term, but has already begun raising money. Mr. Matsunaka, a lawyer who opposes Mr. Owens's positions on growth and education, has served two terms in the Senate and cannot seek a third because of term limits. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Woman Wins Suit on Misleading AIDS Ad
description: A woman with AIDS whose photograph was used in a brochure for a drug to fight the disease without her permission has won a summary judgment in a defamation and civil rights lawsuit against Merck & Company, one of the world's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers.

title: Nananne Porcher, 78, Lighting Designer
description: Nananne Porcher, a theater lighting designer and theater design consultant, died on Sunday. She was 78 and lived in West Tisbury, Mass.

title: The House Rebukes the President
description: The House of Representatives has now provided further evidence of the widening gap between the Bush administration and the American people on environmental and energy issues. In a series of votes on Thursday, an impressive bipartisan majority blocked administration plans for oil and gas exploration in the eastern Gulf of Mexico and in national monument lands, upheld important mining law reforms that Mr. Bush had opposed and restored millions of dollars for land protection and energy conservation programs that he had tried to cut.

title: As Pettitte Recovers, Cashman Is Still Searching for Relief
description: The most significant addition to the Yankees' roster in the near future may not be one of the many relievers the team is discussing in trade talks, but Andy Pettitte.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the indictments of 13 Saudis and a Lebanese man in a truck bombing at the Khobar Towers apartment building in Saudi Arabia in 1993 misidentified the country to which the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh, traveled during the investigation. It was Saudi Arabia, not Iran.

title: Three Countries Are Warned To Limit Money Laundering
description: The major industrial nations warned Russia and two other countries today that they would face restrictions on their dealings with international banks if they did not make quick progress in clamping down on money laundering.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell against the euro and yen, but traders said gloomy European and Japanese fundamentals pointed to continued strength for the U.S. currency. The euro rose to 85.6 cents, from 85.48 cents.

title: James Parker, 77, Curator of European Decorative Arts at the Met
description: James Parker, a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for nearly 50 years who was perhaps best known for his creation of the Wrightsman rooms of 18th-century French furniture, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Wolfgang Fuchs, 62, Helped East Germans Escape to West
description: Wolfgang Fuchs, who played an important role in helping people flee from East to West Berlin after the Berlin Wall was built in 1961, died on June 7 in Berlin. He was 62.

title: Fleeing Stereotype, Seeking Stardom; Sioux Took a Dream and Left the Reservation
description: The empty days on the isolated Standing Rock Reservation crawl along with the pace of lazy clouds, drifting in sync with a serene stretch of the bordering Missouri River.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Third Special Session Planned
description: Gov. Gary Locke said he would call state legislators back to Olympia on July 16 for their third special session of the year, this one to deal with transportation issues, especially the traffic that has made the Puget Sound region's road system one of the most congested in the nation. Lawmakers adjourned late Thursday from their second special session, which concerned the state budget. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HEDWIG (HEDY) (NEE BAUMGARTEN)
description: GOLDSTEIN-Hedwig (Hedy) (nee Baumgarten). Ft Lee, NJ. Formerly of Budapest, Brussels, and Madrid. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. A Holocaust survivor who lived life to the fullest.

title: Two Parties on the Prowl To Claim the Senate in '02
description: John Kitzhaber, an Oregon Democrat who seeks universal health insurance coverage, and Jack Ryan, an Illinois Republican who thinks government is too big, have little in common -- except that each is being beseeched by party leaders to run for the Senate.

title: Where Apples Don't Pay, Developers Will
description: In their sun-drenched orchard here in Ulster County, where the McIntosh and Red Delicious apples are still the size of cherries, father and son should be a whirlwind of activity this time of year: spraying and thinning the trees at Hudson Valley Farms, lining up labor for harvest.

title: G.O.P. Considers Tighter Gas Mileage Rules
description: Republican leaders in Congress have softened their opposition to mandating higher fuel economy standards for automobiles, raising the possibility that the government could require automakers to improve the efficiency of cars and light trucks for the first time in seven years.

title: Meadowlands Plan Is Test Of DiFrancesco's Power
description: The plan for the future of the Meadowlands outlined on Thursday by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco is testing the limits of his power as governor as well as the will of Bergen County lawmakers to press what advantage they feel they have in continuing the negotiations.

title: Prisoner Is Acquitted In Killing On Death Row
description: In a trial drenched in the brutal realities of prison life, a convicted killer was acquitted yesterday of stomping a fellow condemned prisoner to death.

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Issues Prodded Republicans In House Votes Against Drilling
description: House votes this week against oil drilling off the coast of Florida and in areas designated as national monuments seemed to be a clear sign of a new assertiveness among Republicans to stand up for the environment.

title: Time for the I.R.A. to Disarm
description: The Irish Republican Army must begin to give up its arms. It is rare for Protestants and Catholics in Northern Ireland, Britain and Ireland to agree on anything. But at the moment, all of these groups -- except the Irish Republican Army and its political wing, Sinn Fein -- agree that the I.R.A. must disarm. When Sinn Fein signed the 1998 agreement establishing Northern Ireland's peace process, it signaled in spirit, if not strictly in letter, that it would do so. Now the peace process may fail if it does not.

title: Senate Vote Is Just a Step To a Deal For Casinos
description: Gov. George E. Pataki may have won a temporary victory when he convinced the Republican-led Senate to push through legislation late Thursday giving him carte blanche to negotiate a casino deal with the Seneca Nation.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Plane Problems
description: Aviation problems in Canadian-built aircraft on both sides of the Atlantic have raised questions about Canada's fleet. On Friday, cabin pressure dropped suddenly as Prime Minister Jean Chrtien's Challenger jet was taking off from a Swedish airport. He canceled a planned vacation and returned to Canada on a European-made Airbus. And Canada's precision-flying team, the Snowbirds, remained grounded after a midair collision on Thursday sent one Canadian-built CF114 Tutor jet plunging into Lake Erie. No one was hurt. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Cuomos Buy House Someplace in New York
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, who is moving back to New York to run for governor, has bought a house in Westchester County. But exactly where was a matter of some confusion today.

title: A Divided Ukraine Awaits the Pope
description: Here where the Russian state was founded and where the Orthodox Christian faith first took root in this part of the world, Pope John Paul II arrives on Saturday for a visit in a land still deeply divided between Europe and its Soviet past.

title: Powell Comes Up Short In Comeback Attempt
description: How dramatic the Mike Powell comeback story could have been:

title: Article 2001062390922547689 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Article 2001062393539326129 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: With the Swan, the Lake and Debuts
description: A weeklong run of ''Swan Lake'' at American Ballet Theater ended with a blaze of first-class dancing in major debuts and cast changes.

title: Ripken Will Be Named an All-Star
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre, who will manage the American League in the All-Star Game on July 10, said tonight that Cal Ripken would be a member of the team even if he did not win the voting for third basemen. Ripken announced Tuesday that he would retire after this season, ending his storied career.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, LORETTA
description: DENERSTEIN-Loretta. Not a day goes by that she is not missed by her children and grandchildren. Forever loved, Susan and Harris

title: Abroad at Home; Ripple Of Hope
description: When you challenge a tyrant and come close to succeeding, what may he do at the last to hold on to power? That is a looming concern now for Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the challenge to President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.

title: Joseph Ellis: History and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Booby Trap in Gaza Strip Kills Two Israeli Soldiers
description: Two Israeli soldiers were killed by a booby-trapped jeep in the northern Gaza Strip today as European and American diplomats sought to solidify a shaky cease-fire in meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

title: De La Hoya Seeks Title
description: He will enter the ring without a belt in his possession tonight at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. He will also arrive without the aura he carried for so many years. Losing, as he has done twice in his last four fights, has changed that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, CHARLES S., REV. CSP.
description: WHITE-Charles S., Rev. CSP. On June 21, 2001, at age 83. Born in Holyoke, MA, he was ordained a Paulist priest on May 1, 1948. Fr. White served as a missionary, preaching and serving in Winchester, TN; Los Angeles, CA; Chicago, IL. His pastoral gifts were realized as a parish priest in Austin, TX; Lubbock, TX; New York, NY; Clemson, SC; and Boston, MA. Twelve of his priestly years were in service to the parishioners at Good Shepherd Parish in New York, seven years at the Paulist Center in Boston, and fifteen of his final years at Saint Paul the Apostle Parish in New York. There will be a wake on Monday, June 25, 2001, from 6 to 9 PM, at Saint Paul the Apostle Rectory, 415 West 59th Street, New York, New York. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 AM, on Tuesday, June 26, 2001, at Saint Paul's. Burial will be at Mount Paul Cemetery, Oak Ridge, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about divisions among British business leaders over currency policy misstated the name of the top-selling British tabloid newspaper controlled by Rupert Murdoch. It is The Sun, not The Star.

title: For Cautious Alfonzo, Easy Does It in Workout
description: His teammates had been out on the field for a half-hour when, somewhat sheepishly, Edgardo Alfonzo joined them. Alfonzo, the Mets' second baseman, did not have much interaction with his teammates. He had his own things to do, and he moved cautiously.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MIDWAY GAMES INC., Chicago, said it would cut its work force by about 60 employees and exit the coin-operated arcade video game business because of a decline in demand.

title: China Announces Extensive Plan To Combat Its Water Shortage
description: The Chinese government has announced details of a crash, multibillion-dollar plan it hopes will salvage the deteriorating water supply here, which along with other northern cities has suffered from years of unusually low rainfall and decades of unchecked pollution and poorly planned development.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Sky Watch: Our Galactic Backyard
description: In February, this column touched on the subject of how many stars a person could see with the unaided eye. Most of what can theoretically be seen is practically all within our galactic backyard -- within a few thousand light-years of Earth.

title: Article 2001062390646740034 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Sentenced in Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Assails Parole Policy
description: A state judge ruled that Gov. Gray Davis has an unlawful blanket policy of denying parole to convicted murderers and ordered the release of a man who spent 16 years in prison for shooting a boyhood friend. Judge Paul Gutman of Los Angeles County Superior Court held that no evidence supported Mr. Davis's contention that the convict, Robert Rosenkrantz, poses a continuing threat. The ruling is not binding on state courts but could influence parole cases. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Terrorism and Iran: Washington's Policy Performs a Gingerly Balancing Act
description: The United States has never known quite what to do about Iran's role in anti-American terrorism. From the embassy bombings and hostage taking in Lebanon during the early 1980's to the Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia in 1996, Washington's response to evidence that Tehran was sponsoring violence against American interests has been marked by deep ambivalence and contorted internal debates among several generations of policy makers.

title: The Reporters Who Call Him Call Him Boss
description: THIS may turn out to have been the week when Michael R. Bloomberg blew any chance of becoming New York's next mayor.

title: Women's Health: A Devastating Lack of Awareness
description: Why women don't believe their No. 1 killer, really affects them. Plus news on nursing burnout, revitalizing the spirit and banishing wrinkles in an hour.

title: Leaders Are Bunched at Buick Classic
description: The weather cleared up today at the Buick Classic, but the battle to win the tournament remained very unsettled.

title: Article 2001062391439848420 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: An Arrest in Series of Fires In Phoenix Adds a Plot Twist
description: When some partly built luxury homes at the edge of the desert here starting going up in flames three years ago, there were twinges of sympathy for a group that claimed to be setting the fires to halt the relentless destruction of open spaces. The self-proclaimed eco-terrorists even sent letters to local news organizations warning, ''If you build, we will burn.''

title: Needle-Trading Programs Have Few Inroads in U.S.
description: That February night, Gary Langis was doing his usual thing. That is, he was delivering sterile hypodermic needles to two heroin addicts here, and picking up dirty needles to be sure they were disposed of safely.

title: Par-Saving Putt on Second Hole Helps Webb Set Tourney Record
description: Saving par from 7 feet away in a major tournament can work wonders for a golfer's state of mind. It did today for Karrie Webb at the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship, the only major missing from her rsum.

title: National Briefing | Washington: More Nominations By Bush
description: President Bush announced his intention this week to nominate 14 individuals to cabinet or subcabinet positions, and sent the names of 11 individuals to Congress. The Senate did not confirm any nominees this week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES INC., Atlanta, a bottler of Coca-Cola drinks, named G. David Van Houten Jr. executive vice president and president of its new North American unit, which combines the company's western and eastern North America groups. He had been president at the western group. William A. Holl, former president at the eastern group, was named corporate senior vice president.

title: A Forgotten Twain Tale Finally Makes It Into Print
description: Nothing stirs up a writer like other writers. And nothing stirs up editors like Mark Twain. Here is proof.

title: After Insurers File to Leave, State Cuts Costs of Auto Injury Treatments
description: With some of New Jersey's biggest auto insurers threatening to pull out of the state because they say they cannot make a profit, state officials said yesterday that they were cutting the amount that doctors can charge for treating auto injury victims.

title: Fairfield Golfer Is Making A Name Nationally
description: LARRY BOLAND, the golf coach of Fairfield High School, was driving J. J. Henry home after their first practice at the Brooklawn Country Club when Boland asked the freshman what he might like to do later in life.

title: Technology Overdrive
description: BMW's redesigned 7 Series will be unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show in September and arrive in American showrooms in January. Packed with technology, the flagship 7 Series incorporates BMW's iDrive concept, which puts locates important functions in and around the steering wheel and the less-used controls on the center dash. The 4.4-liter V-8 has been upgraded and is paired with a six-speed automatic transmission.

title: A Spending Where-To
description: For European junkets focused on shopping and fine dining, Red Map is introducing a set of guides to London, Paris, Rome and Amsterdam ($5.95 to $7.95 each at Barnes & Noble bookstores). In the laminated, folding-panel format of their American predecessors, these new Red Maps offer Zagat-style information, helping the visitor find stores, hotels, restaurants, museums and parks. A spare, clean design keeps them easy to read -- and as a bonus, they're easy to fold.

title: Trying to Close the Gap Between Dreams and Funding
description: HOWARD GOLDSTEIN tells the story of the musician in Mercer County who got it into his head to ask for government aid to turn his porch into a concert stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTER, GREGORY V.
description: KITTER-Gregory V. Of Greenlawn, NY, on June 22, 2001. President of VSG Consulting LLC. Beloved husband of Sharon and loving father of Valaria. Dear brother of Jeffrey and cherished friend of Mel Mullin. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, NY. Funeral Monday, 3 PM, at the funeral home.

title: A Majority of One
description: While conservative politicians often object to liberal judges who ''legislate'' from the bench, Jeffrey Rosen's article shows the reality: Justice O'Connor, with four other conservative justices, voted George W. Bush into the presidency. With their decision in hand, they searched for a reason. Unable to do so, they created one with their notation that the decision was ''limited to the present circumstances.'' Such political hubris shows which political party is legislating from the bench.

title: France Is the Stage For Hungarian Festival
description: In anticipation of Hungary's expected entry into the European Union within the next several years, the Magyart Festival in France, www.magyart.com, will showcase Hungarian culture with exhibitions, concerts, drama, film, dance and folk events through December.

title: Article 2001062492162304329 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Backs DNA Test Limits

title: A Busload of Aspiring Activists Take to the Road
description: NEW MARKET, Tenn., June 19  Not long after midnight, Brandeis University's Sociology 156a rolled off Interstate 40 at Exit 68 into the TA Truck Stop. Young women toted toiletries into the restroom, young men folded themselves into phone booths to dial mothers and girlfriends. David Cunningham, assistant professor of sociology, popped in two quarters for a video game of Galaga.

title: A Majority of One
description: Sandra Day O'Connor imposed her version of frontier justice on the highest court in the land in her swing decision in Bush v. Gore with its hypocritical turnaround of her federalist stance ( Jeffrey Rosen, June 3). That she is a centrist will be of little comfort if she becomes chief justice. Her approach to the judicial process seems to hinge on the presumption that she knows what is fundamentally best for the country. This has dangerous overtones for voters' rights.

title: Rain-Soaked Buick Classic Won't End Till Tomorrow, if Then
description: The third round of the Buick Classic was postponed today, and the final round has been rescheduled for Monday.

title: Sarah Schenck, John Donohue
description: Sarah Louise Hazlett Schenck and John Joseph Donohue were married yesterday by the Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Inn at Bally Springs, Pa.

title: June 17-23; Reasoning on 'Reasonable'
description: When is a police officer's use of an unreasonable amount of force sufficiently reasonable to insulate the officer from legal liability? The Supreme Court's answer: when a reasonable officer would have made the same mistake. In a 6-to-3 decision dismissing a suit against a military police officer who dragged a demonstrator away from a speech by Vice President Al Gore, the justices expanded a doctrine known as qualified immunity. The doctrine, designed to spare police officers the burden of defending their reasonable judgment calls in court, must be broad enough to ''acknowledge that reasonable mistakes can be made,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said.

title: Turn Down Those Lights!
description: THE starry skies, inspiration for countless poems and songs, have inspired something else across Connecticut: a debate over an electric company's plan to upgrade street lighting in the towns it serves.

title: Heather Baram, Jordan Turkewitz
description: Heather Baram, the daughter of Dorothy Baram of Manhattan and the late Edwin Baram, was married on Thursday evening to Jordan Adam Turkewitz, a son of Suzanne and Michael Turkewitz, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Marc Schneier officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Is This the Face of a Midlife Crisis?
description: HERE'S a guy who did everything right. Graduated from Yale. Married his high school sweetheart. Became a hotshot salesman at one of America's corporate giants. But that's all over now. He has divorced his wife, quit the wireless sales rat race and moved back to his hometown in northeast Pennsylvania.

title: The Tortures of Kafka, the Romance of Cather
description: THE sketchy and the trashy do fine; so does a neat little entertainment. But when it comes to turning a major work of literature into theater, audiences can be in for a long, bumpy ride.

title: Moody's Drops a Rule On International Debt
description: Moody's Investors Service has decided that companies in emerging markets may receive higher debt ratings than their home governments.

title: "Body Toxic: An Environmental Memoir"
description: In nineteen question-mark question-mark my silent grandfather came to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONSTEIN, BEN
description: LONSTEIN-Ben. On June 21, 2001, in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Age 96. Devoted husband and father, grandfather of David, Jodi, Paul, Glen, Stacy, Brad, Marc and Jonathan. Rest in peace.

title: Echoes of Hardship In Stone and Bronze
description: EAMONN O'DOHERTY'S Great Hunger Memorial in V. E. Macy Park in Ardsley is a stone-and-bronze sculpture that consists of a family of five, two stone gables and an overturned basket of potatoes and skulls. The memorial leaves visitors with the haunting reminder that many who came to the United States were motivated by fear and desperation.

title: Banish Wrinkles in an Hour! (For a While, Anyway)
description: LAST summer, Farley Clark began noticing the signs. ''I was starting to get a few little lines around my mouth and eyes and some frown lines on my forehead,'' she said. ''But I didn't think I needed a face-lift yet. I wanted something to perk me up.''

title: No One to Play With
description: NEVER mind that the sun is shining, neighbors who have been hibernating all winter start appearing in backyards and front lawns, and daylight savings time means that it's actually pleasant to run errands well past the dinner hour.

title: The 'Primitives'
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Girl,It Was Scandalous!
description: The Crenshaw high-school prom queen wore Valentino. And that wasn't the only thing Veronika Bozeman had in common with Julia Roberts at this year's Oscars. They both grinned ear to ear as they accepted the top honor voted by their peers. ''I can't believe it,'' Veronika gushed to the press. ''I'm flabbergasted.''

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: For Want of Mark, Chance Was Lost
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: When Science and Politics Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSPLANT FRONTIERS: A special report.; Healthy Give Organs to Dying, Raising Issue of Risk and Ethics
description: On a gray morning in Minneapolis, Tammy Hoff and Dormae Gebhardt sat in adjacent hospital beds making brave jokes with their husbands while waiting to be wheeled off to the operating room. It was a typical hospital scene, except for one detail: the two women, both in their early 30's, were perfectly healthy, and about to have major surgery that they did not need.

title: Business; Suddenly, Less Plaid Is More for Burberry's Chief
description: RADIATING all the energy of an elegant exclamation point, Rose Marie Bravo, clad in a slim red coat and tartan scarf, strode into Burberry's flagship store here recently and surveyed the new fall collection.

title: DataBank; Rate-Cut Hopes Overpower Profit Worries
description: Despite new warnings about corporate earnings shortfalls and reports showing that the economy remains weak, many stocks ended the week modestly higher, buoyed by expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates when it meets this week.

title: Gay Films Arrive, and Are Met With a Gallic Shrug
description: IN the French drama ''Come Undone,'' opening Friday, the director Sbastien Lifshitz serves up a pair of randy male teenagers on vacation who fall into each other's arms as effortlessly as characters in the films of Eric Rohmer fall into deep conversation. But it is not ''le coming out'' (an Anglicism that has become as much a part of the French vernacular as ''Le Big Mac'' and ''le marketing'') that proves to be the dilemma of its brooding protagonist Mathieu (Jrmie Elkam); it's the dissolution of a first love -- a feeling that resonates no matter what flavor your sexuality. It is more a coming-of-age than a coming out tale.

title: Poison
description: BODY TOXIC

title: Watching Grass Grow, And Commenting on It
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Seek Man in Attacks on 7 Women
description: Detectives in Queens are looking for a man in his 30's who they suspect attacked seven Asian women in Flushing, in two instances raping and robbing the victims, the police said.

title: Residue From Industrial Past Haunts State
description: RADIUM is not exactly something anyone would expect to find underfoot, but for Dr. Dada Jabbour, what was surprising was that no one thought to look for it in the former clock factories that once housed a thriving manufacturing industry in Connecticut.

title: Not Stuffy, A Summer Port
description: Summertime port is no oxymoron when you open Otima, Warre's 10-year-old tawny. As soft and light as a caress, and awash in walnut, caramel and prune flavors, this beguiling Portuguese wine contradicts port's stuffy image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BAE (BUROFSKY)
description: SCHWARTZ-Bae (Burofsky). Of West New York, NJ. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Paul Burofsky, Lisa Rubin, P. J. Sklar and Amy Mach. Dear sister of Sylvia Gould and Sally Hurwitz. Loving grandmother of ten grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. Contributions to Hackensack University Medical Center Hospice Program, 30 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, NJ 07601.

title: The Willow Inn Gets Another New Look
description: SOME might remember the Willow Inn several renovations ago, when it was called The Willows. Despite those redos, the restaurant always seemed to retain the roughness of a Scout cabin. The most recent improvement, however, went deeper than slapping on a coat of paint. The reconfigured entry with its heavy polished door, the flowers, sconces, blinds and table lamps -- all contribute to the newly minted atmosphere of gentrification that Armonk has undergone in the last decade.

title: For Want of Mark, Chance Was Lost
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POSTINGS: 87 Units in Hoboken; Condominiums By a Park
description: The Columbus condominium complex recently completed in the center of Hoboken, N.J., offers something not easily found in the dense city along the Hudson -- light, air and open space.

title: The Restless American: On Ed Ruscha's Road
description: IT'S an odd thing about Ed Ruscha. His cowboy charisma has done as much to muddy his artistic contribution as the fact of the place in which he has chosen to make it, Los Angeles. If you were going to cast an L.A. artist in a movie, you'd cast Ed Ruscha, even before you'd cast his old pal Dennis Hopper. Then you might look at the work.

title: Elise Wood, John Hicks Jr.
description: Elise Wood, a jazz flutist, and John Hicks Jr., a jazz pianist, are to be married today at the home of their friends Marjorie and Sherwood Sumner in Great Barrington, Mass. The Rev. Gilbert Caldwell, a United Methodist minister, will officiate.

title: The World; Twilight in the Land of the Gnomes
description: WHEN the British supermarket chain Tesco started selling garden furniture earlier this year, garden gnomes, pointy-hatted staples of British lawns for more than 100 years, were expected to be among the most popular items.

title: In Ukraine, Pope Tries to Heal Rift With Orthodox Church
description: Setting aside objections from the Orthodox church that broke with Rome a millennium ago, John Paul II made his first visit to Ukraine today and tried to placate his unwilling hosts.

title: Er, Um (Ahem)
description: On the subject of ''er,'' I believe that one of the ur-examples of its usage might be found in the Superman comic books of the 1950's. The Man of Steel, caught in an embarrassing moment (usually involving Lois Lane's suspicions about his true identity), would sprinkle his response with a few well-placed ''ers.''

title: Taking the M Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Definitive Roles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, PHILIP P., PH.D.
description: HAIM-Philip P., Ph.D. Psychoanalyst. June 22, 2001. Loving husband of Roberta. Devoted father of Kenneth and Sara. Cherished son of Sara and the late Savas. Beloved brother of Allegra Despotidis, Susie Stone, Anna Burak and Lee Haim.

title: Coping With a Tax That Has Nine Lives
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S idea was simple enough: First thing we do, let's kill all the death taxes. . . .

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Harvard's Hoard
description: Next Sunday, Lawrence Summers becomes the 27th president of Harvard. But the distance from the Treasury Department to this particular ivory tower is not as great as it once might have been. Summers will have less money to play with than he did in his last job, as treasury secretary, but the endowment of the institution he inherits has climbed in recent months to as much as $19 billion -- a sum greater than the physical assets of McDonald's, the G.D.P. of Ecuador, the net worth of all but 5 of the Forbes 400 or, according to The Boston Globe, the endowment of every nonprofit institution in the world after the Roman Catholic Church. As the head of Harvard, there will be no escaping the burdens of high finance.

title: Demotion to Test Driver Was Good Career Move
description: The words test driver drum up images of the glamorous, dangerous and slightly crazy men of the right stuff. But in Formula One this year, testing the world's most advanced racecars has become a kind of haven, a cure for drivers who have hit a roadblock in their careers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, MARGARET
description: AMES-Margaret. On June 22, in Elizabethtown, NY.
