A classics scholar and author who taught at Riverdale Country School and Hunter College, she is survived by husband Russell of Westport, New York, children David Foley of San Francisco and Barbara Foley of East Orange, NJ, and three grandchildren. Memorial contributions to the Ballard Park Foundation, Westport, New York 12993.

title: INVESTING WITH/Derwood S. Chase Jr. And David B. Scott; Chase Growth Fund
description: DON'T confuse the global megabank Chase Manhattan with the Chase Investment Counsel Corporation in Charlottesville, Va., investment adviser to the $36 million Chase Growth fund.

title: The Codes Here Don't Have the Right Ring
description: JOE OHRIN is an actor and comedian who lives in Belleville. But that's not what most casting directors think. Emblazoned on his resume is a 212 area code -- three little digits that even in this day of area-code overload, everyone knows stands for Manhattan. What that means, or is supposed to imply, is that the Mr. Ohrin is a worldly, sophisticated, hip, happening, Seinfeld kind of guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTACK, ADA LILLIAN (NEE PITZER)
description: SCHUSTACK-Ada Lillian (nee Pitzer). On June 20. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Daniel (Lori), Miriam (Howard) and Zachary. Loving grandmother of Joshua and Eli. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Cherished godmother of Esther Fallon. Services Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ, Sunday 12:30. For information ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' 800 522-0588. Contributions to the Kidney Disease Foundation in memory of Henry Bergman.

title: Naturally
description: Horizon Organic is committed to producing safe, flavorful and healthful products. And we are proud that we have helped both small and large dairy farmers convert to organic production.

title: Sarah Rafferty, Santtu Seppala
description: Sarah Gray Rafferty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael G. Rafferty Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Aleksanteri Olli-Pekka Seppala, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antti V. Seppala of Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Alfred Riendeau performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Colorful, Low-Maintenance and All-Season
description: IN many ways, William T. Gotelli was a man ahead of his time. In the years following World War II, when landscaping across the nation primarily consisted of swaths of colorful annuals, he became passionately attached to conifers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an answer in the Sunday Q & A column last week about the whereabouts of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, the 104-year- old widow of the Chinese Nationalist leader, who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, misstated her relationship to Chiang Ching-kuo, a former ruler of Taiwan. He was her stepson, not her son.

title: Napa Sips in New Settings
description: THERE'S been a building boom lately in the Napa Valley, as wineries open new tasting rooms and renovate visitor facilities. And another major project under way, scheduled to be completed in November, celebrates wine along with food and the arts.

title: Watching Grass Grow, And Commenting on It
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; A Chance to Live, and Then Describe, Her Own American Dream
description: WHEN Dewan Kazi Fahima was named her eighth-grade valedictorian in 1997, her family had been in this country only five years and her parents didn't know what the word meant.

title: June 17-23; An Out of Window Experience
Classic Seafood and Pastas by the Bay
description: PICTURE outdoor tables with blue umbrellas and vistas of docks, boats and rosy-fingered sunsets. Inside, diners sit at cloth-covered tables in well-appointed dining rooms where vintage black and white photographs of Long Island locales and mounted half hulls of model sailboats dot the walls. It sounds like the backdrop to marvelous summer dining, but till now the restaurants at the Brewer Capri East Marina in Port Washington have not made the grade. P. W.'s Chowderhouse, last season's entry, was here less than a year.

title: A Majority of One
description: In George W. Bush, America has its first M.B.A. president, who has promised to bring a businesslike approach to government. He may wish to consider applying the concept of a mandatory retirement, perhaps at age 70, instead of life tenure, to federal judges. Public companies have a policy for their officers to retire at a certain age. Only in government would you have a serious discussion about a 71-year-old taking the place of a 76-year-old in a position of such great importance.

title: The Equal-Opportunity Offender
description: What do Puff Daddy and Bill Clinton have in common besides an eye for the ladies and enormous legal bills? ''Both should be brought to justice for crimes committed against Black America for the sake of personal gain.'' Or so it goes in ''The Boondocks,'' Aaron McGruder's daily struggle to keep it real in the funny papers. The comic strip, now appearing in more than 250 newspapers daily, chronicles the adjustment of Huey and Riley Freeman, two African-American kids plucked from their idyllic ghetto-fabulous existence on Chicago's South Side to live with their grandfather in the suburbs (or ''boondocks'').

title: Rumors Aside, Gramm Insists He's Running
description: Rumors Aside, Gramm Insists He's Running

title: Corrections
description: A review on June 3 about ''A Voyage for Madmen,'' by Peter Nichols, referred incorrectly to the boats that placed first and second in the 2000 Vende Globe solo round-the-world sailboat race. Both were boats of advanced design but only one hull, not multihulls.

title: He's a Jazz Riddle Wrapped In Self-Made Mystery
description: WAYNE SHORTER was rehearsing an updated version of ''Water Babies,'' one of his better-known works, for a concert here at the Spoleto Festival. His bandmates wanted to know how he planned to establish the tune's regular rhythm after a loose rubato intro. ''Let's not set it,'' he said. ''I'd always rather go for elusiveness than clarification.''

title: Being Put on Hold
description: To the Editor:

title: Look to PBS
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Rowayton; Park at the Rail Station? First, Endure The Wait.
description: IN this part of Norwalk, where many residents aren't accustomed to standing in line for anything, the annual ritual of queuing up to get a parking permit for the Rowayton train station falls somewhere between a folk concert and waiting to be served by the Soup Nazi. Indulge in chitchat, read the paper, or sprawl out and sleep, but don't even think about sidestepping the protocol of The Wait.

title: School Daze
description: SCHOOLING

title: A Devastating Lack of Awareness
description: STRESS, of course, is not good for you. But when it comes to heart disease and its consequences, cardiologists say they wish women would feel a little more of it.

title: Struggling to Carve Out Common Ground, U.N. Tackles AIDS
description: The devastation is not in dispute. Worldwide, 36 million people are estimated to have AIDS or be carrying the virus that causes it. Nearly 22 million have died, many of them children. And new infections gallop on, at the rate of 5 million last year.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THIS PLACE ON THIRD AVENUE

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about Pratt Institute's annual scholarship benefit dinner at the Rainbow Room on June 13 misstated the profession of Ralph Appelbaum, who was honored. He is an exhibition designer, not an architect.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 3 with an article about the Massachusetts State House referred imprecisely to a section of Boston. The skyscrapers in the distance are in the Back Bay, not downtown.

title: Cross-Examining Milton
description: HOW MILTON WORKS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMBARDI, EVELYN
description: LOMBARDI - Evelyn. Dearest Evelyn, we will miss you and love you forever. Sandy, Selig, Jill, Howie & Melissa

title: Sibling Nuns Will Go to Prison for Protesting at U.S. Military School
description: In all their years as Franciscan nuns, the Hennessey sisters have led lives of intentional simplicity: simple food, simple dress, simple quarters.

title: I.N.S. Both Jailer and Parent To a Child Without a Nation
description: For more than 13 months, an 8-year-old Nigerian girl with pigtails and a thousand-watt smile has been held in custody here by immigration officials, abandoned by relatives after she arrived alone in the United States and now trapped in a legal limbo.

title: BackTalk; Climbing Everest: Risking Death for a View From the Top
description: Only on Mount Everest is failure heroic. After more than 28,000 feet of climbing, Owen West had only 900 feet more to climb to reach the summit last month. But he could not make it.

title: A Sassy Lass Makes Way for Staid
description: She lounged at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street, blond, buxom, pretty as a mud flap girl. Her silhouette was neon, 4 feet wide and 20 feet long, and her eyes sparkled with lights. She was young, nearly 6, and was the marquee fixture of the Playpen, a sex-related business. For many, she symbolized a seedier Times Square.

title: Men's Magazines: How Much Substance Behind the Covers?
description: SCAN the covers of men's health and fitness magazines and you'll see a lot of provocative headlines like ''Nuke Your Gut,'' ''Amazing Abs in Minutes!,'' ''Instant Sex'' and ''Testosterone -- Top Off Your Tank Naturally.''

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Westbury Metals Reports Record Sales for Year

title: The Nation; Breadline, What Breadline?
description: THIS month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen slightly in May, to 4.4 percent. The decline was the first in nine months, and with many stocks rising again, it suggested that the economic slowdown of 2001 might be near its end.

title: Debra Harounian, Harlan Peltz
description: Debra Dina Harounian, a daughter of Roberta and David Harounian of Kings Point, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Harlan David Peltz, the son of Lauren S. Veronis and the stepson of John J. Veronis of New York. Rabbi Mordechai Waxman performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: SOAPBOX; Food Court (Formerly Ridgewood), N.J.
description: THE Village of Ridgewood. A town of charming center-hall colonials, schools that are thought to be way-stations to the Ivy League, and restaurants that are rated Excellent. And restaurants rated Good. And restaurants rated Fair.

title: Necks and Elbows Are O.K., but Knees Are His Thing
description: WHEN asked how it feels to blow out a knee, an athlete is likely to recall the sudden, sickening snap, not unlike the sound of celery breaking in two, or the dizzying blast of pain. But when Jesse Cohen talks about tearing the anterior cruciate ligament of his right knee during football practice at Cornell in 1976 -- an injury that ended his college athletic career on the spot -- what he remembers is the sense of loss.

title: Pirro Explains Decision Not to Prosecute Web Case
description: WHEN word leaked out about a Web site created by two seniors at Horace Greeley High school here, many in the community were appalled. The site included detailed descriptions of the alleged sexual activities of female students, their names and addresses, along with personal and sensitive information about the girls and their families.

title: June 17-23; Tiny Fingers, Toes and Taste Buds
description: Maybe Proust's mother ate madeleines when she was pregnant.

title: Ulster Power Sharing Is Threatened if I.R.A. Stays Armed
description: David Trimble said today he held little hope of any imminent disarmament moves by the Irish Republican Army. As a consequence, he would carry out his threat to force a halt to the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly next week.

title: Forgetful, Fearing Alzheimer's and Hoping for a Cure
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- KEN clutches hope in his hand as the doctor's questions start. It is a wrinkled newspaper article about an Alzheimer's vaccine. He pulls it from his wallet with a look of anticipation flashing briefly on his face  before he forgets to ask the doctor about it.

title: FERRY FOOD
description: After the Cape May-Lewes ferries failed three federal Food and Drug Administration inspections last year, the Delaware River and Bay Authority has decided to suspend cooking on ferries until at least 2002. The inspections turned up violations ranging from flies on the food to improper storage to a lack of training for food-handling employees. For now, the authority is selling packaged items that customers can heat in microwave ovens on the ferries. More than 13,000 passengers take the ferries between Lewes, Del., and Cape May each year. The Authority had hoped to use the ferries for weddings and other parties this summer, but that has been put off for the time being as well. Robert Strauss

title: The Worst-Case T
description: Extreme tourists could well take to Ted Baker's new line of Endurance T-shirts, designed to protect against elements that may not have made it onto the average shopper's radar screen. The color-blocked cotton shirts ($75 at Ted Baker) are treated with various emollient finishes, which are supposed to render them mosquito-repellent, UV-protectant, antibacterial, antistress, windproof, stain-resistant, anti-crease, aromatherapeutic, moisturizing and fast-drying. All that, and they're washable.

title: June 17-23; Prime-Minister Maker
description: Simeon II became the first of Eastern Europe's Great Pretenders -- former monarchs who still lay claim to their thrones -- to return to power. Bulgarians gave his fledgling political movement almost 43 percent of the vote, for 120 seats, or half the Parliament, more than double the vote for the outgoing prime minister, Ivan Kostov. The former Communists, running as Socialists, won 48 seats. Simeon must cobble together a coalition cabinet and find a prime minister, and is likely to keep influencing events, kinglike, from behind the scenes.

title: Strange Goings-On in That Blessed Plot
description: EVEN the title seems weird. Compared with, say, ''Barchester Chronicles,'' ''Brideshead Revisited'' or just about any other classy mini-series to come out of Britain via PBS, ''Gormenghast'' just doesn't have the ring of a classic. The setting for this extravagant two-part PBS presntation, a BBC America and WGBH Boston co-production, is a vast, decrepit castle with owls in the attic, rats in the cellar and lunatics in the throne room -- not a proper fit either, within the traditional British scenery of rolling hills and dreaming spires. And whatever will an American audience make of the show's bizarre brand of humor, which seems inspired in equal measure by Shakespeare's philosophical fools and those clowns on the iconoclastic British series ''The Goon Show''?

title: Contradictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Gambale, Marc Lederman
description: Jennifer Lynn Gambale, the daughter of Irene and Anthony Gambale of Downingtown, Pa., was married yesterday to Marc Richard Lederman, the son of Ita and Barry Lederman of East Rockaway, N.Y. The Rev. James Casey performed the ceremony at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: A Kennedy Readies Herself to Run for Maryland Governor
description: One by one her male siblings in the Kennedy clan have taken their turn in the spotlight but shown mixed results in the family's endless call to politics. But not Robert F. Kennedy's firstborn, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who, in her seventh year as lieutenant governor of Maryland, has worked quietly at grass-roots politics to position herself as the front-runner in the race for governor next year.

title: Looking for Health News? A Bikini Belly? There's More to Read
description: IN the last few years, women's magazines that focus primarily on health issues have multiplied faster than multiple-birth baby strollers on the Upper East Side.

title: Paying a Price for Drinking Men Under the Table
description: ''Hello, you chaps.''

title: Webb Near L.P.G.A. Title After Her Ordinary Day
description: Karrie Webb never found a rhythm in swirling winds that made club selection difficult today, but she maintained a three-shot lead going into the final round of the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship as she tries to capture the one major tournament that has eluded her.

title: On Nasdaq, Pennies May Be Good for Small Traders
description: GET ready to pay higher commissions to trade stocks. And, believe it or not, the change may actually be good for you.

title: Gay Prom Is Fine; How About Gay Rights?
description: That the gay prom on Long Island [''Gays Enjoy the Night at a Prom of Their Own,'' June 17] was covered by 52 media outlets demonstrates the herd mentality of journalists. Similar journalistic energy should have been directed at questioning local legislators about their views on the proposed Sexual Orientation Non-Discrimination Act now before the state Senate.

title: Corrections
description: This chart, which appeared last Sunday, incorrectly labeled the trend line as the ''average ratio of emissions to G.D.P.'' The line actually represents a statistical calculation known as linear regression and a more accurrate description is provided above. The chart should be used to compare emission levels in countries with similar G.D.P.'s. It is not intended to compare countries of vastly differing G.D.P.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ANN (NEE WEST)
description: WILLIAMS-Ann (nee West), 78. Editor and literary agent. Widow of radio producer, Albert N. Williams, Jr., mother of Chicago Reader theater critic, Albert Williams. Died May 25, Northwestern Mem. Hospital, Chicago. Survivors also include stepchildren, Christopher Williams & Holly (Robert) McFarlane. Contributions to palliative care/home hospice program, Northwestern Hospital, 222 East Superior, Chicago, IL. 60611.

title: What the Market Will Bear
description: FRONTIERS OF LEGAL THEORY

title: A Majority of One
description: Considering her position as Supreme Court justice and the impact her decisions may have on our country, I find it disturbing that O'Connor might embrace a motto, ''Maybe in error but never in doubt,'' suggesting that making an error in judgment is less important than losing sleep over it!

title: Lisa Krupnick, Christopher Errico
description: Lisa Jane Krupnick, a daughter of Lesley Rigler Krupnick of New York and the late Robert L. Krupnick, was married yesterday to Robert Christopher Errico, a son of Nicolena and Robert L. Errico of New York. The Rev. Joseph A. Novak performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's of the Lake in Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: In Schundler, A Rallying Cry For the Right
description: John Tomicki, a lobbyist for conservative social causes, usually shuffles through the corridors of the State House with a stooped gait and a resigned smirk on his face, the product of too many legislative and political disappointments over the years.

title: Safe Poets Society
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Oyster Was Their World
description: BEFORE it was the Big Apple, New York was the big oyster, at a time American oysters were known for their size. A dubious endorsement came from the English novelist William Makepeace Thackeray, who wrote that eating an American oyster was like eating a baby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINIKES, JACK
description: MINIKES-Jack. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jack Minikes, beloved father of Michael Minikes, a dedicated leader who serves on the steering committee of our Wall Street Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to Michael and his wife, Cheryl; to Mr. Minikes' beloved wife, Kitty; to his son, Stewart; to his four grandchildren; and to his entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOSKO, EDWARD J.
description: KOSKO-Edward J. 3/6/20-6/24/86 Only goodness and kindness will follow you, and you will live in God forever.

title: Ideas & Trends; From a Mural, New Life In a Debate Over Memory
description: FOR almost 60 years, a series of wall paintings by Bruno Schulz, the Polish-Jewish writer and artist, lay buried beneath a coat of pink paint on a pantry wall in the once-Polish, now-Urkainian city of Drogobych where Schulz was shot and killed in 1942 by a Nazi storm trooper. In that state, the paintings survived -- unseen, but untouched.

title: Creative Works With a Political Edge
description: DURING the last half of the month, New Haven has been staging ''Art and Ideas,'' an elaborate annual festival that encompasses all the arts. Many of the ideas are political and that theme is being aired in lectures and panel discussions involving almost all of the city's cultural institutions.

title: 'Fun City' Era: The Lindsay Years
description: ''There was little in John Lindsay's background that suggested a political career in New York City,'' writes Vincent J. Cannato, an adjunct fellow at the Hudson Institute, in ''The Ungovernable City: John Lindsay and His Struggle to Save New York'' (Basic Books). The 703-page work, which is appearing seven months after Lindsay's death, is a portrait of the larger-than-life figure who presided over the city from 1966 to 1973. The book also explores how the Lindsay era reflected larger themes of urban decline.

title: Dozens Die as Quake Strikes Southern Peru
description: A powerful earthquake shook southern Peru, killing at least 40 people, injuring hundreds of others and sending dozens of homes, churches and buildings tumbling to the ground.

title: A Place Where They Don't Dread Coming to Work
description: AFTER Sharon Maynard's husband of 20 years decided he did not want to be married anymore, she felt her life slipping out of control -- and felt herself slipping into depression. As a single mother of a teenage son, she did not know what to think and what to do and, least of all, where to turn for help.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: Questions for Martin Short; Who's Asking?
description: Q: Your character Jiminy Glick is the star of your new show. Who is Jiminy Glick?

title: Taking Care of Everybody but Herself
description: WOMEN are usually model patients, taking responsibility not just for their own health but also for the health of their husbands and children. We're much better than men about getting regular checkups, taking medications the way we're told to, reading up on illnesses that strike us or our loved ones, talking to other women with the same health concerns.

title: The Red-State Network
description: On an abnormally warm spring day, eight people are seated in what half of America might call a political haven and the other half might call the Belly of the Beast. This is the Sixth Avenue office of Roger E. Ailes, onetime G.O.P. political consultant, TV producer and, these days, chairman and C.E.O. of Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Channel. It's the kind of meeting you find at any TV news organization: the daily 3:30 story roundup. The main players in the room are Ailes and John Moody, the senior vice president for news -- a wry, quiet man who decides what gets to live on Fox's air. From the Washington bureau, the voice of the Fox News anchor Brit Hume crackles out of a speakerphone on Ailes's desk. In short order, the discussion wends its way to George W. Bush's tax cut, which today (after meetings between Congressional negotiators and the White House) has landed at the figure of $1.35 trillion. It's the opinion of the room that somehow the Democrats are going to try to claim victory for this, as they have beaten the president down from $1.6 trillion. ''Oh, yes,'' Hume says sardonically from the box, ''it's a stinging defeat for the president.''

title: A Black Drama Beats the Clichs, and the Odds
description: THE Showtime series ''Soul Food,'' which begins its second season Wednesday night, has the distinction of being one of the few dramas with a predominantly African-American cast to even have a second season. But it's not so much about race; it's about family, and everything endemic to being in one.

title: Japan's New Superstar Redefines Its Politics
description: Adoring crowds form whenever he appears in public. His Internet newsletter is a runaway hit, with some two million subscribers. Even opposition politicians have begun invoking his name to buff their credentials as reformers.

title: Amy Adler, Lenn Robbins
description: Amy Mehler Adler, a law professor, and Lenn Robbins, a sportswriter, were married on Thursday evening by Rabbi Brian Nevins-Goldman at Studio 450 in Manhattan.

title: Lessons of a Funeral
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nurses' Tale: Five Voices From Around the Nation
description: How have nurses' lives been reshaped by the pressures of staff shortages, managed care and the onrush of medical technology? Women's Health asked nurses around the country to talk about what they do, how they do it and how nursing is changing.

title: Rainy Days and Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: A Borough Used to Brickbats Is Hurled Some Modest Bouquets
description: After Yankee Stadium and the zoo, the Bronx has been best known during the last quarter century for its ravaged buildings, persistent drug problem and soaring crime rates, making it the borough most likely to be avoided.

title: Economic Anxiety Among the Affluent
description: The economic slowdown and stock market volatility have made many Americans nervous about their finances, and survey results released last week show that even the nation's most affluent people are a little jittery.

title: Kasparov Finally Cracks Kramnik's Berlin Wall
description: After five tries without any success, Garry Kasparov finally managed to defeat Vladimir Kramnik in his favorite defense and won first place in the Astana double-round-robin International Tournament in Kazakhstan, May 19 to June 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, KENNETH R.
description: COLLINS-Kenneth R. Age 46, of New York City, formerly of Grenada, MS, died at his home in New York on June 22, 2001. Kenn was preceded in death by his father, Clinton U. Collins. He is survived by his mother Ruby S. Collins of Grenada, MS, three brothers Jan Collins, Kevin Collins, and Kelly Collins, one sister Cathy C. Bowles, all of Jackson, MS, and his companion Daniel Barker of Brewster, NY. Funeral services will be held at the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church located at 50th St and Park Ave on Monday, June 25th, at 10 AM, with a reception immediately following on the third floor terrace at St. Bartholomew's. To honor Kenn's life, please make memorial contributions to the School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NYC 10023, for sponsorship of deserving ballet students.

title: Sister Act
description: FANNY AND ADELAIDE

title: POSTINGS: Selling a Home to a Celebrity; Psychic or Real, It's About Space
description: How do you talk to celebrities when you're trying to sell them apartments?

title: A Rising Tide for Value Funds
description: Investors have turned to value stock mutual funds in the first half of the year as funds focusing on rapidly growing companies slumped, a study showed.

title: United States Leads Reining Nations Cup
description: Clint Haverty rode Jumping Jack Whiz to a score of 218 points to lead the United States Equestrian Team to first place after the first round of the Reining Nations Cup Competition yesterday at the Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Cold War Illustrated
description: At the age of 4, Peter Kuper read Crockett Johnson's ''Harold and the Purple Crayon'' and decided to be an artist. At 19, he moved from Cleveland to New York, and in 1979, when he was 21, Kuper started the underground comic zine World War 3 Illustrated, which, with a childhood friend, Seth Tobocman, he has published since. SPEECHLESS (Top Shelf, $19.95), a collection of Kuper's work, documents a career dedicated to bringing the glee of a child's immersion in a picture book to adult concerns like justice, romance and freedom of speech. Though he draws comics, Kuper does not make joke books; instead he uses stencils with collage, watercolors or pencil drawings to depict urban chaos in panels astonishing for their clarity and concision. ''Speechless'' includes Kuper's illustrations for covers for Time and Newsweek, work as politically engaged as what he has done for The Village Voice. His weekly New York Minute strip for The Daily News, his DC Comics book (''The System'') and the graphic novels he has adapted from works by writers like Franz Kafka and Upton Sinclair exhibit a unity of vision and distinctive style. Since 1997, Kuper has been drawing Mad Magazine's venerable cold war comic series ''Spy vs. Spy,'' first created in 1961 by Antonio Prohias. ''It's a hoot to have them destroy each other every month,'' Kuper writes . ''Also, I've got a whole new audience of kids I can now subvert.'' Elissa Lin Meyers

title: Rangers Make Goaltending Their Priority in the Draft
description: The Rangers chose a goalie from Western Canada, Dan Blackburn, in the first round of the N.H.L. entry draft today. But it was their second-round pick, Fyodor Tjutin, a defenseman from Russia, who made the most interesting comments at the National Car Rental Center.

title: Pacific Crab Is Becoming a Local Bully
description: TURN over almost any rock uncovered by low tide in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut and you probably will uncover a small, purplish-black alien with six colorfully banded legs and two nimble claws -- a Pacific shore crab.

title: To Be a Slave In Brooklyn
description: Northerners tend to believe that slavery was confined to the South and that the North was composed of ''free'' states. The truth is that slavery was practiced all over the early United States, including the Dutch colonial settlement of New Amsterdam, which later became New York. The Dutch established New Amsterdam in the early 1600's and immediately imported Africans to work on farms and public works like the fortress wall from which Wall Street gets its name. By the 18th century, New York had more enslaved Africans than any other city in the country, with the exception of Charleston, S.C. Slavery was abolished here only in 1827.

title: Kimberly Henderson, Mark Johnson
description: Kimberly Michele Henderson, a daughter of Franzine and Harold Henderson of Oakton, Va., was married yesterday to Mark Jay Johnson, the son of Melodie and Mark D. Johnson of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: For Him, All Theater District Celebrities Are a Caricature
description: If you were drawing a caricature of Richard Baratz, you might start with the cheeks, which make him look special.

title: Melanie Crowley, Peter Mullan
description: Melanie Dsire Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Jones Crowley of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Downing Mullan, the son of Nancy Mullan-Demirjian of New York and W. Richard Mullan of Tucson. The Very Rev. Carleton P. Jones performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in New Haven.

title: A Majority of One
description: O'Connor seems to have little faith in any branch of the government other than the judicial. Having once served in the Arizona Legislature, she, according to one report, ''understood that these were not such wise deliberative bodies.'' However nondeliberative legislatures may or may not be, they have the distinct advantage of having been elected. She sits unelected, unanswerable and untouchable by the people -- and that smacks of imperialism.

title: How Pipeline And Landscape Live Together
description: Just as the United States is now debating the trade-offs between energy and the environment, particularly in Alaska, a generation ago a similar debate was focused on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. Ferocious claims were made by proponents and opponents alike.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: Process; Aftermath Class
description: A school full of children, a gruesome multiple homicide, a chaotic frenzy of terror and grief: as familiar as this morbid routine has become in America, it was until earlier this month unknown in Japan. So when stabbings at Ikeda Elementary School in a suburb of Osaka left 8 students dead, 15 wounded and thousands in mourning, it was no surprise that the official response resembled official responses in Littleton, Colo., and Santee, Calif.

title: When a Parking Ticket Is the Lesser Evil
description: East End anglers who've been ticketed for leaving their cars parked in remote areas should consider themselves lucky [''Idyllic Beach Incites Battle Over Access,'' June 10] compared with their colleagues farther west, where the State Police have been leaving sportsmen (and women) stranded in the middle of nowhere after impounding cars left in off-road parking areas along the parkways crossing the islands of the Great South Bay.

title: The Voice Of Misfit Girls Like Me
description: NINA SIMONE is a hard case.

title: Rebecca Loud, James Zug Jr.
description: Rebecca Livingston Loud, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Loud of Lincoln, Mass., was married yesterday to James Wharton Zug Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zug Sr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., in a Quaker ceremony at the Wellesley Friends Meeting in Wellesley, Mass. Hal White, the clerk of the Meeting, signed the marriage certificate.

title: Mary Greenway, Bernard Rogers
description: A few days before his wedding on June 16, Bernard Rogers was sitting in his favorite hangout, Cafe Bernard in Basalt, Colo. He was showing off the wedding necktie he had designed to the waiter, who studied the hearts-and-hiking-boots motif and said, ''So, you're in love and you're a shoe salesman?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONKITE, EUGENE P., M.D.
description: CRONKITE-Eugene P., M.D. Died peacefully June 23, 2001. Distinguished leader, researcher, teacher, role model and friend to hundreds. We admired him, we loved him and we will miss him. Kanti Rai, on behalf of his students around the world

title: Investing; Tax Rule Offers a New Peek at Funds
description: A SECURITIES and Exchange Commission regulation, scheduled to kick in later this year, will make it easier for mutual fund investors to gauge their tax liability. Last year in particular, as the market sank, many investors were surprised to learn that they had to pay capital gains taxes despite losing money in the market.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not right. You have to think of the worst-case scenario. If I woke up and found out that my mother or brother had died so that I could have a transplant, I wouldn't want to be alive.''

title: Tips to Keep the Pump Primed (It Isn't That Hard)
description: You only have one heart. Here are 10 tips for keeping it healthy:

description: True Northeast

description: WYSELL-Bertram J. (Buddy). Born on May 23, 1920, died June 18, 2001. Loving husband, brother, dear old dad and grandfather extraordinaire. Loved by: Wolfman, Sheila, Stretch, Rosebud, Sport, the Kid, the Little Prince, Love Bug, the Duke and all who knew him. In lieu of flowers send donations to Patient Advocates for Advanced Cancer Treatments, Inc, 1143 Parmelee N.W., Grand Rapids, MI 49504.

description: Dr. James H. Sammons, a former top executive of the American Medical Association who turned the organization around during a financial crisis in the 1980's, died on June 17 in Chicago, where he lived. He was 74.

description: The momentum picked up by Bret D. Schundler's insurgent campaign for governor has stirred concern among Republicans in New Jersey's Congressional delegation, many of whom have backed his opponent in the primary on Tuesday, Bob Franks.

title: After Long Layoff, Beautiful Pleasure Takes the Day Off
description: The old girl had not been out kicking up her heels in more than seven months, but she showed she still could cause some excitement -- up to a point.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Page 9 in Long Island copies of the Real Estate section today about Port Jefferson carries an erroneous map in some copies. It is a duplicate of a map elsewhere in the section, with an article about downtown St. Louis.

title: Vegetarians
description: To the Editor: Thanks for the article on vegetarian dining. I really appreciated the tips on travel books.

title: Capriati Shrugs Off The Feeding Frenzy
description: If possible, and for only two weeks, Jennifer Capriati would like to live in the blissful ignorance of a game-show contestant locked away in an isolation booth.

title: Liberties; Tales From the Crypt
description: It was bad enough when fat cats got to buy the Lincoln Bedroom. It will be worse if they can begin the bidding for Abe's frock coat.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Festival in Bridgeport

title: Excuses Seem Empty On Not Honoring Officer
description: While I have long been proud of having grown up in Manhasset, the actions and attitudes of some Manhasset residents these days cause me to feel very differently.

title: Language Lessons
description: To the Editor: The Letters on Travel on May 6 about learning foreign languages inspired me to write about my experiences. In 1995, I read a letter in the Travel section about a French-language school in Tours, the Centre Linguistique pour trangers. Based on the letter writer's recommendation, I attended it. I had a most rewarding experience during my two-week stay.

title: How I Undid My Summer Vacation
description: Remember when people referred to a vacation as a getaway? You don't hear that synonym so much today, now that cell phones, pagers and faxes can interrupt our lives most anywhere, anytime. Some people object to the idea of a working vacation, while others manage to mingle labor and leisure and turn a profit, too.

title: Airport Phones Do Double Duty
description: Travelers can now chat on the telephone while surfing the Web using a new type of public telephone that AT&T is installing in airports. The AT&T Public Phone 2000i, which combines a high-speed Internet connection and e-mail with voice calling, has a 12-inch touch-sensitive screen and a touch pad integrated into a full-size keyboard.

title: Old Mr. Flood
description: To the Editor:

title: A Team With More Smoke Than Fire
description: AN opportunity has arisen to examine the obstacles that have prevented architecture from re-establishing itself in New York as a medium of civil discourse. The occasion appeared two weeks ago with the announcement of the winners of a competition to design a nine-acre property, the so-called Con Ed site, on an East River stretch of Midtown Manhattan.

title: Footlights
description: Playing Banjo but Keeping His Day Job

title: Rebate History Doesn't Repeat Itself
description: PEOPLE are worried about energy shortages. Flared jeans are a common sight on Fifth Avenue. The Boston Red Sox are in first place. And the Treasury Department is preparing to mail billions of dollars in tax-rebate checks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCHIN, SULA
description: BARUCHIN-Sula. On June 23, 2001, after a 16 year illness. Survived by her husband Fred and daughters Aliyah and Celia. Shiva begins Sunday, June 24, 11 Tudor Rd, Hicksville, NY. Donations may be made to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, Port Washington, NY, or the Gurwin Foundation, Commack, NY.

title: A Director's Journey Into A Darkness Of the Heart
description: FOR more than a quarter-century, Steven Spielberg has been at the pinnacle of American filmmaking, the most famous, influential and consistently successful director in Hollywood. Beginning as a shaggy-haired wunderkind in the early 1970's, with a cadre of similar film school dreamers, he revolutionized movie-making and revitalized the classic Hollywood genres. He grew into a director who alternated between exploiting the visceral pleasures of pure, hyper-charged cinema in films like ''Jurassic Park'' and the ''Indiana Jones'' series and one who exploded the boundaries of the mainstream with bolder fare like ''Schindler's List'' and ''Saving Private Ryan.''

title: A Stockholm Must
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Stockholm'' by Erik SandbergDiment (May 27) was on target but did not include an important attraction. The nearly 500-year-old warship Vasa, in the Vasa Museum, is a truly extraordinary experience.

title: MORE WITHDRAWALS
description: Two more auto insurance companies last week filed plans to leave New Jersey, following the announcement June 12 that State Farm Indemnity Company, the state's largest auto insurer, will withdraw. In a letter to employees, American International cited financial losses and frustrations with a ''regulatory environment that denies rate relief.'' The governor's office said that the state would not bargain with the companies for rate increases. American International is the sixth largest auto insurer in New Jersey with 200,000 drivers. Newark Insurance insures 90,000. Anne Ruderman

title: MIND AND BODY; She Feels Sick. The Doctor Can't Find Anything Wrong.
description: EVERYBODY feels woozy sometimes. But by the time Chris Woodward was running to her doctor four times a week, she had been having dizzy spells for five years. Then she started having chest pains. But her doctor could not find any medical explanation for her symptoms.

title: Jennifer Winn, Constantine Dimas
description: Jennifer Mara Winn, a daughter of Arthur M. Winn of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Alice G. Winn, was married last evening at her father's house to Constantine Simos Dimas, the son of Nina Dimas of Elmhurst, Queens, and Simos C. Dimas of Bronxville, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, who was appointed a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day.

title: June 17-23; Money Isn't Everything
description: Coca-Cola said last week that it would put its extraordinary distribution network -- which not only moves Cokes to almost every corner of Africa, but gets the empties back for refills -- at the disposal of charities and government health workers. Its trucks could carry condoms, test kits and literature to remote clinics, a spokesman said. Coke will also help write ads for prevention campaigns and donate billboard space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HARRY B.
description: STEIN-Harry B. Passed away on June 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Fischbach). Devoted father of Juliet Stein, Susan and Martin Danoff, Nina and Irwin Wolf. Cherished grandfather of Linda and Michael Perrella, Deborah Chesbrough, Steven Salee and Hans Lupold, Douglas Danoff, Jennifer Danoff and Michael Bernstein. Adored great grandfather of Samuel and Joseph Perrella. A mighty oak has fallen. A giant in the lumber business for over 75 years; the Founder of Huntington Materials and Chairman of Bayport Lumber Corporation; a graduate of New York University & its Business School; the Founder and Past President of Temple Beth-El in Huntington, L.I. and former Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Suburbia Federal Savings and Loan Association. Died quietly in his sleep in his 93rd year leaving a legacy of quiet strength, implacable moral standards, dignity, intellect and love for his family and friends. He was the patriarch of our family and we will love him forever and cherish his memory. The funeral will be held on Sunday, June 24th at 11:30am at Riverside Funeral Home, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 516-487-9600

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEZIALI, EDITH
description: SPEZIALI-Edith. Died Thursday, June 14, at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 86. Born in Evanston, Illinois, she was a longtime New Yorker, living for a short time in Key West, Florida where she worked at the legendary Trade Winds. As a youth Edith received a full scholarship to the Art Students League of New York. Living in Greenwich Village she worked in association with many artists of the day, including John Cage, Merce Cunningham, and Willem DeKooning. For twenty years Ms. Speziali ran a highly successful program for two to fives at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and later was employed by the Garrett Wade Co. in Soho. An avid arts supporter Edith served on the Board of Directors of the American Line Theatre for eight years. In addition to championing numerous arts and environmental organizations, Edith enjoyed an ongoing association with the Canadian Film Board and was a lifetime member of the Cape May Historical Society.

title: Private Sector; Facts First, Lyrics Later
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire businessman who is running for mayor of New York, delivered some observations at the annual awards dinner of the New York Financial Writers Association last week that suggested he was still feeling his way as a politician, unaccustomed to shameless questions from the press and sometimes sounding a bit off-key.

title: Joanne Kornberger, Peter Warms
description: Joanne Kornberger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Kornberger of Park Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter James Warms, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Warms of Skillman, N.J. Msgr. James Turro performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Old Tappan, N.J.

title: When Science and Politics Collide

title: Three Who've Learned the Hardest Way
description: IN a cramped room at the Mount Sinai Hospital's Cardiac Care Center, time is marked by the loud, mechanical beating of Louis Fantauzzi's artificial heart. It is the sound of a tethered life, a life in suspension.

title: Lori Fitz-Gerald, Jonathan Feldman
description: Lori Gayle Fitz-Gerald and Jonathan Todd Feldman were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Pike, an Episcopal minister, performed a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Christian religious traditions.

title: Amy Morishima, William McLeod
description: Dr. Amy Morishima was married yesterday to William Allan McLeod. The Rev. David Quiring, an American Baptist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Wilson Memorial Union Church in Watchung, N.J.

title: Bad Smells, Boredom, Cursed Bananas
description: DAVE ALM called out across the deck of The Breakaway, a 42-foot sportfishing boat docked in Montauk Harbor.

title: In Film Biographies, A Fuller Spectrum
description: EVEN dead, I was still a threat to them.'' The words are spoken by the ghost of the Congolese nationalist leader Patrice Lumumba in the first minutes of Raoul Peck's ''Lumumba.'' Moments later we see his body hacked and burned by shadowy military assassins. The film, opening on Wednesday at Film Forum, allows Lumumba to speak from the grave, to address his own story and legacy.

title: Program Spreads to Sing Sing
description: SOON after the college program began at Bedford Hills in 1997, inmates at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining began asking for the same thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, BERNARD
description: MANDELBAUM-Bernard. Warm Rabbi, Teacher, and Preacher. He encouraged the efforts of Media Judaica to advance ''spiritual renewal and genuine diversity in Conservative Judaism,'' while he upheld traditional values in a kind and generous spirit. Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine The Directors of Media Judaica

title: Making Dance of the Killing Fields
description: OVER the last century, theater has been on the front line in the effort to heal society's deepest traumas. But as yet it has found few ways of exorcising the genocidal horrors perpetrated by Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge on the people of Cambodia from 1975 to 1979. ''Continuum -- Beyond the Killing Fields,'' which will play at the New Theater on Chapel Street at Yale University from Wednesday through Saturday as part of the Festival of Arts and Ideas, aims to remedy this situation by bringing the creative process into the heart of the country's recent history.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing on June 10 with an article about friction between Senator John McCain and President Bush carried an erroneous credit. The drawing, which showed Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush dancing, was by George Booth, not Tom Bloom.

title: True Northeast
description: To the Editor: Suzanne Berne's article about her visit to the Minute Man Monument, in Concord, Mass., (June 3) recalled thoughts of my own visit to the monument several years ago. I came away with mixed feelings.

title: The World: Free Trade's Promise in Latin America; The Poor Survive It All. Even Boom Times.
description: FOR months now, President Bush has been asking Congress for something really big: authority to negotiate the largest free trade agreement the world has ever seen, one that would create a market of 800 million people in the Americas, from the Arctic to Antarctica. In exchange, he has promised that the trade zone will not only create markets for the United States, but will fortify democracy in Latin America and spread the economic benefits equitably.

title: When Science and Politics Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NURSING LIFE; The Nurses' Tale: Five Voices From Around the Nation
description: How have nurses' lives been reshaped by the pressures of staff shortages, managed care and the onrush of medical technology? Women's Health asked nurses around the country to talk about what they do, how they do it and how nursing is changing. BUD HAZELKORN

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLADSTEIN, ARTHUR H.
description: GLADSTEIN-Arthur H. 3/3/22-6/20/94. Always in my heart and mind. Roslyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADLEY, PHILIP N.
description: HADLEY-Philip N. Of Danbury, CT., died June 20, 2001 at age of 73. Devoted husband of the late Flora Werner Hadley. His warmth, grace and generosity will long be remembered by family & friends. Services at the Hull Funeral Home of Danbury, CT. at 3 P.M., on Sunday, June 24th. Interment is at 2 PM Monday, June 25th, Pine Grove Cemetery, Templeton, MA. He will be missed.

title: In a Mirror on Africa, a Hero Unfairly Tarnished
description: IT was in the United States that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X fought their battles for civil rights; yet thanks to the power of American media and popular culture, they also became symbols of liberation for people of African descent around the world. In contrast, the heroes of Africa's own decolonization movement have largely been forgotten, their early idealism long since buried in a bitter legacy of dictatorship, violence and poverty.

title: June 17-23; Etan Patz Declared Dead
description: Twenty-two years after he disappeared on his way to school in downtown Manhattan, Etan Patz was declared legally dead. He was 6 when he was reported missing on May 25, 1979, a disappearance that inspired a national movement on behalf of missing children. His father, Stanley K. Patz, sought the declaration so he could pursue a wrongful death suit against the man he suspects of abducting and killing Etan, a pedophile serving time in Pennsylvania. Dean E. Murphy

title: The Young and the Little Known
description: On Tuesday afternoon in a Manhattan hotel ballroom, at least three teenagers will march in at the appointed time to fulfill an obligation. They will not bus tables, take orders or show off their work at a science fair. Kwame Brown, Tyson Chandler and Eddy Curry will answer questions the day before they become N.B.A. millionaires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOW, WEN TSING
description: CHOW-Wen Tsing. Noted aerospace engineer and digital computer pioneer, on June 14, 2001. He pioneered the use of photochemical circuitry, developed the inertial guidance system for Atlas ICBM, and formulated the design of the first all solid state space-borne digital computer. He retired as Managing Director, Technical Affairs, for the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in 1990. Avid sailor, tireless gardener, beloved husband of 54 years of Esther Peiyu, devoted father of Ping, Ming and Ling, entranced grandfather of Esther and Wen, his loving and guiding strength is greatly missed as the fisherman from Wuling sails on. In lieu of flowers and to honor his deep love and appreciation of music, memorial contributions may be sent to the Si-Yo Music Society Foundation, Suite 2C-S, 711 West End Ave., NY, NY 10025.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERSPRING, HAROLD
description: WASSERSPRING - Harold. Be loved husband of Pearl. Devoted father of Arthur and Fran Wasserspring and Fredric and Barbara Wasserspring. Cherished grandfather of Patti and Brian Adelman, Karen and Mark, Melanie and Adam, and Amy. Great-grandfather of Noah and Alex Adelman. Services Monday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Lara Fenig, Justin Stangel
description: Lara Kim Fenig, a psychiatric social worker, and Justin David Stangel, a head writer for ''The Late Show with David Letterman,'' are to be married today. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson will perform the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: A Short Fuse Could Be a Time Bomb
description: BARRY SEIDEL has done a lot of thinking, and he's convinced his explosive temper was a cause of his heart attack last year. A hypercompetitive, self-employed lawyer who often juggled 20 or 30 cases a day, he was 43 when he collapsed one Monday morning at the Queens County Courthouse in New York, with no diabetes, obesity or family history of heart disease.

title: Spanish Food With Tidbits as a Specialty
description: FINO TAPAS in Greenwich is the latest restaurant to latch on to the mini-craze for Spanish food.

title: OFFSHORE OIL DRILLING
description: A proposal by the federal government to study oil drilling off the New Jersey coast and elsewhere on the Eastern Seaboard was raise and then scrapped last week after protests. The Interior Department had proposed an 18-month study of the impact and feasibility of drilling for oil and natural gas off the Atlantic coastline. The proposed study generated protests from members of Congress, the State Legislature and environmental groups. Karen DeMasters

title: BEST SELLERS: June 24, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Near Australia's Margaret River, a Hint of Bordeaux
description: ON the edge of the Indian Ocean and about 175 miles south of Perth is the Margaret River region, one of the newest vineyard areas of Australia, which within a very short period has established an international reputation for its wines.

title: Festival Director Says Farewell
description: IF it isn't one festival, it's another. The label, rendered meaningless through overkill, is one of the unavoidable signs of summer.

title: Slighted by the Rebate
description: Though President Bush claims that tax rebate checks will make virtually every American family $300 or $600 richer by the end of summer, 34 million American adults, or 26 percent, will be getting no checks at all. And another 17 million, or 13 percent, will get only a partial rebate.

title: When Science and Politics Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: In Taiwan, an Anti-Modern Poet Of Modern Anomie
description: DAYS before the start of the new millennium, as an endless rain falls over a high-rise Taipei neighborhood, a woman's wallpaper is peeling and her walls are inundated. A plumber looking for leaks leaves a hole in the floor of the apartment above her, where a man lives alone. For him, the hole is an object of idle curiosity and a place to spill bodily excretions; for her it's a possible source of contagion. The radio has broadcast warnings of a strange virus causing people to crawl like bugs and seek refuge in dark, humid corners. He drinks, she cleans; each dines alone on instant noodles and tries to stave off the growing sense of panic and isolation. Sometimes, the woman dreams of escape: elaborately coiffed and dressed in gorgeous plumes and sequins, she croons show tunes from a 1960's Hong Kong musical, infusing them with manic joie de vivre.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: The ethicist; Herbal Medicine
description: I have H.I.V. and use cannabis to alleviate nausea and lack of appetite. A friend grows and provides it at no cost. I distribute the remaining cannabis to 15 or so other people who either have H.I.V. or are undergoing chemotherapy. We all know this is illegal but feel that our lives come first. Are we not being ethical? -- Anonymous, Virginia

description: Delays in Release Of Shabazz Grandson

title: Drivers May Face Months of Delays After Fiery Crash Forces Demolition of I-80 Span
description: A small bridge on Interstate 80 in northern New Jersey was so badly damaged during a fiery crash involving a gasoline tanker on Friday that the span has been declared unsafe and will have to be replaced, state transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Sunday Q & A
description: Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

description: Hannele Rubin and Nicholas Geoffrey Duffield are to be married today in Gardiner, N.Y. Cantor Daniel Rous is to perform the ceremony at the Minnewaska Lodge.

description: The Queens of Comedy bill themselves as being loud, proud and outrageously funny. They are four African-American comedians who formed half of a comedy show, along with the Kings of Comedy, that filled the Georgia Dome last fall with more than 40,000 people.

description: If he starts the All-Star Game next month, Roger Clemens, at 38, will be the oldest pitcher to start for the American League, and the span between his All-Star starts, 15 years, will be the most ever.

title: Political Briefing; Rumors Aside, Gramm Insists He's Running
description: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas will turn 59 next month and he has been in Congress for 24 years. He is a power in the Senate, but because he is a Republican, he is not the power he was before Democrats took control.

title: Men's Magazines: How Much Substance Behind the Covers?
description: SCAN the covers of men's health and fitness magazines and you'll see a lot of provocative headlines like "Nuke Your Gut," "Amazing Abs in Minutes!," "Instant Sex" and "Testosterone  Top Off Your Tank Naturally."

title: Teenagers Talk Shop
description: What makes teenagers tick? That was the question posed to 900 13- to 19-year-olds during the preperation of ''Teens Get Real,'' an hourlong special shown last December and being rebroadcast this Friday at 8 p.m. on WB. With the singer Jessica Simpson (below) as host, the special uses film clips and interviews to allow teenagers to speak for themselves on issues ranging from AIDS, gangs and the death of a parent to cheating on exams, friendship and popularity.

description: TUCKER-Stephen H., M.D. Gone 8 years, remembered loved and missed every day. Your family

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: FRAUD

title: Ideas & Trends: Past Imperfect; The Untold Links Between Biographer and Subject
description: ON Monday, The Boston Globe disclosed that the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Joseph J. Ellis had routinely embellished his undergraduate lectures with lies about serving in Vietnam. Immediately, the academic community went into overdrive. There were online debates over professional ethics and calls for Mr. Ellis's resignation. Even an announcement by his employer, Mount Holyoke College, that he would no longer teach his course on Vietnam and American culture did little to quell the frenzy of electronic communication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBERBAUM, LEONA
description: LORBERBAUM-Leona. On June 20th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Laurence and Roger. Services were conducted Friday, June 22nd, by Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz of Temple B'nai Shalom of Rockville Centre. Director: Gutterman's, Inc.

title: Airlines Rev Up E-Ticket Efforts
description: VICTOR J. FERNANDEZ, vice president for operations at Liberty Travel, an agency with 200 retail outlets in the East, says that when he travels with an electronic ticket, he has one eye on any potential storm and an ear to the ground for sounds of airline labor actions. A storm or strike might force him to transfer to another airline, and in that case, as Mr. Fernandez knows better than the average passenger, most e-tickets must be transformed into paper tickets before they can be endorsed to the new airline. Even if the two airlines are leaving from the same terminal -- not often the case at a big hub -- getting the e-ticket transferred to paper will mean standing in line with many others on the same dismal mission.

title: Political Briefing; Boston Gays Blast Democrat Hopeful
description: State Senator Stephen F. Lynch is considered a top contender to fill the Congressional seat on Boston's South Side that was left open by the death of Representative Joe Moakley. But gay political leaders in the district, the Massachusetts Ninth, put Mr. Lynch, a Democrat, near the bottom of their list of preferred candidates.

description: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas will turn 59 next month and he has been in Congress for 24 years. He is a power in the Senate, but because he is a Republican, he is not the power he was before Democrats took control.

title: Kyra Clarkson, Christopher Glaisek
description: Kyra Antoinette Clarkson, a daughter of Christina McCall and Stephen Clarkson of Toronto, was married yesterday to Christopher Eaton Glaisek, the son of Carolyn and Robert Glaisek of Bergenfield, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth Roscoe, a Congregational minister, officiated in Wellfleet, Mass.

title: Lure of Dwarf and Slow-Growing Conifers
description: IN many ways, William T. Gotelli was a man ahead of his time. In the years following World War II, when landscaping across the nation primarily consisted of swaths of colorful annuals, he became passionately attached to conifers.

title: Still Riding So High and Fine?
description: LAST Tuesday morning in the parking lot of Trader Joe's market in Mamaroneck, N.Y., one Lincoln Navigator, one Isuzu Trooper, three Chevy Suburbans, two Dodge Durangos, three Jeep Grand Cherokees, one Chevy Tahoe, one Toyota Land Cruiser, one Mazda Tribute and one Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicle inched forward and back in an excruciatingly slow elephant ballet.

title: Violence Rises as Club Drug Spreads Out Into the Streets
description: It was finding an Israeli drug dealer dead in a car trunk at Los Angeles International Airport 18 months ago that gave the authorities here the first hint that the club drug Ecstasy was becoming a serious problem. He had been killed by two hit men from Israel, said Drug Enforcement Administration officials.

title: Appearances; The makeup Lesson
description: Full disclosure: Evelyn Lauder saved my life. At least she helped finance, through tireless fund-raising, the cancer research that led to the epic campaign to do so, masterminded by Larry Norton, the renowned doctor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXSTEIN, BLANCHE B.
description: EXSTEIN-Blanche B. On June 19, 2001. Beloved wife of Louis. Loving mother of Michael and Lida, and Ted and Patti, adored grandmother of Jeremy, Adam, Isabel, Max and Benjamin. Dear sister of Richard Bloch. Donations to the R. Taub Cancer Research Fund, C/O Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Study on H.M.O.'s Targets the State
description: WHILE health maintenance organization plans are starting to lose favor around the United States, they are booming in New Haven and Meriden, so much so that last year that region had a higher percentage of H.M.O. patients than any other metropolitan area in the country, according to a study released last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKER, EILEEN
description: DICKER-Eileen. June 22, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Chaplain Herman Dicker. Loving mother of Anna & Eli. Adoring grandmother of Shelley and Michael (Edelstein) and Sarah and Jeremy (Dicker). Cherished aunt, sister-in-law, mother-in-law & cousin. Her quiet, steady strength guided and nurtured her family, her inner resolve led to professional accomplishments, and her literary flair was inspirational. She will be missed dearly. Services Sunday, June 24, 2001, 1 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY; 718-445-0300.

title: A Charming Ros
description: Paumanok's charming nonvintage ros blush table wine is a no-brainer. The beach scene on the label -- sand, wispy vegetation -- suggests, accurately, that the salmon-pink wine behind it is the liquid equivalent of a beach novel, a page-turner.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; A New Type of Project for Affluent Saddle River
description: AFTER more than 20 years, changes in ownership and a legal debate, a 28-acre triangular-shaped site along Route 17 is midway through its transformation into a mixed-used development that is changing the face of Saddle River, an affluent community in northwestern Bergen County.

title: Bloomberg Urges Emphasis on Local Issues
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican candidate for mayor, criticized Fernando Ferrer yesterday for suggesting blanket amnesty for illegal immigrants, saying that local politicians should stick to local issues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMARI, MARINA
description: AMARI-Marina. 1955-1998. Three years have already passed. The pain in my heart and the tears in my eyes are forever. Mamma

title: The U.N. Looks at AIDS
description: Tomorrow the United Nations General Assembly opens its first special session ever devoted to a disease. The main work of the three-day meeting will be to set goals for countries to meet over the next few years and to establish a global fund for AIDS and health, which is expected to be run by representatives from the World Bank, Unaids and other groups. It will eventually seek to give $7 billion to $10 billion a year to national programs that fight AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis in poor countries. The session is a sign that the world is realizing the urgency of the AIDS catastrophe. The danger is that nations might content themselves with little more than symbolism.

title: Healthy July Event
description: To the Editor:

title: June 17-23; A Lasting Legacy
description: Cal Ripken never called in sick during his first 17 years in major league baseball. He didn't miss a game for more than 16 of those years. He was never even on the disabled list until his 18th season. A streak of 2,632 consecutive games -- played from May 30, 1982, through Sept. 19, 1998 -- will be Ripken's legacy. The Baltimore Orioles legend announced that he would retire at the end of this season to spend more time with his children and his new passion, youth baseball.

title: Treasured, Yes. But Insured?
description: During the Miami stop of the ''Antique Roadshow'' summer tour last weekend, thousands of people converged at the Coconut Grove Convention Center for a chance to learn if their personal treasures were worth anything. The Chubb Group of Insurance Companies, the underwriter of ''Antique Roadshow'' on PBS, thought that it would also be a good time to learn whether the attendees had enough insurance for those treasures. Ninety-seven percent of the 106 people surveyed had homeowners' or renters' insurance, but 55 percent did not carry additional insurance for their valuables.

title: At a Fitness Boot Camp, Changes in Habits and Waist Size
description: THE proof of the eating was in the pudding not to mention the French fries, hamburgers and ice cream. I had ballooned to 250 pounds on a 6-foot frame, almost 100 pounds more than I weighed in my salad days at Rutgers University 40 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday about a colony of monk parakeets misspelled the name of the town where it is situated. It is Edgewater, not Edgwater.

title: Governor Is Facing Choices On Pines
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco has a deci sion to make or not to make -- that could have a profound effect on 1.1 million acres in the heart of southern New Jersey.

title: An 'R' Rating For Wrestling
description: RESEARCHERS in North Carolina say they have found a link between teenagers' watching pro wrestling on television and violence in dating.

title: With Heartbeats, Slow Is Good, Steady Not So Good
description: IT was a quandary all too familiar to cardiologists. Here was a middle-aged man who might -- or might not -- be on the verge of developing heart disease. His cholesterol was fine, but many people who develop heart disease have normal cholesterol levels. His blood pressure was fine. He did not smoke. But his family history was sobering. His father had developed diabetes and high blood pressure and ended up with two bypass operations. His father's father had suffered a heart attack.

title: Article 2001062490879844808 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Nation; Drawing A Line On Death
description: CAPITAL punishment is a divisive topic in this country, and recently a heated debate has arisen about whether convicted murderers who are mentally retarded should be executed. President Bush jumped into the fray when he said, ''We should never execute the mentally retarded.''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBAKCS
description: THE GRAVITY OF SUNLIGHT, by Rosa Shand. (Soho, $13.) Set in Uganda at the time of the dictator Idi Amin's ascent to power in 1971, this lush, dreamlike tale focuses on the fate of an idealistic American teacher who strays from her marriage to a fellow expatriate amid the political upheaval that threatens to boil over in a country once known as the Pearl of Africa. The result is a ''remarkable first novel'' that ''is as much about a love affair with a country as with an individual,'' Margot Livesey wrote in these pages last year.

title: Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!
description: KISSING IN MANHATTAN

title: Country Kitchen With Homespun Food
description: MILLER'S TABLE is tucked away at 90 North Country Road (631-331-4848) in the rolling hills of Miller Place. This country-kitchen kind of a spot, with its homespun food and welcoming attitude, is a rustic, appealing hodgepodge of wooden beams, crystal chandeliers, slate floors, stone walls and bright bouquets of daisies in glass sconces.

title: Political Briefing; Calling McCain For 2002 Races
description: With his fierce streak of independence, Senator John McCain of Arizona is an almost constant irritant to President Bush and many Republican colleagues on Capitol Hill. But party leaders also know a good thing when they see it -- and that good thing is Mr. McCain when it comes to helping other Republicans campaign.

title: Women's Health: A Devastating Lack of Awareness
description: Why women don't believe their No. 1 killer, really affects them. Plus news on nursing burnout, revitalizing the spirit and banishing wrinkles in an hour.

title: Political Briefing; Party Change Nets Product Pressure
description: Some folks get mad. Some get even.

title: Vegetarians
description: To the Editor: I very much appreciated Betsy Wade's column about vegetarian and vegan dining and traveling, ''Guiding Lights for Vegetarians,'' (Practical Traveler, June 10). Since the vegetarian movement is growing rapidly, it makes sense for restaurants and resorts to offer healthy and humane vegan options.

title: Lives; One of Their Own
description: On Saturday, the last visiting day before the execution, a bus picked me up from a parking lot north of the federal prison in Terre Haute to take me to the main building. Its driver was a trustee, currently living at a lower-security prison next to the main one that houses my brother-in-law Blue, who's in for conspiracy to sell heroin. We drove past the rear of the prison, out of the sight lines of the gathering media. ''My home,'' he said, pointing at the building to his right. ''The yard.'' He pointed to his left. ''Tim's home. And here,'' he said, ''is the death house.'' I'd just seen it an hour before on CNN from stock footage. But like an actor seen in person, the building looked different than it did on television. Smaller. Less imposing.

title: The Nation: An Endangered Act; Sacrifices to a Green Agenda
description: IT started with the best of intentions: to protect all creatures great and small by requiring that when a plant or animal got close to the survival line, everything feasible would be done to prevent its extinction and promote its recovery in the wild.

title: Taking Risks, Moving On: A Follow-Up Visit With Eight Outpatients
description: FIVE years have passed since Lee Chew was paralyzed and close to death with AIDS. But not until he stood up last month to receive both his master's degree in social work from New York University and a special award for his clinical skills did he finally feel his new life was starting. His 83-year-old mother from Virginia sat in the audience. Mr. Chew, 52, saw her after the ceremony.

title: The World; America's Garden Beauties
description: IT'S about three-foot-tall jockeys and 22-inch glass gazing balls. It's about 200-pound cement Bambis grazing near the hedgeline. It's about summer and being American, doggone it, and few cultures do lawn ornaments with as willful a mixture of zeal and irony.

title: Swimmers Take the Long Way (28 1/2 Miles) Around Town
description: The 20th Manhattan Island Marathon Swim, at 28 1/2 miles the longest event of its kind, was made even more difficult yesterday by a storm that pounded contestants throughout the morning.

title: Merryl Snow, Charles Zegar
description: Merryl Judith Snow, an administrative law judge, and Charles Zegar, a founding partner of Bloomberg, the news and financial information concern, were married last evening. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at Essex House in New York.

title: Quietly, a Glen Cove Center Opens for Immigrants
description: Shortly after the village of Farmingdale shut down a dusty outdoor hiring center for Hispanic day laborers, Glen Cove has taken a different approach, creating an indoor center with padded chairs, a bathroom and English classes for those unlucky enough to remain jobless by 9 a.m.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01; The Shyness Syndrome
description: In the social evolution of a new psychological syndrome, there may be no moment more important than the appearance of its first celebrity victims. A star or maybe a fading star ''discloses'' a ''troubling diagnosis'' that he or she has ''struggled with'' in ''silence.'' The star receives warm studio-audience applause and big Hollywood hugs for ''bravery,'' for ''just wanting to help others in the same situation.'' (In the case of rockers and drugs, the evidence of a ''struggle'' is often kind of thin; more often it looks as if they partied really hard and then slacked off a bit when they turned 50 or 60 or the drummer died.) Meanwhile, as the celeb makes the rounds of the talk shows or ''sits down'' with People magazine, the syndrome itself moves up in the world, acquiring a new high profile, maybe a catchy acronym and a presumption that it is ''far more widespread'' than we ever realized.

title: Article 2001062491478531212 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: A Quiet Man With Voluble Fingers
description: TOO often jazz is discussed mainly in terms of its greatest leaders. But much, if not most, of jazz history has been made by artists who sustain long, steady careers, often in supporting roles, influencing the tradition of their instrument and shaping the sound of the music. Henry (Hank) Jones, the 82-year-old pianist, is an example. Mr. Jones, who will perform at Birdland tomorrow with the saxophonist Joe Lovano as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, has brought urbane warmth, soul and swing to every imaginable musical context for more than 60 years. He is a legend.

title: A Beneficial Meeting in Freehold
description: When the actress Jane Seymour agreed to show her artwork at Sea Land Gallery in Freehold, a charitable component seemed natural. Both Ms. Seymour and Sea Land have supported children's organizations over the years.

title: Powell Dismisses Putin Warning on Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is dismissing a warning from President Vladimir V. Putin that Russia will eventually upgrade its strategic nuclear arsenal with multiple warheads if the United States goes ahead with its plan to build a missile shield.

title: RESORTS EXPANSION
description: Colony Capital, which bought Resorts International, Atlantic City's first casino hotel, in May, told the Casino and Control Commission last week that it would break ground on a new $125 million, 496-room hotel tower addition there on Nov. 1. And Steeplechase Pier, a longtime amusement site that was demolished in 1996, may return as part of the expansion. Earlier this month the Army Corps of Engineers approved an application for a ''recreational and entertainment pier'' opposite the hotel. Built in 1899 to rival its neighbor, Steel Pier, Steeplechase was heavily damaged in a 1988 fire. Colony expects the tower and the pier to be completed by the end of 2003. Bill Kent

title: Time for Recalling the Departed And Reuniting the Long-Lost Related
description: THE SETTING -- The squat, gray Mid-Manhattan Library at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 40th Street, which years ago housed the Arnold Constable department store, an elegant, some said dowdy, place favored by society matrons as well as by Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEIS, BERNARD AND DARLENE
description: GEIS-Bernard and Darlene. Old friends, come celebrate their memory, Tuesday, June 26, 5:30 PM, Mark Hotel, 25 E 77th at Madison.

title: Water, Water Everywhere
description: PLACE sprinkler on lawn. Turn on water. Fiddle with sprinkler to adjust spray. Get wet. Scurry away. Repeat.

title: On the Trail of the Holy Grail, Stuyvesant High
description: Michael Wong got straight to the point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, DR. RUTH LEDER
description: SHAPIRO-Dr. Ruth Leder. On June 17, 2001, at age 81. Psychologist. Beloved stepmother of Richard Shapiro and his wife, Patricia, and step-grandmother of Seth and Alex. Also survived by her nephew Drew Leder and her companion for fourteen years, Jacques Solta. Interment is private. Memorial service July 7th, 2001. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: At Buick Classic, Woods Is the Difference
description: There is no better recipe for a golf tournament's success than the presence of Tiger Woods, who is playing at the Buick Classic in Harrison, N.Y., for the first time since 1997, when he finished in a tie for 43rd place. Entering yesterday's third round, he was tied for fourth at one under par, six shots out of the lead.

title: That Glow in the Building Is the Dream of Footlights
description: All the Upper East Side might not be a stage, but if the players combing its byways in the 70's beyond Third Avenue find success, it could be.

title: What's Fair Is Fair
description: JUSTICE AS FAIRNESS A Restatement. By John Rawls. Edited by Erin Kelly. 214 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $17.95.
