title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENBLATT, MELINDA LANDE
description: ROSENBLATT-Melinda Lande. Not a day, not an hour without loving memories. Sleep well, little sweetheart. Mom and Jane

title: Almost 50, And Sold On Stocks
description: I DISCOVERED something disturbing when I turned 49 a few months ago. When friends heard how old I was, they gasped and shook their heads, acting as if I had already turned 50.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Haverstraw; A Village Intent on Reviving Past Renown
description: MICHELLE AND JOSEPH NATALE grew up in the hilly Rockland County village of Haverstraw. Mrs. Natale, an officer at M & T Bank in Tarrytown, said she had childhood memories of ''a quaint little village for children and adults with a busy shopping district and main street.'' By the time she and her husband, a payment processor for Orange and Rockland Utilities, married and settled in their first home in 1971, things were different.

title: An All-He-Can Eat Feast at a Steakhouse Chain
description: FOR the shareholders of Lone Star Steakhouse and Saloon, there has been a lot more more fizzle than sizzle lately. During the biggest bull market in history, the stock of Lone Star, the Wichita restaurant chain, only sank. A shareholder who invested $100 in the stock in December 1995 had $22.08 at the end of 2000. The Standard & Poor's restaurant index rose almost 52 percent during the period.

title: Route 66: Off the Map, Still in Their Hearts
description: Seventy-five years ago a patch of paved road in Chicago's Grant Park marked the birth of Route 66, the iconic American highway. This summer cities along the road, which ran for 2,448 miles from Chicago to Santa Monica, Calif., before it eventually disappeared from maps to be replaced by Interstates, will celebrate the anniversary with tours, art exhibitions, car shows and lectures. In Albuquerque, the National Diamond Jubilee Route 66 Festival, Web site www.national66.com, will be held July 20 to 22. The weekend will include art shows, poetry readings, mariachi bands, and car and motorcycle shows; (818) 352-7232.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Phyllis Lambert; Dressed for the Skyline
description: IN the lobby of the Whitney Museum, Phyllis Lambert was meeting and greeting a who's who of the architecture and museum worlds. But even though it was the opening of the Mies van der Rohe show and she was its curator, many guests steered clear, wary of her very architected dress, which projected out in four points, suspended tentlike by some hidden armature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, LESTER ''LEKE 1'' H.
description: FREED-Lester ''Leke 1'' H. Of Manhattan, died Thursday, June 7, 2001, in New Hampton, NY. The son of Lester H. Freed Sr and Dorothy Harrington, born on March 23, 1940, in Pennsylvania. He was an alumnus of The Hill School and Princeton University. Les was a member of the Actor's Guild and Carpenter's Local 2090. He loved life, fine foods, music, philosophy, physics and people. Beloved brother of Nancy Godshall and her husband Ray, Jane Nyce and her husband Wellington, loving uncle to Liberty, Ray and Suzanne, brother-in-law to Barbara Mayers. Soul buddy to Marta and Wanda, and friend to Robert, Burt, Joe and Jocelyn. He was predeceased by his lifetime partner, Kaipo Daniels, his parents and brother, George Mayers. A Memorial Mass will be held Saturday, June 30, 2001, at 1 PM, at St. Malachy's Chapel, 239 W. 49th St, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to Broadway Cares Equity, NYC; Hospice of Orange and Sullivan (845) 561-6111. For information call Applebee-McPhillips Funeral Home, Inc., Middletown, NY; (800) 707-6309.

title: Bringing College Back to Bedford Hills
description: LAST month, nine women wearing black caps and gowns walked onto a podium here and received their college diplomas as their friends and family members wept and cheered.

title: Building Costs For Schools Investigated
description: The city has begun an investigation into cost overruns on school construction projects by the Board of Education because spending is running about 20 percent over budget in the second year of a five-year, $7 billion capital plan, officials said yesterday. At the current spending rate, there would be a $1.5 billion budget gap by the end of the five years.

title: Lynn Falanga, Edward McCormack
description: Lynn Mary Falanga, a special agent with the State Department's diplomatic security service in Washington, and Edward Joseph McCormack, a special agent with the F.B.I.'s Washington field office, were married yesterday. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Private Sector; His Past, as Acquisition Target
description: STEVEN R. ROGEL is not just an engineer by education. He is an engineer to the bone. He can picture how pipes and screws and cogs work together to create a process -- and how tweaking any one of them can make that process better.

title: True Northeast
description: To the Editor: Long before crosswalks, drivers in small villages stopped to allow pedestrians to cross the street. If you were a pedestrian, you naturally gave a thank-you nod or wave and quickened your step, if you were able. Just because crosswalks were painted and laws were written was no reason to end this friendly custom.

title: Alison Bard, Matthew Markatos
description: Alison Ivy Bard, the daughter of Jessica Bard of Bedford, N.Y., and Richard H. Bard of Evergreen, Colo., was married yesterday to Matthew William Markatos, a son of Susan and Louis Markatos of Armonk, N.Y. Judge Herbert Galchinsky of the Denver County Court officiated at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Pamela Bard.

title: My Neighborhood, Its Fall and Rise
description: I WAS born and raised in the West Farms section of the Bronx in the kind of working-class neighborhood that was then, by definition, either Jewish or Irish or Italian. Most of the raising got done in a small five-room apartment on the second floor of a narrow brick apartment house around the corner from the Bronx Zoo, on a street inside a quadrant bounded to the north by Bronx Park, the south by East Tremont Avenue, the west by Southern Boulevard and the east by Boston Road.

title: Collector of Diverse Talents and Disciplines
description: STANTON WELCH is one of the hottest talents in ballet, an Australian dynamo who has swiftly plucked a slew of plum commissions. Ann Carlson is an experimental sage who straddles the line between modern dance and performance art. They are not the first choreographers one would think of pairing on a program, but in doing so Diane Coburn Bruning has set an intriguing tone for the inaugural season of her Chamber Dance Project.

title: Elizabeth Schmitt, Peter Clay
description: Elizabeth Ann Schmitt, a daughter of Carolyn and Edward Schmitt of Glen Rock, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Gilbert Clay, a son of Vera and Charles Clay of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Robert J. Lewis, a Unitarian minister, officiated at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Style From the Stable
description: CARLA WEIER, the manager of Miller's, one of New York's premier purveyors of riding gear, at Park Avenue and 24th Street, was expounding the other day on the proper way to wear a frock coat. ''The dressage,'' she said stiffly, ''should only be worn with traditional white shirt, white breeches and black accessories.'' A discernible chill in her voice implied that anything else would be heresy.

title: June 17-23; Fitting Right In
description: It started with a sighting by an off-duty police officer in Central Park. Within days, news that a small alligator seemed to have taken up residence in the placid Harlem Meer, a small lake in northern Central Park, had spread around the world. When it was caught -- by a Florida alligator-wrestler and his wife -- it turned out to be a a two-foot-long spectacled caiman, a species of crocodile native to Central and South America. The reptile was relocated to the Central Park Zoo.

title: Braves Complete a Weekend Sweep at Shea
description: Brian Jordan hit a tiebreaking three-run homer in a seventh-inning rally that began with Rafael Furcal's bunt double, and the Atlanta Braves beat the Mets 8-4 Sunday for a three-game sweep.

title: Park Rises on a Former Brownfield
description: FOUR years ago, Dennis Flood, the mayor of Irvington, buttonholed Robert W. Elliott, the mayor of Croton-on-Hudson, at a cocktail party and asked him for advice about how to transform an ugly 12-acre stretch of abandoned waterfront here into a park.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 24, 2001
description: Weeks

title: CRIME
description: ''It's funny the places you end up.'' That's the last line, and pretty much the whole sad story, of BITTERROOT (Simon & Schuster, $25), James Lee Burke's latest meditation on the devastation to the landscape when people make war over what they view as their territorial rights. Billy Bob Holland, the Texas lawyer who carries the moral baggage in this trailblazing series of the New West, has the right idea: he just wants to go fishing. But he can't ignore the distress signals coming out of the Bitterroot Valley in Montana, where an old friend is single-handedly battling a mining company with a scorched-earth policy toward the environment. As if cyanide in the old swimming hole weren't bad enough, the region is infested with brutish bikers, psychotic ex-cons, fanatical militia types and best-selling novelists.

title: Benefit at Metedeconk
description: Some of the L.P.G.A.'s top players will participate in a pro-am tomorrow in Jackson, N.J., to raise money in the fight against breast cancer.

title: Elisabeth Layton, Louis Jacobson
description: Elisabeth Layton, a daughter of Joan Layton Furth and Robert Layton, both of New York, was married last evening to Louis Alan Jacobson, the son of Eileen and Raymond M. Jacobson of North Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Joseph B. Meszler performed the ceremony at the National Press Club in Washington.

title: The Standard Checkup? Well, Not Exactly
description: HUGH HAWTHORNE is not a man easily impressed. But he sounded positively rhapsodic when describing his treatment in February at the Sentara Medical Group in Norfolk, Va.

title: Too Few American Maestros? Try Making Them
description: AWADAGIN PRATT is to perform here on Saturday evening on the Millennium Stage at the Kennedy Center. There would be little news in this statement if Mr. Pratt were playing piano, for he is widely known on that instrument, in concert and on records. Even the actual news, that he will be conducting the National Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Eighth Symphony, is less than earthshaking, for many instrumentalists are taking up the baton these days in varying states of preparedness and with varying success. In fact, Mr. Pratt, who is also a trained violinist and who won a Young Maestro Award in connection with his conducting studies at the Peabody Institute in Baltimore in 1995, has already conducted several orchestras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSFIELD, PAULINE
description: MANSFIELD-Pauline. On June 17, in her 94th year. Devoted mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, mother-in-law and sister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARVIS, JACQUELINE MCKINNON
description: JARVIS-Jacqueline McKinnon. At Lenox Hill Hospital on June 21, 2001. Beloved daughter of the late John and Jessie (Jaye) Jarvis Donnelly of Miller Place, and cherished sister of James Donnelly of Saratoga, Maureen Sideris of Manhattan, and Marion Latham of Hartsdale and their families. She will be deeply missed by her dearest friends Arlene Witt and Dolly Moon, as well as friends and family both here and in Scotland and England. A memorial service to be held in Brooklyn and private burial services on Long Island. In lieu of flowers dontations may be made to the American Institute for Cancer Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SUSAN MIRIAM
description: GOLDMAN-Susan Miriam. Born January 9, 1964, NYC, daughter of Charles Lewis Goldman and Deana Marilyn Sachs, sister of Katherine Goldman, died April 26, 2001, at the age of 37. She was raised in Suffern, NY, a graduate of the Hotchkiss School, 1982, Bennington College, 1986, Hunter College, MFA Fine Art, 1993. An artist who lived in New York she exhibited here and internationally. She is survived by many loving friends whose lives she enriched immeasurably. We miss her dearly and will remember her always. A memorial exhibition of her work is being planned for this fall. Those wishing to contribute towards this can do so by sending donations to the Susan Goldman Memorial Fund, c/o James R. Westmoreland, Attorney at Law, 145 Lincoln Pl, Brooklyn, NY 11217. Email: craig@kalpakjian.com to be notified of memorial exhibit plans.

title: The Standard Checkup? Well, Not Exactly
description: HUGH HAWTHORNE is not a man easily impressed. But he sounded positively rhapsodic when describing his treatment in February at the Sentara Medical Group in Norfolk, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOFFEL, CHARLES
description: TOFFEL-Charles. Of West Milford, NJ. Beloved husband of Mildred (nee Gelber). Cherished uncle and good friend. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: The World; Just What Game Is Putin Playing?
description: TO earn his black belt in judo, President Vladimir V. Putin spent years sizing up opponents before trying a throw. So it shouldn't be surprising that soon after that soul-gazing summit with President Bush, the Russian leader delivered an unexpected blow to his new partner -- and radically shifted the terms of the debate about missile defense.

title: Snooky Bellomo, Andrew Bale
description: Eileen Bellomo, a co-founder and owner of Manic Panic Products, a hair color and cosmetics company in Long Island City, Queens, was married yesterday to Andrew Bale, a radio announcer. Carl Werbock, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated at the bride's home in Highland, N.Y.

title: Even Light Exercise Can Help the Heart
description: DR. JOANN E. MANSON exercises 20 or 30 minutes every morning on a treadmill or a rowing machine and takes a 10-minute walk every afternoon. She lifts weights for 15 minutes three times a week. Like her fellow investigators on the Harvard Nurses' Health Study -- a 25-year project that has produced a trove of medical findings -- she has become a believer in the preventive power of exercise. But for Dr. Manson, a 48-year-old professor at Harvard Medical School, the great delight in the study's findings about heart disease was the realization that ''no pain, no gain'' is a myth -- that even moderate exercise makes a big difference.

title: Charter School Hails Students' Test Results
description: The 144 students in the year-old charter school in Roosevelt -- the first on Long Island -- have experienced ''almost one and a half years of grade growth in one year,'' said the school's chief operating officer, Margaret R. Harrington.

title: June 17-23; Pakistani Solidifies Power
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf seized power 20 months ago from a Pakistani prime minister who headed a notoriously corrupt government. Still expressing ''embarrassment'' at his powers and commitment to parliamentary elections in October 2002, the general formally dissolved Parliament and named himself president. The title will assure him of a 21-gun salute when he heads to India for talks in three weeks. John F. Burns

title: Young Authors Create A Guide to Chappaqua
description: AH, TO BE published it is every aspiring writer's dream. It came true fairly quickly for a group of children here who signed up for a session in a Young Writer's Conference and a few months later found themselves at their own book signing.

title: Lauren Geddes, Ted Duff
description: Lauren Ford Geddes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ahles Geddes of Locust Valley, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Louis Dunlap Duff III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duff Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Church.

title: Geography to Wear
description: If you can't be a globetrotter, at least look like one. The Trash T, popularized by John Eshaya's Jet line, has evolved into the Destination T: studded and beaded, and inspired by locations real and fictional. One line, Joomi Joolz, makes a teal shirt with copper studs that immortalizes ''Brigitte's Shoe Salon'' in Paris, while a black shirt with crystal spangles by Bejeweled evokes that perennially popular roadway, Route 66 (both $92 at Saks Fifth Avenue). And Bardot's army-green beaded number, above, extols the sights of Lubbock, Tex. ($80, Intermix).

title: Townies
description: EMPIRE FALLS

title: Personal Business; Vineyards and Profits May Not Go Hand in Hand
description: MANY people would never consider plunking down several hundred thousand dollars or more to own an apple orchard or soybean farm. But put a vineyard property in front of them, one perched in a romantic location, and stars light up their eyes as visions of money-producing grapes, maybe even a wine label, go swishing through their heads.

title: Sticking to the Script
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worm Did It
description: THE ASSASSIN

title: Giuliani Tries to Balance 2 Lives: Busy Mayor and Warring Spouse
description: The two lives of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani merged shortly before a City Hall news conference last week, when he took a call from an important man in his life: Raoul L. Felder, his divorce lawyer, who was across the street tangling in Manhattan's matrimonial court with a cranky, impatient judge. ''The judge wants to put this on a fast track,'' Mr. Felder told the mayor. Could he set a date to go to the office of his wife's lawyer for a deposition?

title: Er, Um (Ahem)
description: My mother, Jessica Mitford, used the ''um, er'' in a rather interesting way (On Language: William Safire, June 3). When making introductions, she would say, ''I'd like you to meet my daughter and her um, er, ummer.'' We thought ''ummer'' would catch on, being so much simpler than ''common-law husband,'' ''companion'' and ''life partner'' and more modern than ''paramour'' or ''lover,'' but it remained restricted in use to our family.

title: Santa Fe
description: Seventy-five years have passed since Route 66, linking Chicago to Los Angeles, was built directly through Santa Fe. Though the road was relocated south 11 years later, the word was out. Santa Fe was indelibly marked in America's expanded on-the-road consciousness, becoming a hip hideaway for artists and iconoclasts who rubbed shoulders with true-grit cowboys and the Hispanic and American Indian residents who still make up a hefty chunk of the population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, JOEL
description: GROSS-Joel. On May 26, age 97, in Canton, MA. Born in Jersey City, NJ, he was a Columbia College and Law School graduate and practiced law for many years in Newark where he was active in Jewish civic and philanthropic organizations. He held the position of Chairman of the Essex County United Jewish Appeal and was a member of the Board of Directors and served on the executive committees of the Joint Distribution Committee, National Refugee Service and United Palestine Appeal. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Weizmann Institute, Israel, and was general counsel to the State of Israel Bond Issues. After his retirement and prior to moving to Canton, MA, he lived in Longboat Key, Florida with his adored wife Terry (Stavisky), who predeceased him. His children, Ruth Gross Picker, Avrum M. Gross, and Benedict H. Gross, nine grandchildren, and six greatgrandchildren mourn his passing and cherish his memory.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: With His Heart In His Imagery
description: FOR Shen Wei, a 33-year-old Chinese choreographer who is attracting attention at international festivals, dance is essentially about one thing: what he calls ''the beauty of human life.''

title: STATE-FINANCED DNA TEST
description: John Farmer Jr., the state attorney general, announced last week announced that the state will soon accept applications from defendants for state-financed DNA testing. The testing will come with the warning that the results, which may exonerate defendants from one crime, may also implicate them in another. Applicants must also pass a polygraph test. Anne Ruderman

title: You Can't Get There From Here: Summer Brings Lots More Road Work; Cabbies Sigh as Workers in Trenches Dig, Repair and Repave
description: With warm weather, so many things return to New York: the tourists to the subways, the fans to the baseball stadiums, the blue crabs to the Hudson. But the warmth brings back something else, a lot more technical, a lot less welcome and yet just as inseparable from summer in the city: the perfect temperatures for freshly poured concrete and asphalt to harden properly again after the long winter chill.

title: Commercial Property; When Hotels Add Hospitality to History
description: WHEN his real estate broker told Philip Pilevsky in 1998 that the 24-story American Radiator Building was for sale, he barely hesitated before offering $15 million. The site, at 40 West 40th Street, is directly across from Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library in the heart of Midtown, making it ideal for the upscale hotel he had in mind. The Japanese company that owned the landmark office building accepted the relatively low price because at the time the Japanese had largely soured on American real estate and the American Radiator Building had been vacant for several years.

title: Habitats/East 78th Street; From a Concrete Yard, A Co-op's Garden Grows
description: THE yard behind the co-op building on East 78th Street was like a lot of other yards in Manhattan. It wasn't what most people would call a yard. It was concrete -- broken concrete, in fact. It was so uneven that the co-op board decided, about 10 years ago, that it was time to put down new concrete.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Libraries in the Ancient World

title: Impending Lease Reignites Talk of a Rte. 110 Hub at Airport
description: THE proposed site of a transportation hub that might be built around the old rail station at Republic Airport in East Farmingdale is about to be leased, and that has lighted a fire under those seeking to ease traffic congestion along Route 110 at the Nassau-Suffolk border.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an answer in the Sunday Q & A column last week about the whereabouts of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, the 104-year- old widow of the Chinese Nationalist leader, who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, misstated her relationship to Chiang Ching-kuo, a former ruler of Taiwan. He was her stepson, not her son.

title: Bush Supports Federal Law Putting Limits On DNA Tests
description: President Bush, in a surprise to many on Capitol Hill, said today that he would support the passage of a law preventing insurance companies and employers from using newly developed tests of people's genetic makeup to deny them medical coverage or turn them down for jobs.

title: Buildings Emptied Near Sagging Brownstone
description: City emergency workers evacuated four Manhattan buildings last night after determining that one of them, a four-story brownstone at 13 West 29th Street, was at risk of collapse, officials said.

title: Streetscapes/157 and 159 West 88th Street; Revamping a Pair of 1891 Low-Stoop Brownstones
description: THE two soft red brownstones at 157 and 159 West 88th Street are peculiar little structures, two low-stoop row houses on a block of traditional high-stoop buildings. Designed by the thoughtful and inventive architect Clarence True, one was almost completely intact when bought in the 1970's but, in the other, a growing family is struggling with an earlier gut job.

title: The Loss of a Garage Chips Away at a Hub
description: To former residents of Chinatown in Manhattan, their old neighborhood is what some urban planners call an iconographic hub. On the weekends, they return in droves from their new homes, in the other boroughs and suburbs, to run errands, socialize and shop.

title: Bay Shore Takes Steps To Become a Village
description: A citizens' committee in Bay Shore said on Tuesday that it had filed with Islip Town sufficient signatures to hold a referendum asking residents to approve the incorporation of their hamlet into a village.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Page 3 of the Travel section today about an oversize bed in the Htel Royal Monceau in Paris misstates its size. The bed is just over 60 square feet, not 21.5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXFIELD, LEONA H.
description: MAXFIELD-Leona H. Of Greenwich, Ct., formerly of Manhattan, on May 8, 2001 at age 98. She had a long and successful career at Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company. Widow of William Reginald Maxfield. She is survived by his son Henry of Wolfeboro, NH and his family. Originally from Salt Lake City, she was a niece of lyricist and playwright Otto A. Harbach. Elegant, outspoken, lively and witty, she was loved by many and will be missed. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, July 16th at 1 PM in the Chapel at Christ Church, Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue.

title: Catherine Flynn, Conal Gillespie
description: Catherine Flynn and Conal Gillespie were married yesterday by the Rev. Gerry Gillespie, an uncle of the bridegroom, at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in Knockmore, Ireland.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 26 of The Times Magazine today about the Fox News network misstates the ownership of The Daily Telegraph of London, cited as an example of a newspaper with a political viewpoint. It is owned by Conrad Black, not by Rupert Murdoch.

title: Archie Bunker Slept Here. (Actually, He Never Did.)
description: Dorothy Brandow knew what was coming when she answered a reporter's call.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAKIS, PETER C.
description: TRAKIS-Peter C. October 7, 1965-June 24, 1998. Three long and very sad years. In our hearts forever. Love, Mom and Dad

title: A Boost for Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Miceli Set Revival Of Marlins in Motion
description: Major League Baseball is witnessing the second coming of the Florida Marlins. How far they will go remains to be seen, but they have already come a long way.

title: Allenby Rebounds to Become a Contender
description: The worst decision that Robert Allenby made this week came in a restaurant, not on the golf course.

title: Are the Gutters Part of a Condo Roof?
description: Q: I live in a condominium town-house development with 120 families. We vote only for the board.

title: Celebrating Wine In Art and History
description: Through works of art, decorative objects, winemaking equipment and accessories, ''Gift of the Gods: The Art of Wine and Revelry,'' at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto through Oct. 21, illustrates the history of the consumption and production of wine in three separate eras.

title: Next-to-Last Licks
The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: How To Avoid A Blackout; Power Plays
description: As the energy crisis worsens, California weathermen are adding blackout predictions to their forecasts, and other states are bracing for their own power failures as the air-conditioner season hits. Conserve all you want -- please, even modest stabs at conservation could mean closing power plants, not building new ones -- but it's not going to save you when this summer's blackouts come rolling along. Yet these extreme steps might.

title: Where to Go for a Jump-Start
description: Here are a few of the popular residential weight loss programs around the country. Anahad O'Connor

title: Hunters, Gatherers, Fixers
description: CIVILIZATIONS Culture, Ambition, and the Transformation of Nature. By Felipe Fernndez-Armesto. 545 pp. New York: The Free Press. $35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAQUET, SIMONE, REVEREND
description: PAQUET-Simone, Reverend. On June 21, 2001. Beloved wife of Maurice Paquet. Dear mother of Jocelyne Goode and son-in-law James Goode. Funeral services on Monday, June 25, 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Plagiarism, Telepathy or Forgetfulness?
description: IMAGINE a tragedy -- not ''Hamlet'' -- that starts with the question ''Who's there?'' and ends with the command ''Go bid the soldiers shoot.'' Either Shakespeare would have to have known this play, or the other playwright would have to have known ''Hamlet,'' right?

title: Introduction
description: Our article on Sandra Day O'Connor drew much mail revisiting the role of the Supreme Court in Bush v. Gore. Others sought clues about the woman who may one day be chief justice in items as small as the motto on a pillow in her office.

title: Word for Word/Gangland Testimonials; Dear Judge, Joey Whatshisname Was a Well Respectable Guy
description: EVEN people accused of committing bloody crimes for the mob have their supporters. While the authorities might consider a wiseguy nothing more than a heartless killer or a dead-eyed thug, his friends and relatives are just as likely to remember him as the kindly man who once helped an ailing neighbor with her groceries or the doting brother who was willing to share his childhood toys.

title: In 'Comedy of Errors,' Director Accepts an Invitation to Excess
description: ONE of the reassuring things about ''The Comedy of Errors,'' revived once more at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival after a mere eight years, is that you are not expected to understand anything about it. Forget your brain; attend to your heart.

title: S.U.V. TIRE DEFECTS WERE KNOWN IN '96 BUT NOT REPORTED
description: A group of personal-injury lawyers and one of the nation's top traffic-safety consultants identified a pattern of failures of Firestone ATX tires on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles in 1996. But they did not disclose the pattern to government safety regulators for four years, out of concern that private lawsuits would be compromised.

title: In the Region/Long Island; New Projects for Main Street in Port Jefferson
description: LIKE the prow of a ship, a large newly built three-story building sits on a V-shaped lot at the intersection of Barnum Avenue and Main Street less than a mile from Port Jefferson Harbor. A car dealership had been at the site for many years, and the size of the new building has created some controversy.

title: Article 2001062491082136448 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Shake-Ups Rattle Nassau Hospital
description: STANDING in a business suit, his back to a wide chalkboard and his face toward an amphitheater that was packed save a few seats in the front row, Richard B. Turan looked and at times sounded like a college professor teaching his first class.

title: Making Pianos Good as New
description: LIKE people, pianos decay over time. The instruments seem to be static, but the strings exert 20 tons of pressure on the frame, which eventually tears the inside compartment apart. The passing years also ravage the finish and the intricate mechanism known as the action, a series of joints and levers that link the keys with the hammers that strike the strings.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: A Track Event With a Hint of Risk
description: TO Diana Wilson of Brewster High School, the javelin throw is ''kind of cool.'' To coaches and directors of meets, it's kind of a problem.

title: Private Sector; Red-Eyed, Not Blindsided
description: The optimism exuded by Arminio Fraga, president of Brazil's central bank, apparently is not the only contagious thing about him.

title: June 17-23; Macedonian Pact in Doubt
description: In Macedonia, fierce fighting cast doubt on prospects of agreement between parties representing the Slav majority and the substantial Albanian minority in the southern Balkan republic. NATO said it might send some 3,000 European soldiers to help disarm Albanian rebels if a political settlement was reached. But an assault by government forces using helicopter gunships and artillery to try and drive the guerrillas back from positions near the capital, Skopje, left diplomatic efforts in tatters. Alison Smale

title: White Magic
description: With summer officially under way, the chalk-white pantsuit has emerged as a star. Worn by executive women for the office and lunch, it is also popular for evening, often with jackets with white satin lapels or white beading. This season's pantsuits are sleek and tailored, and cut from linen, silk, cotton and blends of synthetic and natural fibers. Considering the upkeep, the radiant white look is perhaps fashion's greatest luxury.

title: Article 2001062490568019252 -- No Title
Leah Anderson, Scott Stanton
description: Leah Justice Anderson, the daughter of H. J. Cummins of Minneapolis and Timothy Anderson of Westbury, N.Y., is to be married today to Scott Clark Stanton, the son of Martha and David Stanton of Waterboro, Me. The Rev. Cynthia F. Grove, a Unity minister, will perform the ceremony at the Kent Manor Inn in Stevensville, Md.

title: Buy a Camel, Ride an Elephant
description: For centuries, the Camel Fair at Pushkar, in the Rajasthan state of India, has been a colorful mingling of sacred ritual and business. Around the full moon in the month of Kartik (October and November), 200,000 or so pilgrims and traders come to this town to trade some 50,000 camels and other livestock and to take a cleansing dip in the lake by the only temple in India dedicated to Brahma, the Hindu god of creation. It has also attracted increasing numbers of tourists, including those on tours by Geographic Expeditions and on American Museum of Natural History Discovery Tours.

title: A Boost for Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' New 4-3 Defense Aims to Be Aggressive
description: How high are the hopes for the Jets' switch to the 4-3 defense?

title: Blue Stone In Cobble Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Hadley Pollet, John Gates
description: Hadley Flynn Pollet, the daughter of Elinore Flynn Hartz of Basking Ridge, N.J., and the late David Anthony Pollet of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to John Courtney Gates, the son of Helen and Dr. Christopher Gates of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Robert Edmunds, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Children of War: Forms of Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Everyday Becomes a Transforming Experience; Poetic Vision Cast on Ordinary
description: WHILE Adriana DiGennaro's peers scream over the Backstreet Boys and pass notes in English class, Ms. DiGennaro, 17, spends her time listening to confessional folk singers and writing poetry. While her Mount Sinai High School classmates were signing yearbooks, Ms. DiGennaro was signing copies of her recently published poetry book, ''Peripheral Vision.''

title: Bayonne Journal; Members Debate a Legion Hall's Fate
description: Perhaps it is only fitting that less than two years after an Army base closed here after defining this working-class city for more than half a century, a ''for sale'' sign went up on the local veterans hall, the Frederick A. Mackenzie American Legion Post No. 165.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, JUDITH
description: BRODSKY-Judith. Our cherished memories are deep; we remember and love forever. Grace and Ruth

title: Banish Wrinkles in an Hour! (For a While, Anyway)
description: LAST summer, Farley Clark began noticing the signs. "I was starting to get a few little lines around my mouth and eyes and some frown lines on my forehead," she said. "But I didn't think I needed a face- lift yet. I wanted something to perk me up."

title: Archaeologist Takes On the Army Corps
description: A FORMER president of the Suffolk County Archaeological Association contends that the Army Corps of Engineers is threatening underwater archaeological sites in historic Sag Harbor, where the corps is replacing a century-old breakwater.

title: Looking for Health News? A Bikini Belly? There's More to Read
description: IN the last few years, women's magazines that focus primarily on health issues have multiplied faster than multiple-birth baby strollers on the Upper East Side.

title: Out and Proud, But Hardly Pectorally Correct
description: HE wears brooches on his windbreakers and his heart on his sleeve. He is unafraid of singing torch songs in a queeny, operatic voice. His acclaimed new CD, ''Poses,'' was inspired by watching a gorgeous gay man falling apart as he aged. For New York's Gay Pride weekend, when shirtless men flaunting sculptured physiques swarm and dance to techno music and disco standards, he planned to be far away, in Greece, at a premiere of an opera by Vangelis starring Jessye Norman and Kathleen Battle. He wears several garish rings, lives with his mother and sings folk songs with his family.

title: A Majority of One
description: Justice O'Connor's brother, Alan Day, is quoted as saying, ''Sandra is very much a federalist.'' Day defines this purported federalism of his sister's as wanting states to ''solve more of their problems'' and for the federal government to ''stick their nose in as little as possible.''

title: One Thumb Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Our Brains, or Not, In the Technology Age
description: To the Editor:

title: When Teenagers and Lawns Part
description: IT used to be the traditional summer job for teenage boys growing up in the suburbs -- mowing the lawn for the neighbors. In the 1950's and 60's, if neither the father nor a teenage son were available to do yardwork and a family could afford to have someone else care for the lawn, a neighborhood teenager would be hired. He would mow the lawn once or twice weekly and occasionally spread fertilizer, toss out a little grass seed, spade the flowerbeds and handle some light cleanup with a rake. Should anything else be necessary, the planting of bulbs, vegetables and new shrubs, families would generally either do it or hire a professional landscaper.

title: Article 2001062493786414239 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Stirring Alarm in the Republican Ranks
description: Bob Franks is in his second statewide race in two years, and he had his gubernatorial campaign speech about controlling taxes and protecting the middle class down cold. But at a gathering of Passaic County Republicans here this morning, Mr. Franks added a message aimed straight at the fears of the elected officials and party workers who came to hear him.

title: Technique Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teacher of Newyorkese Who Taps the Power of Babel
description: Sam Chwat, the dean of New York chat, roams the streets as a giant ear would, listening. A coach to Midwesterners, Southerners and other regional imports who want to talk New York for Broadway and film, he needs to hear, and often tape-record, the contours of each local accent, from Rosie Perez to Fran Drescher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ROBERT F.
description: SIEGEL-Robert F. Died on Sunday, June 17, 2001 after a valiant fight against a rare mitochondrial disease. Robert was a successful executive in financial services. The death of this brilliant, kind and gentle man is a tragic loss for his family, friends and colleagues. He is survived by his wife, a young daughter, both of his parents and his brother and his family. He was 40 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, JOSEPH R.
description: SPECTOR-Joseph R., attorney. Born April 16, 1923, died June 17, 2001. Former corporate council for Singer Corp and Vice President and General Council for UMC Inds. and Crane. Graduate of Dartmouth College '46 and Cornell Law School '52. Survived by his lifetime companion of 54 years, Ralph ''Pat'' Paterline of New York, and his brother Samuel I. Spector of Rome, Georgia. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Liver Foundation for Research, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 603, New York, N.Y. 10038, are requested.

title: Ocean of Beach Badge
description: There's still talk about making the state's beaches free, but beach fees and the badges that go with them aren't disappearing soon. Almost all of those badges for New Jersey beaches, and many for pool clubs and lake associations across the United States, come from one place: the Jersey Cape Diagnostic Training and Opportunity Center in Cape May Court House. The center, in operation for 27 years, provides work experience for people with physical and developmental disabilities, mainly by manufacturing nearly three million beach and pool badges a year. The center produces more plastic identification tags than any other place in the country, said George Plewa, its executive director, while at the same time teaching work values to the employees. About 125 people report to work at the center each day and an average of 50 to 60 of them find regular employment each year, he said. Karen DeMasters

title: A Smaller, More Accessible Biennial
description: SOME logistical changes greatly enhance the ''2001 Biennial Exhibition of Public Art'' curated by the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Healing and Burnout, 12 Hours at a Stretch
description: DOROTHY CUMMINGS once described the whir of working in an emergency room in musical terms, as though it could be conducted and, in some way, appreciated. When she begins her shift as a triage nurse at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, it is 8 a.m. and usually quiet. The crises build as the day grows.

title: Yankees Add Witasick in Relief
description: After killing one tentative deal and considering numerous alternatives in the past week, the Yankees settled on a trade today, swapping the minor league infielder D'Angelo Jimenez to the San Diego Padres for Jay Witasick, a hard-throwing right-handed reliever.

title: Cold Name, Warm Hearts: Demise of a Bar
description: Tracy Westmoreland stood in front of his bar, Siberia, holding an eviction notice. ''This is my third,'' he said with a frown, ''or maybe my fourth. I can't remember.''

title: A Little-Known Award That Is a Big Deal to Insiders
description: FOR a relatively little-known award, it inspires big metaphors. Katie Couric calls it ''the big kahuna.'' The radio journalist David Brancaccio prefers ''the great white whale.'' The news producer David Raziq goes even further: ''The holy grail.''

title: OUT THERE: St. Petersburg; The Czars Are Long Gone, but It's Fun to Pretend
description: ST. PETERSBURG has more than 600 czarist-era palaces just aching to be danced in, but that doesn't mean it's easy to have a ball here. Just ask Irina Nikitina, who organized the Remembering Strauss Ball in the nearby Catherine Palace earlier this month in the hope that ''Russians from the upper class start learning how to behave in high society.''

title: When the Everyday Becomes a Transforming Experience; Epic Fantasy For Millenium
description: MIDWAY through the fabled year 2001, the science fiction and fantasy genre is slipping into a mainstream niche by way of steamy ''X-Files'' finales and time-warped Hollywood blockbusters like ''Planet of the Apes,'' ''A.I.,'' and ''Fellowship of the Rings,'' the first installment of J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy.

title: The Capital Gang
description: DUPONT CIRCLE

title: Article 2001062490104434775 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Bulls, Bears and Wolves
description: HEY, baby, you wanna real man?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, SCHULEM, RABBI
description: RUBIN-Schulem, Rabbi. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of Rabbi Schulem Rubin, the beloved father of Rabbi Eliezer Rubin, and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: June 17-23; A Glut of F.B.I. Reviews
description: After much criticism of managerial and investigative lapses at the F.B.I., the Bush administration and lawmakers came forward with a batch of overhaul proposals. Attorney General John Ashcroft said the Justice Department would begin a wide-ranging review of the agency. And lawmakers proposed a blue-ribbon commission to review the agency's performance and the appointment of an inspector general for the F.B.I. David Johnston

title: Midori Sonoda, Myoung-Jae Im
description: Midori Sonoda, the daughter of Dr. Myung Sook Sonoda and Dr. Koji Sonoda of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married on Friday to Myoung-Jae Im, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Kwan-Ho Im of Naperville, Ill., and Ansong, South Korea. The Rev. Dr. Kuh Chung Kim, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Christ United Methodist Church in New York. A traditional Korean ceremony was held at the reception, which took place at the Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIMETH, CATHERINE
description: NEIMETH-Catherine. On June 21, 2001 at the age of 99. In her home in Woodmere, Long Island. Devoted wife of the late Edward. Beloved mother of Richard and the late Donald. Loving mother-inlaw of Peggy. Grandmother of Debbie, Pamela, Amy and Lisa. Great-grandmother of ten beautiful children. She was a loving and indomitable woman who fought her way through the loss of a son of 23 and three major life-threatening illnesses. Private burial.

title: Relatives Can Be Found In the Strangest Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Test for Students
description: YESTERDAY, students from 11 high schools in Westchester County and Connecticut took the SAT II Biology E/M Subject Test -- for the second time in three weeks. They were among 1,000 students who had taken a different version of the same test on June 2, who were informed on June 14 that their scores were to be canceled. My daughter, Sofie, was one of those students.

title: Setback for Pakistan
description: When Gen. Pervez Musharraf seized power from Pakistan's civilian government nearly two years ago, he promised a quick return to democracy. Now the general has taken his troubled nation a big step backward from that goal. Following the dismal practice of Pakistan's previous military dictators, General Musharraf has appointed himself president and raised concerns that he intends to rule from that position even if an elected Parliament and prime minister take office in 2002. The United States was right to criticize the move and make it clear that sanctions cannot be lifted until more democratic progress is made.

title: A Naturalist's Wonderland
description: IF you sat down with pen and paper to consciously design the perfect island, you could hardly improve on Lord Howe.'' Thus spoke a world traveler some 15 years ago atop the island's highest peak, Mount Gower (2,871 feet).

title: BackTalk; In My Brooklyn, There's Always Baseball
description: It's not Ebbets Field. It's just a little ballpark in Coney Island for a Mets farm team named the Cyclones. But it's baseball in Brooklyn and that's enough to stir the soul of anyone who lived there before Walter O'Malley absconded with the Dodgers.

title: June 17-23; Action on '96 Saudi Bombing
description: Five years of investigation into the 1996 truck bombing in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American airmen and injured hundreds of others bore fruit, as a federal grand jury indicted 13 Saudis and a Lebanese on 46 counts of murder and conspiracy. The indictment said that the 14 were members of the anti-American group Hezbollah, but that Iranian officials -- none of whom were charged -- were involved. Some of those charged are at large; others are in custody in Saudi Arabia, which said the U.S. had no authority to indict its citizens. David Johnston

title: June 17-23; Smoke Signals
description: The Justice Department took a step toward settling its multibillion-dollar civil lawsuit against several big tobacco companies. The suit -- to recover smoking-related federal Medicaid costs and unspecified amounts for what the government says were fraudulently obtained profits -- was a top Clinton administration priority. But Attorney General John Ashcroft told lawmakers that a team of Justice Department lawyers would explore negotiations with the companies. Several of the firms said they were not inclined to settle, since they consider the suit groundless. David Johnston

title: Lauren Somlyo, Michael McGowan
description: Lauren Andra Somlyo and Michael Francis McGowan were married yesterday by Msgr. John J. Skelly at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, PHILIP I.
description: WOLF-Philip I. Of Singer Island, FL on June 15 at age 76 of cancer. He was the retired chairman of Pollux Corp. Over a long career in executive management at aerospace, life sciences and electronics firms, he commercialized the disposable syringe, interferon, CD, dental film processor and honeycomb cores. He was a decorated submarine veteran of WWII serving aboard ''Silverside'' and ''Kingfish''. He graduated from Harvard College in 1950 and was President of several Harvard Clubs. He was President of the Singer Island Civic Association. Survived by his wife, Merle, son Tony and wife Paula, daughter Lisa, cousins, nieces, nephews and four grandchildren. His ashes will be scattered at sea. The family asks that donations be made to the Nature Conservancy.

title: Ilana Sparrow, Benjamin Procter
description: Ilana R. Sparrow, the daughter of Miriam Lane Sparrow and Roy Sparrow of New York, was married yesterday to Benjamin A. Procter, the son of Susan Procter Dusenberry and the stepson of Philip B. Dusenberry of New York. Rabbi Michael Shevack officiated at the weekend home of the bridegroom's mother and stepfather in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Bed Room
description: It's a bed that's been slept in by Britney Spears, Robert De Niro, Ricky Martin and several honeymoon couples -- and it's almost big enough to accommodate them all at the same time.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Greeks Bearing Blades

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: Five from Raman Hui; Coming to Life
description: Subtlety is the key to great animation, according to Raman Hui, the supervising animator on ''Shrek,'' which as of last week was nearing $200 million in box-office sales and was playing in more theaters nationwide than any other movie in history. ''Each character has to be believable,'' Hui explains. ''So even when it's not talking, you totally understand what it's thinking.'' It's something Hui strives for and admires in other animated films -- especially his choices for the five best, listed here.

title: 'Dangerous Liaisons' Through a Marxist Mirror
description: THE East German dramatist Heiner Mller was once asked to elucidate the strange opening stage direction for his 1980 play ''Quartett'': ''Timespace: Salon before the French Revolution/Bunker after the Third World War.'' He responded that the direction issued from ''the hope that the play will also be performed after a Third World War.''

title: Neighborly
description: THE BROTHERS MOON is the kind of restaurant you're always hoping will open in your neighborhood. The service is friendly, it offers takeout and it serves Sunday brunch. Set next to a pharmacy in what once was a small grocery, the place even looks intriguing. Those who drive along this town's main street don't see the restaurant's name but read the words ''Fine Food'' set above the low-slung logo in its windows. And who wouldn't want to try a new place named Fine Food?

title: Aviation Museum Deal Reached
description: PLANS for the Cradle of Aviation Museum in East Garden City are back on track after being stalled for several months as the details of a lease were worked out.

title: June 17-23; Toddlers' Killers to Be Freed
description: Britain announced that two of its most hated criminals, both 10 years old when they tortured and murdered a toddler in Merseyside eight years ago, would be released and given new, secret identities to protect them from vigilantes. The pair, Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, were convicted of abducting a 2-year-old from a shopping center, beating him to death and dumping his half-naked body onto a railroad track. Sarah Lyall

title: Sarah Strasser, Benjamin Kremer
description: Sarah Elizabeth Strasser, the daughter of Francine and Edward Strasser of New York, is to be married today to Benjamin Raymond Kremer, a son of Maureen Kremer and Dr. Edward Kremer of Vaucluse, Australia. Rabbi Jeffrey Kamins will perform the ceremony at Juniper Hall, a historic house in Sydney.

title: QUICK BITE/Spotswood; Won Ton Soup and Other Diner Fare
description: If you concede that a 45-by-85-foot place, with a 12-stools counter, four tables and two booths, can qualify as one of those legendary Jersey diners, then consider Lee's Diner in Spotswood. The enterprise started when Elly Lee came to New Jersey in 1969 and couldn't find a job as an assistant pharmacist, a position she hadheld in her native Indonesia. So, she bought -- what else? -- a doughnut shop, and expanded it in 1973. The diner caters to construction workers from nearby sites, employees of nearby businesses and patrons of local merchants. ''Some of our customers have been coming here for years and years,'' said Miss Lee, who, with new husband, Bob, and one waiter, runs the diner. Lee's is strictly a breakfast-and-lunch place and the fare, which Miss Lee characterizes as 'the most simple stuff,'' is such customary items as eggs, French toast, breakfast sandwiches and hamburgers ($2.25 for a five-ouncer) and other basic sandwiches like tuna salad ($4.95) and a B.L.T. ($3). Plus something else a bit fancier: ''We are famous for our eggs Benedict,'' Miss Lee said (it is $4.95). And more, she said, pointing to a particular item on the menu, one that represents for her a touch of her home continent: won ton soup ($2.75 or $3.75), which to her is no more exotic than, say, eggs benedict. ''All people eat won ton,'' she said. But if you are among them, you'd better hurry: With Miss Lee in a retirement mode, a fast food outfit is casting a hungry eye on the site. NORM OSHRIN

title: So Where Are the Corporate Husbands?; For Women at the Top, Something Is Missing: Social, Wifely Support
description: IT takes a village to raise a child, says an old axiom (and a former first lady). But look around a few corporate rewards dinners or executive retreats, and a twist on that maxim comes to mind: It takes a married couple to run a corporation.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01: On Language; Visit With
description: 'Vice President Cheney has a completely open door'' to members of Congress, said the Bush counselor Karen Hughes last month on ABC's ''Nightline.'' ''He's always available to visit with any member who'd like to visit with him.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BACHMANN, EMILE W.
description: BACHMANN-Emile W. 4 years... I miss you and cherish your memory every day. Love always, your daughter, Karen

title: Manchester Rising
description: THE day I arrived in Manchester, the sun shone. Elsewhere that quirk of meteorology might seem trivial. But in the damp northwest of England, those few rays seemed to emphasize that even a gritty city associated primarily with rain and chill can show a gentler face. Indeed, a warmer presence seems to be the objective the city elders have in mind as they prepare to play host to the Commonwealth Games track and field event in the summer of 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on May 27 about the expiration of Coliseum Books' lease misstated the renewal terms offered by Newmark New Spectrum Retail. The rent would not increase; it would decrease by about 20 percent.

title: One-Stop Shopping For Those Seeking Jobs
description: The promise of one-stop shopping has been luring consumers for some time, but it's a relatively new approach to fighting unemployment.

title: Yugoslavs Act On Hague Trial For Milosevic
description: The Yugoslav cabinet adopted a decree today committing itself to sending the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to the United Nations tribunal in The Hague to face trial on war crimes charges.

title: The Weather Almost Closed the Fishing Window
description: Getting to Maine's Rapid River, which empties into the east side of Lake Umbagog, by canoe from the west shore is often a challenge, and so it was for Ruth Kirchmeier and me on our most recent crossing earlier this month.

title: The Week in Review: June 17-23
description: Action on '96 Saudi Bombing

title: A Bridge That's In, Not Over, a Creek
description: To right the unrightable wrong, New Jersey needs a big rig.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: WARRIORS OF GOD

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MITCHELL LEE MARKS; How to Make a Shotgun Marriage Work
description: MERGERS are never easy, especially when one side does not want the other. Now a state judge in Delaware, where many companies are incorporated, has put a new twist on the challenge by ordering a merger in which one side no longer wants the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ALBERT
description: GINSBERG-Albert. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Albert Ginsberg, esteemed Vice President, Board Member, valued member of our extended family, but most of all, cherished friend. Al was a kind, sensitive and caring person, as evidenced by his reaching out to help those in need. His wisdom, guidance and brilliant counsel was sought by all, whether family, friends or colleagues. Al was a self-made man, coming from simple beginnings on the Lower East Side and rising to become a most highly regarded and respected businessman whose vision and staunch determination enabled him to see opportunity that escaped others. Al's devotion to his family was exemplary. The same man who developed, negotiated and oversaw a complex business deal, would come home that night and get down on the floor to play with his grandchildren. Al identified heart and soul with the students of Boys Town, recognizing that an excellent education, coupled with a lofty value system, represented the best hope for these young boys from limited backgrounds to emerge as young men with limitless futures. Together with his beloved Pearl, the Ginsbergs established a major endowment at Boys Town providing the gift of opportunity for disadvantaged Israeli youth. We extend heartfelt condolences to Pearl, his partner in life for over 50 years; children Liane, Larry and Hilary; grandchildren Sean, Sara, Daniel, Heather and Josh, and the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Michael J. Scharf, President Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Josh S. Weston Honorary Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Teenagers Exploring Options by Looking at Options
description: On a recent Monday, Christopher J. Williams, the chairman of an investment bank, and some of his colleagues met with a group who were not the usual suit-and-tie types -- most of them, in fact, wore T-shirts and jeans.

title: A Majority of One
description: The artists over at Marvel or DC Comics could have drawn a better likeness of the justice than the one on your cover. The mouth is all wrong. Mom deserves better, especially with Jeffrey Rosen touting her as the next chief.

title: Searching for Truth On Cross-Sound Pipeline
description: The June 10 article about the proposed cross-Sound Islander East pipeline project [''Conservationists Are Divided on Cross-Sound Gas Pipeline''] really upset me. John Sheridan, Duke Energy spokesman, failed to tell your reporter that the pipeline will cut as much as a 100-foot swath of environmental destruction through the most sensitive Core Preservation Area of the central Pine Barrens, a place that Long Islanders have spent more than $300 million to protect. Did he tell the reporter that the pipeline corridor will disturb the headwaters of the Peconic River, South Haven County Park and Brookhaven State Park?

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Ford Thunderbird; What's the Word on the T-Bird?
description: MY neighbor, who restores old cars as a hobby, telephoned. Could he photograph his 1966 Ford Thunderbird next to the 2002 model that I was test-driving? He wanted a shot of one of the last convertible Thunderbirds alongside the reborn model.

title: A Boost for Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Shot Heard Round The 15th
description: IF you want to see the world's best golfer at his best, don't bother watching Tiger Woods when he puts his tee shot in the fairway, his approach on the green and holes a birdie putt. All the touring pros do that; he usually just does it more often. Instead, watch him when he hits a shot that maybe none of the other pros would even try.

title: As Wives Move Up, Men Fend For Themselves
description: ON a recent business trip to visit a supplier in France, Peter Sallick, the chief executive of Waterworks, a 33-store bathroom fixtures chain based in Danbury, Conn., was wishing that his wife, Karen, had accompanied him. His dinner with the supplier turned out to be awkward because the conversation centered on business, leaving the supplier's wife to fend for herself.

title: Blue Wall of Silence Doles Out Black Mark
description: The beefy police officers ambled into the International House of Pancakes like a couple of cowboys just back from a cattle drive, teasing the waitresses before settling into a booth and ordering chocolate milk and egg whites on wheat toast.

title: Bethan Brome, Jonathan Lilja
description: Bethan Brome, a daughter of Mimi and Thomas R. Brome of Ridgewood, N.J., was married on Nantucket yesterday to Jonathan Edward Lilja, the son of Ann and Herman S. Lilja of Libertyville, Ill. Associate Justice Mel L. Greenberg of the Massachusetts Appeals Court in Boston officiated at the Chanticleer Inn, a restaurant in Siasconset, Mass.

title: David Goldberg, 70, Transportation Official
description: David Joseph Goldberg, a lawyer who was chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority as well as the state's first commissioner of transportation, died on Monday at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 70.

title: Politics Dictate the Fate Of Shanghai Buildings
description: IT took only a few days for a group of sledgehammer-swinging men to turn the Bei family's century-old French manor into a pile of splintered wood, brick and stone last month. But it will take months to move the Liu family's newer, more modest, house about 400 feet, making way for the grassy hillocks and poplar groves that will eventually flank an elevated highway bisecting the city.

title: Carving a Pop Niche in Japan's Classical Tradition
description: TAKASHI MURAKAMI is a hot item on the international circuit. He's here; he's there; he's everywhere, surrounded by a flying wedge of assistants, turning out immaculately polished Pop-style product, from cartoonlike paintings to dolls and T-shirts. Psychedelic, cute, sexy, creepy, his work is part of how ''new'' is spelled in art at the moment.

title: New Weapons to Assault an Epidemic
description: AS a New York Knick, Fred Crawford suited up with Bill Bradley and Willis Reed. Later he was a member of the Los Angeles Lakers when Elgin Baylor and Jerry West were the stars of that team. He ended his career with the Milwaukee Bucks, whose center was Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. That was three decades ago.

title: Dolly Hall, John Kochman
description: Dorothy Theresa Hall and John Marshall Kochman were married yesterday at the office of the mayor of the Seventh Arrondissement of Paris. Judge Robert Sweet, an uncle of the bride who sits on the Federal District Court in Manhattan, led another ceremony last evening at the Cercle de l'Union Interallie, a private club in Paris.

title: Indians Do Thrive
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sarah Felton, Mark Manasas
description: Sarah Conway Felton and Mark Allan Manasas were married yesterday by the Rev. Holly Lyman Antolini, an Episcopal priest, at the Sunset Congregational Church on Deer Isle in Maine.

title: Helping the Lost
description: To the Editor: About ''The Help of Strangers'' (June 3) by Debra A. Klein: As a retired guide for Boston by Foot, I find myself unable to ignore travelers who seem even slightly perplexed. The symptoms are easy. The responses are predictable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHNERT, ROBERT M.
description: AHNERT-Robert M. Of Bushkill, Pennsylvania and Fort Lauderdale, Florida, died on May 22, 2001 in Fort Lauderdale. He is survived by Margaret, his loving wife of 21 years, a son David, and five grandchildren.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: De La Hoya Ties Record, Winning 5th Championship
description: Oscar De La Hoya, who has earned fame and fortune since winning a gold medal in the 1992 Olympics, seized something else at the MGM Grand tonight -- a share of boxing history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGEL, DR. REUBEN
description: KAGEL-Dr. Reuben. October 18, 1902 to June 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Kathryn & the late Sylvia Kagel. Loving father, grandfather and great-grandfather. A wonderful teacher and role model. He viewed life with wit and wisdom.

title: Katharine Herring, Craig Phares
description: Katharine Ruth Herring, the daughter of Carol and H. James Herring of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Anthony Royer Phares, the son of Jacqueline and Elwood W. Phares II of Princeton. George N. Hurd Jr., a retired justice of the State Superior Court in Massachusetts, officiated at the summer home of the bride's parents in Wareham, Mass.

title: Food; In the Raw
description: Question: When is sashimi not sashimi? Answer: Most of the time. At the risk of rearming Japan, which Disney's Clorox'd ''Pearl Harbor'' failed to do, it's sad to note that in too many Japanese restaurants, what is proclaimed as the crowning glory of the cuisine is usually a mouthful of soy sauce fired with varying degrees of wasabi and the barest hint of some kind of fish flavor. Texture may distinguish the bonito from the squid, but with few exceptions, the taste of the principal ingredient -- the fish itself -- is confused, muted or lost entirely.

title: Transit Watchdog Muzzled
description: When you're a watchdog group, sometimes it doesn't pay to bark.

title: Keeping Alive a Composer's Incidental Inheritance
description: COME on the right day, and Simonetta Puccini herself will greet you at the gates of her grandfather's lakeside villa. The lover of ''La Bohme,'' ''Tosca'' and ''Madama Butterfly'' who has not made the pilgrimage in recent years will be pleasantly surprised. My last tour 10 years ago, conducted by an inebriated caretaker and his dog, revealed the intimacy and betrayed an accrued shabbiness. Restoration has returned a certain elegance to this simple house.

title: Healing and Burnout, 12 Hours at a Stretch
description: DOROTHY CUMMINGS once described the whir of working in an emergency room in musical terms, as though it could be conducted and, in some way, appreciated. When she begins her shift as a triage nurse at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, it is 8 a.m. and usually quiet. The crises build as the day grows.

title: Reckonings; Trust And Antitrust
description: When the European Commission indicated it was likely to block the proposed merger between General Electric and Honeywell, American politicians from George W. Bush on down cried foul, with some alleging that the decision was politically motivated. They're almost certainly wrong about that, but it is true that the E.C.'s case against the merger is far from watertight. Mario Monti, Europe's competition referee, may have made a bad call on this play.

title: In Italy, Culture Vultures Can Be Night Owls
description: Many museums, monuments and archaeological sites in Italy will be open this summer -- as they have been for the past two summers -- on Saturday nights until the most unmuseumlike hour of 11. Through Sept. 15, 61 state-run locations will extend their Saturday hours so visitors can enjoy the views from the Museo Capodimonte in Naples at sunset or the stark beauty of the Castel Sant'Angelo in Rome at dusk.

title: From Way Below The Border
description: CHIMICHURRI GRILL

title: From Entry Level To Top of the Heap
description: Nick Valenti, 53, is president and chief executive of Restaurant Associates, a group based in New York that has more than 130 restaurants nationwide.

title: Turkey's Version of Wrestlemania
description: THERE is only one wrestling tournament in the world at which contestants use tons of olive oil. It is held each year in western Turkey, and its tradition reaches far back into history.

title: The Longest Light
description: A driver in West Milford could whip out an egg, hard-boil it and eat it. Or cook a TV dinner. Or, if a car full of fans were rushing home to watch a basketball game, they would miss nearly half of the first quarter.

title: Letters
description: Our article on Sandra Day O'Connor drew much mail revisiting the role of the Supreme Court in Bush v. Gore. Others sought clues about the woman who may one day be chief justice in items as small as the motto on a pillow in her office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ALICE C.
description: STEIN-Alice C. Died peacefully June 20th, 2001, following a long period of diminished health. She is fondly remembered as the proprietor of Gordon's Book Store on 55th St in the St. Regis Hotel, a mecca for those interested in politics and the arts, as well as for automobile, train and history buffs from all over the world. The shop's closing in October of 1988 left a void in many lives. Her postretirement career as a volunteer, at the School of American Ballet and at Channel 13, reflected a lifelong devotion to this City and especially to the New York City Ballet, which she had followed since its first performances. Her warmth and wit will be deeply missed. Donations in her memory may be made to the School of American Ballet.

title: Southold Rally Opposes Farmland Rezoning
description: About 100 farmers, nursery operators, grape growers and their supporters rallied at Southold Town Hall last week to oppose rezoning of farmland and vineyards to allow no more than one house on every five acres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, MARION E. (MARY ELIZABETH)
description: McGRATH-Marion E. (Mary Elizabeth) of Rye, New York, on June 23, 2001 at the age of 94. Devoted wife of the late Hugh A. McGrath; loving mother of John W. McGrath of New York City, Eileen T. Baynes of Atlanta, GA, Hugh A. McGrath, Jr., M.D. of Metarie, LA, Mary Elizabeth Hutcoe of Mahopac, NY, Richard A. McGrath of Lititz, PA, Julianne E. McGrath of Rye, NY, the late William McGrath and the late Lt. Paul M. McGrath, USMC. She is also survived by 17 grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. She was 1926 graduate of the College of New Rochelle, and received an MA from Fordham University in 1928. The family will receive friends at her home on Monday, June 25th from 4-8 PM. There will be a Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY at 10 AM on Tuesday, June 26. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Paul M. McGrath Scholarship Fund at Canterbury School, New Milford, CT 06776.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: FOR all the people who believe Christina Crawford made up those terrible things in her memoir ''Mommie Dearest,'' the appeal of MILDRED PIERCE (1945) is Joan Crawford's Oscar-winning portrayal of the ultimate loving, sacrificing mother. For the rest of us, it's classic murder-and-a-flashback film noir. The villain is Mildred's self-centered, superficial daughter Veda (Ann Bluth at 17). To give Veda the things she wants, a newly divorced Mildred takes a job as a waitress, opens her own restaurant and ends up with a chain of them. Along the way she marries Zachery Scott, who is shot dead in the living room of his beach house in the first scene. Michael Curtiz directed -- Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: Investing; A Sector Strategy, Overtaken by Events?
description: SECTOR rotation, a strategy based on exploiting disparities in the stock market performance of different industries, was a popular technique for investors during the technology boom of the 1990's.

title: So Much to Declare
description: With the dollar so strong in Europe and Canada, American travelers with retail foresight are stashing collapsible carryalls in their luggage. At Bergdorf Goodman, Tramontano's new oversize tote bag ($225) comes in canvas or denim with leather straps that allow it to be buckled into a 24-inch-long roll. Longchamp takes an even trimmer approach, right, with its bright nylon-and-leather bucket tote, which snaps into a flat square ($100, in orange, pink, blue or yellow at Saks Fifth Avenue). And Tote Le Monde's striped woven plastic market bag ($44 at Anthropologie) can be folded into a rectangle held fast by its own leather handles; it's small enough to slip into a side pocket of even the smallest valise. Of course, since the standard customs limit for incoming duty-free merchandise is $400, these extra bags will obviously be used to carry things like papier-mch Eiffel Towers and Big Ben paperweights.

title: Imaginative Cures For Growing Pains
description: There's trouble brewing in Ashmore, N.C., and that trouble is named Grace.

title: Private Sector; Behind the Tough Exterior, He's a Cats-and-Dogs Guy
description: During more than 40 years at four aerospace companies, Harry C. Stonecipher, the vice chairman of Boeing, has developed a reputation as a hard-boiled boss who is not afraid to pull the trigger on layoffs or to cut loose a money-losing subsidiary. But as his retirement approaches early next year, Mr. Stonecipher, who turned 65 last month, is beginning to explore his softer side.

title: Looking at E-Business From Both Sides Now
description: BOOKS about e-business have proliferated over the last year. Undeterred by the dot-com crash and financial travails of many Internet companies, business publishers have turned to churning out an ever-widening array of guides to help well-established companies prosper on the Web.

title: Not Deep, Not Fast, Not Clutch: Mets Fall Again
description: The Atlanta Braves have fortified themselves with a trade. They have speed, the ability to sustain rallies and a superstar playing at his best. The Mets have none of those things, and that was why they lost to the Braves at Shea Stadium again yesterday, 9-3, in 11 innings.

title: When Fashion and Makeup Do Wonders for the Spirit
description: MY recent obsession with fashion began in a hospital, a few hours after my double mastectomy. In the wee hours of the morning, I crawled into the bathroom to exchange my hospital gown for a nightgown brought from home. Shortly afterward, the night nurse came to change my bandages.

title: She Feels Sick. The Doctor Can't Find Anything Wrong.
description: EVERYBODY feels woozy sometimes. But by the time Chris Woodward was running to her doctor four times a week, she had been having dizzy spells for five years. Then she started having chest pains. But her doctor could not find any medical explanation for her symptoms.

title: True Northeast
description: To the Editor: In ''True Northeast'' (June 3), Wayne Curtis writes about the almost unreal beauty of Camden, Me., while wondering if there could be a Hollywood set designer who would try to pass it off today as a real location.

title: Anne Bass, Daniel Lazare
description: Dr. Anne Ruth Bass, a rheumatologist, is to be married today to Daniel Henry Lazare, an author and a freelance journalist. Judge Nina Gershon of Federal District Court in Brooklyn will officiate at Rain, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Reduced to Ashes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on May 6, about restaurants in Beijing, and a correction in this space on June 10 misspelled the names of the Qing Dynasty minister whose former home is the Bamboo Garden Hotel, site of the Drunken Beauty Veranda restaurant. He was Sheng Xuanhuai, not Shen Xuanhai.

title: After 7 Years of Planning, Memorial to Irish Famine Is Ready
description: WHEN the Great Hunger Memorial of Westchester County is unveiled on Tuesday in V. E. Macy Park in Ardsley, it will be the culmination of an effort by community leaders and elected officials to commemorate the suffering and, ultimately, the courage of millions of Irish immigrants and others who arrived on our shores looking for a new life.

title: Sailing Up to the Beach On a Lake in Zimbabwe
description: After a fine light-air sail across the rippled blue waters of Lake Kariba in Zimbabwe, we coasted into the shallows and eased the bows of our 30-foot catamaran, Biriwiri, to a quiet stop along the muddy shoreline.

title: Ideas & Trends: Reality Check; Will Patients' Rights Fix the Wrongs?
description: HOVERING above last week's Senate debate over the so-called patients' bill of rights was an unspoken question: was all the speechmaking really just a smokescreen that obscures the truly tough health care problems facing the country?

title: When Another Potato Farmer Calls It Quits
description: THE farm stand at the edge of Fairview Farms in Bridgehampton that opened last Thursday was built from the chassis of an old potato truck. It is a relic. After all, the fields where Harry and Art Ludlow grew 2,200 tons of potatoes last year lie fallow this spring. Fourteen other trucks and a potato planter and a potato cutter are up for sale. Weeds are sprouting through the bare expanse of soil that runs from their Mecox Road farmhouses all the way down to Mecox Bay. And the remnants of last season's crop are piled high in the manure spreader, waiting to be dropped on the fields and left to rot.

title: The Fire Last Time
description: DIVIDED MINDS

title: Islanders Create Stir With Trade For Yashin
description: The Islanders lose many games, draw few fans, have not made the playoffs since 1994 and are generally ignored for most of the hockey season, even in their own market, which has three teams. But they usually make a big impression at the N.H.L.'s entry draft. That tradition continued today when they traded the second pick over all and two veterans for Aleksei Yashin, the talented but controversial center from the Ottawa Senators.

title: A Flea Market Hopes to Jump Uptown a Bit
description: The vendors who sell everything from paintings to vintage clothes from the flea market in the West 20's on the Avenue of the Americas have set their sights on a new home: two lots on West 39th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues.

title: Rebecca Rossi, Eric Baruzzi
description: Rebecca Roseanne Rossi, the daughter of Kathleen Rossi of Milwaukee and Douglas Rossi of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Petty Officer First Class Eric Paul Baruzzi, the son of Martha and Ronald Baruzzi of Tinton Falls, N.J. The Rev. Charles Cavalconte, an Eastern Rite Catholic priest, officiated at Easton's Beach in Newport, R.I.
