title: Singles Seeking Same in Big Bold Type
description: THE man, a ''C.E.O. in a major company,'' sought a ''petite Jewish woman, in her 30's, with a joie de vivre, caring heart and integrity, to marry and have children.'' The woman, an ''owner of an international consulting firm,'' wanted a ''special Jewish man, 40 to 55, successful, educated, psychologically astute and interesting.''

title: West Coast Public Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about film versions of historical and biblical epics recently released on DVD referred incorrectly to Peter O'Toole's appearance in ''Lawrence of Arabia'' in 1962. It was not his screen debut; that occurred in ''The Savage Innocents'' in 1959.

title: No Gains for Women On Corporate Boards
description: There is no dispute that women have made strides in corporate America in recent decades; many now serve in top management jobs. Yet while the doors to executive suites may be opening, the same cannot be said of those to corporate boardrooms.

title: Behind the Tough Exterior, He's a Cats-and-Dogs Guy
description: During more than 40 years at four aerospace companies, Harry C. Stonecipher, the vice chairman of Boeing , has developed a reputation as a hard-boiled boss who is not afraid to pull the trigger on layoffs or to cut loose a money-losing subsidiary. But as his retirement approaches early next year, Mr. Stonecipher, who turned 65 last month, is beginning to explore his softer side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, IRENE MARIE
description: HUGHES-Irene Marie. Born June 3, 1955. Died June 8, 2001. Survived by her mother, Sarah Hughes, her sister, Jane Keesler, and two nieces. May she rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, JOHN
description: GERSON-John. June 20, 1997. No one can fill the void. You are in my heart and mind always. E.G.

title: Kim Magloire, Charles Nafie Jr.
description: Kim Marie Magloire and Charles Jennison Nafie Jr. were married last evening by the Rev. David Robb at All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAMANTE, MATTHEW A.
description: BRAMANTE-Matthew A. On June 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Denis, Anthony, and Mark. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Diana, Anthony, Christa, Stephanie, and Matthew. Fond father-in-law of Roseann, Ann Marie, and Graceanne. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn, until Tuesday, 8:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Frances de Chantal, 9:30 AM. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: June 17-23; Berenson Reconvicted
description: For five years, the United States put pressure on Peru to give Lori Berenson a new, civilian trial. The trial was granted: the 31-year-old New Yorker was again convicted of collaborating with terrorists by renting a house for them and posing as a journalist to get into the Congress building to analyze its vulnerability to attack. But unlike the military court that first convicted her, the three civilian judges ruled that she was not a terrorist. Her life sentence was reduced to 20 years. She said she would appeal to Peru's Supreme Court, but her best hope may be for a pardon from the incoming president, Alejandro Toledo. Clifford Krauss

title: Can G.E. Still Prosper Without Honeywell?
description: WORD that European regulators are on the verge of rejecting General Electric's $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International has drawn concerned statements from President Bush and members of the House and Senate as well as editorials in major newspapers.

title: A Tale of a Missing Torah: Nervous Wait, Joyful Ending
description: When is a Torah stolen but not stolen, or taken temporarily but not exactly borrowed? These may sound like paradoxes that a rabbi might pose to a student, but they also describe what happened to a prized handwritten scroll that was found to be missing from a temple on May 27.

title: Counterpoint: Beautiful Exterior but a Lack of Soul
description: FOR an hour, my friend and I watched the middle-aged men in Dockers, button-downs and neckties stop and circle the gleaming black Thunderbird parked on a busy downtown street.

title: Alexandra Rojas, Andrew Castrucci
description: Alexandra Rojas and Andrew Castrucci, both artists, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in Lower Manhattan. The Rev. Charles McTague, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: DIAGNOSIS; Forgetful, Fearing Alzheimer's and Hoping for a Cure
description: KEN clutches hope in his hand as the doctor's questions start. It is a wrinkled newspaper article about an Alzheimer's vaccine. He pulls it from his wallet with a look of anticipation flashing briefly on his face -- before he forgets to ask the doctor about it.

title: Mets Have Much More Than Rocker on Mind
description: The Mets learned during their game with the Atlanta Braves Friday night that the outrageous reliever John Rocker had been traded to the Cleveland Indians. They shrugged.

title: A Fast Track for Mexico
description: It is Mexico's turn for an economic miracle. After World War II it took less than a generation for Western Europe and Japan to go from poverty to affluence. Later came transformations in Spain, Portugal, Ireland, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan. Mexico, with 100 million citizens impatient for social and economic progress, can be next -- if its partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement adopt a strategy to help.

title: Article 2001062492750604098 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Bush May Lift Park's Snowmobile Ban
description: The Bush administration appears to be on the verge of reversing a Clinton-era ban on snowmobiles that was to go into effect in two years here in the nation's oldest national park.

title: Ideas & Trends; In the Shadow of AIDS, a World of Other Problems
description: SEVENTEEN million Africans dead and 25 million infected with H.I.V. have made their point. At this week's Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly, ministers and experts will agree that a multibillion dollar war on AIDS is global priority No. 1. They will say that, and they will mean it. But when talking about aid for the poorest countries, things are seldom that simple.

title: Qwest Stops Construction On a Site in Yonkers
description: Qwest Communications, a Denver-based supplier of telecommunications services, has stopped construction on a vacant 500,000-square-foot distribution center in Yonkers that it had planned to use as a communications center to play host to World Wide Web sites.

title: Bronx Butterflies
description: To the Editor: The article ''Hanging Out With Butterflies'' by Lisa Fugard (May 20) reminded me of an amazing experience my husband and I had in that most exotic of cities, New York -- in Co-op City in the Bronx, to be exact, where we lived for 21 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on June 10 about a new newspaper, Queens Business Today, misstated its frequency. It is month ly, not weekly.

title: Vanity in a Valise
description: Gone are the days of pocketing hotel shampoos and lotions for the next trip. High-end beauty products are now available in miniature packaging, to wear well on the road. This spring at Bergdorf Goodman, Fred Brandt introduced Brandt to Go, at left above, a travel-size collection of cleansers and moisturizers ($3 to $10); they come with a nylon bag designed to cover travel beauty needs with minimal clutter. This month, Essential Elements introduced a kit, center, to hang on a hotel bathroom door, unfolding to reveal lotions, shampoos, lip balm, a stacking canister of face-cream pots and a washcloth ($48; 800-908-4009). Neal's Yard offers a candy tin of little vials, right, filled with bath and body products ($15 at Flight 001). T. LeClerc offers Voyage, a container of loose face powder that the company describes as virtually spill-proof ($60 at Barneys New York). And come fall, Stila will embrace a travel theme in products that feature the Stila Girl holding compass and map at exotic locales like the pyramids and African jungles. If you're having your picture taken at the Sphinx, you're going to want a little lipstick.

title: Tamara Peterson, Eben Weiss
description: Tamara B. Peterson, a daughter of Sheila Peterson of Edwards, Colo., and Ronald A. Peterson of Southampton, N.Y., was married last evening to Eben Oliver Weiss, a son of Patricia A. Weiss of Long Island City, Queens, and Daniel E. Weiss of Manhattan. Judge Ruth C. Balkin of the Nassau County Family Court in Garden City, N.Y., officiated at the bride's father's house.

title: Donica Courter, Paul Dohrenwend Jr.
description: Donica Lee Courter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Courter of Hackettstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Burbank Dohrenwend Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dohrenwend of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Frank Fowler III performed the ceremony at Trinity United Methodist Church in Hackettstown. The Rev. Otto Hentz, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: On a Crusade Against Bad Service
description: THE restaurant was idyllic, perched along the Hudson River where breezes cooled the diners eating under a large striped tent. Joel Baumwoll, a self-described foodie who had taken along a cheerful party of friends, was looking forward to a tasty meal at one of his favorite haunts.

title: Spano Seeks Changes To Law on Land Sales
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew J. Spano has signed a law that gives municipalities the right to buy any property the county sells, even though he said he feared it could be used to thwart efforts to increase the county's inventory of low-cost housing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELFER, PETER
description: BELFER-Peter. 1946-1971. On this your Birthday, we love you and think of you as we do each day. Jean and Ira

title: Men & Health: Lessons of the Heart
description: Three men share their tales of surviving heart problems with humor, courage and the best medicine. Plus news on chronic anger, heart rates and checkups.

title: One Thumb Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Days of Wine, Hiking and Seals
description: MELBURNIANS, it is often said, are inordinately proud that their city was founded by free settlers rather than convicts. Perhaps it's how they endure the world's infatuation with Sydney, neighboring New South Wales's booming metropolis -- and one-time open-air jail. So what to make of the fact that one of Melbourne's favorite year-round getaways, the Mornington Peninsula, harbored an early convict settlement? In truth, probably nothing. This is Australia, mate, a land where only a drongo would let historical pride get in the way of temporal pleasures.

title: Erin O'Reilly, 41, Sergeant Who Broke Up Gangs, Dies
description: Erin O'Reilly, a New York City police sergeant who helped orchestrate the downfall of two entrenched Harlem drug gangs by using a new legal approach, died last Sunday at a Long Island hospital. She was 41 and lived in North Babylon, N.Y.

title: June 17-23; On Federal Death Row
description: The government has executed three men in the last 38 years, two of them within eight days: Timothy J. McVeigh and Juan Raul Garza, who was convicted of three drug-related murders. There are 19 men are on federal death row, and the attorney general has made it easier for the number to grow. In deciding whether to make a case federal, the Justice Department may now factor in that a state does not have the death penalty.

title: Necks and Elbows Are O.K., but Knees Are His Thing
description: WHEN asked how it feels to blow out a knee, an athlete is likely to recall the sudden, sickening snap, not unlike the sound of celery breaking in two, or the dizzying blast of pain. But when Jesse Cohen talks about tearing the anterior cruciate ligament of his right knee during football practice at Cornell in 1976  an injury that ended his college athletic career on the spot  what he remembers is the sense of loss.

title: When Fashion and Makeup Do Wonders for the Spirit
description: MY recent obsession with fashion began in a hospital, a few hours after my double mastectomy. In the wee hours of the morning, I crawled into the bathroom to exchange my hospital gown for a nightgown brought from home. Shortly afterward, the night nurse came to change my bandages.

title: China's Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Child's Death Has Swiss Searching for Answers
description: The death of a toddler left alone to succumb to starvation and thirst while her mother was in jail for stealing has stunned this country, and left people wondering how such an incident could happen in so orderly a society.

title: Letters
description: UPGRADED FILMS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARB, GENE
description: FARB-Gene. Visionary entrepreneur, president Whole Earth Access, passed peacefully at home June 13, 2001, of colon cancer. Gene was 55, born and raised in Brooklyn: BA, City College, NY and MA GWU. Gene created the the New Earth Exposition pioneering solar energy and alternative lifestyles, and co-founded Whole Earth Access, the eminent ''yuppie'' emporium which grew to an eight-store $180 million Bay Area chain, one of the first retailers of personal computers. Two sons Noah & Bryan, wife Toni, parents Jack and Estelle, brothers Larry and Fred, his sister-in-law Laura, cousins Ellen and Claudia will carry on his love of tennis, sports, business and life.

title: Island's Economy Still Hums Along
description: LLOYD STAFFING of Melville is currently screening applicants to fill three openings for controllers at Long Island companies, at salaries ranging from $65,000 to $145,000. Merrill Banks, Lloyd's president, said his recruiters were being highly selective.

title: Private Sector; Putting G.M.'s Angel in the Outfield
description: Executive eyes were beaming Monday night in the General Motors suite above home plate at Comerica Park in Detroit, even if the Yankees were beating the Tigers.

title: Measures Aim At Violence Along Border
description: The United States and Mexico have announced several steps to improve safety along the California border, including a pilot program to arm Border Patrol agents in San Diego with nonlethal weapons that fire marble-size pepper pellets to disperse crowds.

title: Judah and Tszyu Win, Setting Up Unification
description: Zab Judah of Brooklyn knocked out Allan Vester of Denmark 2 minutes 58 seconds into the third round tonight at the Mohegan Sun Casino, reinforcing his position as one of the world's most talented young boxers and continuing his march to a 140-pound unification bout.

title: Three Who Will Carry the City's Torch
description: Swinging his arms, Mick Greene strode up to a schoolhouse in Jamaica Estates, occasionally firing a pink rubber ball against the asphalt with casual expertise. The ball smacked the street and curved back into his palm, as if attached by an invisible wire.

title: Non-Gala Is a Success For Environmental Group
description: Scenic Hudson, an environmental group based in Poughkeepsie, has surpassed all expectations with its annual fund-raising gala -- even though the gala never took place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONTAG, FREDERICK H.
description: SONTAG-Frederick H. Of South Orange, NJ, and Seal Harbor, ME. On June 21, 2001. Husband of Edith V. Memorial Mass to be announced at a later date. For more information contact Preston Funeral Home, South Orange, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Jude's Episcopal Church, Seal Harbor, ME.

title: The Way We Live Now: 6-24-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Brad Palmerio, Asbury Park, N.J., May 5, 2001.

title: At a Fitness Boot Camp, Changes in Habits and Waist Size
description: THE proof of the eating was in the pudding not to mention the French fries, hamburgers and ice cream. I had ballooned to 250 pounds on a 6-foot frame, almost 100 pounds more than I weighed in my salad days at Rutgers University 40 years ago.

title: A Devastating Lack of Awareness
description: STRESS, of course, is not good for you. But when it comes to heart disease and its consequences, cardiologists say they wish women would feel a little more of it.

title: The Gift of Gab Comes at a Cost
description: PHYLLIS HUGHES, a 58-year-old widow, looked out from a window of her freshly painted ranch house and gestured toward the end of the street where a 115-foot cellular tower could soon loom over this middle-class neighborhood.

title: Ecuadoreans' Labors Turn Into Cargoes of Disappointment
description: More than a hundred angry, frustrated Ecuadorean immigrants gathered outside a shipping company called Ecuatoriana Express on Monday, clutching receipts and exchanging stories. The business, on Roosevelt Avenue, had abruptly shut its doors about two weeks ago after months of complaints about undelivered packages.

title: A 'Ridiculous' Show
description: When John Lithgow takes the stage at the Trenton War Memorial tomorrow, it will not be in the space-alien guise he assumed on NBC's ''Third Rock From the Sun.''

title: Developing a Naval Fighting Machine in a Cornfield
description: From the turnpike in Moorestown, what appears to be the top of a Navy cruiser rises from a cornfield. But the three-story, gray radar superstructure is really atop a Navy building called the Combat System Engineering Development Site, or CSEDS . The facility, jointly managed by the Navy and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, is dedicated to developing the radar system that is the heart of Aegis, the Navy's most advanced combat system (which made the news this spring when the Bush administration decided against selling destroyers equipped with it to Taiwan). About 230 civilians and 60 sailors work in the windowless building where new systems for Aegis are developed and tested. There is $250 million worth of equipment supporting the mission in rooms that reproduce combat information centers on ships: dimly lighted but for vibrant displays from banks of computers. Capt. Philip J. Corbett is the commanding officer at the site. Working with a team of federal civil servants, his responsibility is to oversee execution of the military contracts. Captain Corbett recently talked about the center.

title: Addenda: Robert Igiel Retiring From Media Edge
description: Robert Igiel, a longtime media executive who has served since 1994 as president of the broadcast division at Media Edge in New York, is retiring after negotiations are completed with the television networks for the purchase of commercial time during the 2001-2002 season. Media Edge, part of the WPP Group, is to name a successor soon.

title: They're Still Waiting For an N.B.A. Payday
description: Five years ago, Taj McDavid, an 18-year-old senior at small Palmetto High School in Williamston, S.C., waited at the telephone at home with his mother and his uncle for the call that would make him rich and famous.

title: Mimi Sager, Marc Yoskowitz
description: Mimi Ruth Sager and Marc Joel Yoskowitz are to be married today. The bridegroom's father, Rabbi Herbert Yoskowitz, will officiate at North Suburban Synagogue Beth El in Highland Park, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, ABE
description: HERTZ-Abe. Beloved husband of the late Fay. Adored father of Eileen and Howard Grunther, Karen and David Freedberg. Cherished and loving Poppy of Richard and Kelly, Scott and Lisa, Andrew and Elissa. Loving great-grandfather of Sam and Adam. A man of great character and generosity. An unsurpassed devotion to family is his living legacy. Service Sunday, 1 P.M., ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Ben Has a Birthday
description: It was an engineering marvel when it opened in 1926. Not only was it the world's largest suspension bridge at the time, it was also the first bridge to rely on single cables to hold it up. Driven nearly 100 feet below the river on either end, the cables stretched upward like a pair of suspenders over two 380-foot towers, supporting a 1,750-foot span and proving that man could tame nature.

title: Three Who've Learned The Hardest Way
description: IN a cramped room at the Mount Sinai Hospital's Cardiac Care Center, time is marked by the loud, mechanical beating of Louis Fantauzzi's artificial heart. It is the sound of a tethered life, a life in suspension.

title: Shedding A Backpack For a Back Seat
description: OF all the pleasures of foreign travel, there are few more enjoyable for me than the cab ride from the airport into town. De Gaulle into Paris, Barajas into Madrid -- the trip always provokes a melancholy combination of anticipation, guilt and nostalgia that only makes the ride all the more pleasurable.

title: ONLINE CASINOS
description: The state attorney general's office last week filed lawsuits against three foreign-based Internet operations that, according to authorities, provide illegal gambling and make it available to underage users. During a 15-month investigation state investigators created accounts and bet on virtual casino games such as blackjack, virtual card games, and professional sporting events. Atlantic City is the only place in New Jersey where casino gambling is permitted. John Holl

title: Take 2 large men, add olive oil, toss vigorously

title: Political Briefing; Narrowing Race To Lead Virginia
description: Now that the field is set for the governor's election in Virginia this fall -- Mark Warner, a wealthy businessman, representing the Democrats, and former Attorney General Mark Earley representing the Republicans -- how does the race look?

title: A Majority of One
description: Justice O'Connor is an intelligent woman whose decisions I have often disagreed with but have always respected. However, she lost the respect of many with the decision in Bush v. Gore. As your article put it, she is the leader of the federalism revolution, but she ignored that revolution for the exigencies of partisan politics. To use the excuse that the country was polarized and that she acted in its best interest is disingenuous. To intervene as the Supreme Court did destroyed the legitimacy of the election outcome.

title: June 17-23; No Peace in Ulster
description: The border dividing Catholic and Protestant areas in North Belfast is called the Peace Line, but it was the scene of shootings, gasoline bombings and rock throwing as violence that injured more than 60 police officers broke out over whether Catholic students would be allowed to walk to school along a Protestant block. Meanwhile, Ulster's warring politicians found peace just as elusive in emergency meetings aimed at saving the 1998 power-sharing government from collapsing in a stalemate over disarming paramilitary groups like the Irish Republican Army. Warren Hoge

title: A Parade of Suburban Progress
description: IT could be argued that some things are just fine the way they are, and that includes parades.

title: Naturally
description: Michael Pollan's article (May 13) chronicled one man's longing for the pastoral organic-foods movement of yesteryear. However, it failed to convey the positive future that progressive organic producers see for organic foods.

description: Alan Webb did not win the 1,500-meter title today in national outdoor track and field championships. He did not even finish among the first three, which would have given him a chance to represent the United States at this summer's world championships.

description: Hartford school administrators want to distribute contraceptives in the city's public schools to reduce high levels of teenage pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

description: WITH buildable acreages dwindling to a trickle in elite communities from Greenwich to Litchfield, builders are pouncing on leftover parcels from former farms and estates, foreclosed properties and properties in locations out of the fashionable neighborhoods.

The Pietasters, a seven-piece, horn-backed outfit from the District of Columbia, rides ska's third wave, mixing late Jamaican ska, early rock-steady and 1960's soul. They perform at 3 p.m. today at Club Krome, Route 35, Sayreville. Robbie Woliver

title: Mets' April Optimism Seems Long Ago
description: Those were the good old days, those first days of the season. The Mets beat the Braves two out of three games in Atlanta in the opening series, then did it again in New York a few days later. Oh, those were heady times, all right. Right from the start, the Mets showed the Braves they would not be their patsies again this year. More important, they showed themselves.

title: Lip Crit: It Smacks of Angelina
description: NOT since the heyday of the Kirk Douglas chin and Bette Davis's eyes has a Hollywood star's facial feature so gripped the public imagination. At least, that's the impression you get from all the comments lately about Angelina Jolie's lips. But that's partly because critics found little else of substance to talk about in her latest film, ''Laura Croft: Tomb Raider'' (still and all, No. 1 at the box office last week). Some of the lip service:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRYSTALL, JESSE

Contributions may be made to the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, NYC 10003, or to a charity of choice.

title: 2001 N.B.A. DRAFT PREVIEW
description: Duke's Shane Battier will undeniably be among the top picks in Wednesday's draft at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. But as a college graduate who used all four years of his eligibility, he will be in the distinct minority. No fewer than six high school players declared themselves eligible, and one of them -- either Kwame Brown or Tyson Chandler -- is expected to be the first high school player in league history taken No. 1. MIKE WISE

title: An Olympics in New York
description: For the second time in four years, New York City has submitted a proposal to serve as a host of the Olympics, this time for 2012. The offer deserves scrutiny that is both sympathetic and skeptical. New York has many assets to offer the Olympic Games, including an unrivaled urban backdrop, an enthusiasm for sports competition and a remarkably diverse population. New York could also benefit from holding the Olympics. Revenues derived from the games ought to be enough to pay for most of the needed athletic facilities, which would then remain for use by city residents. A major question over the location and financing of an Olympic stadium needs to be resolved. But at this early stage, the possibility of a New York Olympics seems promising and even exciting.

title: Gershwin Diagnosis: It Ain't Necessarily So
description: WHEN George Gershwin died in 1937 at the tragically early age of 38, his doctors said he had been suffering from a fast-growing malignant brain tumor. But a pathologist in Louisiana has come up with another diagnosis -- that the tumor may have been slow-growing and treatable, even with the technology of the time.

title: A Once-Quiet Precinct Council Quarrels Over Its Makeup
description: The 20th Precinct Community Council -- one of 86 such groups in the city that act as neighborhood liaisons with the police -- usually busies itself with awarding Cop of the Month certificates, running food drives and organizing holiday parties for centers for the elderly.

title: Personal Business; In the Insurance Maze, Adjusters Are Selling a Map
description: FOR months, Dieter and Leighanne Klunker labored to restore their 107-year-old house in Fairview, Utah -- painting, refinishing wooden floors and renovating the attic. They even took out a second mortgage to pay for it all. But a week after the work was completed in November 1999, and while the couple and their four children were away, the dishwasher shorted out, causing a fire that severely damaged the house. They lost most of their possessions, including artwork and antiques, as well as their pet cats, parakeet and iguana.

title: 4 Slain in 2 Hours; One Was to Marry Yesterday
description: Four people were shot or stabbed to death in New York City during a two-hour period Friday night and early yesterday, including one man who was slain by a neighbor over a dice game and another man who was killed hours before he was to be married, the police said.

title: Changes in Met Opera Roster
description: Announcements of cast changes usually draw groans from the audience, but the Met in the Parks opera series, which began at Waterloo Village last night, has made worthwhile changes to a roster whose caliber was already higher than road show. The Dominican lyric tenor Francisco Casanova, who last winter stepped in so successfully in the new ''Nabucco'' and ''Il Trovatore,'' is now the Cavaradossi in ''Tosca,'' July 7 at Cooper River in Pennsauken.

title: Next Test for Finance Reform
description: In less than three weeks the House will reach a moment of trial for a cause that grows more urgent every day. Campaign finance reform, which was approved in April by the Senate as the McCain-Feingold bill, has already passed twice in the House, but in a different form. The version that comes up in early July has changes that some lawmakers who support the principle of reform say they do not like. Now, therefore, is the time for supporters to resolve their differences and make the fewest possible changes so that the revised bill -- sponsored by Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Martin Meehan of Massachusetts -- can win Senate approval and be sent to President Bush.

title: 2 Tornadoes Strike Connecticut County
description: Residents of Litchfield County, Conn., tidied up yesterday after two tornadoes touched down in midafternoon Saturday.

title: A Life Story Coolly Told With Voice And Guitar
description: Eric Clapton is a most tasteful rock star. Although this guitar legend has at times fallen prey to the usual excesses -- hard drugs, spiritual zeal and cheesy pop arrangements -- Mr. Clapton has avoided real embarrassments. This is his problem as well as his strength. Refinement can preclude accidental revelation, rock's blessed union of profundity and fun. Carefulness has made Mr. Clapton a master, but an aloof one.

title: Hingis Exits Wimbledon in First Round

Mr. Hackney had been president at Hackney Hackney & Smith, Anchorage, a political and commercial media agency that is being closed.

title: Two Hope Torre Looks Elsewhere
description: The preference of Mariano Rivera and Roger Clemens is to rest during the All-Star Game break rather than pitch. But they have been so good this year that they will probably not have a choice as Manager Joe Torre selects All-Stars among his own players.

title: Young Artists Impressing Venice in the 1700's
description: I couldn't help myself and, the other day, sneaked away from the Venice Biennale, as every other sensible person does at some point. Abandoning the mass of new art, which mingles so hopefully and touchingly with the jasmine and honeysuckle at the public gardens, where the biennale is held, I hopped the vaporetto to San Giorgio Maggiore. There in its last days was a pitch-perfect show about Canaletto's early years, fortuitously timed with a show about his nephew, Bernardo Bellotto, nearly at the end of its run at the Museo Correr in the Piazza San Marco.

title: Future Is Now as Mets Put Hope in the Loss Column
description: Benny Agbayani kept everyone in suspense yesterday by retreating to the left-field fence as if he actually had a chance to catch Brian Jordan's fly ball. Agbayani unintentionally sold it, gradually drifting back, slowly getting his glove in position. But he watched dejectedly as the ball settled into the bleachers. It was another damaging punch to the Mets, who have resembled Tex Cobb four or five times a week.

title: Bonds Respects McGwire Even While Challenging Record
description: At a certain moment during a St. Louis Cardinals batting practice everyone in the ballpark -- fans, vendors, groundskeepers, even opposing players -- invariably halts his activity in a kind of freeze frame to watch the display of fireworks emanating from within the netted cage. It is when the mammoth Mark McGwire, who owns the ever-hallowed single-season home run record with 70, takes his whacks and regularly launches towering shots deep into the stands.

description: When a man offered Feng Chenyun temporary work in another city, she jumped at the chance. Barely literate and desperately poor, Ms. Feng had two children, 10 and 16, and it was nearly impossible to scrape together school fees from her small plot of rice and rape seed.

description: Lawyers for former President Slobodan Milosevic said today that they would challenge a government decree that commits the authorities to hand over indicted war criminals like Mr. Milosevic to the international tribunal in The Hague.

title: MediaTalk; 'South Park' Takes Gross to New Frontier
description: In the last decade, the occasional profanity has crept onto network and basic-cable television. Dennis Franz has made an array of taboo utterances on ABC's ''NYPD Blue.'' Mark Harmon used the four-letter word for dung last year on CBS's ''Chicago Hope.'' Even Ted Koppel used a variation on that word in the heat of a tough interview two years ago on ABC's ''Nightline.''

title: The White House and the Mideast
description: Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, is scheduled to meet with President Bush in the White House tomorrow for the second time in a little more than three months. By contrast, Mr. Bush has issued no invitations to the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, who was a frequent White House visitor during the Clinton administration. This distinction has led to some bruised diplomatic feelings on the Palestinian side. Yet for now, it is appropriate.

title: Many New Extensions Exist, But Not Many Can See Them
description: One wrinkle that could upset the carefully designed rollout of new extensions for Internet addresses is competition from efforts that exist outside the main domain name system.

title: Bush's Vow to Cut Ship Program Gets Strong Resistance From Lott
description: The last time a passenger cruise ship was built in the United States was in 1958. But right now, in a Mississippi shipyard in the home state of Senator Trent Lott, the Republican minority leader, two 1,900-passenger ships together costing more than $1 billion are under construction -- thanks to a government program the Bush administration has called corporate welfare and wants to eliminate.

title: A New Web Site For Tour Fans
description: When the 23-day Tour de France starts on July 7, bicycle racing fans will have a new way to follow it on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONKITE, EUGENE P., M.D.
description: CRONKITE-Eugene P., M.D. Died peacefully June 23, 2001. Distinguished leader, researcher, teacher, role model and friend to hundreds. We admired him, we loved him and we will miss him. Kanti Rai, on behalf of his students around the world

title: Liberty Makes It 7 in a Row
description: By the time the Los Angeles Sparks arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday, some of their air of invincibility in the Women's National Basketball Association had seeped out. After sprinting to a league-record 9-0 start, the Sparks had lost back-to-back road games against the Houston Comets and the Cleveland Rockers.

title: The False Promise of Casinos
description: Governor George Pataki and many in the State Legislature, acting with a dispatch normally associated with disaster relief, are trying to rush through legislation to permit tribal casinos in Buffalo, Niagara Falls and an undetermined third location in upstate New York. Is this happening because hearts in Albany go out to the Native Americans who have been mistreated for hundreds of years or because of a new empathy for community leaders struggling to save declining cities? Maybe a little of both. But my guess is it's because gambling revenues are an easy way to raise taxes without public disapproval and campaign contributions from the gambling industry are a growth area in American politics.

title: Beyond the Limelight, an Adviser Helps Guide the Fed
description: WHEN the Federal Reserve finishes a two-day meeting on Wednesday and announces to an anxiously waiting world whether it is cutting interest rates for a sixth time this year, the statement explaining its decision will, of course, reflect the thinking of Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINIKES, JACK
description: MINIKES-Jack. The Hineni Outreach Movement expresses heartfelt sympathy to Michael and Cheryl Minikes, upon the passing of Michael's beloved father, Jack. Our profound condolences to his wife Kitty, his son Stewart and to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Jack Minikes left a magnificent legacy. Michael's exemplary commitment and devotion is an inspiration to us all. Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis, Pres. Barbara Janov, Exec. Dir. Rabbis Yisroel and Osher Jungreis

title: A New Twist in the Proxy Fight for Control of Computer Associates
description: The largest shareholder in the software maker Computer Associates said he would support the company's management against a proxy fight for control of the board, dealing a serious blow to the fight's leader, the Texas billionaire Sam Wyly.

title: Road to Bali Beckons Victors In a Battle of Women's Teams
description: Two of the country's best women's teams battled in Las Vegas yesterday to represent the United States in the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October. One of the teams included Lynn Baker, Irina Levitina, Karen McCallum, Kerri Sanborn, Jill Meyers and Randi Montin. The other team consisted of Kathie Wei-Sender, Betty Ann Kennedy, Juanita Chambers, Jill Levin, Tobi Sokolow and Janice Molson.

title: Clairol tones down a campaign in an effort to give its new hair products a separate personality.
description: CLAIROL is toning down the well-known campaign for its Herbal Essences brand to introduce a line of products that tone up.

title: We Can Beat AIDS
description: The world cannot underestimate the threat of AIDS, but it would be equally wrong to fall into despair. The facts about AIDS are stark: Twenty-two million people have died, with last year's total of three million the highest yet. In some African countries a quarter of the population is infected with H.I.V., the work force is shrinking and decades of progress in raising living standards is being wiped out. The same will soon happen to countries elsewhere -- in Asia, Eastern Europe, the Caribbean -- unless they take drastic action now. And no country is immune. But in the last few months the world has awakened at last, not only to the scope of the problem, but to the reality that we are not powerless against it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighter Accused Of Abuse
description: A New York City firefighter has been arrested on charges that he groped a 12-year-old boy at a doughnut shop in Inwood, the police said yesterday. The active-duty firefighter, Douglas Chizmadia, 60, of the Bronx, was charged with sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child. A customer at the Dunkin' Donuts at 4923 Broadway called the police at 5 p.m. Saturday and said that Mr. Chizmadia groped the boy, who had accompanied Mr. Chizmadia to the store. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

description: UNITED NATIONS, June 25  Asserting that "in the ruthless world of AIDS, there is no us and them," Secretary General Kofi Annan pleaded today for international solidarity against the disease and compassion for its victims.

title: Compaq to Phase Out Alpha Chips and Use Intel's Instead
description: In a move that underscored the chasm between good technology and viable products, the Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it planned to phase out the Alpha microprocessors at the heart of most of its high-performance computers.

title: MediaTalk; Editor Finds No Joy in Discrediting Writer
description: The revelation last week that Joseph J. Ellis, the Pulitzer Prize winning historian, made up stories about having served in Vietnam attracted the attention of academics and media outlets. But the editor who broke the story is taking no particular joy at discrediting the historian.

title: No Pay, No Work in Albany
description: A few years ago, New York State legislators gave themselves a raise after agreeing that their paychecks would be withheld whenever the state budget came in late. This was supposed to remedy their chronic inability to deliver a budget by the April 1 deadline. The scheme has not worked as planned. This year the budget is more than two months late with no resolution in sight. So the lawmakers, who are not getting paid anyway, are preparing to go home, thus bringing their work output into line with their pay intake. What this also means is that in addition to their failure to fashion a budget, the legislators have shortchanged basic legislation as well. Here are a few issues that may require the legislators to return to work:

description: In his young career, Sergio Garcia has become a crowd pleaser because of his flair for the dramatic.

title: Essay; The Henny Poll
description: To the question ''How's your wife?'' the comedian Henny Youngman would reply ''compared to who?'' He should have said with whom, of course, but the political point is valid: between campaigns, those polled tend to judge incumbents in a vacuum. We will put that right today.

description: Now that the once-coveted dot-com distinction has been tarnished by the technology sector's precipitous decline, it is perhaps timely that two new suffixes for Internet addresses are coming down the pipeline.

He achieved the highest rankings in the industry as a leading investment research analyst covering railroad, trucking, shipping, and air freight companies. Craig was ranked the #

title: The Swinging Side of Cabaret, in Four Variations
description: Music critics and fans alike have squandered hours debating what distinguishes a jazz from a cabaret singer. The conventional wisdom holds that one swings and the other doesn't, that one improvises and the other doesn't, that one performs in cellars, the other in supper clubs. But in a case by case comparison, those distinctions begin to blur.

title: Mexico City Journal; Politicians, Saints and Sinners Alike, Gain Patron
description: Rarely does Emilio Ulloa Prez, an outspoken leftist politician, abandon his party to take sides with its opponents.

title: Energetic or Exhausted, But Emoting All the Way
description: Attending an Al Green concert can be like buying a used car: one never knows how well or for how long it's going to run. An out-of-church performance by Mr. Green can be a fumbling 20 minutes short or two hours of transcendent soul. It can be an evening of gospel preaching or of back-to-back classic hits.

title: U.S. Wades Into Macedonian Conflict and Skopje Erupts
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, June 25  American troops waded into the worsening crisis in Macedonia today, in an unplanned operation to escort several hundred armed Albanian rebels away from a town that has been the most recent flashpoint. The operation set off a huge riot here in the capital, where citizens are already angry over outside intervention.

title: For the Mets, Another Day, Another Debacle
description: It was a rainy afternoon Thursday when batting practice was canceled and Bobby Valentine entertained questions in his office about the Mets' latest key series this season. The Atlanta Braves were entering Shea Stadium the next day and Valentine was asked if he appreciated baseball's new unbalanced schedule for providing the Mets more opportunities to re-enter the divisional race.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harrison: Metro-North Delays
description: A New York City-bound train on the Metro-North Railroad snagged and pulled down power lines above the tracks yesterday morning, causing delays of more than an hour on the New Haven line. Dan Brucker, a railroad spokesman, said the train's pantograph, an arm that touches wires to bring power to the train, got caught on the overhead lines about 11 a.m., between Harrison and Rye. It was the second such accident for Metro-North in a week. The problem, which forced the closing of two tracks, left only one of four tracks in service because one track was already closed for maintenance. The railroad will have two tracks operating this morning, and riders on the New Haven line should expect only minor schedule changes, Metro-North said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Minikus and Oh Star Win Championship
description: Todd Minikus and Oh Star, his German-bred stallion, cleared all nine fences on the jump-off course in 47.94 seconds to win the $100,000 United States Equestrian Team show jumping championship yesterday, the closing day of the team's Festival of Champions in Gladstone, N.J.

description: Zab Judah felt the blood pounding through his head as he looked around the ring Saturday night. His mouth was dry, his heart racing. The punches rained down, and it looked as if all the hard work of the past few months would fall apart at any moment.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Denville Township: Route 80 Traffic Tie-Up
description: Traffic on busy Interstate 80 westbound in northern New Jersey will be rerouted at least until Wednesday after a fiery fuel tanker crash near Exit 39 destroyed a key bridge last week, the New Jersey Department of Transportation said. ''It's going to be a real challenge getting around on Monday,'' James Berzok, a spokesman for the department, said yesterday. More than 125,000 vehicles a day pass over that stretch, he said, and they will now be diverted to Route 10 and Route 46. A temporary two-lane bridge to replace the damaged four-lane bridge will be in place as early as Wednesday, he said.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. SEEKS NEW WAY TO BLOCK CAMPAIGN MEASURE
description: As the drive to overhaul the nation's campaign finance system moves to the front of the House agenda, the struggle over money in politics has turned into an unlikely tug of war for the support of a pivotal bloc of blacks, Hispanics and liberals.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Dies In Knife Attack
description: A 27-year-old man was killed and two friends were hospitalized early yesterday morning after a scuffle with three other men outside a Queens restaurant in which one of the other men pulled a knife, the police said. No suspects had been arrested last night. The dead man, Victor Diaz Hernandez, was stabbed in the chest about 3:30 a.m. The two friends, Alejandro Cruz, 18, who was stabbed several times, and Jose Velasquez, 30, who was stabbed in the right arm, were listed in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center, the police said. It was not immediately clear whether the two groups of men knew each other or what the dispute was about, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Unitarian-Universalists Elect First Black President
description: The Unitarian-Universalist Association, a liberal religious body with a predominantly white membership, has for the first time chosen an African-American minister as its president.

title: Robert Igiel Retiring From Media Edge
description: Robert Igiel, a longtime media executive who has served since 1994 as president of the broadcast division at Media Edge in New York, is retiring after negotiations are completed with the television networks for the purchase of commercial time during the 2001-2002 season. Media Edge, part of the WPP Group, is to name a successor soon.

title: Hong Kong Hotel
description: Summer in Hong Kong brings savings of 35 percent on standard rooms at the five-star Kowloon Shangri-La (and some hot, humid weather,too). The rates, starting at $186 single and $212 double, include breakfast and use of the health club. For another $26, guests get personal butler service, unlimited refreshments, drinks during cocktail hour, clothes pressing and a 6 p.m. check-out. Rates are good until Sept. 30 and do not include 10 percent service charge and 3 percent tax. Call (800) 942-5050 or www.shangri-la.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUD, ROSALIE KEITH KERR
description: LOUD-Rosalie Keith Kerr. Rosalie Keith Kerr Loud, known to her family and friends as Kiki, died peacefully June 10, 2001, in Paris, France while vacationing with her husband. Born in New York City, Kiki was the beloved wife of Theodore Ewald Loud, formerly of Grosse Pointe, Michigan, and New York City. Kiki was the daughter of the late Albert Boardman Kerr, Esq., lawyer and author from New York City and Rosalie Kerr McGavock, who moved to Charlottesville in 1938. Prior to her marriage to Ted Loud in 1982, Kiki was a professional actress, model and singer in New York City. She appeared in numerous movies, television series, commercials and print advertisements. When Kiki and Ted moved to Charlottesville in 1986, she became active in the Albemarle Garden Club, of which she served as president for two years in the mid-nineties. She was also a charter member of the Contemporary Club. Kiki attended St. Anne's School in Charlottesville, National Cathedral School and Vassar College. Kiki is survived by her husband of 19 years, the aforementioned Theodore E. Loud; two daughters from a previous marriage, Keith Randolph Deering Morgan and Alexandra Kerr Deering Haigney; and two grandsons, Keith Robinson Morgan and Andrew James Morgan. A memorial service was held on June 21. Contributions to Garden Club of America.

title: Rising Costs Result in a Proposal To Delay 6 New Queens Schools
description: Board of Education staff members have proposed delaying the construction of six new schools in Queens and postponing most major school renovations in the five boroughs for two or more years because of soaring construction costs, according to board documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORTON, GEORGE S., SR.
description: HORTON-George S., Sr. Of Quogue, on June 20, 2001. Beloved father of George S. Horton Jr. and Helen Horton. Devoted grandfather of George S. III and Nicholas C. Horton. Contributions in memory of Mr. Horton may be sent to the Quogue Fire Department Benevolent Association, PO Box 5026, Quogue, NY 11959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, CETALIE BREGER
description: WEISS-Cetalie Breger. Died peacefully at home on June 24, in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Marcel. Loving mother of Stephen and Robert. Devoted grandmother of Chip, Cindy, Andrew, Amy, Jocelyn, Megan, Caleb, Gavin, Blair, Laurie, Jennie, Michael, Kenny. Loving greatgrandmother of Jared, Geoffrey, Zander, Hanna, Lucas, Chris, Kaitlyn, Kirstyn, Olivia. Her life was an inspiration of courage and loving devotion to her family and all those who knew and loved her. Funeral service will be held June 25, 1 PM, at Chapel in the Woods, Jewish Community Center, Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave., Suite 330, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: What Nol Coward Used to Shock the English in 1924
description: The problem with old plays that expose the upper crust as hollow and vapid is that once their shock value wears off, the plays themselves seem hollow and vapid. Such is the fate of Nol Coward's first big hit, ''The Vortex,'' now dusted off by the Innocent Theater in the West Village.

title: Artist Emerges With Works in a 'Private Language'
description: As the white minibus pulled up to the Creative Growth Art Center at 9:33 a.m., Judith Scott barreled off as if her life depended on it.

title: FORMER SPY CHIEF OF PERU CAPTURED IN VENEZUELA LAIR
description: Vladimiro Montesinos, the former Peruvian spy chief and longtime C.I.A. agent wanted on charges of gun running, money laundering and collaborating with drug traffickers, was captured on Saturday night in Venezuela with crucial help from the F.B.I. after an eight-month international manhunt.

title: In America; A Death Sentence In Africa
description: The young man named Simon was accompanied by his wife and their 4-year-old twin daughters when he showed up at the AIDS clinic in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Evacuated Residents Await Fate of 2 Buildings in Peril
description: Under foot, the floor sagged. Overhead, plaster fell. Walls cracked. Something popped. And everywhere there was the sudden, pungent stink of natural gas. And Cheryl Van Hooven watched her world, or at least the apartment-sized slice of it that she's rented for the better part of 20 years, slowly -- and quite literally -- begin to fall apart.

title: New Jersey Republicans' Fight for Governor Turns Into a Real One
description: With the Republican primary for governor of New Jersey in its final, feverish 48 hours, tensions flared here this afternoon as supporters of Bob Franks and Bret D. Schundler scuffled on a street corner just as Mr. Schundler arrived to campaign along Bergenline Avenue.

title: AIDS Hidden In Myanmar, Expert Says
description: An American expert on AIDS in Southeast Asia says that the military government of Myanmar is falsifying statistics to hide evidence that the disease has reached epidemic levels there.

description: Last summer, a filmmaker named Joe McCarthy set out to make a movie about the Battle of Brooklyn, one of the bloodiest but most overlooked episodes of the American Revolution.

description: The 102 passengers who set sail on the original Mayflower on Sept. 6, 1620, did not have such an auspicious send-off.

title: Brassy Brass Serves Up A Coltrane Devotional
description: I keep saying it to myself, and it always sounds like a joke: the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band performing ''A Love Supreme.'' Jon Faddis's mega-brassy leviathan, a band known for its somewhat witty, extremely busy rearrangements of the jazz repertory, a band at once effortfully ''modern'' and middlebrow, almost an updated version of the Stan Kenton orchestra, taking on John Coltrane's serene, iconic, long-form act of religious devotion.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: DNA Testing And Death Penalty
description: The City Council is considering a resolution to urge the State Legislature to place a moratorium on the imposition of the death penalty until DNA testing is required in all capital cases. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 11 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7384.

title: A Girl Grows Up With the Bad Habit of Reminiscing
description: Grace McKee has all the rich-girl requisites of her era, 1965: A house the size of a hotel. An alcoholic, emotionally immature mother in a French twist and expensive clothes, who is always away on a trip to someplace like Burma and always on the hunt for Husband No. Next. A handsome, decadent half-brother. Ready cash and a sense of adventure. And like so many rich girls of fiction, 12-year-old Grace (Mae Whitman) exists primarily to prove how emotionally rich, full and loving the lives of the less-than-wealthy really are.

description: For the second consecutive tournament, Tiger Woods will head into a final round needing an incredible comeback to win.

description: NEW JERSEY

title: Birth in Boston Riches, Death in Idaho Ruins
description: When Michael C. McGuckin died in May, at 61, his wife, JoAnn, loaded his emaciated body onto an old mattress in the back of the family Suburban, drove the 16 miles into town and delivered him to Dale Coffelt's funeral home. Mr. Coffelt, who is the county coroner, listed the cause of death as malnutrition and dehydration that were complications of untreated multiple sclerosis.

title: New Economy; The Staples merger of its Web site and catalog business offers a lesson in how to re-evaluate online strategies.
description: In the summer of 1998, Thomas Stemberg, chief executive of Staples Inc., the $10 billion office supply superstore chain, went before his board to plead for the go-ahead to implement an aggressive e-business strategy.

title: Award Winners At Cannes Festival
description: A campaign for Fox Sports that parodied TV sports coverage, created by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, was awarded the Grand Prix for commercials on Saturday at the 48th annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France.

Messages may be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). For comments on an editorial: letters@nytimes.com. For newspaper delivery questions: 1-800-NYTIMES (1-800-698-4637).

title: Court Sides With Freelancers in Electronic Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court ruled today that by making their contents accessible through electronic databases, a group of newspaper and magazine publishers infringed the copyrights owned by freelance contributors who had not agreed to have their work reproduced in a new format.

title: Sports of The Times; Garcia Is Becoming Golf's Little Big Man
description: WITH that baby face under that big cap, he looks like everybody's little nephew. He's not just a skinny 160 pounds, he's almost scrawny. But more and more, Sergio Garcia is developing into the world's best golfer next to you know who.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, WILLIS JOSEPH
description: KEENAN-Willis Joseph. Of Port Washington, NY, on June 24, 2001. Veteran of WWII. Beloved husband of the late Janet. Loving father of Willis Jr., Peter, Susan, Betsey Malone and Sally Sferrazza and cherished grandfather of nine. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, 7-9 PM, Monday. Funeral Mass Tuesday at St. Peter's of Alcantara R.C. Church in Port Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Peter's Church would be appreciated.

title: Activist Roadshow's Summer Tour
description: Not long after midnight, Brandeis University's Sociology 156a rolled off Interstate 40 at Exit 68 into the TA Truck Stop. Young women toted toiletries into the restroom, young men folded themselves into phone booths to dial mothers and girlfriends. David Cunningham, assistant professor of sociology, popped in two quarters for a video game of Galaga.

title: Technology Overdrive
description: BMW's redesigned 7 Series will be unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show in September and arrive in American showrooms in January. Packed with technology, the flagship 7 Series incorporates BMW's iDrive concept, which puts locates important functions in and around the steering wheel and the less-used controls on the center dash. The 4.4-liter V-8 has been upgraded and is paired with a six-speed automatic transmission.

title: Compressed Data; Clicquot Fights Back Against E-Mail Hoax
description: For the last few years, Champagne Veuve Clicquot has been struggling with an e-mail hoax. A message has circulated worldwide, tricking many people into believing that if they forwarded the message to 10 friends and sent a copy to the company, they could win free bottles of Champagne. It also led some Internet users to wonder if the company, a subsidiary of LMVH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton in Paris -- was pulling a stunt to gather their e-mail addresses.

title: Webb Wins L.P.G.A. Title For Career Slam
description: It is virtually impossible to detect any emotion behind the reflective sunglasses that cover Karrie Webb's eyes when she plays. She showed a great deal of emotion, however, when the glasses came off after her final putt and she explained her feelings about winning two major championships three weeks apart to become the youngest player to complete the L.P.G.A. career grand slam.

title: Devil Rays' Comeback Stalls Yankees Again
description: The relay throw from second thumped into the mitt of the first baseman, milliseconds passed and Derek Jeter's foot hit the bag, too late. Jeter eased to a stop and turned slowly toward the visitors' dugout, on the third-base side, as the giddy Tampa Bay Devil Rays crossed his path to shake hands. Their eight-game losing streak was over, a blissful moment in a season of nearly total failure.

title: Physicist Said to Be Top Choice For Science Adviser to President
description: The director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York, John H. Marburger III, has emerged as the leading candidate to be President Bush's science adviser, federal officials said today.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Tom Cosgrove, senior vice president for scheduling and marketing at the Fox Family Channel and Fox Kids Network, Los Angeles, was named to the new post of executive vice president, overseeing daily operations including marketing, strategic planning and programming. Fox Family and Fox Kids are owned by Fox Family Worldwide, a joint venture of the News Corporation and Saban Entertainment.

title: Miners' Union Sees Opportunity in Bush Policy
description: The United Mine Workers, once the nation's most powerful union, has declined more than any other labor group, its working membership having plunged to 30,000, from more than 700,000 six decades ago.

title: Coaxing On-Hold Melodies (Your Own) From a Phone
description: Jason Freeman is an even-tempered fellow, but the simple act of making a telephone call has been known to push his buttons. Whenever he is put on hold and is forced to endure the bland, supposedly soothing music that oozes out of the handset while he waits, he becomes irritated. ''And if it's Pachelbel's Canon, I get really annoyed,'' Mr. Freeman said, referring to the numbingly repetitive Baroque ditty.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hampton Bays: Teacher Charges Witch Bias
description: A Long Island elementary school teacher who has been denied tenure is suing her school district on the ground that it discriminated against her because she is rumored to be a witch. The teacher, Lauren Berrios, 32, of Holtsville, claims that after she taught her reading class at Hampton Bays Elementary School about the Massachusetts Bay Colony, rumors that she practiced witchcraft spread through the school. Her lawsuit seeks damages of $1 million. J. Bruce McKenna, the schools superintendent, called Ms. Berrios's allegations ''ludicrous.'' Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNARA, LYDIA P.
description: MANNARA-Lydia P. On June 23, 2001 (in New York City). Beloved sister of Anthony and his wife Marina, devoted aunt of Alexander and Mark, loving daughter of the late Dr. Paul and Luciana Mannara, and caring friend of many. A Mass of Christian Burial wil be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. and 84 St., Tuesday, June 26, at 9:30 AM. Visiting hours Monday, June 25, from 5 to 7 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Marymount School, Vassar College and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Pope Finds a Hard Road To Ending Rift in Ukraine
description: Pope John Paul II prayed today in silent pine woods where nearly 200,000 people killed by Stalin are buried, using Ukraine's dark past to try to broker religious reconciliation in the country's edgy present.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: A Parade Underscores Candidates' Unity on Gay Issues
description: The six men vying to take over City Hall each reached to embrace the rainbow flag yesterday, as the Democratic and Republican mayoral candidates joined in the annual celebration of gay pride that once again turned a large swath of Midtown and Lower Manhattan into a pulsating, gyrating party.

title: Offstage Drama at Long Wharf; The Feud That Led a Proud Theater's Director to Resign
description: They started on friendly terms. Barbara L. Pearce led the search committee that in 1997 selected Doug Hughes as the first new artistic director in 30 years to lead Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Mr. Hughes backed the decision to make Ms. Pearce chairwoman when he came to the theater. Ms. Pearce says she introduced Mr. Hughes to Lynn Fusco, whom he married last year. At fund-raising events, the two regularly performed an impressive pitch on behalf of the theater, with no evident signs of tension between them.

title: Sampras's Wimbledon: An Aura Tinted Green
description: In the days before the crowds filter into the pristine grounds, with only the background sounds of work crews hammering in the 11th-hour details, Pete Sampras often steals a moment alone inside an empty Center Court.

title: Partial, Shaky Truce Reached in Macedonia
description: A partial cease-fire was accepted today by the government and ethnic Albanian rebels, after three days of heavy fighting close enough to Macedonia's heart that visitors could see the smoke and shelling as they stepped off planes at the airport.

title: Return of the Go-Go's, With Muscle
description: Nostalgia for power pop and new wave rock filled Rumsey Playfield in Central Park before the reunited Go-Go's took the stage , as a tape played songs from Eddie and the Hot Rods, the Raspberries, the Replacements and the Clash. Then the Go-Go's themselves took over, pert and eager to take up where they'd left off when they disbanded in 1985.

title: Market Place; Ruling Is Lift To Investors In NextWave
description: When a federal appeals court ruled on Friday that the government had illegally confiscated NextWave's share of the wireless spectrum, the celebration extended beyond the company's offices in Hawthorne, N.Y. A number of investors who focus on troubled companies, including some who had invested in recent weeks, more than doubled their money on shares that were once nearly worthless.

title: Yvonne Dionne Dies at 67; a Quintuplet Who Made History
description: Yvonne Dionne, a member of the first recorded set of quintuplets to survive more than a few days, died on Saturday morning in a Montreal hospital. She was 67.

title: E-Commerce Report; Web sites that reacquaint old classmates gain success with aggressive marketing strategies.
description: AT first glance, Classmates.com looks as if it is about two years late to the dot-com party. The site, which helps people get reacquainted with long-lost friends, belongs in the so-called community category, which had its fortunes peak in early 1999 when Yahoo paid roughly $4.5 billion for GeoCities, a company that helped users build and share Web pages.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Profit Up
description: The Irish no-frills airline Ryanair reported annual results that beat analysts' forecasts, with profits up 44 percent, to 104.5 million euros ($90 million), on revenue of 487.4 million euros, for the year to March 31. The company credited significant cost-cutting and a hedging program that held down its fuel costs. Ryanair carried 7.4 million passengers last year, and 72 percent of the tickets were purchased through its Web site. The company said that it hoped to open a second European hub in the next year, and increase revenue through ancillary services like hotel and car rental reservations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: ERNST-Howard L., on June 18. Son of the late Abraham Ernst & the late Beatrice Ernst Daffner. Brother of Judith Linn and Naomi Paley. Nephew of E. Billi Ivry. Funeral service is to be held at ''The Riverside'' Memorial Chapel, 9:45AM, Thursday, June 28.

title: Penguins In Trouble Worldwide
description: Harry's habits were as predictable as clockwork, so when he did not return from his last ocean voyage as expected, Dr. Dee Boersma knew something was wrong.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tire Venture
description: The Yokohama Rubber Company said it would form a joint venture with Continental of Germany this year to sell tires to Japanese automakers. The 50-50 venture will help Continental expand its sales to Japanese automakers, said Akira Shinya, a spokesman for Yokohama. Continental will also use Yokohama's sales channels in Japan to sell more replacement tires, and expand the venture to Europe and North America to supply the same tire across the world, Yokohama said.

title: Justices Uphold Curbs on Coordinated Political Spending
description: The Supreme Court today upheld limits on how much political parties can spend in coordination with candidates for federal office. The opinion delighted advocates of a broader ban, now before Congress, that would outlaw unregulated contributions to the parties.

description: POST PROPERTIES INC., Atlanta, the largest apartment developer in Georgia, said it had sold two apartment developments in Dallas and Irving, Tex., and land in Charlotte, N.C., for $99 million to pay down debt and finance development.

title: Rocker a Savior, and a Headache
description: THE yellow cab pulled up outside Yankee Stadium about 3:30 p.m. and idled for a minute while the passenger dug for the fare. The dozens of fans standing behind steel barricades were close enough to notice that the man inside the cab was John Rocker, the narrow-minded pitcher who told Sports Illustrated two years ago all the reasons he despised New York and New Yorkers.

title: Aspirin May Save the Sight of Diabetics
description: Reducing the risk of blindness caused by diabetes may be as simple as taking an aspirin every day, a study suggests.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Upromise Gets New Chief
description: George Bell, former chairman and chief executive of Excite@Home, was named chief executive yesterday of Upromise Inc., a company that helps parents create personalized college savings plans. Mr. Bell succeeds Upromise's founder, Michael Bronner, who will remain as chairman. In his five years at Excite, and later, Excite@Home, Mr. Bell oversaw the company's rapid growth, as it rose from 23 employees to more than 3,000 worldwide. ''I am thrilled to join Upromise,'' Mr. Bell said. ''It combines a vitally important mission with a brilliant business idea, and will enable me to marry my consumer service experience with my passion for education.'' Upromise administers plans that help families save for college by accumulating retail rebates in a tax-deferred fund. Such plans, which operate like airline frequent-flier programs, pool together a small percentage of the mony spent at companies like AT&T, McDonald's and Coca-Cola into a college savings account. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: 'West Wing' Producer, a Union Leader, Rules Out Writers' Raises
description: Two years ago John Wells, the powerful writer-producer of shows like ''E.R.'' and ''The West Wing,'' successfully ran for president of the Writers Guild of America's West Coast branch after describing the status of Hollywood writers as ''intolerable,'' ''a disgrace,'' ''unconscionable'' and ''unpardonable.'' Last month Mr. Wells, seeking to change the way writers are treated and paid in Hollywood, led the Writers Guild team in tense contract negotiations with the television networks and film studios, talks that narrowly averted a strike.

title: Passaic Joins Suit to Bring Help for Preschool Programs
description: This city's superintendent of schools, Robert H. Holster, stood today under the blazing sun in a parking lot where 11 trailers are supposed to serve as temporary classrooms for 165 of the projected 2,083 toddlers eligible in September for full-day prekindergarten classes ordered by the New Jersey Supreme Court. But while the state's own timeline indicates that today was the date when the 11 trailers -- and 69 others elsewhere in Passaic -- were to be installed, they were nowhere to be seen.

description: United States immigration officials dispatched a deportation officer to London over the weekend to interview a man they believe is the father of an 8-year-old Nigerian girl who has been detained for more than 13 months in a Miami shelter for unaccompanied immigrant children.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Racial Case Evolves
description: Three defendants accused in the shooting death of a black woman in the 1969 racial rioting in York have agreed to testify for the prosecution in the case in which Mayor Charles Robertson, left, resigned after being accused of homicide and of encouraging white vigilantism. One of the three, Rick Knouse, has said Mr. Robertson, while a police officer during the rioting, supplied him with ammunition and openly urged angry whites to ''kill as many niggers as you can.'' In cooperating with the prosecution, Mr. Knouse agreed to a guilty plea in exchange for a sentence of 23 months. Mr. Robertson has denied any involvement in the killing. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE<BR GERMANY: PRICE INCREASES SLOW German consumer prices rose at a slower pace in June than in May, making it more likely that the European Central Bank will reduce interest rates as growth in Europe's largest economy slows. The amount charged for goods ranging from clothes to energy increased 0.2 percent, less than half May's 0.5 percent gain, the Federal Statistics Office said. The annual inflation rate declined to 3.1 percent from 3.5 percent in May, the highest level in more than seven years. (Bloomberg News)

title: Jets Pick Up Hofstra's Jackson
description: One month before the start of training camp, the Jets continued to shore up the wide receiver position, claiming the former Hofstra star Steve Jackson off waivers from San Francisco yesterday.

title: New Schools Are Rising, But Costs Rise Faster
description: For decades, school construction in New York City seemed to be little more than a huge money pit where the city and state wasted millions of dollars while students continued to suffer cramped classrooms and crumbling school buildings.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Bid Reaction
description: DBS Group Holdings received a negative reaction to its bid for Overseas Union Bank on the first day of trade since announcing the offer. DBS said it would create 600 million new shares, or half the number now issued, to pay for the bid of 1.14 Singapore dollars in cash and 0.61 share for each Overseas share. That priced the bid at 9.4 billion Singapore dollars ($5.2 billion) before DBS shares tumbled 7.3 percent to a two-year low, reducing the offer to 8.8 billion Singapore dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINNEY, ROBERT MOODY
description: McKINNEY-Robert Moody. A former U.S. Ambassador and Editor and Publisher of the Santa Fe New Mexican for more than half a century, died of pneumonia Sunday night at New York Hospital. He was 90. He was a diplomat, corporate director, conservationist, veteran and poet. McKinney served by appointment to five presidents: As Assistant Secretary of the U.S. Department of Interior, as U.S. Ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency at Vienna, as U.S. Ambassador to Switzerland and held two appointments in the U.S. Treasury Department. McKinney bought the Santa Fe New Mexican in 1949. Due to health problems from the high altitude McKinney sold the company to Gannette Co. in 1976, retaining the right to continue as editor and publisher. After a protracted and celebrated court battle, which he won, McKinney resumed management of the Newspaper in 1987 and repurchased the property in 1989. At one time, he owned four newspapers: The Taos (N.M.) News, The Las Vegas (N.M.) Optic in Las Vegas, N.M., The Monte Vista (Colo.) Journal and the Santa Fe New Mexican. The Taos News is now owned by his daughter, Robin Martin, whose succeeds him as head of The New Mexican. Born in Shattuck, Okla., August 28, 1910, McKinney grew up in Amarillo, TX, the son of a minister. His father Edwin McKinney was a descendent of Colin McKinney, a signer of the Texas Declaration of Independence. His mother, Eva, was the daughter of Robert Moody, a trader on the Santa Fe Trail. McKinney graduated from Amarillo High School and was a reporter for the Amarillo Globe News. He received a bachelor's degree, Psi Beta Kappa, from the University of Oklahoma in 1932. Upon graduation, he worked in New York City as an investment analyst at Standard Statistics, now Standard and Poors. He served as a partner in his cousin Robert Young's investment firm from 1934 to 1950 and became successful by investing in bankrupt railroad stock at the depth of the Depression. During WWII McKinney was a Lieutenant Junior Grade in the U.S. Navy. He helped develop the Tiny Tim Rocket and participated in D-Day to observe the devices piercing German tanks. In 1943, he married Louise Trigg, the daughter of a ranching family from Eastern New Mexico. Because of Santa Fe's close proximity to the National Atomic Weapons Labratory at Los Alamos, McKinney became interested in peaceful uses of atomic energy and published a five volume book on the subject. McKinney served on the board of major corporations, including the Rock Island Railroad, International Telephone and Telegraph, Trans World Airlines and Martin Marietta. He was a published poet; His book ''Hymn to Wreckage'' was rated by the New York Times as one of the ten best poetry books in 1947. Mr. McKinney was divorced from Louise Trigg in 1970 and later married Marielle De Mont Mollin who died in 1998. He is survived by his daughter, Robin McKinney Martin, her husband, Meade Martin, and grandchildren, Laura and Elliott of Nambe; step-son, Laurent De Mont Mollin of Florida; stepdaughter, Edmee Firth of New York; and grandchildren, Marie Louise Slocum and Olivia Slocum of New York and John Slocum of Newport, R.I. A funeral service will be Friday at 10AM at Emanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, VA. Memorial services in New York City and Santa Fe will be announced. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Johns College, Santa Fe.
