title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Premier Urged To Quit
description: As Parliament convened for the first time since the shooting deaths of King Birendra, Queen Aishwariya and other members of the royal family three weeks ago, the Communist-led opposition demanded the resignation of Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala's government on the ground that Mr. Koirala ''failed to protect the lives'' of the royal family. An official inquiry concluded 10 days ago that Crown Prince Dipendra carried out the shootings after a drinking spree, but the Communist leader, Madhav Kumar Nepal, reflecting widespread public skepticism about the official account, said Parliament should conduct its own inquiry into ''many pertinent points'' unanswered in the report. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Belgrade Begins Process of Sending Milosevic to The Hague
description: The Yugoslav government took the first legal steps today to hand over the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, raising expectations that he might be transferred this week before an international conference that could bring aid to Serbia.

title: Senators Reject H.M.O. Suit Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Senate Democrats won two significant victories today as the Senate rejected Republican challenges to a far-reaching Democratic bill to define patients' rights for more than 180 million Americans.

title: Love, Anger and Guilt: Coping With a Child's Chronic Illness
description: When a child is chronically ill, the whole family feels the pain, particularly the parents. Regardless of the disease, whether an emotional disorder or a physical disability, the stress suffered by families is remarkably similar. Mothers and fathers talk about guilt, anger and sheer exhaustion. Brothers and sisters can feel neglected.

title: Offense Fails to Show, Continuing Mets' Slide
description: The long summer began about six weeks ago, when the Mets fell to 10 games under .500 for the first time. They have failed to sustain any momentum since, playing a bit better but succumbing to injuries and an absent offense.

title: Webb Wins L.P.G.A. Title for Career Slam
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 24  It is virtually impossible to detect any emotion behind the reflective sunglasses that cover Karrie Webb's eyes when she plays. She showed a great deal of emotion, however, when the glasses came off after her final putt and she explained her feelings about winning two major championships three weeks apart to become the youngest player to complete the L.P.G.A. career grand slam.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Election To Be Scrutinized
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would send 28 election observers to watch for irregularities in today's Republican primary in Passaic County. The department's action comes after an announcement last week by a court-appointed election monitor that violations persisted in Passaic City's May 8 municipal election, including poll workers' refusal to provide provisional ballots, and intimidation of voters by representatives of candidates. A 1999 federal court decree followed complaints by Hispanic voters that they were disenfranchised, in violation of the Voting Rights Act. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: It's Summer: The Boys Are Back in Town
description: There were marching bands and drum corps and a 20-piece steel drum ensemble, but the joyfullest noise of all along Surf Avenue in Coney Island yesterday emanated from the Dodger Sym-Phony, all five active survivors of it, and they brought tears to Judd Fischler's eyes.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a campaign by Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland to restrict suburban sprawl misidentified the county in which he formerly served as executive. It is Prince George's County, not Montgomery.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Illegal Immigrants Caught
description: An 80-foot fishing boat carrying 199 illegal immigrants from Bangladesh, Afghanistan and other countries was intercepted by the coast guard off southern Italy. The immigrants were brought to shore on a coast guard vessel but the crew escaped on a second boat. In a separate case, 24 illegal immigrants, reportedly Turkish Kurds, were picked up near a highway in Calabria. Italy has become a major entry point for people from Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe and Turkey. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: Cheney Withholds List of Those Who Spoke to Energy Panel
description: Vice President Dick Cheney has declined to identify the people who met privately with his energy task force, raising tensions with Congressional investigators who have repeatedly requested the information.

title: Their Financial Crisis Past, Thais Remain Disillusioned; Harsh I.M.F. Remedies Stir Go-It-Alone Attitude
description: Nearly four years after it devalued its currency, unleashing an economic typhoon across Asia, Thailand is still reeling. And while the storm has passed, its aftereffects have proved stubbornly hard to shake, leaving this country in chronic distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, ABE
description: HERTZ-Abe. It is with great sadness that we extend our condolences to Eileen Grunther, wife of our esteemed colleague, Howard Grunther, her sister and brother-in-law, Karen and David Freedberg, and their children and grandchildren on the loss of their beloved father, grandfather and great grandfather. Abe Hertz was a special man. He was erudite, kind and generous. He was always thoughtful of the needs of others. We feel enriched that he graced our lives. Doctors and Staff Daniel Maklansky, M.D. Jerold D. Kurzban, M.D. Burton A. Cohen, M.D. Jerald Zimmer, M.D. Alain D. Hyman, M.D. Barry D. Berson

title: Former Spy Chief of Peru Is Flown to Lima to Face Charges
description: Vladimiro Montesinos, the former Peruvian spy chief who evaded an international manhunt for eight months before his arrest last weekend, was flown to Lima today in handcuffs and a bulletproof vest and began what promises to be months of questioning and legal processing.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Status
description: India's most influential trade body, the Confederation of Indian Industry, has asked Pakistan to reciprocate and accord most favored nation trade status to India. The request came ahead of a scheduled summit meeting between the leaders of India and Pakistan in Agra in July. It estimated the trade potential between the two neighbors at $5 billion by 2005, up from the current $800 million. ''Enhanced economic cooperation would also contribute to stability in the region,'' the confederation said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Still Evacuated
description: Work continued yesterday to prevent the collapse of an apartment building at 13 West 29th Street. But residents remained barred from both 13 and 15 West 29th Street, after being evacuated Saturday night when walls cracked and floors sagged after a rainstorm. The Buildings Department said it was waiting for a report on permanent repairs. Once they are done, the buildings will be reopened, the city said. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: The Pope at Babi Yar

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Surgery For Firefighter
description: Firefighter Joseph Vosilla, 41, of Astoria, critically injured in the Father's Day fire that killed three of his colleagues, underwent four hours of surgery to his shattered pelvis yesterday, an Elmhurst Hospital Center spokesman said. Mr. Vosilla was crushed by falling debris on June 17, when an Astoria hardware store exploded. Another seriously injured firefighter, Lt. Brendan Manning, 47, remained in stable condition at New York Weill Cornell Center. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: This Time Garcia Isn't the Kid, He's the Man
description: Sergio Garcia left nothing to chance today, leaving those in pursuit with little chance.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Violence Flares Again
description: After a weekend of relative calm, riots broke out in northern Belfast on Sunday night when about 20 Protestant loyalists threw stones and paint at Catholic homes. Dozens of people were injured in rioting last week and the British Army is sending an additional 1,600 troops to Northern Ireland over the coming days in anticipation of further violence. The Northern Ireland police arrested and returned to prison a prominent loyalist paramilitary leader, Gary Smith, who was released in 1999 under the Good Friday peace accord; Catholic leaders say the riots were organized by paramilitary groups. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Producer Responds to Woody Allen Lawsuit
description: Jean Doumanian, who was Woody Allen's closest friend for 30 years and who produced some of his films, responded today to a lawsuit that he filed against her, denying the allegations and accusing Mr. Allen of being ''self-indulgent'' and ''fiscally irresponsible'' in his filmmaking.

title: An Addled Hingis Is Ousted On Day 1
description: Not long ago, the calculating Martina Hingis had it all figured out, able to decode the game of every newcomer, quick to find the angle on each power player.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Fed Credits a New Economy With Altering Old Patterns
description: About 2 o'clock this afternoon, the 17 members of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee will file into their second-floor boardroom on Constitution Avenue in Washington, find the large chairs with the brass plates bearing their names and sit down optimistic that the economy is about to improve.

title: Woman Is Rescued In a Brooklyn Blaze
description: Two firefighters sidled past thick smoke and flames along an apartment hallway to rescue a 46-year-old woman yesterday in a fire in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: Back to Basics: How Did Space Get Its Dimensions?
description: In the beginning, there was little need for physicists. The universe, poised at the moment of creation, was ruled not by the four different forces observed in later times, but by just a single superforce. Instead of a smattering of different particles, there was only the tiny primordial mass -- the grandmother of all particles -- ready to explode in the Big Bang.

title: Tips for the Season of Burgers and Briquettes
description: It is now officially summer and peak grilling season has arrived. Although many questions have been raised in recent years about the safety of consuming foods cooked over hot coals, it would be hypocritical of me, the owner of three well-used grills, to suggest avoiding such fare entirely.

title: Washington Talk; Road to Federal Bench Gets Bumpier in Senate
description: At the White House, lawyers spent last week preparing a short list of candidates for the Supreme Court in case any justice retires when the term ends soon. But no one is certain whether that will happen.

title: Teamsters, Tenacious as an Old Lounge Act, Convene in Las Vegas
description: The last time the Teamsters held a big convention here, 15 years ago, their president at the time, Jackie Presser, was borne into a banquet room reclining on an imperial chariot wheeled by men wearing the costumes of Roman soldiers. The 300-pound Mr. Presser, who had been charged with embezzlement the week before, beamed as hundreds of Teamsters feasted and a loudspeaker proclaimed, ''Hail, Caesar.''

title: U.S. TROOPS ESCORT REBELS TO SAFETY INSIDE MACEDONIA
description: American troops waded into the worsening crisis in Macedonia today, in an unplanned operation to escort several hundred armed Albanian rebels away from a town that has been the most recent flashpoint. The operation set off a huge riot here in the capital, where citizens are already angry over outside intervention.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Arena Bill Clears Panel
description: The New Jersey Senate's budget committee approved a measure yesterday to create a Newark sports and entertainment district whose sales tax revenue would be earmarked to help finance the proposed $355 million Newark arena. The bill also creates a similar district for the Meadowlands to help finance a family entertainment and sports complex to replace Continental Arena. The measure, created to keep Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's promise to Bergen County lawmakers that they would not be left without an economic engine for the vast Meadowlands, also earmarks $300 million for a long-sought rail spur into the Meadowlands and extensive road work. The bill is likely to pass the full Senate this week as the state rushes to meet a July 1 deadline set by YankeeNets, developers of the proposed Newark arena. At the last minute, authority was added to the bill for the districts to impose hotel taxes to help finance development. The bill would allow Newark to increase its hotel tax up to 12 percent, from 6 percent, and the Meadowlands district to impose a hotel tax of up to 6 percent. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: The Image Could Be the Wrong Message
description: Women's health and fitness magazines may not be the healthiest reading matter for teenage girls.

title: POWELL, AT U.N., ASKS WAR ON AID
description: Striking an assertive tone for the Bush administration on AIDS policy, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told the General Assembly today that ''from this moment on,'' the world's response to the disease ''must be no less comprehensive, no less relentless and no less swift than the pandemic itself.''

title: 'Calle 54' Live Documents A Latin Side Of the Beat
description: ''Calle 54,'' the film documentary, isn't the beginning and end of Latin jazz. It's a small slice of the New York scene, with a special inclusion of the Havana-based pianist Chucho Valds and his father, Bebo. Nor does it apply theory or history to the bands featured in well-filmed, uninterrupted 10-minute segments: it's purely visual and aural stimulation with the bare minimum of context.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: House Passes Budget
description: At the start of a three-day special session, the House of Representatives yesterday unanimously approved a two-year compromise state budget totaling $26.4 billion. The 144-to-0 vote (with 7 House members absent) sends Connecticut's first late budget since 1991 to the State Senate, which is expected to approve it by today or tomorrow and pass it on to Gov. John G. Rowland, who could sign it into law by week's end. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Joseph Picone, 83, a Founder Of Line of Women's Clothing
description: Joseph Picone, a tailor who specialized in men's trousers until a woman's skirt crossed the threshold of his tiny shop, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Slower Growth Expected
description: Ireland's breakneck economic growth will slow sharply this year because of falling international demand for Irish exports, and the impact of foot-and-mouth disease on tourism and agriculture, according to the Central Bank of Ireland. Gross domestic product growth is likely to fall from 10.25 percent in 2000 to 6.5 percent this year. But the bank warned that the Irish economy and national infrastructure would be unable to support even those reduced growth rates, and it recommended only modest spending increases in the government's annual budget next December. The finance minister, Charlie McCreevy, has stated his intention to issue an expansionary budget, in contradiction of European Union economic guidelines. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: New York to Be First State to Ban Holding Cell Phone While Driving
description: New York will become the first state to ban talking on a hand-held cellular telephone while driving, under a bill that the Assembly passed today and that the governor promised to sign later this week.

title: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Boston, Vacations Definitely Over
description: THE BOSTONS

title: National Briefing | Washington: Threatened Historical Places
description: The National Trust for Historic Preservation released its annual list of America's most threatened historical places, singling out Ford Island in Pearl Harbor, a Navy site damaged in the Japanese attack; the heavily developed valley floor of Telluride, Colo.; and more than 300 independently owned movie theaters. Other sites include the dilapidated Carter G. Woodson Home in Washington, D.C.; the Miller-Purdue Barn in Grant County, Ind.; the Chinese Bok Kai Temple in Marysville, Calif.; frontier homesteads in Lincoln, Neb.; the prairie churches of North Dakota; and the historic Jackson Ward district of Richmond, Va.

title: Japan Must Not Forget
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Seek Help for Now, Not for Later, Scott Says
description: Byron Scott, burdened with a 26-56 record last season as a rookie coach, said today that he believed the Nets would draft a player who could help immediately.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Friday about Billy Collins, who has been named the next poet laureate of the United States, referred incorrectly in some copies to Lehman College, where he teaches. It is a senior college, not a community college.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was a soldier, but I know of no enemy in war more insidious or vicious than AIDS, an enemy that poses a clear and present danger to the world.''

title: Race Riot Hits Second Town In the North Of England
description: After a weekend of violent confrontations that involved white and Asian youths and the police in Burnley, a town not far from the racially motivated riots last month in Oldham, British officials said today that they were trying to decide whether the incidents were linked and what to do to prevent further unrest.

title: Serfs on the Web
description: But how do you make any money?'' This is the automatic response of virtually everyone upon learning that I run a nonprofit Web site -- a dot-org -- devoted to local history.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Brad Palmerio, Asbury Park, N.J., May 5, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKINSON, EDWIN CONSTANT
description: DICKINSON-Edwin Constant, 67. Retired shipping executive and son of the late painter Edwin W. Dickinson. Died June 22, 2001 of complications following bypass surgery in New York City. A service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Riverside, CT on June 30, 2001 at 11AM. Contributions may be made to Heart Research.

title: Stealth Bomber, Once Scorned, Gains Fresh Backing
description: A pair of Air Force pilots recently locked themselves inside a closet-size metal box here for 50 hours, subsisting on cold pizza and instant noodles, amusing themselves with crossword puzzles and paperback books, and taking occasional catnaps on a fold-up chaise longue from Wal-Mart.

title: Article 2001062693915378567 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an agreement by Connecticut leaders on a two-year state budget misstated the size of the income tax cut that Gov. John G. Rowland had originally proposed. It was $10.2 million, not $712 million. (The larger figure is the total by which Mr. Rowland said income taxes would have dropped since he took office in 1995, had this latest proposal been approved.)

title: G.M. Sees a Disappointing Year in Europe
description: The General Motors Corporation will find it ''very difficult'' to make a profit in Europe this year because demand is falling and the company's costs are too high, said Michael Burns, president of General Motors Europe.

title: Judging by Ideology
description: Today, for the first time in more than a decade, the Senate will begin a much needed examination of the judicial selection process. The courts subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee will examine whether ideology should play a role in the selection and confirmation of judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, FRANCES KATZ
description: DRUCKER-Frances Katz, age 85. Wife of the late Arthur Drucker of Paoli, PA, formerly of Rutherford, NJ. Survived by two sons, Paul J. Esq. and wife, Robyn Forbes Drucker of Paoli, and Dr. Henry M. and wife, Nancy Neuman Drucker of Oxford, England, three grandchildren; and one brother, Julian Katz, Elmwood, NJ. Memorial service Thursday, June 28, at Surrey Services for Seniors, 28 Bridge Ave., Berwyn, PA 19312. Burial private. Memorial gifts to Surrey Services for Seniors.

title: Article 2001062693401309774 -- No Title
Canadian Company to Buy A U.S. Miner for $2.3 Billion
description: A Canadian company is acquiring the Homestake Mining Company, one of the oldest American mining operations and owner of the legendary Homestake mine in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: Court May Review Health Insurance Case
description: The United States Supreme Court asked the Justice Department today for its views on laws that bar health care plans from setting up closed networks of doctors, pharmacies and other medical providers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, DOROTHY E.
description: CORWIN-Dorothy E. Of Amityville, L.I., NY (formerly of Massapequa) on June 24, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Roswell W. Devoted mother of Gail E., Thomas W. & Richard A. Corwin. Fond mother-in-law of Sara Jane and Bonnie. Loving grandmother of Peter, Christopher, Lynn, Kristen and Wendy. Dear great grandmother of Taylor Ann. Also survived by a niece and nephew. Family will receive friends Wednesday from 4-7:30PM at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc. 67 Broadway (Route 110), Amityville. Cremation and interment of cremains in Aquebogue Cemetery private.

title: Article 2001062691162254311 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Article 2001062690275260823 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, NAOMI RUTH (NEE GINSBURG)
description: GOLDSTEIN-Naomi Ruth (nee Ginsburg). Survived by husband, Simeon H.F. Goldstein; children Debbie (Jay) Stepelman, Seth (Jill) Goldstein and Jonathan (Mona) Goldstein and nine grandchildren. Past president, Ramat Gan (Bess Eisenstein) Chapter Emunah Women. Funeral at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing Meadow, NY. Shiva at her late home, 3801 Hudson Manor Terrace, Apt 1-O, Bronx, 718-796-0653

title: Seattle Failure Weighs on Future of New Trade Talks
description: While huge diplomatic momentum is gathering behind the idea of a new round of global trade talks, fundamental differences between rich and poor nations and the United States and its trading partners over what should be on the agenda are clouding the talks before they can begin, just as they did in Seattle in December 1999.

title: Program Puts Diabetics in Shoes That Fit
description: When Arthur Winslow, an 85-year-old man with diabetes, told a neighbor in Tamarac, Fla., that he was having trouble keeping his balance when he bent over, he was surprised by the advice he received.

title: Doctor Details Injuries Left in Jail Attack
description: A neurosurgeon testified yesterday that a guard who was stabbed in the eye last year in a federal jail in Lower Manhattan suffered severe brain damage and lost much of his ability to see and communicate. He also suffered a stroke after surgery, the doctor said, and has partial paralysis in an arm and leg.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Kathy Boucher, chief financial officer at Decker, Glastonbury, Conn., and Jay Durepo, creative director there, were both also named managing partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, JOHANNA
description: LOEB-Johanna. On June 24, 2001. Loving sister of Paul, Ernest and the late Claire Kay. Dear aunt of Susan, Diane, Jonathan, David and William, and cousin of Edward Lehman. Services on Tuesday, 9:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Accounts
description: * First Citizens Bank, Raleigh, N.C., a subsidiary of First Citizens BancShares, to McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, to handle its account, which had been at Charles Fricke & Associates, Raleigh. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Macedonia's President Fears Turmoil May Lead to Civil War
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, June 26  Tension in Macedonia's capital eased a notch today, even as the president warned how close the nation is skidding toward civil war and NATO defended its role in a mission here that propelled thousands of angry Macedonians on to the streets on Monday night.

title: Firings and Canceled Lines Tarnish a Luxury Group
description: To the glamorous mlange of film stars, models and Gucci-clad editors who regularly jet into Milan for the fashion shows, the opulent bar at the Principe Hotel is the closest thing to a throne room. It is where Bruce Willis held court after a Versace show until the dawn came up, and where, on the night of Oct. 2, 2000, Stephen L. Ruzow displayed the munificence that had made him one of the most popular figures in the fashion business.

title: At G.O.P. Primary's End, Franks Presses as Schundler Rests
description: A primary campaign for governor that has turned Republican politics upside down drew to a fittingly unpredictable close today, as Bob Franks, the favorite just 10 days ago, ricocheted through roadside diners in search of every last vote, while Bret D. Schundler, the supposed dark horse, struck a front-runner's pose by resting in his office for much of the day.

title: Excerpts From Opinions in the Copyright Infringement Case
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that publishers, by making their contents accessible through electronic databases, infringed the copyrights of freelance contributors. The vote in New York Times Company v. Tasini was 7 to 2. The majority opinion was written by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg; Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the dissent.

title: Self-Cleaning Windows to Be Sold in U.S. This Year
description: Window washing ranks high on the list of most hated household tasks, and some glass makers are hoping that this loathing runs deep.

title: Political Memo; For Torricelli, Altered Senate Heightens Attention
description: When Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont moved his desk to the other side of the aisle a few weeks ago, his embattled colleague from New Jersey, Robert G. Torricelli, suddenly seemed to become a much more important man on Capitol Hill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERTY, PETER X.
description: FINNERTY-Peter X. Retired Director of Athletics, Director of Alumni Relations and a Vice-President of Pace University, of Boonton, NJ and Delray Beach, FL, on Sunday, June 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Betty Jane (nee Trumpbour) Finnerty and the late Anne L. ''Sissy'' Finnerty. Father of Brian L. Finnerty of Boonton Twsp., NJ; Megan F. Pindyck of Wyckoff, NJ; Mary Kay Samko of Arlington, MA.; and the late Peter J. Finnerty. Also survived by eight grandchildren. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated on Wednesday, June 27th at 10:00 AM at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ with interment to follow at Laurelwood Cemetery, Stroudsburg, PA. Visitation is on Tuesday 7-9 PM at the Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Ave, Boonton, NJ. Memorial contributions to the Development Office, Pace University, 1 Pace Plaza, New York, NY 10038, would be appreciated.

title: U.S. Drops Case Over AIDS Drugs in Brazil
description: The United States unexpectedly withdrew a patent complaint against Brazil in the World Trade Organization today and agreed to settle out of court a dispute widely seen as symbolic of the debate over who may manufacture and sell drugs to treat AIDS in poor countries.

title: Martinez Rides to Rescue With Pinch-Hit Homer
description: The Yankees do not win games these days as much as they stagger to victories. With three rookies in their starting rotation, a shaky middle relief corps and a spotty offense, the Yankees rarely have the benefit of taking an early lead and handing it to their dominant late-game relievers.

title: Gambill Keeps Losing, Even on a Grass Court
description: Chris Woodruff nudged his fellow American Jan-Michael Gambill into a deeper state of despair after a five-set victory in the first round of Wimbledon today.

title: Major Delays as I-80 Workers Rush to Install a New Bridge
description: Traffic diverted from a four-mile stretch of Interstate 80 spilled onto smaller roads in several Morris County towns today, as construction crews worked to build a temporary bridge to replace the one damaged on Friday by a fiery truck crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, EDWARD A., JR., M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Edward A., Jr., M.D. Of Mt. Kisco, NY. Died peacefully June 23, 2001, after a long illness. Son of the late Edward and Lucille Friedman. Beloved husband of Sue (Richman). Loving father of Doug and Diana (Frost), James and Kendra (Boeckman), Edward III, Laurence and Judi (Landzberg). Devoted grandfather of Max and Kyle, Justin and Evan, and Spencer and Oliver. Loving brother of Enid Randall (Friedman) and wonderful son-in-law of Lucile Richman. A graduate of New York Medical College, he practiced as pediatrician and allergist in Westchester County for 40 years. On staff at Northern Westchester Hospital and Westchester County Medical Center. Proud veteran of W.W. II and the Korean War. Ed was a world traveler, an accomplished photographer, enthusiastic amateur actor, world class collector of a variety of arts and antiques including museumdisplayed 1939 World's Fair memorabilia, lifelong jazz enthusiast, witty raconteur and warm companion. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 27, at 1:30 PM at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY, 914-666-4840. Family will be receiving visitors Tuesday, June 26, 6-9 PM at Cassidy-Flynn. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Lung Association or Doctors without Borders.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Man Cleared In Cult Deaths
description: A French court has cleared a Swiss orchestra conductor of responsibility in the deaths of members of the Solar Temple doomsday cult. The prosecutors had charged that Michel Tabachnik, 58, was a cult leader, encouraging people in ritual killings and suicides that took place in France, Canada and Switzerland between 1994 and 1997. The court found there was ''insufficient evidence'' that Mr. Tabachnik, who acknowledged having written texts for the group, had deliberately helped set up the killings. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Liberty Stumbles Against Orlando
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato was right. He felt his team might be walking into a trap last night in Orlando, Fla.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Seattle Failure Weighs On Future of Trade Talks

title: The Crack of the Bat: Acoustics Takes On the Sound of Baseball
description: When a baseball is hit directly toward Melvin Mora, an outfielder for the Baltimore Orioles, he cannot immediately see whether the ball will loop over the infield and drop in front of him or sail over his head. So he listens instead.

title: Family Has Profound Effect on Dalembert
description: As Samuel Dalembert lay asleep one night last December, he dreamed of his maternal grandmother, Hyppomene Baptiste. She had reared Dalembert in Haiti and now, in his dream, he was attending her funeral.

title: Technology Briefing
description: DEALS

title: Sharon, in New York, Urges Arafat to 'Put Out Flames'
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, speaking last night in New York, demanded an end to violence by Palestinians as a condition of carrying forward peace efforts, and called on Yasir Arafat to bring a halt to attacks on Israelis.

title: U.S. Plans to Appeal Dismissal of American Airlines Lawsuit
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Justice Department announced today that it would appeal a recent Federal District Court decision to dismiss the government's predatory pricing antitrust case against American Airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC GREAL, THOMAS J.
description: MC GREAL-Thomas J., Managing Director and Research Sales Broker for Fulcrum Global Securities Partners, LLC, New York, NY, of Boonton, NJ, formerly of Mountain Lakes, NJ on Sunday, June 24, 2001. Husband of Maureen (nee O'Brien) McGreal. Father of Kelly A. McGreal-Sandulli of New Providence, NJ; Kim McGreal-DaProcida of New York, NY; Thomas J. McGreal Jr. of Tucson, AZ and Gerard McGreal of Basking Ridge, NJ. Brother of Joseph McGreal of Spring Lake Heights, NJ; Anne Birgilio of W. Islip, NY and Mary McGreal of Garden City, NY. Also survived by four grandsons. A Memorial Liturgy will be held Saturday, June 30th at 12:00 PM at St. Catherine of Siena Church, Mountain Lakes, NJ. No hours of visitation. Memorial contributions to the Center for Chest Disease, C/O Paul Simonelli, M.D., Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 161 Fort Washington Ave., New York, New York 10032 would be appreciated. For further information, contact Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Avenue, Boonton, NJ.

title: Cyclists and Walkers Regain a Bridge
description: Up on the Manhattan Bridge yesterday, high above the East River, the people did look down upon the lands and waters and big metal structures around them, and they were unanimous on two counts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOREHOUSE, BARBARA
description: MOREHOUSE-Barbara. On Sunday, June 24, at age 58, of cancer. Born on March 31, 1943, the daughter of Murray and Elizabeth Sinclaire in Short Hills, NJ, she was a resident of New York City since 1970. She graduated with honors from Fordham University, Lincoln Center. She is survived by her husband, Peter Morehouse, sisters, Mary Attig and Katharine Guyer, brother, Murray Sinclaire many nieces and nephews, and countless loving friends. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 30, at 11AM, at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ.

title: Justices Permit Immigrants To Challenge Deportations
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that immigrants who pleaded guilty to crimes in the years before stringent new provisions of federal immigration law took effect in 1996 do not face automatic deportation, as the Clinton and Bush administrations maintained, but can still seek exemptions under old rules that gave relief to more than half the people who applied.

title: Appointed To Senate, Carnahan Rides High
description: Senator Jean Carnahan says she is making out ''just fine'' in Washington as a widow and novice officeholder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSMAN, JULIAN
description: ROSMAN-Julian, on June 24. Beloved husband of Arline. Devoted father of Lisa, Robert and Deborah Rosman. Loving brother of Elaine Bender. Brother-in-law of Joan. Graveside services today, 1:30 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: AIDS: Universal Truths
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Sex Offenders' Terms
description: A State Supreme Court ruling could allow the release of more than 1,000 sex offenders from prison or parole. A sex offender who was sentenced to four years in prison and five years of parole for violating parole had sued because his parole was longer than his prison sentence. The court ruled that parole must be limited to the unserved remainder of the sentence or five years, whichever is less. The ruling affects those convicted of rape, child molestation and child pornography from 1993 to 1998. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Over the Bridge to Manhattan, for a Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Seeking More Trade With Pakistan
description: India's most influential trade body, the Confederation of Indian Industry, has asked Pakistan to reciprocate and grant most-favored-nation status to India, which would lead to more trade and investment between the countries, the group said. Business leaders have asked the government to set up a meeting with the Pakistani military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, during his visit to India next month. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Over the Bridge to Manhattan, for a Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: British Police Arrest 4 Youths in Slaying of Nigerian Boy
description: LONDON, June 26  Police today brought murder charges against four teenage boys in the killing of a 10-year-old Nigerian immigrant whose stabbing death on the stairwell of a London housing project caused national revulsion because of evidence that passersby had let him slowly bleed to death.

title: A Nigerian Musical Icon's Ideals In Brooklyn
description: ''This music is like food, and I haven't eaten in a whole month,'' said Martin C-Perna as Antibalas slipped into another thick groove on Thursday at Wetlands. Mr. C-Perna, Antibalas's baritone saxophone player and M.C., had missed several installments of the big band's ongoing party and was ready to stuff himself with sound. The food metaphor was charmingly obvious, but no more so than Antibalas's revitalization of the term ''world beat,'' which is obvious in the most invigorating way.

title: C.D.C. Plays Script Doctor to Spread Its Message
description: On the eve of Valentine's Day 1999, the characters on ''Beverly Hills 90210'' were in their usual tizzy. Donna discovered pictures of Noah and Gina kissing. Dylan, having sworn off heroin, cavorted with Gina. After Steve bragged about his flawless tan, his girlfriend noticed a strange mole on the back of his neck. Fearing skin cancer, he took a megaphone to the beach to shout out the benefits of sunscreen.

title: Weighing Drugs' Benefits
description: To The Editor:

title: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Turkey Under Fire
description: The European Union, which is considering Turkey's application to join, criticized the banning of the country's main opposition party and urged political reforms. The union said the decision of Turkey's Constitutional Court to outlaw the pro-Islamic Virtue Party was reason for concern and ''has implications for democratic pluralism and freedom of expression.'' Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Rulings on Funding and Fairness
description: The Supreme Court issued two important decisions yesterday. It moved to preserve the integrity of federal campaign contribution limits, and in so doing gave fresh impetus to legislation before the House that requires a broader ban on so-called ''soft money'' contributions to political parties. It also agreed to remedy an obvious inequity in the nation's treatment of immigrants.

title: Observing the Behavior of Apes, Up Close
description: On a recent morning, Dr. Frans de Waal, a leading expert on the social behavior of apes and director of the Living Links Center of the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center of Emory University in Atlanta, was nursing a cup of coffee during an interview in Manhattan.

title: Equal-Opportunity Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: To End Deadlock, Large TV Networks Cut Rates
description: In the stalemate between Broadcast Row and Madison Avenue, most of the TV folks are blinking.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Protest Over Redistricting
description: In a fight over redistricting, Democrats in the state House refused to meet until the Republicans who control the chamber back off on an effort to bypass the state's Democratic governor. Lawmakers have adopted a Republican-backed redistricting bill that the governor, John Kitzhaber, left, has threatened to veto, but Republicans are now trying to change the plan into a resolution, which would not need the governor's signature. The House minority leader, Dan Gardner of Portland, called the move an unconstitutional outrage. But Republicans also cried foul: If there is no plan at all, the task of redrawing legislative districts could fall to the secretary of state, who is a Democrat. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the violence between government security forces and ethnic Albanian rebels in Macedonia misstated the sites occupied by the rebels. The rebels had occupied a village near Macedonia's capital, Skopje, that is near the city's airport and Macedonia's only oil refinery. They did not occupy the airport or the refinery.

title: The Moment of Truth Approaches
description: Three New York-area underclassmen - Samuel Dalembert, Omar Cook and Eddie Griffin - have entered tomorrow's N.B.A. draft. They are projected as first-round selections. By RAFAEL HERMOSO

title: Dentsu Group Buys Oasis in New York
description: The Dentsu Business Development Group in New York, part of the giant Japanese agency company Dentsu, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Oasis Advertising in New York, an agency that formed a nonequity alliance with Dentsu last year. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pope Visits Babi Yar Site Commemorating Slain Jews
description: With Ukraine's chief rabbi at his side, Pope John Paul II stood silently today before a stark stone sculpture commemorating Jews and others killed by the Nazis at Babi Yar and then quietly recited ''De Profundis,'' a Latin prayer for the dead.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Man Pleads In Arms Case
description: A Jersey City man arrested in a sting operation this month pleaded not guilty yesterday in West Palm Beach, Fla., to attempted exportation of illegal arms and money laundering. Diaa Mohsen and another man, Mohammed Malik, also of Jersey City, were charged last week with attempting to violate the federal Arms Export Control Act after they allegedly discussed the purchase of missiles and machine guns with an undercover agent and an informant. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Campaign Law Upheld
description: The Supreme Court upheld limits on how much political parties can spend in coordination with candidates, delighting advocates of a broader ban, now before Congress.

title: Dictators in the Dock
description: Some once-powerful dictators and strongmen are finding the world an increasingly inhospitable refuge. Vladimiro Montesinos, Peru's shadowy former intelligence chief who was hiding in Venezuela, has now been led from a plane in handcuffs in Lima to face charges of murder, torture, extortion and trafficking in arms and drugs. Yugoslavia has initiated a legal process to send Slobodan Milosevic, its former president, to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, where he will probably land next month. Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile may escape trial on charges of covering up dozens of murders and forced disappearances on the grounds that he is mentally unfit. But after his arrest in London in 1998 and his indictment in Chile, he is a discredited, ridiculed, broken man.

title: Critic's Notebook: Honk if You've Seen These Online Films; BMW Hopes That Its Mini-Movies by Master Filmmakers Will Sell Cars
description: It might not be safe to say there are countless Web sites devoted to showing short films, but I wouldn't want to be the one charged with tallying them. Yet of all the shorts designed to give filmmakers a chance to show their stuff, none are quite as puzzling as ''The Hire,'' the series of mini-dramas commissioned by BMW and currently running on bmwfilms.com.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Request For Rehearing Denied
description: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rejected an appeal by the Internet music service Napster yesterday to have its copyright infringement case reheard by a full panel of the court. In rejecting Napster's plea, the court let stand a ruling that a three-judge panel of the court issued in February. That ruling in turn reinforced much of the legal reasoning reached by Judge Marilyn Patel of Federal District Court, who found in July 2000 that Napster had aided in copyright infringement, and issued a preliminary injunction. Yesterday's decision clears the way for the case to go back to Judge Patel for a trial, though no date for a trial has been set. Separately, the Recording Industry Association of America, which originally sued Napster on behalf of the record labels, late yesterday filed an appeal with the Ninth Circuit. It sought to overturn Judge Patel's injunction requiring the labels to provide file names of all copyrighted works before Napster would have to remove them. And the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences sued Napster yesterday, contending that copyrighted live Oscar show performances were available on the service. The academy's suit seeks monetary damages and a court order to stop the swaps. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Killed In Fall
description: A 26-year-old laborer died yesterday afternoon when he tumbled into an elevator shaft from the third floor of a Clinton Hill warehouse, landing on the roof of the elevator, which was on the first floor, the police said. The victim, Roger Alonzo, was pulling a handtruck as he backed into the open elevator doorway, unaware that the elevator was not there, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Basses in Force, a Tribute to Milt Hinton
description: Bass players crowded the altar and the chancel on Sunday at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights for a memorial service for the jazz musician Milt Hinton, one of the most recorded bass players in the history of popular music. Mr. Hinton, known to musicians as the Judge, was a pioneering figure: he recorded the first big-band bass solo while playing with Cab Calloway and was a leader in the drive to integrate television studio bands in the 1950's.

title: Bush Asks Mayors to Lobby For Faith-Based Social Aid
description: With his plan to expand government financing of religious groups' charitable work in trouble in Congress, President Bush sought today to reassure critics that the money ''will be spent on social services, not worship services.''

title: The Lori Berenson Case
description: To the Editor:

title: California and Energy Providers in Talks Over Electric Fees
description: For the first time since the end of the Clinton administration, California and the companies that sell it electricity sat at the same table today to try to resolve a multibillion-dollar feud over the state's energy bills.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Crash Survivor Arraigned
description: One of two men suspected of drag-racing along a busy street in Oceanside was arraigned yesterday in First District Court here after a crash on Sunday that killed the other suspected racer and the driver of a third, uninvolved, car. The arrested driver, Kevin Hart, 27, of Malverne, was charged with two counts of second-degree manslaughter. The other drag racer, Michael Vasapolli, 30, of North Woodmere, died when his Lamborghini crashed head on into a Volvo driven by Glenn Jacofsky, 43, of Oceanside, the other victim. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Critics Want Adjusted Data From Census Made Public
description: Three months after the Census Bureau decided against adjusting the 2000 population tally for the purposes of drawing Congressional and other legislative districts, civil rights groups, big-city mayors and Congressional Democrats are accusing the agency of suppressing data that formed the basis of the bureau's decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOU, KOU LIANG
description: LOU-Kou Liang. On June 23. Born in Kunming, China, 1918. Loving husband of Tai Yeong. Devoted father of Margaret, Mimi, William, daughter-in-law Debra and sonsin-law Steve and Andris. Grandfather of Jamie, Weston, Teo, Mia, Lukas, Nick and Maggie. He will be greatly missed by all of us. Services on Friday, June 29 at 12 noon at Frank A. Patti Funeral Home, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee NJ (201) 944-0100. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to CAN (Cure Autism Now) Foundation, 5455 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 715, Los Angeles, CA. 90036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTT, WENDY LUCKETT
description: BOTT-Wendy Luckett, 38. Writer and filmmaker died June 12, 2001 in Los Angeles. Born in Alexandria, Virginia, raised in the Chicago area, at an early age Wendy developed an interest in comedy and filmmaking. Immediately after graduating from the Boston University School of Film and Communications pursued what was to become a life long interest. She just completed the co-writing, directing and producing of her first full length film. ''Robbies' Brother''. She is survived by her parents Jane and Joe Hanauer, father, John Bon, brother Jason Bott, sisters Elizabeth Hanauer, Jill Hanauer-Hunter and Liza Bott. Memorial services will be at 1:00 P.M., Wednesday, June 27, 2001 at Pacific View Mortuary Chapel, 3500 Pacific View Drive, Corona del Mar, CA.

title: An Easeful Dance Into the Arms of a Forbidding Partner
description: No specific person is mentioned in the title of Jerome Robbins's ''In Memory Of. . . .'' Theatergoers, if they wish, are free to insert the name of anyone dear to them into their experience of this touching ballet, which shows an innocent young woman dancing with an earthly lover until she is led by a death figure into a heavenly realm.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mcdonald's Offer
description: McDonald's Japan said it would list its shares on the Japanese over-the-counter market on July 26. The initial public offering of the McDonald's Corporation's unit, which operates in the second-largest hamburger market outside the United States, is billed as the largest share offering ever on the over-the-counter market in Japan and is expected to raise tens of billions of yen by selling 26.2 million shares, 12 million of them new and 14.2 million already existing. McDonald's Japan operates about 3,600 hamburger outlets and had sales of more than 431 billion yen ($3.47 billion) last year. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: A New Warning for Male Smokers
description: Anti-tobacco groups, frustrated that warnings about cancer and heart disease do not always accomplish their goals, have been trying another tactic lately: advertisements that link smoking with impotence, complete with cigarettes that droop ominously when young women walk by.

title: It's Too Early for 2004
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberal Radio Mainstay May Sell to Make Way for ESPN
description: The trouble began five months ago. That is when the rumors began to surface that the venerable WEVD radio station was going to be sold and then turned into an ESPN sports station.

title: Japan's Ultimate Insider: The Premier's Secretary
description: Prime Minister Jun ichiro Koizumi is slight and dapper. His secretary, Isao Iijima, is rotund and rumpled.

title: 'Intelligent Dance Music' More Zany Than It Sounds
description: Computers aren't known for their sense of humor, and neither are the people who work most closely with them. But Tom Jenkinson, who makes music as Squarepusher, uses his software and hardware to do for musical slapstick what the internal combustion engine did for travel: speeding it up until it pushes the limits of human reflexes.

title: Stocks End Day Mixed After Climbing Back From Morning Slide
description: The stock market climbed back from a sharp slide today, with modest gains in the technology sector and modest losses elsewhere, as the Federal Reserve considered its next move on interest rates and investors wondered whether another rate cut would produce lasting results.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Deliveryman Trial To Proceed
description: Lawyers for two teenagers accused of killing a Chinese deliveryman argued yesterday that the teenagers' confessions should not be introduced as evidence in their trial. But the judge, Justice Robert J. Hanophy of State Supreme Court in Queens, rejected their argument. The teenagers, Darryl Tyson, 19, and Robert Savage, 15, are accused of fatally bludgeoning Jin-Sheng Liu, 44, with a brick last year. Monte Williams (NYT)

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From testdriving convertibles to tvs for minivans, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: John Cannon, 74; Led Academy of TV Arts
description: John Cannon, president of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, died on Friday in Cologne, Germany. He was 74.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Transfer In Gay Killing
description: A judge ruled yesterday that Ronald Crumpley, who killed two men and wounded six outside a Manhattan gay bar in 1980, is still dangerous and mentally ill and should not be permitted to leave a secure psychiatric hospital for a less restrictive facility. The decision, by Justice Jose A. Padilla Jr. of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, ended Mr. Crumpley's second unsuccessful application to be released. The judge noted that while Mr. Crumpley no longer believed that gay men are ''agents of the devil,'' he still likened them to stalkers. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocery Venture
description: Safeway of the United States said it had formed a partnership with Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, to revamp its online shopping operation. The venture, called GroceryWorks, said it raised $35 million in cash and other assets, including $22 million from Tesco, which will control 35 percent of the voting shares. GroceryWorks will adopt some of Tesco's online methods, including delivering from stores rather than from warehouses. Tesco said its online service was profitable in Britain, with a million customers and about $420 million in annual sales. The companies plan to start delivering groceries later this year in Texas or California. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, JOSEPH
description: HOCHMAN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Joyce; loving father of David and Susan, Seth and Diane and Rise; cherished grandfather. Private graveside service. Donations to Reconstructionist Congregation Beth Emeth, 36 Franklin Avenue, Hewlett, New York 11557, would be appreciated.

title: Wizards Close to Selecting Georgia High School Star
description: On his way to New York yesterday, Arn Tellem took a detour. Tellem, the Los Angeles-based agent for the high school players Kwame Brown and Eddy Curry and the Seton Hall freshman Eddie Griffin, met with Michael Jordan, the Washington Wizards' president, and Doug Collins, their coach, said a person who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: Childs Play at the N.B.A. Draft
description: For the first time in league history, a high school player is expected to be taken No. 1. Here is a forecast of the lottery picks in the N.B.A. draft. Ages of players appear in parentheses.

title: Trivia Question: 50 in 1977
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, MARIE G.
description: SCOTT-Marie G. On June 23, 2001. Loving daughter of the late Frances (nee Loveless) and Benjamin A. Scott. Dear sister of the late Gladys White and Dorothy Stock. Fond aunt of Nancy Anderson, Bette Geraci, Jeanne Groody, Linda Signorini, Roy and Wayne Stock. Reposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave., Richmond Hill. Visitation Thursday, from 11:30 AM. Service 1 PM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS EXTENDS OFFER FOR NEWPORT NEWS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation extended a $2.6 billion cash offer for Newport News Shipbuilding to July 6 because federal antitrust regulators requested more information on the proposal. The $67.50-a-share offer for Newport News expired Friday. About 20.2 million, or 68 percent, of the Newport News shares had been tendered, General Dynamics said. General Dynamics, which is based in Falls Church, Va., and owns the Bath Iron Works and Electric Boat naval shipyards, and a rival, the Northrop Grumman Corporation, based in Los Angeles, are vying for Newport News, the only remaining independent naval shipbuilder. Newport News, based in the Virginia city of the same name, said it supported the bid from General Dynamics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, EVELYN (KIKI)
description: KAPLAN-Evelyn (Kiki). On June 23, 2001, at age 76. Beloved wife of Morris. Loving mother of Lois and Steve Panikoff and Jay and Roseanne Kaplan. Adoring grandmother of Sherri, Toni and Jonathan. Dear sister of Louis Goodman. Interment private.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas dropped on expectations that mild weather will reduce demand for the fuel. In New York, natural gas for July delivery fell 29.6 cents, or 7.9 percent, to $3.446 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Retailer Slides
description: Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer Ltd., warned for the second time since February that weak department store sales would hurt earnings this year. Coles Myer's stock price fell 14.6 percent, to 6.11 Australian dollars ($3.16). The chief executive, Dennis Eck, predicted profit would slide as much as 15 percent this year below his earlier forecast of 400 million Australian dollars ($207 million). Sales in general merchandise and apparel have been particularly sluggish. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: National Team Cuts Friedel
description: Clearly disappointed over not playing against Trinidad and Tobago in the World Cup qualifying victory last week in Foxboro, Mass., United States goalkeeper BRAD FRIEDEL stood next to the team bus and said, ''Everybody tells me I will play in Mexico.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILMAN, CARL E.
description: HEILMAN-Carl E. died on May 23, 2001, in Gibsonia, PA at the age of ninety. Mr. Heilman worked as an attorney from 1939 through 1989, serving until 1973 as a partner in the New York firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Busby, Palmer & Wood, and serving thereafter as special counsel to the firm of Csaplar & Bok in Boston. Also a Fellow of the American Bar Foundation. He is survived by his wife Marie, and two children, John Heilman & Elizabeth Costello, one brother & a sister. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society. For further information, contact Schellhaas Funeral Home, Ltd. at 1-724-443-1505.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, JOHN T.
description: CANNON-John T. Suddenly in Germany on June 22, 2001. President of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. Grand Commandeur of La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. Beloved husband of Gertrude, dear father of Connie. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd corner Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, New York, Thursday, June 28th, at 11 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Diplomat Scofflaws Listed
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday began posting on the Internet the names of diplomats who do not pay their city parking tickets. Under diplomatic immunity, such officials cannot be punished for a number of offenses, including parking tickets. The department's Web site -- http://www.nyc .gov/html/dof/html/pvo25.html -- lists the 25 worst offenders. Egypt heads the list, with 15,924 unpaid parking tickets totaling more than $1.6 billion. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: A Gluttonous Guest Flutters to East Hampton Beach
description: In the woods just north of Main Street billions of hairy invaders are stealing the season, one leaf at a time.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Weakness
description: Shares of Granada Media and Carlton Communications, which control Britain's Independent Television Network, declined amid a weakening market for advertising sales. Granada wants to merge with Carlton Communications to compete better in the increasingly cutthroat television market, but current regulations in Britain prohibit further consolidation among existing players. Charles Allen, Granada's chairman, in a letter written last week to Prime Minister Tony Blair, urged the government to address the issue of media deregulation during the next legislative session, people close to the companies said. (Suzanne Kapner)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Winner Is . . .

title: Contraceptive Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; This Straphanger Rode With Class
description: First, a quick subway history refresher: August Belmont Jr. -- banker, bon vivant, breeder of the famous thoroughbred Man o' War -- was the man who put up the private money to build the city's first subway line, the IRT, from City Hall to 145th Street.

title: NRG ENERGY BUYS 2 NORTHEAST PLANTS FROM CONECTIV
description: NRG Energy Inc., a Minneapolis-based power producer, bought two power plants and stakes in two others in the Northeast from Conectiv Inc. for $630 million. The acquired plants in Delaware, Maryland and Pennsylvania can produce 1,081 megawatts, enough power to light more than one million average homes. NRG expects New Jersey regulators to approve the purchase of another 794 megawatts in Pennsylvania and New Jersey from Conectiv, owner of utilities in four Eastern states, in the third quarter, an NRG spokeswoman, Meredith Moore, said. NRG agreed to buy the combined 1,875 megawatts of oil-, coal- and natural gas-fired generation from Conectiv early last year for $800 million to increase Northeast power sales. Conectiv, based in Wilmington, Del., said the sale would result in a second-quarter gain of $170 million to $175 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAGER, ELEANOR (ELLY)
description: SCHRAGER-Eleanor (Elly). On June 24th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence (Larry). Loving and devoted mother to Steven. Dear Nana to Gregory and Brett. Loving sister of Henrietta (Henny) Davis. Funeral services Wednesday, 2 PM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Senators and Clergy Are at Odds In Poultry Industry Wage Dispute
description: In an unusual clash, 16 United States senators are at loggerheads with 18 bishops from various denominations because of a Labor Department enforcement action that could cost the poultry industry nearly $350 million in back wages.

title: A Home for Theatrical Innovation Rises in Movieland
description: The California Institute of the Arts has long prided itself on being a congenial home for experimental theater, so it was no surprise that Richard Foreman, the avant-garde New York dramatist, accepted an invitation last year to come to the campus, where he created with students a suitably complex new work, ''Bad Behavior.''

title: Article 2001062693987105425 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Routine Analysis May Detect Heart Risk
description: A simple urine test may be able to identify postmenopausal women who have an increased risk of heart disease, researchers reported yesterday.

title: The Return of Sammy the Bull
description: Salvatore Gravano achieved notoriety a decade ago as the high-level Mafia turncoat who brought his boss, John Gotti, down. Judge Leo Glasser, who put Mr. Gotti away for life and jailed Mr. Gravano for just five years despite his admission to 19 murders, wrote at the time, ''There has never been a defendant of his stature in organized crime who has made the leap he has made from one social planet to another.'' Now comes the disquieting news that Mr. Gravano, known as Sammy the bull, soon enough leaped back again, opting out of the federal witness protection program and returning to a life of crime. Sammy the bull's recent guilty plea to federal drug-running charges provides a cautionary tale about the murky trade-offs and hazardous deals that are inherent in the government's war against organized crime.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the E-Commerce Report in Business Day yesterday about Web sites that help former classmates find one another misstated the graduation date of a couple who recently married after becoming reacquainted through Classmates.com. Todd and Candi Emerson of Renton, Wash., graduated from the same high school in 1985, not in the 1970's.

title: Lacking Pensions, Older Divorced Women Remain at Work
description: Hundreds of thousands of women in their 60's, part of the surge of divorces that started a generation ago, are finding themselves forced to stay in the work force because they lack sufficient money to retire. Wages in effect are becoming their pensions.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Sunquest Soars On Bid From British Company
description: Shares of Sunquest Information Systems, a health care computer company, rose as much as 61 percent after a Britsh company, Misys, agreed to buy it for $404 million in cash, or about $24 a share. Sunquest stock rose $8.98, to $23.72, in trading of 1.7 million shares, 76 times its three-month daily trading average. Misys, Britain's largest financial software maker, rose as much as 16 pence, or 3.3 percent, to 501 pence in London. Misys, which makes almost a quarter of its revenue providing computer services to health care facilities, is increasing its focus on the United States and says it expects demand to pick up as hospitals and health care facilities invest in electronic methods to process claims and patient bills to reduce costs. Sunquest, based in Tucson, develops and maintains computer systems for hospitals, laboratories and other health facilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military and fraternal organizations. Visitation Tuesday between 4-8PM at the Alexander Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 W. 12 St. Funeral service will be held 5:30PM Wednesday, June 27, 2001 at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. Private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011.

title: Duracell Is Starting Coppertop Campaign
description: The battery battle is flaring up as Duracell begins a campaign this week to reintroduce its basic product under the Coppertop name. The campaign, including the first television advertising in four years for the basic brand, has a worldwide budget estimated at $100 million.

title: The Autoimmune Snare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMPSON, MARJORIE MCPADDEN
description: SYMPSON-Marjorie McPadden. On Monday, June 18, 2001, the beloved wife of Capt. William G.A. Sympson II USN (Ret.), dearest mother of Sheilah S. Watanabe, Cdr. William G.A. Sympson III USN, Maj. Thomas S. Sympson USA, Sean M. Sympson, and the late John W. Sympson, devoted niece of Julia C. Gilsenan, and grandmother of six. For family and friends a memorial mass will be held Friday, June 29, at 11 AM, at the Church of St. Mary, Roslyn, NY. The family will receive relatives and friends Sunday, July 1, from 2 to 5 PM and 7 to 9 PM at Murphy Funeral Home, 4510 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, VA. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, July 2nd, at 2 PM, in the Old Post Chapel, Fort Myer, VA, followed by interment in Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Mother Theresa's Order (Missionaries of Charity, 335 E. 145th St., Bronx, NY 10451), or the Church of St. Mary's Memorial Fund (110 Bryant Avenue, Roslyn, NY 11576).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, TOBY (NEE MILBERG)
description: WOLFSON-Toby (nee Milberg) of Tenalfy, NJ on June 25, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Theodore, cherished daughter of the late Irving and Selma Milberg, devoted mother of Steven Wolfson and Susan Wolfson, dear sister of Morton Milberg and the late Alan Milberg, loving grandmother of Samantha, Ilana and David. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack NJ on Wednesday, June 27 at 12:30PM. The period of mourning will be observed at the late residence. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to JCC on the Palisades to benefit Alzheimers patients or The Lighthouse for the Blind, Park Ave, New York, NY.

title: New Peru President Won't Enter Berenson Case
description: President-elect Alejandro Toledo of Peru said yesterday in New York that he would not interfere with a court decision last week that sentenced Lori H. Berenson to 20 years in prison for collaborating with Marxist rebels in a terrorist plot. Ms. Berenson, an ex-New Yorker, has served more than five years in Peruvian prisons.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Women's Health section on Sunday about an emergency room nurse at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan misstated the number of nursing schools in the United States. There are about 1,600, not 76, according to the American Association of Colleges of Nursing. (The smaller number refers to hospitals with diploma programs in nursing.)

title: New Marketing Push Is Scheduled for the Breeders' Cup
description: The National Thoroughbred Racing Association will announce today what it believes is a clearer name for what is considered the sport's premier event: a single day of eight races held each fall that attract the finest horses in the world to compete for a combined $13 million in purses. What was formerly called the Breeders' Cup Championship is now the Breeders' Cup World Thoroughbred Championships.

title: Portrait of the Artist as a Giant Spider's Daughter
description: ZE spi-DAIRE, you see, is a metaphor for my moth-AIRE,'' the artist Louise Bourgeois declared in an impressive French accent apparently untouched by 63 years of living in New York City. ''It is an ode to my moth-AIRE.''

title: Article 2001062691138444993 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: Shield Is Sought for Employers Under Patients' Bill of Rights
description: The Senate began a second week of debate today on a far-reaching bill to define patients' rights, with Democrats looking for some way to limit the liability of employers who might be sued by employees in disputes over health care benefits.

title: Job to Raytheon Venture
description: The Raytheon Technical Service Company, a unit of the Raytheon Company and JT3 L.L.C., in a joint venture with JT3 EG&G Technical Services Inc., received an Air Force contract valued at up to $1.7 billion.

title: Designed for Other Worlds, Robot Is to Follow the Sun
description: In the Arctic, every living thing craves the fleeting rays of sunshine during the short summer. Next month, a robot will traverse a cold, rocky wasteland in the far North driven by its own determination to bask in the sun.

title: Stenographer Investigated in Leaks to the Mob
description: The United States attorney's office in Manhattan stopped using a stenographic reporter last year after investigators began to suspect that the reporter was leaking sensitive information about organized-crime investigations to mobsters, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Coltish and Full of Gaiety In Free Waves of Speed
description: American Ballet Theater's ''Tchaikovsky Spectacular'' is a feast of dancers. They rose to the occasion on Friday night and particularly Saturday afternoon in the next to last performances of the company's summer season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JAMES J.
description: QUINN-James J. on June 25, 2001 of Garden City. Beloved husband of Cecilia. Loving father of Maureen, Matthew, Eileen, Patricia and the late Catherine. Cherished grandfather of Samantha, Emily, Erin and Spencer. Dear brother of Ellen, John and Kathleen. Retired in 1993 as Executive Committee Vice Chairman, Accounting and SEC, for Coopers and Lybrand, International Executive Committee. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave.,at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 & 7-9PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 10 AM Thursday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Stealth Jet Seeks Role
description: Four years after the Northrop Grumman Corporation stopped producing B-2 bombers because Congress had balked at their $2.2-billion-apiece price, supporters of the stealth jet are hoping for a revival of the program.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Memo From Osama
description: Memo From: Osama bin Laden

title: Publishers Set To Remove Older Articles From Files
description: Newspaper and magazine publishers, reacting to the Supreme Court's ruling that freelance writers retain some rights to the electronic use of their previously published work, began preparing yesterday to cull thousands of articles from Lexis-Nexis and other online databases while positioning themselves for the next round in the battle with writers' groups.

title: Violent Killing by Youths Leaves a City Dazed
description: To hear people here tell it, there is trouble every year on the final day of high school classes as rowdy students spill into the streets. But last week the annual ritual turned deadly, and today, this worn-down city was still struggling to comprehend why, according to the police, a mob of students had fatally stomped and beaten a homeless man.

title: Congressman's Silence Tests District's Loyalty
description: The flier taped prominently in the window of Representative Gary A. Condit's district office here features a now-familiar photograph of a young woman with dark curly hair and a fetching smile. ''MISSING,'' it blares.

title: On the Track of Venus
description: Q. I have been told that the Maya made precise measurements of Venus. What did they learn?

title: Metro Business Briefing | Teaming Up On Instant Messaging
description: Two New York instant-messaging companies, Odigo Inc. and ActiveBuddy Inc., said yesterday that they would form a partnership. Odigo had been at the forefront of a clash with AOL Time Warner, whose popular instant-messaging program dominates the market but does not allow those with other instant-messaging programs to communicate with its users. ActiveBuddy produces software that answers instant-message users' questions, like what the stock price is for a certain company. Odigo produces an instant-messaging program, and the partnership will allow them to package their software and market them to corporate clients. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Cigarette-Rack Bill Advances
description: The Legislature yesterday completed passage of a bill banning self-service racks that display cigarettes, and Gov. George E. Pataki's office said he would sign it into law. Self-service racks allow customers to take packs of cigarettes on their own. Under the ban, customers will have to ask store clerks to get packs for them. Antismoking groups said the self-service racks made it easy for people under 18 to steal cigarettes. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Latino Pastors Endorse Ferrer for Mayor
description: Taking their cue from the role that black churches have played in past elections for African-American candidates, a group of Hispanic evangelical leaders announced yesterday that they were endorsing the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, for mayor of New York City.

title: For Israeli Defense Chief, No Choice but Optimism
description: Sitting in his small, spare office at Parliament, Defense Minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer looked today like a man with a headache. He pinched the bridge of his nose, and talked about his job as he saw it: preventing suicide bombings, mortar launchings, arms smuggling.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro rose as reports of slowing German inflation fueled speculation the European Central Bank would lower interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 85.95 cents, up from 85.62 cents on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEIS, BERNARD AND DARLENE
description: GEIS-Bernard and Darlene. Old friends, come celebrate their memory, Tuesday, June 26, 5:30 PM, Mark Hotel, 25 E 77th at Madison

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ACTV, New York, which offers interactive television and Internet services, named David Reese, president, to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds William C. Samuels, who continues as chairman.

title: Search Is Down to 2, Maybe, at Bronx Science
description: Months after Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy suggested that his alma mater, the Bronx High School of Science, deserved a principal with a national reputation, the search for a new principal has narrowed to two veterans of the New York City school system, officials said yesterday.

title: It's Too Early for 2004
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcoming Sharon, But Not Arafat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIE, BERNARD
description: SOBIE-Bernard. On June 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Estelle. Dear and devoted father of Michele, Brian and Ruth. Adoring grandfather of Ana-Nicole and Zachary. Dear brother of Minna Karen. We will all miss you. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Hazelden Foundation, 233 East 17 Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: A 'Cloak' of Darkness Brightened by Flashlight
description: Seeking to create an alternative forum for opera, the small company Operaworks, in a living-room-size space on the Upper West Side, has sparked a bit of debate since its inception in 1982. But this is less because of its repertory of less-known works than its accompaniments. In what the group calls ''virtual opera,'' the scores are played by a recorded synthesized orchestra, while the music director, David Leighton, solemnly conducts the singers with a pocket flashlight.

title: J. J. Chisolm, 79, Dies; Lead-Poison Crusader
description: Dr. J. Julian Chisolm Jr., whose crusade against lead poisoning led to innovative ways to treat the condition, died on Wednesday in a retirement community in Baltimore. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSINA, MARTINA DIANE
description: MESSINA-Martina Diane. Born on March 23, 1936 in Brooklyn, NY to Frank Martin Messina and Alice Pennner Messina. Martina Diane Messina died very peacefully on June 23rd at 6:10 AM, surrounded by her family and the love of her friends. There will me a Mass at St. Theresa's Parish, Hyde Park, VT, at 11:00 AM, Thursday, June 28th and a brief outdoor ceremony at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Hackensack, NJ, Saturday, June 30th. Please call 505-474-6430 for the time of the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXEL, ELAINE
description: AXEL-Elaine. Beloved wife of Kermit Axel; loving mother of Jane Bobrick, Blair Axel and Carol Axel; adored sister of Muriel Poliakoff and Louise Miller; motherin-law to Hon. Edward Bobrick, Elisabeth Axel & Joseph Weiner; devoted grandmother of Benjamin, Rachel, Nathaniel, Matthew, Sara, Kermit and Gemma. After a lifetime of giving to others, she died peacefully Sunday afternoon with her family around her. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, today at 11:30 AM.

title: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Step In Killing Deal For Honeywell
description: A draft decision to block the proposed acquisition of Honeywell International by General Electric was endorsed today by a panel of European regulators.
