title: A Journey Through A Woman's Whole Life
description: Sin Cha Hong has become known for her dark, spare dance journeys into the soul. In Ms. Hong's masterly and poignant new ''Woman Laughing,'' this 60-year-old Korean choreographer and performer travels through her own life. Not only does this trip end in laughter, but Ms. Hong is newly mellow company as well.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Jeffords's Wife Speaks Out
description: Among all the reasons that Senator James M. Jeffords defected from the Republican Party last month, his liberal-leaning wife was not one of them. In her first public comments on the matter, the senator's wife, Liz Daley, told The Rutland Herald and Barre Montpelier Times Argus that she angrily opposed the move at first. ''I thought, 'Oh, my God, Jimmy Jeffords is going to hurt a lot of people that I care a lot about,' '' Ms. Jeffords said. But ultimately, she said, she supported her husband's decision. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Woods Going Fishing For His Mechanics
description: MINUTES after Tiger Woods shot an ordinary par 71 yesterday to finish in an ordinary tie for 16th in the Buick Classic, he was asked what he planned to do to return to his usual extraordinary groove for next month's British Open.

title: U.S. Team Has a Lot of Stars, and a Lot of Holes
description: When the world track and field championships are held from Aug. 3 to 12 in Edmonton, Alberta, the United States will be represented by a team of deceptive quality. It may win more gold medals than it did in the 2000 Sydney Olympics (10), or in the 1999 world championships in Seville, Spain (11), but it lacks depth in many events.

title: Secret Agent Men
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, CHARLOTTE R.
description: PRATT-Charlotte R. It is with deep sadness that The Board of Directors and Staff of Citizens' Committee For Children of New York mourn the passing of Charlotte R. Pratt, longtime Board Member and partner in making New York City a better place for children. Charlotte was a Board Member since 1953; served as Secretary of The Board from 1955 to 1994; and became an Honorary Director in 1994. Charlotte's intelligence, spirit and compassion for children will be greatly missed. Nancy Solomon, Chairman Nancy Locker, President Gail Nayowith, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREUND, LUCAS SAMUEL
description: FREUND-Lucas Samuel. ''A fragment of what you felt, of what you knew, A formula, a phrase remains,-but the best is lost.'' We love you. Mom, Dad and Charlotte

title: The 4-Letter-Word Patrol Is in Pursuit
description: Several years ago, Carl Jaskolski and a few employees he supervised at a Milwaukee social services agency put a quarter into a ''cussing jar'' every time they swore. His weekly contribution averaged $3.

title: With Jobs Plentiful, Latest Immigrants Have Found It Easier to Fit In
description: Illegal immigrants got most of the headlines in the 1990's, but they were only a small percentage of the immigration wave that poured into the country over that decade. In fact, recent census figures confirmed what many people already knew -- legal immigrants have become the biggest source of growth in the population and, not surprisingly, in the labor force.

title: In Fighting AIDS, We Cannot Delay
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hong Kong Flight Ending
description: United Airlines plans to discontinue its nonstop flight between Kennedy International Airport and Hong Kong at the end of August, citing disappointing booking levels. The decision by the airline's parent company, the UAL Corporation of Chicago, comes less than a year after it launched the longest nonstop passenger flight between New York and Hong Kong. The carrier will fly its last flight from New York to Hong Kong on Aug. 29; the final flight in the other direction will depart the next day.

title: Geoffrey Zakarian
description: CONFIT is not something that comes to mind for summer. Usually it means duck confit, made by cooking the legs and thighs in duck fat to preserve them for winter. At least that's what French housewives used to do. It's very rich, and just what you want when the weather is freezing.

title: Assembly Approves Program to Clean Up Polluted Lands
description: The Assembly approved a program today to clean up polluted industrial lands known as brownfields, the first movement in months on a long-stalemated issue that the governor and lawmakers call one of the year's top priorities.

title: New Dress Code Takes Shape
description: LONDON  Dressing down is dead. Welcome to the third way of business attire. With dot-boom turned to dot-bust, the deregulated business uniform of chinos and sports shirts has lost its appeal, and men are frantically looking for a new set of rules to help them dress appropriately for their business dealings.

title: King Loses Distributor For Beijing Fight Card
description: The announcement was to be made with all the pomp and grandiosity that Don King, the boxing promoter, has turned into his trademark. There were supposed to be Chinese dragon dancers winding their way through Radio City Music Hall yesterday. There were supposed to be world champion heavyweights holding court. And there was supposed to be King himself, telling reporters about a pay-per-view deal he had worked out for the heavyweight bout in Beijing that he is promoting.

title: Executive Coaches Bridge the Gaps in Australia
description: John McGrath, chief executive of McGrath Estate Agents, a large residential real estate company in Australia, found himself in a bind several years ago. The business he had founded was undergoing explosive growth, but he had never taken a business course or held any other management job, and he was not sure if he knew how to handle it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Guilty Plea In Sex Case
description: A former assistant superintendent in the Brewster Central School District has pleaded guilty to exchanging sexually explicit e-mail messages with a person he thought was a 14-year-old boy, said Jeanine Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, on Monday. The man, Stephen Graeber, 55, of Brookfield, Conn., was the 36th person convicted in Ms. Pirro's Internet operation in which undercover investigators pose as minors. Mr. Graeber, who was convicted Friday of attempted dissemination of indecent material to minors, faces a maximum of four years in prison. He is to be sentenced Sept. 21. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Paper Ballots Avoided
description: The Assembly passed a bill yesterday to keep New York City from being forced to conduct its Sept. 11 primary election on paper ballots. Earlier this year, the city was ordered by the courts to provide a space for write-in candidates in each office on the primary ballot. But election officials warned that the voting machines had too little space and that paper ballots might be needed. The Legislature responded with a bill giving local governments the option of providing write-in space for public offices but not for political party positions on the same ballot. The Senate has already approved the bill; Gov. George E. Pataki plans to sign it. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Article 2001062790023506903 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on AIDS in New York misspelled the name of the president of the General Assembly. He is Harri Holkeri, not Harry.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Mother Charged In Infant Death
description: State police yesterday arrested the mother of a 15-month-old boy who was found stabbed, beaten and burned to death on the patio of his home in Somers. The mother, Kristin Anderson, 29, was charged with murder. Police responded to a 911 call Sunday and found the baby unconscious. Ms. Anderson, who said she suffers from bipolar disorder, is being held on a $2 million bond and will be arraigned in State Superior Court in Rockville.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Still Silent
description: An investigative judge called former President Carlos Sal Menem to court for a second time to answer accusations that he led a conspiracy to sell arms illegally to Croatia and Ecuador in the 1990's. Mr. Menem offered written responses to two points and then refused to answer questions, as he did earlier this month. Judge Jorge Urso is expected to decide soon whether to charge Mr. Menem, who governed from 1989 to 1999. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Lawyers for Embassy Bomber Push for Prison Over Execution
description: Lawyers for a man who could face the death penalty for the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania yesterday offered the jury an alternative: they introduced testimony about one of the United States' most secure prisons, the so-called Super Max, in Florence, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, WILLIAM N.
description: SEGAL-William N. Beloved husband of the late Fritzie, devoted father of Andrew and Ronnie Segal and Bonnie and Robert Morenstein, cherished grandfather of Scott, Dana, Amanda and Emily. Services private.

title: Bid for Bankrupt Airline
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, the largest aircraft lessor, and an unidentified investor are offering to buy National Airlines Inc., which is bankrupt.

title: MetroStars Learn Copa Opponents
description: The MetroStars were grouped with teams from Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela yesterday for the Copa Merconorte tournament, which begins Aug. 1.

title: Invaders in Yellowstone
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, HUGH JOHN
description: BRENNAN-Hugh John. Died peacefully in his sleep in his 90th year on June 24, 2001. He was a Master Welder, Teacher and Poet. He is survived by his nephew and niece George and Helen Knepple and his four granddaughters and their spouses; Patricia Hassett and her husband Michael Ribaudo; Suzanne Saffioti and her husband Vito; Laura Brennan and her husband Richard Pansini; Theresa Brennan and her husband Peter Keim. Also surviving are his great grandchildren Thomas and Kerry Erickson and Peter and Benjamin Ribaudo. Viewing will be held at Robertassio Funeral Home, 85 Medford Avenue, Patchogue, New York on Wednesday June 27, 2001 from 2 P.M. until 4 P.M. and 7 PM. until 9 P.M. Services will be held at Our Lady of Mount Carmel R.C.C., Patchogue on Thursday, June 28, 2001 at 9:45 A.M. Burial will take place at Pinelawn Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York at 11:30 A.M., Thursday, June 28, 2001.

title: Child's Play at the N.B.A. Draft
description: For the first time in league history, a high school player is expected to be taken No. 1. By MIKE WISE

title: Sports of The Times; Cubs-Mets: A Reversal Of Roles
description: WHEN one of the bevy of recent Cub managers was hired, he was asked what it was like taking over a team that hasn't won a World Series since 1908.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Victory For Developer
description: A developer wrestling for control of a large downtown development site won a victory in court yesterday, when Justice Ira Gammerman denied the Battery Park City Authority's request for a preliminary injunction preventing Brookfield Financial Properties from publicly asserting its rights to the land. The authority, the state agency that controls the 92-acre Battery Park City, has wanted to sell the right to build a 1.8-million-square-foot skyscraper at the site on West Street, between Vesey and Murray Streets. But Brookfield has scared off potential buyers by telling rival developers and public officials that it has the exclusive right to develop the site. In March, the authority filed suit in State Supreme Court asking that Brookfield be barred from interfering with the sale. Although Justice Gammerman refused to issue an injunction, he set Oct. 22 as the date for a status conference on the dispute and said he hoped to schedule a trial by the end of the year.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Strike By State Workers Ends
description: State workers ended their 10-week rolling strike, saying they had achieved most of their objectives in the newly passed budget that Gov. Gary Locke is expected to sign. The strike by the 19,000-member Washington Federation of State Employees consisted of a series of staggered walkouts and focused on pay and health insurance. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Second Defendant Is Convicted in 1999 Murder of Social Worker
description: The Amy Watkins murder case came to an end yesterday with the conviction of a 21-year-old Brooklyn man on second-degree murder charges.

title: 4 Youths Held in London in Killing of Boy, 10
description: The police today brought murder charges against four teenagers in the killing of a 10-year-old immigrant from Nigeria. The stabbing death, on the stairwell of a housing project here, caused revulsion because of evidence that passers-by had let the boy bleed to death.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a Buddhist-influenced artwork that was ordered to be either revised or removed from the baptistry of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine before the baptism of the grandson of Bishop Mark S. Sisk on Sunday misstated the installation date of Bishop Sisk as bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. He will become bishop of New York on July 1 and will be installed as bishop of New York at a ceremony at the cathedral on Sept. 29. The ceremony was not held on Saturday.

title: 10 Facing U.S. Charges Of Fraud in Two Offerings
description: The former owners of a defunct New York brokerage firm, LT Lawrence & Company, and eight of its brokers have been indicted on charges of manipulating the initial public offerings of two companies.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent's Debt Rating Is Cut
description: Two credit-rating agencies lowered their ratings on the debt of Lucent Technologies yesterday, adding to the telecommunications equipment maker's woes. Moody's Investors Service and Fitch both cut their rating on Lucent's debt to speculative, or junk, status, a move that will probably raise the company's borrowing costs and could discourage some investors from acquiring its securities. Still, the downgrades are expected to have little immediate effect since Lucent, hurt by declining sales, has been treated by its creditors for several months as if it had junk status. The downgrades follow a similar action by Standard & Poor's earlier this month. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: RADIO BROADCASTER FOR BLACK LISTENERS TO BUY STATION
description: Radio One, the largest radio broadcaster in the nation serving black listeners, agreed to buy the Georgia radio station WPEZ-FM from the closely held U.S. Broadcasting for $55 million. Radio One will buy the station, licensed in Macon, Ga., to expand in one of the largest black markets in the United States. The transaction is expected to close Jan. 30 and may be extended to July 31, 2002. Until then, the company, based in Lanham, Mass., will run the station under a marketing agreement with U.S. Broadcasting.

title: Happy to Be Co-Pilot During Labor
description: Previously, I was with a managed care practice and saw as many as eight patients an hour -- about six minutes a patient. Now I see about three patients in an hour. The other day a patient came in, 38 weeks pregnant. She said, ''I'm scared.'' It takes a lot longer than six minutes to respond to that.

title: The 2000 Bordeaux Already Has Corks Popping
description: DESPITE poor weather early in the season and the worst attack of mildew in a century, 2000 is turning out to be a truly fine year for Bordeaux. And the wine world, which hasn't had much to be excited about recently, seems universal in its acclaim. As the ballyhoo swells, many wine authorities are saying the new Bordeaux may surpass the greatly admired vintages of 1995 and 1985, and collectors caught in the frenzy are paying as much as $1,200 for a single bottle.

title: Hip-Hop Howls Its Way Into the Dramatic Realm
description: By design, there haven't been many attendees at the New York City Hip-Hop Theater Festival who are old enough to remember the 1960's. But for those of us who are, the festival provides a jolt of nostalgia. A youthful fervor to be heard and not dismissed, a righteous denunciation of corrupt authority and urgings of universal brotherhood: the echoes of the Vietnam-era spirit of rebellion in the theatrical expression of hip-hop are loud and clear.

title: Surviving the Indonesian Shuffle
description: When Indonesia's president shuffled his cabinet recently, the outspoken chief economics minister, Rizal Ramli, was judged to be a big loser. Mr. Ramli was demoted to finance minister -- or as he himself noted, ''I dropped from No. 4 to No. 8 in the pecking order.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Food Stuff: Steering Out of the Subway Into a Taco Stand on Wheels
description: The aroma wafts into the subway station at 96th Street and Broadway. As you scale the steps it gets stronger and stronger, until all around you is the smell of spices and grilled meat.

title: Europe Panel Is Rethinking How It Views E-Commerce
description: In a surprising reversal, officials at the European Commission say they will listen to public concerns and are considering abandoning a long-held position on a core legal issue surrounding Internet commerce: whose laws apply in cross-border disputes.

title: Rumsfeld Will Call for Big Cut In B-1 Bombers, Officials Say
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will call for cutting the Air Force's fleet of 93 B-1 bombers by nearly a third when he presents a detailed budget plan to Congress on Thursday, officials said today.

title: Houston, Bouncing Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Natural Food Is Big, and Sometimes Even Natural
description: AS confidence in the safety of the commercial food supply has declined in recent years, consumers have increasingly sought their own remedy: the modern natural food store. They believe, right or wrong, that what such stores offer is more healthful, cleaner, safer and higher in quality, and may also be better for the environment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military and fraternal organizations. Funeral service will be held 5:30PM Wednesday, June 27, 2001 at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York. Private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011.

title: Old Guard Watches Passing of the Torch
description: Moses Malone received the astonishing news from John Lucas, who was nearly his teammate at the University of Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERER, WILFRED (PUDI)
description: LEDERER-Wilfred (Pudi). Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Judy and Michael. Doting grandfather of Joshua and Naomi. Services Friday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: A Sport Opens Its Mats to Women in U.S.
description: Toccara Montgomery was a sophomore at East Technical High School in Cleveland three years ago when she checked out a practice for the newly formed wrestling squad. A rough-and-tumble sort who was always a something of a tomboy, she took Coach Kip Flanik at his word when he assured her that wrestling was a sport in which a woman could not only compete, but also thrive.

title: Thomas Book Author Says He Lied in His Attacks on Anita Hill
description: The author of a best-selling book that attacked the credibility of Anita F. Hill has disavowed its premise, and now says that he lied in print to protect the reputation of Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIERS, MARGARET
description: TIERS-Margaret. Died April 19, 2001 of natural causes. She was born in Paris, France, January 16, 1912. Her parents were Cornelius Tiers of Paris, and Margaret Drumm Tiers, of Montreal. Mrs. Herbert was married to E.N. Potter of N.Y. She leaves son, Allan Robbins Potter, and wife Norma, of Mission Viejo, CA, daughter, Margot Potter Denny, and husband Robert, of Tucson, AZ, a grand daughter, Margot Kiser Jones, and husband Peter.

title: A Last Chance in Macedonia
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  Macedonians were out in the streets here Monday night protesting the way the international community has involved itself in the four- month conflict with Albanian rebels called the National Liberation Army. In front of the parliament, demonstrators burned the flag of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and pictures of the European Union envoy Javier Solana.

title: Trivia Question: 50 in 1977
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Rangers Add College Goalie
description: The Rangers yesterday agreed to terms with the free-agent goaltender Scott Meyer, who played at St. Cloud State University the last four years.

title: New Rounds of Job Cuts Seen at Lucent and JDS Uniphase
description: Concerns over the weakness in the communications industry heightened today as two large companies, Lucent Technologies and JDS Uniphase, prepared for additional job cuts.

title: Article 2001062793544854598 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, JOHN T.
description: CANNON-John T. Suddenly in Germany on June 22, 2001. President of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. Grand Commandeur of La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. Beloved husband of Gertrude, dear father of Connie. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd corner Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, New York, Thursday, June 28th, at 11 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGENSTEIN, DAVID
description: KLINGENSTEIN-David. June 23, 2001. A Renaissance Man who lost a courageous battle against cancer. We will miss you. Bernard and Ann Fried, together with his host or other close friends and admirers.

title: In Fighting AIDS, We Cannot Delay
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Rises and Dow Falls As Investors Await Rate Cut

title: Rail Unions to Merge, Leader of One Says
description: Two unions representing about 70,000 train crew workers at the Union Pacific Corporation and other railroads will merge by the end of the year to increase their bargaining power, the head of one of them said today.

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Christopher Drew was named to the new post of vice president for corporate planning at Brierley & Partners, Dallas. He had been vice president for corporate development and finance at NextJet Inc., Dallas. Brierley is 20 percent owned by the WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEZ, SILVIO, M.D.
description: BAEZ-Silvio, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of our distinguished professor emeritus of anesthesiology and physiology, who served our medical school with great devotion since 1961. We extend our sincere condolences to the family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dot-Com Job Erosion Slows
description: The outplacement firm Challenger Gray & Christmas reported that dot-com job cuts fell to 9,216 for the month of June, down 31 percent from the May level. Internet technology companies accounted for the bulk of the dot-com layoffs, but advertising and consumer services dot-coms were also reducing substantially. In the first six months of the year, 74,199 dot-com jobs were cut.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Hearing Delayed
description: With one of three judges failing to show up without explanation, an appeals court was forced to delay a hearing that was to decide whether to suspend the human rights case against Gen. Augusto Pinochet on the ground that he is not mentally fit to stand trial. Whatever decision the court makes may eventually be appealed to the Supreme Court. The former dictator has been accused of covering up the activities of a death squad that kidnapped or executed 75 people. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFONSO, RICARDO, DR.
description: ALFONSO-Ricardo, Dr. The entire Long Island College Hospital mourns the passing of Dr. Ricardo Alfonso, father of Dr. Antonio E. Alfonso, Chairman of the Dept of Surgery on June 24th, 2001. Dr. Ricardo Alfonso was living in Manila, Philippines and is survived by his wife Marita Alfonso, his sons Dr. Antonio E. Alfonso and Ricardo Alfonso and his daughters Evelyn, Marilyn, Menchu and many grandchildren. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family. John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents, LICH Allan Gibofsky, M.D., J.D., President and CEO, LICH Edmund Giegerich, MD Senior Vice President, Medical Affairs

title: 'Traviata' in Central Park Wins a Convert
description: The combined appeal of ''La Traviata'' and balmy evening weather brought some 45,000 people to the Great Lawn in Central Park, the parks department estimated, for the free concert performance of that familiar Verdi work by the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night. This is the 35th season of the popular Met in the Parks series, which has long attracted appreciative opera buffs and countless newcomers.

title: The Anti-Game-Show
description: Robert Morton was for a long time the producer of David Letterman's late-night talk show, when it was at both NBC and CBS.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: City Comptroller Is Ousted
description: The outside board that oversees Camden's finances has voted to oust the city's chief financial officer, who has held the office for nearly 30 years, on the grounds that he is ineffective and had kept poor accounting records ''for decades.'' The comptroller, Richard Cinaglia, did not return calls for comment yesterday. He has been demoted to assistant business administrator and his replacement has not been chosen. The eight-member Local Finance Board met for five hours Monday before voting unanimously to remove Mr. Cinaglia, the chairman of the board, Ulrich Steinberg, said yesterday. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Gucci Strikes The Right Mix
description: MILAN  Female fashion's phobias and fears are summed up in the query: "Does my butt look big in this?"

title: Along With Signs of Growth, Words of Caution on Economy
description: Consumer confidence rose in June to the highest level this year, a private research firm said today, indicating that shoppers could keep the record economic expansion trudging along.

title: AETHER, CITING FLAT SALES, TO LAY OFF 11% OF ITS WORKERS
description: Aether Systems, a developer of software and services for wireless Internet access, will lay off 150 employees, or 11 percent of its work force, to trim expenses. The company said it expected sales to remain flat for the rest of the year. Aether will reduce annual costs by as much as $78 million, with the job cuts accounting for almost half of that, a spokesman, Greg Abel, said. Revenue is being hurt because of slowing economic growth. Aether is based in Owings Mills, Md.

title: Pineapples From Lilliput, With a Brobdingnag Taste
description: These baby pineapples not only look good enough to eat, they are delicious. Until now, mini-pineapples were strictly decorative, never sweet enough to be edible. These cuties, from South Africa, will be available year-round. At $2 to $3 each they are a bit of an indulgence, but it's one that will impress your summertime lunch guests.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: Webb Wins L.P.G.A. Title for Career Slam
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 24  It is virtually impossible to detect any emotion behind the reflective sunglasses that cover Karrie Webb's eyes when she plays. She showed a great deal of emotion, however, when the glasses came off after her final putt and she explained her feelings about winning two major championships three weeks apart to become the youngest player to complete the L.P.G.A. career grand slam.

title: Steering Out of the Subway Into a Taco Stand on Wheels
description: The aroma wafts into the subway station at 96th Street and Broadway. As you scale the steps it gets stronger and stronger, until all around you is the smell of spices and grilled meat.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Raises Prices
description: EarthLink, the big Atlanta-based Internet service provider, said it would increase the price of its unlimited internet service by $2, to $21.95 a month. EarthLink officials said they believed that the move would not lead to a loss of subscribers. ''We're confident that our customers will stick with us,'' a spokesman, Dan Greenfield, said. The company's decision comes a month after America Online announced plans to increase its monthly fee to $23.90. The rate increase will take effect on Monday. EarthLink's shares rose $1.56, or 12.7 percent, to $13.83. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Interest Rate Cut Anticipated as Fed Resumes Meeting Today
description: Wall Street went about its business today, but it was not business as usual. Investors were awaiting an announcement from the Federal Reserve Board this afternoon about the latest move on interest rates.

title: Zahringer Stays in the Zone And Wins the Ike by 2 Shots
description: George Zahringer III is having fun playing golf again at age 48, and that satisfaction has translated to success. He posted his third victory in eight days today by capturing the Ike, the stroke-play championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: A Savory Bean of Summer Comes Out of Its Shell
description: THERE are few vegetables that mark the divide between a restaurant chef and a home cook as sharply as the fava bean.

title: Assembly Supports Tax Deals for Towns and Nuclear Plants
description: The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would allow local governments to negotiate special multiyear property tax deals with nuclear power plants.

title: Flavors of the Family Tree
description: DAVID PAGE and Barbara Shinn, a couple of transplanted Midwesterners, own Home, a restaurant on Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village, where Mr. Page is the chef. Recently, they set down roots in farm country on the North Fork of Long Island, where they have planted a vineyard and garden and have the simple joy of gathering ingredients just steps from the kitchen door.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The Ifo economic institute has halved its forecast for German economic expansion this year as export growth slows, inflation curbs consumer spending and the construction industry remains in recession. The economy will expand 1.2 percent this year, the group said. In February, Ifo predicted growth of 2.4 percent. In 2002, gross domestic product will increase 2.2 percent, the Munich-based institute said.

title: U.N. Unites to Combat AIDS But Splits Over How to Do It
description: While a special session of the United Nations grasps this week for a show of unity on the worldwide AIDS epidemic, participants are divided among hundreds of different views on how to approach the problem, how to spend the money promised for a global AIDS fund and even who should take part in the debate.

title: New Rounds of Job Cuts Seen at Lucent and JDS Uniphase
description: Concerns over the weakness in the communications industry heightened today as two large companies, Lucent Technologies and JDS Uniphase, prepared for additional job cuts.

title: U.S. to Appeal Antitrust Loss On an Airline
description: The Justice Department announced today that it would appeal a recent federal district court decision to dismiss the government's predatory pricing antitrust case against American Airlines.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Hate-Crimes Prosecution
description: Officials have won what they believe to be the first successful prosecution under New York State's hate-crimes law approved last year, Charles J. Hynes, left, the Brooklyn district attorney, announced yesterday. Mohammad Awad, of 746 42nd Street, pleaded guilty to assault as a hate crime and is to be sentenced Aug. 9. On Dec. 18, he followed Chaim Spear into a subway car, punched him in the face, and yelled anti-Semitic remarks and obscenities at him, prosecutors said. Mr. Awad's plea agreement includes attending an anger-management course as a condition of receiving five years' probation. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Shedding 7 Coats, A Beauty Emerges On a Hospital Wall; Years and Paint Stripped Away From a Noted Abstract Mural
description: For nearly six months, the men of Ward B-11 watched restorers chip and dissolve their way through seven coats of institutional paint. They breathed the mingled odors of solvent and hospital food. They wondered at the stream of important-looking visitors to their day room.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Facelift for an Osteria

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Pope Names New Bishop For Diocese of 1.5 Million
description: To serve as spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.5 million Roman Catholics, Pope John Paul II today appointed William Francis Murphy, an auxiliary bishop in Boston described by his colleagues as a smart, exuberant man with a deep interest in social justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACY, PAUL M.
description: LACY-Paul M. On June 24, 2001. Loving husband of Eileen for 39 years. Devoted father to Paul Jr. and daughter - in - law, Gloria; daughter, Claire, and son-in-law, Robert McKeon; daughter, Susan, and son-in-law, Craig Ryan. Beloved Seanfehr to six grandchildren. Dear brother to Herbert Lacy and Claire Jones. Funeral Mass on June 30, 11 AM, at St. Veronica's Church, Christopher St. between Washington and Greenwich. He lived his life the way he wanted to.

title: Article 2001062790581317095 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Business Travel; As the number of corporate guests drops, many top-rated hotels offer discounts.
description: GRANTED, it was 105 degrees by 1 p.m. Golfers were straggling off the startlingly green fairways laid alongside huge high-desert rocks. Even the people in the pool looked wilted.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Signs European Licenses
description: Napster said yesterday that it had gone partway toward being able to provide its users with access to Garbage, not to mention Moby, Tom Jones and Badly Drawn Boy. Those are among the musicians and bands represented by the Association of Independent Music and the Independent Music Companies Association, two British trade associations with which Napster has signed a licensing agreement. Under the agreement, Napster said that it would be able to offer access to ''hundreds of thousands of tracks'' belonging to hundreds of Europe's independent record labels. Napster said it planned to make the music available when it began its fee-based subscription service later this summer, but there is a catch. With yesterday's deal, Napster has acquired the rights to the recordings, but it still must acquire the publishing rights to the music, a Napster spokesman said. Napster said it was in the process of negotiating those rights. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOFSKY, GLENN H.
description: JACOFSKY-Glenn H. Taken from us by a senseless and selfish act, Glenn was a loving and caring husband, father, brother and friend, who will be missed. He was a nice guy. Keith and Audrey Reich

title: Report Says Ambulances Steer to Their Own Hospitals
description: Private ambulances are much more likely than those operated by the Fire Department to steer emergency patients to their own hospitals, bypassing closer ones, according to a report released yesterday by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Albanians in Macedonia Are Suspicious of the Police
description: Several prominent ethnic Albanian community leaders have disappeared in Macedonia in recent months, and here in the southwestern region, where one local Albanian political leader was killed, the Albanians increasingly blame the police force, which is dominated by the country's majority Slavs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harlem: Minister Robbed Twice
description: A convicted robber released on parole five days ago knocked on the apartment door of a Baptist minister in Harlem before sunrise yesterday and snatched his necklace chain when he answered the door, the police said. A little more than four hours later, the same man robbed the clergyman again, this time in the lobby of his building on West 124th Street, taking a watch and glasses, the police said. The clergyman, the Rev. Kenneth Hamilton of the Greater Calvary Baptist Church, flagged down a patrol car. Two officers arrested a suspect minutes later. The man, John Fitzpatrick, 39, who the police said was homeless, was charged with robbery, burglary and criminal possession of stolen property. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAGAN, JACK
description: CAGAN-Jack. On June 25, 2001 at age 80. Beloved husband for 55 years of the late Susan. WWII veteran, with a Purple Heart and Distinguished Flying Cross. He was a sr. tax auditor/US Treasury, then a CPA and tax attorney for over 40 years. He will be remembered as a man of great intellect, grace, wit and wisdom, which was sought by all, whether family, friends, or colleagues. He is survived by his children, Arlynn, Barbara, Edward and Eric, their spouses, his five grandchildren & his widow, Renee. We will always love him & cherish his memory forever.

title: Steering Out of the Subway Into a Taco Stand on Wheels
description: The aroma wafts into the subway station at 96th Street and Broadway. As you scale the steps it gets stronger and stronger, until all around you is the smell of spices and grilled meat.

title: Return to Sender
description: To the Editor:

title: Orthodoxy and Catholicism Collide in a Ukrainian Town
description: On a windswept hill a dozen miles from where Pope John Paul II was saying Mass this morning, a determined group of Orthodox believers -- men and women working with hammers and trowels -- were building a new sanctuary against what they see as the Catholic assault on their faith.

title: NBC Loves Reality
description: NBC remains nearly euphoric with the results of its forays into reality television this summer.

title: Robinson McIlvaine, 87; Envoy in '66 Guinea Crisis
description: Robinson McIlvaine, a career diplomat who was at the center of a tense international incident while he was the American ambassador to Guinea, in West Africa, died on Sunday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 87.

title: Merrill Warns Of Weakness In Net Income
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the biggest American brokerage firm, shook Wall Street yesterday with a warning that its earnings would sink this quarter and that unless the financial markets bounced back soon it might have to eliminate more than the 3,300 jobs it had already cut this year.

title: Cookies, Cookies, Everywhere, And Plenty of Chips to Eat
description: Wendy Gaynor's wholesale baking career was short-circuited five years ago when her daughter Ruby, now 23, was in a serious car accident and needed her round-the-clock attention. Now that her daughter has recovered, Ms. Gaynor, right, is back in the cookie business, with her first store, a sliver of a bakery shop, Ruby et Violette, at 457 West 50th Street (open Monday through Friday). Violette, 21, is her other daughter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Consultant's Forecast
description: The big European consulting and computer services group, Cap Gemini of France, lowered its revenue forecast for this year and said it would cut 2,700 jobs, mainly in the United States, Britain and Scandinavia, as weaker economies on both sides of the Atlantic cause demand for its services to slow. Cap Gemini, which last year acquired the consulting business of Ernst & Young, predicted revenue for the full year of 9 billion euros ($7.7 billion), against an earlier forecast 9.6 billion euros. Geoff Unwin, the chief executive of Cap Gemini, said the group's operating margin would drop to about 7 percent this year, from 10.5 percent last year. Cap Gemini's share price dropped by as much as 24 percent to its lowest level since early 1998. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about renewed interest in the B-2 bomber misidentified the pilot shown at Whiteman Air Force Base, Mo. He is Maj. Scott Vilter, not Maj. Brian Zembraski. The caption also misidentified where the picture was taken. It was in the cockpit of an actual B-2, not a simulator.

title: Payton, Back From an Injury, Tries to Hit a Winning Note
description: He was like a songwriter who dreams up a tune and quickly writes it down before the notes fade away. Jay Payton knew how well he was hitting in early May, and he did not want to forget.

title: In Life's Dark Corners, The Saddest Slow Dance
description: THE NOONDAY DEMON

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 59 Executed For Drug Trafficking
description: China executed at least 59 people for drug trafficking on Monday and yesterday, the United Nations International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking. Twenty were executed in Kunming, capital of Yunnan province, after a rally where the condemned were sentenced before thousands of people. China has put more than 1,000 people to death since April in a nationwide anticrime drive, according to Western diplomats tracking executions reported in the state media. Not all executions are announced. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Pope Names 28 Ukrainians as Deserving of Sainthhod
description: LVIV, Ukraine, June 27  Paying tribute to a branch of the Catholic faith that was fiercely persecuted in Soviet times, Pope John Paul II put 28 Greek Catholic Ukrainians on the road to sainthood today, seeking to blend the beatifications with his longtime dream of ending a centuries-old schism with the Eastern Orthodox church.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Interactive TV Raises Privacy Concerns
description: When interactive television comes along, it will spend as much time watching viewers as the viewers spend watching it, according to a report released yesterday. The report from the Center for Digital Democracy, an advocacy group in Washington, on marketing materials and filings of companies designing interactive television systems found that, like Web site operators, many of them hope to profit by collecting and selling data on customers' viewing habits. Although the cable TV industry is governed by strict laws, some technologies may not fall under those laws. Jeffrey Chester, head of the group, called interactive TV ''a major threat'' to consumer privacy. Jonathan Zuck, president of the Association for Competitive Technology, a technology industry group in Washington, said providers must find ways to pay for investments in technology and programming. ''Keep in mind that there's no free lunch in life,'' he said. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Sauces Made for Spooning
description: A FRESH-TASTING quick uncooked sauce, made to be spooned over anything and everything, is the easiest way to dress up the plainest foods. Salsa and vinaigrette are two of the most familiar, yet there are equivalents to be found in many cuisines: raw, thin, powerful dressings that are served like condiments and splashed on at the table.

title: At Oval Office, The Suit Rules For Bush, Formality Matters
description: WASHINGTON  One of the first presidential acts of George W. Bush was to decree that he would be running a more formal White House. It turns out that he may be governing a more formal country.

title: Joyous in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Experienced Goalie Next Milbury Target
description: The Islanders have picked up two premier centers and 400 additional season-ticket holders since last Friday, but Mike Milbury, the general manager of a hockey team that finally has some buzz, brought his trusty red cellular phone along to a news conference today just in case he could scare up another deal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAMSTAR SYSTEMS INC., Campbell, Calif., the leading provider of collaborative manufacturing execution solutions, has acquired the supply chain consulting and services practice of the Unifi Technology Group , Charlotte, N.C., a leading consultancy and systems integrator for the manufacturing industry, and formed the Camstar Solutions Group. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Rwandan Leader Draws a Sadder Portrait of Congo Than Does a U.N. Group
description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda accused the government of Congo today of failing to carry out its commitments to end a long regional war, and said the Congolese and their Zimbabwean allies are continuing to arm former Rwandan soldiers involved in mass killings in 1994.

title: Article 2001062791796782068 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOKATLIAN, MELIK
description: TOKATLIAN-Melik. On May 31, 2001. Died suddenly and quietly at home after being ill for some time. An astute businessman, he was responsible for developing a diamond stylii for the LP cartridge and manufactured diamond tools. In the late 1970's he successfully chaired a raffle committee to pay off the remaining mortgage on St. Vartan Cathedral in New York City. He was a loving, caring and very generous person who thought of others first, especially the family members. His loving wife, Florence, daughter, Linda, sons, John and Gary, grandchildren, Kristen and Derek, brother-inlaw, son-in-law and loving nieces Susan and Jill. In Greece his brother, sister, sister-in-law, nieces Christine and Florence. In Sao Paulo his nephews and nieces will miss him and love him always.

title: Davenport Keeps a Victory at Wimbledon in Perspective
description: A French Open match began to unfold on the television set in Corina Morariu's Miami hospital room when Lindsay Davenport pulled up a chair.

title: New Issue at U.N.: North Koreans Seeking Refugee Status in China
description: Seven illegal immigrants from North Korea sneaked past Chinese security guards today into the local office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, saying they would not leave until they had been granted political refugee status and guaranteed safe passage to South Korea.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Former Hostage Wins Lawsuit
description: Thomas Sutherland, a former hostage in Lebanon, and his family won a $353 million lawsuit against Iran in Federal District Court in Washington. Mr. Sutherland, 70, of Fort Collins, was a dean at the American University in Beirut when he was kidnapped in 1985 and held for six years. Iran has never paid damages to plaintiffs in terrorism suits, but the family would be eligible to receive part of the award from the United States Treasury. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: In Fighting AIDS, We Cannot Delay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINNEY, ROBERT MOODY
description: McKINNEY-Robert Moody. Ambassador McKinney was the stepfather of our beloved friend and member of Hunter/Brookdale's Board of Overseers, Edmee deM. Firth, and was a loyal supporter of our work. Our hearts go out to Edmee, her children and all of the Ambassador's family. The Board of Overseers and Staff of the Brookdale Center on Aging, Hunter College

title: Torre Wants Clemens To Do the Right Thing
description: Imagine that Jimy Williams has nothing better to do the evening of July 10 so he's sitting at home and he turns on the television. He punches the remote again and again and again and suddenly, there on his screen, is a baseball game. It's the All-Star Game, and Jimy Williams, being a die-hard baseball man, watches it.

title: Leaner, More Innovative, Italian Footwear Springs Back to Fore
description: MILAN  There is an old tale about Italy's tradition for making fine shoes which dates back to Napoleonic times. The French emperor, having worn out his boots, is said to have ordered a new pair from a highly rated Milanese shoemaker.

title: South African Links AIDS To Broader Issue of Poverty
description: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa skipped the United Nations conference on AIDS in New York today to come to the White House, where President Bush, in the gentlest of encounters, helped him deflect accusations that his government has all but neglected the AIDS epidemic.

title: Bloomberg's Campaign Has Early Bumps Along the Trail
description: Michael R. Bloomberg took Ninfa Segarra, the president of the city's Board of Education, to lunch in Brooklyn the other day. It was a campaign event intended to draw attention to Mr. Bloomberg's education proposal, and when Mr. Bloomberg and Ms. Segarra finished their salads, they walked outside to the waiting television crews that Mr. Bloomberg's campaign had summoned to cover their meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, JEAN S.
description: BECKER-Jean S. On June 20, 2001. Mother of the late Adele Wiland. Grandmother of Beth Cooper and great-grandmother of Adam, Daniel and Josh.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Congress Seeks Information On Fraud
description: Members of Congress yesterday asked for guidance from some of the companies that are hosts to Internet auctions -- Yahoo, eBay and Amazon.com -- in assessing the prevalence of online auction fraud. Representatives Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, left, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Heather A. Wilson, Republican of New Mexico, sent letters to the chief executives of the companies in an effort to learn more about how the fraud occurs and ways to stop it. The lawmakers cited findings from a recent study by the Internet Fraud Complaint Center that showed online auction fraud accounted for about 64 percent of all fraud complaints received by the center from May to November 2000. Company officials were asked what types of fraud occurred in online auctions, what rules existed for dealing with disguised identities and if these rules might actually aid fraudulent practices, and whether certain state laws or regulations interfered with the ability to combat online fraud.

title: Wetlands Plan Faulted
description: A government program allowing landowners to destroy some wetlands if they create or restore others is failing, a scientific panel has found, calling into question a key component of protection efforts.

title: Trial Opens for Third Algerian In Bomb Plot Before Millennium
description: The trial of the third defendant in a millennium celebration terrorist bombing plot opened in Manhattan yesterday, just after another man, convicted of trying to carry explosives into the United States from Canada agreed to testify for the government.

title: Krispy Kreme Chooses GSD&M
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said yesterday that it had formally named GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its brand communications after working with the agency informally for the last seven years. Billings have not been determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPIN, GUTHRIE, DANIEL
description: KRUPIN-GUTHRIE-Daniel, suddenly in California. Son of esteemed member of our Scientific Advisory Board, Dr. Theodore and Mrs. Dene Krupin of Chicago. Our hearts are with them. Gregory Harmon, Robert Ritch, Joe La Motta, Jim Digan, Ali Hodin, and The Glaucoma Foundation Staff

title: LAYOFFS SET AT PROVIDER OF SERVICES TO AUTO INSURERS
description: The CCC Information Services Group, which supplies automobile claims software and services to insurance companies, laid off 130 workers and will exit its claims-services businesses in the United States and Britain to reduce costs. The layoffs represent less than 10 percent of the work force, and the company will take second-quarter charges of $2.5 million for the layoffs and $2.7 million for the elimination of businesses. CCC, based in Chicago, said in April that it would leave the claims-servicing business in the United States and that it was seeking a buyer for its claims-administration unit.

title: Schundler Harnessed Conservatism to Defy Centrist Wisdom
description: He ran as an outsider and he celebrated his victory as one, too.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Nets Looking for a Player (at Any Size)
description: Somewhere in the Sheraton New York ballroom the future of the Nets sat yesterday with legs and potential still folded.

title: For Exam, Recollection Is Nine-Tenths of the Law
description: All of them had graduated from law school within the last few weeks. But instead of celebrating their newfound freedom by, say, snorkeling in Bermuda, more than 1,000 graduates, many of them sleepy-eyed on this Monday morning, streamed into Town Hall near Times Square for what has become a legal rite of passage in New York.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to End Vieques Bombing Raises Questions in Congress
description: By DAVID STOUT

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; G.E.-Honeywell Deal: If at First . . .
description: Why is General Electric still vigorously lobbying regulators about its planned acquisition of Honeywell International if the deal is really dead? Maybe because it isn't -- or at least not yet.

title: Be a Man? But Where Are the Role Models?
description: ''Baby Boy'' opens with the image of Jody, its 20-year-old protagonist, sleeping in his mother's womb as a voice-over explains the film's title and its central theme. John Singleton's new coming-of-age melodrama hypothesizes that young black men are infantilized by a society that allows them little room to grow. In support of this thesis, the narrator notes that a typical African-American man growing up in a neighborhood like South Central Los Angeles, where this film is set, refers to his girlfriend as mama, his friends as his boys and his home as his crib.

title: Transcript of Kay Lee's and Jodi James's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, June 26, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Kay Lee and Jodi James from journeyforjustice.org . This discussion was the third in a series organized by forum participants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, REBECCA ATKINSON
description: RYAN-Rebecca Atkinson. June 24, 2001 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late James F. Ryan. Loving sister of Catherine E. Lynham and Ruth M. Smyth. Devoted aunt and great aunt. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, July 10th, 11AM in the Chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue and 90 Street, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Hamptons Style In Economy Class
description: Great looking and deceptively inexpensive, these hand-hammered, stainless-steel serving pieces are just right for summer weekend house gifts. The collection, Geometrics, by the American metalware designer Michael Aram, is made in India. The pieces coordinate with his other utensils, usually made of silverplate. This group -- a serving set of a 10-inch fork and a spoon, $45; an 8-inch cake server, $24; and cake knife, $20 -- is all available at Arcadia, 261 West 19th Street. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Knicks Expect Quality Pick Despite Waiting Till Round 2
description: As a minor player in the N.B.A. draft, the Knicks will not be involved in any of the highlights of the evening. They will not select the next Kevin Garnett or Kobe Bryant straight out of high school, or even grab an immediate starter with the 39th and 43rd picks.

title: U.S. Study Hails Stem Cells' Promise
description: A new report from the National Institutes of Health says research on stem cells derived from both human embryos and adult tissue promises ''a dazzling array'' of treatments for various diseases, but for some purposes, it says, the embryonic cells are clearly superior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAGO, ROSARIO F., MD (SAM)
description: DRAGO-Rosario F., MD (Sam). On June 25, 2001. Family physician for 60 years in Astoria-LIC area. Beloved husband of the late Anne (nee Zuppert). Loving father of Elizabeth Hoban, Sister Marganne Drago SSJ, Frances, Philip J. and James V. Dear brother of Mary Lombardo. Also survived by seven grandchildren and two stepgrandchildren. Reposing Thursday, 7-10pm at R.P. Drago Funeral Home, 43-10 30 Avenue, Astoria, New York. Graveside service and interment Friday 10:30AM at Mt. St. Mary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Sisters of St. Joseph, St. Joseph Villa, Flourtown, PA. 19031, Adams County Friends of the Library, Gettysburgh, PA. or to St. Francis Xavier RC Church, Gettysburgh, Pennsylvania.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, NAOMI
description: GOLDSTEIN-Naomi. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member, Simeon Goldstein, and our Board member, Deborah Stepelman, upon the loss of their beloved wife and mother. May the families be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Bush and Sharon Differ on Ending Violence
description: President Bush today urged Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to be more receptive to political steps that the administration believes are necessary to cool the Middle East situation, a senior administration official said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell after Russia said it would oppose tighter sanctions on Iraq, signaling Iraq may resume exports. In New York, crude oil for August delivery fell 27 cents, or 1 percent, to $26.98 a barrel.

title: Russian Calls Imprisoned American a Spy
description: An American student serving a one-year sentence in Russia on a drug conviction faced fresh difficulties today, after a Russian scientist accused the American of trying to recruit him as a spy for the United States.

title: European Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes: A Prizewinner Is Almost Family
description: NBC did not broadcast the edition of its hit game show "Weakest Link" that had been planned on Monday night for one extremely odd reason:

title: Seoul Escalates War of Words Over Fishing
description: The longtime quarrel over who has the right to govern the Kuril Islands and the surrounding fish-rich waters broadened today. South Korea issued a stern warning about the impact on its fishing agreement with Japan if Japan exercised its threatened economic pressure to drive its boats from the area.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Dust Cloud Approaches Coast
description: Health officials warned coastal residents to prepare for an approaching cloud of dust from the Sahara, which, following currents in the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, was expected to come ashore this week. The seasonal African dust storm was expected to reduce visibility and air quality, possibly posing a problem for people with respiratory or heart ailments. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, CHARLES, M.D.
description: STOLZ-Charles, M.D. Passed away peacefully on June 25, 2001. Adored husband of the late Marguerite. Beloved father of Ruth, Andrew and Mary. Cherished grandfather of Sarah and Danielle. Beloved brother of Laura. Beloved uncle, great uncle, great, great uncle and devoted friend and physician to many. We will always love and remember you. Services Thursday, June 28, 2001, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Scholarship Fund Development Office, 1165 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461 in memory of Dr. Charles Stolz.

title: Article 2001062791167900039 -- No Title
description: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

title: Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum, 79, President of Jewish Seminary
description: Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum, president from 1966 to 1971 of the Jewish Theological Seminary, the academic and spiritual center of Conservative Judaism, died June 19 at a nursing home in Plantation, Fla. He was 79 and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Tamarac, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERTY, PETER X.
description: FINNERTY-Peter X. Pace University notes with sorrow the passing of Peter X. Finnerty, devoted friend and former Director of Athletics. Our sympathy is extended to B.J., Brian and the entire family. Aneillo A. Bianco, Chairman David A. Caputo, President

title: Protecting Children, Tempting Pandora
description: Some serious social problems in America may not have good legislative solutions. A case in point could be sex and violence in entertainment.

title: An African Leader's Brief Blaze of Glory
description: The title figure of the director Raoul Peck's whip-smart ''Lumumba'' is on the side of the angels, perhaps because he's an archangel, a celestial figure with a mission. Mr. Peck's engrossing, fleet biographical feature, opening today at Film Forum, shares the driven efficiency of its protagonist, Patrice Lumumba (Eriq Ebouaney), who barreled through his brief tenure as prime minister of Congo with a compulsion to accomplish. His initiative is a terrific motor for a movie, and Lumumba's determination to do what's right, coupled with the horrific end of his life, only adds juice to the engine.

title: Sidemen by Sidemen by Sondheim
description: When you consider the music of Stephen Sondheim with its melodic elegance and harmonic bravery, it's astonishing that so few jazz musicians have integrated it into their repertories the way they have the songs of Gershwin, Rodgers, Berlin and Porter. Among jazz vocalists, Sarah Vaughan's extravagantly lush embellishment of ''Send in the Clowns,'' which she elevated into a late-career showstopper, stands as a singular and dazzling exception. But why should that be?

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Schools Chief Named
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley appointed the deputy chief of staff of Chicago's public schools as the new chief executive of the 435,000-student district. The new executive, Arne Duncan, 36, left, is the son of educators and is married to a teacher. He took a year off from Harvard to work in an after-school tutoring program, and was director of a nonprofit education foundation before joining the public school district in 1998. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUFELD, HENRY
description: KUFELD-Henry. Of South Fallsburg, NY, on June 24, 2001 at age 83. We mourn the passing of Henry ''Buddy'' Kufeld, our beloved uncle, brother-in-law and loving husband of the late Georgia Kufeld, OBM. The last surviving sibling of one of Brooklyn Jewry's foremost families, Buddy bore the name Kufeld with pride and dignity. He served his country with bravery and sacrifice during World War II, and was fully committed to Jewish life in his community. Buddy won our hearts forever with his kind and gentle manner, and devotion of all of his family. We will miss him always. The Krause, Kufeld & Michaelson Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN FRANCIS
description: KELLY-John Francis. On June 25, 2001, after a gallant battle with heart disease. He was a retired psychoanalytic psychotherapist and psychiatric social worker, and more recently an amateur painter. Beloved husband of Eileen Donnellan Kelly, he also is survived by his children Mark, Paul, Abby, and Delia. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday 4-9 P.M. Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street,, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 A.M. Saint Francis Xavier Church. Interment The Green-Wood Cemetery.

title: Entrepreneur Envisions a Cat That Doesn't Cause Allergies
description: Coming next -- genetically modified pets?

title: Indexes Bounce Back From Sharp Decline Early in Day
description: The stock market climbed back from a sharp slide yesterday, with modest gains in the technology sector and modest losses elsewhere, as the Federal Reserve considered its next move on interest rates and investors wondered whether another rate cut would produce lasting results.

title: What Price for Military Readiness?
description: Late last week the Bush administration announced that it would add nearly $20 billion to its original request for the 2002 defense budget. If Congress appropriates that amount, as is likely, the defense budget will increase next year by 7 percent after accounting for inflation. At a time when the United States already spends as much on defense as the world's next eight powers combined, and when the Pentagon budget remains almost 90 percent of its average Cold War level, is such a large increase really necessary?

title: 'Real World's' Reality
description: On Tuesday MTV will reintroduce ''Real World,'' the original, modern-day reality program upon which those that have followed with such great success are arguably based.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay in Circuits on June 14 about the implications of an online hoax about the illness and death of a teenage girl misspelled the surname of a Tennessee digital artist who depends on his computer for social contact. He is Steve Lareau, not Kareau.

title: Agassi Deflects Personal Questions
description: Andre Agassi was eager to discuss the way he had just defused the dangerous Peter Wessels in straight sets today, but he cut short any probes into his previous match or current romance.

title: PATIENTS' RIGHTS PICK UP MOMENTUM IN 2 SENATE VOTES
description: Senate Democrats won two significant victories today as the Senate rejected Republican challenges to provisions of a Democratic bill to define patients' rights for more than 180 million Americans.

title: Pricey Linens Cause a Fray in Mexican Politics
description: Whipped for more than a week by reports of exorbitant spending to redecorate the presidential residence, President Vicente Fox accepted the resignation today of a longtime friend who had been appointed to manage official expenditures.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose on speculation that slowing inflation would allow the European Central Bank to lower interest rates in coming weeks. In New York, the euro settled at 86.34 cents, up from 85.95 cents on Monday.

title: Indians Use Legion of Relievers to Quiet Yankees
description: One night after Ricardo Rincon, Cleveland's left-handed reliever, had surrendered Tino Martinez's game-turning, pinch-hit home run, he walked Jorge Posada to reload the bases with two outs in the seventh inning of a two-run game at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SFORZA, DOROTHY W.
description: SFORZA-Dorothy W. On June 24, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Alfred T. Sforza. Loving mother Jonne W. Sevekow and her husband Fred. Cherished grandmother of Samantha and Fred III. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Tuesday and Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72 St., Thursday, 10AM. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum, Ardsley, New York.

title: John Herbert Dies at 75; Wrote of Prison Life
description: John Herbert, the Canadian playwright whose experiences in a reformatory inspired his influential play about prison homosexuality, ''Fortune and Men's Eyes,'' died on Friday at his home in Toronto. He was 75.

title: Reckonings; Turning California On
description: Those wimpy Californians, with all their fuzzy talk about conservation and their hostility to Big Energy, were supposed to spend this summer sweltering in the dark. But events are not following the script. Summer has begun, yet so far power supplies have been adequate -- and prices have been fairly reasonable. In fact, in the last few days wholesale electricity, which often sold for $750 per megawatt hour this time last year, has been going for less than $100, sometimes less than $50.

title: William Nisselson, 56, Head of Post-Production Film Studio
description: William J. Nisselson, the longtime manager of a post-production film studio that became a haven for generations of famous and not yet famous New York directors, died on June 19 at his office in Manhattan. He was 56 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Laguna Madre Journal; Welcome Mat's Out for Bombing in Scrub Country
description: The rugged country south of here on the shores of Laguna Madre is an inhospitable tangle of mesquite chaparral and sand dunes with more cows than people.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Nuclear Secrets
description: Three weeks before India-Pakistan summit talks, a former head of Pakistan's armed forces has broken the tight secrecy surrounding its nuclear armory by saying Pakistan has a ''bomb-in-the-basement policy'' that assures safety by keeping disassembled bombs at a site many miles from the missiles and aircraft that would deliver them. Lt. Gen. Mirza Islam Beg, in an interview with Reuters television, said Pakistan had achieved a nuclear capability in 1989, nine years before India and Pakistan held tit-for-tat underground tests that confirmed the existence of nuclear arms. He estimated Pakistan's arsenal at about 30. John F. Burns (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Colonel Convicted as Spy

title: The Painter of Pies Knows the Real Thing, Too
description: SUBJECTING Wayne Thiebaud to a $48 breakfast was a mistake.

title: Biggest Spenders For Ads Are Listed
description: Spending leaders for the first quarter of 2001 in large advertising categories like automobiles, financial services and drugs are being identified by CMR in New York, formerly Competitive Media Reporting, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres. Overall ad spending for the first quarter declined 5.2 percent from the period a year earlier, according to CMR.

title: Curbs on Blood Threaten Stocks For the Region
description: The New York City region, already desperately short of blood, stands to lose at least a quarter of its potential blood supply as the Food and Drug Administration moves toward restricting donations from people who may have been exposed to mad cow disease in Europe.

title: Article 2001062793909891209 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Formerly Expelled Student Is Valedictorian
description: At Lafayette High School in Brooklyn, a student who had been temporarily forced from the school last year gave the valedictory speech yesterday at the school's commencement.

title: To Peace On Math's Battlefield
description: FEW disputes in education are as bitter as those between back-to-basics and teach-for-understanding factions in math. Each blames the other for low scores. Each complains that it has been caricatured by the other.

title: Panel Proposes a Revamping of College Sports
description: A panel that includes 14 present and former college presidents proposed a series of remedies yesterday for combating the growing problems associated with college sports.

title: Teamsters Accelerate Drive For End to Federal Oversight
description: The Teamsters today stepped up their effort to persuade the federal government to end the intensive oversight that was undertaken 12 years ago as a way of eliminating mob control of the union.

title: Ask, or Ask Not, What They Would Do to Their Country
description: When President Bush's choices for the nation's appeals courts come before the Senate in the next several weeks, should they be asked such questions as whether they believe that abortion is a constitutional right?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENAKER, OLGA SAN GIULIANO
description: MENAKER-Olga San Giuliano. On June 25, 2001. ASID, interior designer to celebrity homes. Her work has appeared in Architectural Digest among other magazines. She has attended the Harvard School of Design and taught at the New York School of Design. Together with a colleague, she wrote a chapter on color for ''Elements of Interior Design''. She was known for her strong sense of space and color. She leaves behind a sister, Iris San Giuliano Chafen, nephew Lucian Chalfen and stepdaughter Drusilla Menaker. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, June 27th, 6 to 9PM. Service private.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 To Carry MSN Services
description: Level 3 Communications, which operates a large fiber optic network, said it had signed a new three-year agreement with Microsoft to provide broadband Internet access service for MSN Hotmail, MSN Messenger and several other Microsoft services. The new agreement makes Level 3 a primary broadband provider for Microsoft Network and comes just a day after the company announced a similar deal with the Internet service provider EarthLink. Both agreements follow close on the heels of Level 3's announcement last week that it would eliminate the jobs of about 1,400 of its 5,900 employees and reduce capital spending. The Microsoft agreement calls for three gigabits a second of MSN traffic to be routed over the Level 3 network, out of MSN's total traffic of 10 gigabits a second. The contract also specifies that MSN will have the option to steer the entire 10 gigabits a second to the Level 3 network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICONE, JOSEPH
description: PICONE-Joseph. The Board of Directors and shareholders of Fifth 912 Corporation wish to extend their condolences to the family of Joseph Picone recently deceased. Mr. Picone was a longtime resident of 912 Fifth Avenue and a member of the board. May beautiful memories bring comfort to those who mourn his passing.

title: With Such Scallops, Who Needs Free Will?
description: CRAFT invites diners to take a trip. The destination is a simpler, cleaner, more honest America, a place where the corn is bright yellow, the bread exhales clouds of yeasty sweetness and the fish swim in water as pure as vian. It's a vision of food heaven, a land of strong, pure flavors and back-to-basics cooking techniques. It sounds wonderful. But as any motorist knows, the trip to bountiful often seems to involve a few twists and turns, dead ends and unmarked roads that can leave you cursing the map.

title: Nino Cerruti Discreetly Exits the Fashion Stage
description: MILAN  With his signature lemon-yellow sweater around his shoulders and to a standing ovation, Nino Cerruti bowed out of the fashion house he took over from his father at age 20  51 years ago.

title: Robot-Rock Intricacies With Sweet and Dark Spots
description: The French duo Air, which performed at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Thursday night, is a band defined by its reluctance to actually sing. As musicians, especially when it comes to using vintage electronic instruments, the pair Jean-Benot Dunckel and Nicolas Godin are impeccable, always finding the perfect timbre and tone for maximum impact. But when it comes to their own voices, probably because they are unable to achieve the exacting control they have over their instruments, they either use guest singers or resort to masking their natural voices with electronic effects.

title: Liberties; Truth, Sex, Lies and Videotape
description: When I covered the brutal psychodrama of Clarence Thomas and Anita Hill that ferocious week in October '91, I used to wake up in the middle of the night haunted by the mystery of who was telling the Big Lie. How could we put someone on the Supreme Court for life without knowing? But everyone was playing to win, so the truth never really entered into it.

title: From California, Mayonnaise With Miso
description: Considering that vegan hot dogs are now served at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, it's no surprise that an egg-free miso-based mayonnaise-style condiment has also emerged from that part of the world. Miso Mayo, made by So Good Food Company in Venice, Calif., is nicely sharp and tasty, excellent to smear on a turkey sandwich, to use in chicken or potato salad or to mix with yogurt and herbs for a dip. Miso Mayo is about $3.99 for a 9-ounce squeeze bottle at specialty shops around the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHUNY, MINNIE S.
description: GERSHUNY-Minnie S. June 25, 2001. Loving wife of the late Abraham, adoring mother of Barbara Gershuny, and Carol (Keith) Polakoff, and devoted grandmother of Amy Katz, and Adam Polakoff. Services 10 A.M. Thursday June 28 at Riverside Chapel, Flatbush Avenue at Avenue L, Brooklyn.

title: Return to Sender
description: To the Editor:

title: PHELPS SEES A LARGER LOSS BECAUSE OF LOW COPPER PRICES
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second-largest copper producer, said it expected to report a wider loss in the second quarter than it predicted in April, mostly because of falling copper prices. The company, based in Phoenix, said its loss from operations would be $1.28 to $1.38 a share, in contrast to profit from operations of 6 cents a year earlier. On April 27, Phelps Dodge predicted a second-quarter loss of 7 to 12 cents. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected a second-quarter loss of 27 cents a share.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Clarke Enters Tory Race
description: Kenneth Clarke, the popular favorite of the Conservative Party rank and file, became the fifth entry in the party leadership race to succeed William Hague, who is stepping down after the Tories' loss in the June 7 election. Mr. Clarke, the only pro-euro candidate, said the party had been ''poisoned'' by an ''obsession'' with whether Britain should join the European common currency. In an 18-year cabinet career, he has headed the Treasury, the Home Office and the Ministries of Health and Education. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: VICTORY FOR DEVELOPER A developer wrestling for control of a large downtown development site won a victory in court yesterday, when Justice Ira Gammerman denied the Battery Park City Authority's request for a preliminary injunction preventing Brookfield Financial Properties from publicly asserting its rights to the land.
