The authority, the state agency that controls the 92-acre Battery Park City, has wanted to sell the right to build a 1.8-million-square- foot skyscraper at the site on West Street, between Vesey and Murray Streets. But Brookfield has scared off potential buyers by telling rival developers and public officials that it has the exclusive right to develop the site. In March, the authority filed suit in State Supreme Court asking that Brookfield be barred from interfering with the sale. Although Justice Gammerman refused to issue an injunction, he set Oct. 22 as the date for a status conference on the dispute and said he hoped to schedule a trial by the end of the year.

title: What to Make of Thabo Mbeki?
description: When he was elected president of South Africa two years ago, Thabo Mbeki assumed the unenviable task of replacing the sainted Nelson Mandela. He did so at a time when the euphoria of South Africa's historic transition to majority rule was giving way to the inevitable reality of profound social and economic inequities that were bound to endure long past the demise of apartheid. The South African leader, who met yesterday with President Bush, is a complicated man who has accomplished more for his country over the past decade than he is given credit for. But he has tarnished his presidency by crudely smearing his political opponents, declining to speak out clearly against violent political intimidation in neighboring Zimbabwe, and irresponsibly refusing to confront his country's catastrophic AIDS epidemic.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Company Posts Profit
description: The Russian oil company Sibneft said that its profit more than doubled last year, buoyed by decade-high oil prices. Sibneft, Russia's sixth-largest oil producer, reported its 2000 profit rose to $674 million from $315 million in 1999, while revenue rose more than a third, to $2.4 billion. Like other Russian oil companies, Sibneft, which produces 380,000 barrels of oil a day, is benefiting from high world oil prices. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Patent Adds Twist to Software Lawsuit
description: A small developer of software for protecting digital information received a patent yesterday that it said would challenge Microsoft's strategy for linking its next- generation operating system to Internet services and content like digital music.

title: Text of the Federal Reserve Statement on Interest Rates
description: The following statement was released by the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee today:

title: Truth, Sex, Lies and Videotape
description: WASHINGTON — When I covered the brutal psychodrama of Clarence Thomas and Anita Hill that ferocious week in October '91, I used to wake up in the middle of the night haunted by the mystery of who was telling the Big Lie. How could we put someone on the Supreme Court for life without knowing? But everyone was playing to win, so the truth never really entered into it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSTEIN, BEATRICE
description: WILSTEIN-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Hy. Devoted mother of Steven and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Tara and Matthew. Services Wednesday at 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Money: No More, No Less

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Nurses Return To Work
description: About 1,300 nurses at two hospitals in the Minneapolis area ended a three-week strike on Monday after they accepted a new contract. The contract was rejected earlier this month by union officials, who said it did not give nurses enough control over their workload. The new contract includes a 19.8 percent raise over three years and gives a designated nurse the ability to close a unit for two hours if it is understaffed. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Jean Carnahan, a Democrat who was appointed to the Senate from Missouri to replace her late husband, misstated the political post of Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who said Missouri figures prominently in Republicans' plans for retaking the Senate. He is a former chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, not its current chairman.

title: Beware Apple Orchards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, EVELYN (KIKI)
description: KAPLAN-Evelyn (Kiki). On June 23, 2001, at age 76. Beloved wife of Morris. Loving mother of Lois and Steve Panikoff and Jay and Roseanne Kaplan. Adoring grandmother of Sherri, Toni and Jonathan. Dear sister of Louis Goodman. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREAN, HERBERT S., DR.
description: STREAN-Herbert S., Dr. On June 25, 2001. Husband of Marcia. Father of Richard and William. Grandfather of Michael and Andrew. Teacher and psychotherapist of hundreds, he will be remembered for his love and laughter. Services Wednesday, 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: A Census Query Is Said to Skew Data on Latinos
description: The Census Bureau thought it had a new and improved way to count the many Hispanic groups in all their variety, but it appears to have backfired. As a result, New York City officials say, the bureau significantly underestimated the size of several groups, including Dominicans and Colombians.

title: House Backs $5.5 Billion In New Aid For Farmers
description: Warning of a farm crisis across the country, the House today passed an emergency aid package of $5.5 billion for farmers, most of whom already receive federal subsidies.

title: The Republicans in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's Republican Party shifted from its moderate course yesterday when G.O.P. primary voters chose Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City as their candidate for governor in the November elections. The challenge now for Mr. Schundler, in defeating former Congressman Bob Franks, who had the solid support of the state party leadership, will be twofold. He must wage a vigorous and issue-oriented campaign against James McGreevey, his Democratic opponent and the man who lost by a scant 1 percent four years ago in his race against Christie Whitman, then the popular incumbent. Mr. Schundler must also repair a frayed Republican Party that has been forced into two angry camps by this surprisingly bitter primary.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Reorganization
description: Spain's largest banking group, BSCH, created two years ago by the alliance of Banco Santander and Central Hispano, plans to cut costs by merging its leading brands, closing branches, selling property and encouraging senior executives to retire early. The plan is intended to reduce costs by 150 billion pesetas ($775 million) while maintaining annual profit growth of at least 20 percent over the next two years and resolving an internal management conflict that has dogged the bank since the merger. BSCH has been hit by economic weakness in Latin America, where it is a leading investor, and says it will shut 1,000 of its 5,000 branches in Spain. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Jets Sign Clark,A Free Agent
description: Maurice Clark, a 5-foot-11, 220-pound free-agent running back who averaged 4.25 yards a carry at Eastern Kentucky the last two seasons, signed with the Jets yesterday. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Alzheimer's Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRENZIS, HARRY
description: KRENZIS-Harry. The Seagate Association expresses its condolences on the passing of Harry Krenzis, lifelong resident and former Chairman and President of The Board of Directors of the Seagate Association. We extend our sincere sympathy to the entire family. Chairperson and President of the Board, Lucille Katz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYKER, LYNN B.
description: WYKER-Lynn B. Peacefully on June 25, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving sister of Karen Stark and the late Augusta Berin, Roxanne Kamenstein, William Berke and Harold Berke. Adored and missed by her many nieces, nephews and godchildren, but forgotten by no one who knew and loved her. Services private.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wine Designed For Hot and Humid Times
description: AMERICANS have never given ros wines any respect. In fact, when American wine producers want to market a ros aggressively, they give it a new name, like white zinfandel or blush, and doctor it with sugar.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: 6 Hurt In Explosion
description: Six people were injured yesterday morning in an explosion in the basement of a two-story frame house on Staten Island, the Fire Department said. The explosion, at 90 Laurel Avenue, led to a fire that took 20 minutes to contain, said Jimmy Maguire, a department spokesman. The injured people were taken to Bayley Seton Hospital on Staten Island. The status of the patients was not immediately available. The cause of the explosion has not yet been determined, but a gas leak has not been ruled out.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Tight Retail Spaces Prompt Suit by the Disabled
description: Every inch of retail space is valuable in Manhattan. And few retailers seem to pack as much into that inch as the ever-growing Duane Reade chain.

title: A Mexican Spot Preserves an Echo of Its Latin Roots
description: IN the mid-1990's, when Rocking Horse in Chelsea was known as Rocking Horse Cafe Mexicano, it eliminated Tex-Mex cooking from its menu in favor of what its owners, Roe DiBona and Marvin Beck, called contemporary Mexican cuisine. This was instrumental in changing the way New York looked at Mexican food. Though Rocking Horse served dishes that might not ever be seen in Mexico City, like tamales stuffed with cornmeal and sweet duck confit served in a pear and habanero sauce, it was resolute in its use of authentic seasonings. In spirit, it was indisputably Mexican.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Setback For I.R.A.
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, lost its chance to have its first Lord Mayor of Belfast when the cross-community Alliance Party withdrew its support because of the I.R.A.'s continuing refusal to begin disarming. In local elections on June 7, Sinn Fein emerged with the largest number of council seats and expected that its longest-serving councillor, Alex Maskey, would get the largely ceremonial Lord Mayor's position for a year. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Radio Days and Reality TV
description: Looking back, it was a nightmare being married to Holland's biggest celebrity, Willeke Alberti. I was 19 when we married. She was 10 years older, and she was also a huge, huge celebrity, the biggest singer and actress in the country. We were followed everywhere by cameras. In those days, the paparazzi were more innocent than they are these days with the incredible competition between the yellow newspapers.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Rooms Near the Airport
description: The first new hotel to be built near Kennedy International Airport in Queens in more than 15 years opened yesterday, alleviating -- at least a bit -- what industry experts have called a long-standing dearth of accommodations in the area. The hotel, a 14-story Marriott Courtyard at 135th and Inwood Avenues, is marketing itself to travelers seeking moderately priced accommodations. It has 166 guest rooms, meeting space, a restaurant, a lounge and a gym. It also offers shuttle service to airport facilities and Midtown. The opening was heralded as an important part of the airport's revitalization process, and a welcome addition to the Queens landscape, said Borough President Claire Shulman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIE, BERNARD
description: SOBIE-Bernard. On June 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Estelle. Dear and devoted father of Michele, Brian and Ruth. Adoring grandfather of Ana-Nicole and Zachary. Dear brother of Minna Karen. We will all miss you. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Hazelden Foundation, 233 East 17 Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: Stocks End Mixed After Fed Rate Cut
description: Some small gamesmanship aside, investors yawned today at the Federal Reserve's sixth interest-rate reduction this year, having fooled themselves twice before.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption yesterday about the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on AIDS in New York misspelled the name of the president of the General Assembly. He is Harri Holkeri, not Harry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFAND, ESTHER
description: GELFAND-Esther. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Esther Gelfand, beloved mother of our devoted members Isabelle and Dr. Simon Wapnick. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column on June 19 about a concert series in Central Park misspelled the names of the series and the site. The series is the Naumburg Orchestral Concerts, at the Naumburg Bandshell, not Naumberg.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: No Bank Sale
description: One of two major banks taken over by the government at the height of South Korea's economic crisis in December 1997, SeoulBank, will remain for sale for several more months at least. The government committee responsible for selling the bank acknowledged that it had failed in another attempt to persuade a foreign bank to take it over. The committee, which had set a deadline of June 30, now hopes to complete a deal by fall. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl's Death Ruled A Homicide
description: The medical examiner ruled yesterday that a 9-year-old girl's death in a school bathroom was a homicide. The girl, Denesha Blow, died after a fight with another girl May 24 at Public School 155 in Brownsville, Brooklyn. An autopsy showed that she died of acute bronchial asthma, but that the fight was a significant contributing factor, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. No charges have been filed against the other girl, but the investigation is continuing, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Macedonian Leader, Warning of Civil War, Urges Calm
description: Tension in Macedonia's capital eased a notch today, even as the president warned how close the nation is skidding toward civil war and as NATO defended its role in a mission here that propelled thousands of angry Macedonians onto the streets on Monday night.

title: Colombia's Repatriated P.O.W.'s Face Tough Adjustment
description: His 14 months as a prisoner of war included pain, despair and the sinking feeling that he would never be released. But when lvaro Acosta, a police colonel captured by rebel forces last year, was told that he would be liberated on June 5, his whole body shook with dread of the unknown world that awaited him.

title: Schundler Wins G.O.P. Primary In New Jersey Governor's Race
description: Bret D. Schundler, the crusading conservative mayor of Jersey City, soundly defeated former Representative Bob Franks in the Republican primary for governor today, setting up a sharply drawn November contest with James E. McGreevey, the Democrat.

title: Family Sorrow After Killing Of Teenager In Bronx Store
description: Carol Tyler turned 18 yesterday, but instead of celebrating she spent the day in shock over the shooting death of a former boyfriend who, his family said, was always trying to better himself.

title: Chenay Beach Resort
description: Five nights for the price of four: that's the deal through Dec. 20 at the Chenay Beach Resort, on 30 acres of a former sugar plantation along the beach on St. Croix, in the United States Virgin Islands. There are 50 cottages with equipped kitchens, air-conditioning and porches. Rates start at $157.50 a night. Also, children 18 or younger can stay for free if they share accommodations with adults, and children under 12 eat free. Contact (800) 548-4457 or www.chenaybay.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Adds Video To Instant Messaging
description: Yahoo is adding video capacity to its instant-messaging service, the company said yesterday. Instant messaging is one of the most popular Internet services, but Yahoo's product is used less than those of its competitors, the America Online service of AOL Time Warner and the MSN unit of Microsoft. According to Jupiter Media Metrix, AOL's downloadable instant-messaging application had 25.5 million users in May and Microsoft's service on the MSN network had 18.4 million. Yahoo had just 11.8 million users. The quality of video is expected to be low -- about one frame a second -- which is far less than regular streaming video, but is enough to let users be more expressive in their chats, said Lisa Pollock, Yahoo's messaging products director. Yahoo also entered a marketing agreement with Logitech, a maker of Webcams. Beginning in July, all Logitech Webcams sold in North America and in certain countries in Europe and Australia will be bundled with Yahoo Messenger.

title: McGreevey Prepares to Go Up Against His Real Opponent
description: After campaigning for four years to reclaim the Democratic nomination for New Jersey governor, James E. McGreevey had little time to savor his victory tonight. No sooner had he finished delivering his acceptance speech in the grand ballroom of the Sheraton Hotel here than the television monitors in the hall flashed an image that could force the McGreevey campaign to overhaul, or even scrap, its campaign playbook.

title: Retired Army Employee, 74, Is Found Guilty of Spying
description: A federal court jury in Florida today convicted a retired civilian employee of the Army of spying for the Soviet Union and then Russia over at least 25 years.

title: Fedders to Cut 800 Jobs and Close a Plant
description: The Fedders Corporation plans to cut 800 jobs, close a Maryland plant and move some air-conditioner production to Asia.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST WASHINGTON: DEPUTY TO BE REINSTATED The county sheriff in Seattle said he would appeal a ruling that forces him to reinstate a deputy who pepper-sprayed two women in a car, and kicked one of them, in the 1999 World Trade Organization protests. An arbitrator decided that the deputy, John Vanderwalker, a 19-year veteran of the force, should receive a 10-day suspension for his conduct against the women, who were videotaping skirmishes between the police and protesters.

title: Head Injury Mars the Debut of Pro Boxing on the Intrepid
description: Professional boxing made its debut on the flight deck of the U.S.S. Intrepid in Manhattan last night. But the picturesque setting was marred when one of the fighters sustained a head injury.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sale Talks End
description: The Body Shop International said that talks to sell its 1,840 health and beauty products stores to Grupo Omnilife, a multilevel marketing company based in Mexico, had ended. The company, founded by Anita Roddick and her husband, T. Gordon Roddick, said earlier this month that it was in preliminary discussions with Grupo Omnilife. But those talks failed to produce a concrete offer, the company said. Body Shop's shares fell 18.5 pence (26 cents) a share, to 96 pence, in London. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My major criterion for conversion is sincerity. You've got to convince me of your desire to become Jewish.''

title: 7-2 Russian Is Set to Take Another Shot
description: Lou Fugazy, the boxing promoter, recalled the night of May 31, 1997, when he first saw Nikolai Valuev, a 7-foot-2-inch Russian heavyweight, in the ring. It was in Atlantic City and Valuev was fighting Terrell Nelson, a promising 6-4 heavyweight from Plainfield, N.J.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Deputy To Be Reinstated
description: The county sheriff in Seattle said he would appeal a ruling that forces him to reinstate a deputy who pepper-sprayed two women in a car, and kicked one of them, in the 1999 World Trade Organization protests. An arbitrator decided that the deputy, John Vanderwalker, a 19-year veteran of the force, should receive a 10-day suspension for his conduct against the women, who were videotaping skirmishes between the police and protesters. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: In California Bullfights, the Final Deed Is Done With Velcro
description: By day, Dennis Borba could be mistaken for just another Central Valley rancher in a T-shirt and red pickup truck. But come Monday nights at this torrid time of year, he puts on his glimmering ''suit of lights,'' custom-made in Madrid, and becomes Matador Borba, grabbing a handful of dirt and crossing himself before stepping into the bullring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JACOB M.
description: SHAPIRO-Jacob M. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and Past President and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Cong. B'nai Israel of Freeport Reuben Katz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan Dicken, Rabbi Florence Helfand, President

title: U.N. Assembly Votes Today On Decree to Combat AIDS
description: The General Assembly is expected to declare on Wednesday that all countries should ''protect all human rights and fundamental freedoms'' of groups most at risk of AIDS and address the epidemic ''to confront stigma, silence and denial'' and ''eliminate discrimination.''

title: Metro Business Briefing | Faster Service, More Often
description: Starting July 9, travelers along Amtrak's Northeast corridor will have access to more frequent weekday service on Acela Express between New York and Washington, as Amtrak doubles service on the route, with six trains in each direction. Departures from Washington will be at 5 a.m., 7 a.m., 7:25 a.m., 2 p.m., 3 p.m. and 5:30 p.m. From New York, departures for Washington will be at 7:30 a.m., 10 a.m., 11 a.m., 3:50 p.m., 7 p.m. and 9 p.m. Amtrak will also add another weekday round trip between New York and Boston on Acela Express, with trains departing from Boston's South Station at 6:12 a.m., 7:12 a.m., 3:12 p.m., 5:12 p.m. and 6:42 p.m. From New York, departures for Boston will be at 7:03 a.m., 8:03 a.m., 10:03 a.m., 5 p.m. and 6 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXEL, ELAINE
description: AXEL-Elaine. Cherished sister, beloved aunt. Your devotion was always in the heart of our lives. Louise and Susan Miller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINN, THEODORE
description: ZINN-Theodore. Age 66 of New York City. Encyclopedia editor, survived by loving family and friends.

title: Article 2001062790547896400 -- No Title
Palestinians Say Halting All Violence Is Impossible
description: The Palestinian government believes that Israel is trying ''to forestall a return to meaningful political negotiations'' by setting the ''unattainable'' standard of a complete halt in violence, according to an internal Palestinian memorandum that is circulating in advance of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's arrival here on Wednesday.

title: Using Intellect and Anger in Service Against AIDS
description: DR. ANNE-VALRIE KANINDA does not look like a big mouth. She is unassuming and quiet-spoken. Aside from her funky wire-rimmed glasses, what stands out most about her is a keen intellect that does not bang you over the head like a hammer.

title: Mexico Is Sputtering on Road to the World Cup
description: The World Cup qualifying match between the United States and Mexico here at Azteca Stadium on Sunday could shift the continent's soccer landscape almost as much as the Mexican-American war reshaped its map a century and a half ago.

title: Students Learn That Social Change Is Not an Outdated Concept
description: NEW MARKET, Tenn., June 19  Not long after midnight, Brandeis University's Sociology 156a rolled off Interstate 40 at Exit 68 into the TA Truck Stop. Young women toted toiletries into the restroom, young men folded themselves into phone booths to dial mothers and girlfriends. David Cunningham, assistant professor of sociology, popped in two quarters for a video game of Galaga.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Timing Unclear
description: President Vojislav Kostunica said former President Slobodan Milosevic could not be handed over to the war crimes tribunal at The Hague before an international conference Friday on aid for Yugoslavia, because he is entitled to appeal his transfer. The United States has pressed Yugoslavia to hand over Mr. Milosevic before the conference. Mr. Milosevic's lawyers are challenging his extradition but said they expect that he will be turned over by Friday. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Return to Sender
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Author Says He Lied in His Attacks on Anita Hill in Bid to Aid Justice Thomas
description: The author of a best-selling book that attacked the credibility of Anita F. Hill has disavowed its premise, and now says that he lied in print to protect the reputation of Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Unions Say Labor Department Is Ignoring Wage Requirements
description: The two largest farm worker unions sued the Labor Department last week, accusing it of bowing to employer pressures and illegally failing to raise wages for more than 30,000 foreign guest workers.

title: Efforts to Save Wetlands Are Inadequate, Study Says
description: A decade-old government program allowing landowners to destroy some wetlands if they create or restore others is failing, a panel of top scientists said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: School Computer Money Approved
description: Gov. Angus King's vision of providing every student in the state with a laptop computer appears to be moving forward despite widespread initial skepticism. The Legislature has approved $30 million for the program, not the $50 million the governor had wanted, but a start. Governor King must now raise $15 million from private donors. The plan has been refined since he first proposed it in March 2000; it would lend laptops to seventh- and eighth-grade students rather than providing them outright. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Bear Stearns Chairman Steps Down and 3 Others Move Up
description: In a long-anticipated transfer of power, the Bear Stearns Companies announced yesterday that its chairman, Alan C. Greenberg, was stepping down from that post. James E. Cayne, the chief executive, will also become its chairman.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Philips Will Quit Making Mobile Telephones
description: Reversing a costly foray into mobile phone manufacturing, Royal Philips Electronics said today that it would abandon the handset-making business completely, except for a minority stake in a Chinese joint venture.

title: Affirmative Action Foe Picked for Rights Post
description: The Bush Administration has nominated Gerald A. Reynolds, a lawyer and staunch opponent of affirmative action, to head the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights, the division responsible for protecting the civil rights of minorities, women and disabled people from kindergarten through graduate school.

title: A Mad Lord Hooting From the Mantel
description: The four-hour fantasy ''Gormenghast'' arrived on the BBC last year alongside huge hype, a merchandising campaign hawking earrings and cuff links, and newspaper articles pointing out that Sting's daughter Fuchsia and his racehorse Steerpike were named after characters in the novels on which the mini-series is based. But when it slips into a low-profile summer slot on PBS tonight, American viewers are likely to say, ''Gormen who?''

title: For City Graduates, Some Parting Words of Wisdom
description: Public high schools across New York City held graduations yesterday. Following are excerpts from commencement addresses.

title: Clinton Fulfills a Request at Graduation
description: ''Dear President Clinton, I am writing you to invite you to my high school graduation.'' So began the March 1 letter to Bill Clinton from Sophia Velez, a senior at the Professional Performing Arts School, a public school in New York City.

title: Natural Spots for Natural Food
description: BELL BATES 97 Reade Street at Hudson Street, (212) 267-4300. Organic grocery prices: 1 pound bananas, 99 cents; half-gallon milk, $2.79; dozen eggs, $3.29. Delivery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNST, HOWARD L.
description: ERNST-Howard L., on June 18. Son of the late Abraham Ernst & the late Beatrice Ernst Daffner. Brother of Judith Linn and Naomi Paley. Nephew of E. Billi Ivry. Funeral service is to be held at ''The Riverside'' Memorial Chapel, 9:45AM, Thursday, June 28.

title: A Prizewinner Is Almost Family
description: NBC did not broadcast the edition of its hit game show ''Weakest Link'' that had been planned on Monday night for one extremely odd reason:

title: FEELING THE SLOWDOWN, OLIN WILL CUT ITS WORK FORCE 14%
description: The Olin Corporation, a producer of metals, chemicals and ammunition, cut its full-year earnings forecast by half and will lay off more than 900 people, or 14 percent of its work force, citing a weak economy. Olin, based in Norwalk, Conn., lowered its 2001 earnings forecast to 50 cents a share from $1. Olin had been expected to earn 83 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Olin, which makes rolled metals and foils, chemicals used in papermaking and bleach, and Winchester brand bullets, said it was making the cuts because it did not expect economic conditions to improve this year.

title: Fighting for Dominance on a Stretch of 42nd Street
description: A 30-year-old tug of war on West 42nd Street has flared up again, pitting two old New York real estate families -- one quite wealthy and the other much less so -- against each other. Millions of dollars are at stake on this grimy piece of 42nd Street west of Avenue of the Americas.

title: Gay Health Ads in Bus Shelters Are Pulled After Complaints
description: Responding to complaints, a company that maintains the city's bus shelters has removed a public service ad at several bus stops in the Bronx that promoted a free health line for gays and lesbians.

title: Mets' Offense Produces Sounds of Silence
description: Dave Engle's workday begins early, before most of the Mets have started theirs. Today, it began under the right-field bleachers, in the Wrigley Field batting cage he described as terrible and dangerous.

title: House Votes to Restrict Mexican Trucking
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to prohibit Mexican trucks from using highways in the United States beyond 20 miles of the border.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Italy's jobless rate fell to the lowest level in more than eight years in April, as farms and construction companies stepped up hiring. The rate fell to 9.6 percent, the lowest since January 1993, from a revised 9.8 percent in January, the statistics office Istat said in a quarterly report. Silvio Berlusconi, who became prime minister this month, has promised to create 1.5 million jobs in the next five years by cutting taxes and spending $35 billion on public works, including a 3.5 kilometer (2.2 mile) bridge to connect Sicily to mainland Italy. The country has Europe's fourth-largest economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 18 about a fire and explosion that killed three firefighters at the Long Island General Supply Company, a hardware store in Queens, misidentified its founder. The store was founded by Morris M. Reichman and later sold to Alec Gordon.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Collecting Beame Memorabilia

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Brad Palmerio, Asbury Park, N.J., May 5, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, EDWARD A., JR., M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Edward A., Jr., M.D. Of Mt. Kisco, NY. Died peacefully June 23, 2001, after a long illness. Son of the late Edward and Lucille Friedman. Beloved husband of Sue (Richman). Loving father of Doug and Diana (Frost), James and Kendra (Boeckman), Edward III, Laurence and Judi (Landzberg). Devoted grandfather of Max and Kyle, Justin and Evan, and Spencer and Oliver. Loving brother of Enid Randall (Friedman) and wonderful son-in-law of Lucile Richman. A graduate of New York Medical College, he practiced as pediatrician and allergist in Westchester County for 40 years. On staff at Northern Westchester Hospital and Westchester County Medical Center. Proud veteran of W.W. II and the Korean War. Ed was a world traveler, an accomplished photographer, enthusiastic amateur actor, world class collector of a variety of arts and antiques including museumdisplayed 1939 World's Fair memorabilia, lifelong jazz enthusiast, witty raconteur and warm companion. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 27, at 1:30 PM at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY, 914-666-4840. Family will be receiving visitors Tuesday, June 26, 6-9 PM at Cassidy-Flynn. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Lung Association or Doctors without Borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, EUGENIA DAVIS
description: NORTH-Eugenia Davis. On June 23, 2001 in Dallas, TX. Beloved mother of Frederick Lee Liebolt, Jr. Loving grandmother of Cristina Walton Liebolt. Devoted aunt of Eugenia Hastings McDaniel and Raymond Lamar McDaniel. Funeral Thursday in Dallas. Burial Saturday in Independence, MO. Thompson's Harveson & Cole Funeral Home, Fort Worth, TX 817-336-0345.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, STEVEN D., PH.D.
description: ROTH-Steven D., Ph.D., on June 25, 2001, at age 56. A graduate of MIT and NYU. Beloved husband of Margaret. Devoted father of Deborah Firfer and her husband Brett, Miriam Dulny and her husband Chaim, and Andrew Roth. Loving grandfather of Chana. Cherished son of Nathaniel Roth and his wife Sophie and the late Dorothy. Dear brother of Vivian Lubin and her husband Don. Brother-in-law of Rosalie Young. Fond nephew of Esther Frankel and Martin Roth. Dear uncle and friend. Services are today, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. He will be sorely missed.

title: Tears of Joy At Graduation For Girls Only
description: THE happiest and saddest place in New York yesterday was a hall in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, just past the Egyptian mummies.

title: Resurrecting La Lupe, a Wild and Soulful Singer Whose Life Fell Apart
description: In a testimonial at church, La Lupe spoke in rapid staccato, her words coming out in short bursts of energy as raspy as her singing voice. ''They call me La Lupe, La Yiyiyi, the queen of Latin song,'' she said.

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Corporate Welfare
description: In his April budget proposals, President Bush indicated his intent to follow through on a campaign pledge to end many of the federal subsidies to business known collectively as corporate welfare. Now, with opposition mounting to his plan to end loan guarantees for risky commercial shipbuilders, Mr. Bush faces the first test of his resolve. Given his longstanding ties to corporate America and an otherwise overwhelmingly pro-business agenda, the president is well positioned to cut such subsidies without appreciable damage to his political base. In the case of the shipbuilders' loan guarantees, Mr. Bush also has the logic of national security and economics on his side. These are reasons enough to stand up to the members of Congress who want the subsidy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, DORELLE
description: TANNER-Dorelle. The Officers and Directors of The Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner, and extend deepest sympathy to her family and friends. Dorelle Tanner served The Garden Club with great distinction and extraordinary ability as its 19th President (1971-1973) and in many other capacities. Beginning in 1953, she served as Treasurer and Vice President for two terms. She also served as Chairman of The Endowment Fund Drive, and Chairman of The Finance and Nominating Committees. A member of The Greenwich Connecticut Garden Club, Mrs. Tanner was a talented and gentle person, who loved life. The successive offices she held in The Garden Club of America speak eloquently of her many accomplishments.

title: Reform Judaism Nears a Guide to Conversion
description: The rabbinical leadership of Judaism's liberal Reform movement is poised to adopt a broad set of guidelines on conversion to Judaism that will embrace traditional practices once rejected by Reform leaders, urge that converts make certain commitments to Jewish life and also formally extend a strong welcome to men and women considering converting.

title: Our Towns; Victory Lap Takes Turn From Right
description: MONDAY afternoon, with the Republican primary election still a day away, Bret D. Schundler was already looking toward November. ''I never believed it was my right to dictate to people,'' said Mr. Schundler, the candidate of New Jersey's rarely visible right wing.

title: Death Penalty Ignites a Musical Coalition
description: Michael Franti has questioned the death penalty for as long as he can remember. Drawn to both underground music and radicalism since his teens, Mr. Franti, whose band, Spearhead, plays tonight at the Wetlands Preserve, considers his opposition natural. He has organized events supporting Mumia Abu-Jamal, perhaps the most famous convict on death row in the United States, and for years has criticized the criminal justice system on panels and in interviews. But until ''Stay Human'' on Six Degrees Records, Spearhead's latest album, this pioneering alternative hip-hop artist had never visited death row in a song.

title: A Central Bank in All Directions; Diverging National Interests Skew European Monetary Union
description: Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the Bank of France and a governor of the European Central Bank, provided a vivid lesson not long ago of how the European common currency has not produced a common economic viewpoint.

title: Different Paths To the Door Of Stardom
description: Kwame Brown and Tyson Chandler are about to become millionaires. The Washington Wizards' president, Michael Jordan, will most likely make one of them the first high school player ever selected No. 1 in an N.B.A. draft. The other will be drafted within the next few slots.

title: ABC Cuts Child Interviews After Their Parents Object
description: ABC News has agreed to remove an interview with schoolchildren from a coming special on the environment after their parents said they had been misled about the nature of the questioning when they permitted their children to participate.

title: Film Dreams Appear to Fade in Red Ink for Manhattan Company
description: The Shooting Gallery, a fast-growing film company that once helped fuel New York's ambitions of creating Hollywood-on-the-Hudson, is heavily in debt and desperately trying to stay afloat, a spokesman for its new parent company said yesterday.

title: Article 2001062792028799463 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Your Thoughts About Pennies
description: To the Editor:

title: Boxer's Death By Hanging Stuns Family And Friends
description: By all accounts, the young man who was rescued from the streets by a passion for boxing had a real shot at making his mark as a world-class fighter.

title: A Last Chance in Macedonia
description: Macedonians were out in the streets here Monday night protesting the way the international community has involved itself in the four-month conflict with Albanian rebels called the National Liberation Army. In front of the parliament, demonstrators burned the flag of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and pictures of the European Union envoy Javier Solana.

title: Losses Posted For Quarter By Palm Inc. And 3Com
description: Reflecting the pervasive nature of the high-technology sector's continuing slump, the biggest maker of hand-held computers and a top computer networking equipment manufacturer reported losses today.

title: Tiger Woods and Me
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPIN, REV. LEO F.
description: HALPIN-Rev. Leo F. Former teacher at Cardinal Hayes High School on June 24, 2001. Brother of Paul J. Halpin and the late Brother John Halpin. Uncle of Jeannette Thatcher, Paula Meyer, Sister Catherine Halpin, R.D.C. and James Halpin. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday June 28 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Mary's Hospice, 5447 Andersonville Pike, Knoxville, TN 37938.

title: Accessories Show Off Their Stuff at Florence Fair
description: FLORENCE  Some see fashion as an evil ringmaster, cracking the whip and making us jump through hoops: a concept that inspired Alexander McQueen's sinister Merry-Go-Round collection for autumn 2001.

title: Aftershocks from a ruling that farmers don't have to chip in to campaigns to promote food products.
description: MADISON AVENUE'S shopping list of accounts devoted to campaigns for products from beef and avocados to milk and plums -- together representing billions of dollars in spending -- could suddenly be shortened after a ruling by the United States Supreme Court. But those involved in the ad campaigns contended that many of them should still survive the blow.

title: Buddy Systems
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From honeymooning in Greece to volunteering on vacation, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Entering Race, Ferrer Focuses On Giuliani
description: Fernando Ferrer entered the race for mayor yesterday by moving aggressively to separate himself from his Democratic rivals. He declared that he would be the advocate for ''the other New York,'' which he said had been neglected over the past eight years, and suggested that his opponents were ''sheep'' who had routinely supported the policies of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Quake Toll Passes 100
description: Civil defense officials have raised the death toll from Saturday's powerful earthquake in southern Peru to 102 dead, with 53 people still missing. The earthquake, which had its epicenter just off the Peruvian coast, left 1,368 people injured and destroyed 11,000 homes in the area of Arequipa, Peru's second largest city. President Valentin Paniagua has declared a state of emergency. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Antitrust Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court overturned Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling to break up the Microsoft Corporation today, and it ordered the judge removed from the case, saying his actions "seriously tainted the proceedings."

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Glasses So Smart They Know Just What You're Looking At
description: READING glasses are the lot of most people over 45, but lenses that magnify fine print blur objects more than an arm's length away.

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001062893190814665 -- No Title
description: This is a lifelong dream.

title: Lucent and JDS Uniphase Prepare for More Job Cuts
description: Concern over weakness in the telecommunications industry heightened yesterday as two large companies, Lucent Technologies and JDS Uniphase, prepared for additional job cuts.

title: 2 Women's Teams Selected For Championships in Bali
description: As a result of women's trials that ended Tuesday in Las Vegas, two world-class women's teams will represent the United States in the Venice Cup competition at the World Championships in Bali, Indonesia, in October. The winning team was headed by Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex., who will make her first major international appearance. She was supported by five players who have already won world titles: Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Randi Montin of Napa, Calif.; Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.; and Irina Levitina of Teaneck, N.J.

description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USSAK, SAMUEL
description: USSAK-Samuel. Beloved husband of Hannah. Loving father of Celia and Lillian. Devoted father-in-law of Mark & Richard. Dear brother of Robert. Ecstatic grandfather of Sarah and Rebecca. Services today 12 noon ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: French Judges Seek to Question Chirac, His Wife and Daughter
description: Troubles continue to mount for President Jacques Chirac.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: FALLING UNEMPLOYMENT The jobless rate has dropped more in New York City than in any other big metropolis over the last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The unemployment rate in the city has dropped by 0.6 percentage points, from 5.5 percent in May 2000 to 4.9 percent in May 2001, the bureau said. Two other major metropolitan areas  which the bureau defines as those with more than one million residents in 1990  had declines of 0.5 points: Indianapolis and Riverside, Calif. Because of the national economic slowdown, unemployment rates have risen in many cities. The biggest increase was in Charlotte, N.C.; the jobless rate rose by 2.3 percentage points, to 5.3 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Article 2001062892541130094 -- No Title
Metro Business Briefing | Daily News Names Business Editor
description: David Andelman, a journalist who has worked for The New York Times, CBS News, CNBC and Bloomberg News, was named business editor of The Daily News yesterday. In a statement, Edward Kosner, the editor in chief of The News, said that Mr. Andelman would succeed Scott Wenger, who was made a deputy metropolitan editor. Mr. Andelman became the deputy business editor in January. He was the editor in chief of smallcapcenter.com, a financial news site, before joining The News.

title: Two-for-One Cruise Rates
description: Fred Olsen Line is expanding its fleet starting in August with the Braemar, a refurbished version of the former Crown Dynasty. To help people remember the new name, it is offering two-for-one rates, meaning two passengers share a cabin for the single rate shown in brochures (except for suites, which are 40 percent off). The itineraries covered under this offer range from Norway to the Baltic to the Adriatic to the Mediterranean, with a 14-night Christmas cruise from Malaga to Barbados departing Dec. 19. On Aug. 24, for example, a seven-night cruise to Norway leaves from Dover, England; On Oct. 12, there's a 13-night cruise through the western Mediterranean leaving from Southampton, England. Most trips are 10 to 14 nights. Before the discounts, rates range from $1,180 to $9,410 a person, based on double occupancy. And for all 2002 cruises booked six months in advance, there is a 30 percent discount. Information: EuroCruises, (800) 688-3876 or www.eurocruises.com .

title: A Way to See the World In True Colors on a Computer
description: Picking colors online can be fraught with problems. You order a T-shirt that appears to be a soft green described as ''pistachio'' on a Web site, for example, and the garment that arrives might better be described as ''fresh lime.''

title: Article 2001062891198959683 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Trims Loss
description: The graphics chip maker ATI Technologies Inc., of Thornhill, Ontario, said its loss narrowed to $27 million, or 12 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter. ATI reported a loss of $128.8 million, or 58 cents, in the period a year earlier, when it slipped to second place in the desktop computer market. It remains the leader in the mobile market. ATI's president, David Orton, above, attributed the improvement to gains in efficiency. ''We have aggressively reduced inventories, which has greatly improved our cash position, without having to resort to write-offs,'' he said. The company reported that improved gross margins of 27.2 percent on sales of $255.9 million helped to offset an 11.2 percent decline in revenue from the period a year earlier. Robert M. Frank (NYT)

title: Emergency Agency Flight Draws Criticism
description: Joe Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, turned a routine business trip to Florida and Puerto Rico last week into a controversial $340,000 flight on one of the nation's most sophisticated flying command centers, designed for use in national emergencies.

title: Souping Up the Cell Phone
description: WHEN Farhan Thawar whips out his cell phone to dial a number, he calls attention to himself.

title: U.N. REDEFINES AIDS AS POLITICAL ISSUE AND PERIL TO POOR
description: The General Assembly approved an ambitious declaration tonight outlining how the world should proceed in its fight against AIDS. Concluding its three-day special session on the pandemic, the world body also made a plea to nations and private industry alike to provide the billions of dollars needed to help pay for the mission.

title: Article 2001062892524339168 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Metro Business Briefing | Film Company Cuts Jobs
description: The Shooting Gallery, a financially troubled film company in the West Village best known for producing the 1996 art house hit ''Sling Blade,'' has dismissed most of its employees, its parent company announced yesterday. The company, founded in 1990, was acquired on May 1 by Itemus, an Internet company in Toronto. The Shooting Gallery, which employed 275 people a year ago, has been dismissing workers for several months, and an Itemus spokesman was unable to say how many employees remained there. On Tuesday, employees of the Shooting Gallery and its Gun-for-Hire Production Center at 110 Leroy Street were notified by e-mail that their jobs would be terminated. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF CANADA, Ottawa, the central bank in Canada, has hired the Electronic Data Systems Corp., to help run a program that sells Canada's savings bonds and other types of debt to the public.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ex-President In Court
description: Joseph Estrada, the ousted president, refused to enter a plea yesterday to the first of several criminal charges stemming from a corruption scandal that drove him from office in January. The court entered a plea of not guilty on his behalf to the charge of perjury. Next month, Mr. Estrada faces charges of graft and economic plunder that carry a possible death penalty. Thousands of troops guarded the courthouse in Manila, though only a few dozen protesters rallied outside. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: French Court Approves Extradition of American Fugitive
description: RENNES, France, June 28  A French court today agreed to extradite James Charles Kopp, an American anti-abortion activist accused in the sniper killing of an upstate New York doctor.

title: At Center of Senate Battle, a Lawyer and a Doctor
description: Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, says his 20 years as a trial lawyer left him with an unshakeable belief that ''regular folks'' deserve a level playing field in fights with corporate giants like health maintenance organizations and insurance companies. And the belief that insurance companies, in the end, respond to the bottom line.

title: Personal Shopper: Secret Sources in the Hamptons
description: AT the end of country lanes and behind garage doors lie the hidden sources that service the high-maintenance Hamptons. And while professionals and antiques dealers use some of the places to refinish furniture and rewire broken lamps, you don't have to be a professional or live in the Hamptons to use them. And there are also great sources for accessories off the main road.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Internet Access
description: A regulator ordered British Telecommunications to make it easier for rivals to offer high-speed Internet services by installing competitors' equipment in its local phone exchanges without charge. The regulator said British Telecommunications could charge competitors a connection fee of 127 ($180) plus 68 ($96) a year for use of the copper wire that delivers the services to homes. Rivals have complained that British Telecommunications has made it hard for them to gain access to the local exchanges. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: California Oil Refineries May Avoid Blackouts
description: California oil refineries are expected to be granted an exemption from possible electrical power shutdowns under a plan that will be voted on by the state's Public Utilities Commission on Thursday.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Governor Wants Tax Increase
description: Gov. Jim Hodges said on Tuesday that he would eliminate $90 million in budget cuts to colleges and universities through a 1 percent increase in the state's tax on groceries. The increase would generate $50 million for colleges and universities. Mr. Hodges, a Democrat, has also asked the institutions to reconsider the high tuition increases that are to take affect this year.

title: Dialogues With the Original Songs
description: An open-air stage is probably the ideal venue for the Absolute Ensemble. Outdoors, it's up to the performer to define the nature of an event, and this eclectic 16-member group, including everything from a classical string quartet to classic rock percussion, is definitely setting out to create its own definitions of concert music.

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Open Door for Bill On Charities Of Churches
description: The White House and Congressional Republicans have agreed on changes to a bill that would expand federal financing of religious groups' charitable work. The accord allows the bill to proceed in the House this week.

title: Cook Like a Pro, At a Fraction of the Price
description: Blue Flame offers discounted commercial ranges and ovens. ''We've sold more restaurant stoves from this location than anyone else in the country,'' said Charles Augusto, president of Blue Flame. The company sells equipment by Garland, U.S. Range and Dynamic Cooking Systems -- all but one, gas. You get more power but, with less insulation than in residential stoves, more ambient heat. And you may have to do without a broiler. Mr. Augusto stocks units from 24 to 60 inches wide. A 36-inch six-burner range is $900 from Dynamic Cooking Systems, $1,000 from U.S. Range and $1,600 from Garland. (By comparison, at Home Depot's Expo Design Center, 36-inch Garland residential stoves start at $5,000.) Blue Flame, 523 West 125th Street; (212) 662-6990.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Pact Sought On Khmer Rouge Trials
description: Responding to Cambodian announcements that trials of former Khmer Rouge leaders could begin before the end of the year, Secretary General Kofi Annan's office said no internationally recognized trials can take place until Cambodia has signed a legal memorandum of understanding with the United Nations. The organization, which has helped Cambodia set up a plan for a war crimes tribunal and is waiting for the necessary legislation to be passed by the Cambodian Parliament, wants to ensure that the proceedings will meet international norms and that the courts will not be politically manipulated.

title: Police Covered Up Corruption, Detective Asserts in a Lawsuit
description: A police detective who spent eight years as an undercover Internal Affairs investigator filed a lawsuit yesterday saying the department failed to investigate corruption aggressively, covered up its failures and retaliated against him for pursuing corrupt officers.

title: The Car Snitched. He Sued.
description: JAMES TURNER learned an expensive lesson in the perils of speeding last fall, but not from the highway patrol. Instead, Acme Rent-a-Car in New Haven charged Mr. Turner a total of $450 for speeding during a business trip.

title: John Yardley, 76, Dies; Had Central Role in Space Flight
description: John Finley Yardley, a retired engineer who played a central role in the fledgling days of space flight and set the stage for the space shuttle program, died on Tuesday at his home in suburban St. Louis. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYNE, JOHN, JR.
description: PAYNE-John, Jr., 92, retired vice president and director of AMAX, Inc., died on June 21, 2001 at his home in Tucson, AZ. He formerly resided in New York City and Old Lyme, CT. Born in Magdalena, NM on December 6, 1908, he graduated from the University of Texas at El Paso in 1931. He worked in the Phillipines 1931-40, returned to the U.S. in 1940 and joined the American Metal Company, Ltd. (which later merged with Climax Molybdenum Co. and became AMAX, Inc.). From 194446 he served in the U.S. Navy, to Lieutenant, then resumed his AMAX career. He was elected corporate vice president in 1955 and director in 1969, retiring in 1973. Surviving are his wife, Setsuko U. Payne, and stepson Michael Davis and wife, Nagako, of Tucson, AZ. His former wife, Marjorie (Chubb) Payne, predeceased him in 1985. Funeral services were private. Memorial donations may be made to The University of Texas at El Paso, Geological Sciences Dept., Institutional Advancement, 1100 North Stanton-Suite 201, El Paso, TX 79902.

title: Accounts
description: * Brasil Telecom, So Paulo, Brazil, consolidated its account at Salles D'Arcy, the So Paulo office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Bcom3 Group, by naming the agency to handle its account, which had been divided between D'Arcy and the So Paulo office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at $70 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, RICHARD LAWRENCE
description: HALPERN-Richard Lawrence. May 18, 1948 to June 28, 1992. Thinking of you with love. We miss you. Mom, Dad, and Robert

title: Sampras Escapes Upset by Outsider, but Seems Vulnerable
description: During each tense changeover inside the carbonated atmosphere of Court 1 this evening, the 26-year-old Briton with the dockworker's physique slipped on his headphones and pumped his ears full of one song: ''You'll Never Walk Alone.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Inquiry Of Funeral Home
description: Police and medical examiners discovered five decomposed bodies yesterday in the garage of a funeral home. The bodies were sent from Wade Funeral Home to the state health examiner's office to be identified. A spokeswoman for the New Haven Police Department, said that the police were working with the city's health department to investigate possible violations of the health code or other laws, but that no charges had been filed. Repeated attempts to contact representatives of the funeral home were unsuccessful.

title: Nuclear Programs Are Losing Ground on Campus
description: Off campus, energy shortages may be creating talk of a nuclear power renaissance. But on campuses around the country, the technology's infrastructure is dying.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Data Center
description: The Globix Corporation, a Manhattan telecommunications company, announced yesterday that it had opened a new Internet data center at 415 Greenwich Street in TriBeCa. The 193,000-square-foot center, the company's second in Manhattan, functions as a warehouse for corporate computer severs. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Loss for Longhorns Is Gain for the Reds
description: The former college quarterback has given up football to concentrate on baseball and is rocketing through the minor leagues, leaving a wake of pitchers craning their necks.

title: The Biggest Ravioli In the World, And Other Finds
description: There's a new 10,000-square-foot player in the TriBeCa design world: Dune, at 88 Franklin Street (near Church Street; 212-925-6171), sells an exclusive line of furniture and textiles by contemporary designers. The duplex space was designed by Nick Dine and its president, Richard Shemtov, whose work is also sold there. The floor, which looks like concrete, is actually poured resin, a much softer surface. The Floor Ravioli cushion by Mr. Dine, inset bottom, is 80 inches by 80 inches ($2,370). Dune's collection includes the walnut dining table ($3,982) by David Khouri, with chairs ($1,750 each, in ultrasuede). The 6-by-9-foot wool rugs, from left, are by Harry Allen ($4,570), Jens Denecke ($3,890) and Mr. Shemtov ($4,125).

title: Sports of The Times; Women as Athletes: The Pictures Don't Lie
description: WHENEVER the latest spate of Richard Williams's musings turns up in the newspapers, I am reminded of last summer's United States Open semifinal, when daughter Venus trailed Martina Hingis deep in the third set and proud papa Richard suddenly bolted his family box seat.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: A Motley Group, a Single Goal; Supporters Rally Round Officer Jailed in Louima Case
description: In the banquet hall of the Bay Ridge Manor in southern Brooklyn, a couple of Marines sipped long-neck beers at a table of registered nurses. A huddle of patrolmen stood near the lobby, where T-shirts reading, ''Love Your Country, Fear Your Government'' were on sale.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sports of The Times; The Museum Was Used For Mayhem
description: THEY are always surprised and they are always sorry when a boxer is carried from the ring with his brain in chaos. It wasn't supposed to be this way, say the people who are making money from the carnage.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Plans Oregon Factory
description: The leading chip maker Intel plans to build a $2 billion plant near existing operations in Oregon that will develop new manufacturing methods to make smaller semiconductors. Intel filed permit applications with the city of Hillsboro, Ore., last Friday, a spokesman, Chuck Mulloy, said. It said it wanted to start work on the factory later this year and have it running in 2003.

title: Metro Matters; Incumbency And the Face Of the State
description: ONCE again, the great State of New York leads the way. We've devised the ultimate in the public financing of political campaigns. Only officeholders need apply.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on June 16 about an effort to remove some merchants who are charged with doing business illegally on Surf Avenue in Coney Island misstated the role of Lew Bergstein. He operates a flea market there; he is not the merchants' landlord.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military and fraternal organizations. Private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011.

title: If It Can Be Printed on Cloth It Can Decorate a Plate
description: Hazel Manheimer is making use of her art school training by reinventing the humble plate with decoupage, the craft of embossing objects with cutouts of colorful images. She uses pictures of old textiles, pasting them on the back of glass plates in a style that is eye-catchingly modern. Plates cannot be submerged in water for washing, so they work best for tea candles, plants and cookies. Her line, called Day Koo Pzh, includes octagonal and round plates from 5 1/2 to 10 inches in diameter; prices range from $40 to $150. At Bedford & Company, 995 Lexington Avenue (71st Street) and the English Country Store, Snake Hollow Road, Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: In a Virtual Maze, Men Are Smart Rats
description: TORONTO -- When moving around in the real world, men and women generally use different strategies to get to the same place, cognitive research shows. But in the virtual world, subtle differences in spatial abilities are magnified, and men tend to perform better than women do in navigating computer- generated spaces, according to findings presented this month at the American Psychological Society's convention in Toronto.

title: Martinez Breaks Out and Speaks Out
description: By the fifth inning, Tino Martinez had a homer, two doubles, a single and five runs batted in, which is more offense than he had produced over the previous 10 games that he had started for the Yankees. It was surprising that Martinez could generate so much in about two hours, but it was even more shocking that he had generated so little since the middle of June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, WILLIAM
description: SEGAL-William. How long did I go back with Bill? I collected rents for Bill's father. When he was still in school he became my accountant and remained my accountant, advisor, counselor and friend until we lost him. Sylvia and I feel the deepest sympathy for your loss, Andy, my continuing accountant, advisor, counselor and friend. Sylvia and Lew Lubitz

title: 5 Days Later, Highway Closed by Crash Reopens
description: DENVILLE, N.J., June 27  At 3:01 p.m., with a state police cruiser pacing a line of cars, the first westbound traffic in days began to roll over a stretch of Route 80 that had been closed since a tanker fire on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, MARYELLEN (NEE LEYDEN)
description: HALL-Maryellen (nee Leyden) on June 26, 2001. Beloved wife of Thomas D. (F.D.N.Y.). Dear mother of Sean T. Loving daughter of John and Kathleen Leyden. Dear sister of John. Funeral Saturday 9:15AM from the Joseph Clavin Sons Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 9:45am St. Andrew's Church. Visiting 2-4pm and 7-9pm Friday.

title: Shares Finish Almost Flat After Latest Fed Rate Cut
description: Blue-chip stocks fell modestly, while technology stocks posted slight gains yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the sixth time this year.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA WILL INVEST $60 MILLION IN ON COMMAND
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the cable television company run by John C. Malone, agreed to invest as much as $60 million in the On Command Corporation, a leading provider of movies for hotel rooms. With the investment, Liberty, which controls On Command, will own 71 percent of the Denver-based company, said Stacy Bingler Forbes, an analyst at Janco Partners Inc. Mr. Malone may combine On Command with another Liberty company or try to merge it with a rival, the LodgeNet Entertainment Corporation. Liberty, which is based in Englewood, Colo., will buy On Command preferred stock with an 8 percent annual dividend convertible into On Command common shares after Dec. 30, 2002, at $7.55 each, the companies said.

title: Royal and DuPont Rethink The Calculator. Go Figure.
description: With digital calculators built into everything from checkbooks to hand-held computers, most consumers have at least one or two of them available at no cost. Yet people still spent $455 million on some 24 million calculators last year, the research firm NPD Intelect reports.

title: Ecstasy's Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bay Shore: Landlord Arrested
description: An angry landlord used his taxi cab to run over a former tenant during an argument in Bay Shore, N.Y., yesterday, sending the victim to the hospital in critical condition, the Suffolk County police said. The landlord, Smith Augustin, 61, was charged with first-degree assault on Khanwaja Mahmood, 46, who underwent surgery at Southside Hospital.

title: In a Virtual Maze, Men Are Smart Rats
description: WHEN moving around in the real world, men and women generally use different strategies to get to the same place, cognitive research shows. But in the virtual world, subtle differences in spatial abilities are magnified, and men tend to perform better than women do in navigating computer-generated spaces, according to findings presented this month at the American Psychological Society's convention in Toronto.

title: Saudis Open Gas Fields to Foreigners
description: Saudi Arabia radically reshaped its energy industry this month, opening potentially vast natural gas fields to foreign oil companies in an effort to jolt awake an economy that fails to provide enough jobs for the kingdom's booming population.

title: INSIDE
description: Agreement on Patient Suits

title: The Copyright Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless and Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; A Missing AIDS Lifeline
description: The AIDS virus is surging across South Africa like a tidal wave, and yet -- incredibly -- condoms in South Africa are not easy to obtain. Teenage South Africans, half of whom could be wiped out by AIDS, have a particularly difficult time getting condoms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLZ, CHARLES, M.D.
description: STOLZ-Charles, M.D. Passed away peacefully on June 25, 2001. Adored husband of the late Marguerite. Beloved father of Ruth, Andrew and Mary. Cherished grandfather of Sarah and Danielle. Beloved brother of Laura. Beloved uncle, great uncle, great, great uncle and devoted friend and physician to many. We will always love and remember you. Services Thursday, June 28, 2001, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Scholarship Fund Development Office, 1165 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461 in memory of Dr. Charles Stolz.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Breakup Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court today struck down a judge's order to break up the Microsoft Corporation, but it ruled that the software company did violate antitrust law in order to protect a monopoly for its Windows computer operating system.

title: The Book-of-the-Month Club Tries to Be More Of-the-Moment; New Judges and Niche Marketing Are Part of a Comeback Plan
description: For most of its 75-year history, the Book-of-the-Month Club was one of the most powerful institutions in the literary world. Its celebrated panel of judges guided generations of uncertain readers toward its anointed books, while the club's marketing campaigns popularized the idea that displaying the right titles on one's shelf was a sign of status.

title: Dean Foods Says Profit Is Down by 93%
description: The Dean Foods Company, the dairy processor that agreed to be bought by the Suiza Foods Corporation, said today that its profit fell 93 percent in its most recent quarter as the company spent more on energy and commodities and on advertising its refrigerated products.

title: Surrounded? Help!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, JOHN
description: CANNON-John. The Board of Directors of the International Council of NATAS extends its deepest condolences to the family of John Cannon. For more than 25 years, John has led NATAS with dedication, commitment and great foresight. John was a man of vision who loved and understood the television industry. The International Council will miss his advice, prospective, breadth of knowledge and, most importantly, his friendship. Our sympathies go out to his family and loved ones. Fred Cohen, President, The International Council of NATAS Bruce Paisner, Chairman The International Council of NATAS Georges Leclere, Executive Dir., The International Council of NATAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MARION SINER
description: GORDON-Marion Siner, on June 23, 2001, age 93, Canton, MA. Predeceased by husband, Emanuel Siner in 1957 and husband, Emanuel Gordon in 1990. Survived by sister, Lucille Sunshine of Queens, NY, son, Joel L. Siner of Cambridge, MA, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Past-President, Women's League for Conservative Judaism; pastAsst. Attorney General, State of New York. Blessed with integrity, clear intelligence, steadfast purpose and loving nature, she will be remembered by her family with great love and admiration.

title: Tense Macedonia
description: The ethnic tensions that violently tore apart Yugoslavia, leaving hundreds of thousands of civilians dead and millions displaced from their homes, are now afflicting Macedonia, a landlocked Balkan republic that broke away from the old Yugoslavia in 1991. About two-thirds of Macedonia's two million people are Slavs, and most of the rest are ethnic Albanians. After a decade of tension between the two groups, and four months of sporadic violence initiated by ethnic Albanian guerrillas there, Macedonia is now teetering between political compromise and all-out warfare.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Securities Penalties
description: Financial regulators penalized Goldman Sachs and Socit Gnrale of France for violating local securities regulations. Regulators said Goldman's covered warrant operation would be suspended for as long as one month because it displayed an erroneous bid for online clients. Socit Gnrale was ordered to halt its equity trading and structured products operation for three days because it offered to sell a client a plan that allowed it to defer losses. The Ministry of Finance, another branch of the government, said it would exclude Goldman for one month and Socit Gnrale for three days from taking part in government bond auctions.

title: French Court Approves Extradition of American Fugitive
description: RENNES, France, June 28  A French court today agreed to extradite James Charles Kopp, an American anti-abortion activist accused in the sniper killing of an upstate New York doctor.

title: Inflated Pleasure At the Right Price
description: EVERY summer my children beg me to get a pool.

title: Japan Is Resisting Following the Fed on Rates
description: Betting that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates today, putting irresistible pressure on the Bank of Japan to further loosen its own monetary policy, traders have bid Japanese government bond futures to record highs this week.

title: Fighting for Space in Memorial Heaven
description: Shaded by cherry trees about 600 yards north of the Capitol sits a 14-foot bronze sculpture depicting two cranes straining for freedom from tangles of barbed wire. Surrounding it is a curved granite wall chiseled with the names of the 10 camps where Japanese-Americans were interned during World War II and of the more than 800 Japanese-Americans who died in combat.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Presidential Designs (and Office Furniture)
description: THE place is a blocklong landmark building wrapped around a shady stone courtyard in West Harlem. The space, a top floor apartment with the high-ceilinged hush of a mansion and the sea grass rugs of an informal refuge, doubles as the work/life headquarters of Sheila Bridges, a home-centric designer with a pronounced knack for prolonging her moment as Manhattan's interior decorator of the moment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Cuts Interest Rates In 6th Reduction This Year

title: Lessons in the School of Cut and Paste
description: TO a student at Spring Lake Park High School outside Minneapolis, it seemed like a formatting problem: the margins on the research paper he was trying to print out for an English class this spring were not aligning correctly. But when he complained to Jane Prestebak, a librarian whose duties include running the school's computer labs, she immediately suspected the actual cause.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Death Threats Aimed At Prosecutor
description: David Leavitt, the Juab County prosecutor who won conviction on five counts last month against an avowed polygamist, said he and members of his family received death threats during the week-long trial. In response, Mr. Leavitt said he bought a handgun, ammunition and a holster, charging the $742 cost to taxpayers. John Bucher, the lawyer who represented the polygamist, Tom Green, said the threats did not come from his client or anyone his client knew. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAR DAVID, LILY
description: BAR DAVID-Lily. Of Atlanta, GA. Services will be held 1:30PM, Friday, June 29, 2001, at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 718-377-8610

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: British Internet Directory Trims Ranks High and Low
description: The British Internet directory service Scoot.com, whose fortunes have skidded, said today that its top executives would quit and that it would cut 285 jobs as it struggles to survive with only three months of cash reserves in its coffers.

title: China and U.N. Meet on North Korea Immigrants
description: Chinese and United Nations officials met today to negotiate the fates of seven illegal immigrants from North Korea who sneaked into the local office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees on Tuesday, saying they would not leave until they had been granted political asylum and given safe passage to South Korea.

title: National Briefing | Minnesota: Tuition Increase Proposed
description: The president of the University of Minnesota, Mark Yudof, proposed raising tuition by an average of 13.3 percent next year and cutting $103.3 million from the university budget because the Legislature approved a budget that fell short of the university's request. The Board of Regents will vote on the plan next month.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit From PC Sales
description: Riding a wave of growth in the personal computer market, Legend Holdings Ltd. reported a 79 percent increase in its profit in the last fiscal year. Legend, China's biggest PC maker, said its sales bucked the global economic slowdown because of the country's ''growing Internet fever.'' The company reported net income of $110 million on revenue of $3.5 billion, beating its sales goal of 2.5 million PC's by 100,000 units. Legend hopes to stoke Internet use further by teaming up with AOL Time Warner to offer Internet service in the Chinese mainland.

title: High Stakes in the Race to Invent a Bettor-Blocker
description: VISIONS of an Internet gold rush can still be a great motivator for technology developers, but the latest prospectors are not in Silicon Valley. They are in Sin City.

title: Wholesome Food
description: IF you want to know more about healthy food and local farms, here are some resources.

title: Pope, Ending Visit to Ukraine, Honors Other Catholics and Reaches Out to Orthodox
description: Paying tribute to a branch of his faith that was fiercely persecuted in Soviet times, Pope John Paul II put 28 Greek Catholics on the road to sainthood today at an outdoor Mass attended by a million people.

title: A Nod to the Limits of Spelling Checkers
description: THROUGH its popular word-processing programs, Microsoft has probably done more than any other company or institution to foster dependence on spelling checkers.
