So it comes as something of a surprise that the new Microsoft Encarta College Dictionary -- a 1,678-page hardcover edition goes on sale in July -- is sprinkled with 400 warnings about the limitations of spelling checker programs.

title: Fireworks Can Now Do Wheelies, And More
description: AT this time of the year, fireworks sell as briskly as barbecue sauce and paper plates.

title: Shades of Red, All Over Town
description: Red is warm, sexy and flattering to people and food alike. In six of Manhattan's latest destinations, all of which opened in the past five months, red is used boldly and starkly. ''Red makes people's skin look good, and I was attracted to its luscious sensuality,'' said Jeffrey Beers, the Manhattan interior designer who created DB, Daniel Boulud's bistro at 55 West 44th Street, top right, which has a room with deep watermelon-red walls and Christopher Beane's photographs of scarlet dahlias. Open, a bar at 559 West 22nd Street, has fire-engine-red sofas. Lenox, a restaurant at 1278 Third Avenue, bottom right, has red crepe-covered walls and banquettes.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Antitrust Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court overturned Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling to break up the Microsoft Corporation today, and it ordered the judge removed from the case, saying his actions "seriously tainted the proceedings."

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND FLIGHT ATTENDANTS TO TALK
description: American Airlines and its flight attendants are set to resume talks today to try to reach a contract before midnight Saturday. Talks between American and the Association of Professional Flight Attendants broke off June 23 after three days of negotiations in which the union said no progress had been made. President Bush said on Monday that he would block a walkout for 60 days if the sides did not reach an agreement by 12:01 a.m. Sunday, the strike deadline set earlier by the National Mediation Board. The airline, which is based in Fort Worth, and the union have been in talks almost three years. Before the last round of negotiations, the two sides were about $572 million apart on issues like pay, insurance benefits and length of contract.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Urged to Run for Governor
description: The once-mighty California Republican Party is so desperate for a credible candidate for governor next year that just a few months ago prominent Republicans here, including Mayor Richard J. Riordan, were frantically courting a movie star with money and a name: Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONE, BRIAN F.
description: MALONE-Brian F. Of Babylon, L.I. on June 27, 2001. Born in Brooklyn, NY on August 14, 1939. A graduate of Xavier Military Academy, St. Francis College and St. John's University Law School. A practicing attorney, a former NYC parole officer, a former NYS Assistant Attorney General assigned to the special commission on Attica, former Inspector General of NYC Dept. of Corrections, Inspector General of the NYS Dept. of Corrections for 25 years. Member of the NYS Bar Association, Honorary Member of NYC Retired Detectives Association. Member of the Montauk Captain's Association. Captain of the Irish Rover. Beloved husband of forty years to Violet ''Vicki'' Malone. Loving father and best friend of Kelly A. Kendrick and Mary F. Malone. Father-in-law of Michael C. Kendrick. Cherished grandfather of Brian, Christopher, Marie, Alice, Lindsey and Michael. Dear brother-in-law of George and Ginger Bruce. Fond nephew of Alfred Malone, Marion Malone and Dolly Langdon. Also survived by many loving cousins, nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, L.I. on Saturday 9:45 AM. Cremation Washington Memorial Park, Coram, L.I. Visiting Thursday 7-9 PM, Friday 2-4:30 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to Catholic Health Services Hospice, 4747-20 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, NY 11776.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Falling Unemployment
description: The jobless rate has dropped more in New York City than in any other big metropolis over the last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The unemployment rate in the city has dropped by 0.6 percentage points, from 5.5 percent in May 2000 to 4.9 percent in May 2001, the bureau said. Two other major metropolitan areas -- which the bureau defines as those with more than one million residents in 1990 -- had declines of 0.5 points: Indianapolis and Riverside, Calif. Because of the national economic slowdown, unemployment rates have risen in many cities. The biggest increase was in Charlotte, N.C.; the jobless rate rose by 2.3 percentage points, to 5.3 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Nets Gain 3 Players by Trading First-Round Pick
description: In a furious first round of the N.B.A. draft tonight, the Nets exchanged one first-round pick for three, hoping to fulfill with quantity a multitude of pressing needs.

title: Schundler Talks of Unity, But Grin Says 'I Told You'
description: Bret D. Schundler's campaign car was at a standstill in Lower Manhattan traffic at 4 p.m. today, when he burned out his third cell-phone battery of the day. Mr. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, won a surprise victory in Tuesday's Republican primary for New Jersey governor, and suddenly it seemed that half the world wanted a word with him.

title: Wrong Signal on Money Laundering
description: If Americans doubted the extent to which the country's banking system is being used to launder the profits of global criminals, they received fresh evidence this week with the arrest of the former Peruvian spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos. His hiding place in Venezuela reportedly was exposed when he sent an emissary to Miami to withdraw $38 million he had sequestered in various American bank accounts. But now the Bush administration seems intent on weakening a worldwide campaign to clamp down on money laundering. If it does, coordinated global efforts to combat narcotics trafficking, arms smuggling, terrorism and other forms of organized crime will suffer a serious setback.

title: Sharpton Planning to End His Monthlong Prison Fast
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, at least 25 pounds lighter but still spiritually and physically strong, plans to end his fast today over bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, his lawyer said.

title: A New Mental Map of the World
description: I was shopping at my neighborhood supermarket last week when my eye was caught by a small food display under a wooden signboard advertising ''Dalmatia.'' The region of Dalmatia once formed the coast of Yugoslavia, a country that seemed to exist with complete geopolitical solidity during my cold war childhood, then disintegrated in the 1990's with such relentless force that it was hard to believe Yugoslavia had ever held together. Strange to see Dalmatia as a foreign foods display in the supermarket: an arrangement of attractively packaged jars of olives, tapenade, fig paste and pickled garlic cloves.

title: N.B.A. Continues Youth Trend, Picking Schoolboys No. 1 and 2
description: Going to college may be a time-honored path to success in many professions, but apparently not in the National Basketball Association. For the first time, a high school player was selected first in the annual draft last night in New York. Three of the first four players taken were high school seniors, and the other player was from Spain.

title: A Privacy Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Denville: Traffic Moving Again
description: The first westbound traffic in days began to roll yesterday over a stretch of Route 80 that had been closed since a tanker fire last Friday. A two-lane, 90-foot bridge has been built over one damaged by the accident, but full relief for drivers may not come until September, when the entire four-lane bridge is expected to be replaced and reopened, officials said. Crews had worked round-the-clock to construct the temporary bridge.

title: Economic Scene; In Europe, G.E. and Honeywell ran afoul of 19th-century thinking.
description: THE European Union's recent recommendation to block the proposed $45 billion merger of General Electric and Honeywell International was based, in part, on an analysis by a noted French economist -- who has been dead for 124 years.

title: Showing Nakashima as Modernist as Well as Poet
description: If two design experts have their way, George Nakashima, the Japanese-American craftsman, who died in 1990, will be remembered for more than his signature slabs of wood. Steven Beyer, a curator, finds in his sensual furniture ''intelligently engineered, visible structure'' and links him to European modernists. Bob Aibel, owner of Moderne Gallery in Philadelphia, contrasts the work's sophisticated structure and those ''preternatural boards'' that ''look like they were dug up with dinosaur bones.'' Among the 31 pieces chosen by Mr. Beyer for ''George Nakashima and the Modernist Moment,'' through Sept. 16 at the James A. Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa. (215-340-9800), are Nakashima's Long Chair (1955; far left) and Carlo Mollino's roll-top desk (1950; left). In ''George Nakashima: Designing Nature'' at Moderne (215-923-8536) through Sept. 15, coffee tables start at $14,500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, SARAH FAGIN
description: JOFFE-Sarah Fagin. 97, painter and teacher, June 24, 2001 in St. Petersburg, FL. Born in N.Y.City. Predeceased by husband, Julian, son Roland. Survived by a sister, two daughters, a son, 12 grandchildren, 13 great grandchildren and one great great grandchild. Donations to Hospice appreciated.

title: 8 Held in Theft From F.B.I.
description: A Manhattan lawyer, a Nevada state investigator and a Las Vegas court clerk were among eight people charged yesterday in a widening inquiry of the theft of secret F.B.I. documents, some of which were sold to mob figures in New York.

title: Fed's Statement on Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates:

title: The Fed Turns Less Aggressive
description: Yesterday the Federal Reserve Board decided to cut interest rates for the sixth time this year in its continuing efforts to stimulate the economy. But this time it lowered its target for the federal funds rate by only a quarter of a percentage point rather than the heftier half-point to which it had resorted in the previous five cuts. The Fed's restraint is likely to signal a tapering off of its efforts to cut the cost of borrowing so as to encourage business investment and consumer spending. Given the mixed state of the economy and the risk that further rate cuts could lead to higher inflation, a wait-and-see approach to future cuts seems prudent.

title: Koizumi Aides Advise U.S. That the Yen Could Soften
description: Japanese officials paving the way for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's first visit here have warned the Bush team that some of Mr. Koizumi's plans are likely to worsen Japan's economic troubles over the next few years, with potentially major effects on the American economy.

title: Slowdown May Threaten U.S. Surplus
description: The weakened economy is beginning to eat into the projected federal budget surplus, complicating the agendas of the two parties in Washington and setting off a debate among economists about how big and sustained the problem will be.

title: Shock Wave in Israel Over Bush's Comment
description: The public disagreement between President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon over Palestinian cease-fire efforts brought surprise and recriminations in Israel today. Opposition leaders charged that the dispute had weakened Israel's alliance with Washington and Palestinians offered rare praise for the Bush administration.

title: Sizing Up AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: For Readers, Online Clubs
description: Readers' clubs, which have been bringing together proper and interested people to discuss books of nearly every kind since who knows when, are becoming more niche driven -- the submarine enthusiasts, say, meeting every other Wednesday night in Sam's basement -- and are rapidly expanding online.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Optimism On Devices Lifts Palm Shares
description: Shares of Palm Inc. rose 16 percent yesterday after the company, the biggest maker of hand-held computers, said sales of its new m500 device will help it turn an operating profit next quarter. Expected strong demand for the m500 products, which use removable cards the size of postage stamps to store photos and music, should help the company report an operating profit in the quarter ending in November, Palm officials said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Wahid And Army At Odds
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid, on a visit to Australia, said he would declare a state of emergency and use the military to prevent parliamentary action to remove him from office. In Jakarta the army urged him not to declare an emergency and said it would protect a parliamentary session planned for August. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Shipbuilding Subsidies Dispute
description: The European Union has granted a brief reprieve to South Korean negotiators before making good on its threat to take a dispute on South Korean shipbuilding subsidies to the World Trade Organization. The union found enough progress to justify an extension beyond June 30 when the South Koreans had been required to come up with a resolution. Europe asserts that South Korean shipbuilders, including Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest manufacturer of merchant ships, and Samsung Heavy Industries, receive government subsidies that more than compensate for losses they take in making ships. The Korea Shipbuilders Association said the demands were unfounded and contradictory and made an agreement unlikely. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Educators Get Pay Bonus
description: Teachers and principals at eight Brooklyn schools will be awarded a form of merit pay as part of an experimental program in two community school districts. The educators qualified for the awards, paid by corporate sponsorship, because of rising scores on reading and mathematics tests. At Intermediate School 311 in East New York, the rise was so steep that every teacher got a $2,000 bonus and the principal got a $15,000 bonus. The teachers at the other seven schools received bonuses of $1,000, and the principals received bonuses of $5,500. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEICZEN, ERNEST G.
description: WEICZEN-Ernest G. of Harrison, NJ. Beloved husband of Cecilia (nee Martinez). Devoted father of Juan Rodriguez and Jonathan Rodriguez. Cherished friend of Ron and Adrienne Braun. Adored uncle of Dana, Jennifer and Kristina Braun; also Ian and Heather. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack NJ on Thursday, 1PM. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Your E-Mail Is Private, But Your Phone Calls?
description: Encryption isn't just for e-mail and online credit-card purchases anymore. Simple communications like phone calls and fax transmissions over public telephone networks are subject to interception and eavesdropping by outsiders, too. So CityCom Telecommunications is distributing a product to help shield calls. The company's GoPrivate encryption device for telephones and fax machines converts an analog voice or fax call into a scrambled digital signal that stymies eavesdroppers.

title: Milosevic Is Given to U.N. for Trial in War-Crime Case
description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Friday, June 29 -- Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader blamed for starting four Balkan wars and impoverishing and isolating his country, was delivered early this morning to a prison cell and eventual trial by the United Nations war crimes tribunal here.

title: After a Crushing Defeat, Franks Agrees to Help Schundler
description: Bob Franks drove alone to the Republican unity luncheon today with Bret D. Schundler and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Gone were Mr. Frank's entourage and the big customized black and beige campaign bus that took him all over the state just days ago. He came by himself today, in a red compact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, SOLOMON
description: TEPPER-Solomon. On June 27, 2001. To our beloved Solomon, wonderful husband of Frieda, loving father of Scott, Marilyn and Bob, adoring grandfather to Eddie, devoted brother of Sid. He will be cherished and loved forever. Services Friday, June 29, 10:30AM at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Advertising Invades Instant Messaging
description: Every day, on millions of computers, instant messages become carriers for the drama and detritus of daily life. Parents send instant messages to make weekend plans with extended family, students pass each other private notes about classmates, spouses check on whether to pick up dinner on the way home.

title: Fans and Foes Greet Former Taiwan Leader in Visit to Cornell
description: Looking energized and utterly in his element, Taiwan's former president, Lee Teng-hui, returned to his alma mater, Cornell University, this week for the first time since a visit in 1995 and wasted little time delving into a topic that has long confounded Beijing and Washington: Taiwan politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Teamsters convention in Las Vegas referred incorrectly to a 1996 government investigation of a Teamsters local in Chicago headed then by William T. Hogan Jr. Investigators found nepotism and other problems at the local, but they did not bring internal union charges against Mr. Hogan, who was suspended by the union. The article also referred incorrectly to Dane Passo, who along with Mr. Hogan was charged internally last month with negotiating an improper deal to have nonunion workers set up and take down conventions in Las Vegas. He is no longer a regional Teamsters official.

title: Supreme Court Says Immigrants Cannot Be Locked Up Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Immigrants who have committed crimes in the United States cannot be locked up indefinitely just because the government has no place to send them, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Smoking? At a Conference on Health?
description: Officials here are perplexed, shocked really, that signs all around the Caf Vienna announcing ''smoking discouraged'' really have not done the trick.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ewing: Anger On The Roads
description: Just over half of New Jersey vehicle owners drive angry and nearly half are likely to try to punish other drivers, according to a new survey. The survey -- conducted jointly by the Insurance Council of New Jersey, an industry group, and the state chapter of AAA -- also found that more than 40 percent of drivers felt ''highly to moderately stressed'' while on the road. The two groups cited state and federal highway safety figures indicating that at least one third of the state's 280,000 traffic accidents a year are caused by aggressive driving.

title: Griffin's Greeting: A Moment As a Net
description: Eddie Griffin sat at a table surrounded by his immediate family and watched in shock and dejection as he was passed over through the first six picks of the N.B.A. draft last night. When his name was finally called by the Nets at No. 7, he stood up and hugged his mother. He did not speak, but the two sighed in relief.

title: Souping Up the Cell Phone
description: When Farhan Thawar whips out his cell phone to dial a number, he calls attention to himself.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lawyers for Milosevic Delay Extradition Proceeding
description: Lawyers for Slobodan Milosevic, the ousted Yugoslav president, succeeded today in delaying efforts to extradite him to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, but the government appeared undeterred and started proceedings to extradite three other indicted men.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft Plans Olympics Site
description: Signaling a move into sports content for Microsoft, MSNBC.com and MSN will join NBC in producing the Web sites for the 2002 Salt Lake City Olympics. The decision ends a two-month scramble by the Salt Lake Organizing Committee to find replacements for the portal company Quokka Sports, which filed for bankruptcy in late April, and Logictier, which was to provide the host services but said it was leaving the host business. ''Microsoft is clearly the company that survives and thrives in the Internet world,'' said Mitt Romney, chief executive of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee. ''Having them as a partner relieves all worries.'' Unlike Quokka, Microsoft will not pay the organizing committee a fee for rights to produce the sites, but will bear the cost of the production and being the host. It will be restricted in advertising its Olympic affiliation and will share ad revenue with all the partners, including the Salt Lake, United States and International Olympic committees.

title: Fujimori Is Wined and Dined by Tokyo's Powerful
description: Not long ago, Dr. Torao Tokuda, a wealthy member of Parliament, invited about 15 of his colleagues to an exclusive Tokyo restaurant with geishas, promising that they would meet a ''very intriguing'' person.

title: New York Health Commissioner Favors Blood Restrictions
description: The New York State health commissioner is backing a Food and Drug Administration proposal that would restrict blood donations from people who may have been exposed to mad cow disease in Europe, her office announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 28 about the dedication of a new footstone in Brooklyn honoring Benjamin B. Levy, who served in the Union Army during the Civil War and was the first Jewish soldier to receive the Medal of Honor, omitted the names of the organizations responsible for the dedication. It was initiated by the Manalapan-Marlboro Post 972 Jewish War Veterans, Department of New Jersey, with help from the Kings County Council Jewish War Veterans, Department of New York.

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Agree on Liability Limits for Patients' Rights to Sue
description: Senators announced today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement that resolved one of the thorniest issues in legislation to define patients' rights. Under the agreement, most employers who provide health benefits to employees would be shielded from lawsuits.

title: Limits On Phillips In Plans For Trades
description: The Mets are a team of veterans who have played for losers and winners. Despite a nice victory today, this team is losing, and players know what usually happens to losing teams: they are broken apart, the pieces traded off to contenders.

title: Advertising Comes to Instant Messaging
description: EVERY day, on millions of computers, instant messages become carriers for the drama and detritus of daily life. Parents send instant messages to make weekend plans with extended family, students pass each other private notes about classmates, spouses check on whether to pick up dinner on the way home.

title: Article 2001062892337193154 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: You Ferrets, Keep Your Weaselly Heads Down
description: Ferrets, alas, will remain bandits in New York City, at least for now: the City Council has quietly abandoned its two-year bid to legalize the small, domesticated animals as pets.

title: It Couldn't Get Worse for Mets, So It Got Much Better Instead
description: Their best starting pitcher left with an injury. They faced a starter who threw harder as the game went on. Their makeshift lineup was silent again. The Mets were on their way to their seventh loss in a row.

title: Jets Sign Two Defensive Players
description: The Jets signed two of their draft picks yesterday, cornerback Jamie Henderson of Georgia and defensive lineman James Reed of Iowa State.

title: Prosecutors Promise Chilling Glimpse of Millennium Bomb Plot
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan opened their case against a terrorism suspect yesterday by describing a plot by Algerians to strike American targets during the millennium celebrations at the end of 1999.

title: Jack Lemmon, Actor, Dies at 76; Awards Included Two Oscars
description: Jack Lemmon, the brash young American Everyman who evolved into the screen's grumpiest old Everyman during a movie career that lasted a half century, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Microsoft Drops Controversial Tagging Feature from Windows XP
description: Facing severe criticism and a potential public relations debacle, Microsoft is pulling one of the features from Windows XP. The planned inclusion of "Smart Tags" in both the new operating system due Oct. 25 and in the upcoming browser Internet Explorer 6 has been indefinitely postponed.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from June 27.

title: CALENDAR
description: Boating in New York Harbor

title: Sizing Up AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Bureau Won't Distribute Census Data on Homeless
description: Reversing the way it handled the data 10 years ago, the Census Bureau says it will not provide states and cities with the figures on their homeless populations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANEMAN, ELIZABETH B. (BREED)
description: HANEMAN-Elizabeth B. (Breed). Died June 26, 2001 at the age of 79. She is survived by a daughter Elizabeth Stinchcomb of Manhattan and two granddaughters Nicole P. Haneman of Manhattan & Patricia H. Cox of Larchmont, New York; a son William F. Haneman is deceased. Services are to be held in Connecticut.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Sodomized At Gunpoint
description: A man with a handgun confronted a 15-year-old girl, her mother and her 3-year-old cousin as they were walking along a street in Queens Village at 3 a.m. yesterday, and sodomized the teenager in a parking lot, the police said. The man stole $250 from the woman, who is 39, and fled.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T And AOL Announce Wireless Plans
description: America Online and AT&T said yesterday that they would jointly develop a new wireless mobile service that will integrate AOL desktop features into a wireless handset. The mobile phones will incorporate features like AOL e-mail and instant messaging. Part of America Online's year-old ''AOL Anywhere'' strategy, the deal could give new momentum to transmission of video and graphics over mobile networks. AT&T Wireless has been pushing to develop such a national mobile network based on international wireless standards known as 3G. The companies also said that AT&T Wireless would substantially increase its marketing presence across the online and offline brands of AOL Time Warner. Planned to run this year and next, the marketing campaign will include promotions for AT&T products.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Delphinium Blues

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; No Fed Magic for Poor Corporate Earnings
description: When the Federal Reserve cut interest rates six months ago, investors stampeded into stocks, certain that lower rates would mean higher share prices. Yesterday, the Fed cut rates again -- by one-quarter of a point -- and investors simply yawned.

title: Abundance Flows From One Small Yard
description: MORE than 30 years ago, Joan Dye Gussow, a nutritionist at Columbia Teachers College who has trained a generation of chefs and gardeners to think globally and eat locally, decided the only responsible way to eat was to know the source of the food. ''How else could we make sure its producers and their land was being preserved?'' Ms. Gussow, 72, asked recently as she pulled weeds in the riverside garden here, which supplies her with herbs, fruits and vegetables year-round. ''And we couldn't know where food came from, I figured, unless it was grown closer to home.''

title: World Court Finds U.S. Violated Consular Rights of 2 Germans
description: The International Court of Justice rebuked the United States today, saying it had flouted international law when two German brothers were executed in Arizona in 1999.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Levy Demotes School Administrator Over Handling of Sex Attack
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy demoted the acting assistant principal of a Bronx school yesterday for not calling the police last month after two fifth-grade girls reported being sexually attacked by two sixth-grade boys in a school stairwell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, ADELAIDE AGATHA (NEE STAPLETON)
description: WELCH-Adelaide Agatha (nee Stapleton), born in Manhattan March 8, 1923, age 78, a creative artist, beloved wife, mother, sister, and mother-in-law and friend. An active member of St. Pascal Baylon Church in St. Albans, Queens, she was a member of the Rosary Society & is much loved & missed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Deadlocked In Graft Trial
description: After deliberating for three days, a Manhattan jury has deadlocked in the case of Darral Hilton, a former administrative chief inspector for the Brooklyn Buildings Department who was charged with two misdemeanor counts of accepting gratuities, including a free meal and sports tickets obtained at a special price. A spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney said yesterday that prosecutors would review the trial transcript before deciding whether to retry Mr. Hilton. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 8 about an astronaut at the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in Houston misstated her given name. She was Dr. Patricia Hilliard Robertson, not Pamela.

title: FED LOWERS RATES BY QUARTER-POINT IN 6TH CUT OF YEAR
description: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today and signaled that its campaign to revive the flagging economy may be entering its final stages.

title: Palmtops With a P, as in PC
description: PART of the agony and the ecstasy of being human is our ability to confront the big questions. What's the meaning of existence? Is there life after death? And which is better: the Palm or the Pocket PC?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNESA, WILLIAM
description: TURNESA-William. The Board of Directors and membership of Quaker Ridge Golf Club mourn the passing of its esteemed honorary member, Willie Turnesa. We remember him as a fine gentleman, an outstanding amateur golfer and a true friend of the game. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, CLARENCE D.
description: BELL-Clarence D., 84 years old. Of Palm Beach, Florida, died on Wednesday, June 27, 2001 following an extended illness. Formerly of New York, New York and Wilmington, Delaware, he was a resident of Palm Beach since 1985. Mr. Bell was employed as a Chemical Engineer with the Dupont Company for over 30 years, and retired as the Executive Vice President in 1972. He also served as a Vice President of the Maimonides Medical Center, New York, New York. Mr. Bell was an avid fisherman and golfer, and a member of the Breakers Golf Club, Palm Beach, FL. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Ragena Lowary Bell. He is survived by his wife, Hilda M. F. Bell of Palm Beach, FL; children, Sally Cooperson (Don) of North Caldwell, NJ, Edward Bell (Liz) of Tampa, FL, Becky Ley (Ken) of Voorhees, NJ, Martin Bell (Peggy) of Miami, FL, Rebecca Folkman (Jonathan Aaron) of Cambridge, MA, Benjamin Folkman of New York, NY, and Jonathan Folkman (Fran) also of New York, NY; eight grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. A Funeral Service will be held at 1:30 PM on Saturday, June 30, 2001 at Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. The family will receive friends at the funeral home on Saturday from 12:30 PM until the time of Service. We invite you to visit, sign Mr. Bell's Remembrance Registry guest book and share a memory at the web site of www.quattlebaum.org

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, NANCY DENTON
description: PERLMAN-Nancy Denton. On June 25th, 2001 in the comfort of the home in which she grew up. She shined a special light on everyone and all those who knew her were touched by her special warmth. Keep the warmth with you for it is the essence of Nancy and her gift to those she leaves behind. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. She was blessed and will be missed.

title: Yankees Shop Knoblauch As Torre Tweaks Lineup
description: The predictable and comfortable familiarity of the Yankees' dynasty fades, with small changes with larger implications found in the lineups Manager Joe Torre is composing and the team seeming on the verge of major change. They are seriously considering trading outfielder Chuck Knoblauch to Seattle and are pursuing the former Yankee outfielder Gerald Williams.

title: Three High School Stars Are Among First Four Chosen
description: Kwame Brown was mostly respectful during the time he spent working out with Michael Jordan, the Washington Wizards' president of basketball operations, two days before the N.B.A. draft.

title: Secret Sources in the Hamptons
description: AT the end of country lanes and behind garage doors lie the hidden sources that service the high-maintenance Hamptons. And while professionals and antiques dealers use some of the places to refinish furniture and rewire broken lamps, you don't have to be a professional or live in the Hamptons to use them. And there are also great sources for accessories off the main road.

title: Rangers May Train at the Garden
description: The Rangers have not made a postseason appearance since 1997, but they may be around Madison Square Garden in the preseason more than usual late this summer. The team has tentative plans to hold its training camp at the Garden.

title: Clarkson N. Potter, 73, Publisher; Founded Imprint in His Name
description: Clarkson Nott Potter, a publisher, writer and literary agent who founded an imprint in his own name, died Sunday at his home in Jamestown, R.I. He was 73.

title: Sex, Drugs and Seed Catalogs
description: Michael Pollan, a writer and gardener, might not consider himself a naturalist on the order of Henry David Thoreau, but he can spot a bug in the grass -- no mean feat to the eye of a visiting New Yorker, who couldn't have found a penny in the sun.

title: Article 2001062890672736255 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism
description: To a student at Spring Lake Park High School outside Minneapolis, it seemed like a formatting problem: the margins on the research paper he was trying to print out for an English class this spring were not aligning correctly. But when he complained to Jane Prestebak, a librarian whose duties include running the school's computer labs, she immediately suspected the actual cause.

title: Souping Up the Cell Phone
description: WHEN Farhan Thawar whips out his cell phone to dial a number, he calls attention to himself.

title: Endgame In China Bid For Entry To W.T.O.
description: China's drive to join the World Trade Organization reaches its final stage on Thursday when its negotiators gather at the organization's headquarters here, with the ink still drying on deals with the United States and the European Union that cleared the way.

title: Factory Problems Unresolved, Schering-Plough President Is Out
description: Schering-Plough, which has had repeated quality-control problems at its factories, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer was resigning.

title: Aalto Interior to Stay in New York
description: AFTER a year of uncertainty, the small architectural jewel known as the Kaufmann Conference Center, designed by Alvar Aalto, is going to stay in the building for which it was designed.

title: G.M. AND RUSSIAN CAR PRODUCER SET TO START VENTURE
description: A joint venture agreement between General Motors and Russia's biggest car producer, AvtoVAZ, became official at a signing ceremony to celebrate the starting point of the $332 million project. The project was first announced in the winter after years of talks, and is the biggest in the Russian car industry to date. Financed in part by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the venture will begin producing Russian all-terrain vehicles next fall, and is expected to reach an annual production of 75,000 cars by 2003. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Palmtops With a P, As in PC
description: PART of the agony and the ecstasy of being human is our ability to confront the big questions. What's the meaning of existence? Is there life after death? And which is better: the Palm or the Pocket PC?

title: Bridgestone/Firestone to Close Tire Plant at Center of Huge Recall
description: Still reeling from a huge tire recall and the end of its long relationship with the Ford Motor Company, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. said today that it planned to close one of its biggest tire factories.

title: New Determination Is Seen Emerging in AIDS Battle
description: It was billed as a world assembly on AIDS, but by the time three days of tumultuous meetings ended today, the leaders of Africa, often at odds and sometimes at war, had come together to dominate the session, showing a markedly new determination to fight the disease that has decimated their homelands.

title: WebMD Executive Moves to AOL Time Warner
description: Not long ago, it sometimes seemed as if every executive from traditional media who could was finding a way into cyberspace. Now, it sometimes seems as if every one of those executives who can is finding a way back.

title: Above a Hall of Sex, a Corner of Culture
description: For well over a year, the second floor of the Show World pornography emporium on Eighth Avenue near West 42nd Street has housed productions of Chekhov and other sober playwrights who don't incorporate dancers' poles in their works. Peter Jacobson, an actor, is happy to be appearing in the latest of them, five one-act plays grouped under the title ''Worldly Acts.''

title: Raytheon to Take $177 Million Charge
description: The Raytheon Company plans to take a $177 million second-quarter charge to cover added costs stemming from construction projects involving Washington Group International Inc. and Pohang Iron & Steel of South Korea.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a lifelong dream.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRES, MARIO
description: TORRES-Mario. The cast, crew and producers of STOMP celebrate and honor the life, talent and memory of cast member Mario Torres who passed in Amsterdam on June 20, 2001. Funeral on Sunday, July 1, at 11 AM at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about an accident on Interstate 80 in northern New Jersey referred incorrectly in some copies to the name of the company that handled the cleanup of fuel that leaked into a creek. It is HMHTTC Response Inc., not Hazardous Materials Handling Technical Training Center.

title: Scraping the Sky, and Even Breaking Through
description: How far is up? The Skyscraper Museum offers some answers at its Web site (www

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, KATHLEEN A.
description: SULLIVAN-Kathleen A. With heavy hearts, the Yale Law School Community mourns the passing, on June 27th, of Kathleen A. Sullivan, Clinical Professor of Law at Yale, our colleague, teacher, mentor and friend. Her compassion for others, her warmth and her dignity will be sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to have known her. We extend our sincerest condolences to her husband, Stephen Robinson, and daughter, Victoria. Anthony T. Kronman, Dean Yale Law School

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURDIK, FREDERICK J.
description: TURDIK-Frederick J. On June 25, 2001 of Swampscott, Mass. (formerly of Long Island, NY). Beloved husband of Jean J. Turdik (nee Herbert). Loving brother of Theresa Menzer. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons East Islip Funeral Home, 200 East Main St. (1/2 mile west of exit 45 W. S.S. Pkwy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial St. Peter the Apostle R.C. Church, Islip Terrace, Long Island, on Saturday 9:30 AM. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, Long Island. Visiting Friday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to Cancer Center of the North Shore, 17 Centennial Drive, Peabody, MA. 01960.

title: Do-Little Albany? Not for Podiatrists or Bitten Dogs
description: It's true that since the legislative session began in January, state lawmakers have managed not to agree on any major piece of legislation -- from loosening New York's drug sentencing laws to revamping school financing to requiring insurers to cover the costs of contraceptives.

title: G.O.P. Victor No Pushover
description: To Democrats who doubted they would ever face him in November, Bret D. Schundler seemed a dream opponent in the New Jersey governor's race. An abortion foe, a friend to gun owners, regarded as a fearsome threat even by some Republicans, he looked simply unelectable in a state where the political center is a mile wide.

title: AMERICAN AXLE SAYS ITS PROFIT WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: American Axle and Manufacturing Holdings Inc., a maker of automobile drive systems, expects its second-quarter profit to be 20 percent higher than analysts' estimates, led by rising sales and cost cuts. The company was created in 1994 from former General Motors plants. Its first-quarter profit fell 40 percent as General Motors, its largest customer, reduced North American production 20 percent. This month, G.M. raised its output plan for this quarter to 1.35 million cars and light trucks, up 1.3 percent from its April forecast. Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected American Axle, which is based in Detroit, to earn 55 cents a share.

title: John Adams, Maligned and Misunderstood, Finds a 21st-Century Champion
description: Admittedly, David McCullough is a booster of John Adams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, RALPH L.
description: SCHUMAN-Ralph L. On June 27, 2001. Dearly beloved husband of Jocelyn (Cohen Luskin). Loving father of Steven (Anne) and Deborah Wohl (Steven). Also survived by Jocelyn's children Mindy Aleman (Gary) and Joanne Zicherman. Proud grandfather of Lisa and Michael Strug, David and Dana Schuman, Jonathan Wohl, Larissa Wohl, Hunter and Troy Aleman, and Lucy Zicherman. Brother of Elliott. Service Friday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Pardon for Felon Considered After Kin Paid Roger Clinton
description: In late January, in the final days of the Clinton administration, the White House told the Justice Department that it was considering a presidential pardon for Rosario Gambino, a convicted heroin trafficker and reputed organized crime figure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  READ, HENRY J.
description: READ-Henry J. The Board of Directors, Medical Staff, Advisory Counsel and Administration of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center, mourn the passing of Henry J. Read, father of our Chairman of The Board, Henry P. Read. The Medical Center and all affiliated with it, extend their sincerest condolences to his wife, and his family. Board of Directors Medical Staff Advisory Counsel Adminstrative Staff

title: G.E. Is Said To Float Plan To Save Deal
description: General Electric has held informal discussions with European regulators about selling a minority stake in its aviation financing business in hopes of winning approval for its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIOFFERO, PAULINE HOLMAN
description: CIOFFERO-Pauline Holman. Died June 26, 2001, Omaha, NE. Wife of Vito. Mother of Clare, Anne, Charles, Catherine, Michael and the late Paul. Sister of John Holman. New Rochelle College Class of '52. Editor Jubilee Magazine, 1953-61; Editor Columban Magazine since 1981.

title: ASTRAZENECA DROPS TESTING OF RESPIRATORY DRUG
description: AstraZeneca P.L.C., Europe's second-largest drug maker, dropped development of the respiratory treatment Viozan after late-stage tests showed it did not have the benefits of rival medicines already on the market. Viozan was dropped after Phase III trials, the final stage of testing needed for approval, showed it did not have the long-term benefits that were expected, a spokesman, Steve Brown, said. Viozan was one of five new drugs with possible sales of more than $1 billion that Tom McKillop, the chief executive, hoped would replace Losec, the ulcer treatment that accounts for about 40 percent of revenue.

title: Personal Shopper: Secret Sources in the Hamptons
description: AT the end of country lanes and behind garage doors lie the hidden sources that service the high-maintenance Hamptons. And while professionals and antiques dealers use some of the places to refinish furniture and rewire broken lamps, you don't have to be a professional or live in the Hamptons to use them. And there are also great sources for accessories off the main road.

title: A Little Off the Beaten Track, Secret Sources in the Hamptons
description: AT the end of country lanes and behind garage doors lie the hidden sources that service the high-maintenance Hamptons. And while professionals and antiques dealers use some of the places to refinish furniture and rewire broken lamps, you don't have to be a professional or live in the Hamptons to use them. And there are also great sources for accessories off the main road.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Marconi Unit To Merge With Easynet
description: Marconi P.L.C., Britain's leading maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in a new company to be formed by merging its Ipsaris telecommunications network unit with the Easynet Group, a British provider of Internet access and telephone services. After the transaction, Marconi will own 49.9 percent of the voting stock in the new company and 72 percent of Easynet, worth about 354 million ($501 million).

title: Daily News Lures Back Ads From at Least 2 Supermarkets
description: The Daily News has been able to lure back at least two supermarkets that had withdrawn advertising after a series the newspaper published that said their markets were too dirty to meet state standards.

title: Pentagon to Ask For Retirement Of MX Missiles
description: The Pentagon will ask Congress for permission to begin scrapping all 50 of its nuclear-tipped MX missiles as a possible first step toward a unilateral reduction in the nation's nuclear arsenal, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, BEATRICE
description: ALEXANDER - Beatrice. Of Bloomfield Hills, MI and Longboat Key, FL., died June 27. Adored wife of 65 years of Gabriel, mother of Molly (Leonard) Schechter of Longboat Key & New York, Ellen and Sara Alexander, grandmother of Sid Atkins, sister of Robert (Frances) Joshel. Charter life member, and NCJW, bibliophile, weaver, world traveler, one of a kind. For information call the Ira Kaufman Chapel, 248-569-0020.

title: Linux System Is Free But the Extras Are Not
description: Q. If Linux is supposed to be a free operating system, why do companies charge for it?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about health experts' testimony before the City Council misstated a finding by Dr. Robert A. Schmidt, an associate professor of radiology at New York University Medical Center, on waiting times for mammograms. Dr. Schmidt said that the waiting time for a screening mammogram at Bellevue Hospital Center was one day, and that it was about three months at Gouverneur diagnosis center and at the Breast Imaging Center at N.Y.U. The waiting times for diagnostic mammograms, he said, are one month at Bellevue and Gouverneur and almost two months at the Breast Imaging Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREAN, HERBERT
description: STREAN-Herbert. Good-bye old friend. I will never forget you. You will always remain in my heart. Love, Millie

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Offensive Lyrics Banned
description: Mitt Romney, president of the group organizing the winter Olympics next year in Salt Lake City, said the profanity-laced music that is favored by many snowboarders would be prohibited in the snowboarding competition. Mr. Romney said more suitable music, like hard rock and mild forms of hip-hop, would be chosen for the snowboarding events to avoid offending anyone. Olympics organizers said they would try to play a diverse selection of music, but would not allow any music that glorified sex, drugs or crime. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Pantone Spectrum Is Being Splashed On New Products
description: The Pantone Matching System has long been every designer's reference point, organizing fanciful shades like Hawaiian Ocean and Lollipop into a universal number key (17-4540 and 15-1764, respectively). Now Pantone, in Carlstadt, N.J., and a team of French industrial designers have created Pantone Universe consumer products, including rubber photo albums (shown, $18), passport covers, eyeglass cases and business card holders in some of Pantone's punchiest shades (from top, Ultra Violet, Orange Peel and Flame Scarlet). Sold at Flight 001, 96 Greenwich Avenue, nearJane Street (877-435-8663 or www.flight001.com) and other stores. AMY GOLDWASSER

title: A Hispanic Theater Festival Fluent in Cultural Ferment
description: It was only in the third play of five presented in the two-week International Hispanic Theater Festival -- ''The Sandals of Time'' by the Theater of the Andes -- that you finally heard a play spoken solely in Spanish.

title: Signals in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Reform Rabbis' Vote Reflects Expanding Interest in Rituals
description: Reform rabbis voted today to adopt new guidelines on conversion, a decision that reflected in part how interest in traditional rituals within Judaism's largest liberal branch, the Reform movement, has been growing.

title: Sizing Up AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNING, ELIZABETH SAND
description: GUNNING-Elizabeth Sand, 44. Beloved wife of Kenneth Gunning of Manhattan, died June 26th, 2001 at home after a courageous battle with advanced ovarian cancer. Born in Killeen, TX, she lived in NJ and CT. before moving to NYC 22 years ago. She graduated from St. Leo College (FL) with a degree in theater and drama. She was employed by the New York Hilton and worked for many years in professional theater. She is also survived by her parents, John and Carol Sand of Bristol, CT, 2 sisters, Kathy of Sarasota, FL and Ellen of Bristol, and a brother, Stephen and his wife Patricia of Farmington, NY. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St., on Thursday, June 28th, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Funeral Mass will be held on Friday, June 29th, at Ascension Church, 221 W. 107 St, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Inc., 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, New York, New York 10119.

title: A new campaign from Oasis stresses the wonders of India for potential American tourists.
description: WITH its breathtaking landscape and fascinating history, art and culture, India would seem to be an ideal vacation destination for American travelers.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Redistricting Could Give G.O.P. An Edge
description: The State Senate passed a bill on Tuesday that would redraw Congressional districts and could give Republicans a chance at winning a majority of the state's seats in the House of Representatives. The bill would cut the state's Washington delegation to 15 from 16, reflecting 2000 census figures, and force two pairs of Democratic incumbents against each other. Democrats hold a 9-to-7 majority in the delegation, but the redistricting could give the Republicans a majority of 9 to 6. The bill now heads to a State House committee.

title: Rudd's Crew Chief Builds a Reputation
description: Michael McSwain said he picked up his nickname, Fatback, because he was a husky boy who grew up in a western North Carolina town without a stoplight, where a husky boy tends to stick out.

title: Charity Is New Force in Environmental Fight
description: From a suite of offices in a high-rise here, a $4.8 billion foundation called the Pew Charitable Trusts has quietly become not only the largest grant maker to environmental causes, but also one that controls much more than the purse strings.

title: Fallon Layoffs In Minneapolis
description: The Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, is making its first layoffs ever, dismissing about 30 employees, or 6 percent of its staff of 500.

title: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism
description: TO a student at Spring Lake Park High School outside Minneapolis, it seemed like a formatting problem: the margins on the research paper he was trying to print out for an English class this spring were not aligning correctly. But when he complained to Jane Prestebak, a librarian whose duties include running the school's computer labs, she immediately suspected the actual cause.

title: Newark Arena Plan Is Stalled for This Session
description: Aides to Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco said today that they were unlikely to win lawmakers' approval on Thursday, the end of the legislative session, for a bill laying the groundwork for a new sports arena in Newark and a family sports and entertainment complex in the Meadowlands.

title: Court Dismisses Arms-Trafficking Case Against Mitterrand Son
description: PARIS  A French court on Wednesday threw out an arms-trafficking case against Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, son of France's late president, on procedural grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXEL, ELAINE
description: AXEL-Elaine. Creative, dependable and valued former V.P., devoted tutor and caring Friend of P.S. 169, The RFK School.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Struggling To Save Accord
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, are to meet with Ulster's political leaders in Belfast today in an effort to sustain the Northern Ireland peace agreement despite the expected resignation this weekend of David Trimble as First Minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly. Mr. Trimble, newly re-elected leader of the largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, is giving up his position as head of the power-sharing local government to protest the Irish Republican Army's refusal to begin disarming.

title: On the Phone, Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Breakup Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A federal appeals court unanimously threw out a lower court's order today that the Microsoft Corporation should be broken up, although the appeals court found that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Office Supplier Slips
description: A leading global distributor of office supplies, Buhrmann N.V., cut its profit forecast for the third time in three months amid a slowdown in demand for its products, particularly in the United States. Buhrmann, which bought the American company Corporate Express in 1999, said late Tuesday that its second-quarter profit would fall 30 percent as the slowdown in the United States spread to Europe. Stock in the company, which is based in Amsterdam, fell 4.95 euros, or 33 percent, to 10 euros ($8.64) a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, BENJAMIN
description: RUDNICK-Benjamin. On June 26, 2001, age 97. Beloved father of Ethel and Seymour Rolnick and Murray and Susan Rudnick. Cherised grandfather and great grandfather.

title: Exxon Mobil To Face Suit Over a Spill In Nassau
description: The Plainview Water District, one of Long Island's largest drinking water suppliers, plans to file a lawsuit on Thursday against an oil company for a spill of M.T.B.E., a gasoline ingredient that is a possible cause of cancer, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, ERNA
description: PRAGER-Erna. We extend our sincerest condolences to Lutz Prager on the passing of his beloved mother. A true ''Eishes Chayil'', she embodied the qualities of elegance, charm and kindness. As a Silver Founder of the Medical Center and a recipient of the Jerusalem Humanitarian Award from our Baltimore Committee, Mrs. Prager personified the highest standards of Tzedakah and Chesed in her love and support of important Jewish causes that build and strengthen Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaara Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the trial of Darral Hilton, a former New York City official charged with two misdemeanor counts of accepting free meals and sports tickets, misstated his position with the city. He was administrative chief inspector for the Buildings Department in Brooklyn, not a buildings commissioner.

title: The Heat Is On, and Businesses Strive to Keep the Power On, Too
description: At the start of a predicted spell of scorching weather, a group that includes some of New York City's largest businesses and building owners agreed yesterday to take steps to conserve energy, like scaling back the use of air-conditioners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, ALICE OLSON.
description: RILEY-Alice Olson. On Tuesday June 26, 2001. of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of the late Thomas Riley, devoted mother of Mary Anderson and Peter Riley. Also survived by four grandchildren. Friends may call at the Arlington Funeral Home, 3901 N. Fairfax Dr, Arlington, VA on Thursday June 28, 6-8PM. Services at St. John's Catholic Church, McLean, VA on Friday, June 29 at 11am. Interment in Nassau Knolls Cemetery, on Saturday, June 30 at 11:30 AM.

title: Knicks Happy to Land Wright and Chenowith
description: Three years ago, Michael Wright was at Farragut Academy in Chicago, wowing the same high school fans who once cheered for Kevin Garnett. If Wright can produce a fraction of the results that Garnett has produced in the N.B.A., then last night's draft will be viewed as a success for the Knicks.

title: Capriati Looks Back to Go Forward
description: There are some moments in Jennifer Capriati's teenage past that she is eager to hold on to, happy to call up on cue.

title: More Muscular Software Makes VCD's Feel the Burn
description: Still saving up the $800 for a DVD burner? In the meantime, the newest version of Toast software from Roxio Inc. makes it possible for Macintosh users to both encode and burn video CD's that will play on most DVD machines, although the picture quality will not match that of a true DVD. Roxio already produces a similar product for Windows, Easy CD Creator, but this is the first combination encoder and burner product especially for Macs.

title: Essay; Ariel Makes His Point to George
description: ''The world is celebrating the cease-fire,'' Ariel Sharon told George W. Bush in the Oval Office this week, ''but we in Israel are going to funerals.'' That pained remark came privately after the U.S. president had used the word ''progress'' 11 times in 13 minutes of the photo op before their meeting.

title: Article 2001062891167191764 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes in Advertising
description: Jody Bilney, president for consumer markets in the retail markets group at Verizon Communications, Dallas and New York, was named senior vice president for brand management and marketing communications. She succeeds Janet Keeler, who is retiring, the company said. Ms. Keeler was based in New York.

title: An Edison Unit Cuts Its Bond Sale 40%
description: A unit of Edison International was forced yesterday to cut a planned sale of high-yield bonds by 40 percent, to $700 million, and offer higher yields to raise money needed to repay bank debt that is maturing this week.

title: America's Cheese State Fights to Stay That Way; Wisconsin Struggles to Keep Pace With West
description: In an old red barn set amid green pastures, Eugene Kegler is milking cows in the late afternoon and wondering whether the sun is about to set on this way of life.

title: Message to Marketers: RU4 Real?
description: EVERY day, on millions of computers, instant messages become carriers for the drama and detritus of daily life. Parents send instant messages to make weekend plans with extended family, students pass each other private notes about classmates, spouses check on whether to pick up dinner on the way home.

title: Beijing Journal; Traffic Is a Mess, and Cabbies Find a Way to Vent
description: Hop into a taxicab from the mad jangle of roads here any weekday morning, and there is a fair chance you will hear the soothing voice of Liang Hong on her radio program, ''Hello Taxi,'' often with John Denver's ''Take Me Home, Country Roads'' playing in the background.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: High Court Rules Immigrants Can't Be Confined Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 -- In its second decision this week affirming the rights of immigrants, the Supreme Court ruled today that the government may not detain deportable aliens indefinitely simply for lack of a country willing to take them.

title: Nasdaq Ends Ties With Messner
description: The Nasdaq stock market said yesterday that it had ended its more than decade-long relationship with Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York by eliminating the agency from a review for its creative and media accounts. Spending was estimated at $30 million.

title: State of the Art: Palmtops With a P, as in PC
description: PART of the agony and the ecstasy of being human is our ability to confront the big questions. What's the meaning of existence? Is there life after death? And which is better: the Palm or the Pocket PC?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Teamsters convention in Las Vegas referred incorrectly to a 1996 government investigation of a Teamsters local in Chicago headed then by William T. Hogan Jr. Investigators found nepotism and other problems at the local, but they did not bring internal union charges against Mr. Hogan, who was suspended by the union. The article also referred incorrectly to Dane Passo, who along with Mr. Hogan was charged internally last month with negotiating an improper deal to have nonunion workers set up and take down conventions in Las Vegas. He is no longer a regional Teamsters official.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: No More Draft
description: The government announced that it would stop the military draft immediately, more than a year ahead of its plan to switch to a totally professional army. In a joint statement, President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who are expected to face each other in next year's presidential election, said the military could do without the draft earlier than expected because enough recruits were joining the army voluntarily. The gradual transition to a professional army, which began in 1996, has prompted occasional protests from young men who wanted the draft ended more quickly. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Reporter Sent To Prison
description: Jiang Weiping, a reporter working in China for a Hong Kong magazine, has been sentenced to four years in prison for leaking state secrets. Mr. Jiang, a Chinese citizen, wrote about a series of corruption scandals that have racked northeast China and dared to implicate powerful local officials.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Antitrust Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court overturned Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling to break up the Microsoft Corporation today, and it ordered the judge removed from the case, saying his actions "seriously tainted the proceedings."

title: Senators Hear Bitter Words on Florida Vote
description: At an acrimonious hearing that showed how bitter the fight remains over the Florida election last fall, two members of the United States Civil Rights Commission strafed each other today and called each other liars. Even Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, got into the act.

title: High Court Rules Immigrants Can't Be Confined Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Immigrants who have committed crimes in the United States cannot be confined in this country indefinitely just because no other country will take them, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Time Plus Gas Equals . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly Note From I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Rocky Courtship, Tyson and IBP Will Merge
description: Three months after the breakup of a contentious courtship characterized by lawsuits and recriminations, Tyson Foods and IBP announced yesterday that they had settled their differences and recommitted themselves to a merger.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Dropping Factories
description: Following a widening trend out of equipment manufacturing, Alcatel said it would cut the number of its factories to a dozen or less from the roughly 120 it operated last year by selling some to contract manufacturers and closing others. Serge Tchuruk, above, the chief executive of Alcatel, whose bid for Lucent Technologies collapsed last month, said Alcatel would not hesitate to use outside contractors. Earlier this year, Alcatel transferred the production of cell phones to an outside contractor and sold its Internet modem and cable manufacturing units. Motorola and Nokia of Finland have also farmed out some production of mobile phones to cut costs, while Royal Philips Electronics and Ericsson have largely abandoned mobile phone manufacturing altogether. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Powell Arrives in Israel to Push Peace Effort
description: With open disagreement between the United States and Israel on the next steps needed to find peace in the Middle East, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here tonight to persuade the Israeli government to move forward and to urge the Palestinians to keep the situation calm.

title: The Principals in the Marbury Trade
description: Mike Wise assesses the trade between the Nets and the Phoenix Suns.

title: $450 Tickets Going Fast
description: Backstage at the U2 concert on Sunday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in New Jersey, there were stacks of two-page, stapled papers offering tickets to Madonna's sold-out concerts at the arena on Aug. 2 and 3. The price for the tickets was $450, which is $200 higher than the advertised top ticket price for Madonna's tour. But these weren't illegally marked-up tickets from scalpers. They were part of what is known as a V.I.P. package, which is increasingly becoming a standard way for the concert business to make extra money from concertgoers.

title: Stocks Climb on Fed Cut and Microsoft Ruling
description: Stocks rose in a broad rally today, although prices eased in late trading, a day after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the sixth time this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEZ, SILVIO, M.D.
description: BAEZ-Silvio, M.D., 85. Of Yorktown Heights and Colonel Greene Road, died Monday, June 25, 2001 at the Fletcher Allen Health Care Center in Burlington, VT. He had been living with his son and daughter in law, Ricardo and Dolores Baez on East Parkside Terrace in Barre, VT since August of last year. Born on July 6, 1915 in Guarambare, Paraguay, he was the son of Ricardo & Regina Baez-Acosta. During the Chaco War (1932-1935) in Paraguay, he served as an Infantry Captain having been decorated for Valor and being wounded. Following his army service, he received his doctorate of medicine from the University of Asuncion in Asuncion, Paraguay in 1942. He then received a U.S. Government Fellowship to Cornell Medical School in NYC in Physiology Research. He became an Assistant Professor of Physiology and Anesthesiology at the New York University School of Medicine. In 1985, he became a full Professor of Physiology and Anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in NYC, retiring later that year. On April 15, 1973, he received the Eugene M. Landis Research Award for his outstanding contributions in Microvascular Research. In 1985, he was recognized for his many years as Director of Anesthesiology Research Laboratories by his colleagues of the Department of Anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. On April 14, 2000, he became a life member of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He was also a life member of the New York Academy of Sciences, a member of the Microcirculatory Society and the Yorktown Heights (NY) Community Association. Survivors include a daughter, Annacleta Regina Baez of New York City; two sons, Ricardo Silvio Baez and his wife Dolores of Barre, VT and Pedro Lorenzo Baez of Randolph, VT; two grandchildren, Alexandria Elena Baez and Peter Lorenzo Baez Jr.; three sisters, Betty Campos-Baez, Chiquita Chaux-Baez and Quillia Baez, all of Asuncion, Paraguay and nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by a brother, Professor Pedro Baez and a sister, Alcira Cardenas-Baez, M.D. A Service of Remembrance will be held at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of New York City, to be arranged by his family at a time to be announced. A Service of Remembrance will also be held at the Barre, VT Universalist Church on Sunday, July 8, 2001 at 2:00 PM. There are no calling hours. Later, entombment will be in the family mausoleum with his long time companion, Professor Patricia Carpenter, in the Recoleta Cemetery in Asuncion, Paraguay. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Central Vermont Home Health & Hospice, 600 Granger Road, Barre, VT 05641. Services are under the direction of the Hooker and Whitcomb Funeral Home, 7 Academy St, Barre, VT.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Ties With Turkey
description: Turkey has become the latest country to form diplomatic relations with North Korea. South Korea said North Korean relations with Turkey, whose troops were reputed to be some of the toughest soldiers under the United Nations command in the Korean War, would ''contribute to peace and stability on the Korean peninsula.'' North Korea, slowly emerging from isolation, has established relations with 10 other nations this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: AIDS Policy Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mlange of Hollywood, Broadway and Bebop Tunes
description: Keith Jarrett's trio, with the bassist Gary Peacock and the drummer Jack DeJohnette, sometimes seems like three or four bands in one. Hollywood, Broadway and bebop standards have been its bread and butter, though Mr. Jarrett's repertory goes beyond the list of tunes that a majority of jazz players like to exercise on; it gets into semi-obscure film soundtrack pieces, with occasional reaches back into prewar jazz styles and forward into free jazz.

title: A Hotel Alliance Splits Up, but Schrager Presses Ahead
description: The publicized alliance between the hotel impresario Ian Schrager and two internationally known architects to build a hotel on Astor Place in Manhattan has fallen apart.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Violent Thief Pleads
description: A violent thief who terrorized Manhattan's Upper West Side last summer pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to a murder and several burglaries and assaults, as part of an agreement that reduced his sentence from a possible 50 years to 35 years to life in prison. The thief, Van Baskerville, 38, a homeless ex-convict, admitted to eight burglaries between West 81st and West 105th Streets; four people were injured. In an instance on West 93rd Street, he stabbed an elderly man with part of a lamp, leaving him in critical condition for months until he died of his injuries. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: A New Ethanol Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Annan Named Unanimously To a 2nd Term
description: Without a dissenting voice, the Security Council nominated Secretary General Kofi Annan to a second term today, months ahead of a deadline at the end of the year.

title: Defense Psychiatrist Tells Jury of Embassy Bomber's Remorse
description: A terrorist who could face execution for his role in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania told a psychiatrist in a recent interview in prison that he regretted that he ''did not ask more questions about what they were doing.''

title: Marathon Raises Prizes
description: When the New York City Marathon is held this year, the prize money will be higher and the run for it will be slightly different, the New York Road Runners Club announced yesterday.

title: Article 2001062891625267107 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Robert McKinney, 90, Editor Who Regained Paper's Control
description: Robert M. McKinney, the editor and publisher of The Santa Fe New Mexican, who fought an 11-year battle to reclaim the newspaper from the Gannett Company, died on Sunday in New York, where he maintained a residence. He was 90.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senator Wants Better Counsel In Capital Cases
description: Six death row inmates have been exonerated in five states so far this year, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said at a Congressional hearing on a bill he is sponsoring to set standards for counsel in capital cases. Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine and a co-sponsor of the legislation, said that if history was any guide, some of the 3,700 men and women currently on death row were innocent. The Constitution Project, a bipartisan group that includes supporters and opponents of the death penalty, endorsed the need for better legal representation in capital cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDDY, MONICA AGNES
description: RUDDY-Monica Agnes, June 26, 2001. Daughter of the late Patrick and the late Brigid Ruddy. Mother of Robert Ruddy of Denver, CO. Grandmother of Jack Ruddy. Sister of the late Robert F. Ruddy. Sister-in-law of Dolores Ruddy of Tarpon Springs, FL. Aunt of Sheila Hartigan, Monica Duquette, and the late Dennis Ruddy. Also survived by several grandnieces and grandnephew. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Friday, June 29, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, June 30, 10 AM, St. John the Martyr Church, NYC.

title: Men Who Are Out of It: Physically, Mentally, Socially
description: UP IN THE AIR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNST, HOWARD L.
description: ERNST-Howard L. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of the beloved son of the late Abraham Ernst and the late Beatrice Ernst Daffner, a longtime friend and supporter; brother of Judith Linn and Naomi Paley; and nephew of E. Billi Ivry, a YU Trustee and Benefactor. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: VA Linux To Quit Hardware Market
description: VA Linux Systems Inc. will exit the hardware business by the end of July to focus on application software and consulting services, the company said yesterday. VA Linux, based in Freemont, Calif., sells servers and workstations designed for use with the Linux operating system. It also announced plans to lay off 35 percent of its 436 employees. VA Linux, which posted a third-quarter loss of $110 million on revenue of $20.3 million, said that it planned to focus on technology that helps software developers collaborate on large projects. Its shares closed at $3.26, down 3 cents, after trading was halted for the news.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Name
description: The hospitality company Bass P.L.C. said it would give up its name, known to beer lovers, and its ubiquitous red triangle logo in favor of Six Continents P.L.C., so called because the company operates in six continents. The name, chosen by an employee, is protected by trademarks and will cost 375,000 ($531,000) to make official, the company said. Shareholders will vote on the change July 20. Bass said it must cease using its name by Aug. 21, as part of its agreement to sell Bass Brewers to Interbrew last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: PINNACLE SAYS IT WILL POST LOSS ON WEAK CASINO RESULTS
description: Pinnacle Entertainment Inc., the casino operator, said it would report a loss in the second quarter on weaker-than-expected results in Indiana and Louisiana. Pinnacle, which is based in Glendale, Calif., may lose as much as $5.5 million, or 21 cents a share, the company said. Pinnacle was expected to earn 10 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Forget the Violin and Keyboard; Listen to the Plumbing
description: There is something charming about a new-music concert at which the high tech and the handmade sit side by side.

title: High Court Rules Immigrants Can't Be Confined Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Immigrants who have committed crimes in the United States cannot be confined in this country indefinitely just because no other country will take them, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Gun Control Groups To Merge
description: Two gun control groups, the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence and the Million Mom March organization, will join forces, bringing together hundreds of thousands of activists. After the mothers' group organized a march on Mother's Day last year, Michael Barnes, president of the Brady Campaign, suggested a merger. The Brady Campaign said it has 500,000 members. The Million Mom March organization said that it did not have a membership total, but that it had more than 230 chapters nationwide.

title: Lawyer Urges Change in Conduct of Lineups
description: David Feige is putting the judges in the Bronx courthouse up to a dare.

title: Boxer Hurt in Bout on Intrepid in Very Critical Condition
description: A boxer who sustained a severe head injury in a bout Tuesday night on the deck of a retired aircraft carrier was in very critical condition last night after surgery at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, a hospital official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILAVEC, JOHN E.
description: MILAVEC-John E. Monroe College notes with profound regret and sadness the untimely passing of our beloved, former Vice President, who served the students, faculty and staff of the College for 25 years.
