His vision, leadership and marvelous understanding of people made him a great example to the higher education community. He was a special person who will be greatly missed. All of us were better off for having known him. Stephen J. Jerome, President

title: Three Stories Tall, And a Hundred Deep
description: LATE one night at Quatorze Bis, the stylish French bistro on the Upper East Side, the conversation turned to chopped liver. Peter L. Meltzer, a co-owner of the restaurant, at 323 East 79th Street, pointed to the ceiling. ''Have you ever been up there?'' he asked.

title: A Reassurance On Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Two-Party System

title: Article 2001062892043769385 -- No Title
description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: Cite Your Sites!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Needle Exchanges, Against the Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: Chico O'Farrill, 79, Musician And Leader in Afro-Cuban Jazz
description: Chico O'Farrill, the composer, arranger and onetime trumpeter who was one of the primary creators of Afro-Cuban jazz, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cheney Says He Expects to Receive Heart Device
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Vice President Dick Cheney said today that doctors would almost certainly implant a sophisticated heart pacemaker and defibrillator during an operation on Saturday, his third significant medical procedure to combat heart disease since he was elected vice president.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Hofstra Student Indicted In Killing
description: A Nassau County grand jury has indicted Shaun T. Alexander on first-degree murder charges in the killing of his classmate at Hofstra University, making Mr. Alexander liable for the death penalty, Denis E. Dillon, the county district attorney, said yesterday. The grand jury accused Mr. Alexander, 23, of Dunwoody, Ga., of intentionally killing Max B. Kolb, 20, at a Hicksville motel on April 25. Mr. Alexander was also accused of first-degree kidnapping and first-degree attempted sexual abuse. Mr. Dillon has not sought the death penalty since it was restored in New York State in 1995. Al Baker (NYT)

title: U.N. Responds to AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Maurice Victor, 81, a Neurologist and Teacher
description: Dr. Maurice Victor, a neurologist, teacher and textbook author, died on June 21 at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 81.

title: Rome Journal; Colorful Characters Lurk Around Monuments
description: When the conservative media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi was elected prime minister last month, Italians -- and many Europeans -- were betting that Umberto Bossi, the excitable, bellicose leader of the right-wing Northern League, would be the first member of the new government to set off an international ruckus.

title: Clarence Thomas: Echoes of '91
description: To the Editor:

title: Outpouring of Loyalty as Milosevic Departs
description: The transfer of Slobodan Milosevic today brought joy and relief to some, particularly the young, angered others in its speed and stealth, and left many more ambivalent for their deep distrust of a Hague tribunal they feel is biased against the Serbs.

title: 'Unfolding': The Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company Speeds Ahead
description: Only one of the three works by Nai-Ni Chen that her Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company presented last Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo was called "Unfolding." But that title was appropriate to two offerings by this troupe, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Acquisitions Made Here and Overseas
description: Several acquisitions are being made for undisclosed terms.

title: Police to Investigate a Detective's Allegations of Corruption
description: Responding swiftly to a police detective's allegations of corruption in the Internal Affairs Bureau, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would order senior police officials to conduct their own investigation of the charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTERS, ADELE
description: WINTERS-Adele. On June 27, 2001. Mother of Susan and Robert Grossman and Dr. Alan and Janet Winters. Sister of Marian Weisenfreund. Grandmother of Eric and Lori, Cheryl and Rich, Jill and Greg, Marci and J.P. and Jarod, and great-grandmother of eight. You will always be remembered in our hearts. Funeral services today 10:15am from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: 'Au Naturel'
description: Keith De Lellis Gallery

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Arts section on Wednesday about the New York City Hip-Hop Theater Festival, whose executive producer is Danny Hoch, misstated the pronunciation of his surname. It is ''hock,'' not ''hawk.''

title: Boys Tell of Man's Beating, but None Use the Word 'Murder'
description: One by one, the 11 boys sat down with police detectives to answer questions about their encounter last week with a homeless alcoholic who was nameless to them. They referred to him as ''some bum,'' the ''bummy-looking guy,'' the ''old guy'' and ''the man that died.''

title: Citigroup Set To End Tactic On Mortgages
description: Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that it would stop selling a type of mortgage insurance that consumer advocates have criticized as a tool for siphoning off the home equity of low-income borrowers.

title: Longhorns' Loss Is Gain for Reds
description: The former college quarterback has given up football to concentrate on baseball and is rocketing through the minor leagues, leaving a wake of pitchers craning their necks.

title: Art in Review
description: Dreams and Disillusion'

title: Clarence Thomas: Echoes of '91
description: To the Editor:

title: Wistful Joy in Soda-Fountain Dreams
description: IF the world were a perfect place, the Wayne Thiebaud retrospective that has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art would be nailed to the walls for good and we would be free to stop by whenever we needed to remind ourselves what happiness feels like. The world not being perfect, the show is around through the summer, so consider yourself forewarned. At the Whitney, as in life, happiness is fleeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military & fraternal organizations. A funeral service was held on June 27, at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, followed by private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY, on June 28. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011. May flights of angels attend her to her resting place.

title: California Cites Generators For Withholding Documents
description: California legislators turned up the heat on power generating companies today, citing two of them for not handing over documents necessary in the state's continuing hearings on the spike in electricity prices.

title: Clarence Thomas: Echoes of '91
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE Bloomsbury , the publisher of the Harry Potter books, said first-half sales and profits would beat last year's figures by a "substantial margin." Its shares rose as much as 7.7 percent, to 842.5 pence ($11.94). Last year, Bloomsbury said first-half sales reached $16 million, before the publication of the fourth book by J.K. Rowling, "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," which sold 370,000 copies in Britain on its first day. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: On Pro Basketball; Oakland's Gritty Playgrounds Gave Birth to a Legend
description: More than 11 years ago, Jason Kidd played basketball at the Oakland Coliseum for the first time. He was a high school sophomore at St. Joseph's in Alameda, a private Catholic preparatory school taking on the most powerful team in northern California, the all-black Skyline of Oakland -- Gary Payton's old public school.

title: Benitez Can't Come to the Rescue of the Mets' Weak Bats
description: The final blow was instantaneous and devastating, as it often is when Armando Benitez loses a game. With one out in the bottom of the 10th inning at Turner Field, Javy Lopez buried a high fastball into the left-field seats for a grand slam, giving the Atlanta Braves a 6-2 victory over the Mets.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about charges in the shooting death of a black woman in the 1969 racial rioting in York, Pa., referred incorrectly to Mayor Charles Robertson. He withdrew his bid for a third term last month after being charged in the case. He did not resign.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Change In Abuse Hearings
description: The Board of Education will end procedures that allow suspected victims of sexual crimes to be cross-examined by lawyers for students accused of committing the crimes, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday. The change will take effect before the next school year. The announcement came after Edward F. Stancik, the special commissioner for investigation, released a report saying that at some of the hearings victims were being asked questions about their sexual history in front of their parents and their suspected attackers. Such questions have long been barred in court hearings and other forums. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Council Bill Tries to Crack Down on the Clank of the Bat
description: Into the annals of legislating personal behavior, already filled with edicts on smoking in restaurants and using cellular phones while driving, comes a bill by two City Council members to take metal bats out of the hands of young baseball players.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Brownfields Center Planned
description: A research and training center for cleaning polluted industrial lands known as brownfields will be established as part of the State University of New York and will be housed at a brownfield site in Utica after the site is cleaned, state officials said on Wednesday. Until the cleanup, the SUNY Center for Brownfield Studies is to operate, beginning this fall, in a temporary location nearby. Besides fostering new technologies for returning brownfields to productive use, the center is to offer bachelor's and master's degree programs in brownfield redevelopment. The 142-acre Utica site, whose past uses have included the manufacture of gas extracted from coal, was inherited in recent years by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation from one of its predecessor companies, the officials said. They added that Niagara Mohawk, which is helping devise a cleanup plan for the site, is to contribute $250,000 to the SUNY center over the next three years. A bill to provide $200 million in state funds to help pay for brownfield cleanups is being debated in the State Legislature. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: RANGERS MAY TRAIN AT GARDEN
description: The Rangers have not made a postseason appearance since 1997, but they may be around Madison Square Garden in the preseason more than usual late this summer. The team has tentative plans to hold its training camp at the Garden.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss For Fuel Processor
description: British Nuclear Fuels, the troubled, state-owned British nuclear fuel processor, said yesterday that it had lost 210 million ($296 million) before one-time items in the year to March, in contrast to a profit of 74 million a year earlier. The company has been dogged by controversy over the falsification of data accompanying a fuel shipment. The British government says it wants to sell shares in the company but no offering is likely soon, the company said. British Nuclear Fuels said ''disappointing overall performance'' was in part a result of the closing of a generator for much of the year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Albany Wins Right to Limit Power Prices
description: Seeking to curb profiteering by power plant owners, the federal government has granted New York the power to limit spikes in the price of electricity this summer, to prevent the soaring rates that hit consumers last summer.

title: Milking Black Pop Culture For Splendidness and Fun
description: A little of the sketch character Pootie Tang went a long way on HBO's now late, probably soon to be lamented ''Chris Rock Show.'' So it's surprising how much fun the character's film debut, ''Pootie Tang,'' is. The shtick built around Pootie (Lance Crouther) is a parody of the inexorable swiftness of hip-hop cool and slang that is cultural currency one week and utterly devalued the next. The sketches fixated on Pootie's patter, a dialect that is a language all its own -- words like tippi-tai for kids -- and its siren's-call effect on, well, sirens.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review in Weekend last Friday about two exhibitions of work by Mies van der Rohe referred incorrectly to the world's fair that inspired ''The Dynamo and the Virgin,'' a chapter of ''The Education of Henry Adams,'' to which a photograph of a metallic turbine in ''Mies in America'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art was compared. It was the 1900 World Exposition in Paris, not the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, RALPH L.
description: SCHUMAN-Ralph L. On June 27, 2001. Dearly beloved husband of Jocelyn (Cohen Luskin). Loving father of Steven (Anne) and Deborah Wohl (Steven). Also survived by Jocelyn's children Mindy Aleman (Gary) and Joanne Zicherman. Proud grandfather of Lisa and Michael Strug, David and Dana Schuman, Jonathan Wohl, Larissa Wohl, Hunter and Troy Aleman, and Lucy Zicherman. Brother of Elliott. Service Friday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bloodless Bullfights
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Faces Defeat on Patients' Rights Bill
description: The shape of Senate legislation to define patients' rights became clear today as Democrats pressed for swift passage of the bill and Republican senators accepted the prospect of defeat on major issues of concern to President Bush.

title: Yellowstone National Park
description: Travelers who book online can take advantage of summer and fall lodging specials at Yellowstone National Park lodges. From Aug. 17 to Sept. 7 and again from Sept. 23 to 29,a mid-price room at Grant Lodge is $69, a high-range room is $79. From Aug. 17 to Sept. 7 and again Sept. 30 to Oct. 7 at the Mammoth Hot Springs Hotel, a room with shared bath is $39, and $69 with private bath; a budget cabin is $39, a frontier cabin $69. At the Lake Hotel Sept. 30 to Oct. 7, a lakeside room is $109, and other rooms are $99. At the Old Faithful Snow Lodge Oct. 7 to 13, a lodge room is $99. Availability is limited, and the fall specials must be booked by Sept. 1. The Web site, www.travelyellowstone.com , also carries occasional unadvertised specials, the park says. The telephone number is (307) 334-7311.

title: Wasting No Time in Her Short Stint in the Big Chair
description: IT'S a blazing hot day, and Sherida E. Paulsen, the new chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, has already hoofed around Harlem this morning to scout a neighborhood, which she won't name, as a potential historic district. She's brought two blouses to the office. (Hey, it's sweaty work, these walking tours!)

title: 'Popular Mechanics'
description: Smack Mellon Studios

title: CONAGRA PROFITS FALL 38% IN ITS FOURTH QUARTER
description: ConAgra Foods Inc. said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 38 percent because of higher energy and marketing costs and inventory reductions by grocers. ConAgra, based in Omaha, said it spent more to promote food products, including Butterball turkeys and Chef Boyardee pasta, just as the economy slowed. Reduced profits from its seed, pesticide and fertilizer businesses contributed to the second consecutive quarterly decline in profit. Sales in the quarter rose 4.7 percent from the period a year earlier, to $6.44 billion, in part because of its acquisition of International Home Foods. Income in the quarter ended May 27 fell to $121.4 million, or 23 cents a share, from $195.1 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier.

title: RITE AID NAMES NEW EXECUTIVE AND CLOSES REFINANCING
description: The Rite Aid Corporation drugstore chain has hired a former executive of Albertson's Inc., Mark Panzer, to lead store operations as the company completes $3 billion in debt refinancing. Mr. Panzer, 44, will be executive vice president for store operations at Rite Aid, a new position reporting to the president and chief operating officer, Mary Sammons, the company said. Panzer was vice president for marketing and sales at Albertsons, the food-and-drug retailer. Separately, Rite Aid, based in Camp Hill, Pa., said it had refinanced $3 billion in debt, more than $1 billion of which was due next year.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Article 2001062991213268706 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Legislature Passes Budget and Medical Lawsuit Bill
description: In its annual frenzy before the summer recess, the Legislature took action today on more than 200 bills, approving what is being called the nation's strongest law allowing patients to sue their health maintenance organizations and passing a $22.9 billion budget for the coming year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Buys A Music Service
description: As part of its effort to expand its entertainment offerings, Yahoo said yesterday that it had acquired Launch Media, a Web music broadcast site that lets users personalize play lists. Users can also download music, read reviews and watch music videos on personal computers. The transaction was valued at $12 million, based on a price of 92 cents a share. The great popularity of Napster led many Internet companies to make investments in music services in the last year, hoping to gain a piece of a new market. Launch Media, based in Santa Monica, Calif., has 7.4 million users. Its headquarters will remain after the deal is completed. Launch Media also announced that it had settled a copyright-infringement suit brought by the Universal Music Group and other record producers in connection with Launchcast the company's Internet radio service. As part of the settlement, Launch Media will pay for past performances and will continue to use Universal recordings on a nonexclusive basis. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Wrong Place, Wrong Time
description: It was a bad autumn for corporate Australia, with a spate of collapses. And it has not gone unnoticed by the news media here that a couple of the highest-profile debacles had something in common.

title: 'Some (Are) Painting'
description: John Gibson

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Lawmaker Bows Out Of Senate Run
description: Although heavily courted by national and state Democratic leaders, Representative Bob Etheridge said he would not run next year for the Senate seat now held by Jesse Helms, the veteran conservative Republican. Mr. Etheridge, a three-term moderate who represents the Second Congressional District in the center of the state, took himself out of the running on Wednesday, becoming the fourth top Democrat to do so. Mr. Helms, 79, has recently suffered some health problems and has not said whether he will seek a sixth term. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: SCHLUMBERGER TO SELL NATURAL GAS UNIT TO HANOVER
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the provider of oil field services, agreed yesterday to sell the part of its business that compresses natural gas for shipping and storage to the Hanover Compressor Company for as much as $761 million so it can focus on helping energy explorers extract oil and gas. Hanover, based in Houston, will pay $270 million in cash and $283 million in stock, as well as give Schlumberger a $150 million note. Schlumberger will also get as much as $58 million for a joint venture Hanover will acquire, the companies said. As part of the agreement, Schlumberger will own 10 percent of Hanover.

title: Boxer Deteriorating; State Reviewing Videotape of Fight
description: The New York State agency that oversees boxing has begun a review of a bout in Manhattan on Tuesday night that left a fighter in a coma, a state official said yesterday.

title: Powell Backing Plan to Monitor Mideast Truce
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that observers would be needed to monitor a cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians. Then, as he prepared to end his 36-hour visit, Secretary Powell announced a seven-week timetable for the two sides to end hostilities and move toward political talks.

title: London's Black Cabs May Not Rule for Long
description: THE famous black taxis of London are a protected but endangered species.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Wednesday about ''Lumumba,'' a film about Patrice Lumumba, the Congo's first prime minister, misidentified the Belgian king who ruled the Congo until it became a republic in 1960. He was Baudouin, not Leopold II. The review also misspelled the surname of the Congo's first president. He was Joseph Kasavubu, not Kasa Vubu.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: German Court Fines Hewlett
description: Hewlett-Packard was ordered by a German court to pay fees on compact disc burners it has sold there over the last three years. The court order is a result of a law passed last year that requires a fee equivalent to $1.58 under current exchange rates for each CD burner sold in Germany in the last three years, and $5.28 for each CD burner sold in the future. The fees were proposed by a German copyright organization as a way of offsetting losses incurred by the music industry from music piracy. Other CD burner manufacturers will also be affected. P. J. McNealy, a senior analyst with the Gartner Group, said that more such suits could be expected. ''Now that we're in the digital age of entertainment,'' he said, ''movie and music bootlegs are all going to be moved around in ways not previously envisioned so this is a method of royalties payment.'' Shares of Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose 80 cents yesterday, to $27.25.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Where Everything Clicks
description: IF you want to come and hear those dancing feet on Broadway, the listening will be easy. Experimental dance-driven shows like ''Fosse,'' ''Contact'' and ''Swing!'' were dominant last year, but more recent musicals are song-and-dance affairs strong on old-time production numbers with tap-dancing chorus girls.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Stem Cell Funding Is Urged
description: About 30 House Republicans signed a letter urging President Bush to permit federal financing for embryonic stem cell research, a field that is controversial because it involves the destruction of human embryos. The letter's author, Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, declined to make it public. The White House is deeply divided on the issue. Some officials argue the research can lead to new treatments, while others say federal support for experiments with stem cells, which are extracted from human embryos, will alienate conservatives and abortion opponents. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: From the U.N.'s Statement on AIDS: 'Prevention Must Be the Mainstay'
description: Following are excerpts from the Declaration of Commitment on H.I.V./AIDS adopted on Wednesday by the United Nations General Assembly:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: America The Wild

title: Jack Lemmon, Dark and Comic Actor, Dies at 76
description: Jack Lemmon, the brash young American Everyman who evolved into the screen's grumpiest old Everyman during a movie career that lasted a half century, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Yun-Fei Ji
description: Pierogi

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: MILOSEVIC IS GIVEN TO U.N. FOR TRIAL IN WAR-CRIME CASE
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader blamed for starting four Balkan wars and impoverishing and isolating his country, was delivered early this morning to a prison cell and eventual trial by the United Nations war crimes tribunal here.

title: Tires, Lawyers, Defects
description: To the Editor:

title: On Pro Basketball; Youngsters Forced To Grow Up Quickly
description: Less than an hour after he was drafted, Tyson Chandler made his first move. Shipped from the Clippers and his Southern California comfort zone to the Bulls and blustery Chicago, the 7-foot, 18-year-old Chandler became a shifting commodity, chosen at the N.B.A.'s annual auction and then promptly sold.

title: Appeals Court Voids Order for Breaking Up Microsoft
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  A federal appeals court unanimously threw out a lower court's order today that the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ) should be broken up, although the appeals court found that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.

title: Jury in Embassy Bomb Case Hears Terrorist's Relatives
description: A terrorist who could face the death penalty for the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania wept silently in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday as his mother and other close relatives described their grief at the prospect that he might be executed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, HOWARD MYRON
description: FOSTER-Howard Myron. Beloved husband of Annette Eizenberg Etlin. Loving brother of Robert and Marcia. Cherished grandfather of Jacob Seth Rubin. Fond brother-in-law of Elliot Eizenberg and Marcia. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Services Friday, June 29, 11AM, Sutton Place Synagogue. Shiva at Foster home, 2-8PM, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday. Donations to Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, New York City.

title: Article 2001062991386242532 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Minnesota Lawmakers Rush To Avoid a State Shutdown
description: Minnesota lawmakers pushed through a flurry of compromises and votes today that legislative leaders hoped could help stave off Gov. Jesse Ventura's threat of a partial state government shutdown.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Saturday about an article on Friday on the indictment of 14 people in the truck bombing of the Khobar Towers apartment complex in Saudi Arabia misstated the year of the bombing. It was 1996, not 1993.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: George Senesky, 79, All-American Who Played in the N.B.A.
description: George Senesky, an all-American basketball player at St. Joseph's of Philadelphia and a player and coach for N.B.A. champion Philadelphia Warrior teams, died Monday at a hospital in Cape May Courthouse, N.J. He was 79.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rape Suspect Arrested
description: A 29-year-old Flushing man, on probation for robbery, was arrested yesterday and charged in a string of violent attacks on women that started in February, the police said. Charges against the man, Edwin Feliciano, include multiple counts of rape, robbery, sexual abuse and harassment involving eight attacks in Queens and one in Manhattan. Mr. Feliciano preyed on 20- to 30-year-old women, most of them of Asian descent, as they made their way home after midnight, the police said. Several victims identified Mr. Feliciano in a police lineup, the police said; results of DNA tests are pending. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Nurses Join Labor Federation
description: United American Nurses, the labor arm of the American Nurses Association, voted to join the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The group, which includes more than 100,000 registered nurses from 23 states, is joining the labor federation to gain its support in labor disputes and reduce warring with federation unions seeking to organize nurses. The American Nurses Association, a professional association that represents the nation's 2.7 million registered nurses, set up United American Nurses in 1999 to bargain collectively with hospitals. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Dweck to Shut Doors After a 9-Year Run
description: Dweck in New York, an agency known for producing award-winning, attention-getting campaigns for smaller advertisers, said yesterday that it would close after nine years.

title: The Unconventional and the Unloved in an Urban Mosaic
description: KISSING IN MANHATTAN

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST OREGON: SCHOOL SAFETY LAW PASSED Gov. John Kitzhaber signed a package of school safety measures into law, including one that creates a statewide toll-free hot line for students to alert the authorities anonymously about potential violence. Another law requires schools to establish antibullying policies. The package is in response to a wave of school shootings around the country, including a 1998 rampage in which a 15-year-old Oregon high school student, Kip Kinkel, killed 2 students and wounded 25 others.    Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Ulster Leader to Quit Despite Pleas From Britain and Ireland
description: Last-ditch talks conducted by Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, in Belfast today failed to dissuade the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble from resigning this weekend as head of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Court Clarifies Police Search
description: New York State's high court ruled yesterday that the police could not board buses and demand to see passengers' identification merely because the buses had come from New York City, a known drug portal. Without a specific reason to ask for each person's identification, the court said, the demand is illegal. In a unanimous decision, the Court of Appeals reversed a decision by both a trial court and an Appellate Division panel in Albany. It ordered that Rawle McIntosh, who had served four years of sentence of eight and a half years to life, be set free. In 1997, the police found that Mr. McIntosh, a bus passenger, was carrying two ounces of cocaine.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Charges Against Former Ruler
description: A group of Ivoirians victimized during the presidential election last year has filed suit in Belgium charging crimes against humanity by the government of President Laurent Gbagbo and the former military ruler, Gen. Robert Gue. Under an unusual law, Belgian courts have universal jurisdiction in cases of crimes against humanity, and four Rwandans were recently convicted for their roles in the 1994 genocide. Many Ivoirians from the Muslim north were the targets of attacks during the October election by soldiers allied with General Gue and paramilitary police close to President Gbagbo. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Unscathed in the Inferno, a Man's Spirit
description: The left side of his upper body, where the tremendous thrust of a fireball struck and threw him 20 feet, is swollen, red and tender. One eye will not blink. And his mouth, still more often smiling than not, opens across the face at an unnatural angle, more vertical than horizontal because of a broken jaw.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: E-Commerce Lobby Formed
description: A group of e-commerce companies and trade groups including eBay, Orbitz and the Electronic Commerce Association have joined forces to create a lobbying organization in Washington. The goal of the new lobby, NetChoice, is ''defending online businesses against efforts to stifle Internet-based competition with protectionist legislation or regulation,'' its officials said. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and Representative Gerald C. Weller, Republican of Illinois, praised the goals. ''If the Internet revolution has shown us anything, it's that technological innovation and a robust marketplace are an unbeatable combination,'' Mr. Lieberman, above, said.

title: Foreign Affairs; Soul Brother
description: Can you imagine what the right-wing Wall Street Journal editorial page would have written had Bill Clinton, in his first meeting with President Vladimir Putin of Russia, declared afterward, as President Bush did, that he had looked Mr. Putin in the eye, got a sense of his ''soul'' and found the former K.G.B. boss a ''remarkable leader,'' an ''honest, straightforward man . . . who loves his family''? Let's see, the lead editorial in The Journal would have been titled ''Soul Brother.'' There would have been one of those little drawings of Mr. Clinton over the caption ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' and the first line of the editorial would have read: ''For a guy who says he never inhaled, we can't help but wonder what exactly President Clinton was smoking when he met Vladimir Putin the other day. . . .''

title: Article 2001062994200663440 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Water's Red, and It's Not Kool-Aid
description: Loud, flashy and steeped in gore, Mathieu Kassovitz's action-thriller ''The Crimson Rivers'' isn't kidding when it describes itself as a fusion of ''Seven'' and ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' With an assaultive soundtrack that amplifies ordinary clocks into loudly ticking time bombs, restless camerawork and narrative false alarms, this French film seems American in all but language.

title: E*TRADE UNIT BUYS DEPOSITS FROM ADVANTA
description: The banking unit of the E*Trade Group agreed yesterday to buy about $390 million in deposits from Advanta National Bank for an undisclosed amount. E*Trade Bank is buying the 15,000 branchless banking accounts from the bank, a unit of the Advanta Corporation. As revenue from online trading has slowed, E*Trade, based in Menlo Park, Calif., has focused more on building assets in its banking unit. Since buying the Telebanc Financial Corporation in January 2000, E*Trade has built its banking unit through acquisitions.

title: INSIDE
description: North Koreans Leave China

title: Appeals Court Voids Order for Breaking Up Microsoft
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  A federal appeals court unanimously threw out a lower court's order today that the Microsoft Corporation should be broken up, although the appeals court found that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the postponement of a championship bicycle race planned for this summer in New York City described it incorrectly. There have been many professional bike races in the city, over a number of years. This one will not be the first.

title: Giuliani May Leave Mansion To Escape Marital Tensions
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is considering moving out of Gracie Mansion to escape the tension in his failed marriage, a City Hall official said yesterday.

title: Article 2001062993383131481 -- No Title

title: With 2001 half over, experts' forecasts for spending become even gloomier than before.
description: FOR Madison Avenue, the second half of 2001 will offer more of the same lugubrious mood that the first half did, as two leading forecasters are again reducing their estimates of advertising spending for the full year. Both are even predicting declines in ad spending in this country from 2000, which would be the first such drop in a decade.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: General Wounded in Madrid Bombing; Basque Group Is Blamed
description: A Spanish general was severely wounded this morning when a bomb in a backpack on a bicycle exploded outside his home. The attack, for which the authorities immediately blamed the Basque separatist group E.T.A., wounded 15 other people.

title: Kofi Annan: An Idealist Who Took the Heat, Shook Up the U.N. and Keeps Top Post
description: Kofi Annan became the seventh United Nations secretary general at the worst of times. The organization was bankrupt, at war with the United States Congress and ridiculed for peacekeeping fiascoes on several continents. The Clinton administration had just driven Mr. Annan's predecessor from office in an unusual display of pressure that still rankles through the Secretariat and the diplomatic corps.

title: Needle Exchanges, Against the Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: He's Poor, She's Rich. Made for Each Other!
description: These days, a realistic Hollywood movie about teenagers seems about as likely as a naughty sex farce from Iran. Early on, ''Crazy/Beautful,'' with its gritty, blue-tinged cinematography, its slangy, mumbled dialogue and its fine-grained feel for the neighborhoods of Los Angeles, looks like an exception. With artful economy, John Stockwell, the director, introduces Carlos Nuez (Jay Hernandez) and Nicole Oakley (Kirsten Dunst), classmates at Pacific High School who come, wouldn't you know it, from different worlds.

title: King Wins Ruling but Will Owe Damages
description: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that Hasim Rahman did not violate a long-term contract with his former promoter when he signed a deal with Don King in May to have King promote him.

title: Arizona Governor's Race May Show Shift by Voters
description: From Barry Goldwater and Morris Udall to Bruce Babbitt and John McCain, Arizona voters have traditionally embraced colorful, unorthodox politicians. Blessed with comfortable weather, affordable housing and a can-do spirit, people here have been generally tolerant of statewide politicians with rough-edged personalities -- even if they disagreed with their political positions.

title: A Judge Overturned by an Appearance of Bias
description: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson talked himself out of a victory, a federal court of appeals ruled yesterday.

title: AOL TIME WARNER TO INVEST IN MINORITY-RUN BUSINESSES
description: AOL Time Warner, the media and Internet company, plans to invest about $100 million for three years in companies owned or managed by minorities and women. The AOL Time Warner Opportunity Investment Fund will invest in companies, with senior managers representing minority groups, that focus on underserved markets with businesses that fit with those of AOL Time Warner, a spokesman, Ed Adler, said. Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive, has said he wants AOL Time Warner to be a leader in promoting diversity in business and the workplace.

title: 3 Brokers Fired By First Boston
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that it had dismissed three brokers in its San Francisco office who had been put on leave amid an investigation into the allocation of initial public offerings.

title: In Milan, the American Slob Is Out
description: MILAN  Marking an emphatic end to the era of luxury sportswear, Miuccia Prada has taken the upscale slob by the scruff of his neck  and put him back in a tie.

title: 'Dreams and Disillusion' -- 'Karel Teige and the Czech Avant-Garde'
description: Grey Art Gallery

title: Chief Editor of Redbook Is Moving to Marie Claire
description: Lesley Jane Seymour, the editor who transformed Redbook from a women's magazine packed with recipes and sniffle remedies into a publication with a mission to spice up the home life of the American working mother, was named the new editor of Marie Claire magazine yesterday. Both are published by Hearst Magazines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDDY, MONICA AGNES
description: RUDDY-Monica Agnes, June 26, 2001. Daughter of the late Patrick and the late Brigid Ruddy. Mother of Robert Ruddy of Denver, CO. Grandmother of Jack Ruddy. Sister of the late Robert F. Ruddy. Sister-in-law of Dolores Ruddy of Tarpon Springs, FL. Aunt of Sheila Hartigan, Monica Duquette, and the late Dennis Ruddy. Also survived by several grandnieces and grandnephew. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Friday, June 29, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, June 30, 10 AM, St. John the Martyr Church, NYC.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Nuclear Operator Approved
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has given final approval for Entergy Nuclear Inc. to operate the Indian Point 3 and James A. FitzPatrick nuclear plants, dismissing a petition by a citizens' group to block the sale. The federal agency initially approved Entergy's purchase of the two plants from the New York State Power Authority for $967 million last fall, and Entergy has been operating the plants since then. But final approval for the transfer of the plants' licenses was delayed by the New York Citizens Awareness Network, which filed a petition raising questions about financing and safety. Indian Point 3 is in Buchanan, in Westchester County, and FitzPatrick is in Scriba, in Oswego County.

title: Secret Service Ousts Muslim; Others Leave White House
description: American Muslim leaders walked out of a White House meeting in protest on Thursday after a Secret Service agent suddenly removed a Muslim student with their group, without explanation.

title: Article 2001062992660642027 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: How the Rosens Of Caramoor Built Their Collection
description: Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y., is renowned for its international summer music festival, which began its 56th season last week and continues through Aug. 11. The Caramoor House Museum, however, is hardly known, even to leading New York City antiques dealers. So this summer the museum organized ''Fancy Finishes,'' an exhibition of nearly 100 pieces of lacquered and painted furniture from its permanent collection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, ARNOLD
description: TANNENBAUM-Arnold. On June 28, 2001 of Port Washington, L.I., formerly of Massapequa Park, L.I. Beloved husband of the late Rebecca Barbara, loving father of Lesley and Irwin Marcus, Cheryl and Andrew Weissman, cherished grandfather of Lani, Scott, Hilary and Britany. Graveside services Sunday, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, RAYMOND PETER, JR.
description: SULLIVAN-Raymond Peter, Jr. Died peacefully on June 27, 2001 at the age of 87 at his home in Scottsdale, Arizona. Beloved husband of the late Catherine McDonnell Sullivan, he is survived by his sister Katherine Meehan, his children R. Peter Sullivan III, Maureen Brookman, Sheila, Kevin, Karen and Sean Sullivan. Also by his grandsons David, Jonathan and Luke Singer and many nieces and nephews. Visitation at the O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton, NY Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. There will be a Funeral Mass on Saturday at 10:00 A.M. at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, 168 Hill Street, Southampton, NY.

title: Schundler Tries to Make Peace With Republican Establishment
description: After railing against the failures of his fellow Republicans in the Legislature during his maverick primary campaign for governor, Bret D. Schundler came to the State House today with a reassuring message for those lawmakers: never mind all that.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Senate Run For Mayor
description: Ending weeks of speculation, Mayor Wellington E. Webb of Denver said he would not run against Senator Wayne Allard, a Republican, next year, a decision that makes Tom Strickland, the former United States attorney for Colorado, the leading Democratic candidate. Mr. Webb said the timing was wrong, an acknowledgment that state voters have been unreceptive to Democrats in recent years. The state's eight-member Congressional delegation has only two Democrats. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Invisible Publishing Sparks a Lawsuit
description: Out of sight, out of mind? Not in this case. A snippet of invisible Web page text has prompted a lawsuit by a Belgian company against Women.com Networks Inc. The suit shows how far Web site operators will go to capture and maintain prominent placement in Internet search results.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Amherst: Kopp Cleared For Extradition
description: A French court agreed yesterday to send James Charles Kopp, an abortion opponent, back to the United States to face trial in the 1998 sniper killing of an Amherst, N.Y., doctor who provided abortions, on the condition that Mr. Kopp not face the death penalty. French law forbids the extradition of anyone who could face execution. Mr. Kopp's lawyer hinted strongly that Mr. Kopp, 46, would appeal the court's decision. If so, the case could take years to make its way through the French justice system. Mr. Kopp is suspected of stalking and then shooting Dr. Barnett A. Slepian. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERBERT, JOHN
description: HERBERT-John. In memory. The clients, staff, board of directors, and the founder of The Fortune Society express our sorrow at the passing of John Herbert, whose play, Fortune and Men's Eyes, inspired our founding. Roland Nicholson, Jr. Chair, Board of Directors JoAnne Page, Executive Director David Rothenberg, Founder

title: Making A Judgement On a Moving Target
description: The appeals court ruling yesterday in the antitrust case against Microsoft left unanswered one of the most pressing questions facing the computer industry: Will Microsoft have to change how it acts?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi's Economic Plans
description: Italy's conservative prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, released economic stimulation measures for his first 100 days including tax breaks for business investment, abolition of inheritance taxes and more flexible short-term labor contracts. The European Union on Wednesday warned Italy that its budget deficit could significantly exceed the 1 percent of G.N.P. target previously set by Italy and the European Union. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Key Sections of the Decision by the United States Court of Appeals
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in the Microsoft antitrust case:

title: An Innocent's Encounters With Reality
description: ''You are a free spirit, Miss Fozzard,'' the aging, wolflike chiropodist tells the prim English spinster, well into middle age herself. ''Have you ever had any Champagne?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, CLARENCE D.
description: BELL-Clarence D., 84 years old. Of Palm Beach, Florida, died on Wednesday, June 27, 2001 following an extended illness. Formerly of New York, New York and Wilmington, Delaware, he was a resident of Palm Beach since 1985. Mr. Bell was employed as a Chemical Engineer with the Dupont Company for over 30 years, and retired as the Executive Vice President in 1972. He also served as a Vice President of the Maimonides Medical Center, New York, New York. Mr. Bell was an avid fisherman and golfer, and a member of the Breakers Golf Club, Palm Beach, FL. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Ragena Lowary Bell. He is survived by his wife, Hilda M. F. Bell of Palm Beach, FL; children, Sally Cooperson (Don) of North Caldwell, NJ, Edward Bell (Liz) of Tampa, FL, Becky Ley (Ken) of Voorhees, NJ, Martin Bell (Peggy) of Miami, FL, Rebecca Folkman (Jonathan Aaron) of Cambridge, MA, Benjamin Folkman of New York, NY, and Jonathan Folkman (Fran) also of New York, NY; eight grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. A Funeral Service will be held at 1:30 PM on Saturday, June 30, 2001 at Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. The family will receive friends at the funeral home on Saturday from 12:30 PM until the time of Service. We invite you to visit, sign Mr. Bell's Remembrance Registry guest book and share a memory at the web site of www.quattlebaum.org

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Nokia Plans Job Cuts
description: Nokia Oyj said it would cut as many as 1,000 jobs at its network unit, as demand for mobile equipment slows. The company is tightening spending after reducing its forecast for second-quarter sales growth by half, to less than 10 percent. Nokia had been counting on an increase in spending by operators as they build next-generation networks. Nokia's shares rose 13 cents, to $21.58.

title: Sports of The Times; In the College Of Basketball Knowledge
description: THE glut of high school players being drafted by N.B.A. teams means, to many, that college basketball is on the ropes, knocked for a loop, kicked in the slats. None of this is true. It is actually a benefit.

title: Hits to Stop Coming Once Gwynn Is Gone
description: And then there was Barry Larkin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROY, ASOKA
description: ROY-Asoka. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) family joins the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend Asoka Roy, who lovingly served as Director of Midwifery at Beth Israel from 1968 to 1983. Our sympathy is extended to members of Asoka's family, and all who loved her. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President & CEO Arnold Friedman, M.D. Chairman, OB/GYN Rochelle Lipschutz Director of Midwifery Sidney K. Stein, MD President, Medical Board

title: Webdenda: Executive Changes in Media
description: Eve Ehrich has joined Attik, New York, a brand communications agency, as a senior producer. She had been freelancing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, DR. OTTO I.
description: REISMAN-Dr. Otto I., Professor of physics at New Jersey Institute of Technology. Born in Vienna, Austria, 1928, he fled to Italy, where he lived through the early 1950's, when he moved to New York City. He was survived by his beloved wife, Eva, of 44 years. Also the devoted father of Deborah Weiss and Edith Reisman. Loving brother of Ines Rosner. Services were held Wednesday, June 27, 2001. Shiva at the Weiss residence through Monday.

title: Letting Your Hair Down While Remaining Lavish
description: George Balanchine is popularly thought of as a choreographer who did not believe in lavish sets, costumes and storytelling. In ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, he indulges in all three to more than lavish effect. The result is a sometimes uneasy mix of narrative and pure dance, though the ballet is interestingly cinematic in the way it jumps from scene to scene and subplot to subplot. But ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' also has something to say about Balanchine and the institution he helped create.

title: Needle Exchanges, Against the Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: A Female Vampire Wins Another Stab at Immortality
description: ''Today, as every day, I'm gonna speak about Good and Evil,'' a character known as the Reverend (Richard Blackburn) preaches from his pulpit in ''Lemora, Lady Dracula,'' an ambitious no-budget horror film from 1973 that has been unjustly rescued from its Crypt of Oblivion. After a storied, botched release, the picture, written and directed by Mr. Blackburn, sank to television and has barely been seen since the late 70's. The only recent evidence of its existence was the whispered assertions of its most die-hard enthusiasts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Appeals Court Throws Out Order to Split Up Microsoft

title: Citing Disease, F.D.A. Panel Backs Blood Donor Curbs
description: An advisory panel for the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that the agency bar blood donations from people who might have been exposed to mad cow disease while in Europe.

title: After 3 Years of Foreboding, A Light New Mood at Microsoft
description: The weather is always a good source of conversation here in the Seattle area, and Microsoft officials liberally invoked meteorological analogies today in offering generally jubilant reactions to the appeals court ruling in the antitrust battle with the federal government.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: European Peace Envoy Arrives
description: The new envoy for the European Union, Franois Lotard, arrived in Macedonia in an attempt to head off full-scale warfare between ethnic Albanians and the Macedonian Slavs, who are the majority in the country. Mr. Lotard, the former French defense minister, arrived after a week of intense fighting, a huge street protest and growing anger over outside intervention in the conflict. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A New Beat In an Old Song

title: Harlem Development Program Not Much Help, Critics and Officials Say
description: Many Harlem community leaders have cast a skeptical eye on a $250 million federal, state and city program that was meant to bring economic development to their neighborhood, saying it has benefited national retailers but has not helped many local people start their own businesses.

title: Actors and Producers Turn Earnest in Talks
description: Negotiators representing actors and producers stepped up the pace of their talks this week with a midnight Saturday deadline for the expiration of their contract.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It would be a good time for all parties involved to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: New State Police Chief
description: Lt. Col. Timothy F. Barry, 45, of the state police has been named commander of the police department. Colonel Barry, currently the head of the department's field operations, succeeds Col. John F.Bardelli, who is retiring this weekend. Colonel Barry, whose promotion was announced on Wednesday, said, ''I have three basic priorities: to maintain community policing for the 82 towns where state police have primary jurisdiction, making sure major interstates are safe, and providing a major crime squad to handle rape, murder'' and other serious crimes.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A 'Tell-Some' Book

title: The Big City; 'Other Half' Is Living A Little Better
description: FERNANDO FERRER wants to help ''the other New York,'' he said in announcing his candidacy for mayor on Wednesday. That phrase has a noble ring to it, an echo of the classic advocacy for the poor in ''How the Other Half Lives'' and ''The Other America.'' But who exactly are the ''other'' people? And why is it charitable to give them that label?

title: A Disappointed Cook Can Only Look Ahead
description: If he had it to do all over again, maybe Omar Cook would have done it differently. Maybe he would have stayed in school for another year rather than plunge into a draft that was filled with players who were younger and taller than he was. Maybe he would have listened to his coaches at St. John's, who warned him that there were no sure things, no matter what anyone was telling him.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, ANNE DUBOVY
description: SCHAEFER-Anne Dubovy. June 27, age 97. Wife of the late Herman Dubovy and Jack Schaefer. Beloved mother of Joseph (Jane) and Herbert (Laini) Dubovy. Grandmother of Hilton, Todd (Dawn), Adam, Sander and Darin.

title: Arafat Sits Down With the Press
description: Yasir Arafat was in an expansive, feisty mood tonight, apparently buoyed by the visit of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. Mr. Arafat even went so far as to declare that the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon -- who has labeled him a murderer and a pathological liar -- was ''definitely'' a potential peacemaking partner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERLICH, PHILIP
description: ERLICH-Philip. Beloved husband of the late Frances (nee Dessner). Devoted father of Sue Carol Weitzman and Sandra Ershow. Cherished grandfather of Donald Weitzman. Services at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, Sunday, at 12:30 PM.

title: Hewitt's Persistence Overcomes Dent's Power
description: Almost every time the lunging Lleyton Hewitt sent up a lob that required a harmless tap to tuck away, Taylor Dent attacked it with the vigor of a puppy pouncing on a chew toy.

title: Supreme Court Limits Detention In Cases of Deportable Immigrants
description: In its second decision this week affirming the rights of immigrants, the Supreme Court ruled today that the government may not detain deportable aliens indefinitely simply for lack of a country willing to take them.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Dalga throws a cooling splash of clean blue and turquoise onto the dreary smog zone around the Queensboro Bridge. The name is Turkish for wave, but it doesn't take fluency in the language to get the drift. Friendly-looking metal fish decorate the walls, a life-size silver rowboat perches overhead, and a rippling sheet of water cascades down a small translucent panel at the entrance to the main dining room, reminding diners that fish is the theme.

title: House Committee Asks Roger Clinton to Explain Some Ties to Pardon Requests
description: Congressional investigators have asked Roger Clinton to explain how he obtained $250,000 in traveler's checks, most of which were issued by banks in Taiwan and Venezuela.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERMAN, IRVING I., D.D.S.
description: ANDERMAN-Irving I., D.D.S. Of Goshen, NY, died June 28. Adored husband of 58 years of Georgia; father of Susan (David) Singer and Robert (Christine). Cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Daryl, Ethan and Rachel. Services at Temple Sinai, Middletown, NY, Friday, June 29, at 12 Noon.

title: When Photography Became Postmodern
description: Over the last year or two, New York galleries have conducted a kind of ad hoc seminar in post-Pop photography. There have been shows of work from the 1960's and 70's by the photographers Stephen Shore, Bill Owens, Robert Adams, Henry Wessel and Joel Meyerowitz, and by the Conceptual artists Jan Dibbets and Bernd and Hilla Becher. There have been shows of work from the late 1970's and 80's by the appropriation artists Laurie Simmons and Richard Prince as well as an exhibition of little-known photographic books by artists from the early 1970's at Roth Horowitz.

title: 2 Election Finance Bills Go to House Floor
description: Drawing sharp battle lines over the overhaul of the campaign finance law, House Republican leaders put their might today behind a bill that would limit certain contributions but stops short of the comprehensive overhaul of the campaign finance law that passed the Senate.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Star Power For Shepard

title: 7 North Koreans Allowed to Leave China
description: A group of seven illegal North Korean immigrants who walked into the office of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees on Tuesday demanding political asylum, were allowed by the Chinese government to leave today, United Nations officials and diplomats said.

title: Some Possible Carrots and Sticks
description: There is still a remote chance that Microsoft could be broken up: a federal appeals court left some wiggle room in its order yesterday that a lower court reconsider the remedy for the finding that Microsoft had abused its monopoly power in the software business.

title: Doctor Says He Took Transplant Organs From Executed Chinese Prisoners
description: A former Chinese Army doctor told a United States Congressional committee this week that he had helped harvest organs from executed prisoners and had even removed skin from a man who had not yet died -- testimony China branded as lies today.

title: The Shetlands, Nostalgically
description: Documentaries about making movies are a staple these days, particularly on DVD, but few project a passion like ''Return to the Edge of the World,'' by the British director Michael Powell. In 1936 Powell made his feature film ''The Edge of the World'' on the gale-bent Shetland Island of Foula. It was decades before helicopters delivered actors and camera crews to clifftops in the middle of nowhere, and clearly none of the filmmakers who washed in and out by boat ever forgot it.

title: Rude Britannia Rears Its Head At Jaguar Plant
description: A JAGUAR sedan being built recently for Queen Elizabeth had a couple of factory-added options: a cache of pornographic magazines that had been deposited in a body cavity and a swastika painted behind a seat panel.

title: Mr. Milosevic in The Hague
description: In 1995 Slobodan Milosevic went to Dayton, Ohio, to sign a peace agreement for Bosnia. The Dayton peace accords committed Yugoslavia to cooperate with the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, including transferring those who were indicted. Mr. Milosevic, it is fair to say, had little intention of meeting this obligation. Yet yesterday Yugoslavia kept his promise and transferred him to The Hague for trial.

title: Yankees Add Gerald Williams, Paving Way for Knoblauch Deal
description: The Yankees agreed to terms yesterday with the veteran outfielder Gerald Williams through the 2002 season, a deal that appears to put them in position to trade the leadoff hitter Chuck Knoblauch to the Seattle Mariners.

title: Slicing and Dicing the Bright Colors of Mondrian's Boogie-Woogies
description: ''Mondrian: The Trans-Atlantic Paintings'' at the Busch-Reisinger Museum, Harvard University, is a collaboration between the school's departments of art history and art conservation. It is really two exhibitions in one, different but intimately related and equally engrossing. And from the way they work together to inspect and expose their subject, the Dutch painter Piet Mondrian (1872-1944), they might well have been jointly titled ''The Anatomy Lesson.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Bank To Be Shut Down
description: The Bank One Corporation said that it would close its Internet bank, WingspanBank.com, and fold its 225,000 customers into the company's other online service, BankOne.com, this fall. By closing the two-year-old Internet-only venture, Bank One, based in Chicago, hopes to save on the cost of maintaining and marketing separate brands. In a statement, Bank One said it planned to integrate some WingspanBank resources and features into its other consumer Internet offerings. Shares of Bank One rose 52 cents yesterday, to $35.52.

title: The Principals
description: Mike Wise assesses the trade between the Nets and the Phoenix Suns.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MGI PHARMA INC., Bloomington, Minn., a pharmaceutical company, said the Food and Drug Administration granted fast track designation for the use of its drug, irofulven, for patients with pancreatic cancer.

title: Conservation-Mindful Bush Turns to Energy Research
description: As President Bush toured the Energy Department today and sent Congress an outline of his program to meet America's hunger for gasoline and electricity, something unexpected cropped up: a presidential proposal for nearly $300 million to finance Clinton-era research programs on energy conservation, money that the administration struck from the budget earlier this year.

title: Mother Jailed on Neglect Charge Is Freed and Charge Is Reduced
description: SANDPOINT, Idaho, June 28 (AP) — A woman whose six children held off sheriff's deputies for five days was freed today after the child neglect charge against her was reduced to a misdemeanor.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 2 Executed In Xinjiang
description: China executed two ethnic Uighurs in the country's far western Xinjiang province for making explosives and accepting money from abroad as part of the region's simmering campaign for independence. It also sentenced five people to death in Tibet, which has its own independence movement, in connection with ''murder, robbery and explosions.'' Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Bit of Dissent on Rates At Fed's Meeting in May
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were split at their meeting last month about how far to go in cutting interest rates, with one of the 10 voting members dissenting from the decision to reduce rates by half a percentage point and two others expressing reservations, according to minutes of the session released today.

title: Lying About Vietnam
description: The Pentagon Papers, published 30 years ago this month, proved that the government had long lied to the country. Indeed, the papers revealed a policy of concealment and quite deliberate deception from the Truman administration onward.

title: Corrections
description: The Home Video column in Weekend on June 8, about the release of a DVD set of films by Stanley Kubrick, described his widow, Christiane Harlan, incorrectly. She was his third wife, not his fourth.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNETONLINE BANK TO BE SHUT DOWN The Bank One Corporation said that it would close its Internet bank, WingspanBank.com, and fold its 225,000 customers into the company's other online service, BankOne.com, this fall. By closing the two- year-old Internet-only venture, Bank One, based in Chicago, hopes to save on the cost of maintaining and marketing separate brands. In a statement, Bank One said it planned to integrate some WingspanBank resources and features into its other consumer Internet offerings. Shares of Bank One rose 52 cents yesterday, to $35.52.

title: Landlord of Collapsed Building Is to Pay $1 Million to Victims
description: A Brooklyn landlord who owned a building in Williamsburg that collapsed two years ago, killing a day laborer in a torrential slide of wet concrete, agreed yesterday to pay $1 million in restitution to the victims of the accident.

title: Europe Indicates to G.E. New Offer Is Unacceptable
description: European regulators have told General Electric that its last-minute effort to revive its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International will not be enough, sounding a death knell for the $45 billion deal.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, MARYELLEN (NEE LEYDEN)
description: HALL-Maryellen (nee Leyden) on June 26, 2001. Beloved wife of Thomas D. (F.D.N.Y.). Dear mother of Sean T. Loving daughter of John and Kathleen Leyden. Dear sister of John. Funeral Saturday 9:15AM from the Joseph Clavin Sons Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 9:45am St. Andrew's Church. Visiting 2-4pm and 7-9pm Friday.

title: The Elusive Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: In Slap at Bush, House Votes to Bar Oil Drilling in Great Lakes
description: In another slap at President Bush's energy and environment policies, the House of Representatives voted today to prohibit drilling for oil and gas in the Great Lakes.

title: Brooks Bros. Expected to Get Discount Bids
description: It is summer clearance time, and everything at Brooks Brothers is on sale.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From warranty troubles to warring views on Chrysler minivans, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Knicks See Wright as Role Player
description: He was the 39th pick of the draft. His name should not inspire hope, create a buzz or provoke thoughts of a new Knicks era. But there is reason to believe Michael Wright could become a contributor someday in the N.B.A.

title: Rebel Force in Colombia Repatriates 242 More P.O.W.'s
description: Colombia's largest guerrilla group today freed 242 soldiers and police officers held as prisoners of war. Some people viewed the release as the first tangible step in long-fractious peace talks between Latin America's oldest rebel group and President Andrs Pastrana's administration.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Record Defense Budget
description: The cost of defense for South Korea is rising to new highs with another record budget proposed for next year and a five-year expansion plan lasting until 2006. The Defense Ministry said it would need $12.7 billion in 2002 to maintain its 650,000 troops on permanent alert against 1.1 million North Koreans above the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas. The budget for 2002, up 7.6 percent from this year, covers the first year of a five-year plan totaling $70.6 billion. Defense officials are asking for fighter and reconnaissance planes, advanced electronic gear, helicopters and naval vessels. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHMELKA, JEAN
description: SHMELKA-Jean. It has been a lonely nine years. Wow! Do we miss you! Rob and Dee

title: Airport Check-In: Not Just a Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft's Core Illegalities
description: Both sides claimed victory after yesterday's unanimous ruling by seven judges of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in the Microsoft antitrust case. The software giant and its investors were clearly relieved that the judges had vacated the lower court's order breaking up the company and reversed one of the findings of illegal behavior on Microsoft's part.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Maureen McCabe -- 'Enchantments'
description: Kouros Gallery

title: A Sort of 007 on the Loose in the Sultan's Harem
description: Gluck's ''Plerins de la Mecque,'' which L'Opra Franaise de New York performed on Tuesday evening at the Kaye Playhouse, falls slightly outside the company's usual mandate of presenting rarities from the French opera canon. Gluck, after all, was a Bohemian composer who worked mainly in Vienna, and although he wrote operas for Paris as well, it was for the French theater in Vienna that ''Plerins'' was first performed in 1764.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Public Defenders May Get Raise
description: Some public defenders will get raises if Gov. George Ryan signs a bill that will make their salaries comparable to those of state attorneys. The measure mandates that salaries for full-time public defenders be at least 90 percent of the county prosecutor's and calls for the state to pay two-thirds of a public defender's salary. Counties currently pay public defenders, while county prosecutors are paid by the state. Mr. Ryan has not indicated whether he will sign the bill, which would require the appropriation of money for the salaries. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 12 about the growing number of American film and television productions in Toronto misstated the name of one source of trained actors and technicians for those productions. It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not the Canadian Broadcasting Company.

title: Chairman Decides to Leave As CNN Is Prepped for Change
description: The chairman of CNN, Tom Johnson, who started at the network just before it rose to glory with its coverage of the Persian Gulf war, resigned yesterday.

title: Article 2001062993683224352 -- No Title
Markets Rally on Hopes for Higher Corporate Earnings
description: Stocks rallied yesterday on brighter hopes for corporate earnings, a day after the Federal Reserve made its sixth cut in interest rates this year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sony Cuts Playstation Price
description: The Sony Corporation reduced the price of its PlayStation 2 video game console in Japan by 12 percent, to $280.72 from $319.22. Although Sony faces intense competition from Microsoft and Nintendo in the home video game market, it is not expected to extend the price reduction to sales in the United States. Microsoft plans to start selling its Xbox video game system in the United States on Nov. 8 for $299. Nintendo's GameCube is expected to reach North American stores on Nov. 5. The PlayStation 2, which currently sells for $299 in this country, has been on the market for almost a year. Sony has sold more than 2.7 million PlayStation 2 consoles in North America and 7 million more overseas. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Grifter Pleads Not Guilty In Killing
description: Sante Kimes, left, who is serving a life sentence for killing Irene Silverman of Manhattan, pleaded not guilty in Los Angeles yesterday to the 1998 shooting death of David Kazdin, a former business associate. The district attorney is considering more charges against Mrs. Kimes, and her son, Kenneth Kimes, 26, who could both face the death penalty if convicted of murdering Mr. Kazdin.

title: JUSTICES REIN IN LOCAL REGULATION OF TOBACCO ADS
description: The Supreme Court today placed significant limits on the ability of state and local governments to regulate tobacco advertising in a case from Massachusetts that also appeared to invalidate a similar law in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, MARVIN M.D.
description: KELLER-Marvin M.D., ''As for me, I shall behold Thy face in righteousness; I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with Thy likeness'' (Ps. 17.15). Died peacefully at home, surrounded by his loving family, June 28th. He will be missed by many.

title: Airport Check-In: Not Just a Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001062992446368682 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Minnesota Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Emerging From a Closet He's Never Been In
description: Francis Veber's giddy social comedy ''The Closet'' finds more delicious, chortling fun in the spectacle of obsequious hypocrisy than any movie I've seen in ages. The film, already a huge hit in France, follows the sudden upward career trajectory of Franois Pignon (Daniel Auteuil), a mousy divorced accountant who is so desperate to save his job at a condom factory that he lies to his bosses and masquerades as gay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRES, MARIO
description: TORRES-Mario. Beloved nephew, gifted performer, passed June 20, 2001. Funeral on Sunday, July 1, 11AM, at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue, N.Y. Ann and Andy Harris

title: APPEALS COURT VOIDS ORDER FOR BREAKING UP MICROSOFT BUT FINDS IT ABUSED POWER
description: A federal appeals court unanimously threw out a lower court's order today that the Microsoft Corporation should be broken up, although the appeals court found that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASOKA, ROY
description: ASOKA-Roy, MS, CNM, FACNM, affectionately called Koko, passed away peacefully in Valhalla, NY on June 22. She was born in India, educated in India, England and the USA, & had an interesting & distinguished career in her much loved midwifery profession. She started her midwifery career in India. Stories are told of her courage when she risked her life to see all her midwives to safety during the partition between India and Pakistan; of her trips to the villages to deliver babies, such as twins in the mud-huts of the war-torn reaches of India when medical assistance was nowhere to be found. After the war, she was appointed General Secretary of the TNAI, the 2nd Indian to hold this high-level 'British' national post. Koko studied to be a midwife tutor at London's famous Hospital, Guys, and she learned to do vacuum extractions in Sweden. She worked as a tutor in England prior to her sojourn to the USA. A pioneer midwife in the City in 1968, she forged ahead to establish the first Midwifery Program at Beth Israel Hospital where she later taught Yale midwifery students and medical students. In 1983, she obtained admitting privileges at St. Vincents' Hospital when she was working in the private midwifery practice of Maureen Rayson, CNM. She then became a Fellow of the American College of Nurse-Midwives. When she retired from delivery practice at St. Vincent's in 1990, the hospital made her Midwife Emeritus. Koko, God-fearing & energetic devoted her life to the care of mothers & babies and toward the improvement of her profession. She demanded high standards from her midwives. Active after her retirement, she attended her last birth, her grand-niece's, at home, at age 82 in 1998. Until recently, she was involved in developing the Beth Israel midwifery archives. She was an inspiration to her midwives, student doctors and clients, and was loved by us all. Her departure represents a great loss to the international midwifery community. Her spirit will live on for many generations. For funeral information, call Maureen's office in Chelsea at 646-230-7708. Maureen Rayson, CNM For the Midwifery Community

title: History Unfolds in a Show on the Square (Washington Square, That Is)
description: Probably no place in Manhattan is quite as arty as Washington Square, in terms of the painters, sculptors and photographers who have lived, worked or simply hung out there to capture its image.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: School Safety Law Passed
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber signed a package of school safety measures into law, including one that creates a statewide toll-free hot line for students to alert the authorities anonymously about potential violence. Another law requires schools to establish antibullying policies. The package is in response to a wave of school shootings around the country, including a 1998 rampage in which a 15-year-old Oregon high school student, Kip Kinkel, killed 2 students and wounded 25 others. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Key Sections of the Decision by the United States Court of Appeals
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in the Microsoft antitrust case:

title: Mortimer Adler, 98, Dies; Helped Create Study of Classics
description: Mortimer J. Adler, the philosopher and educator who helped create the Great Books program of learning, died yesterday at his home in San Mateo, Calif. He was 98.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Menem Charges Requested
description: The federal prosecutor, Carlos Stornelli, formally requested that former President Carlos Saul Menem be charged with heading a racket for smuggling arms to Croatia and Ecuador during his 1989-99 presidency. Judge Jorge Urso, who has already ordered Mr. Menem's house arrest, will decide whether to charge him -- the equivalent of an indictment in Argentina -- some time in the next two weeks. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANEMAN, ELIZABETH B. (BREED)
description: HANEMAN-Elizabeth B. (Breed). Died June 26, 2001 at the age of 79. She is survived by a daughter Elizabeth Stinchcomb of Manhattan and two granddaughters Nicole P. Haneman of Manhattan & Patricia H. Cox of Larchmont, New York; a son William F. Haneman is deceased.
