Services are to be held Friday June 29 at 11AM at the St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Main Street South, Woodbury CT. Contributions may be made to The Oratory of The Little Way, PO Box 221, Gaylordsville, CT. 06755.

title: Needle Exchanges, Against the Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting on a Front In Diamonds and Gold; Teeth Don't Mean a Thing If They Ain't Got That 'Bling'
description: Like the rap stars she loves, Robin Williams wants her teeth to ''bling'' this summer. But since she has just your average whites, the 18-year-old has been frantically shopping for a more glamorous set, the sort that street fashionistas, from Brooklyn to the Bahamas, are snapping in and out.

title: Residential Real Estate; Harlem Co-op Has a Financing Twist
description: The first tenants will begin moving next week into the Renaissance, a 240-apartment co-op in central Harlem that was developed with an unusual financing method intended to make the apartments affordable to people with moderate incomes.

title: As Defense Secretary Calls for Base Closings, Congress Circles the Wagons
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld today urged Congress to begin the contentious process of closing excess military bases, warning that the federal surplus -- shrunken by President Bush's tax cut -- would not provide enough money to replace aging ships, aircraft and weapons.

title: A Pop-Tune Counterpoint To a Family's Wisecracks
description: The Clarks, who own a successful funeral home, are the richest black family in the fictional town of Kent, S.C. But they're just ordinary folks, at least if you believe what you see on television.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Shipbuilding Subsidies Dispute
description: The dispute on South Korean shipbuilding subsidies heated up yesterday with finance ministry officials calling demands by the European Union unreasonable and vowing to fight to keep the union from bringing the case to the World Trade Organization. The European Union, through a spokesman, has warned that ''the clock is ticking'' but extended tomorrow's deadline by several days. The union says that South Korean shipbuilders including Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest manufacturer of merchant ships, and Samsung Heavy Industries, receive government subsidies that more than compensate for their losses. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Milosevic Trial: Test on Many Levels
description: Slobodan Milosevic is finally being brought to trial for crimes against humanity he is accused of committing during the war in Kosovo, providing a new system of international law the major test it has demanded.

title: Article 2001062992212834398 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Arrested In Teenager's Death
description: A 19-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting to death a 15-year-old boy in a dispute over a girl both men had dated, the police said. The man, Raul Davis, was charged with murdering Patrick Seltzer at a convenience store that is across the street from the Castle Hill Houses, where Mr. Selter lived. Police yesterday discounted earlier information that a group of young men had chased him into the store.

title: Green Calls for Port Authority Restructuring
description: Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for mayor, called yesterday for the restructuring of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to give New York City more influence over the agency's decisions.

title: Baffert Seeking Redemption in a Summer That Has Gone Sour
description: He captured two legs of this spring's Triple Crown with Point Given, has one of the nation's top older horses in Captain Steve and is the runaway leader in the national trainer standing with more than $10.2 million in purses. This should have been a summer of fun for the trainer Bob Baffert, one that all of horse racing could savor as it counted down to the newly named Breeders' Cup World Thoroughbred Championships on Oct. 27 at Belmont Park.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Mass Transit Plan Announced
description: Gov. Roy E. Barnes announced a plan to invest an additional $8.3 billion in transportation projects. The plan calls for new public transportation systems and several new highways in rural areas. Residents of Atlanta and its surrounding areas endure the nation's longest average daily commute, at 35 miles a day. Atlanta is also one of the most polluted cities in the country. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Nets' Shake-Up Ships Marbury for Suns' Kidd
description: In a blockbuster deal that swapped two of the premier point guards in the N.B.A, the Nets last night sent Stephon Marbury, their franchise player from Coney Island, to the Phoenix Suns for Jason Kidd, the four-time All-Star.

title: Thorn Had the Say In Rockets' Picks
description: When Rod Thorn, the president of the Nets, emerged from the team's draft strategy room Wednesday night, his face was resolute but he seemed drained from the moves he had made. As it turned out, that was only a preview for yesterday's blockbuster deal that sent Stephon Marbury to Phoenix for Jason Kidd.

title: Clarence Thomas: Echoes of '91
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Opinions in Ruling on the Detention of Immigrant-Criminals
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today that immigrants who have committed crimes in the United States cannot be confined indefinitely even if they cannot be deported. The vote in Zadvydas v. Davis and Ashcroft v. Ma was 5 to 4. Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote the majority opinion; Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Antonin Scalia wrote dissents.

title: Roberts Gets His Rhythm In Bullpen
description: When the Mets sent Steve Trachsel to the minors last month, they softened the blow by citing an example. If it worked for Bobby Jones last year, they told Trachsel, it could work for you.

title: Czechs Pick French Bid For Control Of Big Bank
description: Socit Gnrale agreed today to acquire a 60 percent stake in Komercni Banka from the Czech government, for an unexpectedly high price of 1.19 billion euros ($1.01 billion).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, MARIAN BELLAMY
description: HUGHES-Marian Bellamy, age 89 of Hudson, Ohio. Beloved wife of the late Lloyd F. Hughes, loving mother of Charles R. Hughes, and Susan H. Barker, dear grandmother of Geoff L. Hughes, Bradley T. Hughes, Lynn B. Ogden and the late Sarah H. Ogden. Great-grandmother of Cammie Ogden-Fung, Emilie Ogden-Fung, Morgan B. Hughes and Connor L. Hughes, dear sister of Robert C. Bellamy and the late Elizabeth B. Nicholas, died Sunday June 24, 2001. Mrs. Hughes resided for most of her life in Westchester County, New York. She was Director of Volunteers of the Phelps Memorial Hospital in the 1970's. After many years of volunteering with the Red Cross and various charities she retired to St. Simons Island, Georgia where she was a member of the Cassina Garden Club and the Golden Isles Investment Club. In celebration of her life a Memorial Service will be held at the St. Simons Presbyterian Church, 205 Kings Way, St. Simons Island, Georgia 31522 at 4:00 P.M. on Monday, July 2, 2001. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to the Presbyterian Church.

title: Jacqueline Bootier -- 'Basic Training'
description: Lombard-Freid Fine Arts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, NANCY DENTON
description: PERLMAN-Nancy Denton. On June 25th, 2001 in the comfort of the home in which she grew up. She shined a special light on everyone and all those who knew her were touched by her special warmth. Keep the warmth with you for it is the essence of Nancy and her gift to those she leaves behind. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. She was blessed and will be missed.

title: Clarence Thomas: Echoes of '91
description: To the Editor:

title: Aidas Bareikis -- 'Silence Before the Curve'
description: Leo Koenig

title: Growing Pains, Without the Psychobabble
description: With the movies and television so glutted with psychological jargon that reduces every relationship and situation to the same formulaic banalities, it's almost an event when a serious movie scrupulously refuses to connect the dots with the usual cookie-cutter analyses. ''Come Undone,'' the French director Sbastien Lifshitz's beautifully acted film about an introspective 18-year-old boy's homosexual initiation, first love, suicide attempt and subsequent recovery leaves so much unsaid and unexplained that it captures the uncertainty and emotional turbulence of late adolescence with a poignancy that a more clinically articulate movie never could.

title: Pat Robertson Says Oil Firms Are Stifling Competition
description: Pat Robertson, founder of the Christian Coalition, accused big oil companies today of thwarting his efforts to open a refinery in California, contending that the companies had intimidated bankers to keep them from lending money to the venture.

title: Jets Sign Two Defensive Players
description: The Jets signed two of their draft picks yesterday, cornerback Jamie Henderson of Georgia and defensive lineman James Reed of Iowa State.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Soriano's Next Switch May Be to Leadoff Spot
description: Hilario Soriano, Alfonso Soriano's uncle, was at a Dominican summer league game earlier this week, proudly chatting into his cellular phone about his nephew. Hilario was trying to explain Soriano's quick rise in the major leagues after a stint in Japan, then laughed as he thought of a Dominican expression.

title: A Long Legal Road Grows Longer
description: Key events in the antitrust case against Microsoft

title: Surgeon General's Report Calls for Sex Education Beyond Abstinence
description: In what he described as a bid to give scientific grounding to the volatile debate over sex education, the surgeon general of the United States urged communities today to provide young people with thorough and medically accurate sex education as a way to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, rapes and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Sheriff Says Lights Out
description: Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County is turning out some of the lights in his jails to conserve energy. His office estimates that turning off 60 percent, or 4,000, of the lights in Phoenix and county jails will save about $40,000 a year. The often-controversial sheriff, known for making prisoners wear pink garments and installing jail Webcams, said that televisions would be turned off until 6 p.m. weekdays and that safety was not a concern. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMANN, MORTIMER ALAN
description: LIPPMANN-Mortimer Alan. Beloved husband of Adrienne. Devoted father of Robert Michael, Dr. Richard Douglas, and Rachel Anne. Dear brother of Judith Bayles. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island today 1:30 PM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Step For Global Criminal Court
description: Sweden became the 36th country to ratify the treaty of the International Criminal Court. Sixty ratifications of the pact are needed for the court to begin functioning. Other European countries are likely to follow Sweden, which now holds the presidency of the European Union. The Bush administration says it will never support the court. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: School Official's Push for a Company Is Questioned
description: Irving S. Hamer Jr., the Board of Education member leading its effort to integrate the Internet into the classroom, used his position last year to promote a Web-based test-preparation company where he was a vice chairman, according to current and former city and education officials.

title: Officials Scrutinize Con Ed After Thousands Lose Power
description: A day after more than 11,000 people in New York City and Westchester lost electricity for as much as seven hours, state regulators questioned yesterday whether Consolidated Edison has done enough to repair and maintain its labyrinth of cables and transformers.

title: Airport Check-In: Not Just a Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, SOLOMON
description: TEPPER-Solomon. Space does not allow us to mention all the superlatives. We lost a dear, good friend. Annette and George Fisher

title: Those Rebate Checks
description: To the Editor:

title: William L. Rafsky -- Civil Servant, 81
description: William L. Rafsky, a manager in Philadelphia government for four decades, died on June 11 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 81.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: Restarting the Mideast Peace Clock
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell went to the Middle East this week to build on the tenuous cease-fire that was negotiated with Washington's help two and a half weeks ago and to establish a timetable for further steps toward peace. Yesterday he registered a modest but significant success. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel announced that if the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, could deliver seven days without anti-Israeli violence, the clock would start on a six-week cooling-off period. At the end of the six weeks Israel would take steps recommended by an international panel this spring that could lead to an eventual resumption of peace talks.

title: Article 2001062992661261957 -- No Title
description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: Burger King Pledges Humane Use of Animals
description: Animal rights advocates have criticized Burger King for years, saying that its menu comes from cows that can feel their throats being slit, from livestock that show up at the slaughterhouse frozen to truck walls and from pigs stuck in stalls so cramped that they literally go mad.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Slowdown For Harry Potter
description: Bloomsbury, the publisher of the Harry Potter books, said first-half sales and profits would beat last year's figures by a ''substantial margin.'' Its shares rose as much as 7.7 percent, to 842.5 pence ($11.94). Last year, Bloomsbury said first-half sales reached $16 million, before the publication of the fourth book by J.K. Rowling, ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,'' which sold 370,000 copies in Britain on its first day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGAN, ELTON C.
description: REGAN-Elton C., Died on Friday June 22. Survived by his father, brother, nephews, & nieces & other family members & loved ones.

title: Corrections
description: Acorrection in this space on Saturday about an article on Friday on the indictment of 14 people in the truck bombing of the Khobar Towers apartment complex in Saudi Arabia misstated the year of the bombing. It was 1996, not 1993.

title: Album of the Week: Basement Jaxx's 'Booty'
description: BASEMENT JAXX: "Rooty" (Astralwerks). "Rooty" begins with a shiny sound collage that suggests the sliding doors of a spaceship opening to let in the blue rays of heaven. Then a breathy voice dripping with innuendo whispers "Basement Jaxx," as if it meant something dirty, and you know you're actually stepping into a much more earthy daydream. The psychological world of "Rooty" is hedonism, but disco style as opposed to hip-hop style. Inasmuch as this album is about sex  and it is  it's fabulous sex: nobody is denigrated.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: The Frugal Palace
description: Britain's royal family, under pressure to shed its image of unaccountable privilege, issued its first annual report, showing that Queen Elizabeth II had reduced expenditures to $49 million, down $4.2 million from last year. Michael Peat, keeper of the privy purse, said there had been savings in transportation, palace maintenance and staff salaries. The report was issued to reporters in the basement of Buckingham Palace.icity costs. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Creditors Balk At Swap
description: Hyundai Engineering and Construction struggled for survival yesterday as several creditors balked at swapping debts for equity. Hana Bank, along with two major insurance companies and other creditors, also said they did not want to invest in new shares in a deal for raising more than $2 billion to salvage the troubled company. Nonetheless, the company managed to sell $576 million in convertible bonds in an effort to cut deeply into debt that will exceed $4 billion by the end of the month.

title: G.O.P. Defends Bush in Face of Dip in Poll Ratings
description: Stung by recent polls showing that President Bush's popularity is slipping, top Republican Party officials insisted today that the president was in fine shape politically. They said that given the closeness of the election last year no one should expect Mr. Bush to be wildly popular.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Opposing The Death Penalty
description: Opponents of the death penalty will begin collecting signatures to get a measure on the ballot in 2002 that would abolish capital punishment but give jurors the option of a life-without-parole sentence. The state's death penalty was repealed in 1964, but was reinstated by a wide margin in a 1984 vote. Supporters of the new campaign will have roughly a year to gather the nearly 90,000 signatures needed to put a constitutional amendment to the voters. Twenty-five men are on Oregon's death row. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Memories in Transit, On the Nostalgia Train
description: On a recent Sunday morning, the 59th Street A train platform was busier than normal for a rainy weekend. Families and a stream of rain-drenched runners, fresh from the Central Park Father's Day race, were descending the stairs when they encountered a mysterious empty subway train that roared into the station, slowed and sped up again without taking on passengers.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Francis Bacon, Much Wanted

title: Misreading the Pentagon Papers
description: Over the past 30 years, the news articles on the Pentagon Papers have been based more on mythology and folklore than fact -- everything from how the project originated to what it proved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TALBOT, DONALD E.
description: TALBOT-Donald E. Always in our thoughts and hearts. Roslyn, James, and Cary

title: Do Androids Long for Mom?
description: Steven Spielberg's career as a director has been one of almost profligate variety: from mechanical sharks to the Normandy invasion, from Indiana Jones to the Warsaw ghetto, not to mention the slave ships, the angry dinosaurs and the second worst Pearl Harbor movie ever made. But every so often he comes back to the figure of a lonely boy facing the incomprehension and cruelty of the adult world, and when he does -- most notably in ''E.T.'' and ''Empire of the Sun'' -- it is with a feeling of coming home to emotions that lie beyond the reach of the ruthless sentimentality that has been his greatest weakness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENTLEY, CHARLOTTE MARIE FOWLER
description: BENTLEY-Charlotte Marie Fowler. Peacefully passed away on June 24 at Cabrini Hospice after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Col. Robert A.L. Bentley. She is survived by many loving friends. A native of St. Louis and a 1930 graduate of Smith College, she spent the remainder of her life in New York where she was involved in numerous charitable, military & fraternal organizations. A funeral service was held on June 27, at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, followed by private interment at Mt. View Cemetery, Olean, NY, on June 28. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011. May flights of angels attend her to her resting place.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Sports Plus last Monday about online coverage of the Tour de France bicycle race next month misidentified the networks that will provide television coverage. The Outdoor Life Network cable channel, not ESPN, will provide daily live coverage for two hours, beginning at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time, and will also offer a two-hour wrapup at 9 p.m. Eastern Time. CBS will provide coverage on three Sundays: July 15, July 22 and July 29.

title: Bikini Song And Popeye Please China
description: When Popeye ruled Saturday morning television in the United States and ''Yellow Polka Dot Bikini'' was topping the music charts, the Chinese were in the throes of the Cultural Revolution, reading Little Red Books, condemning bourgeois capitalists, especially American, and raising their voices in revolutionary song.

title: A First Step to Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Milosevic and the Beginning of Honesty
description: When Bob Stewart, who commanded the first regiment of British peacekeepers in Bosnia, was asked by the BBC for his reaction to the extradition of Slobodan Milosevic, he responded with one joyous word: ''Hallelujah.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 4 about Tennyson Schad, founder of the Light Gallery in Manhattan, described the gallery's exhibition of the photographer Paul Strand incorrectly. It was not the first Strand show since Stieglitz's day. A retrospective of Strand's work opened in November 1971, two months earlier than the Light Gallery's show.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bid For Bank
description: United Overseas Bank, Singapore's No. 2 lender, offered 10 billion Singapore dollars ($5.5 billion) for Overseas Union Bank, topping its bigger rival's hostile bid, as takeovers and new regulations increase competition. The offer of 4.02 Singapore dollars and 0.52 United Overseas shares is 6 percent more than Overseas Union's last traded price and more than the bid of 9.4 billion Singapore dollars from DBS Group Holdings. It has support from Overseas Union's management and its founder, Lien Ying Chow. The purchase would give United Overseas the size it needs to compete as the government opens the banking industry to more foreign competition in a bid to make Singapore an Asian financial hub.

title: F.B.I. Wants to Interview Wife In Case of Missing Capital Intern
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking to interview the wife of Representative Gary A. Condit as part of an investigation into what happened to Chandra Ann Levy, the 24-year-old intern who has not been seen since April 30, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALEE, BEN L.
description: SALEE-Ben L. On June 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna until her death; father to Adrian; grandfather to Linda, Deborah and Steven; great-grandfather to Sam and Joe; loving parent to Alice, Mike and Hans. Respected lawyer and judge in Huntington, LI.

title: Cuttings: Making the Most of the Rain You Get
description: THE fifth graders were out in the hot sun recently, weeding the rain garden they had planted from seed last November.

title: A First Step to Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Aphotograph with an article on Thursday about Alberto Fujimori, the ousted president of Peru, who now lives in Japan, carried an erroneous credit. It was obtained from Flash magazine in Tokyo; it was not taken by The Associated Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAHL, GUNNAR ANDREAS
description: DAHL-Gunnar Andreas. The Auxiliary to Bellevue Hospital notes with sadness the loss on June 16th of our longtime friend and board member, dear Gunnar. His compassion and concern for our patients, reflected in his service through the patients' library, is a legacy that will remain. We will miss this wonderful gentleman and all that he contributed for so many years to the hospital and the auxiliary. Judith Makrianes, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LOUISE A.
description: LEVINE-Louise A. On June 29th, 2001 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Devoted wife of the late Seymour Levine. Loving mother of Arthur and Margaret. Adoring grandmother of Sabrina, Zachary, Alex, Jennifer and Stephanie. Services will be graveside Monday, July 2nd, 3 PM, Westchester Hill Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; A Transplant Now Rooted In New York
description: CHUCK KNOBLAUCH of Houston considers himself a New Yorker. A transplanted one, but a proud one. He lives in Manhattan, he rides the subway to Yankee Stadium, he hangs out in trendy places often enough to see his name in the gossip section and he values having a 212 area code.

title: Yanks Put Knoblauch Deal on Hold
description: Yankees executives have wavered over a possible trade of Chuck Knoblauch to Seattle, and for now the deal is off. Club officials determined that the negligible return from the Mariners did not offset the possibility that Knoblauch would rebound from his two-month slump and perhaps haunt the Yankees in October.

title: Study Recommends Abolishing Sheriff's Office
description: An independent study has recommended that the Orange County Sheriff's Office be abolished, citing poor management and training regimes, nepotism and other questionable practices that are ''exposing the taxpayers to substantial risk.''

title: Russian Government Wins Vote For Control of Gazprom Board
description: The Russian government took control of the board of Gazprom today, its latest move to stamp authority on the big company.

title: Knoblauch a Transplant Rooted in New York
description: Chuck Knoblauch of Houston considers himself a New Yorker. A transplanted one, but a proud one. He lives in Manhattan, he rides the subway to Yankee Stadium, he hangs out in trendy places often enough to see his name in the gossip section and he values having a 212 area code.

title: Iran-Contra Figure Back at White House
description: Elliott Abrams, a prominent figure in the Iran-contra scandal of the 1980's, was appointed to President Bush's national security council on Thursday as the director of its office for democracy, human rights and international operations, officials said today.

title: Diplomacy by BMW, With the Top Up
description: Casually dressed in an open-neck blue shirt, King Abdullah of Jordan greeted Secretary of State Colin L. Powell at the airport here today and then escorted him to a welcome-back surprise. The king's custom-made, silver-toned, two-seater BMW convertible was waiting at the back of the terminal for the secretary's use.

title: Article 2001063090475890962 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBARINI, CHARLES J. SR. ESQ.
description: GARBARINI-Charles J. Sr. Esq. 90 years old. The Garbarini/Penna and Petro families deeply mourn the passing of our beloved CJ. He was our ''Great One.'' His long and difficult battle with Glaucoma and Parkinson's disease only enhanced his appreciation of life. He never lost his intelligence, sense of humor and wit. He was a wise, compassionate and charitable man. Charles had a devoted and deep love for Lillian, his wife and ''life support'' of the past 64 years. He was a loving father to his children: Charles, Rita Nugent and Stephen. He was a wonderful father to his son-in-law, William Nugent, and to his daughters by marriage, Ruth and Karen. Unsurpassed was his love for his grandchildren: Christopher Nugent, David Nugent, Samantha Garbarini, Alexandra Garbarini and Micah Singer, Jennifer Layton and Sarah Layton. We cannot imagine life without him, so great is our loss.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Damaged Highway Should Be Torn Down, Panel Says
description: The Alaskan Way Viaduct in Seattle should be torn down instead of retrofitted to withstand another earthquake, said a panel of independent engineers hired by the state. The 48-year-old viaduct sustained extensive damage in the February earthquake in western Washington and has been intermittently closed for repairs. The engineers said the elevated road would continue deteriorating even with a seismic retrofit. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Editors' Note
description: COMING ON SUNDAY

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Census Shows Gray
description: The number of Japanese aged 65 or older has surpassed those below age 15 for the first time since records have been kept. According to 2000 census information, Japan's total population was 126.9 million people, of which the elderly accounted for 17.5 percent, compared with 14.5 percent for young people. The government is worried about the social and economic effects of a declining birth rate and rapidly aging population because there will be fewer workers to support the growing ranks of the elderly. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Fetus Not A Person, Court Says
description: The appeals court has ruled that a drunken driver cannot be charged with manslaughter in the death of a fetus. The court confirmed an earlier ruling that a fetus does not have the same legal rights as a separate living person. The ruling stems from an incident six years ago when a pregnant woman was hit by a drunken driver and her baby was still-born four days later.

title: Senators Reach an Agreement On Nominees for Supreme Court
description: Republican and Democratic senators reached an agreement tonight on how they would handle Supreme Court nominees, a bitter sticking point in their efforts to reorganize the Senate under Democratic control.

title: Premier of Yugoslavia Resigns in Protest
description: The handing over of Slobodan Milosevic to the United Nations war crimes tribunal prompted the Yugoslav prime minister to resign today, bringing down the Yugoslav government and opening the first cracks in the alliance of democratic reformers who removed Mr. Milosevic from power eight months ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Production Slows
description: For three consecutive months, from March through May, industrial production in South Korea has grown at a lower rate than the month before. The National Statistics Office said yesterday that output in May was 2.3 percent higher than in May 2000 after having risen in April by 5.6 percent from the year before and in March by 6.4 percent. Other numbers also indicated economic trouble. Semiconductor exports for the first half of 2001 earned $9.6 billion, down 27 percent from the first half of last year, while orders for construction projects overseas fell 49 percent in the first six months from the period last year. The good news: vehicle exports came to $5.1 billion, up 6 percent from the first five months of 2000, and were forecast at $6.26 billion for the first six months, an increase of 6.9 percent from the first half of last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Judicial Reasoning Is All Too Human
description: Forget the 14th Amendment and the peculiarities of California state law. The real inspiration behind Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia's vote to deny the child of an adulterous affair any contact with her natural father was the legend of King Arthur, Guinevere and Lancelot.

title: Mideast Violence: Which Way Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates and Dollars on the New York Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: Hot Weather Stalls Repairs To Temporary I-80 Bridge
description: Interstate 80, a major artery between Pennsylvania and New York, is tied up in New Jersey on two fronts. Lanes that reopened this week after a crash are again closed for repairs, and state police investigators are having a difficult time finding the owner of the truck that triggered the accident.

title: Move Over, Mount Vernon. John Adams Slept Here.
description: IT is happening more and more these days. John Stanwich will be out in public somewhere, like a McDonald's, and a person will look closely at him, study him for a moment, and then with a knowing look say, ''You are John Adams.''

title: TOMMY HILFIGER AGREES TO BUY T. H. INTERNATIONAL
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, a casual-clothing maker whose sales have fallen as shoppers cut spending, agreed to buy its European licensee, T. H. International N.V., for $230 million. Tommy Hilfiger will pay $200 million in cash and assume about $30 million in debt for T.H. International, which is the parent of Tommy Hilfiger Europe B.V., said Joe Scirocco, the Tommy Hilfiger senior vice president and treasurer.

title: War Crimes Tribunal Expands Milosevic Indictment
description: The international war crimes tribunal issued an expanded indictment today against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, charging him with additional atrocities and naming more victims of the 1999 conflict in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENITS, ALAN N. ''BUDDY''
description: BRENITS-Alan N. ''Buddy''. February 1, 1930 to June 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Nancy (Rush). Devoted father of James, Donald and Andrew. Adored grandfather to Ariel, William, Joshua and Sophie. Loving brother of Helen Glantz and Evelyn Bier. His kindness and compassion will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral service Sunday, July 1st, at 1PM, at ''The Riverside-Nassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Plea Agreement By Ex-Banker Averts New Trial
description: James J. McDermott Jr., a Wall Street investment banker whose conviction for stock fraud and conspiracy was thrown out by a federal appeals court in March, pleaded guilty yesterday to one charge of insider trading as part of an agreement that will let him avoid further prison time and a new trial.

title: Gravano Pleads Guilty To Drug Sales In Arizona
description: Salvatore Gravano -- Mafia hit man, government witness, recidivist criminal -- closed the unlikely second act of his life of crime yesterday by pleading guilty in Phoenix to selling thousands of Ecstasy pills.

title: The Pink Flamingo: Be Afraid. Very Afraid.
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrant In Prison Wins Right To Hearing
description: Enrico St. Cyr was lying in his prison cell Tuesday evening, thinking about nothing at all, when the Roman Catholic priest who often led him and other detained Haitian immigrants in prayer stopped to offer congratulations.

title: Return of Unshaded Renews Rivalry
description: Last summer they were the late-blooming 3-year-olds, responsible for perhaps the most scintillating finish of the season when the fleet-footed Albert the Great skimmed the rail at Saratoga Race Course, desperately trying to hold off the powerful, pounding strides of a rangy gelding named Unshaded.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST</B

title: Yankees to Wait and See On Trading Knoblauch
description: Yankees executives have wavered over a possible trade of Chuck Knoblauch to Seattle, and for now the deal is off. Club officials determined that the negligible return from the Mariners did not offset the possibility that Knoblauch would rebound from his two-month slump and perhaps haunt the Yankees in October.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Budget Cuts For Schools And Universities Will Be Equal
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that Gov. Don Siegelman could not make bigger cuts in the budget for colleges than in the budget for elementary and high schools. Earlier this year Mr. Siegelman, a Democrat facing a sharp decline in tax revenue, ordered elementary and high school allocations cut 3.7 percent while cutting higher education allocations 11.1 percent. As a result of the court's decision, public schools, including universities, now face budget cuts of 6.2 percent.

title: Majuro Journal; A Pacific Puzzle: Connecting Dots Into a Nation
description: What to make of a collection of dots in the Pacific Ocean whose crescent-shaped main island is so slender that a boy can stand in the lagoon on one coast and throw a baseball clear across into the shimmering turquoise sea on the other?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Aer Lingus Appointment
description: The Irish state-owned airline Aer Lingus appointed John O'Donovan, formerly group finance director, as acting chief executive. Mr. O'Donovan will serve until a full replacement can be found for Michael Foley, who was dismissed from the position earlier this month amid allegations of sexual harassment. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Sidebar: Reversing a Trend
description: With umpires calling a changed strike zone this season, runs, home runs and walks are down, while strikeouts are up. Here are the averages (through June 28) compared with averages through June of the previous five seasons:

title: Three Vieques Protesters Emerge From Prison After 37 Days
description: Just before 9 a.m., three men slipped out a side door of the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn into the humid air. They enjoyed a few seconds of peace and quiet. Then the reporters spotted them and the stampede began.

title: Unemployment Up, Prices Down In Sign of Japanese Recession
description: The unemployment rate in Japan returned to its peak level in May, consumer prices continued their relentless fall, and wages dropped once again, the government reported today, further signs that recession is once more gripping the Japanese economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMAN, BERTHA (BERT)
description: ELMAN-Bertha (Bert). Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Lynn and Judy. Motherin-law of David and Kenny. Dear sister of Lou and the late Jack. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, Cory, Rebecca and Joanna. Service Sunday 10AM at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Opinion Is Divided in Serbia Over Handover of Milosevic
description: The image of Slobodan Milosevic being flown to jail inspired pity in Natasa Popovic, a young woman who works at a newsstand in Mr. Milosevic's hometown, Pozarevac. She also said she believed that it was Serbs who should judge Mr. Milosevic for any war crimes, not an international tribunal in the Netherlands.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Patients' Rights
description: The Supreme Court today granted a patients' rights case for decision in its next term that raises a legal issue addressed by the Senate bill on patients' rights.

title: Mr. Cheney's New Heart Problem
description: Vice President Dick Cheney is heading back to the hospital this morning for the latest in what are becoming recurring episodes involving his damaged heart. Once again Mr. Cheney and the White House are portraying the event as a relatively minor, precautionary step that will not interfere with his performance of duties, and in an immediate sense they are probably right. But when one minor precautionary step succeeds another, the continuing chain of events inevitably raises questions about whether the vice president can continue to serve effectively or is on some kind of downward spiral in which a weakening heart will eventually drive him from office or off the ticket in 2004.

title: Hearts Lead to Diamonds As 2 Become Life Partners
description: For two leading figures in the world of bridge to be married is a rare event, but it happened yesterday in Dallas when Sidney Lazard, who has been one of the world's best players for half a century, formed a life partnership with Betsey Wolff. She was formerly married to Bobby Wolff, a multiple world champion, and she herself won the World Mixed Teams title in 1972.

title: Israel's Water Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; A Reform Rabbi Who Finds Himself in Demand
description: During the annual gathering of rabbis of Judaism's liberal Reform movement this week in Monterey, Calif., Rabbi David Ellenson was a busy man -- mostly off the conference floor. A reporter caught up with him in his hotel room, between his taking a phone call and attending a meeting, both business related. Rabbi Ellenson said he had not had much time to participate in the gathering going on in the same hotel, the meeting of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

title: CHENEY'S DOCTORS EXPECT TO IMPLANT DEVICE FOR HEART
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that doctors would almost certainly implant a sophisticated heart pacemaker and defibrillator during an operation on Saturday, his third significant medical procedure to combat heart disease since he was elected vice president.

title: Yanks' Clemens (11-1) Continues to Be Beyond Compare
description: David Wells will be forever beloved at Yankee Stadium for his supersize uniform, for his ability to win big games, for pitching a perfect game with a hangover, for his admitted preference in alcoholic beverages. Vodka over beer, for the record.

title: Israelis and Palestinians at Odds Over Cease-Fire Timing
description: As Secretary of State Colin L. Powell flew away this morning, he left Israelis and Palestinians in inauspicious disagreement about what they had agreed to in a time line for cementing their wobbly cease-fire.

title: Philadelphia Journal; As Little Institutions Go, This One's All but Gone
description: Maybe it was the way Tony Dell grabbed his female fans by the ankles in the middle of ''Light My Fire.''

title: The Supreme Court Exits
description: The Supreme Court concluded a tumultuous term on Thursday with important 5-to-4 decisions on immigration, tobacco advertising and the rights of property owners. It was an appropriate ending for a session in which 26 of the 85 cases were decided by a one-vote margin -- including the term's defining case, Bush v. Gore, a historic verdict in which the conservative majority handed the presidential election to the conservative candidate, George W. Bush.

title: Article 2001063093221544504 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Competition Wins in Court
description: Every so often, hard cases make good law. In one of the best antitrust opinions in years, a federal appeals court this week brought sudden clarity to the epic Microsoft case and delivered a ruling that will guide business practices in the shifting technology market.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Carbon Dioxide Emissions Jumped In 2000
description: American emissions of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels rose 2.7 percent in 2000, a much higher rate than the average 1.5-percent annual rise through the 1990's, the Energy Department said. The emissions rose because of strong economic growth, cold weather that increased oil use and a drop in electricity generation by dams, the department said. Carbon dioxide accounts for 80 percent of the country's output of heat-trapping greenhouse gases, officials said.

title: Hot Summer Rates in Phoenix
description: Here's another Web-only deal: the Pointe Hilton Tapatio Cliffs and Pointe Hilton Squaw Peak, both in Phoenix, are offering rates as low as $84 a night in July and August for suites if reservations are made through www.pointehilton.com The rates at the Squaw Peak start at $104. Although Phoenix is very hot in summer, the resorts have a number of pools to cool off in, as well as good desert golf, spas and fitness centers. At the Web site, click on "book a room" and then select the "Hilton value rate." A one-night nonrefundable deposit is required and space is limited.

title: Article 2001063090476577917 -- No Title
'Unfolding': The Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company Speeds Ahead
description: Only one of the three works by Nai-Ni Chen that her Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company presented last Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo was called "Unfolding." But that title was appropriate to two offerings by this troupe, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend yesterday about the Steven Spielberg film ''A.I.'' misidentified the Jewish ghetto where part of another of Mr. Spielberg's films, ''Schindler's List,'' is set. It is the Krakow ghetto, not Warsaw's.

title: Even in Victory, Mets Suffer a Loss
description: The Mets can mark their season by their three visits to Turner Field. They began their defense of the National League championship here, reached the halfway point tonight and end the regular season with three games in September.

title: Youth Movement in the N.B.A.
description: America's inner cities are full of playground legends who never made it through college and ended up on the street when a professional sports contract failed to materialize. The prospects of a college degree for many fine young athletes grew even dimmer this week when the National Basketball Association held its annual, nationally televised draft. Four of the top 10 choices were teenagers who have decided to bypass college altogether. Astoundingly, only 4 of the 28 first-round selections had completed four years of college.

title: Marbury Is All Right With Trade To Suns
description: Stephon Marbury walked out the front door of his house today decked in velour sweats the color of the hot summer sky. He appeared to be floating up there, less than 24 hours after he was traded from the Nets to the Phoenix Suns for the fellow All-Star point guard Jason Kidd.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph with an article on Thursday about Alberto Fujimori, the ousted president of Peru, who now lives in Japan, carried an erroneous credit. It was obtained from Flash magazine in Tokyo; it was not taken by The Associated Press.

title: China's Release of North Korean Refugees Sidesteps Sensitive Issue
description: In permitting seven North Korean asylum seekers to leave here today on medical grounds, China turned its back on the central question the incident raised.

title: S.E.C. Warns Investors On Analysts
description: Responding to an outpouring of complaints, the Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an alert to investors not to rely solely on stock analysts' reports when they make decisions about buying and selling stocks.

title: American Military Personnel Suspected in Okinawa Rape
description: The police on Okinawa said today that a Japanese woman was raped in a parking lot and that the victim and a witness had identified the attackers as foreigners who were most likely United States service members.

title: The Mayor-Elect of Passaic May Serve Despite a Crime
description: After two frantic days of legal maneuvering and court hearings, the mayor-elect of Passaic today won the legal right to take office on Sunday, despite a felony conviction dating to his days as a police officer in Puerto Rico in the 1980's.

title: 'Percussion Pieces': Curran Never Loses Himself in the Dance
description: Sean Curran has the suspiciously earnest, slightly subversive persona of a silent-movie comedian. His timing is impressive, as is the way he immerses but never loses himself in the dance. Those gifts were a great part of the pleasure of his snazzy new "Metal Garden," the opening section of a suite called "Percussion Pieces" that was presented by the Sean Curran Company on June 12 at the Joyce Theater.

title: Mideast Violence: Which Way Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Apologizes To Muslim Student
description: President Bush apologized for the the Secret Service's eviction of a Muslim student from a meeting at the White House on Thursday, an incident that prompted Muslim leaders to walk out. The Secret Service said it was mistaken for escorting the student, Abdullah Al-Arian, who is a Congressional intern, out of a meeting between Muslim leaders and staff members of the White House Office on Faith-Based and Community Initiatives. Mr. Al-Arian's father ran a pro-Palestinian policy institute with Mazen Al-Najjar, who was jailed by the government on secret evidence. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the National Basketball Association draft misidentified the high school attended by the No. 1 selection, Kwame Brown. It was Glynn Academy in Brunswick, Ga., not Glynn Hill Academy.

title: Terror Trial Is Disrupted By Outburst Of Defendant
description: An Algerian accused in a terrorist plot to strike the Los Angeles airport during millennium celebrations in 1999 brought his trial to a halt yesterday, flailing his arms and banging his head on the counsel table as an old friend and former co-defendant testified against him.

title: Toyota and Peugeot in Pact To Produce Car for Europe
description: Toyota Motor of Japan and PSA Peugeot Citron of France announced today that they would jointly develop and build a small fuel-efficient car for the European market.

title: BILL ESTABLISHING PATIENTS' RIGHTS PASSES IN SENATE
description: Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the Senate tonight passed a bill that would establish a wide range of patients' rights for more than 200 million Americans with health insurance.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Communications Merger
description: Two Indian mobile communications companies said they had agreed to merge most of their operations, creating the country's largest wireless provider, with a million subscribers, a 28 percent market share and a market value of more than $2 billion. BPL Communications, based in Bangalore, contributes its mobile phone operations in the two southern states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu to the merger and will own 49.32 percent of the combined venture. Birla Tata AT&T, a three-way equal partnership of AT&T and two Indian industrial groups, Birla and Tata, contributes operations in Maharashtra and Gujarat in the west and Andhra Pradesh in the south. To comply with regulations against owning two licenses in the same territory, BPL will withhold its Maharashtra license from the merger. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Candidates and Dollars on the New York Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: No Progress For Boxer
description: A boxer who sustained a severe head injury in a televised fight Tuesday remained comatose and in very critical condition yesterday, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the steps that some New York City businesses are taking to conserve electricity during the heat wave misstated the reserve available to Consolidated Edison at the peak of energy use on Wednesday. It was about 3,000 megawatts, not 13,864. The larger figure was the utility's total generating capacity at the time, including its reserve.

title: Mideast Violence: Which Way Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMEDIA NEAR DEAL FOR EMAP'S U.S. MAGAZINES
description: Primedia, which publishes Seventeen and New York magazine, is close to a deal to buy Emap's United States magazine business for about $515 million, executives close to the deal said yesterday. Emap, a British publisher, has struggled with its American magazines since it paid $1.5 billion to buy Petersen Publishing in 1998. Emap publishes dozens of Petersen's enthusiast titles, including Skin Diver, Guns & Ammo and Snowboarder. Primedia has bid on the properties in the past, losing out when Emap won control of Peterson, then known as K-III Communications. Primedia is controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: The Role of the Insurer
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Seeks Criminal Charges Against Publishers
description: SEOUL  The South Korean government broadened its charges against national news organizations Friday as the authorities named two of the country's best-known publishers among five newspaper executives recommended for criminal charges of tax evasion.

title: Town Immortalized by Art Is Divided Over Industry; Can Culture and Factories Coexist on the River?
description: The tourism industry has worked hard in recent years to cast the Hudson River Valley as a ruddy-cheeked play land of nature, history, art and cute-as-a-button Victorian bed-and-breakfast hotels.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Gesture To Opposition
description: In its latest conciliatory move, the military junta has allowed the National League for Democracy, the party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to reopen two branch offices outside the capital that had been closed four years ago. It also released nine members of the party, continuing a series of releases that appear to accompany talks between Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and military leaders.

title: A Fast Way to Live a Classic, But a Slow Way to Die in It
description: Valmont -- that cold-hearted, handsome devil of a French aristocrat -- wears a flowing white dress to act the part of his most recent sexual conquest. As he removes the dress at the end of the play-acting, he tells Merteuil, his female partner in sexual scheming, ''I do believe I could get used to being a woman.'' Merteuil replies, with the slightest lift of an eyebrow, ''I wish I could.''

title: Pentagon Says Osprey Lies Arose From Push to Succeed
description: The commanding officer of the Marine Corps's only squadron of V-22 Osprey falsified maintenance records because he felt pressure from his superiors to make the Osprey, an innovative but crash-plagued aircraft, appear ready for full production, a Pentagon investigation released today has found.

title: Math Test Needed for High School Graduation Had Confusing Errors, State Officials Say
description: Amid growing concern over low math scores, New York State officials acknowledged yesterday that a statewide test given to thousands of students as a requirement for high school graduation contained several confusing errors.

title: Article 2001063090156168769 -- No Title
description: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

title: Test Company Says School Inquiry Put End to Deal
description: The chief executive of an online test-preparation company said yesterday that New York City school officials had abruptly halted plans to buy test materials because of an investigation into whether Dr. Irving S. Hamer Jr., a member of the Board of Education who was a vice chairman of the company, had improperly used his influence on its behalf.

title: A Daring Theory That Stalin Had Walter Benjamin Murdered
description: In 1940, in a small hotel in the coastal Catalan town of Port Bou, the German-Jewish philosopher and critic Walter Benjamin was found dead. He had just made his way across the Pyrenees Mountains, fleeing certain death in France at the hands of the Nazis. As the story goes, he was denied passage into Spain. And so he took his own life, overdosing on morphine.

title: U.S. to Reassess Snowmobile Ban in a Park
description: The Interior Department said today that it would reconsider a Clinton administration plan to ban snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park.

title: Article 2001063094220065743 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Op-Art
Jordanian Muslim Cleric Calls for Death of Author in U.S.
description: A radical Muslim cleric in Jordan has issued a religious opinion that advocates the death of a Muslim scholar in the United States in punishment for a book he wrote about Islam.

title: Rangers May Yield To Temptation of Jagr
description: While the Devils were eliminating Pittsburgh in five games during the recent Stanley Cup playoffs, a New Jersey fan near the Penguins' bench in Continental Arena kept shouting at Jaromir Jagr. ''Hey, Jagr!'' the man yelled at the Penguins' captain. ''You'll make a great Ranger!''

title: William Sewell, 91, Sociologist Famed for Study of Wisconsinites
description: Dr. William H. Sewell, a sociologist who guided a study that looked at the underpinnings of success by following more than 10,000 people over 40 years, died on Sunday in Madison, Wis., where he lived. He was 91.

title: Kidd Is Happy for the Chance To Try to Revitalize the Nets
description: Jason Kidd knows he sounds crazy. He says he is excited to be traded to the Nets. He says the Nets will make the playoffs next season.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Confident Words
description: On a visit to the Philippines, President Abdurrahman Wahid denied reports that he was planning to fire his military leaders and expressed confidence in his own tenure. ''I will not be impeached and I will survive,'' he said, in a reference to a parliamentary session scheduled for August.

title: Microsoft Case Back in Play, And the Lobbying Heats Up
description: As federal and state prosecutors ponder what to do next with Microsoft, they have already come under enormous lobbying pressure from the company to settle quickly and from its rivals, most notably AOL Time Warner, to continue litigating.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Ex-Official Cleared In Tax Case
description: France's highest appeals court has found that there is not enough evidence to investigate and try Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's former finance minister. The official, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, left, faces charges that he granted an illegal tax break to the fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld in exchange for a videotape containing allegations of corruption charges against President Jacques Chirac. The court said it had decided that the case against Mr. Strauss-Kahn should not be sent on to a rarely used special court for trying senior officials. Mr. Strauss-Kahn resigned in 1999 to clear his name of other corruption charges, some still pending.

title: Article 2001063093664013021 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Corrections
description: A map in Weekend yesterday with an article about the New York Transit Museum's Nostalgia Train located the train's last stop, the Rockaway Park station, incorrectly. It is in the western part of the Rockaway Peninsula, not the eastern part.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Anchovy Deaths Puzzle Scientists
description: Millions of anchovies have been dying of oxygen depletion in Brookings and a nearby river, creating a stench and providing a feast for seagulls. Scientists say the causes of the phenomenon, the third such mass fish kill in 30 years, are not fully understood. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Park and Dial
description: To the Editor:

title: Diallo Officer Is Joining New Fire Dept. Class
description: Edward McMellon, one of the four police officers involved in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, will join the Fire Department on July 16, fire officials said yesterday. Although not unexpected, the decision to hire Mr. McMellon came over protests from minority firefighters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIESER, ROLF
description: KIESER-Rolf. Professor of German at Queens College and the CUNY Graduate Center, born in Switzerland in 1936 and educated at the University of Zurich, died peacefully on June 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Tamara S. Evans, cherished brother of Ursula Egli of Feldmeilen, Switzerland, and Vreni Vontobel of Grut, Switzerland, brother-in-law and friend of their husbands Heinz and Heiner, devoted uncle of Katrin, Susan, Andrea, Marc and Philipp, fond son-in-law of Eva and Felix Schlienger of Nidau, Switzerland, dear companion of Albertine van Thiel, New York, and dedicated teacher of his CUNY students. His wife wishes to thank the doctors a d nurses both in Wetzikon, Switzerland, and at New York Hosptial for accompanying him through his illness. Memorial services will be held in New York and Switzerland at a later date.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Woman Joins Top Pilots
description: Four years after Israel's High Court overturned an army ban on women as fighter pilots, Second Lt. Roni Zuckerman, 20, became the first woman to graduate from a rigorous pilot training course. Graduating sixth in a class of 70, she will enter an elite unit whose pilots fly F-16 fighter jets.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Mayor Proposes Airport Expansion
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago presented a plan to expand O'Hare International Airport and reduce flight delays by up to 40 percent. The $6 billion plan would add a new runway and restructure the seven existing ones. The plan now goes to Gov. George Ryan, who has the power to veto runways. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: An Attempt at Humor By Sampras Falls Short
description: In front of a suddenly uneasy audience at Court 1, Pete Sampras revealed questionable judgment and taste today during his interaction with a ball boy during his third-round victory.

title: 'Chaconne': George Balanchine Moves From Heaven to Earth
description: George Balanchine's "Chaconne" moves from heaven to earth. The first scene of this work, which the New York City Ballet presented on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, appears to take place in a blessed otherworldly realm, and many of its sequences emphasize unhurried walking steps.

title: Busy Chief Executive Seeks Apartment That's Convenient to Gracie Mansion
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has looked at more than 10 schematic drawings of two- and three-bedroom Upper East Side apartments and expects to move out of Gracie Mansion within six weeks, a close friend of his said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lobbying Is in Full Swing From Microsoft and Rivals

title: Hamilton Is Benched Over Playing Time, and His Mets Future Is Unclear
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips was trying to help today when he suggested to the agent John Hamilton that his brother, Mets outfielder Darryl Hamilton, meet with Manager Bobby Valentine to discuss his playing time. But a 10-minute meeting in the manager's office and a hallway at Turner Field ended with Hamilton's removal from the lineup and, almost certainly, his removal from the team.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: McVeigh's Defense Cost Millions
description: The defense of Timothy J. McVeigh in the Oklahoma City bombing case cost taxpayers $13.8 million. Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court, who presided over Mr. McVeigh's trial in Denver, released the figures. Mr. McVeigh employed 19 lawyers. He was executed on June 11. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A First Step to Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Artificial Intelligence For the New Millennium; A Revolution More Bland Than Kubrick's '2001'
description: For those wondering when artificial intelligence will truly take root, here's a bulletin: it already has.

title: Words, Served Hot, Not Minced
description: THE wording had a familiar, ominous ring that didn't sit right. This was a written statement issued the other day by three members of Congress from New York City and New Jersey. They were most unhappy with the editor in chief of El Diario La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Carter Seeking Alliance of Moderate Baptists
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who last year broke with his denomination, the Southern Baptist Convention, over its increasingly conservative direction, has been host to two meetings of leaders of moderate Baptist groups to seek ''common ground'' among them, such as sending out missionaries, he said in an interview tonight.

title: Budget Surplus Could Dwindle, Bush Aide Says
description: The Bush administration raised the possibility today that the slowing economy could drive the federal budget surplus down this year by more than the government had previously estimated. Democrats said such a shortfall could create a budget deficit by their definition.

title: Film Festival Will Open With Work by Rivette
description: The 39th New York Film Festival will open on Sept. 28 with a screening at Avery Fisher Hall of ''Va Savoir'' (''Who Knows?'') by the French New Wave filmmaker Jacques Rivette, whose works include ''Celine and Julie Go Boating'' (1974) and ''La Belle Noiseuse'' (1991).

title: World Briefing | World: Tribunal Aide Denies Genocide Charge
description: A former investigator for the Rwanda war crimes tribunal who has himself been accused of genocide and crimes against humanity pleaded not guilty at the court, based in Arusha, Tanzania. The former investigator, Simeon Nshamihigo, 42, had been working under an assumed name when he was arrested in May. He is accused of taking part in genocidal attacks on ethnic Tutsi and Hutu politically opposed to the Hutu-led government in 1994. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Plea Mailed to Roger Clinton Was Flagged By President
description: In the last weeks of the Clinton presidency, when Roger Clinton was visiting the White House for a few days, a piece of mail arrived addressed to him from the family of a convicted drug dealer looking for clemency.

title: Monster.com Parent in Deal for HotJobs
description: The parent of Monster.com, the job search Web site, announced yesterday that it would acquire its largest rival, HotJobs.com, for $460 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, DIANE M.
description: MOORE-Diane M. June 27, 2001. Retired Assistant Principal with the City of New York's Pregnant Teenagers Program. Loved and cherised by her family. Survived by her mother Mae Weech, children Lisa, Allyson and Eric and grandchildren Ciara, Cristina, Brandon and Jalen. Services today 11am, Church of the Intercession.

title: Annan Begins 2nd Term Pledging To Bring U.N. Closer to People
description: Pledging to bring the United Nations closer to the people it was created to serve, Kofi Annan swore himself in for a second term as secretary general today after being re-elected by acclamation, and with applause, by 189 member countries.

title: Corrections
description: A brief news report in SportsThursday about a change in the New York City Marathon course misidentified the part of the course that is affected. It is mile 23, not mile 25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, RUTH LEDER
description: SHAPIRO-Ruth Leder. Memorial service Saturday, July 7, 2001, 11:30AM at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st St)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A First Step to Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivanisevic Turns Back the Clock as Roddick Unwinds
description: The colorful Goran Ivanisevic took his place on Court 1 today with a left shoulder all but tethered by duct tape and a wild-card entry onto the grounds as a sympathy gift. Poor Goran, his heydays on grass were so long ago.

title: His Own E.R. In His Chest
description: In the tests that Vice President Dick Cheney is to undergo today, doctors subject a heart to stress to determine whether it is at risk of developing a rapid rhythm that could lead to sudden death.

title: Florida Senator Takes Hostage on Oil Plan
description: In a new challenge to the White House, Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, today promised a ''fight to the death'' against plans for oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico and said he would hold up a Senate vote on the nominee for a top Interior Department official to protest the plan.

title: SAP AGREES TO RAISE STAKE IN COMMERCE ONE TO 20%
description: Shares of Commerce One Inc. rose 37 percent after SAP A.G. agreed to increase its stake in the company to 20 percent. The shares rose $1.58, to $5.84. They had fallen 95 percent since Sept. 29, when the price reached a 52-week high of $84.13. SAP, the German-based maker of business-management software, said it would spend as much as $225 million to increase its stake in Commerce One from 3 percent. Commerce One, based in Pleasanton, Calif., sells software and services related to online marketplaces, or exchanges, that link buyers and sellers directly. SAP's American depository receipts rose 34 cents, to $35.09.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD., Exeter, N.H., a diversified manufacturer whose ADT unit is the biggest maker of burglar alarms, has agreed to buy the Edison Select security unit of Edison International, Rosemead, Calif., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Excerpts From Cheney Health Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference yesterday in Washington at which Vice President Cheney announced that he might have a cardiac pacemaker implanted, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: Did Cradles Always Rock? Or Did Mom Once Not Care?
description: When eight gay couples decided to sue the Canadian government for the right to marry last year, they recruited a historian of the family to file a brief on their behalf. The Canadian government did the same. As a result, when Halpern v. Canada is heard in Ontario Divisional Court this fall, the judges will be asked to consider conflicting testimony about the nature of marriages and families in the past.

title: Robert L. Crowell, 92, Head Of Reference Book Publisher
description: Robert L. Crowell, president of the Thomas Y. Crowell Company, a New York publishing house that is now part of HarperCollins, died on Friday at his home in Ponte Vedra, Fla. He was 92.

title: Penalties in Kyrgyzstan
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurst Outdoes King With a 63
description: Betsy King sizzled with six birdies on the first nine holes she played today on the Seaview Marriott Bay course. She seemed headed for a course-record-tying 63 until she bogeyed her final hole in the first round of the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic.

title: Court Review Sought in Bedford Paganism Suit
description: The guardian of two children in the Bedford school district has asked the United States Supreme Court to overturn a ruling dismissing claims that the district promoted paganism, New Age thinking and the occult.

title: Jay A. Rabinowitz, 74, Justice Who Backed Legal Marijuana
description: Justice Jay Andrew Rabinowitz, who as a member of the Alaska Supreme Court helped shape state law and was remembered mainly for pronouncing marijuana legal, died on June 16 at a hospital in Seattle. He was 74 and lived in Juneau and Fairbanks.

title: Abroad at Home; At the Heart of Liberty
description: Enrico St. Cyr came to the United States in 1986 as a legal immigrant from Haiti. In early 1996 he pleaded guilty to a drug offense, knowing that he could avoid deportation by getting a waiver from the attorney general. Later that year Congress passed a draconian immigration act that removed the waiver option. The Immigration Service moved to deport him -- without the possibility of a waiver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SAUL M., M.D.
description: FELDMAN-Saul M., M.D. of Fairfield, CT, prominent Bridgeport doctor, died June 29 in Bridgeport. Dr. Feldman is survived by his wife, Nancy (Newman) Feldman, his children, Bruce Feldman and Terri Silvers and Marci Sapers, step daughters Deborah Messulam and Allison Peyton, and eight grandchildren, a brother Dr. Morton Feldman, a sister, Bonnie Reese. Services will take place Sunday, July 1 at 11:00 at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2710 Park Ave, Bridgeport, with interment following at Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Vincent Medical Center Foundation, Saul M. Feldman M.D. Memorial Fund, 2800 Main St, Bridgeport, CT 06606.

title: Official Questions the Math Behind California's Energy Bond Issue
description: To hear California's state controller tell it, the problem with the state's plans for a $13.4 billion bond sale, the largest in history, is that the math does not add up.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Award In Uranium Suit
description: A decade after they first went to court, 32 people who contracted radiation poisoning from a Canon City uranium mine were awarded $16.3 million by a federal jury in Denver. A lawyer for the defendant, the Cotter Corporation of Lakewood, Colo., a processing company that operated the mine, said the company would appeal. Three plantiffs have died of their illnesses since the case was filed. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Revised Inflation Estimate
description: The central bank in Brazil raised its forecast for inflation this year, saying a decline in its currency, the real, may increase prices. The bank also cut its estimate for economic growth to take account of the impact of energy shortages. The new forecast for the 2001 inflation rate is 5.8 percent, up from a 4.8 percent estimate in March, according to its quarterly inflation report published yesterday. The central bank lowered its forecast for economic growth this year to 2.8 percent from 4.3 percent. The bank attributes the increased pace of inflation to the ''vicious cycle'' of the depreciation of the currency in the second quarter and the increase of uncertainties surrounding energy shortages and their potential economic and political impact, the bank said in a report.

title: Article 2001063090419508830 -- No Title
description: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

title: Plan to Modify U.N. Sanctions Against Iraq Bogs Down, Powell Says
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell won support from France and China today for a plan to loosen restrictions on trade in civilian goods with Iraq, but he said that continued resistance from Russia made it unlikely that the proposal could be adopted at the United Nations by a deadline next week.

title: INSIDE
description: A Pardon Note Initialed BC

title: Article 2001063092994417231 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: U.S. Report Finds Flaws in Study Of California Power Companies
description: An investigative arm of Congress faulted federal regulators today for claiming that there was no evidence to support accusations that power companies manipulated California's electricity market.

title: Candidates and Dollars on the New York Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO ACQUIRE CARDIAC PATHWAYS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation agreed to buy the Cardiac Pathways Corporation for $115 million in cash to add to its line of products that treat abnormal heart rhythms. The purchase values Cardiac Pathways, a maker of systems for diagnosing irregular heartbeats, at $5.27 a share, Boston Scientific said in a statement. That represents a 9.2 percent discount to Cardiac Pathways' closing price Thursday. Shares of Cardiac Pathways, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had jumped 67 percent in the last week. The deal would broaden Boston Scientific's offerings in its cardiac electrophysiology unit. The company, a leading maker of products used to clear heart arteries, said the purchase would modestly add to earnings this year. Shares of Boston Scientific, which is based in Natick, Mass., fell 51 cents, to $17. Cardiac Pathways fell 59 cents, to $5.21.

title: After a Disheartening Loss, the Liberty Wants Revenge
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato gave his team a day off Tuesday to recover from its humiliating 67-54 loss to Orlando -- its first defeat after a run of seven consecutive victories.

title: Upper Manhattan Loan Program Gets a Three-Month Reprieve
description: A loan program for fledgling Upper Manhattan businesses that had been threatened with extinction won a three-month reprieve yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Defiance On Khmer Rouge Trials
description: The government could proceed with a trial of former leaders of the Khmer Rouge without the United Nations, Prime Minister Hun Sen said. In a pugnacious statement, he brushed aside a reminder by the United Nations that it must still examine and agree to a formula for a tribunal that has been approved by the government.

title: Wild, but Disciplined, With a Side of Potatoes
description: The Cisne Negro Dance Company, which manages to look both admirably disciplined and wildly energetic, brought four New York premieres to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. The unfamiliar choreography was worth discovering. And the dancers deserved, and won, hearty applause.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROY, ASOKA, MS, CNM, FACNM
description: ROY-Asoka, MS, CNM, FACNM, affectionately called Koko, passed away peacefully in Valhalla, NY on June 22. She was born in India, educated in India, England and the USA, & had an interesting & distinguished career in her much loved midwifery profession. She started her midwifery career in India. Stories are told of her courage when she risked her life to see all her midwives to safety during the partition between India and Pakistan; of her trips to the villages to deliver babies, such as twins in the mud-huts of the war-torn reaches of India when medical assistance was nowhere to be found. After the war, she was appointed General Secretary of the TNAI, the 2nd Indian to hold this high-level 'British' national post. Koko studied to be a midwife tutor at London's famous Hospital, Guys, and she learned to do vacuum extractions in Sweden. She worked as a tutor in England prior to her sojourn to the USA. A pioneer midwife in the City in 1968, she forged ahead to establish the first Midwifery Program at Beth Israel Hospital where she later taught Yale midwifery students and medical students. In 1983, she obtained admitting privileges at St. Vincents' Hospital when she was working in the private midwifery practice of Maureen Rayson, CNM. She then became a Fellow of the American College of Nurse-Midwives. When she retired from delivery practice at St. Vincent's in 1990, the hospital made her Midwife Emeritus. Koko, God-fearing & energetic devoted her life to the care of mothers & babies and toward the improvement of her profession. She demanded high standards from her midwives. Active after her retirement, she attended her last birth, her grand-niece's, at home, at age 82 in 1998. Until recently, she was involved in developing the Beth Israel midwifery archives. She was an inspiration to her midwives, student doctors and clients, and was loved by us all. Her departure represents a great loss to the international midwifery community. Her spirit will live on for many generations. For funeral information, call Maureen's office in Chelsea at 646-230-7708. Maureen Rayson, CNM For the Midwifery Community

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Children Got Wrong Vaccine
description: A government vaccination program in 1973 inadvertently injected as many as several hundred children with a livestock vaccine instead of a vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, Health Minister Micheal Martin said. The name of the human vaccine, Trivax, was similar to that of the product for cattle and sheep, Tribovax T. No long-term effects have been reported, but Mr. Martin demanded an investigation from the pharmaceutical company that provided the vaccine, GlaxoSmithKline.

title: Colorado Asks Court to Review Ruling Releasing Sex Offenders
description: The Colorado attorney general has asked the State Supreme Court to reconsider its ruling this week that would allow a large group of sex offenders now in prison or on parole to be released because of conflicting state sentencing laws.

title: Making the Most of the Rain You Get
description: THE fifth graders were out in the hot sun recently, weeding the rain garden they had planted from seed last November.

title: A First Step to Balkan Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Rejects Honeywell Plan to Save Deal
description: General Electric's proposed acquisition of Honeywell International appeared all but dead yesterday after G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., rejected a last-ditch modification by Honeywell aimed at satisfying European regulators.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Bid For Eircom
