description: The eIsland consortium, which is led by the Irish businessman Denis O'Brien, increased its bid for the former state phone company Eircom to almost $2.57 billion, even though Eircom accepted a rival offer two weeks ago. The other offer, for $2.46 billion, came from Sir Anthony O'Reilly's Valentia Group, which is backed by George Soros. The Dutch telecommunications concern Royal KPN and Telia of Sweden, which hold a combined 35 percent of Eircom, are locked into accepting Sir Anthony's offer unless another bidder makes an all-cash offer of more than 1.355 euros a share. Mr. O'Brien's latest offer -- his eighth since bidding began last October -- is for 1.375 euros a share, of which 0.12 euro is a warrant to be redeemed in 2004. It is still unclear whether Mr. O'Brien will change those warrants to cash to win over KPN and Telia. He also lacks the crucial support of Eircom's unions, which hold 14.9 percent of the company. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: University Tuition Increase Is Halved
description: The University of South Carolina halved a tuition increase to 5.2 percent. The university's president, John Palms, said the move came in response to vetoes by Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, that restored state college financing. State residents will pay an additional $196 in tuition for the 2001-2002 academic year, putting tuition at $3,964 for the year.

title: At 67, Inspiring a Quest for Perfection
description: Wayne Shorter could be the one remaining figure in jazz for whom one never gives up raised expectations, the last of the demigod jazz sphinxes. But why should it be he? If it's for his involvement in the 1960's Miles Davis quintet, he isn't the sole remaining musician from that group. It's not because he always stayed pure, in some ghastly sense of jazz conservationism: he's had his tricky moments with jazz fusion and long ago gave up New York for Los Angeles.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Inflation Worries
description: The European Central Bank is worried about inflation in the 12 nations using the euro and will do everything to bring it down, Otmar Issing, the chief economist of the central bank, said. The recent consumer price rises are ''making us concerned,'' Mr. Issing said in a speech at the Austrian National Bank. ''We will do everything to bring the rate of inflation down over the medium term.'' Inflation in the dozen euro nations rose to 3.4 percent in May, the highest since the introduction of the European single currency in January 1999. While the central bank said the rise was because of temporary factors like higher oil and food prices, faster-than-expected money supply growth suggests prices may remain untamed. The central bank aims to keep inflation below 2 percent in the year, a goal it has missed every month since May 2000.

title: INFO-QUEST REDUCES STAKE IN AREMISSOFT TO 14%
description: The AremisSoft Corporation's top shareholder, Info-Quest S.A. of Greece, cut its stake in AremisSoft to about 14 percent from 23 percent of the outstanding shares. Info-Quest, based in Athens, sold 2.2 million shares of AremisSoft, a maker of business management software, from March 21 through Wednesday for $9.75 to $19.15 each, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Info-Quest now holds 5.3 million shares of AremisSoft, which is based in Westmont, N.J. That number is down from the 7.5 million split-adjusted shares Info-Quest reported last November. AremisSoft shares fell 30 cents, to $16.20.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Transforming Trust into Trade
description: Not only because of the recent summit in Ljubljana, but from my own discussions with both Vladimir Putin and George W. Bush, I have a new optimism about the future of relations between the United States and Russia. Unlike the hawks in Washington and Moscow who would like to put Russian-American relations on the foreign policy back burner, these two presidents understand the importance of the relationship.

description: ''If it were the doctors' judgment that any of these developments constituted the kind of information that indicated I would not be able to perform, I'd be the first to step down.''

title: National Briefing | Education: Graduate Test Will Add Essay Section
description: The Graduate Record Exam, a test taken by more than 400,000 applicants for graduate programs in the arts, humanities, science and engineering each year, will undergo its first change in more than a generation. A new section in the 3 1/2-hour exam, which has until now asked only multiple choice questions, will require written essays to demonstrate students' analytical ability. The change will take effect in October 2002. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RABBI IRA

title: Modjadji V, Rain Queen, Dies in South Africa at 64
description: Modjadji V, the last of a line of rain queens and the only woman who was a tribal ruler in modern-day southern Africa, died on Thursday in a clinic in Petersburg, South Africa. She was 64.

title: THE HOSTAGE BUSINESS: A Special Report; Kidnapping With Money as the Only Object
description: The first message crackled over the radio 18 days after kidnappers had taken 10 men from a remote oil-drilling site in the Amazon basin of Ecuador in October. A man with a Colombian accent who called himself Pedro demanded $80 million.
